Review: Love!! We have the kung pao chicken, broccoli beef and of course the soup dumplings and they were all amazing

The new location that JH has moved into was a great idea. It is incredibly clean and fun atmosphere. The dumplings and Chinese far were spot on. I absolutely love their soup dumplings and they never disappoint. Cannot wait to return.
Delicious food. If you asked me to recommend a place to eat in Chinatown I would recommend this restaurant.

I have been looking forward to Joe's Shanghai for quite some time, and finally got to go! This location is in Chinatown along with many other yummy Asian eateries. My friend and I split an order of pork soup dumplings, chicken lo mein, and shrimp fried rice, and it was plenty of food. The portions are pretty big which is good for eating in in large groups. All of our food was delicious and came out timely, even with a crowded restaurant. The soup dumplings were delicious and full of flavor, I would definitely recommend ordering these. The noodles were also very flavorful, they may have been my favorite item we got. The shrimp fried rice could have had a little more flavor, but nothing a little soy sauce couldn't fix! I would definitely recommend Joe's for a great meal in town!
I always come here just for the dumplings when in Chinatown! The restaurant is always busy but the dumplings come out quick. Delicious!!!!

My friend T told me that I'd wake up thinking about soup dumplings the following day.  I thought this was impossible because the only food I wake up thinking about is Five Guys Burgers.

I hate when T is right, but he was right.  I almost don't mind that I burned the crap out of my mouth on the first try though my lower lip is bright red and I no longer have taste buds.  I still want to go back now.  Like, right now.  Soup dumplings are great (I only had the pork) though there is definitely an art to eating it correctly which I obviously have not mastered.

We also had the crispy beef which was good too, but was not soup dumplings.  

Place is pretty big, wait was 45 minutes on a Friday around 6:30 (we got foot massages across the street while we waited) and they seat patrons in wherever they can fit you.

I looooooove the soup dumplings.  Get the crab meat one, because it is tastier.

The shanghai noodles are great as well.

I just do not come here often, because there are ALWAYS lines, and we always had to share tables with other patrons (except 1 time when I went in with 5 others)

Do not expect good service, because this restauarnt  is ALWAYS packed.

Just like every other popular restaurant in Chinatown, you'll likely share a 10-person table with strangers, the wait will be long, and the service will be curt by American standards; that's all just part of the experience. 

The soup dumplings are among the best in town -- they're probably the richest, so don't come expecting a light, delicate broth -- and the wrappers are wonderfully paper-thin (in fact, that might even be a detriment, as they're hard to pick up without breaking lol).

The rest of the menu is only okay, but I always say that every restaurant has its specialties, and you have to know what to order, and sometimes more importantly, what NOT to order.

This place has amazing xiaolong bao(soup dumplings) for the price along with delicious saut√©ed green beans that weren't overly salty, and a green onion pancake that is actually layered and flaky. I haven't found a good green onion pancake anywhere but LA so I'm happy to finally find one that isn't one dense piece. The service is efficient and they timed our dishes well while constantly refilling our drinks. Their fried calamari could use a little more seasoning in my opinion but other than that it was fried well. The spicy beef noodle soup had a delicious flavor, the broth wasn't overly salty and it had a nice kick of spice and flavor from the cilantro. I highly recommend this place but remember it's CASH ONLY

If you are a fan of steamed soup dumplings, this is the place.

I can easily eat an order of Crab AND Pork dumplings by myself in a single sitting.  Maybe even a third order.

They are filled with super hot liquid so I like to hold the dumpling in the soup spoon and puncture the dumpling with a chopstick.  As the liquid oozes into the spoon.  Let it cool off a liitle and then slurp some of the soup.  Then take a bite of the dumpling.  

So juicy, so good.

You may want to wear an old shirt when you eat here as you end up squirting yourself at some point during your meal.

Cheers!
N.
Great dimsum place and in my opinion the best soup dumpling in the city. I always go to the Chinatown location as they have more options. Other dishes such as jellyfish and noodles are also great.

I think the food here might be the best on planet earth and I'll leave it at that.
The soup dumplings r impeccable
The scallion pancakes r to die for.

Food is super good. Shanghainese dumplings, eggplant, chives pancake...

Just don't expect nice service. Service is fast and efficient. You may have to share a table with strangers - no prob. You have to eat and then leave; if you linger, they will look over your shoulder and ask, "need anything else?"

I will literally travel halfway across the country for these Pork Soup Dumplings. I lived in Shanghai for a few months last year, and I can honestly say that the soup dumplings here are even better than many places in Shanghai. The other Chinese dishes here are pretty good as well. They're usually pretty packed, so don't expect stellar service. Honestly, it's pretty sufficient for a busy restaurant.

Loveeee this place & their pork soup dumplings. 

They also have great scallion pancakes.  Service pretty good but it's the food that never disappoints.

Expect a long wait evenings/ weekends.

Was recommended by a friend to try it out because it's a popular Chinese place and she was right. It was sooo busy when we went. Place is also not too big. Tables were pretty close to each other. We were lucky to get a table right away but then lines started to form after us. There was no empty table. Service was okay. They don't really come check on you but they are busy, so maybe that's why. The staff recommended the beef with string beans which we got and I really liked it. The beef was well marinated and not chewy at all. We also got a hot and sour soup, jelly fish, and soup dumplings for appetizer. Everything was pretty good. 
Note: this place is cash only. Not sure if it's a common thing in Chinatown NY but we didn't know.

Incredible soup dumplings.  If the thought of delicate dumplings filled with pork and/or crab meat and hot broth gets your juices going, come by and stay awhile.

With the exception of the dumplings, which are among the best I've had in the States, the rest of the food is merely very good for standard Chinese.  The kung pao chicken is a fantastic mix and has just the right amount of kick to it.  The dried sauteed shredded beef is a new favorite in lowdel, oily, spicy, and perfectly filling.

Besides the food, the seating at the restaurant leaves much to be desired.  Small groups may have to share a larger table with another group.  Great if this is your first time and it feeds your diversity/authenticity craving, but just annoying otherwise.

Scalding your tongue here is like:
Watching Seinfeld for the first time, you laugh, it's good, haha, you're older now, it's not perfect, but you have your favorites, which you love even more: no soup dumpling nazi for you.

Welp, Joe's went and moved so might as well review the place now since I can compare the old and new spots all at once. 

First of all, the new location (right on bowery) is bigger, nicer looking, but still somehow feels like the old place. Mostly because there is a line, and you still get a raffle ticket with a number on it that means nothing*. Here are some things that remain the same:

*Cash only
*Tax and tip are included in your bill (but leave a few anyway, as they only give themselves a 15% tip)
*That aforementioned line
*The quality of the food (we will get to this in a moment)

Some things that have changed:
*No liquor license yet, so don't expect a Tsingtao with your dumplings 
*Tea does not come automatically when you sit down, but if you ask they will still bring it...in a soda class now (bring back the teapot guys)
*The bathrooms are nicer
*The place is brighter than the old one

All in all, this place still feels like the Joe's of old, just an updated version of it. The dumplings are still cheap and still good, as is the fried rice. The portions of rice are also still exceedingly generous for the price point and should be shared (unless this is all you're getting, but come on, you're here for soup dumplings and you know it). I hope it gets worn in a little soon though, as Joe's to me should have the feeling of a place that has been around forever - this place is an NYC staple and should feel as such. Yes, the location on Pell St will be missed, but they needed to expand; the fact that there is still a line to get in, even with all the extra seating highlights this. Thanks for keeping the food and the prices the same, I'll absolutely be back for a bamboo tray of soup dumplings soon (no, I'm not sharing, get your own). 
___________
*If you're a party of two just stay in line, they will eventually need to fill a two top and if you're closest to the front of the line, you win.

After having Din Tai Fung soup dumplings in Hong Kong, I thought there was no way I could find a better soup dumpling/XLB out there... Joe's Shanghai proved me wrong. This place is more affordable and by far more authentic, despite attracting the same amount of tourist popularity. 

Expect a wait, and expect to be crammed at a large table with other patrons if you only have 2-4 people in your group. The food comes pretty quickly, but don't expect attentive service here, which is typical of any busy Asian establishment. 

The scallion pancakes are really good. Crispy on the outside, chewy inside, and not too oily. Very flavorful, and the pancake itself is thick. You get a generous portion of soup dumplings for the price, and each dumpling has SO MUCH soup in it... much more than in the XLB from Din Tai Fung. We also ordered the pork with eggplant dish, which was delicious - make sure you get a bowl or two of white rice to go with this. 

All in all, an affordable and extremely satisfying meal. Definitely stop by if you are in the area and looking to fulfill a XLB craving.

Love the soup dumplings from this restaurant are amazing!  I tried a few other dishes but that is the one that stood out to me the most as it was my first time trying it.  Not entirely fond of sitting at a table with a bunch of strangers BUT that has nothing to do with the food.  Noodles where good and the scallion pancakes were delicious!
I tried this place on the way home from work- it didn't disappoint! The pork soup dumplings were fresh and flavorful and the scallion pancakes were delicious! I'll definitely be back!

So I hope you people visiting NYC have gps on your cell phone because if we didn't, we would have never found this place. It was hidden in China town....where they take you to secret doors in the back that leads you to a room full of designer knock offs. It was kinda fun seeing all the different secret doors and stairs. LOL!!

Anyways...back to food. They have two different soup dumplings...they're both awesome with the vinegar soy sauce. Pick one or the other, or both....you'll love them. 

BTW, if you want to buy gifts to bring home, do all your I love ny shopping in china town. It'll save you a ton of money. You're welcome.

It was a bit hard to find.  And after about a 10 minute wait on a busy beautiful Sunday in NYC during lunch, we were seated at a communal table, which we didn't mind.  

The waiters were not so friendly.  They knew we wanted the dumplings but before we could really look through the menu, he turns the pages for us and leads us right to the 2 choices of dumplings.  He also mumbled and we weren't sure if he got our order.  We wanted something light, because we wanted to walk down the street for dim sum afterwards.  So we got what others have been recommending... the crab/ pork dumplings and the scallion pancakes.  

They arrived a few minutes later and by that time an Englishman, obviously a tourist like us, sat at our table.  He watched us eat the dumplings carefully.  We placed each one on our spoon, bit a small hole, sucked the piping hot soup out, then poured some ginger, vinegar, soy sauce into it to cool it off before eating the rest of the dumpling.  The whole place smelled like the vinegar.  After the Englishman gets his dumplings, he thinks he can just take the whole thing with his chop sticks and pop it into his mouth.  Needless to say he burned his entire mouth and I bet the rest of the 15 dumplings he had to eat were not as enjoyable through a singed palate.  

The scallion pancakes were delicious.  Crunch, chewy, not too overpoweringly oniony.  

The dumplings were a hit as well.  The crab flavor was definitely from the crab roe (boogie, I call it).  I'm not normally a fan of the orange, yellowy goop when I eat fresh crab but the flavor in the dumpling was delicious.  

Despite the place having a "pending grade" from the sanitation department, being a bit grimy with not so friendly service... the experience of eating the soup dumpling was memorable.  As well as the price... $13.  Not bad at all.  I was very tempted to get more food off the menu.  It looked delicious as we could see from other tables.

Their pork dumplings are perfect and also such a great deal! This is the only place I ever want to get pork dumplings ever again (5/5) 

We also got the shanghai fried rice (4/5) and the kung pao chicken (4/5, it was good but not the same as I remember two years ago. Last time I went it was the softest and tenderest chicken I'd ever had. this time the consistency was pretty average.) I also loved their scallion pancakes (5/5) so light and fluffy and crispy all at the same time.

Also, the new location is so much nicer than the old one! I cannot recommend this place and their soup dumpling enough!

Came here every time I am in NYC. Always a line up on the dirty Chinatown streets, always cramped and busy inside. 
Juicy crab dumplings and their beef soup noodles are a must! 
Their slow roasted duck is extremely tender and juicy. Give it a try!

You have to go and try the soup dumplings! Sooo good!!! We ate ate a communal table and met some wonderful New Yorkers who gave us some great tips on what to order and where else to go. Great cheap eats, one of our favorite meals!

If I lived in Manhattan, this would be a regular place for me on a cold day.

Their Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai Soup Dumplings) are filled with a lot of soup and tasty meat. The skin was a bit thick for my tastes and the vinegar dipping sauce wasn't vinegar-y enough to balance the soup and thick skin. BUT I've never had that much soup in a Xiao Long Bao before! That seals the deal for me. Very filling.

Also had Scallion Pancake and some Pan Fried Pork Dumpling. Hard to go wrong with fried food :) Better than all the Xiao Long Bao's I've had in San Francisco.

Everytime I'm in New York, I spend the first few days saying "I want to go to Joe's Shanghai" over and over again to anyone who even mentions food. Eventually I talk someone into going with me (usually lured by my promise of bringing them to Chinatown "back rooms" where you can get Luis Vuitton knockoffs for 25 bucks). I order the pork and crab soup dumplings and a Tsing Tao, and achieve true happiness which will last me until I'm in NY again. Akshay is right - don't bother ordering anything else. The soup dumplings will set you straight.

I feel kind of bad. I've been here countless times and every time I just make a meal out of the Shanghainese dumpling (xiao long bao) or as my friends would call it "soupy dumplings." I should really try the rest of their menu. Come here for the xiao long bao and take caution eating it if it's your first time (the soup in the dumpling is hot). The scallion pancakes make a great appetizer and a cold bottle of tsing tao (a chinese beer) helps to cure any burns in your mouth from the "soupy dumplings."
I go alone so I can stuff as many motherloving soup dumplings my body cavity can hold without being judged by the people I love.

Thankfully I know the people running this joint cause the wait is unbearable... the soup buns and scallion pancakes never disappoint. Minus one star cause the sauce for the buns always spill out when getting to go. ; - (

Lately I've been hearing so many great thing about Joe's Shanghai that I just had to try it. Finally on Friday night I made my way to Chinatown ( the hidden part) and after being asked to wait 15 minutes ( not bad at all , I thought it would be hours) I got to experience Joe's Shanghai. Dining here is definitely experience, definitely not a fancy place or anywhere near it, the service is take your order, feed you fast and get you the hell out of there. They seat you randomly with people you don't know but that makes the experience rather fun. Right away they offer you their signature crab or pork soup dumplings. I tried the pork soup dumplings, the waiter taught us how to eat them and damn were they good. We then ordered the sesame chicken which was delicious and full of flavor. The beef and broccoli wasn't my favorite, the broccoli was great but the beef a little chewy. We then had the pan fried noodles with chicken and vegetables and boy were they amazing! I will definitely be back to tried the crispy beef and other goodies. If you're in the mood to eat very casual, fast, fatty, good and cheap this is the place.
CASH ONLY!!! FOOD IS TASTY!!! I love fried rice and general  chicken, but soup dumpling is a little heavy when it is cold!!
What can you say about Joe's that hasn't been said. The vibe of the place, the smell, the formal and prompt service, and of course the soup dumplings. Magic. Deep fried whole duck anyone? Yes please.

Really long wait. Shits good, but When the waiter dropped trow and starting pissing all over the table, I was like WHOA! I mean, I like R.Kelly as much as anyone else, but Geez Louise! Speaking of R.Kelly, has anyone heard the new album? Its surprisingly pretty good...I mean it doesn't hold up to the soul godfathers of yesteryear. I mean he's no Isaac Hayes or Curtis Mayfield, but it's definitely worth a listen.

 But I digress. Food is good, and the wait is really long, but anywhere I can get good dumplings and a golden shower at the same time merits 4 stars in my book! Cheers!
Get these dumplings! You will not regret it! Probably one of the best soup dumplings I've ever had. We got pork and they were so delicious!

Read reviews for this place that made my mouth water! Drove all the way from Jersey to this place for the world famous soup dumplings. And oh my God it was delicious. The dumplings were filled with hot soup, the soup was rich and tasty, the skin of the dumplings was thin, the pork was tender, the soup dumplings were just down right succulent. I would def travel all the way back to NYC just for these dumplings, we almost mistaken some other restaurant down the street with a similar name, so make sure it's JOES SHANGHAI! And be careful! They are hot!

Made the trip to Chinatown to pick-up from Joe's Shanghai (via Seamless/Grubhub) and it was well worth the effort. 

We had the Pork Meat Soup Dumplings and a Scallion Pancake for appetizers and both were excellent. We even managed to get the Soup Dumplings home intact (though we accidentally punctured a couple of them In serving them). Though they probably would have been even better if we had been able to eat them in the restaurant, they were still very much a treat.

For our main dish, we had the Peking Duck and it was also very well done. It came with the usual accompaniments (wraps, scallions, cucumbers and hoisin sauce) and was perfect for sharing. 

The service was friendly and efficient.  They have a table setup right inside the door and the food was well packaged for travel.

Great choice for pick-up or delivery!

Decent beef noodle soup for $5, and 8 xiaolongbao for $5?  Pretty cool.  The green onion pancakes (congyoubing) was kind of fried in a funky way - nowhere near what I had regularly in Taipei.

The soup dumplings were pretty good.  They were huge and the skin is thick (which I like).  the filling was okkay..  I think I'm spoiled from Din Tai Fung.

But the price, and the quantity, and just the overall fast, Chinese service makes it pretty great in my book.  

3.5 bumped up to a 4.

Went on a Saturday around 5:15 and was seated in 5 minutes (with 2 other people).

Pretty crowded, but I was a little skeptical at first.  It's filled with bairen. Heh.
This place is awesome. Shared a table. Good sized portions. Definitely get dumplings. Super busy and a small wait but you'd expect that with such great food.

First experience having xiao long bao .  I took the Chinese bus solo.  Seated at a 6 top with several other people that didn't know each other...and we were all there on a mission.  Xiao Long Bao.... I'd so do it again! The BEST!
Great food, but in Flushing NY not NYC.  Loud, busy, crowded, wonderful!

My girlfriend and I just moved to Chinatown so we Yelped the area and saw this place with the most reviews. LIke everyone else has said, get the pork dumpling to start off with. They seat you at a big round table with a bunch of other strangers so be open to having some one you don't know sitting next to you. Give them some time to cool down or cut open and let the HOT juice out. They have tons of fish, chicken, pork, beef and other dishes to choose from so go hungry. They staff is very fast paced to hurry and make your decision on what you want. When you're finished don't sit and make small talk unless you notice that  there isn't a line out the door of people waiting. If you do stay and they have people waiting they usually get their one staple guys to politely walk by several times and say ' Ok, Thank youuuu......ok, thank youuuuu!'

That's their nice way of saying, thanks for coming now get the ?#&* out :-)

Lived up to the hype. Price are reasonable, portions are large enough to be considered family style. I had the crab meat and pork soup dumplings and the chicken and shrimp with plum sauce. Both were very good. The soup dumplings are a must try and it's what they are famous for. You really cant go wrong with any dish. 

I took a photo after I ate a bunch of dumplings so note the dumplings currently come with 8 (not 4 as in the pic).

I heard this place was famous... So of course as I was in NY I had to go! I am very happy that I did! To be honest, I am giving 4 stars only because the place itself is small and crowded. I was wearing a large, warm jacket and there was no room for it. I felt like I was hitting people as I was walking past them to get to my seat. 

The food itself was absolutely amazing though. It was my first time getting dumplings so I was a tad nervous, but overall I had a great experience.  I had the pork dumplings, put some soy sauce on them, and they were so GOOD. We also got the chicken lo mein, that was pretty good as well. 

Super cool location in Chinatown, I just wish the restaurant was bigger and spaced out differently.

Out of all the Chinese restaurants out here in NYC, this would be the only one I would keep on going to! CHEAP AND TASTY 

There soup dumplings are AMAZING! nothing like its kind in Cali (yet). Be careful while trying to eat them because they make a great splash. Even after +10 times coming here, I still make a big mess. I love taking the first bite and slurping up the soup. Suggest using a spoon to aid in eating. Add vinegar and hot sauce will top it off! The pork dumplings are so bomb, but also try the seafood ones as well. Both so good and delicious!

The other dishes are ok, not to my standard of chinese food, but I suggest just order 2-3 orders of dumpling and that should be good enough for 2 people.

Wow! Amazing soup dumplings. My friends and I got the pork and crab soup dumplings and we both agreed that pork was the best!! (Pork is the classic soup dumpling protein choice). The size of those dumplings are HUGE and filled with plenty of delicious warm soup. I would say they're the BEST soup dumplings I've had. (I've tried the ones in Asia too!)

We also got the fried rice and they were amazing. It was a bit greasy but that's what made it good. Would say it was a guilty pleasure! 

Definitely recommend this restaurant for anyone visiting or in New York. It's a must try! 


Tip 1: Bring CASH!! Most China town restaurants only accept cash. They do have an ATM right outside the restaurant 

Tip 2: Don't be intimidated by the line. You can get seated soon if it's a party of two.

soup dumplings were great, and the sesame pancake was good too. we were there late on a Sunday night, and it was packed! 
service was ok, prices were good, and I will return!

The real deal when it comes to soup dumplings. They don't take reservations I think but expect to wait a bit if busy. Love their fried rice, egg drop soup, soup dumplings, bok choy and lo mein. Casual fast service! Must try.

This place was amazing! It was a spur of the moment to go & I don't regret it one bit. The soup dumplings are the best ones I have ever had in my whole entire life & I am 101% sure I'm never going to find another place who makes them as good as them. They do only take cash & it was 45 minute wait with a line out the door BUT it was worth it. I would do it again if I had too.

Communal Chinese eating at it's best! Long waits are marginalized when tables of 8-10 strangers share their dining experience. The waiter takes your soup dumpling order before you are even seated. Wonderful food experience - delish eggplant & scallion pancakes at extremely reasonable prices. Super attentive waitstaff.

I loved this new location that they moved to. The new restaurant is beautiful and clean and spacious unlike the old spot. And they're not competing with imitators next door. Came for the soup dumplings. I got greedy and ordered 2 orders so had to take one home and they still tarred so good the next day. My 2 year old daughter loved it. I took some American friends and they only got fried rice but they said it was the best they had.

Make sure you don't come hangry cuz you will have to wait and make sure you bring cash as they are cash only!
Soup dumplings are to die for. The scallion pancakes are deft the best... it's family style. You get to engage with other locals. It's a quick in and out though. Super fast service.

The main reason you should step food into Joe's is for the soup dumplings.  they're very, very good.  soupey, porky, savory, and delicious.  Everything else is marginal.  but seriously- why are you looking at the rest of the menu?

CASH ONLY. Love this place. The eggplant dish is so good. Also got some fried rice, divine. This place is usually really crowded so last time we went, we got our food to go which suited us fine. They have a love of food.

I want to give Joe's a 5 star rating on account of their soup dumpings. I dream about these bad boys and have actually ventured all the way to chinatown from the upper east side just to get my fix. 

The rest of the food is decent quality chinese food. Not amazing but not bad, either (hence the downgrade to 4 stars). Go for dumplings and you'll never be disappointed.

Oh. I like the samplings soooo much. 
Also the stuff called "baozi". 
I would introduce it to my friends.

The best xiao long bao ever - it's a MUST! I would recommend getting the Shanghai Style Pan Fried Noodles as well. 

If you don't know how to eat xiao long bao (some people in our table didn't know how), just pick up your XLB with your chopsticks and place it in ur spoon then drizzle some soy sauce + ginger on it. Then poke a hole into the XLB with your chopsticks and drink the broth in the spoon and TAKE A BITE! :-) 

The only thing that was weird for me was how we were seated. You basically get seated at a round table with a bunch of random strangers depending on your party number. My boyfriend and I got seated at a table with 4 different parties. I think I'm just used to sitting with my family during dim-sum time, but you totally forget about this once you get your food!

TIP: I would recommend ordering one dish at a time. My boyfriend and I got pretty full after an order of XLB and the Shanghai Noodles.... we still ordered another XLB though...

Walked by and noticed there wasn't a huge line, so I made it a deal to visit again.

Last time I came to Joes Shanghai, I wasnt too crazy about the place itself- since the service was ok and I was being seated with complete strangers which got pretty awkward. However, the pork soup dumpings made it all worth it.

This time around it wasnt as busy, so the service was better as expected. I was just with my boyfriend, so I had to sit with random people again. I guess since I knew what I was expecting, it wasnt awkward at all. The other couple at the table were actually visiting from California and didnt know what to order, and I found myself babbling about how great the place is to convince them to get the soup dumplings.

After not much convincing (literally like 5 seconds later) the other couple also ordered soup dumplings. And we all sat and raved how great they were as we were eating them hahah

Seriously the best soup dumplings ever though.

I hate to give them a 5 star cause the wait and the service was horrible. But they were that good. 

We got to Joe's around 6pm on a Sunday and there was a crowd already. Hostess said 30 minutes so we waited. LIAR!!! took us an hour. But oh well. 

We were seated with another party of two on the same table. It was super awkward but after the food came out we didnt care. 

We had the

128. Singapore Chow Mai Fun - AHHHHH DONT GET THIS!! we tried to be adventurous and we failed. Miserably. 

The Crab soup dumplings and the scallion pancakes were bananas. Twice as big ad Din Tai Fung. The soup is also way more dense. It was too delicious. We were moaning after a couple bites. Sorry table next to us. We messed up with the order and they cancelled our pork dumplings but we were too stuffed . Next time Joe's! 

Also, we left around 8pm and they were calling numbers saying some people wont be able to be seated so get there early.

CASH ONLY.

Absolutely love XLBs and heard this was THE spot to check them out (from Chicago so there surprisingly aren't many good places for XLB).

Came here on a Sunday afternoon and no surprise, there was a line. We had a party of 5 and didn't have to wait too long, maybe 20-30mins? Estimated was 45-60 so we were quite happy! 
Please note your entire party must be present to be seated.

*We were all seated in a big round table with other parties. Looks like they do communal seating to maximize tables. We didn't feel too squished luckily but perhaps not everyone's cup of tea.*

Ordered the two crab and pork XLB and two regular pork one (each order came with 8 baos). Both were absolutely amazing! Perfectly thin skin with a delicious broth inside. They also give you a dish of soy sauce/vinegar/ginger mix. The party next to use ordered fried rice only and we couldn't believe it, but to each their own! 

Would definitely come here again the next time in NYC - for more XLB and probably try some of their other dishes!
I highly recommend this place for its authentic food and good service. Don't let the tightness of the place be a bother. Just be a part of the celebration of the Shanghai's best.

Just here to reiterate what everyone else has already reviewed:

After the rave reviews of a couple friends, and trying some soup dumpings in the SF bay area, I can say with conviction that these soup dumpings are worth the hype.

I was even more impressed by the Shanghai Noodles.  If you visit this place, you NEED to order the shanghai noodles.... this is NOT an option.

This is definitely going to be a stop of mine with every trip to NYC.

What an interesting dinner experience! 

Pops and I were staying in Lower East during our trip to NY and we knew we had to visit Chinatown at least once, being so close to the area. We decided to grab dinner as well and found this great place!
Obviously one of the most famous places in the neighborhood, we knew we had to drop in to taste their famous xiaolongbaos.

The arrangement of the restaurant was quite a sight. All these different groups of people were seated in the huge round tables with other strangers. It was interesting to share a table with 8 other people that I had never met before. 

Service was very quick even though the place was packed. We got the xiaolongbaos and eggplant dish. As I had expected, the soup dumplings were absolutely delectable. The soup was so wonderful and there was no need to dip the dumpling in the soy sauce. The eggplant was very delicious too. Portions were huge and we had to ask for a side bowl of rice to eat with the eggplant since the sweet taste was very strong. 

Although it was a tad bit uncomfortable to share a round table with strangers... It was a fun experience and the delicious food soon made me forget about the awkward crowdedness. Seriously, those dumplings really were amazing!!
Joes shanghai is known for their soup dumpling and let me tell you it's very good. It comes out hot and taste amazing.

Pretty good dumplings.   I also got vege crispy pan fried noodle, and scallion pancake.

Scallion pancake is s dish that's hard to go wring with and theirs did not dissappoint.

Pan fried noodles had a bit too much sauce, but i thought it was pretty good.


They didn't have a ton of stuff my picky girlfriend wanted to eat, but maybe that's because she was not in a good mood.   I think the scallion pancakes cheered her up a little bit though.


This place is probably better for parties of 4+. Dishes are huge, so be careful not to over order.

OKAY BEST PORK SOUP DUMPLINGS EVER. Blown away. Could have eaten 20 of them myself. The other food was way good too, but definitely make sure to get the pork soup dumplings. That's a MUST!!! The line is usually long so plan on about a 45-60 min wait. Luckily there's fun little shops and you can walk around China town to kill time.

We were in China town and we wanted to find a really good restaurant in that area so we decide to yelp it and this restaurant came up with a four star rating so we had to try it.  

The place was packed with tourist.  The waiters were not that helpful with the menu, but we found out by neighbors seated next to us that the place was known for its soup dumplings (which were excellent).  
Definitely worth it.
good pork steamed buns and snow pea leaves.

This review will also be jumping on the soup dumpling hype train that Joe's Shanghai so rightfully deserves.

On top of the raving reviews already placed here, I'd like to add one more note about the soup dumplings: even if you are a baby in chopstick using years, the likelihood of you getting dumpling to face while retaining soup in said dumpling has gone up 100% because the top of the dumplings are rather firm and the skin is thick enough that if you pull gently but firmly, you will be rewarded with soup galore.

Trust me, if you're going on a first date and you're going with someone who knows their chopsticks but you're not prepared for that chopsticks interview but you still want to pass off as somewhat knowledgeable of good food in NYC, order those soup dumplings so that 1) the most awkward part of the date is not that you don't have a table to yourself to create intimacy but it's that you might make a fool of yourself with lack of chopsticks skills but it turns out 2) any type of wiggling chopsticks will still get those dumplings where they need to be: your stomach, 3) your date will be so distracted by how fabulous the soup dumplings taste that your date won't even notice you struggling to convert dumpling to mouth, and 4) you haven't gone to the ATM in weeks but these dumplings are $7-10 for 8 per order and you had $20 in your pocket anyway so phew! you got this. Second date in the bag. Now go get ramen.

Joe's Shanghai has the best xiao long baos ever!

I have never said that about a xiao long bao, and I might not ever say that ever again for another restaurant. Thanks to a recommendation from a friend who came here a few months prior, I'm glad I made the stop here for dinner. Came in around 6pm, and my friend and I were seated immediately. Because we're a small party in a trendy restaurant, naturally the servers would seat us at a big table to share with other customers. The restaurant has that typical Chinese restaurant setup, which I'm glad because a lot of popular restaurants would have probably conformed to a more modern look.

My friend and I shared the crab and pork soup dumplings.

YES, THEY CAME. Everything came out hot and fresh, and was just YES. Not even a dollar per dumpling, AND the dumplings were filled to the max with flavorful soup? How could anyone resist?! Even adding a piece of ginger and some vinegar sauce on the side made it delicious. I was extremely satisfied with solely the taste. It's hard to find really good XLBs like these too.

WARNING: Soup is burning hot inside so be careful not to take a huge bite.

Made. My. Day.
The soups dumplings are okay. For NYC they're pretty good. Other dishes are many typical Americanized Chinese dishes.

By far the best Xiao Long Baos (pork meat soup dumpling) I've ever had! I've had quite a few but these are definitely my favorite. The size, price, texture, quality, and taste were all great. Had to get a whole 2nd order of them after seeing how good they were.

Highly recommend!

My first time at Joe's Shang hai. Had always heard good things and had to try it for myself!

Prices were very good and the food is so filling. We ordered soup dumplings and scallion pancake. They give a lot and it really fills you up. Great service and short wait. 

Pretty good and highly recommend!

I love this place over din tai fung. 
There's a hustle and bustle to this restaurant. Just be prepared to feel claustrophobic 
Food is great!!!! Definitely recommend the soup dumplings. They need to franchise this place!!!!!

Soup dumplings. Enough said.

But if you want a few more words, I like to order the scallion pancake. My boyfriend had the seafood noodles once and it was a huge bowl with a colorful arrangement of seafood pieces (shrimp, crabmeat, that squiggly pink thing you see in ramen) and veggies. We love our veggies!

It's almost impossible to get a table at this place because the lines are so long, so I ordered takeout on Grubhub instead. I ordered the pork meat soup dumplings and the scallion pancakes. The downside of getting them to-go is that they're not steaming hot when you go to eat them. Still, the soup in the soup dumplings is probably the best soup I've ever had in a soup dumpling. I can see the hype behind this place. It's worth it!
Best spot for dumplings and so much more! I always make sure to order from this place (in the pandemic) if I'm at all nearby. Pre-COVID, the long wait was worth it.

As close to traditional Chinese food you will ever get  at a restaurant in Manhattan. 
Soup dumpling are fenominal but also the whole fish is delicious. 
If you love fish, I recommend getting any fish prepared whole on the menu.
The reviews are true. It is good, I had the spicy beef specialty and a soup dumpling. It's pricey but they are shareable for two

The first time i've ever had soup dumplings was at Joe's.  Since then i have found Shanghai Cafe who's soup dumplngs are better than Joe's and you dont have to share a table with other parties.  I do love Joe's but it has become a tourist spot and the quality and service isn't what it used to be.  Dont get me wrong, the food is great.  The sesame chicken and the fish in black bean sauce are awsome.
I just dont unerstand why the prices would be higher at their other locations.  The location in Queens has to be the worst when it comes to service.

Holy mother of Soup Dumplings, this place is the S#!$! 

I heard about it through some colleagues, and fell in lurve once I popped a dumpling. The vinegar sauce with ginger balances the slightly oily soup, but I prefer to load on the spice for extra flavor! 

There is a reason people come from all over for this restaurant, and wait in line when it's 12 degrees out for over an hour. The price is also recession-friendly.

It took me a few times before I was able to branch out and order other items on the menu, as I tend to go specifically for the SD. Try the scallion pancakes, Crispy Jumbo Prawns, and Kung Pao Chicken (my favorites). 
I'm a firm believer they add a hint of crack in the soup, because I just can't stay away!

The best soup dumplings ever. I will be a loyal customer for life. Also love the entrees. General Tso chicken, crispy shredded beef, spicy Szechuan beef, all good. Also love the scallion pancake and the cold sesame noodles. Go there, it's the best. Nice new location with more seating (inside and out ), but I do miss the charm of the Pell Street Joe's.
I love this place !!! Always going to different places to compare Chinese food taste. This place was very good but little noise. Dumplings soup was ok. Definitely will advise for my friends.

so.good.

unfortunate that you can't make reservations and sometimes you literally wait till the end of time for a table because it gets so crowded.

but well worth it the hangry temper once you get your dumplings :)

Here's the thing. People go to Joe's to try soup dumplings, because most places in the country don't have them. And they are delicious. They are also made with lava inside, so punch a hole in them or take a little bit to let them cool, lest you set your facehole on fire and lose the ability to taste anything else. And you should taste other things, too, because Joe's has so much more than soup dumplings. Fried rice cakes with shrimp is another thing. Cold sesame noodles. Fried pork dumplings. About 170 other dishes.
Here is my one issue with the place. It is really popular, and as such, they can pull off communal seating and a really weird scheme for seating you and your group. My group of 4 waited about 15 minutes when we were called. Then, we were put inside in on-deck-circle, waiting in a totally in the way area for another 10 minutes, waiting for space to open up. We spent that time getting closer and closer to one another as people came up to the register for one reason or another, even though the wait staff will take your money at the table. Whatever. This would not work in a place less amazing.
It's worth it.

Another place I have to stop to get some delicious soup dumplings. They've relocated since I last visited in 2019. They don't take reservations and they're cash only. We went on a Sunday evening, around 5pm and I had to go inside to grab a ticket. It was about a 45 minute wait. Luckily, it had stopped raining so we just hung out outside until our number was called. 

I recall the previous location being family style seating but probably because of Covid, it's no longer like that. We were seated at our own table but we were fairly close to other tables so it's not like social distancing was a thing. I knew that I wanted the pork soup dumplings so I ordered that and my fianc√© order the hot and sour soup and lo mein. 

Everything came out quick and hot. I took a bite of one of the soup dumplings and burnt my tongue but I was so excited to eat them! I topped the dumplings with the ginger sauce that they provided up. The soup was so rich and tasty. It was very comforting since in was cold and wet outside. I tried a spoonful of my fianc√©'s soup and it was good as well, hot! The lo mein was really good. I was very pleased that it was not too salty. I've had lo mein at other places and they've always been too salty. 

The service wasn't that great but I would still come back just for the food. I did notice that a 15% service charge was added at the bottom of my receipt which caught me off guard but I'm glad I noticed it.
Best soup dumplings and peking duck I have ever had. Food came out in a timely manner m. Will definitely be back!

Review only for food. Their soup dumpling is perfect. I have no whatever complaint to it. Rich, tasty, juicy, memorable! The dumpling skin was thin yet held the juice in very well. Juice from the well marinated meat was delicious. However, other dishes are ok only. I had the wonton noodle soup and some stirred fried seafood dishes. They are average like other Chinese restaurants. It would have been 3 stars if I hadn't had the soup dumplings.
Be aware. They are cash only and the wait was pretty long during lunch time (12-2).

I've been here a couple times.  The food here is good.  The xiao long bao's are very good.  The other dishes were good as well.  I really liked the scallion pancakes here, they came out extremely crispy, which I like.  The other dishes were good as well like the noodle soup they had and the sliced stir fried rice cakes.  

Overall, very good. This location gets really crowded at times, but its usually worth the wait.

Good food good service. Would return for their soup dumplings. Server was helpful letting us know how much soup dumplings to use for our group. Vet attentive. Gotta stop by here if you're in China Town. Definitely with a try.

I've been coming here since I was a teenager... less often when I was actually living in Chinatown, way more often now that I know how special their soup dumplings really are having moved away. 

Yes, they are known for their soup dumplings.. and yes, that's all I ever get there because if you are already in Chinatown there are far better places to get anything else on the menu. 

Some people might say that Din Tai Fung is far superior to Joes.. but I wouldn't go that far.. DTF is good, really good, but different from Joes. You come to Joes for the big juicy, impossible to eat in one bite dumplings.. you go to DTF for the small flavorful bites. With that said, I have yet to find anywhere that does the soup quite like Joes does. 

I will, however, say that Joes has been slippin throughout the years. What once was easily a consistent 5 star meal now has its 3-4 star days where the dumplings are overcooked, stuck together to where it's impossible not to break them causing all the juicy goodness to go to waste, or sometimes worse.. all the juice has dried up due to the overcooking. This seems to happen more often during off peak times when it is not busy.. perhaps they have their B-level chef running things during those times.. but anytime I come during peak hours (weekends, holidays, lunch, etc) they are always on point. 

Even with all the slippage, I will keep returning to joes for my soup dumpling fix bc I've yet to find anywhere else that does it better than Joes on a good day, and it's good enough for me to consistently come back knowing that I might encounter an off day. 

Get the crab or the crab/pork mixed ones over the plain pork ones.

Delicious food with very fast service! My friend and I went on a Sunday evening and it was busy but they sat us within 15 minutes and we had our soup dumplings in front of us about 10 minutes after we sat down! This spot is great for ordering a few different things and sharing everything among your party! Must try: soup dumplings of course and Shanghai noodles! We also got the sesame chicken which was nice and crispy

Went here during jury duty last week. Got sat at a group table and had a very good meals. All i ordered was the crab and pork dumplings and they were out of this world. They are the dumplings that have broth inside them. They just had an incredible flavor to them. Got there at 1pm, had my food by 1:15 and back to the jury room at 1:45. Great break from a day of sitting around waiting to be picked for service.

It's in Chinatown hence it is Asian cuisine. Let me just say that they have the best dim sum I have ever had the privilege of eating, they were cooked to perfection: tasty, steamy and juicy. I arrived here by recommendation and it more than fulfilled my hunger. The food was delicious, I had pan fried noodles, a side of rice and dim sum. The service was excellent and amiable. Don't be fooled by the name, "joe" this place is good, authentic and surprisingly inexpensive. I recommend everyone that is in the area, whether visiting NYC or not to stop by and enjoy the food.

Incredible dumplings

I went here with my girlfriend on a Saturday around 2. After a 20 minute wait, we were sat at a table for 6 with a family in the loud and crowded restaurant. The noise and bustle, which would have been annoying at most places, is all part of the Joe's charm. 

We had heard that the dumplings were the things to get here and we were not wrong. We split an order of fried pork dumplings and an order of the soup dumplings. Neither disappointed. 

The fried pork dumplings had a great doughy shell. It was perfectly chewy on one side, but fried and crispy on the other. While these were great, it was the soup dumplings that really stole the show. I had never had soup dumplings before, so that may have been part of my amazement, but these were the single best thing I have had in a long time. I don't want to describe them here because I would do them a disservice...

By the time we had eaten the dumplings we were full so did not have a main course, however all entrees we saw looked great and we will definitely be back!

Stopped by for dinner while in the City...love the XLB (Xiao long Bao).  They are some of the best I've had.  Their rice cakes with pork and vegetables was very good as well.  Stop by if you are in the mood for good Chinese food but be ready to wait in line.

Amazing pork soup dumplings, I would actually travel all the way from DC to eat these if I craved it badly enough (I did once). 

Also got a spicy whole fried fish once that was AMAZING. Mixed the sauce with some white rice and fell into the most amazing food coma later.

Home of the xiao long bao.  The ratio of soup of soup:meat:filling is spot on.  With a nice draw of umami on the first slurp.  I prefer the pork only.  

I also had the Shanghai noodles with shrimp.  The serving was surprisingly generous and the flavor was very nice.  The food is a little heavy/with a lot of oil.

You definitely feel rushed to eat/order.  If you come with a small group, expect a communal table.

Yummy soup dumplings
Made fresh, filled with meaty broth
Almost burned my mouth

Like the haiku?  What makes this place great is that it's easy to find and the dumplings were the best thing we ordered.  We made the mistake by ordering some other dish on the menu and weren't as impressed.  So stick to the xiao long bao and you're all good.  

TIP: Don't be eager like me and attempt to eat the entire dumpling all at once... you'll be sorry.

SO GOOD 10000000/10 childhood nostalgic favorite dumpling crabmeat joint of all time. So sad they closed the flushing location so whenever I'm in Chinatown I have to make a pit stop. Other dishes like the crunchy noodles are also amazing. Food is quality, and that's all that really matters.
Soup dumplings here are phenomenal. The other food is good but if you're here, order the soup dumplings.
Like everyone else, I was blown away by the dumplings. Some locals will say it's too touristy. Disregard!

We had to try a little of everything- the pork gyoza, scallion pancakes, spring rolls, and lo mein. It was definitely more than two small girls could take on. But everything was delicious. The gyoza and spring rolls were a tiny bit greasier than I'd expect, but still delicious. The vegetable lo mein was incredible. I'd go out of my way to eat here again.

I was introduced to this place by my friend. Their soup dumplings are delicious. The first time I went, we only had appetizers. I couldn't stop eating the soup dumplings. They have 2 varieties, The crab and pork are my favorite. Will definitely go here when in Chinatown. Make sure you get a small table if you want privacy. They will fill all of the round tables. I tend to not mind having the locals at my table because I like watching what they eat and then try it. They can recommend some great dishes.

CASH ONLY. They have ATMS there. My soup-dumpling-expert friends all said that these were the best soup dumplings they ever had. They are twice the size of normal soup dumplings and have way more soup in them. 

Wait time on a Saturday at 6 pm was an hour 

I got the beef noodle soup. Beef soup was nice and light. Beef good quality 

Onion pancakes a bit too salty

Service great. Very organized and efficient
Omg the soup dumplings!!!! Love love love! They also have a strictly take out place. That's always great in the run or a lunch run.
The food here is amazing, but there will sometimes be a wait. Because of how busy the place is, they sometimes split a 10 seat table into several groups, but the food and price makes it all up.
When in NYC, stop by and eat here! LOVED the soup dumplings! They're the BEST and so delicious

I was meeting with some friends for lunch and decided on Joe's Shanghai since it's a popular soup dumpling place that's conveniently located relative to my day's plans to tour the city. Now, on my ride to NY, I watched a Taiwan tourism video that compared the soup dumplings at Ding Tai Fung to the ones from Joe's (03:05 on http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xXk0ZpPAGU0), and he said the ones at Joe's are like "Paula Abdul's saucer nipples." So I didn't have high expectations.

But they turned out to be really good. We got a tray of the pork and the crab/pork, which were cheap and delicious, although I couldn't stop giggling about saucer nipples the whole time. We also got green onion pancakes, and these were among the best that I've had, which is pretty impressive. Minus one star because we shared some beef tendon noodles but I saw no tendons (only chunks of beef) in our large bowl. We asked our very stoic waiter whether it was the right dish but he just grunted and walked away so we had no idea if that was a yes or no.

Outside of the food, everything else about the restaurant was pretty amusing. Our small table was seated at one of those enormous tables, alongside 2-3 families with their babies and grandpas. Our hilarious server wouldn't respond to anything I said. Whenever I asked for something i.e. a cup of water, he would stare me down and just walk off, leaving our group a little confused about whether he understood me or not. Lo and behold, my water would magically arrive at my table a minute later. 

Overall, it was a decent experience with delicious food that was also super cheap. The three of us were stuffed from the four dishes that we ordered, yet the total came out to be only $8pp including tax/tip.
This place is worth the wait! Their soup dumplings are really good and the scallion pancakes are crunchy and filling :)
soup dumplings are a MUST!! absolutely amazing, the room is a bit small so you won't have an amazing amount of space. however, big groups are welcome. a classic!

BOMB 

The soup dumplings are to die for. I totally understand the hype!! The dumplings are also pretty large so it was very filling. We also ordered the jellyfish which was good but could be a bit more flavorful. The Shanghai thick fried noodles were so good!! Rather oily but flavorful not too salty and authentic 

Had to wait 30 min on a Sunday afternoon but so good

Cash only. 

Their xlb are a lot bigger than the typical xlb. Tasty & always hits the spot. Would prefer a sweeter & more umami filling but these will do.

Place was packed so I don't be annoyed if you have to share a table.

While it is not the best, it is very good.  I ordered spring rolls and general tso chicken.  the spring rolls were a little soggy, but the general tso chicken was the best that I have had in years.  White meat chicken, no mystery meat.  Good flavor; a tad spicy, but not too hot.  I think I have found my Chinese food fix for NYC.
I'm really bad at eating soup dumplings and the liquid always bursts on to my hand instead of my mouth (note to take a hint from M&Ms). But. These are goooooooood and worth the clean up.

This is the best place to eat and before I went I thought it was bad but after best place in Chinatown.  The food is very good but it's pretty big.  The sesame chicken is the best chicken you can get and second best is the Kung Pow Chicken. I would always recommend this to anyone that likes Chinese. Looks small but very good food especially the chicken.  Very good service and fast to get your food.
The soup dumplings here are pretty good. This is known as the place to go to in NYC for soup dumplings so you should come here at least once so you can look cultured.

Does Joe's Shanghai really need one more review about the soup dumplings?? I kind of thought once you've had one soup dumpling you've had them all, but it's really true... Joe's is the best. I particularly enjoyed the pork/crab ones.

Other food was great too! Oh, and a tip -- apparently they always include the tip in the bill regardless of party size, thanks to our table-mates for pointing it out as we were getting ready to leave some cash on the table.

Is there anything I can possibly add to 800+ reviews? Probably not, but I haven't read all of them yet.

I wish this place only served dumplings and you could get your own table. Then it would deserve that last star I left out since their non-dumpling foods are just so-so.

The lines here are always out the door so do yourself a favor and go to Joe's Ginger. It's half a block down Pell, always empty, and opened by the same owner/chef as Joe's Shanghai.

Bet you didn't know that!
Terrific place, really large portions. Cash only, they have an ATM you can withdraw for a fee.

My girlfriend wanted to try this place a few weeks ago, thinking it was dim sum. I got there first, and was promptly sat at a big communal table with 4 other women. It was a little awkward, but I got over it quickly. My friend arrived a couple minutes later, and we decided to share food.
We ordered soup dumplings, spring rolls, sesame chicken, and chicken with broccoli. Everything was amazing, and they served hot tea/water, which was very much appreciated with the cold weather we were having.
It ended up being around $40-$50, I believe. They also put automatic gratuity on it so just be aware of that. I was about to give them a 20% tip on top of the gratuity, but ended up just giving the extra % to make it 20% after I realized this. :) Definitely coming back here soon!

My boyfriend took me here to end our night on new years eve. He had already been here but wanted to take me because he raved about how good the soup dumplings were! We had been to a different place w/ xiao long bao before here in Boston but he said they weren't as good as Joe's Shanghai!

We got two orders of crab + pork soup dumplings and one order of pork soup dumplings. They come with eight each, so we each got 12 dumplings. They were just delicious! So flavorful and also very filling (which is a good thing). I almost died when I finished all 12 dumplings because I was so full. 

And, just like my bf said, these WERE better than the place in Boston! I loved it here!

Soup dumplings: superb. I don't know what you're doing here if you don't order the soup dumplings. Scallion pancakes are deep fried as opposed to pan fried, so I'm not a big fan. I definitely recommend their shredded pork noodle soup, but I usually come here and fill myself up on soup dumplings with friends.

Really good soup dumpling! We tried the pork and pork/crab and both were tasty but I loved the pork/crab combo. The crab added another layer of flavor. 

It is a little weird that you share a table with multiple people depending on how large your group is

ordered :
Steam Crab meat dumpling ( Xiao Lun Bao ),
Shrimp Pan fried crispy noodle,
Stewed tofu with Crab,
Beef with scarlion,
about 80 bucks (include 15% surcharge)

The steam dumpling as good as the old days , never disappointed. Rich crab meat flavor n meaty pork stuffing.

Highly recommended the thin crispy pan fried noodle , non greasy, it's light, with or without the sauce are delicious.

generally, all dishes on the salty side, good supplement in the hot day :p

**
a good place for big n small group

**
no wait line on weekday lunch hour to sit, 1 hour wait from order to server 4 dishes

**
walk-in only, no reservation

**
cash-only

Btwn 4-5 stars, feeling generous so I'll round up. 

So far my favorite NYC soup dumplings - skin is thin, soup is plentiful, and overall yummy. We also had the usual eggplant dish I like (Yu Xuan Qie Zi) and they made it pretty good too. My friend got some lo mein which looked ok, but all I remember is we cleaned our plates so it must be pretty good. 

Def had a wait, not too long, make sure your entire party is there or they will not seat you. B/c it's so popular, they'll seat you anywhere, so we were at a 6 top and sat with 3 ppl from another group, no biggie.

One of the best juicy dumpling I've ever had in my life!!!
must try again when I'm in New York china town

Anything less than 5 stars is blasphemy and you should get your tongue checked for some kind of oral cancer because you obviously are suffering from some kind of condition that messes with your taste buds.  The small juicy dumplings are simply amazing.  Possibly the best you can get in the whole US.  From what I've heard it's nearly as good as some particular place in Taiwan.  Anyways 5 stars for this place.  If you gave it 4 stars, must've been the service, if you gave it 3 stars or less you should go to the hospital IMMEDIATELY to get yourself checked out.

We ordered Joe's Shanghai to our hotel while staying in Manhattan on business. We got a large variety of items and all of them were very good. I highly recommend Joe's of you get a craving for some excellent Chinese delivery.
Delicious and cheap. Try the crispy fried beef strips. Their soup dumplings are a must.

The key to getting a quick table at an in-demand hole in the wall in Manhattan? Simply go in the middle of a weekday during a freezing snow storm, duh! My tourist friends and I were in the mood for some piping hot soup dumplings to melt our snowman layers and turn us into humans again. Luckily, there was no line and we were seated right away at a table for 5... we didn't even have to share with anyone! 

We knew we wanted soup dumplings, and we got the chicken and the pork. I liked the flavor of the chicken much more than the pork. We also ordered the scallion pancakes (absolutely delish), and took the waiter's suggestion on a dry fried beef dish that I would have never ordered myself, but really enjoyed as a nice contrast to the dumplings. 

It's always fun to introduce people to soup dumplings for the first time. My friends had a blast perfecting their bite and suck strategies and it was a great meal to fill us up on a winter day so that we could go back out and brave the elements. Highly recommend, but don't know if I'd stand in line for hours for it as others claim to have done at busy times!

Love this place.
We were here on a Monday afternoon and were seated quickly but every table was full. The day before we saw a line out the door. The service is fast and friendly as are the other diners. The staff was happy to make menu suggestions and the food was awesome.
I love soup dumplings. Joe's has soup dumplings that are larger than your other dumpling shops. Very filling!

Delicious and reasonably priced. The soup dumplings were freaking amazing (be sure to eat them in the way that doesn't land you to the hospital with 3rd degree burns) and the scallion pancake was one of the best I've ever had. Most of their entrees seemed to be pretty standard Chinese food you could get anywhere, but man..those soup dumplings....

Get there as early as you can; my friend and I went at 4 PM on a Saturday and there was already a 20 minute wait. I wasn't crazy about the crochety old man at our table.  The kvetching from him was constant throughout dinner (I need more hot sauce, where's my hot sauce?! Oh let me bring cans of coke to dinner so I don't have to pay for them with my meal...) the communal dining leaves something to be desired.

Oh hell, how i LOVE this place....

I popped my cherry for soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai and NOTHING has beat it since.... especially, nothing over here in Southern California. 

I dream about it all the time! Every time I go to NY, this is first and last place I have to eat at.... that's how good it is.

Man, my mouth is watering... it's just not fair... mother EFF' I'm buying a plane ticket right now! now... anyone want to offer up their place for me to crash at??? haha

I much prefer the Chinatown location to the midtown. This place is like a machine. You get in, they seat you, they feed you, and you're out. 
Of course I went for the soup dumplings. There's just nothing like them anywhere and other people have tried and failed to replicate these morsels.

I tried Joe's Shanghai for the first time during Chinese New Year's in the middle of the COVID-19 pandemic. New York City had just opened indoor dining.

The experience actually surpassed my expectations. I was skeptical at first about a place with such a reputation and that catered to what seemed to be a primarily non-Asian clientele, in addition to the hour-and-a-half long wait. But lo and behold, the food was actually very good. We ordered the soup dumplings (obviously), scallion pancake, saut√©ed string beans, shredded pork w. dried bean curd and Chinese celery, and the Shanghai saut√©ed flat noodle. 

However, the service wasn't quite 5-star worthy and I cannot in good conscience give 5 stars to a Chinese restaurant that doesn't give you rice with your entrees.

My first experience with soup dumplings and I loooooved them! Apparently this is the place to go. We also had some thick noodles, potstickers, and green beans. All were fabulous. I will DEFINITELY be back.

This place gets busyyyyyy. Makes sense since their green bean dish and white fish dish were both deliciously flavorful. Their soup dumplings were meh, but their customer service made sure my water cup was always full and my finished dishes were picked up and out of the way almost immediately. I'd recommend putting a name down early on because the wait can go from 0-100 in a matter of minutes, and they don't text/call you when your table is ready; therefore you're waiting in front of the place for a bit.

MJ's Star : 4
Price : Crab meat with Pork meat steamed bun(8) $6.65
             Pork Steamed Buns(8) $4.65
             General Tso's Chicken $12.95

I'm a fan of this place because I enjoy the long a** lines where my boobs are pressed along a strangers back , the conversation w/out of towners that have never been this close to a black person (except that time during the O.J. trial when everyone was glued to the television), & the seat by the door where people stand & put their a** in your face or hover over your food while pointing & asking "What's that?" as you eat your Dim Sum. I've been to plenty of these places in china towns across America & I still will come back to this one. I even like sharing a table w/strangers while I pick off their plate & pretend it was my order...That always is an ice breaker & keeps money in my pocket so I can walk a block over for a cannoli & some expresso in Little Italy. I'm from NY & I love being on top of people, so I don't mind the crowd @ all...Yes lots of pun intended...LOL!

This place really does have good pork dumplings. I am Chinese, but this is actually the first time I've ever had Shaolin dumplings! *gasp* I know, what was I missing the entire time? 

The dumplings were pretty amazing. It comes in this dim sum bamboo container, nice and pipping hot. The dumpling was cooked perfectly and the soup within the dumpling was delicious. 

We also ordered Shanghai noodles. It was soo yummy! The noodles were so tasty and the sauce is really amazing.

Packed when we got there somehow we sat down quickly! We just wanted a soup dumplings which were very good! Service was okay... asked for iced tea then was given Brisk in a can which is weird. We didn't realize it was cash only so just a minor inconvenience.

THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!!! I brought my friend to this place a few weeks ago after finding it on yelp! At first, I had no clue whether if it's good or not; however, my parents told me that this place is famous and delicious, and that they even have it at flushing (if it's in flushing, you know it has some sort of standard). I ordered my childhood dishes: scallion pancakes, cold sesame noodles, and soup dumplings. My friend ordered sesame chicken and vegetable fried rice. THE PORTIONS ARE HUGE!!! So worth it for the price! I am the PICKIEST person with my scallion pancakes; I usually judge a restaurant by their scallion pancakes. THEY WERE SO CRISPY AND HOT AND FRESH AND THIN!! If you've truly tried scallion pancakes in Taiwan, you would know that it should NEVER be doughy, and have very little scallions. Joe's Shanghai NAILED it! Even my friend, who only eats american-chinese food, fell in love with it and made me promise to bring him back here to have some more. The sesame noodle was alright; they did well with the sauce but the noodle was too thick. The portions for soup dumplings, fried rice, and sesame chicken were HUGE!!!! Perfect, if not, a bit too much (which is never bad). LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!!!!!!
Still the best XLB.  We try to stop here whenever we are in NYC, just for their dumplings.  Worth the cholesterol spike!

In Chinatown NY, lays the home to one of the most famous dumplings in the world. The world famous soup dumpling from Taiwan makes a US appearance at the one and only Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown. 

Now as a lover of all things Taiwan (and since my family is from there) I've had my share of Taiwanese soup dumplings it also known as xiao long bao. This soup dumpling is one of the best that I've had and I do have to say, it beats the ones from Taiwan. 

The soup dumpling has got so much flavor and soup in the dumpling that you carefully pick them up and place it into your soup. Bite a small hole so you can get a little of the soup out and then pour some soy sauce and vinegar on top to add a little pizazz and then consume it all in one bite. Careful, contents may be hot but oh so delicious. 

Joe's Shanghai does the xiao long bao right here and man I'm so excited to have tried this place and can't wait to tell all my friends about it!!

Food: AMAZING 5 STARS!
Staff: not so great. (Only reason why we took away a star)
We had the soup dumplings, pork and crab with pork. Both we're very delicious and juicy just like they should be. We also got the kung pao chicken, chicken fried rice and fish with rice wine sauce. All three were equally amazing. My wife and I are not big fans of fish but my mother in law wanted it. So we tried a bit. The fish was not fishy or even fish tasting. It was as if we were eating chicken. 

The staff on the other hand was just wrong. It started great with our waiter asking us for our drinks and right away placing our xiao long bao order. He showed us how to eat them correctly (plus, plus) and then he left and rarely came back. We had at least three different waiters serving us. Which I could understand if the place was packed or understaffed but it wasn't. Honestly for the food deliciousness I would go there again and again and again. We were stuffed, great food, great portions and prices.

Food was particularly good on the day we visited. Service is always good. Ambiance is very nice at this location. The only thing is that you have to wait for 30 min to 2 hours to get in. But that shows how popular they are.

We have been here twice during our 2 visits to NY, and it never disappointed us. Although the place is small and we had to share table with other strangers, we didn't mind. We actually had nice conversation with our neighbors both times. Food is excellent. We always had pork soup dumplings and it never disappoint. We tried other dishes and they were just as good. We had tried watercress soup, scallion pancake, friend noodles, beef with broccoli. We highly recommend Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown (don't go to Joe's Shanghai in midtown, It's not the same).
Love the soup dumplings here!  The place is big and we did not have to wait long to get a table. The service was efficient and kind.  Pretty good overall- great go to for soup dumplings!

Yup, soup dumplings are riiiiiiiiico.
I would skip th crab and stick w th pork soup dumplings
U gotta eat .em right away, else they.ll get cold
But believe it or not, even cold they were good and soupy
Saut√©ed garlic spinach shoots dish was really good
Beef dish w mini fish cakes was good too
Overall they have good seasoned happy woks sizzling flavors for all plates coming outta th kitchen
I loved it
Loved it all
Saucy, good sauce
Tasty, quick
Not that much love from th service but these guys work hard and during rush hr, there's a wait
So take th early bird dinner time slot and beat th crowd 
Yuuuum.

Not sure if it's because I haven't gotten soup dumplings in awhile, but their soup dumplings are huge! My friends and I ordered pork soup dumplings, Shanghai style noodles, and a  cold chicken noodle appetizer.  The noodle appetizer comes with shredded chicken breast, cucumbers, and flat rice noodles doused in a peanut sauce. It was pretty good, but it was too saucy. I definitely recommend the Shanghai styled noodles (#122)! 

Wait staff were nice, but you sometimes share a table with random people if you don't have a large enough group. There are a few tables that fit ten people, and we shared a table with two other groups.
Xiao long bao here is great.  Would recommend Shanghai cafe over Joe's but this is still good stuff.
Soup dumplings were delicious. Scallion pancake was too. Cash only and automatic 15% tip included.

I came for the soup dumplings, and they were excellent.
10/10 would order again
Fresh, flavorful and you get quite the serving!
I struggled learning to eat them, but will not give up, I will continue to go back for the soup dumplings.

I've been looking forward to trying this for months. Definitely get the soup dumplings. The broth is more on the thicker side than Din Tai Fung in LA. There's a lot of flavor to it and it was super good. We went during the weekend and we only waited for 5 minutes. The price is pretty awesome for what you're getting too.

My absolute favorite!!!

If I could I would eat here for a meal everyday! They do get busy so don't be surprised if you are given a long wait time. The seating arrangements are very crowded. Most of the tables are shared. The shared tables can fit 6-8 people. Keep in mind that you'll be sharing elbow room with a stranger! 
The xiao long bao (soup dumplings) are a must. Please be gentle with them. The soup inside is meant to be enjoyed not poked and wasted. I see people poking holes and picking them up ferociously with forks....it makes me cringe. Simply pick up the dumpling with the tongs gently and place in the soy sauce to cool and enjoy!  

A few other favorites that you can't go wrong with are...
beef lo mein
snow peas
pork fried rice

Don't get too comfortable, this restaurant turns tables very quickly. This restaurant is CASH ONLY and gratuity is already included no matter how small the party.
wow! must try. the dumplings is what brought me here and honestly was worth it. so flavorful and filling. get the pork and the pork and crab dumplings

What can I say that 3,218 other Yelpers haven't said already? How about thank God/dess for jury duty for bringing me to Chinatown to finally sample the many treats of this crowded, labyrinthine 'hood. Joe's had a short line, a cranky but efficient line management system, and fine enough service. You don't come here for the decor. Pork and crab soup dumplings are awesome, hot and steamy with great flavor. Scallion pancakes were solid as well. Nothing fancy, just decent food and that's good enough!
Only got delivery from this place, but it is one of the best Chinese food that I have had. Their dumplings are amazing and General Tso's chicken is really good. Definitely recommend!

This place is super busy and they have a pretty quick turn around. Orders are taken quick and food comes out fairly quick. Now for smaller parties expect to share a table with other almost like when you have dim sum. We ordered a few things just for a snack and everything was yummy. Now there most popular item is the steamed soup dumplings. That was  the main reason for our visit and glad we got to try them .

Dumplings are what it's all about.  Saut√©ed string beans are good too. But honestly, who cares about anything other than dumplings? It's the only reason we go there.  Pork, mixed doesn't matter.  Little steamed buns of deliciousness. And learn how to eat them right or you'll ruin your shirt and burn your mouth!!

i cannot believe how popular this place is!  came here to eat with a friend on a sunday evening and there was a huge group of people waiting outside, but we luckily got seated straight away because there were just two of us.  i'd say if you don't want to wait, be sure to go with a small group because they always have a few spare seats at shared tables.

dumplings = good
noodles = mediocre

just like everybody else says.  but stop by and quickly order some soup dumplings straight away and they'll get it to you before you're ready to order the rest.

Best Shanghai Dumplings I ever had! I love their thin dumpling wrap. I savour the soup/broth when you bite into it. Describing it makes my mouth water. Ah I better stop. 

You just gotta try it when you're around the Chinatown area. Price is decent. Before I forget this place is PACKED almost most of the time. Go during off peak hours or you will wait for hours. I went here once when it rained, and there was no line =].

I came here for the first time after hearing about this spot for years. I was actually with a girl from China, so if that's enough credibility.. she LOVED it. 

The Crab and Pork Soup dumplings are fantastic. It's about $6.75 for 8 of them, and they're quite large. Filled with soup, this is a must order if you have never visited Chinatown before.

Wow is all I have to say!

We ordered their dumplings - fried rice and Lo Mein (steak in both) and WOW!!

It was 5 of us and there was so much food but kept on eating because it was THAT GOOD!!
