Really good xiao long bao, with lots and lots of soup.  I also really like the "kaw fu" (sp?), it reminds me of what my mom used to make.  It gets really crowded and so you might have to share a table with other people.  And the atmosphere is definitely lacking.

The XLB's are as good as everyone says. Bring your out-of-town friends here and blow their minds. 

As mentioned in other reviews, they do cram people in the place so you can count on being seated with strangers at the same table. 

I tried the XLBs, pea shoots, Shanghai fried rice and Kung Pao chicken. Everything was good but the dumplings were the star of the show. Next time I go I'm just going to get the dumplings. 

The interior's not much to look at but, let's be honest, you're here for the dumplings.

I wonder if they put drugs inside..
so good!!!!!!
I came here like 10 times and never get tired of soup dumpling.
shit.

A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!! Best dishes are of course the oh so famous dumplings and the jumbo hot and sour shrimp! The only downside is the waiting line and crowded sitting area but believe me - the food is very much worth the wait!
Soup dumplings are amazing, but the seafood ones tasted too fishy. The orange chicken had nice big pieces of white meat. Would definitely go back here again.

The BEST soup dumplings I've ever had -- and I've lived in NYC for almost 20 years. This restaurant does have a massive wait/line to get in, and you can only pay in cash, but trust me, the wait is worth it.

I've heard a lot of good things about Joe's Shanghai but wasn't planning to stop by since I can easily eat xiao long bao back home in LA and I usually don't crave it. However my friend kept raving about this place and finally I caved. 

We were seated around 8 on a weekday and it was crowded but there was no line. We were all starving so between four people we ordered four baskets of pork xiao long bao and an order of green onion pancake. The pancake was quite crispy and surprisingly not as oily as I imagined (but it was still oily lol). The xiao long bao comes nestled lovingly between pieces of shredded napa, which was good to munch on to offset the heaviness of the juicy fatty dumplings. One con is that the vinegar didn't contain much ginger, I'm assuming it's because this restaurant gets a large amount of non Asian customers that probably don't like ginger but I could be wrong. Anyways, the dumplings were so good that we actually ordered another basket after we basically inhaled the first four. I like the fact that they give orange slices at the end, it's a good palate cleanser after all that fatty goodness. And the total came out to be so cheap!! Will definitely come back if I'm ever in the area again.

Finally an affordable meal in NYC!  Four friends and I shared a meal at Joe's Shanghai and to put it in their words "how do they pack SO MUCH SOUP in one dumpling?"  Wait in line, try out their xiao long bao, and admire the craft - simply exquisite.

Everyone knows that XLB is the thing to get here...even Joe's Shanghai.  Other than the dumplings and maybe the green onion pancake, I feel as if the other menu item prices are marked up. In order to make it a complete value meal, we did not order any of the main entrees.  

Oh, there's a wait too...but I'm sure you already know that.

I love this place. The soup dumplings are so good, the pork and crabs ones are the best! I'm sure this is like 1000 calories but it's worth it. When I'm working in NYC and my friend come to visit I always take them here and they all love it! Even picky eaters love it here! All the other food is good too but I could just come here for the soup dumps! 

Make sure to bring cash!!!

-Very aunthentic chinese food, if you have a small party, be prepared to share a table with others
-WARNING: they only take cash so be prepared
-Food is amazing!!!!!
-Expect a long wait

My favorite place in Chinatown. I've gotten off a bus from Boston and ubered straight here. The wait sucks but so so worth it. Get the soup dumplings, Shanghai noodles, Chinese eggplant and really anything! It's all amazing

I'm originally from shanghai China where xiaolongbao originally comes from. Before I go there, I doubt it will carry authentic xiaolongbao. However, it surprised me. It is not only authentic but also, it beats most of the xiaolongbao in shanghai. We ordered crab xiaolongbao. The outside flour layer is well made. The soup, meat, and crab is perfectly mixed! Love it!

This place is bustling with people of locals and tourist alike and there is certainly a reason why. The interior is nothing to write home about and pretty non-descript, the service is quick friendly and helpful if you ask if you get a waiter who speaks English. You might have to share a table if your party smaller than 4. 

But the food is the delight here. The crab soup dumplings are hot and full of hearty goodness(we had to explain to a neighbor how to eat it as to not burn their mouth). In addition to the dumpling was the Pork and Dried Bean Curd with Shrimp and Bean Paste, String Bean Szechuan Style (with Pork) and Seafood Fried Flat Noodle. Everything came out fairly quickly from the kitchen. (They must have an army of cooks.) The String bean had slices of jalape√±o peppers but wasn't too spicy. The noodles where still firm and not soggy and the pork dish had a great texture. Everything was well seasoned, flavorful and not too greasy. This is why we keep coming back and willing to wait and only pay cash(they don't take cards) is the food. You come out with a fun experience, good food and fairly wallet friendly.

So I guess this is the Chinese joint that hipsters go to.  No matter, the place was legit. We were visiting NYC and Opti wanted scallion pancake. This place had it on the menu so we went to check it out.  Great scallion pancake and great steam dumplings.  This was a rare treat for me and it took a certain talent to eat them properly but after a few I was like a pig in a trough with these little morsels. I also like that the table were large circular tables where multiple parties were seated at so essentially you'll be rubbing elbows with strangers while scarfing down these dumplings and getting totally messy in the process.  It's all good though because folks go to town on these dumplings and manners are an after thought. Don't worry how you look just go at it.  Good time. 
Cash only!

Came here last night and was seated within five minutes. Note, if you're coming in a small group, say 2-3, you'll most likely be seated at a communal table. We were fine with this as it reminded us of our time eating at some places in China. Pretty efficient use of space. 

We saved our stomach space for both the pork and crab&pork dumplings, which were absolutely delicious! These soup dumplings are larger than what we're used to with pretty thick skin. Perfect for those that tend to break dumplings often lol. We also ordered garlic string beans which were simple and a great side to our XLBs. 

Do note, they included tip on our bill for 2 people, so make sure if you don't want to leave extra tip when leaving. Cash only with an ATM inside and outside if needed. Service is quick and efficient. Expect to raise your hand if you need additional attention for extras such as more napkins, water refills, etc. Standard.

Get here early to beat the crowds and remember cash-only! Also, expect to sit with randoms as the seats are just in this manner. Don't expect good service, this is a Chinese restaurant, it is a get in-get out attitude. But for what it is, there is nothing better. The only thing you really need to get here are their famous dumplings, Shanghainese style pork/crab meat dumplings that have broth in them. They come out hot so make sure to poke a little hole and engulf with caution. This place is a must-try.
This is s good place if you like Chinese food and you like soup dumplings it also comes out of the kitchen fast

One of the best places for xiao long bao in Manhattan!

sigh....if only that actually meant something. Even though Joe's Shanghai doesn't rank high in the grand scheme of all Chinese food, let's remember we're in nyc and not Shanghai. It's all about expectations, right? Among the other xiao long bao options in the area, it certainly stands above the rest. 

Super packed during lunch time, but surprisingly the wait time isn't that long because the waitstaff works efficiently to turn over customers. Definitely not the place to go if you're looking for a slow lunch with your group (you'll probably be sharing a table with random people). However, for decent Shanghainese food at an extremely affordable price, it's a great choice. My recommendation is to forget about the rest of the menu and just stick with getting dumplings. After all, it's probably the real reason you're going there, and most of the other dishes on the menu are somewhat underwhelming.

Great food!
The Dumplings are so delicious, so does the drunk chicken~!
It's an amazing experience for Chinese food!

Maybe it's too populous. Sometimes they seemed to forget to make our order.

ATTENTION NON CHINESE FOOD LOVERS!  

If you didn't like chinese food before, you will after this experience!

Yes, I did not like eating Chinese food before because I think the food is greasy and the flavors aren't of my particular taste.  And so when my local friends took me to this joint, I wasn't excited to go.  

We arrived at a hole in the wall, located next to a Quicklys.  Because the wait was long, we went next door to grab a boba drink while we waited.

When it was finally our turn, we walked up the small flight of stairs to our table and well, behold, there were other strangers at our round table.  Because it was so packed, we were told, not asked, to share a table with another group.  I didn't mind, in fact, I had fun chatting it up with them.

I got seated and recognized that I was a minority in this restaurant.  Yes, I was an asian person, in Chinatown, in a restaurant made up mostly of caucasion customers.  My pessimist side thought, "how great can this place be?  If asian people aren't even eating here?" (No, I'm not a racist and far from it, just aware of my surroundings.)

Anywho, the dumplings came out and there were bigger than what I'm used to in California.  OMG!  These were delicious!  And the razor clams!  The sauce was amazing!  Despite the sandy texture because they probably failed to clean them fully, I really enjoyed my first razor clams ever!  

The orange chicken, usually not my choice of entree to order was so good!  It was really crispy on the outside and the chicken was moist as you take a bite into it.  And once again, the pieces are bigger than what I'm used to.  I'm beginning to think "is NY really bigger and better than CA?"

We had a few other plates that were really good, but I'm going to try and not keep this review longer than it already is.

SO YES!  If you're in NYC, you HAVE TO GO to this place!  It'll change your mind about Chinese food forever!  And if you already love chinese food, this is going to be your FAVORITE RESTAURANT!

crab and shrimp soup dumplings changed my life!
I almost always order sesame chicken when i get chinese but upon the recommendation of a friend I ordered the green beans sauteed in bean curd. 
The plates were HUGE and yes its a little bit more pricier than what one is used to in chinatown but its worth it. I devoured a plate of green beans and i loved it. and i even had leftovers for the next day.
Their soup dumplings rock my world.

I came here specifically just to eat the crab and pork xlbs because they were so good the last time I was here in 2013. I can definitely say that they are worth it. Each xlb is large and the soup inside is very flavorful. I came in the morning at around 11:30 on a Thursday and there was no wait time. Service is quick just like any other Chinese restaurant. Make sure to bring cash cause they don't take credit card.

My gosh, this place has the BEST dumplings I've ever had. Trying their pork soup dumplings is a MUST! It's a little tricky to get the hang of eating it but the flavor is delicious! I'll probably come her every time I'm in New York without a doubt! Their new location is pretty nice and spacious, and we only had to wait about 15min on a Saturday evening! 

This place is also cash only!
Since my last review when I moved out of NYC, I probably went there another 10 times; pretty much everytime I go to NYC... This is THE BEST, period.

Everything is authentic and good to the core. 

The sugar pig shoulder, the xiao long bao, tang yuan, etc etc. Too many to name. 

The only star taken away is because the joint is way too busy! I

Love this place! But the only thing I can really recommend is the soup dumplings, which they are famous for. We ordered the pork fried rice, duck, and other dishes but they were just sort of lackluster. Nothing special. Also ordered the fresh ginger ale and it was OK. Not my favorite. The service is quick but not the friendliest. The person that sat us was sort of rude. I understand the place is packed but still, no need for that standoffish attitude. Will definitely go here again for the soup dumplings but probably nothing else.

Ahhh, the shrimp in garlic sauce was so good! Liked my chicken hot and sour soup alot too. The black mushrooms were a little too big and impossible to chew...could have been cut into half and served. The one star goes off for my disappointment with the soup dumplings.

This place is typically packed so while we got to Chinatown, our group went to put our names down for a table. After we got our name in, we opted to go have our "meal" at a nearby noodle shop. After we had some noodles, we returned to Joe's.

Joe's is a fairly small restaurant with not too much seating. We came here with only one thing in mind; soup dumplings!  We ended up ordering some scallion pancakes as well.

The soup dumplings have by far been my favorite. We had an order of the pork dumplings, and the crab ones. They were both delicious, but the crab one was my favorite.

The scallion pancakes were probably the best I've had! 

I can't wait to come here and try out other food options; the menu looked wonderful.

Went to Joe's for the first time on a Sunday evening and was absolutely blown away. We came with a group of 7 without a reservation, so for future reference make sure your whole party is there before you try to be seated. The hostess, staff, etc. can seem a little aggressive but pretty accommodating, and they were able to seat us within half an hour or so. It's pretty busy, and they really try to get you in and out, so have a general idea of what you're ordering before they come to you. Even though it's a little overwhelming this is THE place to go in Chinatown, so it's a must.
If nothing else, get the soup dumplings. Also, know how to eat them so go with someone who does. They are absolutely incredible - we got an order of the crab dumplings and an order of the pork. In total we got 3 orders for our party, which was more than enough. We also ordered sesame chicken and beef with string beans. 
The whole thing was super cheap - $9 per person for all of that. And it's CASH ONLY so make sure you know that before getting there. I will definitely be returning.
Delicious chinese food. i love their soup dumplings & the mu shu pork

The quest for soup dumplings continues...

Tip: cash only! There is an ATM at the entrance 

Food: 

- Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings): for a touristy spot, these are actually better than others I have had in NYC. Their version is on the larger side filled with delicious broth, and the skin wasn't too thick or doughy. Be careful not to burn your tongue as they come out piping hot! I like to make a small opening to let the steam out, so it can cool down and pour some of the vinegar sauce inside for the perfect mouthful 

- Scallion pancakes: pretty standard 

Ambiance/Service: No outdoor dining available. We waited about 30 minutes for a table for 2 people on the weekend for lunch, which isn't terrible. The place was clean, and the service was solid. 

Overall: I do like their soup dumplings, but I would come during off hours because it's not worth an excessive wait

Back for the second time to take my brother and sister in law. Finally had the crab XLB. Oh. My. Soooooo good!!! Also ordered a whole sweet and sour fish- was ok, house friend rice was deelish! And of course we had to get shanghai noodles!

Way too packed ALL the time and I guess you can call what they do "service". You will wait outside to be seated. The food is mostly traditional...but if you must order one thing, order the dumplings.
 I recommend going with a group so you can be seated on a revolving table that lets you "pull" whatever entree your'e interested in and share. The dumplings are a must. A tad too touristy though.

I came with a friend for saturday dinner at 7:30pm and it was super busy. We waited probably 30 mins before getting seated and they asked if we would be willing to share a table with others, which we agreed to, but if you don't want to do this, the wait would've been longer. Additionally, usually when I've had to do this at restaurants I would share like those long rectangle tables where you're never actually sitting directly in front of people you don't know but here we shared a round table with a lazy susan, so it was a little awkward lol but my friend and I still enjoyed our dinner!

We ordered the pork xiaolongbao, shanghai noodles, and spicy szechuan style sliced beef. The pork xiaolongbao were huge and could barely fit in our spoons but were delicious. The spicy szechuan beef was pretty good too¬†- very saucy and a little sour. I thought the shanghai noodles were not bad but nothing special - a little bit on the blander side so I would probably opt for something else if I came back. Overall, my friend and I had a good time and would recommend trying esp the xiaolongbao!

Viva xiaolongbao!!!! Raaaaaaaaah!!!! A truly mind-blowing experience. The best of NY!!  Don't leave NY without trying crab meat soup dumpling or else you will be missed out on eye-opening culinary experience....I'm dead serious!

Food:A++
Service:B-/C+
Atmosphere:C

You are not an official New Yorker until you've tried Joe's Shanghai!

Order only the xiaolong bao, the scallion pancake, the chinese ravioli with soup and fried quail. Especially the friend quail, it is so good that I went back the other day and bought 5 as snacks. Good spot for brunch but the wait is about 30 minutes to 1 hour when they are busy. The one in flushing has better Xiaolong bao but the location of this store can't be beat.  Also, be prepared to share a table with strangers because they mostly use roundtables.

Always love coming here. The food is really great if not sometimes a little inconsistent. It's fun to share a table with total strangers and strike up conversation (I've even swapped food with my neighbor...to the horror of my friend). A great NYC place to visit. Going on the earlier side at 5pm is a good idea because this place gets very crowded.
Best Soup Dumplings I've ever had.  They were literally on every table in the restaurant.  Took a little while to get in, but it was definitely worth it!

So impressed when I came here! Came from a small town in CT and happened to get sat with a couple from there too. They taught us how to eat the soup dumplings, which were so good! The pork was my favorite. We also Got fried chicken (ok) and general tso's chicken (very good!) 100% recommend and want to come back!!

Never fails. Got two soup dumplings, a pan fried noodle and a shrimp/pork dish. everythign was good except for the shrimp, surprisingly. It had no flavor. Come for the soup dumplings - everythign else is just ok. This place would get 3 stars, but recently i've been going to nearby places to try their soup dumps and theyre just not as good, so bump up to 4 stars.

My college buddy told me that Joe Shanghai was the place to hit up for xia long bao and the Crab ones were superb. 

We got here right when they opened up at 11AM. If your a small party you might end up sharing a table with other people, which we did. It was kind of awkward since we were sitting up right next to them on one  of those round tables.

We ordered:
- Crab Xia Long Bao
- Pork Xia Long Bao
- Hot and Sour soup.

The crab xia long bao was pretty freaking amazing. Definitely unique, juicy, and full of flavor. The pork was allright. Definitely different than the ones you eat in LA.

The Hot and Sour soup was overpowering. I've never had such spicy soup and literally my eyes burned...

I wish I ordered more food, but Joe's Shanghai is a definitely do not miss restaurant.

Five stars are for the soup dumpling and the deep fried flounder, both were outstanding. The soup dumpling are really something special!!! The Generals chicken on the other hand was just regular. It's worth enduring the wait to get in, don't ask me how they manage it but the do. Every chair is full every evening, so this means you sitting at tables in a communal way, so be prepared for that, also it's cash only. They average price for dinner is 27 per person so it's not that bad. When yo arrive, go in and give your name and get a ticket. Next you wait patiently out front; table for two maybe 30 minutes, table for four or more might be a bit of a wait.

Honestly I've eaten more delicious xiao long bao/soup dumplings and I won't say theirs are the best I've ever had.  BUT theirs are likely the best in the city.  Compared to other soup dumplings you can eat elsewhere, theirs are more toward "Shanghai" style.  I love their flavorful and juicy soup dumplings and I would recommend you to eat, especially the regular pork ones are good enough.
Service is slow and there is usually always a line waiting but their soup dumplings are pretty good. Their other dishes are okay but definitely come for the dumplings.

It was a little bit of a long wait and the system for waiting was taking a number and it felt a little chaotic. The food was great and the atmosphere was fun; semi-communal with tables to share for smaller groups. The soup dumplings are a must try!
If you're looking for a soup dumpling eatery ... You've found it ... Joes reputation is very well known ... Must try!

An NYC Chinatown must! The soup dumplings were pretty impressive. It is, however, a bit wierd to think about how they are made. The inside dumpling filling starts off as a solidified gelatinous filling that melts once heated which is why they become soup dumplings. Although a bit wierd, they were still delicious and worth trying!

Your two best xiao long baos(soup dumplings) in NY would be here and the one in flushing called Nan Xiang. I've been a fan here for years, strictly only coming here just for the crab&pork soup dumplings. If you refer back to my Shanghai Asian Cuisine review(which is sister to Shanghai Asian Manor) you'll understand why.

The rest of the food here pretty much SUCKS... besides their braised slice beef from the cold appetizer section.. I love getting that too. Other than that, pass on the wait if it's long and you're really hungry. Come here if you're just craving to snack on soup dumplings. I'm always lucky and never had to wait more than half an hour for seats anyways. Their crabmeat&pork is the best one in the game IMO, and I'm only talking about that specific soup dumpling... Theirs is filled with so much crab you could really taste it compared to other spots! Hard to decide how to rate this, if they should get 3 or 4 stars ...?
If you love dumplings you can't possibly not check this place out. Amazing dumpling, they have each and every kind you would possibly want
Great soup dumplings and I just love the sesame chicken and vinegar sauce. The staff was even nice enough to give recommendations. 5/5
Classic old style Chinese restaurant. Food was good the service good as well. Dim Sum was very tasty. Good to try it once but it was too traditional for me.

My bf welcomed me to this devil of a place-- We have been twice and it's seriously delicious. First, you have to get the crab and pork soup dumplings. Holy Moly, I could just eat serving after serving of that. 

We got several other dishes over the various visits, but the ones that really stick out in my mind were a chicken with roasted chestnut special (oh my goodness, so so good-- chestnuts were full of flavor and very meaty), a singapore noodle dish which was a little greasy, but still really great-- spicy and yummy. 

Still, nothing compares to the dumplings. 
Also, I love that they finish your meal with freshly cut oranges which somehow are always the BEST oranges I have ever tasted. 

Now, I want to come back...

We took a spontaneous trip to NY and stopped by on a whim. On a cold Saturday night around 6pm the wait was around 15 minutes to get inside. I would recommend grabbing a menu and figuring out your order prior to sitting down. It's traditional Chinese where small parties might end up sitting next to strangers. Our xiao long bao order took ~15 minutes to come out but we had to remind the waiter about our scallion pancakes order. I wish I could review the pork xiao long bao we ordered but they gave us 2 crab ones instead. You can really taste the crab and if you leave with a burnt tongue then you know you got it fresh!

The service is fast so pro means that you'll always get your refills quick but con means right as you're picking up your last xiao long bao, someone's going to swiftly take your plate away and hand you the check. 

We also got charged a 15% service charge. Surprising to us (a party of 2) and kind of put a damper on the meal (especially when we were looking for something warm and cheap)

Freakin' delicious.

But I don't need to tell you that...this is Joe's 4000th review on Yelp (literally I am number 4000) and it seems quite clear that the freakin' soup dumplings are freakin' delicious.

On our first visit, we foolishly opened up the menus looking for the words "soup dumplings" and had to confirm with the waiter that number 1 and number 2 (pork and crab) were what we were looking for. Yes, he said, those are the soup dumplings. And they were every bit as amazing as we'd hoped. For my tastes, the pork was best.

But a word of advice: if you don't know how to properly eat a soup dumpling, google it and watch a quick vid. In a nutshell, use the tongs to grab the dumpling from top (so it doesn't break) and place it on your spoon. Bite off the top, slurp out a little soup, and spoon a bit of that delicious vinegar on there. Now take a good slurp of the soup, and then eat the dumpling.

FREAKIN' DELICIOUS.

Joes shanghai is soup dumpling heaven. Everything else on the menu is not really worth mentioning but the dumplings make up for it. 

You should get the pork soup dumplings and maybe a noodle dish if you need a side of some sort. I've gotten the pork and crab soup dumplings a few times but the classic pork is where it's at. 

When the dumplings comes out, don't pop it all in your mouth like a fool. The soup will burst out and burn your mouth! Bite a tiny bit of the wrapping on the top to let the steam out and let it cool down first before eating the rest.
We tried this place and it was decent. Din tai fung is much better. I don't believe New York has one so this place will have to do.
Went for lunch during work and it was packed.  Ordered the soup dumplings and they were really good.  Staff was fast and polite as well

The food was amazing and came out relatively fast. The xiao long baos were so flavorful and soft; by far the best soup dumplings I tried!! Although we were seated in a big round table full of strangers it was fine since the food was that good!

It was 11:30am when we got there, and they open at 11am.  The place was already full but we had no wait, even though we were a group of eight.  By the time we finished, maybe an hour later, there was a short queue at the door, people getting tickets for lunch.  So beware, this place is famous and in all the guidebooks--come early or go off-peak. 

The famous soup dumplings are swell.  If you're a connoisseur or have a refined palate, you'll surely have opinions, and I suppose a blindfolded side-by-side comparison between the dumplings here and ones from Flushing (http://www.yelp.com/biz/nan-xiang-dumpling-house-flushing) would net opinions from me as well, but for most people, this'll do nicely. 

I think the same must be true of all the other food: folks who know Chinese food well or who've been coming to Joe's for a long time seem to note it's all gone downhill, but I had no direct comparison to the past and everything I tried seemed okay to me.  To boot, a Hongkonger* I know goes out of her way to come here when in town, and that's got to count for something, or it does for me.
  
Aside from the dumplings, my impression is that the food here is uniformly solid to good.  One standout from my table was the Jia jia mien--this was the first time I've had the dish at a Chinese restaurant instead of a Korean one, and I know it's originally Chinese but I like the Korean version better.  The contrast between the two was interesting, though.  The jia jia mien here was less tart, less dark, and much creamier than I'd expected.  If you love the Korean version, I'd get this just to compare.  If you haven't, it's still not bad--thick noodles topped in a soybean paste, with tofu and I guess pork.  Simple, but hard to dislike.

* Is this the worst city-native appellation in the world?  I think it might be.  The people of Hong Kong deserve better.

The soup dumplings were one of my favorite but we ordered so much because we wanted to try a little of everything the crispy beef and kung pao chicken were so tasty also some of my favorites from the 10+ different dishes we ordered all the meat was good quality and veggies were all so fresh it is cash only so just make sure you have that on hand service was fast but don't expect a server that is engaging they are there to get you in fed and on your way the food was definitely a 5 the service is about a 3.5 but over all it was delicious

Arrived here and waited about 15 minutes to be seated. The seating is shared so you are sitting with a bunch of people you don't know. We actually liked this set-up a lot, it was unique. We started off with the soup dumplings which were delicious and then ordered the chicken and shrimp in plum sauce which was also very good. The service was so-so in regards to friendliness, but it was busy and crowded so I will give them the benefit of the doubt. Decent prices and great food. Two thumbs up.

Definitely one of the places I hit up every time I'm home.  I only like the original store -- the dumplings at the other ones are either not as hot, or the soup (hot and sour, Hong Kong style) is loaded with pepper.  Admittedly, I only order three things here:  Soup dumplings, hot & sour soup, and Shanghai fried rice cake.

Super soupy dumplings, super fast service.  Me likes.

We stopped by to try the dumplings and boy were we happy! We didn't have anything else to eat when we were there because we didn't need anything else. The dough was soft but still had a bite. The filling was simply delicious.
I was referred here by a friend and it was amazing! The soup dumplings were incredible and so was the friend rice! I will recommend this place to anyone looking for great Chinese food in NYC!
Soup dumplings took my breath away. They were so so good, have not found a place who can even compare. Affordable, delicious, consistently great.

Joe and I go a ways back.
He was my first friend in Chinatown. I'd go to his place pretty often and always introduced him to my out of town visitors. 

All my friends like him too...although the adjectives they use for him might not be appropriate for a PG review. But usually we'd describe Joe-ster as "f*cking awesome" or " SO good...so good." 

My girlfriend also exclaimed,  "OMG, that was Amazing!" ...which makes me question what Joe did with her. But since I think of Joe as a gentleman, I'll just believe that he cooked her some fabulous dumplings!

Cause Joe cooks a great meal for cheap! My favorites are still the pork/crab dumplings and the green beans (a little oily but great flavor.) The skin of the dumpling is pretty thick, and I sometimes end up just eating half the skin and scarfing down the filling. 

Anyways, Joe's always been there for me. Like my friend Jane (http://www.yelp.com/biz/jane-new-york-2#hrid:-J7trffW_8Q0WX5Swx-xyw) however, he's so popular that he always makes me wait at least an hour before I get to see him. I sometimes go next door to Quickly (whose business is profitable solely b/c of Joe and their proximity) and grab a drink while waiting. 

Since he's so popular, you'll be sharing a table with his many friends, so don't expect privacy when you come here. Just expect to sit down in some close quarters, eat a ton of steamed dumplings, and leave incredibly satisfied.

What more can you ask of a Chinatown dude who came all the way from Shanghai?

Realize that Joe's Shanghai usually has a lineup, that you may be sitting at a table of 8 next to someone you don't know and that they only take cash and you're good to go.

If you're reading through the reviews here you already know the xiao long bao (soup dumplings) here are absolutely to die for.  In my opinion so are the snowpea leaves, which since coming here I've been buying a big bags of and sauteeing up because I can't get them out of my mind. 

The service here is isn't typical American service, but more of what you can expect from a Chinese restaurant.  If you are rating the service by those standards, it is excellent. 

Come, enjoy!

Ordered A1 and A2 XLBs and a scallion pancake. The pancake was super crispy and traditional.  The XLBs were for sure different; the wrapper was thicker than usual but surprisingly held a ton of soup inside, which is great!  Not sure if I liked the crab & pork or the original pork one more, both were delicious!

I have been there twice now. 
My wife and I were visiting from Cali (the Bay Area) back in Oct. '18. Following a friend's recommendation all 3 of us went to Joe's Shanghai on a Saturday for lunch. Needless to say there was a wait but we put our name down and came back after 1h. 
My memory is a little fuzzy as to what else we ordered (probably just some noodles and a veggie dish) but the XLB were delish for sure. 
One order comes in 8, almost double in size compared to DTF and very juicy and flavorful. We are by no means XLB connoisseur but after trying a few places in the Bay Area, I can say that wifey friend and I were very pleased and satisfied. 

Part II - I am back in NYC and I wanted my first meal to be Joe's Shanghai.
Came here on a Sunday at 2pm this time.
No wait, got seated at a community table, got 2 orders of XLB & food came out fast. Just as good as I remembered it!

Is there a wait? Yes.  Is it worth it?  You bet.  Decor is awful, the crush of tourists is demeaning, but my god, the soup dumplings are special.

If you really can't stand the wait, go to Joe Ginger right down the block--the dumplings are 90% as good and you can sit down immediately.

BTW, there's more than Xia Long Bao on the menu.  Joe's main courses are awesome too.

Walking into Joe's was literally like walking into a restaurant in Shanghai- crowdy and loud, and English was a second, maybe even third, language...and I loved it all the more so!  I wanted to go to a place which serves authentic Chinese food in a place that feels authentically Chinese and this is exactly what you get at Joe's (despite the very American name).

We went here mainly because of their famous soup-dumplings, and just one look around and you'll see the dumplings are as ubiquitous as the water on the table. We ordered two orders of 8 each and they literally flew off the table. The soup inside is nicely salty and the pork is very flavorful- I could have easily eaten 20 of them! We also ordered the turnip cakes which far exceeded my expectations. They look like a patty with flaky phyllo dough on the outside and the shredded turnips on the inside. For the entree we ordered sesame chicken and it was so amazing we had to order a second one. The chicken was like nothing I've ever had; it was tender and actually moist- not dry and hard- and the breading was light and actually complemented, not masked, the chicken. 

For a feast of 4 our grand total was only $40. So if you're looking to have a taste and feel of China but you're on a budget, head to Joe's!!!
Delicious! Had an order of soup dumplings and pork fried dumplings. Perfect for eating your heart away on a budget. Just note to bring cash!

As someone who grew up in NYC, the food is decent compared to other restaurants in Chinatown. The "shanghai tiny buns" is good but you can probably go to shanghai cafe or this small shanghai restaurant on Elizabeth St. for the same price and  ... without the LONG wait. 

I think this place is pretty overrated. With a party under 4 people, you would most likely have to share a table with strangers. If you're new to Chinatown, try Shanghai Cafe on Mott St.

I don't know how long they've been relocated for but I JUST recently found it! The restaurant made such an upgrade and looks beautiful inside! 

Came by for dinner with my boyfriend. Waited about 10 mins. or so. They checked for ID and vax card, and was then seated. 

The restaurant was FULL. It was a bit difficult to get a waiters attention but other than that, the food was as good as I remembered it from the previous location, from the xiao long baos and appetizers to the entrees. Everything was delicious - XLB, scallion pancakes and sliced braised beef noodle soup. We left with bellies full and dishes emptied. 

Not sure if it is because of the pandemic but the gratuity was not optional, as in they posted it on the check. My boyfriend and I didn't mind but it was the first time seeing it for a party of 2.

Fast and delicious food! Shanghai soup dumplings are the must. Loved the eggplant dish as well - it's got a bit of kick/just the right amount. The rice wine rice ball dessert was on point too. 

The mushroom and bamboo was a bit disappointing compared to other dishes. Bamboo shoots were too raw. Also had three salt duck or something. It was good but as the same implies, can be quite salty so would recommend having rice or some other plain dish to balance it out.

Two words: soup dumplings. That's what you need to order. Also the scallion pancake and pretty much everything in the menu is good. Hordes of people and endless lines that are expertly managed and move fast considering the crowds. Cheap, abundant, yummy and tip is included. Heaven.

this place is always a must when i'm in nyc. i actually searched for it for 2 days on my first trip and finally found it. they are known for their amazing soup dumplings, good sized dumpling bites filled with broth that explodes with flavor in your mouth! how to eat it - bite the top, blow on the steam, pour in vinegar and soy sauce, enjoy! i tried the singapore noodles last time, and they are amazing. they're like thick udon noodles with a slightly sweet brown sauce. the place is a true hole in the wall, so expect fast service that may not be too friendly but moves with a purpose.

I normally think of Chinese food as greasy peasant food and so it means something when I say this place is above average.

Just finished eating here on a Tuesday night on one of the warmest days in 4 months.   Wait was 45 minutes and the crowd was one of the most diverse dining crowds I've seen in NY. 

I tripped out on having to share a large family style table w/ strangers but that made it pretty interesting.  No big deal. 

Crab/pork dumpling is a must have.    All other dishes seemed on point and looked just a notch better than other chinese places.

Joe's Shanghai was recommended to us by some friends that raves about their soup dumplings. We've never had soup dumplings before and let me tell you, they are AMAZING! The restaurant was crowded the entire time, which to me means they are obviously doing something right. We also ordered spring rolls, general tso chicken, and chicken lo mein. The spring roll was large and yummy and the general tso chicken and lo mein was the best I've ever had (and I LOVE oriental food). I've been thinking about the food since the moment we left. Do yourself a favor and check it out!

I've taken a bunch of friends and family here often and everyone stuffs themselves silly.  You must get the usual, which is the crab and pork soup dumplings, that I have for an appetizer.  I always order the shredded beef which is sooo crunchy and good.  Everytime I order it, people sitting next to me ask what the name of my dish is.  Today, I was pleasantly surprised when my friend ordered this tofu dish that I never tried.  Again, everyone started ordering the same foods we ordered.  Another favorite is this thick udon-like fried noodle with seafood.  I don't know the name but the waiters usually figure out what I want.  A must-go.....period!

The place where the epitome of soup dumplings in NYC can be found.  My boyfriend and I love this place.  We have a ritual of getting stuffed here on a Saturday right after they open with 1-2 orders of the pork soup dumplings and a big bowl of the noodles with shredded pickled cabbage, then digesting in the foot massage place next door.  We never spend more than $20 to have a great meal.  I always feel sad for the people who eat there and don't have any soup dumplings, and instead have the horrible americanized chinese food offerings.  What a waste.  Definitely try their noodles if you're looking to try something new here- they're super tasty, filling, and cheap!

Word of warning- NEVER go to the location in uptown!  It is a pale imitation of the chinatown joint, even the dumplings seem off.  Maybe they're not as fresh.

Their infamous soup dumplings live up to the hype-- huge, supple, and properly juicy with a generous amount of soup and filling. This is the one item to try if you visit!

A solid spot in Chinatown for Shanghainese food that's great for groups at any time of the day. I came with friends on a Friday night right before closing time and it was still very busy inside. We ordered the pork soup dumplings and stir fried rice cakes with vegetables.

The soup dumplings were great and bigger than I expected with a proper amount of soup, definitely the star of the show. Paired with vinegar and ginger, these dumplings are so satisfying and delicious. The rice cakes were just okay-- not that chewy or flavorful on their own. I'd probably just order the soup dumplings if I were to come again. 

Every order comes with orange slices at the end of your meal for a nice refreshing fruity finish! It is cash only so be sure to come prepared!
Best Chinese food in the city. Really fast, too. You may have to share a table, because they are so packed.

No reservations and cash only !!

Their XLBs were way better than Din Tai Fung's not gonna lie And the crepes/wraps for the Peking duck were perfectly thin!
Staff wasn't very friendly but food was amazing per usual. We got soup dumplings and Chinese greens. Really flavorful and didn't wait too long for the food.
Joe' Shanghai has great food and wonderful service! We waited about 40 minutes for a shared table but it was worth it! We were told they are famous for their dumplings and they didn't disappoint!

My only "must visit" restaurant when I visit New York. It's a 100% no frills experience hidden in the back alleys of Chinatown and I LOVE IT. The lines are long, they only take cash, they automatically add a 15% tip to your bill, you have to share a table with random other patrons at times, and they yell at you in Chinese (just a little lol)...But everything is forgiven because their XLB is where it's at. 

I don't worry about ordering anything else except the Xiao Long Bao (at least one tray per person) and the scallion pancakes. My family has ordered other items off the menu that were good (sweet and sour fish in particular is excellent), but in my humble opinion, don't waste valuable stomach space. Focus on the Xiao Long Bao - you're in it to win it! 

There's also a rolled ice cream place, Juicy Spot, down the road that's open late if you need dessert. Ferre-Roll Rocher is my fave!

I had heard about this place for a while, this seemingly-mythical restaurant with NYC's "best" xiao long bao (soup-filled mini-buns). Hadn't gotten around to trying it until a friend suggested it off-hand. I'm glad I finally got to go!

The line at the door might look intimidating, but actually moves fairly quickly (if you're dying of boredom but still really want the food (which you should), go to the bubble tea shop next door or something!). As soon as we sat down, the waiters asked us how many baskets of xiao long bao we wanted: a good sign.

In the end, four of us ended up eating 5 orders of xiao long bao, plus a small serving of the dan dan noodles. The xiao long bao ARE as good as people say they are; they're filled with soup and are incredibly savory. They aren't artificial looking/tasting, with the fakely fluffy white skins; instead, they look and taste completely homemade. I personally enjoyed the traditional and the ones with crab meat equally, but two of my friends thought the crab was a bit overwhelming and instead just devoured the traditional ones. And the whole bill wasn't too bad: $50 total including tax and tip!

Definitely stop by here if you have a chance!

While this is touristy and the service is average, the food is really good. The dumplings are amazing and worth lining up for. Have been back to Joe's on a few occasions. It's always a great place to take guests who are in town and then pop round to Apotheke for a drink afterwards.

Cash only. 

Came here on the insistence of a friend who is a die-hard Joe's fan. I was kind of freaked out by the C hygiene rating (From Serious Eats: A letter grade of 'C' indicates more than 28 health code violations. For instance, sanitation violations at this level sound like "Evidence of mice or live mice present in facility's food and/or non-food areas;" "Hand washing facility not provided in or near food preparation area and toilet room;" or "Food item spoiled, adulterated, contaminated or cross-contaminated.")

There's often a wait, you get a deli-style-number and wait to be called, you're often sat at tables with other guests. 

When you're seated, you'll be given hot tea and asked if you want to order the dumpling they're famous for while you choose other food from the menu. Choose from pork or crab, we had pork. The steamer basket comes out promptly with 8 plump dumplings filled with a savory broth and meat filing. 

Pick up a dumpling and place it in your soup spoon. Nibble a small hole or poke a hole with your chopstick and slurp out the hot broth. Very tasty. 

We also ordered a hot chicken dish with cucumber which sounds weird but was actually my favorite part of lunch. The scallion pancake was tasty. Flat friend Shanghai noodles were fine, nothing memorable. 

I would probably visit again but I'd like to see the hygiene rating improve. For what it's worth, none of us got sick :)

I see why so many people love this place. The service was prompt, attentive and welcoming. More importantly the food was DIVINE. Had one of the noodle dishes and I'm still dreaming of the amazing flavor ...and as a midwesterner, I had to get the old standby of orange chicken - Yes, I realize it's a contrived dish. I don't care. It was SCRUMPTIOUS.

This is my favorite Chinese restaurant in New York. We always get their pork soup dumplings, of course. They're a must order. We've tried their crab and pork ones before but felt that their pork ones are better. The soup inside the dumplings is a tiny bit greasy, but otherwise the skin is thin and chewy and the meat inside is wholesome without extraneous fat and grit.

We are also big fans of their chicken fried rice, which we always ask to be done without soysauce. Topped with white pepper, it's the perfect amount of not salty. We usually order a dish of garlic stir-fried veggies, whatever they have fresh at the moment. Their water spinach and watercress are both delicate and fresh.

I've tried their noodles before, both the panfried on both sides kind and the thick kind, and they're both good but I think you should save your stomach for other things unless you're really craving noodles.

We've also tried their General Tso's chicken (don't judge), which is pretty good too. We've also tried their long neck clams done in black bean sauce, which were also pretty good and not too expensive.

This place is always reasonably priced. One thing that most people don't notice is that tip is already included in your bill. I think there's some fine print on the menu that says that and maybe even some signs on the wall. I don't remember if the receipt does. So thank me for saving you guys from paying tip twice!

Joe's Shanghai is probably the most touristy chinese food place in NYC, well - knowned for their xiao long baos ( soup dumplings) , its a spot to check out at least once whether you live in NYC or just visiting.

what is a soup dumpling? - its a soup filled dumping that you must eat with a spoon because the hot soup will come gushing out... 

i must agree with other yelpers as in that there ARE better places for soup dumplings IE los angeles( ding tai fung) or Asia. but we are in NYC and its good enough!

they also have an assortment of traditional chinese starter dishes ranging from marinated cold cut beef to scallion pancakes.

my favorite was the crab and port dumplings, they are a must try,

ps send me a message if you want to know HOW they get the SOUP in the bun =)

xiao long bao, onion pancakes, and noodle soup with pork and pickled veggies are always ALWAYS on our table when we come here. and my boyfriend and i come here almost every week, if not, every other week. i was pretty excited to find a place that had shanghai food, as the noodle soup is my type of comfort food.

we come here so much, the servers know us by now.

and they seat you chinese style, which is at a huge table with other groups of people. it's always funny to listen to the haoles explain to their other haole friends how to eat the dumplings. 

case in point, one time this lady was sitting with her husband and as she poured massive amounts of salt on her dumplings, on her chicken corn soup, and on her fried rice, she announced, "THIS IS THE BEST CHINESE FOOD EVER!" then she proceeded to pour sugar IN HER TEA. absolute sacrilege. and her husband kept spilling the soup from the dumplings onto his place. i just laughed silently and looked at my boyfriend with rolled eyes.

ps avoid the uptown location at all costs. it is of no comparison and it sucks donkey balls.

This was my first time having authentic Xiao Long Baos (soup dumplings) and it definitely did not disappoint.

I highly recommend trying their soup dumplings as it seems that its the star of the show at their restaurant.

My table ordered both the pork and crab soup dumplings; most of us enjoyed the pork over the crab dumplings. However, I enjoyed both just the same. The crab soup dumpling has a very pungent punch of crab tasting, so it may seem harder to digest or enjoy. 

My table also ordered their other dishes as well, they were alright... nothing special. I would definitely just recommend having their soup dumplings.

I would give this review a full 5 stars for their soup dumplings but unfortunately will have to only give 4 as the servers were rude and got annoyed every time we asked for/about something.

Walking onto Pell street where this restaurant is located made me feel like I was in the allies of Beijing. The line for joes was out the door. Though the wait time wasn't too shabby. Waited about 10 minutes. I'm not a big fan of Chinese food. I'll have it like once in a blue. Though with the Chinese New Year being celebrated I suddenly had a craving. The food here was good. The portions are nicely sized. I ordered shrimp fried rice and vegetable lo mein. My two favorite Chinese food items. The service was good, nice guys! Upon bringing the check, they slice oranges  and give them as a dessert. If I'm ever in the mood for Chinese, this will be the place I'll be heading to for it.
Amazing food!!! Crab and pork dumplings were to die for! Like a little hidden Jem and the service so so fast.
My fav crab soup dumplings. Great cold n hot dishes. It's packed now so good. Cash only

As we drove back to New Jersey in the Lincoln Tunnel, my wife asked me "So, are you going to give Joe's Shanghai five stars?" 

When she asked me this, we were blissfully full, having experienced wonderfully prepared soup dumplings and other delectable dishes. I was preparing to have dreams about this stuff. If these ratings were only about the food, Joe's would get 11 stars from me. But, alas... Eating out is about the entire experience. 

I cannot say what hasn't been said here. The food at Joe's is phenomenal. Soup dumplings are the signature dish, and they definitely get there for the Yen. So does everything else, particularly the scallion pancakes, which were strikingly comfortable like the Jewish version ... and addictive like warm crispy tortilla chips and cilantro-laden cool Mexican salsa. The noodles were al dente and succulent like anything you might imagine from 'The Sopranos' or 'Goodfellas,' but in a spicy Asian sort of way. The only weak area involved the hot & sour soup. If anything, it was a boring half-hearted effort. 

Service on our visit was quite attentive, and accurate considering we shared a communal table with three other parties.  And though the 30-minute wait could have been trimmed to 15 minutes with a little organization on the part of the hostess, I quickly forgot about the 30-degree outside temps when we were ushered indoors -- one step closer to dumpling nirvana. 

But it's neither the half-ass hot & sour nor the disorganized hosting that irks me. Believe it or not, it's the whole cash-only thing. And the automatic 15 percent gratuity.  Sure, I brought cash. But I have to wonder why such a busy place won't get with the 21st century and accept plastic. (I could guess why, but I digress.) The automatic gratuity pretty much defeats the whole meaning of gratuity. In fact, it becomes a fee when it is part of the bill. But, I was going to give 20 percent, so Joe's Shanghai lost a few bucks on us in that department.

Hey, my principles aside, this place is marvelous. Fun. Delicious. I'll be back with plenty of cash next time I'm in the area. This is truly some of the best Chinese food I've ever eaten.

This xiao long bao is only one that my son will eat the filling.  He's an extremely picky eater, so any hint of anything besides meat is a no go.  Other places that only have meat fillings, the filling tends to be hard and chewy.  Joe's has the right amount of soup as well.  Also had the nan goa (Shanghai rice cakes with pork).  That was good as well.  
Still one of the better scallion pancakes I've had anywhere.

Saw this place with high ratings on yelp so we decided to stop by. Definitely didn't disappoint!! 
The soup dumplings were pretty delicious.
Amazing soup dumplings. The crab ones are the best. Also the eggplant is to die for. The wait is not to die for but can be avoided

This is hands down my all time favorite Asian restaurant. Maybe even my favorite restaurant of all time. Their soup dumplings and crispy beef give me life! I have eaten here twice in one day before. Their soup dumplings are crack, literally. Sooooo sooo good. Their dumpling sauce is also incredible, I love that it has fresh ginger in it. So yummy and fast service. Highly recommend if you're visiting or need a good spot as a local.

Oh my god, I will dream about the soup dumplings at Joe's every day of my life. Our wait was around 20 minutes when we arrived at around 11:30 on a Sunday. Service is rude and they aren't helpful at all but it just adds to the experience. I feel like it's better if you go in knowing what you want to order already, so all you need to know is that number 1 and 2 are the soup dumplings. 

My friend and I each got an order of the number 1, and a scallion pancake. We were stuffed at the end of the meal and only paid about 15 bucks each. CASH ONLY! 

I will be back when I return to NYC

You go there for only one thing - the pork soup dumplings with crab meat... Best in the city that I know so far, even surpassing Chinatown Brasserie which I gave a rave review.

Your step-by-step guide to your Joe's Shanghai experience:
Patiently fall in line
Sit down
Order your soup dumplings (1 order can satisfy 2 people I would say)
Gently pick one up with your chopsticks from the top (the rest of the dumpling is too delicate)
Quickly transfer to a chinese soup soon
Poke a hole on your dumpling (I use my teeth)
Pour a teaspoon of the black vinegar with ginger sauce that they give you inside the hole
Chow with caution (it gets hot)
REPEAT UNTIL SATISFIED

I have dreams about Joe's pork soup dumplings. Holy bajeesus those things are good. I usually take friends from out of town there and nobody has been disappointed. Yummy scallion pancakes, and all their chicken dishes are bomb! All white meat, well cooked, and flavorful. I love the family style seating. The wait staff are efficient and patient with tourists. Definitely a Chinatown classic, and one of my favorite places.
Absolutely amazing food. The tables are communal, so it's not a very intimate dinner, but is great for a casual bite to eat.

When in China town, take a break from your bargaining and have some tasty chinese food and a beer.

Don't bother picking stuff out of the menu, just tell the man what meat you are hungry for and he will create a menu for you.  Even if you want something else. 

-1 for cash only and stinky bathrooms

Definitely worth the wait!! Best soup dumplings, we had the crab/meat dumplings, orange chicken, noodles (thick) and many other things they were all delish! One last things- we were a group of 14 on my second visit and they accommodated us!
Soup Dumpling was definitely worth it but what is underrated was the age shredded beef.

Best place to get soup dumplings in Chinatown and tri-state area... Although, my family thinks the quality has downgraded since they've gotten so popular. They're always busy with a wait, but the wait usually isn't too bad since people know that their specialty is soup dumplings. The scallion pancakes aren't bad either. I prefer pork over crabmeat, but that's just how I grew up. The only other place comparable that I've been to is Din Tai Fung out in Los Angeles, and that place is a chain that's all over Asia. 

** For the newbies, your party will not get your own table, but will be seated wherever a seat opens, unless your party takes up a whole table.. Be ready to be friendly and experience the way Asians make the most use of space and time! 

How to eat soup dumplings:

1) Gently pick up the dumpling from the top with the tongs.
2) Place onto your spoon, making sure not to burst through the skin.
3) Bite the top of the skin off so that you can top it off with the vinegar sauce.
4) Slowly and carefully suck the juicy goodness out of the dumpling.. Be careful, soup is HOT!

Enjoy :D

Of course, a crowd favorite. I love this place, always have! In the old location and new I would always want 2 baskets of the xiao long bao's. Typically i only get the pork one but this time tried the crab one. It's still pretty good. Joe's shanghai definitely uses thicker skin, but that helps it not rip so I'm okay with it. We got seated instantly since there's only 2 of us and its morning of a Monday. Usually there's a line and the larger your group the harder it is. Anyways I love this place. yes there's better xiao long bao's in nyc with thinner soup dumpling skin but that's fine. I love it all. NYC soup dumplings are just so good compared to rest of America. Apparently the "large Shanghai xiao long bao" is not the standard in the world... Poor west coast people got used to eating mediocre tiny Xiao long bao's from din tai fung. i want them LARGE like this! In fact this is regular size.  I love the hot soup inside!

Such a great experience in China town, we arrived at 6pm on a Friday and surprisingly there was no wait (there was a line when we left). Shared tables for smaller parties. We shared the fried dumplings & shrimp fried rice, I would come back for this also! Everyone seemed to get the boiled dumplings, which also looked amazing. Totally recommend!

Wanted good duck while up in NYC for the weekend, a Chinese friend recommended Joe's - she was right!

Middle of the lunch hour (12:30) the place was packed, but we got seated in 10 minutes flat. It is communal seating, so if your party is less than 8 people, you may have to share a table with another group - not a big deal for us.

The waiters are quick and knowledgeable. We wanted duck and asked for 2 orders, the waiter just said "no, only one for you". Between the basket of steamed pork buns and the half of braised duck, he figured we'd have plenty for two adults and a child. He was right, and we didn't waste any food, saving room for dessert on Mulberry St.

The steamed buns are a signature dish here and every table had at least a basket, some three or four. Highly recommended item, we certainly enjoyed our order.

FYI, there's no Peking Duck, so if you're looking for that, go elsewhere. For great steamed buns and excellent braised duck, this is our new spot in NYC.

Seriously so so so good. So good! Best scallion pancakes I've EVER had. We ordered so many Shanghai dumplings and sadly nothing else. We were obsessed. Definitely the best, biggest, best-priced dumplings I have ever had. Also do not miss out on the fried dumplings either soooo good. Oh man, I miss this place already.

This was our first experience eating in Chinatown and let me tell you it did not disappoint! Thanks to yelp I was able to look at the menu ahead of time and order the sesame chicken and my fianc√© ordered the kungpao chicken. Both plates were super rich in flavor, by far the best Chinese restaurant we have ever been to! Be prepared to wait a while location is kind of small, they will also seat you in a table with others but amazing experience will definitely go again!

My friend, who is from China, took me here for soup dumplings.  It was right after the New Year parade, so it was crowded and there was a wait.  We sat at a communal table, and things were a bit rushed.  But that's understandable.  We got crab and pork and just pork dumplings.  They were delicious.  I had never had them before and didn't know how to eat them, but my friend showed me how.  Now I'm a huge fan!

All hail the Soup Dumpling !

IF you're looking for the most authentic Chinatown experience in lower Manhattan, there is ONLY one choice... Joe's Shanghai.

Rule #1

You MUST order the Crab & Pork Dumplings.

... but that's just the appetizer.  

They make the best Orange Beef, and I really love the pan fried noodles.

I think Soup Dumplings are my favorite food.

I've actually come to the realization that buying anything but the Soup Dumplings is a waste of money.  Not because the food is that bad, but the Soup Dumplings are that good.  Don't get the seafood ones- Straight Pork.

The perfection of the Soup Dumpling actually compensates for the fact that the place received a "B" healthy rating (like most China Town Restaurants) and the fact that they don't take Credit Cards.

My friend had this place on the list to check out , so we came and had to see what the hype was about! There was a line , but it wasn't that bad. You just grab a number and chill in the area!

We got inside , it was packed and we were bunch with different groups of people in one table. I didn't have any issues with that , cause I came to see what all the noise was about! Prior to this we had already ate a bit , but we wanted to see what's so good about the xialongbao. We ordered xiaolongbao and another plate of noods. Honestly both plates were really good , I can see why people are making noise about xialongbao, It was very very juicy. Prob the most juiciest I've ever seen from a xiaolongbao! I personally really wouldn't wait in a line again for this place , just cause I'm not a super huge fan of xialongbaos. Overall experience was pretty cool though!

*Be aware , if there is a line you might be seated with another group.
I've been going here for years and just had dinner again the other night. Truly some of the best and most affordable chinese food in the city.

Because they are about to open a Din Tai Fung in Seattle, I just had to give myself a preface of Xiao Long Bao before that main event.

Joe's Shanghai has apparently been a staple in the New York Chinese food scene since the beginning of time. Because of this, its fame made actually getting the food an arduous task. We waited an hour in the cold  for a table to be ready at the Chinatown location. It was so annoying...

But when we actually got inside, it felt pretty authentic. We just got 3 orders of beef xiao long bao for about $6 ea. It was enough to fill up 3 people. Quality was good and things came out really fast. The only thing that might be a turn off to people who aren't accustomed is the service. Just don't expect happy faces when you come to dine here. Just get in, sit down, order your food, pay, then leave. The servers will appreciate that the most.

BTW: CASH ONLY

Ive been wanting to check out Joes Shanghai every time I come visit new york but never got the chance to until this past trip! it was a Sunday afternoon so it was quite packed but the wait wasn't that long, maybe 45 minutes we waited? We ended up going next door for drinks while we waited. Of course we ordered the special pork soup dumplings! Now I'm from chicago and our soup dumplings over here can't even compare to new york soup dumplings. They double in size and is so delicious! we ordered a couple other dishes also that was quite yummy. Definitely wake up early to come eat here on the weekend as it can get super packed!

I prefer Joe's in Flushing, but the food here was just as good.  We were also seated as soon as we got to the restaurant, as we came earlier in the day, between lunch and dinner.

Two of the people accompanying me were having their first soup dumpling experience, and were planning on sharing an order, but after having their first tastes, another serving of pork dumplings were ordered immediately.

One downside... we asked that all of the food come out at the same time, so that I could enjoy the dumplings on top of the Shanghai fried rice (one of my favorite dishes... so simple and so greasy haha), but I had to sit staring at my dumplings for ten minutes.  Hardest. thing. ever.

As mentioned before, the wait can be very long so I recommend coming early or not coming super hungry so you try it out!

The service was quick and the servers were attentive. We got our food almost as soon as we ordered it, which is great since we had to wait a bit. 

These are the first *real* soup dumplings I've had and they did not disappoint. We did two rounds - one pork & one crab seafood one. Both were so delicious! 

Loved the noodles and beef as well. The noodles were flavorful and full of veggies. They were soft and filling. The beef was crispy but not too crispy that it was straight fried which is always a thin line at restaurants. 

The main thing to remember is to bring cash when you come here so you don't need to take from the ATM in front. So delicious and I recommend everyone try it!

We typically try to get to Chinatown when we're in NYC. This was rated high by Yelp so selected this one for a try.  It measures up well with our local favorite Chinese cuisine (see my Char Koon review), some in family said no, but others thought it was close.  To be fair, more visits are needed for comparison.  The Soup Dumplings are unique to this place, and worth it just to try those.  They were very good, but you may hear so much about them beforehand, your expectations may get too high.  Expect to wait at peak meal times, we waited about 30 minutes for a party of 6.  They work hard to keep things moving.  Our service was very good and prices were reasonable, good for NYC.
The food is good. Dumplings are good. Be careful of using your credit card. I had a credit card used only at the restaurants and that same weekend shopping in Queens was used with that card!
Fantastic soup dumplings, and really cheap! We (party of two) got lucky and happened to get seated in about fifteen minutes.
Dumplings are delicious. Highly recommend this place to try soup dumplings. We waited 25 minutes or so to be seated today!

The wait on a Sunday night for dinner was about 45 minutes and as far as the food was concerned it was worth it. My family and I had a few entrees and some dumplings and the food was great.

To reiterate what a few other people have stated the place feels like a tourist trap and is way too expensive (even for NYC). Cash only is also a negative along with waiters who hover over you and watch you eat.

Ok so the food is freaking good...prepare to wait at least 15 mins for this place and DO NOT expect five star service. This place is constantly flooded with people so the waitstaff are focused on getting people in and out. I don't think that's a bad thing at all tbh. Probably some of the best Chinese food I have had. We kept it quite simple with our orders and got the sesame chicken and Kung Pao chicken (we don't eat pork and the vast majority of items have pork). The food is darn good though! Fast service and straight to the point.
The soup dumplings are a must - just order by the dozen! You will not be disappointed. The wait can get a little long but it is worth it. Weekdays have to be less crowded than weekends!

I've been eating my way through Chinatown with a buddy who is a long-time resident.  He swore that this is one of the best, and I'd have to agree.

The soup dumplings were great!  I'm glad my knowledgeable friend showed me the proper way to eat them, as I would have had a messy and scalding experience otherwise.  Apparently you're supposed to sort of nibble at the pouch and let the majority of the soup flow into the oversized spoon.  For my fellow uninitiated honkies:  DO NOT just pop one of these into your mouth!  

I also recommend the spicy beef with sliced jalapenos; I'm used to these dishes being long on spice but short on flavor, but this version had plenty of both.

My only knock is that it is pretty crowded - but I probably wouldn't want to eat anywhere in Chinatown that isn't.

Known as the best soup dumpling place in NYC, Joe's is definitely good and now earned its spot in the running as far as my preferences go. First thing to note- cash only, but this didn't deter the huge groups waiting outside from experiencing the crowded nature of this restaurant. 
We were seated at a round table with two other couples, which made it a bit awkward (especially since we ordered the most food and our dishes basically took up half the table). We tried both the pork and the crab soup dumplings, and I was extremely proud of myself for eating them in the "correct" manner - biting a small hole in the dumpling and drinking all the soup without spilling out of the wrapper. We then ordered the salt and pepper shrimp, which was okay, and the braised pork shoulder, which was delicious. Definitely worth a try if you're around Chinatown, just be prepared to share your dining experience with strangers.
Obviously the best soup dumplings I have ever had. Cash only. Crave it always.

5 star dumplings 
2 star service
5 star value.

Let's face it, you're not coming to joes Shanghai for a romantic quiet dining experience. If you're like me you want get get here, shove some quality dumplings in ur face, and then be on your way. The pork soup dumplings were literally mind blowing. The crab soup dumplings weren't too far behind. Be prepared to wait and don't even think you're getting seated without ur full party there. Do not expect a friendly staff. Do expect to feel satisfied when you leave. 

2 other things to note: 
cash only
To my long haired ladies, beware that ur hair doesn't dip into the soup from the dumplings. The feeling it leaves you with later on is quite unpleasant.
Went here specifically for the soup dumplings and they were a solid choice. Do yourself a favor and love yourself a little and enjoy some soup dumplings!

Usually very crowded in here, be prepared to share a table with strangers

Juicy soup dumplings

Crispy, flavorful spring rolls, and scallion pancakes

The noodle dishes were OK, but I think they're better known for their soup dumplings.
2 Words. SOUP DUMPLINGS. I have never had anything of this sort and now I'm on the hunt to find a place that makes these magical balls of flavor if it even exist!! Must have in NYC!!

Three letters...X L B! The xiao long baos (soup dumplings) here are one of the best I've had ever. My friends and I got the pork soup dumplings and the crab meat and port meat soup dumplings and both of them were equally amazing! It was the prefect soup to meat to dumpling ratio. The soup in the dumpling was very rich and flavorful. We also ordered the spicy salt and pepper prawns and it was delicious, the prawns were juicy and not dry at all and the shell was coated with so much flavor. This dish can get too salty depending on where you order it from but not here! It was just the right amount of salt. Another dish we really enjoyed was the chef's recommended spicy schezuan style fish filet...this dish was sooo amazing. I've tried this same dish at other Cantonese/Chinese restaurants but Joe's Shanghai tops all. The shrimp friend rice was super good as well and paired nicely with the main dishes and was flavorful while not being overpowering. My friends all really loved the spicy chili oil that was given for the soup dumplings! It was so good that they were about to ask for a side of it to take home. I'll definitely be coming back!

truly honestly do not know what the whole rave is about. after having heard from several friends about joe's shanghai and their dumplings, i knew i really had to give this place a try.however, went for lunch and tried their dumplings and they weren't that awesome. they were not bad but not that crazy awesome. the food wasn't trashy though so that's the good thing. and this is the first time i shared table at a chinese restaurant.
So yummy! Especially love the soup dumplings! Great place to visit when traveling & the bathrooms are very clean!
Yes, this place is a tourist haven, but as a New Yorker I still love it. The soup dumplings are the best and their other dishes are really impressive. Highly recommend.

The food was great! We had the pork dumpling soup, fried pork dumplings, shanghai fried rice, and the beef and broccoli. ALL were so tasty! Also, the portions are big enough to share. :) 

It was fairly on the crowded side but so worth it! (Mind you we did go around 5ish.) Wait was not that long either. 

I loved it and would go back again the next time I'm in town!!

Hot, tasty, OG dumplings. 

Ordered (2) servings of the pork dumplings and scallion pancakes. 

Bunch of sake too. Finally glad I went here. Service is very fast and ambiance is like a nice Chinatown restaurant.

Came here for the first time with some friends from back home. Wait was about 40 minutes for 3 people at 1pm on a Snowy Saturday. When we were seated we were paired with another couple to maximize seating in the restaurant. 

Ordered the pork soup dumpling and scallion pancakes. 

The pork soup dumplings were bigger and juicier than ones I've tried before from the west coast. 

The scallion pancakes were one of the best I have tried. Crispy but not too oily. 

Service is comparable to a quick dine in restaurant. 

They charge an automatic 15% gratuity.
I ordered the crab and pork dumplings . It was great and flavorful. The bathroom was clogged up . And it took about forever to order as well as get our food even though that's all we ordered

4.2/5

restaurant was really spacious and clean inside, but keep in mind they only accept cash. they were very polite considering we were a group of 8 who walked in with luggage and no prior reservation! we got the soup dumplings, shanghai noodle soup, shanghai noodles with beef, sesame chicken, and fried rice :D. they were all very good and were brought out quickly

also the restroom is hella nice and clean. if that means anytning

Every item I've tried here I've loved. The XLB are pretty famous so make sure to always order those. We also usually get the scallion pancakes, eggplant, and fried rice. This is a great spot for dining with a large group. Though if you're coming alone an order of XLB hits the spot.

The best Chinese food I've ever ate, hands down! I've been here several times and the service and food is always spectacular. Waiters are very attentive and take the order as soon as you are seated. This last time we went we came on a Friday for a late lunch and luckily were seated right away. I have came here in the winter before on a weekend night and waited an hour and a half outside because of how popular this place is, so plan accordingly. The tables are shared so unless you have a big group you'll probably be seated at the same table as another group but it's never bothered me. The place is definitely loud inside because of how busy it is, so not a great date night place. We always order the pork soup dumplings and crispy beef which are outstanding every time. The dishes are a bit on the pricier side ($17.95 for crispy beef) but worth every penny. The place is also cash only and tip is automatically added. The service is amazing-water always full and empty dishes always gone. I know they have 3 locations, but I've only been to this one and you will not regret eating here!
Excellent Chinese food for an affordable price! Xlb soup dumplings were my favorite, Din tai Fung who?

Joe's Shanghai has some of the best soup dumplings I've ever eaten! They are bigger dumplings and come out hot and steaming. I would recommend the pork dumplings. Also, be sure to check out some of the cool dessert places in the area!

Tip: Be prepared to order quickly & pay cash!

Love the Soup Dumplings (Pork or Crab with Pork), The Duck with The Pancakes and their Kung Pao Shrimp or Chicken. Can Have Enough of them, They're so Well Rounded on Flavor, Presentation and Price. Always Make an Excuse to go and visit.

Of course, you must come here to get the soup dumplings.
The first thing they ask you when you sit down is if you'd like to start off with the dumplings first. My group ordered 3 pork and 3 crabmeat/pork dumplings.
Everyone finished it in a flash.
