We ordered loads more like seafood panfried noodles, seafood fried rice cake, mushrooms & bamboo shoots, and sesame chicken and shrimp. Everyone finished everything. 
It's packed during lunch and dinner hour so be prepared to wait or try to get a number as soon as you can.
It's a small place.
Prices are reasonable.
Many people here are non-asian though during the times i've gone in. Perhaps the publicity is what influenced such a thing.
two thumbs up!!!

Famous Xiao Long Bao (Soup dumplings)? Of course this is a must. 

We made sure to get here early and were glad we did because the restaurant got pretty busy really fast. I know people mentioned it's weird to sit at a big round table with other people you don't know, but that's normal in Asia. Trust me...it's much better than having to hover over people while they eating waiting for them to leave so you can have a table.

We ordered the Crab XLB and the Pork XLB as well as some green onion pancake. Just a dash of vinegar with each soup dumpling and I was stuffing my face. Delicious dumplings. These soup dumpling are the variations I like too as it comes with thin skin and lots of soup. I've never been a fan of the ones with thick skin and less soup like Din Tai Fung chains serve all over Asia. I was happily pleased.

It definitely lives up to its reputation! Hands down the best dumplings I ever had. The pork dumplings with soup inside were incredible. The fried rice dishes are also very good. Bring cash, no cards accepted.

This place is awesome. Nice and helpful staff as always. I always came here when i was younger so i do have great memories of this place. The food is amazing its so tasty. I came here with family and we all loved it. It may be slightly pricy but its worth it. Also this was the place that introduced me to glass noodles(no not actual glass that would hurt) but its super tasty. I have to also say that the seafood here is very good and this is coming from a person who dislikes seafood very much. Come here give it a try you wont be dissapointed.

Soup dumplings were out of control.

I think they automatically assume any non-regular/non-Chinese/English speaking person wants them, which is fine with me, because they knew my mother, brother and I were 1. not regulars, 2. not Chinese (because unlike you idiots, Asians can tell other Asians apart) and 3. speaking the English, and preemptively asked if we wanted soup dumplings before we even looked at the menu.  The waiter did not prompt the man next to us for dumplings, and instead waited until he made his own order in a Chinese dialect they shared.  They did ask the two teenage girls immediately.  

I love their website's how-to for soup dumplings: To prevent burning one's mouth and to savor the dumpling, the preferred method of consumption is to bite off a little piece of the doughy wrapper, drip the broth to a spoon or suck the broth with a "slurp", then eat the rest. LOL. I burned my mouth off the pork buns.

Scallion pancakes, fried whole fish, noodles, rice, eat them all.  

A lot of communal round tables, and not in that trendy farm to table way.  In a no one gives a shit kind of way,  except the two teenage girls seated with us -- suck it.  They have non communal tables, but why bother waiting?  It was crowded as hell when we went for lunch, and even more crowded half an hour before they closed the other time I came for take out.

I had to come here one last time before leaving New York, even if it was by myself and just to devour a whole order of crab and pork soup dumplings. I've been wanting to do that for the past decade or so that I've lived in New York, and it was totally worth it. Joe's Shanghai has become incredibly touristy over the past few years but its soup dumplings are still number one in my book. When with friends, I would order soup dumplings, fried flat Shanghai noodles with beef, a big pile of stir fried veggies (snow pea leaves or water spinach), maybe some braised duck. But I will always treasure that day that I sat obliviously among tourists who gawked at me as I devoured eight soup dumplings all by myself. I'll miss you little soup dumplings! Counting down the days til I slurp ya again

I know there are thousands upon thousands of reviews. I know this place is super hyped, ridiculously crowded, and overpriced compared to other ChinaTown joints. However, despite all these things I wanted to add my two cents and say this place had THE best XLBs I had in New York.  

Lucky for me, my husband speaks perfect Cantonese and decent Mandarine. This, in combination to his charming personality, gained us a decent wait time of only 35-40 minutes on a Saturday night. We shared a table with 6 other people and we expressed to the waiter we were in a rush to make our broadway show in an hour. Our waiter was really attentive and we received exceptional
service as we really had minimal wait time from the time we were seated, to ordering, to our food coming, and the check. 

We ordered pork XLB, crab and pork XLB, along with the shrimp fried rice. 
- The pork XLB ($6.25) was everything I love in a soup dumpling and more. The skin was nice and thin, the pork packed a ton of flavor and was so moist, and that soup though. Man that soup was so good and rich. I seriously need to learn how they make this because I could eat these dumplings for days. You seriously need to try this with a hint of vinegar and each bite is perfectly flavored. I was really sad when I ate my last one because it really was that good. 
- The pork and crab XLB ($8.25) this was a close second favorite with pork of course being my favorite. The crab flavor really comes out and the soup inside was the perfect blend of pork and crab. As with the pork dumpling the skin was nice and thin and the flavors were there. It really is a comforting dumpling and my husband's favorite of the two. 
- The shrimp fried rice ($10.25) was the icing on the cake as it was cooked perfectly with each individual rice grain separated rather than mushed together or in clumps. The shrimp was fresh and cooked perfectly. My only grip was that it was quite overpriced, but hey it's Manhattan. 

Overall, this will be my go to place for XLB when in Manhattan and this has to be my top 2 places, second only to Din Tai Feng.

These are the best soup dumplings in town! The crab meat and pork ones are my favorite. They're so flavorful and I always eat too many. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone who loves Chinese food and dumplings.

i have never been a soup dumpling fan. i grew up eating them from time to time, and i even have a din tai fung just minutes from my home...but still, i didn't see what all the hype was. actually, i didn't even know what soup dumplings were...i only knew what they were called in mandarin. and maybe because the soup dumplings i had weren't all that soupy.

until i came to joe's. i see why people are addicted to this place, the dumplings are quite tasty. i love the unique taste of the crab ones...i've only had pork before. they're really soupy and delicious...it takes a bit of practice to get the slurp and eat technique down!

you MUST have the braised tofu with spinach...it's the best dish there. well, i haven't tried it all, but i'm willing to bet it is! and it's always good everytime i have it.

the only downside, of course, is the wait. but the service can be pretty good...just depends on the waiter. the hostess is quick and efficient- just make sure you hear her call out the numbers or you might miss your turn

Great food and fast service.  It's so busy but thier system of sharing tables with other people was a nice way to do things and keep service up.  The dumplings were great but as a new person, should be shown how to eat them, I broke two before I figured out how to get them.  Also need to wait till they cool down so they don't burn your mouth

came here with the roomie, her bf, her brother and friends from college for dinner last night. let me tell you that this was a great christmas meal!

the place was packed and we were told it was going to be at least an hour wait. good thing tiffany speaks chinese, our time got bumped down to thirty minutes instead! once we sat down andy ordered an order of the pork and crab soup dumplings. and a couple minutes after that we added another order of pork soup dumplings, beef pan fried noodles, scallion pancakes, and baby bok choy.

now apparently there are a couple different ways to enjoy these soup dumplings. one, just pop it all in your mouth. but do beware that you will burn your tongue that way. another, bite a little hole at the top, add a little of their ginger vinegar, and enjoy little slurps and bites here and there, still trying to avoid burning your tongue. and three, make a hole in the dumpling, pour the soup out into a tea cup, eat the dumpling and sip on the soup. all great strategies to enjoying a soup dumpling, and i am sure others have thought of other ways to eat these delicious little suckers (pun intended).

i opted for the second version above and enjoyed my first soup dumplings experience! not gonna lie, i couldn't really tell the difference, taste wise, between the pork and crab ones, aside from the orange tops on the crab. they were very tasty and i like the tangy twist the vinegar adds to it. our pan fried noodles were pretty good, although we are all used to yellow egg noodles for this dish, not the white rice kind. and the baby bok choy was also delish, no surprise there bc garlic always makes a dish taste better. the pancakes have a different sauce for them as well, which i thoroughly enjoyed the taste and texture of all together. all if this for 49.80, including 15% gratuity, score!!! this whole meal was just very pleasant and i can't wait to come back!!

Line was really long and it was super crowded inside but we went on a Saturday afternoon and waited for an hour for 2 people. The dumplings were pretty good but I don't know if the skin was too sticky or the steamer wasn't big enough, the skin kept breaking and the soup kept leaking out. The soup was delicious though, super rich in pork flavor and the meat wasn't too salty at all. Skin wasn't too thick which I like a lot. Tempted to try other things but only if the line isn't too long.

Delicious soup dumplings!!  My roommate and I pretty much crave food from this place 24/7... and manage to take the subway down here often.  These dumplings are amazing but everything here is also great.  We usually get the eggplant with garlic sauce - YUMMY.  Enjoy! :)

Joe's.. you are always true to me. 
Pork & Crabmeat Soup Dumplings. 'Nuff said. (2 orders is enough to split btwn two)

I would give this place 5 stars but the wait was F'en ridiculous. I waited over an hour and a half! 

The soup dumplings was pretty tasty and prices were definitely reasonable. I didn't like that I had share a table with strangers but that New York for you. I don't like it when people are all up in my instagram business! :) I'm that Asian who take pics of my food. JK! 

Next time, I will go to prosperity dumpling as I heard it's the exact same thing with a shorter wait time.

Long wait but totally worth it! This was the "it place" when it comes to soup dumplings and boy oh boy do did I love them! 

Our wait was about 30-45 minutes long, not too shabby, but keep in mind this was around 1-2pm so definitely not during the lunchtime rush. They give you a number and someone needs to stay close by to listen to them yell the numbers. 

The place isn't huge, so expect to be a little squished together, which isn't too bad. We had a Chinese speaker on the team, so communicating was definitely not a problem for us and so I can't vouch that they're English is good or not. 

The soup dumplings are a MUST MUST MUST if you come here. Soups are nice and piping hot, they serve complimentary tea, like most Chinese restaurants do, and we had drunken chicken (chilled). We had multiple "layers" of soup dumplings, most of them being pork fillings and 1 tray was crab filling.

The idea of the place is they ask you first hand if you want soup dumpling. PLEASE just say yes (since I recommend it -wink wink-). The reason why I say decide NOW is that it does take them a while to make. They do make it fresh when ordered. So before you even finish your "layer" of dumplings. I highly recommend you order another set (if you want) when you are HALF WAY FINISHED! This way there's no long wait in between. 

Instructions for first timers with soup dumplings?
First the tricky part if to get the dumpling OFF the bamboo steamer. This is hard because it slightly sticks to the bottom. They do provide a tong for you to use, but in my honest opinion, chopsticks were easier for me. So the really tricky part if to grab these suckers off the steamer and ONTO your SPOON!!! This requires some ultra awesome skills! 

After you successfully grab these wonderful buns onto your spoon nibble off the top and I mean it when I say nibble a small hole because next you're going to decide whether or not you want to put black vinegar inside the dumpling! I absolutely love the black vinegar with the dumpling, but if it's not your cup of tea don't do it! I'd recommend trying it with at least one to see if you like it or not. But if not skip the vinegar part and now onto the "sucking" part. What you want to do after you nibble off a hole on the top, you want to suck the soup into your mouth SLOWLY. Be careful not to burn your mouth! After you've successfully sucked out the soup you plop the entire thing into your mouth and chew. Make sure you can handle a bit of heat, because initially it's going to be HOT. 

After you're finished all these steps you have truly become a soup dumpling master! FYI for the crab dumpling, since it's nearly impossible to remove all the shells, there might be a tiny fragment of the shell stuck in the meat, make sure to chew slowly! Not that I had a problem with the crab dumpling here, it's just my word of caution when it comes to crabs! 

Overall excellent place to eat at! Definitely loved the homey feel of the restaurant and would totally recommend this place to anyone! I absolutely enjoyed my expereince here.

Food was INCREDIBLE. I chose this place on Yelp because I saw how many reviews it had. I did not know until I told my cousins that everyone knows this place!  The soup dumpling to me were better than Din Tai Fung. They were big and contained so much soup!  and the soup tastes fantastic. The shrimp fried rice was so delicious and tasted home cooked. The green onion pancake which I've had many times at other places tasted SO much better than anywhere else. Can't wait to come back here. It gets packed so show up early!! Staff is so efficient and super nice.

Start spreading the news..... actually it's not news this place has been on the off beaten map for a while now and it is known for its dumplings (Chinese crab and pork broth dumplings) to be exact and they do not miss the mark. Definitely worth splitting your wooden chopsticks open. Cash only and 15% gratuity added at end of check. But they have free views of gold fish and tea.

Wow, look all all these reviews!!! It's true! Joe's is amazing! It's been about a month now since I visited Joe's Shanghai ans I still can't get over the incredible meal I had there. I've been to plenty of Chinese establishments in San Fran and LA and NOTHING compares to Joe's soup dumplings. If you are ever in NYC, please make it a must and stop by Joe's . You will not be disappointed. Oh, make sure you have patience to wait for a long time (during holidays/weekends) especially if you're with a large group. I waited about  2 hours. Trust me, its sooooo worth the wait. :)

Pork and crab soup dumplings- enough said! You have to order that! Hands down, best dumplings I've ever had. Scallion pancakes were also good, but very greasy. Very busy restaurant, so be prepared to share a table with strangers, since they fill up all available space. Just had this yesterday, and I'm craving for it again today.
Yes the orange chicken is better than Panda Express, in case you were wondering. Cash only, community seating, but other than that it's really good. Don't mind the sketch area.

**CASH ONLY ** 
They have an ATM at the entrance if you need cash tho.
 
I really wanted to be critical, thinking this place might just be overrated and a tourist trap of some sort but right when I bit into that crab pork soup dumpling, I was in heaven.
They make their dumplings with love, and I fell in it. 
The soup is so flavorful and is a little thicker than what I expected. Tasted more like chicken broth, quite oily as well. But sooo worth it! 
The dumplings costs around $10. 
They're not stingy with the crab either but be careful when eating this because there might be some shell still in the meat mixture. I crunched on a few. The dumplings of course come with the vinegar soy sauce and ginger as well as chili sauce which had a sour taste to me. 

We also ordered the pan fried noodles. Light and airy noodles that pop in your mouth with that perfect crunch topped with the thick gravy sauce packed with napa cabbage, your choice of meat, and bean spouts. 

That being said, the line isn't really worth the wait. We came around on a weekday 1.5 hr before closing so we didn't have a wait. We enjoyed our experience so we returned on a saturday late afternoon only to realize there was a huge line waiting. We ordered to-go and had a picnic at the park nearby. 

The feel i got from the restaurant was authentic and you know they're working hard when they're eating from small plates from the kitchen at the front desk while helping customers at the same time. 

This place isn't the best for cleanliness but the food we ate here was bomb! This location is hidden in an alley in Chinatown.

i feel in love this vegetarian plate instead of the dumplings. I don't know what it is called in english because my chinese friends ordered it for me; "ku foo." so tasty, sweet and juicy sorta like tofu.
Such a family style type place but you don't mind sharing a table with whomever after you start chomping on those magnificent dumplings. Yum.

This is one of my favourite Chinese restaurants in New York. Their soup dumplings are amazing, specifically the Pork ones. While I have ordered other dishes from this restaurant (all delicious, I'd recommend trying them out), I do tend to only get their soup dumplings now as I pair them with other side dishes from various restaurants in the area for my meal. And the soup dumplings are always, ALWAYS, the highlight. Whenever I try a new Chinese restaurant I compare their soup dumplings to Joe's and nothing has ever beaten their phenomenal taste.
We LOVED this place. Soup dumplings were great. Fried pork chop was great. Noodles were great. Crispy fish okay. Sauce a bit heavy. Prices very reasonable. Loved the atmosphere.
The pork soup dumplings and fried flat noodles are delicious!

Be ready to wait for a table and possibly even share a table with another party as the restaurant is tight and busy. We ordered two types of Xiao long bao, one pork and one with pork and crabmeat.  Both had nine pieces each and was packed with great juice and flavor. Wait time wasn't too long for food or for dining. The dough was just the perfect amount not too thick but large enough.

I really like this place. The soup dumplings, scallion pancake and cold sesame noodles were all absolutely delicious. Icy Tsingtao beer is the perfect accompaniment. Servers are great, and the price is right.

Joe's Shanghai certainly is an interesting joint.

We were strongly recommended to try this place on a trip to NYC recently.

We entered and were immediately greeted by staff.  They promptly seated us at a round table that already had two other patrons dining at.  The table seated 7 so I think they focus on a community type of experience.

There were three of us and we ordered one order of pork and shrimp dumplings, an order of Kung Pao Chicken, and a bowl of rice.  I didn't think it would be, but it ended up being just enough to feed all three of us.

The dumplings were amazing.  If anything, I should have had another order just for myself.  They simply were delightful.

We ordered the chicken just to have a safe, "everyone happy" entree, and it too, was delicious.  I think it was the best Kung Pao I've had.  Not ridiculous spicy, and the chicken was plenty filling.

In all, a great dining experience and I'm sure to stop by next visit to the city.

First of all this is a CASH ONLY restaurant and well worth it! Our entire meal was split between four people and came out to be less than $50 with tip included. I did not have the pork soup dumplings but the rest of the table did and they were WELL enjoyed. Be warned their soup dumplings are big so you might not have room in your stomach for other food. The chicken fried rice and the chicken fried noodles were amazing and well done. The food was excellent and the service was very good. We had a wait but it was WELL worth the wait for this delicious food and the price is unbeatable! Will be coming back for more many times in the future!!!

Tourist trap? Yes. Still the best soup dumpling to be had in Chinatown. 

Used to have a friend that worked here, so I apologize if I've ever cut in front of you because of my connection. 

If you come here, and don't order the soup dumplings, then please leave. Not just this page, but get out of Chinatown. 

Another thing to recommend is the fried rice cakes. And here is a really good of the menu dish to try--beef with hot peppers. If you can handle spicy, definitely get this. It is banging. Sometimes it will be almost unbearably spicy depending on the batch of peppers. You've been warned. 

And be prepared for long lines. Unless you have a connection. Then when you cut off the 20+, feel guilty. 

And remember--you were never here unless you had the soup dumplings. You're welcome.
Loved it all!  Fried rice, dumplings are a must! Sesame chicken.  Very impressed!  One of those meals you remember!

Not sure why, but this time I went was /much/ better. The wait was ~45 mins for 5, which was not bad, and the XLB was much less oily this time. Super tasty yay! Also every other place in NYC I go to get XLB is much worse, so the rating has been revised to reflect that.
Delicious. Arrived when they opened so no wait. Dumplings were the best we had in NYC. Great service. Excellent experience!
The best soup dumplings I've ever had! I would def recommend Joe's Shanghai to anyone visiting NY that is looking for a good Chinese spot. The service and the food was awesome!

Vegetarians and pescetarians - no soup dumplings here for you. I tried asking if they could make their crabmeat and pork dumplings without the pork but alas, they could not. 

My friend loved the dumplings. I loved the snow pea leaf dish with garlic (off menu but just ask). They don't carry Chinese broccoli, though, which was disappointing and surprising. We also ordered a whole steamed flounder, which wasn't bad, but not properly seasoned. The texture was good, but the flavor was not - way too bland. 

Overall, not bad but I'm not sure it's worth the wait if you don't eat meat.

Cash only!!!

This was my first time here but it looked like the space was recently remodeled. It has a clean, sleek, modern look to it.

We ordered the Vegetable Dumplings and they were amazing! I feel like dumplings usually have mashed up ingredients on the inside, but these had cut up veggie pieces so I knew what I was eating (A+!). We also had Scallion Pancakes which were delicious. I ordered the Genreal Tso's Chicken and it was great - and big enough portion to take leftovers home!

Note - if you want rice with your entree, you have to ask for it!

*CASH ONLY 
*Typically a 20 minute wait to eat at a shared table

All you need to know about Joe's Shanghai is that they have the best XLB (soup dumplings) ever. I've had many in NYC and around the USA, but nothing compares to here. The amount of soup in one of their XLB is double the normal amount for only $6. I gotta give a shout out to their wine chicken ($8) as well, tender with a pronounced flavor.

Meal Value (from 1-10, my measure of quantity/quality of the meal compared to price): 9
The best soup dumplings at an affordable price - come eat here already!

One of the most visited and recommended restaurants in the area. The remodeled location is much more modern and accommodating, but I do miss the culture found in the old location. 

While their normal menu is subpar, they really do a great job with their soup dumplings. Their pork and crab soup dumplings are little buns of fun. Each dumpling is filled with a fantastic burst of flavor. Top each bite off with a dap of vinegar and you'll experience a blend of savory and tart.

Come for the soup dumplings only!!

Don't miss the xiao long baos here! They're definitely the best! I also like the kung pao chicken and the seasonal vegetable dishes (watercress & doumiao). 

Yes, this place is always packed even on a freezing cold Tues night.

If you haven't noticed, every table with have the famous and delish crab soup dumplings. Best value in Chinatown.
I'll eve make a meal out a whole order to myself and a bowl or rice. 
Everyone has a technique to eating them. Definitely take a small bite out and blow into the dumpling before putting the whole juicy thing into your mouth or you'll get burned. Also careful not to choke on the black vinegar. Um... YUM.

What's a visit to NYC without a stop at Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown? They have the most succulent Xiao Long Bao's this side of Shanghai (I'm assuming since I haven't been to Shanghai, China yet).

According to Joe's website - Xiao Long Bao or "Little Dumplings in the Basket" was originated from Nan Xiang, a suburb of Shanghai. Their perfectly symmetrical shape, resembles a pagoda.

Shall we get to the nitty gritty?

1) The wait is long. The food here is that good. Now that you're warned, don't be hating because you're impatient. It's not Joe's fault that you have Attention Deficit Hyper Disorder (ADHD). Take a chill pill. All your 1-star anger will dissipate shortly.

2) High probability that you might be seated on a big table with strangers if your party is three or less. It might not be your cup of tea. However, I grew up with this in LA at other Chinese places. You're here to eat not socialize for hours on end over bottles of wine. Besides, I've meet some cool people eating this way. 

3) Dumplings come in crab or pork meat. You can't go wrong with either but I prefer the crab. Each order has about 8-10 dumplings. Be careful when taking your first bite. These things are filled with hot, juicy goodness. Take a small bite off the top, blow some air in to cool it down and pour in the ginger/soy sauce for flavor. It's best to take the dumpling in one bite. Otherwise, if you bite it in half, the dumpling will fall apart and juices will everywhere.

4) Scallion pancake. Eat this while it's piping hot! Dip it into your soy sauce if you want. I just eat it as is.

That's it for me. I just eat dumplings and scallion pancake here. I'm easy like Sunday Morning.

Once you're done, pay quick and GTFO. Until next time Joe!
Soup dumplings number 1 and 2 in the menus and super filling I think ordered too much and the scallion pancakes are fire; waiters are always in a rush tho
Good food and portion size it good as well. You definitely get what you pay for. Soup dumplings are good and a must get item.

We ordered the following:

Soup dumplings 5/5
Fried rice 5/5
Sesame chicken and broccoli 2/5

The dumplings are the best anywhere. The sesame chicken and broccoli (cold and partially cooked) were a letdown. Fun atmosphere, definitely worth a visit.

The crab and pork soup dumpling is really as good as everyone says. Full of soupy goodness and they don't skimp on the crab either. Although I did notice during a recent visit that they skimped on the ginger in the soy sauce dip. The eggplant with pork dish is also delicious. Don't come here if you're on a diet.

This was one of my top foodies on my list to try while in NYC ! And I fell in love with their soup dumplings ! Omg the texture of the cute little dumpling was amazing, as for the pork and broth inside. It is heaven in my mouth. Very cheap also! I became addicted to soup dumplings ever since trying it here at Joes. The service was quick and the servers were nice and attentive. And yes it's very small inside and usually gets really packed that you have to share tables with strangers, but I don't mind as long as I get some soup dumplings in my tummy lol I will definitely be back whenever I'm in NYC again!
Best shanghai buns I have ever eaten so far! :D They come out hot! The flavors of the soup and the meat are perfect. If you want to see them for yourself, feel free to watch my video!

So good! Expect to sit with strangers and mingle! The pictures do no justice on how delicious the dumplings are! Expect a wait and bring cash. We got extremely lucky as we were a small party of 2 and came at an awkward time and were seated within 10 minutes. Lots of photos of celebs on the wall, so gaze and look around while your food is being prepped for you

Yes, the dumplings were awesome like everyone says!....especially with the hot sauce on them. we loved it so much we came back 2x on our 5-day trip. 

had some pan-fried noodles as well (#143 on the menu) pretty tasty as well.

definitely worth the wait.

Soooooo gooood! Definitely worth the 15-20 minute wait in line. We had the Soup Dumplings as a starter just as everyone should when coming here. Be careful if you've never had one before, they are full of sauce and you don't want to be wearing it for the rest of your day.  We enjoyed veggie low mein, sesame chicken, and pork fried rice. The Low mein was amazing the rice wasnt as flavorful but everything was cooked with quality ingredients you could tell.
In general, typical Americanized Chinese food. However, they have the best soup dumplings that you'll find anywhere. Well worth a visit.

what to order: XIAO LONG BAOOOOOOOOO!!!
tip: don't stray too far, sometimes they underquote and if you're not there- there goes your table!

My boyfriend and I got SUPER lucky and got sat right away- even though there was like 50 people outside waiting. perks of having a small party! woo! We saw a customer get into a loud, heated argument with the host for underquoting him, calling his number (which he missed because he went somewhere) and then gave his table away.

Also! If you have a small party, they will sit you with other small parties at one, big round table. So be prepared for that.

First off, I work at Din Tai Fung, which means I have had my fair share of xiao long baos.. but damn, Joe's just kills it. Their XLB are a lot bigger and juicier- there is so much more soup! At first I thought I wouldn't like that much dough, but I was wrong. I was struggling at first because I wasn't sure how to approach a XLB of this size but basically, you gotta just eat it all in one bite! Shove it all in your mouth with some vinegar and ginger!! hahah

I liked eating the XLB with the cabbage too! We ordered a noodle dish which was good but oily. I ended up adding the cabbage from the XLB to the noodles to make it a little healthier.

PLEASE COME TO ORANGE COUNTY!!!!!!!!!!

We came here because a friend recommended this place when we were looking for a good place to go in Chinatown. We were looking for somewhere authentic and apparently this place was known for its shao long baos. There was a line out the door so that was a good sign. 

I wouldnt say this is the BEST shao long bao i've had, but its definitely really good. All in all, it's really good, but i wasn't extremely impressed. I feel like you can get this kind of food elsewhere. 

And service was really good! Not sure why people said it was bad. They were very attentive and the food came out really fast. I thought it was slightly strange to sit in a big table with strangers, but I guess they have to do that to pack the customers in. 

Conclusion: Not bad, but not over the top impressive either.

Take a walk there, the crab and pork dumplings are so flavorful and juicy. I can see why they are famous. Scallion pancake was a bit greasy, but I still devoured it. Pork chops were really good, like just the right sweet and salty. I think someone from our group ordered the chicken on top of hard noodles, there is a specific name, and it was gross.. it's a small cramped spot, cash only, and like many little Asian spots order, eat, pay and go..

My biggest mistake I make coming here is ordering regular food - which is pretty good - instead of getting the cheaply priced and completely delicious dumplings. One order of the amazing dumplings is a few bucks and should mostly fill you up. Even when leaving stuffed I'll keep thinking how good the dumpling broth is and the tactile joy of gently biting a small slit in the skin to suck it out. Sounds obscene, but the best food experiences are.

The service is bare-bones. You pretty much have to grab a server by the fanny to get them to notice you. But the fast pace is kind of fun, as is the Russian Roulette of being seated next to whoever happened to be at the same open table.

When I tell you...THE WAIT WAS WORTH IT...and I hate waiting. During our visit to New York, I heard so many great things about Joe's Shanghai. I didn't think to believe the hype, but there was a crowd waiting outside. We waited nearly an hour for our table. 

When we were finally called, we had to share a table with two other people which wasn't preferred to me but it's New York, and the place was packed. However, we were served pretty quick. 

Now the dumplings. I've never had a soup dumpling before..and I'll never find another dumpling as good. I'm not being dramatic, I came back home to find soup dumplings but nothing compared. I dream of them (again not being dramatic.) The dumplings come fresh, they are nice and large and have the most flavorful broth. I ordered the pork and crab meat...yes.

This is a mouthgasm waiting to happen!! Warning: there may be a line and the wait is not pretty (like any other popular NYC restaurant). 

I came in the dead of winter and was forced to wait 45 minutes for a table but lo and behold it was completely worth it! They seat you family style - for those of you who don't know it's usually a large circular table with other patrons. Your food is placed in front of you in a rotating circular section in the center of the table.

The soup dumplings are to die for, however for those who don't eat pork be forewarned that none of their soup dumplings are pork free. Also get the salt & pepper shrimp. For how much it costs, they give you quite a bit of shrimp and it is pretty darn authentic. YUMMM!!

This is a place you come if you want good (and cheap) food but don't be surprised if the decor isn't stellar or if there is a wait.

I've tried soup dumplings in HK (din Tai Fung) , LA(din Tai Fung, Mama Lu)  and NYC (Joe's Shanghai), and Joe's Shanghai is ALWAYS my no. 1. 

Must order the crab soup dumplings if you only order one, it's so flavorful and you can taste the crab essence. For the regular pork one, it better than Don Tai Fung but not as great as MaMa Lu. But Joe's keep it authentic by steaming their soup dumplings on cabbage. 

One thing I also want to mention is that the size of dumplings def grew a size or two over the years. Which is great for holding the soup in the dumplings!

It has been over 10 years since I last wrote about Joe's Shanghai. Everything that I've said about Joe's Shanghai's food back then is still true now. The dumpling quality is still one of the best in New York due to the thin chewy skin, dense broth and well-seasoned pork. They're also one of the last restaurants to serve 8 soup dumpling in a basket. Most other restaurants serve only 6. 

Joe's, for those of you who are new to this restaurant, has been around since the mid-1990's when it was one of the first soup dumpling restaurants in New York City. I still think they make the best version of soup dumplings in New York City. What has changed recently is that Joe's has moved into the old 27 Sunshine space at 46 Bowery. This was a great move because diners now have a larger, brighter and more modern space to eat. I recently visited and noticed that since the space is larger, there's a lesser likelihood of table-sharing as with the old space at Pell Street. The service was also the same: quick and efficient. When the bill came, there was the same 15 percent tip, which is automatically added to the receipt. This is understandable because of the large number of tourists who come to this location. Joe's is still cash only. There's two ATM machines in the vestibule of Joe's if cash is needed.

I ordered a beef fried rice cake and an order of pork soup dumplings. Both were just as good as in the old location. I looked at the other tables and noticed that the food looked the same, with only the plates and utensils upgraded. 

It was nice to see the food remain true to Joe's long history. I look forward to trying some of the more Shanghainese dishes on the menu in a later visit.

There's always a huge line here with people waiting outside. The wait time could be anywhere from 20 minutes to 1 hour. The soup dumplings are so worth it though! Out of the 5 times I've been here, there was only one time that the soup dumplings weren't that great.

Two words:  SOUP DUMPLINGS!

Have you ever had dumplings with soup inside of it?! No? You my friend have not lived. 

Genius....Fucking Genius.
The house special fried rice, eggplant, fried pork chop, beef brocolli, green beans, sesame chicken, general tso was all delicious.  Everyone from our party of 13 enjoyed all the dishes.  DELICIOUS!
The soup dumplings are a must try here!!! Dumplings are very big so definitely can share 1 order with another person. The soup inside was very good and it complimented the meat well.

Love this place!
This place makes food that makes my mouth water all up!
Some of the best dim sum I've ever had we got the steamed veg, scallion pancakes and the cold sesame noodles and it all tasted so fresh
The best pork/crab soup dumplings... period.  If you haven't tried it, you haven't lived.  Its that simple.
Maybe I overhyped it in my head. Very good and def. worth doing at least once.

I first came here four years ago while I was on vacation, and I had to go back when I was back in NYC. And boy I was not disappointed! I split an order of the pork xiao long bao (XLB) and the crab XLB with a friend. So we each devoured 8 XLBs. We loved it so much that we came twice during our trip. The wait is definitely worth it because those little (acutally it's ginormous compared to other places) dumplings make you so happy!  When the flavors from the warm soup inside the juicy XLBs explode in your mouth, you'll want to keep eating and eating. We tried some other dishes, which were pretty much forgettable. I would recommend sticking to the XLBs. Of course these are not as great as the real deal in Shanghai, but it's the best that I've tasted in the states.

I will always come to this restaurant when I go to New York. 
The soup dumplings and pan fried noodles is a Must Have. The pan fried dumplings is good too! 

I found out recently they relocated to a bigger location. The inside looks very elegant and fancy now. 

*** CASH ONLY ***

Joe's serves the plumpest, juiciest soup dumplings (xiao long bao) you'll probably ever have in your life. It wasn't too difficult to get a table for two here on Saturday around noon; we actually walked in and were seated immediately at a table to ourselves. Got really lucky! Seeing some larger groups waiting outside made us a little apprehensive about the wait time, but it ended up being only 30 seconds. Since the staff knows that most patrons are here for the soup dumplings, our waiter quickly asked how many orders of them we wanted so that we wouldn't have too long for the kitchen to steam them. We then ordered a scallion pancake and string beans when he came back later to our table. 

Like many other Chinese restaurants, the food comes out shortly after ordering, which is perfect for hangry and impatient people like me. The scallion pancake was super greasy and the string beans were good, but the headliner of the meal was for sure the pork soup dumplings. Eating and savoring them is an experience everyone should have. They were literally bursting with flavor! I've had xiao long bao at Din Tai Fung in China, and I must say the ones at Joe's were very comparable. 

Note: 15% tip is automatically applied to your check, no matter your party size

I don't usually like Chinese food but these dumplings are a must have! Come early and be ready to take your number and wait in line outside- they do not take reservations. It is hidden on Pell street in Chinatown but the food is great and certainly stands out. Also recommend the duck, was delicious.

The dumplings were amazing!!! Definitely worth making the trip to China town for them. We had the crab and beef mix dumplings. We had a chicken dish, spicy shrimp, and a crispy fried beef dish which was out favorite. The place was full of people so we knew we were in a good place. The service was quick and food yummy!!

We got seated fairly quickly! The soup dumplings were delicious and perfectly sized. The broth inside was had so much flavor and perfectly rationed with the dumpling itself. The crispy noodles were pretty good but it could have been crispier.

Best soup dumplings in china townÔºÅ Just had lunch there, have to say it was the best soup dumplings i have ever had. if you looking to try some soup dumplings in china town this is the place you want go.

Best soup dumplings (their specialty) in Chinatown hands down!! Pork shoulder also very good. Scallion pancakes were better a few months ago not sure what changed. Be aware tip included on ALL checks since its a tourist spot.

On vacation during the New Years holiday in New York we decided to stop here without knowing much about the place.  First off anyone who knows anything about New York is seating can be limited so definitely want to come real early 11:00am or real late.  Also driving is a nightmare you will want to take the bus or subway, parking in the city can $25 and up with no in and out privileges.  Parking garages that go for 9 an hour fill up real fast and driving to get to them is a nightmare.

So as seating was limited even at noon we were lucky to share a table with two other couples, this is very common in Hong Kong and I am sure Chinatown, NY.  The item that everyone in the restaurant orders is the Shanghai crab/pork soup dumplings, for 8 you pay 6.95 and they are very filling.  Inside is a very hot soup broth that is wonderful would not surprise me if they used duck broth instead of chicken broth.  Just be careful as juices can fly all over the place when you eat these dumplings.  The other dish we tried was jalapeno diced tofo and pork this was very good as well.  The interesting the I noticed about chinatown restaurants in New York rice never comes with the meal you usually have to pay a buck or two extra.  The other negative and this goes for most chinatown restaurants the bathrooms are horrible, but if you have to go better do it bathrooms are hard to find in the city!!!

You have to wait approximately an hour before you are seated. Once you are seated, they will bring you water and ask if you want to order the xiao long bao first. Don't be surprised if they seat you next to strangers and spill water on you. Also you may not really hear what your friends are saying because it's extremely loud there. The pork and crab xiao long bao are really yummy. It has more soup than other restaurants that serves xiao long bao, but the meat is smaller. The scallion pancake is really good and wasn't that oily. The duck was really flavorful and delicious. However the vegetable wasn't that good. Overall, if you are willing to wait an hour and want xiao long bao with more soup, then you should come here. But, if you are in a rush and rather have more meat in your dumpings, then this place isn't the place to go.

First time in New York and my friends brought me to the best Chinese food in town. The soup dumpling was redonculously good, chicken cucumber dish different but very tasty. Portions are totally sharing.  We got lucky and walked right in to a table. I can't wait to eat here again

I found this place on yelp and it looked like the best place for soup dumplings in NYC. I'm sure everyone else has said this, but it's crowded and the wait on a winter's day (when we visited) was difficult. We were seating with some random folks, which made me feel oddly at home. The dumplings were juicy and piping hot. We ordered another dish that I can't remember, but it wasn't really worth mentioning. The dumplings are their specialty anyway. Out here on the west coast, I'm pretty much addicted to Din Tai Fung and you can't compare the two because they are different styles. I'll be back to Joe's the next time I'm in NYC.

What can I say...a tourist hot spot, and normally I would be annoyed at the long waits,  and half-clueless patrons tearing away the soup dumplings with their forks, GAH!!! However, I love these soup dumplings here so much that nothing comes close. I'll agree to sit at the round table with other dumplovers and put up with the chaotic customer service and loud atmosphere just so I can indulge in some fabulous, soup-filled masterpieces.

Go, experience it. YOU MUST. These are not regular dumplings folks, these are not some pot stickers you throw on the stove..

This place is the bomb. Even on a rainy Sunday night we had to wait 15 minutes. Family style tables were fun though a bit cramped. The food was great. Soup dumplings are a must. Green beans were lovely. Wasn't a big fan of the sesame chicken...too sweet. Can't wait to go back!

AMAZING SOUP DUMPLINGS! otherwise known as Â∞èÈæôÂåÖ . Get the crab one. Super cheap and sooo amazing. Full of crab flavor!!! Much better than the overrated Din Tai Fung. And even arguably better than the crab specialty Â∞èÁ¨ºÂåÖ I've had in shanghai and I've had many soup dumplings (Btw obvi shanghai is in the title and it's The city  known for this dish). so I feel like I have a pretty decent tastes in regards to this. I'm here to say this is One of the BEST. All caps cause its that good!

Just TRY it. ITS THE EPITOME OF CRAB XIAO LONG BAO taste. and super cheap

I have to admit I have never eaten soup dumplings anywhere else in the world so I have no basis of comparison.  I've been to all the Chinese hot spots in North America and maybe I was not paying attention at those times, but I've never had the shanghai soup dumplings until I went to Joe's a few years ago.  However, I have eaten many dumplings and Joe's version is so much better than what I'm usually accustomed to.  

Regardless of my lack of basis of comparison, these dumplings are very good.  Are they the best in NY or in the US?  I don't know but if someone is going to say they've had better, they better identify that establishment who makes the same dumplings. Trust me, I will try to seek out those establishments to see if you're right or just full of it.

I believe some of the bad reviews are from people who order other items beside the dumplings.  If a place is known for their soup dumplings, it's usually not fair to order the fish in soy sauce and then complain the entire place sucks, which is what some of the reviewers have done. 

What is clear is that it is almost undisputed by most of the reviews that the dumplings are unique and exceptional.  Some haters call this place a tourist trap.  A tourist trap is when only tourist goes to a place, when they could be going to a better place where the locals visit. As far as I can tell from reading the reviews, there aren't many places, even in NYC, that sells soup dumplings.    The characterization is unfair, especially in light of us going to eat at this place with some NY locals, recently, who have lived and worked in Chinatown for over 15 years.  They all agreed the soup dumplings are fantastic and an "attraction" to the NY area and they routinely bring their guests to this restaurant.

If you want to order something else at Joe's, the braised pork shoulder is exceptional, if you don't mind the fat.  Yes, it's greasy and fattening but it's also damn good. .  

It's ironic how some of the reviewers complain about the greasiness of the food but don't do the same when they eat bacon.  When you eat pork, there is a high percentage that your meal will be greasy.  The dumplings are pork and the braised pork shoulder is pork.  You're not eating chicken breast. Get a clue and don't waste our time posting your complaint that the food is greasy.

First time to Joe's, always known they are famous with their soup dumpling. 2 minutes we sat down, waiter came to ask if we want to order the soup dumpling? we picked the crab pork to start. We should've ordered the pork soup dumpling, because it will come faster, we waited the crab pork one for over 15 minutes.

Their soup dumpling is verrry good, not only it is tasty and flavorful, its big and have more soup. The dumpling wrapper doesnt break easily like other (3++, i hate to lose the soup). we also ordered 2 other dishes. Its good, it is not salty at all. The noodle we order is spicy enough, the heat is just right. The hot sauce on the table, have no other flavour only heat but surprisely it is a good match with the soup dumpling.

Everyone comes here for the dumplings, but I was impressed by their other dishes. That's not to say the xialongbao (aka "soup dumplings") weren't fantastic (they were), but I was really blown away by everything on the table.

Surprisingly, the pea shoots were the highlight of the evening. Juicy, savory, enormous portions. A standout. The scallion pancake was also scrumptious, especially with the dipping sauces. The sweet and sour jumbo shrimp's were plump perfection. And the crab soup dumplings were heaven. A+ meal. Would come here again in a heartbeat.

The wait times weren't bad, although it was PACKED on a Wednesday night. I can't imagine what it looks like on a Friday or Saturday evening. Not sure if they take reservations, but they have ample room and large tables for groups.

Definitely show up with a thick wallet, because this place is CASH ONLY. Not to fear, there is a Bank of America around the corner.

So far my favorite Chinese restaurant in NY. Impressive.

Why Come Here? Sample Northern Chinese Cuisine, Great Soup Dumplings, Cheap Eats

Joe's Shanghai is the epitome of what one envisions in a New York Chinatown restaurant. Hectic, cash-only service. Pots of tea on communal tables. A large menu containing numerous dishes you've never heard of. It's almost too perfect in these regards, which actually ends up giving it an aura of in-authenticity. But that's okay. It provides great Shanghainese (and other types as well) food in a setting that's far more approachable to many New Yorkers than the divier places nearby or out in Flushing. Here's what we ate:

Crab & Pork Steamed Buns - Joe's is known for these and with good reason. The broth inside is out of this world good.

String Bean Szechuan Style - Lightly fried green beans with a little bit of spice. They're a nice veggie option, but not terribly exciting.

Beef with Broccoli - Thin pieces of beef, crispy on the outside and tender within covered in a tangy orange glaze. Addictive stuff.

Shanghai Fried Flat Noodle - Tasty noodles with a good helping of pork and veggies.

Ordered crab and pork soup dumplings, vegetable dumplings, scallion pancakes, and spicy calamari. I have to say that Is agree with the reviewers the crab and pork dumplings were my favorite- flavorful and done very well. I haven't had vegetable dumplings like this but I liked it. The calamari was fresh and crisp. I was a bit disappointed with the scallion pancakes though. It just didn't rack up with other places I have had scallion pancakes. Not as crisp, not as flavorful, and not as chewy.

Definitely one of my favorite places to eat when I'm in New York. Food is great. It's worth the wait and yes, you might be waiting. You might sit next to some complete strangers depending on how many people are in your group, but despite that...it's still worth it. 

Order the soup dumplings and the scallion pancakes...very good! I wish I could remember everything I've ordered from here, but I don't. I just remember it all being very good. 

Honestly, it's been over 2 years since I last went here and I still remember being really satisfied after eating here. My mouth waters even remembering this place. Even my cousin who doesn't even like Chinese food really liked the food. Everyone that comes with me to eat here also loves it. 

I would give this place 5 stars but they need to make this place bigger to meet the long wait and demand. If you're in Chinatown...check it out.

With over 3K reviews, I'm pretty sure they don't need my 5stars but this place is my favorite place in the city. Anytime I have visitors, I bring them here for soup dumplings. We've tried other things like: pan friend noodles, bakchoy, general tsos, scallion pancakes, lo mein, fried rice, and many other dishes. I've been extremely happy with everything I've eaten there. LOVE me some Joe's!
Pork Soup Dumplings. They were so uh-maze-balls. And the pork jalapeno dish along with their regular dumplings were also superb. Ugh I'm getting hungry now. Just try those, you wont be disappointed.

THE best soup dumplings EVER. I moved from NYC 3 years and every time I go back I have to stop by Joe's Shanghai and get (2) orders of the soup dumplings - one of the Crab Meat and one of the Pork - and the Pan Fried Crispy Noodles with veggies. Always consistent, always delicious. The soup dumpling's broth is perfection, packed with all the flavors you want. It never disappoints. A must if you're in NYC!!!
Okay, I love this place so much.  They have the best Juicy dumplings and Sesame chicken.  The other place that is just as good would be New Green Bo.  They are both amazing.

I love coming to Joe's Shanghai (try to come earlier so you won't have to wait as long).

The soup dumplings are fantastic and cheap for the amount you can get per order, which is one of the best things about Joe's. They aren't on the menu that they give you when you sit down, but the waiter typically asks you if you want them. 

The pan fried noodles and sweet and sour pork are both very tasty and authentic. The pork was especially tender. 

Only recently did I notice that it seems to be a trend in popular restaurants in Chinatown to sit you at a large table with strangers if your own party is small. Sometimes it can be awkward, but usually people don't mind.

The pork soup dumplings were SO good! We also got the crabmeat dumplings and Shanghai noodle soup. I really liked the Shanghai noodle soup when the chili oil was added, but it was kind of bland. I would rather get another pork dumplings instead of crabmeat dumplings.

This classic soup dumpling spot will always have a special place in my heart. Everything here is amazing. From the pork and crab meat soup dumplings to the chicken pan friend noodles. 

Make sure to bring your cash!

Came here hoping to get lunch but the wait was extremely long. We opted to get takeout and eat it outside instead. It took us 10 minutes to take our order because service is nonexistent at good Chinese mom and pop places. We ordered takeout and it took 30 minutes to get our XLB.

Crab meat and pork XLB - very flavorful. You can taste the crab in this. The skin is super thin and explodes with soup once you bite into it.

Pork XLB - very flavorful. A solid pork xiao long bao.

Their soup dumplings were fabulous - there was a bit of a wait but definitely well worth it!  Btw - I couldn't stop taking pictures of the huge goldfish in the front - see pictures.

Service was alright but the food was really good - the soup dumplings, I can't stop talking about how good they were.  The xiao long bao is just really yummy!  Everything was just so good there - even from the string beans to the Chinese broccoli and egg drop soup and the pepper salt porkchops - yum!

Sorry Yank Sing in SF and Sorry Ding Tai Fung but I've converted.  OMG, I am sooo happy to finally give a 5 star to a restaurant!  With limited time in New York and limited room in our stomachs we still managed to come here twice because it was just that darn good!

I travel around the world just to eat siu long bao (soup dumplings), been to the original Ding Tai Fung in Taiwan, tried 20+ siu long bao places in Shanghai, had it in SF, had it in Hong Kong, had it in LA and Joe's basically killed all competition.  I think I went into a trance when I had my first bite, the soup and flavors bursts inside my mouth tantalizing all my taste buds.  The meat consistency was perfect, not too fatty not too dense. The ones at Ding Tai Fung almost taste like powder compared to this yet this is also fluffy enough of a meat filling that it's not tough.  The soup is not too fatty, after eating 3 trays of it (24 dumplings - yes I eat a LOT) I wasn't greased out like I was at Yank Sing in SF.  The Crab dumping is the best, actually tastes like the crab roe unlike some places where the crab and pork ones basically taste the same.  The skin is perfectly thin like Ding Tai Fung and doesn't fall apart easily so holds the soup very well.  Finally the soup flavor is just insanely tasty - It's just Siu long bao perfection!

Heard all about this place for the longest time, and i finally got to try this myself. It definitely lives up to the hype, not like any other shao long bow I've tried. Filled with so much flavorful broth, the meat itself was so tender and delicious. It's definitely a little gem and somethjng you must try when visiting NY.
Our nephew lives in NY and recommended this place it was sooo good! From their famous pork dumplings and their sesame chicken and their rice it's all great! I would highly recommend it!

Yummy soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai. We ordered two regular pork and two crab soup dumplings. All were perfectly cooked and so tasty. The place was packed you should always be prepared to sit with strangers. The service was spotty but it didn't matter everything you need is brought to you as soon as you sit. This restaurant only accepts cash so be prepared to bring some.

Arrived at 1:30pm on a Saturday, got seated for 5 people by 2pm. Places was crowded but we were well taken care of, the complimentary tea was nice! Had to order the soup dumplings and they did not disappoint. Ordered the fried rice and sesame beef as well but had to change them to to-go orders because the dumplings were so filling! Definitely a place to check out if you have the chance.

the only positive thing i have to say about this place, is the same thing everyone else says.... HOLY SOUP DUMPLINGS.

oh also, there pan fried noodles with chicken. excellent. 

service sucks, but lets be real; this isn't jean gorges.

first timer in chinatown and had someone recommend this must go to restaurant. fell in love with the hole in the wall vibe. we (party of nine) were seated very quickly and had our food come fast too. the soup dumplings are TO DIE FOR. literally the best thing to get.

Yeeeeeeees had these soup dumplings a year ago and I still salivate when I think about them. The dumplings so juicy that I accidentally sprayed my friends across the table when I bit down on one. Definitely will come back next time I'm back in New York!

This is my second visit. I brought my friend here with me, and he likes it too. i would come back again and again. I've had better soup dumplings before but Joe's does not disappoint. Scallion pancakes are a must too.

Got off the plane, checked into the hotel and ran down here.  This is my second time here and we wanted to kick off our NYC eating extravaganza with a bang.  As soon as you sit down they immediately ask you if you want XLB because that is what every one is here for.  Don't worry they come back for the rest of your order later.  Other dishes are good, but I could eat my body weight in XLB.  Cash only at this location.

I LOVE their pork soup dumplings. A must experience for all the friends who come to visit me in the city. Also try the Sesame Chicken and the scallion pancake. Service is only OK but the food is worth it.

i swear i come here at least once a month. i have my birthday here every year (is that sad??) 
this location is now my favorite joe's shanghai location, followed by the flushing location.

my favorites on the menu
- scallion pancakes
- pork soup dumplings
- stir fried string beans
- eggplant w garlic sauce
- shanghai styled noodles with beef
- stir fried rice cakes with chicken
- chicken fried rice 

if u want to get a lil turnt, they sell bottles of chinese beer here too. 
cash only, service charge is 15% and included in the bill (some people tip extra not knowing its already included). 
avoid this place on weekends from 6-9pm, wait can be up to an hour and a half. 

some will argue that this place is a tourist trap - i mean, it is, but food is awesome. i'd eat here every night if i were on some sort of strange high carb diet.

I wasn't very big on Shanghai food, but then this place was pretty delicious. My first time coming here was with my parents and grandmother. My mom had been recommended this place by someone at her work place. The place is pretty crowded because a lot of tourists and people around has heard about their delicious soup buns. It was pretty yummy, but there really is always a handful amount of people here.
Another time I had went with a friend. We ordered some noodles. My friend enjoyed her dish, but I must say that my dish of noodles was another story... Not the best, but otherwise, their regular Shanghai stuff is good!

Best. Xialongbao. Ever. 

Yum!!  Their XLB are hot and juicy and delicious!!  I wish they had one in CA!  It beats Din Tai Fung hands down.

We've also ordered their fried rice and string beans, which was good, but the portion is a little small.  I only came here for the soup dumplings.  Yum.

The only weird thing when I first came here was to sit with some random strangers at the same table.  But it's a New York experience, I hear.  :)

It can be touristy and a long long wait.  Go early!  Afterwards, you can have dessert a couple doors down at Chinatown ice cream factory.

One of my favorite places for soup dumplings in NYC! There is almost always a wait and it's cash only but it is worth it. You can get a lot of food for a small amount of cash. The regular dumplings, fried rice and scallion pancakes can't be missed!
Great food and service! We had amazing soup dumplings, crispy beef and kung pau chicken. Ambiance was clean but no frills. You are there to eat!
Best soup dumpling ( Shao Long Poo)  shop in the NYC. Don't expect other food here as others are not that good comparing soup dumpling. But I came back this restaurant many times and I will.

Came here by myself (party of 1 is always slightly embarrassing, but I'm not ashamed) on Saturday night at 7:30 and there was a line out the door. I waited about 30 minutes and then was seated at a table with 10 other people. I ordered one order of the crab soup dumplings and one of the pork soup dumplings. They come in eights. Yes, I sat down, I ate 16 soup dumplings myself, paid (cash only) and left.

I liked the crab ones better than the pork ones. The pork ones tasted like a lot of other pork dumplings. And after my 16, my mouth felt kind of dry (even after downing two cups of water and two cups of tea). But for as hectic as it was in there, service was pretty attentive and quick.

Note: The crab dumplings were $8-something and pork were $6-something, and they automatically tack on a 15% service charge (yes even for a party of 1), so after tax it came out to about $18 total.

The dumplings themselves are pretty good.. and I crave them occasionally, but I'd give Joe's Shanghai 5 STAR for the experience. I'd like to say a group of us are regulars here, we've visited both locations (Flushing and Manhattan Chinatown) and we can't really complain about the food; for Chinese food, it's not too greasy or oily - doesn't leave you feeling super guilty after the meal. 

The dumplings themselves are always excellent; I prefer the pork over the crab ones, the crab ones are a little too "fishy" for me. I think the experience of eating these soup dumplings itself is what I always rave about. Most people when they think about soup and dumplings, traditionally,  they think about the dumplings being submerged into a bowl of broth like in most Asian cuisines, however you're in for a surprise if you haven't tried these before at Joe's Shanghai. You have to find out and experience them yourself. Don't forget to put enough of the vinegar/soy sauce concoction!

delicious! great quality, fast service and affordable meal prices.

after a long tiring day of walking on canal street and listening to the same phrase "you want omega, rolex, i have here" a billion times, joes shanghai is a great place to sit down and enjoy and good quality meal. I highly recommend this place for a great chinese dish and dumplings. I must say the dumplings are amazing!

only downfall is, it is a new york style eatery, in sense that they want you in and out. its good for new yorkers, however me, i like to sit and take my time, not have my check on the table before I havent even finished my meal.

The soup dumplings are delicious! I have yet to find better soup dumplings ever! I have been to this location more than once. I also tried the scallion pancakes which were very good as well as a special entr√©e with prawns. Make sure to bring cash! Also, if you can't find street parking, the parking garages nearby are very expensive so make sure you are on foot when visiting.

Certainly the best soup dumplings you'll find in NYC. Ding Tai Fung and you know, places in actual Shanghai might be better but this place is pretty classic. Came here on a Sun night with 7 old friends - mostly Caucasians, mind you - and they loved it. The wait wasn't too bad once we were all present (maybe 15 min?) and because we were a good-sized group, we got a table against the wall to ourselves (yes folk, you should except to share tables if you have less than 4 in your party - true Chinatown experience).

We ordered 4 palates of the soup dumplings (3 pork, 1 crabmeat - I think it was a general consensus that we all liked the pork better), cold sesame noodles, scallion pancakes, Shanghai noodles, "kong xin zai" (green "hollow" Chinese veggie), eel with yellow chives (in a brown sauce), and Peking chicken. The soup dumplings and noodle dishes were excellent, but the scallion pancakes were too greasy (my white friends liked it but I've had better) and I found a couple of weird bones in the eel, which was also a little salty to eat by itself (perfect with rice). The total bill came out to be $106 including gratuity - $15/person, with drinks. The restaurant was loud, animated, and a little crazy like a good Chinese restaurant should be, but it was all background noise and didn't interfere with our conversation. The servers were also pretty accommodating with large groups (and adding seats halfway) and helpful with menu choices.
Absolutely Delicious !! Our 9 year son loved it! He wanted to try some good old authentic dumplings and after doing some research this had the greatest reviews so we decided to check it out.

Was it worth the 20 minute wait? HELL YES. 

As a visitor from San Francisco, known for its Chinese food, I was pleased to find this jewel. Awesome assortment of Shanghai-nese dumplings, thick noodles, and garlic veggies. Joe's Shanghai is perfect for cold or warm weather. What a unique and special place to eat!

I've had soup dumplings in Shanghai and these are just as good! 

When we first came here, I was a bit deterred by a few things. First, THIS is the location to go to (as opposed to the midtown one) but it's located in Chinatown and the street is a bit deserted. You will, however, see a crowd of people clutching tickets and looking hopefully toward the door. Who are they looking for? The person in charge of the waiting list, of course! She yells your number out, tells you to wait by the door, ensures that your party is all here, and then finally tells you to wait in side. SECOND, unless you have a big party and get really lucky, you will probably share a table with another group. Get over it. The couple that was finishing up their meal across from us were really nice, but the second group of people...not so much. 

Order the crab and pork dumplings when you get there, and maybe scallion pancakes as an appetizer. I haven't had the other food..why would I waste precious stomach space on something other than dumplings? I've heard the pork-only dumplings are really good as well. 

When they bring out the dumplings steamed on cabbage leaves, get ready. Use the tongs to gingerly pick up the top of the dumpling (be careful not to break the exterior or the soup spills out!) and admire how the bottom of the dumpling droops a bit, JUST LIKE IT SHOULD. Place it on your soup spoon, pour some of the black vinegar/ginger/soy sauce on top, and bite a small hole into the skin of the dumpling. The rich and delicious broth will stream out onto your spoon so carefully drink this and then enjoy the rest of the dumpling. Heaven in my mouth. 

Cash only, and I think gratuity is included (but we added another tip anyway).
6600 reviews can't be wrong. What an awesome experience and delicious dinner! Highly recommend anytime you're in the Chinatown area. Just remember... Cash only!

Awesome food! We've loved everything we've eaten here. However, be prepared for crowds and long waits. 

Hopefully someday they'll expand!

Also, remember to bring cash.

This place is always extremely crowded, but the wait is well worth it. Best spot in Chinatown! The soup dumplings are to die for. I have been coming here for over 10 years and will continue to come back. Only place I go when I am in the area. My family and I always bring out of towners here to give them the real Chinatown experience. They do seat strangers at the same table, so if you do have a small party you should expect that.

This place always has a wait and there is no wonder why... these are the absolute best pork dumplings I have ever tasted. The way the broth melts in your mouth and the way there just jam packed with flavor is incredible. Try to come on a weekday to beat the lines

Yes yes yes yes the answer is yes. You cannot visit NY without trying Joe's Shanghai! Or if you live here go more often. The Xiao long bao is bigger than most its certainly not bite sized. Dough was also a little thicker but I liked that since there's more soup in this dumpling than most. 

When we came there was a line out the door with a 40+ min wait. We just took them to go and ate it standing up on the street. Not the best in terms of experience, but better than waiting. You can't pass these up! Ugh craving them now as I write this.

One of my go-to spots for ordering in Chinese food. Can't go wrong with their fried rice & moo shoo dishes! Also their scallion pancakes are delicious too. However, I've found their dumplings and spring rolls a little inconsistent (occasionally overly greasy / lacking flavor, most time pretty good tho).

Overall rating: THE BEST XIU LONG BAO IN NYC. 

Food: This is perhaps my favorite restaurant in Manhattan's Chinatown. I first came here when I was 12 and the xiu long bao (soup dumplings) were amazing. Even today, they are equally amazing. The "skin" is not too thick or thin. They don't stick to your teeth and they're a little chewy. The meat is very bitey (which is a great thing because it's not loose and mushy)and juicy. The crab meat ones have a good seafood taste and the normal pork ones have a great meaty taste-- not smelly. The soup was a nice consistency and rich with flavors that complimented the meat. We also had the fried dumplings, which were also delicious! It's a little greasy, as expected, because it's fried, but it's so good. so good. if you like dumplings, you'll like it. The skin is one of the most important parts and it's similar to the ones used in the xiu long bao, meaning it's good. Also, if you come here, you should save most of the room in your stomach for the xiu long bao. If you wanted an actual Chinese dinner, the food is about the same as the next top rated Chinese restaurant, probably with a shorter wait. 

Cost: My boyfriend and I ordered one crab meat xiu long bao, one pork, and one fried dumplings. The total was about $30 with tip and everything. 

Atmosphere/Appearance: The place was small and there are as many tables that can fit as possible. They are mainly large tables, so smaller parties will probably end up sharing a table. If that makes you uncomfortable, it's ok it's part of the experience. I actually liked the hustle and bustle and how cozy it was. 

Service: There are usually many employees working. Again, being in Chinatown, it definitely helps if you spoke Cantonese or Mandarin. If you don't know how to speak these languages, you can always learn a few phrases and give yourself a pat on the back. It'll be well worth it for the food alone. The servers were also very quick to ask if we wanted to place an order for xiu long bao so they can get started right away, which was absolutely brilliant.

Only came here to try the xiao long bao and it was certainly quite the experience! The gf and I came before the lunch rush and was able to get seated at a shared table (two gentlemen sat across from us). We were not too hungry and only wanted to share an entree and decided to go with the XLB as it is highly rated on yelp. We also received complimentary tea and about 10 minutes after ordering received our freshly steamed XLB. The skin is not as thin as Din Tai Fung but it certainly helped hold all the dumpling juice inside. There was so much soup that the XLB would droop down from the weight! The meat was tasty enough as well and for about $10 I definitely felt it was worth the price. 

Overall, the service was quick and I was fortunate that the staff didn't give me a hard time for only sharing one entree or requiring a minimum per person. Highly recommend visiting this restaurant and would definitely consider ordering more if I had a larger group!

Very good soup dumplings! I initially walked by and didn't have cash on me (restaurant is cash only for dine in) but I was able to place an order through yelp and pay with a credit card. It's right next to the Manhattan bridge so it was a nice view to eat outside anyway.

Came here about 12 on a Saturday and there was a 20 min wait for 2 people. I had read ahead about the place so was satisfied and happy. 

Things you should know:
There will be a wait
You will be sat at a table with others
Service is fast and somewhat rushed to get everyone in 
15% gratuity already added to bill
the pork soup dumplings are awesome and you need to order them as soon as you sit
You get hot tea with your order

I also liked the scallion pancakes however not the best I've ever had they were quite good. Shanghai noodles were also very good but oily in a good taste way but bad for your stomach later ! These things are reasonable priced. Not sure why chicken dishes are so pricey here but we didn't get them. 

For the soup dumplings. I thought there was a decent amount of pork and that delicious broth. The crab ones I heard are a bit fishy so I stayed away.  

We had  an extra item on our bill that we had to ask them to remove so check your bill !

Typical yummy soup dumplings. Always crowded. Most of the time you need to wait. Food will be worth it though. However, there are so many other great Shanghainese restaurants around Chinatown that this place is pretty much a tourist trap.

SO HAPPY we got the chance to try this place out. The first time we came to New York, we heard the wait for this place is ridiculous so we avoided it at all costs. This time around, we decided to give it a shot since we were in the area. We lucked out because we were seated in 10 minutes, tops. We were seated at a large round family table. Confused at first, since others were already seated, we realized they sit as many parties as they can at each table. Efficient.

Also to my surprise, Joes isn't a dumpling house. I expected the menu to be a variety of dumplings/dim sum but instead it was a typical Chinese restaurant menu: fried rice, chow mien, beef, etc. What you're looking for and what they're most famous for is an appetizer. Crab meat with pork meat steamed buns.

Now, you would think we knew how to eat the buns correctly since we've had Din Tai Fung back home... But idk if we were just hungry and not thinking straight but we both bit right into it and it was a huge mess!! LOL so my friends, make sure you bite the top off first, let it cool down a bit then add your soy sauce and/or hot sauce into the dumpling and devour!

We also ordered the scallion pancakes which were a HIT! Be sure to try.

CASH ONLY!! Thank goodness there was an ATM nearby or else we would've been washing dishes to pay for our meals.

Soup Dumplings (sometimes also called Juicy Buns) are the specialty here, and they are definitely very good. But don't stop there, because while they're known for their dumplings I was actually more impressed by their Braised Duck and their Shredded Eel with Yellow Scallions. The Soup Dumplings are good, but I think I actually prefer them at Liberty View in Battery Park. As a side note, the last time I went to Joe's Shanghai, I ended up sharing a table with Chad Lowe.
Their soup dumplings aren't bad. Not my go to for soup dumplings but I really like their Pan fried noodles here.

Soup dumplings!!! The only reason why I came. I'm from Atlanta and I have not yet found a place with good soup dumplings. So I was determined to eat some while visiting NYC! First of all, it is a cash only place. So be sure to have that in hand. Second, the place is VERY crowded. Tables are close together and you will most likely being sharing a table with another group if you have a small party. The servers are very impatient. We literally just sat down and the gentleman was already trying to take our order and kept coming back like every 30 second. We wanted to view the menu since it was our first time. My friends and I didn't order much because we just wanted to snack. So we ordered soup dumplings, scallion pancake, and a pork dish. They were all very good!! Literally the best soup dumplings and scallion pancake I ever had! The soup dumpling was nice and hot with great flavors. The scallion pancake was crispy and tasty!
