The pork dish tasted generic, but good. Even though very crowded and busy, I wouldn't mind coming back to eat!

Another group sat at my table with me, so I only got to picture the soup dumpling.

Had so much fun at Joe's Shanghai yesterday and it was definitely some of the best Chinese food I've ever had. The soup dumplings are hard to eat, if you are a novice, but well worth the trouble. We also had the Moo Shoo pork, which I would highly recommend. We went on Sunday at 1 pm and only waited ten minutes for a table. Service was very attentive.

Got the crab and pork dumplings as an appetizer. Got 8 full sized ones. Yummy. Soup inside them with meat. Entrees we ordered were chicken with mushroom & bamboo and schezuan beef. Chicken with mushroom/bamboo was outstanding. Would come here again. Cash only.

Yeah, okay, does Joe's really need another review?

Well I'm going to throw my SORTA ABC (American born Chinese, but not really) 2 cents in here:

1. Food here is not that spectacular, it's just good to me.  But duuuude it's cheap, tasty, service is fast (even if you wait some pretty minutes for a table), and the quality is consistent.  (I've been here quite a few times thanks to an obsessed fwend.)

It has a good, no fuss no muss atmosphere because it's teeming with people and hot steam from those lovely little soup dumplings, and nobody's going to look at you when you bit into a scalding dumpling and act a fool.  Speaking of which....

2. The soup dumpling is the draw of this place.  Hence, haven't tried much else.  Don't think anything else could be that spectacular.  Very common Asian fare.

Was that 2 cents....times a hundred bazillion? Show me the money!
Excellent soup dumplings -- love how they explode in my mouth. My boyfriend recommends the vegetarian duck, a small yet really tasty appetizer.

Excellent Shanghainese food. The soup dumplings, of course, are famous. The lion's head meatball was AMAZING and savory and the pork with bean curd skin was great as well. 

This place can get crowded, especially on weekends and holidays. Try coming on a weekday at 11 or 11:30 to avoid crowds.

To be completely frank, I've had better soup dumplings and scallion pancakes (in China), but that's not exactly a fair comparison and this side of the big pond, Joe's Shanghai is pretty much as good as it gets. The waiting gets a little annoying though if you're a regular, simply because there aren't many peers in town.

Best soup dumplings in NY.  The staff is a little rude, but that's expected in Chinatown.  A bit heavy handed on the MSG.  The automatically add 15% tip to the bill.  I'm just rating them based on the pork and crab dumplings.

The best XIAO LONG LAO (soup dumplings) I've ever had, exceptionally flavorful and filling! 

I wish I had the chance to try other dishes on the menu,  but was too full from our multiple orders of the soup dumplings

ok the soup-filled pork dumplings - i don't know how they do it (actually i do - they freeze the broth then wrap them in the dumpling wrapper and when it steams - the broth thaws and stays inside the dough - clever indeed!) - but um um good! lol - quite an experience indeed. totally will go back - if i can ever find it again!

It's taken 9 months but I've finally managed to patronize each of the restaurants in the Joe's Shanghai trifecta.  Be prepared for a wait of at least an hour and once seated, expect hurried wait service since seating is limited and they want to maximize turnover.  The stand out dish is of course the xiu long bao. While it's near perfect in construction and flavor, I still prefer the soup dumplings at nearby Shanghai Cafe.  I think the wrapper there is thinner and more delicate.  The meat tastes fattier too which is not a plus for most people but most certainly is for me.  

The other stand out dish for me is the fried mantou roll.  It's $1.25 and comes with five mini fried mantou and condensed milk. for dipping.  They're golden on the outside and the inside is still like a dense roll.  Drizzle sweet condensed milk on it and throw it down the hatch.  I can't think of a better breakfast/dessert item.

Great xiaolongbao and dampling.
If you're tired of having American food,Go there and live your american life.Here absolutely won't regret you.

known for their juicy dumplings. 
it's like din tai fung dumpling house in arcadia (on the west coast) except the dumplings are bigger, doughier and greasier and with more crab flavor.

i like it but it's too greasy so i can't eat a lot of them...

I really enjoyed Joe's Shanghai. We got:

-Crab and pork soup dumplings
-Pork soup dumplings
-Fried rice cake
-Saut√©ed string beans
-Wine Chicken

The food was great, and probably some of the best soup dumplings I've had. Wine chicken was also very spot-on with the wine. Overall, great place to eat in Chinatown, but expect a long wait to get in.

I only came here for soup dumplings, so that is what my rating is based on. 

Seriously, the soup dumplings were SOOO good!! I want to go back there again but I dread the crowdedness of the restaurant and it's extremely distracting environment. But it was totally worth it. To give a little background, I've had many a soup dumplings in Taiwan, which almost makes me snobby about soup dumplings and dumplings in general. But I like to think that I just strive for good quality, satisfying food. I honestly think Joe's Shanghai delivers, and I may change my mind when I go back again, but so far, 5 stars.

This is our absolute Favorite when we go to NYC!!
During our last week in Ny this last thanksgiving holiday, we at here 3 times. I feel sorry for the other Shanghai restaurants in NYC as they will never get us as patrons as we are now lifelong Joe's fans!
Their XLB, the yummiest and bestest! Slurp!!
The crab ones are good too but if i had to choose, the pork ones are bombastic!
Thier steamed dumplings are ono too!
During our last visit we ordered the razor clams and they were so delicious, however we ran out of room from all the dumplings we had so we will have to sample them again next time we're in NY... not that we're complaining :) !
The wait is long yes, but it's worth it for perfection.
Cheap and Delicious! We love you Joes!

This isn't overhyped. Not even a little. 

The Good: Soup dumplings have a ton of flavor. Cheap. And the waits are surprisingly short.

The Bad: You'll probably have to share a table. You'll feel rushed. The side dishes are really mediocre. But who comes here for the sides?

This place is a MUST! Although this review is old because I went about 3-4 years ago I insist you try this place. Again, before my travels I start to research what locations have good tasting food based on reviews and this one had so many. It's literally some where in china town hole in the wall place , but worth it! Worth the wait and everything I came here for some pork soup buns I think called Xiao Bao best purchase in my life I can still remember the taste up until this day! Just amazing every thing was delicious. The ambiance is also interesting we waited for our turn to sit and we got sat with a group of other people that we did not even know in the same table which was interesting to me, but since the volume of people and their set up is big round table and or squared ones they seat you as it becomes available according to how many you have in your party. Anyways hands down would return I just loved it! Better than LA Chinese food.

Joe's Shanghai is always a highly recommended restaurant, and it's pretty good. Their soup dumplings are delicious and really filling, so I'd actually recommend only ordering one or two other items. Their corn and chicken soup is so delicious! My boyfriend and I loved it and kept getting seconds and thirds. Joe's is a really authentic chain, and I highly recommend it if you ever have a craving for good Chinese food. Yes, it's pretty overhyped, but I don't think you'll be disappointed. Prices aren't bad, and service is decent even during busy hours too.

Oh Joe's,

We've been going to Joe's for a very long time so I figured it was about damn time I wrote them a gleaming review. Call me a no-taste having basic plebian but I think Joe's Shanghai has the best tasting Xiao Long Baos (XLBs) anywhere this side of the Andromeda Galaxy. Better than Shanghai Manor, better than Ding Tai Fung (shoutout to the Taiwanese), better than Cheng Huang Miao (shoutout to the Shanghainese), and better than anywhere else you're going to suggest.

Heads up - wait is always 30min+. Might explain why the food always tastes so good. Others may dock it a star or two for the slow rotation but I don't blame em. 

Here's what we ordered:

10 Pork XLBsÔºèÁå™ËÇâÂ∞èÁ¨ºÂåÖ: In a lot of remote places outside of the developed world you don't have all of the superfluous items that the rest of the world has, all you have are your basic necessities - the things that you need. If Joe's were that remote place, and you were that simple farmboy, then Pork soup dumplings would be that basic necessity. If this were all you ordered, then that would be A-ok. Thin skin, nectar of the gods (soup), and fragrant-ass pork. I have seen the face of heaven and it is served in a bamboo basket. 

Pro tip- bite the top off first to avoid work-related injuries.

10 Crab XLBsÔºèËüπÁ≤âÂ∞èÁ¨ºÂåÖ: Every light casts a shadow, and every yang must have a yin. So it is with pork and crab XLBs. Eat a pork then eat a crab, then eat another pork. It's the circle of life. The soup is a little stonger due to the aroma of the crab and almost resembles a light seafood broth/base. The filling leaves a tiny bit to be desired since sometimes the crab meat can be a little loose, but that's probably due to the excess water of the crab meat. 

Scallion Pancakes/Ëë±Ê≤πÈ•º: Another go-to dish whenever we pay a visit to Joe's. Crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. 

Pro tip- use the scallion pancake to mop up the leftover vinegar/soup spillover on your plate for guaranteed high-cholesterol and saturated fats.

Shanghai Thick Noodles/‰∏äÊµ∑ÊäÑÁ≤óÈù¢: A slight variation to the usual take-out restaurant chow mein fanfare. I'm usually not a big fan of ordering this dish since I don't see what's so special and I'd rather save room for the XLBs. Not bad though, it's just a shame that it has to share a roof with dishes that are so much better. Kindof like how Stockton/Malone were great players that unfortunately had to play in the Jordan era. 

Ham and Pork Shank Soup/ËÖåÁ¨ÉÈ≤ú: Growing up, one of my best friend's family was Shanghainese and they used to make this soup all the time. They'd make it so good that my parents would call in advance whenever we'd have dinner together to make sure they were making it; if they weren't, they'd offer to buy the requisite ingredients to make it. Joe's, while not as great as those made by the Li family (names changed to protect those involved), was not bad. The pork was tender and the soup was aromatic or 'xian' enough. The only thing lacking were the bamboo shoots. You could tell that they were from a can bought from HK Supermarket a few blocks down.

The wait might suck but Joe's is definitely worth the wait and the possible communal seating if they're packed. Hopefully you happen to sit across from a billionaire or your potential future wife/husband?

I found Joe's through my fianc√© who used to live in New York. I never really had the urge to ever visit New York, but I took the trip for her. As a side note I absolutely LOVE New York and Joe's due to this fact. She stated that there was a good restaurant in chinatown we should check out. I was not very adventurous at the time, but I thought why not I am on vacation. Good was an understatement my mind literally exploded with enjoyment inside my brain cavity when I tried their famous soup dumplings. When this  pork soup dumpling sat in front of me I was taken back with negative thoughts. It appeared to be a sack of meat wrapped in dough, but starving I put this oddity into my mouth. Immediately wonderful and magical things began to happen. This odd sack of meat immediately triggered explosions in my brain. If I was not in  fear of being arrested I would have jumped on top of this shared table to scream out to everyone how good this amazing pork soup dumpling made me feel inside my whole body. I wanted to raise my fork in the air(due to my inability to use chopsticks I know its shameful) and shout at the top of my lungs, "soooooooooup Dumplings". Instead I turned to my Fianc√© and said quietly, "wow these are amazing", far from my intended reaction. It was probably for the better for everyone around me .

Waited about 45 mins to be seated, but the food was 100% worth it. We ordered the soup dumplings and scallion pancake. I've wanted to try soup dumplings for so long and oh my goodness these were incredible! The flavors, the warmth, everything! Be careful not to burn your tongue when you eat the soup and it can get pretty messy (or maybe I'm not eating it right lol) The pancake is a must-try as well. (They don't except credit cards so make sure to bring cash!)The price was definitely worth and it's easy to see why this restaurant is so popular. I would recommend this place to everyone!

Must go! 
Hole in the wall place with some awesome  Chinese food. Their pork soup dumplings and Shanghai fried rice are worth a try. They usually have a wait so go prepared for it. Their specials include spicy fish which is delicious and melts in your mouth. I am usually a fan of scallion pan cakes and had higher expectations from them but they were average here. 
The service is good quick, easy on your wallet and love the oranges in the end.

Our first time ordering take out here and it exceeded our expectations! 

1. Crab Meat with Pork Meat Soup Dumplings (8)

63. Diced Chicken & Cucumber with Hot Pepper

67. Shrimp & Chicken in Plum Sauce

I couldn't get over how delicious the dumplings were (the crab added so much flavor). I will happily order the shrimp and chicken in plum sauce again, too (shrimp was nice quality). My husband likes spicy and he enjoyed the diced chicken and cucumber with hot pepper. Too bad they don't offer outdoor seating, but for now I will order again on Door Dash (very fast delivery and food arrived piping hot).
The soup dumplings are on par! It's a little expensive, but you won't regret it!

I like Joe's Shanghai but I had better xiao long bao's (like Din Tai Fung in Asia), but for the price, I can't really complain. My boyfriend & I ordered the pork and the combo (shrimp & pork). I like the flavor but one thing I have to complain about is the broth. The broth felt really oily and I also didn't like that the dumpling skins are really thick (okay, that's two complaints!).

We also ordered the Shanghai flat noodles and the Schezuan noodle soup. I liked those so no complaints about those.

Would come again.
Damn good Xiao Long Bao & Scallion Pancake. Pretty efficient service too. Hubby thought the shredded turnip buns were legit.
The best xiao long bao in the city! A trip to NYC won't be complete without a visit to Joe Shanghai.
This place is great. Soup dumplings and beers.

Was here for a quick 2 day weekend in NYC and definitely wanted to try what everyone was hyping about. I think the pork ones are much tastier than the crab ones. The XLB here are huge! They're bigger than the ones at Din Tai Fung. 

We also had the Green Onion Pancake, Shanghai Beef Wok tossed noodles, and a plate of Garlic Sauteed Ong Choy. Yum. 2 crates of XLB. What I like about this place is the price and the generous ginger. 4 people $10 each. And when we wanted extra ginger he brought out a plate of ginger for me and my girlfriend. I was so happy! Worth the wait here even if the hostess is slightly mean.

Tucked away on a bustling side street in NYC Chinatown, Joe's Shanghai was hopping when my husband and I arrived for early dinner.  They have only one table for two, so we first shared a round table with a single customer and two young women who spoke in Chinese.  After they left, two other groups joined the table.  We did not find the setup intrusive and were able to see close up other dishes which looked even better than what we ordered.  For starters, the crab and pork soup dumplings were fantastic.  I was expecting soup, but these eight large dumplings are served in a bamboo steamer over a bed of cooked cabbage.  They need no condiment; however the soy sauce with ginger shavings on the table was a nice addition.  I was eyeing another appetizer and was glad we ordered only the dumplings because they were more than enough for two.  For mains I got the Szechuan fish fillet, which was perfectly spiced and cooked and melted in my mouth.  It was served with bean sprouts (only) so may be best to share, as one person eating fish and sprouts may find it boring after a while.  I would have preferred a colorful veggie or two added.  My husband got the double cooked pork, which was notches above any carryout version we have ordered.  The complimentary hot tea and white rice were also good.  Service was fine and the wait was reasonable.  My suggestion for improvement is to remove the clutter--employees personal belongings in plain sight--and deep clean the entire place.  I had no sanitary concerns.  For esthetics only, as a sprucing up should improve the dining experience.

Ver authentic food with excellent service! The dumplings are a must, perfectly steamed bursting with flavor with the first bite, we also had the pork fried rice and chicken and egg noodle dish, can't remember the exact name. The fried rice was some of the best I've had but the egg noodle dish was just ok, good but kind of bland. The food here is fairly priced and portions are definitely shareable. Will definitely be back on our next visit to New York. Our biggest selling point to eat here was not only good reviews but upon walking through Chinatown it was the only place that was packed.

Believe the hype! 

I've been to the Joe's on W. 56th, but there's no place like the original on Pell. I've never waited outside a restaurant to get in. This night, we waited an hour and a half...in a drizzle...and it was way more than worth it. 

Why? Two words: soup dumplings! 

It's been said by many that Joe's makes the best soup dumplings in the world. And I'm one of those people. If you've never had one, imagine a pork dumpling. Huge. Soft (not the chunky dumplings that you get at your neighborhood Chinese restaurant). Now, when you bite into it a whole dumpling full of soup pours into your mouth (hopefully)! 

So after 2 big baskets of soup dumplings (we had a party of 5), we dug into some General Tso's chicken (awesome), Spicy Pepper Salt Prawns (amazing) Moo Shoo Pork (damn good) and Scallops and Prawns (mmmmmmm). Joe takes these classic Chinese restaurant staples to a whole new level. 

If you want a drink with dinner, they have beer and wine. If you're going for the wine, you have 2 choices: house red and house white. If you want rose, order half red/half white. 

Now, if you're hoping that this is a white tablecloth restaurant, keep hoping. This is a warm, inviting, packed place where you'll probably get to know the people at the tables next to you. You might feel like you're being rushed to eat and get out, but don't fall for that. Just take your time and enjoy some of the best Chinese food you'll ever eat - including the best soup dumplings you'll ever eat! 

The above is my opinion about Joe's. Now, I'll state a fact about Joe's. The night we went, it was cold and drizzling. Dozens of people were waiting in the cold rain to get in. Right across the street was another Chinese restaurant (afterall, this is Chinatown, Jake). Not only wasn't anyone waiting outside that restaurant, no one was in that restaurant. That should tell you all you need to know about Joe's.

Excellent and Terrific portions

Pros: service, greeting, food, portions, lot of food for money, especially in NY, table cloth, nice table, canned drinks

Cons: very busy and be prepared to wait, comfortable in inside
Best soup dumplings in the world. They only take cash, but so very worth it!! Can't wait to come back! The baby bok choy is very yummy too. Love this place. I would give it 10 stars if I could.

I am a dumpling lover and man these pork soup dumplings were huge and JUICY! So much flavor in just one bite and delicious. I could eat a whole order myself. I also ordered the shanghai noodles and they were nice and saucy. These two items are my go to's when I eat at a shanghainese restaurant. Would definitely go back!

So much for keeping kosher Joe's Shanghai definitely lives up to all the hype. I can't think of anything more satisfying than a hot, soupy dumpling on a rainy NYC day. Even with a super packed house, I was seated immediately and served just as quick! If dumplings aren't your thing,  they should be! A must eat in NYC:)

This place is great, best soup dumplings for now. Be careful, they are hot, and you might burn your lips.

Also like the beef lo mein as well.

Eating soup dumplings is as nerve wracking as playing Jenga with your closest friends. It's great company, but if you break a dumpling and let the soup go too early, you will be publicly humiliated.

This was my first foray into soup dumplings and I'm quite pleased. They pack in different textures: the folded doughiness, the soup broth, the pork. 

Be sure to top them with some of the chili sauce and black vinegar.

My party of 3 only had to wait about 10 minutes on a Saturday at 12:45pm before being seated in a communal table (don't worry, we weren't expected to make awkward conversation with strangers. "So aren't these dumplings as good as the spring weather right now, eh?")

The scallion pancakes were nicely layered and served hot, I enjoyed those. 

My friend ordered some flash fried noodles with beef and broccoli that I thought were worth a pass, as they tasted like an above average version of generic takeout Chinese food. 

And now I can say I've tried jellyfish, which has a texture that resembles seaweed salad with less of a complex flavor. Yeah, we ordered jellyfish because why the heck not?

The price for all that food came down to about $14 a person, which is a real bargain in NYC.

Service here is spotty. I usually expect, as a bare minimum, to have a waiter stop by every so often to refill your water. That doesn't happen here, but there are a lot of waiters circling by that you can ask. 

This place is cash only which isn't awful either (if my meal costs $20 at a minimum, like at Katz's, then it's another story...)

I'm not a huge fan of them automatically adding a 15% service charge. I would have tipped that anyways, but when you force someone to pay a specific amount for service without prior notice (no notice like "parties of 8 or more pay 20% service charge" written on the menu), it serves as an excuse to be able to let the service slide.

This place was my food staple when I lived in New York. Shanghai dumplings, Shanghai fried noodles and Onion pancake. It's all i get. Breakfast, lunch and dinner. The walk is a frikin hike through chinatown, but well worth it. I shed a tear thinking about this place. so many memories.  be sure to poke a hole into the top of ur dumpling and fill it wih the red vinegar. HIT!
I don't mind sharing tables with complete strangers, but you are so close, its an honest mistake if you reach over and crab one of their dumplings.  

JOE IS MY BRO.
Da-dumps are amazing! Love this place. Been many times. Highly recommend to everyone visiting New York as it's a staple

Joe's Shanghai was better back in the day (late 90's) before it was "discovered" but I still love it.

Unless there are a lot of people in your party, you get seated at a large table for eight with a bunch of strangers. The only real downside to this communal seating is hoping that the other people don't hear you talking about them or catch you staring at their food while you try to figure out what they ordered and why it looks so much better than what you got.

As I said, Joe's was better back in the day. It was less crowded and I am convinced that the food was better, particularly the steamed pork buns that Joe's is so famous for. Eating here was much more laid back and you never felt like you had to leave quickly to make room for the next hungry group.  Service came with a smile instead of that hint of impatience when you don't know exactly what you want.

On the bright side, the portions haven't gotten any smaller and the prices haven't gotten any higher. I still recommend heading down for a good meal that starts off (of course) with soup dumplings and leaves you feeling satisfied, with a full stomach and barely a scratch on your wallet.

This place is great! I came here as a party of 7 around 5:30 PM on Lunar New Years and beat the rush. As we were leaving, there was a large crowd outside waiting for seats.

We ordered an array of items: pork soup dumplings, crab and pork soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, sesame chicken, shredded pork and dried bean curd with jalapeno, string beans, Shanghai flat noodles, and steamed sea bass‚Äã. I thought everything was solid and everyone was so full for a very reasonable price. My favorite was definitely the soup dumplings since they were very flavorful and full of soup--the soup inside filled up my entire soup spoon! The sesame chicken was freshly fried and was still crispy under all of the sauce. The string beans were nice and charred from the wok.

I would recommend this location as opposed to the Midtown location since there is definitely a price difference and I think this location tastes a bit more authentic as well!

Awesome place if you are craving dumplings. There were a lot of people when I was there. Place is not too big. The staff was kind and attentive. Bit loud there but the food was good. Luckily the dumplings were filled and big, not little filling with too much flour. I dislike dumplings like that. I don't like how the table needs to be shared with others. Wish there were separate tables.

This place was amazing. We stayed at the 50 Bowery hotel right next door and decided to give this place a try on our last night since it was just a minute walk away. 

This place is cash only. There is an ATM right when you enter if you need cash for a fee. We arrived around 5 PM and were seated quickly as it was before their dinner rush, but the restaurant did fill up later on. 

We ordered the pork & shrimp dumplings, young chow fried rice, scallion pancakes and orange chicken. Coming from So Cal, we were used to paying more for less so we were pleasantly surprised on the price and portions. The dumplings were much larger than what we normally see and less expensive. The dumplings are listed under appetizers but for the portions you get, they are essentially a meal. We ordered a few different dishes, but would have been satisfied with just 2 orders of dumplings and the fried rice. 

Overall, the food and service were excellent. The tastes were all spot on for all our dishes. The broth in the dumplings came out hot and fresh. The scallion pancakes had a great crisp on the ends. Our server was very attentive to us despite the language barrier. This place is a must-try if you are ever in the Manhattan Chinatown area.

Best soup dumplings! Everyone I asked about soup dumplings recommended Joe's Shanghai to get my fix and they weren't wrong. 

However, they are SUPER BUSY!! We only wanted soup dumplings so we called ahead to over for carry out and I recommend you do the same if you don't plan on sticking around. 

The dumplings were delicious. The skin was thick enough but also had a good amount of filling and soup, too. I'm sure it would've been even better had we eaten it hot in the restaurant but I thought the ones we had were delicious too.

Really, really good place for weekend brunch: you just can't beat juicy, warm, tasty xiaolongbao for so cheap on a Sunday morning (or rather, early afternoon). Ignore the B rating posted at the front door: I have never felt weird after consuming massive amount of their food, and, unfortunate as it is, you honestly can't find that many Chinese restaurants that are both clean and still authentic (well, maybe I'll give you Cafe China). Just go straight to the soup-filled dumplings; the other dishes here are not really worth your time except as a palate cleanser. Also, try to arrive here at the opening time or slightly after: massive lines begin to form later in the afternoon, and I remember coming here at 3PM with a friend facing a three-hour wait.

Meanwhile, as you wait for your delicious baos to come out, look for that funny Sonia Sotomayor photo where she poses with the waitstaff. One would think Supreme Court judges don't spend their precious time eating $4.95 soup dumplings. Well, think again!

One of the best xiao long bao in the city! 

Generally I'm not too impressed with NYC Chinatown dim sum places since I am from Vancouver. But when I am jonesjng for some good dumplings, I want to come here. 

Beware of the long lines, and the sharing of tables with strangers, if that kind of stuff bothers you.

My Chinese friends Split on if this restaurant is "authentic" or not. All I know is that it is Delicious. I give it 5 stars for the Dumplings alone, they have other good dishes like the Bass and the baby bok choy is good. 

My girlfriend's mother is chinese and has lived in chinatown for decades and she swears by Joe's (yes i know it's not nice to swear!).

It's easily worth the price and the wait and it's right off Bowery so it's not like you'll have to travel too far. One of my favorite places in the city!

This place is insanely popular- even an hour before it was closing, there was still a line outside. Tried both the pork and crab soup dumplings. Both had a ton of soup inside, which was greatly welcomed. Personally, I didn't get a huge crab taste (might be due to the amount of vinegar I use), but the pork filling definitely tasted good, and seemed more worth. We also tried some of the other noodle dishes, not bad but nothing stood out. Will definitely come again for their soup dumplings though!

Love their Soupy Dumplings! Price is good, service is fast. Cash only. The only thing that bugs me is when the second you are done, the waitstaff cleans your table and can't wait for you to get out. They will stare you down. It is a busy place, I get it. 
Can I digest my dumplings please?
While the service left something to be desired, the soup dumplings and the Shanghai noodles were incredible. 5 stars for the food, 3 stars for the service.

Thank goodness they deliver on DoorDash because there's always such a long line whenever I pass by / take the trek down to Chinatown. The delivery service takes a very reasonable amount of time and the food is amazing. I love the soup dumplings here, probably one of the best I have found on the East Coast so far.

Only waited 10-15 min for 2 people on Saturday just before 6pm, though it was packed with long lines. Interior is very pretty. 

Food is 10/10. Ordered soup dumplings and wonton soup, they are listed under appetizers but are actually very large portions and I would consider them entrees in portion size. Soup dumplings are enormous with a TON of soup! None of them were torn either. Szechuan beef was really tasty, it was a huge plate meant for family-style sharing. Beef was tender and full of flavor. We also had a simple fried rice with only scallions and egg, I normally am never impressed by fried rice but this fried rice was not too salty, not bland, very light. Best fried rice I've ever had. I can't pick a favorite menu item as everything we ordered was excellent. They also have an enormous menu (way bigger than online), so I was really impressed they cooked all our dishes to perfection.

Service is 10/10. These waiters are the most efficient waiters I've ever seen and basically knew what you wanted and do it before you could ask. They will bring extra small bowls, large spoons, extra plates as soon as they serve each dish because dishes are family-style and they know you're going to share. They don't waste your time talking your head off, they just take your order, help you choose items if you ask, and just silently and quickly remove old dishes, give you new ones. And they clean up and turn over an old table to serve new guests in like 10 seconds. I know this might be an odd thing to go on about, but I was genuinely so impressed. I've been to a few fancy restaurants before, but Joe's Shanghai waiters knock them all out of the park. 

Tip is included in the bill as an 18% service charge (you don't tip on top of it unless you want to). Cash only like most Chinatown places. I hope come back often!!

Expect to be quick when ordering...which is good because that means the quicker you get to taste the delicious soup dumplings. We ordered the pork dumplings and yes they where the best I have ever had. We also ordered the Kung pao, sesame chicken, spicy prawns and green beans. I enjoyed the sesame chicken the best, so much flavor and tasted great.
Soup dumpling is very good. I have to wait 30min to eat but Its really worth. Best dumpling ever

Delicious and extremely affordable. I come here every time I'm in Manhattan. The dumplings are awesome!!! I've tried many other dishes and they've all been good but I prefer to just have lots of dumplings!!!

Oh, soup dumplings, how I love you. Don't go here if you are into excellent, attentive service. This is not the place for that kind of experience. Servers aren't mean or anything, but its a very efficient ship that's run here. You order what you want, you get it, you enjoy it and you're out. That said, the food is delicious and the soup dumplings are a must-try for those who haven't partaken. A culinary treat for sure.

I'm giving Joe's in Chinatown 4 stars instead of 5 for two reasons. One I have yet to try the one in Queens which I hear is the best of all three and two I've only had their dumplings but, HOLY AWESOME DUMPLINGS! 

Dumplings are one of my favorite foods and Joe's was my first experience with soup dumplings. They were very yummy but the one thing that skeeved me out was, the "soup" inside the dumplings coagulates on the plate and makes you feel kinda gross for eating it. Oh and get the pork soup dumplings. The crab/pork ones aren't as good. Also, the pork fried dumplings are TO DIE for. I Highly recommend them.

P.s. I had some questions as to whether or not you can reheat the soup dumplings after they are cold and the "soup" hardens. Well, you can and it will get soupy again. Just pop them in the microwave for 30-45 secs and you should be good.

Happy Eating!
amazing soup dumplings as everyone knows.  What everyone doesn't know is that other items on the menu are delicious as well.  Baby clams in black bean sauce and the crispy orange beef are my faves.

Good lord, this place is delicious and crowded because you can't get a good "siu lohng bao" (soup dumpling) in Chicago, that's for sure!  I don't care for the crab ones, they taste a little funny, kind of like old egg yolk.  Go for the meat!  I also love the Shanghai noodles, which are thicker and shorter than udon and slightly wavy.  It is mixed with vegetables (cabbage?) and pork.  There's another location in Flushing, Queens, and they are both equally great!

There is community seating with 11 people per round table. I was apprehensive with sharing a table with strangers at first but it was actually a nice environment. Food came super fast and it was delicious
One of the best authentic NYC Chinatown dining experiences you can get. Huge banquet style tables make this a fun place to go with a group of friends. Two words: SOUP DUMPLINGS!!

Truly the soul food of Asian cuisine is XLB's. Between the rich fatty broth inside the bun to the densely flavorful meat and skin, it's impossible not to recognize XLBs in a class of its own.

Joe's Shanghai is no different. The simplicity of the ingredients and the familiarity of consistently low prices makes this establishment one to remember. It was featured in many foodie lists and mainstream travel shows but they still serve humble dishes for the everyday person. The portions are good, the food tasty and unpretentious. The XLBs are steamed in a bamboo pot and served to you in it as well. Be careful not to burn yourself with the broth. It's very easy to get carried away. 

The seating is quite horrendous. If you're not coming in a group of 4 or 5, expect to be communally seated and not in that trendy hipster coffee house kind of way. It's more like in a round table forcing you to stare away at something than to look someone in the eye while you're eating. If that doesn't bother you, go ahead and enjoy the food in the simplest, most practical way.

Delish xiao long Bao in US..
Very good service!!
Order crispy fried duck!!
Thanks to my sister for her recommendation

We came in for a pretty late dinner so the notorious line wasn't as long as usual which was nice! We ordered the pork soup dumpling as well as the pork & crab soup dumpling and they were both extremely tasty!! Soup was very flavorful, but the skin was a little thick. 

We also got the eggplant in szechuan sauce and the string beans sauteed with garlic and pork. Although they were both tasty, I must say that the vegetables were rather soggy and extremely oily. While I would give it a 5 for flavor, it's not the place to get fresh vegetables! 

Finally, we got the twice cooked pork! Again, flavor was good but it was extremely oily and they gave us much more cabbages than actual pork which was kind of a downer. 

Overall very satisfied with the food, it's definitely a place to go in NYC!

Omg. I still have dreams about this place. Their dumplings are literally the best thing I have ever tasted! The community seating is a bit weird, and there was no public restroom (unless we just didn't look hard enough). Despite all of that, this place deserves 5 stars! We recommend it to anyone who tells us they are visiting NYC, and we can't wait to go back ourselves. I might just hop on a 5 hour flight just for this...
It's all about the shao long bao.  Very delicious and well worth it.  It can get pretty crowded in there so go in prepared that you might share a table with someone.

Truly the end of an era. This new location is GORGEOUS and brand spanking new. The decor is simple and not overwhelming however I will forever reminisce about their old location filled with photos of famous visitors to the location as well as the fear of being run over by cars navigating down the one way street as we wait for our number to be called. The food here is luckily the same quality as their old location however the speed of the dishes were so slow. We came during an off lunch hour and the restuarant was not at all busy. However each dish took a significant amount of time to arrive at our table. 

DIshes we love here: crab and pork dumplings, shanghai thick noodles, string beans, shrimp with meat sauce. You can not go wrong with ANY of these.

place is pretty good and decently priced.

besides the dumplings we ordered something on the noodles page called subgum friend noodles.  i wont spoil the surprise but it was actually pretty good.  who knew! lol go for it = ]

one of the things i do dislike tho is the fact that they use the same hand towel to scrub down every table so it leaves that dirty, old, raggedy smell behind on the table top for at least 20 mins.

Stopped in the other day while in Chinatown. We wanted to try some "must have eats" while visiting  New York and Joes Shanghai was on our list and was also recommended by my brother. Mom and I ordered the pork and crab soup dumplings and a side of scallion pancakes. According to our waiter, these two items were the most popular on their menu. Soon as we bit into the dumplings, we were delighted by a nice creamy porky crabby surprise sitting in a slurp size spoonful soup. I don't know any way to describe it other than it was a nice meal for a cold winter day. The scallion pancakes were also a delight as well. It was crispy and came with a side of soy sauce for dipping. This is a very popular restaurant so the lines getting on do get long. Lucky for us, we didn't have to wait at all. The service was excellent and the food was delicious. I'd come back again

Love this place, always bring out of towners. Classic spot for soup dumplings in China town. Other dishes are good as well. Not the cleanest and the service is not the best, but that is part of the experience. Can be a long wait at popular times. Good place for big groups.

Came here per my friend's recommendation while visiting NYC and I'm glad I did! It's cash only by the way but they have an ATM inside so no worries there.

We ordered the scallion pancake, the pork soup dumplings, chicken fried rice, and the garlic eggplant. Everything was delicious, we enjoyed the soup dumplings a lot. The only complaint I would have is that the table was really small so we had to play a game of Tetris to fit all of the dishes/plates on the table.

Two words: Soup Dumplings.

Family style seating and overly anxious servers. We went during non peak hours and the place was busy. Get there early for seats--get there later and you'll surely be waiting in line.

The food is a bit greasy, however, people mainly come here for the soup dumplings--they are a cut above absolutely amazing!

i am giving 5 stars for the best pork steamed dumplings ever !!!! 

check this place out :)

It's not all just hype, the soup dumplings are legit. Had the pork and crab dumplings and they were very tasty, rich flavor... I wanted to order seconds.

Not sure why people are raving over the scallion pancake, I didn't think they were anything special. 

A couple next to us ordered either Seasame or a type of General Tso chicken and it looked so good I wanted to ask to try a piece. Isn't that why there's communal seating? ;)  

The communal seating isn't terrible but it isn't a fancy or clean looking place. It's Chinatown.  But the dumplings are def worth a visit.

Ok, for me the best bang for my buck was here at Joes Shanghai!! I found out this place was ridiculously good through a friend who frequents NYC often and loves to save money. 

If u can find this little hole in the wall Shanghai style Chinese restaurant you may have found the holy Grail of dumpling spots in NYC! First, let me just say they are famous for their dumplings with broth inside, you eat it with a spoon and chopsticks. You top it with some vinegar and soy ginger and you are set!! 

This place was absolutely packed on a Wednesday and we ended up sitting at a table for six with another family of five. We didn't mind sharing a table because they had been here before and they drove 4 hours from D.C just for dumplings!!! 

So we ordered one Crab and one Pork dumpling. They come 8 to an order and it's under $5 bucks!!! We also ordered some shanghai noodles and a scallion pancake which were also out of this world good!!! Our total bill was under 25 bucks and we finished it all!!! 

Not only did the food come out really fast, they even got my gf water when she asked for it and refilled it without asking! For me that was definitely a first in any crowded restaurant!! 

Joes Shanghai don't change a thing! I'm coming back soon, it's only a 5 hour flight and a jump on the 6 train!!!

i went yesterday w my bf and couldn't wait to post this review!! we got there at around 4pm on a very rainy sunday and only had to wait about 5 minutes for a table. this place is always packed with crowds of people rotating out of every table. the service is efficient, quick, and all you have to do is politely flag down one of the many servers whenever you need anything. they're all so nice and attentive and the FOOD?! there are truly no words for how delicious, delectable, authentic, and plentiful the cuisine is. we literally couldn't stop eating. im having the leftovers as i type this and they're somehow just as good. i'm eating slowly to savor it all! the soup dumplings are so rich the broth sticks to your lips and ribs. the crispy beef absolutely fucking blew us away. idk why but we had very low expectations for it, but omg!! i would order two plates of this next time, one to take home untouched lol. the duck was melt in your mouth, and the half serving was more than enough for two people. the scallion pancakes, i could eat everyday for the rest of my life. they heat up so well in the oven and also melt in your mouth. even the fried rice (with eggs and green onions) was so simple but perfect. i can't say enough great things. this place should have 3.5 stars (iykyk), it's that good. make sure you bring cash!!

I'm literally addicted to this place. When I least expect it, I am hit by a strong craving for the hot and flavorful juice of the pork soup dumplings. 

The dumplings are consistently good no matter where or when you go. I have yet to find another dish that I really like here so I pretty much just order the dumplings. 

Cash only at the Chinatown location, cards accepted at the Times Square location.
I never wait longer than 20-30 minutes at the peak hours. The communal seating is fun and you'll meet some people from all over the world.

Visiting NY for the week and these other reviews were on point. Great food and quick service! We sat in a big round table with other guests which was different but ok since there was plenty of space. We will make it a point to come back here if we are ever back in NY. Pork dumplings were on point.
Great soup dumplings. Usually long lines.

Went here per reviews and were nicely surprised. It was a very popular place with great food and fast service. The biggest problem was they only take cash, they do have an ATM out front though. There seems to be a long wait for people but our group of 10 got in quick, we were lucky. If they're busy and you are a small party, they will seat you at a big round table with other small parties.
Their menu is great, they are well known for their soup dumplings which were only eight dollars. Decent prices as well!
As is prevalent in New York, they do not like you to sit around and enjoy, it is an eat and go environment. Also, no free refills on anything but water.
Would definitely recommend, great experience!

I went to This restaurant today with my cousin and i had an amazing experience! We ordered The pork soup dumpings mushu pork and Hong Kong style noodles! Very friendly employees and amazing food! This is a must have place in new York!
A Chinatown classic to be experienced while visiting NYC. The crab dumplings are true to their Shanghai roots. Coupled with an order of veggies and some green tea and your good to go.

Good soup dumpling, expect to wait 30-60mins on weekend.
No reservation system, you'll need to walk-in.

Great restaurant, well priced in Chinatown. Their dumplings are the best in town and everyone is super friendly and take care of you fast. I have been here several times and compared to other competitors that are close by and nothing is as good as them, both service and food!

Two words. SOUP DUMPLINGS. Joe's Shanghai is know for their soup dumplings and they are amazing. Always a great place for food. Always busy so you'll probably have to wait to get in there. FYI the restaurant is cash only! Other than that good food, nice atmosphere, and clean.
Five stars for absolutely delectable mouthwatering soup dumplings! I definitely don't dig the whole table sharing though. It's truly uncomfortable but the food always drags me back here

SLB were very soupy and good.  Scallion pancakes were good as well - they're not my preferred way of having them cooked, but I liked them.  They're crispy on the outside, very greasy, and chewy on the inside.  Not all the slices in the scallion pancake were uniform, so some tasted better than others.  My husband ordered the Kung Pao Chicken and said it tasted fine...just like Pei Wei.  Total bill for 1 order of SLB, Scallion Pancake, Kung Pao Chicken, and Coke - $30 including the 15% automatic tip.

We arrived around 3pm on a Saturday and were told it would be a 20 minute wait for a party of 2. We waited less than 5 minutes and were called to our table. 

We've been wanting to try their famous soup dumplings for years and todays the day we finally did. We ordered their pork soup dumplings. 

I wasn't sure how to eat them at first so I glanced to the table next to us. I saw they used chopsticks to poke at the dumplings and to let the soup drain out into the spoon. So, that's what I did. It was a little messy to eat but I got the hang of it. 

The pork soup dumplings were delicious and were perfect on this 30 degree day.

Remember, it's a cash only restaurant!

Well - I'm from Queens so I usually go-to the restaurant in Flushing.  My fav dishes are obviously the soup dumplings, Joe Shanghai Fried Flat Noodles, Sesame Chicken & the shrimp/prawns with chili sauce ( I ask for the shell off ).  The table situation is for sure different than most restaurants.  They have giant round tables and you can be seated with complete strangers.  A tad awkward if you sit down and they get their food first and you are starving, Its torture!  Don't expect the best service, but expect some delicious eats!

not bad for just general chinese food! they had a pretty large menu from dimsum to more typical restaurant dishes. service was especially good, the waiters brought us extra wraps for the duck since we had more people. 

scallion pancakes (8/10) - hit the spot, crispy but not oily! would recommend for sharing

pork xiao long baos (9/10) - some of the better xlbs i've had in ny! i prefer xlb that doesn't have really thick skin so this was perfect for me.

peking duck (7/10) - pretty standard but portion was kinda small for half a duck. only comes with 4 wraps by default. 

string beans (8/10) - pretty standard but this dish is still a great choice for veggies

stir fry tofu and veggies (9/10) - waiter recommended this as an add-on and it was surprisingly good! the tofu really gets all the flavor and there's a wide assortment of veggies included 

Ê¢ÖËèúÊâ£ËÇâ (pickled vegetable pork belly? not sure the english menu item name) (5/10) - the sauce felt to thick and salty for my taste. and the pork belly slices were also really thick and a bit too fatty. wasn't terrible but would pass since there's better items!
Good dumplings and food. The wait time wasn't so bad for a weekday around 7.

Of all the food I've tried in New York, this place has got to be my favorite !!!

My friends and I were lucky when we came here because there was no wait! This place kind of smells funky though. I think it's the vinegar they put on every table. 

Of course we had to get the soup dumplings ! We ordered 2 orders of the crab and pork mix dumplings, crispy beef, and shanghai noodles.

I felt like I was in heaven when I tasted the soup dumpling for the first time. It was so good!!!!!!! The hot tasty soup burst in your mouth when you first bite into the dumpling. Oh man.... Salivating at the moment. The filling was so tasty and you can really taste the crab. I tried it with the vinegar but it was too overpowering. I just want to taste the goodness of the dumpling! Add some sate chili for a bit of kick. 

The crispy beef was well... Crispy. It was tasty. A lot of batter though, and it kind of tastes like orange chicken. Eat it with some steamed rice and you're set!

The shanghai noodles was good and flavorful as well. Nothing too special about it though. 

If I ever get to come back here... I would order like 3 trays of soup dumplings for myself!!!!!

People say it's touristy..... well then f*ck it i'm a tourist baby! 

Soup dumplings: oh ya 
Green beans with pork: yes
Crispy orange beef: Don't like from anywhere EXCEPT Joe's

My group of 4 got lucky as we got seated right away when we came for lunch around noon. We were seated in one of the larger tables and shared with a family of 4. The table was big enough so it wasn't so awkward. The place was already so busy with diners. Service was REALLY fast, non-stop and quick. Our server wasn't the nicest. Seemed like he wanted us out faster than in. The table comes with hot tea to self serve. We ordered their famous and popular soup dumplings and scallions as starters. I didn't eat any of the soup dumplings because they don't offer a vegetarian or just seafood options (*SIGH*) but everyone seemed to have loved it. The scallions were very yummy and I was tempted to order another round but saved my hunger for the main dishes to share. I went with the Stewed Mixed Vegetables and Bean Curd with Crab Sauce. Both very tasty and plenty to share with 4. A ton of options for all types. Don't miss out on this hidden place if you're running around Chinatown.

I think I probably waited 40 minutes to get a seat here but it was well worth the wait. I was in a party of 2 so we ended up getting seated at one of the large round shared tables. The restaurant is small and very crowded and you may need to sit with others so just keep that in mind. The food blew me away! I think it's the best XLB I've ever had. The dumpling skin is so thin that the soup looks like it's going to break through the skin when you pick it up (I hate it when the skin is really thick and doughey). We tried both the pork and crab/pork dumplings. Both were very very good. The only caveat to this place is the long wait - otherwise I'd be here every time I visited NYC.

This place has some of the best Chinese food in Chinatown in my opinion. My friend and I came here on a Tuesday night, which is the best time to go for that it's pretty empty. We got a table to ourselves which was a plus because it came to my attention that people do have to share their table with strangers sometimes depending on where you sit. 

We ordered the scallion pancakes (which are to die for) the infamous soupy dumplings, which I freaking loved, general tso chicken that was okay, rice, and the braised pork shoulder. The pork shoulder was pretty good, but also pretty expensive. I definitely plan on returning to this place, but only during the week so I don't have to end up standing on a line for god knows how long.

Joe's Shanghai gives the new meaning to the term "awesome goodness".  

In Joe's world, awesome goodness comes in the form of a bamboo steamer with eight crab and pork xiao long bao, or mini steamed dumplings filled with minced meat and just the right amount of broth.  

The space was cramped enough to make any self-respecting fire safety inspector weep with frustration: large lazy-susaned round tables near the back of the room, which serve as communal tables where patrons - locals and guidebook-holding tourists alike - dine; high waiter-to-patrons ratio; a ton of hungry patrons loitering outside hopeful that the wait for an empty space wouldn't be that long (and it wasn't, as said waiters were not shy at making sure people get in, get served, and get out in the shortest time possible).  

If you ever visit NYC, Joe's Shanghai is a definite must-see.  And with total bil coming up to $29.60, our group of six well-fed, pleasantly plump individuals still had enough to spend at nearby Soho.

These soup dumplings will haunt you long after you have left those smelly, too-small, overcrowded streets of chinatown. Can't really speak to the other food, but if it was actually dog food aside these golden lilttle dumplings of heaven, it would still warrant a 5 star. Yeahyeahyeah- soup inside is hot and takes a college level course of its own to learn how to eat them, but isn't that part of the appeal?

Go to spot for soup dumplings! The food is really good and service isnt the worse for how busy it gets! 
They also have some bomb af shanghai noodles and rice cakes if you arent feeling soup dumplings tho
Love the soup dumplings.  Other dishes are good too, but it is the dumplings that the restaurant is known for.

I love XLB anyway.  But, I brought my mom here.  She liked it.  when ya momma likes it, ya gotta love it!  =)

my memory is fuzzy, but don't you have to share seats with people?  If so, how very "authentic."

PORK & CRAB SOUP DUMPLINGS!!!! 
If you go to Joe's Shanghai and don't try their soup dumplings, then you're doing something wrong! (some ppl at our table ALMOST missed out until the Chinese couple told them they MUST get the soup dumplings)

Once you get seated, you're most likely gonna be sitting with 2 or 3 other groups of people (each table fits about 10 ppl). The dumplings come out in nice little wooden steam pots. When you're picking up your dumplings, be super careful so the soup doesn't spill out. Don't think you're all good to go only because you have your dumpling on your spoon! Even more carefully, bite the top of the dumpling and drink the soup inside first. If you just shove it in your mouth, you will end up with the soup all over your plate/hands/table. 

There's going to be a wait, but pretty worth it :) It's really crowded inside & you may not feel totally comfortable sitting with strangers, but that's part of the whole experience, so enjoy it~  

CASH ONLY!!

Soup dumplings! Omg, had to be one of the best soup dumplings I had, it was so tasty and delicious. Very affordable and service was really fast. The restaurant is pretty small, and it's pretty busy here so don't be surprised if there's a wait. The only thing I wasn't a fan of, was that we had to share a table, which would've been fine if they had asked us first, but basically were just seated and told that we had to share our table with two strangers.

If ever in the area, these dumplings are definitely a must.

The dumplings here were so so so juicy and delicious. The dumplin skin was also not too thick. We got there at around 10:00 pm, which was perfect because there was no line, and we were seated immediately. The waiters were very fast and our food came within 10 minutes. You'll probably be placed at a big table that is shared with a few other parties, but everyone minds their own business so it's not really an issue. It's very packed and busy though, so probably not the best place to go for a date.

This is by far my favorite Shanghai place to go to. Always a line, always loud, always a rush, but ALWAYS DELICIOUS!

of course i recommend the steamed dumplings. DEF crab if you eat seafood, but pork is good too. not to sound annoying but they're scalding so find a way to eat them without burning yourself, spilling all the soup and looking like an idiot trying to cool the contents with your mouth opening - you'll possibly be sharing a table with strangers.

As for the other dishes, i have no idea of the name bc i order them in chinese, but the scallion pancakes are good, we get a thicker noodle dish with meat and veg, there is also this crispy white noodle that has a saucy topping and makes the noodles soft which is good, i get the simple shanghai fried rice minus the scallions (so just egg and rice) but i use this wonderfully simple dish so that i can soak up excess soup (if i even manage to drop any) so that i don't waste a single drop!

it's a quick in and out atmosphere. many tourists, many regs and they combine tables (heads up to anyone who doesn't know how asian places can roll).

yum! :)

oh my. the soup dumplings truly were out of this world, reflected in the five stars (which i stingily dish out, so it really was GREAT). i'd go back in a heartbeat if it wasn't so far.

*ordered the crab and pork

Excellent food in this tiny little hot spot. Apparently this is the go to spot for soup dumplings for all the celebrities so when I went to visit New York, I had to check it out. 

We ordered some pork soup dumplings and crab soup dumplings, as well as some scallion pancakes and cold fish and cold jellyfish. The soup dumplings were really good but I would recommend that you order multiple orders separately. We ordered two of each kind and when we started on the second batch, the 'soup' on the inside of the dumplings was soaked up in the near already. The scallion pancakes were good but weren't anything special. The cold fish had an extra fishy taste and smell (no thanks!) and the jellyfish was good. 

Overall a good experience but maybe not worth the wait (this place gets packed every night and there's almost always a wait). There are plenty of other places in Chinatown with good soup dumplings!

The soup dumplings are okay but I wouldn't say they're worth the 3 hr wait. I wish they weren't so stingy with the vinegar. Like it's just vinegar!!!!!!! Just give one vinegar a person and do some extra dishes! How do you expect people to share vinegar in this day and age.

Dumplings! They're the draw, but the rest of the menu is solid, too!

It'd been years between visits. They even relocated to the Bowery from Pell St in the intervening time! The experience was still very familiar. About a 20-30 minute wait in the street for a table, followed by excellent pork soup dumplings and less gratifying pork and crab dumplings (skip them and double down on the pork). Their eggplant in garlic sauce was delicious. Scallion pancakes were solid as an app, but nothing to write home about. 

It was a nice visit that lived up to expectations and recollections in all respects, except that the space is brighter, cleaner, and far newer. I do, however, miss the pictures posted in the old space. I'd recommend it!

There is a reason there is a line here 20 minutes before opening. They have the best soup dumplings in the city. Maybe the best anywhere. The new digs on Bowery is a vast improvement over the old place on Pell Street and closer from the subway station. The soup dumplings are a 5. The veggie lo mein was OK but needed more variety of vegetables and no tofu. I don't consider tofu to be a vegetable. It's more like discarded shoe leather. To be fair the noodles were not overdone and had a nice bite to it. Service was good and efficient. I believe Yelp claims that Joe's Shanghai accepts credit cards. Sorry, but it is cash only. There were others in line who realized that and had to find a money machine or eat elsewhere. Sure, we have never had a bad meal in New York 's Chinatown but there's a reason we and others make a beeline to Joe's.
I have been eating here once a week for years. Perhaps not the most beautiful interiors, but the best soup dumplings on the planet.

I've been coming here since I was young as I've always loved the soup dumplings.  The only reason I took off a star is because I went back recently and felt the quality had slipped a little.  I felt the same when I went back a year ago but thought it could have been a fluke.  

Today you can find many great soup dumplings in the city (although this is the original) so I'd suggest branching out (after you've tried Joe's).

Looking at all the reviews on yelp, I thought this place would be pretty popular but we walked into a half full restaurant for lunch on a Friday. Also it's in an alley street just south of Canal street. Surprised that they make you share a larger table with another smaller group. It makes sense when it's busy but there were other empty tables. Anyways ordered the pork and crab soup dumplings right away. Then we decided on the seafood chow mein as our other dish. It was just enough food for three girls without having to take any leftovers home. The dumplings came out quickly. I, of course, couldn't wait to try it so I actually burned my tongue a bit on my first slurp of that soup. I liked the skin was thin and there was plenty of flavorful soup inside. I couldn't really taste the crab so I would maybe just stick with the pork ones next time. I still gotto say my favorite xio long bao is still from Din Tai Fung here in California. The chow mein was a bit oily but I liked the sauce and the thick noodles. And they put a lot of seafood in there - shrimp, scallops, and squid. I felt like they should because it's like $13 for that dish and twice as much if we had just gotten the chicken or beef version. I would totally eat here again for their soup dumplings.

You can get the best soup dumplings!!!!
Other foods are also fantastic, too!
Great taste, very reasonable price,....always full. You have to wait 30-an hour in dinner time, but it worth to wait!

Don't forget to bring cash.

Files of lost pictures that inspired a review from a person with #fatboyproblems. First trip to New York back in 2012 and I've never had or even heard of soup dumplings aka xiao long bao! I was taken to this place to eat and boy oh boy to my surprise I'd found something that I like as much as noodle dishes! I will definitely be back here agian when I'm I'm new york!

I was on a mission to try the best soup dumpling in the country. That's exactly what I did. If you travel deep into China town and down a scary little back alley then you find the soup dumplings you seek. We came right when the place opened to avoid crazy waits and got seated right away. The green onion pancake was delicious. We got two orders of soup dumplings because they were that good. My boyfriend still brings them up although it's been months since our trip. One of the few spots I will go out of my way to visit again next time I am in town.

I always find myself going here whenever I am in Chinatown. I absolutely LOVE this place! I highly recommend getting there early so you don't have to wait too long because it gets packed! It is a very touristy spot, but I don't mind because the soup dumplings are so good!
This place has the best soup dumplings ever....a must try, never had a bad meal here, definitely a recommend to anyone who likes dumplings or Chinese food

This place never disappoints. Everything I've had here over the many years I've been coming has been consistently delicious. The soup dumplings are huge and flavorful. The scallion pancake is flaky and so so good. The real winner though, is the string beans with minced pork. Every bite we took, my friend and I had to discuss how good it was. They're somehow cooked and flavorful but still as crisp as if they were freshly picked. This place is a must!!!

We came at 6:00 PM and had to wait an hour to be seated. The crab and pork soup dumplings are a must get. As you bite into the dumplings a rich soup broth bursts in your mouth. 

We also got the sesame chicken and off the menu broccoli in garlic sauce. Both sauces were very thick and rich so I don't recommend getting both and would suggest to get some sides of rice as a pallet cleanser 

* You don't come here for the nice atmosphere or to have a long drawn out dinner. We were in an out in 35 minutes (yes even after ordering and eating all that food). The servers hover around you and the second you are done with the dish they grab the plate before you can put the serving spoon down. 

Had to knock them to 4 stars because of how uncomfortable the 5 servers standing over your shoulder felt.

I went there my first night in NYC. It was great. If you look for an intimate place you better go to another restaurant cause they offer large circle tables. Thus several people can sit around one table. The food is really good! It's definitely a place to good with friends and enjoy real Asian food!

Very good but would not wait in a long line for it

Recommended:
* Soup dumplings are indeed very good, can't go wrong here.
* Lions head meatballs very soft and great taste

Above average:
* Fish filet in wine sauce was tasty altho a little salty
* Beef with scallions ($13.5 after tax). Beef quality is definitely above average for chinatown. Dish was a bit too saucy but good enough.

Just okay:
* shanghai fried noodles with pork decent but nothing special.

I recommend takeout or going in when its not so busy.

I agree this place isn't quite worth a very long wait (try New Green Bo or Shanghai Gourmet or Moon House), but if you happen to come during an off-hour, check it out!  You can order your food while waiting, so it's ready once you sit down.  Warning: you'll probably be seated at a table with strangers, you'll be shooed off once you're done with your meal, and it's REALLY loud.

Along with the soup dumplings (I personally like the normal ones w/out crab) and other Shanghai dimsum, I recommend the braised pork shoulder.  It's REALLY fatty, but tasty, and excellent over rice.

1ST THING u should order is soup dumplings- shao long bao. The price is so cheap and they are delicious! Foood is great and service was good too. But my only complaint is the interior of the resturant, the light was dim and it looked kind of shady. Dont be mistakened though because the food is delicious. Other notable dishes are the singaporean noodles and fried man tao

I had lunch here when I was in Manhattan for a visit. My friends brought me here and we had dumplings. I thought the dumplings were very good and fresh.  The same quality you get in San Francisco Chinatown, but I prefer the Bay Area Chinese food, overall. The onion bread was very good too. Similar to how my mom's makes it, but of course not as good as mom's.  I could tell this place is a local favorite. I saw a few white collar workers were having lunch here and they seem to really enjoy it.

Best (Xiao long bao) soup dumplings I've had anywhere and blows LA's Din Tai Fung out of the water. Expect a wait. Expect chaotic (but organized) service. Be open to sharing a round table with strangers. Their regular pork soup dumplings are the best. The crab and pork ones are good too but can sometimes have a fishy taste. I have but usually don't order other Chinese dishes on their menu since the dumplings make a great meal on their own. Worth the wait! This is a repeat visit resto for me, and the quality has remained consistent over the years.

Do book ahead of time if you want to go to this place with a large party! This place gets crowded at night especially on the weekends!

The best dish i remember getting from this place is their onion pancake. What makes it great is their dipping sauce, which is sweet soy sauce (genius)! 

Other than that, their soup dumplings are alright, some of my friends complain that it doesn't taste fresh, but i have no complaints (do try their crab filling dumplings). The dough is thin and the soup was tasty. 

Their rice dishes are quite authentic, but their noodle dishes are rather oily and just not well made. I feel like there are better places than this over hyped restaurant in China town if you're really looking for good soup dumplings and authentic chinese food. Overall, not a bad restaurant.

Came here to get that NYC experience as a tourist lol. We had the pork soup dumplings my husband and I both enjoyed them very much he's usually very picky about greasy food but he didn't think it was greasy or salty. However they are filling so we could only finish two baskets and took the rest home. I order a soup which had thick noodles and some kind of red broth was super greasy and could not finish it hence the 4 stars. Lo mein was greasy as well but good and had this smoky flavor. I wouldn't recommend the entrees here unless u want clogged arteries, however  I do recommend the soup dumplings.

OMG.. I love their soup dumplings!! It was soooo good! The dumpling was good without any sauce added to it. They give you a small dish of vinegar sauce and I feel like it just overpowers all the flavor of the soup dumpling.. Be careful when taking your first bite into the dumpling though.. It will burst out with hot soup! Don't burn your tongue! But the the soup was so yummy I did not want to loose any at all! I would try to sip as much as I can before it drips on my plate... As for what kind we got.. We got the crab and pork meat mixed together.. YUMM!! We got two orders for 4 people.. Honestly we could have eaten more.. But we ordered more plates so we didn't want to over order.. Wish I could have had more though because the other plates we ordered was ehh... We got the shanghai flat noodles.. I felt like it tasted like regular stir fried noodles.. Nothing special.. And we got the crispy beef plate as well.. Ehhhhhhh I seriously thought it was all batter.. No beef at all.. And tastes like orange chicken... SERIOUSLY! Should have just ate more soup dumplings!! 

I give this place 4 stars because the only good thing was their soup dumplings.. Their other plates was just mediocre Chinese food plates.. Blah!

Soup steam dumpling is the best. Very nice and fresh taste. Must to have here.
Beijing duck is not good, eatable but below average. Too dry and not well seasoned.

- everyone goes for their soup dumplings, that's pretty much all you need to know, anything else on their menu can be had anywhere else and would probably be better elsewhere, but their soup dumplings have yet to be matched
Some of the best dumplings I've ever had. Definitely know why they are known for them! Everything we ordered was great and very reasonably priced. For sure need to make this a stop!

The hot & sour soup is smooth and sharp and simply wonderful. Pork dumplings, fried or steamed: very good.  But it was the prawns with a snazzy chili sauce that really made me say, hey that was a nice taste sensation. Bravo! The service is pleasant and very talented, too.

Came here for a last minute dinner with a friend. Located down in an alley in Chinatown, this place was very crowded and for good reason. 

The menu of not extensive, but what they have is delicious. We ordered the Shanghai Cabbage  and Szechuan Beef Tendon Noodle Soup. Though these aren't their most popular dishes, we were absolutely stuffed by them.

The interior is your classic Chinese restaurant, nothing to write home about there though perhaps a little bit aged and worn out looking. It feels like it needs a little freshening up. Perhaps a new coat of paint or a change of the wall-to-wall carpet? 

The tables are all designed to seat 10 persons, so dinner is family style, just don't lose your meal on the giant Lazy Susan in the middle of the table.  

You need to be aware that this place is a cash only establishment! Don't even think about paying by credit card. 

Now the reason that I'm giving it only four stars is because my friend and I felt very neglected by the waiter. We had to call him over multiple times to either order drinks or get the check. When the check was requested, they began removing our plates, even though we still had food on them and weren't quite ready to head out. We only wanted to pay the check so that we weren't in a mad rush at the end, since it was very close to closing time. And that's really the main thing. We felt as though we were being rushed/kicked out. I'm not implying that their closing hours shouldn't be observed, but there are more polite ways to do it. A simple, "we are closing and would appreciate it if you would finish up, please." I don't feel that's asking a lot, but to each their own. 

Still, I would come back here and try out the rest of the menu. The items that our neighbors ordered at our table looked and smelled delicious. 

Enjoy!

I don't know about what crowds people are talking about, as I went on a Thursday (after Sanur) at about 5 pm with a friend and there weren't many people there (the large upstairs room --which you pass en route to the bathroom--was closed).

The xiaolongbao is cheap! For 4-5 dollars (I forget the price) you get eight big soup dumplings, each with a lot of soup. I've had really good ones in Singapore, and though Joe's Shanghai could make the skin better to have the perfect texture, the xiaolongbao is nevertheless more than decent, and savory, and worthy to be eaten with delicate care. We carefully placed each xiaolongbao on the big porcelain  spoons we got (for fear that they would break, although they seemed decently strong), and the xiaolongbao was steaming hot! They were so big and had so much soup that I spent about several minutes eating each one, each one an intense experience..

But as a Singaporean, I think what the dish really needs is minced ginger -- they give you such thin shreds of ginger in soy sauce.

This place had lines at 2:30 in the afternoon. It is cash only and you sit in communal tables. There is no ambiance whatsoever, it's not for a romantic date but if you want excellent pork soup dumpling then this is the place. We also ordered the shrimp noodle soup that had a really good flavor but the scallion pancake was a let down. I forgot to mention that this place have very inexpensive food for NY standards. The service is fast but don't expect friendly. There is only one bathroom each for men and women and it is not very nice but you don't come here for nice bathrooms or ambience. You can definitely believe the hype.
Firstly, I don't know anything about authentic Chinese cuisine. But this place was packed and unbelievably delicious. I'd come back again and again if I lived in Nyc.
Fantastic spot. The soup dumplings are incredible. I could eat them forever. Super good. Go
Classic soup buns, family style.  Joe's is the quintessential Chinatown restaurant that is always reliable in service and quality.  Be prepared for a wait especially with a large party.

TLDR: It's a great sit down for families w great portions! The wait is a tad long& it's cash only!

-Taste: I know Joe's are notorious for the soup dumplings, but I was craving more plates. The Mapo tofu and the eggplant were flavorful to my liking and plus is Veg. Friendly
-Portion size: They are pretty generous with their plates. 3 plates can feed about 3-5 people!
-Price: Each plate was about $13, which is reasonable for much food they give you
-Service: It is definitely easier if you come with a native speaker, but the staff are kind and check to see if you need assistance quite often
-Ambiance: It's pretty spacious for a Chinatown sit down but a bit loud inside
-Return: Yes! But I would say you get more of your buck with a bigger group to try a little bit of everything on the menu.
Walking hangry around chinatown i stumbled upon this hidden gem and from that time i dream of their soup dumplings which are by far the best i had

Ahhh, Joe Shanghai. How I love you. Although every time I visit I forget that you're tucked away on Pell Street and inconveniently almost completely on the east edge of the island, when I arrive you never disappoint. Of course I'm not the first to write about your heavenly soup dumplings, but I will indulge the details of my own experience: I love the first bite that scalds my tongue, the delicious pork nugget that sits inside you like a pearl at the bottom of your floppy soup-filled pouch, the spiked tongs that i use to pluck you from your bamboo and lettuce lined palace, and the taste of the warm broth rushing into my mouth through the small chopstick size tunnel i poked in you. Yum.

Went there last night upon recommendation from a local! Very good chicken fried rice and General Tso's chicken. Nothing fancy about service but turnover is the game and they get 'em in & get 'em out!!! Well worth the visit!!!
