I've been going to Joe's for nearly a decade now. The new location has completely lost all charm that the old one had, but it certainly felt cleaner. I feel as if the food's quality isn't a good as it used to be (minus the dumplings.) I also found it sad they didn't give free tea anymore. However there is no better soup dumpling spot in the entire country compared to Joe's! They nail it every time.
Crab soup dumplings. They're as good as everyone says. Definitely a must if you are in NYC.

Great place for amazing dumplings, chinese food and then some. 

You won't come here for the atmosphere, it's typically packed, and not decorated to please the eye. But you'll quickly forget when you have a mouthful of amazing dumplings and enough broccoli beef to feed you and the person next to you. Seven of us went, and ordered enough to feed 9. We walked out with only $15 each including tip. Well worth it. 

Recommended: Dumplings (they're a must). Broccoli beef, General Tso's chicken

Their pork buns taste so good!! I bought my mom here to eat it. I also got the pan fried noodles with beef and it tasted really good. 

I highly recommend this place.

This review is pretty short but this place is so tasty.

Hard to order, but once you get a hang of it, food is really good! Be sure to order the dumpling soup. Couldn't understand what the waiter was asking me, but got help from others at the table. Good food and a good friendly time.

This place gets packed and for good reasons. The dumpling was soo good. The broth inside is the best part. We also got egg fried rice, which was the best i've had in a while. We ordered i think scallion pancake is what it was called, the sauce it came with was perfect.
Small line when we got there but only about 15 minute wait.  Food was excellent.  Enjoyed Dumplings with 3 sauces, Sesame Chicken, and Shrimp Fried Rice.  Yum!
the wait is really long but the food is pretty authentic. the dim sums are very good. the vegetable dished could be better.
Place is not bad, service is average, food is pretty good. Place is sort of a hole in the wall, but the prices are priced accordingly by Chris Fasullo

Fantastic soup dumplings, and also super cheap! But I wasn't the one who hung around for two hours when we put our name down lol. It's a LITTLE faster if you have a small group, but still, the crowd was outrageous, like an auction with people yelling out numbers!

On to the food. 

$6 for 8 pork dumplings. $7 for 8 seafood dumplings! The skin is thicker than I'm used to but still so good. And these were probably the hottest (Temp wise) that I've had.

The pan fried seafood noodles was delicious! Love pan fried chewy noodles. 

Scallion pancakes were a little burnt and kind of too oily for my taste.

Kung pao chicken was made with white meat? Haha, it was alright still

Shrimp fried rice was yum!

Be prepared to possibly share communal tables and be super cramped. Also. Cash only!

TL;DR

1. Large portions
2. Fresh everything 
3. Accurate wait times 
4. Cash only 

Came here on a busy Friday night around 8pm, waited 45min for a party of 2, and it was on the dot accurate. Was seated with water by 845.

Ordered the regular pork, and pork + crab soup dumplings, garlic eggplant, hot and spurt soup, and sesame chicken.

Eggplant is always a good choice.
Chicken was great, but pricey.
Soup was amazing.

See you soon, Joe's Shanghai

I love Joe Shanghai's. If you go here and don't get the soup dumplings you are doing it all wrong! They also have some dim sum options but not a larger selection, again you go here for their soup dumplings. For anyone wondering how to eat them, use the spoon to place the dumpling on so you don't lose the soup inside! 

Their beef or chicken rice cake dish is also delicious. Veggies tend to run up to $13 which is a lot if you are just a party of two, but I would get the snow pea/bean leaf or Chinese watercress! Nom nom!

Wanted a quick lunch but ended up waiting over 1 1/2 hr for a table.  Since this place was recommended, we wanted to give it a try.  We were very hungry by the time we got to eat.  We ordered Crab & Pork Soup dumplings, Eggplant w/ Spicy Sauce, Spicy Szechuan Style Fish Fillet, Turnip Cake, Singapore Chow Mei fun and other dishes I can't remember. All the food was good but not sure if waiting that long is worth it when there are so many other restaurants in China town we could've tried.

A group of 3 of us walked in at around 6 PM on a Wednesday night and were seated immediately. I guess we got lucky because right after that a couple other groups came in and then there was a line. We sat in those two large communal round tables in the back. 

The scallion pancakes (2.95) are good and also a small portion (reflected upon by the cheap price). 
The xiao long bao (8 pieces, comes with steamed lettuce and vinegar sauce) was delicious! My first time having soup dumplings so I don't have anything to compare it to, but I thought the soup inside was very flavorful and the meat was tender and the dough that makes the dumpling was slightly chewy which I loved. 

We also ordered the Shanghai noodles and a beef/green bean dish. The shanghai noodles were probably the biggest disappointment. It wasn't anything crazy and the noodles were very greasy. Good nevertheless. The beef/green bean dish was great! Couldn't stop eating the green beans. 

Service is friendly than I would have expected. They do clear the plates as soon as you finish your food. Alcohol is served very quickly. Tsing tao 5.50 was a common beer that everyone else in the table ordered. A 15% tip is already included in your bill. 

Now I'm off to try other places that aren't so hyped to see if the xiao long bao at Joe's really is worth the hype!

SOUPY  BUNS!!!!! Say it out loud. So delicious.
Cheap and the wait staff was hilariously nice.
Moo Shu was good not the best but good.
Greasy chinese is great  most likely anwhere but, I would stick with thedumplings here.

Came here to see what all the rave was about their pork soup dumplings. This wasn't the first time that I encountered soup dumplings either so I did have something to compare to their food. I gotta say, the soup dumplings are actually very very delicious! The dough on the outside was moist and not hard so it was easy to bite into the dumplings. The soup was sweet and the pork was just the perfect compliment. The group I came with couldn't get enough so we ended up just ordering more. 

I would definitely recommend this place for the food, I don't know about the atmosphere. We weren't expecting to get seated with people we didn't know even though we had a large party but it got less awkward after awhile so it wasn't too bad. 

This is obviously Chinatown so of course it's going to be cash only so be prepared for that. On the bright side, the pork soup dumplings here are probably going to be the best for the cheapest price also. Eight for 5.95!
Great food and good find. A bit tight on the inside...

Went to Chinatown and stopped by this restaurant for lunch the last time I visited NYC! The wait was 20 minutes during lunch time but it's worth it! The food was delicious especially the dumplings! Huge portions and not expensive! Great restaurant for families too!

Been here multiple times. The quality of the pork dumplings never falters. They are consistently delicious, and are presented to you pretty much as soon as you sit down. It is assumed you want them. I have been exploring the menu over the course of my visits and have some favorites: the fried rice cake with seafood is classic and delicious. Fried crispy whole sea bass, though a task to eat, is very yummy. The sauteed winter vegetables are delicate and refreshing. Try to get here between 5-6:30 so you have only a 10-20 minute wait. Service is quick and there is only about a 5 minute wait for your food.

Soup dumplings were good. I loved the pork fried buns. The General Tso's was very fresh but I was disappointed that it didn't come with any rice or noodles. Others with me had the Lo mein and fried rice and said they were very good as well.

This place was crazy busy when we came in. Of course we weren't surprised, it was definitely a tourist spot within Chinatown. We had a party of 4 and waited about 30 minutes. It's kind of communal sitting, where they fill up any empty seat they have at their many tables. For example, we had maybe 3 separate parties at our table. 

Service was not the best, but I was very impressed with their efficiency, considering the sheer amount of customers AND workers there. They seem very disorganized but they have their own system that definitely works. You don't have just one waiter, but multiple can come up at a time to help. It's very loud inside so maybe not the best place for a first date!

We ordered 2 orders of pork xiao long bao and they were really good!!! They looked pretty messy but you can't deny their taste! We also ordered hot and sour soup, beef and broccoli, and some seafood dish I can't remember. Everything was just really good typical Chinese food!! Although the hot and sour soup had these chunks of chicken (I think) in which I did not care for. They were too tough. 

The place wasn't the cleanest either, but then again, with the amount of traffic coming in and out I don't blame them. They do what they can and you can tell they would much rather get customers in and out than spend their time making sure the restaurant is presentable. Maybe other locations aren't quite as crowded, so if I visit NYC again I'll definitely pay them a visit!

Also they are cash only!!!

They make one of the best soup dumpling I ever had! It is soooo good. However, I always need to share the table but the taste totally make sharing the table worth it. I usually don't go during rush hour so I never had to wait long. The price is reasonable and location is convenient.

This place gets PACKED! This is my 2nd visit. First visit, we had to wait for about 40 minutes to be seated at this BIG table shared with a few other parties. I have to say, it was brutal to see other people at your table with their food while you wait for yours. 

My 2nd time there, no wait (lucky us!!). It was on a Tuesday night, but the place was still filled! The workers know people go there for the dumplings, so before we even sat our butts down, the waiter already asked how many orders of dumplings. Personally I thought it was kinda rude but if I guess I wouldn't mind if I was SUPER hungry and ready to chow!

The two of us got an order of the dumplings, Shanghai noodle and a shrimp noodle soup. Everything was delicious. The trick to eat the dumpling is to eat the top first, suck the juice inside, then eat the whole thing. Both times, I had very good experience with the service and the food. I'd go there again :)
Soup Dumplings :) If you want more authentic Chinese food(shanghainese), try this.
Crab dumpling is very good same with the chefs special prawns.. Hong Kong style noodles are good too..

The first time someone brought me here, we were on a third date. I was suspicious. Suspicious that he had been too lazy to make reservations at a restaurant that takes reservations, mostly, but also suspicious that this wonderful thing he was referring to as a soup dumpling, something I had never heard of before, was really just wonton soup.

8 Pork Steamed Buns later, I was a wholly changed individual. JS soup dumplings have since become one of my favorite things to eat, right up there with everything else that poses a potential mess-problem and is sort of unhealthy. I have even expanded my preferred terms of endearment (Sweetie, Honey, Babe) to include "Joe's Shanghai Soup Dumpling". It doesn't get much more loving than that.  

The menu is rather extensive, perhaps too extensive for thorough familiarity. Everything I have had here has been good (scallion pancake) or great (try the noodle soups), but you will see from looking around at other tables that the soup dumplings (pork or crabmeat/pork - I prefer the pork) are definitely the go-to items. 

The two issues that I have with Joe's Shanghai: They do not deliver and they do not take reservations. Almost always at capacity, you will be forced to wait between twenty and forty minutes to be seated. Where do you wait? Outside. This is all fine and dandy during the summer but during the colder months? Not so fine, not so dandy.

Side note: Once inside, you may or may not be seated at a table full of strangers. Best not to come here if you need alone or one-on-one time.
Hands down the most delicious soup dumplings that you'll ever put in your mouth. This is the place to go for soup dumplings. They own them in New York. Get like four baskets.

Jewish Christmas@ Joe's:

Fan-f*ckingtastic.

Yes, there was an hour an a half wait. It was worth every minute.

We had:

1. FOUR orders of crab and pork dumplings. 
2. TWO orders of General Tso's Chicken
3. TWO orders Jumbo Prawns with Meat Sauces.
4. Beef with Scallions
5. Twice-cooked Pork
6. Orange Beef
7. Some noodles (enhanced with pork, of course). Don't remember the exact kind, but they were fantastic.

Oh yeah, and a partridge in a freakin' Shanghai-nese pear tree. 

BADASS.

Kill me. Kill yourself. Kill everyone you know.

NEXT YEAR, BITCHES.

Tips: 
-Come early!! The restaurant may be open, but they do not start taking orders until 11am. I arrived at 10:45am, and there was already 2 tables "reserved" by 2 customers sitting there. Even if all members of your party arrive before 11am, orders are not taken till 11am. By 11:20am, the entire place was jam-packed! 

-This may be common sense haha but order the soup dumplings (8 per order). The first time the waiter asks is if you want soup dumplings. All other food items are comparable to 500 other restaurants in Chinatown. However the soup dumplings... oh my lord, are one of a kind!

-I prefer the crab soup dumplings to the pork. I was surprised at the amount of crab in each dumpling. The crab flavor is very prominent in both filling and soup. 

-Eat it while its hot!! The dumplings are not as good as it cools to room temp. 

Dislikes:
- Cash only $ 
- 15% involuntary gratuity/service charge 

Best soup dumplings I have ever had? Yes, in my life thus far.
Is it worth the hype? Well....  I do not think its worth the wait if its more than 30 minutes.

I had one of my favorite dishes of 2008 here:  

Steamed Buffalo Carp Fish Belly.

OH.  MY.  GOD.  SWEET.  JESUS.  MAMA.  SATAN.

_C$

Gotta hand it to Joe's - best soup dumplings ever.
Get the pork soup dumplings only - the rest of the menu is too greasy and average at best. I personally don't like the crab and pork - I feel the fishiness of the crab is unnecessary and doesn't pair well with the savory pork. 

The pork filling is juicy and full of flavor - I haven't found another shop that makes their XLBs with as much soup filling as Joe's - superb.

The skin is also extremely well made - not doughy or thick but cooked to a perfect chewy texture and thin - definitely hand made.

The wait is horrible as expected - you might have a better chance on a random early Monday or Tues night - prime dinner time and weekends you're looking at at least an hour wait. Here's a secret though if you're not looking to wait but still want to try the famous soup dumplings - go down the street (a few steps) to Joe's Ginger (owner is the same) and so are the soup dumplings.

It's a cleaner set up and they charge slightly higher prices for the same food but it's a great option to get the same food with less wait.

Service is the same at both places - non existent and rushed. You'll most likely share tables here as well unless you have a large group. Cash only and they automatically add on 15% tip - which I don't mind since it's the standard and the food is pretty cheap already.

This place was the shit, good as fuck. The Zsechuan beef cacerole was  really good, big, and flavory. I also liked the shrimp and chicken in plum sauce. I ve tried several chinese joints here in Chinatown and of all, this hits home run. I loved the price/serving size ratio and the quality of the food is just so freakin good

Yummy......their specialty here seems to be their juicy dumplings. Be sure to eat them while they are piping hot because the juices once cold will revert back to its gelatinous state (pure lard)

We also had their Spinach with a touch of garlic, General Tso's chicken, and their Scallion pancake as an appetizer. All these dishes were delightful. No wonder this place is so popular with all the locals.

Be forewarned, they only accept cash. Also, space is scarce. You might have to sit with a another group of people at the same table.
i love  wearing  nice  warm  furry  hood  parkas  coats  nice  & warm  in  the  winter  time

Best soup dumplings in New York, or so they say.  They are definitely among the best I've had.  For the bite sized awesomeness these piping hot soup bags deliver to your taste buds, the rest of the menu could go unnoticed, but actually most of the dishes here are also very good.  Try the pork belly or a vegetable dish as a side.

Joe's Shanghai was hands down the best soup dumpling I've ever had. The dumpling skin is thicker than what I am used to at DTF but there was so much more soup in the dumplings.
During Covid at this location they have two tables outside but it looked like most people were ordering to go.
Delicious pork dumplings! Service was a little slow, CASH only, table was a little bit sticky, but the food made up for it. It was delicious! Try the fried rice cakes, different and very tasty!

Wow this place is Xiao long bao heaven.

Crab & pork soup dumplings - 5/5. Best I've had in the US, hands down. Lots of delicious soup in a thin wrapper. Only complaint/wish is that the dumplings are hugeee so I wish the spoons were also bigger as it was impossible to not spill the liquid gold (aka soup). 

Beef lo mein - 3/5. Nothing exciting. It was fine. Perfectly average. Probably the smallest portion of lo mein I've ever gotten though from a non-Americanized/fusion place. 

Looking around, the portions are "normal" and not oversized like you'd expect from a Chinese place. But it's to be expected given how mainstream this place is, and is now in a nice looking / not hole in the wall looking place. Outside of the soup dumplings, everything is mediocre and overpriced (relative to the small portions) and nothing too special. I wouldn't come here for anything else. But I will be coming back again and again for those soup dumplings!!

Cheers to SOUP DUMPLING!!!!

But what sucks is you have to share your table with strangers and there's too many damn tourists!

LONG WAIT!!!!!
soup dumplings are good especially for the price but they're just decent with no huge wow factor. definitely a solid choice if you want something cheap and filling though (also great for groups)

Love this place so much. You may have to wait over an hour for a table but it's worth it. Best soup dumplings in the city! The entrees are all excellent. It's one of my go-to places to take people from out of town.

Down, maybe a little out but NYC remains a helluva restaurant town. Joe's Shanghai is amazing... go for the Hong Kong style Hot and Sour soup and stay for the Crispy Beef. Two personal favorites but you could throw a dart at the menu and still be gobsmacked. An easy five stars.

YASSS SOUP DUMPLINGS! 
Okay, story time: 
I'm in New York for the FIRST time- and only there for 10 hours before I head back to Baltimore. I have a train to catch at 11:05 from Penn Station. I'm near Central Park so I take a train and jog walk like half a mile to Joe's Shanghai. Got there around 10 and sat next to other people and ordered 2 types of soup dumplings. We literally scarfed them down because of time crunch but also because they were SOOO good. 

I think coming from LA where I've only tried soup dumplings at Din Tai Fung (don't judge me pls) coming to Joe's Shanghai was a game changer. I'd be here all the time if I was in New York. Please go and try

Joe's Shanghai has a reputation for being one of the Chinatown eateries that you have to visit.  One thing to note, Shanghainese dishes are a little different from other Chinese dishes, which is why eating at Joe's is such a treat.  The two more popular dishes are the xiao long bao and the Shagnhainese style fried noodles.  I could stuff myself with both of those all day.  Some of the other cold appetizers aren't bad either, I'd say order one or two dishes, say the chicken, jellyfish, or beef, just to try them out.  While you could order some of these dishes at other restaurants, this is the spot in Manhattan where they are the most authentic.

Great place for a cheap yummy date! Though, maybe I got a bad batch of soup dumplings, but they were really disappointing. 

   But, the crispy beef was wonderful!! I'd definitely come back for that!

There's not much else I can say that hasn't been said. But maybe I need to come back with a true soup dumpling expert, anyone want to provide the guidance?

Great soup dumplings!!! Everything else other people ordered looked / smelled so good too! I definitely think the pork and shrimp dumplings are too heavy on the pork, didn't get much shrimp out of it.

Everyone know Joe Shanghai by now and I probably won't add much to what's been written.  I will say that I still think it's better than Ding Tai Fong in LA.  The soupiness of the dumplings is just..perfect.

Here's what we ate:
1. Pork and crab dumplings - For the record, I think that the pork dumplings are almost just as good as the ones with crab and the crab ones are 50% more expensive.  I can go ghetto and just stick to the pork ones.

2. Sliced braised beef noodle soup with vermicelli  - The beef is amazing but the soup and noodles are only average.  It's a little spicy which makes it better.

3. Scallion pancake - a staple and still very good - crispy and tasty.

4. Vegetarian duck - So good and stuffed with mushrooms.  I'll order this every time.

5. Shanghai fried flat noodle - Some people apparently love this but I think it's terrible and a waste of stomach space - especially when you could be getting in an extra 3 or 4 of those dumplings. 

6. Braised Pork shoulder - My greatest find!  My cousin saw some other table order it during a different visit and wanted to try it.  I had never had it before.  Boy, was I missing out.  It's a massive piece of fatty pork marinaded.  It is absolutely amazing although two of these would probably be an instant heart attack.  We were a party of 7 and didn't really eat the entire thing.  I would not recommend ordering this with anything less than that number of people in your party.  That just means that you must go to Joe Shanghai with at least 7 people because it's a MUST-ORDER.

I love this place and despite the wait, it's still worth it to me.  Go Joe!

Great soup dumplings! We loved the pork and crab, and we went for a late lunch so no lines at all and service was actually really nice (especially compared to what we had read in reviews). Cheap, good, and would go again! 

Cash only.

Super popular,
If you go during dinner  expect to wait at least 30 minutes. Space Inside is pretty small. If you go with a small party you will most likely get placed at a big table with others. Alsoooo order the soup dumplings (crab but also pork).

YES. Best XLB I've had so far and that's comparing it to places in the Bay Area, California. Huge pieces that are all consistently filled with soup. And the prices are so reasonable. $6/8 pork, $7 or $8 for 8 crab/pork. I'll definitely be back here for more

hands down...the best soup dumplings. the rest of the chinese food was ok....
but eat loads of these delicious soup dumplings!!!

Joe's is one of the more famous restaurants known for their Xiao Long Bao (Steamed Pork Buns, the ones with the soup inside the dumpling).  

In California, most of the Xiao Long Bao's I've tried have been pitiful at best.  Usually, the moisture has left the dumpling by the time it has hit the table.

At Joe's, I believe everyone of the Pork ones had soup in it.  Tasted good.  Unfortunately, the Crab & Pork ones had a few deflated ones. 

The Subgum Fried Rice Cake was cooked very nicely and was very tasty.  Lion's Head (meatballs) were tasty, but had a texture and dryness I didn't care for.

The things that didn't do it for me here:

- most of the tables are for large parties, so you'll end up sharing a table with strangers

- CASH ONLY

- automatic $15% service charge

I would include service, but who expects good service at a Chinese place?

Been here three times and it definitely hits the spot.  Not anything fancy and you will most likely have to share a table with strangers, but it's good stuff.  Get the dumplings, they are piping hot and delish.  Had the orange chicken or beef, can't remember which, but it was goooooood.  We order a ton of food when we go and finish everything.  And sometimes, order seconds of the fried rice!
i dream about their soup dumplings.  i get two orders for myself (for real)... sometimes it scares people.

Best soup dumplings I've ever had. The restaurant is family style, so your party shares a table with other people. It sometimes takes a while to be seated, but service is fast once you do sit down. It's best to know what you want to order by the time your server gets to you for the first time -- the place has a busy, chaotic vibe.

The soup dumplings here are on point. The broth is nice and rich with pork fat. The pork inside the dumplings are decent and the dumpling skin is to chewy. Service is okay. You can't have high expectations for a Chinese restaurant that has high volume of traffic. Definitely, worth a try
Great food! Love the soup dumplings! We had to wait for a bit but was totally worth it! The service was great and the staff was very helpful.

Lunch time, party of 2....no wait! I checked reviews before and saw that it was a cash only establishment. They do have atm's up front....and if you are worried about a service charge, it is probably time to change your bank. 

We picked the crab meat and pork soup dumplings and then asked the server for a recommendation. He pointed out the crispy shredded beef. 

The dumplings arrived first and they were sooooooo good. It's hard to wait for them to cool down, but that broth can be painful if you start in too quickly. The filling was delicious and the broth was rich and delicious. I was surprised by the crispy shredded beef. It was completely different than I had imagined. It seemed similar to orange chicken, but with strips of beef. It was sweet and crispy and paired well with the white rice. This was a lot of food for a party of 2....sadly we couldn't take it with us, so we made sure to finish the dumplings.

This place is busy, lots of tables but everything seemed to come out quickly.
Soup dumplings were on point! Really fresh and delicious! The rest of the food was average. It's mighty packed and you'll have to make up your mind quick or wait a bit.

Quick in and out. Very attentive service, we only had the crab soup dumplings, pork soup dumplings and scallion pancakes, but all three were delicious. We will be back to Chinatown to hit this place and tiger sugar, for boba, just around the corner.

The service is like the service at any other place in Chinatown - not good.  But the food is great!  Definitely come with a group, so you can eat family style and sample a little of everything.

Joe Shanghai is not as vegetarian friendly as other Chinese restaurants, but it's still good.  My friends and I ordered some fried noodles with vegetables, an eggplant dish without the pork, turnip cakes, veggie duck, and soup dumplings (no vegetarian option here).

The only dish I wouldn't recommend was the veggie duck.  We ordered it based on a favorable review that was hanging on the window outside.  Definitely could have passed on that one.  Everything else was delicious, and the sauces for the noodles and eggplant were super tasty.  A little oily, but dude, it's Chinese food.

Man, writing about this is making me hungry.

Hidden in a small alley in Chinatown, I wasn't sure what to expect. But before I knew it I was gobbling these succulent dumplings, filled with steaming broth and a crab meatball. And oh my gosh, so juicy and ahh... And so cheap!!! It was only about $5 for 8 or so dumplings, and they can fill you up fast!! Warning, warning, this place gets packed!! So prepare to be sitted in a squishy environment, but it will be all worth it. =)

The whole experience of Joe's Shanghai is what you look for in Chinatown.  While waiting for a table, I wanted to cool down and went next door to Quickly for a Thai Tea.  The whole process was pretty streamlined and didn't take that long considering how many people were standing outside.  

I wanted so many things on the menu but couldn't resist the soup dumplings and, just for a little variety, I also got the scallion pancake.  Not only was the food remarkable, I loved sitting at community tables.  The diverse group at my table were sharing food just by spinning the lazy-suzan at the center of the table.

During my most recent visit here, we rolled up at noon and there was NO wait surprisingly. We walked right in and got seated immediately. We must have just beaten the lunch crowd that day. 

Tip: This no-wait occurrence is rare so expect a wait at all other times because JS is usually always packed.

JS isn't a place you go to for dim sum, but rather authentic Shanghainese dishes, and their infamous soup dumplings (xiao long bao) which are a must and probably the sole reason why JS attracts herds of people. Their soup dumplings are a mix of crab and pork dumplings so for you vegetarian or non-pork eating folks, this wouldn't be the ideal dish for you. Unfortunately, they don't make exceptions. 

Tip: I highly recommend poking a small hole with your chopstick at the top of each dumpling to let out some of the steam to prevent yourself from burning your precious taste buds. You will need them to fully indulge in these crafty, one-of-a-kind, skillfully handmade dumplings. Use your soup spoon to sip and savor the remaining "liquid explosions" that gush out of each dumpling.

Another surprising treat at JS are their scallion pancakes. They are super crunchy, yet so moist and boasting with unimaginable flavors on the inside. They are quite addictive. Don't be surprised if you tack on one more order of them to your bill.

Other must-orders/haves:
- young chow fried rice
- roast duck
- watercress

The service here is always on point so actual chow time is never interrupted.

Other tips:
- Since the demand is high and crowds are rampant, get in and get out is common courtesy. Don't linger longer than you need to. There are hungry people waiting in line to devour what you just stuffed in your happy belly.
- Expect a half hour to an hour wait.
- Since JS is a compact place, expect to be sharing tables with hungry, happy strangers. JS takes advantage of every seat option available.

I haven't had one bad dish here, and personally that's a great indication of a successful restaurant with satisfying food, and a bargain one at that. This is one of my favorite go-to spots in Chinatown.

Ever since I was little my name was Xiao Long Bao and my favorite movie was Spiderman with the great Tobey. Ever since I watched part one I wanted to find the alley with the Chinese lady singing the original spiderman theme song, you know spiderman spiderman. I finally made my way there and was at a ah. While I was rolling around I ran into this restaurant and was like ohhh they sell my name here so I gotta try it. Omg life changing all I did was bite, blow, suck, and take it in whole. I fell in love doing it 8 times at a time with each tray I just couldn't stop. Thank you Tobey for leading me here.

Best Xiao Long Bao. The line is worth the wait.

Joe's is the ONLY place I go to for soup dumplings (get the pork and crabmeat one, more flavoful). I did try soup dumplings elsewhere because some people kept insisting that joe's is not "authentic", and I was disppointed (as predicted). Maybe those other dumplings are the real deal, but WHO CARES, joe's tastes so much better!! Also, try their String Bean Szechuan Style (with Pork) - AMAZING, crispy, and flavorful with bits of yummy pork and pickled veggies. 

yes, the service is bad, but what do you expect - this is standard in chinatown, get over it! 

food can get a bit greasy and the wait is long (indicative of its yumminess!), but that doesnt deter me from bringing/recommending everyone i know to joe's...and i haven't heard one complaint yet.

By far, the best Chinese food I have ever had in Chinatown. Thanks Yelp reviewers! The only sad part was that we stopped for lunch and not dinner. This is the only bean curd I have enjoyed. It was crispy and served in a rich (just spicy enough) brown sauce, loaded with mushrooms and veggies. The veggie LoMein was chock full of a variety of vegetables, not just noodles. The service is impeccable, and the restaurant clean and nicely decorated. We were greeted with hot cups of jasmine tea. The waiters were on standby so that no cup was left I filled, no request not immediately satisfied. We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves here.

Yes, it's all been said before, but I will again anyway.

Love, love LOVE the soup dumplings!  Was taken here by friends for my first soup dumpling experience.  Fantastic taste and mix of textures and sensations - hot soup, dense pork filling, chewy dumpling and delicious sauce.  

The place is a mad-house, with fast-moving staff and a crush of diners.  Don't even try to figure out the waiting list.  It's like trigonometry or something.  Just happily accept a table, order some dumplings and some Tsingtao and start looking at the rest of the menu.  Seems hard to go wrong.

We had fantastic pea shoots - so sweet and tender, with a little garlic; beef and green beans; crispy noodles and vegetables; crispy prawns in meat sauce; and General Tsao's Chicken.  All were good, but I must say that the pea shoots and beef with green beans were my two faves.  But I definitely felt like all their food was prepared well and from very good ingredients.

This is totally on my must-stop list now when I'm in town.

This was one of my favorite places to go when I lived in NYC and a fun place to take out-of-town guests...there just isn't quite an experience like this one!  When you get to Joe's you will most likely find a HUGE line outside the door.  You take a carnival ticket with a number on it from the girl inside and she continually shouts out numbers into the street.  When your lucky number is called, it is your turn to head inside.  Sometimes the line moves at a decent pace, but at other times, it takes way over an hour to be seated!  (PS, they don't really like it and aren't very helpful if you ask where you are on this list!)

If you don't like eating with a bunch of strangers, this probably isn't the place for you!  Most often you are sat at a large communal table with a bunch of strangers (unless your party is large enough to take up the entire table).  It can be fun if you are placed with the right people, but it can also be a bit awkward.  

As far as food goes, well, I LOVE their soup dumplings!  We usually order at least two trays of both the pork and the crab dumplings.  They are super flavorful but I'm not the most graceful when eating them...probably not a place you'd go to impress a date for the first time.  I also love to get their scallion pancakes for an appetizer.  For entrees, I usually end up sharing with the people I go with, but I can say their beef and broccoli and sesame chicken are pretty tasty (as well as their other dishes...I've just had these two most often).  

The waiters are extremely efficient and work like a well-oiled machine...they know how to turn the tables over quickly to ease that long line outside.  However, they are definitely not the most friendly and often forget to bring me my soda!  Definitely come here for the experience and some dumplings...but don't expect to get inside quickly or to receive friendly service (PS, they only take cash, so make sure you have some)
It's Joes. That's all you need to know. Get scallion pancakes. Aswell as everything else

Visiting from California !!! This is by far the best Chinese food restaurant!!! I'm pretty picky I was a little scared to try at first but once I went in and seen how busy they were I knew I was in the right place !... oh and there were nice enough to charge my phone thank you !!!!!

Soup dumplings all the way.  Service isn't great, and you'll be sitting at a table with other people.  It's a bit eclectic, but that's why you go there.  If it's too crowded you're also right by Joe's Ginger which is basically the same exact thing.  Don't forget, cash only.  Did I mention the soup dumplings?
Soup dumplings are to die for, their pancakes are pretty good. The crispy rice noodle was interesting, definitely a great flavor. But I can live on their dumplings . Service is always amazing

soup dumplings are the famous dish here, and very cheap to boot.  If I lived closer, I would eat here far more often, and even go just as a snack.  I've tried multiple dishes here over the years (duck, fried rice, friend pork etc) and have not been disappointed.  

The restaurant adds Tip to the bill automatically, so be careful you don't double tip!  And it's Cash Only.

You are likely to have to share a table, and there's probably a crowd, so try going near off-peak times.

The soup dumplings here are delicious. I'd say this is one of the best places to get soup dumplings in Chinatown, but the other foods on the menu aren't as worth it. I highly recommend you don't go during their rush hour, which starts around 7PM, because the wait becomes long and the service becomes poor. If you are going in a large group, make sure the majority or all of the people are there because this is one of those restaurants that will not seat you during the rush hour unless your entire party is there.

Din Tai Fung in the LA area was my favorite place for xiao long bao until now.  Joe's Shanghai has awesome xiao long bao.  It's bigger, and because of that, the dumpling is way meatier tasting and super juicy.  Practically speaking, it's a little big for stuffing them in your face, but taste-wise they're awesome.  I also like that Joe's Shanghai has so many other dishes to eat that are also very tasty.

We had the orange beef (suprisingly awesome), sweet and sour fried yellow fish (very tasty), shanghai noodles (very tasty), sauteed mushrooms with bamboo shoots (tasty and flavorful), and green onion pancake (pretty standard, but very good).  I was totally stuffed for a mere $11.

Pros: Shanghai Dumpling Buns
Cons: VERY hard to get a seat and they don't take reservations

Thoughts: This is one of the staple restaurants in NYC's Chinatown and has yet to be replaced. It's something about those dumplings that can't be duplicated. There isn't any other place that would make it as good, maybe Joe's Ginger a block down that's owned by the same people, but it's still not as great. I've tried finding a Shanghai Restaurant in other big cities and have yet to discover it. They have the regular ones and they have ones with crab in it. The trick is eating it without it squirting all over the place... luckily I think I've mastered it with all the times going there. This place is a must try... if you can wait for a seat. Oh, and their other Shanghai dishes are good as well, such as Drunken Chicken and Scallion Pancake.
Soup dumplings were melt in your mouth savory.  Thick beef broth flavor is probably its selling point.  Delicious, but I'm a dumpling lover.

Came here after reading copious amounts of stellar reviews on here, and I can say I wasn't disappointed!

Was with my fellow elite friend, isa and marco, and had the famous siu long bao. It was great. Other stuff we had included Tawainese noodles of some sort and another carby dish, reminiscent of gnocchi. Am not familiar with names. 

It was really really good, partly due to the novelty aspect. But the downside was that it was SALTY beyond any sort of belief! To the point where I couldn't get thru the following 3-4 hours because of the excess MSG. 

So yes, if they toned that down a notch, I'd be happy. Would still come back tho!
I love the soupy dumplings!!!!  I don't come to NYC that often but when I do this place is a must go every time!

Yum! Best Chinese food ever! We ordered the soup dumplings, stir fried green beans, the Shanghai fried flat noodles and the chicken General Tso and I would recommend all these dishes, in that order. We had to wait 20mins to be seated but so worth it. By the time your seated and starved everything is delicious. The best dumplings I have ever tasted in my life and the green beans, oh... my mouth is watering as I type this review. I would come back again and again and take all my friends with me. It's a dingy little place in Chinatown but it makes the experience culturally authentic.Nothing to complain about, I just love this place!!!

I've been there with my girlfriend a few times now. I think it is a very approachable option for nicer/more authentic Asian food. Their soup dumplings are a must get. I've also had chicken with garlic sauce and some items off of their specials menu and they were all very good. Great food at an affordable price. Can be crowded sometimes so make a reservation if possible.

What can I say that 450 reviews haven't said already?  I just came back from this place again recommended by a friend... Driving to Pell Street is kind of annoying because it is a small street and there is always traffic in that area... parking is a real pain if you are like me and refuse just to put it in a lot, but otherwise taking the train would be ideal...

Here I am on a rainy day, super cozy and hungry and than it happens I spot the line to get in Joe's... I go up to the hostess for a table and she tells me 10 minutes... but as I walked in that door the smell of food i would soon be devouring consumed me... this wasn;t any old chinese take out food... this is Joe's... this is one of those great feelings you don't expect like on a hot night flipping the pillow and than laying back down on the cold side of the pillow... that's what this place is like!!

I sometimes expect the chinese food in Chinatown to be cheaper, I am not sure why, but it is always the opposite and it always pisses me off... everytime. But my god $4.65 for those giant melt in your mouth pork dumplings I had yesterday.. I will take it... um and by that I mean one order everyday of my life.. oh my and the seafood, and any type of noodle... Basically, what it all boils down to is if you like have a favorite local chinese food restaurant do not come here, you will be ruined, spoiled for life and forever addicted to Joe's...

The most amazing soup dumplings and scallion pancakes you will ever taste. There is typically a line, but it moves very fast. Communal seating, extremely affordable, cash only. This place is the best!!!

If you're coming here, then you know what the deal is. It's all about the soup dumplings, and they are delicious--even moreso on a cold winter's day. I can't speak for the pork version, but the crab soup dumplings were delightful. The dumpling skin was perfect from textural standpoint. The fillings were flavor-packed, juicy, and tender. And to be honest, they're just plain fun to eat. Why have a dumpling and a bowl of soup on the side when you can fuse both together into a Megazord of scrumptiousness? 

For the sake of full disclosure, I can't give this place a perfect rating because the other items I tried were not anything to write home about as far as being memorable. They were pretty good but not great. This is where you come to get soup dumplings. The other Chinese offerings can be found with equal or better taste in other NY restaurants and particularly in Queens--a gem for East Asian cuisine.
I dont know about ya'll.. but this place freaking nailed with those soup dumplings. I've tried some soup dumplings from other franchises too, but J Shangai make the best ones.

This place is awesome! I enjoyed the crab and pork soup dumplings, crispy beef and broccoli noodles, and crispy duck! I came here late on a Monday night and the place was packed (which is a good sign) This place takes cash only! 
Everything was delicious! I would love to return to try other things!

This place was legit old school chinese restaurant.  Located in a seedy wet alley looking street which seems as if one will be getting into a kung fu fight coming out of the restaurant just as on the old kung fu movies. 

I had the Shanghai noodles and pork dumplings...ate the entire plate of noodles and about 6 dumplings.  So delicious. 

Authentic chinese cuisine.

Joe's Soup Dumplings ($5.50-6.50) are what made the place famous, and they're hard to resist. The grimy atmosphere might make you leave our monocles at home, but so long as Joe's keeps making delicious, cheap dumplings, I'll be coming back whenever I'm back in NY.

This place is very nice! I love their soup dumplings. I've been twice so far, and both times have ordered the soup dumplings. The service was very nice, quick, and polite. I also highly recommend the orange chicken! It is delicious! It does get crowded at peak hours, so I would recommend going earlier if you do not want to wait.
Can't go wrong with the food here, all around amazing food. Keep spoon feeding me that MSG please. Your service is going to be awful but small price to pay for great food.

BEST dumplings! Thought this might be a tourist trap but we do not have anything close to this in LA. The dumplings were so juicy and the and the skin was thicker than other places. We also tried the Chinese pancake, string beans, noodles, and some other items but the dumplings definitely overshadowed all the other dishes.
Definite must try when in NYC
So so happy I ran into this place.... everything was amazing and plan on going here up until the day I fly out! So delicious!! Organic and local!
The best dumplings!  Place that little dumpling in your soup spoon, break the dumpling skin so that the juices flow out into your spoon, and place in your mouth ... Mmmmm, heavenly ...

3.5 Stars

Some of the dishes at Joe's Shanghai are pretty good and others I would get somewhere else. I liked the minced chicken corn soup, it was a very simple blend of corn kernels,

My bf and I have had our fair share of XLBs and scallion pancakes back home. We heard about Joe's Shanghai and had to check it out during our trip in NY. The interior is quite nice, clean, and updated. Luckily it wasn't too busy so we were seated immediately. We ordered the crab and pork XLB and the scallion pancakes. The XLB came in a set of 8 and were pretty large. The outer skin was soft and the soup inside was thick, savory, and tasty. There was a good amount of crab/pork filling and surprisingly, I tasted a lot of the crab meat/flavor. The XLB was AMAZING! The scallion pancakes had a thick consistency, crispy on the outside and slightly chewy inside. Perfect scallion flavor and tasted really good with the side of vinegar sauce provided. This place is cash only and there are ATMs right by their front door. Definitely worth the hassle to pull out some cash!!!

Absolutely love this place. My favorite place to get shanghai buns is from Joe's shanghai! It is so delicious, once you've tried it, you'll be looking forward to the next time you'll be able to get your hands on some more. If you've never tried it, better get it to it then! My favorite way to enjoy my shanghai buns is to open up a small hole on top and drizzle a little bit of the sauce they give then when it's at the perfect temperature, stuff the whole thing in my mouth, doing it like this, you have the juices pouring out to keep the bun moist as you chew. *drool*

fantastic ghetto chinese food.  crushes every chinese place i've tried in the city not in chinatown.  communal seating isn't a highlight but kind of interesting.  only complaint is that they don't deliver to gramercy.
Once you've had Joe Shanghai dumplings...your life will never be the same again. It's a must try for any Asian food enthusiast.

This was suggested not once, but twice by folks I knew. I went in during a weekday and I managed to find it not as crowded as I was originally concerned. Especially being one person they accommodated me and knew immediately what I wanted to try. The Xiao Long Bao I had was Pork. The soup was fatty and delicious and really warmed me up. 

The issue I had was that the skin wasn't well put together and some did burst upon handling it but no worries, I managed to scrap up every bit of soup I could find. Still a solid choice but it's not there as my favorite soup dumplings, but I will come back and try again.
Whole in the wall spot but best soup dumplings there are. Tips- you do sit in a communal table so that could get weird. Also cash only.
Delicious soup dumplings!! Also had the saut√©ed bok choy which was amazing and a scallion pancake. Would def come again. Cash only.

Soup dumplings heaven another very hyped restaurant, their new location give you a lil more elbow room while dining compared to its old location. Cash only is the only draw back, no one carries cash nowadays!

I was mad about the wait time, but it's so worth it. We ordered the crab meat with pork soup dumplings, Chilean sea bass, and the house special glazed crispy chicken. The chicken was delicious, of course. But that might've been the best sea bass (from a Chinese restaurant) that I've ever had. So moist and tender, but still held its integrity. And of course, my absolute favorite was the dumpling! I wish I ordered more but I didn't want to overdo it. Honestly, I can't even describe the dumpling. You just have to try it for yourself.
Well worth the wait! Best Chinese food I've had in a long time. The dumplings are to die for!! I can't wait to return to NYC! Chinatown was one of my favorite places!

I liked dining here. Soup dumplings came first then around time we finished dumplings, noodle came out. I like eating crispy noodles and husband likes to drench then in sauce before eating them.

Service was fast. I'd like to return to try different menus!

The food was sooooooo goood. Absolutely amazing definitely my favorite Asian restaurant in all of New York. We ordered the sesame chicken, general tso chicken, Mongolian beef, fried rice and the lo mein. Everything was perfect. Another thing is they only accept cash.

CASH ONLY! They have ATMs on site if needed.

I came with four friends for a Sunday evening dinner. You have to have the whole party there to get seated, and they'll give you a ticket number and ask for contact information.

Food: We ordered the crispy shrimp pan fried noodles, pan fried dumplings, scallion pancakes, beef and broccoli, pork soup dumplings, and crab and pork soup dumplings. The soup dumplings were really good, I usually prefer crab soup dumplings, but I liked the pork soup dumplings here better (but both were very good!). The scallion pancakes and pan fried pork dumplings were also very yummy and cooked well with a nice crisp on the outside. The beef and broccoli was also nice and flavorful, and the beef was tender, but I did expect a bigger portion than what we got. The pan fried noodles were okay, there wasn't a ton of flavor and the water chestnuts and corn had a strong canned flavor. I probably would order everything again except for the pan fried noodles. 

Service: This place was really busy, but we still got our food in a timely manner. I think they could make improvements to their waiting area and process since it's a small area by the doorway and lots of people just huddle around and there's no clear line. A woman cut in front of us when we were waiting at the front by the host table, so that was a bit annoying since there wasn't a very organized system or line.

Stumbled upon this hidden gem when I was adventuring Chinatown and it definitely did not disappoint. The Xia Long Bao with pork was delicious! Very packed when I came here, but totally worth the wait!!

Best Chinese food. I've been coming here for ~10 years. The dumplings taste like you've died and gone to heaven they are the best. I would come here just to get several servings of dumplings to myself and I'd be the happiest person alive. The atmosphere is nothing special and they pack people in by filling every seat, which means you'll be sitting at a table with strangers. However, the food is so good that the atmosphere doesn't even matter and you won't care about the weird couple sitting in front of you. You won't be disappointed-it's a must go to in nyc.

My friend brought me here and it was on my list of places to visit in NY.

She ordered for us. We had the crab and beef (?) soup dumplings. I wasn't  a big fan of the crab but I definitely loved the beef one. It was delicious. 

I would definitely come here again. I hope to find a soup dumpling restaurant where I live.

For some reason I thought this would be just a quick grab joint like many others in Chinatown.  But no, they have a full menu.  It's a sit-down place with communal tables and lots of hustle & bustle.

So you're looking at the menu...where are the soup dumplings you monsters!?!?  Don't you worry child, they offer those up front when they stop by to take orders.  And are totally cool with you only ordering dumplings and disregarding said menu.  You should do this.  

And maybe the pepper shrimp.  Thems boys were good.
Dinkier location but it doesn't matter. The Xiao long bao are great and I always get them. Other good options are any seafood dishes, and some of the noodle dishes as well.
Get the dumplings get some of each pork &crab   always a wait but worth it

cheap good food. their vinegar is different from every other soup dumpling place i've tried. no one can match up to it. Not as clean as I'd like it to be, but you can't expect anything more from a restaurant in chinatown. lines can be long, but it's worth the wait. you might share a table with other customers, but who cares - you're there for the soup dumplings, not the people or ambiance.

The  soup dumplings were good, I can go either or..but the beef with broccoli, pork fried rice and fried chicken was delicious. Now they don't have duck sauce, but you don't need it. The chicken could have used a bit of salt, but went well with the tsing tao beer. Note be prepared to sit with strangers, and its cash only.

Nursing a slight hangover, I finally got the SO to go dim-summing with me, only to learn, a 1-mile walk to Chinatown later, that Joe's Shanghai is NOT a dim sum place at all. Darn it, Yelp keyword search, daaaarn it! Should have done more research! Joe's menu is far more appropriate for a special occasion seafood outing a Chinese family might make than an early morning carbo-soak for the liquor-addled. But all was not lost...

What we DID find was New York's best-reputed soup dumplings. I went with the crab/pork combo. The 8 dumplings that came moments later were tasty--not perfectly chewy, but tantalizing enough to suck down a dozen. The dumplings bleed fatty, oily broth that looks as good as it tastes, and this is definitely the highlight of Joe's dumplings. We decided not to dip into more exotic options, like duck web with celery, but I did get an order of scallion dumplings that was awesome.

Joe's you've definitely thrown down the gauntlet for soup dumplings. There may be a better place for them in this big city of ours, but I haven't found it.

Yes, it is that time of the year where I am to visit my big red apple, NYC...AgAin..
No rain will stop me going to Joe's Shanghai...

Awesome Service: I usually have good luck with the wait. I believe the usual wait is probably 45min to an hour. Everyone that do patiently wait, they know it is worth it. Also, they change our plates frequently and they are very responsive when we 
need service.

This restaurant reminds me I am dinning somewhere in Asia where you may just whine up sharing tables with other patrons which is fine by me because you just end up meeting new folks...

I only come here for the Shanghainese dumplings. We had three orders tonite along with onion pancakes, chicken veggie noodle soup, and spring beans. We also got an appetizer ( jellyfish & cold chicken)

This is the best place in the U. S. other than in Asia or Canada where you can get the Shanghainese dumplings where the skin is quite thin and very juicy.
Delicious, collagen-rich soup dumplings with a filling almost as good as the soup inside.  Do NOT order anything else.  Save your stomach for all the soup dumplings you can eat!

First time back in many years, and I must say, I am very happy with the changes. First off, the food was and still is great. Still the best soup dumplings in the city and some of the best and authentic Shanghainese food I've ever had in the US. The reason why I haven't been back in years was because of the poor service and cleanliness, but that all seems to be fixed now, even on a fairly busy Sunday night. Previously, the tables and chairs were so dirty that I didn't want to sit, the table next to me had a dead fly in their dish, and the waiters/waitresses were rude, aggressive, talked back, and just leave if you asked questions. Luckily I didn't have anything even close to that experience this past weekend. Much cleaner, good lighting, and our waiter helped tremendously with our orders and even cracked some good jokes. Completely changed my mind about the ambiance. 

While the wait can be long, the line moves fast and there are a lot of snacking shops nearby in Chinatown.

Consistently great soup dumplings My favorites are the crab, pork ones.

Try to avoid large groups, it will be a wait. If you do have a large group, make sure everyone is there, or else they will not seat you.

Orange beef is very good, though it could be a little thinner like at Chinatown Brasserie. Most people come for the soup dumplings.

This is a must visit every trip to New York. The best Chinese food anywhere. This place is an experience in itself. The tables are all big and they sit mixed parties together. The food has always been great every time we visit.

Must have:
Pork Soup Dumplings
Scallion Pancakes
Shanghai Noodles
Green Beans
CRISPY BEEF (MUST HAVE)


This place will not disappoint.

NOTE: This place is cash only!! 

Love going here!!! Everything you get is really tasty, though some dishes are a bit on the heavier side because they're a bit greasy. 

You can't go wrong with their xiao long bao! It comes in pork or crab, but both are good! Pork is still going to be my first choice though. Give your xiao long pao a bit of hot chili oil to get a touch of more depth of flavor! 

Crispy pork chops are also real good! Paired with some simple shanghai fried rice is a really good meal. 

I don't mind this place not being the cleanest all the time because I love the food!

Before I do my usual blathering, let me just say that the soup in these soup dumplings is THE BEST I have ever had, hands down. This made it all the more devastating when my second dumpling promptly spilled its treasure into not-my-mouth. (I won't confirm or deny that there were tears.) (ALSO they're CASH-ONLY, don't say I didn't warn you.)

The two of us showed up at the famous Joe's Shanghai around 8/8:30pm on Sunday evening, having worked up a pretty huge appetite. We were given a number and told we could expect to wait about 20 minutes, but 5 minutes later, we were being ushered in by our host without having needed our tickets. We sat down at a table with 3 other parties of 2 (so a table for 8, for those of us who are here to read about food and not to do math). 

Immediately after sitting down, we were asked if we wanted XLB. While my boyfriend was a little bit taken aback by this, having barely looked at the menu himself, I really appreciated this because I know that freshly-made XLB take a while to prepare and I wanted to eat them ASAP. I only hesitated when thinking if I should order 1 or 2 orders of the pork+crab XLB. (8 for $8.25 -- honestly a better deal than I was expecting) SO YUM YUM IN MY TUM TUM you guys. My boyfriend was a bit sad that the skin of the dumplings didn't hold up that well (aka the soup spilled and we cried, I mean, thought about crying but did not do it) but I didn't think it was a big deal at all.

I think we were only slightly miffed that we also ordered a vegetable dish (we had been eating really unhealthily up until then...) and it came out a decent bit after our XLB arrived. We were hoping to nosh on veggies before eating our XLB because we wanted to eat more afterwards... and so we settled on just one order of that delicious soupy goodness. 

Service was brisk but fast. You're not here for individualized attention, folks. You're here for delicious food. Even our simple veggie dish was soooooooooo tasty. Plus, the servers aren't even rude, they're just trying to get as much food to as many people as possible. I thought about that while staring at their wall of celeb photos, one of my favorite things to do while eating in New York.

Worth the hype. Go. Rejoice.

I never thought dumplings could be so amazing! We tried this place last year as part of a NYC food crawl, and I must say this place really opened my eyes.

Non descript storefront in Chinatown didn't prepare me for the great meal to come.  We got there just before the lunch rush and the place filled up fast.

Definitely worth a visit - I wish we had something like this in Los Angeles.

I come here every time I'm in Chinatown and I assure you this place never disappoints. It's tucked away on a side street that's pretty packed. I will admit if you get there around lunch time you will be waiting. Don't be surprised if you have to wait for 30 mins or longer but it will be worth it. 
I always bring people here whether they are from the area or out of state and each time I get the same thankful response. I actually started coming here as a child with my aunt and I've been going for at least 10 years. 
The place is pretty big with individual and family style seating. Usually they mix match groups at family styles which is pretty cool since it allows you to connect with others. 
Service is always fast and courteous. I always order pork soup dumplings along with a scallion pancake and a Tsing Tao. I've known others to order chicken or noodles and those were also amazing. When I got with one other person my bill is always under $20 and that includes tip. Even in a group of six we didn't pay more than $55. Make sure you have cash as they DO NOT take card. Definitely a place to visit when in NY.

The steamed crab and pork dumplings really were delicious!  I ate them for my meal.  Everyone needs to be prepared to pay in cash though.  The menu is pricey and you should have lots of cash on hand.

I ate solo since I was just in town for a couple of days during Spring Break and stayed at a little hotel around the corner.  I went on a Tuesday and there was no wait.  So I suggest staying away from the typical Friday thru Sunday crowded nights.

Let me start by saying that I gave up pork about 10 years ago. It was challenging at first, and often came at the extreme irritation of friends and family. About a month ago I decided to give up my "pork is for dorks" campaign and make the leap back in to swine dining. Here is my tale...

I have a group of old co-workers that when we worked together went on plenty of soup dumpling missions. I always had to sit on the sidelines because they don't make soup dumplings without pork or seafood (which I'm allergic to).  Well, when I decided to dive back into the belly of the beast what better way then to finally partake in a soup dumpling reunion dinner! So we decided on Joe's because allegedly they have the best in the city.  I was surprised at the wait on a Monday night at 8:30, the place was jam packed! For 5 of us we waited about half hour, and we ended up sharing a table with a another couple. The soup dumplings were free flowing (it's one of their signature dishes so they pass them out like candy). OK time for the big jump.................................................
the pork dumplings were good, not amazing. The meat inside was like sausage (I have always disliked sausage from any animal). The soup and the dumpling part were pretty good though. I must say that we got a number of other dishes and they were all quality (that's where 3 stars come in). I'm giving the 4th star for atmosphere, cause I always feel like I'm really in China when I go to Pell street (plus is super close to my favorite teahouse-Teariffic). OOOOh, and they give you the most delicious orange slices after your meal.

All in all the pork dumplings were not worth me sacrificing my chances of getting into the Nation of Islam (that and the fact that I believe Farrakhan is an evil man)

I'll keep you posted on my adventures in Babe-land

HUNGRY HIPPO CHOICE: Scallion pancakes (best I've had)

TIme: Lunch and Dinner

Who: w/ friends (groups no bigger than 4 people)

Price: around $10 per entry

Recommendation: Go here once and try it out. This place is always packed! You will most likely share a table with strangers. Order the dumplings. Basically, they're soup dumplings that explode in your mouth. Eat with caution, but eat with ginger and soy sauce. Use chopsticks, not forks. The goal is to have all the soup in your mouth and not all over your plate and pants. 

Note: This is the NYC's equivalent of Din Tai Fung of Los Angeles or in Shanghai or Taipei. 

Other Info: Cash only. Located next to a go barber shop $7. So if you're feeling fly after you eat, get a haircut. 

Locals: Too packed for comfort. I wouldn't go here after once. 
Tourists: Prepare to wait in line, but give it a try. It's a taste of Asia in NYC. Be careful not to burn yourself...
I am salivating just thinking about Joe's soup dumplings. A required stop every time I'm in NYC.
Yum yum yum!!!!! Wth this place is the good!! Most def worth the wait to get in.. The smell outside is so inviting yummmmmmy!!

*the wait is ridiculous. Come early so you can get a number for a table.
*you know why you're here: soup dumplings!
*their sesame chicken is also very delicious and recommended.

Okay, all the stuff I previously said except now 4 stars because they make the best orange chicken I've ever had in my life.

THE EFFING BEST ORANGE CHICKEN, EVAR!!!
Always a treat to come here when I visit NYC. Good food at a great price. Be prepared to wait during lunch and dinner rush.

Being a man from China and having been to both Midtown and Chinatown Joe Shanghai's, I must say the Chinatown one is a must. Sure it's in a somewhat dirtier neighborhood, the $5 soup dumplings are to die for. They're cheaper and hence more volumous in Chinatown, so you could seriously get like 5 plates for your party and pay a measly $25. 

The only thing is that, I wouldn't get anything else from Joe's Shanghai. It's not known for anything else, and everything else is kinda overpriced for simple vegetables. I kinda see this place as a go to take out place to get bang for buck and instant satisfaction.

Cheap eats, and so worth the wait.

Go inside to grab a ticket and get your name on the list. Then, get back on that sidewalk because the line actually moves fairly quick. It's a very fast-paced restaurant, and you don't wanna miss your spot! Waited about 30 mins. Not bad, very fast wait.

We only ordered 1 order of the pork soup dumplings for $6.75. IT WAS SO DELICIOUS. 8 of these dumplings split between my bf and I, was just enough to satisfy (looking back, I wish I ordered more, but that is the gluttony talking!!!). Sit down, and take a good moment to enjoy these delicious things. 

The soy sauce mixture is a little reminiscent of vinegar, but I thought it was tasty spooned on top of the dumplings. Or you can eat them plain. Your preference!

A must-try and must-stop for every NY trip.

Shout out to my 16 yr old niece who suggested we go. She really likes their soup dumplings and I see why. We got the pork filled dumpling which isn't overly seasoned, yet still very flavorful. I'll warn you as she warned me, be careful when biting into it b/c the liquid inside is hot. 

We also got the scallion pancake  (really good), shrimp fried rice (good and generous amount of shrimp, and the General Tso (good). It was a lot of food for two people, which we quickly realized as we got full and realized what little space there was at our table. Being just the two of us, were seated at a table with a lovely party of 3, who like us.... had eyes bigger than their stomachs (they ordered a lot too). 

The space and location... I have to say I like. It's on an extremely narrow street and very tight inside.  The decor isn't fancy, but what they have going on looks fine, clean, and the pics, awards, articles on the walls are a testament to how good they are. Plus, with so many people waiting to get in (despite it being crowded) is another good sign that's it's worth it. Only downside, not once did anyone stop by to refill waters or see if we wanted more drinks. 

TIPS: They only take cash. They only seat you once your entire group is present. A 15% service charge/tip is automatically added to bill. When you arrive immediately find the host with the clipboard, you're name won't be added to the list, but your group size will and you'll get a #.

Great spot in Chinatown for some very good food. The soup dumplings are a thing to behold. Make sure you pick them up the right way or you will ruin one and look like a tourist in the process.  Getting here pretty much any time after opening means waiting for a table.  If you are just a small group, you may be seated with other people. Not very big inside. Service is quick and helpful. They are pretty organized in running things from what I've seen and have never had a problem with our orders.  Worth making a stop here for next fix of Chinese food.

Okay 2 words SOUP DUMPLING are amazing! They are just the balance of savory and yum! The place is small and fast. They even might sit you at a table with other people, it's ok just be friendly plus they might even give you some helpful suggestions like us! We had the soup dumplings are a must do not pass up these pillowy purses of broth and pork (just watch you don't burn your mouth they come out pipping hot). I had soup and my friends had pan fried noodles, both very tasty. The people next to us had the salt and pepper shrimp  they looked so deliciously crispy!! I'm totally getting g the next time. 
I was a little nervous reading some of the other reviews that didn't rave about this place, but to each is own, right!! My friends and I loved it, great food, good service, and great prices!! Oh beer and wine only! Enjoy! Tip: not sure how to eat a soup dumpling look around the room and you'll be a pro in no time.

So good!!! Had read good reviews of this place and wanted to go while we were in NY, it was an hour wait but it's near some cool bars so we just went and got drinks while we waited. Got the soup dumplings and orange chicken-both were amazing! The service was good and the food came surprisingly fast. 10/10 would recommend
Pretty good Crab and Pork Xiao Long Bao. As someone from LA, I still prefer the Din Tai Fung on the west coast. Look forward to try other dishes next time I'm in NYC.

i'll echo everyone else's reviews and recommend the pork and the crab/pork soup dumplings! c'mon, 8 pork soup dumplings for under $5?? SCORE!

we showed up wednesday night around 9pm and got lucky that we didn't have to wait in any lines. they did start seating other groups with strangers if there was room at the table. lucky for us we were a group of 4 with our own table=P.

we ordered the typical pork soup dumplings, pork/crab soup dumplings, scallion pancake, shanghai fried flat noodle, & the pork fried rice. not sure if it was bc we were tired from all the walking we did, but the food just hit the right spot for all of us. haha greasy chinese food after a tiring night is always the best!

i should say though i much prefer the soup dumplings back home at Din Tai Fung in Arcadia.  For those of you visiting so cal and in search of some awesome soup dumplings...Din Tai Fung all the way. the soup dumplings here are wrapped more thinly with a bit more flavor. though joe's shanghai is really well priced for what they do offer.

remember..Cash Only!

THE BEST SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS IN THE US!
I may be a bit biased because this is the first restaurant that I had shanghai dumplings, so it has a special place in my heart. However, I have gone on a search for good dumplings on the west coast, tried shanghai dumpling king, tried din tai fung, still nothing compares. Not to mention that their pricing is UNBEATABLE! You can order a couple of orders of the dumplings +chow mein for less than $20! The only bad part is that there is a very long wait, so be sure to get there early or you'll be waiting 45+ mins in the Quicklys next door. The do sit multiple parties in a large table to conserve space, so if you're claustrophobic, you better get over your fears because these dumplings are worth it!

this place is perfect so please dont go cause i dont want to share soup dumplings or wait on line behind you to get them. the seasonal vegetables are good too. salty and soupy and perfect. but the dumplings.

Great soup dumplings. I was ecstatic when I got on a Cathay Pacific flight and they served them in business class. Made the 20-hour flight that much better.

I've had the other entrees here and it's pretty standard. Go for the soup dumplings.

Good lord these are amazing and there's NO competition. I always end up ordering a non soup dumpling option and regret it, so just stick to #1 and #2 on the menu and you can't go wrong. If you HAVE to order something on the side get lo mein or the General Tsos. Also help yourself to the unlimited tea.

This is not the Joe's I remember on Doyer.  This new Bowery location is modern and spacious.  Soup dumplings remain above par.  The've got a nice amount of soup inside medium thickness wrappers.  Joes is the only place in CTown I know that also serves a delicious braised tofu over a bed of steamed spinach.

Every single time I visit NYC, I make it a point to stop at Joe's Shanghai. Yes, you'll have to wait, but it's SO worth it. Basically, you put your name down and wait for your name to be called. No fancy pager system, they're keeping it old school. Usually they're pretty spot on with their time estimate, so I'll walk around, get a massage, have a pre-meal treat and still get back with enough time to stand around and wait.

My go-to order is scallion pancakes, soup dumplings and chicken lo mein. Everything is incredible, but the juicy soup dumplings are really the star of the show. The service is HELLA quick because they're trying to get people in and out as fast as possible. And, I appreciate that. If after waiting an hour, you don't know what you want, you're doing it wrong.

They bring out orange slices with your check, which is a fun little touch. Be warned that this spot is CASH ONLY, so come prepared.

I didn't understand stand why people love Xiao Long Bao before until I had the best one at Joe's Shanghai. The dumpling and the soup inside was amazingly delicious. All the staff were also very helpful and nice.
Awesome xiaolongbao! I go there almost every month for the xiaolongbao. Double fried noodle is good too!

Heard that Joes was the spot famous for Dumplings and after the reviews decided to check it out.

It was a bit hard to located as I didn't know my way around Chinatown well. The sitting in the place is interesting as you have to share the table with random people. 

The food here is pretty good and portions are pretty large and the price isnt too bad. Recommend it but its average compared to L.A. joints.

Got the soup dumplings and I have to say, I prefer the pork over the crab. Really good soup dumplings!!!! So much soup in each dumpling. We got some more food on the side and it wasn't as good. The shanghai fried rice is very plain, and the green beans could've had some more frying in the pan (they were soggy and a little bland). 

Appreciated the fast service so that they can get you in and out fast.

Soup dumplings are awesome... I like the scallion pancakes, mapo tofu and veggies too.

I saw John Noble, the crazy scientist from Fringe here. He likes the soup dumplings too!

Came here when it was raining outside and they got me and my girlfriend seated quickly. They have a lot of workers doing different jobs to allow for quick service. As soon as we sat down a server came by and we put in a order for the xiao long bao. They served us water and in about 15minutes our first order came out and we put in an order for the deep fried pork chops and fried rice. The xiao long bao was pretty good and very cheap! The deep fried pork chops and fried rice was good. If you are in a hurry and just want some warm food to pass the cold weather they do a good job on getting people in and out. I would come back here but maybe just order 4 orders of the xiao long bao.

We came here with our NY native cousins, Sophia and Vivian, for lunch during our summer vacation. OH MY GOD!!!  Dumplings are delicious!  Our 3 kids couldnt get enough.  We must of gone through 6 or 7 trays of dumplings.  Our 9 year old daughter (picky eater) was scooping the drippings from her plate!  We also had the crispy deep fried noodles, that was very good as well. This place gets packed!  So make sure you get there early!

The nyc gold standard for xlb.  My first bite completely scalded the inside of my mouth which was embarassing as 20 plus strangers are seated with you at a large table staring at each other, yet it was still delicious.   Wait was long but worth it.

Why are you here other than the fact that you are coming for their famous soup dumplings? If it's to be around the street with a history of chinese gang shootings, then continue along. Otherwise, come here for shanghai food! 

Super fast, quick paced and good turnover for seats, I luckily didn't have to wait on a weekday before 7 PM. Past 7, there were lines that were starting to form. 

XLB: I LOVE IT. Great huge XLB with plenty of soup in it. Stellar, worth it. I really enjoy the regular XLB versus the other variations. 
Scallion Pancakes: Damn freshly fried pancakes, you do me in. Love it, definitely a great appetizer. 
Shanghai Rice Cakes: Ahh.. this is sounding repetitive. Delicious and tasty. Only thing were the noodles were a bit on the oily side. 
Broad Noodles: Also quite delicious - plenty of pork mixed in with the noodles.
