Szechuan Style String Beans: I loved these. Other places I went to do an ok job with this dish, but damn was this amazing. While I loved all the food I ate here, this was actually my standout dish. 

Loved eating here, sadly I can't just come here everyday. Overall, it isn't that overly expensive for their food and drinks. 

RUN HERE.

Let me caveat by saying that the five stars are for the Soup Dumplings ONLY. If i never have to eat anything else, I'll have Soup Dumplings the rest of my life, with ginger and whatever is in that soy sauce they give u at the table. i've gone to the one in Flushing at least 5 times in the past two years, and the last two times I was there, I brought one group of ladies from toronto and they said "Hey! I've heard about this place!" they're from toronto!!! 

I also had the fried eggplant, which was served in half a cup of greasy frying oil. oil aside, the eggplants were very very good as well. 

The beef noodle soup is my go to dish at any chinese restaurant, but the soup they serve at Joe's is always toooo salty for my liking. 

Make sure you get there before/after the lunch/dinner rush or else you could be waiting up to an hour for a table. 

And also, this restaurant is VERY foreigner friendly. At any point in time there is almost a 50/50 split of consumers who are Asian and all other. :) enjoy!

After wandering around Chinatown deciding where to eat, we happened upon Joe's Shanghai and decided to take a friend's suggestion to eat here. Obviously, the soup dumplings were the thing to try, and so we did. My vegetarian friend told us that from her non-veggie days, the crab ones were the one to go for. I don't really like seafood, but I thought that crab would be relatively safe. SO FISHY OMG. I like the soup dumpling experience, but the crab was over the top fishy for me. Next time I will go for pork.

Vegetarians: The mixed vegetables with bean curd was INCREDIBLE. I've had my share of bean curd, but this was by far the best I have ever had. It was totally saturated with the sauce, but perfectly crunchy on the ends. Mmmmmm.

I can't say that I loved the scallion pancakes. They were fairly average.

But seriously. The mixed vegetables and bean curd. The underdog at Joe's Shanghai. Get it in addition to your soup dumplings.

SEXY SOUPY XIAOLONG BAO!!! We went for lunch and the wait was pretty short. Great noisy Asian place to spend with your great noisy Asian family. The staff was fast and the dumplings...OH MAH GAWD the dumplings were hot and fresh. I loved how the skin was so saggy because the filling produced so much soup while they were being steamed. The dumpling skin had a nice chewiness to the texture. mmm I will eat you when I come back.

My tastebuds have tried the best XLBs this world could offer. From the ones in Shanghai to Taiwan, and even to CA, my tastebuds have gracefully had them all.

This resturant is a bit different. First of all, it's super popular so there is a line and they do not take reservations. Second, you'll meet someone new as the tables are all communal. We waited about 30 mins for lunch.

Price: About $10 per dish

Food: The XLB here are bigger than the ones I have had and the skin is a little thicker (which is not my preference), but the flavor is kicking. Each bite is full of flavor and it takes multiple bites for these XLB. The MUST order dishes are the original pork XLB and the crab and pork XLB.

Service: They are super busy, but it's just like any other Asian restaurant.

Joe's Shanghai is a lot of fun.  It feels very "authentic" (whatever that word means these days).  I am Chinese and have had a lot of dumplings and xiao long boa in my life (including in Shanghai), so I can't say that the dumplings and XLB were the best I've ever had.  However, they were definitely yummy, and I would go back (and wait in line).  The service is quick (though not friendly, but what can you expect from a Chinese restaurant).  

One thing that was off-putting was the smell when you walk in - the sour smell was confusing.  It was either the smell of feet on a hot summer day OR the smell of the red vinegar you put on the dumplings.  I chose to think it was the dumpling vinegar.

I wish I lived in NY just so I could eat here every weekend. By far the best Chinese food I've ever had. You won't be dining in for the experience or the ambiance but the food makes up for it tenfold! You walk in, take a number for the hostess, and wait outside. Don't be frightened by the amount of people waiting outside, our wait went by really fast. (10 minutes or so). You sit at a table with other diners so there won't be any privacy. We ordered the scallion pancakes, pork dumplings, and shanghai noodles. All were AMAZING! It was my first time at a restaurant like this so my bf and I didn't know the way to eat the dumplings. You place them in the soup spoon so that the broth ends up in the spoon instead of your plate. Mmmmm they were sooo delicious!!! I hope to go back the next time I'm in NY!
The soup dumplings are really great, and the prices are not bad.  Eight bucks with tax and tip gets you an amazing meal!

It was such an ordeal trying to find this place at ten o'clock at night. Traveling the streets of N.Y. with two 70 yr olds, one 7 yr old & two republicans was not easy. Starving for great Chinese food someone had suggested & trying to meet our cousins..... But in the end - WELL WORTH THE JOURNEY.  If you crave good authentic Chinese food, this is the place. No B.S. just good food. For you first timers, try the soup dumplings, they're sooooo worth it!
Delicious and affordable comfort food! Yummy juicy buns. The customer service is not too impressive but most Chinese restaurants don't offer good customer service especially if their food is good.

This is in my top 3 places to take people when they come to the city from out of town.

I hate to be repetitive but...

SOUP.  DUMPLINGS.

There is simply no comparison.  I was skeptical at first but after my first bite I was in love.  I am not a big guy but I can finish an entire helping by myself (if you've been there you know that's terribly gluttonous).  

I LOVE that the servers scowl at you if you don't start with the soup dumplings.  So awesome.

Everything I have ever had here is good.  The noodles are good.  The standards (Kung Pow, Tso's) are good.  The crazy stuff is good.  Just a fantastic all-around Chinese restaurant.

I do hate that they don't take reservations and sometimes the wait is a bit... well... just whets my appetite more to be honest with you.

I gotta say, though, why won't these darn places start taking credit cards?  Hit an ATM before you go because they are cash only!

Well this place is a hidden gem of Chinatown! I mean I'm sure it's famous but you have to enter through  like an alley to get here so it makes you feel like you know a great place. When you come in, it's family style seating, which mean you sit a big table with Probably 2 other couples who just got there or just finishing up. Which is kinda awkward of you all order the same thing and forget which one is yours. The Xiao long bao here is is sooo good! One of the best I've had! The lions head is also very very very good! It's sooo juicy and rich, I had to ask for a bowl of rice to counter the flavors. We ended up taking most of it to go and ate it back at the hotel. Also still all very good!

We went on a Saturday morning for brunch. The place was empty. We realized after being seated that this was a CASH only place. How inconvenient!  Had I known we would have gone to another place that took credit card payment. 

You get menus to order. There isn't much of a dumpling selection. We asked the table next to us what they would recommend. We ordered the pork soup dumplings, the pan fried dumplings, sesame noodles and scallion pancake. Nothing amazing but it was good in its simplicity. I recommend going in with an open mind, cash and set no expectations.  The food is simple and tasty. 

My friend said that the place looks renovated. The design is simple and clean. Good lighting. Clean floors.

The best soup dumplings ever!! A must go when in Chinatown NYC!!! But it can get packed so you will most likely sit next to random people!! But by the time you taste the dumpling... You'll forget your name.!!
The dumplings to start off we're excellent! Apparently very popular as well. Followed the dumplings up with some general tso's chicken and crunchy shredded beef. It was a highly satisfying meal.

I love going to Asian restaurants and a bunch of us dropped by here. The staff is nice enough and there's a casual, relax vibe to the place. You may have to share a table with strangers, huge plus in my book. Like the wise man in the van said, strangers are just friends you haven't met yet.

Go with the soup dumplings, there are different varieties but the ones I had are great. Juicy with nice flavors. I'm told they're translated to "little dragon buns" . . . All in all, a great stop for a visit. Thank you, I'll come again.
Awesome soup dumplings. Excellent sesame chicken as well. Generous portions for everything!
Awesome dumplings! We got the General Tso's and some white rice. Food was fast, fresh, and delicious!
Soup dumplings and their lo mein is some of the best i have ever had.  Be prepared for a line though!

I'll never understand why there is a huge line in almost every good-looking restaurant in the US, however the food was worth the wait (almost 1 hour in the cold). People were just so brain-frozen to even think of the food they wanna eat after they finally got inside. The service is quick and they serve you with some hot tea which is great. Pork dumplings are very delicious and the portions of other orders are pretty big for a person. Good pricing as well. Loved the place all in all.

Best soup dumplings ever.  My wife and I come here all the time.  Get the crab ones  they have way more flavor then the plain pork.  The best thing about this place is getting seated with complete strangers.  My wife hates it, but I love watching the rookies.  It's so funny to see people take a burning hot dumpling with boiling hot soup and shove the whole thing in their mouth.  Watching them spit it out is just too much.  Watching people trying to chew it back instead of spitting it out is even better.  They start tearing up and the only thing in arms reach is hot tea.  People walk out of this place with no taste buds and double tip for third degree burns.  Just remember the tip is included.

Amazing food but a little crowded. 

We tried out this place on our first visit in NYC. Like all other places we have come to learn....its quite crowded. We waited about 15 minutes at 10 pm at night which is really fast. We were seated at a large table which threw me off and made me feel slightly uncomfortable. Don't get me wrong, i love getting to know new people but with Chinese food - my husband and I order a few different dishes and the table was crowded. I also get anxiety so this was just not the best eating experience which ultimately led to us eating half our food and packing up the rest to eat at the hotel. 

The food was amazing!! We ordered the scallion pancake which was perfect! We ordered the soup dumpings which were soo yummy. We also ordered the vegetable fried rice and General Tso chicken which so full of flavor and crispy. All of the food was delicious.  My recommends would be to definetly try this place out and if the crowds are not your thing try going during the week.
Bring cash! Fill your belly with lots of delicious food. Fun time all around. Great spot to share with friends.

This place is the mecca of pork soup dumplings. Came to this place twice during our recent NYC trip.  These dumplings have plenty of soup in each one, so care needs to be had when enjoying these.

Don't expect great decor or friendly service. Cash only...so be prepared.

great soup dumplings and they got models as waiters. the duck was nothing special but their crispy chicken was great. the skin on the soup dumpling was pretty thick compared to other places. pancakes and noodles were pretty solid

Excellent soup dumplings .  The wait for a table can be rather long though.  They do have a large selection of wonderful dishes besides soup dumplings. If you are into meat, get the shank!  Big, a little fatty but delicious!!!  This place is one of our family's favorites

Excellent Shanghai dumplings! A very full bodied broth coupled with a meatball filling, the xlb is exactly what you'd expect from a Shanghai dumpling place.

My girlfriend, her friend, and I navigated through Chinatown to find this place so I could try it! (I'm from California, so east coast eateries were my main conquest for this trip) I was not disappointed. I ate until I could eat no more. Joe's Shanghai is a must have if you're ever in Chinatown.

FIVE STARS FIVE STARS FIVE STARS! Like Chinese saying, if smth is important, you must say it 3 times!

I'm not going to comment on their other dishes. They are good and decent, but you get those dishes anywhere in a regular chinese restaurant. So I'm going to skip reviewing on those dishes. 

BUT BAM! SOUP DUMPLINGS! OMG. THESE SOUP DUMPLINGS ARE SUPER BOMB ASS SOUP DUMPLINGS i am running out of words to describe how good they are. Not only they are cheap ass budget friendly very affordable unlike some restaurant(s), they are also HUGE in size (tbh i think that's americanized, but its a good modification imo ;P). And on top of that, they just simply taste great! 

The soup just rushes out as you bite into it, and THAT IS HOW SOUP DUMPLINGS SHOULD BE! The skin is very thin and saggy, EXACTLY HOW GOOD SOUP DUMPLINGS SHOULD BE. There's plenty of air room inside the dumpling, and lots of soup contained inside, with a decent amount of meat. THAT'S HOW SOUP DUMPLINGS SHOULD BE.

Yes, I repeat many times! Soup dumplings are NOT supposed to have thick skins! many places have this mistake, where they make thick ass soup dumpling skins, which just kills the entire dish. Also thick skin means not enough soup inside, unless they are very stingy on their meat... 

I certainly do not want to go to Ding Tai Fung anymore after coming to this place for soup dumplings. I was only in NYC for 5 nights, and I HAD to come here for two dinners because I just fell in love with their soup dumplings.

If I'm visiting NYC again, I'm definitely coming back for another round of 30 soup dumplings hehe :P

Really, what is the point of telling you what you already know? 

Shanghai dumplings / xiao long bao / those ones with the soup in it / just try it already dang it!

Don't be all annoying and try and order other dishes (maybe a veggie one or two just to help things along.)  I can make an entire meal of the happiness and so can you - just beware burned tongues!

I hope someday to date someone who loves dumplings as much as me - is that too much information?

The dumplings were AWESOME! We got both soup dumplings. The service was loud. I also saw Kevin from Top Chef! which gave the experience a big plus. Other than that, we were situated with another family (awkward). They expect you to order as FAST as possible. We had to wade off waiters asking us multiple times that we weren't sure what to get. The food was pretty good (not extraordinary good), but the soup dumplings were one of my favorite experiences in New York. Price was reasonable, but I would totally come here again, even if it means sitting with another family.

I've been here twice in the last few months and they are great!!! Best soup dumplings outside of Shanghai. The price is also really good. You will often have to sit with others and they don't take reservations so that might be a drawback for some folks. Overall if you want great food, cheap prices, check this place out

I Could live off of their soup dumplings, they truly are delicious! The meat is well cooked and the broth is light but richly flavored.  
The rest of the menu is averagely priced and good but nothing worth fussing over. If you like Asian food and love soup dumplings then this is the spot for you. 
Do expect a possible 20 minute wait if you go in the evening on a weekend, and a possible wait weekday evenings too. 
But I'll say it's worth the wait if you've never been there just to give their dumplings a try. However if you want a full meal worth raving over I'd suggest going in the day just for the dumplings.

Please get the soup dumplings! Never would I have thought shrimp and pork would mix, but boy oh boy was I missing out! Make sure to poke a whole and let the steam out before biting into them, or you'll be in for a hot surprise ;-) 

Also tried their fish and dry noodles (forgot to snap a pic) and they were both delicious! If you're in the area make sure to stop by!

Had to check it out about reading reviews online and in Yelp. I ordered pork soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. The scallion pancakes were surprisingly good, while the soup dumplings did live up to the hype. Expect a long wait if you eating in groups of 2 or more. It's also very cramped inside so they might places multiple groups in the same table.

Oh my!  How I love these xia long bao -- Shanghai Soup Dumplings!   
Just wish I could find some coming even close in San Francisco!  

You order one pork, one shrimp the minute you sit down.  Then look at the menu, see what else sounds good and order something else once the dumplings are delivered.  

Eat carefully -- your tongue will be scalded forever from the piping hot delicious broth nestled inside each delicate dumpling.  

If you don't want to wait, go during an off-hour. Get there at 2 or 3 p.m. and you'll be seated right away, sometimes sharing a big round table with others already there.  

After you eat here, walk down Pell towards Chinatown, and on the corner is the oldest continuing shop in Chinatown -- it is chock-full of wonderful curios and the owners are delightful.  Prices are great too.
Soup dumplings were great,  and the other items were good. Nothing outstanding, but satisfying nonetheless. The restaurant was nice, clean and service was fast. Don't forget it's cash only.

Cash only. Get your soup dumplings here. The seating is group style,  and encourages sharing.  Other than soup dumplings, another favorite is jellyfish.  It looks like onions and tastes smokey and ligament like. Not a gooey taste but still pretty good cold app. For the main dish besides the dumplings I got chicken and broccoli which a lot of others were getting too . Overall, worth the trek to Chinatown.

Soup dumplings are delicious-but the real star here is the Chinese food. Best Lo mein and crispy beef I've ever had. Tight dining room with some communal tables-but my husband and I actually met some very cool exchange student from Italy! No frills, but so very worth the wait.
The reviews don't lie. Amazing food. Great place to try when in Chinatown. It was packed so you know the food is good! Bring cash, it's cash only!

Best Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.
They just moved from their historic location and opened a new place around the block with a renewed and eye-catching style.
When it comes to these things I still prefer the old and ugly looking space that almost feels unwelcoming but that's still gives the authentic Chinatown experience. But that's my personal and obviously nostalgic opinion and it doesn't matter.
So, please order the soup dumplings, they are the best ever.

Chicken and shrimp in plum sauce! Gosh, I want to eat that again right now. I came here last weekend on Saturday at an odd 4:30 time. It was surprisingly packed, but only had to wait 10 minutes for seating. 

The service was extremely quick and the food is just so good. Soup dumplings are of course a must have here. You are seated at your table and the first thing the waiter asks you is if you want soup dumplings. Just say yes. The shanghai noodles were delicious too.
You have to come here for the soup dumplings!  If you don't, you haven't really lived life to its fullest!
Great soup dumplings!  We made mistake to order other items off their menu.  We should have only order their amazing soup dumplings because we felt everything else was just okay in comparison.
Best soup dumpling in NYC. Go early for a shorter wait and order soup dumplings as soon as you get to your seats. If you have room get the scallion pancake as well.

This place is not hard to miss. There wasn't a long line when we went (around 8pm on a Saturday night) but we waited at least 20 minutes to be seated. It was so crowded that they will seat you in a big table with other people you don't know. It was also stuffy. I couldn't breath that good.

We ordered the famous Xiao Long Bao (pork and crab) - which was the best dumplings I've ever had! Soooo good I wanted more!!! I also love the yang chow (spelling?) that we ordered. The prices were also cheap. 

Prepare to bring cash. They only accept cash.

Let me make this clear,  this four stars are for the the Shanghai dumplings only.  Now with that said,  in to the review.  

This place is known for their dumplings so it was a no brainer to stop here since I was in NYC for the week (so sad that it was only a week,  oh why can't I be richer! ?) 

We ordered the dumplings, Shanghai noodles and red bean flat cake thingy (I forget what it was called exactly). The dumplings were as praised. They were huge,  full with soup, and everything about them was good.  The rest of our food was pretty bad.  The noodle and red beam cake were so oily and tasteless that we didn't even care to finish them. 

After l leaving all I could think about was how stupid I was for not ordering just the dumplings but instead wasted my stomach room for crappy middle and red bean cake.  So the very next day I came back for more,  except this time I only ordered the dumplings.  I'm so proud of myself lol

If you are a fan of Shanghai dumplings then this is the place to go!  Also they charge a 15% service fee on everything regardless of your party size or how much you order.

Already a regular of Joe's Shanghai although I've only been here a month, I'm always after the scallion pancakes and soup dumplings! 

Though the skin on the soup dumplings could be a bit thinner for the true soup dumpling texture and taste that I so enjoy, Joe's Shanghai has its own spin on it - there's so much soup packed into each one, and a generous amount of filling/meat in each one too! And at its price in a place like New York (8 soup dumplings for ~$8-9), it really can't get better than this. The scallion pancakes are another favorite dish of mine, partially because of the delicious sweet sauce that they use with it too! They're also really affordable, at around $5 for a stacked plate. Joe's Shanghai has a very modest storefront and only accepts cash, but there's always a line out the door waiting to be seated during peak lunch and dinner hours. I've already taken my friends and my boyfriend here to visit, and they've all loved it. 

Great service and quality of food - I'd definitely come back again!

This was the highlight of my trip to NY. The food was so flavorful and fresh. The beef and rice cake was very yummy and the pan fried vegetable noodles were delicious. 

We ordered the pork soup dumplings. The broth was so rich and savory, it was mind blowing.  I can't get that flavor out of my head it was so good. This will be a tradition for me when in NY. Bravo!!!

The most iconic Chinese restaurant in chinatown by far! The food is always amazing, best beef with broccoli in Manhattan and the soup dumplings are amazing! Staff is usually curt, but it doesn't matter because the food is always sooooo good! The soup dumplings are cheap but sometimes other things on the menu can be pricey for no reason!

Not much new to add. Most of the dishes we ordered were fairly standard, and the staff certainly wants to move you in and out. Now to thier claim to fame, the soup dumplings. The pork dumplings were delish and the crab dumplings were superb.  A must try if you're out in New York.

After waiting in line outside for a half hour to try out Joes, we walked into a very cool, high energy environment. The entire restaurant(which holds about 115 people) is communal seating. I believe 9 people fit at a round table inside. We immediately ordered the soup dumplings which are an obvious MUST. They were perfectly cooked and bursting with warm soup inside! We also had the kung pao chicken which was great and the Lo mein(PHENOMENAL)! We will def be back!

I'm torn on how to approach this review.  On one hand, the place is cramped and you never get a whole table to yourself.  Also your entire party needs to be present at time of seating, which I'll forgive due to their busy nature.  They take cash only.  And finally, there is virtually no foyer so in the dead of winter you are stuck waiting outside for your number to be called while your fingers and toes scream for mercy.

On the other hand, it's delicious.  The xiao long tang bao's (pork, don't waste your money on the crab ones) should be eaten rapidly - not only because it tastes better hot, but to compete savagely for the last dumpling.  I always leave this place with my jeans unbuttoned.

Other noteworthy dishes: shanghai noodles, string beans w/ pork (rice not included)

(This review is based on the skins & soup of the xiao long bao [soup dumplings] alone.)

Located on a tiny street in Chinatown and famous for its xiao long bao. Unfortunately for me, they did not have a pork or crab substitute (since I can't eat either of those), so my friends generously donated 4 of the skins to me. So from what I tasted, it was good, but I really wish I could have tried it for real.

The restaurant was extremely crowded because everyone loves this place, so we waited out at least half an hour in the Chinese snack shop down the street and ate a bunch of samples before coming here.

This place is really worth the hype. Usually I don't think that way about places and think they are overrated, but not this place. I think it's also because I went on a Monday when there wasn't a huge crowd. We actually got seated right away and were served promptly. You go for the soup dumplings of course. The menu is a bit confusing as it doesn't actually say "soup dumplings" but if you just ask them for the soup dumplings they'll explain it to you. If you are in the mood and craving something warm this is definitely the place!

After dinner in Chinatown failed the previous night, I planned to try Joe's Shanghai.
But, I was too lazy to head back downtown.
Scrolling through Yelp, I discovered that Joe's has a second location at 56th street, only a few blocks from my hotel.
Upon arrival, I feared that the waiting line would subvert my revised plan.
The polite hostess informed me that I could be seated - in 45 minutes.
However, after less than 10 minutes I was at an upstairs table.
Service is on-the-spot.
Multiple members of the staff attending to several tables at once.
Likely to guarantee fast turnover and maximize service.
However, at no time were they rude or pushy, just immediate and attentive.
I started with pork bun (soup) dumplings.
Very good.
A tasty broth surrounding seasoned pork in a doughy wrap.
6 to an order; sizable and satisfying. 
I followed with an order of Szechuan string beans with minced pork and clams in black bean sauce.
Both platters were fresh and hot; prepared well and tastily seasoned.
The meal more than redeemed my craving for good chinese food.
Prices on the higher side, I was not put off because (1) I got a table quickly during dinner hour on a Saturday night; and (2) it was good food with good service.
Good possibility I would be back during my next trip. 


Returned twice more.
Each time the food is as good as expected.
And, service is always excellent.
Recommended!!

A totally unnecessary review since Joe's is (in)famous, but just to put it in writing: sit down, don't ask many questions (prepare to feel rushed/confused), but order so many soup dumplings. Rinse and repeat. Joe's is perfect.

Thought the meat dumplings filled with spoon size soup were delicious and will revisit soon. Only wish, I had known about the restaurant's unusual practice of including 15% tip on the bill- Won't double tip next time, thanks to yelpers.

I had been craving good Xiao Long Boa (steamed soup dumplings) for sooo long. There is nothing on the west coast that has impressed me so far, so I was excited to come here when we had a chance to visit New York. 

This place came highly recommended by my friend. She comes here every time she comes to New York. And it did not disappoint. 

I was surprised to find no long line-up like the reviews suggest (we were there on a Saturday 11:30 seating), however, it was lightly raining outside. 

We were seated with a bunch of strangers (reminds me of asia!) and proceeded to order the soup dumplings (SOO juicy), onion pancakes, and a soup based noodle that I can't remember anymore. 

Top it all off, it's super cheap! YAY! So satisfying.
The soup dumplings are a must!!! I also love the fried rice, being from the West Coast it is difficult to find the right flavor for fried rice in NYC and this place nailed it!
It gets busy late afternoon but I know why now. Im not a Chinese food expert but it's probably one of the best meals I've had in a Chinese restaurant.

So I came here last weekend with 10 people and they seated us still pretty quickly. Our table of five ordered two orders of dumplings, two orders of cripsy noodles, two orders and scallion pancakes, and an order of sauteed rice cakes.

Ending bill plus tip - $11 each! Ridiculous!!! Sooo much food, so good, served piping hot, quick service, in and out in less than 30 minutes. You cannot beat this place.

Best idea for Thanksgiving dinner yet. When we arrived around 6:00 we received #40 as our ticket. Twenty minutes later my daughter and I were seated. While we waited we got to speak to the other people also waiting. Several got in line before realizing Joe's is cash only! 

We ordered the scallion bread appetizer and it was really tasty. For dinner we ordered Shrimp with broccoli. Usually when I've had this dish there's so much broccoli and very little shrimp. Not the case with Joe's. And we ordered saut√©ed Shrimp. Both came with water, hot tea and white rice. 

All of the food was amazing and the portions were enough for two meals. Great leftovers!!! And the check for $44.00 was not bad at all for a party of two who didn't have dessert or beverage. 

Will be adding Joe's Shanghai to my list of favorites.

Pretty good xiao long bao at a price that was definitely right.

As a tip, they line is sort of long and if it's cold outside that sucks. It was cold outside today.

Don't bother with the pork and crab xlb, they don't use much crab so it doesn't taste appreciably different.

Don't bother with anything besides the xlb. Their spicy fish and cold noodles were pretty meh. not necc bad but like most xlb places this is the only dish they can really make well so don't fight nature, just get that.
Got some steamed soup dumplings at the OG. The juice is so thick and savory. Price and ambience is also fun

Wow, who knew soup dumplings could be this HUGE? Not as in the latest rage, but twice the size that I normally have?

My friend and I have a love for xiao long bao, and we trekked through Chinatown for her favorite spot, Joe's Shanghai. It ended up being one of my favorite meals during my 4 day trip in NYC. She had told me there usually is a wait, but getting here around noon on a Saturday, we were seated right away. It's a pretty small restaurant, but has about 20 tables. What weirded me out at first was you share tables. So our table of 5 consisted of 2 parties of 2.

We ordered the scallion pancake and the crab and pork meat soup dumplings. It took some time, but man was it worth the wait! The scallion pancake was PERECT. nicely fried, and not super thin like other places i've had. Ive only had pork XLB's, so the scent of the crab was not so pleasant to me (i like crab though). So I went ahead and ordered the pork ones. Exepct about 10-15 minute wait.

These huge dumplings are oozing with soup and yummy pork filling. Since they're so big, I could not even finish the 8 pieces. I got to about 5, and by then, they were so cooled down that it didnt have that irresistible flavor to me as much anymore. I think if I ate them before the scallion pancake, I would've inhaled them all up like no thing. I believe a set of 8 ranges from $5 to $8 which is not bad! They only have the two options, and it's cash only.
Dumplings were delicious. Recommend the crab & pork. Scallion pancakes were my favorite!! Highly recommend

Describing Joe's Shanghai as "magnificent" is an understatement. My brother ordered our meal, which consisted of pork steamed dumplings (pictured), string beans, fried rice & pork, and general tso's chicken. Each dish brought a distinct set of flavor that simply can't be replicated. 5/5 stars.
Food was great! The servings are pretty large especially the rice. The orange slices at the end of the meal are a nice touch.

Dined: 9-25-18
Lunch

It was raining and we were in Chinatown, very HUNGRY! I wanted to try an authentic Chinese food restaurant because we were in NEW YORK!!  We came across this restaurant and decided to eat lunch.  It was very crowded, so there was a wait.  The host asked if we wanted to share a table with another couple. At first, we declined because we preferred our own table...but after waiting for another 10-15 minutes, we agreed to share. I mean come on, it was pouring outside, we were hungry af, let's just EAT!  We ordered their famous pork soup dumplings, like everybody else in the restaurant. The dumplings were so juicy and flavorful! We also ordered Chicken Lo Mein and Young Chow fried rice for my daughter.  All the food was good. It's pretty packed inside, not much walking space. I don't think my mother could go here with her walker. The waiters were quick and fast talkers. Think of it as crowded, good food, tight places and you're out. Thank you.

Somehow the words Joe and Shanghai doesn't fit together, one may think this is an Americanized Chinese resto?

Certainly not the case!  the service is unfriendly but fast, the tea is boiling hot and prices are dirt cheap.  A big bamboo steamer filled with piping hot tender little pouches filled with meaty broth and pork meatballs -- these are Xiao Long Baos or soup dumplings as everyone knows them by.

Some basic survival tips on how NOT to burn yourself while eating XLBs:
1. Gently lift dumpling to your soup spoon.
2. Bite off a small opening on the side or at the top to open the knot
3. Add 3:1 ratio of soy sauce: vinegar into your soup spoon (thanks Alex L!)
4. Let the soup drain into the spoon (to cool it off) or slurp carefully.
5. Eat and repeat!

I also tried their turnip cake, but that was just a fried ball of grease.  Yuck.

It's best to get here before the lunch rush hour or peak dinner times for maximum enjoyment.  Get it while it's hot!

We got this to go one morning because we didn't want to wait in the long lines. I tired the Pork Soup Dumplings and Green Beans. The dumplings were really good even after being packed in a box for a little while, so I can imagine that they are 10x better when in person. Definitely one of the better soup dumpling places I've been to. Would love to go in person next time!
Amazing soup dumplings! Service is very quick and you sit family style. Great way to meet people and have a quick meal. Very inexpensive too.

Ordered delivery on UberEats and was unsure how it would be after the lengthy delivery. It was great! The food arrived and was still very hot & everything tasted as if it was in the restaurant. The hot&sour soup was delicious and very hot (it didn't even need to be heated up in the microwave). We ordered two orders of the soup thinking we would each have one... I don't recommend doing that unless you want a ton of leftovers. One order of the hot & sour soup can easily provide 2.5 servings. The spring rolls were also good and were still crispy (somehow they didn't get soggy with the delivery). We also ordered shrimp fried rice that was a pretty large portion and very good. The shrimp fried rice was not dry at all and hit the spot. The sesame chicken was still crispy and perfect... Joe's thought of a great method to deliver the sesame chicken (they cut out a hole in the plastic lid so the condensation didn't cause the chicken to get soggy) and it worked so well. The entire meal tasted just as good as in the restaurant. Overall, this meal was AMAZING! We are already talking about our next order. Would love to help provide business to this great place especially during covid. We look forward to next time!

We wanted to try soup dumplings and heard great things about Joe's.  Upon arrival, i was a bit turned of by the service and the unpleasant server.  However, the food definitely made up for everything.  We ordered the crispy duck and beef, soup dumplings and noodles.  Everything was heaven in your mouth.  I would have given it 5 stars but the service is horrible.  We had asked our server what he recommended and he looked at us with annoyance and was very unhelpful.  :(

Truly amazing! Joe's is located on a small street in Chinatown. We arrived a little after 5 PM and there was already a 25 minute wait. That's when you know the place is good! 

Joe's looks like your typical Chinatown restaurant. There isn't anything special about the interior, but the emphasis is placed on the quality of their food. Note: they only take cash!

[ Pork Soup Dumplings ] Our group of four ordered four sets of soup dumplings. Each set is served in a dim sum box and comes with 8 soup dumplings. The soup dumplings were bigger than I expected and they spill over the soup spoon. The skin of thick but easy to break apart and the flavor of the soup is deliciously rich. My friend taught me her technique! First, you bite a hole into the soup dumpling and drain the soup into the spoon. Then you dip the rest of the dumpling into the provided vinegar and chase it all down with the soup. 

[ Scallion Pancakes ] Very crispy and oily! These served as great "sponges" to soak up any soup that spilled from the soup dumplings.

I came here because I was craving soup dumplings and saw that this place has good reviews.
While I think the soup dumplings were good, with the right amount of juiciness, I was personally not a fan of the amount of ginger they packed in there. I think it obscures the flavor of the meat and soup. Some people might like it that way, it's just not for me.
The other dishes I tried (fried rice, stir-fry noodles,etc.) were good, but not the most amazing
Overall good food, but nothing that stood out among all the great restaurants in Chinatown

Came on a weekend with my husband around 2pm, and it was pretty easy to get seating. The ambiance is clean and big, with high ceilings, with both big and small tables! 

XLB is where it's at here. They're big, juicy, soupy, and delicious! Comes with 8 and they're pretty affordable. I would say they're pretty on par with Nan Xiang honestly. 

I wasn't a huge fan of the other dishes though. We tried the double cooked pork belly, and it kind of just tasted like stir fry with MSG. Not sure if this is because it's the "Shanghai northern style" but it kind of just reminded me of just like...a beef and broccoli type dish. Just with pork and peppers and mushrooms. It tasted very American take out style. 

Overall, would most likely just come back for the XLB's here.

My friend was visiting from out of town and mentioned she really wanted soup dumplings, so I did some research and found this place was the highest rated one, and not super expensive, so we went on a Saturday night. They don't take reservations, and I knew it was gonna be insane given we got there a bit before 9, but the restaurant knows the demand is high and they are prepared. They give you a ticket instead of taking names, and call out numbers as soon as enough seats are vacated at the communal-style round tables inside. 

We waited about 25 minutes because bigger parties didn't want to wait very long, so not too bad for a party of 2! Once seated, the service was very prompt, and it needs to be that way in order to get diners in and out, which is why they tack on the service charge to your bill, saving you time. Also, it's cash only, so bring your greens. 

We ordered the pork soup dumplings, which were OMG fantastic. I could probably have just eaten those alone. They give you complimentary tea, which kind I couldn't honestly say, though I thought jasmine. Be mindful with the tongs that you don't squeeze too hard, or the broth inside will seep out before you get to savor it. I picked up the dumpling carefully with the tongs and placed it in my soup spoon, then used a chopstick to make a little hole near the top so I could suck out the broth, then eat the dumpling. I recommend the chili paste with the dumplings if you want a little kick. The dumpling itself is tender and chewy and the pork inside is just right and not too salty. The broth can't be described, you just need to order it and see for yourself.

We got sesame chicken (came with a side of cool broccoli, which after the tea and the soup dumplings, I didn't mind) and kung pao chicken; both of course came with sticky white rice. Both were giant servings. The sesame chicken has a sweet glaze and the kung pao comes with a bunch of peppers. Neither were very spicy.

The place is very snug inside and I would not recommend bringing a stroller, luggage, or lots of bags, so keep that in mind. Other than that, it's a quick walk from the Canal St subway station and is definitely worth the wait! I'll be back!

i think this one is the original. i can't remember. but if its not, its not the good one. there is DEFINITELY a difference b/w joe's shanghai and joe's ginger. i went to ginger last time (if that's the second store) and it was terrible! and it wasn't just one order that i got b/c i got 5 and they were all bad except for 1. that says smoething. wait in line at joe's shanghai, it's well worth it

Has a C rating but we waited amidst crowds of mostly tourists with a good mix of Chinese families and groups for about 30 minutes to get a table. It's communal seating which I loved & the inside is drab and tacky but in the best way possible. We only got fried rice but it was just as good as some of the fried rice I had in China! Overall I would go not only for the good food but also the overall experience. It's super busy and chaotic but worth risking the C rating lol 

Also worth mentioning the food is meant to be shared. We had no idea when we ate there so my brother and I both got our own fried rice & our friend got her own noodle dish. We were the talk of the town for the rest of the table as they were Chinese and didn't speak any English. They visibly made fun of us the whole meal lol. We didn't mind though because honestly when we were in china we got the exact some reactions no matter how much we tried to blend it or how much of the customs we followed or the language we spoke. Felt like being right back in western China lol.

Soupy dumplings (3 stars): they were huge, very soupy, quite tasty, but a little on the greasy side even for soupy dumplings. Very affordable. It is a different technique than DTF. DTF's wrapping is more plastic-y and gel like (which is rather unique and untraditional). These are more bread like, possibly with quite a bit of lard into the wrapping to keep it tender and flavourful. 

Pork chop noodles (4 stars): The pork chops were very well-fried, do ask for it on the side rather than soaking in the soup, though. The dumpling were soupy enough for me to soak my noodles in. Yum.

Scallion pancake (5 stars): the best of all the stuff we had--crispy and beautifully fried.

A very bustling place, I personally enjoyed the chaos, but if you don't, avoid busy hours.

Soup dumplings are amazing! (Xiao Long Bao) I went from Din Tai Fung to this OG spot. No disrespect to DTF but the price for the dumping's here are way better and just as good. We got an order for about $9! We also ordered the Shanghai fried rice and crispy pork chops. The outside part of the dumping was just a little to thick for me but that didn't take away from how good those dumping's were. Fried rice and pork chops were like any other place but still good. Tables were a little too small for all the food we ordered but keep in mind the restaurant is not very big. We came when it was raining and there wasn't a wait but I can only imagine how long the wait is when it's a nice day out. They make it an effort to get you in and out. Also, 15% tip is already included when paying for check.(look on the last page of the menu) Overall, will come back to this place! Cheap food for vacation! (CASH ONLY)

We got here on a weekday lunch time and didn't have to wait for a table of 7! Perfect timing because the restaurant was busy but we got here just in time. We had to share a big table with another party though but that was totally fine.

Everything we ordered was quite delicious.

1. We ordered two juicy pork dumplings. It was a perfect amount to share amongst us. If you compare this to dtf, these are wayyyyy bigger. That means more juice inside the dumplings. The only thing is, you need to get used to picking the dumplings up and onto your plate. My first two attempts were unsuccessful and i disappointedly had to eat them without as much juice left inside. Regardless, it was still delicious!. I love the dumplings with a lot of vinegar and ginger so don't hesitate asking the waiter for more!

2. The mapo tofu without meat was also really good as well. there wasn't really anything that went wrong with this meal. Even without the meat, it had a lot of delicious flavor.

3. The minced pork noodle came with a lot of pork on top. Make sure you mix it around before putting it on your plate. It is pretty saucey. The noodle is different from other places I had this dish from. This place comes with a slightly thicker whiter noodle.. which is pretty good. 

4. The green onion pancake was a very small portion in an order but the crisp of it was perfect and the flavor was very aromatic with the onion cooked into it.. slightly different from other places I had these pancakes from. 

This place was quite delicious! But there are so many Chinese restaurants in this Chinatown area, I would want to explore the other restaurants even though I would also come back here in a heartbeat.

I wanted to experience what the crowds of people waiting for a table at Joe's Shanghai was all about so my husband and I and a friend of ours had lunch there a few weeks ago. Some of the dishes we had were soup dumplings which were perfect in my opinion, cold noodles with sesame sauce (I've had better), clams in black bean sauce which were delicious and a bean curd dish wish our friend liked very much.
It was very crowded but the service was fast and efficient. I would definitely try it again but after growing g up and eating in Chinatown for most of my life, I think there are far better restaurants in that neighborhood.
The ambience is of a typical Chinatown eatery - noisy, crowded but inviting

One never forgets the moment they fall in love with something for the first time. I've read the reviews and although there seems to be plenty of better places to get Xiaolongbao in the world but this was where I lose my soup dumpling virginity.

First of all, there always seems to be a wait but because the staff inside doesn't mess around, your wait will never be as long as you expect it to be. And once you're inside and order the soup dumplings, it won't be long before you're feasting on them.

I didn't know what to expect. My friend tried to explain in words but he just said that I needed to try them. He kept saying Xiaolongbao in a slightly racist accent but after my experience here, I have been doing the same.

The pork ones are around 5 bucks and the crab ones are closer to 7 so for the price difference, I'd stick with the pork ones (they were my favorite anyways). Each order gives you 8 dumplings so order as needed.

I discovered the best way to eat these without burning your tongue or the roof of your mouth is to make a small incision at the top of the dumpling. Once that's done, slowly sucks out the oily soup broth that will change your life forever. Don't be hasty as they are very hot. Once you've sucked out about half of the soup, the other half should be cooled off and you can pop the whole thing into your mouth.

If you've never tried them before, you'll fall in love instantly and be craving them the next day as you sit in your car/bus/train on the way to work.

Last note: CASH ONLY. Xiao for now.

Not much to say about this other than AWESOME soup dumplings! The only thing I find a little weird at first is that you sit with other people but other than that it's a great spot to get your dumpling fix. It's crowded and busy, but it's worth the wait!

If you manage to beat the crowd, do not mind table sharing with strangers, and focus on the xiao long bao ( mini soup buns, bao = buns not dumplings, to be accurate ), the culinary experience will prove worthy. Been here thrice, and midtown location once which offers better seating options

Food: 4.75/5 to the Crab & Pork Xiao long bao - seafood & pork pair off as perfectly as green tea & azuki.

How to Eat: Gently (without poking a hole) lift the bun and place it on the soup spoon, bite off a teeny tiny bit off the top while lifting the bun by chopsticks, and drink away the heavenly fresh (hot! be ware) soup inside - remember you're entitled to slurp during such soupgasm - then drip inside some vinegar and ginger (aids digestion on top of the flavor balance) before devouring the rest of the bun. 

Stuff in as many buns as you can handle, order a small dish of seasonal vegetables stir fried with minced garlic to complement the meat. All other dishes (2/5) are highly NOT recommended. Go elsewhere for noodles or fried rice or dim sum, Joe's Shanghai = Xiao long bao

The dumbest way of eating is to bite into it unstrategically, lose all the soup that is the soul of these buns, and burn your mouth......

Ambience (1.5/5) loud, packed to your elbows, forced to share table with strangers often tourists who stare and ruthlessly knock over their tea or vinegar; be prepared to arrive early in order to avoid the queue 

Service (3/5) efficient, fast, most convenient if you speak Chinese

Came here on a weekday afternoon and there was no wait time. My brother and I split an order of the famous XLB and their salt toasted fish. The XLB came out piping hot and was perfectly soupy on the inside. The salt toasted fish was fried to a perfect crisp, loved the bits. 

We couldn't eat too much this visit because we had dinner reservations later on that evening. The food that was being brought to other tables looked delicious. Service was quick as well.

*cash only

I was brought here by a friend. He's a college student fairly new to the area whose friends are all college students, so naturally I expected that this guy knew nothing what real food was. I was surprised to find that this place was actually really good and sold Xiao Lung Bao. The food was great. 

I'm a little more inclined to give this place a 4 star, but since it was a while ago since I went I'm going to give the place the benefit of the faint memory and give it 5. I remember it was great food, but the price was on the high end. Only restaurants that have food quality that exceeds their price range get 5 stars from me, but like i said benefit of the faint memory.

My husband and I ordered the pork soup dumplings and orange peel chicken. The dumplings were absolutely amazing, and I wish we had just gotten 2 orders of them as our meal. In case you aren't well versed in eating soup dumplings, use a soup spoon!! This way you don't have to balance the dumpling on chopsticks and won't potentially lose the delicious soup due to an unfortunate dumpling tumble. The orange peel chicken was good but not necessarily exceptional. My husband grew up in Seattle where really good Asian food was everywhere, so his standards are very high, so it's not that the orange peel chicken wasn't good, but it's hard to wow him. However, we can't wait to go back for lots of dumplings! 

I also have a several food allergies, and the servers were very helpful and accommodating with that. This is a must-try when you go to NYC!!

I love how piping hot their soup dumplings are every single time.  There's nothing worse than eating a cold soup dumpling and I've had them at other well-known spots in Chinatown.  But never at Joe's.  Their Shanghai Noodles are also fantastic as well as other items.  My usual items are scallion pancakes, General Tso's (I see you judging me, but really...it's really good), and their veggie dishes.  Go early to beat the line!

Joe's hole in a wall.
Shanghai noodle is must to try.
Green string beans was made excellent.
Kung pao chicken is ok if you don't mind it's super spicy. I didn't ask to make it without chilly overload.
If you love peanuts it's a lot in king pao.
Expect to have 2-3 guests on your large round table and have conversation together.
Restroom need to be repaired.
Nobody expected clean restaurant from Chinese fellas. At least believe they wash hands after dirty stuff and removes stickers from complementary oranges before cutting.
Good luck
Soup dumplings are amazing but the rest of the food was lackluster. Service was fast. Not worth waiting a long time for

This place usually has a line around the block, but it had been a very rainy night and morning, so it was a miracle to have no line and empty tables at noon! They also have a great machine for rainy days which wraps your umbrella into plastic as you walk in (you are obligated to use it by the staff at the front door who will help you figure it out).

They are famous for their soup dumplings, which are huge! We ordered two trays of the pork and crab and devoured the wonderful broth inside the dumplings that brimmed with crab flavor.

The green beans with garlic was also a table favorite.

My friends indulged me as I asked to order the steamed flounder which was not only beautifully presented, but also delicately cooked.

So delicious! A great experience. Be sure to bring cash.

We had the soup dumplings, the beef with string beans, and the Shanghai fried noodles with chicken. What a feast! We really enjoyed each item and would have liked anything else on the menu, too, I am sure. The tables around us were buzzing and the restaurant filled up quite a lot while we were eating (so did we). The flavors were all so rich and full of umami. Yum, yum, yum! Get there early to be sure you get a table.
Noteworthy xiaolong bao that compare favorably to many I've had in Shanghai, China. Clean and classic decor. Would recommend as an introduction to xiaolong (soup dumplings)
so worth the wait, so amazing. The soup dumplings and crispy beef are not to be missed.

We were seated almost immediately, probably cause it was just 2 people. Fast service and attentive staff. I dropped my chopstick twice  and they gave me a new pair within 10 secs. We got the crab and pork soup dumpling and the pork meat soup dumpling. I honestly thought the crab meat one was better because there was an extra flavor. Though the flavor did remind me of the canned minced crab meat, tasted good regardless, but the reason why I give it 4 stars.

amazing food!! i read reviews saying the soup dumplings aren't anything to rave about, but i thought they were amazing. the portions are family style and perfect for two. the service was excellent! it's well worth the wait.

Love their soup dumplings; #1 in CT...(or maybe NY & US lol) but aside from that, that's pretty much their specialty dish. Had the pork shoulder dish here with my friend one time and it was not my type of food so I didn't really like it. I don't really like their other dishes as well (mainly because they are really really greasy) except for the braised tofu dish with vegetables stuffed underneath or their pepper and pork noodle soup...and that's pretty much it. When I do go back, it is always for their soup dumplings. And everytime you eat, they serve you a small portion of oranges, which is pretty accommodating compared to other regular dine-in in other restaurants. But they do include the 15% tip before hand so do not be mistaken and tip twice, but personally I think it makes tipping easier and less for me because I usually tip more than 15%, but if they're gonna do that, then let it be.

5 star...as good as it gets. the stars are for the crab/pork soup dumplings. frequent visitors to NYC, we love to try new places, and there are so many options.  next visit (next week), we're going back.

We were lucky enough to sit at a table with two sets of Chinese-speaking patrons, who advised "crab/pork soup dumplings" and showed us how to eat them.  Truly fantastic and unique flavor. we (the two of us) ended up cancelling what we had ordered and replaced with a second serving.  

Crazy but not chaotic, memorable, the shared table perfect place to get recommendations and help.

Can't wait to return.

Joe's was part of a recent food crawl I took part in through Chinatown,  popped in for a couple of orders of soup dumplings on a Thursday afternoon, and to our surprise found an empty restaurant.

I'm jumping on the soup dumpling band wagon with the least surprising review you're going to read about eating here.....  

The dumplings are perfectly prepared, twenty twists a piece in traditional fashion. The ratio of soup to pork was spot on and each bite was better than the last. 

My only issue with their product is the dumpling sauce, this is purely personal.....  I'd love a bit of vinegar in there for some tang, but that's hardly a blight on a near perfect dumpling experience. 

As good a soup dumpling you'll find, that said I can't speak for anything else on the menu.

Love this place-inexpensive and delicious.  I bring all my friends and family here who come to visit, and now my Dad insists I take him there anytime he visits.  Their soup dumplings are awesome and I also really love their chicken and cucumber with red pepper.  The wait can be ridiculous, so I usually try to get there for right when they're about to open-if not, prepare to stand around for a long time (especially if you have a group of more than 4).  They seat you with random people but that's never bothered me at all, but I do tend to talk a lot.  Definitely an experience.

This is a neighborhood spot I love to go to. The food is always good and so is the service. You will have to wait during the lunch rush though so be prepared. I had the soup dumplings. They are a must!

this place lives up to the hype! it's a small place, you may even walk by it, but don't! 

We waited about 30 minutes for a table, which on a saturday at 1pm was expected. Once our name was called we were taken to a big round table which we shared with 10 other people. So, don't expect to have a table all to yourself, as most the tables in here are like that, just a heads up. 

THE FOOD:
fried pork dumplings - huge dumplings and super yummy, I was really pleased with these. nice crunch on the outside and the filling as perfectly seasoned. 
Soup dumplings - probably some of the best I've had! Served steaming hot and none of them broken, which was so nice given that's an easy thing to do
Sesame Chicken - served with steamed broccoli, the chicken was obviously fresh and the sauce was sweet but not overly so
Crispy pan fried noodles with chicken - so we expected this to be a 'dry noodle' dish, like wok seared, but it was a nest of noodles that were deep fried which was SO fun. The basket of noodles was the vessel for wok-ed chicken, broccoli, baby corn, jicama and carrots and as the sauce sat in the bottom the noodles got softer so there was a fun crispy/soft texture going on. we really enjoyed this 

We didnt get dessert cuz we were full, so note that the dishes are HUGE and meant to be shared. If we had each ordered a protein and a side we would have been taking most of it home.

Used to come here a lot with my family when I was a child.  There is always a line, but definitely worth the wait.  The soup dumplings are delicious and well priced.  Their other stir fry dishes are really good too.  Brings back the childhood memory every time.

You just gotta stop by if you're in New York. What else do I say more about the place? 

Oh but dear chef, 
please try not to pop the dimsum so the soup would not leak out of it when we're ready to eat. :(

If your come here order a number 1 or 2 thats what they are famous for. Dumplings have soup inside and are always cooked fresh comes with vegetables which I don't eat. If you plan on dining in make sure you havr reservation because the wait can be a while.

Interior--one of those old Chinatown restaurants so it's very cramp, dark and you gotta share tables with strangersthere's no waiting area inside

Service--average. Food comes out pretty fast even when they are extremely busy. They only seat you when your whole party is there.

Taste--the pork dumplings are DELICIOUS and bigger compare with average dumplings. They come out really hot since there's soup in them so make sure don't burn yourself. 

3 of us ordered 4 dishes, came out with a total of $56, which is a pretty good deal considering we were extremely full.

Cheap & Yummy Eats When You Visit NYC!!! First stop is to go there directly after land it and order their delicious pork soupy XLB. It's totally worth it. This place is the OG place and try going during non-peak time to avoid long waits. The place is crowded inside and don't forget to bring your CASH!! And, 15% tips is automatically added to your bill so I guess it makes up for the cheap meals. I order of soup dumping is around $6.95ish comes with an order of 8 big pieces XLB. Super good deal and super delicious. I can tell and taste the Dumpling wrap is handmade and super fresh too! You have to personally go there and experience it :)

Delicious soup dumplings! My family is Shanghainese so I'm always looking for an authentic place for my taste buds. I'm really happy that I found this place to curb my appetite for soup dumplings, which before moving into the city, I've only been able to eat when I'm in Shanghai. 

For sure get the soup dumplings! It comes out in a steaming basket and is super hot so make sure to let it cool a bit. 

This place has a huge line - I was here at 9:30 pm on Saturday and waited 15-20 minutes for a table. You might end up getting seated with another party if you have fewer people.
Good soup dumplings. The new location is spacious and clean. Always here for soup dumplings. Will recommend here if your around the neighborhood.

Got the scallion pancake, pork soup buns (XLB), and the Shanghai chow mein. The scallion pancake was divine , so were the soup buns, but would've rather ordered an eggplant dish instead of the noodle dish as there was not much to it.
great scallion pancake and fabulous pork buns and pork and shrimp buns.

In the heart of China town, such a cute area. But it gets extremely busy and just be warned you might have to share a table with people you don't know. The food is wonderful! My family and I had the ?vegetable fried rice, the vegetable lo mein, and the fried noodles with beef. All super yummy! My personal favorite was the vegetable fried rice. Prices are very reasonable. Would definitely go back if I was in the area again. Such a cool place! Just wish it was a little bigger.

If you love dumplings, meeting new people and speedy in & out service, this is the place for you! Today we had the pork soup dumplings, General Tao Chicken & Shanghai noodles with my party of 3 and the bill was $40 with tip. The food is fast, looks and tastes delicious and the price point is fantastic -if you stick to water and tea which is complimentary. The seating arrangements allow you to meet new people (as you will be placed at a table with others) and find out about other great restaurants in NYC if you're lucky.

Food was really good, higher priced than other places for sure but understandable due to the popularity. The service was really great, made it all worth it. Shanghai noodles were a bit dry, as was the Shanghai fried rice, but they can bring any sauce requested. Sesame shrimp was nice and crispy, without too much sauce. Scallion pancakes are thick. 

The wait wasn't bad, even with lots of people outside waiting. There were so many people working that everything moved along quickly.
Eat soup dumplings here. Eat it while it's hot. Community table. In and out. Not the place to chit chat.

The wait might be long but so worth it! I have only tried Xiao Long Bao a few times at Din Tai Fung in Bellevue, WA but I personally think Joe's Shanghai is a lot better in terms of price and portion size.

My group of 5 split 3 orders of the juicy pork and 2 orders of the crab xiao long baos.  The crab was good but the juicy pork was definitely the favorite of our group.  We also split an order of beef in oyster sauce that was unimpressive.  If anything, just stick to ordering xiao long baos.

A few things to keep in mind:

* You will not get seated until your entire party is present at the restaurant.
* Your party may have to share a table with other strangers (no biggie for me)
* Cash only.

Best soup dumplings 
Other dishes are delicious too 

Our waiter was nice.  

We were a group of eight people.  Waited for 30 minutes on a  busy Saturday night.  Worth the wait.

I was between 4-5 stars because the soup dumplings of course are probably the best I have had. Maybe Marks dumplings in DC and my son had some in LA but said those were the size of Hershey kisses.
These were big and full of soup and the dumpling skin was not too thin or thick. The initial ones will burn your mouth so wait a few seconds. Perfect on a cold winter day. The broth is rich and full of flavor. We ordered 2 crab and one pork- I liked the crab better.
We also had duck- it was good- a lot of skin and a little lean but the skin is our favorite part. The schezwN beef was very good but a little chewy.  Fish was very good and the thick seafood noodles were great.
But I thought the highlight was the dumplings

The soup dumplings and wonton soup are absolutely delicious!  We also ordered General Tsos Chicken was good but a bit on the pricey side compared to the other dishes.  Ordered some beef chow fun which was really good too!  BEWARE:  Cash only.  The place is crowded, you will more than likely have to wait for a table (outside) and may have to share a table.  Also, don't be offended if your server is rude or impersonal.  Lol

Visiting New York for a short weekend trip, this place was recommended from a friend who heard was worth trying for their famous soup dumplings.
Venturing through Chinatown, this was pretty easy to find.  We came here 15 minutes after it opened and did not have to wait from which I heard could be over an hour wait typically.  Small place with about round 15+tables that can accommodate 4-6/table.  We were only a party of 2 and were seated at a table with another group of 3 people.  Was unexpected that we had to dine with strangers but from a business aspect, they want to make good use of space to serve more customers.  
We ordered the famous crab and pork soup dumplings and scallion pancakes.   The soup dumplings came out and was piping hot and on a bamboo steamer. Looked impressive.  Took my first bite carefully and ....
Best dumpling I have ever had.  All the right flavors in the broth and the dumpling wrapper almost melted in my mouth GOOD!!!!
The scallion pancake had a hint of scallion flavor with a crunchy shell which was the perfect pairing with the soft dumplings.
I definitely would make time to return again just for the dumplings when I return to New York and would also like to try the other yummy looking Chinese dishes I saw here.

Midtown: Pricey but the crab and pork soup dumplings were great!!

Chinatown: not pricey, huge soup dumplings! We tried the pork, crab and pork, scallion pancake, and Shanghai cabbage wonton soup. Would HIGHLY recommend pork soup dumplings (best in NYC and flushing imho), the rest were not worth getting. Maybe get a veggie plus the pork soup dumplings. 8 per person is a good amount!
Used to come to the old spot all the time before they expended to this location. Some of the best (and largest!) XLBs - must try their crab XLBs! Come early to avoid the crowd.

Good Shanghainese food BUT don't come here for the Xiaolongbao. For a place known for Xiaolongbao, theirs really disappointed me because it was so bland and overly chewy. However, the other dishes were great. The scallion pancake was my favorite because it's super crispy and flavorful, but be forewarned that it tastes nothing like the ones you can buy at the supermarket. 

Make sure to come right when the restaurant opens to avoid waiting for a really long time. It's a bit on the pricier end but it's probably worth it. Overall, I would probably come here again but will try other things on the menu.

Just stopped by for soup dumplings and flat noodles    As always, it's an 11 out of 10.  We have XLB at home in the west coat, but these are fatter with better tasting soup and more tender wrappers.  Punchline:  these are the originals for many of us ...

Being from out of town, it's hard to find authentic soup dumplings and these did not disappoint! Food was delicious. Service was speedy. The wait appeared long as there was a line out the line door when we arrived but as a party 2 we were sat immediately. (The line out front was for for larger parties waiting for tables) FYI cash only but there is an ATM on site and parties were not seated until everyone was present.

Shanghai dumplings are great here, so are the other menu items. Don't order too much if you're walking around after dinner, and don't feel like carrying leftovers. Get here early for dinner to avoid the long lines. 5:00 pm on Friday and we got right in with a table of six.

This place has such a strong reputation for a good reason. When you go, do not just order soup dumps! You have to try the other food, including their vegetable dishes and noodle dishes too!
As for the soup dumps, they are delicious, though I find them to be a bit to "bao-y" - the skin is thick. I prefer a higher meat and soup to skin ratio personally.

The service was excellent, I got the shrimp lo mein-a nice large portion size- it was tasty! My only issue is with the lack of vegetarian options, I couldn't try any of the specials so I'm not sure this placed lives up to the hype.

Friends of ours took us here, highly recommending the soup dumplings.  I thought, oh yea - I know what dumplings are....yea right.  The Soup Dumplings here are absolutely fantastic, never had anything like that before.  

First you wait, probably outside the door...give your number, and wait some more.  This place is PACKED, but DO NOT stray, it is completely worth the wait, I promise.  We finally got our table, sat family style with other folks.  There were 6 of us, and they fit us in quite nicely.  Everyone gets the same question, what kind of soup dumplings, crab or pork....not, "do you want soup dumplings", you're getting them.  And it's a good thing, they are awesome.

I am so glad someone was with us to teach us how to eat these things.  First you put hot sauce in the corner of your plate, take the tongs and pull out a dumplings - place onto your rice spoon, bite a small hole in the top, set the spoon on your plate.  Spoon the hot sauce and the soy/ginger sauce into the hole you bit.  Lift the spoon and suck the soup, it is incredible!  Then bite into the dumpling and eat away.

If you give this place less than 4 stars, you are obviously crazy and don't take food seriously!  The best soup dumplings I have EVER had.  

The best time to go is on a weekday, after 2pm or very late.  The cheese line is serious at this place. Wear comfortable shoes and jogging pants for the extra space you'll need once you're done eating here.  

When I'm done eating here, I feel like a fat baby, and ready for a nap.

There's a huge line out the door all the time because this place is as good as it gets!

Since there are such long lines, the restaurant tries to fill up all the seats at a table. Our group of 3 was seated with 2 other groups of 2 and 3. A little awkward but totally worth it for the delish soup dumplings!

We ordered the crab dumplings and pork dumplings. These are probably the best soup dumplings I've ever had outside of Shanghai. The dumplings are rather large but made fresh-to-order. It comes out steamy hot and tasty!

Super top delicious crab and meet soup dumplings, I read and heard that they are famous for those. So don't miss them!
Also the shrimps steamed dimplings and the fried pork dumplings are really delicious.
We also had the shrimp wonton soup but because they need a bit more time for the preparation, we had them at the end and, being of a more delicate flavour, tasted a bit less. Be sure to have this soup first and I am sure it will be great.
Ah, we also had the Mei Fun noodles (spicy curry, dry panfried) and they were very giod too.
Service is fine, tables are round to share.
It was pretty packed, so no much space for pictures this time. 
Also make sure you are not sturving when you go, because there might be a long queue to wait. Unless you are very lucky...
Price is fair, 40$ in two and we ate really a lot. No credit card.

Last month I ventured into the big apple with my partner in crime and indulged in some tasty morsels. One treat that particularly stood out was the concoction of pork and dough from Joe's Shanghai. As you cautiously take a bite of the hot dumpling, its deliciously fatty contents trickle down your throat and into your stomach. We left fully satisfied and continued on our food-venture.

Never had soup dumplings before this place, and im in love. Theres always a line everytime ive gone for good reason. Food is amazing, cheap, and i like the communal round table seating. Dont order the bean curd, looked and tasted like. The spicy cabbage is great and the 2 soup dumpling orders are enough for two people.
Went on a Sunday for lunch in the winter and there was no line. The crab soup dumplings is a must, even if you don't like crab get them!! The orange beef was delicious and spicy which I liked.

We came for an early dinner on a weekday and there was no wait time. Of course we ordered some xiao long bao/ Shanghai dumplings / soup dumplings / little dragon buns. We also got some scallion pancakes and fried pork dumplings. Everything was delicious and nostalgic, and not so nostalgic.
While these soup dumplings from Joe's Shanghai are delicious, they are very different from the xiao long baos I am used to eating. I'm not a xiao long bao / Shanghai dumpling snob, but I've been eating these dumplings ever since I could consume solid food. They just aren't 'authentic.' I hate using the A word, because it's so vague and meaningless. Food trends and even food traditions are changing all the time. 

In my opinion, these are the deviations from a typical soup dumpling. 
- Super-sized type dumpling. Each dumpling is nearly the size of a small burger. 
- The flavor of the meat filling also tastes a little different, could use more flavor.
- The skin is too thick. 

What I do like: 
- The meat in each dumpling is a generous amount
- There is plenty of soup encased in each one, 
- Very good price, so I did walk away feeling full and satisfied.

It is a cash only establishment, so once again, I have to plan out a visit to the ATM first. Just an extra step that cuts into my eating time. I'd still come back for some very affordable, extra large dumplings again.

The best crab dumplings i have ever had. I have been here several times and every time the food is super phenomenal. If u are traveling and want to go to a good authentic Chinese restaurant then u MUST go here . My fav restaurant to go in NYC !

Great crab and pork soup dumplings. Lots of filling and the price is definitely worth it. The cold noodles and vegetable dumplings were also delicious, but their soup dumplings were just superb. Service was fast and the waiters were attentive.
The steamed pork dumplings here are legendary. I get random cravings about them and when I go I'm never disappointed. Great service, love the atmosphere and the food is always delicious. 5 STARS!
I wish I lived in NYC!!! I crave the soup dumplings all the time and nothing comes close in the Bay area

wow-i've never meet so many a-holes in such high concentration in one place here in nyc EVAR!

they scream at you, order you around, and degrade you at any chance they can. they won't let you enjoy your meal at a reasonable pace with your companions before they start kicking you out. 

DAMN waiters!

they know their xiao long bao is the best in the city (but not as good as http://www.yelp.com/biz/din-tai-fung-arcadia-3#hrid:l3F-7BMk81AZSzzmBeMaSw/src:search/query:xiao long bao). they are pretentious and stare at you to speed your meal at every chance. i had the flat noodles with pork to accompany my dumplings. 

BE CAREFUL with the dumplings--they will explode in your mouth and not in a good way! pierce the skin and suck the pork juice, add sauce, and enjoy!

back to the review. we didn't finish our meal and i was scared  that our boxed takeout was going to have a little aqqq-choo sauce!!!! :$

remember that there is grat included and if you feel generous, tip these well oiled machines of waiters and don't let them get to you.

The good:
- Amazing soup dumplings.
- Great food in decent prices.
- Round communal tables make it perfect for groups.
- And of course the BYOB policy!

The bad:
- It's the Chinese version for Seinfeld' soup natzi. Expect very rude service
- Far from everything else and long lines

I took my childhood friend who was visiting from my tiny hometown.  We had a great weekend.   Of all that we did this, Joe's Shanghai was what she loved most.  We had a great group of strangers at our table, the dumplings are amazing, not to mention everything else we had.

Soup dumplings galore! Can not get better than this. Also we had the sesame chicken and Singapore thick noodles. Couldn't finish it all but always come to joe's for our Chinatown fix when we are in NYC.

The food comes out pretty fast and you can make RSVP. we had a group of 12 or so and we were able to be late and get seated pretty fast.
