The pork and soup dumplings were good, eggplant dishes were good but maybe too much sauce, the babyshrimp dish came with huge portion, both the pork and chicke rice cakes were really good, we also got the giant meatballs which were good, etc. The food came out to be $13 a person and we ate sooo much even though we were starting with the 8 crates of soup dumplings.

Food was amazing and so,so fresh. The lines are ridiculous because the food is so good. However me and my co workers didn't have to wait . Get there knowing you are gonna wait but it is beyond worth it. They treated us very nice. The dessert was AWESOME. The scallion pankcakes were delicious..
Best soup dumplings you can find in NYC outside of Flushing. Delicious! The indoor ambiance makes me feel like I am in China

Had to wait to get seated, took 25 minutes. The restaurant was crowded, loud and crazy. Seating is family style with a lazy susan on the table. Food was pretty good. The highlights were the pork soup dumplings, the turnip buns, jellyfish and fried quail. Place only takes cash and prices are good.

Having heard so much about Joe's Shanghai I had to try their Soup Dumplings! I arrived on a Tuesday at 1:30pm and unsurprisingly there was a huge crowd of people waiting outside. I stepped inside to get a ticket (don't lose this!) from the lady and that was when the true test of patience began. Since I was by myself, I was told that the wait would be about 30 min which turned into an hour. Pretty long if you ask me for a single person, but clearly there were many larger parties in front of me who had already been waiting just as long if not longer. 

Once seated, I already knew I only wanted one thing: the Crab & Pork Soup Dumplings (XLB)! While waiting, I got a chance to see the interior which was modern and very clean. As soon as the XLB arrived I could feel all of my excitement as my mouth drooled in anticipation. Upon opening the bamboo lid, a huge plume of steam escaped revealing 8 of the largest soup dumplings I have ever seen! Somehow these delicate pouches of joy were able to hold all of the delicious and fatty pork broth that completely coats the inside of your mouth. The crab/pork filling was very meaty and tasty while the skin was thin. The top was a bit too chewy, but overall a very satisfying XLB. 

Overall, the XLB is top notch and is quite comparable to what I have had here in the Bay Area for those who have had Din Ding Dumpling House. I'd say Joe's Shanghai is slightly larger and fattier so you definitely get more bang for your buck. Only downside is that it is cash only. I don't think I'd wait here again by myself, but would certainly be willing to come back with a group of friends to try more things as a group.

Joe's is definitely not your standard traditional Chinese restaurant.  First thing I noticed - neon pink and green lights adorning the ceiling...majorly tacky and I felt like I was in one of those really shitty whitewashed Chinese restaurants.  Second thing I noticed is the clientele - you have a very wide diversity of people eating here, likely because it has become so popular.  A rainbow of ethnicities, some dressed as bums, some in suits, Joe's attracts people of all backgrounds.  To maximize efficiency, they have it set up that wherever they can sit you, they will.  This usually means sharing large 12 person banquet tables with 3-4 other parties.  Very interesting in that you get to meet a lot of different people, but definitely unheard of in Chinese restaurants.

As for the food, it did not disappoint.  The soup dumplings are decent but lacked that juicy explosion in your mouth.  Frightening though to see so many noobs tear it apart, bite into it, or just plain mishandled these little bundles of joy and leave all the soup on their plate.  Absolutely taboo.  However, the stir fried rice cake here is the best that I have ever had.  So underrated.  Ppl need to bow down to this more than the xiao long bao.

So my sister use to go to school in New York and whenever it would come up in a conversation she would go, "But Joe's shanghai, you have to go there! The dumplings have this delicious broth! You can't just have one order."

Finally, I decided to go to NY to visit my friend and after years about hearing of Joe's from my sister I made it a priority to go there! 

Luckily when we went we were seated right away. They sit you at a round table and if you're party doesn't fill they table they fill it with other guests. Not as bad as it sounds, just don't be shy! Good food is definitely an ice breaker. 

Our food was placed on our table and I found myself at a pause. I was afraid that it was overhyped, so I tried my best to lower my expectations. 
Took a bite into a xio long bao, smiled and did that little wiggle, YOU KNOW, that little happy dance you do after eating something really yummy!

Sometimes I find myself sitting in Din Thai Fung in LA and remembering that glorious trip to NY where I blessed my taste buds with Joe's Shanghai!

Best in all of NYC

Amazing authentic experience , in China town no less

Good vibes
Must get soup dumplings **

I really love the soup dumplings here. They are just freaking awesome. I've tried many dumpling spots all over the five boroughs. I just love all sorts of dumplings from all over the world but I must say this is the best soup Chinese dumplings I've had in years. I've been to this spot more than 3 times and I order just the dumplings. They are super cheap and the juice is just heaven when it pours in my mouth. 
The only drawback is there is no drawback. I haven't tried any other food here and probably will not because the dumplings are just too good to pass on. 
I see a lot of people order other food items here but I do t really see t point since the dumplings will just devour your tastebuds!
The wait is a little long during peak hours that is around 5-8pm it'll die down after that. But if you are solo or just 2 then it shouldn't be a problem. Groups are freaking hard to get a spot. 
Love the dumplings....

One if my all time favorite joint for soup dumplings. I'm a native Shanghainese, growing up eating Xiaolong Bao, this is about as authentic as it gets, also very reasonably priced. I much prefer the flavor here then of Ding Tai Feng, which is way over priced, and just OK  tasting.

Great chinese.  Famous for their soup dumplings -- and for good reason!  I also love their noodle dishes (especially the fried noodles).  They have a really good beef with jalapeno dish that's a must if you love (very) spicy food (it's sometimes a special but not on the regular menu -- but they will make it if you ask for it .

Cash only and typically 30 minute wait or so.  Everyone sits at big round communal tables which adds to the overall experience.

Joe's Shanghai is hands down the best place in NYC for soup dumplings. The soup dumplings here are the best. The dumpling skin is thin and the soup is very flavorful and the bits of pork inside it makes this dumpling so perfect. When it's very hot I usually poke a small hole in the dumpling and pour out the soup on the spoon and mix a splash of vinegar. I also really like the fried dumplings, and the Shanghai Fried Rice. In the fried rice, they have broccoli, eggs, and some scallions. It sounds plain but it taste amazing. The wait is long and as soon as you sit down the waiters will ask you how many orders of dumplings you want and they come arrive very fast-usually about 5 minutes. Also you do have to be seated with other parties and space is tight. But the food is great and well worth the wait.

Of course the downside of this place as many people come to realize is the rudeness of the waiters and management but we all keep coming back because the food is good. My friends and I do a monthly soup dumpling outing to Joe's because it's just the best comfort food. And its cheap!

Many believe that Joe's Shanghai has the best soup dumplings in New York City. Personally, I like the soup dumplings at Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao (38-12 Prince St, Flushing, NY 11354) in Flushing slightly more. Nevertheless, I would not argue with anyone that goes with Joe's. Their soup dumplings are legitimately that good. While the dumplings are definitely the star dishes, the other dishes are very solid too. I really enjoy the cold cut meats and jelly fish as another appetizer. The rice cake entr√©e dishes are excellent. The pan fried noodles are very good too.

Joe's has two more locations: one in midtown Manhattan and the other in Flushing. I have been to the midtown location many times. Of course, it is more expensive because it is midtown. In addition, the Pell Street location has the better food. It is usually packed and there I usually a wait. Joe's Ginger is on the same block. It is not affiliated and the food is not comparable. As a result, I would either wait for Joe's Shanghai's soup dumplings or abstain from soup dumplings. From personal experience, I have eaten at Joe's Ginger, confused it for Joe's Shanghai, and sullied the good name of Joe's Shanghai by saying it was overrated.

If you are looking for recommendations for good Asian food in New York, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my personal list in the city, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.

Good spot, great value.  
It's tucked away off of Canal street but worth the walk.  Customer service is ok, considering its China Town.  
Family of 5 ate comfortably for $62.00. Would definitely come back.  
We had the sesame chicken, pork fried rice and fried dumplings.  Would highly recommend all of those.

The long line with tickets for seating is evidence of the quality of the food. Two friends and I ordered the xiao long bao, citrus prawns, kung pao chicken, and eggplant - all delicious and in generous portions! Our leftovers made a big lunch for me the next day.

Be prepared to share a table with 2-3 other groups. The environment is loud and crowded, so you know that everyone enjoys the food.

This restaurant is pretty big and fits a great amount of people. I was surprised to see that majority of the people that dined here were tourists and we were lucky enough to sit in the last few tables. This restaurant only accepts cash and they have an ATM machine right at the front of the entrance. I wouldn't say that this place was amazing and one of my top goto places for soup dumplings but it is pretty decent here. The fried dumplings are great and my friend who does not like fried dumplings actually really enjoyed the ones from here. The soup dumplings had a good amount of soup in them. The beef fried rice was pretty good as well and there was a good portion of meat inside. They do include about a 18% service charge in your bill and all the waiters are extrmely patient and attentive. 

There are many different ways to eat soup dumplings for those that are not too sure how to eat them and are reading my review. First off, it is really hot once you lift the lid off of the bamboo steamer. Use the tongs that they give you or your chopsticks and grab the very tip of the soup dumpling that sticks out the most. Then place is onto the spoon.
1. You can just eat it as a whole but will most likely burn yourself if you do not wait for it to cool off. 
2. Take a bit off the tip of the dumpling and you will see that inside there's a ball of meat and soup surrounding it. (At this point you can either add a spoonful of the sauce that they provide, which usually consists of soy sauce/vinegar/ginger, inside the dumpling or not have sauce at all) Wait for it to cool off and then eat as a whole or you could drink the soup first then eat it. 
3. Another way is taking a bite of the tip of the dumpling and pour the soup out onto the spoon.
There are many different other ways to eat a soup dumpling but just make sure to let it cook off a bit because you will get burned. I've made many mistakes in the past hahaha.

Family style which was super surprising, but ended up being fun. Really great food- soup dumplings were just like the homemade ones I had in China. Everything was perfect. 10/10 will definitely go again.
Such a lively place! Always full when we go, fast moving, getting you delicious food fast.  We love loved the giant soup dumplings, so good!

It's been years since I've been to Joe's. Last time I ate at Joe's was at the old location. I got take out which was still amazing.  The crab & pork soup dumplings had an explosion of flavor with each bite. Even in a takeout container the soup dumplings had a perfect consistency & were so flavorful. 
This was the first time I had the scallion pancakes. Again a perfect consistency & full of flavor.  Shrimp Lo Mein had an abundance of small shrimp. 
While I missed the hype & vibe of the old location, the food was as amazing as I remember it to be.

Love the new space - a very modern and exciting vibe. The wait is intimidating. We were quoted 1h40min and that's almost exactly how long it was. It was certainly worth it. They were still working on getting their liquor license as of 12/25, but it's a pretty basic selection of beers. That's not the reason you're here. The real reason is absolutely the soup dumplings. I had never eaten them before so I popped the first one into my mouth and scalded the entire thing. After I figured it out I was able to enjoy them and found myself wishing I had 24-36 more to eat. This was followed up by the general Tso's chicken which was without a doubt the best I have had. Perfectly crispy on the outside, delicate and flavorful on the inside, and a nice lingering spice of medium intensity. It is cash only and the prices are more than fair. By the end of the meal you will forget all about how long you waited.

This restaurant lived up to my expectation. The XLB was better than Din Tai Fung in San Jose. The size was good, bigger than San Jose DinTaiFung. They also had a good amount of crab for each XLB. The fillings were pretty flavorful, too. The crab flavors did stood out. 

The XLB soup was fatty (not oily), and had lots of meat flavors. Lots of Napa cabbage too. Probably the best XLB i've had in the U.S

I also ordered the Yang Chou fried rice (fried rice w peas, chicken, eggs), which was also very good. I had more than half of it togo. $24 in total for this meal and it fed me more than 2 meals. Great deal!

CASH ONLY.

One of the better dim sum places in manhattan if you can't make it out to queens. It gets crowded on weekends at all times with long wait times so if you have a large group you will have to wait if you go at peak hours. We always get a large variety of dishes and always leave full !

My quest for the best xiao long bao has brought me a long way from my home in Hawaii...... all the way to Manhattan's Chinatown. I was here on vacation (I used to live here and consider it my home) and browsed Yelp, of course, to look for a place to eat soup dumplings. A few reviews stated that Joe's Shanghai was very good, although touristy. Hmmm.... I was staying in the Village so Chinatown was close by. Why not? My best friend from my early NYC days and I hopped in a cab and off we went.

I'm happy to say that when we went today, it was not filled with tourists. In fact, it was filled with a lot of locals, which is always a good thing. We were promptly seated and brought glasses of hot tea, which were so good on this cold February morning. We ordered turnip cakes, scallion pancakes, pork pan fried dumplings, and pork xiao long bao. Where do I begin to describe how delicious the food was? The turnip cakes were crunchy on the outside, soft and almost creamy in the middle, and a very good start to our wonderful meal. Our server quickly brought out the scallion pancake and pork dumplings. Scallion pancake is a must have - nicely crispy with a deliciously mild scallion flavor. The black vinegar complemented this perfectly. Pork pan fried dumplings were also a hit, with a crunchy exterior and deliciously moist interior, with lots of pork flavor. Our last dish brought out was the pork xiao long bao. This beats any of the XLBs I've had in Hawaii. Very juicy, with hot, flavorful soup that you slurp up after you poke a small hole in the side of it, then add chili oil or black vinegar and enjoy the heavenly pork filling. What an outstanding dining experience! I hope to come back on my next trip to NYC, which will be in a few months. Other tables were having fried rice, noodles, chicken and beef dishes, but there were only two of us and we didn't have the stomach space, so sadly the amount of food we could eat was limited. I give this place a well deserved, solid 5 stars.
The fried dumplings were the best I've ever had. It is a must go place. The table style is communal which is great for meeting new people. I loved my time here!

I come with a bunch of friends for dinner. This was the last to-eat item on our trip to NYC. I sit down, the waiter comes over and asks if we want any dumplings. Obviously it's because it takes some time to steam. There's 6 of us. I say I want 4 orders...my friend stare at me. Fine, fine...change it three orders.

We order other dishes, here and there as well. The crab XLB comes out, and everyone LOVES it. No one can have enough. And I'm like, duh that's why I wanted 4 orders. My sole purpose of going to Joe's Shanghai is for the crab XLB. It's awesome, and you can't get anything else like it from CA. The rest of the menu is so-so. Nothing to write home about. Nothing to rave. It is what it is. BUT THE CRAB XLB. That's all you need yelpers. It'll change your taste buds. Promise.

Now our friends also asked why the Chinatown location, why not the one in midtown? And obviously Flushing is too far. Chinatown because (a) it's cheaper and (b) you get two more pieces than Midtown!

5 star food, 2 star service. The servers are a bit rude and you have to share tables but the food is honestly worth it. Try #1 on the menu ! Amazing xiao long baos. The fried rice is also pretty good! Definitely try it at least once.
The soup dumplings were a delight. Pan fried noodles were OK... The wait was long but it was a Sun...

This is classic New York Chinese, it's very hard to find this in other parts of the country. The soup dumplings were amazing- good in size, but also having a dumpling skin that doesn't spill easily. (Many soup dumpling places have dumplings that break as soon as you pick em up). The flavor of the dumpling was fantastic too- it had a little bit of crab roe flavor combined with the classic pork filling. The wait was not too bad either, we waited about 10 minutes for a party of 3 on a weekend.

I have been craving this food since the year 2000, when I was first introduced to this cozy crowded habitat. My friends were crazy for the  dumplings, but my taste buds went wild for the Pan Fried Chilean Sea Bass ! Oh my Godddd!!! Hope it's still the same when I visit this year...yeah, I'll write another review in May 2008 after 'I'm back.
 One thing I discovered about New York...the good food joints usually have a line outside.

5 Stars for the soup dumplings alone. 

The quality of food is perfect and affordable.  I would definitely go back again.

tasty XLB (steamed soup dumplings).   fatty, piping hot and affordable.

come here for the soup dumplings (pork or pork and crab) and perhaps an order of shanghai noodles (stir fry) or scallion pancakes.  tried other dishes through the years and trust me they are not memorable and not worth the cash nor calories.  
 
do not expect good service, they are abruptly efficient.  likely reason why 15% gratuity is already added to the bill.  zero ambiance.  expect lines.  and yes, despite all this I am still a fan.

Joes shanghai has the best soup dumplings I have ever tasted. I have tried their crab soup dumplings and their pork soup dumplings and both were AMAZING. This is the perfect thing to eat on a cold day. This is the perfect thing to eat on anyday. Inside the dumplings is liquid soup with crumbles of soft meat inside. It all, sort of, comes together in harmony once in your mouth. It is a must try, very memorable food that will create an experience that will last a life time.

I never write reviews but this place was amazing. great service and even better food. had pork soup dumplings for the first time in my life, and I don't think I'll ever forget that first bite. a must if you're in China town!

this was my first experience with xiao long bao and it won't be my last.  
i was visiting a friend in nyc last weekend and she took me to joe's shanghai...it was a friday afternoon (around 3pm) and there was no wait (but we shared a table with another party since there were only two of us)
we split the soup dumplings, scallion pancake and fried pork dumplings...our bill came to less than $20..

their scallion pancakes were tasty and addicting...the pork dumplings were good, too...but the best part were the soup dumplings..
they were amazing.  

go and try them. now. 

if i wasn't here in houston, i'd be there slurping the goodness that is in their soup dumplings.

I have died and gone to dumplings heaven .  If given the option I would seriously consider trading my first born son for some crab dumplings . The service is the only thing holding me back from giving this dumpling house 5 stars .

Came here twice, once eat-in & once to-go.

EAT-IN -- 5 stars
They sit you wherever there's space, so we sat with like 2 other parties. Relatively little wait because of that, which I appreciated. We got one order of pork xiaolongbao & one of crab. Both were SOOO good and hot and juicy, totally worth the craziness. Quite filling for boyfriend & me. They churned these babies out fast too, so we were in and out like *that*. AMAZING experience.

TAKE-OUT -- 3 stars
Told my parents this place was amazing, so we had to get some xiaolongbao even though we were in a hurry. They weren't nearly as good when you're not eating them superfresh, and I was a little embarrassed. We didn't even save that much time since the xiaolongbao took longer for takeout I guess. BOOo.. lesson learned.

5stars for Pork dumplings, the rest 3stars, hence 4stars for average.
I would suggest sticking with pork over crab or you can be like the other newbs and try them for yourself then settle for pork in following visits. The dumplings are served 8 at a time, after having a few, you will understand why tea is served, to counter the fatty soup within the dumplings. Having said that, pork dumplings are delicious, the best around.
This place does require an overhaul. Service, cleanliness, and waitlist system can all be improved. Service is more of an obligatory requirement here, not sure who the client is. Cleanliness, look for yourself. Waitlist, often 3 parties are thrown in together on one table, I barely enjoy eating with my kids never mind strangers!
Ultimately, this place is popular because the pork dumplings over come all the minuses and more.

The Next Time:
Go for early dinner or late dinner. Prime time does not work here unless you know the owner. Do not take kids. Skip the crab dumplings and stick with the pork dumplings.
Well known with good food. Felt rushed.

Wow, this place is quite the attention getter. My bf and I waited about 20 minutes to get seated? We walked around China town while waiting so it wasn't so bad.
We sat family style with other people but on our own separate tab. Kind of crammed but it's okay. Anything to get seated fast and food in our belly! 
We ordered the regular pork XLB, crab/pork XLB, and their crispy noodles w/ beef. 
The crab/pork XLB was so so so good & flavorful!! Also, the crispy noodles were diffferent than we ever had. We didn't really eat much of it because we got full since the XLBs were so big. The price to portion ratio was so worth it & so affordable I think.

What changed the game to us was later in the evening when we ate our crispy noodle leftover, all the juices had soaked up and man ..... it was sooooo good. I enjoyed it that way better than fresh & crispy! It's because their noodles are like poofed rice noodles. I can't explain it but the texture and taste was a 10/10. I'd come back when in NY!! I think they are moving locations soon???

Review is only for the not so xiao, xiao long baos! Really though these are some of the hugest xlb dumplings I've ever had and coming from California I've been to tons of Chinese restaurants in my lifetime.

The pork ones are pretty good but the pork/crab ones are soooooo juicy and delicious. Highly recommend springing for the crab ones because they're wayyy more flavorful and they actually do put a good amount of crab. They add some yummy steamed shredded cabbage which is nice because most places don't give anything with their baos.

I liked the crab pork dumplings so much I came back two more times in my one week in NY. Nothing else on the menu really impressed me in addition to the fact the prices for everything else seemed too high.

Still will keep coming back and doing my takeout bao orders when I'm in NY.
So after we ate at another place, we order some for to go back to our apt. Not a big dumpling fan but the dumplings at this place was delicious! So soft and the juice inside of it was to die for!

I was blown away by the food at Joe's Shanghai. I will admit, I was a little thrown off by the name when a friend informed me that that's where we were headed, but as soon as I turned onto Pell Street and saw the crowd waiting outside on a MONDAY NIGHT, I knew any reservations I might have had were obsolete.

We were there with a large group...there were eleven of us. While we did have a bit of a wait, it wasn't nearly as long as I was expecting. A couple of people actually went for a 20 minute massage right across the street while we waiting, and we ended up missing our table and having to wait a little longer!

Even with that, the wait wasn't that bad. We were all able to sit around a big table, which was a little cramped, but not anything I'm not used to. The hardest part was being left handed and sitting next to a rightie, and having chop stick battles all night.

Of the group of us, there was only one person who had eaten there before. As a result, she took charge and ordered a bunch of dishes that everyone could share, which really was the best way to do things. And even though we had 3 vegetarians at the table, everyone left full. The service was great, too! I think, at times, we had up to four people waiting on our table. They all helped each other out. And they stayed totally in the background, which is the goal of waiting a large group.

I think the best part was the price. There were 11 people in our party, everyone left full, we had an entire bag full of boxes of leftovers, and the check broke down to $12 a person, including tax and tip. For the sheer amount and quality of food, I was blown away by the low price. I couldn't even count how many dishes were ordered!

I'm definitely going to be coming back here. I was very impressed by this restaurant all around. I'd definitely recommend it.

One of the best dumplings and Chinese food in general. There's few locations and I've heard the China Town one was the best. 

The only thing I was a bit annoyed was that they didn't call our number or thought we weren't there and waited extra 15-20mins....good thing the food was delicious ha. I'll definitely come back. 

Things I ordered:
- shanghai noodles 
- pork soup dumplings
- kung pow chicken

Had 'em in Shanghai, had 'em in L.A., had 'em in Toronto, had 'em at Joe's Shanghai in Manhattan.  The best is at Joe's Shanghai.  

The amount of soup in one dumpling is incredible, and the fact that the soup does not break the thin dumpling skin is a skill only known to a select few.  Knowing how hard it is to make these puppies makes eating them so much more enjoyeable.  

Indulge, eat as many as you can and then take a long nap.  When you wake up, congratulate yourself, and thank me for having saved you 2k in airfare to Shanghai.
Rude service..but with food this great..who gives a damn! Definitely worth the 40 min wait.
Been here multiple times. Love the soup dumplings. Great options for Vegetarians as well. Regular joint

This place has one of the biggest and juiciest xiao long bao I have ever had. We ordered pork soup dumplings, pork and crab soup dumplings, vegetable lo mein, and shanghai noodle soup. My favorite was the pork soup dumpling; the skin was thin yet it still held onto the soup very well. The vegetable lo mein and shanghai noodle soup was okay. If I come here again, I would stick to the xiao long bao.

The line outside is a but intimidating when you first get there however they are pretty efficient with getting you seated quickly. I am visiting from San Diego and my friends showed me this place and I'm glad they did. Dumplings that inside it has soup?!? Like WHAT.. Haha had to try. Got the scallion pancake BOMB.. The dumplings are really good got the pork and it's actually really filling. The chicken fried rice with soy sauce was really good.. I feel like anything you order would be really good.Service was average nothing amazing. Had to ask for more water a lot but definitely is worth a shot and be ready to wait.

Absolutely lived up to the hype!!! Cash only so make sure you have a good amount. A lot of fun to go to with a big group or just a couple people. Soup dumplings are a must and the general tso's was sick too

Ok. 4 stars only because when I walked down the block there was a less famous place with cheaper soup dumplings. AND because I don't like to sit with strangers who talk about eating cats and dogs while I eat...

ANYWAY, took my brother and his girlfriend here when they were visiting from Miami. Very friendly staff. Short wait, because we sat with other people. Dumplings were pretty good.. Not great. But I don't have much to compare too. I will let you know later.... but it was worth it.

The food tastes like any other average restaurant you can find in other places but it's still good. It wasn't a wow experience to me even though I heard so much about them. They also have very big portions. The pictures below were shared by 3 people and we couldn't really finish it all.
best soup dumplings ever the rest of the food is good but the soup dumplings man so so so so so so so so so so so so so good

Came in the middle of the afternoon on a weekday just for the soup dumplings. Had to wait about 10 minutes but it was so worth it. All the food coming out around us looked amazing-- I will definietly be back.

How do you get a vegetarian to eat their pork? Send 'em to Joe's Shanghai! WOW, their dumplings (xiao long bao, or XLB), are amazing. There's no need to look at the menu. Just order the crab dumplings (crab and pork mix) and you're set! Hear that-- the CRAB dumplings. It tastes so much better w/ the crab. 

The trick is how to eat them. It's actually a delicate procedure: pick up the dumpling GENTLY from the bamboo steamer. Don't go all crazy or you'll poke a hole and spill all the yummy juices. Once you've picked it up, put it on your spoon and tilt the spoon sideways, balancing the dumpling in place with your chopsticks. Then, nibble a tiny hole in the dumpling skin and suck out the juice- delish! That is actually the best part of the XLB. 

And don't act all weirded out that you're sitting at a communal table. Space is at a minimal in here, so don't get all huffy you can't get a private table. Expect a 30-45 minute wait for seating. But it is SO worth it. We went here twice in a 2 day span and would have come more if we had the chance. This is a MUST visit whenever you're in the area.

Ventured here on a Saturday afternoon for lunch and was glad we did!

**First and foremost: they only accept cash!!!** (We never carry more than $10-$20 in cash, so we had to stop across the street in a pharmacy and pull out cash from the ATM there.)

So, we headed back over. It was pretty busy around the lunch hour, but we were seated right away. Just as others have mentioned, if you are 2-3 people coming, you will be sat at a cozy table with strangers. It was fine for us, but I know some people may not prefer that dining style. The interior is older and overall, it was pretty cramped, but we were there for the food. As a side note, the pics others posted on here were helpful because the menu is very simple and contains no pictures or detailed descriptions.

They give you your own little pot of tea, which is always a nice touch. We couldn't wait to order the pork soup dumplings. They arrived quickly and were everything I had hoped for and more! We actually ended up sharing with the others at our table because we still had 2 main dishes coming out.

My husband loves trying different bizarre things, and tried the cold appetizer of kidney and vegetables. It was actually not bad. It had a little too much of a game meat taste for me to want more, but it was tender and kind of reminded me of Buffalo or venison. I wouldn't order it again, but hey, it was worth trying something out of my comfort zone!

I ordered the pan fried noodles with chicken. This portion is huge...like, 2-3 people could easily share this and be full, especially if you've had the dumplings to start with. I loved these noodles! It was my first time having them, and they easily soften up in the sauce, but the crunchy bites were also perfect.

My husband ordered ginger chicken. This didn't come out like we had expected, but was delicious nonetheless. Just know, that the chicken with this dish isn't nicely chopped up for you, but instead is the whole chicken pieces with the meat still attached to the bones and the skin is still in tact. 

The service was very quick, even on a busy Saturday afternoon. I def will go back next visit to NYC!

Packed to the tits, but the food is so fire. The prices are good and I love the communal seating. Made some new friends. Even if you're a vegetarian the food is gooood. Serving sizes are big so bring your tupperware and your other stomach.

Have heard a lot about this place so it was a must visit during our last trip to NYC. The xiao long bao are not xiao! They are quite big! Do not assume they are Ding Tai Feng sized dumplings! We had two orders of the pork soup dumplings and two orders of the pork and crab soup dumplings. I preferred the dumplings without the pork.

The green beans were also tasty.

We arrived about half an hour before opening and didn't line up until about 15 minutes before opening. We were able to grab a large table for 6. The staff are very efficient in seating you, taking your order, clearing the plates and grabbing your check and payment. Very lean operation.

If you are traveling as a small party be prepared to share a table.

couldn't help but take my French friend to his first soup dumplings experience at none other than joe's shanghai! i remember when I first came here in 2016, this place blew me away (and dintaifung out of first place for soup dumplings for me).

- crab and pork soup dumplings ($10). these were the dumplings that stole my heart the first time i came!! the crab makes the filling just punch you in da face with flava... so bold, soooo crabby, and so soupy!! love love! 

- regular soup dumplings ($8). these were a lot less flavorful than the crab ones! if I didn't get these with the crab ones, they'd be decent, but in comparison, they were just ok! 

- boiled pork dumplings ($10). these dumplings thankfully came out before the soup dumplings ... i say that because they are pretty bland with a really soggy wrapper. they tasted ok by themselves, but once the soup dumplings came out, didn't really get any more attention from us... def just stick with the soul dumplings!!

Go to the Chinatown location! (Or don't, so that I can get a table there quicker ;) ) seriously though the soup dumplings are to die for - if you eat here and don't get them I don't know what's wrong with you. They'll rock your world but be careful they're HOT!

I love their beef tendon stew with tofu and Xiaolongbao very very very much. They are Super delish! Their noodles are good too.

Very crowded place though. After a long waiting and got seated, the seats were extremely close to the people beside us. We shared tables with the others all the time.

After all, come here for food. Nothing else.
Great food and service from dumplings to entries. The only thing is braving the long lines, but worth it!
Super yummy soup dumplings and cheap cold beer were enough to get me here, and are probably enough to get me to come back.

Have been here multiple times and it doesn't change, it jsut remains great. Soup dumplings are the go-to and what their known for. Easily eat two baskets with a friend. All of the entree dishes like the spicy chicken dish with rice, etc are all great!

the soup dumplings, period.  if you only want soup dumplings, then heres your place.  if you dont care about sitting next to strangers or getting mediocre service that push you out as fast as possible, then come here.  luckily, most people only care about that because its always crowded.  best soup dumplings around.  tried a few other places too, but nope not as good.  besides those, they have a really tasty pan fried noodle.  great taste.  so come for a quick great meal and maybe even meet a few strangers who have the same crave for a yummy soup dumpling.  a side note, the joes shanghai on fifth ave is terrible! way more expensive and food isnt as good.  only go to this location in chinatown.  cash only tho.

The best Xiao Long Bao I've ever had. Visited NY two weeks ago, visited Joe's twice. The XLB was amazing! Big and juicy, very tasty. I'm a big XLB fan, after visiting Joe's Shanghai, Ding Tai Fung is no longer my favorite place to have XLB. Find no where to eat the best XLB at Los Angles. Definitely come back. Highly recommend!

Yummy!!! LOVE soup dumplings and these were a good 8/10. I have had some really good xlb and I'd say these were pretty solid. The crispy noodles were also bussin and had a lot of beef and veggies! The beef wasn't cheap, asian fast food beef and there was a decent amount of it. 

We arrived around 6pm and didn't have to wait. There was a line by the time we left though! Prices aren't the lowest but the serving sizes are good. Servers are also always around to refill water which was nice.

I've never tried soup dumplings in my life, and boy do I regret not trying them after my first visit to Joe's Shanghai. 
Their dumplings are juicy and tender, and dare I say the best dumplings I've ever tried in my life. 
Although I had to wait a while for a table, it was totally worth waiting out in a cold rain because those dumplings immediately warmed my body. 
I recommend trying them with fried rice and spinach. 
In fact, all dishes are delicious, so do yourself a favor and give them a try.

the dumplings are cheap and delicious.  i went with my friend who is more familiar with the food than i am so i let her take the reins and she did an excellent job.  one good thing about communal sitting is that when you order too much (like we did), you can give it to your neighbors!  the scallion pancakes were so good.

Newly renovated location = less claustrophobic, more luxe! (but we're talking about a high traffic Chinatown gem here, so folks, adjust your expectations accordingly).

Get pork soup dumplings during off-peak hours, like 3pm on a Tuesday.  Scallion pancakes don't disappoint either- they're crispy and crunchy (a rarity)!

Don't forget to bring cash!

I was recommended this place due to its popularity & my love of soup dumplings.

Net, net: eh. Average rating is accurate at 4.3. Pork soup dumplings are good, but definitely have had better a few blocks away or for takeout in Brooklyn. I didn't strongly dislike it, but I also won't be seeking it out or marking it as a favorite.

Things I like:
- speedy: I arrived around 6:30 on a Monday in a hurry & got out by 7:05ish
- waiters are no fuss if that's you're style; however I did just realize I didn't see any waitresses 

Things I didn't like:
- personally, way too bright. I didn't get the Chinese cozy charm that I prefer
- 1 or 2 dumplings leaked in the container, so picking it up & placing on my spoon was unnecessarily messy
- I prefer spoons that are larger than the dumpling to feel secure in my bite & let the soup be runny for one big slurp
- broth was okay. ‚Äç I'm not sure how to describe it.. but it just didn't do it for me

It got packed around 7 with a wait out the door. So if you're still going to try it (because to each its own) & you don't want to wait - try before 6:30.

Also it's cash only. There's a sign when you walk in. Two ATMs. Two BOAs within a block in either direction. It's on alll of the reviews here & on Yelp. Please don't be that obnoxious tourist trying to negotiate using a CC. I'm embarrassed for you.

We went there n Sat night and there were many people wait outside the door. OMG. So my friend and I waited about 30min and finally we had a seat in a big round table with seven other people. 

I must say the "xiao long bao" is sooooooooo delicious that I can't stop eating them!!! Highly recommand "Crab Xiao Long". It is so delicious and juicy. I think I ate 15 bao zi that night.

Also I like the red bean dim sum. It is puffy and sweet. Oh I can't help myself with one more!!!

Anyway, their space is too limited. People all sitting in a small place and talk to each other loudly.

In a word, I love it !

Thank you fellow Yelper's!  I wanted to celebrate Chinese New Year's in Chinatown with some good soup dumplings, and I came to you for suggestions.  It was between Joe's and another place, but the other sounded like I wouldn't have room to sit.  

I was not disappointed- as soon as we receive menus, the efficient waiter asked how many soup dumpling orders we wanted.  They were working on those gorgeous babies while we browsed the menu for more good food.

I wasn't crazy about the boiled pork dumplings though- they were heavy and not appetizing enough to have more than one.  

We also ordered delicious sauteed water spinach and some baked turnip buns, and I obviously didn't eat fast enough, because my brother got most of the soup dumplings!  I will be back again.

As a foodie and someone who loves Chinese food, I decided it was time to start exploring Chinatown. I've been to Joe's a few times now and I haven't been disappointed. They don't take reservations and it's always crazy so I try to go at off times and usually the wait is only a few minutes. The smaller your party, the better chance you have at sitting. I'd say if you go with more than three people your chances of sitting relatively quickly are slim.

I would give this place five stars but I usually always have some small issue with the service. I always have to ask at least two or three times before someone brings me water. From my encounters I've noticed the waiters aren't very good at catering to their specific tables so I try to grab whoever is closest to me but that doesn't always work.
As soon as you sit down they ask if you want soup dumplings because if you aren't get soup dumplings at Joe's, why did you even bother going? They're always on point and delicious.
I'd advise having some kind of idea what you want to eat before even sitting down so that as soon as the waiter comes over you can order your food and be done with it. Once they walk away, it's so difficult to get them back.

Many good Chinese restaurants in NYC, by Joe's Shanghai never disappoints.  The soup dumplings are up to the hype and their braised noodle dishes are outstanding.  Worth every second I spent waiting to be seated (15 mins) and I recommend it highly.
Excellent food, terrible service.  It says it is family friendly, but it really was not.

Love love love the pork soup dumplings and the salt and pepper shrimp! I came here on a Monday around lunch time with some girlfriends and luckily we beat the lunch crowd that were waiting in line for a good minute. I heard it gets really crowded and is usually a long wait on most days so I'm really glad we lucked out and were seated right away.The service was very efficient and the food was delicious, I will definitely be back!

Excellent Soup Dumplings.  There is usually a line, but it moves fast.  Be prepared to sit with strangers.  The place is crowded and loud.

Soup Dumplings are what makes this place famous, and you shouldn't miss them, but the rest of the menu is very good.

The staff is fast and abrupt.  It's tough to get clear answers to any questions you might ask.

I've been twice and would eat here again.

Best Chinese food in the country. Located in the heart of Chinatown.

No reservations so be early and expect a wait, worth it...

Last visit, Tuesday afternoon, I went around 11:45 sat down right away, it was packed with a waiting list when we left. Incredible in Chinatown where there are literally hundreds of choices.  Most other diners were native Chinese, I was one of the few "white" guys there.  My dining companion is Phillipino so they let it go... just kidding.

My must have foods start with the crab soup dumplings. I could finish there but the young chow fried rice is the BEST ever!  The braised port shoulder is a delicacy.  Don't forget to get a scallion pancake, goes perfectly with the the rice or on its own.

You will not be dissatisfied even if you have to wait....  a nice tea compliments the lunch well.

Love the dumplings here! Crab and pork are my fav. My friends and I will do food tours around NYC (we come from all over the states) and we always make sure to come here and get a FEW orders of the dumplings! Haven't had another place like this one!

You have to come here to try the Crab dumpling. They are know for this.  It is soo good. At first I order one order of the Crab dumpling and didn't realize how good it was.  After I midway finish the 1st order I had to order another because it was that good. I also order a few other dishes here but it was ok. The food tends to be a little greasy but that's your typical chinese food. The restaurant is small and a little dirty but they are very busy. If you don't have a large party be prepare to share a table if your seated in one of the bigger tables. It's how' your typical asian restaurants are run if you came from Hong Kong. They have a lot of servers here so the service is quick. No matter what time you come here there is always a lot of people.

I always see these soup dumplings on the travel channel and I always wanted to try it.  I'm so glad my first time is at an authentic Chinese restaurant.  The dumpling comes out piping hot so be careful with your first bite.  It comes in a pork or crab meat variety, I like the pork more.   We also ordered Salt and Pepper Pork Chops and Beef Lo Mein.  The pork chops was really good, the lo mein I can do with out though.  It was really pack so you may have to share table more smaller groups.

if i'm in new york for 3 days (and i will be next week) i'll go here twice and get the xiao long bao. i like to think san francisco has a pretty broad spectrum of food but nowhere in the bay area have i gotten xlb anywhere as good as at joe's shanghai in new york. i know someone else basically said the same thing but it's worth stating again. for a while i was on a mission to find it in san francisco, on the peninsula, basically anywhere i could get to in a car. alas i have given up and settled for joe's shanghai

When you arrive at the restaurant you're probably going to have to wait to be seated, but trust me it is worth it. When you finally make it inside you will notice one thing: soup dumplings on every table. These are some of the best soup dumplings in the city and must be ordered if you decide to dine at Joe's Shanghai. The broth within the soup is so perfectly flavorful and the perfect amount of creamy. The pork is well seasoned and the chives bring it all together. Nothing is better the eating soup dumplings on a cold New York day. Please visit!

Great tastes! Soup dumplings were fantastic! Portions are very large we couldn't finish everything but it was enough to bring home for a lunch next day. Long waiting line, however we came for a late lunch around 3-4pm and only had to wait 15min.

Joe's Shanghai is a solid soup dumpling spot that I frequent when I am visiting NYC! My sister lives in NYC and I am from out of town so whenever I go visit she always brings me here for a meal. They have good soup dumplings, not the best I have ever had but definitely good and the portion size to price is pretty good as well. They have a good amount of soup inside of them and the meat filling to soup/wrapper ratio is good as well. We also ordered the sweet and sour soup and the beef low mein which were solid choices as well. This is a new location they opened up which is more spacious and updated than their previous locations. Overall I definitely enjoyed this place and would recommend.

Xiao long bao lives up to the billing.  I ordered the pork shoulder and must admit it was super tender and incredibly tender.  the portion size could have easily could have served 2-3 guests.  the wait may be 20-40 minutes but that is the norm and the staff does a great job of moving things along without really rushing the customers.  Highly recommended.
Excellent option for this cuisine! A star cleanliness rating. Best scallion pancakes I've ever had. The pork soup dumplings were fantastic too. On top of it all, friendly service.
Dumpling breakfast happiness. Fast easy tasty, my love for dumplings  thank you. Go eat and be merry

My husband and I had to try Joe's Shanghai when visiting NYC for the holidays. We were pleasantly surprised surprised that there was no line it was definitely busy though. We shared a table with another couple which I thought would be weird since the tables are so small but it wasn't. Every table had 1+ orders of the soup dumplings. We tried them and they were good. They're definitely worth giving a try. We also had the fried dumplings and pork fried rice which were ok.

It was definitely a positive experience. Being able to sit with others and see what they ordered, as well as enjoy our food at a low price, it was the highlight of our day. Scallion pancakes, both kinds of soup dumplings, and shredded pork soup were amazing!

Walked in here at 2 ish on a Sunday, scared that the wait would be monstrous. Luckily got seated right away. Just had to share a table with 6 others, nbd as long as we got our dumpling fix. $14 for an order of dumplings, beef soup noodles, and scallion pancake? Not bad at all. 

Be careful about the temperature of the dumplings!! I really like their hot sauce and mixing it with some of the vinegar for a kick, but really the dumplings are perfect on their own, without sauce. 

My goal in the future is to have a dry plate. Aka, no soup spillage. It always breaks my heart when the soup oozes out. Not only is it ugly, but it's such a waste of the hearty, delicious xlb broth.

Oh yea their tea was particularly nasty :( dunno why it tasted like a mixture of a million different types of tea leaves. It's such a simple thing but it really disturbed me.
My go to place for Shanghainese in NYC. Always packed but worth the wait.

I've heard such good things about this place that I was really excited to go. There were a bunch of people outside waiting to be seated but my boyfriend and I only needed to wait around 10 minutes for the two of us. They do an interesting thing where if you have a small enough party, they do community tables and you share a table with another small party. I was pretty hungry so I didn't mind sharing a table.

We ordered two orders of xiao long baos (xlb) and one order of potstickers for 6.25 each and 8 pieces which is pretty cheap! When we got the orders they were super hot and fresh! The potstickers were flavorful and luckily it didn't taste too oily like some places make it. The xlb were huge and very flavorful! Probably the best soup dumplings I've ever had!

I LOVE LOVE LOVE shanghai dumplings! I haven't had good shanghai dumplings since my go-to shanghai restaurant shut down a few years ago back in the bay area. I was so excited to try their dumplings after reading the yelp reviews. We ordered the shanghai dumplings, fried bean curd, vegetarian duck & shanghai noodle soup. This place is sooo cheap! The meal was about $23 for all we ordered! Everything was good!!

What can I say about Joe's that hasn't already been said? Yes, you're probably going to have to wait. Yes, it's cash only. Yes, you're going to have to share a table with strangers.

Honestly, all of this is manageable if you come prepared. Put in your name and go walk around, grab some dollar dumplings down the street, etc. Get cash from any of the major banks in Chinatown. Sharing the table is no big deal. I've been here countless times and sometimes you sit with chatty people, sometimes everyone sticks to themselves and their group. 

Now, onto the food. The soup dumplings are very, very good, but I have had better in Flushing. The rest of the menu is good too, but obviously the soup dumplings are the main attraction. The service is fine. You definitely do have to flag wait staff down for water, extra napkins, etc. but I'm not expecting silver service here. 

I come here a few times a year and it's always worth it.

Hole in the wall with the most delicious soup dumplings. Every time I'm in the city I frequent this place! Meaning I come here 2-3 times even if I'm only in town for the weekend. The other food options are alright but I definitely recommend their specialty dumplings. Lunchtime during the week is always hectic but I do not care. I will wait around for a table for those dumplings. The ambiance is a little chaotic... expect to share your table with strangers! Don't bring friends that are picky eaters or don't like pork. This is not for them.

Best soup dumplings in Chinatown. Chose the pork meat dumplings as those were recommended.  Went here for lunch on a Sunday. Be prepared to wait but they have a ticket number system that moves fast. They also have a lot of tables and turn them over quickly. Everything was very fresh and clean and they had tons of staff who helped us order quick and get on with our day walking around Chinatown and Little Italy.

Dumplings here are the best I've ever had. We ordered them fried. I also liked the soup dumplings but be warned that they are messy. We were able to sit after about a 30 minute wait on a Saturday afternoon. The sesame chicken I could have done without. Definitely will be back.

Stopped at Joe's for dinner while visiting NY and was impressed! I highly suggest the pork dumplings - they are excellent and great for sharing! The helpings are pretty big so we split out entree as well. Something to be aware of prior to going is that it's a little noisy, you may be seated at a table with other people - there were 3 of us and we sat at a table with another group of 5 - and it's CASH ONLY!

Wow -- the passions invoked by Xiaolongbao...  :)  I'm going to write a different sort of review, particularly since most of the reviews have discussed many points to death, ie: quality of service, decor (lack thereof), alternative foods to the house specialty -- I agree with the concensus statements.

However, the XLB must be respected.  There's a comparison in an earlier review between Joe's and Ding Tai Fong of Taiwanese fame.  The mother ship restaurant in TPE is solid -- I can definitely say it's worth eating -- but other franchises (say, in LA?) aren't as good as the mothership.  Haven't been to the one in Japan yet...  Furthermore, true dumpling fever really doesn't hit you until you try the best in SH.  Though I've had some pretty amazing dumplings in Toronto and HKG.

But wherever you go, Xiaolongbao definitely serve as a display for one's dumpling proficiency.  Why?  Because the XLB requires quite a few components.  (Though, I like Shengjianbao -- and to me it can  display even more aspects of dumpling mastery)

What is it?  Simply put, you can call it a soup dumpling.  Traditionally served in round, wooden containers, the dumplings are cooked over a stream of steam, that can heat a whole stack of round containers, which are porous on the bottom.   The first place to screw up is what you cook it on.  Tradition puts it on a leaf -- which soaks up oil, but more importantly, prevents sticking to the container.   Sticking to the container loses dumpling points -- which can cause tears in the skin leading to tears in the eye of the dumpling lover as the "soup" pours out and away.  Personally, I like to transfer the dumpling into a chinese soup spoon first, where you can inspect it and "enhance it" with sauce.

The sauce is traditionally a soy based sauce with strips of garlic.  It's probably a bit uncouth to dip your food in the sauce, so one might consider pouring some atop the soup dumpling.  I've seen some people open the dumpling on top, (carefully! lest the soup spill!) and pour some of the sauce into the dumpling.  A good sauce for XLB should provide contrast to the flavour -- and no more.  The richness of the XLB soup and the texture and flavour of the meat should be the centerpiece.

Let's move further inside.   The skin shows off another dumpling skill.  Bad skin falls apart, tears easily, is uneven...  Bad skin folding results in uncomely dumplings.  Some houses make their skin thick and spongey, others thin and more elastic.  DTF goes for option 2, Joe's type 1.

Inside -- the "soup" and the meat.  I'm not going to go into too much detail here... but the "soup" obviously is not recommended for a "heart-healthy diet".  It's largely adipose... but is included as an additional component -- it's not "just" the natural juices of the meatball inside -- be they crab based or pork based.  

So: score card:
Skills for the container
Skin 
Skin folding
Sauce
Soup
Stuffing (meatball)

Don't worry, I'm not actually going to rate Joe's this way.  :)  I like their XLB -- but I don't love them.   I give them a 4 for taste and accessibility.  You don't need to get on a plane to get them, and its in a reasonably accessible place in NYC.  I'm not a big fan of their skin style -- and sometimes the crab consistency is a bit powdery for my tastes.  On the other hand, I stop by Joe's every other trip to NYC... so that should tell you something?

Don't be a tourist. Follow these simple rules:

1. Take the train to Canal street (parking is a toss-up)
2. Only order the soup dumplings (get one order per person, e.g. one pork, one crab, if you're with two)
3. Get Chinese beer with it
4. Bring cash (they only take cash)
5. Don't whine about waiting for a precious seat  (you're in NYC, no one's special)
6. Don't show up with half your party (if you want to eat within a reasonable amount of time, limit its size)
7. Do get a bubble tea from next door while waiting in order to curb your hunger
8. Don't be afraid to eat the cabbage
9. You can use the sauce if you like, but it isn't necessary.

I was born and raised in NYC, yet haven't lived there in over a decade. I still come back just for the dumplings. Yes, they are that good.

*** BONUS: A common game played is to take bets on who spills the least soup. The person with the dirtiest plate at the end of the meal pays.
Amazing soup dumplings! My husband and I have been on the search for good soup dumplings, and this hit the spot. Will be coming back to New York for more.
The soup dumplings are good, and you have to share the table. But Like I said the soup dumplings are sooooooo good. The wait is a mutha too, but it is worth it. Did I say the soup dumplings are good.

Love this place! One of my must go to places in NY for their stream soupy dumplings.  This place always have a long line, but they work fast and it's cheap!  Can't beat it!  If you're new to NY, I would highly recommend this place...it's so popular...it comes up on google maps when u're looking at the area.

Went there for lunch. There's no line and it's cash only but there's an ATM nearby. The interior decorations are nice. We ordered the crab and pork soup dumpling and the Shanghai egg noodles with chicken. The soup dumplings  are amazing and flavorful. This is a must. We didn't like the noodles for it's price its not worth it.

The first time I came to Joe's Shanghai, I was still a kid visiting NY for the first time with my parents and their friends.  I remembered the busy atmosphere, the fish tank at the door, and the set up of the tables.  Most of all, I remember how happy I was eating the endless number of yummy dumplings.  The only thing I didn't remember was the name of the restaurant.  Years later, I came here again because of a friend's recommendation, and the second I set foot in the restaurant, I knew I was in the same restaurant I visited as a kid.  It was a very special moment....

So back to the review:
The soup dumplings seriously make me weep with joy...I love those little things!  You can't come here and not order these!  After ordering these, just pick whatever else you want off the menu...I haven't had a bad dish here yet.  The dumplings are the most memorable thing about the restaurant though.   

The service is kind of rushed because the place is always packed during mealtimes, and they like to group different parties at one large table to seat everyone more efficiently.  I don't really mind because the food comes out at lightning speed.  

I took off one star because the wait for seating can be torture. I remember waiting for an hour just to get in once.  Watching everyone else enjoying their awesome dumplings makes me really grumpy.  But when you finally sit down and have that first soup dumpling, you realize that it was all worth it!  

I make trips to NYC a lot (mostly for the food), and I never leave without at least getting some dumplings from Joe's.  I am so thankful to have found this restaurant again!

Pork xiao long bao on a rainy December day = perfection. Got here close to opening time on a Thursday so no wait. There's definitely an art in eatu g these without breaking them and wasting all the yummy soup! 

I came with my mom, and she agrees four stars is appropriate. She was a little peeved that they didn't accept cards, as its more of a restaurant than a small eats shop.
The soup dumplings, scallion pancake, general Taos chicken are delicious and a MUST when you visit this restaurant. You may have to wait to be seated, but it is well worth the wait!!

The soup dumplings were amazing!!! We waited 45 min to get seated and we sat at a big table next to two other couples. First time dining at a place where we had to sit with random people. It wasn't as bad as I thought it was. We also ordered noodles and Kung pao chicken. It was good, but wouldn't go back for that but would go back just for the soup dumplings!!! Advice: order 2-3 orders of soup dumplings and nothing else. The sauce, the texture, meat all together was ridiculously good. The more soup dumplings you eat, the more you want to keep eating them!!!

Despite having been to nyc quite a few times I had never gotten around to going to this iconic NYC institution.

My moms side is from the Shanghai region and so I grew up eating Shanghainese food. What's interesting about this restaurant is that they seem to cater to people seeking authentic Shanghainese food as well as people who are here just for the soup dumplings who order things like general tsos chicken and beef and broccoli.

Egg rolls, $3.50 EACH is a bit much. There is a particular variety of egg roll unique to Shanghai. This is not it.
Soup dumplings, these are legit. Great pork and crab flavor. Good amount of soup. Very satisfying. Skin is on the thicker side but didn't bother me. No complaints here.
Yang chow fried rice, had all the correct components including chicken and ham. would have been good, but they forgot the salt.
Shanghai fried noodles, thick noodles stir fried w pork and spinach. Good wok hai, good flavor.
Lions head meatballs, super soft, fatty and luscious. Very tasty.

Overall I generally find these places to be overhyped, but this place met expectations for the most part aside from a few missteps.

Chinese food is never on my craving radar (cravedar?) when I charged with choosing (essentially never).  Therefore, I (1) don't know anything about the great Chinese restaurants in NYC and (2) would never willingly try one on my own.

Needless to say I found myself at Joe's Shanghai for a good friend's birthday party and the food was seriously stellar.  We ordered around a dozen dishes to share and everything was communally placed on the glass inner circle, which could be rotated by anyone for the greatest instant gratification dining experience you can imagine.  

Even if - like me - you would be fine never eating Chinese food again - you must check this place out...good as it gets.

Dumprings! I love me some dumprings! 

After a 20min wait, we sat down and ordered the pork dumplings, green onion pancake, green beans, and drunken chicken. These XLB's are some of the juiciest I've ever had, but the skin could've been thinner. They tasted so meaty, I almost thought they were beef for a minute. 

8 large dumprings for $4.95 vs. 10 small dumprings for $10.95 at Din Tai Fung. Just a completely different dining experience. Joe's is grungy, bustling, and they churn out some delightful soupy morsels.

came several minutes before it open to avoid the crowds.  Let me tell you, the crab soup dumplings were awesome.  Pours some vinegar and hot sauce and you are all set.  This is by far the best thing i ever ate in my new york city trip!
Serve super fantastic xiaolongbao (dumpling). The place isn't that big so if your party is 1-3, you might share the table with others

Stopped in one day for lunch... ok, just a TON of dumplings... and man were we stuffed!

Decor: While unassuming from the outside it is semi-cramped inside (expect to share a table with one, or two, groups). The actual decor is about what you'd expect from a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. The tables vary in size but the smaller the group the better... - be warned that it does get BUSY during lunch.
Bathroom: I didn't use it while there.

Staff: Our waiter was very attentive and very quick with taking our orders. He was speedy bringing out our multiple orders of Soup Dumplings and everything arrived at once.

Food: We started with the Pork Soup Dumplings (x3) and that is all we had haha. Wow, the Soup Dumplings are OUT OF THIS WORLD FANTASTIC! We knew what we were there for (as I've been to Joe's in mid-town previously) and we enjoyed every bite. I would, however, recommend that if you are ordering multiple orders of dumplings you should do them (at most) two at a time - any more than that and they can cool off by the time you get to them. Oh, and hot tea is complimentary but we had tap water (you have to ask for it) and two Cokes.

Value: The prices are not bad and the food is delicious, so you get great value for your money here! P.S. - Cash only!

This place is a great spot and the dumplings are worth it alone. I already can't wait to tell others about this place and am already dying to go back!

Soup dumplings! Oh, my lovely soup dumplings! Yes, this place is touristy. Yes, there is always a wait. Yes, they sometimes rush you out. But if you are prepared for these things, and just keep thinking that the food will be worth it, then you are in for a treat. Everything I have ever had is yummy. Crispy prawns, shredded beef, noodles, fried rice, General Tsao's, and their shrimp wonton soup. It's all yum. This is a cash only establishment, and even though tip is included, they will sometimes not return with your change, thinking it's a tip. Make sure you tell them that you expect change. You can, of course, then tip them over the 15%. Can't wait to go back!

Being from LA, the closest we have to this is a Din Tai Fung. But honestly it's not even good to me! So I was kinda iffy trying this place out. I had to give it a try because my friends were raving about this place. It is kinda of awkward having to share table with strangers like now I really have to eat properly. Everything we got was so good. Service was okay!
Great soup dumplings!!  i like that the chicken is not in pork broth.

I came here with a friend and thanks to Yelp I came prepared knowing that the first thing that would be asked by the waiter as we get seated is whether we want the dumplings for they take a bit to come out. I told him we wanted both the pork and crab one. We also ordered the shredded beef with peppers and another beef and chicken dish. Starting off with the dumplings, I really recommend the pork ones, they have a really good taste. The shell is the right consistency and the meat inside was really good. The crab ones (seafood dumpling or whatever it actually was ) we did not really like. The taste and smell of it just wasn't appetizing to either of us. We left three or so on the bamboo dish. Its true what they say that you will be sharing your table with other people but it makes it interesting because our table at least was open to conversation. The walls are covered with photos of famous people that have visited we were stoked when we saw the character that plays Daryl on the walking dead had visited. As we were leaving in front of us came in Justin Brescia. I didn't know who he was but my friend got super excited and took her word of his importance. She didn't ask for his photo because she didn't want to intrude on his date. But anyways this place is a must for soupy dumplings, pork are a must, crab = try at your own risk.

Dear reviewers,
Please stop posting pictures of the soup dumplings.
After 1000 of the same pictures, I believe users will get an idea of what they look like.

Anyway, you can tell by the 2000+ reviews and the line that's out the door on a cold winter night that this place is simply awesome.  Like Barney Stinson awesome.
AWESOME!

We were a little caught off guard when our party of two was taken to a large table to share with two other parties, but it's only a hassle for the party on the side of the wall, since it's hard for them to get out after finishing their meal.

We ordered the Shanghai fried noodles and the soup dumplings. The soup dumplings were amazing, and it was funny how they gave us a pair of tongs to pick up each dumpling. The soup dumplings were amazing, though - would absolutely come here again just for that. The Shanghai fried noodles were also very good - we ordered it because it's such a classic dish for us to get whenever we go to Shanghainese places - it was good but didn't necessarily stand out to us.
Always a solid experience.  Great menu and of course the soup dumplings are among the best in NYC.

This place was PACKED on a Saturday lunchtime. I was told the wait time for party of 2 was 15 min but waited about 20 min. 

We ordered the pork soup dumplings which was amazing it's definitely a MUST TRY and the serving portions was huge. It arrived first and didn't get the noodles until much later, I had to follow up twice to get it. 

When the Shanghai saut√©ed udon noodles arrived it was pretty good but honestly not worth the wait. I'm docking a star for the lack of ambiance, it was too crowded and no music which I consider an important part of the experience. I would come here again on a weekday and order the pork dumplings again. 

Value - 5/5
Ambiance - 3/5 
Food - 4/5
Bustling restaurant with decent ambiance. Ordered the Soup dumplings & crispy shredded beef, delicious! Cash only so come prepared. Only complaint, the tea was pretty bad but overall worth trying!
Best soup dumplings in the city.  Touristy but worth it.  (Crab dumplings so-so, pork dumplings are amazing).

***NOT A DIMSUM PLACE***

We came from DC metro area and was looking for a good dim sum place. I loved how the Shanghai food here was not greasy at all! The food overall was very good and the condiments were a nice addition. Although I was originally disappointed since it did not have dimsum, but it worked out for the best since everything we got was so delicious.

Lets do some simple math here:

+5 Stars for the Soup Dumplings
- 3 Stars for the confusing service (I believe that we somehow ordered without looking at the menu, and within, oh, 4 seconds of being seated)
- 1 Star for our spring rolls never arising
+1 Star for being an anchor destination to get me out to explore Flushing
+ 2 Stars for the price - 15% gratuity included, in and out with a a slaked party of 3 for under $20.

That's it. Go for the soup dumplings, leave a happy, albeit somewhat confused camper.

Came here on one of our last days in NYC, a rainy day infact. That didn't seem to dampen the mood once the we poured some hot tea. 

The shanghai dumpling or siu long bao was pretty good. I've had better, but it was reasonably priced and still very good. Had noodles, can't recall which kind, but that I did enjoy them. 

Would come back if I was in the area ever again .

As far as service decor and what not, don't expect anything more than a typical chinese eatery.

The soup dumplings are fantastic.  The dough is great.  Not too doughy and not too thin.  And the flavor of the broth is phenomenal.  The staff is nice but just a heads up that you may feel a bit rushed.  If you are lucky enough to snag a table just know that there is a long line of people waiting behind you and you will feel the eyes of the staff waiting for you to finish your food.  You will get used to it though so no hard feelings!

This is a great place for America shanghainese cuisine. However, it may not be the perfect place for Shanghainese, it's not a native shanghainese flavor. If you don't like flighting all the way to China, this will be one of few good choices to settle with.  

All the food here is good enough for everyday consumption, but sometimes the freshness of the ingredients need an upgrade. (E.g. Steamed soup buns). If your soup buns have massive vinegar in them, you should start questioning the freshness of the meat. It happens from time to time.

Anyway, Joe's Shanghai is standing out with above average food and quality service in Chinese community. It's a good choice for family lunch or dinner.

BEST SOUP DUMPLINGS EVER!!! We got there just before it open at 10:50 am. Good thing too because after like 5 mins later there was a line already 2 store front down. 

The place seem like the other Joes shanghai i tried a couple years back when I came. Not much that huge can fit a decent amount of people. 

The shine come from the resturant namely there soup dumplings. The best I ever had. Mainly came just to eat it again. Mouth watering..

I sound like a schlocky country bumpkin tourist but the General Tso chicken was the best thing we had. It was perfect. The meat in the soup dumplings was meh but otherwise they were great. I liked the family style seating and the wait went quick (15 minutes). Service was predictably terrible but as Jack said, it's Chinatown.

What does one do when he has jury duty downtown for lunch?  Well, you can go to your favorite Chinese spot, or you can really take advantage and go somewhere that usually has a ridiculous wait at night or on weekends.  Joe's Shanghai definitely fulfills the latter so off I went.  

No wait for a table of one, sweet.  I went with the standard order of soup dumplings and scallion pancakes, figured I'd keep it simple.  Five minutes later the food finally appears...making this a good spot if they cut your lunch break at jury duty, though does that ever happen?

Anyway, soup dumplings were pretty standard, nothing that stood out among other places in Chinatown.  The scallion pancakes though?  They were top notch, can't think of a better spot in Chinatown off of the top of my head, they felt like they were double fried for double the yumminess (and probably double the fat).

Visited Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown for dinner based on a recommendation. The 25-minute wait for seating was tolerable given the restaurant's size and comfort. The servers were sweet, but unfortunately, the food lacked flavor and felt overpriced. Beware, it's cash-only, and there's an automatic 18% gratuity. Overall, a mediocre experience with nothing noteworthy to rave about.

Went to Joe's on our first night in NYC. Had this recommended by many and bookmarked when we decided to come to NY. Let start off by saying that we are lovers of XLbao and come from the west coast of din tai fung. We came with an open mind and was absolutely BLOWN away. 

I think we got lucky b/c we had NO wait. Walked in and sat right now. 

Ambiance: Small chinese establishment in chinatown. Loud. You may be put in a community table as small parties is hard to accomodate since they have quite a few large tables. For us it was no problem b/c we've been to many asian establishments that do this. I can tell other groups of travelers were not as comfortable but hey this is a learning experience right! Overall ambiance is pretty typical of a fast pace chinese restaurant. Has a family feel to it as well. You can see pictures of the numerous celebrities on the wall that have tried their food which is always kind of cool too. 

Service: Fast and easy. We had NO problem with the waiting staff and they were very quick to all of our request. Food came out hot and we didn't' have to wait long for our food to come. 

Food: OMG. That's all I can say. It was SOOOO good.. thats all we were craving for the next few days in NYC. Unfortunately, we did not go back but we still crave the nomz till this day in LA. The XL bao was to DIE for. IT was sooooo juicy. It had a good balance of sweet and salt. Can we talk about the size though? We ordered the crab and the regular pork one and devoured them as if we never ate in our life. I think for us one of the main differences that DTF has with this place is that their soup is a little more oily compared to the clean taste DTF has. But hey.. a little more OIL and fattiness doesn't hurt right? The green onion pancake.. you know how when you take a bite of something and you smile bc it was bomb? well my boyfriend's face and EYES smiled to a point i'm like.. uhh are you okay? He said it was one of the best he's had. We always order it everywhere we go and he said it was the best. The noodles were a tad salty but it was still VERY VERY good! overall 5/5 highly recommend and if they were to EVERY open on in LA...omg. everyday man. 

I think some reviews were upset about the wait. I understand.. considering how small of a place it is. I still think overall we had a 5/5 experience and the food speaks for itself. HIGHLY recommend if you love soup dumplings!

[02/11/2010, 9:00pm]

My then boyfriend took my best friend (who was visiting from Bolivia) and I here while we were on vacation in NYC...and now we're married. For those who argue that correlation doe not imply causation, I beg to differ, at least for the case of Joe's Shanghai.

What we ordered:
