Shanghai Cabbage w/Meat Wonton in Broth 
Shanghai Chives & Shrimp w/Meat Wonton in Broth
Eggplant with Garlic Sauce (with Pork)
Beef with String Beans

Best soup dumplings ever. EVER. Oh, and the eggplant pork is delicious and the green beans so crispy and flavorful. Mmmmm. LOVE.
I could eat these soup dumplings every day for the rest of my life and never tire of them. That's all you need to know. Even in a takeout container they're *chefs kiss*

Sorry din tai fung, I've replaced you with Joe's Shanghai. I fell in love with the pork soup dumplings (XLB) here. You get 8 big and juicy dumplings for $6 which is a price that you can't get elsewhere. My boyfriend and I shared 3 orders and finished it feeling satisfied. Tons of flavor with authenticity.  

Be advised that you may share a table with a different party if you have space available.

Always packed but worth the wait. Mouth watering soup dumplings are too delicious for words. The combo crab and pork is my ultimate favorite. I have tried other dishes as well and they are also tasty!

Are you kidding me NYC? BEST SOUP DUMPLINGS IVE EVER HAD. 

Soup Dumplings (5 stars) - comes with 8 HUGE dumplings and the best soup ive ever tasted

Crispy beef (5 stars) - so flavorful and cooked perfectly!

Shanghai noodles (5 stars) - oh gawd....

Chicken fried rice (3 1/2 stars) - it was good. Not the best ive had

CASH ONLY!!!
Absolutely loved this place! We were in town as tourists and our friend who lived in the city told me of this place. Most amazing food and great dumplings!! The wait is worth it!

Came here this past Sunday with a group of 10 people, around 1pm.  Around the corner, another dim sum place had over an hour wait.  Here, we waited about 20 minutes, which for a large group in the middle of the weekend, is a dream.

Great food, quick, FRIENDLY service, and SO VERY AFFORDABLE!  We got TONS of food and only paid about $20 bucks each.  There are also tons of vegetarian options so fellow vegs need not worry.
The soup dumplings are simply the BEST. Nowhere else compares.

Wow...wow.

(did you notice the double-wow?)  I was really blown away by the xiao long bao at this place - they're definitely the juiciest that I remember. The price at under $5 for a basket of 8 really earned it the 5th star in my book.

People mention that the it's not all that - and it gets boring after a while.  Well most things you eat for a prolonged period of time have the same effect.  But if you REALLY like soup dumplings and they're one of your favorite foods, then you'll have no problem finishing a basket here.

The one downside was that I didn't find anything else on their menu that was great.  Part of the reason is that I frankly don't know how to order here.  If you're reading these reviews I suggest finding OTHER dishes to get.  You're obviously going to try the xiao long bao...so focus your efforts elsewhere.  I had:

-Hot and Sour Soup - gooood taste but not hot (temperature) enough.  It was warm/hot.
-Shanghainese Noodles - not bad as a side dish or in place of fried rice/rice
-Beef Noodle Soup - really bad. haha.  I was envisioning Din Tai Fung where the xiao long bao and beef noodle soup were BOTH amazing.

I didn't have these but they looked pretty awesome:
-Eggplant
-Fried Tofu
-Scallion Pancakes

And a note about the service/rudeness.  I didn't notice anything wrong with their service.  I felt a bit rushed at some points (primarily to order) which I'm guessing is what others refer to as being "rude."  A lot of others complain about long waits.  Sorry yelpers, but this isn't a perfect world.  You're going to be rushed to order in order for people NOT to wait.  If you're going to complain about one, don't complain about the other! lol.  I also felt like it's the good old-fashioned chinese style...they want things to be quick and efficient.  However, even though I was able to order quickly in cantonese, I never saw them get mad at anyone else that was slow to order...so just go and enjoy it already if you're in NY! :)
Stopped in for soup, dumplings, and soup dumplings. Everything was great. Love the feel of Chinatown and the vibe of the restaurant.
Good soup dumplings. Good shanghai fried noodles. Place is located on an unassuming side street in chinatown. But this place is legit. One of my favorite chinese meals in new york.

Okay so it's true, the pork dumplings are amazing here. I like how they do their green beans, too. But this brief review is dedicated to that seasonal delicacy, the soft shell crab. 

I never used to go to Joe's because I really hate the whole waiting an hour for my dinner scene, but when softies are in season, I will put up with it, thanks to a friend of a friend who turned me on to the magical time known as soft shell crab season at Joe's Shanghai. It's like he gave me my first hit of crack: now I stand outside with the huddled masses, awaiting the moment my number is called, so that I may eat crunchy sea bugs and soupy balls filled with seasoned ground pork. Yes.
Long wait outside (40+ mins in a Friday evening). Lovely dumplings (pork were best). Colorful service (brusque but comical). Great price. Green beans were tasty, fried chicken was okay.
The soup dumplings were amazing! The pork and crab were absoltely delicious. Would have given five stars but it is always so crowded. I was lucky enough to get my own table.

Ugh so good. Give me all the dumplings. *Tip: when  eating dumplings use the spoon to catch all the juice. 1. It's delicious 2. It will get all over you if you don't. Authentic Chinese- simply delicious. Yeah you'll wait 30-40 minutes but it's worth the wait! OH! Big thing to note: they only accept cash which is odd BUT they have a ATM right by the door.

The last time I had Joe's Shanghai, I was a wee (actually, not so wee, the Senior 15 is a very real phenomenon) college student, intimidated by large Chinatown crowds and by Chinatown waiters who slap utensils down on the table, but lured by this thing called soup dumplings. It's been a long time since I inhaled that first burning gulp of crab-infused pork broth, mixed with the a few drops of soy sauce and ginger. 

My first piece of advice is to get here before the obvious meal times - if you're going on a weekend, the best bet is 2:00-5:00. 

My second piece of advice is to tell the waiter right off the bat that you're ordering soup dumplings, so that, if you time it just right, the first batch comes to your table only a few minutes after you place your order for other dishes. 

Everything other than the soup dumplings was a little less dazzling. I loved how sugary and crunchy the crispy sliced beef was, but it may not be everyone's cup of tea.  The crispy pepper skin duck and baby bok choy were standard Chinatown fare. 

If you're less than 5 people, get ready to share a table with other happy strangers slurping down soup dumplings. 

NEXT TIME: more of the crab-pork, though if I end up in Chinatown during a peak hour, I'm sure there's another restaurant a stone's throw away that also serves soup dumplings.

I'm laughing reading the reviews for this place. People are giving them less stars because they're crowded (because the food is great and not their fault), because they do communal seating (this allows more people to be seated), automatically charge gratuity (a ton of their customers are tourists who wouldn't tip otherwise and being a waiter here must be one of the most stressful experiences of all time), and are cash only (this is completely reasonable and they have an atm at the front for your convenience.) 

Soup dumplings are incredible, scallion pancakes and crispy and perfect, Lo mein is smoky and wonderful, prices are beyond reasonable for a place this hyped and the portions are massive. My coworkers and I routinely go after work and are more than happy to wait because it's always worth it!

Great dumplings for a great price!!! Yes, you are seated at the table with strangers if you have a smaller party. Most importantly - it's a CASH only establishment [at least for when I was there, they only wanted cash.. so he told me to go to the pharmacy across the street. For this reason, I give them 4 stars, because there should be more signs posted if this is the case or they should inform parties before they are seated]
I LOVE SOUP DUMPRINGS. Nom nom nom. I love when they give me third degree burns in my mouth~ HASHASHASHA!
good simple food.  dumplings were solid.  beef noodle soup was just what i was craving for.  would like to explore their menu further the next time im in town.

Joe's Shanghai! Really delicious soup dumplings that come out piping hot. I was very impressed that the waiter immediately asked us what kind we wanted right as were getting seated. "Pork," my friend declared. We also ordered the Shrimp and Chicken in Plum Sauce based on recommendations. It was tasty. I couldn't quite figure out what the crispy vegetable in it was... wintermelon? Anyway, overall experience was good. 

Zero wait time, fast service, and filling food.
Great soup dumplings and sesame chicken was sweet with Smokey flavor from the wok. Went on a Friday night and it was packed. Only had to wait less than 30 min. Practiced great Covid safety measures.

Great food, great mini bum, avoid the rush hours if you can not wait that long
Excellent service as well.
EPIC get the soup dumplings and the meatballs!!!!! The wait can be long and the service is rushed but that's part of the experience. The food, all of it, is succulent like MELT IN YOUR MOUTH.

Every time I am in New York, I visit Joe's.  This place is amazing.  This is where I fell in love with Soup Dumplings and will always be my favorite.   A few weeks ago, I was able to bring my two children (9 and 11) to try soup dumplings at Joes and they fell in love immediately.  Love, love, love this place.  Thanks.

The food and culture were great... but I don't think I really understand the hype. 

For some reason I was picturing the menu to have 25 different types of soup dumplings... and all different kinda of weird dishes. The menu is pretty much like most other chinese restaurants, and there are only two different choices of soup dumplings: Pork and Crab. 

We ordered crispy duck, pork noodles, and both dim sum options. 

The pork dumplings were really good; neither of us cared for the crab. The duck was good, as were the pork noodles. 

I was excited to come here, and no I'm not disappointed, but I wish they had more options for the dim sum... be creative!

Came here on a weekend for dinner. There was a long line, but I appreciated that the workers kept things moving so we didn't have to wait too long (maybe ~20 minutes for a table for 2). The process of getting a table may not be intuitive, but you have to go in the restaurant to check-in with a worker, who'll give you a number. They'll call out the number when a table for your party is ready so you'll need to stay close to the restaurant while waiting. The menu is pretty extensive. We tried the pork soup dumplings and fried rice cakes - both were delicious, prices were reasonable, and service was fast.

Indeed is all about the soup dumplings. HmmMmmmm I can go for some right now. It'll warm up this popsicle body of mine!

A bit hard to find and community tables can throw people off, but endure the wait! It's worth it. I was always told that I had to try their dumplings (I was never specifically told it was a soup dumpling) so in my mind I'm like what's so special about another dumpling, but yes soup dumplings are a unique invention.

First you take a bite off the top exterior of the dumpling. Second you taste some of that savory broth. Third you pour in some vinegar sauce and chow down!

Let's refocus! Our group of 5 also ordered their shanghai noodles, bean curd, and kung pao chicken. Everything was flavorful and tasty! Extremely enjoyed all of it and love that the chicken in the kung pao were small vs the naturally large sizes they often come in.

Worth the wait! 

P.s. service sub-par. They seriously want you in and out especially when it's really busy.

The xiao long bao aka soup dumplings on their own are "as good as it gets." Everything else is decent but not remarkable. The sauteed snow pea leaves and Shanghai noodles didn't leave too much of an impression, though I liked the smokiness of the noodles. It's a NYC institution and shouldn't be missed. But aside from its most well-known dish, the other offerings don't warrant the long lines.

A great NYC Chinatown pick. 

Step 1: Go in and get sat down next to some tourists or locals.

Step 2: You can look at the menu, but you already know you came here for the xiaolongbao soup dumplings. Take too long and waiters will start offering recommendations and might even order for you. If you ask for a dish that takes 15 min to prepare, alternatives will be suggested. 

Step 3: Promptly receive your food. Eat dumplings way too fast and burn your mouth. The pain is worth it, because they are pretty good. Some of the dishes you ordered may or may not arrive, but you don't care too much as you are already pretty full.

Step 4: Pay, leave, look forward to coming back.

This is a bit (but not really) of a coincidence that this review of Joe's Shanghai follows the review of the "world famous" Din Tai Fung http://www.yelp.com/biz/din-tai-fung-two-arcadia

But I did come to Joe's a couple weeks ago in my most recent trip to NYC. My friend (actually it was her sister) raved about this place and insisted we go before I left... so we did.

Because they would only seat us once the entire party was present (which is actually most excellent -- unless you're rollin' with laggers), there was a bit of a wait.

Once seated, we ordered more food than we could handle (a couple/few orders of the dumplings, noodles, rice, eggplant, and another vegetable dish).

These dumplings (aka xiao long baos), if they went head-to-head with those of Din Tai Fung, would win based on three primary factors:
- The Size Factor: Joe is bigger than Din
- The Skin Factor: Joe had slightly thicker skin (which I prefer) and it was a bit better cooked (Din's usually feels a minute or two undercooked -- for my taste)
- The Juice Factor: Joe's juice, or rather soup, is for more than Din's. Perhaps do to the Size Factor, Joe's soup easily fills up the white "chinese" soup spoons... easily.

All in all. Solid.

Love their soup dumplings! 

The wait can get long when it's during lunch or dinner time but it is worth the wait. If you are in a rush call in and get it for take out. Takes about 20 minutes and they give everything even the sauce! I make sure I stop here every time I go to New York

First time at the new location. I have always frequented the pell st location for numerous years. The new place is def nice. The food is fantastic as always and the service is great. I will continue to come here cause I love the soup dumplings. On a side note to bad the flushing location closed.
My signicant other- who is from Shanghai- says this is one of the most authentic in NY.  I guess I will believe her.

First visit was with super-picky sibling and grumpy, unadventurous children. Wildly successful. We had 2 orders of soup dumplings, shrimp noodles, tofu + veggies and a couple other items. Can't wait to return - sans family. Great service, too!

I was excited for my first visit to Joe's Shanghai to try their soup dumplings and they did not disappoint!  They were absolutely amazing!  So much flavor and I'm already looking forward to my next trip to NYC to have them again. We also had the fried dumplings and scallion pancakes. Both were the best we've ever had. Make this a stop and you won't regret it.

My friend has been going here for years and brought me here to try it for the first time. Tea was readily available and very comforting while enjoying the turnip cakes, which were perfectly crispy and the pork dumplings, which were flavorful and delicious. 

I'm usually not a fan of Chinese food, but this place really changed my mind. And the prices are very reasonable (cash only though). I will definitely be coming back. Just make sure to go a little earlier, since the place can fill up pretty quickly.

Slurp Slurp.

The dumplings are literally made for Giants, or persons of really big mouths. I wished i took a picture of the dumpling placed on the spoon so you can see how enormous it was. But trust me, they're huge! 

I get disappointed a lot by XLB at almost every restaurants I've been to because 1) its too dry to be called a XLB or 2) its not meaty and flavorful.  However, cravings were definitely satisfied here! The dumplings (or what NY ppl refer to as buns) are full of flavor and broth!
Between the two of us, we got the regular pork XLB and the crab XLB. If you're not a fan of roe, you wouldn't like the crab, but lucky for me.. I love roe and it was the best XLB I've ever had in my life. Din Tai Fung (from HK, LA, Seattle & the Bay Area) does not even come close to Joe's Shanghai. 

So glad that my best friend knew her way around and insisted that we arrive prior to opening time since the lines were starting to pile up. We got there ~15 mins earlier, and were the 10th party in line. 

Next time I'm in town, Joe, I'm coming for you!

I come here quite a lot and really thought I wrote a review, but I guess not.

Most of the time when I come here there is a wait. HoweverI came here for an early lunch with my best friend around 11:30am and we've got seated right away. But later when it was really lunch time, the restaurant was packed.

My best friend wanted to order 2 orders of the soup dumplings and I told him we might not finish all of our food. His response was "I can share everything with you, but when it comes to these soup dumplings I am greedy and I prefer not to share." And yea, we ended up ordering 2 orders and a noodle dish. Finished all the dumplings and doggy bagged the noodles. 

So yes, soup dumplings are not meant to be shared because they are THAT good!

Great food!
Still on the high end side! Still affordable without embarrassing friends! The steamed meat bao live up to its name! Don't like it cos they only take cash! That's how they pass the savings from credit card fees!?
I really like the food here. The place is always busy especially on weekends. The line can get long sometimes, but the food is delicious and price is good!

Holy cow, this place is madness! 

It's a relatively small spot and it seemed that literally all of Manhattan (myself included) required soup dumplings on a Saturday afternoon. Shoe up and get a number - you'll probably be seated with other groups if your party is less than 6. They also won't even talk to you unless your whole group is there and yes, they make you prove it. They turn tables like the place is on fire!

Inside is hot, chaotic and incredibly noisy. Settle in and order away - but know that things here are large so maybe order a little less. Of course, I didn't realize that and had way too much in front of me! Their soup dumplings were excellent - an order will definitely fill a person up because they're big, plump and filled with scalding broth. I had pork dumplings as well which were plenty good but definitely focus on the soup dumplings. 

Reasonable prices, super fast service and a definite Chinatown experience.

I was visiting New York for the weekend and this was on my list of eats to try.  This ended up being my favorite food of the weekend, so freaking good!!!  We heard it'd be less crowded for lunch so we decided to go then, but there was still a pretty decent sized crowd waiting outside.  We were starving and almost didn't wait, but boy am I glad that we did.  Their xiao long baos were some of the best I've had.  You know it'll be good when the pouch is sagging with juice.  Did I mention we were starving?  So we ordered the pork chop noodles, green onion pancake, and 3 steamers of xiao long baos....might have gone a little overboard.  My favorites were both the pork and crab xiao long baos and green onion pancake.  It was kind of hectic in the restaurant and be prepared to make friends cuz you'll probably end up sitting at a big table with strangers, French in our case.  It's definitely a sit down, eat some awesome food, and say bye kinda joint.  I still dream of their xiao long baos though.

Best soup dumplings. Ever.

The pork and crab xiao long bao are so good, you'll want to name your firstborn after them :P

Excellent food!  Well worth the wait.  My wife had dinner at Joe's while we were in NYC for New Years after doing some research on Yelp.  We waited outside for 45 minutes in the cold and the rain.  My wife was one step away from killing me because she was miserable.  Once we made it inside the crowded restaurant we placed our order and the service was fast.  The waiter was not the friendliest but that's NY.  We had the dumplings for an appetizer.  They were absolutely AWESOME! We had General Tso's Chicken, Fried Rice, Green Beans, and Chicken Kunpao.  Everything was great.  My wife actually said the time in the rain was worth the awesome food.  Highly recommend it to anyone visiting NYC.

Joe's is a classic Chinatown restaurant particularly for those people who are huge fans of the "soup dumplings" that are the big draw for those who like Shanghainese cuisine.  I don't eat pork, so I don't eat the soup dumplings, but my wife makes us go there every time we can so she can get her fix.

Other than the dumplings, Joe's is a pretty standard Chinatown restaurant, with a big menu filled with dishes (of all types of Chinese cuisines) where some dishes will be great and some will be greasy and underwhelming.  The place is crowded and noisy, with communal tables, so be prepared for that experience if you go there.  

That said, it's a solid restaurant for the area, and you pretty much get what you expect. And if you're into the soup dumplings, this is the place to get them.

SOUP DUMPLINGS! I'm not particularly a fan of sharing tables with complete strangers. I honestly do not think that anything else is really that special and stands out as much as what it's known for, soup dumplings. A must stop if you are visiting in the winter! The wait is pretty long, but it's worth every second!
These soup dumplings have no competition. Hands down best in the states!  Try the veggie duck too. It's mushrooms wrapped in tofu skin.

Stopped by on a Sunday evening, had to wait about 20 minutes, you'll probably end up sharing a big table if you're a smaller party than 10. 

Nomz: Came here for the soup dumplings, had the pork ones, if it's just two people I would recommend one pork dumplings and something else. Personally, I think only having the dumplings gets repetitive, but you do you. 
Had the crispy noodles with beef and it was really tasty, would get again! Also have had the Shanghai noodles with chicken, which lacked flavor to me, prefer the crispy ones. 

Service: This place is busy but they are on top of your orders and water, fast moving waiters. 

Ambiance: It's nice, lots of round tables and two seaters, minimalistic light brown wood, well lit place. 

Nope or Dope: Dope, this is where I get my soup dumpling fix for now :)

I finallyyyyyy had an opportunity to try Joe's Shanghai and I was beyond excited. I have read countless reviews about this restaurant and was looking forward to my meal.

After waiting for one of their tables of 4 (the restaurant is mostly communal seating) we made our way into the establishment and took a peak at the menu.

We started off by ordering their famous soup dumpling's. I had never had anything like them before and we all really enjoyed the dish. 

We then moved on to a spicy chicken dish, a pork noodle dish and a large sea bass serving.

All of the dishes were unique and filled with flavor. I especially enjoyed the sea bass, it was a large portion, the saucy was tasty and the fish was cooked to perfection.

Hundred's of people before me have written positive review's of Joe's. This place truly is great, definitely check it out.

So U know why u r coming here...AAAAND you know the dumplings are good here (as long as they aren't sticking to the bottom of the steamer), i think they added more crab to the crab/pork ones!!!, and you are going to wait for them duh... but what else should you order?

My advice: 
since u r probably sitting at one of the communal tables next to another Asian Chinese person is to ask what THEY like that is different, or typical shanghai style food.  I do that each time I go to Joes and never have been dissapointed!  We had shanghai seafood noodle soup, spring roll, shredded pork and pickled cabbage soup, subgum fried rice cakes, sesame chicken (for the scared out of towner) and shanghai fried noodles with chicken.  All the family style portions had loads of veggies.  We certainly didn't starve and had a great time sharing and talking with the 2 couples at our table from Hong Kong and getting married and moving to Indiana--what country is that in again?? Our bill...less than 60$ w/ tip included...love that!

My only beef is that the waiter sees white man and automatically tries to steer me toward "safe" foods that typical american people would eat.  i've been to china and spent some time eating the food and i love the cuisine, the weirder the better for me!!  so go out on a limb yelpers!!
Delicious and always know what you are getting, we have no dined in since they changed locations but the food is always great! The hot and sour soup is not the same sny more though :[

The hype is real. Their infamous soup dumplings delivered. We got both the pork and pork/crab and their scallion pancakes and another fried lobster dish but who cares about their other dishes right? Let's get straight to business. 

In the West Coast, where I come from, Din Tai Fung is the place to go for soup dumplings. Which one was better you ask? Well honestly it comes down to taste and preference. Joe's Shanghai's soup dumblings are bigger and filled with more soup! YUMMM!!! 


BUT...
It was also more oily and heavy as well. I prefer the clean taste of Din Tai Fung but for oil, lard lovers, I can see why Joe's Shanghai reigns on top in NYC!

Joe's Shanghai is a staple for New York tourists that are looking for something other than cheese cake factory. Definitely get the soup dumplings. There is always a wait, I recommend putting your name in and going across the street for a foot massage while you wait.

We hear that the place gets pack quick, so we arrived before they were even open!  We stood in the cold weather for some good xao long bao!  The place did get pack quick when they opened though, so come early!  The service was fairly fast, we had the following:

Pork soup dumplings - steamy hot porky, rich soup with a splash of vinegary soy.. yum

Pork and crab soup dumplings - almost the same, with just a hint of crab, delicious still

Be careful when biting into it, I was overexcited and ended up burning myself.. but so good!!

I won't boast too much about this spot because it seems like everyone was already put on game.

The best Chinese food I've had to this day!!! I mean, it's tough to beat like corner Chinese stores in the hood but this was such an amazing experience. I'm usually not this impressed with Chinese food.

We went for lunch and was seated immediately (it was a Monday tho). The service was prompt and convenient since we were hungover & starving lol.

We got the chicken corn soup, veggie dumplings, and the sesame chicken. Everything tasted as expected but super fresh and flavorful. 

Can't wait to return.

Due to the rain and colder weather on a weekday morning, my friend and I didn't have to wait in line for their famous soup dumplings. It was a little weird being seated in a corner of a table and sharing it with a couple since there was plenty of space and tables around us. I supposed they did that just in case the place suddenly becomes busy. 

The menu was a bit overwhelming with the many options listed and I actually had to ask the waiter to point out where the soup dumplings were listed. They have two kinds of soup dumplings: crab and pork. Each kind came with 8 dumplings sooo...we were stuffed by the end. These were 8 large dumplings so definitely bring people to share them with. For the price and how large each dumpling was, I thought it well-worth it. I am by no means an expert in soup dumplings but they were really good especially with the black-ginger sauce.

In general, I am not a fan of Schezuan food. We also ordered a spicy beef dish (sliced) with bean sprouts but the sauce was too much. It wasn't spicy either which was disappointing. Overall, very good soup dumplings and recommend it if you're in the area!

If you want classic, authentic soup dumplings, this is the spot you go to. The seat is communal style, so if you come with a smaller group, or two or three people, you will probably share a table with others. Which is totally fine and actually adds to the experience in my opinion. My personal favorite thing to eat here are the pork soup dumplings, however everything else is great. There's usually a wait cause it's a popular spot, but if you go there earlier than you'd ideally like to eat, you can deal with that. It's in the heart of chinatown down a little crowded alley, and you really get the full experience being there. The walls are lined with pictures of famous people who've gone and eaten there as well.
Came here again with friends for Sunday lunch. Soup dumplings are still amazing (none broken this time :) The service isn't bad but the way the talk to you is a little rude...

I love their soup dumplings! Many would argue that it's a tourist trap but what is a tourist trap if it delivers good, consistent food? 

Always order the crabmeat dumplings - you won't regret sucking the living juices out of the poor dumpling! Then sip on some soda before you go for round 2 because that's how the Chinese do it! 

Other choices are not necessary at this establishment if you can fill up on dumplings all the way. Just a suggestion!

This place definitely lives up to it's hype. The xiao long bao is absolutely fantastic, best I've ever had. They are bigger than what is served at other restaurants, and they hold a lot more soup. I always make the mistake of trying to stuff a whole one into my mouth, having the soup explode,  and struggling not to spit it out as the hot soup sears the inside of my mouth. I can't help it, it's just THAT good.

Definitely the culinary highlight of my trip to NYC.
Always amazing. Always a long wait but worth it. The food is amazing and authentic. The staff is very friendly as well. We come here from Westchester at least three times a year.

Pretty solid for churning out soup dumplings. I also enjoy their lo meins and their eggplant with garlic dish. It's always crazy busy so it's likely you may have to share a table, but for the most part, the wait isn't unbelievable. I'll always come back!
Love their style noodles. Choice of ingredients can be improved with larger pieces. Good flavor.

This place was highly recommended and confirmed by all the great reviews. Waited for almost an hour and then had to share a table with 4 others while we were a party of 5. That's 9 total. Fortunately, the table is next to the wall of celebrities. 
They pack you in tight so there's no room to maneuver to take photos or at least be courteous to your shared dining parties. 
All of this was well worth the wait. The pork and crab dumplings were to die for. The dumpling skins were not thick which can be too overbearing and takes away the overall flavor. Very good soup and meat flavors. There is nothing frozen about this dish. To enhance this dish, we ordered a side dish of sauteed mushrooms. It was cooked to perfection and not salty like most Chinese joints I've encountered. 
As busy as they are, there is no sense of rush. The staff are attentive and quick to respond. The place is dated and needs a cleaning but don't let that be a hindrance in dining here. That's why the price is so reasonable. Don't fix it if it ain't broken!
Would highly recommend and return. Just wish they had one close to me in CA.

I am coming here every. single. time. I visit NY from now on. This place is absolutely fantastic for lunch, and so affordable! 

I came with my boyfriend for a late lunch on a weekday. We got seated at around 2pm, after about a 20 min wait. I think that it's really hard to get a table for big parties, so you will have better luck coming in small groups. Either way, be prepared to maybe share a table with someone else, because this place is ALWAYS busy and full. We shared a table with another family of 4 that had 2 young children, and I preoccupied myself during the wait by watching the adorable little one eat his xiao long bao :) 

We ended up ordering 1 noodle soup to share ($5 - pork and pickled cabbage - SO MUCH NOODLE!) and 2 orders of the xiao long bao ($10 for 16 - such a great deal since where I come from, they are often almost $1 each). We also got the scallion pancake, which was really crispy and came with a delicious and surprisingly sweet sauce. Lastly, we got some mixed vegetables for $5 - I had to negotiate with my boyfriend on this one because he doesn't like veggies much...

It was a completely satisfying and filling meal for only $28 including tax and tip. I would recommend just buying a ton of things off the appetizers and sharing, because the actual dishes are pricey and are pretty big portions, so you wouldn't get to try as many different things because they will fill you up fast. 

I can't wait to come back again. The xiao long bao = perfection.

Best Xiao Long Bao ever!
Whenever I come up from Atlantic City to New York, this place is definitely on our to do list. Crab ones are definitely my favorite.
I love their scallion pancakes, and this one soup. I forget what they call it but its the one with the bamboo shoots, snow peas and pork. Very light and delicious.

They also let you order the dumplings raw to take home, but I always find that the skin never turns out restaurant quality when I cook them. Much rather trek back to New York and have them done right with their superior dumpling cooking powers.

Have had xiaolongbao in Seattle, Vancouver, Chicago, San Francisco, and Dallas. Of all these places, Joe's Shanghai is in my top 2 of favorite XLB. 

For 5.95 you get 6 large XLB filled with delicious seething hot soup and ball of meat. It was so delicious that I returned three days in a row and I was only in NYC for 4 days so that's saying something. We ordered three orders of XLB and that is all we ordered from the menu since everything else paled in comparison to delicious XLB. 

Be warned that there always seems to be a minimum wait time of 20 minutes to be seated. There is always a line outside the restaurant as the restaurant is quite tiny for the amount of people that love frequenting this restaurant. 

Nothing too impressive with the decor. Typical Chinatown restaurant decor.

First time in Chinatown and this place is apparently a gem, so we had to check it out!! 

We went as a group and were there to share items, so unfortunately didn't get to check out the large scale "entrees", but we got a couple orders of the dumplings and also scallion pancakes. Although I didn't have the dumplings, my friends were more than thrilled by them, and were surprised at how filling!! I had the scallion pancakes and while oily, they tasted delicious! 

This place isn't the best for a sit down long dinner, it's extremely popular and so, they work a very quick ship. They'll have you in and out but honestly, didn't even matter! It's just part of the experience. Definitely would be back to try more of the vegetarian options!

The best soup dumplings around!

Get cozy sitting next to some strangers. This is the sorta place where they fill up any and every seat. I enjoyed chatting with some tourists from Texas!

A great spot to stop in while in chinatown!
This time I tried stuff other than the soup dumplings, and they were great! Try the fish- delicious!
Very good place. Ordered takeout and drove to NJ. Food was still warm and quite tasty. We ordered Sesame Chicken, General Tsos, and spring rolls. All were quite good.
It's 10pm hungry from a trip to Woodbury commons and coming to this kind of a dingy place but when you sit down to devour this pork dumplings, it heaven !!! At 11 people are still coming in!

I've come to New York several times and this is still my favorite dumplings place. I don't mind the long line, I don't mind the bingo game the hostess plays, I don't mind the cold or the heat while I wait. I come, share a table, have my dumplings, if it's cold outside, the best Hong Kong style soup, I pay and I leave. Great experience granted.

The best soup dumplings I've ever had! You'll most likely have to wait in order to eat, but I promise it's well worth it. A little crowded since you share tables with other parties (round tables that for up to 10 people) but overall very fast service. Highly recommend this place if you're looking for authentic food and amazing dumplings!

Yummy yummy goodness in my tummy!!  This place is the real deal!  I have been to Shanghai China restaurants and the food here is just as good!  Highly recommend the soup dumplings with ginger vinegar. Enjoy!!  Chinatowns best!

Every time I go to visit my cousins in New York, my top food request is Joe's. Soup dumplings are amazing!!! Someone recently told me that he didn't like them, and had he been sitting next to me I would have kicked him right in the head. WTF?! Who doesn't love soup dumplings?!?!?! 

Last time we went a random dude at our table ordered 3-4 orders of soup dumplings just for himself....a man after my own heart. Yes, they are that good, but their other food is just as delicious. I feel like you can't go wrong no matter what you order as long as you order the soup dumplings first. I almost gasped when the other random people at our table declined the dumplings. Again. WTF!? Who doesn't love soup dumplings?!?!?!

This one deserves 5 stars.  A NYC classic.  There's a reason for the "insane waits" and "long lines".  You don't get a better soup dumpling in the city.  Scallion pancakes are amazing.  If you're in a small group, be prepared to be sat with strangers.

I don't have much new insight considering that this is review number 392, but I just wanted to gush about my Chinese New Years lunch. 

It was sooooo good. Some of the tastiest pan-fried seafood noodles I've ever had. Their scallion pancakes were flaky fried perfection. Among the 5 ppl I went with, we ordered several dishes, including shredded roasted chicken over cold peanut noodles, sesame beef and the much beloved soup dumplings. Somehow, after splitting the tab, I only had to throw down $6 -- incredible for the food coma I soon fell into.

Not a dish passed by my table that I wasn't tempted to snag (good thing for will power).

Was recommended to this place when I asked friends about dumplings/dim sum type food. They accept cash only!! 18% tip is added to every tab

This place does offer cart style dim sum but a wide array of Chinese food. Quick and easy service. We got seated right away for two in the afternoon. Our table and seat was not wiped down however so there were stray noodles around when we were seated. 

We got the pork soup dumplings which were nice and juicy. None had popped on the way to the table and had a lot of soup in them. They taste best hot so I was happy to have that experience as they became less appetizing as the meal went by. The soup was pretty good but I have had better soup dumplings. You get 8 for about $8. 

We also got the gumsub pan fried noodles for about $17 and the portion was generous. Loved the mixed seafood and noodles but the sauce was on the salty side which was inevitable looking at how dark brown the sauce was.

Overall, it was a tasty experience but had some hiccups between table cleanliness and salty flavor.

My friend treated me to A-ha concert and a night at the Crown Plaza in Time Square. I was thrilled not to mention shop heaven! In return, I'd treat her out to dinner and lunch for all the good times! Days before our big trip to NYC, she was talking about Joe's Shanghai's dumplings and how WE HAVE TO EAT LUNCH there before we come back to Boston!! It sounded like lunch was the most important thing of this trip, never mind that this is A-ha's last concert in the States. 

We go to the dumpling joint and this place only takes CASH! So we head back out the door and search for a couple blocks for a ATM. As soon as we sat down, the waiter immediately asked "what kinda dumpling you want?" LOL! This place knows they are the best in this category! LOL! It's a small and very busy restaurant so expect to share a table w/strangers and be rushed out to make room for new diners. Don't expect to lounge around. 

0 Stars for customer service. I eat at many Chinese restaurants and customer service is not the most important priority which is a typical experience for me in any Chinatown in any state. Basically, waiters just serve your food with an indifferent attitude. But this place has ONE of the worse waiters. I'm talking about this one specific waiter who had the worse attitude. The sad thing is NY has this service charge which customers are forced to pay no matter how the bad service is. This joint automatically rewards this jerk 15%. I asked for a little take out box to put my leftovers in and this douche gave me a "geezus christ look" with a crooked smirk and to add on top of that, sound effects that came from smacking his gum. A very small task to do which he has done a million of times before, it wasn't as if I was asking him to sacrifice his life. My God! This was all displayed in front of me and my friend. It was like living out a comedy and the joke is on us because we're going to get screwed with the 15% service charge! Haha! This is one reason why restaurants should not implement a service charge. 

We ordered the famous steamed bun or most folks call it a dumpling. It's deceiving when the menu says bun because I'm thinking it's bread like dough with meat inside. This is not a soup dumpling that floats in a broth. It's a thin skin bun that is stuffed w/meat and with a bit of broth inside. I think of it as dim-sum. It's steamed in a bamboo basket. The broth inside steams the meat and infuses it with flavor. Each order comes with 8 dumplings. The dumpling is medium size and one person can finish one order. 

This is what we ordered: 

3 stars for shredded turnup cake. I was expecting a square white jelly like turnup cake but instead, it was a puff pastry stuffed with shredded white carrot (law-bok) . It was very bland and the filling had no taste or filling. I would pass on this appetizer but if you do get this , dip in soy sauce or something. You get two "cake" per order. 

1 star for Cold Noodles in Sesame Oil which is exactly what it was. Greasy and tasteless. I would DEFINITELY pass on this one. To make this better, they should add some kind of seasoning, maybe chopped green onion and throw in some REAL sesame! It look like greasy black noodles. 

5 stars for Crab Meat w/Pork Meat Steamed Bun (dumpling). It was all made fresh. You can definitely taste the crab and it even had crab roe. The combination of the pork and crab were very delicious. If you like the seafood taste, then this is something you should order! 

5 stars for the Pork Steamed Bun (dumpling). It tasted great and the pork was lean and had the right combination seasoning. 

The hardest part to eating these dumplings is not breaking it apart before you put it in your mouth or you'll loose the broth inside it. 

Despite the bad customer service, I highly recommend ordering the dumplings!!

Even in 40 degree weather, there were at least 20 people waiting. It took approximately 15 minutes to get a small table for two, and seating felt a bit cramped. I came with high hopes to try their soup dumplings (which is what Joe's Shanghai is pretty much known for). Not to say that it wasn't good, I'm just not sure that it matched up with all the popularity. Before we finished our food, the waiter dropped off the check with 15% tip and tax already included. Overall, food was decent but don't expect to stay there for too long.

I'm so glad that my first soup dumpling experience was at Joe's. Why I waited so long to try soup dumplings is beyond me! I ordered the garlic sauce dish and scallion pancakes in addition to their famous soup dumplings. From my first and very last bite, I enjoyed each moment throughly. The food came out quickly and servers were friendly. 

When my friend and I arrived around rush hour, there wasn't a line/crowd but we still waited about 5 minutes to be seated. By the time we were headed out though, it started to get a bit crowded-- especially for a Tuesday night. I was in the area that following Saturday and remember seeing a line going down the street to enter so your best bet it to get there as early as you can because they don't accept reservations. And don't forget to bring CASH! :)

Best Xiao Long Bao in USA!! It is better than ding tai fung  for sure!! a lot soup inside every bao!
i went there at least twice a week for the 2-3weeks I am in NY. it is SO GOOD!!!
I wish they have a shop here in LA.

Food was delicious. Of course had the pork soup dumplings. Clams were good. So we're the green beans.  Service is fast but like most asian restaurants, don't expect warm and fuzzy.

Bathroom was really unkept. Someone should be looking into this.

This past weekend, I was walking around china town with my brother looking for a non-sketchy place to grab dinner and ended up here. We sat with a fun, large family who ordered the jellyfish appetizer and dared us to try it. Not something I would have EVER ordered on my own...but it actually didnt taste too bad! For entrees we got the orange beef and general tso's chicken and both were very good. Portions are pretty large- we ended up taking some home. Their rice is some of the best I've had with chinese food. My only complaint was that both dishes had minimal vegetables...I think there were only 4 pieces of broccoli in the chicken dish. 

I like that they give you tea before eating and oranges after on the house. Unfortunately it was WAY too hot to get the soup dumplings which they are known for, so I definitely need to come back and try those.

The best pork soup dumplings in NYC by far!!
Didn't expect it when I went in, but was blown away by it. 
However, all there other foods are sub-par, nothing special.

But do get there fried bread with condensed milk. yum!

Finally came to try the famous soup dumplings- they were the best I've ever had. Very juicy and just the right size. Also tried the shanghai fired noodles which were delicious but pretty greasy. I came on a Tuesday afternoon and the place was packed it was like we were seated with the table next us. They could use an update on decor tables are close and the pink and green lighting makes it very dim inside.
Had a great experience! I was escorted right away to my table! Clean and the waiters were very attentive. I tried the dumpling soup, which was delicious! I highly recommend it!

Some of the best Chinese food you'll find in the city for cheap. You absolutely must get the soup dumplings. They are absolutely delicious. Everything else on the menu to fantastic-- fried rice, chicken and broccoli are two staples although the more adventurous among us would find ample to keep you happy there. 

A few things to note if this is your first visit. 
1) The food is made for sharing. You'll get better value with more people. Meat dishes tend to start above $10. Dumplings are still super cheap, if I remember correctly, they are less than $7 for 8 or so. 

2) You will have to wait at least 30 minutes for a seat. No reservations. Its that popular, and for good reason. 

3) You may be seated at a table with other customers not in your party. Its weird but you'll get over it when the food arrives. 

4) Cash only. 

I would give this 5 stars were it not for some of the ambiance related things. Food is excellent. I highly recommend.

This place is proof that not all Asian food tastes the same.  The flavors were exceptional, the wait want bad, and the service was great.  We came in at lunch on Sunday and it was fantastic.  We had a beef dish, calamari, duck, and shrimp fried rice.  All excellent.  We also had the pork dumpling appetizer which was awesome.  They also serve Tsing Tao, need I say more?  Definitely on the list for a return visit.

The dumplings are incredible.  We also had a few other dishes and they are also very good!  
The service is mediocre, waiters were quick with you and they are quick to get rid of you as they want to turn the tables.   The only reason this place doesn't get 5 stars is because of the service.    
BTW 15% TIP was included in our check.

My friends and I took a recent visit to NYC and we were really excited to try this restaurant in Chinatown, and it did not disappoint! I personally got the Steamed Veggie Dumplings and the Veggie Fried Rice and both were sooo good! Everyone at the table was raving over the quality of the food. The service was great and the food was brought out quickly. The restaurant itself is really pretty inside, and we didn't wait at all (there were 4 of us and we went around 4 PM on Thursday). Overall, I would totally recommend this place!

Amazing!!!! The soup pork/crab dumplings were absolutely fabulous!!!! We lucked out and got in without a wait. We sat down at a table for 6 (there was 4 of us) and then immediately sat 2 more people with us! No some people might not like this.... I loved it!! The women we sat with were Asian ( and from LA)and had specifically sought out this resteraunt for soup dumplings.... they said this was the best!!! End result .... a must go!!!

On a cold winter's day, there's nothing better than some decently priced Asian comfort food to warm you up like Joe's Soup Dumplings. This is the only reason I go to Joe's - because they are usually really busy, and the tables are pretty cramped. If you go during a busy hour (like dinner) and are a small party, you could be seated with another group of people at their shared, common round tables. It's the only way they can keep their queue moving...but if you don't feel obliged to talk to your neighbors (IF this happens to you), then it's totally worth it once those Soup Dumplings hit your belly.

I was skeptical of the cheesy name, but am really glad my friend took me here. Having sampled all the best XLB places in SF (and hacing tried Ding Tai Fung), I can assure you this blows everything out the water. Well that is if you like BIG FAT XLBS with not just pools of soupiness but giant lakes. These are true gushers.

We got to the place around 11 am on a Saturday and were able to sit down right away (possibly because of our small party size?) at a communal table. The waiter immediately set down a teapot, and we immediately ordered one "long" of regular pork XLBs and one of crab and a pork & preserved veggie rice cake dish. Althougher with 2 Tsingtaos, our bill was around $30.

I was definitely more of a fan of the pork. The crab was defintely decadent and the broth tasted like roe...which I can appreciate but am not the biggest fan of. The filling was very sizable and though the wrappers/flavors were not as delicate as high-end XLBs (aka DTF's), they are very satisfying and good for hungry tummies. Same with the pork. Having tried some terrible XLBs, I can really appreciate how 1) the wrappers don't fall apart when you lift them 2) the filling is not falling apart because they have been frozen 3) the wrapper is not hard, evidence of freezing 4) the filling is big enough so the wrapper-filling ratio is all skewed 5) there is actually enough soup to call them "soup dumpings" 6) the flavors are pretty authentic to Chinese food in China. See how bad XLBs can be?

This place is SO GOOD!!!! I wish there were more dumpling types bc the dumplings here were amazing!!! We got the pork soup, pork fried and crab! We also got orange chicken, Shanghai noodles, scallion pancake, fried rice and veggies! The wait was very long so I would get here early and not go weekends if it's avoidable! It really hit the spot and was super filling and yummy after a long day walking through nyc!

During jury duty at a nearby court someone recommended the dim sum and it was easily the best I've had anywhere (SF, Boston, NYC). It's a cramped and hurried place, but that's to be expected in Chinatown. Since I was by myself I got seated along with 4 other small parties at a big table. Quick service and very attentive and lots of current celebrity pictures on the wall. Now, the best part. 

I ordered the steamed pork buns as my meal since it was just me and didn't want leftovers. They looked very different than the steamed buns I'm used to (the denser, fluffier kind with the kind of bbq flavored strips of pork). These were soft, thin, and filled with thinly ground pork in a broth that was rich, tender, and succulent. If I had no qualms, I would've slurped the broth left on my fish. I did my best by just taking spoonfuls. I hardly use "life changing" when describing food but this goes on my top 10 dishes of all time. Will definitely come back.

5 stars for their soup dumpling. It's simply the best of its kind. Pork is better in my opinion.
I wouldn't order anything else (their other dishes are at the 3-3.5/5 level only). Don't order the fried fresh fish, it tasted like sadness and not fresh. I would just save my stomach for the soup dumplings

This place is pretty cool for lunch. If you're not there with 8 of your friends, they will sit you with some random people at a big 10 person table most likely with tourists. It's a whole other experience this way, and I'm a big fan.

My friend and I shared a lot of small plates including the crab meat and pork soup dumplings (xiao long bao). Which were all delicious! The Quail quarters were the typical slightly overcooked, crispy skinned deliciousness. And I'm from NorCal, so I haven't had or haven't been exposed to the fried turnip ball that is full of WIN. 

Also try the peanut noodles if you're not so adventurous. They are surprisingly awesome.

Xiao Long Bao was AMAZING!  Some of the best I've ever had!   Careful or it will explode crazy hot broth in your mouth or your clothes.

We also had this garlicky broccoli (also AMAZING), sesame chicken, and fried rice.  I walked out with a garlic pork baby in my tummy, but it didn't bother me one bit.

One thing that is sort of a downside, you eat at a table with others...the others at our table were a little "off".  Just a forewarning.

My favorite shanghai soup dumpling in nyc.  The crab and pork soup dumplings have a perfect balance of skin thinness, soup volume, soup richness (seafood sweetness), and substantive pork.

For beginners, either clamp or chopstick the tip at the top and place on to your spoon.  Bite a hole to the top or side, slurp the soup slowly, then eat the rest of it.  If you try to just pop it in your mouth, you will likely burn your tongue.  If they've been sitting for 5-10 minutes, then you can probably just pop them in your mouth without slurping the soup first, without worrying about burning.

Besides the dumplings, which I'll usually get 2 orders of 8 each, try the shanghai thick fried noodles, the seafood thick fried noodles, drunken chicken, and pork cutlet soup noodles.

As a minor dessert, red bean fried pancake.

Also, another Chinatown place that is quick, not rude, just quick.  They're not kicking you out, they're just trying to turn over as much as they can, don't take it the wrong way - but also don't try to take forever.  This isn't a 2-3 hr dinner date place.

This is THE spot for dumplings in NYC! Recommended by a friend, we got here around 12:30 and were quickly seated. There are tons of servers and service here is super fast and efficient. They get you in and out. I knew I wanted the pork soup dumplings, but they weren't listed as such on the menu. The pork soup and the crab and pork soup dumplings were the first items on the menu, and if I recall correctly, I think they were listed as "buns". Either way, that's what I ordered and crossed my fingers it would be what I wanted. The waiter was very fast and I felt pressured when he was taking my order (maybe it was just me), and I wasn't sure if he thought that wasn't enough food, so i kept ordering. I ended up with way too much food and had leftovers, but try to remember that the soup dumplings are large and filling and you do get 8 per order. I also went with pan fried dumplings, which were good, and eggplant which was a  huge portion!

Interesting place for dumplings. Unlike other places Around the area, this places takes aim time to be seated and get food orders. Seating consists of 2 or more parties at one table (sharing). It can be hit or miss depending one how much everyone orders. Dumplings are average but the crab meat dumpling is the highlight of this spot and never disappoints. Don't expect to go in and out as it takes a while. 

Food is good , space is small
The crab soup dumplings are much better than pork! We three people had boiling fish, broiled duck and pork and shrimp. Not bad.

I have to say I haven't been to this place in a while so this review is probably not as relevant as others.  I've been to this location many times and I've always been impressed with their food.  It's simple Shanghainese.  Sure the wait staff is rude but it's NYC and wait staff are rude in Shanghai too.  The dumplings were always delicious and fresh.  Bring cash since they don't accept CC.

For the west coasters: Joe's is better than DTF. The skin is thicker and chewier. AND it's only $5 a rack!!!!

For the first-timers: 
- grab a xiao long bao (XLB/soup dumpling) without breaking the skin
- put it on your spoon
- bite a hole at the base of the XLB, suck out all the soup (careful, it's hot!)
- add (vinegar/soy or hot) sauce and enjoy the rest of your XLB in one bite!
XLB are best while hot.

My sister and I enjoy the XLB so much we came here for lunch and dinner once (we're from out of town). 10 minute wait for lunch and 1.5 hour wait for dinner -- still worth it (y)
Great Chinese restaurant. Have the soup dumplings. They are outstanding. We ordered too much food and we're happy to take it home.

A hidden gem in Chinatown. It's in a small alley like location.  Expecting a wait during the evening. I did a Togo order and it took 20min.  Food was good but a bit pricey. Small place and if more than 10people it will be hard and annoying.

Your run of the mill good Chinese place with great soup dumplings 
Tbh no place is good enough to wait for 3h but if you can get a table on time you're in good hands :)

Fast service, lots of food, reasonable price

Recommend the soup dumplings, while fish dish, Peking duck, beef schezwan style but maybe not the scallion pancakes 

They give oranges with the check which I love
Soup dumplings are must have. Has lots of soup inside, not easy to make! We also had the crispy shredded beef, also highly recommended

Came for a quick lunch with my mom; she loves soup dumplings and this is our go-to soup dumpling restaurant in Midtown. Despite being told that the wait would be about 40 minutes, we were seated and had ordered within 20 minutes.

We had an order of crab soup dumplings and one xue cai rou si mian (pickled greens & pork noodle soup). Both were delicious as usual. 

One comment: the portion sizes of the non-dumplings seem to have gotten smaller while the prices have increased.
Great dumplings the flushing location seems the best also the lamb shank is really good
I LOVE Joe's Shanghai. Must order the soup dumplings and scallion pancakes.  Kung pow chicken  and shrimp Lo Mein are also great. One of my favorite spots in Chinatown!
The soup dumplings were amazing! The staff wasn't friendly, but they were very efficient. I will totally be coming back!

Came here for dinner last night, and yes it lives up to the hype. They make excellent dumplings!

We had two servings of the soup dumplings and one serving of the fried dumplings, an order of spring rolls and some Singaporean Noodles with beef.

The place is a bit dive-y and very busy, but hey we are in China town and everything was tasty and very affordable, so two thumbs up!
Their crab soup dumplings are the best. Me and my friends get them at least 3 times per week. Absolutely delicious.

Best crab soup dumplings this side of the pacific hands down. Yes the wait can get long at times but trust me when I say it's worth the wait. The soup dumplings are definitely on par u not better than the ones I've had in shanghai. Destination spot CHECK. Ps it's cash only, but food is extremely good and cheap.

Delicious and juicy crab/pork dumplings.  I took a big bite and all the juice squirt out of my mouth.  This place is so popular there's a 1-2 hour wait depending on your party size on the weekend.  Lucky for us, we tried coming back on a weekday and no wait at all.  We also had Beef Tendon noodles...which was ok.

Definitely come here for the dumplings.

Really can't say enough about how good this food is. I saw some people complaining about how they sat people together at tables, but i didn't mind it at all. 

You need to order the dumplings.  I also got the chicken lo mein so so so good. 

seriously.. Just GO!

oh yeah and CASH ONLY!

They have the best soup dumplings & scallion pancakes.
However the new location was sooo loud, we couldn't even hear the person next to us at our own table

This spot was great. Me and a group of 3 (4 total) came here Sunday night. It was packed. Tables either come by 8 or 2. So be prepared to share tables. The food was insane. Sesame chicken dumplings (#9 and #10). Salt and pepper shrimp. Fat noodles (forgot name). The won ton soup was also good and comes family style. Highly recommended.

I had heard a lot about Joe's Shanghai from friends and so some of us went to check it out around 10pm. Luckily, we found seating right away. I've heard that those who come at peak hours are not so lucky.

We had mostly soup dumplings (we ordered 3 orders of 8, or something like that) and the rest of the meal consisted of beef fried rice. I found the beef fried rice to be pretty average, but the soup dumplings were among the best I've ever had. I can't tell for sure if it was THE BEST I've ever had, because I've never gone to a place in which the majority of my meal consisted of soup dumplings. It could just be that I liked it here so much because I had so much of them. Nevertheless, the quality was very high.

okay first of i NEED to get this off my chest: I am reviewing this on the xiao long bao's (XLB), not on the rest of the food.  YOU GO HERE TO GET THE XLBs!!!  NOT NECESSARILY ANYTHING ELSE!!!!  for the ppl who gave this a low rating, its usually because they expect everything else this restaurant gives to be excellent as well, but its only mediocre.  if i were to rate it based on everything (which i guess I should be doing) i would give it a 4.  but still, the XLBs are the best I have ever had.  really really good.

BEST xiao long tang bao (Steamed soup dumpling: $5.95 for 8 pc)
BEST scallion pancake ($2.95)
BEST drunken chicken ($7.95)

No really, it's amazing how a well-renowned Chinese restaurant can serve all these excellent food at cheap prices! The star of course is the XLTB. Be careful when you pick up a dumpling so that you don't break it, because it is filled with hot delicious soup that you do not want to waste! Once you carefully placed it on your spoon, break it so your spoon will be filled with the soup within. 

Don't try to directly bite the XLTB like a normal dumpling! It will be a hot mess.

Be sure to get the golden pan-fried scallion pancake and the drunken chicken too! I haven't had a drunken chicken this good ever since my first drunken chicken dish in a high-end restaurant in Taiwan.

It's cash only and you may have to wait for a while so be prepared. If you are visiting NYC Chinatown, you need to eat a meal here especially if you want stellar XLTB!

Absolutely the best soup dumplings I've ever had. I lkke Americanized Chinese food (white meat chicken!), so the menu is perfect for me. You may end up waiting a while for a table, but it'll be worth it.
Of course the dumplings were great, but we were blown away by the whole crispy fish, which was incredibly flavorful.

Delicious food, very affordable, quick waiting staff.
Cash only, doesn't serve hard liquor.
Try the scallion pancakes and of course the SOUP DUMPLINGS.

One of the best Chinese restaurants in the city, but make sure to come with a small party or get ready to wait!  It's also best to come on a Monday evening to avoid the swarm of people. Here are some must eats:

1.  Soup dumplings (order them the second you sit down)
2.  Scallion pancakes (the best in the city)
3.  Shanghai flat noodles with pork
4.  Beef with scallions

As a general note the restaurant circles all of their best and most popular dishes, so just stick with those because the chef knows best!

We went to Joe's Shanghai after the Interactive Van Gogh experience (thank you Yelp Elite community for those free tix!)

We ordered the soup dumplings with pork and crab meat, and we both thought they were delicious and well priced, as well. 

The kung Pao chicken -- somewhat of a basic normie choice -- was also appetizing. Really not the kind of the dish you'd expect them to screw up. It came with a side of white rice. 

The Szechuan noodles, however, were pretty plain, and we didn't think the stew was anything to write home about. However, the accompanying beef was just chewy enough and very tasty!

The service at Joe's Shanghai deserves a mention because it is mediocre. The hostess was kind, but the waiters pressured us into ordering right after we got there, and kept walking near our table after it was served, never asking about our meal, or offering more water as our glasses of water emptied out. Rozena says this type of a service is normal especially in Chinatown, but I think differently.

The food at Joe's Shanghai was really great! Plus, for a restaurant in Chinatown, I was surprised at the design and upkeep of the atmosphere.

We were able to fit 11 people with no wait on a Tuesday and ordered a lot of food. I recommend the cold tofu and chow mein. We also got the peeking duck which was amazing!
everything was superb! the soup dumplings are a must try, and i loved the bok choy. CASH ONLY!

Soup dumplings... my kyrponite!  I was first introduced to this fabulous dish by a college friend from Taiwan.  Ever since then, I have been in a search for amazing soup dumplings.  Word thru the grapevine told me this place is the best! Unfortunately, by the time I went to visit Joe's I was already hooked on Din Tai Fung.  
I was on vacation meeting up a friend there, in which i was a bit late.  My friends had already ordered and once I arrived dumplings had already made its grand entrance.  Dumplings were a bit warm.  I was surprised to see the size of the dumplings.  I was use to the smaller Din Tai Fung dumplings.  I couldnt wait to try these.  I picked one up very carefully and proceeded to do my dumpling-eating ritual.

1. Pick up the dumpling by its tip
2. Dip dumpling in soy sauce/ vinegar concoction that i had perfected to my palate
3. Place dumpling on my spoon, and ginger on top of the dumpling 
4. Devour it with the soup Exploding in your mouth (the best way to enjoy it in my world)

As i was chewing and eating and thinking about the dumpling that is being processed in my mouth, I had a hard to trying to taste the soup.  The skin of the dumplings were a bit thicker than what i am use to.  The meat itself was delicious hearty.  (and after walking for 30 mins trying to find the place, it was a slight reward on my physically activity workout)  
Unfortunately I didnt get to the look at the menu to see what else they have available but from my observation at other tables they all look great!  Cheap good food that fulfills your hunger pang!
 
Is it worth the trip? Well if you never had soup dumplings... then by all mean check it out!

We were on a hunt for dim sum. Thought this was the place, but it wasnt. So we sat and decided to eat anyways. LIttle did we know, we hit the jackpot!!! we got soup dumplins, pan fried dumplings and a pancake. BEST soup dumplings EVER! The price made this yummy dumpling even better! 

This place is exactly what you think when you think chinatown. Everyone we dont know is sitting together around the same table. Its packed, so service may not be the best. The vibe was awesome and so was the food. Im definately going back nex time!
This is probably the best shanghai bum restaurant in town. I was here with a friend, and we really enjoy the food here. Pretty much most of the food is tasteful, and I will be back!

I recommend Joe's Shanghai all the time for their soup dumplings. so delicious!

The dining setting is fast paced and you may sit with strangers. But if you're ok with this, then Joe's Shanghai is for you!
Xiao long bao (soup dumpling) is very awesome. I'm just a tourist but i been there 2 days in a roll.

Joes Shanghai is an NYC experience. Usually a wait if 20 ish minutes but it moves fast. You sit at communal tables and the service is not personalIzed and is very rushed. But don't get it twisted, just how it is in china town. Pork steamed dumplings, scallion pancakes and string beans are the go to.

My first dine in experience after COVID. 
Joe's shanghai is my favorite weekend location since college:)) 

beef in spicy chill sauce: i think they changed formula. it has strong vinegar flavor now. a bit disappointed but still okay. 

Soup dumpling: AMAZING

We love Joe's Shanghai! We used to go to the Flushing location until it closed and this location is just as good! The ingredients are always fresh, from the broccoli to green peppers, and the ingredients great quality, beef, shrimp, and scallops. The sauces are always perfectly flavorful and seasoned.

One of my favorite dishes is the scallops and prawns in garlic sauce, the sauce is so very good. 

It looks popular to eat indoors too (no outdoor seating) but we have only ever done takeout from this location. Takeout has always been pretty fast and well organized.

This place is a must for newcomers and NYC veterans alike.  You can obviously tell from the reviews that the soup dumplings are their specialty.  They come with crab and pork or only pork filling.  The dumplings are pretty good sized, and the dough is perfect so that you don't prematurely rupture the dumpling itself.  I also tried some pan-fried combination meat noodle dish, which was pretty good, but I forget exactly what it was called because I was so distracted by the amazing soup dumplings!

This place is cash only, and during peak dining hours you'll probably have to wait.  The good thing is that the staff moves quickly and with a purpose.  Also, to minimize wait times, they seat multiple parties together at those larger round tables to ensure there are no empty seats in the restaurant at a given time.  My party was quoted a 20 minute wait at 3pm on a Saturday, but we were seated in 5 minutes.
Its cash only and there is usually a line but worth the wait. The best soup dumplings in town!!
i'm a fan of their soup dumplings, quick service and moderate prices.  the dining area is frugal.  don't expect fine dining.  its cash only and they include gratuity on the check.

Best xiao long bao I have ever had. 

I've also had their stirfry green beans with beef and that was also a good dish! So is the cold peanut noodles that they recommended. ( I feel bad because my friend ate this when she's allergic to peanuts.) oh and my other friend got a bad stomach ache. It's a good thing nothing happened to me otherwise it would've been a 4 stars instead of a 5.

I love me some Xiao Long Bao (XLB)! Was so excited to try this, it was the first thing I ate when I landed in New York. 

Got the pork xlb, pork and crab xlb, and scallion pancake. They were all delicious! They're much larger than normal but in my opinion, the more the better. I also love how there is a lot of soup in the dumplings. The worst is when they're dry! 

Just FYI, on the menu, they don't call it juicy dumplings or xiao long bao. That confused me at first because I didn't want to end up with regular dumplings. They just call them as dumplings instead under the appetizer section. 

Usually there is a really long wait but I didn't have to wait at all. I went around 12pm on a Thursday.  They also make you share a table with other people so that could make some people uncomfortable. The walls also have photos of all the celebrities who have been there. It's a must go spot!

Are you looking for some tasty Eastern Chinese food at a good price in New York's Chinatown? Are you willing to wait a little while to eat at this place? Are you also willing to deal with service that's not great? Well, if you said yes, this place has your answer. The 2010 Not For Tourists Guide to New York City had said that the crab soup dumplings "are essential Chinatown eats" (page 27) and this place is one of the most talked about restaurants in New York's Chinatown. After waiting for 25 minutes, my friend and I were able to get a seat at this place. 

When my friend and I sat down, we quickly ordered the #1, Xie Fen Xiao Long Bao, which is the Crab Meat with Pork Meat Steamed Bun. This is the crab soup dumplings that the guide was talking about. 

One basket filled with Xie Fen Xiao Long Bao is enough for a light appetizer for 2-4 people and there are 8 pieces. I actually enjoyed the flavor of the bun, and the meat inside. I don't think I tasted much crab meat. I was able to enjoy the buns by taking a small bite, and sucking the warm broth inside the bun. The dark soy vinegar sauce made the Xiao Long Bao tastier and I liked the warm and soft chewiness of the bun. I have eaten Xiao Long Bao in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and the somewhat decent city of Boston, and this place in New York's Chinatown does a pretty good job in making Xiao Long Bao. 

As for other dishes, my friend got #139, which is the Pan Fried Noodles. He liked them, but I was not impressed. The noodles were bland and it was doused with a lot of sauce. I would not recommend ordering this dish if you really want a great Chinese dinner. The portion was generous, though. 

However, they do a good job with this noodle dish, and I would highly recommend this one. I got the #143, Ge Shi Chao Nian Gao, which is the Fried Rice Cake with pork. This is a rice noodle dish where the noodles are shaped like small and flat oval tablets, which look like cakes. It has some strips with pork, fried in a wok with spinach. I thought it was a tasty dish, with tender pork and soft and somewhat crisp fried rice noodles. This is a great choice to complement the Xiao Long Bao, and one dish is enough to feed a very hungry man for dinner. 

The service was not great, but somewhat effective. You may have to yell a little loud and clear if you know what to order. and the servers are not really friendly. A 15% service charge is added to your bill. This is probably the first restaurant I have been to in the USA that actually charges a service charge no matter how large the group is. 

Since this place is really popular, and you have a group less than six, you may have to share a large table with people you don't know. This may not be a bad thing. 

Overall, if you really want some Xiao Long Bao, this is a great choice as long as you are willing to wait for a table and you are willing to deal with not great service. I would not say that it is a place that you really have to go to according to the guides, but it is a great choice for some Xiao Long Bao and some Shanghai-style Fried Rice Cakes. Is this the best place for Xiao Long Bao in New York's Chinatown? Possibly. Is the Xiao Long Bao on par with Shanghai's or Hong Kong's Xiao Long Bao? Probably not, but this place is pretty good and worthwhile to go.

Loved it!  A hole in the wall place in Chinatown with delicious dumplings for cheap.  Loved the pork dumplings!  The table sharing was a first for me but a couple of people at the table were very friendly and added to our experience.  The servers were swift but not too friendly but we got our food very fast so we were happy.

My friend and I get dinner once a month. This month was my friend's turn to pick. He had bookmarked Joe's Shanghai a while ago and we finally got around to trying it. We got there early enough on a Thursday (around 6:45) that we were able to be seated right away. (When we left there was a wait) It's a large restaurant with high ceilings and some modern decor. It is however very bright and somewhat loud.

Our waiter was nice and the service was fast and furious (we got the impression that they knew how to turn tables). They landed the appetizers in rapid succession. The soup dumplings (pork and pork with crab) were quite good, certainly on the substantial side. Not the top I've had but certainly in the top 3-5. The turnip cakes were tasty, nice texture. I wasn't blown away by the cold noodles with peanut sauce, serviceable but a little off texturally and underwhelming seasoning. The cold chicken in wine was tasty, it was good with the chili oil that's on the table. We moved on to the lion's head meatballs and then the beef with flat noodles. You get four large meatballs and they were tasty. Not the best example of this dish that I've had but passable. The waiter recommended the beef with flat noodles. In his defense, he may have thought we were into basic dishes. It lacked pop, the noodle texture was alright, not an overwhelmingly good dish.

I gave it four stars because we didn't eat anything that wasn't at least tasty. That said, nothing blew us away. Felt a bit geared towards a touristy Chinatown experience. Also, cash only.

There is no denial the steamed pork soup dumpling are SO GOOD!! And for the price $7 for 8 dumplings!! You can't really beat that and that is the reason why I keep coming back!
However I need to precise that the service here is pretty bad.. they are rude and try to rush you through your meal (if they could feed you to make you eat faster they would).
So go there for the pork soup dumpling (the crab one are not as good) but don't expect to have a calm or romantic dinner.

A group of 7 of us stop by Joe's Shanghai for a quick bite (with a place like this in the city, is it ever quick??) and as expected, Joe's Shanghai delivered some pretty delicious bites.

Let's start with the xiao long baos (steamed soup dumplings) - While these were still good, they're not the best that I've had (even counting previous times at Joe's Shanghai).
