The biggest thing for me was that the dumplings came out really flat. I'd say the skin might have been just a tad too thin and they probably could have used a little bit more meat in it. But either way, it still tasted like heaven.

The beef noodle soup was the biggest disappointment for me. While the flavor of the broth and the texture of the beef was spot on, the noodles were a little bit overcooked for me (I find overcooked pasta/noodles are prone to high volume places like these). 

For what it's worth - the wait this time wasn't as bad as they said it would be. From initially being quoted an hour wait, we ended waiting maybe 15 minutes.

My favorite - Xiao Long Bao place! If you want fabulous soup dumplings this is definitely the place to go.
Yes the wait is long. Yes it may feel a little weird to be seated at a round table next to total strangers. But it's all worth it after you have a bite of their pork & crab soup dumplings.

I agree with the other reviewer wherein, you go here for the XLB's not for their main dishes. The main entree's weren't bad at all, I'm just saying that I wouldn't go here if I didn't want to order XLBs.

Service is what I would expect in any other Asian restaurant wherein they really just try to get their job done in a rush. But I'm used to it.

Note: Pricing is also affordable. Their XLB order comes with 8 dumplings. Cash only!

I highly recommend this place. (And Quickly's next door!)
Delicious every time we go. Xiao long bao one of the best I've ever had. Also just tried the scallion cake and had to order another because it was so yummy.

This place is the ultimate NYC tourist trap because it is very well known for their soup dumplings (I can see why). Their soup dumplings are delicious and addictive. They are perfect to eat on a cold winter day or night. The only downside about this restaurant is that chances are you will have to be seated with strangers in their large round tables (so they won't waste any seat space as hundreds of people wait long periods of time to get a table everyday). I was awkwardly seated so closely with strangers in the same table and when our different orders arrived at our table (note: mostly everyone who comes here orders soup dumplings), it would be kind of difficult to sort our orders out.

My wife and I had dinner at the new Joe's Shanghai on Bowery, just around the corner from the old place. Everything about the new restaurant is wonderful--the service, food quantity, price, and the nicely decorated space.  We ordered veggie dumplings, crispy Hunan beef, and shrimp and scallops in garlic sauce and enjoyed every dish. We would definitely recommend this place if you are in Chinatown.

4 stars for the soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. By far the best I've had in the city with a nice chili oil. Love the  depth of the broth in the dumplings. Thick skin so they do not easily break. The pork is soft and melts in your mouth. Always quick and fast service. This place is usually packed at lunch time. A definite must try. Remember it is cash only and service/gratuity is already included on the bill.

Was in NY for work and my co-workers wanted to eat in Chinatown so we decided to try Joe's Shanghai. Honestly I came in with no expectations, because being from LA I've been spoiled with good authentic Chinese food. I knew coming in it wouldn't be authentic and the food would cater to tourists. But the food was actually pretty good! 

We had 4 people in our group and we had to share a large table with 2 other parties. The restaurant was jam packed and service was not friendly. We ordered a bunch of dishes and shared. We all agreed that the soup dumplings was the highlight! We still talk about the dumplings til this day LOL I wish we got another order. Some other dishes I enjoyed were the Shanghai noodles, scallion beef and general tso shrimp. My coworkers liked the scallion pancake but I thought it was too thick. 

Overall I would return for the noodles and dumplings. Be sure to come early because when we left, the crowd outside got bigger!

I've been meaning to come here to try the XLB. It's not bad!! But it's not your Din Tai Fung, if that makes sense.

We were only a party of 2, so we got seated asap. Everyone comes in parties of 4+ and it's packed with tourists down Pell St. 

We got squished into a shared table with others and ordered the crab xlb. I was pleased to see that these were pretty good sized - not the skimpy, overpriced ones. They were pretty good! 

My only complaint is the juice almost always spilled when picking it up. They don't give you any bowls either. So you're just trying to balance and catch everything in a normal-sized spoon. The meat was also pretty chewy, made me think it was undercooked.. but don't believe that's the case. 

Probably a one-time thing for me. There are plenty of other xlb places in the city to try. But definitely give this place a shot if you haven't been before!

For starters: Service isn't great here. Not that I was expecting much, but often it's hard to get seated, they forget to bring you the menu, etc.

However, the food here is incredibly delicious. From the soup dumplings to the fried rice, I highly recommend.

This place is quite good. We got the dumplings and the service was pretty good. Super fast and nice wait time. We really only ordered dumplings and noodles. But it's kinda pricey for what u get. But the dumplings were huge but epic soup dumpling. Honestly when I come to New York again I prolly won't go here just to try the other options.

I first came here with my brother-in-law and oh, 6 of his male cousins and had no idea what to expect. The soup dumplings should probably be named "crack" dumplings because I crave them on a weekly basis. I have to say that the one thing I love most about living in NYC is having access to amazing Asian food and Joe's is #1 on my list. All the dishes (well, the authentic Chinese ones) are made just like they would be at home. I could do without the wait (since I always show up starving), but it's generally a good sign (i.e. that the food is THAT good). It's weird to be seated right next to someone that you don't know while having dinner, but the food's so good, you won't even notice. You must go here.

The soup dumplings are AMAZING. Shanghai noodles are also good, and the cabbage with black mushroom. I've never had a dish here I didn't like. The midtown location is prettier, of course, but Pell Street is the way to go. In midtown you get six dumplings per basket; in Chinatown you get eight, and they seem fresher. Plan to wait in line outside the restaurant, and plan to be seated at a large table with other parties.
The dumplings are amazing! I've been here a few times and have loved everything they have. You don't always get a personal table so be ready to potentially sit around a table with random people.

The best soup dumplings I've ever had!!! We also ordered fried dumplings/potstickers, crispy seafood noodles, fried rice, general tso chicken. Everything was delicious. Even the hot chili sauce they keep on the tables. Make sure to bring cash, it's cash only.
It's a hidden gem in Chinatown! Whoever likes Shanghai food should come here and have a bite. Very authentic flavor! Based on my 4 years living experiences in Shanghai.

Joe's Shanghai absolutely lives up to the hype. Yup, the crab & pork xlb are on everyone's table and are absolutely the best. The spring rolls and scallion pancakes were super flaky and crispy as well -- everything tasted super fresh and not overly greasy at all! We did have to wait around 40 minutes though to get sat and everyone waits outside in the hot nyc sun but it was very well worth it. Oh and the service was just fine. Straight forward service and food came out in a timely manner for how busy the place was! This isn't fine dining yall!

Best Chinese in NY I go here every time I come to NYC. Make sure you get the dumplings when you come. Also the line is long so be patience did I spell that right? Very reasonably priced and service is fast once you finally sit down. They also sit you with other people which was fine with me. They get your order in if you are ready and bring your food out when it is done.
I hate this place. It ruined soup dumplings for me. It's never been the same. The texture, the flavor, the filling, even the price. Best soup dumplings I've ever had.

I'm not from New York, but if a friend who doesn't even live in New york recommends Joe's shanghai, this guy Joe must make some really good stuff! Of course we ordered the Pork Xia Long Bao (soup dumplings) 8 for only $5, what a steal! Our friend told us theres no point in ordering the mixed crab/pork one since theres barely any crab and they charge an extra ~$2, smart thinking! I also got to try the shanghai fried rice, which was pretty good! The place is very small, approx. 12 tables? The service is just like any other asian place, awful! At first, I thought the service was okay, but as time went by I realized the workers standing over our table and handing us the bill and literally standing there until we paid! I don't blame them since the place is small and people are always waiting for tables, but gosh don't be that rude! Don't be surprised, the bill has tax & tip included. We had a table of 7 people and we each paid under $10 each. I definitely recommend this place. You know where you can find me on my next nyc trip ;)



*Pork xia long bao [eight for $5]

excellent soup dumplings ,  a great variety of sauces with delicious spring rolls
fast service
cash only

This is a pre-covid review. I always like to mention this because the menu could have changed. 

I ate here with a few friends when we were in town. It was on top of our list because of the raving reviews about this place. The reviews did not disappoint. They have those stars for a reason. My review would just be full of "delicious" and "tasty" so let's just cut to the chase. Everything I list below was !

Pork Soup Dumplings
Pork Dumplings
Shanghai Noodle Soup
Kung Pao Chicken
Crispy Shredded Beef

Delicious soup dumplings and affordable food. This place is always packed and it's better to go for 3 ppl and under. You have to share tables with strangers and it's loud in there. My husband and I just go in, get the crab dumplings, jellyfish and shrimp fried rice and leave right after we finish eating. They serve the food rather quickly. Not a fan of their fried noodles.
Grew up eating this place when it was on Pell. All the dishes are great and crab meat soup dumplings a must.

You're guaranteed to wait because this place is always packed. My sister insists it's the best place to eat in Chinatown. 

This place is known for their dumplings, but sadly none of them were vegetarian so I had to just sit and watch wistfully and my sister and her boyfriend devoured two orders of them. 

I was able to enjoy a tofu and mixed vegetable plate that was delicious and the shallot pancakes came with a sweet dipping sauce and were definitely my favorite part of the meal. The bean curd and spinach dish that I ordered was greasy and weird and I wouldn't recommend it. 

Service is pretty good and they work to get people and food in and out as fast as possible.

After reading the review on yelp a few months ago, my friend decided to take us to Joe's Shanghai. Tucked away in a little nook of Chinatown, this unassuming restaurant was well worth the trip from Queens; and from what I've experienced, it deserves the high yelpers rating. 
 Make sure to bring cash with you, as they don't except plastic; also be prepared to wait a good amount of time... As this place is almost always busy (but well worth it!). As stated in previous reviews, the dumplings are a MUST, as they are probably the best tasting dumplings I have ever had; the delicious meat/porky broth on the inside is what makes Joe's dumplings famous. Just be careful, as the broth is steaming hot. Learning how to eat them is also fun. Some people poke holes into the dumpling and slowly slurp up the juice; I tried this method, and it works for the most part. Just don't pop them whole into your mouth, unless you want to look like a fool.
 Besides the dumplings, Joe's Shanghai also delivers the goods in it's entrees. I've had the duck on many occasions, and it's always savory and delicious. Just be careful when ordering entrees, as the portions are fairly big. 
 As with other jam packed Chinese restaurants, Joe's Shanghai uses a table sharing method. Whether or not this is a good thing is for the individual to decide; I prefer the more conventional style, being able to share an explicit and often scandalous conversation with my friends without worrying about eavesdropping yuppies, but I do admit that this system seems to fit in with the cute, unassuming, unpretentious picture Joe's Shanghai has painted itself. And it's sometimes funny to hear other peoples conversations; but then again it's not so great to get into an argument with a disillusioned, overtly rude, 30 something year old new yorker about how much to tip the waiter. I know that his jealousy of my youth and beauty must have been great, but please try to leave the waiters tip out of it.
 All that aside, Joe's Shanghai is well worth the wait, and a delightfully fun experience.

Joe's Shanghai is a classic must visit every time I'm craving some authentic and delicious Chinese food. The first time I visited, the place was still in the older location and looked a bit more like a mom and pop shop than what it is now. The new remodeled location looks great. It's very clean and almost doubled in seating. 

We arrived on the weekend for a late lunch and the wait was still around a 40 minute wait. Once we were seated the turnaround time was super quick. The way to go is family style, so you can try a bunch of different things on the menu. 

We kind of over ordered for a party of three but here's what we ordered: 

Cold noodles - i would not get this again. It tasted like noodles with peanut butter and nothing else. There were about 3 cucumber slices and it did not live up to the traditional cold noodles I remember having as a kid. 

XLB - we ordered 3 baskets, which was way too much food haha. Their soup dumplings are HUGE. They're almost twice the size of what I remember them to be. Delicious, the skin is super thin and the soup is SO flavorful. Loved every bite. Make sure you eat this warm so the soup doesn't solidify. 

Sichuan beef - hands down the best dish second to the XLB. The meat was tender and flavorful. The bean sprouts were the perfect compliment. 

Eggplant - This dish was ok, not as saucy as we remember but still a delicious dish. 

If you're in the area, you must stop by and try Joe's! But FYI it's cash only!
I have an asian tongue and I have to say that I love this place especially the dumplings!! The soup inside is nothing to say more than great!!!

XLB's, ftw!!!

I love soup dumplings; they're absolutely delicious & filling. Although I'm originally from LA (tons of great Chinese restaurants), the first time I had xiao long bao was when I moved out to NYC at Shanghai Cafe.

Shanghai Cafe's XLB's are okay, but I actually prefer the broth of Joe's XLB's much much much more. There's something about the richness of the broth at Joe's Shanghai that I was very impressed with.. it didn't taste watered-down like the ones at Shanghai Cafe, to explain it in the most simple terms, I guess. I've had XLB's three times at Shanghai Cafe, and all three times, I thought the broth there was a bit watered down/tasteless.

Joe's Shanghai staff is much nicer and they don't push you to eat fast, pay the bill, and leave quickly, ha.

My friend & I shared a table with complete strangers, but that's nothing new at Chinese restaurants. We sat by the wall that had Jeremy Lin's photo with a waiter, so that was cool. The prices are decent, the staff is nice, and most importantly, I really enjoyed my XLB's.

So freaking good. Try to get here before the rush. Small parties of two are your best bet here since they put different people at a 10 person table. The turn around here is quick. The waiter asks you right when they seat you if you want the XLB. Just say yes because you do. I really like the pork dumplings. The skin stuck to my lips a bit but the soup was sooooooo yummy two orders of XLB and scallion pancakes and you're full for a pretty good price. Totally a must go here.

This place is great! I love the food, service, and location. The wait time can be crazy sometimes because of it's worth it. The food is family style so whatever you order make sure you share because it's too much for one person. To kill some time while you wait for a table, get a foot massage across the street, it is so worth it.

We waited about 2 hours standing outside for our party of 3 to be called on. Usually, I would be irate over the insane wait. However, we went during a very busy time of the year AND the food was to die for. Be prepared to be crammed in and share a table with other people. The soup dumplings were amazing--thin, sticky dough filled with a delicious broth and a melt-in-your-mouth pork filling. I've never tasted anything like it! The Spring Rolls were also the best I've ever had. They need a larger location, but I would definitely go matter no matter what.

Excellent XLB.
Being from LA we go to DTF enough to compare. 
These are bigger, juicier, and less expensive. 
The skin is slightly thicker, but needs to be in order to hold the soup inside. These are like if you have an expert grandma making them for you.
Scallion pancakes were also outstanding. Crispy outside, soft inside, with nice scallion flavor.

Excellent and authentic Chinese restaurant! I have eaten here many times, sometimes with friends, during my many stays in NYC, and, just as is true with their sister shop called Joe's Ginger which is located nearby, the food is great! 

Intrestingly, I consistently notice that a great many of this restaurant's customers are local Chinese residents and also visitors from China, all of whom regularly insist that the food is very authentic and "real". 

They also do not overdo the MSG, which I really appreciate, since I am MSG-sensitive, and rather, they tend to be very conservative in their use of MSG.

The manu has some great and rather unique offerings, with many offerings remaining very true to the authentic Shanghai cuisine.

One word of warning: this restaurant tends to get very crowded, very fast, once 5 PM approaches each day!

I have always had great meals at this restaurant, with no exceptions!

Going to join in on the hype and say that the crab soup dumplings here are the best I've had in the states. The pungent flavor of crab intestines really comes through, whereas I've found at other places that it's hard to distinguish the crab from the pork soup dumplings. In my experience, this location does a much more consistent job of providing fresh batches of dumplings versus the Midtown location. If you come at an off-peak time, the wait is very reasonable. We arrived around 5pm on a weekday, pre-dinner rush, and waited less than 10 minutes. Focus on the soup dumplings and order other dishes as sides, since everything else is pretty run-of-the-mill.

absolutely excellent food. Went with a group and got the pork soup dumplings along with an order of pork Gyoza. These were the best soup dumplings I've ever had in my life! The only issue was that the line was very long, but it's because it's so popular everybody wanted to go.
Delicious. Must pay with caah! Family style eating is best. Its community seating, but so yummy. Dumplings, kung pao and crispy beef all so tasty. This is my new hidden gem.  Loved it!!!

Great food  ambiance adds to your experience as you dine in Chinatown NYC.  Pork dumplings in soup are as delicious as you would expect them to be.  Service is quick as there is always people waiting to be seated.  Cash only with an ATM appropriately found right outside the entrance.  Ordered sesame chicken which was also quite delicious and it comes with a nice side of green broccoli .  And something that I loved was that end of meal orange slices placed in the table.  Sweet delicious fresh orange slices to help cleanse your after meal taste buds.  If you are visiting NYC I would recommend taking an Uber to get there as Chinatown can be confusing if you don't know it.

A little know note.  I use to work in Flushing and ate in Joe's Shanghai, the 
ORIGINAL Joe's.  Chinatown is A BRANCH of Flushing...a real Different.
Yes, it borders on touristy but the Pork Dumplings are the best.  I like the
simplicity of it...no decisions get the dumplings, get a cold beer and warm
yourself up.  One of the reviewers said it had not been updated since 1943.
Since Joe's Flushing only opening in the early 90's I don't think so.  It
deals on quantity and forgets about ambiance..ok by me as long as dumplings
keep being delicious.  If I want ambiance I will have to pay for it.
I must get out of a rut and try the scallion pancakes.  Flushing has the the
same fishbowl but is quite a bit bigger and a little more formal...not much

Never dissatisfied so warm as it goes down feels like love  I was like, is that Joe of Shanghai lol??? No one she visit China without stopping here first.....there are others but these are tha best! Go change someone's life and take them here!
Soup dumplings were fabulous. Tried the chicken fried rice which was also good, but nothing can beat the dumplings.

Come for the soup dumplings and scallion pancakes, stay for nothing else. 

One order per person, two if they're gluttons. I prefer the pork only, since the crab and pork are just ok and nothing too special.

And I'm serious about ordering nothing else except the xiao long bao and scallion pancakes.

Came here on sat for dinner and wait was about 40 min, they give you a raffle ticket that's easy to lose so dont lose it !! 

There are a few chairs and benches outside to sit on. 
This restaurant has gotten so popular because of yelp and word of mouth etc, there are peiple from all parts of the world eating here. 

You have to split tables with people, if you don't have enough of a ful table, so we ended up at a table with 3 other groups which I hate because it's kind of awkward sometimes. 

We ordered xiao long bao, crab xiao long bao, dan dan mian, garlic eggplant, rice cake with beef, and shredded pork with jalapenos and bean curd. 

My favorite dishes were the dan dan mian, and the crab xiao long bao. The crab xiao long bao had amazing crab flavor and was so savory and delicious. The dan dan mian was super peanut butter which I love !!! The eggplant was way too sweet, so I only had one piece. The other dishes were not really my taste either because they were too sweet. 

Must get the crab xiao long bao!!
Food and service was great! It seems like locals even come here to eat as well as tourist!

Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Dumplings. Just AMAZING. We got there at the perfect time because the line was not to long but by the time we walked out, there was a huge line! We ordered 1 order of the pork dumping and one of the crab-pork dumpling. Both were great. But if I had to choose, I'd choose the pork. There were many other shops that served dumplings but I'm glad we chose this one.

I've come here ever since I was a kid and whenever I get a chance to go, I would never say no! This is absolutely the most amazing place ever and I've never tried a soup dumpling place in NYC that is better than this, in my opinion at least. I've loved it since I was young and I'll continue to love it till this day. Joe's shanghai lives up to it's name and makes amazing soup dumplings.

Let me start by saying, if you mind sharing a table with strangers, this is not the place for you. Joe's only has 10 person round tables, which they fill up, so unless you are a party of 10, you're sharing a table. But if that doesn't bother you, then by all means, if you are in Chinatown, you have to come to Joe's. And yes, the soup dumplings are famous for a reason. I am glad the the other people at our table got theirs before us, because there's a technique to eating them. I don't know how many they make a day, but the nine people at our table had 48. 

We also had the Shanghai fried rice and the crispy whole fish. The rice was good, not greasy like the kind you get at  many take-out  places. Simple, with egg and scallions. The crispy fish was cooked well. The menu says it's spicy, but it wasn't at all. I don't know if they made it less spicy for us because I asked how spicy it is. He said medium, but it wasn't . 

So a pot of tea, 8 dumplings, a platter of rice and a whole fish for $41 pre tip. Not bad. Oh, by the way, it's cash only. 

My daughter said the next time we're in New York we have to go back to Joe's. And, oh yes, we definitely will.

I was watching the Karate Kid one night and was like wow I want Chinese food. Best decision ever. Went down to Pell St and got some love from my main man Joey Shanghai. They have the best shrimp in the state most likely from the Hudson River and their chopsticks are very easy to use they always have a custom pair with rubberbands they give to their most experienced customers. Xi√®xi√®, Joe, Xi√®xi√® (yes that is authentic Chinese LeAndre is a very cultured, classy man from a classy family in the hills).

came here with some friends on a day trip.  the xiao long bao were so good that we ordered four plates of them, two of the regular and two of the crab ones.  the crab ones were soooooo good!  
don't remember the specifics about the other dishes we ordered but everything was so delicious that it didn't even matter!  the prices were decent and the wait was at a minimum.  reason for short wait: coming here on a weekday afternoon!
Really great place to eat! I would recommend them for their soup dumplings! The broth was delicious and rich. The service professional and friendly, not too long waiting for food.

As my friends and I arrived at a hole-in-the-wall in a sketchy-looking area at night, I thought to myself, the food better be good if I'm gonna risk getting mugged and it was worth it.

Food:
I was told that they had great soup dumplings called Xiao Long Bao (shanghai style steamed pork buns).  When they mentioned soup dumplings, I thought it was a bunch of dumplings in a soup. When the food was dropped off, I realized that the soup was inside each dumpling! It was my first time having these and I was blown away. The meat was delicious and the soup provided even more flavor. Top each bite with ginger and soy sauce and it'll be an excellent meal

Service:
Mediocre. They just take orders and drop them off. They don't really check on you to see how you're doing and it takes forever to get a refill of water.

I think that Joe's Shanghai's xiao long bao are likely to be the best in the city and probably the best on the east coast (I've even heard best in America but let's not get ahead of ourselves).  The soup dumplings truly are delicious and flavorful, though compared to the real deal of Shanghai, they still need work in the aesthetics area.  Don't waste your money on the crab flavored soup dumplings since they suck and don't taste better than the regular pork ones.  Also, the other food is pretty unspectacular.  I like to eat soup dumplings here as a pre-meal appetizer or a snack.
Bueno bonito y barato! Absolutely the best soup dumplings eva! Community tables, crowded even at 3pm but wait time was 15 mins. Definitely coming back and next tine ordering more!!
Warning, this is a cash only place. The food was exceptional. The beef tendon noodle soup and crab dumplings were super good. I especially like the carp belly with buffalo sauce.

CASH ONLY

I'm prepared to get some opposition on this, but let me just go ahead and say that this place is over-hyped. 
Don't get me wrong, their xiao long bao are delicious, but I wouldn't go far as to say that they're sublime. It's definitely more of a tourist attraction to eat here-- you can definitely find better XLB elsewhere in one of the other many restaurant in Chinatown. Though I must say, their crab XLB is one of the most delicious I've had. However, their pork XLB is nothing too special. And because this place generates so much foot traffic, you may end up sitting communal style at a round table with strangers. Service is at times frantic since there are so many customers. And just because you're all sitting together it doesn't mean you order at the same time so at times there can be confusion/mix-ups in the orders and it can be somewhat overwhelming. 
Overall, their XLB has a great balance of flavor, texture, and broth-to-meat ratio. As for their other dishes, I wouldn't know. I come strictly for the soup dumps. Prices are cheap and the place is just eat and go. 
There is almost always a long line, so if you can avoid it, do so.

Must have - the steamed dumplings. Two kinds. Both great!
I go to this place one in a while for their cheap and delicious food. The location is kinda hard to find but it does not stop people from all over the world to come.
Usually you have to share a big round table with other people (there's way too many people..). Sometimes you can make friends while eating there.
Obviously it's not a place for a romantic dinner, but it's so much fun.

Joe's Shanghai has got a new regular! 

Came here for the first time the other night and shared soup dumplings and scallion pancakes with the boyfriend and I kind of wish I came alone so that I can pig out with out feeling bad lol! We shared pork soup dumplings and crab soup dumplings and both found the crab to be our favorite. These soup dumplings are delicious and they are definitely not cheap on the soup! Very juicy (i even dirtied my cardigan from splash back!) and delicious flavor. This is my first time eating soup dumplings so you can take this review with a grain of salt, but my boyfriend is Chinese and said these were amazing so this gives me more validation lol!! Now this is not my first time having scallion pancakes and these have to be the best scallion pancakes i've ever had. Can't wait to go back!!!! 

Like the other reviewers have mentioned, you will be seated with other parties which can be kind of akward but once you get your food you seem to care a lot less about the others around you. The wait can be long it seems if you have a large party, since it was just me and my boyfriend we waited around 20minutes (in the harsh January cold tho). The biggest reason I deducted a point, was not for the wait because I don't mind waiting for good food but because our waiter and buss boy who took care of our table were very rude and brutal. They practically threw are food on the table and almost knocked down my tea on more than one occasion. Seriously lucky that I enjoy food so much I can look past this rude behavior. Also, before we even asked for the check our waiter brings us the check. Yes its great we didn't have to wait for it since we were ready to go, but how does he know that!?! Please ask first, i know its extremely busy but i don't think its right to basically kickout customers. 

So all in all, don't come here expecting amazing service but do expect to eat some delicious food.

When you are in Chinatown, this is a must try place at least once in your lifetime. I stopped in on Thursday right when they opened at 11am. It was the best decision I made in NYC to have not wait time and getting to be seated immediately. 

Once we sat down, it didn't take that long for more customers to trickle in. Our server was decent but you don't go into Joes for the service. We only came in for the soup dumplings and ordered one of each (Pork and Crab & Pork). It took about 20 mins for the dumplings to come out, but once they did it was delicious. 

Each soup dumpling order comes in an order of 8 in a steamer basket. Each dumpling has actual soup to sip out and has a equal ratio of dumpling skin and meat. It's hard to find a good Chinese restaurant that will make this properly. 

The only gripe I had was regarding the dumpling placements. It was difficult to grab some of the dumplings that were touching each other because we didn't want to pop or rip the skin. 

Overall, I wanna go to Joes every time I am in town!

The food was here was good with it being in China Town. There were a lot of options to get from the menu so I would advise looking at the menu online before coming. Also take a look at photos for added measure. 

The service was not so good. We felt rushed the entire time. The wait staff does not check to see if you need anything after they dump your order at the table. They also do not have ice for water or sodas on a hot day in July. Overall I would come back because I liked the food, but I would lower my expectations for service with a smile here. It's a shame that smiling when serving has left the planet.

Got here on a bustling Saturday afternoon and was told that the wait would be 20 minutes.  With all the people packed outside the restaurant, I thought that was ridiculous and that there was no way we'd be in within 20.

Low and Behold, 20 minutes later, we are ordering the famous, hyped dumplings.

The dumplings were AMAZING.  The kind of amazing that makes your eyes do somersaults when you close them and you slurp up the savory salty soupy goodness that can only be found here.  The pork dumplings were RICH.  I don't even wanna know how much fat I'm potentially consuming but it was worth it.

Aw Man, I wanna give this place 5 stars but I can't because the service wasn't the greatest.  They worked fast, but the younger servers who were assigned our table kept slacking off and gave us weird looks whenever we ordered more food.  Also, not a fan of sharing tables, but suppose it's part of the experience.
The food and the ambiance are delicious, if you're lucky to get a seat. The duck was simply outstanding.

The hype makes for a long wait, but the pork soup dumplings are worth it. And trust me, one time I got minor food poisoning from their crab-pork soup dumplings and I still go back for the pork soup dumplings. The sesame chicken (yes lame order I know) was too sweet and syrupy for me but the garlic broccoli is delicious and underrated.

The dumplings are little dumplings of soupy happiness. This is a great place. They are fast, efficient and would definitely seat you with a random family.. so be prepared to make friends. We also got some side orders of a pan fried red bean dessert - I do not recommend. We waited for a long time outside, so long.. we had to be creative with games. Anyway, just be prepared to make friends with your own friends.

Great Shanghainese food, especially their xiao long bao, little meat filled dumplings filled with some of the tastiest dumpling soup! There's also lots of other shanghainese dishes, many prepared authentically... i used to live in shanghai soam quite an expert!


 Anyways, this place would have gotten five stars from me, except for the very cold and hurried waiting staff. Our table was full galfway through dinner and another dish arrived. Instead of trying to move plates around or come back later with the dish, rhe waiter just proceeded to plop it on top of two other dishes, toppling the vinegar dipping bowl in the process!


 The London Insider on his travels
http://www.london-insider.co.uk

99.9% of Chinese food in Manhattan is garbage. Joe's on Pell St is that .1%. I am a white dude who grew up in Long Island but I know my Chinese food

If you want polite waiters, a clean restaurant and no wait, this place isn't for you. But, if you want some bomb ass Chinese food this is the place to go.

Everything is good. Everything. Get the soup dumplings but don't hesitate to get your normal Chinese food favorites. Also get the steamed mini buns with condensed milk for something amazing (it's not on the menu).

Haters like to say, "this isn't authentic Chinese food, it's American Chinese food". Who cares??? Go to Beijing if you want something authentic and tastes like the food came from an animal shelter.

The waiters are rude but I find it fun to be just as rude to them. I think they appreciate it.
Four stars for dumplings and no line! Go on a rainy day :) However, the rest of the foods are mediocre. I probably won't comeback again, unless I'm craving for crab and pork dumplings.

I went on a Monday and there was no wait.  The soup dumplings are  delicious and filling but the group seating with strangers is awkward.

I went again on a Saturday with a large group and the wait was extremely long, but not impossible.  With 9 people they still sat strangers with us though!  The food is worth it.

Amazing soup dumplings! When I first came here, I didn't realize what they were (my Canto friend ordered), so I took a big bite and carelessly sprayed scorching broth everywhere. After that lesson was learned, I was able to enjoy these dumplings with a lot more caution. The best way I found to eat them is to take a teeny bite out of the skin, dump the broth into the spoon they give you, sip the broth, and eat the rest of the dumpling. Like many restaurants in Chinatown, they give you free tea too!

Beyond delicious. Amongst my favorite if not my favorite place in town.

Must have:
Crab xiao long bao
Shanghai rice
Shanghai noodles

Also pretty good the fried duck although extremely greasy.

Great restaurant, quick service and came close to opening on a weekday so there wasn't a line or wait. Only got the soup dumplings and were so filling and delicious. The broth was flavorful and portions were big. Left happy and full and would come back next time I'm in NYC.

The PORK xiao long bao (soup dumplings) are awesome. I wouldn't compare them to the ones in china or taiwan... but they're definitely the best around here. =) Dont' forget to eat the napa that's cooked with the xiao long bao. They're actually not bad!

Question of the day was... how do they keep the soup inside??? Someone said they inject it and another said they put the soup in there frozen. Any takers? HAHA. 

Things we ordered:
- Pork Xiao Long Bao. BEST choice. Best to order a couple of rounds ahead of time since it takes a little while to make. 
- Crab Xiao Long Bao. It's OK. Pork is better. But good to give it a try.
- Cold Braised Sliced Beef - Not bad here. 
- Cold Jelly Fish - Just okay as well. 


For next time: I'd just go for the pork xiao long bao.

Great to come with a group when in Chinatown. They do communal seating, so you can buy a few dishes to share with your group. The soup dumplings are my favorite part. They get people in and out of there fast, so there typically isn't a very long wait.

Favorite soup dumplings hands down. I've tried a lot "hype" soup dumpling places and this beats them all. I don't even like soup dumplings that much and I love this place. I always get the pork and crab dumplings. The place is usually packed so to get in and out, it's best to know your order beforehand. The scallion pancake is also very good.
Wow, everything was delicious! Highly recommend the soup dumplings and, well, everything!
Man, this place was gooooooood. Soup dumplings on point. This place was packed but totally worth the wait. Tried both the pork and crab xiao long bao as well as trying a few noodle dishes. So good!

One of my greatest weaknesses: dumplings. Specifically, soup dumplings. I had my first soup dumpling in Los Angeles at Din Tai Fung, an equally famous establishment on the West coast. Ever since then, I have not been able to shake my craving for the little balls of dough and broth! Will C. and I decided to check out Joe's Shanghai around 2:30pm, thinking that the wait wouldn't be too bad. We were so, so, so wrong. If you're thinking about dining at Joe's Shanghai, just be prepared to wait no matter what time of day it is. There are a couple of spots to grab some bubble tea nearby, which is a great way to keep your mouth/stomach occupied while you endure the painstakingly long wait.  

Once inside, you'll notice that about 90% of the seating is communal. You will be sitting next to strangers and it is quite cramped, but keep your eye on the prize. You're there for the soup dumplings! I couldn't help but lol when I opened the menu because it looks like they crudely circled the pork and crab soup dumplings in ballpoint pen to indicate the dish's popularity. The first thing a waiter will ask you the moment you sit down is if you want to start with some dumplings. Your answer should be yes and you should be making multiple orders of the stuff. Between the two of us, Will C. and I ordered three orders of soup dumplings (2 pork, 1 crab). Each order comes with 8 dumplings, so you do the math. Between the pork and the crab dumplings, I preferred the pork dumplings as they were richer and the soup was denser in flavor. That being said, after my fourth or fifth pork dumpling, I felt like the soup was a little too rich and greasy for my taste, but this does not take away from the fact that Joe's has some great dumplings that live up to the hype. 

Getting good service here is nearly impossible. Because the restaurant is so packed (when I say packed, I mean borderline crazy), you gotta be a little aggressive to catch the attention of a waiter. So yes, dining at Joe's Shanghai requires a lot of patience, but patience yields favorable results...which in this case comes in the form of a piping hot, adorably shaped dumpling.

The food was delicious.  5 stars for that, but it was a little pricy, and the seating is pretty bad. We were at a round table that was cut a quarter of the way to fit more people, and even then my elbows were rubbing against my  girlfriend. If you're a party of two expect for the waiter to sit someone at your table half way through your meal. That was a little awkward but understandable . The dumplings are flavorful, taste fresh and plump.

Great place for a quick bite to eat. We were seated right away even though it's busy all of the time. We always get the crab soup dumplings. The location in queens definitely makes better dumplings though.

After a long bus ride to NY, we were pretty hungry.  I was a little confused at first because when I read soup dumplings in other reviews I imagined a bowl of soup with dumplings in it.  Hah.  The reality was much better - soup INSIDE of the dumpling. Yumm.

Service was quick.  We walked in and were seated right away at a table with others.  The waiter asked us if we wanted the dumplings and we asked for the crab meat.  We also ordered the scallion pancake.  Total came to around $13 including tip.

Ordered some crab with pork meat dumplings omgddd so delicious. When u take a bite the soup and all the flavor bursts into your mouth. I must say this is something new, but would definitely eat again. Second entree was fried porkchop also delicious. It was very crunchy. Young chow fried rice was great also. Overall this is my favorite Chinese food in nyc

Pork dumplings over the crab dumplings. They are still both great and steaming hot. 

Din Tai Fung is still a contender but this place is authentic and you can't beat the prices. 

It would be nice to have more ginger, make sure to ask for more!

Soup dumplings are always tasty!! I like the ones with crab a little bit more. Today we tried steamed Chilean seabass.... it was fantastic!! Really really good..... highly recommened! 
Sadly We got one dumpling with not properly cooked.... we asked the server but they said it s just flavor :/ (I mean we knew it s flavor but it's uncooked!).... so that s the reason for 4 not 5 stars this time.

Ordered in-person take-out from Joe's and got the Shanghai Noodle Soup with Flat Noodles. This wasn't as good as the soup dumplings or stir fried noodles, but they were still decent (could have been more flavorful and less greasy). 

When I went, Joe's didn't have any sit-down dining options, though there were two tables outside the restaurant people could sit at. It's also cash only.

We had crab and pork meat soup dumpling ($7.95 per basket) and a fried pork chop with sweet plum sauce and a side of steamed rice ($12.95) Both dish were good and decent price. There was a 8.875% tax and 15% service charge for the bill. They take cash only too!!

One of our stops during a dumpling tour with Sarah B. Seating for two was promptly given. There was a line out the door but I'm guessing they have larger parties. It's not my first time here but I like taking first timers to give it a try. The dumplings were tasty as usual. I still find it too thin and they often rip before making it to your taste buds. We tried a new dish since there's a one dish per person minimum. The pork fried rice cakes were delicious. It's my second favorite dish here now. 

Time to go back to Shanghai Cafe =]

Believe the hype people!! It's one of the best authentic Chinese food I've had from Boston, California, Philadelphia and New York. We went a little before prime time and still had to wait about 30 minutes. Once seated- they'll fill up a round table with strangers- they take your order and food comes out in a reasonable amount of time. 

- Pork Xiao long bao: excellent, juicy and the skin is perfect. 
- Hot & Sour soup: good, traditional taste like other Chinese restaurants. Chunkier mushrooms. 
- Stir fry flat noodles: saucy, greasy and great flavor. 
- Yang Chow Fried rice: this was my absolute favorite! The flavor was delicious, one of the best I've had! 
- Crispy pork chop: good, had a slight curry flavor, I'm assuming for the nice golden color. 

They only accept CASH and 15% gratuity is already incorporated in the bill- although I left extra for the great service. We will definitely be back when in NYC.

This was my first time having authentic Xiao Long Baos (soup dumplings), and it was an absolute delight.

I wholeheartedly suggest giving their soup dumplings a try, as they steal the spotlight at this restaurant.

Our table opted for both the pork and crab soup dumplings; while most of us favored the pork, I found both equally enjoyable. The crab soup dumpling packs a strong crab flavor punch, which might be a bit intense for some palates.

Service was just okay - the place was packed and chaotic. Definitely not the spot for a peaceful dinner!

I have to admit, Joe's Shanghai was simply excellent. They are much cheaper than the competition. Every single menu item that we ordered was extra fresh and tasty. The staff was really helpful and service is very good. Yum!
Fantastic soup dumplings, good prices, and crazy busy atmosphere. If you have time (usually long wait times), and are looking for a fun and tasty experience Joe's Shanghai is the place to be!

So I've been to Joe's Shanghai at least 4 times now. I love their soup dumplings! I never had any when I was China, or I don't remember, so I can't really compare. But still, they're really good! I only like the pork and crab ones though. My boyfriend and I ordered both and we ate the one with crab first, and then the ones with only pork. The ones with only pork tasted good, but I kind of felt like it's missing something. So if you want to try both, eat the one with only pork first!
Other dishes are ok, but not too impressive. I tried beef with scallion, one of the soup noodles, and some other dishes. But now we just order enough soup dumplings (usually two orders) to fill us up and nothing else!

Oh and this place is ALWAYS crowded. So if you go during lunch or dinner time, they'll probably make you share a table with other people. You can always hear some pretty interesting conversations...

Bring on the soup dumplings!!

I still cannot believe I've only recently been introduced to soup dumplings!  And...months later, I still cannot get enough.  There's something special about eating a piece of dough with meat and soup exploding in your mouth.  If that isn't "magic" (in food at least), then I don't know what magic is.

Asian Shanghai Manor (as my first place of soup dumplings) will always have a special place in my heart...but I was really excited to finally try Joe's Shanghai after hearing so many raving things about it.  The soup dumplings were amazing here!  They actually do taste better than those at Asian Shanghai's, and service is extremely fast here.  The scallion pancakes are great as well, but Asian Shanghai's is much chewier.  We also ordered a stir fried noodle seafood dish.  It was a little too dry and crunchy for my taste, so I would recommend to go with a lo mein or noodle soup instead.

This place is crowded, so make sure your party's ok with waiting for a while.  Also, you will most likely not get a table of your own, but it's also kind of neat to share a table with a party (or two) with strangers.  The people I sat with were extremely friendly and tourists, and they were just as excited to eat there as I was.

Definitely a must-try at least once when you're in Chinatown!  But, otherwise...let me stick with my bias of Asian Shanghai.

Secret. I think that Ginger place down the block is the same restaurant. Their soup dumpling tasted the same and line is like 10 times shorter.

I am wondering what I can say so that It's not the same as everyone told you about this place. 1. long ass line every day any day. 2. order soup dumpling 3. share table is common 4. order more dumpling to go 

I started coming here during college and it never stopped. I tried other places and there are second best dumpling and THIS IS THE BEST no doubt. however, if you can justify waiting in the cold for a warm dumpling, do so. There are other place to try like a bit over to East broadway for some authentic chinese dumpling and down the shanghai fried bum is good too. 

Anyway if your asian friend in this case most likely chinese bring you here, just say sure and go ahead with it. Never doubt. If you are hungry, it's not a good idea to go here cuz you might eat someone before eating anything. good luck.

I can sit here and give an account of all the dishes I ate here or I can just tell you why you're really here. The food isn't superb. It's safe. It's one of the more recently and intricately decorated restaurants in Chinatown that you would hope that other spots would follow suit because we all want a nice and shiny Chinatown. 

This restaurant is a great choice for both locals AND tourists alike. It's where when the Asian guy starts dating a white girl, to bring her to to ease in the hyper niche stuff. It's where all the mid-west tourist families that want to sample soup dumplings for the first time and not have their ungrateful bratty kids not scream for CHICKEN NUGGEEEETS. And when they do, you can order them the General Tso's chicken and wonder if you really love them and then come to the conclusion that you do, regardless of how uncultured they are.

I think the portions are small for the price and I think they can get away with it because where else are you going to go for this level of ethnic standardization in Chinatown?... HUH? The soup dumplings are unfortunately OK. This is heartbreaking news as this is what blew up the restaurant. I think it's because they have to constantly crank them out. Victims of their own success?

I'd like to further add that don't get the pan fried noodles. It's my favorite dish to get at Cantonese restaurants but they just do it so differently that I wouldn't want that to be the impression to you (yes you, the white girl who just started dating that handsome Asian guy).

And I'd come here again! Because I forgot to mention, it's great for groups. Tony the Tiger would approve. Asians call it "Family Style" but in the business industry they call it "Tourism", as they lick their lips. Come to think of it, I noticed they didn't have the spinning table wheel that's usually meant to help share. Is Family Style dying?

Everytime I'm in NY, I always make a beeline for Joe's Shanghai for their crab and pork dumplings!!!  They are the BEST I've ever had and I have yet to find another restaurant that does this, can't even find it in San Francisco.  You notice that everyone that goes there ALWAYS orders this house specialty, it would be shameful not to order it!  I enjoy the other items on their menu but my focus is always on the dumplings.  The service is not too bad for such a crowded place (the wait is worth it!) and they get you in and out quickly!

We came on a Sunday night for dinner and we ended up having to wait around 30 minutes before getting a table which is not bad. This place is pretty efficient in what they do so they get patrons in and out pretty quickly so the next group can get on in. And no seat was empty -- they would seat couples at a large table with a family if two seats were available at the table! AWKWARD! But anyway, the soup dumplings are freakin' huge and freakin' delicious!! We ordered the crab & pork -- each was full of delicious liquid!! Just amazing!! We also ordered a plate of the Shanghai noodles -- so greasy but so so so good!! This seriously was an awesome meal for 2 at only $20 total. You can't beat that!

Great food long wait once you're in your golden.  food is really good it would be nice to know upfront more of a wait time and that it is a cash only environment but overall great place hard to get to but worth the wait

We made Joe's Shanghai our last meal in NYC. 45 mins wait for a party of 4 on a late Sunday night = enough time to stroll through Chinatown and into Little Italy for quick sightseeing and to work up our appetites. 

I love the suspense and seriousness from everybody waiting outside. Whenever somebody gets called in for a precious seat, they can't help  grinning and rejoicing for the food they're one step closer to. Once inside, I adore the camaraderie feeling of the restaurant by sharing a round table with strangers. Everybody had a smiling face happy to be feasting on some good eats.


green onion pancake/cong you bing/ - the dish I always and must order when I'm at a new restaurant. One of THE best cong you bing I've ever had. All of my friends agreed as well. I love how the pancake wasn't too oily yet crispy to the nth degree. 

shanghai dumpling/xiao long bao/ - juicyjuicyjuicy! the soup inside the XLB is flavorful and the filling melts in your mouth. 

We also ordered noodles and a veggie dish which both were on par as well.


A quick note on the service: I was sitting facing the AC vent. I applaud the server who noticed I put on my jacket during my meal. Even though I wasn't that bothered by the AC vent, the server without anybody asking took the initiative to adjust the AC vent so air will flow in another direction.

I hope Joe's will be just as great the next time I visit New York.

DERMAGERD Soup Dumplings!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

On a serious note, if TSA wouldn't get mad at me for purchasing a suitcase, filling it with these soup dumplings, and bringing them back to California with me, I totally would have done it.

Probably the best Chinese food I have EVER had.  Highly recommend.  

If it isn't obvious, get the soup dumplings.

Very busy place. Be advised if ur party doesn't fill the table they will sit strangers with u lol. It was very interesting. Know what u want b/c it's a fast process. Waiter wasn't very patient, but it wasn't a major issue for me. Dumpling appetizer thingy was good and this was the best fried rice I've had. Their ginger dip was bomb!!! I would recommend the place. BE ADVISED CASH ONLY!!!

We have been coming to Joe's since the 90s when they were originally located on Pell Street in Chinatown. There is one in Midtown and one in Flushing, New York (Queens). This current one is located at 46 Bowery. The last time we were here was in 2018 and the location on Pell Street was still open.

This is our "go to" spot in Chinatown for when we visit. We went with the crab and pork soup dumplings, Shanghai flat noodles and the roasted pork with vegetables. All were good dishes and the quality and taste were the same. The food here is consistently good and the service was quick. 

The new spot has a different layout and is brighter and cleaner than the last place. Gone mostly are the large round tables. They had a few in the rear of the dining room. The last place had them as the primary seating for patrons. The complementary tea is also not offered any longer. 

Overall Joe's is a nice spot in Chinatown. It is a tourist trap of sorts and the prices have definitely gone up! It's cash only and there is an ATM in front by the door.
The dumplings are to die for!!!! Beware the %15 service charge. Should I have tipped on top of the service charge? I don't know, but we did end up doing so.

Love  coming here to this place!! Been here several times with friends and family. I mostly come for the soup-filled dumplings!!! But the rest of the food here is good too. It's a no-fail favorite, as well as a must have per visit to NYC.
Bigger, newer, cleaner, and certainly more modern and comfortable... Joe's is back in a huge way on the Bowery!
Long waits but worth it for the soup dumplings. Lots of good dishes on the menu. Good drinks. Good service once you get a table. Reasonable prices.

I don't care if it's not as authentic as some other places in Chinatown.  It's jaw-droppingly delicious. It's hot. It's spicy. It's served with rice.  The green beans are sauteed with bits of pickled mustard and pork.  The soup dumplings are just right.  And that's enough for 5 stars from me.

Still got it! 

After missing coming here last time due to the new location, I finally made it on this trip.

Soup dumplings taste as good as ever, juicy. I tried the Guota tofu (a braised tofu dish with spinach this
time) and it's great too!

The skin is not the thinnest, but the flavor and gelatinous soup can't be beat. Maybe it's the fond memories I have of coming here with my grandma as a child. 

Will be back again soon!

We came upon this place on a whim. We had about 48 hours in New York and one of the locals recommended this place to us for good dumplings. There is usually a line but we (party of 2) were seated in about 30 minutes. The bustling atmosphere and community style seating gives you the full NY experience. We got two orders of dumplings- pork and crab soup dumplings and fried pork dumplings. The food came out hot and fast! I really enjoyed the soup dumplings, the filling is juicy and quite flavorful. Would recommend ducking in here for a taste!

I first ate at Joe's Shanghai (at their OG location) several years ago and recall the xiaolongbao here being just all right. I recently dined at their new location and, I don't know if it was the fact that their new interior decor is just so much better and put me in a more generous mood or if they changed chefs, but the food was fantastic! I had the pork XLB (if you order just one thing, this should be it), which were flavorful, plenty juicy and not overly oily. In my ranking of New York City soup dumplings, the XLBs here might not be #1 but definitely rank within the top 3. We also ordered the vegetable lo mein, which were also very good and much better than I expected. It's also not super greasy, but just really well cooked with great flavors. It's a great option for vegetarians here.
Best soup dumplings in the city. Get about one or two full orders of the pork soup dumplings per person and that's it. Monthly tradition spot for me and my friends

One sentence - This place is a NYC staple. 
Enough said.

Literally with 4 friends, we scarfed down 8 orders of soup dumplings of all different kinds of variety (crab and pork). Personally, my favorite is pork. They do have a few other dishes you can try, but I come for the soup dumplings.

Tip: Go to the flushing location, you won't be waiting in line to get a table.
The XLB was ok.  The pancakes were even better.  All the other stuff was pretty greasy.  Comparing it to Din Tai Fung and some good San Francisco dumpling places, they are all the same level for XLB.

This place lives up to the hype.  Always busy, they give you a number and seat you at a large round table with others.  Soup dumplings are spectacular, their reputation is deserved.  If you haven't eaten them before, ask your waiter to show you how--the soup inside is hot! Mapo tofu was also prepared nicely, and they spice it to your request.  When you are seated there will be a pot of hot tea waiting for you--I find that to be a nice touch.  Don't forget--cash only.
TASTY soup dumplings!! Their xlb is on the thicker/bigger side but so so delicious!! We got takeout but the restaurant looks super cute inside and always bustling!
The pork soup dumplings were off the hook! The long line and wait was definitely worth it. I know authentic dim sum when I see it, this place is a hidden gem.

Soup dumplings were the best. It was the right amount of soup and meat. The crispy duck was tasty. The quail app was a little dry. There's already a 15% gratuity added no matter what. Don't over tip if you don't want to.

Good service, and really good food for the price you pay. We ordered fresh bacon w/ preserved veggies (very nom), clams w/ blackbean sauce (nom nom too), string beans, snow pea leaves, and pan fried noodles (not so nom kinda greasy actually). Considering it's my first time in NYC, it was really good Chinese food and we were very satisfied with our meal..... also pork dumplings were delish
Best Chinese food in NYC if you don't mind waiting and sitting with randos. Delicious food, efficient staff in basic surroundings.

Since there's 2500+ reviews on this place already, I'll make this quick and easy:

Quick tips: Cash only. Tourist Spot. Hole in the Wall. Well-priced. 

Food tips: 
-Pork soup dumplings are great. 
- Crab and pork soup dumplings are interesting. 
- Green beans with pork are delicious but pricey $9.95
-Stir-fried noodles taste...americanized.

Long story short: pork soup dumplings

I love this place! It's one of top go to Shanghai places to eat at in Chinatown.

I would always come here at early to make sure I get a table. There's always a line waiting for the restaurant to open at 11, so I would come here early in the afternoon. Once you sit down, the waiters usually ask if you would like an order of soup dumplings. IT'S A MUST! They're really delicious and hot. 

Also order scallion pancakes if you come here early enough. There was this one time I went around 4 in the afternoon, and the scallion pancakes weren't as crispy as the time I last ordered them. I like the Kau Fu there also. I'm not sure if that's what it's called in english, but it's a cold side dish fish with a special Shanghai sauce. The rest of the food on the menu is mediocre. 

The service is alright. They would often hand us the bill, hurrying my table to leave when there isn't a long line waiting outside.

Overall, a solid Chinese XLB restaurant that caters to their Western customers. The classic XLB was filled with delicious soup broth, skin slightly thicker than I'd like but overall very good. 

We also ordered the scallion pancake which has a lovely buttery and flakey texture, sesame chicken which was over breaded and the Shanghai stir fried noodles (saltier than I'd like). I went with none-Asian friends and they absolutely loved every item we ordered and could not stop raving about the food. I'm happy they enjoyed the meal but I'd be a bit more selective about certain items if I was dining with my mom/family members lol 

All in all, a great dining experience but not as outstanding as the hype suggests.

Don't go here for dinner, it's always way crowded. Late lunch might be a better bet, you'll be able to relax, drink some tea, and enjoy your 'xiao long bao' in peace. 

So unlike the Peking Duck in Chinatown, the xiao long bao (or soup dumplings) are just as good as they are in China (Shanghai), no really. The traditional buns are typically made with crab and pork, but for some reason I prefer the plain pork. And yes, remember that the liquid inside is burning hot! 

It's not actually 'soup' but melted 'meat jelly' so it technically can be hotter than boiling water. 

Lots of other stuff here is pretty decent as well, but hey 8 dumplings (one steamer basket) makes a pretty good lunch right?

Oh Wow! This place was awesome, usually not a big fan of Chinatown NYC but this place is worth coming back! Highly recommend the Soup Dumplings! Service was quick and portion was  great - taste at the right priced!
However if you come at a wrong time you might have to wait outside, so come early!

I've been away from the ny food scene for so long, any Chinese restaurant in Chinatown tastes good. 

Joe's Ginger is not Joe's Shanghai. I got confused bc how many joe soup dumplings can there be? My friend who lives here told me that they are owned by the same owner... Joe? 

Do not go on a romantic date here. Not unless if you enjoy the company of a stranger third wheel at your table. Yes, I saw this happen. They split tables with labeled tags. There is an automatic 15% tip then, tax on top of the bill+ tip. 

Soup dumplings here has always been the best I've ever had, I haven't been to too many, but they seem to have all the right components: just thick enough skin, lots of soup, a nice flavorful meatball filling in the middle. 
Scallion pancakes are awesome too: it's very crispy with flakey layers served with a sweet soy sauce. Their fried rice reminds me something my grandma would make. They use simple ingredients and maybe msg to transform each dish into something to crave for.

The staff is usually brusque and trying to get you in and out as quickly as possible. 

They still charge you 15% automatically for those unpredictable levels of service.

Usually, you have to sit with strangers who are annoying and/or clueless. 

The radio is often tuned to a station that the military could very possibly use to defy the Geneva Conventions and break prisoners of war.

Occasionally the dishes are inconsistently spicy and/or salty making the rating of certain favorites shift from perfect to passable. 

But in general, the majority of the food is so good that you'll overlook all of these nuisances and be hastily shuffled out of the restaurant in a euphoric stupor.

And yes, the soup dumplings are good.
Still love this place. Fun atmosphere. Shared tables. Delicious soup dumplings, crispy beef, sesame chicken and rice. We travel from Chicago to eat here! Marvin our waiter was fabulous

The dishes are shareable and delicious!  We also JD the steamed pork dumplings and they were fantastic.  This restaurant always has a wait but not for long. And it is worth the wait!  If you are in NYC, this is a restaurant you MUST visit!  Fantastic!

Pork.Dumplings. 

Soup. Fried. I love them both equally.

If only I could eat dumplings every day without any repercussions.

A friend and I went here after drinks nearby. We had 15 mins to close and they sat us down although I'm sure they wanted to turn us away.

Food was great. No lines since we got there so late. Typical Chinatown Chinese restaurant vibe that is cash only. Service was ehh but I don't blame them. We were the assholes that came in right before close.

I will be back. #dumplingsforever

The BEST soup dumplings ever! 

Make sure that's the first thing you try when order or dine there!

The pork and crab dumplings were vvery good. The skin was more chewy that the dumpligs at Shanghai Cafe and it was great that you taste real crabs, not artificial.
We had the Shanghai fried noodles which at first glance looked like it was not cooked well because the noodles were all stuck together. Then the wsiter stsrted cutting it and serving. I guess it was ment to stick together. It turned out quite good. The noodles were actually nice and chewy.
I don't know if I would come here often, because there's usually a long line and long wait to get in.

I came here with my sister for lunch when it was pretty crowded, so we got sat down at a table with other people. It was a round table and they were able to fit three parties at the table. It wasn't too awkward though since the table is relatively big and everyone minded their own business. 

We ordered the crab xiao long bao and seafood pan fried noodles. The soup dumplings were very flavorful, and they definitely had a great mixture of the pork and crab in the dumplings. The pan fried noodles were delicious as well. I thoroughly enjoyed the perfectly crisped noodles with the savory sauce and lots of seafood! Joe's is a great place in Chinatown worth checking out!

Down the alley known as Pell Street in Chinatown is Joe's Shanghai. Out of the three that exist in the city, this is the best of them all. A tourist trap - absolutely, but I have yet to taste a better pork soup dumpling in Manhattan. Is it really worth the 45 minute wait during dinner time, probably not since I think the soup dumplings here are just marginally better than some other Shanghai-nese restaurants such as Moon House, New Green Bo or Shanghai Cafe which have shorter waits.

Is it worth the hype? Yes. 
Is it worth waiting in the cold for a table? Yes, the experience is worth it. 
Is it different because it is not at the old place? Let's just say you feel intimate with your fellow diners. 

We came for the dim sum. Stayed for the experience and the tea. 

If you are NY, swing by and enjoy the dim sum. Also, get a snack because the wait is part of the experience. 

This is one where I forgot the pictures.

YUM!  

here's what to order when you first sit down.  depending on how many people you have...my friend and i usually get an order right when we sit down cuz it takes a while for them to make.  we only get an order per 2 people.  then when we're almost done with order another one, this way they are always HOT.  :)

~crab and pork soup dumpling (preferred)
~pork soup dumplings (are also good)
~shanghai noodles
~stir fried rice cake
~vegetarian duck (which is tofu wrapped black mushrooms, its a cold dish)
~the scallion pancake is decent there too

If you're coming to Joe's Shanghai, prepare to wait at least an hour before you get seated. I went with a group of five during the evening, and although the wait was long, the food was definitely worth the wait.

The pork xiao long bao is a must-try! The pork dumping was more flavorful than the shrimp. Each batch has eight pieces, all decently large. The fried calamari is the best I've ever had; lightly fried but very flavorful and has a slight kick from the peppers. The beef and broccoli is honestly very flavorful and pairs perfectly with rice. The ja jiang mien was okay; I wouldn't get it again. The sauce was much sweeter and had a strong peanut flavor; it tasted like spring roll peanut sauce.

Overall, the food is delicious and comes out of the kitchen pretty fast. I would definitely come back and try more dishes. Highly recommend.

Pork soup buns or dumplings were pretty good. That was what everyone was basically getting. That's what they're known for apparently. 

There was no wait but spaces are small so they sat us down with random people around a table. This is common in New York? Still something to get used to. 

We ordered the scallion pancakes and the turnip cakes. Liked the scallion more. 

We had two orders of the dumplings. They were soupy and delicious. 

They have pics of famous people on their wall that's fun to look at.
Good authentic Chinese food. You may have to share a table with strangers but that is part of the charm!

We ventured into Chinatown and headed to Joes after a friend recommended.  The dumplings were absolutely amazing.  We did share a table but it was part of the experience and we totally didn't mind.  It was busy but very short wait.  Wish I could take some home with me!  I'm sure I won't be able to find anything like that at home!  Must try.

This place was yummy for sure. They were filming a movie on the street and so we didn't have to wait as long. The service was very efficient and I appreciated that. The pork soup dumplings were awesome. We also ordered the general tsos chicken and the shrimp fried rice. Great food for the price!!

i love this place. it was surprisingly tasty and very afforadble. my group of 6 had 8 dishes for about 10$ a person. from the soup dumplings to the wonton soup to the other stuff haha. its nice to know all chinese places are basically set up the same. family style plating with plenty of seating. a rarity in ny. 

this place was quite deep into china town so be careful of shady people but the great part is you get to experience the town. 

def would come here again.

Quite simply, this is where to go for great chinese.  Why do I say , "quite simply"?  Any yelper can throw away any notion of ambiance or a dimly lit romantic dinner.  This is the real Chinatown.  Lights up, no manners, and an 'get in and get out' attitude-yet the food makes up for any perceived rudeness.

There will be a line.  Go up and tell the door lady how many are in your party.  She'll give you a number, and despite the long line, they are incredibly fast.  You will be taken to a large table to eat with strangers unless you have a large party.  If there is one chair available at your table?  It will inevitably be filled by a stranger, but it was still a pleasant arrangement.

When seated, expect to be yelled "DUMPLINGS?!?!" almost immediately.  It is one of their most popular items, and why many travel to eat there.  The crab/pork dumplings were incredible.  In the menu they have their popular items already outlined.  We ordered standard items (general tso's chicken and calamari with black bean), and were amazed by the freshness and overall quality of ingredients.

When dinner is done, they bring free oranges for dessert, and automatically put 15% tip on your bill.  Remember... CASH ONLY!

I'd definitely go back for the food and fast pace that makes this one of the best in Chinatown.

Came here just for the soup dumplings!

Got an order of the regular and the crab xlb. The xlb here were so huge! And were full of soup

They were good, but not amazing. Pretty average compared to LA

The BEST dumplings in NYC. 


No reservations, walk in and cash only.
Also they might sit you at a table with parties.

I was a fan of the whole experience...as some other reviewers point out, this place is a little divey, you sit with strangers, and the waiters are pushy. BUT the dumplings are pretty tasty, the food comes out fast and the price is good. Dining here made me feel like i was on an episode of Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations. I'll definitely stop in on my next visit to NYC to try the crab,pork dumplings.

Holy dumplings, Batman! A friend suggested we celebrate the lunar new year here for lunch so off we went. Even with the holiday - the streets were thick with confetti - we only waited about 20 minutes to sit down. Not bad.

Together we ordered four dishes: the shredded pork and salted vegetable noodle soup (3 stars), the Shanghai fried flat noodle (4 stars), the pork dumplings (5 stars), and the crab/pork dumplings (5 stars). The dumplings were easily the best; we ate so many and left feeling so full, we felt like dumplings ourselves. 

Be warned: you'll be sharing a table with strangers. But you're a New Yorker, and you're okay with that, right? No? Then move to Kansas; I hear there's lots o' space out there.
I still think Din Tai Fung has the best soup dumplings but this place comes in close behind

WHY am I still seeing groups of tourists waiting 30 minutes to sit down at Joe's just to order some Kung Pao Chicken? I usually refrain from reviewing overly hyped places, but seriously! Enough is enough!

SOO...Okay tourists. This one is for you. Yes you. Read this review before you make the silly mistake of eating General Tso's Chicken when you should be eating....

Pork and Crab Soup Dumplings: Order this as soon as you sit down. It takes awhile to steam up. There are 8 in an order, I imagine the average person can pack away at least 4, so base your order off of this metric.

These are not normal dumplings. DO NOT just stab it with your fork and shove into mouth. YES I HAVE SEEN THIS. AND IT MAKES MY HEART ACHE. I realize that most cultured people know how to eat soup dumplings, but I feel the need to explain here. Maybe someone else has explained but it is buried among the 1000 reviews. 

They are called soup dumplings because they have HOT SOUP INSIDE! 

1. Put some of the soy sauce-vinegar-ginger  (in the small dish they set in front of you) in the spoon. The vinegar cuts the grease of the soup and adds a nice tang to your palette. 

2. Use your chopsticks (or tongs if you don't have chopstick mastery) and very gently pick up the dumpling from the top (where they twisted the dough together to close the dumpling). Place the dumpling on top of your spoon.

3. VERY GINGERLY bite a SMALL HOLE in the side of the soup dumpling and IMMEDIATELY start to slowly suck the soup from the dumpling. Careful it is VERY HOT.

4. Once you have gotten most of the soup. Go ahead and eat the rest of the dumpling.

What else do I recommend ordering? Well, you can't go wrong with the scallion pancake (dip in the sauce they bring you, add some hot chili oil). Also, I like the Shanghai Fried Flat Noodle. They use a chewy, almost Udon-noodle like noodle and stir fry it with pork and Chinese bokchoy. Authentic version of lo mein.

I also like the fried rice cake. If you've ever had Korean food, you've probably had rice cake (Duk, or in dukboki). They take this and stir fry with veggies and/or meat. So like lo mein with rice cake.

Okay. Now that I've written this lengthy review, I won't be seeing any more SQUIRTING of soup wasted onto your plate, and blah looking Americanized Chinese food, right?? I hope so!

Crab meat dumplings and scallion pancakes are my top choices in this restaurant. Been here plenty of time, those 2 items were a must order every time I go here. Awesome food. Crowded atmosphere. If you are a party of 4 or less, the chances of you having to share tables is very high. If you don't mind that, then this place is a must visit!

The pork and crab soup dumplings are amazingly delicious.  The sauce isn't really needed since there's so much flavor in the dumplings.
I would give this place 5 stars, but there was open seating.  You would share a big round table with other customers.  The waiters were pushing us to order right when we sat down.  We didn't get to look at the menu yet, but luckily the waiter was nice because we were able to speak chinese.

*edit* On my second visit back to NY, I had to come for more delicious dumplings.  Ordered green onion pancakes again, pork & crab dumplings and rice cake with chicken.  I remembered the pork dumplings tasting much better last time, but it was still good.  My favorite is still the CRAB DUMPLINGS! FULL OF FLAVOR!
