The wait was about 1 1/2 hours. Once they called our number, we felt as if we won the lottery. The food is great and not too expensive. Overall a good experience despite the long wait for a table.

PROS:
-crab Xiao long bao

CONS:
- You must have everyone in your party present in order to get seated. I am little annoyed at this. Even if the majority came you can't be seated until everyone is there. Such a strict rule too. See my grandparents are old so they take a longer time to walk to get there so they wouldn't seat us until everyone is there. By the time my grandparents came, the table was gone. 
- Also be prepared to share tables with other people if your party is small.

The restaurant is a very busy one, with a size being small as well. So keep in mind that you'll be waiting. They have small tables and also large tables. We had a party of 8 so it was quite a while. They seat people as soon as a party leaves but it varies by size, not by the order you placed your name. We waited for a little over an hour and got seated at a large table but it was community style. The other half of the table was with strangers but I personally liked it because food brings all types of people together. *truth* you obv don't have to talk to them if you don't want to. 

What's great about eating at an Asian restaurant is that there is a dish for everyone. So, I am pescatarian, so I eat seafood but not any traditional meats like red and chicken. So I ordered a shrimp noodles dish. There was broccoli and other vegetables but the noodles come hard. And you have to mix the shrimp and veggies together with the sauce to make the noodles not as hard. But it was honestly one of the better dishes, even the meat eaters agreed. I didn't get to try other Chinese restaurants in the area because we didn't have a whole lot of time in New York, but I would def recommend this spot!
The food is super good!  The shanghai dumplings are so juicy and good.  Every time I come to NY, I have to stop by for dumplings!

While exploring the alleyways of Chinatown my girlfriend and I stumbled upon this place not knowing it was a popular attraction for amazing soup dumplings. We spent the morning walking around and worked up quite the appetite and we were drawn to this spot due to the long line right outside of the storefront. Being avid yelpers we decided to see what all the hype was about! we were not disappointed. We got the pork and crab soup dumplings as well as sesame chicken and WOW were we satisfied! The dumplings were so amazing and filled with flavor, it was exactly what we needed. We have never had a better order of sesame chicken anywhere else. The chicken was perfectly crispy and flavorful. I can definitely say we will be back on our next trip to NYC. THANK YOU!

Came here to try their ever so popular soup dumplings and now I'm wondering if there's any possible way I can get them shipped to me in Houston. These soup dumplings definitely live up to all the hype. They have the most delicious broth inside that just burst into your mouth when you take a bite.. it's dumpling heaven. 

Other than the crab and pork soup dumplings, we ordered the Shanghai noodles and scallion pancake. Both were delicious. The noddles were a little on the oiler side but oiler the tastier right ? There was also complimentary tea wish was perfect for the weather outside. At the end of the meal, they give you sliced oranges and a wet towel which is super nice. 

Something that I found funny is that once we sat down, our waiter came to us and asked "do you want soup dumplings ?" Instead of the typical, "what would you like to drink ?" It's like they know what everyone comes here for !! 

Tips for if you're wanting to have the amazing experience of Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings: don't go on the weekend if you're not willing to wait hours and BRING CASH.
The crab dumplings are good. It gets busy and crowded at lunch on a weekday. I ordered for takeout and didn't need to wait in line during lunch time.
Really great place! The food is very authentic and not too pricy. They actually check your vaccine cards before you dine in which I think it's a great idea! High recommend their soup dumplings!

What else can I say that hasn't been said already? Go for NYC's best soup dumplings!! 

Joe's is always packed. It doesn't matter if it's dinnertime during the week or lunch on Saturday afternoon: there will be a wait. Also be ready to be sit down family style with complete strangers at large round tables.  Only makes the experience better.  Service is pretty quick. The longest thing you would have to wait for is to sit down.  I've never had an issue with the servers; they've always been pretty quick. Just a reminder, they are CASH ONLY. Prices are pretty cheap. They also have an extensive menu with other Chinese items, but I tend to stick to the dumplings only. 

There are two types of soup dumplings: pork or crab. Personally, I can't decide which one is better so I get both. Each bamboo steamer comes with about 8 steaming dumplings. The broth is oh, so good and the meat is well seasoned. The dough is chewy enough, without it being too dense.  The flavor of the dumplings just pop in your mouth with each bite.  I guarantee these dumplings will hit the spot on a cold winter day. 

This is definitely a must try if you are in Chinatown.
For me the best soup dumplings  ever ever and soooo cheap. Place is only simple but you don't go here for that go for the soup dumplings then go further for some other Chinese if you are not full

I came here after watching a Fung Bros video on this place. I never had soup dumplings and always wanted to try it out. Apparently Joe's Shanghai is the best in the east side so I was really excited to go! 

The store was really easy to find in chinatown and when I went inside the restaurant, half of the seats were filled. We were placed in a round table with two other families and I was surprised at how famous this place is! There were pictures of I'm guessing the owner with other celebrities like Jonah Hill and Emma Stone!

When I saw the menu, it was like a typical Chinese restaurant menu with a variety of dishes like noodles, meats, and seafood. Of course we opted for the soup dumplings and I thought there would be a huge variety but there was only two! So there was a regular meat one and a meat with crab. We got both and the dumplings came in approx 10 mins, even though our waiter said it takes more than 20.

Pictures don't do it justice but holy these dumplings were ginormous! I mean they give you tongs to pick them up.

The soup in these dumplings were oh my god, heavenly! Be careful not to pop them and rip the skin! I loved the crab one because they put actual roe in it, giving it a really nice taste and texture.

Only downside is the customer service. I felt like they were pushing us out even though the restaurant still had empty seats.
Dumplings where amazing & service was fast. Will go back for sure when I'm in the city

I ate here while visiting New York for the first time and I have to say that their "Xiao Long Bao" without a doubt is way better than Din Tai Fung (in Arcadia). Not only were they moist but they are also bigger in size. 

It was a bit of a pain getting a table if your entire party is not present because they will not seat you until everyone is around (sounds familiar). Other than that our food came out in a reasonable amount of time considering they were busy on a Monday night. 

Definitely a must try for anyone visiting from out of town.
Soup dumplings, everything else is irrelevant, you don't go to a burger shop to other a hotdog then why come here for anything else

Yummy food. The soup dumplings were so good! However wish they had a bigger variety. We had the pork soup dumplings and the crab soup dumpling and both great!! The Singapore noodles were good as well. The sesame chicken was actually a favorite!

The service was meh. Very crowded and overwhelming. Not some place to come for a quiet dinner! Our glasses were very dirty but it seemed that was normal.

We had lunch but hubby wanted something shanghainese since we visited Shanghai last year, he missed their food.
We order the scallion pancakes, the soup dumplings (of course), and the fried dumplings. The crab meat soup dumpling had a good flavor to it, you can tell the crab meat was fresh and sweet. The fried dumplings are ok, not very special. The best was the scallion pancake! The dough was perfectly chewy, the pancakes were fried to perfection, soft inside and crispy outside! Love love love! 
The place was so busy, even on a Monday afternoon. We had to share a table with some strangers. Which was ok with me.

The best dumpling soup ever. I ordered the scallion pancakes and dumpling soup (8 piece per order). You won't be disappointed. It was heaven! Small restaurant and you share tables with others. The food comes out fast. Other dishes were good as well like the seafood fried rice cakes. By the way, don't expect any good service here... It's a Chinese restaurant! LOL

Soup dumplings, soup dumplings! Yeah I've never ordered anything else there, besides a few bowls of rice. Definitely get the pork soup dumplings. It gets a little crowded, and wait times depend... and you may also have to share your table with other patrons too, but just pretend they're not there.

Pork Soup Dumplings. Divine. 

A friend and I have been faithfully going here for dumplings (MUCH prefer the pork over the pork and crab combo) every two weeks for the past six years. It's sick but it's true.

On weeknights, if you arrive by 7pm, you don't have to wait. Since we've become regulars here the waitstaff has actually started being nice to us which is confusing and wonderful at the same time. No longer must we wait for water, no longer are we told, "NO" when we ask for that "um sauce, you won't tell us what it's called but it tastes kind of like..."

Going to Joe's is one of the reassuring rituals in my life. I even like sitting next to all the out of towners and giving them suggestions about what to do in NYC. Except for the one time our table got in a political argument, it's always been fun to sit family-style. Encouraging, even. It sort of makes me want to sing "We Are the World." And then tell the tourist next to me she's a wimp for getting shots before visiting India.

Get bubble tea afterwards at Green Tea Cafe to round out the evening.

The soup dumplings deserve their reputation. I could eat several of the steamer baskets myself. However, the noodles and fried rice my friends ordered were average.

Yes, there is a certain way to eat the dumplings. I made an ass out of myself but NOT b/c of lack of technique. My brain apparently does not understand the correlation of steam and hot. I bit into the dumpling and tried slurping out the soup. I didn't know it was going to be that damn hot (temperature wise). So, I ended up splattering the dumpling all over my plate. This was seconds before telling my friend "yes, I KNOW how to eat them". His look of disapproval was paid back by him burning the back of his throat as he swallowed the soup. I was told that swallowing vitamin E liquid quickly helps the pain. I withheld this information from him in case he went to Duane Reade for this remedy. Smugness should always be remembered.

How to do Joe's Shanghai:

Come during "off" hours.  I.E., not lunchtime or dinner time. 
Be prepared to share a table if you are not a party of five or more. 
Order "soup dumplings" or xiao long bao and a Tsingtao.  Don't order anything else, it's just mediocre.
Pour yourself some tea while you wait for your food.  The tea also washes down the oil. 
Eat and drink.  To eat xiao long bao, put one on your spoon and either have the top or side of the dumpling.  The soup should spill on your spoon and this will help cool it because scalding soup in your mouth sucks.  When cool enough go ahead and eat.  Enjoy your drinks. 
Pay in cash when done.  A service charge is already added so if you tip more, you're extremely generous. 
Restrooms are in the back of the restaurant and are very basic. 
Enjoy the rest of your day!

I assumed there was no point to life. 
Then there was Xiaolongbao, and Joes serves my favorite.
I don't really care if the soup dumplings are famous or not.. my aunt and uncle took me there and after a bit of crab soup dumplings, I'm thinking, "damn, why don't other places make this?!"

I've been here for a while and I always walk out satisfied. I go with my mom or dad during lunch time. It's more relaxed and less people, as opposed to dinner time. One round of crab-meat dumplings is enough for my dad and I. The soup is the best part of the meal, just be careful not to let it explode all over the place! Definitely take a visit for a decent sized meal and price.

If you're so hungry and your stomach is grinding itself, you might want to have a small snack before you come to this place to keep your sanity.  The wait is pretty long... 20-40 mins during lunch time.  I was dying when i went... especially hung over from the night before, it wasn't a fun wait.

Finally when it's our turn to sit down, the waiter led us to a small table facing the wall, and 2 people already sitting at the table.  I looked at the waiter, and he said, "sit here"...  my husband, being an american and never been to Asia, his jaw dropped...  

i guess they're doing it real asian style, squeezing everyone and their mother in and occupy every seat!  

Then, before we even got tea or water or menu... the waiter assumed that we're going to order the soup dumpling, he said, "pork soup dumpling ok?"  I was like... okay... sure I was there to eat the soup dumping, but can I sit down first before you take my order...

Sitting at a table with strangers has its perks, one of the girls has been there before and was very helpful on what we should order.  We tried both the pork soup dumpling and the pork and crab soup dumpling, I think the pork flavor over power the dumplings, can't really taste the crab in the 2nd one.  So next time I would just get the pork one.

We also got some typical chinese dishes, like stirfried rice cake, some chinese broccoli, you know, you gotta work your veggies in.  The green onion pancake is different then the ones I usually have, it's fantastic.  This was a carb filled lunch.

I always wondered what the soup dumpling fuzz is about - after trying it, I gotta say, this whole soup dumpling is a fad.  I grew up eating this dumpling, we called it Xiao Long Bao, it's always been juicy... so I guess I thought when they call it "soup dumpling", it's different then the ones I used to eat as a kid from the street vendor in Taiwan....  food was good here, but I guess I'm just a bit disappointed it's no different then the one I know, plus the wait, and I had to sit with the strangers, and the pushy waiter... I knocked it down to 4 stars.

If you don't mind the wait, then you'll love the xiaolongbao at yet another fantastic 4 star place.  I seem to be finding a lot on this trip.  You should stick with the XLB and the green onion pancake.  Both well worth the 30 minute wait.  Not too enamoured with the  noodle dishes and the fried rice cake was oily but quite tasty.

Those who don't appreciate a good XLB should just go somewhere else and maybe reduce the wait time (not likely with all the die hard fans and damned tourists I think) because this could be the best I've ever tasted.

The soup dumplings OMG. So good. You share tables which is a good way to get to know some random strangers. We also had the general tso's chicken. Big chunks of white meat chicken, fresh broccoli and awesome sauce. Hit the ATM bc this joint is cash only.

We came at a really good time - 12pm on Thursday = no wait! Instantly seated! The weird thing about these Chinese New York restaurants though is that all their tables fit all aka, if you're a party of 8 to 10, you'll have your own table. However, if you're 6 of smaller, be prepared to engage in communal tablesharing. 

These over word of mouth places also attracts ppl of all natures, including those who are not very familiar with Chinese food. As a party of two, we shared our table top with two women from New Jersey and a couple visiting from Alaska. In this one hour time frame we educated them about xiao long baos - what they are, how to eat them, how they're made; got the whole table to order the ong-choi and green onion pancakes. Only in America! 

Soup dumplings are divine. We split 8 for two people and combined with the other dishes, I had to be rolled out. Hot, steamy and SUPER fatty. 

The green onion pancakes were much thicker than I would have normally liked, but still good nonetheless. 

Ong-choi was my favorite...I had been craving the taste for days. There's something about this trio of foods that makes it super comforting.  

The moment we left the restaurant, a line was forming and we were glad to have missed it by a heartbeat. To each dumpling, his or her own. Enjoy!

Nice people, quick service, no frills, best pork soup dumplings I've ever had in my life! I've been coming here for years and it never disappoints. Try the shredded turnip cakes too. The shrimp fried rice, meh, though shame on me for ordering shrimp, aka mud puddle bugs, in Chinatown.

You dont come here for the atmosphere, the service, or the location... if you want cheap delicious soup dumplings then look no further.  For $6-7 for an order they are a great bargain in NYC.  Each order contains 8 dumplings.  We usually order Shanghai pan friend flat noodles and they are also excellent.  The noodles come after you finish your dumplings.  If can go with the flow and arent too uptight to wait outside and then get crammed into a very tight restaurant you will be in for a treat.

They serve beer but you are welcome to bring your own wine.  a 15% gratuity is added o your bill automatically.

I'm conflicted between 3 or 4 stars. I say... 3.5 and here's why:
Arrived at 130pm-145pm with a party of 3. The restaurant was at peak lunch hour on a week day. With no where to sit, we are told to wait outside. Fine. After a few minutes, we are called in. We follow the woman inside but she then turns around and there is NO table or space for us- umm...??? Awkward. 

Seating arrangements are interesting- you will most likely be eating a table full of strangers unless you are lucky to get your own table. 

After waiting for another 10mns, we are seated. We ordered pork and crabmeat dumplings and a side of bok choy. The food came out promptly. Our bill was under $37-38. We paid $45 only to find out the GRATUITY WAS ALREADY INCLUDED!!! UGGGH... they didn't even say anything to us... gee thanks. They definitely don't pride themselves in customer service here.

Stopped in at Joe's Shanghai for lunch with a coworker the other day and found this place to be pretty cool! We ended up ordering both types of the soup dumplings (which I have never had before) and found them to be really delicious and cheap. We were watching other foods come out of the kitchen and couldn't stop drooling over all the great looking food coming out. 

Overall, this is great spot, and the soup dumplings are perfect on a chilly day (we went when it was 90 degrees which I don't recommend). 

The only downside is that the tables are shared with small parties, and it is CASH only.

The food is very good and delicious! 

We got lucky and didnt have to wait in the midst of chaos. 

I've never loved soup dumplings like theirs! The sauce they used for the crispy noodles was superb! Not overly thickened with cornstarch or soy, but very well balanced. 

It's a small place, that's very busy for a reason. Dont expect amazing service like a gourmet restaurant. It is a family style place. I kinda felt like I was home. Haha

Come try the food here!

Joe's Shanghai have the best Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings) ever! My mom and I came here today to try it for our first time. We ordered the pork with crab meat Xiao Long Bao. One order comes with 8 pieces. It was delicious! We ordered for a second round and we loved it! 

I highly recommend all who craves and loves Xiao Long Bao to come here! Would totally come again!

Not going to lie when I first arrived here and was told the wait was going to be over an hour I was really upset. But once I sat down to eat I was blown away. I had the pork dumplings, Scallion pancake, and the pan fried noodles. 10/10 on all of those.  Food was great and once I was seated service was quick and efficient. I would deff go back

Delicious. The pork soup dumplings were really tasty, but my personal faves were the scallion pancake (OMG so perfectly crispy and salty) and the Shanghai fried flat noodles (great crunch from the cabbage, and the pork in it has a sort of smoky flavor). It's really efficient but sooo crowded. But def worth it.

It's funny, I can't even remember what movie I was watching yesterday, but one of the very first scenes, Joe's popped up on a driveby.  And mind you, the movie was filmed in the early 90's.  So, even back then, this place was prevalent.  Honestly, with how busy this place is, I am shocked there isn't more than 10-15K Yelp reviews.

With that being said, I went on a trip to NY a few months ago with my friends from the Bay.  I wanted to show them what was up with the food scene in NYC.  After gorging on all sorts of stuff, We managed to fit Joe's in on a Saturday night, before they closed.

This place sits in an alley, which, at first glance, it looks terrifying.  Don't worry, the locals just hang out on the street smoking weed (the young ones), and the older ones playing games and singing passing around a bottle of vodka.  With that being said, I didn't feel threatened.

While you wait (which, I would presume 90% of the time there is one), you get a raffle ticket- that is their queue system.  The place is small, so, your best bet is to hang out on the street and soak up the aromas of New Orleans-esque odors (aka sewage).  You may even catch a kitchen staff member or two just sitting outside chillin.  

They keep saying this place is cash only (they have an ATM, so do places down the street if you need one)- however, they may have upped their game.  Needless to say, the whole visit was confusing (and I was sober too), so, bring enough cash (or a loaded debit card) to be safe.  

There were 5 of us, and it looked like we shared a table.  I swear, if they could fit 8 at our table, they would.  With that being said, this place is very, intimate.  One of my buddies is even taller than me, and I was cramped- so I could only imagine how it felt for him.

I ordered the XLB via seafood and meat, along with the potstickers.  Also, had water and tea to drink (fyi, the tea seemed easier to get than the water...).  

Honestly, I wasn't too impressed with the seafood XLB, and it had an off yellow color, like bile- don't spill it on your clothes unless you want to look like a rabies bite victim.  Aside from the looks of the liquid, it just seemed underwhelming.  Mind you though, this place was bringing orders of XLBs out like Katz's slings pastrami sandwiches.  They must have a crew to just make those.

The potstickers were ok, I liked the texture, but the flavor was underwhelming as well.  Maybe that is the way it is supposed to be... But those were probably my favorite items I tried.

When we got our check, we got orange slices- the healthiest thing I ate all day.

I was glad I got to try it for the experience, I will def have to check out the one in Flushing now, but, I can't go with another group that big, I almost got stuck at the table.  Oh yea, and if you are a germophobe- steer clear of this place, just saying...

My Girlfriend and I came to NYC for comic con, and as huge foodies, we had to check out Joe's Shanghai after seeing all of its amazing reviews from other Yelpers. It's located in Chinatown, and you do have to explore the area a bit to find it. Stepping into Joe's Shanghai, the interior is very simple and it does not have the greatest ambiance. The utensils also did not seem that clean, and there were some cracks and chips on my plate, but I guess if you're going here, you came for the food.  There are only round tables that seat 8 people and due to their limited space, they will put strangers next to you if your table is not filled. 

Fortunately, the servers are very efficient and super quick. We only ordered one item, which was the pork soup dumplings. They came out super hot and were a great value, you get 8 pieces for $8.00 (Cash Only). The soup dumplings tasted just like the authentic ones I had in China. The soup is very flavorful and the dumpling skin is light and delicate. 

Overall, if you're in NYC, I would recommend coming to Joe's Shanghai for some authentic Chinese cuisine that doesn't break the bank, and to experience Chinatown.

I've been coming here for about 10+ years now...introduced to by friends. Best soup dumplings I have had by far...and I've searched, believe me. The mixed soup dumplings, shanghai fried rice with a side of scallion pancakes...something that will immediately put you in a delicious and comforting food coma. If you're a local, it's the perfect lunch/dinner; a bit challenging when you're coming from NJ, but parking isn't too bad considering regulations in NYC are strict. You'll always find a spot in China Town! If you go on a weeknight, especially wknd night, expect to wait an hour for a table (a table that you may or may not share with others). Lunch gets quite busy as well, but you're in the clear if you arrive before 12pm. Absolutely worth the wait, regardless.

Joe introduced me to soup dumplings, and now I feel like I'm in a Chuck Norris film on a never ending quest to find soup dumplings of equal or greater quality. I must be in the middle of the movie because nothing has come close, and I'm ready to quit my job and just open my own damn dumpling restaurant.

Based on recommendations from colleagues, I stopped here during my NYC trip around 3pm in the afternoon on a Friday. There were a lot of patrons dining already and we got seated right away BUT we got seated on a big round table with 3 other people already there. Apparently they share tables here to fill up all the seats. 

The server asked if we wanted soup dumplings as it takes 20 mins to cook and we answered yes. We also ordered a plate of fried rice to share. Hot tea was served. Dumplings and fried rice was absolutely delicious, I am a fan!

This place is highly popular as we stared at a wall filled with celebrities who have visited and taken photos with severs and owners. Wish we had our own table for a little privacy but we didn't stay too long as we wanted to explore Chinatown right after. Great little place and won't mind another visit when I'm back in town.
Best dang dumpling! I burned my mouth and would do it a thousand more times just to eat these dumplings faster.

I go here every chance I get when I'm in NY! I missed xiao long bao so much from my time living in China, & this was a godsend. They only have 2 types, pork & pork w/ crab. The pork ones are definitely the better of the 2. The scallion pancakes are quite tasty & they offer free Jasmine tea when you sit down. If you're craving your soup dumplings, you can't go wrong!!

their famous soup dumplings never dissapoint.  also delish are the scallion pancakes, the new year's cakes with veggies, the eggplant dish is good enough to convert non-veggie lovers and the double cooked pork (a little spicey) was an enormous hit!  i go here to celebrate chinese new year each year.  it's not much for ambiance, and there is always a wait (even if you reserve) but it's sooooo yummy!  beer only

the best crab soup buns I've ever had. Trust me because I'm from Hangzhou, which is near to Shanghai. 
the skin of the buns is translucent, you can see the juice inside.
The crab soup is perfect, not too salty or fishy, just perfect.
OMG I will definitely miss it.

After taking an Uber to Chinatown whilst in NYC, we stumbled upon this establishment. The people gathered outside waiting for a table, led us to believe we would not be disappointed.

We waited about 20-30 minutes on Saturday night and based on reviews on Yelp, that wasn't too bad. When you go in, expect to sit with strangers because you will. This wasn't an issue for my partner and I, we just weren't expecting it. We were immediately brought a pot of hot jasmine tea, which was much appreciated after having stood in the cold for half an hour. 

After a few minutes of drinking our tea, we noticed that many people were ordering what we thought were dumplings, but they were actually soup dumplings. Since we ordered the regular dumplings, which were very tasty, we didn't get to try the much revered soup dumplings. If you go, try those as they seem very popular.

After ordering our dumplings, we decided on crispy shredded beef and shrimp fried rice. Both were excellent, but the crispy shredded beef stood out with it's citrusy bits of orange peel throughout the dish. 

I would definitely come here again and try other things on the menu or even order some of the same things. Everything we had was exceptionally good.

On a side note, make sure you bring CASH, because they don't accept anything else and the ATM in front looks dodgy.
Fantastic. There is a line but the wait usually goes pretty fast. Casual and fast spot to eat! Inexpensive as well! Highly recommend.

Joe's soup dumplings are by far the best thing on the menu. Although everything was good the soup dumplings are a must.
 It's a small restaurant and we were a party of two that shared a table with six other people. I didn't mind just know before you go.

joe's shanghai is probably one of the better XLB places i've eaten at...although nanxiang in flushing is better (thinner dumpling skin and better flavor)...

but you cannot beat joe's for the price...my dining partner and i had one order of the pork XLB http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0CjK3esfpFcxIopebzjFxA?select=I0EnPz6hK1NoJ5rDJ8IHsQ http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=gUkqdzdD0jhqsjM-AZAWVw&select=CZXkIWuDq50BMOPlLxKtbA, one order of pork/crab XLB http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=gUkqdzdD0jhqsjM-AZAWVw&select=JRlQHMi3kfP23NSfsDhdRg, scallion pancakes, and the shanghai noodles with shrimp http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0CjK3esfpFcxIopebzjFxA?select=DnlLxSU6lisgvUGRe8wlsw...

the XLBs were very juicy, the scallion pancake was crispy with a fair amounts of scallions http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=gUkqdzdD0jhqsjM-AZAWVw&select=wj0pbsVi0x1X0hPgjcjWEQ, and the noodles were packed with shrimp...*drool*

i think i need a large bore IV started so i can get a XLB broth infusion...

NB:  make sure you go inside and grab a number and not waste any time waiting outside...

The best soup dumplings ever! I always make sure to stop here when I'm in New York City because they definitely do not disappoint. So juicy and soupy and delicious, I crave them all the time. I usually find that one order of XLB per adult usually satisfies everyone, but if you want to order other things, then you can adjust that ratio.
Rice cakes, scallion pancakes and orange chicken (little cringe) are also really good here. 
At some tables, it is community seating, but in my opinion, that's how you get the authentic experience! It's also cash only!
best. soup. dumplings. ever. great place...will always come back.

Love this place!! My brother used to live in NY and everytime he goes back to visit, this is the first place he goes! We went for the soup dumplings of course and also had the delish shanghai noodles. The family style seating isn't ideal but it's a small price to pay for the DELICIOUS AMAZING soup dumplings. I wish we had just as good dumplings in LA. Yummmm. I can't wait to go back to NY just to have more of these dumplings :)

If you have never tried soup dumplings - this is the place! We ordered 3 orders of pork for the 6 of us with a few other traditional dishes. Living in CT you can not find this delicacy so whenever I am in NY this place is worth the trip.

Went to try what I was told was the best soup dumplings in Chinatown. The dining area was full on a summer week night, so I was hopeful about the hype. Despite the crowd, we were seated immediately at a large table that we shortly thereafter shared with another group of 5 visiting from the UK. We were quickly attended to and served our delicious fare. The soup dumplings were tasty, though it did take a bit longer to receive our order of crab stuffed dumplings than did our neighbors across the table. The supporting dishes were also quite flavorful, especially the minced bean curd and eggplant with garlic sauce. Only one star removed for being a cash only location.

The crab/pork XLB (soup dumplings) from Joe's was probably my favorite thing we ate during our trip to NYC. Definitely a 5 star worthy XLB and the best I had anywhere. The XLB was so juicy and flavorful! The crab essence and flavor was prominent and the meat is tender. The skin of the soup dumplings was not particularly thin but was just right to hold up all the juice inside. Highly recommend the crab/pork XLB**

We also had the green onion pancake and a plate of seasonal veggies. The green onion pancake is different from what I am used to. The ones here are a bit thicker and super crispy. I liked their version just as much as the thin chewy one I am used to. The veggies were decent. Not super oily nor salty. Missing a bit of "wok-hey."

The wait wasn't too bad on a Saturday morning. We got a number and waited ~15 minutes to be seated at a shared round table with 3 other parties. I didn't mind sharing the table and liked that they worked pretty efficient to minimize the wait time.

I will definitely make sure to come to Joe's again on my next trip to NYC.

We end up swinging through here every time we are back in NYC.
The dumplings and a must. Also careful technique is a must when eating these tasty but molten hot juicy liquid explosives of pork heaven.

And yeah, service is a bit "rough around the edges", as others may point out, and yeah, the ambiance is a bit rough as well, but you're not here for that. And plus, this is New York, this is how we do. ;)

Joe's Shanghai is great! You should expect to have at least a 15 minute wait to be seated but the food comes out pretty quickly especially if you use those 15 minutes wisely and prepare your order!!!!! I unfortunately do not eat pork/sea food so my options were very limited. I want some soup dumplings but they were all made with pork! Too bad. I started with the scallion pancake which was so great!!!!!! I highly recommend them. I finished with the Kung Pao chicken which didn't have too much flavor, I probably wouldn't get it again.

I've been going to Joe's for years and I cant say enough good things. The food is great and the experience even better. Every time my family or friends visit from Europe I take them here and they are super satisfied with the soup dumplings. Please, stop complaining about the service. They help as much as they can, this is a fast paced restaurant managed by very driven Chinese people and yes it is always packed but they always do their best when you ask. 

Enjoy! Eat tons, everything is good!

Service: Happened to be around the area.  Called in advanced to have crab dumplings. Once I arrived food was already prepared waiting for me!!

Ambiance: Tight atmosphere. 

Food: I'm personally spectacle not knowing exactly what I am eating. However, my first but was oddly textured, but delightfully tasty! Although, it wasn't just crabs. The gelatin soup was overbearing.

Do you eat pork? Do you like dumplings? Are you near Chinatown? Yes? Go to Joe's Shanghai, order some pork soup dumplings, and experience bliss. There are better places for Chinese food in NY, so just stick to the dumplings.

It's small, it's busy, it's dirty, but the soup dumplings are worth it. We've been countless times and whenever someone in our group orders anything other than the XLB, they always kinda wish they just had more dumplings. Make sure to use your vinegar and chili sauce, and order a side of scallion pancakes for good measure.

I heart joe's shanghai
if i said it was "just average"- that'd be a lie
The soup dumplings are delish
it is definitely joe's best dish!

Mmm i love joe's crab and pork soup dumplings. The thought of them make me drool (gross i know, but they're soooo good! haha) i've had the Shanghai Noodles, but I wouldn't recommend the Pan Fried Noodles-- the noodles have a weird texture-- almost  like styrofoam. 

I've have the scallion pancakes-- they're pretty decent too, but it's kinda pricey for just a few slices.
I stumble upon this place while I was visiting NYC. I order some food for to go, and it was some of the most amazing food that I had in NYC.

I've been to both locations one in China town and one in midtown. Great food here. The dim sum is really good. I recommend ordering the fried shrimp and the generals tso chicken. You won't be disappointed.

You can honsetly never go wrong with Joes, but I have had better. Food is a tad bit on the oily side, but honestly still very good. Haha. If I'm in chinatown and craving soup dumplings its the only place i`ll go, however there's better soup dumplings in the other boroughs. Hate that there's a long wait at like all times !

Although this place is crowded and they sit you with strangers, I definitely enjoy the xiao lung bao! Perhaps the best one I've had so far. Big and super juicy with thick soup! Just to let you know, you have to get a number if you want to be seated. Then they will call you when they are ready.

I had the xlb, pork buns, wonton soup, noodles ... basically a lot! When I came back to dallas, man, I miss this place! Can't compare at all.will be back!

I don't care how busy it always is ( literally busy from opening to closing everyday!) or how you have to share tables.

The XIAO LONG BAO are bombbbbb!
my all time favourite place to eat when I visit NYC. The soup dumplings are perfectly made, and so delicious and so freaking cheap!


I always wanted to learn their secret recipe of how they can keep all that yummy soup in those thinly and perfectly made dumplings? I am obsessed with these and there is no way I can go to New York without my Joe's Shanghai!

Did I mention they are so cheap too?!!!

I have been going here since I was little, and I still love it. Every time I go, I get the soup dumplings. I recommend the crab and pork soup dumplings over the pork ones. I also like the string beans and beef and broccoli. It is worth the wait!

I was with a party of 12 and while the wait wasn't that long, they require your whole party to be there before they seat you, and they do count! We ordered the Pork Soup Dumplings, Double Cooked Pork, and Peking Duck. The dumplings weren't all they were hyped up to be, but still delicious and larger than expected. The Double Cooked Pork was my favorite dish. It was very spicy but still flavorful. The Peking Duck was surprisingly big! You definitely get what you pay for. Overall the experience a bit of a let down as this location is very hyped up but it was just average in my opinion.
Great place for soup dumplings. Either pork or crab! The place is small, so expect to sit with other people at a table!

Joe Shanghai is probably the best dumpling place I have ever been to in my life I am only 12 years old but you wouldn't believe the places I've been to. In my young life, I have been to Hong Kong and have tasted "best" dumplings in the world. The crab dumplings are so good. And the pork dumplings are also spectacular. And to top it off they have soup inside that is just marvelous.

Joe's Shanghai is a definite must for me whenever I visit NYC. I always always always always have to eat here at least once. Why? Because it is delicious! It not only satisfies my hunger but it makes me feel all warm inside! 

At first I was a little afraid to try this place out because not everyone on yelp is accurate since everyone's taste buds are so different. Not only that but there are a few other places where it was just over hyped and it wasn't as good as I thought it would be. On top of that, when a place becomes famous, their quality slowly slides downhill. I can tell you, Joe's Shanghai is none of the above. 

Joe's Shanghai may not be where all the awesome customer service is because come on, stereotypically, Chinese places aren't known for their customer service. Joe's Shanghai, however, is definitely consistent with their quality of their famous xiao long baos or soup dumplings, as most people refer to it as. 

ALWAYS ALWAYS ALWAYS order some xiao long bao/soup dumplings. In fact, that is the first thing they ask you when you sit down. "You want some dumplings?" Granted, heavy Chinese accent seeping through their English but it works. I always prefer the pork/original type but they also have a crab/pork one if I remember correctly.

NOTE. When you get these dumplings, they are steaming HOT. Do NOT be that person that puts the whole thing in their mouth the second they get it. DO NOT!! You will burn yourself so bad! Let it cool for a few and I suggest taking a small bite and drinking the soup first. There is SOUP on the inside and it will burn you if you eat it too quickly! ...Yes personal experience :( No I never put the whole thing in my mouth but the soup does burn me...

Be warned. This place is really popular so you most likely have to wait unless you're eating at odd hours like at 3-4 pm. If you go with a party, your party must be all present for them to sit you down. Also, not your typical restaurant. You don't get to have a table all to yourself most of the time -- you'll have to learn how to share. I know it's an odd concept because I don't like sharing my food, let alone my table! But no worries! It'll be fine! It's actually very similar to how they sit people overseas at a dim sum place. Plus that way, they can get people in and out faster. 

Aside from their pork dumplings, I have tried a few other dishes but they weren't as memorable. Teehee. 

Give Joe's Shanghai a try and order the dumplings. You can't go wrong.

Good dim sim food

I think Shanghai you seasoned its food better and had better soup dumplings.

But hey this is solid and hits the spot if your craving soup dumps and noodz

The dumplings were great - definitely lived up to the hype, although I still think the best I've ever had is on Highway 7 in Toronto, Ontario.

The noodle soup were okay. Nothing spectacular.

A bit of a line to get in, but worth the wait to check out.

I absolutely love Joe's Shanghai. Their soup dumplings are amazing, I only eat the crab meat with pork one. It's always so flavorful. 

JellyFish
Crabmeat w/ Pork Soup Dumplings
Fried Salt and Pepper Shrimp (w/ shells on)
Shanghai Noodles with Veg.

Absolutely no complaints about this place.. walked in about 7pm with a party of 5 and was seated immediately . Staff was GREAT, very attentive . Food was delicious ..all of it.! You must try these soup dumplings!
Yummy soup dumplings, it's worth the wait.  The rice cakes there are also very good.

5 Stars for the Soup Dumplings! 3 stars for the ambiance / service. It's crowded, you have to share tables, and the service is rushed since they are trying to move people along quickly. Great deal. Worth it. Go... right now.

The food here is flavorful and comes out fast, but the service is lacking. While we were starting to get up they already seated people at our table so we trapped against the wall. We then were repeatedly bumped towards the door even though we didn't have our coats on. 

That being said, we didn't have to wait and were seated as a party of 5 at a shared table immediately at 11:30. We ordered Scallion Pancake, Pork Soup Dumplings, Crispy Shredded Beef, Eggplant, Green Beans, and Shanghai Noodles with chicken. The tea was hot and refilled quickly. The table was set with a soup spoon and small dishes of vinegar waiting for our first order of dumplings.

The beef was sweet and crispy but not chewy like other versions of this dish I've had. What I thought were shredded carrots were bitter pieces or orange peel mixed into the dish. The eggplant had a crisp, blistered skin which yielded to a squishy center but it needed flavor. It tasted solely of the oil it was fried in. Green beans were salty with firm wrinkly skins that snapped with each bite. The Shanghai noodles were almost the size of udon noodles and were very comforting and familiar in a slightly sweet brown gravy sauce.

But the star here is the XLB. The soup dumplings, when plucked from the steamer (I used my fingers since the tongs are more risky) had the perfect mouthful of soup. The broth was flavorful and the dumpling wrapper wasn't too thick. The meat inside was actual dumpling filling, not mystery meat that I've seen ooze out of other dumplings.

Cash only, but not that expensive! There's an ATM right when you walk in.

Just order 8-13 or 14 on the appetizers menu.

This will give you
2 x soup dumplings (different types)
1 x scallion pancakes
1 x cold sesame noodles
1 x fried dumplings

With 3 sodas this dim sum feast for 2 will set you back only $44 dollars including tip, and trust me, it's more than enough food.

Don't expect this to be a romantic dinner though. I went with my fiance and they seated us after a 30 minute wait they seated us at a table with 9 other people. Everyone else finished before us and they started a 4 person cleaning the rest of the table furiously, so we finished our last dumpling and scrammed.

Still a GREAT experience!!

CASH ONLY!!!
Went to visit China Town today and this place did. it disappoint. These were truly some really tasty soup dumplings and the beef pancakes were amazing. The worker was also super nice. 10/10

Sunday 9/11, party of two, we were seated immediately at 1:30 p.m.  The restaurant was packed.  

Next to us at the communal table sat two Spanish tourists and I told them, "This place is known for their dumplings."  I don't think they understood me but I pointed to items #1 and #2 and they nodded their head.  

At the big table of eight next to us sat eight caucasians, all eating soup dumplings.  Not something I see every day.  

As for us... we kept it simple.  

Crab & Pork Dumplings -  I ordered two trays ($6.95 each, 8 per tray) of these and couldn't finish it all.  On my first tray they even gave me an extra dumpling!  Wasted, such a shame.  At first I couldn't taste the crab, but by the time I got to my fourth dumpling, the crab taste was just bursting out before I even took a bite.  I guess my taste buds just had to get adjusted.  Nice and soupy.  

Pork Dumplings -  $4.95 for tray of 8.  Very good, but a little less flavorful than the dumpling meat that's mixed with crab.  Very reasonably priced.  

Green Onion Pancake - Six pieces, pan fried with just the right crispness.  Mind blowing... no.  Good enough to order again next time?  Definitely.  

A few things for the first timer...

With your chopsticks, pick up the dumpling by the top nub (yes, it looks what your mama nursed you with) and put it onto your plastic soup spoon.  Pick it up gently out of the tray so that you don't puncture or rip the dumpling skin.  If you lose all/any it's juice/soup, that's a fail.

The provided mixed sauce is vinegar, soy, and fresh ginger.  Put some on top of the dumpling that's now sitting in your soup spoon.  The reason you eat it out of the soup spoon is to protect when there is drippage or for when you bite too eagerly into a steaming hot dumpling.  Burn...

Don't be afraid to ask for extra ginger.  The vinegar, soy, and ginger really do bring out the flavor of the dumpling, otherwise, it's pretty plain.  Mix in some ground red pepper if you like it spicy.   

***Why do Chinese people make such a big deal about soup dumplings?***  

It's not that it's China's best food, it's because not every restaurant makes them fresh and a decent soup dumpling is hard to find.  The worst is when you go to a restaurant that has this on the menu and they steam up some grocery store frozen ones for you.

Love the dumplings. ITs just so amazing how much juice it has got. price is also very reasonable. 
The only drawback is the wait time. Man I had to wait like 40mins to get in and they only take cash!!! bummer
If only everyone upgraded to 21st century by accepting digital payments,especially in NY. anyways i guess it is what it is. Will try the flushing location since I heard there is no wait and more parking space.

Amidst all the recent hype about unicorn meat (http://www.thinkgeek.com/caffeine/wacky-edibles/e5a7/), I've always wondered what it would taste like had they made the real thing. 

Picture it. Crab meat soup dumplings from Joe's Shanghai. 2010. Chinese unicorn takes you on a ride - over the oriental rainbow.
So good and always packed. One time they had a C rating and I ate there anyway, it's that good! Ps I didn't get sick or anything.

This may seem like a hole in the wall nestled in China Town but it is THE BEST Chinese food I've ever had. The wait is worth it, the seating allows you an opportunity to meet new people (you may sit at a table with other parties), and the service is quick. I order the sesame chicken, note the broccli comes out cold, they're know for their dumplings and fyi your soda comes in a can. A note was handed out advising the china town location will be moving December 1st so next time I visit I'll be anxious to see the new location.

Every look and bite of their soup dumplings make me regret every time I have ever gone to DTF. 

It's cash only, you get seated with strangers, and the service/attitude will always be at best lukewarm, but that'll be everywhere in Chinatown anywhere so get comfortable with it. Thankfully when we came by on a weekday at 2pm, the wait was minimal. We only ordered the pork & crab soup dumplings and the pork soup dumplings since that's what they are known for, and we had a lot of more eating planned for in NYC. 

These soup dumplings were BIG, about 3 times the size of normal XLBs from DTF or any other Chinese restaurants where I've had them. That got me concerned that the dumplings would be too doughy, but that wasn't the case at all! They had just the right amount of dough, with plenty of flavorful soup and fillings. Even with just 2 orders of the soup dumplings (total of 12 dumplings) got us full. Compared to what I've had from the PNW, these were definitely the best I've had and they were perfect on a cold winter day.

Yes! This is the place for really tasty Shanghai dumplings! 
The dumplings are large and filled with lots of delicious juice. Definitely hand made. 
The scallion pancakes are crispy and delicious, but a tad greasy.
The restaurant was filled with Chinese people with a blend of a few tourists mixed in. 
They accept cash only, but their prices are really reasonable! 
They also add an automatic 15% service charge. 
I recommend this place heartily.

So regardless of my negative reaction from Joe's Shanghai a couple years ago. I decided to take the plunge and risk the being of my digestive system. I was craving for shanghai soup dumplings. I got it for take out and it was ready to go in 15 minutes. I must say, compared to Full House, the quality was much better. I had the crab meat soup dumplings. The wrapping didn't break and it came through after my first bite. Compared with Full House, it has a different taste to it but not a bad taste. Both are good in their own ways but I think I'd prefer Joe's over anywhere else. Definitely trying their wontons next week! Stay tuned!

Absolutely in love with this place. They're super busy so they're customer service is unintentionally ok and not great but it's definitely doable. Of course the soup dumplings are out of this world. This time around we got the sesame chicken as well (among other things) and it turned out to be so so good. Gosh I wish they had a place like this here in DC... Hmmm, do they?!

I can see why this place is so popular. I had first tried it many years ago at their original location in Flushing. This new hub has been open for a while now and there's always a line out the door and down the block. It's popular with tourist and locals alike. I can't say it's my favorite soup dumpling spot, but it's definitely worth a stop. My friends sing praises to the orange beef fish, while I found it too sweet and not sure how I feel about it after the first try. I'll surely come back again as it's one of their faves and update my review. The ambience is relax the attention is active, so it sure is worth a stop.

Felt like years since I last came here. Maybe 2 years lol. Either way it has been so long that I forgot I wasn't a fan of the crab and pork soup dumplings, note to self, stick to pork only. My mother in law has heard about this place from us for years and she tried to make her own soup dumpling but failed. She too liked pork over crab and pork. Until next time Joe!

There was about 40 min wait on a Friday night, which wasn't bad given how many people were waiting outside the restaurant. Pretty crowded space and they seat smaller parties together at large circular tables. The waiter took our order first and the soup dumplings came out pretty quickly while the rest of the table stared at us out of jealousy. The size of the soup dumplings is larger than your average soup dumpling and there is plenty of soup. Compared to ding tai feng, the skin is thicker and the presentation is less delicate overall, but still delicious. My friend and his family are from Shanghai and they think that Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings are better than the ones back home, so that's saying something. Also, eight for the price of $6.25 is a steal. This location is cheaper than the midtown location which is eight for $8.25. Will definitely be coming back for more.
We had that dumpling soup and orange beef and hot and sour soup. All was ridiculously good!

While around Chinatown I wanted to try these Pork Dumplings I have kept hearing about!! Well when walking in to get to the table it was pretty busy during lunch hour which just shows that they must be doing something right with all these hungry mouths! The service was very quick, came in ordered the dumpling right away and WOW!!! The flavor was so robust the soup was nice and hot but not mouth scorching, the table had Chili Oil to compliment the Dumplings, which was a nice touch if you are into that kind of thing! Can say I want to go back and try other dumplings and other food they have on their menu, just from seeing other plates that people had around me, I was wanting to try this and that! Thanks for you business!

When we arrived there was a line. The hostess gives you a number and you wait to be called. If it's super busy they will seat smaller parties with other people for communal dining like on cruise ships. We had a great family dine with us. The pork and crab soup dumplings (first timer) were so good! The whole experience was a blast.

The soup dumplings alone earns this place five stars. HOW do they pack so much soup into each little dumpling? So delicious and definitely for the "MUST" list for the dumpling lovers. I recommend trying both the pork and crab soup dumplings. That said, the crab dumplings are SO good.

I can't wait to go back. 

I've been twice, Saturday for an early lunch and Sunday for a late dinner. Both times the restaurant was packed but the wait pretty reasonable (under 20 minutes). The service is attentive. Cash only and very economical. 

I usually don't like to give reviews for just one dish, but the soup dumplings are SO superior here I couldn't give this place any less stars!

Everything we had was delicious! The soup dumplings, orange chicken (my favorite), kung pao chicken, and beef and broccoli. After finding out about this place in China Town I will make sure I come back and visit every time I'm in New York!
This is a cash only place which is ok with me. The food was great. The service was fast and the food was hot. The dumplings were big and delicious. The soup is enough for 2. I definitely enjoyed it.

By far my favorite Chinese restaurant! I crave their soup dumplings all the time. Although they are not known for their service I think that is part of the charm of it. Big group, small group, it's always a fun time. You have to have everyone in your party there before you will get seated and it's cash only. They do include a 15% tip on the check every time. Also, the picture I attached is right when it opened. I have never seen it that empty. We always get dumplings, pan fried noodles, and scallion pancakes. The price is super reasonable as well!

There is ALWAYS a line out the door.  I went on a Sunday at noon and luckily I was seated right away. 

REASONS YOU MAY NOT LIKE THIS PLACE:
If you are in a rush, don't like crowded spaces or sharing tables, then you probably won't like this place.  It is a communal setting so we were seated with 2 other couples at a round table but everyone is busy slurping the soup dumplings so you prob won't notice  anyway.

The food is great (and you WILL be full) and it's so cheap for the city ($36 for 3 dishes including tip) so this balances out all the bad stuff 

The soup dumplings are made fresh and are good, but if only going for these, there are other places in Chinatown that serve pork soup dumplings.  (example: shanghai cuisine on Mott St) 

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1) soup dumplings 
2) chefs special: shredded spicy beef if you like spice
3) the cabbage wonton soup if you wanna opt for a soup (+add white pepper)
4) bring cash 
5) 15% tip is included in the bill but I gave a few extra dollars

Second time coming here from Philly.  Can't get anything like this back home.  Everyone comes here for the xiao long bao's, which are probably one of the best.  There are two options - crab with pork and pork.  Best to try both and you'll love the juicy buns!

Reliable standby. Avoid the crowds and order for pick up (they don't deliver). Prices have risen considerably since they moved to their new location. Their soup dumplings are as good as ever, and the eggplant and pork is excellent. The Flushing location's kitchen has always been a cut above.

A Literal hole in the wall with the best soup dumplings I've ever had in my life. An hour wait and you have no clue why. BUT once you eat there it all makes sense. Soup dumplings are incredible and the other dishes are on point. Highly highly recommend
Joe's has moved to their Bowery location and this new location is anything but dirty and smelly! It looks amazing inside and there's plenty of space!

I HAVE NO WORDS!

.

.

Okay, I think I've gathered myself enough. 

This place is amazing! The soup dumplings are out of this WORLD!

Both the crab/pork, and the pork options of the soup dumplings are well worth the try. But the pork ones are simply transcendent. Absolutely divine. How on earth do they pack so much flavour into them??

By recommendation of our table mates, a family of 4 seated with is, we also tried the prawns in meat sauce, and the scallion pancakes. These too, were delicious.

But those soup dumplings. C'mon.

We came for the soup dumplings and were not disappointed! I didn't know what to expect and was a little worried about the wait time when I saw the large crowd waiting as you first walk in. 
They only have large round tables - seat about 10 people each - at which you are seated according to available space. We were seated immediately which was great. However, you end up staring across the table at strangers. 
The food was good - kept to the basics. I enjoyed the beef and broccoli and the pork soup dumplings. The sesame chicken was ok.

Best Asian food i have ever had. Ive tried din tai fung in LA and must say that this place tastes much better! 

I had the dumpling soup and it was really good. The vinegar soy sauce just went amazing with just about everything i had.

Overall its a great spot, we love this place and will definitely come back soon!

After reading the rave reviews about this place I headed there and it did not disappoint! Everything that was brought to the table was absolute perfection. The soup dumplings were probably the best I've had (now the bar is so high) and the rest of the dishes were all perfectly seasoned and so authentic. We ordered the sauteed flat noodles which were so yummy and long! We also ordered fried rice, wonton soup and Beef and green beans. Portions of noodles and rice were great to share but I wish there was more of the beef as it was amazing. There was a long line but we only waited for about 15 mins or so. This is now a place I will come back to everytime I'm in the area.
Good place for xiaolongbao. I feel like their xiaolongbao is bigger than others. Clean and bright environment. Good service. The food comes very fast.

I have often been quoted as saying that nothing can compare to the Joe's Shanghai of my youth.  Indeed there is something awsomely authentic about the soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai.  Much more expensive higher end versions have sprung up all over the country, but still cannot compare to the original.  The Young Chow fried rice, the Singapore curry mai fun, shanghai noodles, been curd szechuan, and many other dishes are special works of joy here.  When Joe's Shanghai catapulted into everyone's consciousness in the 1980's, Shanghai cuisine was certainly a novelty.  I hope Joe's Shanghai stays around for another generation.  With the coming of the New Chinatown these older establishments where you are forced to eat with strangers, and your waitors and waitresses have a real New York attitude are indeed refreshing.  It is true that you can never go back, but there are certainly legendary NYC Chinatown establishments that hopefully will go on forever!
The taste is much incredible. It is amazing to find this spot. The steam bun met the expectation. Be careful do not break it when you move it into your dish.

Came here once with my cousin and it is legitimately the best soup dumpling I've ever had. Can't wait till I'm back in New York to eat the yummy crab dumpling again!!! I recommend anyone who's in town to give it a go for sure!

As soon as we seated, they immediately asked if we wanted their soup dumplings. It's like they know you came here FOR their soup dumpling and that's 100% correct (we did). 

We had the pork and it was delish- definitely will be back to try their other foods. People next to us ordered pan fried noodle and it looked good!

P.S- be careful when you eat them, they are HOT and filled with soup! I usually bit a little hole then drink the soup then eat the dumpling.

This place is a little hidden gem of soup dumpling delights!  We were greeted with a very busy dining room but were able to be seated within 5-10 minutes and were immediately given a pot of light tea to start with (particularly lovely on colder days.)  We ordered two steam trays of soup dumplings that smelled so amazing my vegetarian friend even partook in the items!! Helpful hint: make sure to puncture the dumpling directly over your spoon so you don't lose any of the broth and also so the steam can escape (otherwise be prepared to scald half of your taste buds.) We also had the eggplant which were good, although I'd prefer a bit more spice to be added to the dish.  I recommend going with a group so you can sample a large portion of the menu but beware, this hole in the wall is cash only!

This restaurant was highly recommended by previous visitors and we were well advised!   We went mid afternoon, which I would recommend...about 2:30 pm -4:00 pm. No wait, seated with others at a community table which made for great chit chat.  We ordered the soup dumplings, fried rice and General Tso's chicken.   Very authentic, flavors very true and worthy of the praise.  They only take cash, no credit cards, so be prepared.   Pricing is reasonable, so that makes it easy.  The service is very rote, but friendly.

Came here with the fianc√© and his family! The line was so long have to waited an hour for it but guess what?! All worth it! The dumplings taste so good better than other dumpling places I've gone to. Not only do the dumplings taste delicious, their soups as well.

I wanted to hate this place because the wait was supposed to only be 45 minutes (lies, all lies) but it ended up being over an hour, it's cash only, tip is included and the waiters act like it is, AND they got a C health inspection grade.

BUT...the food was amazing and very reasonably priced.  The crab and pork dumplings were juicy and delicious and not fishy tasting at all.  The shanghai noodles w/ beef were also great.  Everything we ordered was either good or great.  I would go back again, but hopefully when it is less busy and cleaner.

I know this place is a tourist trap, but the soup dumplings here were pretty darn good. When the dumplings came out, they look like they had been flattened since there was so much soup inside of them. Be careful, as always, when you bite into one since it literally explodes with hot soup. We ordered both the pork (original) and crab dumplings, but I must say that the pork ones were simply better than the crab ones. The crab ones tasted strangely fibrous and were not as juicy as the pork ones.

Joe's Shanghai is CASH ONLY so make sure you have enough before you decide to dine here. Since this place is a tourist trap, expect to wait in line for a bit before making it inside. Another thing to note is that there is communal seating--different parties will all be seated together at the same round table (we had three groups sharing one large table). I've experienced communal seating before, but never at a round table. Since everyone is able to see everyone else, it is a little bit of a strange experience...but most people will be so focused on eating their soup dumplings so it all turns out okay.

Joe's Shanghai took my xiao long bao virginity.

I had never even heard of xiao long bao previous to attending college in New York (SoCal represent!), but one of my friends took me here since she frequents this place.

After hearing rave reviews from my friends about this mysterious dumpling, I had high expectations for trying xiao long bao.

My expectations were exceeded. The second I bit into its soft folds, my LIFE CHANGED. Seriously. It was like heaven exploding in my mouth. Coupled with the vinegar/ginger sauce, it was amazing.

So although I'm no xiao long bao connoisseur, I can definitely recommend this place to anyone.
Delicious! Obviously soup dumplings, but the eggplant with pork is delicious too!  Perfect amount of food for two hungry girls.  Family style is fun too :)

If you are ever wondering why the streets of Chinatown are pretty empty on a Friday night it's because everyone is HERE. 

Word on the street is that their soup dumplings are comparable to Din Tai Fung and a guy next to us even mentioned their soup dumplings were spot on to the ones he had in Shanghai! 

You walk in and this place is PACKED. I mean like the hostess is giving out tickets for parties to wait to be called on type stuff. Luckily, if you are only a party of two or an alone dumpling enthusiast  you will definitely not be waiting for long. 

My boyfriend and I stumbled into this place and got seated right away. It seemed like the host was leading us back to the kitchen but little did we know  they sit multiple parties to one big round Chinese dinner tables! While this could definitely be awkward for some people and not the best option for a first date, we ended up having a fun time with the other dumpling lovers around us. It was almost refreshing to share awkward smiles and the appreciation of good dumplings. 

On to the dumplings! So we ordered the soup and regular pan fried dumplings. The broth was one of the best I've ever had and the pan fried  ones were so crisp to a T. 

Will be back soon!

Joe's Shanghai is my go-to spot to take people visiting the NYC area, and I always bring them to this location specifically.  You can't go wrong with any of the soup dumplings, but I'd also recommend the orange beef and the crispy beef. Portions are great.

If you have a smaller party, you may wind up having to sit family style with another small party, which you can either see as a bad thing or an opportunity to make friends. Warning: Joe's is CASH ONLY so keep that in mind when you're coming in.
The Classic. Always delicious dumplings. Hit or miss on the soft shell crab, which was oily, gritty and had the wrong texture. Otherwise-this place is always delicious:)

Went with three people and we ordered soup dumplings, beef and broccoli, scallion pancakes, sea bass, and an eggplant dish.

Garlic eggplant was delicious as was the beef and broccoli. 

Totally worth the wait!
The best soup dumplings around. I would recommend Joe's to anyone visiting the area. Great atmosphere but beware, cash only!

My favorite place for soup dumplings and scallion pancake in chinatown. Although it's busy most of the time and packed with tourists and people think it's hyped up, I still really like this place. You'll most likely be seated with a group of strangers unless you have a big enough group to fit one whole table. Also be on the look out for celebrity sitings. They have pictures of celebrities who have dined there on the walls. I even sat right across from jake gyllenhaal once too!

Came here with friends for dinner for our NYC trip!

Thankfully, we came RIGHT before the extreme wait. They told us it would be ~20 minutes, we only waited 5 minutes! Woo hoo :)

The service was super quick, they took our order swiftly, and our food came out quick! I was impressed bc it was so DANG busy that night (the line was out the door). The restaurant was very crowded, but that's what happens there are a lot of customers.

We got the pork soup dumplings. Super. Savory. and. Delicious. The soup was extremely rich and- of course- sizzling hot! We also got other entrees/dishes which were just as good (pork+bean curd? and the pancake appetizer), but the soup dumplings are 10/10 and probably the only dish I can remember and left a mark.

I would come back here for lunch if I ever come back in the area! Definitely recommend coming here with friends/family for a nice hot meal :)

incredible soup dumpz, aka my little friends, oh god woooOWOoOWOOWO

they are just so perfect, not oily, freshly made, delicate little dough pockets filled with flavorful warm broth

damnit I wish I could have a pillow made out of this I would have the sweetest little dumpling dreams ever.
Excellent service and the crispy beef is to die for. Just remember to bring cash as that is all they accept

so i went in a group of 4 and we got seated on a huge table with a bunch of other people. i was real hesitant about this place because what if someone steals our food on the lazy susan?!!?!? i tend to hate stuff when people claim best ever like here when everyone told....BEST XIAO LONG BAO'S EVER. we got a bunch of those(my first time having them) and some curry noodles and some other non-memorable stuff.

the XLB's for sure lived up to the hype. actually they went beyond the hype if you can believe it. like avatar. but that's a different story. hahaha

i've had XLB's from various places in california like din tai fung or hole in the wall places up in san francisco, but joe's knocks them all out of the juicy sauce. get it? like knock them out of the water? but instead of water, juicy sauce??!!?!? 

wakka wakka wakka

Literally came here twice during our trip to New York. Everything we ordered was soooo goooood! 
Both times we came, we ordered the pork meat soup dumplings and young chow fried rice. I can say those were our top favorite dishes. The pork meat soup dumplings are HUGE, not your typical size soup dumpling (this is a must get!!). Also, the fried rice may look bland but it's packed with flavor!

The Szechuan beef noodle soup was okay. It needed more flavor as it was a bit bland. The crispy shredded beef was good. Tasted almost like sweet and sour pork. Also, the scallion pancakes are worth trying!

The food came out pretty quick which was good for us because both times we came, we were all starving!! 

Service was decent. They were super quick at getting us whatever we needed like extra bowls, napkins, water, etc. 

Not sure if it was just a one time thing or we just missed it, but we noticed there was already a 18% or 20% service charge on our bill (the second time we came). The first time we came and paid, we didn't notice the service charge included in the bill so we might have double tipped them. So just make sure to check the bill before paying so you're not over tipping! 

FYI, they only accept cash! They have an ATM right in front of the entrance in case you don't have enough cash on hand.

Joe's Shanghai is delicious perfection of soup dumplings. Why you would order anything else is beyond me. If you are looking for great non-soup dumplings, try Vanessa's or Prosperity you fools!

On to the dumplings! A steaming hot perfect crab soup dumpling will put you in heaven, especially in the winter! (though I've had Joe's in the humid heavy heat of NY in July and they were still amazing). 

Order the CRAB dumplings over the simple pork. Even if you don't love pure crab, there's something about the crab flavor that creates a rich meatiness in the dumpling broth!

NOTES: There are shared tables (yes, you may sit next to a stranger) and you WILL have to speak up if you need something (extra sauce, etc).
Good soup dumplings. Be prepared for long lines but worth it.

Good New York Chinese. Soup dumplings are great, as is the American Chinese fare (sesame chicken). Pan fried dumplings were okay, not amazing. Service is typical. Expect a wait to be seated, but grab a drink at the park restaurant/bar next door.

Yummy for my tummy... soup dumplings made of... crab and pork... so good... in my tummy... scallion pancake... great as an... appetizer... my thoughts... floating about with dreams of yumminess... the crab paste peeking out... the soup bursting out of the dumpling in my mouth... me so full... me so happy... me like the joe shanghai tshirt on the wall but when I go to buy one all they have are polo shirts that would make me look like a manager at joe shanghai so i... pass... so yummy in my tummy... me like joe shanghai.

Ok if you like authentic dumplings, this is the place for you.  It is a bit off the beaten path and they accept cash only, but the dumplings are worth it.  Really everything we had was fantastic.  The shrimp and beef dishes were very tasty go just before noon and beat the rush.  Note that small parties me be seated with other groups.
The best XLB's I've ever had in the U.S.   Much better than the overrated Din Tai Fung.  Slightly cheaper than average XLB prices.

What's up with the 'C' grade?

Food was tasty and plentiful. However, the 'C' grade prevented me from fully embracing.

This review is really for the XLB. No place on the west coast comes close to this. Definitely worth the wait, if there is one. After eating here, any other restaurant that serves XLB just doesn't even come close in taste, with the exception of Din Tai Fung.

Get here early, and get BOTH crab and pork dumplings. They are awesome. You just have to wait for them because of the line. I also liked how the seating works, you may end up eating next to people you dont know. So the conversations over the food were interesting and fun.

Back to the dumplings. Ive never had anything like them. Bite off the top and suck out the soup, then eat it? Sounds good to me! They are so flavorful and once you add their sauce they give you, dumpling goodness!

Also the tip is included in the check. But since the meal will be around 15 bucks, i wouldnt complain.

When I go to Chinatown with a group or just me and my wife this is the place we usually end up.  Excellent dumplings, scallion pancakes are also great if a little on the oily side.  Everyone always has their staple "go to" Chinese dish and I am willing to bet this place will not let you down.  There is usually a wait but it moves quickly as every seat in the place is used, as is the norm in most Chinese Restaurants of similar style.  So get in line sit down and meet some new people for a change!

i went here because a friend told me of this place, i went in and it was kinda busy, i was sat away at a table. i was by myself so it was kind of awkward. i ordered the scallion pancake and the pork dumplings. both were really delicious. i lost my money and they were nice enough to tell me where an atm was and let me go get that money. i'd go back here.
Ordered the pork soup dumplings and was thoroughly satisfied!  The soup was so delicious and nothing like I've ever tasted before!  Definitely a place to try if you're craving good dumplings.

Definitely the best Xai Long Bao in NYC! Easy to find, lots of seating, fasat service, and delicious food- everything I need. Note- if is cash only so come prepared or take the hit at the ATM in the front, either way it's totally worth it!
Soup. INSIDE. a pork dumpling.  its so good so make sure you order more than 1 order.  the dumpling sits in the spoon, bite the tip, suck the soup, eat the dumpling.  add the sauce to taste

Best soup dumplings ever. Also loved the lo mein.

There is always a line but it's definitely worth the wait! Very reasonably priced too!

Only reviewing the XLB.

$6 for eight insanely delicious soup dumplings. 

By the way, people get way too crazy about analyzing every aspect of XLB, but I just sat back and enjoyed and it was awesome. Everything was balanced in my opinion, maybe a little light on actual pork meat but whatever. I loved it. 

I think they were better here than Din Tai Fung....

Great soup dumplings. 
Surprising well cooked, juicy and large white meat chicken in the general tsao.

Came here for lunch on a Wed. No waiting at all when we arrived a little past noon. Servers were attentive and efficient. My order:
Soup dumplings: probably one of the best I've ever had. 5+ stars
Pot stickers: nice crunch with good portion filling. 5 stars
Shanghai thick noodle: not bad but could've used a little more flavor. 4 stars
String beans: great flavor but mushy, 3.5 stars 
Crispy spring roll: it was a bit mushy. I didn't enjoy it that much. 3 stars. 
Since there isn't a half star rating, I give it 5 stars because their soup dumplings are amazing.

Delicious! 

I recently traveled to Taiwan, where I fell in love with  Xiao Long Bao's at Din Tai Fung. After searching yelp for the best XLB in Manhattan, I decided on Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown. We ordered the scallion pancake and two orders of the pork XLB (it's pork buns on the menu). They were both fantastic!
