Personally, I prefer Korean scallion pancakes (pajeon) but these were excellent in their own way. The XLB was so good! Not quite as good as Din Tai Fung, but very delicious.
Chive pancakes and eggplant & pork in spicy garlic sauce to die for!!!!!

We stopped by here after the Lubar Festival parade. Waited 30 minutes for a table to our selves, as they wanted to seat us at a group table. 

We weren't offered the free tea mentioned in other reviews.  We ordered both soup dumplings listed as appetizers: the pork and the pork/crab.  They were amazing and filling!  We also ordered the Shanghai noodle that a lot of others on Yelp have raved about, but we thought they were just "good".

Loved this food and experience. So NY Chinatown! Better food than in Vancouver and Singapore. They don't take reservations. You will probably sit with other customers at a large table. So fun and memorable. Go hungry! Totally reasonable prices. Yummy! Add Joe's Shanghai to your must do list of NYC!

BEST Soup dumplings eveeeeeeeeeeeer ! The price is pretty good too ^_^. The noodles and rest of there food that they serve are pretty decent. Well this spot is known for soup dumplings anyways. It cost about $5 for 8 soup dumplings. Def worth the money. MUST TRY IT !!! (:

So the soup dumplings are amazing. I can't find another place in California that would make them at the way Joe has them.

Okay okay...Din Tai Fung...whatever. The dumplings are tiny, but they will do until my next trip to NY.

Other items to try:

Crispy Beef and Broccoli - My second favorite dish (1st are the dumplings). Just try it. Its the sauce.

Pork Shoulder - If you a lil daring and you have a few calories to spare, try it. Its great! The sauce, the meat (or whatever meat you find amongst the fat and skin) on a bed of steamed spinach is delicious.

As a lover of chinese food I had to stop in this place after reading all of the reviews and I was not disappointed. We ordered the Chicken lo mein and the General Tso's Chicken and loved every bit of it.

i am a lover of shanghai cuisine. while i am not a huge fan of sharing a table with random strangers, i will make an exception for joe's shanghai (at least i will for the one on Pell). after having ordered the soup dumplings from the midtown location via seamlessweb on many a weeknight evening over the past several months, i finally returned to the mothership for a very tasty/oily meal with my family and roommate. after a 35 min wait, we were seated, and the feasting began. we went with an order each of the pork and crabmeat soup dumplings, and then followed up with a seafood feast consisting of scallion & ginger soft shell crabs, sauteed shrimp, eel casserole, seaweed battered oysters and chinese mushrooms w/chinese vegetable (yes, the myseterious vegetable vaguely named, chinese vegetable). every dish was wonderfully tasty and equally oily. reminded me of being in shanghai, except nyc chinatown is slightly dirtier, smellier, and in general, there are more non-chinese people in the general vicinity than shanghai.
Place was PACKED at 5pm, which is always a great sign. Dumplings were outstanding, lo-mein was great ... chow-mein was not worth it and should be skipped. Go for the dumplings tho! Awesome.

The only downfall of this place was the wait. Came here on a Sunday night around 915 and we were told the wait would be about 20/30 minutes but we waited about 45/50 minutes. We were put at a table with 4 strangers so it was a little uncomfortable. We ordered both pork and crab dumplings. The crab was good but I prefer pork, unfortunately all the pork ones were stuck to the lettuce beneath them and as I tried to pick them up they all ripped, each and every one. We also ordered shrimp fried rice which was delicious and the Kung pao chicken was even better and mixed together it was one of the best dishes I've ever had. Everything was good and cheap, I'll definitely be back even though I know there will be a wait.

If you love soup dumplings, you won't find a better place to get them. Absolutely DELICIOUS and soup-y each and every time. My boyfriend and I always get crab/pork soup dumplings, fried rice cake, and scallion pancakes. Everything else on the menu looks appetizing as well. 

Do not come here if you're looking for an intimate setting. You will almost never get a table to yourself if you're only a party of 2/3. I can almost guarantee that you'd be placed at a table with other guests. It COULD be awkward especially if you're joining a very large party. I would also not recommend coming here for dinner time if you want to be seated quickly. You will probably wait about 30 min...but it's well worth it!

This is a popular restaurant with tourists so expect long queue.

It is located close to the Canal and Bowery St intersection.

The food and service were good.

oh boy oh boy oh boy i finally get to try Joe's Shanghai after being tortured by Doriee D for YEARS with her constant rambling and pictures ! 

We came here for break...brun.. yeah BRUNCH on a Wednesday morning. Our plan was to arrive right at opening right at 11am but due to some subway maintenance and leaving a little later than we had expected, we got here around 1130A instead. To my surprise and joy, it was still fairly empty. We had gotten our table for 6 in the middle of the restaurant almost instantly. 

Since I have been deprived of XLB for so long on top of being tortured year after year, i decided to YOLO (like with a lot of other things on my trip in NYC) and order 2 Pork XLB (Pork Steamed Bun) and 1 Crab with pork XLB (Crab Meat with Pork Meat Steamed Bun). Normally, 3 orders would be fairly easy for me in any other store. I had underestimated the size of these dumplings and how FATTY and RICH the soup instead the dumplings where. Oh also each order is 8 dumplings... 

For those who don't know what XLB (Xiao Long Bao) are... they are dumplings with "soup" inside. To go into more detail about that, they make a congealed form of soup with the cartilagenous parts of teh pig, chill it, and mix it with the seasoned meat mixture. When steamed, the gel melts creating "soup" within the dumpling. 

If you have NEVER had XLB, please be careful when eating it. The skin/wrap is really thin so try not to break it when picking it up. Also, the soup is EXTREMELY hot. So either nick a hole and pour it out into your spoon or just YOLO it and burn your tongue (so worth it) Lol 

Back to my underestimation of this dumpling. Size wise, they are probably 50% larger than my usual XLB i get in LA (no not Ding Tai Fung). Its a small family owned place ive been going to for like 20 years. The "soup"... oh man ITS SO FREAKING FATTY AND RICH... after i ate 1 order, i was half way through the 2nd.. i was like oh man.. i NEED some hot tea to help this broth go down. This has NEVER happened to me. I literally had to ask the waiter for a fresh batch of hot tea. 

Unfortunately ! it being my first meal of the day ... and it being so rich and heavy... i couldn't finish all 3 orders :( i ate 21 of 24 pieces. I mean still pretty good, but one of my fail YOLO experiences ... BUT IT WAS SOO GOOD ! Wrapper was nice and thin but not over steamed and lost its "chewy" texture. The meat was soft and flavorful with its as mentioned many times already FATTY, HEAVY, RICH soup.. 

Oh we also ordered a Shanghai Fried Flat Noodle (tho technically ive never seen it called flat noodle... in chinese, its called Shanghai Fried THICK noodle so it confused my friend when i had suggested that to my friend. This is one of my 3 staple items i almost HAVE TO order every time i go to a shanghai place. XLB, shanghai style thick noodles, and shanghai style rice cake. Those 3 items had satisfied me for years every time i went to my fav place in LA. Their version is like most with veggies, slices of pork, and lots of noodles. Flavored well and made really well. Color is a nice deep color. So yummy! 

HIGHLY recommended place to eat and try if you are in NYC's chinatown or just NYC in general. Worth the trip. Prices are REALLY good. Normal Pork XLB was 6.25 for 8.. Crab one was 8.50 i think. REALLY good pricing in comparison to other places ive been to when even a normal XLB was in the 8s..

A party of 5 visited this place on Saturday evening. The place was busy but managed to get a seat immediately. Ordered crab pork soup dumplings (super), vegetable dumplings (good), scallion pancake (not impressed), veg fried rice (good in taste but less quantity), pan fried noodles with chicken (liked it) and fish in Szechuan sauce (liked it as well). Service was quick, moderate-high priced, good experience.
Food was good but I wouldn't say is worth the hype, the xiaolongbao was definitely the best thing. If you're doing weekend lunch make sure to come before noon or you'll be waiting for a while

Quality: Over averaged
Taste: excellent
Price: Very cheap
Service: don't expect much.
Reservation is a must especially for dinner. I waited for almost 45 minutes. The waiting area was tiny. Only 4-5 people could stand indoor area. The rest had to wait outside and it was windy and freezing. We were arranged to sit with other people sharing the same 10-seat table.

My friend decided to tour a group of us around the city and took us to Joe's Shanghai.  The boys got there first and had already started waiting.  That place is busy.  After about a 25 minute wait, we were ready to be seated.

Entering the restaurant, every table had at least one basket of Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao).  We were seated at half of a large table in the back.  The other half was occupied by a family.  This was the first time that I've had to share tables in the US.  But, if the food is good, I think it's worth it.

So, by popular demand, we ordered the dumplings.  We also ordered some green beans, kung pao chicken, and rice (you know, if we got tired of the dumplings and wanted standard Chinese American fare).  

When the dumplings came out, I was excited to show my friends how to eat them.  I used the tongs to grab the dumpling by the top and moved them to my soup spoon.  Then, I took a small bite and steam from the soup came out.  I could barely wait to devour my dumpling before I remembered--the vinegar and ginger!  Added that and began tasting.  It was the best Shanghai dumplings I've had in awhile and certainly, in the United States.

The green beans were good too--greasy, but if you're Chinese, you know that you need the grease and the hot wok to make food taste that good.  Mmmm.

Otherwise, the service was horrible.  The waiters were really rude and abrupt, throwing things at your table or walking away before really listening to what you wanted.  But, it's great food, which means they have the right to be rude. . .right?

I live in the area, and pretty much on any given weekend I can see a long line just spilling out of Joe's Shanghai and onto the Chinatown streets. If you can manage, come on a weekday for lunch. You'll rarely find a line then, and even if you have to wait, it won't be long. 5-10 min tops.

Joe's Shanghai has a full menu, and you can get pretty much anything you'd expect from a restaurant serving Chinese fare. However, the star of the restaurant is the Xiao Long Bao, the soup dumpling, which appears as the first two items on the appetizers menu. Everything else is fluff (albeit, tasty fluff).

I'll usually get one or two orders of the crab soup dumplings and an order Shanghai fried rice. Shared between two people, this seems to be more than enough food, and it is plenty cheap~! 

Other than that, it's a pretty no-frills place, service is meh (but you aren't here for that, you're here for soup dumplings, remember?), and the decor is nothing special. Oh, but the walls ARE plastered with photos of celebrities that have been to the restaurant, posing with the owner. Is anyone familiar with the ancient meme, "Prancing Cera"? Well, there's a picture of Michael Cera in there wearing the same exact outfit he had as Prancing Cera, leading me to believe that the two were taken on the same day.

Anyway, look for that picture if you're a Cera fan.

This place should be 5 stars. The xiao long bao here is as good as the street vendors in shanghai. Lots of soup inside the dumpling, which is the authentic way to do it. The pork is the best but the shrimp is also ok. I've been here every time I'm in NYC, which is about 7-8 times in the past couple of years. There might be a line outside since the place is really popular. I haven't been to any of their other locations but this one is enough to satisfy my cravings. One more thing, the seating is combined tables, so you'll probably be seated with strangers unless you are in a big group of 7-8 people. Check this place out!

Come here for the soupy dumplings and do not leave until you have had one full basket. Otherwise you will sorely regret not having had your fill the next day. It is that good, and certainly worth the wait. These dumplings are by far the best. Don't be hasty in biting into the dumplings, as they are really hot and, if attacked too ravenously, will spew its hot liquid soupy insides all over the unsuspected amateur. Note that you have been well warned.

Other dishes worthy of note are the stir fried rice cakes, stir fried shanghainese noodles, and kow fu (soy sauce flavored wheat gluten). The dry sauteed string beans are also tasty and well executed (not over cooked).

I hate waiting for anything, I really do. But Joe's Shanghai always suckers me in. Soup dumplings are always hot/fresh and it's just so good. I've never had a problem with the staff rushing my groups out, even when it's slammed. Servers do often need some repetitive reminders that I ordered this dish, or that dish, but I've never had a problem otherwise.

Soup dumplings to die for.  I remember a blur of a meal with 15+ people scarfing down food after one of those Seaport shows, but there remains searing image burned into my gustatory retina of those killer soup dumplings.  Slow-mo of (cue 70's porn music bow-chika-bow-wow): biting off the chewy dough of the top, slurping brothy goodness, spooning in dipping sauce and the revelatory goodness of that meaty center.  Swoon.

BEST SOUP DUMPLINGS (Xiao Loong Bao) IN NYC!! Everything else is average. I personally love the crab meat soup dumplings more than the regular pork one. When you're here, please say hi to my mom Elaine (the cashier) :)

Soup dumplings were really amazing. But pork pan fried noodles was just ok and beef with scallions was not tasty. I would come back for the dumplings and to try hot and sour soup and beef with peppers (it looked very good on the other table). 

Environment is messy, if you are just 2-4 people you will probably share table with others. 

Service was ok, very quick but waiter didn't speak English well and was pretty rude.

Joe's Shanghai is all about one thing - 'Xiao Long Bao', also known as 'Soup Dumpling', and they have 1 main pork based version, and 1 crab (seafoody) version! The particular thing about this particular outlet is that its always tooooo crowded, very touristy and you have to always-always wait in the line to get in! I like the other mid-town location for my own reasons..but definitely you gotta come here!

Joe's Shanghai is a good place if you want XLB, soup dumplings and other northern Chinese food. The XLB is savory and flavorful with a chewy outer layer, a lot thicker than Ding Tai Fung XLB if that's what you're used to. Shanghai fried noodles come in big portions at a decent price about $8. The drunken chicken might be a little too drunk for my taste, but the it is flavorful as well.

The service is efficient here. Servers are attentive and bring out the food in a timely manner. The only issue I have with this place is the cash only policy. It's inconvenient because the food is priced more than the normal amount of cash a person would carry. Other than that, this place is a decent Chinese food joint.

Lost in New York, we yelped a possible dinner stop before going home. Stellar reviews drew us in, hunger urged us on. The pictures of all the celebrities visiting on the wall made us stay. Still out palettes can be finicky. We ordered the mu shu pork, the house special fried rice and the shrimp in lobster sauce. All were delectable. The rice - flavorful without being overpowering, the shrimp was large and tasty, and the mushu was too much for us, but we had to eat some more. Due to the confusion of our taste buds, i forgot the soup dumplings. These were exquisite. The soup was flavorful and had enough oil to make it surface while eating the meat part. Needless to say, we enjoyed our meal. Albeit it can be a little confusing to find it ( dont confuse it with joe's ginger on the same street), it is though well worth the find.

P.S.
Cash only! 2 atms available on the main st.

Joe's Shanghai is wildly popular in Chinatown. It's in a great location and can commonly be found with groups of people waiting outside for their names to be called. I am a huge lover of xiao long bao, so I was looking forward to trying them out. We went in for a later lunch and were seated right away. Despite the odd time, it was still packed. 

We ordered the wonton soup and xiao long bao. Honestly, the wontons were almost as juicy as the soup dumplings, so it felt like we were eating two variations of the same dish. Both were phenomenal. The xiao long bao was flavorful, filled with a tasty broth and had great ratios of meat to soup to wrapper. They were relatively large compared to others I've had in the past, so it's amazing that they still tasted so good. 

This place deserves the praise. It has an endless menu, which I imagine has many good things from what I could tell from the two things we tried. The staff was friendly and came by a couple times to check in, but they definitely move quickly throughout the dining room. I'm very excited to go back one day to try out so more items, but xiao long baos will always be a staple in my order.

Pork dumplings made the meal, I could have satisfied myself with these alone. We got here as soon as it opened at 11 to avoid the rush and not even 15 minutes later the place was packed. It is clearly one of the better restaurants in Chinatown, a great choice to experience the area.

Ugh I go back on fourth on who's soup dumplings reign supreme between here and nom wah. Of late, I'm thinking Joe's might be edging ahead. 

Usually has a wait at peak times. Staff are efficient though not overly helpful or friendly. Often times you end up at a table with other people. 

The food is just wonderful though and well priced. I always get both the pork and crab/pork soup dumplings. Their Lions Head is delicious! Super soft meat balls in a delicious salty sauce with baby boc choy. Yum.  Also recommend the shanghai fried rice. 

The eggplant is delicious but would only get with a big group as the portion is huge. The string beans are tasty but very very salty. 

Overall they could come down on the salt but at the end of the day I will definitely be back (and again and again and again). Their soup dumplings are incredible. I've been to the other locations and they simply aren't as good as this one.
The BEST Chinese food hands down! Look no further. What more better than Chinese food in Chinatown. FYI Only cash is accepted here.

The General Tso Chicken is THE best. -Not exaggerating what so ever. The green beans are really good. The chicken fried rice is strong. The pork soup dumplings are really good. Always a very busy restaurant. No reservations can be made. Service is fast. CASH ONLY.
Crab Shiao Long Bao and Scallion/Green Onion Pancake are the way to go here.

Finally stopped by this place after an event at a nearby university with some friends and had a pleasant experience. We came by around 10:20 not knowing that they close at 11:00 and the service was impeccably fast and delicious. For a party of 7 we got four orders of soup dumplings, pork fried rice, spicy noodles, and a crispy pork dish. And before we knew it we ended up clearing the table just as 11 hit. Only reason I'm giving this spot 4 stars is because the bathrooms were super nasty and kind of made me question how sanitary their kitchen was

I tried many restaurants in my recent week in NYC.  This is one of three that stand out so well that I wish to write reviews (the other two are the very upscale Le Bernardin in Manhattan and then Juliana's pizza shop in Brooklyn).

This place's xiao long bao dumplings are wonderful and not something I know how to find in Indiana, where I live.  We were a party of two, showing up late on a mid-weekday.  The place had a horde of waiting customers outside even though several other restaurants on the block had open seats and no crowds.  After a 20 minute wait, we were seated at a big roundtable with two other parties.   The foods were great, the service hopping and efficient, and the experience a delight.

Waiting time: 15 minutes. Not that bad.

Ordered their pork steamed bun and beef noodle. It was awesome, although we need to wait yet another 15-20 minutes. I knew it took so long due to the hectic conditions inside the restaurant. (servers were pretty much overwhelmed with orders and bills). Oh, and don't forget that Joe's Shanghai only accept CASH. Would give a 5 if they accept credits though.
Love their shao Lim bao, Shangai pan fried noodles and sauteyed string bean dish.  Been a happy patron for 7 years and I keep coming back.  Check out their ginger ale film Brooklyn.  It's memorable!
The best place to eat chinese food in NY, you have to try the shangai noodles. The place is really famous and we had to wait 40 min to get in for a table, but it was worth it.
Came here just for the soup dumplings. I'm not a soup dumpling expert but these were delicious. Make sure you know how to eat them properly before you try them!
Best Xiao Long Bao in New York.  I highly recommend.

We were surprised to be sitting at a family style table with a rotating middle portion but I have no problem sitting with other people just be aware if you hate people or something. There was no wait for us but the place was full of people, the waiters work quickly to get you in and out. The dumplings are legit and the rest of the food is very good too. Complimentary green tea as well.

During our trip to NYC, my friends and I really wanted to eat here! I'll warn you that the wait was long, the restaurant is small so there isn't a good spot to sit while you're waiting. We got seated after about 30-40 minutes, but we had to share a table with a couple, who just about finished their food and was replaced by another couple. We actually had a good conversation with this other couple who were also traveling so I guess there's a silver lining to that.

It's been a while since I've been here, but I do remember that their dumplings were good! To me, ‚Äãthey're better than Din Tai Fung, but it wasn't better than the ones from Shanghai Asian Manor. We also had the Shanghai flat noodles, beef braised soup, and rice. The couple sitting with us offered some of their scallion pancakes and that was actually really delicious and crispy!

Service was good and the prices were reasonable. If I ever came to NYC again (jk I will) I would definitely come back here.

Shanghai dumpling 
#9 - crab and pork
#10 - pork

The wait was at least 1 hr.  Was it worth the wait? It's definitely a place to try.  

What makes a good dumpling is the thin skin perfectly sealed to trap the soup. Joe's Shanghai dumplings contains soup, BUT the thickness of the skin overwhelmed the meat and soup inside.

I prefer small sized dumplings that has equal amounts of skin, meat, and soup. Joe's dumplings was a little too large that what you're eating is mostly skin and soup. Why not order noodle soup then??

Some of the best Chinese food I've had in a long time. Worth the 40 minute wait on a Sunday night. I had been dying for decent scallion pancakes for ages, and these did not disappoint. 5 people, after tip, $82. We had sesame chicken, szechuan beef, and shrimp lo mein, along with a bunch of appys. A must try!

Food was really good however service not so good at all. They also add automatic 15% tip to your bill, so to them they don't really care how your experience is. Amazing food though just maybe next time I do take our instead.
This place rocks.  Still the best around!  And their staff is very attentive.  Price is super affordable.

Dumplings are my all time favorite food, and I consider dumplings to be their own food group. These are *some of the best xiao long baos (soup dumplings)* I've ever had. Upon planning to visit NYC, a couple friends, and friends of friends, recommended I come here. While eating, I overheard a group at another table saying they were from over seas, and they made a point to come to Joe's to get their fix. I've concluded, this place is the dumpling destination in NYC...one might even say pilgrimage. With that said, I don't think there's much to say that hasn't already been said about Joe's. An unassuming name, but wildly delicious and reasonably priced. 

TIPS
+ Order the xiao long baos (note: the soup is super rich and leans towards the fatty side). 
+ Cash only! 
+Be prepared to wait.
+ Seating is family style so you will likely be seated next to other parties.

There always seems to be a line of people waiting to get in.  They'll give you a number for the wait and when you finally do get your table, you'll have to share it with complete strangers.  If you don't mind this, then the food is actually quite good.  

I recommend the sesame beef  entree and the black mushroom and bamboo shoot entree.   

Atmosphere is definitely casual.  They don't bring you glasses for the sodas.  The food was quick and the service was very good.  I would like to go back, but will do some research to determine when it's less crowded so I don't have to share a table with a family from Georgia.

We stopped here because of all of the great reviews and it did not disappoint. The pro dumplings were out of this world good! I would come back for those alone. We also enjoyed the general tso's chicken and they can adjust the spice to your taste which is nice. Everything was really good. The restaurant is crowded but they get you seated quickly. Only thing to note is it's cash only so bring some with you to avoid the ATM fees.

Ahhh! My 100th review must go to Joe's Shanghai. Love this place always, last time I came here was pre-pandemic at the Flushing location and been meaning to come here for a while. There's usually a line, so I usually just opt for another soup dumpling place in the area, but nothing beats Joe's Shanghai. The soup dumplings are perfect, the pea shoots are delicious, the chicken is perfect, and the mapodofu was great as well! I recommend everything- you can't go wrong with their extensive menu. The inside ambience is super nice and modern inside and service is quick. My mom and I did decide to wait and I'm so glad we did!

Oh the spooks of Halloween night in NYC. The crappy rainy weather as we watch goblins, clowns, and super heroes trotting along in the rainy weather. 

Great for 30minutes, but now this demon and her friend are cold and hungry. Where do we venture to before heading to the next scary Halloween event! HINT: Joe's Shanghai. 

Nothing hits the spot like puncturing a hole in the delicious dumpling and having the broth pour into your spoon as you sip the soup. Then eating the dumplings. 

Also its always entertaining to watch friends eat it for the first time and burn their mouths on the dumpling since they don't know any better and chomp on it right off the bat. 

Seating is a pain unless part of big party (so hopefully you are popular) if not enjoy sitting with strangers. 

Note: when someone doesn't tip its because the restaurant automatically adds 15% gratuity. For those who gave my friend and me the dirty look, learn to read!

The Shanghai Noodle Soup was really, really good, made with a rich  soy base, thick udon noodles, greens and thin slices of pork and ginger. The soup dumplings were plump, soupy and flavorful, not at all greasy. Service was efficient and friendly at lunch time. The bathroom was acceptably clean.  Cash only. Line stretches down the block on Fri. and Sat. night.
Best soup dumplings period. Get ready to wait in line.

I've been hearing people talk this place up for awhile now so I was glad to finally swing by!

Party of two on Saturday at 11am, no wait, they'll seat you at a large table them fill it with other patrons as they stroll in.

We ordered their crab and pork xlb and their pork xlb. Crab and pork was the better of the two, mainly cuz the meat had a nicer, juicier texture to it. 

Otherwise these are huge in size, they're overflowing your soup spoon! Tons of soup in every one too!

Make sure to bring cash as they dont take card, and make sure to come hungry.
wow, their dumplings are DELICIOUS!!  A definite must if you are in the NYC Chinatown area on vaca. I've yet to find dumplings like this back home in San Jose, but i'll keep my eyes peeled.

I absolutely love this place! The only reason I am giving it four stars is because their most famous dish (soup dumplings) are a little too oily and salty, in my opinion. I'm not sure if it was just the serving that I got but it the soup inside tasted too thick and oily, although it was still delicious but not amazing. I ordered their other dishes also, including their beef noodles and scallion pancakes (a must!). Their noodles are very flavorful and they put a lot of meat in the dish like they don't scam you. I suggest if you are having the soup dumplings, you can get the noodles and scallion pancake to share. 

The place is good for large parties as they have tables that can seat up to 8 people, however, the wait time during peak times can be about an hour so just keep that in mind. Smaller tables tend to clear up faster.

Love Joe's Shanghai. Been to the midtown and flushing location multiple times, and this was actually my first trip to this one. 

The food is just as good as the other locations. I am always amazed at just how delicious the soup dumplings are every time I get the opportunity to eat them. While the soup dumplings are the main event, their twice cooked pork is also the best I've ever had.

One small complaint. There's always a wait at all their locations. However, what I've appreciated in the past was relatively accurate wait times. For example, when they say a half hour, the wait is somewhat close to a half hour. At this location, this is not the case. We were told 20 minutes (which seemed impossible given the crowd), and it turned out to be well over an hour. If they had told us an hour from the start, we gladly would have waited, but it was a little frustrating seeing the clock tick way past 20 minutes. 

Also we were a party of 4, and were seated at a 6 top with another party. Not a big deal, but was a little unexpected.

Overall though - this place is the real deal. You come for the food and not much else, and the food absolutely exceeds the hype. I cannot recommend Joe's enough to anyone looking for a delicious Chinese food experience.

We were seated right away, but the place was packed! We enjoyed sitting with others in this atmosphere and seeing what others had ordered before us. Wound up with the soup steamed dumplings (delicious), pan fried noodles and beef (best ever), and chicken and vegetables (good, but would not order again). People sitting next to us we're raving about the crispy shredded beef. Go and enjoy!!

Some of the best Chinese food I've ever had. The menu was extensive and I'm sure there is a dish for everyone! Located in the heart of Chinatown, you don't want to miss this stop. Do note that this place is CASH ONLY before going:)

 Crab Meat with Pork Meat Soup Dumplings ($9.95) // Succulent, juicy, and full of crab flavor! Loved these and they were the best soup dumplings I've ever had. 
 Pork Meat Soup Dumplings ($7.95) // Loved these as well! A classic done perfectly. 
 Eggplant with Garlic Sauce (w Pork) (12.95) // Phenomenal. The eggplant was soft and coated in the sticky garlic sauce. Loved the flavors and textures of this dish. 
 Saut√©ed String Bean (w Minced Pork) ($12.95) // Have to get your veggies in!! Light and crunchy dish to balance the rest of the meal out.
amazing!! their soup dumplings are amazing. we came here for brunch and absolutely loved it.
Soup dumplings, cold noodles sesame paste. Got here right at opening 11- already hopping. Don't think you can go wrong with anything on menu.

The BEST SOUP DUMPLINGS in New York is at Joe's Shanghai. 

We had to wait about 40 minutes but it was well worth the wait! 

They really don't waste any table space, let me tell you that! Be ready to share your round table with strangers! But luckily the strangers we sat next to were so nice! My boyfriend was HANGRY and starving and this lovely lady next to him could totally TELL... LOL and so she even offered her dumplings to my boyfriend to curb his appetite before we got our food, and in turn we offered her some of our food when it came out as well. 

I had two of the cute personal sakes. It's lid is actually the shot glass! How convenient is that!

We had like 3 orders of the XLB or Xiao Long Bao (SO GOOD, SO STEAMY, SO JUICY) 

I really do miss them already and can't wait to come back here on my next New York Trip!

Jackpot! Finally... A hyped up place that did not disappoint. Had 6:00 reservations with a dozen of my coworkers. We were seated immediately, with only half of us there, no questioned asked, no pressure or rush to get orders in while everyone else arrived. 

We ordered a ton of food. Really, it might have been an actual metric ton. 

Pork soup dumplings (5 orders) - I won't say they were the best soup dumplings I've ever had, but they sure were tasty. Nothing bad to say. 

Shrimp and meat dumplings (10 orders) - not overly fishy at all, nice and tasty. Fan of these too. 

Squid with veggies and jalape√±os (2 orders) - really nice dish. Pleasant spice with big chunks of squid. 

Kung pao chicken - some of the best Kung pao I've had anywhere. Juicy and spicy and a little crispy. 

Minced saut√©ed squid and pork with jalape√±o (2 orders) - love this. Mixed and chopped bits of deliciousness with some spice. 

Crispy pork chop wit salt and pepper (2 orders) - not really Szechuan, but not to say it wasn't really good. It's a fried pork chop, so be wary of the bones. 

String beans with Szechuan sauce - nice spicy and tasty string beans. If you really feel like you need something green, this is the way to go. 

Shanghai fried flat noodle (2 orders) - great noodle dish. Think of giant Lo mien noodles made of spongey pasta. 

Probably 50 Tsing Tao's. 

I can honestly say there was not a single dish I wouldn't recommend; everything was fantastic. Service was attentive and I never felt rushed to order or to leave. 

Best part... Total after tax and tip came to under $40 per person. Really just  a great experience over all, and I will be back!

BOMB. Like... the best asian food I have ever had.  Soul dumplings, scallion pancakes, shanghai noodles and some beef dish - all insane. Everything they brought out looked amazing too, the fried chicken, all the typical chinese dishes (sesame chicken, chilli chicken, etc) and this full fish dish that looked and smelled incredible. Quickly turned into one of our favorite spots in the city!

Love their XLB. I am a very picky XLB eater. After coming back from Shanghai, my XLB standards have rly rocketed. But I am a fan of Joe's. Both the pork and crab ones are good. Don't bother with the other dishes. We tried their double cooked pork. Disaster. XLB only here. New location is very nice. No longer the ratchet Chinese restaurant where you need to share tables with strangers.

[Joe's Shanghai] Chinese restaurant known famously for their Xiao Long Bao. They used to have multiple locations however after COVID I think they only have one location

There is quite literally nothing better than this restaurant. I could live off this for the rest of my life. I have been to this restaurant over 20+ times now. Every time I'm in NY I have to make a stop. 

Always go for their XLB. They have 2 kinds: pork or pork & crab meat. Personally, I like the pork alone. I usually don't order off the rest of the menu however this one time I did. 

Steamed chicken w Scallions and ginger sauce 
Clams in black bean sauce 
Chinese spinach 

I know some individuals are going to comment about rude service but they have to understand that it's an authentic Chinese restaurant. They're not there to be nice, they're there to make sure you get your food and everyone is fed in and out the door. Also, rudeness is sometime a good indicator if you know a Chinese restaurant is good . Ambiance is super busy. Everytime I have been. 

Overall, 10/10. You can not go wrong with the soup dumplings. Could care less about the rest of the menu. 

https://www.joeshanghairestaurants.com

46 Bowery St 
New York, NY 10013

We came here specifically for the soup dumplings and hands down, probably one of the best I've had yet. Thankfully, we came right before the rush so there was no wait. Be sure to come right before 12, because after that, It gets pretty packed. The only weird thing was we were seated at a circular table with a couple already there, so it was a little awkward staring across from us. 

The first thing the server asked was "would you like to order soup dumplings first?" So it was obvious that this was their specialty! We wanted a light brunch so we ordered two orders of Xiao long bao, one pork and another crab, as well as scallion pancakes. 

I personally enjoyed the crab more, but both with very good. Steamed on a bed of cabbage, which played as a nice accent and addition to the meal. The soup within the dumplings were plentiful, filled my whole spoon. It was rich and savory, perfect on a cold day, and the meat was well seasoned. The scallion pancakes were nice and crisp but were a bit on the oily side. 

I'm definitely going to come back for these soup dumplings next time I'm in NY!

My friends and I got here on a weekday and the place was pretty empty. Somehow, the guy was still angry at us for not knowing what we wanted the moment we sat down. Ehh... that didn't bother me too much, but just warning some people who are extremely sensitive to waiters who like to rush patrons. (I find it to be a sign of authenticity for Asian food.)

Now to the food!
- Soup dumplings: This is my first time trying soup dumplings so I honestly have NO frame of reference for these delicious bombs of boiling fire. However, they were amazing. Gotta love the simplicity of soup broth inside a thin, delicate dumpling wrapper. It's like a reverse noodle soup. YUM.

Seriously, that's all we ordered and were happy. Be careful when eating these things because they will seriously burn your tongue, lips, throat, etc. if you aren't careful. Then you would be too numb to enjoy it! Bite into the side to let some steam out, then sip it slowly, then eat it once you feel ready.

This is a dumpling of patience, and you shall be rewarded greatly.
Best soup dumplings in all NYC. Can't rate the rest of their food because that's all we have when we go

Delicious soupy buns....i only come for the soupy dumpling...i literally sit down and order 2 orders of the crab kind, slurp it up and leave.  The rest of the menu is just okay...really nothing to sing about.  there are so many shanghai places in c-town that I only like one thing from each.  this place has the best soupy dumplings.  
don't go to the one uptown...they use the frozen dumplings there..not worth the price or convenience.  
Cons:  no credit cards, hoevering waiters...weird.
Soup dumplings soup dumplings soup dumplings. Everything else (except the brusque service) is really good, but...soup dumplings soup dumplings soup dumplings.

Love it!!! Dumplings are awesome!!
Shredded beef was great, spring rolls great.. shrimp fried rice great!

4.5 stars!

So this place was extremely hyped up by all the west coasters I know so I wanted to know how legit this place actually is...

After having some good Shanghai dumplings in Japan (close to Shanghai, but not close enough), the crab and pork ones remain to be AMAZING! The crab and pork ones are SO much better than the regular pork ones (FACT). The crab really makes it! I honestly went at some weird time so I didn't wait long at all!

I heard a lot about this place and when my husband and I visited NY, I told him we HAD to come here. We were here back around Halloween (I know it's a late review) and were seated rather quickly. We did show our vaccination cards because it was required, I'm not sure about now. I ordered the pork soup dumplings and crab meat dumplings. My husband ordered Kung pao chicken or something like that since he's not a fan of authentic Chinese dining, which sucks for him because he's missing out. Anyway the food was SO good, even the kung pao chicken. We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Customer service was 10/10, food was 10/10. I HIGHLY recommend this place!
Best dumplings, beer and customer service sucks though.  This rating is for the Chinatown location.
The soup dumplings are the bomb! Went a second time and got the beef and broccoli. Very fresh and the service is good.

Excellent food, worth the wait. Clearly, among the best Chinese food in the city.
I highly advise getting the soup dumplings. Don't order to much because it's easy to be enticed by all the amazing dishes

THE BEST PORK DUMPLINGS IN THE WORLD!! Steamy and soupy when you bite into it, so you must eat it with a soup spoon! That's all you have to order there. That's all I remember eating there even though I'm sure we ordered a lot of other things. It's always packed and you have to share a table unless your group is perfectly a party of 10. This place is on the map for a reason! We still dream about it!!

Best (or at least second best) xiaolongbao in all of NYC!

Terrific scallion pancakes, as well --- just PERFECT.

#topratecustomerserviceaswell

We came specially for the crabmeat soup dumplings. They were delicious. Sharing the round table with someone else is a bit different for us but maybe this is norm here since the restaurant is small.

Warning, cash only.

I absolutely love Joe's. It is on the expensive side for Chinese food, but the quality is fantastic and the portions are large. 

I highly recommend their pork dumplings and if you're a fried rice person you can easily turn an order into 4-6 servings. 

Most entrees I have had are the standard style of Chinese food you see in the US, just a better tasting, higher-quality, version. 

It's also worth mentioning that I've never had a bad delivery experience from here.
The soup dumplings are simply the best! They are so delicious and authentic. I crave them on a weekly basis. The service is also spectacular. Servers are kind and accommodating.

Best scallion pancake I've ever had was from here. I find myself always coming back for that reason! Of course the soup dumplings are great and well as the beef noodle soup. The prices are great as this is cash only. I think the one on upper east side prices are more expensive. This is the original location and you can definitely feel the authenticity. One thing I will say is that the service is okay, they don't really give you water unless you ask which isn't a huge deal for me but sometimes they forget even if you ask! Lol. The restaurant is a shared table restaurant which means most of the time you'll have to sit at a table with other people, so if you're not into that sort of thing just be mindful when you come here. They do have two people tables but only about 4 of them. Taking off a star for not offering srirachua sauce though

Yum yum yum!  These are by far the BEST soup dumplings I ever had.  Big, plump, flavorful, and most of all juicy!  So juicy that you have to be careful when you first bite into it.  I accidentally bit into mine the wrong way and the soup squirted into my hair (i have long hair).   I suspect that a lot of grease must be inside the dumplings though because when the liquid that got into my hair dried up, my hair became stiff as a board. But, don't worry, the dumplings don't taste greasy or anything. 
I ordered a shrimp dish (i forget which one) but even that was so good!
I had to wait in a line that went out the door, but it was worth it.

Definitely the best soup dumplings that I've had in the city. The atmosphere is definitely casual and friendly - you'll definitely be seated with another party. I recommend the pork and crab soup dumplings. They were so soupy and so flavorful. Also had the best scallion pancakes I've ever had A perfectly crispy. Will definitely be back.

visited nyc last weekend and came here for the famous soup dumplings...and man were they yummy! i ordered the pork dumplings, the carb and pork dumplings, and the scallion pancake (super yummy too!). that filled me up so i couldn't try any of their regular menu items..hence only 4 stars. also, the service could have been better (after asking the waiter 3 times for a straw i had the bf just get up and get one for me). we came here on a monday morning and it wasn't packed at all. now im back in SD and craving those dumplings!!
Best dumplings around! And all the dishes were excellent too. Somewhat of a wait but definitely worth it!!

Juicy pork buns are one of my favorite dishes and Joe's is the perfect place to get them! The buns are consistently made with a thin skin and filled with oily delicious juice. You must have them if you stop by here. I've tried other dishes here, and they're pretty standard. I'd recommend stopping by here for a snack, and then heading elsewhere for a real meal. Come early or late because the restaurant gets crowded around lunch hour! Cash only!

I think this place is great for XLB (soup dumplings).  It's not a hype.  In fact, I think this is better than the Famous Taiwanese Branch Ding Tai Fung known for the XLB (Soup dumplings) .  

I don't think every dish at this place is a sensation, so you do have to know what to get here.   XLB (soup dumplings) sure can't go wrong here.   The scallion pancakes are not bad, because they almost fried the outside of it.   Normally scallion pancakes are a lot drier than what they make here.  How can it go wrong if you fry it?     Got the shrimp noodle dish and I think that is a waste of money.  If the one noodle soup based dish isn't good, I am sure the rest of them won't be good here either.  The soup base lacked flavor and bland; not a good choice for this place.   

Didn't get to try their pan fried dumplings because the dish never came and they charged us.   When I told them we never got that dish, they were nice enough to take it off the bill.  Seriously... where did the pan fried dumplings go?     Unfortunately, I never got the try it.   I hope it tasted bad, otherwise I missed out on awesome dumplings.  boo!

So they charged us 15% service fee and is included on the bill.  I don't actually like it when people do that, because I think its rude to ask for specific tip.  A tip is a tip, and it shouldn't be set for you how much you should tip.   

When it gets busy, you have to share a table like it is in HK.

Such a long wait, not sure if its worth because I was afraid it was overrated. I got the pork soup dumplings which was much better than I expected. The dumpling skin was dying and didn't break that easily. My main dish (shanghai noodle soup) was not so good because it was very oily, I know I won't be getting fat noodle soup anymore. Maybe the dry dish would have been better and if I had someone to share it with.

The scallion pancakes were also pretty good.

when i first moved here 5 years ago, i came here on a rainy sunday afternoon and thought the soup dumplings were the best thing i'd ever tasted. i also have an admittedly weird love/hate relationship with burning my tongue (no joke), so i loved the boiling hot soup inside.

however, on subsequent visits i felt like while the price kept rising, the food quality kept diminishing. when tina c. wanted  to come here again i inwardly groaned, but decided i'd give it another shot. aaaand...

this place got better! the soup dumplings were just as good as the first time i had them, and the other dishes we had were all great! it's still unheard of to spend $15 per person on a family style meal in chinatown that doesn't contain seafood, but i was happy overall. in addition to 3 orders of soup dumplings we had the braised pork shoulder (VERY fatty),  orange beef, spinach, and a noodle dish that i really need to get the name of because it was EXCELLENT (my friends did the ordering). 

it's so nice when places exceed your expectations :)

I went for the first time maybe 4 years and I remember that they were the best soup dumplings ever. I finally went back to revisit and I think it's a newly renovated location. The indoor seating looks more modern and nicely decorated. 

The soup dumplings are huge and extremely filling! Double the size of din tai fung. they are the best when consumed while hot. I really enjoyed the pork dumplings but I wasn't a big fan of their crab and pork dumplings. I wish I got to try more of their food but i was already too full from the dumplings. Definitely a must visit if you're looking for a good soup dumpling place .

Dare I say I liked the XLBs here better than Din Tai Fung's?? (please don't shoot me... and I mean only the DTF in Cali). They are bigger than your average soup dumplings at Joe's, but that's not why I liked them. The quality of the meat, soup and skin was noticeable. And their scallion pancake is a must order! I didn't try anything else here, but there really is no need... those two things are where it's at. The only reason why I docked a star is because I hate the whole communal seating idea. It is really awkward to be sitting at a table with a bunch of people you don't know. Luckily the people at our table when we went were cool, but I can imagine if you come here often you'll find yourself stuck in an awkward situation at some point, especially if you come solo!

The soul dumplings here are delicious!! Best I have ever had in my life. The scallion pancakes are great as well. It is a popular restaurant, so do not come Friday night expecting to get a table right away.

Everything about this place makes me not want to come back. It's a tourist trap. On weekends, it's impossible to get a seat and the line is out the door, usually as a cluster.  During the weekdays, even during off hours like 3PM, there's still a line. And you can't ever sit at your own table, it's always shared with strangers.  

OTHER than that, I guess the Xiao Long Baos are decent. They are large and fat, and always look deflated.  Don't use the tongs please, unless you plan on losing all the soup (actually more like pork fat and residual protein) in the steamer rack.

Cash only. And good luck getting in.

Despite the downsides (shared tables, chinatown type service, being a little touristy), I still give this place 5 stars for the food which happens to be AWESOME.  loved the crab dumplings, which i expected to love.  also loved the pan-fried noodles, which I only expected to like.

best chinese food in the whole usa !!! the pork soup dumplings are a must and are better than any other place i've had. and i've had a LOT of chinese food and dumplings in my life. i will always return to joes whenever i go to NYC. the place is always busy but the move pretty fast so the wait isn't super long

This is the third stop of our food tour as I have heard so much about this place from my east coast peeps. 

My main purpose is to try their XLB. So, we ordered the crab XLB and standard pork XLB for the four of us. Hubby wants to try their smoked fish, but they said they ran out. So, he ordered the salted duck.  I think it's way too salty. But my hubby likes it. 

Onto to the XLB. The skin is much thicker than I thought. However, it is a very juicy XLB.  I am the only one who likes the crab one. Rest of the table prefer the standard pork one. Kiddos think the crab one tasted funky - whatever that means. 

Servers are ok.  I wouldn't say they are friendly. They are more indifference.  Overall, I would say it's 3.5 stars.  I have rounded it up to 4 stars as it's pricing is ok.  Remember it's cash only!!

Yummy Xiao Long Bao, but other menu items were just mediocre. I know there's a lot of hype around this place, even at 10pm when the place closes at 11pm. The 3 of us ordered 2 orders of XLB, one original and one with crab, an order of fried rice, and string beans. I preferred the regular pork XLB's because there was too much going on in the crab ones, but both were tasty and extremely juicy. They are the most soupy XLB's I've ever had and the thickness of the exterior was pretty good. The only problem with that is it makes the XLB's really hot so be careful!

These XLB's do not even come close to comparing to Din Tai Fung, though they're pretty good.
One of my favorite soup dumplings I've ever had. A bit touristy and crowded, but it's so yum and even the kiddos like it.

Absolutely delicious. Got the soup dumplings with crab meat- holy moly, bursts of magical goodness into your mouth & the pork fried rice- good but not as fantastic as the soup dumplings. Was busy, waited about 10 minutes or so, not bad. Cash only. Service was decent. Did feel slightly rushed, but I guess that's what happens when people are waiting.

One of the best soup dumplings you will eat on the east coast!!! It's always a fun and delicious experience when you come to joe's. First, you have to go inside and tell the person with the clipboard how many people are in your party, and grab a ticket that has your number on it. Then you wait outside for your number to be called. Be aware that waits can be extremely long especially for a big party at peak time! Then you go inside, and if you have a small group, you will most likely sit with random people, which makes things fun and interesting! I always order the scallion pancakes and pork soup dumplings. They are legit so amazing, I don't even bother to get anything else on the menu.

Yum yum yum. Delicious XLBs to satisfy on a rainy night.

The crab and pork XLB were soft and tender, and the soup was perfect. They came out steaming hot, and were a perfect pairing with the dry fried green beans we had. We also had the green onion pancake which was plentiful and devoured quickly.

The wait wasn't too bad, we put our names down and went across the street to get foot massages (at Foot Heaven!). By the time we were done and relaxed, it was time for us to be seated.

The restaurant is cramped, but you don't mind when you're stuffing your face full of tender soup dumplings.

You have to try it at least once. Think what you want about the food after you have tried it, but don't base your decision on coming here off of the ratings. That's my gift of advice to anyone reading these reviews who has not been here yet contemplating if they should go.  Some say it's the best food ever and others think it's overrated so really you can't put a stamp on it. Also, bring cash whenever you do decide to come here. No credit cards!

BUT, I will walk you through the experience. 

First off, everyone always says you can tell how authentic a place is by its customers. Well, the crowd here is always extremely diverse. Not only do I always see a family from an asian country, but there are people who have traveled from all over the world as well. There was a man that I met there once who lives in California (grew up in NY) and he told me that every time he comes to visit he makes sure to stop at Joe's before he goes back to Cali. So, that should tell you something right there.... 

In regards to the wait it really just depends on the time of day you are going. If you show up at 7PM or later you are definitely going to be waiting on a long line. I was actually in the area last night around 10PM and saw my precious Joe's Shanghai with a longggggg line! It's actually a really nice thing to see. It'll be a sad day when I don't see a line there -- the apocalypse will be coming for sure. 

If you're not in a large party you will mostly likely be seated with other people. The place is cramped with large round tables, and some small on the side. So get ready to meet some new people! 

There is a crazy amount of service staff everywhere. You can't really tell the difference between waiters and hostesses. You'll also probably be serviced by multiple people for multiple things so if you need anything don't wait for the person you think is "your waiter" because you kind of don't have one. 

You will feel rushed when ordering. They will automatically assume you want the soup dumplings as well. Seriously, that's the first thing you will be asked "pork or crab?" CAREFUL CAREFUL CAREFUL when you eat them because they are delicate here, but the skin is thicker than other places :). They also stick to the cabbage for some reason? I've only recently encountered this problem with them here, but I still enjoy the soup dumplings regardless. Oh, and the amount of soup in these dumplings is just amazing! It exceeds the amount of space you have in your spoon! This is where I learned how to eat them so Joe's holds a special soft spot in my tummy. So sentimental! 

You'll be brought tea. Not ice water. So if you want it you'll have to ask for it.... And ask for it as soon as your waiter asks you about those soup dumpling orders ;). 

The food portions are HUGE. I mean... HUGEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!! Don't even think about eating a dish by yourself you're going to share and you will be full off of the second plate even if you are sharing with other people. 

Seriously, the pace of the restaurant is so fast but don't let the staff make you feel rushed to eat. Eat at YOUR pace and enjoy it. You waited, and everyone else has to wait too! 

They add tip to the bill so DON'T TIP! I doubt they changed it. 

TL;DR
You have to do it at least once, probably will experience a long wait and be seated with people you don't know, portions are huge, service is speedy, don't add tip, MOST WILL AGREE THE FOOD IS AMAZING INCLUDING ME but you need to use your judgement on that one.  

ENJOY :D!!

I really think the dumplings are just ok.  Not as great as other people make it seem.  I went again hoping I'll taste a difference!

But this time I ordered other items.  And true story, the scallion pancakes are the best I had too.  I thought they were better than the dumplings, but my friends disagreed, thus the four stars!

The eggplants are really good but really greasy.  
their other food is pretty good! I don't know why people don't write about them!

cash only, wait is going to be for awhile and you'll end up sitting with strangers.  oh yeah don't even THINK of receiving good customer service.

GET THE PORK SHOULDER. you have to. I get it every time and everyone always looks at it and starts drooling. If I am feeling nice, i will offer to those drooling bystanders. It's a big shoulder (bone in) with a thick brown sauce on a bed of spinach for those that want some green stuff.

Braised tofu is good too.. kind of like a todo version of the pork shoulder.

authentic? i don't know but it's real good!

BEST "fresh & salted pork with bamboo shoot soup" in NYC or probably in East coast! They take time/ 40 min  to prep/ cook this soup, compared to other places' almost instant- ready versions, even look at the color of soup, you will know the difference!

I was wandering around the area and I stumbled across Joe's. Looked up the yelp reviews and decided to give it a try. Service was prompt and friendly. Restaurant appeared clean, table setup was nice and ambience was what you'd expect. It was just myself so I stuck with one appetizer. The waitstaff recommended the soup dumplings. They were delicious!! Go and check this place out. 
Tip is already added to your check when they bring you the bill.

Overall, prompt service, clean restaurant, good atmosphere and great food!

I want to cry when I think of this place. All I can say is GO THERE. 

The pork soup dumplings make my groins ache for New York City. I. NEED. THIS PLACE. Thank god for Chinatown. 

The green beans are flash-cooked in super-hot oil, making them wrinkly, weird-looking, and over-the-top tasty.

GO. THERE. NOW.

Whenever I pass by here, there's always a long line. Decided to just take it to go to see what the hypes about. 
I ordered the pork meat soup dumplings and I was impressed. The skin was slightly chewy and thin.  The meat was tender and packed with soup. Simply delicious.

this is one of my favorite restaurants in new york. 

i love it because they serve great pork and crab soup dumplings along with regular food (not dim sum like ding tai fung in LA). although i think ding tai fung has better soup dumplings... this place is great because of the variety and everything for the most part is really good. be sure to get the scallion pancakes... it's probably the best i've had. 

if you want to avoid waiting... there's a location in flushing which is much bigger.

Some of the best Chinese food I've had in NYC.  My favorite thing from here would be the shanghai soup dumplings.  It's impossible to not want to order tray after tray of the scrumptious, mouth-watering dumplings.  Whether you order the pork or the crabmeat (get this one) dumplings, they are both awesome and guaranteed to satiate your taste-buds... as long as you're a carnivore.  Their noodle dishes are also pretty awesome, but when I think of Joe's Shanghai, all I want are their soup dumplings.

The wait can be a bit of a nightmare and because they are always so busy, service can be a bit slow or rushed- but for the food, totally worth it.

I need to go back to nyc.. yum.

I had a great experience here.  Found them on yelp and just so happened to be really popular.  Always expect a wait but it is so much worth it and if you have a small party you will be sharing a table with another small party.  A little awkward but it's all part of the experience.  My favorite of the two soup dumpling was the crab.  We will definitely be coming back again.  Let's see how this one compares to San Francisco dumplings.

Love the soup dumplings. Not used to sharing a table with strangers but it makes the experience even better as you can share more! The service was quick.
The bathroom was gross!

Best soup dumplings I have ever has in the city!!! We two ordered some sesame noodle, 2 box of soup dumplings, and we were so full that couldn't finish them all. Eventually it only cost us like less than 30 bucks! The cheapest(but super yummy) restaurant experience I have ever had in the city! 
Def will come back.
The best crab soup dumplings I've had including in Hong Kong   Great scallion pancakes too

Joe's Shanghai has long had a place in my heart, ever since I was first brought here with my Chinese class. It's place was solidified when I recently had my birthday dinner there. We started as a party of 8 and soon grew to 16. The staff just kept adding chairs and bringing more cold beers. Our waiter kept pace with our growing party and appetites. The food was delicious, plentiful and cooked to perfection. We ate until we couldn't eat any more. And then we ate some more. The total bill was very reasonable, around $20 each.

The best part came at the end of the meal. The entire waitstaff brought out a plate of cupcakes (that my friends brought) ablaze with candles and sang out Happy Birthday. And when I say sang, I really mean more like screamed, at top volume. With the entire restaurant chiming in. It couldn't have been a more perfect ending to the meal.

They only lose one star because it is a hectic place, and you do sometimes have to wait.

My friend took me here for my birthday because 

1) she claimed they had the best soup dumplings in the city
and 
2) i had to have noodles, it was my birthday after all.

To say this place was tiny, is an understatement.  But it's NY!! what do you expect.  We were seated at a larger table with two other parties. (so that was a first for me) I laughed a bit because I started to think "damn, they really know how to utilize space!"  
We ordered 2 orders of the dumplings, 1 pork and 1 crab, and a house chow mein.  Both were delicious and in the end the bill was only $22 for the two of us!!! 
There was another thing I was confused on, and maybe someone out there in Yelp land can help me...... why do they pour tea on the table before they clean it?!?!

If you're looking for a relaxing, quiet meal, this is not the place to go. Chinese restaurants are not known for their service (which can be off putting for people who don't understand that); rather, Chinese restaurants they are known for delivering quick and efficient service. Joe's Shanghai is no exception to this rule. Guests sit at communal tables with other parties, which I personally don't mind. It's interesting to interact with all the tourists who are confused at what they're supposed to order and  how they're supposed to eat what they've ordered. 

Joe's Shanghai delivers quality food. The xiao long bao soup dumplings do not disappoint. I would definitely pick the pork ones over the crab ones, not just because the pork ones are cheaper, but because the the pork ones taste better. We also got green beans which were cooked to just the right crunchiness.
 
I love this place, but allot time in your schedule to wait for a seat! It is crowded most of the time with waits of at least 20 minutes.
you cannot ever go wrong with these dumplings. Grade A delicious. My only thing about this place is the food is not always consistent, however it is still good.
Love this place.. soup dumplings are only the start.. crispy shredded beef i think are even better than the soup dumplings.. cash only and usually has a line.. also table sharing is common..

Always plenty of people but it is worth it. The dumplings are very good and they serve generous portions.

But you have to sit with other random people, which can be fun.
The service is fast although often grouchy. The restaurant is bright and clean. While it is out of the way, it is a tradition to visit for the superb fried rice!

This place is still the best there is in Chinatown for good old soupy dumplings. There will be a wait, it will look like utter chaos outside. You will get elbowed by a little chinese old lady. But it is all worth it to have those delicious steamed treats.  I always get a vegetable side to make myself feel better for the gluttony - it never disappoints either. Have not tried much else on the menu.

So this was one of two best Dumpling spots I been. Please try the soup dumplings wow the broth is amazing. The noodle are pulled and cut just the way you like them. The beef pancake crispy and savory.

Love the Xaio Long Bao here. The wrapper is incredibly thin (as it sound be), so be careful when picking up the dumpling en route to your mouth, hehe. The pork meatball inside is well seasoned and the broth is delicious! Between the 3 of us, we ordered 2 trays and devoured them all (and you bet we were taking count of how many each person ate because no one wanted to loose out, haha)! We also had the Kung Pao Chicken which was tasty. The scallion fried rice, however, was a little salty and I probably wouldn't order it again. All in all, Joe's Shanghai is a great little gem in Chinatown! PS: during peak hours, you'll likely sit at a community table (which is a lot of fun)!

I've been wanting to try this place so I had very high expectations. We arrived there around noon and the place was packed. There was a wait but they got us in pretty quickly. The place is very traditional Chinese, in that they put you in a table with strangers so they can get as many people in and out as quickly as possible. 

We ordered a few items to try. We started with the Pork Fried Potstickers which were excellent. We also ordered the Crab Meat with Pork Meat Xiao Long Bao and the Chicken Pan Fried Noodles. The Pan Fried Noodles was delicious. Loved the flavor of the chicken and vegetables. My only complaint is the noodles were too thick and it was overcooked. But it helped to have the extra sauce to coat the noodles to soften it. The Crab Meat and Pork Meat Xiao Long Bao was a bit of a disappointment. I think I would have preferred the plain Pork Meat Xiao Long Bao. I thought the crab meat overpowered all the other flavors. Overall, I would recommend this place. Great food and low prices.

Maybe it's something about that former location or whatnot but the softness and delicate nature of the bao's skin did not do it justice. Still juicy inside sure, but not complete. So for $15.00 and plus cash only, there are other competitive xiao long baos in the city!

It's funny. I sat down and the waiter flips to the page with the dumplings and asks how many? 
I was about to ask "How did you know?" 
Did he have telepathic powers? Is he a mutant? Is this Asian guy Cyclops and Jean Grey's son, Nathan? 

But, I was starving, I didn't bother to ask. I just said ALL THE DUMPLINGS!!!!

But, really I ordered 8 crab and 8 pork = 16 dumplings. All the soupy goodness made me really full. I was actually afraid I was going to hurl in the restaurant. Lucky for everyone, I did...
Just kidding! 

I was fine in a few minutes. Loosened my belt in the restaurant. Rubbed my temporary buddha belly. Ah... and I had this sh!t eating grin on my face. Life is good. 

Verdict: Dumplings good. And cheap. $5 for pork and $7 for crab. And, so filling. 

I would come here again. 


Please don't steal this review, Nerdalicious. I spent 3 minutes on it.

The soup dumplings here are phenomenal, and you are wasting your time and money if you go elsewhere and eat soup dumplings.
Really nothing else to say other then that the soup dumplings here are amazing.
They only take cash which is an inconvenience I'd be willing to go through to come eat their soup dumplings.

Great spot downtown, my friend brought me here for their dimsum soup dumplings, first time trying them, loved!! Very nice environment, staff could be a bit more friendly-er, all in all we loved the food. I'd bring my family here next time if they crave Chinese food.

You can't go wrong the with pork dumplings...or any of the dumplings. The service was amazing, we went in the middle of the afternoon to avoid the wait, it was what everyone had said it would be and if I lived in NY I would be a regular. If there's a wait it's worth it.

First things first: This establishment is CASH ONLY so make your way to the ATM before arriving.
 
People have been raving about Joe's Shanghai so  made me way too Chinatown to try out their soup dumplings. This is a pretty popular place but luckily when I came in a weekday afternoon we were seated promptly. 

We order fried potstickers, crab soup dumplings and beef soup dumplings. Their potions are huge so we definitely had to take a box to go.

The soup dumplings were good and I appreciated their large side but I actually enjoyed their fried potstickers more. Since it received a lot of hype from people I had higher expectations but it was still decent. I would definitely come back for potstickers and to try other dishes.

Holy cow dumplings! I don't know how I've lived in NYC this long and never been to this place. I suggest the crab dumplings and the carp belly. 
This place is excellent.

This place is pretty good. 
The line moves fast. 
Soup dumplings was top notch
I would go back

I can never get enough. 

Their new location has so much more space but the food quality has remained the same. 

This trip, we ended up with pork XLB, scallion pancake, salt and pepper pork chops and Shanghai noodles - all top notch.

The dumpings were great here but customer service not so much. If they sit you at a big table then you'll have to share the table with other people which i thought was a little odd but I'm from the south so maybe it's just me.

Loved it! 

The juicy pork dumplings were one of the best I've had. There were plenty of soup inside each dumpling. I enjoyed it so much I came back before heading back to LA!  The crab & pork were good too but I would just stick to the pork ones.  Get the pea sprouts with garlic. It's delicious! All tables are communal. You will be seated with strangers! And it's crowded. I wouldn't recommend coming here with a big group unless you have an hour to wait around. 

CASH ONLY

When I walked in, I saw a lot of old photos of popular Asian artists who've eaten at this place. I guess this serves as good advertisement for them.

Since everyone raves about their XLBs, we had to order that. Their dumplings were large, and I couldn't believe the amount of juice/soup that was contained in every dumpling. I'd never seen that much soup through the XLB skin before.  The skin was relatively thin and there was sufficient meat inside each dumpling. We'd ordered both the crab version and the original pork version.

However, taste wise, it was good but I wouldn't wait in line to eat here.  I enjoyed the XLBs from Koi Palace in Daly City, CA more. Btw, we were lucky that we didn't have to wait for a table, since we arrived during odd hours (3-4 pm). Never the less the restaurant was still 60-70% full at the time.


Anyways,

Took some friends visiting out of states to Joes for some soup dumpling and Peking duck and it didn't disappoint. 
Services were good and friends loved the food. Win win. 
Jelly fish: 10/10
Spicy szechuan beef: 10/10 
Soup dumplings: 10/10, def order the ones with the crab meat, less dry and more soupy, texture is also better 
Scallion pancakes: 3/10, dry and no scallion flavor. A little disappointed at this. 
Saut√©ed snow pea leaves: 10/10 
Peking duck: 10/10, the skin is crispy
Overall, glad Joe's lives up to their standards and my friends were satisfied.

This was our first stop on our first day in New York City this trip. My wife found this place on yelp and we decided to take an Uber there. We walked in this place and it was a full house. The soup dumplings are a must! Our meal consist of soup dumplings, two spring rolls, Beef fried rice, beer and sake! My wife also ordered some kind of soup noodle dish but I don't know what the name of it is. Overall the experience was good our service was great and the food was excellent.

+93982093840810928019823081092 stars. 

JOE'S SHANGHAI is a MUST TRY when visiting chinatown. 
The SOUP DUMPLINGS are to DIEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE for. OGOMGOMGOMGOMOGMOMGOMGMGOMGOMOMGOMG.
Fried pancakes or whatever you call it is DELICIOUS too. 
& the give you complimentary oranges at the end. 

ajsdf;lajsd;fja;ls going back before I leave back to California.

P.S. THE WAIT IS TOTTALLLLLYYY worth it.  TRUST ME!!!!

Ok, totally worth the hype. Their pork soup dumplings are the best ones I've had in the city. They are so good you don't even need the accompanying sauce. The soup is very rich, smooth, and satisfying. Crab dumplings... Meh... Stick to the pork ones, or try just to try them. 

It's communal seating but honestly who really cares. These places are always loud and crowded anyways. Came here at 5:30pm on a Friday and didn't wait long at all. They have lazy Susan's at the large round tables, but seems like they don't rely use them, not even to put the dumplings on the table. Oh well. 

We also got the crispy shredded beef. It was awesome. Crispy and sweet just how I love this dish. Dumplings here are where it's at. Just plan ahead and come early to avoid the crazy wait.
Don't expect good service but the food is unbelievable. Order the soup dumplings...don't hesitate.

I've been dying to visit Joe's house to try some of his xiao long bao for the longest time now! It's been bookmarked on my Yelp for days, and now that my friend hustles around NYU, she finally took me and damn... Joe delivered the hot, steamy goods... woof.

It turns me on just thinking about how good the xiao long bao is here! I've seen my friends go up and down on their reviews, and perhaps it's a combination of the chef cooking that day, or how long it's been since I've had these little dragon dumplings, or maybe the fact that I think Din Tai Fung is hella overrated and needs to step down.

Yep, prob the later.

But you must try the food here. The hour long wait? Sure, but just grab some ice cream or boba before hand and you're settled. When you are seated, whether you are sharing a table or not, know what you want beforehand. The servers are busy but they try to help as much as they can considering the mob rush during the evening hours.

When you order the xiao long bao (pork or crab, either were great!), make sure you know how to eat it! Take a small bite on its side, suck it (the soup yo), and then swallow... or chew on the meat a little bit so that you don't burn your throat. Please dip it into the vinegar and ginger for an extra punch. The xiao long bao here are larger, have thicker skin, and are overall tastier.

You're still reading my review? You either have a really dirty mind, or are just hungry. I choose both.

Anyway, tag on a scallion pancake, some Shanghai Fried Noodles (which are not referred to as lo mein here), and you're all set! They even throw in some orange slices in true Chinese restaurant fashion when you end your meal.

Thanks Joe. You gave me a fab ride for my mouth... and you weren't that expensive either! Keep it up and I'll be coming back soon for round two, hun.

Came here strictly for the Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao). It was absolutely the most delicious dumpling I ever dad. The wrapping hold so much soup and the filling was absolutely amazing. I had one of each of the pork and the crab filling. Price was very reasonable, 8 dumplings for $6-$8. We also ordered an onion pancake but that's pretty much it. I would give this place 5 stars for the dumpling itself, but the service here is not very good. We had to share tables with strangers and before we even sat down the waiters asked us what we want and I was like we didn't look at menu yet and he just rolled his eyes. When we got the check to pay and signed the credit card receipt, we pour some tea to drink and the waiter literally reached between our hands to grab the receipt. He couldn't wait 3 sec for us to put the tea pot down. If it wasn't for the super delicious dumplings, I will never come back.

My go-to place for soup dumplings! Always crowded but worth to be in line.
recently found out that their chicken / peanut dishes are amazing, too.

Although they are cash only, prices are good!
This is a must-try place if you are in China town area.
