Joe's Shanghai reminds me of my dining experience in Shanghai.  I was seated in a round table with total strangers while enjoying their world famous Soup Dumplings stuffed with crab and pork meat.  Really enjoyed their super hot sweet and sour soup.

5*****S all around for the entire experience from food to service.  Can't wait to come back

LOVE IT!  fantastic selection of dim sum and usual Chinese fare all authentic and delicious! this classic NYC SPOT adds to it's atmosphere with communal table seating where you can share NYC stories (or not) with neighbors and/or tourists alike. FUN FOOD! Often crowded, if going for Sunday dim sum, get there early for a good table!

If you Come here make sure you come with an empty stomach because while I was here I ended up ordering a second order of dumplings just because there is nothing in the DC area that can compare to it. Man I really want soup dumplings again!

Yes this place is very touristy and yes the lines can be long on the weekends but they do very well on what most ppl go there for: the xiao long bao or the soupy dumplings. 

Now I can't say they are the best bc I've heard some other places in chinatown and queen's chinatown that rival these, but compared to the westcoast's reigning champ Din Tai Fung, I have to say they do edge them out slightly, mainly because of the amt of juice in Joe's dumplings and obviously the cost. 

As soon as you are seated the first thing they ask is if you want the dumplings. You have the choice of crab or pork. My fav is prolly the pork but the crab is good too but the broth can be really rich and after a few of them im kinda over it. If your with a group I rec getting an order of both (comes in 8 each). With the dumplings they are also known for their scallion pancake which isn't thing fancy but a fried asian pancake with scallions but its pretty good to snack on while you're waiting. 

I probably don't rec ordering other stuff on the menu unless you are having an all out dinner here since most dishes are family style and come in large portions. 


TIP: It's cash only and 15% tip is already added to the bill. Don't forget to immediately add ur name to the waiting list when u get there esp if you have a big group.

Now living in Miami, I have dreams about these dumplings, literally. I woke up one night from a lovely dream I was sitting in Joe's with my favorite pork dumplings in front of me. I woke up salivating thinking of those lovely morsels. Yes, they are THAT good. The soup is actually inside the dumpling with the meat. It is hard to express the love that are these dumplings. I have been here so many times and I actually have had the other food. The other food is excellent but I always pass because I want to gorge myself with dumplings. You often will see celebrities rubbing elbows with common folk. Get to know your neighbors because you eat at the same table with other diners. By far one of the best eateries in NYC. Joe's Shanghai, I miss you dearly.

This is my go to spot for soup dumplings. They have two varieties, crabmeat with pork or just pork.  Honestly, I don't see much difference in the crabmeat version, so why pay more?  I just stick with the pork dumplings.  If I'm hungry or with big group of friends, I'd go for the shanghai noodles as well, but often that's greasy, but tasty.  Aside from the dumplings, I'm not too impressed with their other food items.

This was part of our food tour in NYC and we were already pretty full by the time we arrived. We ordered the crab dumplings, pork dumplings, scallion pancakes and chicken lo me in. The clm was ok but the dumplings and scallion pancakes were delicious. Next time we'll be back with empty stomachs.

Joe's pork soup dumplings never fail to please, always friendly staff and excellent food 

They will tend to rush you and the line is ping but food is good (love the Peking duck)

Delicious Shanghai Dumplings!! aka Xiao Long Bao. In fact, it's my favorite! It's a MUST-STOP for me on every NYC city. 

People ask me all the time, how does it compare to Din Tai Fung?? In my opinion, Din Tai Fung is overrated and is just "OK". Joe's Shanghai dumplings are waaay better! They are bigger, plumper, juicier, and tastier. What more can you ask for? 

They are steamed over lettuce, so they stay moist. The broth inside is soo juicy and flavorful! DTF barely has any juice inside. Also, here, they come in pork dumplings or pork & crab dumplings. I like both, so I always order a tray of each. The price is affordable like $10-12/each tray of 8 dumplings. (Can't remember exact price, sorry). 

My only complaint is the service. (-1 star) The Chinese waiters are not that friendly or nice, but I guess that's expected of a typical Chinese restaurant! This is your typical small Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Nothing pretty or fancy. But, the dumplings are so good that it keeps me coming back!

Joe's Shanghai is like any other stereotypical Chinese restaurant.  It's staffed by no nonsense Chinese who may be a little blunt and ready to rush you out of there.  It's loud and crowded, but hey, you're not there for the atmosphere.  You're there for the xiao long bao!  We had a long layover in NYC, and decided this place was a must.  We ordered one pork and one pork and crab.  I preferred the pork and crab.  The pork was a little dry.  The pork and crab xiao long bao had the perfect amount of soup in it, the wrapper was just the right amount of thickness, and it was succulent.  Of course, I forgot that I recently had an allergic reaction to crab, and this set off another reaction, but it was totally worth it!  We also had two bowls of noodle soup, and they were delicious! Broth was flavorful, and it really hit the spot.
Incredible Chinese food, fast service, everything is good!! Expect long waits on the weekends

Soup dumplings! Best i ever had. Get them, other food on the menu comes in large portions enough for 2 maybe 3 to share i sometimes have to ask for extra white rice ( the white rice serving is small) communal seating, they will show you how to eat the dumplings. I really enjoy coming here very crowded on the weekend, during the week is best

Joe's Shanghai is the spot you bring your friends who are visiting NYC -- total tourist spot. That being said, the quality of the food does not disappoint and it's overall a stellar experience.

The location has moved from Pell St. to Bowery so trade the older, kinda funny (XLB + vinegar) smelling space for a new modern, clean look. It's in prime location and during rush hours it'll most definitely attract an impressive crowd.

Must orders:

- Scallion pancake
- Shanghai fried flat noodles
- XLBs! pork... try the crab too!

You can get most of the standard banquet-style Chinese foods here... it's all solid. Don't forget to add an overpriced veggie -- gotta get that fiber!

Our go to place when in Chinatown.  The soup dumplings are quite delicious and filling and the scallion pancakes are quite possibly the best I've ever had.  Even though I'm not a huge fan of communal sitting, the food and the prices are what always have me coming back!

Warm, flavorful soup dumplings perfect for a cold day. One of the most popular soup dumpling places in the city. Expect a 30 or so minute wait outside the restaurant. It's always packed so expect to sit at a table with other parties. 

A no-frills place that focuses on the food. The waiters come over and ask you for your soup dumpling order just as you sit down and those take longer to make than other dishes. 

I come here for their crab dumplings. Delicious and a wonderful flavor! Their pork dumplings are great as well. Lots of broth and meat and the dumpling skin isn't too thick. Thin skin which still holds in all the broth! 

Great casual, cheap, delicious meal.

Absolute 5 stars! 

This review is just for the dumplings and the service. They are known for their dumplings, so why would you order anything else! The dumplings are seriously some of the best I have ever had. Have you guys heard of din Tai Fung, very known for their dumplings. Well....I loved it here more than din Tai Fung!!! I can't believe I am saying that. I wasn't hungry when I came, so I think it tells a lot how good they were. The soup inside the dumpling was so flavorful, unlike I have ever had. 

Now, we all expect bad service at a Chinese restaurant, but the employees here are on top of it! Given the volume of ppl they get, they stay pleasant and very approachable. It was soooo busy when we came, but since there were only two of us, they seated us right away at a table with other ppl. Yes! That's a thing here. They seat you at tables with other parties. 

Oh, another thing would be the price!!!! I think it was like $7 for 8 dumplings. That is not expensive at all! Especially for that kind of quality and deliciousness! I would pay more than $7 any day! 

The bad thing about discovering these yummmmmmmy dumplings would be craving them and no way of getting my fix. ):
My goodness. I only had the chicken fried rice but it was simply amazing. I will be remembering this place for when I am in the area again.

This place is NOT a tourist trap.  Yes, the service is a bit rough around the edges, but the food, and the soup dumplings in particular are excellent.  The dumplings are quite simply one of the best things I've ever had.  They are rich and delicate at the same time, they are soft and softer, which leads me desiring something crunchy.  Despite the textural neutrality, these are just amazing little dumplings.  Not sure if I prefer the pork or the crab versions, they are both excellent .  

One piece of advice, do not order 2 orders at once, because they will stack the steamed containers on top of each other, and by the time you are finished with the top order, the bottom layer have had time to cool a bit and perhaps deflate.  Order one at a time.  Occasionally they will put a few too close together, so when you grab one, it rips and looses its wonderful broth.  Its a real bummer, you can watch the disappointment around the table when it happens.  Eating them is a bit complicated, but after a few orders I think i have it down, and it adds a bit of fun to the meal.  Take a small bite, then a small sip, but leave enough broth for the big bite with the filling, perhaps add some of the pungent black vinegar/soy/ginger mixture on the table that I happen to think is fantastic, or the red peppers in oil which is great but not hot enough.  

After that soft hot course perhaps follow up with the scallion pancakes for that needed crunch.  Also very good, hot and crunchy but not too oily.  Or change it up with a cold course.  We had the Fried tofo, which was surprisingly spongy, although packed, or should i say soaked with flavor so I enjoyed it.  The Singapore noodles were the best dish aside from the dumplings, they rival Udon for the thickest noodles I've ever had and i think they win.  Great chewy noodles with a few nice greens, another fulling and tasty dish, although as expected a bit oily.   

I can't give this place 5 stars, because every time I go, there seems to be some issue at the circular communal tables with strangers talking too loud about either their sex life or their inability to pay the bill not realizing Joe's Shanghai only accepts cash, welcome to chinatown.   I understand that sitting at these tables is the price we pay for such amazing food and its just part of the experience, unless you are the lucky enough couple to get the table for 2 by the door (you are MINE next time!), so I wont dock them too many stars for that, but it does dampen the dining experience a bit.  If you have 7 people and can get an entire table by yourself, I suggest ordering a bunch of dishes, most importantly the soup dumplings and share it all.  Very highly recommended, if you can stand the awkwardness of the communal table and the mediocre and sometimes rushed service.  I look forward to returning to try the Razor Clams.
First time visiting Joe's Shanghai.  Their crab and pork soup dumpling was pretty big compared to other places.  You can definitely taste the crab.

Do you like wonton packets of heaven?"

These soup dumpling blings that everyone is talking about are actually really good.  I bring all my "out of towner" friends to this place, and it always is a hit.  I wouldn't make a habit of eating these luscious things that ooze possible lard-like substance that promotes post orgasmic spasms.  And yes, everyone has their techniques which is always fun to watch and marvel.  But ask the busy wait staff, what is the freshest vegetable that is in season or fish as well.  Sometimes it pays off to order off the menu.  But I am a big fan of the chicken rice cake thing.  It reminds me of thinly sliced Japanese mochi noodles - and always filling.  And my friends always seem to want to get the Singapore Curry mei fun - I have a weakness for it as well.  But if you just stick to 2 stacks of steamed soup dumplings, you won't go away unhappy.  Mange, Mange!

Must go for the soup dumplings!!!

We also got the eggplant and pork and it was amazing. Service was fast.  Don't miss this spot!

Best soup dumplings I've had in America! 

I lived in Shanghai for a year so I've definitely gotten a taste of the best from the original creators. 

The skin of the soup dumping was just the perfect thickness, not too thin as to where all the soup would leak out, but not too thick as it would be tough to chew either. It was a good balance. The best skins do the job of holding the soup and meat together, adding a slight chew, but not changing the nature of the dumpling and making it taste too starchy. 

The pork and soup was simple, but absolutely delightful. The best is that after the savory tastes passed, the soup brought a slightly sweet after taste, making you crave more.

Seriously, don't come and not order the soup dumplings. It's a must!

My favorite place for pork soup dumplings!! Fair warning - it breaks easy.. so have your soup spoon ready!!! Thank goodness there's ALOT of juice in it!!! We also ordered the egg plant dish, sesame chicken, and Sichuan beef which were all good. Will definitely come back.

The soup dumplings are a must have. They are very hot (like they should be) so be careful when you first eat them. Another thing I would recommend are the scallion pancakes. It's very basic, but you can never go wrong with them. Joe's is generally very busy so depending on how many you're with, your seating might feel a little bit cramped.
Soup dumpling heaven! Enough said. #1 in NYC

Have you met my friend Cathy H? She wrote a really great review of Joe's Shanghai where she offers step-by-step directions on how to eat Xiao Long Boa(see here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/joes-shanghai-new-york-2#hrid:TeX-A9rZ5es92mHEJv8xOQ). 

First let me say, you MUST eat at Joe's Shanghai, when in NYC Chinatown, and like other yelpers have said the one thing you absolutely must get are these dumplings. They are a rarity on most menus (at least in DC) and the ones they make here are superb.

I took Cathy's list of directions as a table side reference on my last visit to Joe's Shanghai, because every time I have eaten here I managed to make a big sloppy mess of myself. If you're shy about how to tackle eating a delicate soup filled dumplings, I recommend printing her review out and bringing it with you.

Be aware that Joe's Shanghai seats people family style, so if you come in as a pair you will most likely be seated at a big table with others. Normally, this is not a problem, but you have XLB dysfunction like I do, you'll get performance anxiety at the thought of eating this delicious yet technically complicated dumpling in front of other people, particularly if you're non-Asian. This might be a result of my many years under the watchful eye of my former Asian Mother in Law or the fact that I am not familiar with foods that gush. 

Every single other person in this restaurant, manages to eat their XLB with such grace, gently lifting it with tongs, biting small holes and sucking out that delicious broth like a freaking dumpling vampires. They finish their entire basket of dumplings with a clean white plate and table cloth under them. I complete a bowl of dumplings with pants and shirt covered in broth, my plate overflowing in broth, and with a table cloth with soup slaughter stains all over it.

So if you're not as skilled as 99% of this restaurant is with eating XLB, I now present my own instructions for eating XLB:

Step One: Wear a dark shirt and pants
Step Two: Walk in and be seated with other patrons.
Step Three: Order either pork and/or pork with crab XLB, request 2 additional cloth napkins.
Step Four: Make sure other dining patrons are not watching and judging you.
Step Five: Grab XLB from basket with tongs, accidentally puncture the top, place on spoon 
Step Six: Act like you know what you are doing and puncture a small hole with your mouth, try to suck out broth (which is thick and oily, and flavorful).
Step Seven: Scream cause it's hot.
Step Eight: drop dumpling on plate, watch broth ooze from all the dumpling puncture wounds
Step Nine: Make sure other dining patrons are not watching and judging you.
Step Ten: Grab injured XLB, spoon sauce on it and shove in your mouth
Step Eleven:  Scream cause it's hot.
Step Twelve: Repeat steps 4-11 for the rest of the remaining 7 dumplings.

Despite the mess and extra laundry to do, these dumplings are amazing, and worth it. I can't wait for my next trip!

Pork soup dumplings were good but quite big and slightly difficult to eat. Pork friend rice was dry and did not have much flavor.  The crispy beef was well balanced flavor wise.  Crisp pork chop was great !   General Tso's was just okay.  Service was attentive.  Tight quarters with seating. They definitely pack people in there .

It was a casual Sunday night and while things in Chinatown seemed to be slowing down just a tad, you would have thought the line outside Joe's Shanghai was for the launching of the iPad 6.0. Their waiting system is actually pretty efficient, as they give you a ticketed number, you put your name down and (hungrily) wait it out until your number is called.  For as many people as there were crowded outside, the wait was only about 30 minutes--they seriously get you in and out and on with your night without making you feel rushed. Even if you do want to stay there all night to eat up all the soup dumplings they've got in the back. 

I honestly think that if you only ordered the soup dumplings you would be thoroughly satisfied.  This is not to spurn the rest of their menu (because everything was extremely satisfying) but it is to say that if you only have a limited amount of time in New York like myself then you want to over-compensate for the fact that you may never encounter dumpling like this again, hence the necessity for five orders of the mixed (pork and crab) dumplings.  You want to slurp and savor those joyful delights of packaged wonder and then do it ten times again. If you don't care about having lots of variety at your meal then yes, order only the soup dumplings and be shameless about it.  We also ordered the baby bok choy and mu shu pork that you fold into the pancakes. Again, all Chinese dishes to die for.  

It's communal seating so don't be prissy and shy about eating amongst strangers. If anything, it makes your meal that much more enticing because you notice that old school families know exactly what to order and oh look! They also ordered three rounds of soup dumplings. They totally know what's up.  The service is very fast and runs with the efficiency of a well-oiled machine. Reasonable prices make this one of the best meals I've had in New York.

Believe the hype!   I'm not sure why fellow yelpers aren't giving this place high ratings.  The food is so good!!   I like seasoning and spice and despise bland food.  If you want watered down food, go elsewhere.  But if you want good Chinese food, huge portions, good prices and amazing soup dumplings, go to Joe's Shanghai.  We went on a Friday night and we had to wait about thirty minutes to be seated.  It was packed inside and out.  There were 4 of us, 2 of whom were Chinese, and we sat at a table by ourselves.   Yes, the place is cramped and it definitely is not the most lavish place, but the food is excellent! Our hostess was nice and the servers were attentive.  

We had 2 orders of Xiao Long Bao(and we ate all of them, 4/person, lol), pork and crab & pork, I preferred the plain pork, but the crab & pork dumpling was fine too.  We also ordered a ton of food, all of which was delicious: I highly recommend the Orange Beef, the  Shanghai Fried Flat Noodles and the Mu Shu Pork.  A couple of things to note: almost as soon as you sit down, a server will ask you if you want soup dumplings, just know before going there whether or not you want them--they take time to prepare as they are handmade.  Also, this is not a place for lingering, when you are done eating, the servers will want you to pay, so other people can sit down, so just keep that in mind.  I will definitely go back to this place very often and it's not even remotely close to my apt.

Joe's Shanghai is by far my favorite "Real" Chinese food Restaurant in (China Town) NYC. The Place is a little "Overrated" but definitely the best Chinese Food your money can buy. The Place is always packed, there is always a wait of 20-30 minutes, and always a line of people that spills out the door into the Street. Your Patience will be rewarded. Once your number is called, you are entering a Frenzy, the Restaurant is always super packed, you are guaranteed to sit in a table with complete strangers, Its cool I've never had a problem with it, just a bit awkward lol. There "Soup Dumplings" is a must, its the first thing the waiter asks you when you are seated, "what kind of dumpling"" Ordering these dumplings is a must. We always order the pork & crab dumplings, they come out hot and Steamy served on a steam tray, the dumplings are full of Flavor Liquid and just pop in your mouth with flavor, they are literally full of soup and are to die for, but careful because they are so hot that i always burn my mouth lol. They have an extensive menu, everything I've tried so far is pretty good, Beef with Scallions, Shrimp Fried Rice, Pan-Fried Flat Noodles and Seafood, Salt & Pepper Pork chop etc. The Staff is very attentive and service is pretty quick. This is not the Typical place where you sit for hours and spend time conversing and sipping your wine or eating desert, You almost feel the common courtesy to eat rather quickly to give courtesy to the 100 people waiting in line outside for their turn to enter and take your place next lol. That overall decor of the restaurant is not fancy, the Atmosphere is Lively, (Very Busy). I recommend this place to anyone who is interested in eating "Real" NYC Chinese food in China Town.

My friends and I went here for our friends giving last year and my I can't wait to go back this year.

So this place is in the back streets of Chinatown which kinda made it hard for my friends and I to find, but we were very glad we did. The wait was about 20 minutes which wouldn't have been bad if it wasn't pouring outside and the only place to stand and wait was outside the restaurant not ok when your umbrella is flying away and you weren't weather prepared.

Anyhow we weren't able to be seated until all of our guests were present which made the wait a little longer, which was our friends fault. When we were seated we were immediately greeted by a waiter and he took our drink orders. The only problem was that we could barely understand him and vice versa ( good thing our friend spoke Chinese because One of my friends was allergic to peanuts and the waiter couldn't understand that in english.)

The food was amazing we literally ordered 2 orders of Pork, Chicken and Beef dumplings, 2 orders of rice (fried rice, and chicken fried rice) The shredded pork soup was phenomenal! For approximately 8 of us the food portions were average and it did leave me personally full.

The drink variety is slim but the food variety is amazing. We're having our annual Friendsgiving there again this year and I can't wait to try the duck this time!

We ordered:
+ Bok Choy: I needed some greens during my trip. It's not on the menu but they offer it.
+ Scallion Pancake: we could have done without this but it was so crispy and good. Since it was fried, this pancake filled me up in the beginning.
+ Pork Dumplings (XLB): These were the first XLBs I have enjoyed other than my favorite (Din Tai Fung). They are massive and hard to "plop" in your mouth. I made a mess several times; trying to open the dumpling, pour the soup in my spoon, or even just placing the whole thing in my mouth. It was a quite an embarrassing moment... but I looked at others and they too were also struggling.
+ Crispy Shredded Beef: hands down a favorite dish of the night. It came with a small side of broccoli which was nice for an added green vegetable. 
+ Fried Noodles: This "chow mein" like dish was delicious. Super oily but filled with cabbage and chicken which was delicious.

Hubs and I clearly ordered more food than we could eat on our last night in New York. I wasn't really watching the food come out and assumed the plates were fairly small (comparing it to DTF). Yeah, no. These are fairly large family styled plates. I highly recommend to not order the amount we did unless you want leftovers. They packed our food really well and we were able to take it back home with us without any spills or even a smell. It warmed up well and tasted just as delicious.

I recommend checking out Joe's Shanghai if you have the time. And by time, I mean roughly 30+ minutes to stand outside until they call you inside to wait some more until your table is ready. Cheers!

On a rainy night in the city, this was definitely a great stop. There was a short wait, and you may have to share your table with strangers, but sucking the broth from those pork dumplings was awesome. Is this place better than Din Tai Fung in Cali...not quite, but close. Their dumpling were a bit too thick skinned for me, yet they are larger in size. Also, the meat mixture in Din Tai Fung's is better, and at Joe's, they don't have the red vinegar with ginger.

not too good of service because it was so busy but the food was AMAZING!!!! I am soooo addicted to it! I want it again! and again- This is a great place to people watch as well 

xoxo Jenna

We went back here again after going to Top of the Rocks. we went here at 10pm (they close at 11pm) and it was still packed! thankfully we didn't have to really wait.. AND we got our own table this time (last time we had to share a table with a group of people). 

We originally were gnna try the other Joe's Shanghai that wasnt in Chinatown.. but we noticed that they give you fewer number of dumplings and charge you more. Instead we went to Joe's in Chinatown.. and it was well worth it again! Definitely one of my favorite spots. Tastes great on a cold night!

I am so glad I came to Joe's Shanghai! I had seen several recommendations on both yelp and YouTube. The food did not disappoint! It was very busy when I went alone at about 2:30 but I was seated immediately at a community table. There were several couples at the table and I had a great conversation with a man traveling from Germany. 

I read a recommendation for the pork meat soup dumplings so that is what I ordered. They were FANTASTIC! 

I was wishing I wasn't alone so I could share multiple dishes.  Several of the other couples at my table ordered noodles which looked and smelled amazing! I am definitely going to bring my husband back here for dinner to try the lo mein and sesame chicken!
Dope as fuck, get racks on racks on racks of soup dumplings and then leave. Theres no need for an entree. The crab one sometimes tastes kind of fishy, so get the normal one to be safe.

Soup dumplings were great (definitely better than average) but the fried rice and house chicken (basically sweet and sour chicken) were both super average.

Cash only!!!

YUM this place is so goooood. I only recently discovered Joe's Shanghai after four years of living in the city and it could be my biggest regret yet. Their xiao long bao are the best I've had in the city. I definitely prefer the pork over the crab, although for some reason everyone I know feels the other way. And yes I HAVE tried other things on the menu, although I admit its reallyyy hard to get past those dumplings. The Yang Chow fried rice is tasty and not too oily. The Shanghai Fried Noodles are tasty too, but I wish they'd have a little more veggies to balance out all the dark sauce. The scallion pancakes were meh, but that's how I feel about almost all scallion pancakes.

Random non-food related tips: Cash only. 15% tip is added but they make that pretty clear on the bill. Communal seating, dont be scared. And the waiters are actually really nice once you get over the fact that they're rushing you (seriously, their turnover rate is unbelievable)
Best soup dumpling place in china town for sure. the place is always crowded. i went there last sunday, the wait was like almost an hour but it was definitely worth. going back again!

I have been wanting to try Joe's Shanghai for years now. Finally, I was able to make it down to Chinatown to try the soup dumplings.

We got to the restaurant and the people at the "front" asked us if we wanted to wait (about 20 minutes) or sit at a shared table. We didn't want to wait so we sat at a 6 person table and ordered quickly.  I do have to say that it was a bit awkward at first but we got talking with our neighbors.

We got the scallion pancake as an appetizer and the pork only dumpling and the pork and shrimp dumpling. The scallion pancake was crispy and well cooked bit I just wished it was a bit warmer.
Both dumpling orders (most of the dumplings with the exception of a few that were punctured) were filled with delicious broth. The dumplings itself are larger than the kind I have had at Din Tai Fung and definitely more soup (in those that were intact). The soup was fattier also. 

I was disappointed that some dumplings were broken and the soup had leaked out.  

Definitely worth making your way down to Chinatown to try the soup dumplings!

I still dream about these dumplings!! I want to go backkkk! I've tried soup dumplings in so-cal and Joe's Shanghai totally wins in flavor and taste!! We tried both the pork and crab soup dumplings....i personally liked the crab ones better because they were more flavorful to me, but my friends really liked the pork ones. The dumplings are very large with a lot of soup filled inside and only $5 for each batch.

This was definitely an experience for the books. I truly had no idea what I was getting into when I brought my girlfriend and family here based on the yelp reviews. 

We followed our yelp map deep into Chinatown, where the streets smell of fish and garbage and you stick out like a sore thumb if you're not Asian. When we were in sight of the restaurant, I knew that we had to be in the right place because there was a crowd of people waiting outside to get in. 

There was a 'Hunger Games' sort of vibe in the air as the hostess walked out with her list every 10 minutes or so and everyone in our group prayed that she would shout out our number so that we could come inside, away from the garbage and fish. I thought that I heard her call out our number and I shouted, "I'm here! Number two!"  And I ran to the door. She didn't even look and said, "wrong number, we number three." I turned around and walked back to my spot in shame with my head hung low.

After 30 minutes of waiting in the alley we were finally called. Honestly, it was pretty weird inside. They had us sitting at a communal table, which I had heard about, but somehow figured that it could not possibly happen to us. Yup, there we were, with two Asian families that seemed to know the drill here. The waiter came up and asked not, "Do you know what you will be having tonight?" But, "Which dumplings do you want, #9, or #10?" My father was dumbfounded, and had a "what the heck are you talking about," look on his face. We ended up settling on the #9. (They are famous for their dumplings, and we did know this before we entered.) The waiters were very weird... to say the least. One of them kept leaning on my dad's shoulder while her surveyed the room. It was so bizarre that it was actually very funny.

Let me just say that these were the best dumplings I've ever had. They were served in these wooden circular dishes that they were likely cooked in as well. The broth inside of the dumplings was unreal. Seriously, amazing!

My parents had the fried rice and pork shoulder. I did try both. The pork shoulder was very tender and had some great flavor. The fried rice was too greasy, I didn't like it. Sadly, the experience left Elizabeth (my girlfriend) without an appetite, so she didn't eat.

As we were finishing, the waiters began hustling us to get out. They must have asked if we were done three times before we were even done eating.

To be honest, the dumplings really saved the day here. They were so amazing that they really overshadowed the rest of the experience's flaws. For the record, everyone else hated this meal... I thought it was incredibly entertaining and funny.
Oh how I miss you, soup dumplings!
The food was good and the wait is long but it goes by fast. The service was good and the food came out pretty fast. I recommend it.

Very busy but not a long wait. Family style seating if your a couple of two. Dumplings and stuff ordered by a friend. I will report soon. Some kind of pancake.. lol it's GOOD.  Dumblings are very hot( temperature) but GOOD!  Walk over or Uber. Definitely a stop if you are in NYC.

Came here on 3/3/16 and thank goodness my coworker dragged us here.  We walked! Walked a good 5 miles to get to this place thinking it was closer.  This restaurant is located in an alley of China Town.  Cobble stone streets that gave it an old world feel, pretty cool! We didn't wait too long to be seated.  Our table was a communal table, meaning we shared the round table with 2-other couples.  Which can be awkward.  We ordered two different dumplings.. and they were juicy, hot awesomness.  Loved them!! we also ordered a few other items but they were did not impress me as much as the dumplings!

The place is small, and cash only!  Take a look at the photos on the wall, many celebs have dined there!  Would come here again when in town.

*** 4.5 stars ***

After complaining about how there's no good Chinese food in NYC (at least in the borough of Manhattan) I stand corrected. We ordered Joe's on Christmas Day and everything we had was excellent. I ordered online and made a mistake (accidentally ordering two eggplants) and wanted Moo Shu Chicken but the platform only offered pork, so I called them after placing my order and they were able to switch out the extra eggplant for green beans and switch the meat on the Moo Shu. The gentleman on the phone was very patient and helpful due to it being probably their busiest day of the year. He said that it would take a while due to how busy they were, but it was only about 35 minutes before our take out order was ready to pick up (even though the duck alone was supposed to take 40). We arrived to a huge crowd waiting outside for a table - great sign.

For 3 of us (and leftovers for many meals - they gave us serving ware for 10...):

Peking Duck Half 30
Snow Pea Leave 20
Moo Shu Pork (Chicken) 19
Shrimp Pan Fried Noodle 20
Pork Dumpling (8) 12
Eggplant with Garlic Sauce 17 
Sauteed String Beans 17
House Special Glazed Crispy Chicken 23

The duck was a great price and my only complaint is that the skin was a bit fattier than I would have liked. Definitely on the pricey side at ~$20 per dish including veggies, but this is NYC after all. Our favorite dish was probably the House Special Glazed Crispy Chicken - it had an orange chicken/ general gau's like sauce but was larger pieces of quality chicken meat than either of those dishes generally is.

A definite NYC favorite!

I came where because of what I heard from others and the plentiful Zugat awards the restaurant has received. My family and I ordered 2 different types of soup dumplings - the pork dumpling and the crab dumping. The dumplings were delicious and so was the soup inside. One thing I recommend is not to order to much. We ordered about 6 trays for 8 people and that was way too much. I believe most people can eat around 3-6 dumplings before you are tired of it so order wisely.

I've only ever head soup dumplings in Boston's Chinatown, so I can't say that I have much to compare to. However, the pork dumplings and the crab dumplings I had here were great! The service here was pretty quick as well, which I appreciated. I also recommend getting their fried rice, as it wasn't too salty and it was a great way to fill up after having some dumplings. Don't forget to sprinkle some of the black vinegar on basically everything! Also this place is cash only.

Get the xiao long bao, and nothing else! Joe's Shanghai has been bookmarked for years and I finally got a chance to try it after my third time in NY :). 

Came here before our Peter Luger reservation lmao but had to squeeze it in since I really wanted to try. 

We didn't have to wait around 4pm and since the xiao long baos are so popular, when you're seated they already ask if you wanna place an order so they can start prepping them. 

We also tried the Peking duck and maybe I'm a Peking duck snob but it wasn't good. The crepes they give you to wrap the duck were more like full sized tortillas. I'm used to crepes half the size, and much thinner. The Peking duck skin was good but the meat was dry.

Would opt to just get the dumplings next time if we come back. 

Cash only, of course!

In this day of COVID, they do a pretty nice job at their new location.  The tables are definitely spaced apart and the servers aren't pushing you out which is a nice change.   The bathroom is down a steep set of stairs so that's something to consider if this is a challenge for you or a friend.  The soap in the bathroom is about 1 part soap to 30 parts water so be sure you have hand sanitizer with you (there's was empty).  We had a nice experience and I'm glad we went.

Loved everything about this place. The service was fast and the food was fresh and delicious. The soup dumplings are definitely to die for. Juicy and tasty. Crispy beef, pan fried noodles, fried pork ribs are amazing. Definitely go there again
Very good food. Cash only, just fyi, but there is ATM available. 35 minute wait to get in for lunch, but service was quick after that.

I would give it a 3.5 star if I can, but yelp don't have the option. Don't get me wrong, the food is still good, but I guess I was disappointed because my new york friends set a high expectation for me since they always boo-booing Chicago's chinese food.
1. soup dumplings (xiao long bao), we got the crab meat one, well it doesn't taste like crab meat, maybe it just has high pork meat to crab meat ratio? the size is huge, so $7-8 for 8 dumplings is a great deal. tons of soup, but I don't feel the dough wrapper is thin enough and the soup is not as savory. it didn't give me the euphoria when the soup burst in my mouth that I had when I was eating soup dumplings at Lao Szechuan in Chicago.  The spicy whole fish is good too. but be careful because you need to be good at teasing the meat off the bone. 
2. atmosphere: super crowded and you will have to share tables with other parties. they don't take reservations for party less than 10. so on a Sat night you will have to wait for ~15-20 mins. 
3. service: pretty fast and friendly service compare to other restaurants in Chinatown, but the waiters might come off as impatient (its understandable tho, considering how busy they are and how many tables they have to deal with).

What a treat it was to come here! The place was bustling with customers but I was seated rather quickly, only waiting a total of about 15 minutes. 

I wasn't expecting to sit with a table of random people (that's how small it is and how packed it gets), but it wasn't an issue and everyone either socialized or kept to themselves. 

The service was okay. No water is provided unless you ask, and it took about 10 minutes to get my sprite. The food however comes out in a timely manner, even fast I would say.

We ordered the crab/pork soup dumplings, the pork soup dumplings, the lo Mein, and the kung pao. The crab/pork soup dumplings were amazing. I've had better in Philly, but a close second for sure! The pork soup dumplings were just okay, def tasted different than the crab ones which sometimes some places skimp on the crab and you can't tell the difference. The main dishes were AMAZING. I wasn't expecting this place to wow me outside of the soup dumplings but the kung pao was some of the best I've ever tasted.

I'll be back!
short wait and the staff was friendly. After a very hectic day, we ordered dumplings and two entrees. The chicken was really good and generous portions.

So I've been to the one in Flushing. And it was very good. Joe's in a Chinatown for the win! Amazing meal (even despite the wait during the Christmas Day rush.) soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, crispy beef. Definitely recommend!
Good food, but a bit crowded. Service is also inconsistent (i.e. they may stop by intermittently, but you can usually catch someone's attention).

Its been 4 days since I've had Joe's dumplings and it doesnt feel nice. Ive had Shanghai Dumplings IN Shanghai and I don't remember it being as good as this!!!!
You must order the scallion pancakes....I couldn't stop eating them.
The soup dumplings here are unreal. The fried dumplings are fantastic. Service is fast and efficient. Great food and dining experience.
Wonderful food! Soup dumplings are spot on and the scallion pancakes are worth it too!

Must try: dumplings! I went to shop in new york for the day and was unhappy because my boyfriend rushed my time there so we can go eat here.  So, i wasn't in the mood for anything basically.  Our friend ordered 4 things of dumplings and told me that I must try them, and so I did and that's when I fell in love!! Its something about them: the sauce they serve the dumplings with, the hot steamy bamboo baskets they had them in, everything was perfect.
This place is very crowded, we had to share a table that's how crowded it was (but i guess that's how all busy NY restaurants are?).  I'm usually very impatient, but for the dumplings i didn't mind waiting  a little.  I will try to make it to this restaurant every chance i get now. Awesomeness.
The best soup dumplings in the world!!! I come to New York just to have some!!! Every bite is an orgasm and you won't forget it!!!! HIGHY RECOMMENDED!!!

My Favorite spot for Chinese food in NY...Yes its crowded and I've had better service at other places, so if that really bothers you get your food to go or delivered...because this place makes great food! The soup dumplings are a must order, I also like the shanghai fried flat noodles, crispy duck, and chicken and shrimp in plum sauce.
I have never had a bad meal here, and I go often! In/Out vibe, no frills. Wine is low quality but delish! Fast Service. Sometimes a wait, but worth it!

this place is a small whole in the wall in new York's china town. it was a couple blocks for the subway but worth the walk. if you're with a small group, expect to be seated with strangers. this is my first experience and I'm quite positive that others were a tad uncomfortable eating face to face with strangers too. i love the soup dumpling here, especially the seafood one. It is so juicy and each bite (for me) was tastier than the other. I like to eat it with chili oil and dip it in the vinegar soy sauce they offer. the lo mien is yummy too. i was so stuffed from the hot and sour soup and dumplings that i couldn't finish the lo mien.

in terms of cleanliness, it reminded me of any type of Chinese restaurant in china town. the service was prompt but the waiters have heavy accent.  this was my second trip there, and it wont be my last.

CONS: not the classiest joint in town, not very friendly staff, and it's cash only
PROS: fast service, you only have to tip 15% since it's already included on each check, and awesome food

I've had the soup dumplings, the sesame chicken, the fried rice, the lo mein, the chive pancakes and the duck. I've also had the sake here. It's very yummy. It's a place to go for the food not the dining experience.
Great dumplings, a classic in NYC. Usually feel a little full/sick after a big order but it's worth it....

Went here last night with my bff's family. We got our ticket and the lady said it'll be a 40 minute wait. Turned out to be an hour and 30 min wait. At this point we had no patience. When they called out our number, everyone waiting outside clapped for us since it was our turn after waiting for so long!! We ordered 4 boxes of pork soup dumplings(8 pieces in a box), Sea Bass, and spicy shrimp with broccoli. Everything was delicious. Place is super busy so go early!
whenever i come to nyc, i always need a trip to joes. just give me a basket of xiao long baos and i'm good to go. the soup inside one dumpling fills up a whole white soup spoon. juuuicy!

Last week, my boyfriend, friends and I went to a horrific Shanghainese restaurant called 456 Shanghai Cuisine and ate unpleasing soup dumplings. I always wanted to try Joe's Shanghai and tonight my boyfriend and my best friend decided to go eat. I love trying food with them, because they're opened to trying most new places and food as well!

It was semi-busy when we got there around 6PM. I was still a little stuffed from my lunch, but I had room for a light dinner. We had three bamboo steamers of soup dumplings. We had two pork soup dumplings and one crab & pork dumplings.The soup dumplings were voluptuous, plump, delicious, hot, and heavenly! These were about the standard size of a typical soup dumpling.

 As soon as the soup dumplings came, I was breathing in that heavenly scent of soup dumplings. It felt as if I was getting a facial. Any way, there was real meat inside and broth was just excellent! I took my sweet time savoring it!  The crab & pork soup dumpling was a little mediocre because we didn't really taste the soup. I'm not sure where it went. 

We had two plates of scallion pancake. It was golden brown, crispy, crunchy, and I felt as if I was getting a foodgasm because it was one of the best scallion pancakes I ever had. We also got a plate of beef fried noodles. I am not sure if that's the actual name, but I couldn't quite finish my portion cause it was so fattening and so much noodles! I almost fell into food coma because of the food, my boyfriend and my best friend just kept piling food on my soup spoon and plate. Thanks a lot guys!

Overall, a great dinner experience with top-notch service and dirt cheap! The total came out to $44.23, which isn't bad because we had 2 plates of scallion pancake, 3 plates of soup dumpling, 5 cans of soda, and 1 plate of noodles! Great food and Great company, really go hand in hand. It's been a while since I came upon a great restaurant in Chinatown, but I've got to say Joe's Shanghai won my heart. I will definitely return here! 

Yay for Joe's Shanghai!

I don't know many other places where you can go to eat for $80 for a group of 7 people. The line was a bit crazy (lots of tourists and we waited 40 minutes on a Sunday at 7pm), but I'm really happy we waited! Our waiter was so sweet and helpful with vegetarian options.

here's the thing.

i'm not a jew. but i do hang out in new york for the holidays.  

and, you know what? i feel you have to have a "go to" jew for christmas night. 

and michael f. is the one....his review is so spot on.


"Jewish Christmas@ Joes:

Fan-f*ckingtastic.

Yes, there was an hour an a half wait. It was worth every minute.

We had:

1. FOUR orders of crab and pork dumplings. 
2. TWO orders of General Tso's Chicken
3. TWO orders Jumbo Prawns with Meat Sauces.
4. Beef with Scallions
5. Twice-cooked pork
6. Orange beef.
7. Some noodles (enhanced with pork, of course). Don't remember the exact kind, but they were fantastic.

BADASS.

Kill me. Kill yourself. Kill everyone you know.

NEXT YEAR, BITCHES.

My friends and I decided to celebrate the Mid Autumn Moon Festival by going out and finally trying the famed Joe's Shanghai. After walking through a relatively empty Chinatown at night and passing several other restaurants that almost lured us in, we finally reached Joe's!

The wait was incredibly long though. They have a number system like most other restaurants so nothing too complicated. The hostess told us it'd be about 30 minutes, but it turned out to be more like 50 minutes. Even then we had to share a large table with two other parties. It didn't bother me or my friends, but if you'd prefer privacy, maybe come by at a slower time? (If it actually happens at Joe's.)

We ordered the famed xiao long baos, the Peking style minced pork noodles, and kung pao chicken (why not). The xiao long baos were great! The noodles were decent too; super generous portions for only $4.95 (really great deal...it was enough for four of us). The kung pao chicken was alright, nothing to rave about but I'm not a huge fan of this dish anyway. The total came to be about $32 so $8 a person! Really great meal for such a low price. I definitely want to come back here as soon as possible and try out their other dishes!

By far the best soup dumplings I've had... eaten in tandem with with an onion pancake, downed with a chilled bottle of Tsingtao, the combination becomes something living, breathing, right near and straight out of the faded yellow pages of the legendary Chinese folk tales your mom told you at one point in your life to never believe, to forget completely.  An experience worth passing down, generation after generation.  The suspense of not breaking the outer shell in fragile transport by chopsticks' end, an eternity to the vinegar soy sauce concoction.  The first bite, the anticipation of the indescribable seasoned, animal-derived fatty soup flooding the roof of your already-salivating mouth, so delicate, yet you just want to get it over with and go for the kill.  You do.  And it was great.

The most fabulous dumplings in the whole of Manhattan! Super thin casing that you bite into and suck out the soupy juice and bite into the hearty meat.  I'd give them 5 stars only for the fact that it's always packed, there's often a wait and the staff/servers are always brusk

We went on Sunday around 2-3pm and the wait was about 25 min for 2 people. They were very busy! The food was so good!!! I highly recommend the crab and pork soup dumplings, I haven't had a soup dumpling like that before! The scallion pancakes were super crunchy and crispy with a great scallion taste, also recommended! The service was quick and the food came out fast.
I love this place. The service is fast and the soup dumplings are to die for. I make sure to visit at least once every time I'm in NYC

I looked this place on Yelp and found all of the "rave" reviews...so we ventured our way into Chinatown and found it! Plastered on the front window was an newspaper article in Japanese praising this place for it's "shiyoronpo" or pork-ginger dumpling with soup inside. It is always a good sign to see that the Japanese community has put a mark on this place. Not a full serve dim sum place, but very tasty dumplings. 
I recommend sticking with the traditional pork shiyoronpo.....crab, not so  much.
Soup dumplings. Crispy shredded beef. Yum. Service not as good but good is pretty on point

fire dumplings
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
this paragraph serves a placeholder to meet yelp's requirements for the minimum character length of a review. all reviews posted by this reviewer are unsolicited. the views expressed do not necessarily reflect the policies or positions of the corporation or its employees. past performance does not indicate future results. always consider all the risks involved before visiting any establishment.

We have been coming to Joe's Shanghai for over 15 years or longer. It has been consistent in its quality and affordability. We love the pork dumplings and baby shrimp entree. At one point, we could fill up for under $11. This time around, it was more like $45 for 3 people with a side of scallion pancake. We have also tried the mid-town location but love this one for the shared table, crowds and generally efficient service. You can sit, order, eat and pay all within 30 minutes on a good day. It is not a place to linger. I recommend it to everyone and not everyone wants to wait in line but I don't think anyone is ever disappointed. I would even say it is BETTER than Ding Ta Fun.

Tickets and Hotel for 5 days = $1,600, Tickets for Broadway Shows = $ 600 for 2 shows, subway ticket to Canal street = $2, Joe's Shanghai dumplings = $PRICELESS. 

Let me start off by saying we were here in New York for 5 days and went to Joe's 5 days. We were given a list of 15-20 restaurant recommendations from my girlfriend's friend and his advice was if we were to only to go to ONE restaurant within that list, it had to be Joe's. 

How great can a chinese dumpling place be you ask? Well put it this way, we actually ordered the wrong dumplings the first day and we left thinking that we had just had dumplings from Heaven. We're from San Francisco so we've got pretty amazing palettes and aren't easily impressed, but this place was all that and a plate of dumplings.

really amazing pork soup dumplings! highly recommend it. the dumpling skin is thin and very chewy, not thick at all which a lot of places could be, and the broth is heavy but not too heavy. it's light in a way and you don't really feel gross after. they give you a side of soy sauce ginger vinegar to eat with the soup dumplings, more heavy on the vinegar side, but it really helps and compliments the soup dumplings by cutting through all that oily fat.

it does get really packed, so come at an odd time.

We tried their crab w/ pork and just pork soup dumplings. They are good fresh, but you let it down cool too much, the skin hardens and is not as delectable.

These soup dumplings are very juicy, but fragile. They were not as enjoyable when you accidentally rip them open and lose the soup inside. The crab w/ pork was more unique than the regular pork, but both were good.

The pan fried dumplings were too oily. The pan fried noodles suffered the same fate. The thick white noodles were different from the yellow egg noodles I am used to.

Overall enjoyable, but I would not wait in a long line to eat here.

Arrived with my boyfriend at 645pm on a Wednesday and we were seated immediately. Didn't read yelp reviews so wasn't expecting to sit at a communal family table, sharing it with 4 other people. Anyway, it wasn't bad or that awkward, but scanning around the room I could definitely tell people at other tables felt uncomfortable haha. 

Service was DEFINITELY rushed - I felt so rushed to order that I just made my boyfriend order everything  (didn't care what to get) and he didn't look at the menu, he just spewed staple dishes in Cantonese. Food came super fast, it was DELICIOUS. The pork dumplings were good, definitely had better, but still good- dumplings were very large with lots of soup that came on a bed of steamed cabbage (instead of the regular wax paper), which I thought was a nice touch. But let me take a second to RAVE about the young chow fried rice. Holy sh!t, best fried rice I've ever had! My boyfriend also ordered these pea shoots dish which were fantastic, but since he hadn't looked at the menu, turns out they cost almost $17 (omg, $17 for veggies)... he didn't mind since apparently these pea shoots were as authentic as he remembered them from his hometown. 

The waiters watched you like a hawk to collect empty plates. Funny story time: I was struggling to get the last dumpling from the bamboo basket onto my spoon with my chopsticks (what an epic fai), and mind you the waiter is watching you the entire time to collect the soon-to-be empty bamboo basket - so I think he either got real frustrated with my chopsticks skills or was too eager to collect the empty basket that he suddenly literally picked up the dumpling with the tongs and placed it onto my spoon. Literally no emotion on his face while he did it. I didn't ask for help. And then he picked up the basket and was gone with the wind. Who does that???? I laughed so hard. But I can see how other people may think it was an intrusion of privacy since it pretty much was. Either way, I thought the entire situation was funny and wanted to share it here.

Anyway 4 stars because the food was phenomenal. I'm coming back, regardless of the service!

The food is ALWAYS amazing quality! Everyone can find something here. I was able to select more than 3-4 servings because of the menu's variety. They ALWAYS have great noodles and dumplings. I visited twice last week and still can't get enough of the soup dumplings (made with pork and crab meat, to be exact) and will definitely order the orange beef. It was worth the roughly 20 minutes we spent waiting. I'll see you again soon!

Usually just go here for the soup dumplings, which are possibly the best thing in the world, but their other food, isn't really that great. But I don't mind coz I could eat those soup dumplings every meal, seven days a week. If you go for dinner, be prepared to wait up to an hour. They use a crazy numbering system that can seem random. The lady originally told us 30 minutes, which went down to 10, and five minutes later became 20 again. When all was said and done we actually waited for an hour. They seat you at tables of 8 with random people which can be a cool experience if they're friendly or just whatever if they're not. Either way, really cheap food, really good soup dumplings, you need nothing more. 

Tip: If you're looking for Joes Shanghai, don't get duped by all the imposter Chinese restaurants nearby with "Joe" or "Shanghai" in their name. Also, I don't recommend the midtown location.
HEY TOURIST! If you're only gonna to order Fried Rice and Kung Pao Chicken, pick any other joint in Chinatown and save yourself the wait. Sheesh.

Tried this place out and I love it! I saw some of the reviews that others had made for this place and I have got to stop by and try it for myself. And what the people say about this, is accurate and spot on! The food is wonderful, employees are great, the prices are ideally to food and portions! Great job and I recommend anyone to try this place out as I had done as well!

Came here on a Sunday around 11:00 for lunch. The place was already half filled with patrons. By 12:15, it was full. We were waited on right away. And the servers were attentive and did not forget anything. They checked on us, changed our plates mid meal and made sure our water cups were always full. The place was a bit on the noisy side with great conversations all around. Good for families, but not for intimate dates. 

We ordered two different kinds of dumplings, two different noodle dishes, green beans and salt&pepper pork chops. All was cooked and flavored well. We were not disappointed with anything. Serving sizes were as expected.

This is the best Chinese food in NYC. Hands down. I have been coming here for my entire life. The steamed buns are an absolute must, and the jelly fish is amazing. Go out on a limb and try it. Don't bother with ordering American Chinese food, because this is a legit establishment and they will probably laugh at you. I have heard the soft shell crabs are great and I will be trying them in a few minutes. Seriously it is worth the wait, as hesitant as I am to write this review and make the wait longer for myself. Enjoy!

Best Xiao Long Baos or Shanghai Dumplings I have ever had! My last trip to NYC we had to go two days in a row to satisfy us. We ordered the pork and crab dumplings and the hot and sour soup. 

There might be a little bit of a wait but it is well worth it! Also, keep in mind that you might end up sharing a table with other people since they are always so busy. The reason why this place isn't getting a 5 star rating is because the service. They are not very attentive at all.

I love soup dumplings! I personally enjoy these more than the Din Tai Fung ones in Taiwan, which is blasphemy for some, but these are just... more delicious. I think they are slightly greasier, but that's probably what makes them taste so good. 

Please make sure you have cash, since it's cash-only. 

We waited about 30 minutes on a Saturday night. I didn't love the lady barking out numbers angrily, but about 20 minutes into our wait she seemed to have a change of heart and started asking for all our numbers and asked us to be patient. 

Once we were seated, a waiter came by very quickly to get our soup dumpling orders, so that we could get them started while we decided on what other things to eat. We got one order per person: two pork ($4.95 each), one crab ($7.95), and it seemed like just the right amount. We also got a soup to start-- super reasonable at about $5-- and each got at least a bowl's worth out of it. To try to balance it out, we got stir-fried snow pea shoots, which were the most expensive at about $14, and another appetizer. 

Everything came out quickly and while the place was busy, I never felt rushed. Service is about what you expect at a Chinese restaurant, though I think the servers' English here is better than usual, probably because it's such a hot tourist spot.

I will fly here from San Francisco to eat Xiao Long Bao! But it's also because I can :)

The soup dumplings here are truly delicious; the skin is thin enough, and still retains the soup. A bad dumpling would have skin that is too thick but it's hard to have thin skin because the soup will likely leak from it.

Prices are great, very fair. 

I've had their noodle and soup dishes, all good, and all authentic.

They even sell my favorite ginger ale (I actually discovered it here).

This place is popular so expect to share tables!

Unfortunately, I once had to share with these three 'adults' whom could not stop talking crap about people they knew. Their content got x-rated too. I was really surprised by their bitterness. They seemed neither disabled, nor poor; why be so hateful? Negative vibes like this damper any meal, but Joe's Shanghai was still pretty damn good despite the smell of ugly insides just a few seats away.

I have been to many place for soup dumplings to see if I can find a better one than Joe's shanghai serves. I have found none! I truly believe that Joe's Shanghai has the best soup dumpling outside of Shanghai. I should have known this since whenever I do come here there's always a line and a little bit of a wait. No other place I've been to has had a line. I know I'm not alone when thinking if there's a line somewhere then it must be worth the wait! 

Second, as soon as you're seated they immediately ask you "how many soup dumplings?" They know everyone comes here significantally for that and then if you want to order some other things then that's okay too. But if you come here and dare not order soup dumplings then curses on you! 

They come out in thier little steam baskets, served on lettuce, the cutiest and most tastiest little pouches hold your choice of either pork and crab or just pork and filled with this broth that is just mmmm! Be very careful when eating them since they are super hot! The first time I remember I came out of that restaurant with no tastebuds lol.

I like using the technique of putting them on my spoon and nipping a little hole through the side and sipping the broth out slowly. Do Not pour out the broth! That is the wrong method and irritates me when people do that! Lol. You're ruining the whole purpose of the "soup dumpling".  Anyway, if I order anything else, they have very good "Mongolian beef" aka beef with scallions, "young chow fried rice" and "pan fried noodles". All are really good options. No complaints on the staff, they were always very nice and move quickly. Seating is set up family style, meaning you are most likely going to be seated with other people, but if you come with a group, you will probably end up with a table to yourself. If I can eat these everyday I would! Simply put, delicious!

Wednesday night at around 8:30pm and the line are still long with about 30 people waiting to enter the restaurant. No reservations waited about 30 minutes and most tables are communion and shared with others. Only cash. It is all worth it. Known for their soup dumplings, 8 in 1 serving, we had the pork, and crab fillings. They are served very hot and you need to wait before diving into them. We continued with the chicken orange and the Shanghai Fried Flat Noodles. Inexpensive and good.

Insta@dish_360 

The Good: We wanted the best soup dumplings and both Google and Yelp pointed us to Joe's Shanghai. We got the crab and pork meat soup dumplings. Okay, so basically it's a dumpling that has your protein of choice and when you bite down the soup pours out. Absolutely. Frikkin. Delicious. 

We also had the scallion pancake which was crisp and addicting. Texturally, they complimented the dumplings and didn't feel too "heavy." 

The Bad: Cash only. NBD they had an ATM on site. Also, the wait staff is not pleasant by any means  not a deal breaker for us. I saw other reviews that echoed this sentiment. Honestly, I don't care as much about service as a lot of people do. I'd go back for the dumplings as long as the quality in the kitchen held up. ‚Äç I'm also not a fan of the shared tables. We just aren't social enough to want to share a table with a bunch of people we don't know but that's personal preference.

Aftermath: This isn't an intimate date night spot. We tried the items they're known for and we left happy. We'd be back but I'm not sure if I'd explore the rest of the menu. It's not a place I would care to sit and spend a lot of time at. I'd eat what I knew was going to be executed well and then leave. 

Insta@ dish_360

THE BEST OF THE BEST!

despise of the LONG BRUTAL wait and the unorganized wait list, the soup dumplings is really worth the wait. 

each bite is a burst of juicy flavor and you can really taste the perfection in each dumpling. the order comes with steamed cabbage and is a nice touch. orders come out pipping hot so make sure you cool off the soup after you take a little bite. just make sure you don't spill the soup inside because it's the best part of it all!

we ordered the green onion pancake and WOW. just WOW. it was seriously the best one i've tasted. i wish i ordered a whole plate to myself.

when you come to joes just stick to the soup dumplings and the green onion pancakes. the other entrees are mediocre. just stay away from ordering too much other items. 

you will be seated with other parties so be prepared to sit in a big table with strangers. food comes out fast so you'll be on your way quickly. remember CASH only. enjoy!

Greatest dumplings in New York - hands down.  I really don't know what else to say but "Just go!"  If there is a line at Joe's Shanghai walk one block down Pell Street and head to Joe's Ginger.... same owner ... same food ... same AMAZING dumplings ... all without the outrageous lines you find at Joe's Shanghai.  

I would skip going to Joe's if you aren't into dumplings.  The rest of their food is mediocre.

Bon apetite!

Is there anything I can say about this New York institution that hasn't already been said? No, but here's my review anyways. 

This spot is for anyone who has a craving for soup dumplings, wants an introduction to soup dumplings, or has a bit of time on their hands for the wait time. However, I highly suggest shifting your eating schedule slightly up if you're planning on visiting- especially on the weekends. By arriving around 11:30 am, instead of 12 to 3, you can get seated almost immediately, rather than standing outside for around 45 minutes after the place (and queue) fills up faster than the speed of light.

My theory is that their soup dumplings went "viral" on the internet due to the novelty of having soup inside of a dumpling, which seems rather rare in other cultures. However, other authentic Chinese dishes are just as great, but without a funky combination of two foods. If you're new to Chinese food, I highly recommend trying out the È±ºÈ¶ôËåÑÂ≠ê, or "Eggplant with Garlic Sauce (w. Pork)", under the vegetables section. It's the ultimate combination of sweet and savory, which pairs incredibly with the creamy eggplant. It must be eaten with rice. 

The bathroom is a little janky, especially having to walk down a narrow corridor of steps to get to it, but the rest of the restaurant is nice and clean! I'm not sure that it would be accessible to people with mobility issues.

Soup dumplings are really good but sitting next to strangers?  Maybe not so much.  It's probably just staying true to Chinatown fashion, but if there's an empty seat next to you, best believe it's going to be filled up whether you know that person or not.  It's actually kind of funny how every seat is utilized and at a round table made for ten, you may know only one other person.  It's New York right?  

Prices are true to Chinatown form as well and though you can get these same soup dumplings elsewhere, Joe's Shanghai has built a reputation akin to Grimaldi's and you just have to visit at least once to say you've been there.  There's a location in Flushing and midtown as well but the Manhattan Chinatown version is kind of THE spot to try out.  Flushing is good too, and midtown I have no idea, but I believe it's pricier and not as good.  I would imagine it's not as good because of the direct correlation in price and geographic location in relation to the downtown spot.

The wait is not too long and there's fairly quick turnover.  On weekend nights, it gets hypercrowded and I would imagine it's not really a place yo want to go if you want to have engaging and intimate conversation but if you want to make new friends then I guess it's the spot for you.

It's definitely on my must visit places for out-of-towners.

My favorite Chinese restaurant in all of Chinatown.  Ive been to them ALL.  This is the spot.  Open pretty late and the food is ALWAYS fantastic.  Fresh with a very very large selection.  I usually get the shrimp in white sauce.  mmmmmmm  it gets pretty hectic here, but that's part of the fun.  Busy and bustling Chinatown.  If you're not into all that, you can always take your food to go and if you live in the area, they deliver.  I also recommend the pork dumplings.  Fantastic.

I arrived here for the soup dumplings. When we got in, we were quickly seated. The place seemed very compact, but I actually liked the atmosphere. It was a little dark but it was a good change of pace to the dirty sunny day that I went there. 

The dumplings were amazing. The soup inside was delicious, and the size of each dumpling was pretty big. It was a nice starter for me. I would definitely go back here.

siu luo bao. It's the MUST-HAVE item in the US outside of Shanghai, China.  

I've only found 1 other place in the west coast that has it, and it keeps me content, but not satisfied.

excellent quality for the price! we were able to walk in without any wait on a thursday night but I imagine this place gets pretty busy. Classic dim sum restaurant scene with a busy bustling energy. For the food, we started with the pork soup dumplings. GET THIS. They were huge, first of all, for the price and could easily make a whole meal. I loved slurping out the soup and found it very flavorful. We also got the scallion pancakes, which if you're a fan of these are especially tasty (if a bit oily - but I don't mind that). Lastly we got the half peking duck. Again great portion size and had a perfectly crispy skin with a hefty amount of meat. 

Overall, this is a great spot for a group of friends looking for a warm hearty meal. I definitely recommend!

The dishes here are from Shanghai apparently (as the name denotes).

Beware: They don't accept reservations and Cash ONLY. 

1. Food
 
*Scallion pancake - just ok and wish they gave us more than 2 small dishes for the sauce 
*Pork and Veggie dumplings - no question of course the pork dumplings were flavorful so skip the veggie dumplings unless looking for vegetarian dish 
*Squid with salt and jalape√±o - still loved Hop Li (LA Chinatown) version 
*Whole Peking Duck - for a whole duck, skimpy serving of the green onions (not sure why) and the sauce. It was served with these tortilla-like wrap which we did not like for to us did not compliment the duck. We still prefer those fluffy white buns 
*Orange Beef - it was recommended and it was everyone's favorite dish

*Service - we had a water spill and they quickly mopped it so really appreciated that 

There were a lot of people waiting when we got there at 6 pm. We were given a ticket with our number and were told the wait was for 30-40 minutes. At 35 minutes, they called our party of 5 - not a bad estimation from the hostess

It was pricey as far as we were all concerned and the servings are not big.

It is a very popular restaurant in Chinatown (NY) and I can see why. If this is your first time and wanted to try Chinese food in NY - solid Chinese restaurant to try for first time visitors.

I love Joe's! I've been coming here for years and I absolutely love it here!

I've loved everything I've eaten here.

My favorites are the: sesame chicken and the pork soup dumplings! They're both delicious and flavorful!

I can't wait to come back here! I'll definitely be back again soon!

Ordered the well-reviewed Crab and Pork Dumpling (8 piece) for takeout. The dumplings were filled with a good amount of crab meat while the dough was chewy and soft. I look forward to dining-in and trying more items in the future.

Fantastic and authentic Asian restaurant. Went with two friends on a Saturday night and enjoyed the pork soup dumplings, Kung pao chicken & shredded beef with green peppers (my favorite). Excellent food, very reasonable prices. Some of the best Chinese good I've ever had honestly.  

My only issue was the crowded restaurant and community tables.  The tables aren't any larger than your traditional dinner table yet they stick you next to strangers to share your dinner. It's more than worth the compromise though.

Pork soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. [insert Homer Simpson voice here]

So amazing! Yum, yum, I love eating these here! Fried dumplings are also good, but the Pork Soup Dumplings are the Bomb!!!

If you come in a small group you may end up sitting with a whole bunch of strangers, but you need to overlook that. These dumplings ROCK!

Can you say soup dumplings? Pretty much the most well known soup dumpling place in Chinatown - and the recognition is well deserved! Very good food. Usually a wait.. expect to share tables. And as with all Chinatown joints, curt, quick and loud service, cheap cheap cheap, and overall propensity to over-order.

I brought my family to try Joe's Shanghai in their new location and I can say they don't disappoint! We ordered several batches of soup dumplings but who doesn't? What I can recommend is to just focus on ordering the soup dumplings. While you can order other items on the menu, soup dumplings is what they're known for!

Now for the description of the soup dumping... it has just the right density for the dumpling wrap and once you bite into it, soup just oozes out and so deliciously into your spoon (or if you prefer sipping it as you drink it). 

Just be careful as you bite into it! I once had an accident where I bit into the dumpling too fast and all the soup squirted onto my tie! I'll never make that mistake again!

So bomb. Massive soup dumplings! Ordered way too much food. 
The scallion pan cake is perfect too, crispy and hot.

My favorite place to get steamed soup dumplings in New York. This restaurant definitely lives up to all the hype and is definitely worth your time to visit. The soup buns are huge and spectacular. They are fresh, juicy and have the perfect texture inside and out. I like to eat them plain with no sauce because of how delicious all the natural flavors already are on their own. 

I would also recommend getting the scallion pancakes which are cooked to perfection: crispy on the outside and soft/chewy on the inside. I come here every time I visit New York and always bring my friends.
Great Chinese food. General tsos beats their Seaseme chicken. And their pork dumplings have a seasoning I don't love but over all above average Chinese food.

This place is heaven! The best soup dumplings I have ever had! The West Coast has nothing like them! All the food was delish we! However we as a bit exaggeration we waited for over 3 hours when we where initially told 30 min. We had just landed in NY & our friends treated to this dinner thru told us it was a must try when in the city. We were hungry and tired & did I mention cold! So the wait was ridiculous but the food was the best I had while in NYC.

A few New York natives recommended this restaurant in the heart of Chinatown so I had to check it out! The food was all so enjoyable and there was great value for the price paid, especially with these huge portions. The Sesame Chicken was probably my favorite, it was some of the best chicken I've ever had. 

Also they don't take reservations, but we came in around noon on a Friday and got seated immediately, and the service was quick! If I lived in New York, I'd come here all the time.

Just your average restaurant that is fortunate to have a legacy. Rushed and busy, it is good for people watching but that's about it. Soup dumplings are the same as most I have had. 
And they add a tip in already. Most don't check so they get double tip.

Crab and pork xiao long bao (soup dumplings) FTW!

Joe's Shanghai strikes me as a very straightforward restaurant. With the large volume of customers, they receive - they tend to rush your order as well as try to sit you with strangers to maximize seating as much as possible. Which is fine- I know what I'm going to order hours before I make the trip into the city anyways. 

If you are the kind of person who has problems with strangers staring at you eating while waiting for their own food - Joe's Shanghai might not be the place for you. But if you're a fan of skillfully crafted dough married with flavorful hit-the-back of your throat meaty broth, disregard the haters and be sure to be your own critic with this joint. Sometimes, classics are classics for a reason. And also, be sure to bring cash.
