Why (I ate here):  Husband's favorite dumpling place.  This always has been and always will be one of our lunch stops when we visit New York.

What (I ordered):  Crab and Pork Dumplings, Shredded Turnip Cake, and Salt Pepper Crispy Duck.

I came here for:  Lunch 

Verdict:  Dumplings are perfect (nothing in Seattle compares). Everything else I've tried (that day as well as during previous visits, such as the scallion pancake) are solid performers. Haven't been disappointed by any dish yet.

Highlights:  The dumplings, for sure.  They are generously proportioned, and have just the right amount of juice inside. Very quick service.

Tips:  Consider ordering one tray of dumplings at a time.  When the dumplings get cold, the juice inside will congeal and the skin won't be soft and malleable as it should be.  

Be prepared to wait, as this place is always packed unless you arrive right when they open.

Also, be prepared to "share" a table with others.  I don't mind this, because it gets me my food quicker, but others who aren't used to this concept (sitting at the same table as a family of 6) may be turned off.

Highly recommend trying their soup dumplings. Definitely some of the best I've had, better than Din Tai Fung in my opinion. Cash only and gratuity was included in the bill. 

I can see how this place can get busy so avoid coming during peak meal times. They seat you wherever there's an available seat so you'll most likely share the table with other guests. The service is fast and I can see how it can be a bit intimidating if you don't speak Chinese. Don't get offended if they seem curt or unwelcoming!

As we were looking through the menu, they waiter came by and asked if we were going to order the soup dumplings and he could put that in first while we kept browsing. 

The pork soup dumplings (8 pieces) are huge! And there's so much fatty, savory soup inside. If this is your first time eating soup dumplings, DO NOT just take a bite out of the dumpling. The soup inside the dumplings is meant to be drained/drank first. I felt that the skin was a little too thick. But it did help prevent the dumpling from breaking easily and losing all the soup inside. 

Wish we got more orders but we wanted to try soup dumplings from other restaurants in the area.

One of my friends highly recommended this place when I went to New York.  I'm glad I listened and tried this place because OMG.... I've found a new love!

This place was packed on a Wednesday night.  Bf and I ended up having to share a table with a family of 5.  The family was super nice so we didn't really mind much.

We ordered one crab and one pork xiao long bao.  Each order comes with 8 pieces of delicious soup dumplings for about $5!!  We also ordered shanghai noodles and onion pancake.  

This was my first time ever eating xiao long bao.  Add a lil bit of vinegar and soy ginger and OMG.....it was delicious!!  The dough was not too thick and not too thin and held the soup inside really well.  MmMm.. foodgasm!  Ever since i came back home I've been looking all over san jose for a place comparable to Joe's Shanghai but none I've tried even come close to half of joe's xiao long bao goodness.  the shanghai noodles and onion pancake were also very tasty.  One of the best onion pancakes I've had.

While boarding the plane back to the bay one of the things running through my mind was regretting not coming here again before leaving NYC.  This place is definitely on the top of my list when i go back to NYC.

5+++ for Joe's Shanghai!

i was a first timer at this!  but, ive always wanted to try shanghai dumplings for awhile now.  

this place is located right in an alley.  its get pretty packed.  especially during the early mornings.  keep in mind that you will have to share a table with complete strangers.

dumplings were the only things we ordered each and every time we came here.  they come in crab/pork or just plain ol' pork.

they're little dumplings filled with soup broth.  please make note that these little suckers are HOTTTT.  i burnt my tongue and lips at the excited-ness of trying them out! =X  

there's also a technique to eat them.  pick them up.  put it on your soup spoon.  bite a tiny little hole.  blow.  then you can suck the soup out.  then just eat away! =P

theyre soOooo freaken tastyyyy!  i love it!  theyre a must try!
SOUP DUMPLINGS (and if you don't know how to eat them it's cool--they'll gladly give you the tutorial) lazy Susan round table with strangers is so communal I dig it

This place has the best soup dumplings I've had in the city so far.  I was brought here by a Chinese ex-pat years ago, and he took control when we were ordering.  Couple orders of soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, cold sesame noodles, fried rice cakes, and some other stuff which I can no longer remember.  We ate a TON of food and I was stuffed, but it was one of those situations where it all tasted so good, neither of us could stop.

As I said, the soup dumplings are sort of the main attraction here, but the rogue winner in my book is the fried rice cake dish they offer.  They make these medallions of rice dough, which have the consistency of udon noodles or dumplings in a way, and stir fry them with whatever you choose.  They're pretty unique and as I've come to realize, a bit of a challenge to find.  At least at the Chinese places I frequent, it is not common to see on menus.  If you like chow fun or similar types of noodle or rice dishes, you'll most likely enjoy this, too.

Unfortunately, this place has really jumped the shark in terms of tourist draw and over the top hype.  It's often a mob scene now with very long lines to get in.  Yes, it's good, but as others have stated, there are a plethora of other options in the immediate vicinity that accomplish virtually the same.  With that said, if you can stand the wait, or if you can go at non-peak hours, it is definitely worth a visit.  I have taken groups here on several occasions and it's always a big hit, particularly with out-of-towners.  I love the communal, family style seating they offer.  Almost always guarantees an interesting experience!

Wow, this place is quite the experience! First off - it was located in Chinatown and we found parking extremely difficult to find. We went on a weeknight and the wait was long, and discovered it was cash only but luckily there was an ATM right outside the restaurant! Be warned: the restaurant has a B health rating. We didn't have high expectations from the looks of it.

They seated us at a large table with strangers - a bit awkward, but it seems that is the norm so that they can reduce wait times. Our food came out quickly, although the service was a bit lacking. Had to ask for water, etc. several times and it seemed like the servers just didn't want to be bothered. 

As for the food - the entrees were good, but my favorite item here was the pork xiao long bao (soup dumplings). They are quite large, and the soup inside is so flavorful! They come in orders of 10 and our table ended up ordering 7 orders!! Next time I go, this is all I will order! I also really liked the green beans with minced pork as a side.

It ended up being very affordable for a large group.

Loss of a star for the poor service and entrees not up to par with the soup dumplings.

Pork soup dumplings are virtually identical to pork and crab, so don't both with the crab.   Shanghai noodle with beef are also delicious.  Salt fried pork chops are not worth it.  Cheap and delicious.

Forgot to review this when I went to NYC for vacation. But, for record keeping sake, come here to eat the XLB! Great prices and it's one of the juiciest XLB I've eaten! (Disclaimer: I have not been to Shanghai; just comparing SF XLB to NYC/Joe's) Stick to the traditional XLB. I recalled the scallop one not being as tasty.

Why would you go to Joes Shanghai - well, that's an easy one - soup dumplings. They are way bigger and more filling than others I've tried. Surprisingly, they travel well too. I feel like I end up here with coworkers for lunch more often than I do dinner but good for both occasions. There's better Chinese food around but their known for their soup dumpling.

If heaven served Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings, no one would ever sin again. In my opinion, if you venture to this spot, you must order the soup dumplings, and only the soup dumplings. The other food on the menu is good, but nothing to write home about, or a review for that matter. Take a hint from the long lines outside of the door: the dumplings are awesome and everyone, except for you, knows about it. Clue yourself in and take some dumplings to your face.

-1 star for service. It's hit or miss. One time I asked for a hot sake, which I've had there a dozen times. The server looked back to the kitchen and almost whispered, "hot sake, I have to make that". Then he looked back at me and told me that they don't have any. I asked a different server, who heated some up, brought it to me promptly. Our server was put out that I went to someone else, but that didn't stop me from returning here. To tell the truth, they could mess up the drink orders every time, and I'd still be happy as long as they got the dumplings right.

Best dumplings everrrrrr!!!!!!

Perfect on a nice cold winter day - pork soup dumplings and wash it down with a Tsingtao - pure deliciousness!!!

The only thing is that it could get a little crowded, so depending on what time of day it is you might have to wait a lil bit!

And I know sometimes one can get a little weirded out about sitting at the round tables with strangers, but for me it adds to the experience! (it's funny watching people watching you on your own strategy of how to eat a soup dumpling!!!
Very authentic Shanghainese food! We sampled both types of Xiao Long Bao and the pan seared dumplings. Very delicious and authentic. Nicely done!

We got here around 2PM and the place was packed. Waited about 20 mins to be seated. We were a party of 6 so that could be why. The food was very good. The best was the pork with scallions!! It didn't seem touristy like some people say, seemed like a lot of locals too. I would have given it 5 stars but our waiter was not too friendly. I guess the excuse could be that they were very busy. I would definitely be back!
Delicious soup dumplings and wonderful family vibe throughout the restaurant! Worth the wait and not too heavy on the wallet for delicious food with great portions!

I always have a craving for Shanghai food every other week. If I could I would eat it every week! I've been going to Joe Shanghai since I was a little kid and I loved it! 

Their staple item are their soup dumplings which is usually number one and two on their menu. I always order both the crab meat and also the pork since I'm always with a group we usually always devour the soup dumplings. Be careful not to have all the soupy goodness spill! Their scallion pancakes are always so crispy and good. I always like to dip it in their vinegar sauce or the sauce that comes with their fried pork dumplings. These fried dumplings aren't like the ones you get at a dollar dumpling spot because the sauce that comes with it makes it a million times better! 

For souls I always opt for the hot and sour soup. If you never had it before it's different but in a good way. It's spicy so be careful! If you wanted to opt for something not spicy their chicken soup with corn is good but a little basic. 

For vegetables I love getting their eggplant or string beans! I don't know what is it but the way they cook their eggplant is so good especially with the sauce they add. It's a little spicy but it's not terrible! I can never handle spicy but this was bearable. 

For noodle and rice dishes my favorite are their Shanghai noodles and fried rice cake! Those choices never let me down and it comes on a pretty big portion to share with a group. For rice dishes I always opt for their Singapore chow mei fun. It's a little spicy to beware but it's delicious! 

The only downside is that they don't have fun smoothie drinks or bubble tea. They have soda, tea, and beer so you'll have some options. But the service is very quick although it might be annoying to flag someone down when you need a water refill but they're very quick with taking your order. 

This place also gets super crowded during dinner so you might be waiting for a while. During lunch time on the weekdays it's not terribly crowded.

Crab Dumplings were very unique and tasty if you like crab :)
Pork XLBs were super juicy, however, I like my XLBs a tad bit smaller, perhaps bite size. lol Their XLBS are huge, it takes me about 4 -5 bites which defeats the purpose in my opinion. 

I do LOVE their green onion pancake, it's the best i've ever had, hands down :)

Oh expect to share a table with 2 - 3 other parties depending on the size of your group. It's cool though, reminded me very much of Hong Kong :)

Came here because of yelp reviews.  Opened at 11 and arrived at 12 PM on saturday of thanksgiving weekend and there was already a 30 min wait.  It was well worth it.  Service was rude but prompt and efficient which is what I prefer.  If you are a small party they will seat you at a larger table that is shared between several other parties.  Although it was packed, food came out promptly and was piping hot.  

Got the soup dumplings which were good but not the best I've had.  They were a little greasy and heavy for my taste.  Also tried the scallion pancake and shanghai stir fried noodles which were good and slightly above average.  The noodles tasted fresh and homemade.  Good experience overall.  Would go back.  There is a lot left to be desired.

Authentic as it gets, walked in to a full house but was seated within minutes. Soup dumplings are like nothing I've tasted. Protip: look around for a pro dumplings eater to figure out how to tackle these things. Other dishes were great as well. I'd go back.

Famous for the Shanghai style soup dumplings. Perfect on a cold day, ideal Chinese comfort food
Must be careful how you eat to avoid getting your mouth burned by the very hot soup...bite or cut the corner, to let the soup cool off before eating

Gets a little used to the vinegar smell from their dipping sauce that invades the whole restaurant but the food is definitely worth it. This is definitely a must try. I had both of their dumplings shrimp and pork. This is such an amazing type of food. Lol. I did my research on how to eat it properly before I went and I'm glad I did as I did not make a fool of myself. I took one star away for the service. It seems like they dislike anyone who is not Asian, the server and manger really seemed to be acting like jerks but I gotta admit the food made up for it. The other highlight was their orange beef. This is not your ordinary thin dry beef, it's actually crispy outside and juicy inside....We ended up going a second time before we left NY. Had to have the dumplings again, it's true what they say you will feel happy and in piece while you eat them.

I will start by saying I do not think this place was worth the wait AT ALL. We waited approximately 45 minutes to go in.

LAYOUT

Like most places in chinatown this place is extremely packed and all the tables are close together. They have a "family style" seating arrangement. Expect to sit with others if you have a party of less than 9. 

PAYMENT

Cash only which sucks but, thats most of Chinatown.

SERVICE

Because they are so busy they rush you out which I'm not a fan of. It takes the waiter a while to come back around but they are relatively attentive. 

FOOD

The food is pretty good. Nothing crazy or out of this world but its definitely fresh. What i like the most is the fact that you can order things that are not on the menu. I wanted chicken and broccoli and for some reason it wasn't on the menu, but they made it anyway. They also have gluten free choices including noodles which was helpful since my baby cousin is allergic to gluten. 

Overall, I would recommend if there was no line

**CASH ONLY**

Location: On Pell St, it looks small on the outside but the inside is packed.

Service: They have service doooown. It's packed, but they're so incredibly efficient and you're never really waiting for anything.

Food: Of course, the dumplings. Yes, they are incredible. Some of the biggest XLB I've ever had - and the juiciest. Scallion pancakes were okay, a little too thick in my opinion. The chicken fried rice was also amazing!
Good soup dupplings. Xiaolongbao!!!
Soup dumplings and fried rice are good. Everything else on the menu was lacking, especially the beef noodle soup.

Best dumplings I've ever had. A place I went to the last time I was here in New York from California. I couldn't stop talking about it and couldn't wait to get back to New York and take my friends. It's a pretty tiny place and it gets a little crowded. You have to share tables with other people. That was fine I guess. The wait was rather long, But with more than 5000 reviews. All I can say is they need to expand.

Famous. This is the one word that's used to describe this place. There are a countless amount of celebrities that have been here and there's a reason for it. Come with a group for sure. This is the type of place that you order a number of plates and share within your group. You HAVE to get the dumplings. There is no way you cannot come here and not order the dumplings. It's what they are famous for. There's 150+ items on the menu to order so I'll drop se suggestions. On top of the dumplings, the sesame chicken is also good, the crispy duck was amazing, highly recommend it. Pork fried rice is a fantastic side dish to have. The quality of the food is a notch above your typical Chinese take out and it's always a good time to come with friends to Joe's. I will definitely be back.

was visitng from out of town, and met up with friends who insisted on going here for dinner.  I was very skeptical on what a soup-dumpling would be like (the dish that this restaurant is famous for), but I was pleasantly surprised at how tasty they were.  We ordered the crab and pork dumplings, plus scallion pancakes and (I think) turnip rolls.  All were excellent.  It was crowded but the service was prompt.  Will definitely stop in again next time I'm in town.
This place is great. It's not fancy at all, but if you are just looking to sit down and have some tea, dumplings, and soup then this is a good place to go. I felt like I was in Hong Kong again.

I just died and went to xiao long bao heaven. One can never eat here and not try the soup dumpling--both pork and crab plus pork! I can sit and finish two servings under 15 minutes. Beware: portions of almost everything in the menu are good for at least two people. So you better be hungry and ready when you feel like dining in here. Cash only, can stay long or servers give you "the look", you get to share a table with strangers (which i always find awkwardly exciting).

Fun Fact: xiao long bao = soup dumplings. Joe's shanghai dumplings are hand-made, made to order, and slightly bigger than a golf ball. It is a must here! 
-
Located in Chinatown @ 46 Bowery, New York, this restaurant serves Shanghainese cuisine and is known for their soup dumplings. 

Expect a wait at all hours of any day, also know that they usually call you earlier than expected. You get a ticketed number. We were quoted 40-45 min and came back at 30 min and our number had already been called. This seemed to be the case for many. I highly recommend the OS NYC Arcade Bar next door for a drink and games as a great waiting spot! 

They have a very extensive menu, and therefore something for everyone! From apps to main dishes, chef recommendations, noodles, fried rice, and all kinds of meats and vegetables. desserts - there is a whole lot of savory and some sweet for your palette. 

I highly recommend trying their Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings) and ordering those to start for the table. I tried the pork ones (they also have crab and pork+ crab). Imagine a dumpling larger than the size of a golf ball, filled with fresh minced meat and juicy broth seamed in a traditional bamboo steamer to keep the juices inside the soup dumplings moist. 

 WARNING for new soup dumpling eaters: do put put the whole soup dumpling in your mouth when it comes to your table. The broth is most likely HOT and it might burn your mouth. This has been my favorite way: 
1) Put soy sauce and vinegar onto the plate with sliced ginger (this is your dipping sauce)
 2) Take the soup dumpling and dip it into the sauce.
3) Then put the dumpling into your spoon, and bite a TINY hole in the wrapper of the dumpling to either 1) release juices on spoon or 2) suck SOME of the juices out and then: 
4) Finally eat

I've had a lot of soup dumplings in my life and I would rate these a 4 out of a 5. They rock because they do not leak and are tasty, though I prefer a less fattier broth and thinner skin. 

I also got to try the vegetable lo mein and that was VERY good - a strong wok essence which I love - and the vegetables were a mix of both Asian and American Vegetables. 

Service was quick - it felt very rushed as they were trying to get people in and out. The table were very crowded - and would have preferred given the COVID world, if the tables were a bit further apart. The tables left, right and to the top and bottom of us were all within a feet apart.  The lady manning the front and handling the wait and getting people in whilst also manning telephone and to-go orders did a fantastic job - quite the multi-tasker! 

All in all,  I had a great experience here!
The crispy beef is PHENOMENAL! The service is great and they have great pork soup dumplings! Best place to eat in Chinatown!

Absolutely amazing food. Like everyone else says, the soup dumplings are delicious and juicy, with tons of flavor and soup! Only downside is that service can be a little slow since the restaurant is so popular and servers may seem a little impatient.

The soup dumplings were hot, fresh, and delicious. My young son devoured his chicken dish (recommended by server but don't remember the name). The service was incredible! Didn't have to ask for anything, the servers are positioned throughout the restaurant watching their tables for anything that might be needed. I was there on a Monday during the holiday break and arrived about 30 min after opening. Got a table right away and ordered food before our coats were off. Turned out to be perfect timing - 10 min after arriving there was a line out the door and around the corner!

I really liked this place. I was in town for work and heard about Joe's Shanghai from a friend. 

When we got there there was a bit of a line, but it only took about 5 minutes to get a table. Some complain about communal tables, but that's an authentic touch too. They have "private" or single party tables too. We didn't have to deal with it because we had a pretty big group, so we took a whole table. The service was pretty on point. As we sat down the waiter said "Dumplings? Tsingtao?" Exactly what we were looking for to start the meal. 

As dinner progressed, the staff there was very very helpful. We just wanted some of the best on the menu and they kept it coming. I can't say there was a weak dish. Everything we had was pretty much amazing. 

Definitely try the dumplings, it's an experience, but give them a chance to cool before you dig in. Otherwise you're in for the burn of your life. The prawns were amazing too. 

I don't get the haterism. It's great chinese food. Pretty authentic if you ask me. I'll be making a stop on any trip to NYC.

BEST DUMPLINGS EVER!!!! When I went to New York City for the first time me and my brother went to this place and loved it!! The food here it's reaaaaally great, then this second trip we really had to go and the flavor of the food was even greater!

5 stars for everythings here.. I came with my teacher and my classmates (we were 11 peoples). They were pack already. We ordered Pork steam bun(my favorite) Pork fried and steam, pork fried rice, house fried rice, shrimp lo mein, fried chickens (I like it too) and some soup. Lucky us that 2 of my friends are Chinese. Service was fast...

3 stars for the dumplings.

1 star for the creepy gross fish that i can't stop looking at.

and the last star because the neon hostesses make me feel like they're landing airplanes when they seat people.

2 words! Soup Dumplings! Redunkulous! 5-stars for the DUMPLINGs alone.  The only other time or place I had these were at the infamous, Din Tai Fung in LA.  

They came in these large, circular steam baskets.  These dumplings were so big, you need a tong to grab them.  They do fit in your Asian porcelain soup spoon so that you can somewhat eat them correctly.  Once you bite into one, all those juicy flavors from the pork just oozes in your spoon.  At that point, you just want to slurp and keep biting away.  Savoring each bite.  I still think Din's is slightly better, but Joe's definitely gave them a run for their money.

Do not order anything outside the parameters of dumplings.  I regret ordering their fried rice which was super mediocre and possibly the worst I have had.  Two baskets (8 dumplings each) of these per person would suffice.  In fact, the waiter even ask you upfront if we came in to order just the dumplings, so thats a pretty big indication of its popularity.

Happy slurping!

Good soup dumplings, although in my opinion it is not number 1 in the city. The soup dumplings here are juicy and satisfying, definitely worth a short wait if need be. Too bad it's a tourist trap now.

Best soup dumpling anywhere. Better soup than ding tai fung. But line can be very long.
Recommended - soup dumpling (crab ones), orange beef, shanghai flat noodle, eggplant...I've never had a bad dish there.
PS - it's cash only

We heard about this place from friends and so we stopped by after the US Open this past weekend.  The  pork Xiao Long Bao (Soup Dumpling) was good, but not that big of a deal as folks hyped it to be.  The Bao was hot and tasty but the flavor was so so.  We expected more especially after reading about folks raving.  Not a full disappointment, we discovered that their cold cut combo (chicken in wine, & smoke fish) was very good.  BTW, the wait time is a little bit long.

Fantastic!

My four kids (7-11) and their hungry parents had an unbelievable lunch here--ate like hungry wolves, of course downing several helpings of the famous dumplings, and shrimp noodle soup, and pan fried noodles.  All delicious!  And--all for $60 for the six of us!

We'll be back!
Really good food, I wish I had known before it's cash only. Otherwise, definitely would recommend the soup dumplings. I think it gets really busy after work and on weekends.

I absolutely love Joe's. The euphoric little soup dumplings are what you come here for. As soon as you sit down they ask you what kind you like (There are two, plain pork or pork with crab.) If you're a soup dumpling virgin then go for the plain pork, they're cheaper and just as orgasmic as the crabs. Please note that there is a lot of soup in the dumplings, don't just poke a hole in it and let the soup drain all over your plate! I saw someone do that yesterday and wanted to say something but... that would have been awkward...

The rest of the food here are typical to most other restaurants in the area, however, if you are tempted to order something else on the menu (or off) here are some items that I ALWAYS get:  1. "Yang Chow Fried RIce" It's chicken, pork, shrimp, egg and veggies fried rice without soysauce. 2. "Beef Shanghai fat noodles" I added that fat in there because I didn't know if there is a shanghai regular noodle. This dish also comes with spinach mixed in, it can also be very oily. 3. "Orange Beef" It's crispy saucey and spicy! And, the orange taste is not overpowering. 4. "Braised Tofu with Spinach" This dish is for you vegetarian lovers who think Joe's Shanghai isn't for you!! The description says it all.Also, this item is not on the menu, so you'll have to specifically ask for it.

This place is no glam, service has no frills and sometimes you bump elbows with a neighbor sharing your table that you don't even know (Let's face it, the wait is shorter like this). FYI, the workers in collared shirts are the waiters and the workers without are bus boys etc. So if you tell the bus boy, rather a worker in an uncollared shirt, your order chances are they'll give you a deer and headlights look and your order will never be placed.

My niece came to visit from Georgia for a few days and Thursday was the only day I am off to take her out so in this blistering heat wave I  played a tourist guide!!  Also called my nephew to join us as he just migrated  here about 3 weeks ago and has really not been around yet.  We all took the subway and first stop was Ground Zero, St. Paul's Church where  most of the memorabilia from 9/11 was kept, Wall St area, Battery Park, where we watched a little nice entertainment then we did the Circle Line, Statue of Liberty to Ellis Island then we were ready for the Kill!! Food I mean!!

Ended up in Chinatown and I remember my daughter saying, "Mom I don't care where we are going...just make sure there is  Air  Condition"  when I asked her what kind of cuisine she want, Vietnamese, Thai or Chinese Food .. so we all proceeded to Joe's Shanghai .where their Air Condition was to the max!!

In this sweltering heat I ordered the "Soup Dumplings", just wanted my guests to have a taste of their famous Xiao Long Bao!!  then we proceeded and ordered the  Noodles with Shrimps, Mix Vegetables with Seafood, Braised Beef with Noodles, and Diced Chicken & Shrimp in Plum Sauce.  As always, their food was extremely delicious.  Love Shanghai food, they certainly are a lot different from their Chinese counter parts like, Sichuan or Cantonese...they have this very distinct tasty flavor. This place is always full even though they don't accept credit cards...people still flock to eat here.....We went to  Mei Lei Wah for some delicious Siopao before proceeding to Times Square TGIF then home!!!  

Must have stayed in the bathroom for an hour to cool off!! NICE!!

Met with the rest of the gang at Times Square TGIFAfter

We came here for a late lunch. It was pretty packed but we got seated right away. I think the pouring rain outside worked in our favor. I would normally get this place 3 stars because I don't think the soup dumplings were amazing. I actually prefer the ones in Arcadia better, however the jumbo prawn was amazing and so was the string beans! Yums! I was a bit annoyed that they take cash only, specially because I has to run out in the rain without an umbrella to find an ATM. Will I be back? Yes, for the prawns!

If you are in New York's Chinatown and need a place to experience the best ever soup dumplings head over to Joe's Shanghai on Pell Street.  Amazing, fresh, hand-made daily little yummy parcels of pork and crab broth filled dumplings are to die for!  Just heave these and maybe some green beans or rice cakes as a side.  Be careful not to burn your mouth as the scalding hot broth escapes onto your spoon. You won't be disappointed! Expect a wait of up to an hour though but that's all part of the fun. Speak to your fellow devotee's as you wait to get inside. Cash only, no cards or debit.

This is an updated review!

I always come here with a big group of my friends and we are never disappointed with the food. The consistency that this restaurant has with the flavour of its soup dumplings is great!

You have two choices for soup dumplings: pork and crab. Both are delicious, the crab is a little bit pricier. Aside from the dumplings, I recommend the pan-fried noodles because they are delicious! So are the scallion pancakes, tripe, and jellyfish. 

There are tables for everyone but if you are eating with a big group, there are big round tables in the back to accommodate big parties. This place is also CASH ONLY but a good think is that there's plenty of banks down the block and around the corners to withdraw money. 

Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area!
The food was good there, although wish it was more authentic. Can probably can more similar but authentic food in Flushing.

The soup dumplings!!' WOW!! I'm still thinking about these days later. We did not try anything else but those were enough to really impress me! And I think we got 8 for $12 so very reasonable in price! We went on a Friday afternoon and it was still very busy, so I imagine the wait probably gets long during typical dining hours! So worth the visit! I would absolutely recommend to anyone visiting NYC!!!

My first and second visit here were very different. The first time, the soup dumplings I had been hearing about for years were just 'meh' and the service was atrocious. We were a group of 7 loud ladies, so I decided to give it another shot, only this time as a party of 2. 

HOLY SOUP DUMPLINGS. I seriously think I was in a different restaurant all together. The soup dumplings were delicious and had tons of flavor, unlike my first visit where they were lacking in that department. Service was much better this time, probably because it wasn't an obnoxious large group. My only complaint was the waiter sneezed all over his hands right above our table, then reached for my water glass to refill it. KInda grossed me out a little, but definitely will not keep me from coming back for more soup dumplings!

We also ordered sesame beef and pan fried noodles with chicken. Both were large portions and very good, but the sesame beef was out of this world.

Absolutely love this place. Hands down the best soup dumplings in town! When we talk about soup dumplings, I would give it a 10/10. When we're talking about an overall experience as a restaurant then I'd give it a 7.5. I do like the complimentary orange for dessert, but the place can improve on cleanliness.
Best soup dumplings in NYC. All the tourists know about it now which makes the line longer. Good thing I'm a regular so I don't have to wait!

As my brother was going to NYU for grad school I would always come visit about once every other month and I COULD NOT leave NYC without getting the XLB from Joe's. 

The wait is long and sometimes (actually all the time) you have to share tables but its all worth it.


Din Tai Fung in LA cannot compare nor should anyone compare the two, Joe's Shanghai is simply that much better.

I've never had Xiao Long Bao before so we decided to give Joe's a try after reading their good reviews.

We ordered the Pork Dumplings, Crispy Beef noodles and Hot and Sour soup. The dumplings were sooo juicy and flavorful and tasted really good while it's hot (we left a piece on the steamer and it did not taste quite as good anymore when it got cold). The dumpling skin was definitely not the ones that are sold for 99cents/pack at a 99 Ranch store. It was soft, chewy and held the soup in the dumplings very well.

The noodle dish was loaded with a lot of beef and broccoli, the Hot and Sour soup was just ok (I've had better).

We got there at 11am and by noon, the place was packed and there was already a long wait for a table. On our last night in town, we wanted to go back to Joe's but a huge crowd of about 30 people were already waiting outside indicating at least an hour wait so we decided to look for another place we can go to for dumplings.

If you want to try Joe's Xiao Long Bao, make sure to get there really early to avoid the crowd!

If I could rate this 11/10- I WOULD!!! The food here was absolutely phenomenal. We ordered the pork soup dumplings, Shanghai noodles with pork, & the sesame chicken. The soup dumplings were so so good it tasted like wonton soup & the pork meat inside was cooked to perfection. The sesame chicken was so fresh & the white meat was plentiful. The Shanghai noodles were my favorite dish. They tasted like a thick doughy type of lo mein. 
I loved the food & the portions were very good. My friend and I shared each plate like a family style type of dinner. There was still leftovers once we finished. 
I can't wait to come back to joes Shanghai!
Also FYI- it's a CASH ONLY restaurant. They do have ATM's on site. Also, please expect to wait if you go here because it's very crowded! People were waiting outside in the cold so you know this place is worth it!!
As I left I told the people waiting that it's worth the wait, some people were laughing because I got food all over my shirt!!! You know the food is good when it's all over your shirt.  xD

I feel like I don't need to elaborate on this review since it's been reviewed so many times.  All I want to say is that I feel like this place has better dumplings than Din Tai Fung.  These dumplings are packed with soup and juicy goodness, DTF's not so much.

This place has so far been the best of all the Chinese food places we have been! Only real down fall was sitting next to randoms. The beef broccoli was amazing! Not a huge fan of food like this so I can't complain that the rest was good or bad

I've been to Shanghai before and have eaten a lot of xiao long baos, and I think this place has one of the best.  It's so good on a cold night and it's also pretty cheap.  We got the pork xiao long bao, shanghai chow mein, and a scallion pancake.. all soo good.  There was a long wait for dinner, but since it's in chinatown, you can walk around and explore some fun shops. 

There's another place near this restaurant that's called Joe's as well, so make sure you go to right one (Joe's Shanghai has a green canopy thing).

i love a place where the waiters remember me and take the time to wave hello.  and well, these guys probably know me because i think i used to come here almost once a week.  and ordered pretty much the same thing, depending on group size:  soup dumplings (pork), scallion pancakes, beef with green beans, chicken pan fried noodles (or rice cakes), chicken and cucumber with hot peppers, braised tofu and snow pea shoots (off-menu).  and so it's kinda like how norm or cliff must have felt at/on "cheers", only these guys don't necessarily know my name.

best to go during off hours or bring a book (or ipad) to read while you wait for your number to get called for a table.

Only tried the soup dumplings and Shanghai noodles.  Both were good as advertised.  Restaurant was very busy and we got lucky because we were a large party and they happened to have a large table available when we put our names down.  Otherwise, I imagine the wait would have been 45 minutes or more.

Dumpling goodness! My girlfriend and I went to this place because of their mouth watering Soup Dumplings. First and foremost the ambiance was packed; we're even seated next to 2 parties. It is weird to do it this way since we're seated with people that we don't know, but thats how you get seated as soon as possible. Like, "Yo whatchu you ordered stranger?" Lol. Yeah most foreigners or Non-Asian might complain, but thats how they do it in Chinatown lol. Nevertheless, the service was fast and efficient.. really good customer service for a busy place.. really impressive Anyway.... the food!

Yeap we came here just to order their Soup Dumplings :) We ate a lot from other places since we're in NYC Chinatown, afterall. The Soup Dumplings are one of the best dumplings I ever eaten. It is so unique that few Chinese restaurant have it on their menu. The soup is a little salty or even fishy, like a lobster flavor. Although, it is consist of pork; more flavors are packed in one bite. It really felt like I am eating this in China; never been to China, but thats how I imagine it to be. Its outrageously good and I really recommend trying it, when visiting NYC Chinatown. Overall, heck yeah gonna go here again and might order 4 to 5 orders in one seating.. dead a** lol :)

Soup dumplings were good and lived up to expectations!
Don't expect much in terms of frills - this is a bare bones type of establishment.

You really cannot get much better than dim sum at Joe's. Note that it is cash only and 15% tip is included! Sometimes the wait is nuts, but often it isn't as bad as the crowd outside would appear. The pork soup dumplings are mouth watering. I've also tried and liked the orange chicken, beef fried rice, general tsos duo, and lo mein.
Best steamed dumpling i ever tried! Place is so tiny though. You share table with others

Two words. SOUP. DUMPLINGS. 

First of all let me say that going to Chinatown for Chinese intimidates the hell out of me - how do you know what place are the best?! Ah! 

An old colleague of mine suggested that we do Chinese for lunch the other day and said his favorite place was in Chinatown...SO I put my "brave face" on and headed down to meet him.  

He says: 
"We have to order the soup dumplings...the soup is INSIDE the dumpling!"

I say:
"INSIDE the dumpling?"

He says:
"Yes, INSIDE the dumpling..."

It all reminded me of the scene from 16 Candles when Long Duk Dong is explaining to Jake Ryan about Sam being at the church to get married...haha!

Anyhow, within the walls of this communal-seating-Chinatown-oasis I discovered the art of eating these soup filled dumplings...  When the dumplings are brought to the table, you need to place the dumpling into your soup spoon.  Then you need to nibble the tiniest little hole into the top of the dumpling so that you can slurp the soup out of the dumpling, then you can stretch out that hole little more to allow a spot for you to pour in a spoonful of the soy sauce/vinegar/ginger mixture on the table.  Then you can finish the dumpling in about 2-3 bites.  

They are DELICIOUS - we got the crab & pork dumplings which I highly recommend!!  We also ordered the General Tso's Chicken and the Dry Shredded Beef which were both awesome as well.  It was definitely some of the best Chinese I've had in New York!

Delicious, well-made, no frills soup dumplings. A bit heartier and bigger than that of the also well known Din Tai Fung. Cash only, quick in and quick out kind of place. Be prepared ahead of time! They rush you a bit there, but for a place that is so busy you'll be glad they did the same for those ahead of you! Beware of cash only and 15% gratuity included already.

The Peking Duck was so delicious. Delicious sauce, crispy skin, fluffy bread and scallions make it complete. The only small improvement could be if the duck were a bit more tender. Service is fast and nice. Very very good and would eat here again.

Came in on a Tuesday afternoon and it was not busy.
Service was like any other, but food was amazing ! And cheap. Of course we got the dim sum. All food was good.

This is by far one of my favorite xiao long bao place's...one bite into the crab dumpling...juices pour out onto your spoon...like a little bundle of rich broth just waiting to erupt...(beware very hott!!)

Beware of wait time...

Everytime I go to NY i always have to stop by. Definitely need to check a few other places out but its sooooo good here. I never really had to wait too long so I cant complain. I always over order and get like 4 plates of soup dumplings betweenn me and my wife but I dont regret it. Get the pork. The other ones are whattever. So good especially when its cold!

Clearly,  a few people know about Joe's Shanghai down the little alley on Pell street.  It's a virtual cornucopia of international tourists and locals that ate not Chinese.  Usually that would be a bad thing, but this place is very good.  We enjoyed the Crispy Duck (a little dry and salty), Shanghai rice and the infamous dumplings with crab & pork.  These were down right tasty.  When I asked the waiter what they were famous for, he pointed right at it.  Out of the thousands of photos posted on Yelp! For Joe's, at least half are the same photo of these tasty dumplings.  Don't forget to eat these if you come to Joe's.  It's nice to be somewhere warm and packed on a cold New York night with a nor-easter bearing  down in the next couple hours.  We can be trapped indoors with warm bellies while we hibernate.

As recommended by the Fung Bros, I found this spot a classic for Dim Sum. While in New York, my buddy and I wanted a taste of home and decided to scope out Chinatown. We ordered about half the menu and ended up finishing everything! The food came out within seconds and it was authentic, delicious with decent portions!

My first xiao long bao experience was at Joe's Shanghai back in October 2002 when my friend and I took a trip to NY.  Ever since then I've been searching for something similar in CA but still haven't found one.  Din Tai Fung is close but not quite.  Joe's is juicier and has a super thin skin (almost like a water balloon).  Only problem is the skin can break easily because it's so thin.  I went back three years ago and it was still as good as my original experience.

Service is so so and not too fond of the communal tables.  If you are a private person I don't recommend you come here.

There's another location in Midtown (around corner of 56th & 5th) that is clean and doesn't have communal tables, but for some reason it doesn't taste as good.  I think it's the grime that adds charm and flavor at this location.

They have other dishes too but they weren't that memorable.

CASH ONLY and there's usually a long wait on weekends.

whoa whoa whoa! 
that was an explosion of yummy in my mouth... literally. 
(please note that this was my first time ever eating these...)

My friend had told me about this place their Shanghai-nese dumplings... I was skeptical and rather confused.

The place is a staple of ChinaTown in NYC. They're very busy even on the rainy day that I passed through. 

Quickly seated with some random strangers - I suppose that's more efficient than having a bunch of small and large tables. I just asked for the dumplings and water. After all, this is NYC - there's more food to be eaten elsewhere.

Service was quick and before you knew a bamboo steamer appears before you with some "soupy dumplings"... I believe you get about 8 per order. 

Supposedly there's a proper way of eating these (by piercing the skin and sucking out the soup), but that's not fun. I just plop them straight in and munch. But watch out! The first few will burn your tongue!

I'm sure prices vary, but I chose pork and it was about $4.75 + tax + tip. Do note that they'll automatically add 15% tip for you... AND it's cash only!

Besides those two annoyances, yummy! I'd go back for more~

The soup dumplings are good but by far, Shanghai Cafe has the BEST soup dumplings out there! Skip the crazy lines of all the tourists who don't know any better. Check out the other gems of Chinatown and not fall for this tourist trap!

Wonderful food and experience. Line was out the door on a cold Saturday afternoon for lunch, but the 30 minute wait was worth it. They use every inch of the place, no space wasted. We were sat at a round 6 top with 2 other couples, even so we still felt like we had our own space to enjoy our time together. 
Our waiter was very attentive and helpful, teaching us the right way to eat the crab and pork bun, so delicious. 
Cash only and tip included in price, although only 15%.

They're a little too expensive compared to other soup dumplings around town but very good, fresh, piping hot burn in your mouth dumplings!! Also it was weird being seated in a large round table with 3 other parties in the same table! But I'd get the soup dumplings, the general tso/sesame chicken was regular tasting.
Amazing amazing soup dumplings. The pan fried noodles was very good as well. We had a little awkward situation while sharing the table but the manager was very sweet and put us at another table.
Soup dumplings are probably my favorite food and I have to say these are some of the best I've ever had! The rest of the food I got was equally delicious.
Wow. Incredible dumplings and Shanghai noodles are really special. Worth the hype! Prepare for an epic food coma afterwards though.

It's crazy busy but we didn't wait long, they combine small party's on a big table, so it makes for good conversation.  I love general joes chicken and there's was ok, the fried rice was ok also we got the chicken but not a lot of chicken in it. 

I will say we enjoyed the pork dumplings were awesome! We would have just orders two orders  and maybe one order of general joes!

All in all there were a lot of Asian people eating there which is a good sign for a Asian restaurant!

Came here with a large group (8) and was seated immediately. The soup dumplings and crispy fried shrimp here is a must try! The service here is always super fast and friendly. All the portions here are family style. This is also a cash only please. Not sure if they are under new management because their menu says a different name but the food is still the same.

Word Of The Day "Soup Dumplings".
Thats pretty much all about Joe's Shanghai.
I have visited their Mid Town location the this particular one and none failed on the Dumpling THE BEST. Rest of the menu is pretty mediocre nothing out of the ordinary your sameOl sameOl Chinese Food. I mostly have my fill on the dumplings. The other dish that impresses me is the Fried Noodles the dish starts out with crispy fried noodles with your regular stir fry ingredients but a bit saucy in the center so as you eat your way in you go from crispy to soft a good play on textures.
Only drawback Cash Only and 20-30 min waits always.
FYI - There is NO wait for parties with pregnant ladies and preference for parties with toddlers.

My boyfriend kept raving about this place and this time around when I went to visit him we had to go. We waited for about 45 mins because this restaurant does not take reservations.  It's first come first serve. 

It's a small hole in the wall Chinese restaurant in the heart of Chinatown. This place only accepts cash. We were put at a community table with 2 other groups. The place is very fast pace and has a family feel to it. 

The service is fast and easy. Food came out hot and quickly. The food was worth the wait. The soup dumplings with pork filling were to die for. They were a great balance of sweet and sour. We ordered Kung pao chicken, general tso chicken, young chow fried rice, and vegetable chowmein. All the dishes were excellent and cooked exactly how they needed to be. 

It's a must try Chinese restaurant especially for the dumplings.

Great food, love the new location. I live in the neighborhood and this is a great place to take friends and family who are visiting. The new location is super polished and the food is always great! If you're familiar with Chinatown prices, this may seem pricier to you, but it's absolutely worth it!

Best xiao long bao I've had in a while.. Although it doesn't beat Din Tai Fung it's comparable. It oozes with flavorful broth and is quite delicious. 

We were seated at a large round table with 2 other parties, which some might find  awkward, but it can be standard at some Chinese restaurants. 

Besides the regular xiao long bao, we also had the one with crab meat, scallion pancakes, fried rice, and egg rolls. I didn't try the egg rolls, but my friends said it was a little too oily so I wouldn't recommend it. Everything else was delicious! 

The only downside to this place, is that it's cash only. Our bill came out to $43 for 3 people so it was a pretty cheap and satisfying first dinner in New York.
Fantastic spicy calamari in black bean sauce and steamed dumplings!!!
The crab & pork soup dumplings are simply the best in the US! Worth every second of the hour + wait outside. There would still be an hour wait if they only had those 2 things on the menu! G.O.A.T.!!!

One of the best soup dumplings I have tried. We ordered three trays one pork, and two crab combo. Eat them while they are hot or they soup will conjeal back to a solid. Come early or share a table with others it will get crowded fast. The dumplings are large packed with meat and soup. The top of the dumpling was a little doughy and I prefer the pork over the crab.

Tried the Crab & Pork Soup Dumplings, Pork Soup Dumplings, Sesame Noodles and not sure of the name of the dish of vegetables we ordered...tong cai in Chinese? 

8 large dumplings for a fairly good price ($6.95). FYI the location in Chinatown is cheaper than the uptown location. 

Sesame Noodles are pretty good - very simple, but flavorful. 

The restaurant started to get really busy around 6:30/7 p.m; we went on a Monday and a bit earlier and didn't have to wait.

Soup dumplings of course!!! Fried rice is great as well! Fast and friendly servers prepared to take care of even the most needy guests. Definitely trying the whole fried fish next time as it seemed to be on a lot of tables around me. Can't wait to come back this place is awesome

One of my favorite foods happens to be soup dumplings, so of course I had to try this place when I came to NYC.

It was a Saturday afternoon around 1pm and there was a wait and line outside the door. For two people, it was a 20 minute wait, which isn't so bad considering it's a small restaurant. When we got seated, I realized they sat us at a half-circular table against the wall meant for 5 people where a 3 person party was already seated--meaning we had to share a table with strangers. The other guests weren't bothersome, so we didn't mind.

We ordered the pork soup dumplings ($8) and the crab & pork soup dumplings ($11) first. Compared to the famed Din Tai Fung, these dumplings are about 2-3 times bigger in size, and it came with 7 dumplings. It was a bit difficult and messy to eat due to the dumpling size being so huge, but it was sooo good! Although some of the crab ones kept popping as we picked it up from it's tray, so that was pretty disappointing. We also ordered the saut√©ed shredded beef with jalape√±os ($16). Another great choice! They didn't bring us any rice, so I suppose you have to order it on the side and pay extra, but we were too full to even bother with it.

The service was a bit awkward, as this is a genuine Chinese restaurant and the servers can barely speak English. I often found our server standing a foot or two behind us and staring, as if waiting for us to call on him. Overall, quick and friendly service.

Definitely would recommend if you don't mind waiting and/or sharing tables!!

I absolutely loved Joe's Shanghai, I had some of the tastiest dumplings there! The first set of steamed goodness came in a basket with 7 soupy, hot and full of pork flavor, dumplings. 
The second basket was filled with crab meat soup dumplings, equally delicious! 
If you enjoy dumplings, you need to try these for sure. The restaurant is packed but efficient, you'll be sitting with other people on your table, but that's the fun of this type of seating arrangements. You get to know people in the process while enjoying food. They had many offerings on the menu but I can for the dumplings. 
Get there early, there's usually a wait... but it's worth it. 
Now go enjoy!

These are the BEST dumplings in town! The soup dumplings melt in your mouth instantaneously and the pop of flavor is dreamy! I ate so much I almost exploded but it was so worth it. I am already dreaming about going back. Tip: Go on off hours. I went relatively early and there was no wait. I once tried to get in at peak dinner hours and the wait was an hour. I didn't stick around

Don't forget to stop right on the corner. They have an unreal dried fruit and meat and fish store! It's like a unique candy store. I highly recommend stocking up on dried kiwi's and ginger! Try some of the dried fish to!!!

I've been wanting to try soup dumplings for a long time so it was awesome to finally get some at Joe's Shanghai! The restaurant in China Town is surrounded by a ton of other hole in the wall restaurants that all appear to be the same, but Joe's was the only restaurant with a long wait, which was a good sign. 
I was seated at a round table that another family was already seated at, which was a bit odd/awkward. I enjoyed the fresh tea kettle that was set on the table when we sat down. We started with an order of pork soup dumplings, which were rich in pork flavor and very filling. I tremendously enjoyed them, but we also got Shanghai Noodles that we're a bit bland and soaked in oil. The noodles would benefit from some teriyaki and spice. 
10/10 recommend visiting just to try soup dumplings!

We went to Joe Shanghai for 1 thing and 1 thing only: xiao long bao. There always seems to be a line in front but this time we were determined to eat here. You have to go to the lady in front to get a number and then you wait outside until she calls your number for you to be seated. If you have some time to kill, there's a bubble tea store right next door. They were doing buy 1 get 1 free (or 50% off) boba but I'm not sure if that's always the case.  

We were seated fairly quickly and immediately told our waiter that we wanted 3 racks of pork xiao long bao. We also got an order of sesame noodles which were super sesame/peanut buttery just how we like and an order of green beans. The green beans were over salted and were a little friends instead of cooked in oil and garlic like we were used to. However that's not the point, the point was that the xiao long bao were delicious and filled with TONS of soup. Be careful for your first bite because you don't realize 1) how much soup there is in these things 2) how hot they come out from the kitchen. 

If you go on their website, there's a funny video about how to eat them and how not to eat them. As cute as the video is, it doesn't compare to how delicious the soup dumplings are.

Great find! Food was really good, really fast, really fresh. The wait might be long during the normal meal times. We (party of 4)went on a Saturday at 3 and waited 40 minutes. It's family style seating so fun to meet other people from other places. They are know for their soup dumplings. Delicious!!! Also ordered scallion pancake and sesame chicken. Yum! Cash only but there's an atm right at the entrance. Visiting from California and wish we had this in our town.

This is a must visit for a delicious, quick meal in Chinatown. We weren't starving, so all we ordered were the pork soup dumplings. The dumplings were not only absolutely delicious, but they also were larger than expected and came with 8 to an order. This could be a meal in itself for someone who came hungry! The service is fast and efficient, you will have a wait time but the staff is quick to get people in & out so that you can enjoy your meal. Joe's is a great place!

I've been living in New York City for 30 years and I can tell you that Joe shanghai has the best Chinese food. I have been going with my family to the one on 54th St. it has been the best food every time that I go there and the service is good as well. We were stuck in the rain downtown and for the first time today we went to the Joe Shanghai downtown. The food was still the best. However, before you go to this one downtown you have to know that they will seat you wherever they want and there is a 50-50 chance that you're going to be sharing a table with other patrons. If your social person you won't mind. The other thing is that they absolutely only except cash. Do not go there unless you have more than enough cash otherwise you might be embarrassed not be able to pay the bill. The different dishes are about 4 to 5 dollars less than the one uptown, but the one uptown you can use your credit card. So you don't have to worry during the meal if you have enough money to pay for it. I will Continue frequent Joe Shanghai often but I will stick with the one uptown. Also remember that both uptown and downtown during the prime hours of lunch and dinner there is a half an hour to one hour wait time. So go off hours and you have the best of both worlds, little wait time and the best Chinese food you ever had.

Delicious food! Fast service! Well priced!  At a non standard meal time the restaurant was full when (with lots of locals as well as tourists) every other restaurant within 5 blocks had no more then 3 tables. One thing to note is it is cash only, and a little hard to find.

I love Joe's, but I think that Shanghai Asian Manor's soup dumplings are slightly better. Joe's are definitely good, but it's also super popular due to the fact that it was the first soup dumpling place in Manhattan.
Everything I could ever want or dream in a dumpling. They got us in an out quickly and took great care of each customer

Yum, yum, yum.  The dumplings are fantastic!  

Try to go with a big group - it's much more fun to order and share a bunch of different stuff, and it seems like they rush you less if you're taking up a whole table yourself.    

It's a little cramped and loud, but that's part of the fun of this place!
Shanghai dumplings..mmmmm 2nd time here since my last visit to NYC.

SOUP DUMPLINGS! 
It was so crowded when I went and they don't take reservations for groups smaller than 10. I suggest getting 9 of your closest friends and making a reservation. Everything is giant and family style so that seems to be the most fun way to experience Joe's anyway. 
I prefer just the pork to the pork and crab (I may be the minority on this one). But I will eat any soup dumpling that is put before me at Joe's!!!!
AND cheap 2 of us got an order of soup dumplings each and some fried rice and it was 20 dollars TOTAL! Hooray!!!!

Best Chinese food Ive ever had! I was very lucky and came on a day that they weren't super busy. Only took me 5 min to be seated, but be aware wait time cane be high. They do turn people in and out quickly but not in a rude rushed way. The soupy dumplings are a must and both are to die for and apparently as legit as it gets without having to travel across the globe. I also tried staple items as the sesame chicken and main, the best, as well ad the crispy duck, and chicken in plum sauce. This is a place liked by locals and tourists alike which always a food sign. The prices are standard aprox 15-20 per plate.

The first time I ever went here was with my boyfriend at the time who was half chinese and his mom was his biggest food influence. So I knew that waiting for a while it was really worth it. All I knew about Joe's Shanghai  is that they were famous for their Soup Dumplings. I had no idea what that meant but I was really excited to try it. Let's just say after eating the Pork Dumplings I was sold. I have taken MANY MANY people to this restaurant after eating there. 

When I go to Joe's I always order 2 orders of Pork Soup Dumplings which come in  5's.The crab dumplings are aight but not really my thang. I order the chicken Rice Cakes which are amazing. It basically is chopped up chicken with these little quarter sized rice cakes which are soft and goes so well with the chicken and then they throw in some bak choy. I also order they're tofu the bean curd and veggies. Mmmm... the taste is like nothing i've had. The tofu is fried and then its doused in sauce and veggies. by this time  i'm a big fat lard that can't move... 

Some things that suck about Joe's is the wait and having to sit with people that you don't know. But after a few Tsing Tao (chinese beer that is also good) you start making friends and forgetting that you're having dinner with a bunch of people you don't know. Also, they add in their own tip but all they have are these little signs on the wall stating that. So if you weren't paying attention you're giving them way more than you should. 

After living in China for a year and coming back this food is as  close to "real chinese" food that i can have. I suggest that people definitely try it out. Don't forget CASH ONLY!!

Whenever I travel to NY, I always make time to dine here. Their soup dumplings are that good! Their service can be a bit rushed, which is good since I know what I want....This place can get so crowded - I appreciate the fast turn over!

Best soup dumplings I have ever had.  Honestly, I have tried and tried to replicate their taste by ordering them at other restaurants, and I have never been able to.  The best!  Pork and Crab are the way to go.  JUST DO IT.

Another gem in Chinatown that you'll be lucky to stumble upon. I only hear of great places to eat in Chinatown from friends, not necessarily because I walked into a random restaurant in Chinatown and it turned out to be good. Nope! If you're planning to eat in the Chinatown, you need some recommendations or you should refer to yelp! Anyways, my friends took be here because of their craving for soup dumplings. What are soup dumplings exactly? Well, it's what they sound like.

I can into this place thinking that I will be eating dumplings in soup. You know, like wonton style? Nope. I was wrong. We order 4 orders (one order each) of soup dumplings that comes with 8. Yes, our eyes were bigger than our stomach. We got two orders of the pork soup dumplings and two orders of the crab and pork soup dumplings. On top of that, we ordered a place of broccoli and beef and a plate of pan fried noodles that had beef. Boy did we stuff ourselves that night. I'm surprised the waiter didn't look at us like we were crazy...

The soup dumplings were deelish. They were kind of hard to eat. There is a technique to eat them. You have to carefully pick them up from the steam tray and place it on your soup spoon. The you have to poke a hole in the wrapper so the soup will spill out slowly. Then you sip the soup and SLOWLY devour the dumpling. WARNING, it is mostly likely you will burn your tongue! The pork dumplings had a different flavor/soup from the pork and crab dumpling. They were both really good! I think I prefer the pork and crab one more. The broccoli and beer was okay. Super flavorful and slathered with sauce, just the way chinese people like to eat your veggies. The pan fried noodles were pretty good. The noodles were rice noodles I believe, kind of looked like udon but pan fried with veggies and beef. Very flavorful and yummy. I liked it. I could have done without the broccoli and beef. 

All in all the place was good. Service is very "chinatown." You know what I mean. Fast pace, gotta wave them down, pressures you to order fast and get you to leave fast. Yeah. That's how it was. But if you move past the service, the food is good. If you're small party, you will probably sit at a huge round table with random people. That's legit Chinatown style. Ha!

My favorite joint for shanghai dumplings! I'm hungry again just thinking about the broth that spills out of the dumpling as you take a bite into the dumpling skin that is neither too thick or thin. When I come here, that's all I want, an order of their shanghai dumplings. I'd also get an order of them spring beans, perfectly fried and stir fried with garlic and soy sauce into the perfect crunch when you bite into it. It's a crowded restaurant and you'll be sharing the table with others, but worth it! So get cozy with your new friends at the table and just enjoy!
We got the pork meat soup dumplings and Szechuan beef noodle soup.  The food was delicious!

Love this place! Tucked away in Chinatown is this gem. We went for the dumplings and were not disappointed! This place can get pretty packed but they seem well-staffed and can handle the rushes. We got the mixed pork and crab dumplings. They literally fell apart! The main dishes were fine too but the dumplings stole the show. Check it out if you're in NY!
Delicious. Love going there with my wife and kids. The kids adore the place and the food.
Very testy food , makes me back to the home already, we will back again if we have time in the New York City
Really good dumplings, also the turnip shortcake and the duck was really good crispy.

One of Chinatown's great attractions!

Last night the dude and I were restless and hungry and very happy to live near Chinatown so we hit up joes for some soup dumplings.

If you don't already know, they're awesome here. If you don't order anything else, get some of those.

Communal seating and classic Chinatown environment (don't expect to be waited on hand and foot but service is friendly and perfunctionary if a bit rushed-after all, there's always at least some wait here) reminded me of my visit to Hong Kong. 

Definitely a NYC favorite of mine.

HARD TO FIND

prepare for a wait, even though it was short and know what you want to order our waiter didn't have time or energy to answer any questions or give suggestions

thanks to you guys I ordered the pancake which was the best I have ever tried in my life, the dumplings burst w/a liquid once bitten so be careful (they were alright)

Pretty good but one could argue that there's lesser known options that have higher quality for less money. But always a solid choice if you don't want to make too much effort. It's like thinking Olive Garden was the best restaurant ever when you were 13 - you don't know anything else. Or maybe that's just me , honestly Olive Garden is . Joes is the Olive Garden of Dumplings.

Your in China Town....Joe takes you to Shanghai, China...it's busy, but not crazy yet. The two of us are three back from being called to the "Diners Table". But, they call "six" of us up and suddenly your transported to China...you sit at a large round table sitting all parties. A printed letter of the English (you think) alphabet is placed in front of each group. No one converses with any "outsiders". It's as if you are sitting at a private table, but it's not private. The menu looks like it's written in a different language. The English writing seems foreign to you. You choose two cups of sake, a Szechuan Beef and a Shrimp Lo-Mein. The beef is tender medium rare perfectly cooked. The beef is in a Szechuan sauce most delicious (Gen.Tso married to Miss Hoisin..:). Our Sake was delivered in small odd looking bottles. But this Sake very good!!!..:) The Shrimp Lo Mein was tasty; The shrimps though smaller than desired, were accompanied by crispy delicious bean sprouts. Waiters come at you like Ninja Warriors, seeming to drop in and out of sight from the ceiling..:) We had plenty of leftovers to take back to our Temporary Villa. Oranges brighten the end of this fun meal. As you leave somewhere near 7pm, you see the crowd of people (many Asian) waiting with great humility (humility is not thinking less of yourself; it is thinking of yourself less."..:) to be called to the Round Table. Thanks for reading. 
Avram Arthur Chan

Best soup dumpling I ever have...hands down. 

Everything else is just so-so.

Had seen this restaurant and heard about the good food so decided to try it. The line was out the door but the wait wasn't too long  and I can see why the staff is very helpful and the food is delicious very good flavor and portions we had the chicken lo mein and Kung pao chicken with a side of scallion fried rice the portions are generous and full of flavor would definitely go back when I'm in my

Crab pork soup dumplings: wow. The best Shanghai dumplings aka XLB I have ever had! The soup inside had a great flavor and a nice, thickened consistency and the dumpling skin was nice and chewy. The entire thing was a delicious bite, and a very generous bite at that! 8 pieces of this one was approximately $11, which I felt was a deal. 

There is a little alley way to the right of the front door to the restaurant where there is some seating to enjoy the food. 

Highly recommended!
Soup dumplings!! Joe makes the best in the city. Whenever I have a craving I have to order from here. They are always perfect. Get the pork stuffed, divine!!

This restaurant its a regular stop for us, everytime we go to NY city. We had the crabmeat dumplings. The waiter showed us the proper way to eat dumplings. They were delicious. We will definitely come here again.

This is where my friends and I go for a SNACK.

Wait a bit, dodge people coming in and out.

Get smacked in the face with a door.

Share a table with a Chinese woman and her freaking adorable Grandmother (who can house an entire tower of soup dumplings, by the way.)

Order the pork soup dumplings and the pork and crab. Enjoy the complimentary hot tea on the table. Pay like, 14 dollars (tip is included already!).

Vamoose.

Snack time at Joe's Shanghai.

Soup dumplings - good; other Chinese food - good; space available to sit and configuration - really, really tight.

Don't miss Joe's Shanghai if you love soup dumplings.  They do have the best in the city.

Health Grade: A

I've been here many times - mostly with friends/family who visit. I will admit, we never really order anything else besides for the soup dumplings, but they are definitely the reason I come back over and over. They're piping hot when you get them and delicious. I've had both the pork and crab, and they're both good.

I dream of the pork soup dumplings!!!  Best I've ever had!  

This place is so much fun and chaotic!  Bustling interior.  Be prepared to literally knock into some strangers and start up a conversation.  Unless you have a huge party you'll be seated at large tables where you (can) share food with people you've never met (or just talk, but keep the food to yourself).  Everyone is just thrown into this melting pot of a place so it's easy to be chatty and even walk out with a new friend or two.

Hand down the best xiao long bao I've never had. I'm willing to wait in line for this place. But it's super small and the tables are crammed against each other. The meat inside is decent sized. The dough isn't too thick to chew and not too thin where it'll pop when you pick it up.
Amazing dumplings - both pork and crab+pork! Succulent beef+broccoli, awesome noodle soup - best we've had in years!

fun fact about their soup dumplings: most places use a piece of wax paper on the bottom of the steamer, you know, like normal dim sum dishes. but the thing is, these dumplings are so delicate that when you pick one up, the bottom of the dumpling usually sticks to the paper, and the force of the lifting tears the skin which causes the soup to leak out. you're then left confused and distort, heart broken over the puddle of dumpling essence that was so helplessly wasted. i like this place because not only are their soup dumplings (and all other dishes) so stupidly delicious, but also because they were smart enough to use lettuce leaves to line the bottom so that the dumplings sit on a slick surface. you can thus successfully pick up your dumpling in confidence, without the worry of potential heartache, and transport them onto your plate with your little pouch of liquid happiness in tact. yay happy endings
Some time ago I was made to come in there. Now you`ll see me there now and then. I love that cuisine. And this place never disappoints. Delicious! Thank you

Get there early if you're going on a weekend. The wait is well worth it. I recommend getting everything family style that way you get a taste of everything. Soup dumplings are the signature dishes here at joe's

The xiao long bao or soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai definitely live up to the hype! And I should know, I've been to Shanghai!

I would say these are even better than Din Tai Fung on the West Coast. The soup dumplings here are bigger than normal and there's sooo much soup inside of the dumplings. I've been to places where there is no soup in the dumplings and it's the biggest let down ever. 

There's usually a wait, but it moves rather quickly. We were seated within thirty minutes. We also ordered the Szechuan Beef noodle soup which was very flavorful and the pork chop noodle soup which actually comes with fried pork chops on the side and not in the soup. 

I will be dreaming about these soup dumplings!

like their xiao long bau, steam bun, yum and juicy......
typical chinese restaurant service in china town. 
will come backfor the steam bun.

One of my all-time favorite dim sum places in NYC. 

things to order: 
bean pastry
the scallion pancake
soup dumplings (of course!!!). 

trick for eating the soup dumplings: once you have placed the dumpling on your spoon, bite the top off and sip the soup out.  This will prevent any sort of mess. 

happy eating!

get the soup dumplings. killer.

awesome service, great food. can't miss with this place. wait can be long, but worth it.

My first review is pretty ancient and thought it required updating especially since they have a new location. The new location is very nice and is much more modern to their old location. 

First things first, don't forget this place is CASH ONLY. The service still isn't the greatest. The staff isn't very friendly and rarely do you see anyone smile there, but hey, we know why we all come here... THE SOUP DUMPLINGS. My favorite is the pork dumplings. If you really like crab, you'll enjoy the crab ones. They have a hint of a seafood taste, but I prefer sticking to the pork. 

We wanted honey chicken, but they don't have that so we got the sweet and sour chicken. Portion size was pretty small. It was not even close to being worth $21. It's more sour than sweet. We were told it came with rice, but we had to flag someone down to ask for rice and they brought this time little portion that is not a shareable portion. I wasn't a big fan; would have preferred another order of dumplings instead. 

A lot of first timers come here and I noticed they have no idea how to eat the dumplings. I educated the table next to me as I noticed they were trying to look over to see how it was done. 

I thought this little verbal tutorial might help: 
(Check out my photos to see the examples numbered for this description)

    1. Use the tongs to gently grab the dumpling at the very top. If you are too rough, it could pierce and cause you to lose your soup.
    3. Place dumpling on your mini soup spoon. 
    4. Bite a tiny hole near the top. 
    5. Use chopsticks to hold the dumpling up while you drink the soup then devour. 
::CHECK MARK:: If your plate looks like this in the end, great success!
::X MARK:: FAIL.

PS: Careful eating your first dumpling. They are extremely hot when they come to the table. Give it a min or two to cool down. Hope this was helpful. Enjoy!

this place is very good for Chinese fan food. 

the food is very cheap. we ate a lot kinds of food but still pay cheap price.

recommended this place when you come to NY.

one thing I don't like: cash only, but cash only is popular in NY.

What do you order at a Shanghai Restaurant?

Of course, SOUP DUMPLINGS!!  

You MUST order the CRAB and/or PORK MEAT SOUP DUMPLINGS when you go to Joe's Shanghai!!  Trust me, if you are here with a group of friends and family, you'd want to order more because 1 order only comes in 8.  Before you know it, 8 of them will disappear into everyone's tummy.  Anyhow, back to the soup dumplings.  The meat and soup are mixed incredibly well inside the thin layered dumpling.  To top it off, the dumplings taste even more scrumptious after dipping 'em in some ginger/vinager soy sauce.  I just love it!!
