Come eat their soup dumplings!! This was the best soup dumplings I've ever had. We stayed in Chinatown right next door to this restaurant so we had to try it. The dumpling soup was oozing out of my mouth while I ate it but that was the best part. Soupy and chewy, just how I like my soup dumplings. If you are in Chinatown, this is a must try!
Community style dining with great dumplings.  Very strict wait staff.  We were told what to eat, lucky for us the food was tasty.

as a self respecting shanghainese, i cannot give this place more than 4 stars. but boy am i glad that it's on this side of the ocean! yum. totally makes me miss shanghai. places like this are just a drop in the bucket there... sigh. there are rules for how locals eat xiao long bao and also secrets for how to prepare the juiciest hehe. okay i'm going to stop now bc i sound very elitest.

"THIS IS A MUST TRY!!!" FOR CHINATOWN It was difficult finding food that caught my eye, Gotta say the food from here was QUITE amazing FYI Me and my family had the fried rice, low mein, beef & broccoli, orange chicken & the dumplings everything was beyond fire. Recommend making reservations early the line can get crazy, since our hotel had a patio we ordered to go We went a little overboard but enjoyed the leftovers the next day

This is my second time at Joe's Shanghai. I first visited the Flushing, Queens location about a year or so ago. Yesterday, I visited the China town location in Manhattan. When we arrived, the hostess informed us that there was a 30 minute wait (we were a party of 4) however, we were seated about 5 minutes later which was a major plus. 

We started with soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. BOTH ARE MUST HAVES (especially the soup dumplings which is what Joe's is known for). Since we were a party of four, we ordered multiple dishes which we all shared. LITERALLY EVERYTHING WAS DELICIOUS! The General Tso's chicken was probably the best General Tso's I've ever had.

I guess the only downside was thaour waiter so badly did not want to be there. It was written all over his face. If he wasn't such a Debbie downer, I'd have given five stars. Otherwise, phenomenal food and fun atmosphere!

Sat down very quickly, and waiter was attentive. I order the pork dumplings (8 for $6!) great choice. The egg roll was kind of pathetic to be honest. Friends got the soup dumplings and enjoyed.
Honestly, great food for a great deal. Would come back!

Somehow ended up here late night with a few friends. Ordered a round of soup dumplings and some other delicious dishes. 

Memory is a bit hazy- did Whiskey Tavern come first? Or after? 

Just wanted to include a brief review, as this would make a good jury duty lunch break. The service is quick and it's walking distance from the courts. I wish I came here instead... still craving soup dumplings.

dumplings!!!!
this location is better than the other located in queens...but i havent been to the midtown east location yet.
Amazing. We had the crab and pork soup dumplings as well as the pork soup dumpling. Both were equally amazing, but I liked the crab best of the two. Must visit in Chinatown

After hearing all the hype about Joe's Shanghai, I decided to give it a try when I was in the area during lunch. We got there at 11:30 and there was not a single table that wasn't occupied. Immediately I thought, the hype must be real and I was even more excited.

Ordered the pork soup dumplings and they were delicious. I really wanted to try the pork and crab soup dumplings but my friend doesn't eat crab so I settled for the pork. It was good and just the right amount of juice inside the dumpling. The fried pan noodles were also good- tasty, noodles were great, right amount of pork. One of the orders came out incorrectly and they had no problem switching it and correcting the mistake. 

I would definitely return but because it is so busy at night, I would opt for going during lunch.

Come early and expect lines. They only accept cash so go hit up a ATM first. Famous soup dumplings. They moved from their original location. More spacious and updated then the original spot. Happy the AC was pumping during this hot July day. Soup dumplings was on point. Make sure to let it cool before you punch a hole in the dough to release that savory hearty heavy soup broth. I wasn't careful and the soup squirted all over my shirt and pants. Battle scars but worth  walking  around stained shirt and pants.
Tasty and then some, ordered scallion pancakes and pork dumplings, also a crab and pork dumpling. Sauces on point, fast service!!

This place is awesome. The pork dumplings are amazing. The water spinach definitely compliments it. We even sat next to Japanese people who coached us though ordering and properly eating the dumplings. One of the best eating experiences I have ever had. I will eat here again if I can.

Came back again for the nth time and tried the Lion's Heads for the first time.  The giant meatballs were so tender and tasty and rival the best Lion's Heads in China.  I was also impressed that the waiters didn't rush us even though there was a long line of people waiting to be seated and it was prime dinner time (Saturday at 6-7pm).

Everytime I visit NY I make sure to stop by Joe's for some Xiao Long Baos.  They're basically pork soup dumplings.  I don't know how hard these are to make, but in the Bay Area I know of only one place that can make them close to how Joe's makes them....with just the right amount of soup and pork.  Most of the Xiao Long Bao dumplings here come with the either come with the skin too thick or not enough soup.  The dumplings are are affordable at around $7.  I've also tried the onion pancake as well as noodle dishes, but the main reason I visit are the dumplings.    

Basically you put one of those bad boys on a soup spoon, nibble a little of the top of the dumpling, and pour some of that vinegar sauce on top.  YUM!

Visit Joe's for the food.  Not for the service.  Most of the times you won't get a friendly smile, a waiter trying to make conversation, or smiley faces on your check.  The service is cut throat, no frills, here's your food, eat it and leave so we can seat the next party type of thing.  They're  trying to get you in and out.  If you go at peak times during lunch and dinner, expect a line.  The wait to get seated can be very long.
Hands down one of the best places to eat in all of NYC.  The food was amazing. The service was great! The atmosphere was authentic and inviting.  Definitely try the dumpling appetizer!

I was in Chinatown and decided to try this much talked about place. The inside and outside are just like any other typical Chinatown place. The prices here are comparable as well.

We had an order of fried dumplings and also the soup dumplings as well. They were both very good and very succulent. I actually liked the fried ones more (despite the soup ones being the specialty here), simply because I am a bigger fan of fried.

Also, I tried some of their Fried Rice, which was well done but with the same quality you would find in any Chinatown place. The other entree I tried was their Fried Rice Cakes with Beef. Their version here was excellent. The Fried Rice Cakes dish is very similar in taste to Beef Chow Fun except the noodles are shaped like discs and are chewier. I like the way this restaurant prepared the beef in it as well - very soft and moist.

I've been here so many times and would take friends here all the time. The wait times aren't as bad when you go during off-times. However, this place has gotten so much busier than before. We waited 45 min at 3pm for 3 people. Go in small groups to get seated faster. They now also add the gratuity to the bill that they didn't do before. Still pretty cheap for some good soup dumplings. Other stuff on the menu are really good as well! I would recommend scallion pancakes and turnip cakes if you want to try something different!

Very clean environment and the food was very good.  The service was quick (perhaps because it isn't during hottest time of the day) and the food came out a lot quicker than expected.  The pot has a lot of things in it including crab, fish, mussels, etc.  I personally liked the Ma Po Tofu.  Highly recommend!

Brace yourself for the musty air, seafood stench, and Shanghainese flavors, all faintly yet pleasantly grazing your olfactory receptors. That, my friends, is a recipe for a legit Chinatown experience. By luck, our party of 3 was seated right away in a full house on a Tuesday at 7:30pm. We got 3 orders of XLB, an order of scallion pancakes, and the shrimp fried rice cakes. Soup dumplings have just the right consistency--skin breaks with the slightest puncture so handle them with some TLC before chomping down. I recommend ordering each round individually to maximize the freshness of the dumplings. The scallion pancakes were a bit drier than expected, but nothing too unpleasant. With the best for last, the shrimp fried rice cakes are a must-try. Generous portion size with a plethora of rice cakes, right amount of shrimp & mushrooms, and minimal veggies. All for ~$50 with tip. As anticipated, service moved quick. Expect to sit elbow-to-elbow with other parties in the same table, which I think adds to the experience. This place is no joke.

The food here is SO good! I love soup dumplings and really enjoyed the pork ones at Joe's. I also thought their wonton soup was perfect. Overall, if you're looking for staple Chinese dishes (such as noodle soups, dumplings, fried rice, and protein-centric plates) you're going to enjoy this place.

Disclaimer: It is cash only. Plus, their seating system is hectic AF. When my group arrived they were swamped and gave us a ticket with a number on it. They called our ticket and gave us less than a minute to make our way through the chaos to the stand before giving up our spot. Then, the host was a little rude about the situation...but we enjoyed our food once we made it in. Worth it though.

Craving soup dumplings?  Save yourself the 16 hours flight to Shanghai and see Joe's in Chinatown.  They will hook you up with 8 of the most delicious crab/pork dumplings for only $8.75.  The pork dumpling are amazing too for $6.75 for 8 pieces.  Everything else on their menu ranges from ok to meh.  For dinner sometimes there is a crowd, but midweek is ok.  They also do pick-up orders.

How anyone can review JS with lower than 5 stars is beyond me. 

Here's a tip: do NOT got here for anything but the Soup Dumplings. They are like pure heaven erupting into your mouth- pork or crab! I was introduced to this place 6 years ago when I got back from traveling abroad from SE Asia and I was super impressed. The ambiance is also super fun if you are looking for a truly family-style place that takes you out of the cold in NYC. You will sit at a full table of strangers, so if you are on a first date and do not want to be to intimate yet, this is the place for you. Seating goes quickly as does ordering and food delivery.

I love Joes!

Din Tai Fung has NOTHING on this place.  Yes, I've been to Din Tai Fung MULTIPLE times.  Yes, I know what it taste like.  NO!  It is not better than Joe's Shanghai.

First and foremost, these Xiao long bao's are THE MOST SOUPY/JUCIEST one's I've EVER had.  I tried the crab and pork based on the numerous recommendations here on yelp.  Well guess what, 400 people aren't wrong.  They are both amazing.  I'll save you from reading what everyone else has typed and just say, "go out and try it"

Aside from the xiao long bao I had the hot and sour soup, kung pao chicken and the shanghai noodles.  All were very good, especially the noodles.  While they weren't as amazing as the xiao long bao, they were good enough to add to them.  It just helps me affirm this 5 star rating.

Pros:
 - AMAZING xiao long bao
 - solid chinese food

Cons:
 - the wait (I waited around 45 minutes for dinner on a Sunday night)
 - seating (you share seating around a table of 8)

A little over priced but food was great! Lots of seating and a wide selection. Great place to get soup dumplings but also all the local New Yorkers go to flushing for the best soup dumplings. Portion sizes are pretty good and we had no wait on a Wednesday evening with a part of 3
Good soup dumplings. There is long lines. You need to go either before 11am or after 2 pm if you don't want to wait.
Best dumplings ever! The shrimp fried rice was super good too! Will definitely be back here soon! Yum!

Amazing, addictive, legendary soup dumplings? Check. Tasty beef with bean curd? Check. Loud, crazy atmosphere with typical Chinatown service? Check.  Worth the 45 minute wait and every penny? Most definitely.  I cannot wait to go back!

Of course there's going to be a wait. So be prepared! We were super excited to try the dumplings here since we LOVE XLB (Shanghai dumplings) so that was the only thing we had. We ordered both the pork and the crab. The pork had more flavor and also soup more than the crab. So I recommend on ordering just the pork dumplings!

For this place, you just gotta forget about the decor, the service, and the ambiance. Why? Because it's a Chinese place right in Chinatown that serves some pretty seriously delicious soup dumplings. And Chinese service is most of the time, pretty bad. Have you been to a dimsum place before? It's just the culture. There's so many people in there and waiting outside for their food they gotta turn them table quick. 

Been here many times throughout the years and this place never let me down on the taste of the food. Soup dumplings always come out piping hot. My favorite is the crab pork soup dumplings. I also get a fried rice dish that I can't remember the name of in English but it has all the meats in there plus shrimp and egg. The scallion pancakes are pretty good too.

All in all its an awesome place to go for some good soup dumplings and don't be surprised if there is a long wait time.
Their soup dumplins are the best, I we also had the friend rice and General Tso's chicken. Best Chinese I've ever had in the USA. Worth the short wait, takes only cash.

Joes Shanghai was delicious. We had the meat soup dumplings, braised 1/2 duck, and scallion pancake.  The soup dumplings were perfect on a cold January day, the scallion pancakes were authentic, and the duck was easily the best ever I've had. The meat was incredibly soft and came right off the bone. The texture was very similar to pork ribs, and the sauce was just right!

Joe's Shanghai is more about getting a hold of those tasty little soup dumplings packed with huge flavor whenever you can for me. So here is the deal. 

I read some of the reviews on here and some of the obvious statements that some people make are hilariously contradictory within the same paragraph. Ok, moving on ;)

Sure there are probably better "Soup Dumplings" or what they refer to as Xiao Long Bao (XLB's), in the world. I would hope so, especially in China.... no?

Point is there is NOWHERE better in NYC for the price, the taste, and plainly the SOUP DUMPLINGS Period!  (*purposely equally contradictory statement*)

The soup dumplings are BOMB. If you come here after 6:15pm Mon-Wed then you are going to wait. DO NOT sit around looking like you don't belong anywhere in all of Chinatown when you arrive. Walk straight in and look for the asian girl with the clipboard and ticket numbers, let her know how many people in your party, and take a number. Thursday - Sunday you would have to get there by 5:30pm to not have any real wait. After that, good luck. 

We normally order the pork/crab dumplings. They are the ones we like best, some bok choy, a bit of shrimp fried rice and a couple of traditional "New York" chinese dishes like Kung Pao or Chicken Broccoli. Irrelevant since we really just come for the dumplings, beer and bok choy. 

Joe's Shanghai is an absolute MUST especially if you have never had a soup dumpling in your life before and whether or not you are from NYC or not. If you are NOT from NYC, are visiting in town, and not sure of when you will ever be back, then for you it is DEFINITELY, 100%, POSITIVELY A MUST! and, you will be hooked. 

Make sure while you're waiting outside you read up on their window of articles, how to eat the soup dumplings properly so that you don't burn your mouth on the first bite and actually get to enjoy the thing. For those of you that may get a little nervous from the pressure of this, it's ok - You can also order a small soup bowl, which my brother does, and just dump the dumpling in it and enjoy in all its glory! 

Remember that the place is CASH only. The cheapest ATM, in case you do forget your cash, is the .99 cent ATM inside the McDonalds on Bowery between Pell and Bayard. It's a half a block away so basically, if you are standing at the door of Joe's Shanghai facing outside you make a right as soon as you get out of the restaurant and walk to that corner. You can cross the street and walk to the corner since you will have to cross it later anyway. That corner will be "Bowery" at which point you then make a left on Bowery and walk a few paces until you see the golden arches on your left side, where the storefronts will be, as you walk towards "Bayard". McDonald's is literally on that block. 

Also remember that it is communal sitting so you're not thrown off if you happen to be seated with other people. If you are a group of 2 or 4 you can request some of the private tables for your party, which just means you may have to wait  a little longer. Big Groups are great here but you do wait longer as well, and everyone in your party must be there to be seated or they will skip you until your party arrives, so keep that in mind.

Regardless of the wait and cash only thing, the soup dumplings are a must try and nothing really ever beats the experience and atmosphere of being in Chinatown for me anyway, which Joe's Shanghai helps to complete somehow. 

5 stars for the dumplings alone. They are worth the wait.

As a new comer to Chinese food, I give this place a top review. Insanely great soup dumplings, I could eat the whole bowl to myself. I also had the fried dumplings, just as incredible. It's community seating for the most part, so come ready to sit with strangers (probably not a great place for 1st and 2nd dates). Also, be ready to wait outside for at least 15 minutes if coming for dinner. There hasn't been a night of the week I haven't had to wait. It's a top place for soup dumplings! P.S. - bring cash.

The place is always crowded but its worth the wait. Service is prompt and attentive meaning you get your food fast. While the menu is vast the best item  is the soup Dumplings. The Dumplings are very delicate due to being filled with a rich broth to drink before consuming the rest with complementary black vinegar and chili oil. The next best item in my opinion is the fried rice. Whether it's the chicken,  beef, pork, or Shanghai style each version has its own unique flavor that when mixed together creates a new depth. All in all a great place to go with a few people and try several dishes. Just make sure to get enough soup Dumplings for everyone.

Great place for soup dumplings!! Other dishes are just okay.

If you visit during the week, the wait is tolerable (~15 minutes) during regular meal times (lunch or dinner) and almost immediate towards the beginning or tail end of their operating hours.

If you visit in the weekend, expect a hefty wait unless there's a huge weather event (snowing, rain, etc.)

The key is to march in there confidently and find the lady with the clip board. Give her your name and number of people in your party, and she will tell you how long, and most of the time give you a number. If not, she will tell you to stand aside and table will be coming right up.

The soup dumplings are quite big (compared to Din Tai Fung), soupy, flavorful, and very satisfying. Tip: Order one to start and then as soon as the first one comes, tell the server you want another. Many times, people order two soup dumplings at once and by the time they're done with the first one, the second one on the bottom is already cooled.

I actually think this place may be better than Din Tai Fung as the soup dumplings are more filling, cheaper, and doesn't have MSG (at least I don't go home thirsty after eating here).

This is a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Do not expect good service. Fight to eat. Eat to fight. Don't be offended if the servers are dismissive, impatient, yelling at each other, or in a bad mood. Imagine yourself working there a week and perhaps you'll behave the same way.

Flag down any of the servers for anything you need. If they're not the right person, they'll talk to the right person for your table/section.

Also, service charge is already included in the bill. Cash only as many others have stated but there's an ATM right outside the inner door now.
It was everything we hoped for and more. We were craving soup dumplings, and soup dumplings we had. Cheap, tasty, and relatively healthy.

Maybe this is an opinion influenced by extreme hunger (we had just trekked across the Brooklyn Bridge before coming to Joe's), but these are the best soup dumplings I've ever had. I got scared when I saw that the line was out the door, but the hostess was super efficient and quick with seating - shared tables help with this. So so good!

Went there with a friend to try their soup dumplings. Got the regular pork soup dumplings and it was good but not to the point where I am surprised. There were a lot of people and it was very crowded. shared a big table with three other sets of people and were squashed. but despite all the people they didnt get our orders wrong. only thing i disliked was that it was hard to call someone if you needed something.

5 stars for the food was so good, I got the pork dumpling and orange chicken. They are family style plates but are on the smaller side but still delicious!
2 stars for the staff, they  left a little bit to be desired, the food was sort of just dropped off in front of you and I felt tense. Not sure if it was because of I had a service dog but they asked a couple times if we were done yet with food still on our plate. Know it's a busy place so not reading too much into it but the food was delicious.

I did one order of the pork soup dumpling at Joe's Shanghai -- the soup was a great temperature, minimal tongue scalding and very flavorful. The black vinegar had a vaguely medicinal taste, but otherwise was good. Dumplings has strong structural integrity and we're sticky when I chewed them. Only negative with the dumplings was that they didn't have the ginger seals that some others do. Would happily take friends/family there are on future occasions.

Solid 4 stars. 

Since my most extensive experience with xiao long bao has been with Din Tai Fung (been to the locations in Costa Mesa, Arcadia, Seattle, Taiwan, and Hong Kong), this review will focus largely on comparing the two locations.

Where Joe's Shanghai wins:
- Soup:dumpling ratio: There have been times when I bite into DTF's xiao long bao's and the amount of soup was disappointingly small. The XLB at Joe's were so juicy that I had trouble eating it (a good problem to have). 
- Pricing: prices here are substantially cheaper than DTF's, which means more bang for your buck. 

Where Din Tai Fung wins:
- Flavor of the soup: the soup in the XLB at DTF has a noticeably more complex flavor profile. 
- Service: more polite, but I think that comes with the fact that DTF has a more upscale ambiance. Minor win. 
- Other food items: at both DTF and Joe's, I've ordered some of their non-XLB dishes. The food at Joe's overall was just okay - not bad, but not stellar. Their scallion pancakes were good, but it was really fried and rather oily. Their vegetable dish was mediocre, and was actually the most expensive thing we ordered. The noodle soup was rather bland - would definitely skip. DTF's other menu items are overshadowed by their XLB, but it's better than the one's I tried at Joe's. 

Differences:
- Atmosphere: many of the DTF locations are on the nicer end, with a clean, upscale atmosphere. Joe's Shanghai on the other hand is more similar to your typical Asian restaurants - loud and casual. Not a pro or a con in my book for either case. 

Overall, I wish that DTF and Joe's Shanghai's would fuse together - bigger, juicier XLB at a cheaper price, with DTF's soup base. But very solid 4 stars - would definitely go back if I'm in the area.

After indulging in Philly cheese steaks for lunch, the bf and I wanted something light to eat for dinner. Since we took an earlier Bolt bus back into NYC, we decided to head to Joe's since we were supposed to check it out last night.

I've heard so much about this place from friends who have visited and since I love xlbs, I had to get an order...or two. Thankfully we arrived at the right time which meant not having to wait for a table. We entered the very tightly packed restaurant and told one of the girls (who are wearing by the way, florescent yellow/green sweatshirts) we wanted a table for 2 people. Since the place is so tight and busy, they seat you homestyle, meaning you're sharing the table with another party.

Once we sat we got our hot tea and ordered one order of the pork (which I heard is the best and costs ~$5 for 8 pieces) and one order of the pork and crab combo (~$7 for 8 pieces). It took about 10 minutes for the xlbs but when they arrived, I forgot about how long it took and jumped in.

On first glance, the xlbs look larger than the standard sizes I've seen in Richmond, Canada and in Burlingame. But when you try to lift one off the bed of cabbage, make sure you grab from the top or you'll break the dough and all the sweet, tasty meat sauce will be gone.

I felt there was more xlb sauce than meat which I was a bit disappointed in. The skin was thin and chewy and the pork meat tender. You get a side dish of vinegar with pieces of ginger. I like ginger with my xlbs so that added accompaniment was appreciated. The pork and crab combo....yeah, don't even get an order. It's not worth the price or the taste buds. Luckily my bf is a human vacuum with an indiscriminate palate so he got to finish the pork and crab combo while I enjoyed my pork dumplings.

If you like xlbs or want to try them, I'd definitely recommend this place. Just be prepared to wait in line and make sure you have cash on hand since they don't accept plastic.
We came for one thing and one thing only. Soup dumplings! Boy did they not disappoint. The broth was fantastic and the pork full of flavor.

I've been to the one in Flushing and quality and look of restaurant is the same. We arrived around 9:30 on. Monday night so it wasn't very busy but still a good amount of people - they sat us right away. We got the pork soup dumplings, chicken fried rice, and Shanghai noodle soup. Everything was fresh, came out very fast and was delicious. Can't wait to come back and try some other dishes!

There was a time when I would come here with my friends in earnest. We'd wait outside for an eternity as the hostess kept promising everyone that their table would be ready soon. After an hour, sometimes two, we'd go in and see who could eat the most dumplings. I usually got to two baskets before keeling over and dieing. The soup dumplings are still good, but no longer the best in the city. They're definitely not worth the long waits. The rest of the menu is surprisingly good as well. I love scallion pancakes and they do a great one. All of the usual Americanized stuff is there and executed much better than expected. And it's still pretty cheap.

Best soup dumplings I've ever had.

Yes, it's crowded, but it's an institution!

This place has the best dumplings I've ever had! My family has gone here before, but we wanted to find it again because of one thing we loved the first time we went, the soup dumpling. We had gone to chinatown in Italy not long ago to get some soup dumplings, unfortunately they disappointed us. We got to this restaurant and were instantly seated at a table, we ordered some pork soup dumpling, scallion pancakes, spring rolls, and fried dumplings. The food came out in a couple minutes and we tried one of everything, and it did not disappoint. All of the food was delicious. The soup dumpling broth was rich in flavor and the scallion pancakes were very crispy. The only thing that was not entirely perfect was the spring rolls, instead of spring rolls they gave us egg rolls, it was not a big deal though because they were still delicious!
The look of the restaurant is beautiful and very clean!
I will definitely be telling my friends to come here!
Soup Dumplings were great but regular menu items are hit or miss. If you do order something other than dumplings, the fish belly is really good.

I recommend the food at Joe's Shanghai for lunch.  It is not overcrowded, however, you may need to share the table with other guests (pretty normal in chinese restaurants).  At times, I pass by the restaurant during dinner time and the long waiting lines form outside the restaurant.  

It has the authentic taste from Shanghai and I usually order:
- Crab Meat with Pork Meat Steamed Bun (8 per order) 
- 3 cold dishes platter with Braised Sliced Beef, jelly fish, Wine Chicken
- Lion's Head (Stewed Pork Balls)
- Lima Bean Salad and Pork with Bean Curd Tripe (for healthy eaters)

The quality of the food is consistent everytime I visit the restaurant.  
There is a 15% tip included in the check, which is very reasonable.

(12.12.15) Yum, yum! Had the pork soup dumplings and the crab & pork soup dumplings. The ginger in the soy sauce was great. Line is incredibly long and they pack you in like sardines, but it's worth it for the experience. They even have pics of Jeremy Lin's visit there on their walls!
Very simple, go for the dumplings.  Everything else is good, but your standard Chinese restaurant offering, the dumplings, excellent!

I had been hearing for months from my friend how awesome they were.  They're frigging dumplings, how good can they be?  Up until now, my experience with dumplings have been at cheap chinese restaurants around Los Angeles and Orange County.  Probably not the greatest frame of reference, but if there are people in front of Joe's waiting with Cold War-like paranoia making sure the girl didn't pass up their number it can't be all bad.

The dumplings were amazing.  The soup inside was so tasty and with each dumpling I ate, I was simultaneously happy that I was eating them and sad that there was one less dumpling for me to enjoy.  My girlfriend, her friend and I split one order of the pork dumplings, one order of the crab dumplings, the water spinach, and the noodles (I forget what kind, but they were damn good too).  

I guess the only sticking point could be that you may sit at a table with strangers because it's so crowded.  It gets kind of awkward when they get your food before you and they get to eat while you're frigging starving.

#9, #10. That's all you need to say. They call soup dumplings "buns", so if you actually try to order by the menu you could get confused. To be honest I could not tell the difference between the shrimp or pork dumplings, but the ones I think were the shrimp ones tasted better. Also go with scallion pancake and shanghai noodles.

The difference in wait between 2 ppl and 3 is significant, since if you're group of 3 they'll wait for an 8 person table to open up so that they can sit you with another group of 3 and a group of 2.

Stuffed my face and in the end was less than 20 bucks a person.

Luckily no wait! Came on a Friday night and got seated immediately. Ordered the scallion pancake and XLB. The pancake was a bit thick and not a lot of green onions... It was a good crisp but other than that probably wouldn't order again. So at least 4 of the XLB skins broke upon contact which is a downgrade BUT if you are able to get an intact XLB in one bite then man is it good. The soup is flavorful and there's plenty of meat with not too much skin. If you're in the area and there's not a long wait I'd give it a try.

I've been here twice now and love their Xiao long bao both the crab and pork ones. Scallion pan cake is another favorite dish of mine. Avoid weekends or holidays if you don't want to stand in line for hours to get a table. You most of the time will be seated with other strangers so get comfortable.

We were able to sit outside due to COVID and I'm so glad we did. The weather was great. Besides that, the food was absolutely delicious. We had soup dumplings, hot and sour soup, and Kung Pao chicken. Food was flavorful and made quickly. Service was awesome. Will definitely recommend!
Great food, exact same owner and menu as down the block except less crowded. Food is usually good but I have to give them 4 stars because the staff isn't attentive enough.

Delicious dragon buns!!!  This place makes the best soup dumplings for sure.  

Every dish there is good, but, do not skip the dragon buns/soup dumplings, since that's what they are famous for.

Damn good soup dumplings, but you're on Yelp so you already knew that.  Everything else is pretty typical - pickled veg, beef pan fried noodles, decent service.  Only other thing worth noting is it's cash only.

Dumpling heaven! I mean really, the holy grail! 

Came in on a Saturday night, so it was predictably crowded, but the wait wasn't long. It was also systematic, with numbered chits and what not! Got seated at a large round table with 2 other couples, but didn't mind since this wasn't expected to be fine dining in any case.

Too bad that they only accept cash though, and since we'd been to 3 pubs earlier the same evening where we felt inclined to tip well, both of us were running (scraping-the-bottom-of-the-barrel) low. Soo, all we tried was the pork soup dumpling! But the tip from a friend paid off, and these were awesome! The spicy sauce went beautifully with the piping hot, delicately flavored little bags of soupy, meaty, goodness, and they were gone in 60 seconds! Man, if only I had more cash on me! 

Servers were efficient and polite as well, and we'll probably be back to try some more stuff on the menu. So glad we stopped by!

The point of eating authentic Shanghai dumplings is BECAUSE of the juicy wet meat juice inside of the Dumpling. If you don't like their dumpling because it easily breaks PLEASE TRY your local chinese take out that trick "foreigners"

IF YOU PREFER to eat dry dumplings then please head to a Allen St Dumpling or if you prefer bootleg thick coated dumplings please head to your Great Wall take out.

HOW TO EAT SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS 1)enjoy the sweet aroma when it is served 2)carefully use the tong and pick up the dumplings one by one to prevent it from sticking 3) when you want to eat one, carefully use the tong and pick it up NOT from the bottom but from the hardest spot - the top 4)quickly use your soup spoon and place the dumpling on it. 5)add some vinegar/soy sauce on it if you like 6)bite the top(the hardest part)and slowly suck the juice out 7)finish it 

*Please don't eat the cabbage underneath the dumplings.....

*Customer service suckkkks here. They always seem on a rush to kick you out.(then again, there is usually a huge line) Worse, they just seem really agitated. I've not met one close to friendly server here - so don't expect much. 

*Crowded. Expect to sit next to old grannies to drunken drunks.(alcohol friendly) Hey, you get to meet new people.(The truth is almost 99% of the time the people you sit with are A-ok)

THE BEST DARN SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS IN NYC. Oh yea, I also visit san francisco alot and many sf'ers say SF does not have a dumpling place like this.

This was my 2nd visit to Joe's, specifically for steamed dumplings and they didn't disappoint. So simple, flavorful and delicious.

My own complaint was that we were sitting right by the door and it was getting chilly, so we got cold every time the door was opened.

Can't wait for my next visit...
Good service, very good food. The restaurant itself is an easy laid back traditional Asian restaurant
Even if you don't order their famous dumplings (which all contain pork), this is still a great place, and a great value.

I've found that the more hole in the wall a dim sum place is, the more I'm gonna like it! This spot is no exception. 
It was packed- but they managed to seat my party of two immediately (the turnover speed is INSANE!). 
The food is so inexpensive, we decided to get at least 5 dishes. Everything came fast and at a great pace, so we didn't feel rushed or hungry! 
The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because the crispy noodles were very chewy- not crispy.

I always come here for two things: pork/crab dumplings and beef rice cakes! When I'm in town, I often take solo visits here and just enjoy the food. This is their newer location so it's nice and spacious. Waiting times are often not too long and if anything, there's a bunch of boba shops and bakeries nearby you can check out while you wait. The service is fast. They take safety precautions with temperature checks. Would recommend to anyone who comes to Chinatown, you won't regret it.
Best soup dumpling ever, get the crab meat one. It was an hour wait for us , but it's totally worth it

CASH ONLY 

Yes
Pork soup dumplings
Fried potstickers 
Chicken fried rice
Sesame chicken 
Thick noodles 
Wonton soup

My favorite restaurant of all time.
There's always a wait to get into the place, but it's totally worth it!
The soup dumplings? THE BEST. They're famous for good reason. And the dumplings aren't the only worthwhile thing on the menu! Try the Shanghai noodles. When I die, heaven had better be FULL of them, because they are the tastiest noodles I've ever eaten!

I'd recommend Joe's to anyone. Yes, it's crowded and noisy, and since it's family style you may be sharing a table with a stranger, but it's all part of the experience. Everyone should go here at least once for amazing, authentic food!

A must-go every time I am in nyc. I love the soup dumplings and the taiwanese noodle stir fry. Everything is very reasonably priced and delicious. It is true that the service could be better and you will get seated with random strangers but its somewhat expected of Chinese restaurants. Overall enjoy coming here and to me is the ultimate comfort food..!

Love this place. I tell everyone to go here. The soup dumplings, orange beef and fried rice are my recommends. It's also a good place to try something new! It can be a wait but totally worth it and you get SO MUCH FOOD. It can also great really loud but that's part of it. Feels like Chinatown but it's not weird. Check out their website, too--they've made a funny video about how to eat the soup dumplings. Ha.
honestly, this is some of the best chinese i've ever had. the orange chicken is perfect. i  joe's shanghai!

Excellent! I ended up finding this place on yelp myself and after reading reviews, we decided to give it a shot. We were not disappointed. There was never an empty seat! At first the seating arrangements were odd to us but at the end we really enjoyed the company and the food was just delicious!

Probably one of the best place for "xiao long bao" (pork one! i dont like the crabmeat) in the USA. I forgot the other restaurant in NYC that is also very good...It's not really compareble to Asia because a lot of them broke because their were stuck to the plate thing and the soup spilled out which kind of defeated the purpose of the whole dumpling...

Their shanghai fried rice---OMG ORDER IT!!!! I just ordered it on a whim because it had "shanghai" in its name and when it came, you don't know how disappointed I was just looking at it. I was thinking to myself "oh god, it look so plain...it must taste awful." NOPE. Took a bite and my eyes lit up. I said "Wow, this is the best fried rice i've ever tasted." Or one of the best. And everyone agreed. Also got the pork noodle-- that was okay. The scallion pancakes were nice..but so greasy. My friend got the "artificial duck" because she's a vegetarian..I tried to stop her..but she wouldn't listen. And in the end she said it tasted like rubber and mushrooms. Ew.

Oh, there's a long wait. We waited..maybe 30 minutes...or more...around 8pm on a Sunday. I guess if you eat a lil later you don't really have to wait...

dont order anything but the Shanghai dumplings, with crab or shrimp or pork, they are all very good. Service & ambience sucks though, so you have to close an eye and just enjoy those freaking dumplings!!

We were visiting New York and definitely wanted to stop by and see what soup dumplings were all about! Our wait was about 45 mins long and we were seated with two other groups so it was very interesting to say the least. I guess they were trying to seat everyone as soon as possible.  We ordered to orders of the pork Xiao long baos, spring rolls and shanghai fried noodles.

The spring rolls came out first and they were nice and hot. The fillings was your standard but they were a lot larger than we expected.

The noodles came out a little after and they were good but a little too greasy for my liking.

The pork xiao long baos finally came out and they were steaming hot in all their deliciousness. The dumplings came out piping hot and were overflowing with delicious broth that was full of depth and flavor. The sauce was a nice compliment to the savoriness of the dumplings.

Overall, this was our first experience at soup dumplings and we found them delicious. Other than the wait, we would definitely consider coming back again!

Must visit!!!

Joe's Shanghai was on my to-visit list and it did not disappoint, at all :) My boyfriend and I visited around 4:45PM on a Saturday and was seated after waiting for around 5 minutes. I think we were lucky because I've heard how crazy the wait can be on Yelp.

We got 2 orders of the soup dumpling bc duh and wonton soup, scallion pancake, fried rice.

Pork soup dumpling (10/10) STAR OF THE SHOW i'm not kidding when i say it's the best xlb i've ever had! It's huge and at a great price. The skin is thin and has the perfect chew but no so thin that it breaks inside the steamer. Sooo much soup inside and the filling is seasoned well. I could taste the gelatin from pork bones and it was right up my alley :D

Everything else was also good but nothing that blew my mind :) Service was also okay. We paid $65 after t&t for 2 people and had leftovers to bring home. 

Food 4/5
XLB 5/5
Service 3/5
Experience 4.8/5

This place is all it's talked up to be. You must get the soup dumplings and eat them first. They are best fresh and not worth taking for later. The green beans were delicious and the pan fried noodles were very good. The place is small and you have to share a table with other people, but the great thing about that is that the people you share the table with sometimes leave you their leftovers!

My friends and I went here to try out Joe's Shanghai.  We had to try out the soup dumplings and we just ordered a side of fried rice.  I've had Dinh Tai Fung's soup dumplings in Arcadia, Ca and I must say, Joe's Shanghai is pretty descent.  Nothing beats Dinh Tai Fung (since they have a VARIETY of soup dumplings), but Joe's is pretty close.  Unfortunately they only have Pork Dumplings so vegetarians or pescatarians be informed.  For the price, its reasonable.  8 dumplings for 4.25 ~ 0.50 cents each.  Try it out, I am sure you will like it!

Couple of things to know on how to eat the soup dumpling.

1.  Place soup dumpling on spoon.
2.  Use chopsticks and puncture one whole allowing soup to seep out a little.
3.  Place sauce on top.  (IF you want the sauce to be a bit spicier, mix the chili in, helps enhance your taste buds!)
4.  Devour in one bite to enjoy party in mouth!
Our server Ken was very friendly and excellent.  Steamed buns Were worth the wait!
Love the crab and pork soup dumplings! There are places with better value soup dumplings, but I still like to frequent this place.

Come for their Xiao Long Bao!! We were quickly seated, but since it was busy they seated us in a large table that had two empty seats. Everyone was friendly and enjoyed their own meal/conversations so it wasn't a big deal. If you wanted your own table, you could specify but it'd probably be a much longer wait. 

The XLB was one of the best I've ever had! There's so much soup that it nearly filled my whole spoon. They're also cheap and come out quickly! I ordered two (8 pieces each) and it made us both extremely full. I'd high recommend trying their pork XLB - it's worth the hype!

This is my first review of Joe's Shanghai's but I have been several times now. I have been to the one in Manhattan and the one in Chinatown most recently which this review is based on. The one in Chinatown was a little hard to find at first because it recently moved to a different location and my uber ride took me to the older location. Luckily, it was still walking distance to the new location so it wasn't a big deal but just something to keep in mind. The new location is 46 Bowery St which is a bigger and much nicer space than before. 
Every time I go to Joe's I always order the same thing which is the soup dumplings with pork and the scallion pancakes. Both are very delicious (especially the soup dumplings) and are something I crave every time I am in NYC! The soup dumplings are not available where I live (SC) and so this makes them even more enticing every time I come to NYC.  I would say they are the best soup dumplings in the city but that would not be fair because I have heard there are many other places in NYC that have great soup dumplings as well but I never want to take the chance of being disappointed since I usually have very limited time when I am in the city. Having said that, you cannot go wrong here by coming here for the soup dumplings and this is always a must do spot in the city if that is what you are craving. The only caveat with going here or to any of the locations is that you are looking at a 45-60 minute wait which is annoying but I feel like it is still worth the wait. I am giving Joe's 4 stars only because I have ONLY eaten the scallion pancakes and soup dumplings and they have a pretty extensive menu available. I do not feel like it is fair to judge an entire restaurant based on 2 items off the menu even though they are so delicious. I will say though that I have seen other food items come out of the kitchen and they all looked really good.

Pro Tip: If you go to the new location in Chinatown then go next door to the hotel called Hotel 50 Bowery NYC. They have a great bar and rooftop that is a perfect place to get a drink and enjoy a nice view while you wait. It's a little pricey but worth it.

Two words, soup dumplings (or three words, xiao long bao).

It is a very touristy location, but that doesn't mean it's not good. The inside is crowded, and a little dirty, but hey, it's Chinatown. My group was sat at a table with strangers. The waitstaff was quick and efficient.

The soup dumplings were great. The prices are very reasonable ($4-6, depending on the type). The original pork has a better flavor than the crab and pork, and is cheaper! The soup dumplings are large and tasty. However, the skins are VERY thick. Normally you have to be delicate when getting them, but with these there's little risk of tearing.

This is in NO WAY on par with ding tai fung. But it's still damn good.

Worth going to, but I need to try Shanghai Cafe for comparison. Try going early or late to avoid the tourists and the inevitable wait.

This place is a tourist trap - NOT. This is one of the "touristy" locations that I absolutely love. I'm a big fan of the crab soup dumplings, good pricing and old school Chinatown feel. Chinatown is getting way too gentrified, Joe's Shanghai keeps it real and maintains that culture

I have a massive blister on the roof of my mouth courtesy of the piping hot crab and pork xiao long bao here and I would not hesitate to take another massive blister if it meant that I would get another order of these babies.  

They were absolutely delicious and despite the pain they might inflict, are well worth it.  The broth is super rich and even slightly fatty, but that is all part of the goodness.  The skin of the dough is maybe slightly on the thicker side, but it had a good chewiness to it that gave and resisted just enough, not unlike a good woman.  My only knock against it was that two of my eight XLB had leaked so they were devoid of much broth when they arrived.  That was the only downside to what was otherwise a tremendous soup dumpling.  

The green onion pancake was also surprisingly good.  I generally prefer the flakier kind to the doughier ones, but this one was like a little hybrid, with a crispy crunchy slightly flaky outer crust and a denser, chewy center.  It was very pleasant.  I thought the green onion flavor might've been a little light though.  It probably could have benefited from a bit more green onions, but I may just be nitpicking here.  

I came at an odd hour; well past the lunch crowd and long before the dinner crowd set in, so I was seated immediately.  The XLB order was pretty much placed right away and arrived fairly quickly.  The rest of the food arrived similarly quickly.  The service was efficient and typically Chinese, which is to say, not super friendly, but not rude.  The prices were pretty reasonable for what you get and I'd definitely come back for more XLB.

Literally the best Chinese food I've ever had. Out of all the resturants in the nearby vicinity this was the only place with a line & a wait outside. Wait time was about 20 minutes but we'll worth it. Ordered the pork dumplings and they were incredible.. a mix between a soup and a dumpling!  Great for groups, just plan to wait to be seated.

Returned to Joe's after an 8-month hiatus and my love for this restaurant remains unwavering. Our wait for 9 people wasn't too bad for a Sunday evening (approximately 30 minutes). We had a really funny waiter who helped us pick entrees (as I'm always at somewhat at a loss for what to order other than the soup dumplings and green beans Szechaun-style, especially when I'm put on the spot to order for the table by my darling father). The pork soup dumplings were delicious as always. Other dishes we had that were really good - scallion pancakes, sliced beef with jalapeno, pork fried rice, prawns in chili sauce (though it's not really a chili sauce and more of a sweet sauce), kung pao chicken, and water spinach. Not a fan of the curry noodles so I wouldn't recommend that. Oh and good to know: it's cash only.
Super delicious Xiao Loong Baos (dumplings filled with soup base and shrimp and crabmeat). Had a great meal here and very reasonable/cheap prices. Had a short wait but was well-worth it.

Food was on time and amazing!! Staying at 50 Bowery and it was very convenient. Ordered the crab and pork soup dumplings, shredded beef and jalape√±o soup and the house special glazed crispy chicken. Would definitely go back as it was an amazing experience. Soup hit the spot as the weather had gotten colder and a cold started to set in. Spicy nature of the soup knocked it right out!

Perhaps the best chines food I have ever eaten. Dumplings were incredible, scallion pancake blew my mind, and sweet and sour chicken and rice was delicious. Whenever I stop through NYC, I will be sure to make a stop here. The lines out the door speak to the quality of the food. Definitely stop here if you have the chance.

In 1994, they opened their first Joe's Shanghai in Flushing, New York. It quickly becomes the favorite for all diners up till this day but not in flushing anymore, you'll have to travel to Bowery Street in Manhattan.

The original name for this dumpling is Xiao Long Bao, but due to the complicated pronunciation,  simply call it "Soup Dumplings" (based on the soup inside the dumplings). It quickly become an acronym for Joe's Shanghai. Mention "Soup Dumplings", everyone knows you're referring to Joe's Shanghai. 

In 1995, they opened their Chinatown restaurant in Pell Street.  However, the place proved to be too small to handle the growing capacity they have, so in December 2019, they moved to a nearby location - 46 Bowery, New York. 

Soup dumplings were delicious as always, The pan fried noodles was just not the same. So little noodles for the amount of beef and vegetables in their delicious gravy on the plate. 

They opened at 11 with a small line but within 30-40 minutes it completely filled up.

This place was very good. The lo mein noodles weren't anything special, but the General Tso's chicken were definitely the best I've had. I would recommend getting that. They also give you some complimentary oolong tea.

I liked how comfy this place is. I go here a lot with my friends and have never had a problem with getting seats or nothing. Food is great and it is everything you would expect out of a shanghai spot.
I think the main thing to look out for when determining a good from bad shanghai spots are the crab dumplings and this place does not dissapoint in that regard. Dip them in some vinager soy sauce and prepare to be happy.
Had to mark it down a star because like most restaurants in chinatown the utilities are not all that clean and that is absolutely gross

We had the dumplings (recommended, pork), beef and broccoli, chicken and vegetables, shrimp and scallops with veggies, and general tsao chicken.  All of them were fantastic!!  The wait was quoted as 20 mins, but they got us seated in 2 mins.  The restaurant is casual but it was packed the entire time we were there.  I would most definitely go back!!  We shared a table with some locals and they ordered lo mein plus deep fried pork and it looked good too!!  Great experience, wish I could give a 6!
I'm having a craving with soup dumplings. This is the place! Last time I was here, I think the rating was E? LOL. Still, there's a line.

My friend hyped this place so much for their xiao long bao saying it's the best she's had in America. And it certainly lived up to the hype. We literally stopped in just to snack on some XLBs and they were super quick with service! The dumplings were huge compared to others I had, and there was something about the flavor about these that were just different and better than any other XLBs I've had anywhere else in the country. So next time I'm in NYC I have to come back to Joe's Shanghai.

I came here mainly for the Soup Dumpings, So that's what I got.  2 orders of the crab w' pork Dumplings.  Soup inside was piping HOT(So be careful) and delicous, the stuffing was very flavorful.  Way better and cheaper than DTF in my opinion. Will definitely make another visit if I'm ever back in NYC.

Obviously you should be expecting a long wait time for a place with this many reviews.  I was here over the weekend when it was snowing out and the temperature was in the 1 digit.  But that didnt stop other people from coming here also.  If you come here with 2-3 people, expect to be sharing a round table with other people.  My wait time was around 20-25 minutes.  My only gripe is that if you're asking people that are waiting to wait outside, that you make the effort to go outside to call their numbers.
Best soup dumpling of the city.  I love the ones with crab meats.

I think those who gave this place anything less than 3 stars, especially locals, are just trying to differentiate themselves from the tourists. I've had xia long bao in China, and Joe's Shanghai is certainly comparable, and definitely the best I've had in the U.S.! Sure the wait sucks and the service is horrible, but what else can you expect from a busy restaurant in Chinatown? When in New York, go.

This place is in a cute little alleyway in Chinatown that looks like it could be a movie set (wouldn't be surprised if it has been.) 

The wait is extremely long, so plan ahead.

Instead of belting out synonyms for "good," I'll just say this place was a 5 (Yelp) star experience.
Best! So good and never been disappoints. The line can be heavy on weekends but most of the time if it's just a table for two you can be in and out fairly quickly. Highly recommend.

Our meal at the Chinatown outpost of Joe's Shanghai was by no means a comfortable experience.  The wait was considerably long, the place was crowded, the smell of soy sauce and rice vinegar filled the air, and we were seated on a communal round table elbow-to-elbow with three other groups, all of us pretending not to be listening to each other's conversations.

Few items are worth all the trouble.  Fortunately, Joe's Shanghai's Xiao Long Bao fits the bill - in both price and quality.   The Xiao Long Bao Joe's Shanghai were quite fantastic.  They're plump and very tasty and the skin was perfectly thin and chewy.  The soup was hot and soothing.  

Apart from the dumplings, I'm not too crazy about their other entrees, though they were still all above average, and not overly saucy.  My suggestion?  Stick with the XLB (pork and crab are both good) and walk over to Rice to Riches for some grubbin rice pudding dessert.

Also, service can be pretty frustrating.  It's not as bad as other people experienced and I think language difficulties may be perceived by others as being rude.  Regardless, you wont get the VIP treatment here, just good dumplings.  They only take cash and even add a mandatory 15% service charge, regardless of the size of your party or your order.

Best* soup dumplings ever.  Don't waste your time or appetite by ordering anything else here.

The service is hit or miss, like with every establishment.  I actually got a great waiter.

The wait for a table shouldn't be surprising, considering its popularity with the tourists.  I had to wait about 20 minutes for a table for 3 when I arrived at 7 pm on a Friday night, which I found reasonable.

And honestly, the complaint about the price --- where else can you get food this good and this cheap in Manhattan?  You get 8 dumplings for less than $5, if I remember correctly.

Here's a tip -- the optimum temperature to eat the soup dumpling is right below scalding.  Cold dumplings aren't satisfying, so place one order the moment you get to your table, and when you receive your dumplings, place your 2nd order.  That'll ensure that your dumplings are consumed at its perfect steaming hot temperature.  

* I consider them to be the best because they're the largest I sampled (between Joe's Shanghai, Shanghai Cafe, and Yeah Shang Hai Deluxe Corp) which means that Joe's Shanghai dumplings contain more broth, which is my favorite part!
You won't be disappointed if you want some real Chinese food. Other than the famous pork bun, the other dishes are good as well. Traditional Shanghai food. Recommend for everyone.

The soup dumplings were pretty good, service quick and attentive, especially for a Chinese restaurant.  We had some great prawns as well, the were in a red sauce (hot pepper prawns??), sorry I wish I could remember the name but they circle the item number of the popular dishes on the menu with ball point pen, so I think if you go with any of those items you are probably going to be OK.
Fire soup dumplings, they get it right every single time. The first bite will hit you with the most delicious flavor. Go here!

I heard a lot of good things about Joe's Shanghai, especially their famous Xiao Long Bao! Their authentic soup dumpling is the reasonable why we wanted to stop by and check it out. When we first arrived, we were expecting a long waiting line but we didn't see any. I thought they are closed today but turned out we were just lucky! We came in and sat down right the way around 1145. Highly recommend to come early for lunch on a weekday!!! With just two of us, we ordered the best dishes on their menu, Crab Flavored Shanghai Xiao Long Bao and Shanghai stir fried thick noodle. Omg! I love their food! So authentic that literally brought me back to the time I was visiting Shanghai!!! The stir fried thick noodles was perfectly cooked, flavorful, and just the way it should be. The crab flavored Xiao long Bao came as it finished in the bamboo steamed basket. So fresh and simply awesome. The size is bigger than I expected. The flavor and quality were also better than I expected. The crab flavored filling and soup in the Xiao long Bao were the one of the best that I've ever had! I was totally shocked by the flavor of Xiao long Bao! I highly recommend this place and I will come back every time I am in New York!
Loved the food...had YUMMY soup dumplings..crispy prawns ..sesame chicken. Service very good.
Seriously, best soup dumplings ever! I miss the hole in the wall when you used to have to share large tables with other groups, but so happy that they had expanded to a larger location!

Believe the hype, this place is amazing!!! I have gone three times within the last three weeks with three different people who all agree that this place and the food is incredible. I've ordered the pork soup dumplings, the Shanghai Style Flat Noodle and the fried dumplings each time. Definitely recommend the noodles to share!! The soup dumplings are flavorful (a bit too hot, so let them cool down a bit) so be sure to get that when you're there!

If you want to spend some money on great Chinese food, and want the real Chinese restaurant experience, this is the place.  But only go with a group of people.  It's about the experience as much as the food.

I have been waiting to come here and am so excited I finally got to try the soup dumplings! 

First of all they were huge! And so delicious and soupy! I only tried the pork dumplings so next time I'll have to try the crab. We also shared the Shanghai flat noodles.... YUM. I was stuffed and couldn't be happier.

Couple of things to note: if you're in a small group or pair, you will get seated with other people at your table. It's very busy and tight inside the restaurant but then again you probably know that coming in. Before even asking you what you want to drink, the server will ask you if you want dumplings lol. Oh and the food is super cheap! 

Most importantly you won't regret it. The soup dumplings are awesome and I can't wait to come back!

Joe's Shanghai serves some of the cheapest soup dumplings you'll find, and they aren't bad. But for all those people out there who even try to compare this place to Din Tai Fung, it isn't even close. At about only a dollar per soup dumpling, this place is a great value and the dumplings here are soupy and flavorful, but it's a far cry from the sophisticated craft that is the world-famous Din Tai Fung soup dumpling.

We stopped by here for lunch on a Sunday, and tried their soup dumplings. Positives include the fact that they are pretty cheap, pretty sizable, and are filled with plenty of flavorful soup. Unfortunately, they lack the delicateness people love Din Tai Fung for, and the skin of the dumplings is pretty thick here. This means that the soup dumplings rarely break, but that also means the dough to soup and pork ratio is off and the dough is pretty chewy (not a good thing here). The key test these dumplings fail is that they cannot be eaten in a single bite as they are simply too large. That being said, while I've had plenty of better soup dumplings elsewhere, I've rarely had any that were cheaper.

We had to wait about 20 minutes for a table, and I don't think it's worth any longer of a wait. They also add on a 15% service charge here regardless of party size, so keep that in mind. Decent cheap soup dumplings but doesn't exactly live up to the hype. 4 stars.
Great Soup Dumplings. New York Staple. Never close.

This place is well-known for their soup dumplings, and I've visited other locations before. I recently went in with a friend to eat some soup dumplings, and they certainly were tasty, but unfortunately, they were pretty fragile. Almost all of them broke and leaked out before we could put them on our spoons. Still tasted great, but it was a bit disheartening to see all that soup gone.

We had a fairly long wait and ended up sharing a table, but it wasn't too bad. I'd go back, if only for the soup dumplings. Regular, though - I've tried the crab ones before, and they weren't great.
I'm from Los Angeles but I was definitely loving this place. The orange chicken was excellent and veggies were crispy. Although it was busy they were pretty efficient and didn't have to wait long.
The pork dumpling soup tasted...out of the world! didn't like the pancake though my husband liked both!
Never disappoints. I always stop here when I'm in the city. Very good food. The soup dumplings are a must. I leave happy, full and with left overs to enjoy later.

The xiao long bao at Joe's Shanghai is good but inferior to the ones at Din Tai Fung in Arcadia, CA.  The juice is much tastier and the skin is thinner and less doughy at Din Tai Fung.  All in all though, still a good and cheap place for New York.

Joe's Shanghai has arguably the best soup dumplings on the east coast. Thankfully, it's here in New York City else I would have to travel to Shanghai just to have these dumplings. Actually, speaking of which, I had to share a table with a family from the Midwest. He said that the entire cost of flying his family there, staying at a hotel in New York City might have been all worth it for that meal alone (more than $1000). And when given the check, he could not believe that the meal he had cost so little! Of course, that's a bit of an exaggeration. Still, it doesn't take away from the fact that the food here is very good and fairly cheap.  

To make everyone happy, you would will have to share a table with someone else. This is not unheard of in crowded restaurants in Asia, but certainly, it's something different in the US. If you wanted a table to yourself, you would either need some luck with timing or spend a long wait for one. In either case, I think it works out since the soup dumplings are so popular. They steam them in batches and if you're unlucky enough to order them when they've finished off a batch, you're in for another wait as well. In the end, the whole sharing tables idea is not so bad. 

The service here is variable. I can't seem to justify why it is exactly. But I've had better experiences coming here in the dead time in between lunch and dinner. I assume before lunch would also be good too, if I could drag myself out of bed that early. 

Joe's Shanghai has to be one of my favorite places to eat in Chinatown. It promises good food at a more than reasonable price. And more importantly, they come through! Though they have added a 15% gratuity fee, it's actually a modest sum to ask for because you certainly could feel obligated to give them more. This restaurant epitomizes the Chinatown experience as there are a bunch of restaurants in the neighborhood that are absolutely cheap, but not necessary good.

The turnover here is crazy. They pop out soup dumplings like there is no tomorrow. 

The pork dumplings come out in 5 minutes or so. They are hot, the steam will burn your tongue. Eat it with a spoon and your chopsticks. Put the dumpling on the spoon, bite off the top of the dumpling. Let it cool. Pour in some vinegar. Then enjoy! The skin is not too thick, the pork actually takes like pork, and the soup is savory - what is not to like? 

Service here is fast. You ask for it, you get it a couple of seconds later. The waiters are well-versed in English (at least vis-a-vis food-related requests). However, do expect to wait to be seated. This place gets crowded quickly and waits can be up to over an hour!

This place doesn't disappoint. Quick service, tasty
Food very reasonable priced. Be aware of the service fee on the check. The new location is clean

If you are living or visiting NY, you HAVE to come to Joe's. The soup dumplings are the best best ones I've ever had. Each one is filled with so much flavorful broth. My sister and I ended up going twice on our quick trip. I will definitely be back next time I'm in NY.

I give these five stars to what i've had at Joe's, and it's their xiao long bao's or steamed dumplings. The key is to wait for them to cool down a little, and eat the whole thing in one bite, if you let the juices flow, the dumplings aren't as tasty. I personally prefer the crab, but I've grown up with crab. I would recommend this place for a snack, and I would only recommend the dumplings, the place is so packed that you get crammed with other groups, it's nice just to dive in and out.

$5-7 for an order of XLB?  Yes please.

Having always been stuck going at the wrong times with hoards of people inline, myself and Freddy Jr R were lucky to have to wait for about 20 minutes.  Family style seating, so if you're in a small group then you will be seated with other groups of people.  No biggie.  

Immediately when we sit down, the waiter already asks which dumplings you want.  You can get the regular ones for $5 or the crab ones for $7.  We order one of each as well as the pepper skin duck as well.  

XLB is a rare dish to find done well in the Washington DC area, so I'm happy to say that these live up to the hype.  I'm sure I can find better ones in the Queens Chinatown, however with our limited time frame and our apartment being in the LES, Joe's fit the bill.

The pepper skin duck was delicious too.  Cook perfectly and plenty of meat on the bones since sometimes Chinese places will give you the cheap cuts.  

Total bill was less than $30.  Had we just ate the soup dumplings, it would've been much less.  I can see myself easily taking down 4 of these soup dumpling orders if I was extremely hungry.  For two people I say 3 orders is pretty good.  Not to be missed in Manhattan's Chinatown.
I randomly tried this place and have been a fan since then. we had soup dumplings and it was amazing.

Soup dumpings, Xiao Long Bao, Siu Loong Pau... however you like to call them, Joe's Shanghai gets 'em right.

The look and scream of my friend when he grabbed one of the dumpling and all the juices spilled out: PRICELESS

The Shanghai fried flat noodle reminded me of my grandma's cooking.  A definite PLUS.

Only negative thought: As soon as we sat down, the waiter asked what we wanted.  I asked to give us a minute and the waiter walked away looking exasperated... we know Xiao Long Baos require time to steam and that it should be ordered first if at all possible... but couldn't we first sit down and look at the menu?  Also, they tend to group you with other groups on a large table.  I guess this can't be avoided when the place is busy and there are multiple small groups (less than 6).

My friends and I looked every bit the tourist we were looking for this place (it's a decent walk from A/C/E Canal St.).  Thank goodness a local storeowner pointed us in the right direction towards Pell.  The food made this place well worth the excursion.

Food: 5/5
Decor: 3/5
Service: 2.5/5
Cost: 3.5/5

I love this place. It's always super busy so be prepared to wait and unless you're with alot of people, you will be sitting with strangers.  The food is worth it tho. Do not go here and not have the soup dumplings. That is the whole point of coming here lol They are the best so far in my book. I haven't been able to find a good NJ replacement. I'm still looking.

Best.Soup.Dumplings.EVER.

AND! their Spicy Pepper Salt Prawns were AMAZEBALLS.  Seriously, I'm salivating just thinking about it.....

Doesn't look like much when you walk by, but the place is packed. We tried to take a # but the wait time went from 15 min to 45 min when we checked. Not sure if they gave or spot away or what, that why -1 for that. Food was good and hot as we stayed in the hotel next door. I think it would have been perfect if we could eat inside, as dim sum is as much about the atmosphere as it is about presentation. Having it in a take out contain kinda looses something.

I really enjoyed the soup dumplings here. My one issue with the restaurant was that we sat at a large group table, and the other guests were tourists who asked us many questions about New York travel, which wasn't my ideal mealtime conversation

Oh man! These soup dumplings were spectacular! It was my first time here and my friends had been raving about them. I was skeptical, because I've only had terrible soup dumplings. But, I've been converted. I now believe in the healing power of a solid soup dumpling!

This place is SO BUSY! I went there with friends at 2:30pm on a Friday and waited for about 30 minutes outside. I like the soup bums, especially the crab meat with pork steamed ones. Six soup bums are enough for a girl. It only cost us about $7.5 per person for that meal including taxes and tips. The restaurant calculated the taxes and tips (15%) for the customers.

Joe's is definitely a super popular tourist restaurant. Please note that this spot is CASH ONLY, but there are ATMs inside.

It was pretty crowded when we had went, and we waited around 20 minutes. However, once we were inside, we were served quickly. It was nice inside, and the space was very large. We ordered the steamed vegetable dumplings, flounder, fried rice, and a vegetable dish.

The flounder was delicious - it was fried and the perfect amount of salty. I thought the dumplings were decent, and were pretty standard. I am glad that I got to try Joe's Shanghai, but I think there are some other restaurants in the nearby area that are just as good, if not better!
Soup dumplings are da bomb, but you'll have to wait in a queue to get in.  Go in a big group so you can try a bigger swathe of all the menu.

Crab Meat with Pork Meat Soup Dumplings, Shanghai Fried Rice, Fresh Calamari with with Spicy Black Bean Sauce, Sauteed String Bean ($78.15): get their soup dumplings!!! This spot was pretty popular with almost every table filled when we arrived. Their soup dumplings were super super good. All the other dishes were okay and portions were on the smaller side, so I would probably just get soup dumplings next time. Dined in person! Cash only!

Prompt service. Wait wasn't that bad. Organized.  Food was fresh and delicious.  Steamed dumplings were amazing. Good sized portions. Clean and busy.  Highly recommend if visiting Chinatown.  Ps.....cash only

I've accepted the fact that it's hard to stay "authentic" to your regional cuisine when the restaurant has become so incredibly popular and widespread. The food has definitely been adjusted to suit American tastes and I can taste hints of Cantonese cooking in it as well. Not that it's still not delicious but it's lost the authenticity of that region's cooking.

It also doesn't help the beginners to this cuisine that come here b/c most of the waitstaff are not knowledgeable about the menu so you won't get much help, just trust the description on the menu or look around at the delectible tasty items being brought out...buut Joe's is still far superior than its other xiaolongbao making counterparts in Chinatown. Just went yesterday for an early dinner and the place was packed, tables being shared, orders being taken at the speed of light, delicious saucy plates of food being brought to the tables.

Had the usual bamboo steamer of pork soup dumplings (no crab for me, thanks), was good but not great, the meat honestly tasted like it was frozen for at least a few days and then steamed..you can also tell because it was not that soupy. then came the scallion pancakes which I normally hate ordering, but they were suprisingly delicious and fresh, with just the right amoutn of crispy flakiness but also doughy on the inside..we also had Shanghai thick noodles which were veryyy savory but also greasy and full of MSG-ness but that's what makes it SOO DAMN GOOD. 

It his the spot for me, but my Shanghainese mom and her friend were unsatisfied, understandably so. Would I come back here again and bring friends? Of course..just not any time soon, especially since I can get something better from my Grandma's kitchen, but Joe's is still one of the handful of Chinatown places I would still recommend for a hearty lunch or dinner. If you must get authentic Shanghainese food, I don't think theres hardly any left in Chinatown so you should just cross the bridge into Flushing and eat at the little food stalls or minimalistic dumpling joints there.

I literally only come here for the famed soup dumplings with the occasional side of scallion pancakes. And it's totally worth it.
This place is featured in pretty much every tourist magazine, so be sure to go at a brunch/mid-afternoon time unless you want to get a ticket stub with a number on it as you wait outside to be seated.
This place also bundles you together with other unsuspecting people in order to save space. Which is efficient, but often awkward because you don't know the person you're eating across of, and you kind of feel like you're on a blind date getting judged by hoe you eat.
But I digress.
The food here comes fast, hot, and never not-delicious. The crab-meat soup dumplings actually taste like crab!! Not imitation crab!!!! Dumpling skin is plump and the juice inside is always the right amount of bold.
I've been coming here since I was a kid, and will continue to do so.

Excellent!
The Xiao Long Bao taste so good, makes you wanna slap yo momma!

I've been to Joe's awhile back but then I moved from NYC so it had been a few years. Decided to take my dad here when we were visiting nyc again and for one thing wow it is in a totally new location. It's much brighter and bigger inside. We were seated quickly as we didn't mind sharing tables with strangers. The soup dumplings were still delicious. We got another noodle dish that I would not get again. Just come here for the soup dumplings and you will be happy.

Joes Shanghai is the real deal! My nephew is from the West Coast and raves about the Shanghai Soup Dumplings in San Francisco. We were in the city for the day and planned our day around lunch at Joes! The seating is table sharing which allows for quicker availability but may be awkward for some. We ordered pork and crab soup dumplings that were absolutely amazing! I had never eaten them before but will be going back for sure to try more!! Authentic is the key word at Joes. A lot of locals eating there as well. This place is highly recommended! Give it a try!!
the soup dumplings are a must! there might be a wait but it is really worth it! great food and great prices

Very good, and very greasy Chinese food. Great complimentary tea as well.

The soup dumplings were phenomenal, full of broth, and meat; a very savory dish.

Pan fried noodles were also great, very tasty, decent amount of meat and veggies, and noodles were perfect.

Cheap, but good Chinese food. If you're in China Town and having a hankering for some MSG laden food (just kidding), then Joe's is a great spot, especially if you want to try some awesome soup dumplings that actually have a ton of soup in them.
