Read the reviews and had to make a stop here. Their "xiao long bao" are the best in the US of A. I'm craving for more. They are not skimpy with the size and had so much soup. Other dishes were very good too, especially the onion pancake.

When are we going to NYC again, Kat?

Oh, how I miss my childhood of family trips to Joe's. 

I have since found much better soup dumplings in the city, but, Joe's will forever be my initial soup dumpling love. Hailing from a Shanghainese family, I've also tried just about every other item on the menu. The food is fairly on spot with how middle level quality restaurants in Shanghai are like. 

As an adult, I've actually avoided Joe's in favor of many other restaurants and ethnic foods. More specifically, ingredients in Shanghainese food tend to be obscured and muddled by the various sauces used in the cuisine. However, I still highly recommend Joe's to friends and individuals who have not had the chance to experience what I'd consider the original Shanghainese restaurant in NYC.

There is only one menu, but there should be two. One for soup dumplings and another for Chinese food; I'd only need the former.

Yes, as a dingy Chinese diner in Chinatown you're going to get relatively authentic and tasty Chinese food. However you're actually going to pay a lot for that General Tso's (or muffler), like $11.95. Or you and your friends can just show up and buy a tower (8 dumplings per bamboo steamer) of soup dumplings and call it a day.

Do that. Only that, because what else is there?

Their soup dumplings are excellent. Would recommend the ones without crab. They are actually more delicious and less expensive than the crab ones. The other dishes tend to more catering towards the American palate, I.e a little greasier and saltier than I would prefer. Very tight quarters, but that's just New York.

Top notch outlet.  The reviews concerning the pork soup dumplings (xiao long bao) are right on.  Absolutely delectable.    To the innocent observer, it may seem as we over-ordered (we had four orders, each with 8 dumplings) but there were five kids and four adults (and, while few were looking, I managed to take care of 8 of them myself...

Everything else we ordered paled in comparison, and was simply "as expected" - which was to include crispy duck, chicken chow-mein, and fried rice.

Yes, I know we ordered the most pedestrian of options, but the pork soup dumplings ought to absolve us.  

Regrettably my picture reflects an empty steamer in the foreground.  Take this to support the "so-good-we-cleared-the-containers" notion.

P.s., thanks to Heather Melom Encinosa & Co. for introducing us to Joe's Shanghai!
The interior is really nice. Everyone is friendly. But the food is why I'm writing! I've only tried the famous soup dumplings but I travel from Boston often to bring some home. Yummy
I'm a fan. Been here a couple of times and I do think the soup dumplings are excellent. The other food is good too.
Best soup dumplings I've ever had! Enough said. Plus the prices are so reasonable. Hope it doesn't change ever.
Food was delish and the service was good. It's kind of a pain that they only accept cash but it's do-able. The beef with string beans was amazing.

The xia long bao is to die for here. Extremely thin outer layer with juicy and extremely hot meat and juice in the core. Whether it's seafood or pork, all are delicious. One can serve as an appetizer for 2 but I would definitely get at least two. One seafood and one pork.

It gets extremely busy and the seating is tight inside.

Cash only.
The most succulent juicy dumplings I've ever had. Don't expect it to be a fancy place, just another Chinatown restaurant loud and crowded but worth it.

always make a stop here whenever im in new york. ill admit that the dumplings are better than the din tai fung in Cali because they don't sheist you on the soup inside the dumplings as the ones in Cali are super dry. 

just be careful and SIP SLOW! i burned my tongue because i had no patience when biting into these little bundle of joys.

this is a place where you CANNOT be shy. its all communal seating. funny how you can tell who the antisocial customers are. theyre the ones who whip out their tabloid newspaper and make NO eye contact even when both sides of the table are obviously making loud a$$ slurping noises from the dumpling juice.

Second time here and it was delicious, I have to say service is just not there but its typical for the area. My friend and I were a party of 2 and if you are a pair you will be seated most likely on a round table with other pairs which I didnt mind because I'm very social haha. Their is a pot of tea ready for you which I loved and they came to take our order fairly quickly within 10 minutes...I ordered the Seafood noodles and a Chefs plate of the sliced spicy beef with bean sprouts....we devoured everything! The couple next to us also ordered the beef and they thought it was too spicy, however I'm Mexican and felt it was average. Once we finished we asked for our check and didnt notice the added gratuity but what are you gunna do...good food, fairly quick and packed...good eats in Chinatown

Soup Dumplings are on point. Would go there again for that. Sadly, I also got their seafood pan fried noodle and was disappointed to see it made differently than with yellow noodles. It also lacked some flavor. How we we also had the seafood flat noodle and that was delicious!

by far the best experience i've ever had.
the dumpling are amazing.the scallion pancakes are awesome. in general the best dumpling place in the world.

Joe's Shanghai has the best dumplings I've ever tried in New York City.  However, I'm giving it four stars for the food mainly, and not anything else.  The wait is completely ridiculous on the weekends, so definitely avoid it if you can.  I usually come here on the weekdays for a late lunch.  The waitstaff isn't the friendliest bunch, and the hostesses are kind of rude.  One hostess was actually texting on her phone while she led us to our table.  They also have added gratuity which sucks because the service definitely does not deserve the 15%.  The decor is almost nonexistent.  The food comes fairly quickly though, so that's something.  I would recommend this place only for the food because I can't find any other place with better dumplings.

Having recently been to Shanghai just a year prior to coming to Joe's its safe to say that Joe's had a fairly high bar to reach. My friend and I ordered the pork soup dumplings, green onion pancakes, and pork rice cakes, all of which came out in a surprisingly quick amount of time. One thing I was slightly disappointed about was that they didn't have sheng jian bao (pan fried pork buns), which are a traditional staple of almost all Shanghainese restaurants. Regardless, the xiao long bao was so good that upon having our first bite of it, we immediately ordered another two orders of it. The soup dumplings were probably the bets I've had in the states in a long time, and are slightly larger than normal ones (not complaining lol). They're filled with just the right amount of soup: not too much as to overfill your mouth, but also not too little to leave the dumpling feeling empty. On the other hand, their green onion pancakes were a little doughy and could use more green onions in my opinion, but they also had a pleasant crisp to them and had a nice sweet soy sauce that came with it. Finally, the rice cakes were slightly overcooked and felt kinda mushy and uncomfortable to chew, but otherwise had solid flavor. Joe's is most likely famous for their XLB, for good reason, and everything else that I ordered (all traditional Shanghainese cuisine) was decent and stayed pretty close to their roots (aka not Americanized). I would recommend staying away from more Americanized Chinese options (orange chicken, general tsao's chicken, etc) and non-shanghainese food (i.e. Szechuan beef) since this is a pretty traditional Shanghainese restaurant and doesn't really specialize in those cuisines. 
5 stars for the xlb, but overall score is bumped down to 4 because the restaurant as a whole seems somewhat one-dimensional (unless they change their name to Joe's XLB or something).

The pork soup dumplings are amazing! But do be careful, they are served at a mouth-scalding temperature! I like to bite a small hole in the dumpling, let some of the steam escape while balancing the dumpling on the spoon so I don't lose any soupy goodness, and then I go in for the kill! Delicious, huge, end of story.

I also tried some other dish, which was decent/whatever/unmemorable... But let's just forget about that. 

Focus on the soup dumplings! They will not disappoint you!

Joe's Shanghai is the place to go in Chinatown. It's cheap, it's delicious, and they have a menu that's expansive enough that everybody in your party will be happy. I've been here many times, and my go-to is the soup dumplings.

The most important thing to know is that you should be prepared for a pretty long wait if you're here for dinner time. For a table for two, and it was not even the most crowded I've seen it, I had about a 25 minute wait. When we were able to be seated, we shared a table with 4 other people... Which was kind of tight, but I can't fault the place for being popular.

On the walls around the restaurant, there are photos of every celebrity you can think of with the owner. It's dim, it's cozy, its surprisingly quiet for a place that is standing room only. 

The food came out surprisingly quickly for a place that was this packed- and the food was good. I only come here every so often because of the weight, but I've never regretted the wait.

Food (5/5 stars):
One of my favorite places to get Pork Soup Dumplings! They were much bigger than your average soup dumpling, which I appreciated.

Experience (5/5 stars):
* Price: reasonable
* Wait Time: we waited 15 min for a table after lunch hours on a weekday
* Service: good 
* Ambiance: it's a beautiful Chinese restaurant

New location, seating is more spacious and comfortable, and food is great as always.  The soup dumplings are amazing of course, and I also got the Szechuan beef.  It's a bit presumptious of them to add an 18% gratuity even for a party of one, but fortunately they do have good service.  Also with the renovations they seem to have the cleanest and most modern restrooms in all of Chinatown.  Bring cash, it's cash only, otherwise I would give it 5 stars and order even more food!

Apart from it's very "UN-romantic" seating, The food is exquisite.  AUTHENTIC CHINESE FOOD done right. Generous serving amount and totally Affordable. You'd have to mind the wait (at times). Just don't get upset. It's Chinatown!

This is a very popular restaurant! Every time I walk past, there is at least a 20-30 minute wait, but as soon as you taste the food you will understand why! 
Most people come here for the classic pork soup dumplings, and I recommend you do the same. The soup dumplings come out plump and steaming, with plenty of soup for you to slurp up. We also ordered scallion pancakes and an eggplant dish. Dishes come in pretty big portions, so we had plenty of leftovers to take home. Service is very fast and efficient. Remember to bring cash!

The soup dumplings here are the BEST! Other spots in the neighborhood have Shanghainese soup dumplings, but none of them compare to the original Joe's Shanghai dumplings. Aside from the dumplings, the other food at Joe's is just okay, in my opinion. But it's absolutely worth a trip for the soup dumplings - out-of-this-world amazing!
This place is ridiculously delicious.  We had the pork and crab soup dumplings are out of this world!

Best soup dumplings! I always come here to get soup dumplings becuase it's affordable, the service is fast, and the soup dumplings taste amazing! The place isn't as formal as other restaurants because you share a table with other people if you don't have a large party. But if you don't mind sharing a table with strangers and are looking for great soup dumplings, this is the place to go!

This place would be five stars but it felt too pricey for chinatown and they automatically include a 15% service charge which pushes the price even higher. However, definitely go to this one over the midtown location, which is even more expensive (though they might not have the service charge). Anyway, unless I was taking friends or something I would probably go to one of the 5 for $1 dumpling places instead of this 9 times out of 10.

Having said all of that, my soup dumplings were obviously amazing and my fried rice wasn't bad either. This place is family style  which is nice because it's actually less awkward eating alone here. Also watching the Asian ladies next to me eat was a good lesson in the proper consumption of a soup dumpling. On the downside, this also means that 5-7 legit Asians got to witness my shame upon accepting that I'll never succeed at chopsticks and asking for a fork.

If you're a tourist and/or independently wealthy and therefore not at work during the week 1ish-4ish on a weekday are good times to avoid some of the crowds the other reviewers mention.

My experience of Joe's has always been pleasant.

Their waiters speak good english and they are very helpful.

The XLB though.. you get 8 of them per container and it is full of flavor.. YUM! Trust the orange oil XLB they are always more authentic than the cleaner ones.. 

The only downfall I have is that their XLB always have some shards of crab.. However.. I guess that is what makes them taste so authentic? haha...

Anyways, good job Joe's Shanghai!

Joe knows how to make the magic happen. He knows what he's doing. 

Three beautiful, intellectual women shared a table with me, discussing how their husbands are oh-so-very close to publishing a book. They laugh, they toast to refreshing sesame noodles and delicious soup dumplings- happily giggling while they say, "Sorry I keep squirting on you!"

STOP.

You are dirty if you thought otherwise.
(That's what she said)

Joe's a popular guy; ladies, food, beer. Who wouldn't want to be him? He has a line all the time waiting to experience his savory dishes. That pickled cabbage- oh man! Tangy and simple. The portions are just right too. It's more than the amount served for tapas/dim sum, but less than a traditional Chinese restaurant portions. This is awesome because you can try a variety of foods without having to force feed yourself and feel fat when you go shopping after (hint: do not try on clothing after lunch). To give you a better picture, 4 people ordered 8 dishes and the total was roughly $70-80. That's including tax and tip!

Joe... You da man.

Came here on a Thursday night at 6p as a family of 4.  We had to wait only 15 minutes.  Its pretty cramped and loud inside but I promise you, it's WORTH it.  Their soup dumplings are probably some of the BEST you will ever have.  The soup is so flavorful and they have just the right amount of meat in it as well.  The wrapping dough is just the perfect thickness.  You MUST get this!

We also got the shanghai fried noodles, deep fried buns that you dip in condensed milk, and fried green beans.  We really liked how the fried green beans were not overly salty but just perfect (some places I feel like over season this dish).

Definitely COME EARLY.  As we were leaving (around 7p), there was a huge crowd waiting outside!

I love this place! We ordered the crispy Shanghai pan fried noodles with beef, Pork soup dumpling, sweet & sour fried pork, and Shanghai fried flat rice with beef. If you go for dinner on Fri, Sat, or Sunday be prepared for a 30-45 min wait. Plan accordingly and you'll be fine.

Great place, cheap food, crowded atmosphere, worth the wait.

It's a great place good cheap eat, but do know that there is almost always a line to eat here. 

Famous for their steamed buns, you can't go here and not eat it!
I also highly recommend their garlic eggplant dish, really good! I don't like eggplant and that dish made me love eggplant. 

It'll be crowded in there and if you go with 2-3 people, chances are you'll sit at a round table with 2-3 people you don't know, but that's part of the experience. Great place!

If you want the same thing, but in a "finer" restaurant, they have another location in Midtown. Prices there a little bit more expensive, and I don't think the food's as good, but it's an alternative!

Enjoy

This place is known for their dumplings, and you know what, they're a pretty good deal -- as in their cheap. Are these comparable to Shanghai or even Din Tai Fung.. maybe not but not a bad effort.

The problem with the dumplings is their skin. It is way too thick to be considered Xiao Long Bao; they actually give you EDGED TONGS to pick them up which just goes to show how durable that skin is. I have honestly never seen tongs used to pick a Xiao Long Bao up. 

This might be due to the learning curve and delicate hands one must have to eat one of these dumplings. Usually you use chopsticks to pick it up gently and put it into a soup spoon, pour some vinegar/ginger on top, and bite off a small piece of the skin to drink the soup inside. Usually the skin is much thinner and delicate that many times, the dumpling does not make it into the soup spoon fully intact.

Taste-wise, the dumplings (both crab/pork and pork) were good. Be careful when drinking the soup inside because it does come out piping hot.

I also ordered the Peking Style Minced Pork Noodles that were in a slightly spicy peanut tofu sauce, which was pretty good. Also good were the fried green beans (si ji dou / four season bean).

Like other places in Chinatown, you're most likely going to have to share a communal table because there are a predominance of huge family style 10-12 seat round tables at this place so just beware of that before coming.

Even though the texture and flavor aren't as good as I've had, the prices just can't be beat. Given that an order of 8 dumplings will set you back $5-7, it's really hard to complain that much.

Really good. The pork dumplings are a must and by far the best I've ever had. If you have a small party the wait isn't bad. You do sit with other small parties as well. Be prepared to know what you want when you arrive. They want you in and out. We also tried General Tso's Chicken with vegetable lo mein. Enjoyed both entrees. Cash only and tip will already be included.

You wait in line a while to get in this place. The primo is their steamed dumplings, which are excellent and stack up against the best I had in China.  The grilled green beans were also excellent.  The noodles were meh.  Service is great and people really seem to be having a good time there.
Always get the classic xiao long bao and noodle sticks! You can never go wrong with it. Be prepared to wait and don't be shocked if the make you share a table with strangers!
No credit cards accepted.  Very good but small place.  You will be seated at a table with other people.  The food is very authentic and good.  Prices are reasonable.

Came here with two friends. Wait is about an hour depending on when you come. This place was on my dumpling roadmap so while we waited we walked over to try Nice Green Bo. Between the two, I would have to pick Joe's Shanghai. When you first enter Joe's, they greet you and give you a ticket. They call out ticket numbers whenever a table is available. Really busy on a weekend morning/afternoon. I ordered the pork soup buns and the crab soup buns. I like the texture of the dumpling wrap. It's not as thick as Nice Green Bo. But the soup buns are pretty salty. I probably chugged a glass of water for every 4 buns I ate. If I have to choose between the pork or crab soup buns, I would pick the pork one all the time. P.S. BE CAREFUL TO NOT BURN YOURSELF BY STUFFING THE WHOLE THING IN YOUR MOUTH! Definitely be coming back again.

We stopped at Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown for a quick dinner before heading home after an exhausting day in downtown NYC! As usual the place is packed but we were able to grab a table on the second floor.  The service is diligent and quick and the food is always fresh and delicious!  After having spent the entire day enjoying different small plates in various places in Little Italy where we joined the celebration of the Saint Genaro Feast, we kept our dinner selection light.  My husband and I shared the combination Pork and Crab Soup Steamed Dumplings and Crispy Shrimp dish as the Entr√©e served with white rice.  Steamed soup dumpling is the signature dish at this restaurant and I concur!  They are light pillows of dough with a tasty meaty filling enveloped in a liquid sauce which characterizes the dish..  Delightful!  I can make a meal just of these!!!  I do prefer the pork dumplings to the crab ones, though... but they are both great!!!  The shrimp dish turned out to be in a spicy semi-sweet garlicky sauce which went absolutely well with the white rice.  This restaurant never disappoints!  When you are in the area and in the mood for great steamed soup dumplings do not hesitate to give Joe's Shanghai a try!

I found myself exploring China Town for the first time and decided to pop into Joe's Shanghai.
There was a wait, but since I was a part of 1, it took about 15 minutes for me to be seated.
I ordered the house glazed crispy chicken which was a large portion, and I also ordered the wonton soup which was a GINORMOUS PORTION.
Being solo, I finished about 1/2 of the chicken and maybe 1/4 of the wonton soup.

I can't tell you what all is in that glaze for the chicken, but it is SO flavorful. Not so rich that it's overpowering, but just the right balance of sweet/savory. There were plenty of veggies with it too - that's a bonus to me. The breading was indeed crispy, not soggy like so many breaded chicken dishes in sauce that I've had at other establishments outside China Town.
The chicken was tender, and the dish was hot & freshly made.

The wonton soup was everything a wonton soup should be: the dumplings were full as could be, and the broth was a great hearty flavor. No watery soup here!

My only lamentation is that I wish I could have taken the rest to go, but alas I wasn't going to be able to carry it around with me for the rest of the day.

Side note: This place is cash-only, so bring cash or be prepared to use the ATM in the foyer.

Honestly I am obsessed with this place. My boyfriend and I come here whenever we get a craving for some soup dumpling. They are to DIE FOR here (the pork is better than the pork+crab meat tbh). You get 8 for like $7, can't beat it. We also get pan fried pork dumpling which are also to die for, and if we're feeling extra hungry we split a plate of chow or lo mein (big portions). The bill is never over $30! Can't go wrong!

Be prepared to wait if you come on a saturday afternoon, and you sit at a big round table with strangers! Its not terrible tho, food is worth it.

The soup dumplings here are 10/10. We also got the pan fried noodles. I could just eat the soup dumplings forever, they are big and have a lot of soup in them.

My sister and I ate here multiple and times and doordashed multiple times during our one month stay in NYC.

They're also open for in person dining late night.
Food was good. Service not the greatest but I already knew that coming in. Overall it was a good meal

Really good good here! We had the crab and pork dumplings, shredded beef, scallion pancake, and vegetable fried rice. I think the beef was my favorite. Scallion pancake was crunchy. The restaurant moves quickly too. We didn't wait long for all dishes to come out. I used a ton of the chili oil and my water was refilled right on time and frequently. Only note is the fried rice was missing some flavor. I used all the other sauces on the table to make it better. Regardless will definitely come back.

The only reason to come here is for the xiao long bao. You can order XLB with pork or crab. We tried the crab and it was very "soupy" which is good. We got a few other dishes too (onion pancake and seafood noodles), but both were mediocre. If I were to come back, I would only order XLB and nothing else.

Luckily, we came at 4:00 pm so there was no wait. We had to share a table with another party and when they left, another party joined our table, but it was ok.

The soup dumplings really do live up to the hype. We got both the pork and the seafood ones; I liked the pork better but they were both great. You have to be very careful when picking up a dumpling though because a few broke open when we tried picking them up with the tongs. Also, the soup dumplings were actually listed as "buns" on the appetizer part of the menu and not as "soup dumplings," FYI. 
I also ordered the spring roll, which tasted great, but the portion was so tiny, it's not worth it.
This place is cash only!

I looove the food! Really traditional Chinese food, not American Chinese and the price is really good!
Probably my preferred Chinese restaurant. Sure I will be back!

Do I even have to review this place? There's already so many...
I've been here probably 5-8 times and every experience has been similar so I guess I owe a review.
You're always going to wait to get in because it's so poppin' (and worth it). You can get seated right away IF you get there right when it opens.
Because of the amount of space available and popularity of the place, you'll most likely be seated at community tables with other guests, which is cool. If you're lucky, you'll get one of the smaller tables to yourself and your peoples. 
I would say that the service could be better because they seem to rush everything and try to get everyone in/out ASAP that they forget to be more accommodating. But, food comes out quick!
Must order: Soup dumplings! I wish they had veggie soup dumplings available.
I've tried multiple noodle dishes, and none have disappointed. I'm just going to say that you won't go wrong with any dish you order.

Awesome soup dumplings. They were big and really cheap! We also tried fried rice and husband got a chicken dish. Everything was great but such big portions. It was kind of nice though because we ate our leftovers when we got back to our hotel.

We went all over NYC looking for food and this was by far my favorite restaurant that I tried while in NYC. The XLB were phenomenal. The dumplings were juicy and flavorful. The only downside to this restaurant was the wait to get inside. Would I do it again? Hell, yes.

I am definitely going there again. You know it is a good asian restaurant if you see white people. 
I had Soup Dumpling from China to US. 
This is the Best Soup Dumpling I ever had! Get the Crab and Pork. (Better than Shanghai, China's)
Try it with the Vinegar and EAT the CABBAGES after you are done with soup dumplings!!!!


Also the Cold noodles was the one of best had. No offense, Better than what my Mom make. And we were from Shanghai.

I usually avoid touristy places but this place was too good to ignore, delicious, and it reminds me of my grandmother's cooking. If you're visiting New York City , this is a must go. P.S the Soup dumplings are the main focus , it should be the first thing you order there

One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city. Although this isn't the original, iconic location down in Chinatown, the more upscale midtown option is in some ways even better. With table cloth covered tables and reservations, you don't have to deal with the long line outside a shady block. Although the dim sum options are limited, the few options they have are absolutely delicious. All of the standard American-Chinese dishes are delectable as well.

I came here from a friend's recommendation. The dumplings were excellent! Especially the soup inside, I haven't taste a better place yet other than here. I personally like the pork crab one better :P The waiter took our orders quickly before getting our tables settle down, so the food came really fast!

*drool..* why can't you have on in sf? :T

Joe's Shanghai has always been my family and I's favorite Shanghainese restaurant. My husband and I came here on our very first lunch date 18 years ago at their old location on Pell Street and decided to check out their new location for lunch again (we used to go to their Flushing loc too but unfortunately, they closed). We got all the signature dishes ranging from crab/ pork soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, Shanghai fried rice and fried rice cake with beef. This place has the best soup dumplings with perfectly thin skin, flavorful broth and just enough meat filling. 

All the other dishes were also cooked to perfection and food came out as quick as humanly possible. The customer service was near perfection with both water glasses and hot tea always remaining full without us having to ask. Parking can be a nightmare and there can be a slight wait due to covid occupancy limits. We went around 1 and waited only about 5 minutes or less. Besides that, this should be every person's go-to Shanghai restaurant when that craving arises. FYI: cash only and there's a 15% service charge, which is automatically added to the total bill.

Joe's is a fantastic restaurant.  Table for 2? The restaurant sits you at a table for (?)people warmly sit together, showing me friendship to be or not? I always find other soup-dumplings. 16 Pell St -„Äã for your feet, etc, then you cross the narrow street literally, and eat, and eat...! Delicious,  perfect seasoning, never rushed! I wish they would deliver to Brooklyn! Easy enough to take home. One (1) train, all the way! Listen to  ,  and in a click, you're in CHINATOWN.  A DAY OF YUMMY FOODS@Joes, , A FOOT RUB at Heaven,. Extended to your wishes! 16 Pell Street is the start for your tired feet. Then, a meal of your choice!! You will never forget; you'll be back!  I hope you love this "day" as much as I do!!
I had the (crab) soup dumplings, absolutely delicious!  And cheap!  I'd eat this everyday if I could.  I don't care much for the vinegar sauce.

pork soup dumpling was maybe the best thing i had on this trip. so much better than expected. i don't even really like soup. servers don't seem to be friendly but thats normal service for me when we are talking any restaurant in any chinatown.

I was told to visit Joe's Shanghai to try their infamous soup dumplings! It was a beautiful day in Chinatown and I have arrived at the restaurant to find a busy and loud atmosphere. Plenty of servers running back and forth removing plates from tables and I could see the dumplings already on many tables being eaten. I was very eager to be sat and order and to my surprise we were given a table almost immediately. 
    My friends and I sat next to a couple who had already eaten most of their dumplings. I asked if they were the famous dumplings everyone talks about and the couple insisted that we try and finish the rest of their dumplings. We were shocked and accepted their generosity to try them. The hype was so true! The dumplings were delicious! I immediately ordered a fresh order for myself. A few minutes later they were placed right in front of me hot and steaming. I carefully placed this new hot steaming dumpling onto my spoon and began to slurp all the juices that were spilling from the doughy surrounding. The inside was filled with pork which was very flavorful and pleasing. I could eat these dumplings all day. They were one of the best things I've ever tried. If you're going to visit Joe's Shanghai you won't be disappointed with the dumplings. I'll be sure to return when I am in New York City again.

I love these soup dumplings. When I used to live near the financial district, I would stop by here for lunch with my roommates. I have never been disappointed here. The only thing is the restaurant can be a little messy but it is still cleaner than most of the other Chinatown restaurants.

Excellent food.  Had the fried rice with dry scallops. Excellent and light on the oil. Snow pea sprouts very good. Splurged on shrimp with walnuts.  Can't go wrong.  Could mix of Chinese patrons meaning it's close to the real thing. Will go to Uncles again
You will not have better Chinese food in your life. I felt like the parents that turned into pigs in the movie Spirited Away. I could not stop eating.
Perfect Chinatown restaurant with friendly staff and quick, attentive service.  All the food was on point, hot and delicious.  Facility was very clean.  4 stars for being cash only, otherwise a 5!
Shrimp rice cakes may be my new favorite food. Got this place delivered to upper east side on Friday and the soup dumplings and shrimp rices cakes were to die for!

Big juicy dumplings. It's standard - great but not amazingly good. It's what a dumpling place should taste like. The wonton has more dough than what I would normally like. I also got the spicy fish fillet w rice. Super spicy and good! I rather go to Din Tai Fung but for the price point here, you can't really complain.

Got seated after waiting for only 10 minutes which was great. However, the compromise was that the seating area was super crowded and my table was only like 1 foot away from the table next to me. I could easily hear the conversation of the couple next to us. 

Besides that, the food was delicious and the servers were attentive. I loved the soup dumplings and flat noodle dish. The spring rolls were a bit too greasy for me but yummy overall.

Wow this is a truly amazing restaurant. Their dumplings are bar none! I went one night with some buddies of mine and was totally blown away. The people who run this joint are also super amazing, totally unexpected and five stars every time!!

Everything I ate was amazing. I cant stop dreaming about the scallion pancakes and the dumplings.

I also really enjoyed the community style dining.I read a lot of reviews about "awkward" seating and conversations and I just think its a sad reflection on society. People rather stick with their small groups than have a chance to experience something different.
Always delicious dumplings and decent food. I bring friends from out of time for the experience of shared tables, rude wait staff and yummy dumplings.

Does this restaurant need a review?  Of course! They have moved about 2 blocks from its prior location, offering much more space and the requisite social distancing. The food has NOT changed, and that's a good thing! The soup dumplings are still out of this world. The rest if the menu is also thumbs up. Remember, they are CASH ONLY, don't get caught unexpectedly and having to use the ATM at the door.

Great soup dumplings or Xiao Long Bao! The pork ones were my favorite. The dumpling wrapper were thin but were strong enough to handle the soup. We also had the Seafood fried flat noodles. They were delicious as well! Will be returning

You know when you go back to this place twice in the row for dumplings, that this place is good. We actually did that and "yes" it was the best dumplings that I have ever eaten in the states. We ordered a couple of orders to start which comes in a basket of 10 and trust me, when you start eating them - they go fast. 

Every dumpling is steamed perfectly, cooking in it's natural juices until you release the juices by putting them in your mouth. The key is to pick each of the dumplings and let the soup-base juice drain in your spoon.

Don't be surprised when a total stranger sits with you, sharing a table is common especially during lunch time.

Excellent variety of Chinese food. Everything you order there is good and believe it or not, I'm not a Chinese food fan but this place is phenomenal. 
The crowd is big everyday so expect a wait of 20-30min. more or less. The line goes outdoors but it moves given the space in the restaurant is a descent size and you usually share tables there.

Best place EVER!!! Been going there for years and the new location is super easy to get to.  This is a must have place as their soup dumplings are as good as those from Taiwan

A must have in your list of places to go

This is a legitimate Chinese place. But with flavors that aren't too foreign, it is easy for tourists to enjoy themselves while having a new experience. I would definitely recommend the soup dumplings, because that's something that you can't experience at your corner Chinese restaurant. That is, unless, you live in china town in NYC.

I dare you to find better soup dumplings than here .
Decor very simple but who cares when the food is perfection.
The wait....sucks.  The food.....AWESOME!  Best soup dumplings in American.  And those sauteed green beans are nomz too.

Joe's Shanghai was my first ever experience with soup dumplings and I was not disappointed. So yummy! We also had the soft shell crab and a soup of some kind, which were both just as delicious. The bill was very reasonable too.
Above average Chinese food and I'm super picky. Good prices!

Dang it.  The white people have discovered it, and now the lines are super long.

For those who haven't been there, be prepared to share a table and wait a long time for it.  I think it is totally worth the wait though.  I think the lines are better if you go for lunch/brunch, not dinner.  Waiting around in the street in sketchy chinatown is also not advised anyways..

A basket of pork XiaoLongBao was about 5 dollars.  That's ridiculously cheap.

I also really loved the flavor of their beef ChaoNianGao--I think it translates to rice cake in english?  If anyone knows a place that does ChaoNianGao as good as Joe's, please let me know.

And the ConYouBing (scallion pancakes) were super good too.  2.65 for six slices.  I might just go there for a snack one day...

It is a given to most New Yorkers that this is where you go for the best soup dumplings. For the newbies of soup dumplings, it can be a challenge, so please follow these steps:

1. Order the crab pork soup dumplings with a side of scallion pancakes.

2. On your spoon, carefully tear your soup dumpling with your teeth (without letting the steam fog your glasses or burning your lip). OR be smart and poke a hole with a chopstick. 

3. Sip the heavenly goodness. 

4. Put some sauce on it, if you choose, and devour the rest of the dumpling.

There you have it! I only wish someone taught me how to eat these things many years ago. I would have not wasted all that precious broth or suffered from minor burns!

Right in the middle of China town Joe's serves great and fast shanganiese food. Line seemed long but it moved fast. Tables are communal and waiters are immediately in your face asking you what you want so you better be ready to order. We tried the pork steamed dumplings, spicy garlic scallops and shrimp with steamed vegetables. Food was served within minutes of sitting down, the dumplings were the best for sure and the broth was good. They only take cash so make sure to hit the ATM before getting there. Not the best Chinese food I've had
But over all it was a good experience.

Didn't expect it but, Joe's Shanghai was actually something else. The value is exceptional. The most flavorsome dish was Lo Mein, me and my friend genuinely loved it. It was so yummy. Team: perfect. Attentive and professional. What an amazing find Joe's Shanghai is.
authentic but expensive on cash. xiao long bao is defnitely the awesome

Joe's Shanghai has the best xiao long baos in NYC. Being from Shanghai myself, I had to come and see what this city had to offer - in the sense of Shanghainese food. I was not too excited about seeing this place, as it was not in the best neighborhood, but I quickly realized my suspicions were not confirmed. This happened as soon as I sat down. I came for dinner on a Saturday, and I had been walking a lot. The staff understood our pressures to get good food after a long day. Overall, not going to this place and eating the XLB would be like living in a house without a roof.

The soup dumplings were amazing here!! The place has gotten much busier since the last time my husband came and you can expect a short wait or to be seated with strangers. However the food does not disappoint and is worth it :)

First time here!! The wait is long on the weekends, not sure about the weekdays. Once you're sat down, menu comes out, food comes quick. We ordered and the food arrived in about 5 minutes. We got the Pork Dumplings 5/5, Scallion Pancakes 4.5/5 (could've used more scallions but that's just for my own liking, otherwise, very crispy), and then we got the Peanut Noodles 4/5 (they're very good, but it's super filling since the noodles and sauce were so thick) - I mixed with their soy sauce which was really good. The place overall is very nice, and very crowded. The bathrooms are downstairs. Women's restrooms has three stalls, not sure about Men's.
Great food. Long line no reservation. Soup dumplings are incredible and their rice! CASH ONLY

I have nothing to add to the conversation concerning the soup dumplings. They are the reason I was back to eat at this place. I brought my wife this time because she and I both thought that she would love them as well but alas, it wasn't to be. All the better, that just left me to eat both shares :-). What I would like to mention is the braised pork shoulder. It was divine!!!  The flavor was rich and well developed. The portion was easily enough to feed two. Of course I will admit to a bit of a prejudice, for I believe that there is little to not love about any part of the pig but this dish elevated the shoulder to unbelievable heights. It was so tender that a knife was superfluous. Absolutely falling apart melt in your mouth. The fat and connective tissue had rendered out every last bit of goodness they had to offer. I am drooling just remembering it. 
Yes, the place is a hole in the wall on a small back street (am tempted to use the word alley). Yes, there is a wait at the busy times of the day. Yes, there can be language barriers. Yes, you will eat family style with perfect strangers. Yes, it is wonderful!!

HELLO SOUP DUMPLINGS!!! *DROOOOOOOOOL*

I had one request while visiting China Town...soup dumplings. My friend (the New Yorker) took me to this place, and boy was it worth it. We didn't wait long, but there were a ton of people in the restaurant already so we were really glad they were able to seat us right away.

I can not tell you how DELICIOUS those dumplings were. I tried the pork dumplings and the scallion pancake thing. They both come with these sauces and each sauce complimented each dish so perfectly. I'm seriously salivating just thinking about it. Both were really amazing!! I really enjoyed my experience here, and the service, for an Asian place, was actually really great! 

I will definitely have to come back to Joe's the next time I'm in NY! Can't wait!!!!!

Best place to go if you have a xiao long bao craving.  As a 5 foot 2 happa I can eat about 2 orders by myself.  That's how juicy and delicious they are.  I prefer the classic pork as opposed to the crab, solely because they are the tiniest bit fattier and make the soup that much tastier.  The scallion pancake was meh, a little dense and a little too oily from over frying.  Skip them and just order the soup dumplings.  

Having been to Din Tai Fung in Shanghai, I can say these are not the best soup dumplings I've ever had, but definitely the best I've had in New York thus far.  

Don't bother with the tongs because they'll puncture the wrapper and lose all the delicious soup!  Brush up on yo' chopstick skillz if you aint asian, because there is a proper way to eat a soup dumpling (grab the top, bite a hole in bottom, drain out soup to spoon, drink soup, eat dumpling, add vinegar as desired).  Don't try and eat it all at once because I guarantee you'll burn your tongue off.  

Easiest to go if you go with a small group since they seat you at large tables with other parties.

Cash only, but at less than 5 bucks for a steamer of xiao long bao, you won't be needed much of it.

And gan bei cause it's BYOB.
classic - i would eat breakfast and dinner here four times a week if i lived closer - definitely great for the winter evenings.

This is my favorite place to get Chinese in NYC. Everything here is good and I really recommend. it's authentic and the taste is phenomenal. I always crave it when I'm in the city. I think it' better than Din Tai Fung because this place has more options.

I have to admit that I was a little skeptical of Joe's Shanghai at first. I walked up and there were about 10 tourists waiting to eat here (OK OK and there were lots of white people inside which I generally take to a be a "this is not authentic asian" sign). After waiting about 10 minutes, my friend and I were sat at a communal table with 4 other diners. I'm actually kind of glad we shared a table because the people next to us got this awesome looking fish dish which we also ordered. It was a steamed sea bass with ginger and green onions. The fish was really tender and flavorful. Good dish. 

We also ordered the pork and crab soup dumplings (shao long bao) and they were good. They certainly weren't the best I've ever had but definitely in the "better" category of the many I've sampled in Manhattan's Chinatown. Flushing is a whole other ballgame obviously. We weren't really all that hungry so we ordered soup - mustard greens with pork. It was decent - not all that exciting, but it was light if that's what you're going for. 

The server was surprisingly friendly and actually gave me another Chinese restaurant recommendation (I think it was because I spoke Mandarin with him?) 15% gratuity is included in the bill. You pay up at the front and get shooed out for the next customers. 

Summary? It's cheap and hits the spot.

Alotnof people avoid this place claiming it to be overpriced and a tourist trap. I disagree. The Soup Dumplings are the best in Chinatown. The crab one has roe in it and is full of crab. The Rice cakes was the best dish I had that day. N one makes it like Joe's
Amazing Pork Soup Dumplings , Crispy Pan Fried Noodle w Beef . Also try the Chicken & Green Beans w. Garlic Sauce. Consider this your inside Scoop.

THIS IS THE REVIEW I WAS TALKING ABOUT FROM THE SECRET BAR DOWN 2 streets from here!

I LOVE THE DUMPLINGS!!!! anyone that visits ny, chinatown should come here for them!!!!!

they also give great service and try their best focusing when they are so busy.
Soup dumplings!  That is about all that needs to be said. If you are a fan of soup dumplings this is the place to get them and it is well worth the wait.

I'm not an expert but I've eaten A LOT of chinese food in my life.  Anytime I get an out of towner to visit and they like Chinese this place is the place.  I have never had anyone say that it wasn't the best.  Yea, yea the soup buns are delicious.  I like the string beans szechuan style.  You can't go wrong really..

The restaurant is in an alley. Despite the location, there was a crowd of people, which made us reluctant to wait. However, after having to track down the waitress with the seating list, we literally got seated right away.

It was uncomfortable sitting with other groups but everyone got used to it.

The servers were actually pretty nice/helpful, though sometimes hard to grab their attention. The waitresses handling the people were actually the ones more hostile. 

We tried the crab soup dumpings, pork soup dumpings, and scallion pancakes.
We were stuffed by the end of it. All were pretty tasty, but too much..I was crying for hot sauce by the end of it. As the restaurant isn't all that clean, I opted out of using the sketchy old-looking bottle of hot sauce in the middle of the table. 

Be careful to not burn your tongue from the soup from the dumpings! If I had to choose between the two types, I would order the crab. The scallion pancakes would also be a great appetizer to share among multiple people.

Delicious as always! Soup dumplings or xiaolongbao are always the way to go! Our neighbors had a dish I hadn't seen on the menu that we decided to try which was amazing. Ask for beef or pork rice cakes. My only complaints are they really try to hussle you out and it's overpriced for Chinese food (they charge for the rice). We split around three dishes for three people and it came out to $21 each. The fact that they carry Tsingdao makes up for it. Oooo also make sure to order the eggplant (qiezi). Mmmmm
If you don't mind sharing the extra seat at your table with a stranger then this place is a must for Dim Sum.  We are definitely going back!

Went two nights in a row. I have been dreaming about the soup dumplings. Just know that if you are going solo or in a small group you will most likely be sat with other people at a large table. Was awkward but then I made friends!

Such a small store for such popularity! Holler from Sunny San Diego!

Pros:
- Amazing Xiao Long Bao. The crab one and the other ones were amazing. GET THESE if you dont know what you're doing! You wont be disappointed!
-Prices are okay. Not too expensive but not cheap either.

Cons:
- If you are in a small party and there's another small party at a big table. They will put you with them. Kind of randomly awkward (it worked out for us because they were nice and offered us some of their food).
- Their Beef Noodle Soup was okay. Nothing special. 

I will come back if I'm ever back in NYC :)
I just have a question , does anyone here know what brand of rice Joe's Shanghai uses? I've been wanting to know for some time now. Come here at least once a month, great soup dumplings.

Joe's Shanghai is just simply wonderful. The price was super reasonable - I couldn't believe it! Joe's Shanghai had incredible food, I really liked their Sesame Chicken. The greatest part of the experience was the service. We will most certainly be back!

Come here for the Xiao Long Bao (XLB's/Soup Dumplings).

There is almost always a line to get in here. You may have to share a table with another family. 

They offer crab meat, pork meat, and crab/pork dumplings. I enjoy the pork ones a bit more. Two orders of soup dumplings was enough for the four of us. Each order comes with about eight.

I have ordered some of their other dishes in the past and was unimpressed by them. Therefore, I come here primarily for one thing. 

The soup dumplings make a nice meal, but they also serve as a wonderful appetizer. We usually come here for appetizers, then go to another restaurant around Chinatown for a full blown meal.

{Note} Cash Only

$5 Soup dumplings all day! So good, it will be worth the wait. Just avoid the busy times where everyone and their tourist mother also wants to go. It's an experience. Great to take out of towners to as well.

Me and my mom went to this restaurant at 4 on a Thursday and there was still a line to enter and to get a seat.

Atmosphere:
-It is crowded it this restaurant but it's expected.
-There is a high chance that you would have to share a table with other diners.
-There were pictures of famous celebrities that visited this restaurant hanging up all over the walls, so that was pretty neat.

Service:
-The greeter was very friendly considering how many guests she must see everyday.
-The food came out fast.

Food:
-Sliced Braised Beef Noodle Soup ($6.25)
-The noodles were so smooth. I loved how the meat was so tender that it would just melt in my mouth. Since these were the same price as the soup dumplings I would rather just get another tray of dumplings instead.
-Pork Steamed Buns (8 for $6.25)
The famous soup dumplings! When I was picking the dumplings up, the skins kept breaking which was a disappointment but based on the other times that I've been here, this is rare. I probably just got a bad batch. The meat filling of these dumplings were very generous compared to other restaurants. I would recommend trying the dumplings with the vinegar that they provide, it gives it a different taste and you might like it more than the regular version.

Me and my mom decided that the next time we come to this restaurant, we would prefer getting two orders of the soup dumplings instead. I highly recommend you to visit this restaurant, especially if you like soup dumplings.

The soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai is well worth whatever wait is required at the door.  The soup dumplings are the main attraction of this place.

When you first go in, you have to give your name/# of party to the woman at the front with a clipboard.  (Note: you have to go back to her after a few minutes to confirm that you are still there and haven't left in order to secure your spot.  Otherwise, your name gets crossed off apparently)

When you finally make it in, they seat you at one of the big round tables.  You WILL sit with other people you don't know.  Could make for an interesting story or two (:

When I come with my friends, we always get a few orders of the pork dumplings and a lo-mein dish.  I also tried the kung pao chicken here, which is pretty good.  The dish portions are generous, but they charge extra for rice, fyi. Be careful of the hot soup dumplings! There's a certain finesse to eating these not-so-little (perfectly sized actually) morsels of delight. Poke a hole in the top to let out some of the heat/steam.  I like biting the whole top layer off and sipping some of the hot soup out and then devouring the rest once it's cooled down.  Yum! (:

My idea of Chinese food is golden fingers and fried rice. So when I came here with friends, I was kind of apprehensive about what I'd eat. 

Food - Delicious. Ive never liked dumplings of any kind, and didn't think I would like them here. I couldn't get enough! You have to get them if you come here. Our General Tso's and some noodle dish were delicious as well. Everything is served family style. 

Service - quick, not much else to say.

Atmosphere - Much like Chinatown itself: hectic and busy. If you come here with more than 5/6 people, chances are you are not eating together. There are communal tables. If you come with 7 people, and there is a table with 5 seats open, guess what? 5 people from your party are sitting there, and the other two are sitting someone else. Unsure if they take reservations, though. Our party of 4 sat at a table with two other ladies, which worked in our favor. Said ladies taught us how to eat the dumplings, and what was good here.

I was very pleased with my experience here, and will definitely be back when I'm in the area. Check it out, if you haven't been.

Me and my friend stumbled on this place while walking through chinatown. Definitely one of the best Chinese restaurants I've ever been to. Be sure to get the dumplings, they're amazing and really cheap.

There are certain things that I have heard over the years and always held off on believing. One is how wonderful the Chinese food in NYC is. This place made me a believer. 

The pork soup dumplings were unbelievably good. I'd never had anything like them before. They were delicate little pillows filled with the most flavorful broth and perfectly seasoned pork I've ever tasted. The ginger soy sauce they serve on the side added a sweet and salty component that made the things just sing!

Then we got the Beef and Broccoli and Kung Pow Chicken and both were simply fantastic too. Rich brown sauce that wasn't a gelatinous mess like so often I've found. Then the broccoli was fresh and crunchy that was a great compliment to the beef.

The King Pow Chicken....wow! So good. So flavorful and just the right amount of spice too. 

Seriously the meal was just wonderful. Great food, great service and honestly great prices too. Three people ate dinner for about $40! If I lived here I'd be a regular customer.

This place is CASH ONLY, which is to be expected when you're in Chinatown. But fret not, they have an ATM machine right outside if you don't have any. I've seen my friends frequent this place and finally decided to go with them. We made the mistake of going on a Saturday night and the regular 15-20 minute wait turned into an hour long wait. I'm not complaining about the wait time, I completely understand, but I think they need a better system of seating people or at least informing people that it's not just based on the number you're given but also how many people are in your party. I felt bad for the hostess because people kept pestering her about tables when their number was skipped and she was getting really confused and frustrated which in turn made the customers even more frustrated. 

After finally being seated, we each ordered the regular pork soup dumplings, beef fried rice, saut√©ed string beans with minced pork, and a beef noodle soup.  The portions were huge! We had to take half of our food home. The soup dumplings were bigger than I anticipated and were delicious. The pricing was very reasonable as well; $6.75 for 8 pieces. I enjoyed the orange slices that they gave us at the end. 

Service is typical of Chinatown, they want you to be in and out so they can get as many people in. Food came out quick and plates were whisked away as soon as they empty. But even with the quick service, we felt relaxed and were able to enjoy our food. 

Overall, I definitely would recommend this place for anyone looking for soup dumplings in Manhattan. But I suggest coming on a weekday or some time earlier in the day. or prepare to wait for a while. I also would love to see a better system for those that are waiting to be seated and when they do, I'll give them the extra star.

Food is better than average. My kids enjoyed it. We got scallion pancakes, pork & crab dumplings, beef Lo-mein & shrimp fried rice. The Lo-mein had a good quality beef & the noodles were thicker than a standard Chinese take out which I prefer. The rice was average with petit shrimp. We enjoyed both dishes. The hits for our table were the dumplings & pancakes. My children have advanced taste pallets so getting them to try & enjoy the dumplings/pancakes was easy. However, we were accompanied by two children who were not very adventurous & we ended up ordering 4 trays of dumplings to accommodate everyone. Everyone killed it. Regarding the seating process, you get a ticket & wait for your # to be called. The numbers are not called in order. I was told 15 minutes, but waited a little over an hour. We had a big party & they were really busy. At some point you've waited so long you just decide to succumb to the wait. In the end it was worth it. Nice pot of hot tea to warm us & we left with full belly's! As mentioned it's cash only, but it's cheap!
Joe's Shanghai was probably the only place I liked in NYC. Their soup dumplings were excellent. I recommend their eggplant with garlic l, braised duck, general tsos chicken and the saut√©ed clams.

Great soup dumplings but service was not. They kept rushing us and would pick up our food when we had one dumpling left on the plate and transferred it over to another plate so we could hurry up and finish after being there for all of 10 minutes.

I understand that business is about making money and there were a lot of people outside but after waiting an hour in line and then to get my food, I would have liked just  LIIIIITTLE bit more time to enjoy my food. It's a very small place and it's hard to walk anywhere without bumping into anyone. 

This place would have gotten a 1 star from me for the customer service but I would hate to deter anyone away from trying their exquisite Xiao Long Bao.
Beautiful and delicious soup dumplings! So delicious! They spill onto your shirt, but it is worth it. I am going to go back.

This is ranked the top location in NYC for XLB so I had to come try it. I came with my boyfriend earlier in the day before lunch time and we were seated immediately. We really just wanted to try the XLB and nothing else. We ordered just one order of the XLB and I appreciated that the waiter did not judge us lol. Fast service, quick and easy! They also offer take out too. Most people come for the XLB but I did see that other dishes looked good. Price was reasonable, but was it the best XLB I've ever had ? No. It was good, but just not the best. Love the quality and freshness though!
It's pretty good, kinda expensive for what it is but the dumplings were good. Honestly though, there's a million places like it and they all have shorter lines

Probably my favorite chinese restaurant of all time. First of all, this place is going to be packed when you get there, expect a wait. Let me tell you though, the wait is well worth it. My friends and I went there at 1pm on a Sunday and waited 20 minutes. Secondly, the seating is family style, large community tables of 10-12. If you're not a fan of sitting next to a person you don't know, this may not be the place for you. I, however, could care less who is sitting next to me, as long as this place keeps up the quality of their food, and ridiculously low prices. I came in here with 5 others, and we were all pleasantly surprised that our waiter knew perfect english (not trying to be racist or stereotypical). It is a general assumption from the wait staff that you are there for the soup dumplings, and that is the first thing they ask you when you are seated, everything else is kind of extras. Out group got the soup dumplings, General Tso's chicken, Seasame Chicken, Beef Noodles (OUTSTANDING), fried dumplings (in my opinion better than their steamed counterparts), and fried rice. Fair warning, order one order of soup dumplings at a time. After about 10-15 minutes, they get cold, and the quality of the product drops significantly. Also, for 6 people, the amount of food we ordered way WAYYYY too much. I think our final bill ended up coming out to $100 (gratuity included), and I would say we took home 1/4 of the food we ordered.

I've been here twice this past month and more times than I can recall in the past. 

The first time I went with folks that work at Rocketboom. Here's what they said:

"This is the only place in China town where I can eat Chinese food and won't get sick from it afterwards."

The 2nd time I went with Jeff C.'s group on a dumpling run. Here's what they have to say about it:

"I'm glad this place have Tsing Tao (beer)."

If you're ever in china town NY you mist stop by Joes for some soup dumplings. Try to get there when the restaurant opens to avoid the wait. Its small but most places in NY are and the turn around time is quick. Sometimes you might be sitting with another party at your table. My favorite is the crab dumplings but the pork is good too. Both are packed with flavor. It might take you a few times to master not spilling all the broth on your plate.

The daughter INSISTED I go here while in NYC and I'm glad I did.  Would've been much better to go with someone else, but going by myself is better than not going at all.  Since it was just me, they seated me at a communal table.  There was a group of 3 friends, and another 2 oriental women.  I ordered the soup dumplings, which were SO VERY GOOD!  I struck up a conversation with the 3 friends, hoping that they'd offer to let me try some of their food.  It was VERY obvious that they'd ordered WAAAAY too much.  But when they didn't offer, I thought they'd be taking the leftovers home with them...  But they didn't!  It was sooooo sad to watch all that food go to waste, and I hadn't had a chance to try any of it!  The oriental women did offer, and I tried a soup that they had which was better than I'd expected it to be.  The building itself is kind of a dump, but the food was outrageously good.  And NOT extremely expensive, like most things in NYC!

My annual trip to China for work doesn't look like it happening this year, and because of that this summer has been the summer of Chinese food (and lots of running because of it). 

The latest installment Shanghai Soup Dumplings. I have flown out of Shanghai twice but never had the chance to try a famous soup dumpling so Joe's Shanghai in China town would have to suffice. 

First off there is the technique, you pick up the top of dumpling carefully with your chop sticks and place it in the soup spoon, then once safely on your plate you gently puncture the top of the dumpling to let the soup cool, at this point you can suck a little soup out if you so desire, then once the dumpling is cool enough you attempt the eat the whole thing.
Biting into this wonderful morsel is new experince in itself, first soft sticky dumpling skin, then the rush of the soup and finally the meaty center. It is like a party in your mouth.

We had other food as well but the soup dumpling was the star!

Forget the soup dumplings and get the Shanghai Chives & Shrimp with Meat Wonton in Broth. Don't get me wrong, soup dumplings were good, but we thought the wontons were so much better. Even the server said wontons have better flavor.
We ordered the crab and pork soup dumplings. They were hands down the best I've tried! Add the chili oil and vinegar sauce, so flavorful!

My favorite place for soup dumplings. They are so good! Also recently renovated and the indoor dining is very nice. Quick service and friendly staff. Take out always on point. Their hot and sour soup is so good.

Came here for the soup dumplings, of course! Also got an order of the fried rice cakes. I think it's a little pricey for chinatown, there's always a wait for a table, and I don's think it smells that great. That being said the soup dumplings are huge and delicious and what more could you want on a cold day?
The BEST xiao long bao ever!! Steaming hot, juicy, soupy dumplings!! The original was great but the crab XLB was even better!! Too many good stuff going on in my mouth for one bite!....So good!!

Came for the soup noodles and was not disappointed.  I will say, I did not like the ones with the crab, they tasted fishy to me.  Next time, I would only order the ones with pork only.  My husband agreed with me.  We also ordered the Singapore Chow Mei Fun and loved it.  I have not been to the two other locations, but I loved traveling down to Pell St location, it feels like going to a secret hideaway.

Out of this world amazing soup dumplings. One of the best meals I've ever had. My friend and I showed up about an hour early because we were told the wait can get crazy but we were still the only ones by the time they were open. We got an order of soup dumplings and an order of on fried dumplings. The soup dumplings were big and sooo juicy. The soup inside was so damn flavorful, it was like WOW xlb's can taste this good?! They were really big so equal parts fantastic and tricky. I feel like with soup dumplings you have to get them in one bite to do it right so that's quite the big bite. Pan fried pork dumplings were really tasty too but pales in comparison to the xlb. Staff were friendly enough but you don't go to Chinese restaurants for the service!

First time yesterday for dinner, it's a great place. Everything we ordered was super, garlic eggplant, Shanghai shrimp and of course the steamed  crab dumplings. Highly recommend this place. Service was equal, very nice place.

I dream about these soup dumplings. Fantastic food, but be prepared to wait since they do not take reservations here. Also, it is cash only! We were seated at a communal table with one other group of five, and it was fine. It does not take away from the experience. The food comes quickly, is hot, and delicious!

The soup dumplings- amazing. Never had before, so I may be inexperienced to make that call, but I would go back and wait in that crazy line again just for them! Dumplings, rice/lo mein, and an entree dish would be enough for 3-4 average eaters- and all for about $10pp including tip!!! Great value. Plus, unlimited jasmine tea (a fave). 

Be prepared for a long wait, long bathroom lines, subpar service, and sitting with a table of strangers. But like I said- that price!

The only thing worth getting is the pork and crab "steamed bun" which is, of course, soup dumplings.

There's a line to be seated even late at night which is probably due, in part, to the fact that so many other places in Chinatown close 10pm or earlier (despite posted hours to the contrary - I'm looking at you Shanghai Asian Manor).

I've been eating Chinese food all my life.  So much so, that I got very tired of it.  And because its availability is high, the quality seems to go down and I rarely enjoy it.  Joe's is a different story.  This food is exceptional.   It was so delicious it was hard to put down.  I had the Green Beans and Beef and an order of Egg Fried Rice.  Amazingly exceptional.  I don't know how I will ever eat and enjoy Chinese food elsewhere.  Additionally, the community table sitting/eating was fun and we enjoyed great conversations.
Obviously, can't compare with Asia and with that being said, this is some of the best pork Xiao Long Bao I've had in the States. Onion Pancake and Shanghai style stir fry noodles were good as well.

This review starts what I believe will be 5-10 days of reviews of lunch spots near the courts on Centre St.    Yes, that means I am a juror (#5), so with my 1.5 hrs I figured I would do some good.

I usually go to the Joe's Shanghai in Flushing, and rarely go to this one and the one on 56th Street.  I have had soup dumplings all over NYC and Shanghai, and these are officially the best.  They trump the other Shanghainese places in Flushing (others have skin too thick or broth too lean).  My lunch here at the Pell St location consisted of a simple tray of 8 pork and crab soup dumplings.  And while the taste was spot on, a few were stuck together and some others were stuck to the bottom.  Both issues resulted in a loss of the precious juice; a major problem.  Hence, the knocking of a star.  I also like the beef with rice cakes, which I did not get this time but would recommend. For the best ambiance and cheapest prices, I would suggest this location and the Flushing location.

UPDATE: I was dismissed from jury duty because the case was settled.  No more fun Chinatown lunch adventures.

If you don't already know about Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings, crawl out of your cave and go get some. And please bring me a dozen.

The only thing i have to add is that, lately for me, an order of soup dumplings is not complete without the PEA SHOOTS. Sometimes they're not on the menu and I think they cost as much as an order of soup dumplings, but totally worth it.  YUM.

Joe's Shanghai is one of the most popular Xiao Long Bao (XLB- soup dumplings) spots in Chinatown and for good reason. They moved from their original location a few years ago where you had to share a circular table with other diners ( which added to the dining experience in China town) but they maintain the same great food. The XLB are large and filled to the brim with soup in addition to being well priced. It is a must try when visiting! Outside of the XLB, Joe's also serves other classic Chinese dishes but the star has to be the XLB. Joe's is a cash only establishment and there is usually a 20-30 min wait for a table. They do also automatically add an 18% gratuity on top of your bill regardless or how much you order or if your party size. Overall, Joe's Shanghai is definitely worth the stop for  their XLB, but make sure to bring cash!

Yummyyy soup dumplings and reasonable price!! I would def. come back here :) The only downfall is that they seat you with a bunch of strangers so it's kind of awkward hahah. Besides that, the food is pretty satisfying.

We heard about this place from chef Robyn from the rumor's bar kitchen "palate party" in Wilton manors, FL. check them out!!! 

Upon walking to the place located in a Chinatown-esk neighborhood, in an alley. There was a huge line outside the door. Walk inside give the hostess the number in your party and she gives you a number. Eventually the same hostess will come and call random numbers to come in. It's family style seating so be prepared to make friends at a shared table if necessary. Small place, seats about 25 people. 

They are known for their soup dumplings so that is all we were there to try before our flight. You can choose from crab or pork meat with crab. These dumplings were the best I have ever ever had. Huge portion, 6 for $9. We got the mix of pork and crab. Full of delicious broth with so much filling. Steamy and heaven! 10hrs later on a flight back home to Fort Lauderdale, and I was still talking about them. 

The people we got sat with ordered other food, that also looked and smelled delicious!

For sure an adventure, not the best Chinese food I have ever had but very interesting. First off cash only so make sure you know that. Second it a scrum to get into this place so for sure plan to get there 30 minutes or more before you plan to eat and don't be surprised as you get seated for 10 strangers at a big family style table.  We were at a table for 10 with just the two of us. We had the soup dumplings of course and they were for sure the highlight. If I would were to go back I would have gotten two orders of those and perhaps just one dish more (for two people).  They are worthwhile as others point out, be very careful when eating as the soup is inside. 

We had a sesame chicken dish that was very good and a broc beef that wasn't amazing but servicable.  This is an experience and due to buddy who lives in the city I found it.

As point out cash only and the put the 15% tip for you, frankly the service sucks so they probably were getting less so added in.

I think I was supposed to like this place more than I did or maybe soup dumplings just are not my thing. CASH ONLY establishment. Friendly takeout and it takes 15 minutes to get the dumplings to go. 

Soup dumplings are 8.95 for a nice portion.

Best damn soup dumplings EVER. I was in absolute heaven here w/ these little juicy purses of deliciousness. 

Joe's Shanghai is apparently really well-known for these little puppies, but the noodles that my friend ordered are supposed to be a real hit too. The noodles were as good as she had promised, but I'm sad to report that I can't recall the name of em'. 

We ordered the dumplings and the noodles + a bowl of rice and were stuffed by the end of the meal. They are more than plenty for 2 people.

Thanks to my bff for bringing me to this Chinatown gem! What a treat!!

It's been my must and first stop restaurant when I come in town.

Always, always, always! order xiao long bao or as I call it, explode in your mouth of deliciousness. I've also ordered the shrimp shumai soup. Delish!

They open at 11 a.m. and make sure you get there early enough cause it will get busy. If it gets busy, they will start seating people (if 2 or less) in a big round table with other strangers. I wouldn't mind that cause I'll be making friends anyways.

Service is just like any where in Chinatown, hard to explain and hard to understand. But it's hard for them to mess up your order.


Cash only and please don't be that guy who will give up your watch as collateral and run to the ATM.
First time eating "soup dumplings" was at Joe's.  It's a great place to get an introduction.  Their scallion pancakes were cooked to a scrumptious crispiness.

YOU MAY BE FREEZING OR SWEATING OUTSIDE BUT KEEP WAITING- IT'S WORTH THE WAIT.  Go inside and get a number and the lady will call you. There's no reservations and they will not call your phone. Do not walk away because when the lady calls your number and you do not answer she will give your seat away. 

It's aways crowded in here but the dumplings comes quickly- like 10 minutes fast if you order right away. 

This is a solid place for good Shanghai food. You get everyone from all walks of life to eat here from the locals, business men from Wall Street, college students, to tourists. Yes there is a long wait- usually about 20-40 minutes but the food is very good. The services is okay. This place is always packed. There was a time where it was easy to find a seat but that was over 10 years ago.

Xiao long bao- soup dumplings are the best here. It's always hot and it has cabbage underneath it which taste very good with the vinegar dip the dumplings comes with. The soup is to die for. No funky smell or taste- just really good dumplings.

pan fried dumplings also known as potstickers- they make these deeped fried and it comes with a sweet sauce. I like it, 

Shanghai thick noodles- dont get this. it's a greasy mess. They are thick udon type of noodles with soy sauce and preserved vegetables. I do not like this at all. 

Shanghai fried rice- Very good. Some of the best I had. Remember this is the Shanghai fried rice NOT the pork fried rice or the yeung chow!! This is nice, chewy rice texture and eggs with scallions and brocolli stems in tiny pieces. Here's a pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/joes-shanghai-new-york-2?select=ze5EjzJBcJfKTLOWpEmfag#liWom4GCKRqUWqPyyMzjjg

A fixture of China Town, this place simply makes the best Chinese food I've ever had. I don't know if it's authentic, and the dining room is cramped and certainly doesn't have much aesthetic quality, but you're not going to care because the soup dumplings are absurdly great. Everything else on the menu is excellent too, and the food lacks that overly syrupy/MSG overdose tendency that much of "Americanized" Chinese food has - meaning that despite the generous portions, you don't end up in a food coma afterwards. Put simply, the place is great.

Still my favorite Soup Dumpling spot in Manhattan! I hadn't been in almost a year, and the dumplings were just as flavorful. We waited for about 15 minutes on the Monday of labor Day weekend, and it was well worth it. Also, remember, it's BYOB!

Also enjoyed the kung Pao and the Sauteed String Beans with pork. 4 stars instead of 5 because of crowding and the effect on table service which was brusque at best, and bothered at worst. We ordered two orders of soup dumplings, and didn't get our second until well after we had our entrees. The price of popularity!

We only ordered soup dumplings. ONLY soup dumplings. Plus fried scallion pan cake. 

The soup dumplings here is good. I like the crab meat soup dumplings better than regular pork soup dumplings. The crab has more flavor and tastes much better. The regular pork soup dumplings tastes too oily. 

Overall, this is a good place to go.

Tucked away in a random Chinatown alley, Joe's Shanghai is a hidden oasis of amazing flavors. Ok, maybe not that hidden, considering the place was freaking packed and people (including us) waited at least a half hour outside in 20 degree weather.. or maybe that's just how popular it is.. 

The famous soup dumplings (Xiao long bao) from Joe's are pure awesomeness!  They are made to perfection and don't break and spill like at other places.. So good.. we killed like three or four orders of them!!  Oh yeah, we also got some pan fried noodles and a shrimp soup.. pretty tasty, too.  

It's was worth the long walk deep into Chinatown, dipping and dodging the Gucci and Prada peddlers along the way.  And it was definitely worth the wait just for those little flavor packed Chinese dumplings.  Joe's is a MUST hit for any NY trip.

SO cheap, and SO good. I just don't like sitting in a table with people I don't know.
