But the restaurant has no choice because the line to eat is so long (I don't like waiting either, super impatient especially waiting to eat). So in a table for 10 people, they would fit 3 couples there, or 2 families there. I still think it's the best Â∞èÁ±†ÂåÖ place in Chinatown.

Visited Joe's Shanghai last Friday. Waited about an hour to be seated. This was partly due to how crowded it was, and partly because they won't seat you unless your entire group is there. We ended up having 9 people instead of 8, and one of the employees kinda flipped out a little over that.

Very crowded and noisy inside, which is typical of dim sum places. Reminded me of dim sum back in Hong Kong. My husband and I are vegetarian, and there were plenty of dishes for us. Loved the scallion pancakes! I was sad to have to pass on the soup dumplings. They looked amazing! 

Our bill came to $132, including tax and tip. We had ordered a ton of food, and I was surprised by what a good deal it was per person. 

The website says no reservations, but they will take reservations if you have a party of 10 or more.

After hearing my family rave about this place I finally got to try it. It's a hole in the wall kind of place. This place is starting to gain traction because there's a lot of celebrities eating here. I want to say that their soup dumplings are the reason why they are coming but I looked at some peoples table and there's no soup dumplings. Do remember if you're coming here it's cash only. 

I came for the soup dumplings. I'd only order soup dumplings here and maybe every now and then chive pancakes. 

They serve two types of soup dumpling. The classic pork soup dumpling and a crab soup dumpling. I like the crab soup dumpling a lot more than the pork. The crab soup dumplings has the classic pork with some crab and fatty part of the crab. I totally recommend this place for that.

BEST ASIAN RESTAURANT I'VE PROBABLY EVER BEEN TO! I'm a huge critic when it comes to food and I can honestly tell you that Joe's Shanghai is amazing! The wait was a bit long and kept getting longer, but that's okay given how great the meal was. The standout dishes for me were the pork soup dumplings and the sesame chicken. Both the crab and pork soup dumplings were good, very different, but still good. The better one was for sure the pork dumplings, however. The broth was rich and flavorful as was the meat. They were a favorite amongst the whole family. Now, I'm afraid to have soup dumplings from anywhere else because I doubt any other restaurant can top my experience at Joe's Shanghai. I'm hoping to be able to get my hands on some frozen ones if they ship to other states. The soup dumplings were life-changing and I would recommend them 100 times over!! Thank you Joe's Shanghai!!!
Shanghai dumplings were great. This place gets packed from what I read but it wasn't bad at all mid afternoon.

This place is definitely the place for soup dumplings! HENCE MY PICTURE =) Always crowded but so worth it.  Even though I feel awkward sitting at the table with many other people. (its a small restaurant so you share your big round table with other people if you go wtih a few people)  But the feeling definitely goes away knowing your going to have some yummy dumplings.  we would buy basket after basket.  
everything else there is okay but i really wouldn't go there to buy other entrees.  Just fill yourself up with the soup dumplings because they are so worth it.

I also think this shanghai in chinatown is the best.  we went to the one closer to time square and it was more expensive and the taste was actually different and it seemed like there was less soup in the dumpling.

Things to note:

The wait sucks.

Tsingtao beer goes with anything on the menu

The two teenage girls that work the door always screw up the numbers and I end up waiting longer.

Loads of tourist.

Loads of Chinese Families, so you know it's the real deal.

You sit with a bunch of people you don't know. So if you get the fat smelly dude as a dining partner, sorry brother.

Pretty much everything on the menu is good.

Soup Dumpling! Get them or don't even bother going.

After a failed attempt to get a late Sunday brunch at Locanda Verde (subway closures, taxi snubs, and no seating after 3), we made our way to Joe's Shanghai for a very late lunch.  I'd had the place on my list since 2009 but never found a convenient time to go.  Apparently the restaurant is packed with a line out the door at all times - there was a half hour wait at four in the afternoon.  Impressive.

We took a number and grabbed boba next door, and with our hunger temporarily addressed, the wait wasn't terrible.  When a large party cleared out, a man called our number.  We were a party of three, and we got seated at a communal table with a few other small groups.  The setting was pretty dingy and uncomfortable, with, incredibly, the locker room stench of worn feet.  To my relief, that faded behind the smell of Chinese food when we sat down.

Service was curt and kind of funny.  "What dumpling you like?" was the standard greeting.  Our waiter spoke very little English and offered zero help with the menu when we asked what else was good.  Not rude, just brutally cursory.

We got an order each of pork and crab soup dumplings, and they were quite good.  They came eight to an order, so two orders were more than enough for three.  The dumplings were big and somewhat hard to eat.  I haven't worked out how to eat xiaolongbao without either losing all the soup or burning my mouth, so I did plenty of both.  Maybe someone will tell me the secret for my birthday one year.  Scalding aside, these were good dumplings.  The skins varied in thickness, but they were good where thick and good where thin, always supple, never too doughy, and sometimes pleasantly sticky. The insides were great, too.  I have to admit I couldn't really distinguish between the pork and crab (I suspect that the crab dumplings are mostly pork, or that our waiter mistook our order), but both sets of dumplings featured succulent mounds of meat enveloped in a wealth of hot, flavorful, fatty meat juice.

The dumplings were the main event, but we added a couple other dishes to round out our meal.  We chose them mostly at random from that vast, meagerly descriptive menu, and they were decent.  I actually quite liked the double cooked pork, which came in a stir fry with a mix of vegetables and mushrooms.  The meat was tender and very flavorful, with a hint of spice.  I was less keen on the Shanghai pan fried noodles, which came in a heap with some beef and greens.  They had a bouncy texture that was good enough, but the soy sauce flavoring was pretty one-dimensional.

I don't know that I'd brave the wait to try Joe's Shanghai again (I mean I haven't even been to Din Tai Fung, which is the main XLB purveyor back in L.A.), but it was worth it the one time.  You must love dumplings to enter, enough to put up with a long wait and a rather unlovable setting. If you do, though, give the place a go.  Let me know if you make it out without burning the inside of your mouth.

I heard about all the hype with Joe's Shanghai and my friend actually told me his last meal on Earth would be their chili prawns so I meannnnnn I had to see what the hype was all about.

We came here around 6 and waited 30 min for a table which I felt wasn't that long since we came during peak dinner time. They had a temperature check at the front and a place to sign-in with your phone number (I'm assuming to give customers a call if there were any covid issues?) and we got seated at a table that an employee had just sanitized. 

We ordered the crab meat and pork soup dumplings, chili prawns with shell off, sauteed flat thick noodle with beef and sauteed string beans with minced pork. Ok, first of all, the XLB is filled to the absolute brim with delicious soup. I have never encountered a XLB with that much soup inside. The filling was full of flavor and you can taste the crab and pork really well. The other menu items were all equally delicious and I can see why my friend loves the chili prawns so much. The prawns are super plump and the sauce has the perfect balance of sweet & sour and loaded with large pieces of garlic.

Wow, honestly 10/10 solid meal! We even considered coming here a second time but decided against it to try other foods, but I'll definitely be coming back on my next NY trip.
Best soup dumpling I've ever had!! Singapore noodles too spicy but whatever were good. Everything was delicious!!

The past couple of times I've been to NYC I have tried getting into Joe's Shanghai. There was always a line out the door, and at least an hour-long wait. So when we happened to be in Chinatown on a Monday afternoon, imagine my delight! Famous for the "soup dumpling," Joe's Shanghai is a bit of a New York establishment...

I should have done my research ahead of time. Instead we went in without a clue (like most tourists.) We were seated at a round communal table, and given chopsticks and some green tea. The menu was somewhat baffling. Although the restaurant is known for the "soup dumplings" these items were not prominently featured on the menu. I flipped through for a while before asking the waiter for help. I was given a cross 'you-look-Chinese-but-can't-speak-the-language?' stare and after much confusion, the waiter made my order for me.

The Xiao Long Bao or, "little dumplings basket," arrived fresh in a bamboo steamer. They were round, symmetrical things, that supposedly resemble a pagoda shape. Observing my neighbors, I decided the best way to eat them was to plop a dumpling on my spoon, nibble off the top, drizzle in some of the vinegary sauce, and then suck the meaty broth from the steaming pouch. Afterwards I could munch away at the delicious little crab and pork meatball and the yummy doughy wrapper.

Other specialty dishes at Joe's Shanghai include, the shredded turnip shortcake, a variety of seafood options, braised duck and Shanghai fried bean curd (this one was delicious!)

Please note: Dine carefully on the "soup dumplings" as these little pouches of steaming hot liquid can result in severe tongue burning!
The most amazing traditional Chinese food I've ever had! Service was quick, and it was definitely worth the trip to China town.
Absolutely amazing! Been to NYC 3 times and to Joe's Shanghai a total of 5 times! The dumplings are a must! The general chicken is amazing and the pieces of meat do not disappoint!
YUM dumplings + fried rice off da chain! Worth making across town for.  I know good food bring a foodie from LA.

Shanghai Cafe Deluxe is my go to spot whenever I'm in NYC but this time I was with some friends who wanted to try Joe's Shanghai so I bit my foodie tongue to go with the flow. I've always wanted to compare Joe's to Cafe Deluxe since so many people rave about Joe's. 

Overall, I still prefer Shanghai Cafe Deluxe since their soup dumplings are better. 

1. The dumplings were like a young teenage boy where the skin is so thin the dumplings were prematurely bursting with the graze of a chopstick.

2. The soup dumplings at Joe's are bigger but too big for the spoon where the dumpling skin flows over the spoon which makes it harder to eat. 

The flavor of the broth was good though with the Crab being my favorite. We also ordered the fried rice cakes and I liked Shanghai Cafe's better. These were pretty greasy. But the other items we ordered were actually really good.

Service was satisfactory and it was great to finally try out Joe's but my heart lies with another.
May take a bit to get seated but great dumplings, sesame chicken, scallion pancakes and more
best soup dumplings in nyc, sesame chicken good also
Soup dumplings are the best in town. Family style dining makes this a normal occurrence as a solo diner. If there's a wait, grab a drink around the corner at the speakeasy apothke.

I was kinda conflicted when trying to rate Joe's Shanghai.  If I could, I'd give it 4.5 stars...5 for the soup dumplings, but .5 deduction for bad service.  Normally, I'm not one to deduct for non-food related stuff (especially cuz what's the point of food...it's to eat it), but the combination of all the bad service-related issues plus the other so-so dishes on the menu, I ended up giving it 4 stars.

Let me start with the soup dumplings.  I'm from LA, so I've tried Din Tai Fung (the west coast contender for best XLB), but in my opinion, Joe's has, hands down, the BEST soup dumplings ever.  Every time I visit NY, I HAVE to have at least one meal at Joe's...even if it means waiting an hour to get one order of soup dumplings to eat as a appetizer before heading over to another restaurant for an entree and dessert.  The skin is perfectly thin and chewy, while the soup inside is so savory, you can't get enough of the soupy deliciousness.

For those who had tried other XLB places, here is how I think they compare.  Din Tai Fung - Joe's soup dumplings are way bigger, plumper, tastier, and cheaper.  Winner in all categories (except for atmosphere...DTF is way cleaner and presentable as a restaurant).  Shanghai Cafe - The skin is way too thick and doughy for my taste, but the inside does taste cleaner (not as greasy).  

Finally, let me touch upon why I ultimately gave Joe's Shanghai 4 stars instead of 5. On Yelp, their business hours are listed as being open everyday until 11pm, so imagine our surprise when we got there at 9pm, and they practically shooed us out of there saying that they were closed (the place was about 3/4 full with people still eating).  How rude!   And just a heads up - when you're paying, the bill they give you already includes a 15% tip (regardless of the size of your party).

Best XLB that I have ever tasted in my life! Not that I have tasted that many....but still...it's the best! I went to the Midtown/Manhattan location a couple of weeks ago during a bachelorette party weekend. The crab/pork dumplings were rich, flavorful, and addicting. I really did not understand why people liked xiao long bao's until I tried Joe's Shanghai. I wish they would open up a location in the bay area.

First rule: be prepared to be seated with strangers.
Second rule: rude hostess is to be expected.
Third rule: order the soup dumplings.

This is a traditional family style restaurant, where strangers are grouped together into a table, filling every chair - elbow to elbow. If you're shy, bring lots of friends. The soup dumpling are amazing. I like the traditional pork soup dumplings, and sometimes have the pork/crab soup dumplings as well. 

There is a secret to eating them:
1) place a single soup dumpling on your spoon
2) bit off the tip of the soup dumpling and let the steam out
3) pour a dab of the vinegar sauce into the opening
4) slurp the soup through the top, leaving some
5) then stuff the whole soup dumpling in your mouth

Your plate is guaranteed to be clean and all the yummy soup will be in your tummy and not on your plate.

And to the "non Asian" family I saw over the holidays, who were cutting their soup dumplings in half on their plates, leaving the soup - seriously, what part of the "soup dumpling" did you not understand?!?! It was heartbreaking to watch you guys eat.

Two words. Soup Dumplings. Best I have ever had. Pan fried noodles are also really good and crispy if I have enough room for them after the dumplings. The place has been packed every time I have been in, its family style seating so there have been times when I have gone in by myself and got sat at a table with 8 other people I dont know, but I think that just adds to the atmosphere.

Most of the time, unless you go during off hours, you wait forever for a table, get seated next to slobbering strangers, then get rushed out the moment you're done with your last bite. But being treated like such crap has never felt so worth it because those soup dumplings are soooooo good. I've definitely eaten fourteen or fifteen in one sitting, which is kind of gross (but it felt so right at the time!). If you've never tried them yet, just get up and go now. They're like heaven in a bamboo steamer.

This place never disappoints! It has effectively ruined all Chinese food from hence forth. We order crispy beef and fried rice. Our kids love the pork dumplings, which is huge since they won't try anything new.
Great food. Great prices too. Dumplings and buns are phenomenal. The tofu dishes were delicious. Many locations. I personally have gone to 3. And they were all wonderful.
I love Joe Shanghai its the best. The soup dumplings is to die for. The general tso shrimp is so crispy but yet so sweet. General tso chicken is also great.
Their food and pork dumplings are okay, but the crab and pork dumpling (xiao long bao) is amazing. I haven't been able to find another good crab flavored xiao long bao.

My friend was raving about their pork soup dumplings, so we came by for those. They were absolutely fantastic! By far, the best soup dumplings I have had so far. $7 gets you 8 hot, delicious soup dumplings. You'll be craving soup dumplings the next day, and the day after that. 

Joe's Shanghai starts to get busy even when they have just opened for the day. Seating here is efficient, they fill their tables by pairing you with other groups, which is a pretty neat concept. 

I'll be returning soon for those soup dumplings!!

There was a line at 2pm, but we decided to wait anyways because it took us forever to find the place and we've read so many good reviews. The hostess is rude, she threw our menu on the table, but I can understand because the place is packed with lines out the door. We ordered the Crab Meat with Pork Meat Steamed Bun (really juicy and tasty), Sliced Braised Beef Noodle Soup (a good warm soup with fresh noodles), and Shanghai Fried Flat Noodle (my ultimate go-to item). I really enjoyed the food, but don't expect a great atmosphere. They were watching our every bite to see when we would be done to get us out. Again, I can understand, it's just really crowded! Also, they don't use a lot of MSG as other Chinese restaurants, which was a big plus for me, and the food tasted very fresh.

Joe's Shanghai is well known in Chinatown amongst both tourists and locals. Although I wouldn't say it is the best place to get soup dumplings or other Shanghainese dishes, it is a sort of right of passage in New York Chinese cuisine. 

Expect a wait, especially on weekends and for large parties as Joes does not take reservations. There's always a wait outside spilling into the street(we had a 30-45 wait for a party of 2 on a Saturday evening) and inside the restaurant is bustling and filled to capacity. Unless you are with a large group, you will likely be seated at a table with other diners. Although some might find the restaurant's tight space and shared tables uncomfortable, I enjoyed the energy, seeing what others were ordering, and chatting with other diners. 

If you're a tourist visiting Joe's, pay attention!! For the best experience, order items for your party to share. Guests are served tea with their meal so drinks are not required. Joe's is especially well known for their Xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and I would say it's a must. Both the pork and crab soup dumplings are good, but I love the crab soup dumplings. DO NOT waste your visit by ordering the typical American Chinese dishes you're used to ordering at your local Chinese takeout spot (General tso's, Kung pao chicken,Sesame Chicken etc. Two other parties at my table did this and I was crying inside). Some tasty dishes that I recommend if you're new to Chinese food are Szechuan Beef Tendon Noodle Soup,  Shanghai Fried Rice, and Saut√©ed String Beans. From my experience the spice in dishes is toned down, even dishes marked as spicy are not too spicy. For those that want a bit more heat, there is also table chili oil (also pretty mild lol) to kick it up a bit. The meal is finished with complimentary orange slices, yum!

TL;DR expect a wait, order the soup dumplings, skip the American Chinese stuff you're used to, try something new.

Have you even eaten in New York if you haven't eaten at a Joe's something??? It's classic. And Joe's Shanghai is no different. 

It's on the edge of Chinatown, walkable from the metro station. The restaurant itself is pretty spacious and has a more modern vibe to it. 

My friend and I came in on a weekday afternoon (2pm) and it was still busy. We waited about 10 minutes for a table and the service was prompt and super speedy. 

We ordered the pork soup dumplings, the string beans with minced pork, fried rice cake with beef, and crispy pork chop. 

XLB: 9/10 this is my 3rd time coming here and I feel like the dumplings just keep getting bigger and bigger. The skin is on the thicker side and it's filled super full of soup and pork. They taste amazing, but minus one point bc I'm a thin wrapper girly

String beans: 10/10 perfectly cooked, not too mushy and not too crispy. Has that perfect crunch without being raw. Also perfectly flavored. Definitely a veggie dish though. The "with minced pork" means it has a small topping of pork. But super super yummy. Will always get this when I come here. 

Fried rice cake with beef: 9/10 chewy rice cakes with huge chunks of tender beef. Yummy, but not as flavorful as some of the other dishes. 

Crispy pork chop: 8/10 pork is tender and juicy and the fried outside is crispy. It's flavored really well and the sweet and sour sauce they serve with it adds the perfect extra flavor. I just wish the pork to batter ratio was a little better, batter can be a bit on the thicker side. 

Overall, amazing place with quality food. Definitely a classic. Add this to your list of "Joe something's" that you've been to

Our number one place to go for soup dumplings. We don't usually order anything else so can't say much about the other dishes. The wait can be long at times but it's definitely worth it.

It's the perfect about of soup, pork, and skin per dumpling. We love to order the crab one. It's absolutely delicious and I'm getting hungry just thinking about it!

My wife and I wanted to have a late lunch. I had read a review on this location and decided to stop. We were very lucky in that there was an open table for two at the front of the restaurant. Not knowing what is best, we ordered some gyoza and one order of soup dumplings. OMG we should have only gotten the soup dumplings!  The gyoza was ok but the dumplings...absolutely awesome. We ordered two more orders of these tasty gems. 
The richness of these juicy dumplings and the tasty morsels of filling were heavenly! When we go back it will only be dumplings.

My wife and I attended Joe's Shanghai on a Friday night and was greeted with a long line out the door.  After our long wait the soup dumplings were worth the wait.  In addition the sesame chicken was delicious.  Absolutely worth the trip!
Soup dumplings are so necessary! I've had a very limited selection here (we just came for the dumplings). Good prices and a TON of food. Service is pretty good. We enjoy coming here regularly.

I have been to all 3 locations. My favorite one is the one located in Flushing. This one in Chinatown is not bad though. The wait is the worst part of it. At any given time you will wait half an hour to an hour. It's definitely worth it though! The other downside is they tend to sit you with random people, you can be sitting with like 2 other groups. It's kind of awkward at first, but most of the time, everyone is friendly. The wait staff is quick! Once you sit down, you can order your soup dumplings and they come out rather fast. I have to say the soup dumplings are the best thing on the menu --I always find a craving for them once the weather gets cold. The pork soup dumpling is the most popular, but the crab soup dumpling is my favorite. I also love their steamed buns with condensed milk as the dipping sauce!

I actually like the dumplings here but not the pork-only ones.  There is nothing more to say about the dumplings that hasn't been said already.  However I think people are missing out if the only thing they order are the dumplings.  Their pure vegetables (not the junk with baby corns or their ilk) especially the snow pea leaves are so really good.  Also I suggest trying crispy chicken (only the skin is fried) or the pork shoulders.  Actually I haven't had anything bad except when I ordered typical Chinese American dishes like sesame chicken which came with a sauce that was way too heavy and sweet.

One bad thing is the wait.  I feel their whole wait list system is just plain broken which is why I like to come at slightly odd hours.  However the service is fine; you might need to raise your hand to get noticed but it isn't like they are ignoring you on purpose.

Soup dumplings were amazing and waiter was helpful in instructing the proper way to eat them. 

Also ordered bubble tea and the chicken with mixed vegteables which was standard Chinese food. 

Pork soup dumplings were worth it though.

My only exposure to soup dumplings has been at Din Tai Fung in California which I like perfectly fine and even crave sporadically. But I have friends who swear up and down that the soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai will make my panties wet with joy so on our most recent trip out there, we stopped by Joe's Shanghai at my insistence, if only to sate my curiosity (the whole "so delicious it'll make your panties wet" thing was so not believable to me). 

Going to Joe's was seriously a random act so we actually ended up walking a few miles in the rain and ended up there at like 4 p.m. in the afternoon which I figured would be a good time to beat the crowds. I knew the place was popular but I mean, who would want soup dumplings at 4 p.m. on a hot and rainy summer day? A lot of people apparently as when we got there  the restaurant completely packed with a little bit of a wait.  

We had plans for dinner later on so we shared one order of the juicy pork soup dumplings between the two of us. To be honest, when I actually tasted them, I was sort of sad we were only sharing one order since by then I had to acknowledge they were pretty good and I could have eaten 2-3 orders all by myself. 

Was it that good? Yes it was good but who doesn't like soup dumplings? Was it better than Din Tai Fung? I couldn't say, the texture is different and each have their positive points. Would I go again? Sure, if I happened to be in NYC standing in front of the restaurant and there wasn't a line. Did it make my panties wet? Uhm no.

 Bottom line: I'm glad I tried it but with so many places in NYC to still get through, there probably won't be a repeat visit.

Overpriced tourist trap
Mean hostess with a mean attitude and desperate need of manners. Watery dumplings, and barely ok everything else. Places hasn't been cleaned or re furnished since 1943
This place is definitely paying for fake reviews. I get that it's always packed with tourists, but 2000+ reviews and 4 stars for unspectacular Shanghainese food?! You must be kidding me.
We got the soup dumplings and scallion pancake and it was just okay. Service was good. Weird that they charge a gratuity for all parties no matter the number of people. I wouldn't come back
This place has gone downhill now that it is a tourist destination.  The dumplings are still good, but nothing else is.  Joe's Shanghai in Flushing is much better.

I'm still searching for a decent soup dumpling restaurant in NYC. For me, this restaurant falls short on many levels. Immediately, upon entering, you'll be hit with a funky smell. The restaurant probably needs new carpet. Give it a few minutes and you'll get used to the smell. On to the food. All of our dishes were glistening in oil. I've come to expect this type of preparation at most chinese restaurants, but it was a little too much here. After waiting 30+ mins to get seated, you're ready to feast, so you get past the smell and oiliness quickly. Your stomach will be full after a meal here, but the quality and atmosphere could be improved. Also, don't forget this is a cash only restaurant!

Wanted to try the best soup dumplings in NYC but found the place a little overrated. I found the dumplings dry on the outside and soup not as flavorful as others I've had. It was nice to see all the famous pics of people on the wall who have eaten there.

My friend recommanded this restaurant for me, but unfortuanately I had a verrrrrrry bad experience at there, probably this is the worst restaurant service I have ever had in New York. They refused to gave us seat only because one of our friend still on the way and didn't wait for the seat with us, we waited in January's cold wind for 30 minutes while there was a spare table all the time, and get a bunch of stink-eyes from waitress and boss because we argued. The food was OK , the price was cheap, but still very hard for me to take such a bad service. I'm a Chinese, I love Chinese food and always gave rather good rate for Chinese restaurant, but this one really irritated me. I can't believe our Chinese fellows can be such mean. There are tons of wonderful food in China Town, if possible, chose another one,  this is not the only choice.

Listen, I love Joe's Shanghai, their thick noodles with pork and their soup dumplings are the fucking bomb. But I don't like the fact that their sesame chicken is 19$. It doesn't taste any different than your average NYC Chinese restaurant sesame chicken platters.

For unknown reasons, this is probably the most popular spot in Chinatown. I'm kind of surprised but the food here is just alright at bed. I haven't been here too many times having been brought recently via a reservation and also with a group once. They specialize in XLB/xiao long bao and I would not order anything else but them. 

In terms of said soup dumplings, I have had better even in Manhattan Chinatown. As said by others, the skin is a bit too thick. The broth inside is fine. The meat is the best quality where the crab and pork is a lot better than the plain pork. It is a pretty good soup dumpling but there's better. I have (mistakenly) ordered the kao fu which I found it to be too cold so the texture was off not to mention the odd sizes of the wheat gluten compared to other spots. Another person got a noodle dish which was overpriced and just not that good. 

Perhaps the high reviews are coming from people who have never had Chinese food outside of American Chinese classics or something because I can't see why this place is popular enough to have a line out the door. Low/mid 2.
As an Asian! I will say it just ok, pretty average! And place is a bit dirty. So I guess they know how to put money on Advertising. Maybe their food is more for the people who are not Asian

I was visiting in NYC and decided to give this place a shot.  The xiao long bao weren't too bad and I am a bit biased since I prefer dumplings from the northern part of China.  With that being said I gave this place an extra star for their XLB, however everything else was pretty terrible.  

General Tso's chicken was more like orange chicken you can find at Panda Express and the Garlic Scallop and Shrimp had barely any flavor.  I forgave the fact that the place was not that clean and that we sat next to the trash as it is packed and super busy, but was so disappointed in the food.  Panda Express food for anything but Panda Express prices and I hate Panda Express.  The spring rolls should just be called  fried eggroll skins because their was literally nothing inside and the scallion pancakes were oily and soggy when they should be light on the oil, crispy on the outside, and layered goodness on the inside.  

I try to be gentle on Chinese dining since there are so many regions and specialties, but this place is a tourist trap.  I would agree with many of the reviews only order the XLB and if you are used to amazing XLB then just go somewhere else all together.  This place is not worth it at all.

I usually love the food here but today I was not as impressed. The pancakes and noodles were super greasy. The bao were really doughy and the dough was tough. I also found a piece of plastic in the noodles. I get they are busy but I think they should be a little more aware of what they are doing. Definitely questioning if I would go back.

I have been looking to trying food in this restaurant based on the reviews and was deeply disappointed. 

The soup dumplings were officially the worst I have ever tried and I had tried a lot of them in various parts of the world including close to where they originated in Asia  

The corn and chicken soup had no taste and sesame chicken needed resuscitation with lots of sauce to at least have some flavor. 

Possiblity I'm not used to this taste and I apologise for this review as I assume huge number of people waiting in line who obviously like the taste but it is not for me.

this place is just OK for me since I've had better Chinese food in Chinatown. it's such a tourist place and trust me, if you're tourist, please walk around Chinatown and experience other Chinese restaurants, they're way more authentic & tastier than Joe's Shanghai. tourist books may be helpful but sometimes, not ALL the restaurants that are recommended in the book are "good". 

cash only and authentic Chinese food don't have beef broccoli and General Tso's chicken and many more.

My family and I got lucky and the line was not long when we arrived around 2:00 pm, there is usually a long line outside.    

The food was good - just good/decent, the overrated xia long bao are no way near as good as dim tai dings.  If you come here, just try the xia long bao and not the other entree dishes.  My family and I just arrived from miami, and we went straight to China town to get our late lunch at joe Shanghai following a friends recommendation. We were hungry after a long day journey but did not find the food as good as the other yelp reviews.  Get prepared for decent food.  

The service was impeccably rude, and most of the time felt like the waiters were trying to kick us out of the restaurant to admit others.  Even when we were done ordering and done eating, the waiters did not give us a good impression/service.

If I go back to New York City chinatown, I would try out other restaurants and definitely another place for xia long bao.

Classic spot for soup dumplings and you can never go wrong here. However, the other dishes were somewhat lackluster. I was craving Americanized young chow friend rice as well and having been raised by Chinese restaurant owners, I was massively disappointed in their other dishes. The young chow fried rice had zero taste, so I imagine the chefs forgot to add flavor given customer traffic. I'd still return for soup dumplings, but may not be so willing to try their other menu items.

We had a good time here although we aren't completely certain we'd come back. We enjoyed the food, but just weren't super impressed in the end. Felt underwhelmed. That being said, or group did have a fun time, just be prepared to be seated family style with other patrons at large tables!

I was a bit of disappointed. I went there because of good review. The restaurant is so crowded. I ordered the famous crab dumpling; however, the dumpling filling has crab shell. Some dishes just put too much of soy source and oil. I was so embarrassed since I brought a guess there with me. If you had good Chinese food before, you won't consider to go there again.

Havent been here for a few years but stop by yesterday. It was a disappointing at best.  the XLB or soup dumpling are still loaded with soup but they were obviously sitting in the steamer too long.  In each of the three order of XLB there were 1 or 2 that had burst.  

Wait staff was fine. The other dishes order (beef with green peppers) and rice cake with beef were greasy and average.  Quality has gone down and Joe's is jusy living off its previous reputaton. I have had better XLB in Flushing.

Whats even more insulting is that a 15% gratuity is automatically added to the bill.  Service was fine but the quality of the food wasnt.

If you like to inhale your food, in a chaotic atmosphere, with abrupt and pushy "hurry up and order" waiters (when there were plenty of empty seats tonight, Super Bowl Sunday) then this place is for you.
If not, you're better off ordering takeout and sitting on the curb to really enjoy what I believe, are the finest scallion pancakes in New York City.
The soup dumplings were good too, nothing to rave about as so many do here, but overall, for the hype and quality of what was ordered by my party, I've gotten delivery uptown and found it just as good.
But again, the scallion pancakes are immaculate.
Note, count your change.  My friend (who treated) noticed his change was $5 short.  This from a man who has dined all over NYC for nearly 6 decades.
He told me, "This has never happened before." But because they already add in the tip to the total, felt the need to ask for his proper change.

No.

Dirty looking.

They seated us in a round table with 3 other parties. Fat dumplings with fatty brought inside. It's supposed to be a light CLEAR broth. I'm not supposed to be seeing un purified broth. Sick. Tasty, but sick. Stomachache after.

Hot and sour soup was good, but we were too full from 2 sets of dumplings.

Restaurant was awesome in terms of service and food, but shared tables has its downside sometime.. this person has been talking about me in front of me and possibly taking pic of me without consent, so I took a pic too just for the record

Waited in line for an hour just to realize they forgot about us. When we approached the seating staff, she insisted that we didn't have our whole party with us when we actually did. No apologies either. Sat us down with some random strangers, waiter delivered food without telling us who it was for. When the food came, it was horribly mediocre. Screwed up service and run of the mill food. With the long queue to boot, this place hardly deserves half a star from me.

This is probably the worst restaurant I had ever gone to in Chinatown NY. I ordered a dish, but obviously they did not have one of vegetables, so they just used others to replace it without telling us, pretending to offer the right dish. I knew he moment I saw. Shouldn't the restaurant at least tell the customer that they do not have something rather than pretend nothing happened? This is lack of credibility. And they only take cash. I asked if I can write a check, and they said 'no, who knows whether your account has money." No respect to customers, at all.

The customer service is horrific. The woman who calls out your number when they have a table ready was not calling my number even after 20 minutes when she said they'd be ready so I went to ask her. She said to wait 20 more minutes. I told her we've been waiting 20 minutes and she said "You have no right to talk like that to me. Wait 20 more minutes!" She calls our number a minute after that but seats us at a same table as some random strangers. The restaurant also automatically includes a 15% tip fee into your check. 

Terrible workers and overall rude and annoying experience. 

You can get soup dumplings at better serviced restaurants and probably won't have to wait as long for them as Joe's Shanghai. Fuck you Joe's Shanghai.

The food was okay. Since the place was very crowded, they did not give us an option to share seat or not. 
We ordered soup dumpling and fried fish fillet. The soup dumpling was okay but nothing outstanding. The fish fillet for me was a bit too greasy.
Overall, it's just like any other dumpling place.

Not bad at all, but I guarantee you'll find better on the Pacific side :)
The only things really worth ordering were the xiao long bao, all the other food was not even mediocre. The skin was a little thick for my liking but the broth was tasty. Be prepared to have a shared table.

To be fair their soup dumplings are unparalleled but the tourist lines ain't worth it. Joe's Ginger which is a few walks down  (90% sure they have similar owners). Skip the wait and go to the other place.

We were seated at a rather small table to share with 4 others.  Its typical to share tables at chinese places but I've never been to a place that had so many ppl at such a small table.  I noticed that my spoon had dried food bits on it and asked the waiter for another.  When all our food came it was a challenge to maneuver.   

We got two orders of dumplings and crispy squid.  Dumplings were average.  I guess the squid is from some other region because it was very greasy and soggy.  Being korean we needed our hot oil so we asked the waiter for another jar since it wasnt easy to share the one jar with 4 other ppl.  He just took the jar from the other side of the table from the other diners and walked off.  At that point I just told myself service isnt a strong point in chinese restaurants and I let myself not be guilty for tipping low (or not at all) as is the custom.  

When the bill came I was shocked to see 15% tip was included.  When I asked the cashier she said it was included in all bills.   I guess they felt the need to capitalize on their tourist trap success and charge for what they call service.

So I've decided that there are definitely better places in the city for soup dumplings.  If you want cheap food, crap service, and a kick in the butt for mandatory tip then go here.

The three of us stopped by for some xiao long bao around 6 PM on a Friday night and were told that the wait was 25 minutes.  There were a lot of many people waiting and complaining about when they were going to be seated. The place was so crammed, we ended up taking up a little corner on the stairs and waited for over an hour to be seated.  About one minute after we ordered, we got two orders of pork steamed soup buns which definitely had been left out for a while....they were hard and not very juicy. 
About thirty minutes later we got our crab meat with pork soup buns and these were delicious.  Maybe I'd go back for the crab meat with pork soup buns, but I don't know if I'd be up for waiting so long in a crammed area. How do you New Yorkers do it?

The dumplings are what's "hot" here. Even the shrimp dumplings have pork in them, all of the dumplings have pork in them, it doesn't say it on the menu but ask and they will tell you. 

The shrimp I ordered wasn't anything to scream about, barely any seasoning on it, it wouldn't hurt them to have some bean curd options... On the upside I'm pretty romanced by the scallion pancakes. 

The waiters are pretty passive, the "don't wanna be bothered" demeanor is every where. 

Ooo yea, and plan for a 20 min - 1 hr. wait on weekends,

New York's Chinatown has always been a treasure trove of exotic delights from sugar apples, rambutan, crocodile meat and ancient herbal cures. And yes, xiao long bao, or as we call it in English, soup dumplings. 

Literally translated, xiao long bao means 'little basket bun' and not considered a dumpling by the Chinese for it is pinched at the top as opposed to dumplings, which are pinched along the semicircle. Mistranslated as it is, it has made its way from Shanghai's province of Nanxiang into surrounding Asian nations and into the United States. They are made using partially raised flour that results in tender, almost translucent dough but one that won't break while cooking, and traditionally pleated 18 times. The broth inside is produced by wrapping the filling with a gelatin based aspic or by grounding it into the filling. As the buns steam the aspic melts and the result is that lip smacking deliciousness that is the xiao long bao. 

Joe's Shanghai opened its first store back in 1995 in Flushing, New York. Since then they've opened 2 other locations, one in Chinatown and another in Midtown. They also have 3 stores in Japan where xiao long bao has a cult following of sorts. A visit to Joe's during peak hours inevitably means a wait but turn over is fairly quick and a half hour wait is more than worth it for their xiao long bao. Since the serving portions are rather large it's best to go with a group of 4 or more. Try both the pork and crab xiao long bao. To consume them minus the painful hot broth burn place a bun on a spoon, gently nibble off a piece of the dough to let the steam out, season with the vinegar sauce, and savor the bun together with the broth.

Bad service. They ask us to share table with others. Bad taste either. Left with dishes almost like it was served, and cost us $20/each. I lived in Shanghai for 7 years and I know the cuisine. The materials are low quality, and not well cooked as well. One of the worst Chinese restaurant.

4 star for their soup dumplings- they were pretty fat and juicy! However the best part about a soup dumpling is the soup... They actually had the audacity to serve one that was clearly popped and dry. I was so annoyed because I had to suck it up and eat that one :'( other than that, the pork soup dumplings were delicious. Crab soup dumplings were alright- I still recommend you try one of these just so you can decide for yourself if you like it!

Other food- DONT DO IT... Unless you're not Asian or you're into like Americanized Chinese food. If you are bringing your Asian friends and family here, seriously don't bother with the food outside of soup dumplings. That last picture was apparently twice cooked pork... But for anyone who actually has eaten twice cooked pork, this is nothing like it!
The green beans were okay but they were supposed to come with more meat in it...
The beef dish was mostly veggies and like a small amount of beef... It should've been in the veggies section of the menu!
Everything tasted unauthentic which is really unfortunate because I expected better from an Asian restaurant in Chinatown.

I'm a New Yorker. This is New York Chinese food, plain and simple. I don't get the thousands of fawning reviews. Tourists? Bots? People who've never had decent Chinese food? It's OK - I've had better. 

Tip: if there's a line out the door, as I've heard there can be, go to any place nearby. No difference.

The food was excellent. I enjoyed how they grouped multiple parties at one table. It didn't feel awkward at all. It was really packed. And the service wasn't as good as I hoped it would be. It felt rushed. And a waiter spilled some hot tea on my friends leg. Again, the food was great. I would have preferred better service though.

Everyone be sure to do not double tip! They have already charged you 18% service fee. 

The soup dumpling was 2/5, quite disappointing with its thick layer of skin. The fried rice was pretty good though.

Bad service, missed our order, put wrong food. Everything is oily, I don't recommend any one who wants have decent dinner experience come to here. Besides soup dumplings, there are all American style Chinese food. If you are Chinese please save your money and find other dim sum places are way better than here.

Maybe I just don't "get it," but I thought all the food we got was just fine - not exceptional.  We got the soup dumplings (xiao long bao), scallion pancake, and bok choy w/bean curd.  The bok choy/bean curd dish came with a lot of thick sauce - just wasn't what I expected, but it was fine.  Xiao long bao were fine, I didn't think they were that exceptional.  The scallion pancake was crispy.

I guess it's good to try it once if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way again to eat here.

XLB were good, but some were a bit dry at certain parts. Turnip cake was very tasty, as was the roast beef noodle soup. Extremely reasonable prices. 2 hour long wait for Christmas dinner, though. Honestly, not worth more than a 45 minute wait... the prices definitely justify the wait.

I don't normally write reviews but I felt compelled to because I came to Joe's Shangahi with a friend based on a recommendation and also reading Yelp reviews. First let me preface by saying I'm from Singapore and have eaten at some really darn good Xiao long bao restaurants in Singapore and Taiwan. The friend I was with had also lived in Singapore and Taiwan before though she's not Chinese. We ordered the regular pork XLB and the crab meat and pork XLB, plus the scallion pancakes and crispy pork based on Yelp reviews. I have one word - NO. To anyone expecting anything resembling Din Tai Fung XLB, you couldn't be further from this. Even though the skin was thicker than it should be and a lot of it, every single XLB tore off the lettuce leaf, but at least that gave us a chance to see the fat scum in the broth that came out of it. What we could salvage of the broth tasted blah. The scallion pancake was thick, deep fried and soaked in oil. The crispy shredded beef was really mediocre. Needless to say we didn't finish anything even though we had arrived with a XLB craving. The next day I went to another Shanghai Asian Manor for round two, I was hesitant from the previous experience but it was waaaayyy better - definitely go there instead!

xiao long bao was tasty but one came out with skin already broken (unacceptable)

green onion pancake way over fried

dou ban fish fillet was too salty

Nah man these are NOT the best soup dumplings.  The staff here were nothing short of obnoxious.  I can't believe there was a 2+ hour wait for some dang dumplings.  It has become a tourist oasis, everyone thinking that they are getting the best, where in turn there are so many other places better than this.  I was hugely disappointed by the soup dumplings because they were not filled with soup! The scallion pancake was probably the only good thing that we ate, and that was not even cooked correctly - it is not a deep fried pancake - it's supposed to be pan-fried! The pan-fried dumplings had no flavor either, just plain balls of meat with flour coating on it.  What did I even eat?  Everything was just oil with no flavor.  Dear tourists, steer clear of this one.  At least go to the Flushing location, Joe's Shanghai because this one is doing it ALL wrong.

For second dinner we decided on Joe's Shanghai! They are known for their soup dumplings and we couldn't wait to try them :) We ordered some beers, tea and crab/pork soup dumplings. We also got some scallion pancakes as well. 
The soup dumplings were good but weren't the best I've had. The broth tasted great and you get plenty of crab but the meat itself I feel wasn't seasoned as well. The scallion pancakes were okay too. Overall the meal was just okay. Worth the try though!
The soup dumplings were gamey.  They serve the same food that's at a joint with a lit up menu over the counter.

There were 4 of us that went at around 11pm and the place was packed! We really wanted to taste their uber popular soup dumplings so we sucked it up and waited 20 mins to get a table - which we also shared with a couple of strangers.

I am not a dumpling kind of gal but their soup dumplings were good, not the best (I've had better). Honestly, it was all about the broth. The dumpling itself was ordinary, but what made it juicy was the broth inside it.

I am confused why this establishment has such great reviews the food was bland, mediocre, and forgettable.  The service was okay and the waiter surprisingly told our group not to order a dish because it was frozen.  The dumplings were just okay. Stay away and do not be fooled.
This place is packed with Good Chinese Food! The Soup Dumplings are to die for!We'll defly go back to this Place!I just dont like the idea of sharing table with other People.Otherwise its A okei.

This place was super busy when we came around 8:30PM on a Thursday night. Luckily, we were seated within 15 minutes but they almost wouldn't seat us because even though we were the only group of 5 people waiting to be seated, the receptionist was convinced that there was another group before us... but there wasn't. We ordered 3 orders or the crab xiao long bao and 2 of the pork xiao long bao. They came out piping hot, which was great! Unfortunately, many of the xiao long baos (I'd say over half of our order) was broken so all the soup leaked out before they even touched our plates :( They were bigger than the ones I've had at Din Tai Fung, but the quality wasn't there. Other than the rude receptionist that seated us, the service inside was okay. Something to note is that they already add on tip to your bill so double check and make sure you don't double tip (unless you want to, then you're welcome to do that! :) ). This place is definitely quantity over quality, but it's decent for the price so give it a try and judge for yourself!

I came here a bit early (10:50a) and there was already a line formed. Getting a table was no problem if you waited in line but at 11:10a, all tables except the larger table in the back was full. 

Soup dumplings are actually called Tang Bao but I guess here it's called xiao long bao. Anyways, make sure you tell the server what kind of soup dumplings and how many orders when he first approaches so you can get your food fast.

An order comes with 8, Burin and I shared one order which definitely made us content. The dough was cooked just right: soft and a bit chewy but not too chewy. Not sure if this is standard but there is an automatic gratuity of 15%.

We shared a table with a couple who ordered 4-5 dishes! They even admitted ordering too much but they enjoyed their entrees and even offered us some but we were already content and kindly declined their offer.
Been there so many times. Dumplings are good. But never know they put service charge even two people and not telling you. AWARE of that. We tipped every single time until we noticed last time..

Friends and I waited for almost an hour to get a table, even though the girl told us 20 mins wait. We went from 2 people ahead of us to 4 because she let 2 Asian group in and not have them wait just like everyone else. We finally sat, please know, all dumplings are pork. The food was just like any other Fast food Chinese restaurant, nothing special. Not worth the wait and the hype.

My son has been throwing up all day. I feel very queasy. This is very expensive junk. Unfresh and sketchy food that caused us food poisoning. We had the crab soup dumplings, twice cooked pork and the mai fun. Also, this isn't advertised anywhere but this restaurant is cash only. How is that still possible? The atm fees are outrageous of course. I don't understand how it is rated so highly on yelp

Joe:

Our twelve year affair is over.  We're done.  

Yes, we've had good times.  I've overlooked your flaws (sub par food, rude service, excessive lines) because you had some very good qualities...ok, maybe just one good quality: soup dumplings.  

In truth, our relationship was built on soup dumplings.   I bent over backward, waited in the streets amongst garbage bags and the foul summertime smell of Chinatown.  I ignored others offering Xiao Long bao and saw only you.  

No more.  

Tonight,  after waiting an hour in the stank streets, you gave me a steam tray full of soup-less dumplings.  Two batches of deflated sacks.  Why you wanna play me like that?  And in front of my out of town guests, no less.   

Then, a roach crawled across our table.  A ROACH.  I threw up a little in my mouth.  I felt itchy all over.

The shine has officially worn off.   Even if I have to learn to make Xiao Long Bao myself, I'm never coming back.  We're through.  Adios. 
F*ck you, Joe, I'm so over you.

Food is great but expect not get homey service. Depending on your race you can get treated well or poorly. If you don't order enough food for the table they try to rush you and sometimes the check is given to you at the table without it being completed. It is a get in get out establishment.

Very bad service. This restaurant caters to tourists. Not authentic Chinese food. We waited for 1.5 hours to get in and one of our dishes never came out. The waiter never showed up after taking the orders. The only person that helped us at the end was Jeff. He came and apologized for the lack of service and for missing the food. They included 18% service charge on the bill, which is fine if we got decent service.

Wow. Worst service ever! Why bother going here when there are so many other places to have XLB!! seriously rude staff - from the 'hostess' fixing her hair to the wait staff walking by. Forget it...absolute tourist trap.

Oh my gosh. Those dumplings were fantastic. I came here because my mom's coworker recommended it. I must say though that the non-dumpling dishes that we ordered were rather bland. Their string beans were undercooked and very tasteless; my family only ate half the dish and didn't even bother to consider taking it home with us. So when you come here, JUST EAT THE DUMPLINGS.

I heard about this place for having "the best dumplings" ever.

I tried the dumplings and they were good. Only good because of the sauce that came with it. I was craving the sauce, not the dumplings. 

And looking at the prestigious reviews articles and celebrity photographs hailed on the walls of Joe's, I find it quite disturbing that this establishment takes cash ONLY. 

It's like Michael Mina or Gordon Ramsay accepting cash only!

Ordered wonton soup with shrimp wontons, Shanghai beef, Crispy Duck and Seafood with fried noodles. The crispy duck was ok, shanghai beef too soggy, Seafood with fried noodles, noodles was not crisp but the rest was ok. The wontons & steamed dumplings was the best part of the meal. Strangely the main course arrived before the soup & dumpling appetizer. Overall nothing to rave about.

The worst wait and service experience. 

Person said the wait was going to be 15-20 mins., but ended up waiting an hour - namely because I was a party of 3 and a party of 5 was easier to seat. This logic makes no sense to me and why should this matter since you have to share a table with strangers. If I was given an honest estimate on the wait, I would've went someplace else.

Finally got seated and put my order in, which consisted of soup dumplings, a rice dish, and a vegetable dish. 

The waiters never said "Happy Lunar New Year" to my group, while many non-Asian customers received a warm welcome with New Year greetings. What a joke. I guess that's why 85% of the customers were non-Asian.

Ate the soup dumplings and they were good as usual. The rice dish came and, like typical asian dinners, the rice should be eaten with something, like the dam vegetable dish I ordered. 

We waited 15 mins. for the vegetable dish (while the rice was getting cold) and then ended up asking the waiter how long it will take, who went to check but never came back with an answer. I decided to cancel the vegetable dish and was given an attitude.

Paid my bill and collected my change and gave the waiter a $1 tip while he stood next to me to make sure I tipped.

Would not recommend this place to anyone.

From here on out, you're dead to me Joe Shanghai.

First of all, I completely understand that Chinese restaurants are not known for their service. I have been to many Chinese restaurants in my lifetime. However, I actually walked out of Joe's Shanghai because the waitress/hostess was such a b word. We came in around 3PM on a Thursday.. it was busy but not the usual line out of door busy. There were 2 spots available, one was part of a larger table shared with other people and the other was a small 2 person spot in the corner that they were still cleaning. When she pointed us to the larger table, I asked if we could wait to sit at the smaller one. She yelled at me, saying that it was too busy and that that was all they had. 

I don't care if the waitress doesn't even talk to me as long as the food is good but yelling is uncalled for. Very disappointed.

I've heard it's sooo good from friends but unfortunately it's pretty limited for those with a gluten allergy. I was able to get something, but it was plain chicken, rice, veggies and a little bland. Definitely grateful they had something to accommodate though and my friend enjoyed her meal!

I've been here on a Monday for lunch, and it definitely wasn't crowded then!  The soup dumplings are pretty big and soupy, and the other food is satisfying.  Nothing spectacular though and a little bit greasy.  Since I'm currently living in a place devoid of decent Chinese food, it hits the spot for me.

I eat quite often at Joe's....But I agree with some of the reviews. Some or should I say most of the food here are really nothing to rave about...but it's really a matter of KNOWING what to order. I've learned the good and the not so good. So next time you go, definitely order the pork soup dumplings (can't say much about the crab one since i'm allergic) they are known for these so you really can't go wrong! it's great especially during cold weather. Also try the beef fried rice cakes, scallion pancakes & vegetable with bean curd

Restaurant is set up like a large dining hall. We ordered the pork soup dumplings and the boiled pork dumpling. The pork soup ones were pretty good, but lacking some flavor. The boiled pork ones were relatively average, but not bad. The waiting staff is very attentive and kind. Hot tea is complementary on the table and is delicious. The only downside to this restaurant is if you are a group of 4, you may be seated at a table for 6, which you will end up sharing with a random group of 2. The tables are circular as well so you'll most likely be sitting across from a random person.

Ive been here a number of times.  

The smell outside of this restaurant is a test of willpower to any brave patron.  Of course you probably rationalize "hey I'm being DARING and coming to Chinatown!  Gotta get used to a few putrid smells right?? Its authentic right??" 

Literally every time I've been here its the same awful smell out front.  Sometimes with a green watery sludge nearby.  

On to the actual restaurant.  Soup dumplings - they are really good.  They are fatty and sticky and soupy, and porky, and they are good.  

Ive had many dishes ranging from chicken, noodles, steak, pork.  I would say that overall the meat scares me a little bit here.  Its always extra soft...not undercooked, but somehow doesn't have the texture of meat as I would expect it.  This happens with the chicken the most.  Perhaps they texturize the meat first?  Perhaps its just a texture I don't really like. 

I dunno about saying this is the BEST Chinese food I've had.  Its A-OK.

The shao long baos (soupy buns) are the best here.  Be careful, soup inside buns is VERY HOT.  The other kitchen dishes are overly oily, I always feel heavy and gross after eating the noodles or other dishes. 

They pack you in like sardines and rush you out, kinda dingy too but must try the shao long baos with crab!

Totally not impressed by the soup dumplings. My expectation may have been too high from reading the reviews. I was expecting the same standard as ones I had in Taiwan. Unfortunately, it was not close. The skin was too thick. The fillings were just okay. The dumplings were a little too big to feel delicate.

The service was efficient but robotic.

When you go, order:
1. soup dumplings: the pork + seafood ones were better than just the pork ones
2. scallion pancakes: I grew up eating these things, and hands down, this place got great scallion pancakes

don't order:
1. jellyfish: bland bland bland.... again, my grandma always made this dish when I was a kid.. this place does not make their jellyfish well...
2. cold sesame noodle: nothing too special.. 

The thing I really didn't like was how I felt so stressed out the whole time I was eating there... rush rush rush..... I could not enjoy the delicious food even if I wanted to.

When Joe's Shanghai first opened, it was like the hottest restaurant in Chinatown.  Now that the word has spread, I feel like the quality has declined slightly.  The dumplings are okay.  I prefer the crab to the pork, and you should make sure you order the soup dumplings right when you sit down since it takes 20 min to cook.  

After waiting forever, you are ushered into the craziness.  It's super crowded inside and the waitstaff totally rush you to eat faster and finish so they can give you the bill and seat the next waiting party.  Service can feel rude at times.  Terrible for large groups.  I stopped eating here since it's become a major tourist attraction.

Jon- Our dumpling pilgrimage continues. My buddy Jaideep says this is the place. It was pretty good- but I think I'm more of a fan of Shanghai Cafe. The dumplings were aiiite. Big, filled with juice, and tasty, but I think they don't cut it the way Shanghai Cafe knocks them out of the park. And you only get 8 :(  All the places in LA give you 10!

We also ordered the green scallion pancakes, beef noodle soup, and hot and sour soup. I've been downing hot and sour since I was a kid. It was just a little hot, just a little sour. Didn't want to make the bold move. And where was the fungus?! Green scallion pancakes were too thick, too crispy. Doesn't match up to my grandma's. Beef noodle soup was just barely okay- some thin slices of tough beef, a few sparse greens, bland broth, and doughy noodles. Not bad. 

We didn't mind sharing tables, and the service is really attentive. I think it's funny how they ask you right away if you want dumplings. The waiter asked us first in Mandarin, then Cantonese, and then English in one breath! I chuckled. 

I'll come back here, but it ain't the best on the block. . .

Jenny-
This place is definitely overhyped, and after seeing all the attention from the press, I was disappointed.  The dumpling skins were thin, but every dumpling burst when barely even touched, and some of the juice was lost.  The hot and sour soup was blah.  It had shrimp and little pieces of pig blood in it, which I found interesting.  Not to toot my own horn, but my hot and sour soup is waaaaay better.  

Honestly, when I walked into the restaurant and saw that Asians were in the minority of the clientele, there was a high chance that the food was going to be disappointing.  The service was excellent, but I came here for good food, not good service.  Plus, the waiter kept trying to take away my food when I was still working on it. 

Jon-

I cannot vouch for Jenny's hot and sour soup. She has never made it for me :( And she always thinks a place is not authentic if there aren't a bunch of FOBs patronizing it.

Naaaaa
I don't recommend here, I know more good place.
Go to Shanghai 21 at China town.

You'll want to look elsewhere. Food below par. Pork dumplings smelled and tasted like canned dog food. Actually that does a disservice to dog food. Don't bother asking about minor changes or substitutions. Customer service seems to be a foreign concept. Cash only joint. 15% gratuity automatically added to bill and it shows in the crappy service and attitudes.

We came by on a Wednesday evening and ordered takeout.  We ordered crab and pork dumplings and double cooked pork.  The food was good however the service is not so much.  The girl placing the grubhub orders on a table will elbow you snd push you out of the way, personally not how I would treat customers, it's a cash only place, wait they take grub hub orders how can you be cash only then  but they say they are. If you ask for extra sauce packets or hot sauce packets you start getting dirty looks.

I was deceived by Yelp's rating of this place. Yelp stars should be given based on a combination of things -- taste, service, decor, etc. 

First, it felt weird that the waiters were giving non-Asian customers the special treatment -- shaking their hands, saying Happy Lunar New Year, etc. -- while my Asian party was given a less friendly attitude. For God sakes, we're Asian; at least wish us Happy New Year too! I know that non-Asian customers are the bulk of your business (80% of the customers in the restaurant were non-Asian), but show your own people some love too!

Second, the dam waiter's thumb was swimming in the vinegar sauce for the soup dumpling when he brought it to out table. GROSS!

Third, two dishes that should have been served at the same time were served separately. We decided to cancel the order, but was given an attitude.  

Fourth, the bathroom was filthy, which made me think back to the waiter's thumb swimming in my vinegar sauce.

Would recommend people not to go here; there are other soup dumpling restaurants that are just as good.

LOVE the dumplings, both pork and crab are very food. 

other than dumplings, everything else is extremely greasy, i meant EXTREMELY. thats a huge no no for me. I would def come here for the dumplings and probably JUST the dumplings
I hate when I am hyped up about a restaurant and go to find out the food is blan and just sucks

The XLB is very good. plumpy, juicy, as good as the ones in Shanghai.
Serice is rude, room is crowd, which is actually ok for me. Nevertheless, EVERYTHING ELSE is pretty bad, not authentic Shanghaiese cuisine at all.

Recommendation: XLB (steamed dumplings) ONLY,  they are GOOD!Ordering anything else and you will regret.

SO maybe I am not the best person in the world to rate this, given that I am not the biggest fan of Chinese food, but I am not sure what all the hype is about. 

I will start with the positives -- the Kung Pao Chicken and soup dumplings are delicious. The soup dumplings are filled with broth and pork, and have the perfect consistency, which explains why Joe's is known for this dish.  I also enjoyed the crunchy shrimp in meat sauce - which is a bit of a tangy, spicy dish FYI.

Ok now for the negatives: As for the rest of the food, though, I was pretty underwhelmed. We ordered the crispy beef, flat noodles and general tso's chicken as well as one additional dish, and none were really incredible. It also didn't help that the food rating outside was a "B".  Also, the service was terrible. There is a long line to get in and the servers stand next to your table, grilling you until you leave. They don't bring you any water and when you ask for it seem annoyed and they tend to ignore you every time they walk past. Overall, it was a pretty "mehh" experience and I don't think I will be going back.

This was not the same Joe's Shanghai experience I had when I went there ten years ago. The dumplings aren't as fresh, the meat inside is typical take out mystery meat, and the broth inside is now greasy where it was once fresh and brothy. I was very disappointed. I was ready for a one of a kind experience and got something more along the lines of    a better than average Chinese take out experience

The food is everything cracked up to be but for Yelp's sakes, please accept credit card for the convenience of your guests. Who cares, just charge a surtax for credit card use. This will really help out business and foreign travelers.

I'm a Din Tai Fung fan myself but I can appreciate Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings. Worth a visit and it is fun looking for it.

Like everyone says, you can't beat the soup dumplings. Had both kinds (pork and crab-pork), and they were delicious. Should have stopped there. Also ordered the Crispy Pepper Skin Duckling (influenced by a 20-year-old daily news review in the window), which was not that great. dry, flavorless. win some, lose some!

I don't know what the hype for this place is. Honestly, it's just alright in my book.  The xiao long baos weren't even memorable for me, and didn't leave me craving for more.  I think Shanghai cafe is a lot better than this place.  Of the dishes I've ordered here, none of them left me wanting more.  

I got the scallion pancakes, and they were alright. The soup dumplings (xiao long bao) were just ok....maybe it's the skin.  It was thick compared to other places I've had them.  meh...I don't even feel like describing anything else...it was just ok.
Ok food. Not very authentic. Xiao Long bao was good but definitely not the best. Yes you should try it. Is it going to WOW you? Probably not.

first impression of this place:  the place is packed with non-asian people.  this must be a "westerner trap".  no person that really eats chinese food would appreciate this place.

yes, meh, i've experienced better.  try ANY place that serves shanghai food in California and you will find better xiao long bao, or "soup dumplings" as those new to chinese/taiwanese food will call them.  the meat was NOT juciy, the skin was much thicker than i would like, and the wait is ridiculous.  as for other food: i've had better stuff at panda express. 

save your money and visit din tai fung.

If you're asian and have tried actual authentic Chinese food, this place is not worth it. Leave now. Notice how there's no asians here, it's all tourists. The wait is short, but that's because they sit multiple groups at one table. It was the most awkward dinner I've ever had 

The food at most is just average.The infamous soup dumplings were mediocre. The outside skin is pretty thin which is a plus but the fillings were rough and I couldn't even taste any crab in it. The rest of the food is average, however I saw the roasted duck and it looked pretty good to me. Maybe try that? I"d recommend just walking over to Little Italy and eating there.

I guess sometimes Yelp ratings can be deceiving, as I had high expectations coming to Joe's Shanghai, and left slightly disappointed. Located off of main roads in Chinatown, it's a small hole in the wall kinda place, surrounded by an abundance of other Asian restaurants. As with most Chinese restaurants across the USA and Canada, you're not really going for the best decor or ambiance, cause you're definitely not going to find it haha.

We ordered a few things to share, including the steamed pork dumplings and the Xi Long Bao (steamed soup dumplings). The steamed pork dumplings, despite being $10, really mimicked the ones you could get in a bulk bag at the grocery store. Served with vinegar, it didn't taste bad, but it definitely wasn't super fresh nor mindblowing. I will admit, the soup dumplings were far better and definitely the redeeming factor. They were massive in size and were piping hot and fresh. 

I wouldn't say this restaurant is a huge standout among all the Asian restaurants in NYC, but if you find yourself in the area, the steamed soup dumplings were really tasty and good value!

What am I missing???
Not a fan. I didn't come into this expecting 5 star service, didn't come into it expecting 5 star cleanliness, but was expecting delicious xiao long baos from the rave recommendations from friends. Alas, I should've known, looking at the walls lined with celebrity pictures... 

The XLBs were really big, difficult to eat in one bite. However, the real catch was, the skin/dough wrap was really inconsistent and roughly textured. We tried both the pork and the crab filling. The crab filling was really clumpy. 

We also ordered chicken Shanghai rice cakes and a plate of bok choy. The rice cakes were also really inconsistent in texture: chewy and soft. (Not sure if this is just Shanghai-nese style? Nevertheless, it was very inconsistent) The bok choy was fine.

Surprisingly, we didn't have to wait. I feel as though if we did need to wait, I would've disliked it even more... Not worth it! Lastly, I felt extremely unclean eating here. Was not a pleasant experience.

Very underwhelming. We ordered the shrimp spring roll, pork meat soup dumplings, prawns in chili sauce, and the Shanghai saut√©ed flat noodles. For a singular spring roll that cost $5, it wasn't anything special. The pork meat soup dumplings were okay; the dough was very chewy. The saut√©ed flat noodles were also alright, it had more vegetables than noodles. But the spicy prawns in chili sauce were the best out of everything. This place wouldn't be my first choice to recommend in NYC for soup dumplings, but it was worth a try.

Not a fan and don't understand the hype. We waited forever to get incredibly greasy flavorless Chinese food and share a table with incredibly annoying tourists. Why?! The soup dumplings all had pork so I couldn't try them, but my friends were not particularly impressed, including my friends from China who are obsessed with soup dumplings.

We lined up for over 40 minutes to be served. We ordered soup dumplings, baby shrimp, beef and vegetable. It is fair to say only the taste of soup dumplings and vegetable could be accepted from a Chinese point of view.

Poor service. I did think it was interesting that we were sat at a table with others unannounced- the place was packed. The dumplings were disappointing, but not bad. The jelly fish appetizer was good, but plain. The broccoli and mushroom vegetable appetizer was good.

Soup dumplings is what they are known for and I can say it's yummy. It has become a tourist spot due to many celebs going there. Long wait line and have to sit with random strangers at tables. Service wants you to eat fast and gtfo to service other people. Decor is non existent and cash only. 2/5 for me just because good food is still existent is this bustling place.

The thing about this place is that they are always rushing you out the door. The minute your food drops they haunt your table in hopes that your almost done. They basically start clearing the minute the dish looks half empty. The dumplings are fantastic however. They really do a great job with those pork dumplings and I love them... BUT everything else is mediocre. I guess I would say get the scallion pancakes and the red bean dessert...but nothing is comparable to those dumplings. The service really sucks. I mean, they're quick and your order comes out right away...but you don't feel welcomed to stay and enjoy your meal. It feels like your in a fast food service environment so just be aware.

So, after viewing on yelp how highly recommended this dim sum restaurant was, we made it priority to go while visiting NYC.. I was expecting all the dim sum appetizer dishes to be great; but they were really nothing special.. Their dumplings were definitely delicious as well as their scallion pancakes.

I was so excited to try this place as it is supposed to be known for the XLBs. But, sadly this place is all hype. We got the dumplings (xiao long bao), crispy beef, and soup (can't remember what kind). The crispy beef was ok. It wasn't as crispy as I thought it would be. The soup was not memorable. Their famous XLB was bleh. The weird chunky soup inside had a strange taste to it. The consistency reminded me of a watered down chunky gravy. I prefer the clear soup inside the XLB from Mama Lu or Din Tai Fung. 

The place is tiny. They divide tables up so you are sitting in a round average sized Chinese restaurant table cramped with 2 different parties.

This place is crazy, in good and bad ways. 

First, the good:
-soup dumplings are pretty good. Would I wait 30+ mins for it again? Probably not. Do I think other Shanghainese restaurants have just as good soup dumplings? For sure. 
-prices are decent for NYC. Average per person comes to $27 a person, after drinks and food. 
-service is fast. We got our order taken and out in 15-30 mins. 

The bad:
