-every other dish besides the Chinese food is VERY VERY bland. Fast food Chinese food is much tastier than what we got. We had the spicy roast duck and the fried pork....it was both BELOW AVERAGE. The duck was over cooked and the fried pork was chewy in the inside and the outside was hard. We were really disappointed.  
-the waiter was really rude and abrasive. He has a major attitude with our family and we excused him because they were busy but if it was a tip based restaurant, we wouldn't have left any. 
-Oh yeah, a mandatory 15% tip is added on to each bill. 
-the lines to get in average 30+ mins.
-small tables - can only fit so much and barley have space to eat. My hands kept touching my neighbors. 

Overall, pretty poor service and food. Yes the dumplings are good but I wouldn't go here again.

2.5 - even 3 stars. (Rounded down for uncleanliness and notably bad service.)

Alright, so I ended up coming here for at least an unexpected third time after my last review. For some reason, everyone in NYC just seems to want to visit this place?? A friend and I were around the area (in SoHo/Nolita), and we were deciding between Lombardi's Pizza or Joe's Shanghai (we had been to both already). She seemed to prefer Joe's Shanghai for the price...so I went along with it with little fuss...although as my previous review suggests, I'm not the biggest fan of the place. Haha. 

I don't remember there being much of a wait for the two of us. But this was the first time I had to share a large table with two (actually, I think three) other parties. Another time I was with one friend, and I guess we were lucky to get a table for two. Anyway, this time around, friend and I were the only two Asians on a large, circular table with a couple of white European tourists, and out of towners. There was one particularly obnoxious man who throughout the meal insisted that he knew all the best things to order on the menu, as if everyone around him wanted his "expertise." This guy went on forever...literally throughout the meal...which made my dumplings even harder to digest...friend and I just could not get over how ridiculous this guy was. And he recommended random fish dishes instead of the dumplings... 

Anyway, seating like that is just another reason to avoid this place. It is also so dirty and grimy (even for Asian restaurant standards) that I would not bring my Chinese family here... And especially considering all the other options around, there is little reason (other than the very inexpensive price) to come here.

Not to mention, the oily, grimy-textured dumplings didn't sit too well this time around with my friend's stomach...

Known for their soup dumplings which are indeed excellent; but just two varieties- pork & crab and pork. Little else that would be considered dim sum (no other dumplings, shrimp or otherwise; no roast meats, turnip cakes have pork in them, etc) so I have no idea why it gets listed under top dim sum places. The other dishes I saw around looked heavily greasy and uninteresting.

The food here is a good but not anything extra-ordinary. It's not something I would wait a long time for. We waited about 20 minutes. Service was quick and easy. Soup dumplings are big and tasty, but again, not something I would go out of my way for.
The cold sesame noodles are delicious! But the "C" on the storefront leaves me thinking...I hope it was cold sesame noodles I ate...

I know, everyone loves this place. Not me. I have been there twice...both times take-out. First time the young woman who took my order was very nice and friendly. She made suggestions and was quite helpful.  However, the food was all very underwhelming. Fast-forward a year and another disappointing experience today. On way home from work I passed it and thought I would give it another try...as it was kinda empty. This time the two women at the counter who took my order were not friendly or helpful. I understand the language barrier, but if I have a question and they can't understand me or answer it, would it not be the end of the world to have one of their co-workers who does speak English help out?  But they were not very interested in helping me. When I asked the host for a menu he did not even want to be bothered to move aside so I could grab one. Overall even putting the language barrier aside, the contact I had with the staff today was cold.

The soup dumplings were good...but not amazing. The scallion pancakes were great, but they are good at a lot of places. Although the place was kinda empty, the people who were there were mostly tourists.  Maybe I have not ordered right the times I have been there, but in my opinion this place is not so much a hidden gem, more like a over-hyped tourist trap.

Okay shanghai dumplings. This place has great reviews and was referred by a friend while I'm visiting NYC. I don't know if I would get in line for this place. (We didn't have much of a wait during lunchtime on a weekend.) I had much better dumplings in ding tai fung and other shanghai places.

Meh. 

You ask, "HYPE or the REAL DEAL?" Unfortunately, HYPE.

I only came here for the Xiao Long Bao.

So.... my bar might have been set a little too high.

In retrospect, my problem was that I had been missing and craving Din Tai Fung so much since my last trip to Indonesia in November 2011. Especially so since my OB/GYN asked me to cancel my trip back home when we discovered I was pregnant with my first. 

In my mind, the PERFECT Xiao Long Bao must meet the following requirements:
1.) Thin, slightly translucent wrappers that don't tear when you lift them onto your spoon. (Joe's wrappers were too thick, kind of gummy, and yet tear surprisingly easily, relatively.)
2.) Well-flavored soup. (Joe's soup was just decently flavored.)
3.) Bite-sized portions. A larger quantity of regular-sized XLB would be better than fewer giant-sized XLB. (Joe's dumplings were way too big.)

I'm going to need to give Yank Sing's XLB another try when I get back to the Bay Area. I could be wrong, but I feel like even Yank Sing has Joe's Shanghai beat.

If that doesn't satisfy my craving, I'll have to take yet another secret trip (doubt Dr. Green will ever read this review) down to SoCal to visit the Din Tai Fung in Arcadia. Sure, the crab XLB (too fishy) & "Shrimp & Pork Wonton w/ Spicy Sauce" (not as sour nor at all spicy in the US) are still not as delicious as the one in Jakarta or Beijing, but at least they have great pork XLB.

______________________________

TIME/DATE: February 27, 2013 @ 6pm / crowded but no wait.

AMBIANCE: Crowded, typical Chinese "hole in the wall" restaurant with round tables for family-style dining. The three of us were seated at a table with 2 other couples.
SERVICE: Quick, no nonsense, no chatter.
VALUE: Decent prices, relatively large XLB.
CHANCE OF RETURNING: 15%

:::: FOOD ::::

* CRAB & PORK XIAO LONG BAO - [3/5] 
* PORK XIAO LONG BAO - [3/5]

For a tourist trap place, Joe's Shanghai is not terrible. That being said, I only got the soup dumplings - one pork and one crab - so I cannot attest to the other food. Honestly, the soup dumplings were pretty good and had lots of meat and soup inside, which is pretty surprising (most places skimp on the meat). The crab had an interesting flavor, and it's not bad, but I think the pork is definitely better. The pork soup was really good, even though I burnt my tongue on the first sip. The only complaint I have is that the skin of the soup dumplings were sticking to my lips every time I took a bite. 

The other food looked kind of mid and was pretty expensive, but I don't know if you should expect authenticity if none of the other diners are Chinese. Also, this place is cash only and adds an automatic 18% gratuity, which is a little weird for bare minimum service. This restaurant is definitely geared towards tourists, but the interior is clean and the soup dumplings are pretty good.

After hearing such great things about soup dumplings I had to try them.  This place was supposed to be the best but I left disappointed.  I didn't think they tasted that great.  The price was fair, around $5 for eight dumplings.

Why on earth does this place get so much hype?  Is it just merely because there's no good Chinese food in NYC?  
I'm from California and I'm going to admit - I am a big fan of Ding Tai Fung.  I've heard mixed reviews from my friends as to which joint is better but I would have to say Ding Tai Fung for sure!  

Here's what we ordered:
Xiao long bao
Szechuan Beef Tendon Noodle Soup
Vegetables

Xiao long bao isn't that great as the skin is super thick.  
Szechuan Beef Tendon Noodle Soup was a disappointment as it was quite bland for a spicy dish.  I had to dunk hot sauce in the soup for flavor. 
I guess you can't really go wrong with vegetables but it was $9.95 vs. the xiao long bao and noodle soup that were $4.95.  

The only plus side is that this place is pretty cheap.  I mean 8 xiao long bao for $4.95 is a great deal but why torture yourself to cheap bad food?  

Two thumbs down!  I'm never coming back!

I was told that there was going to be a long wait for it, but there wasn't. We were seated pretty quickly. I was told that the dumplings were really good, and they were yummy. We ate the pork soup dumplings, and it's only the second time I've eaten soup dumplings, so not much to compare it to. The soup was good, but I had more noodles than broth. The beef rice cakes were yummy, we took them home with us. Wish it was a little cleaner, and less crowded for seating.

This i what I don't understand.   The front of the store is narrow. the  Smell from last night garbage still there  / One morning I found a dead rat right outside the sideway in front of the resturant .  
 
and these tourist still stand in front this smell.  - what class.


The owners attempted to repair the street of the pot hole but the pot holes are still showing up or coming back.

Dirty and Touristy 
Have to Share a Table with strangers
The back of the restaurant was kinda messy
Very tight seating
They rush you out when you are done.
Good food tho.

there should be 32" between seating by Fire Department - Health Hazard if there was a fire and you had run of there.


Comments i have seen:

"Not very big on the communal dining aspect though."

"The place is really busy on Friday and Saturday evenings, so the wait for a table will be a long time."

"got seated right away at this big table with some other strangers "

"This is no high class dining establishment... here you sit, you eat, you pay, and you leave (given a check before YOU ask for it)"

"The food is a bit greasy,"


Totally  Not a place where the Locals would be hanging at   but a  bridge and tunnel joint .

Nothing more dumber than a tourist going there than , standing out in the cold/heat (and the smell)  for over hour just to go in and eat and be rush out of there.   That is not the kind of new york experience I would want 

Still 2 stars.

Go to Nam Wah on Doyer, at least their sideway don't smell like last night trash

We've  lived in the east coast for 25 yrs and moved to texas 6 months ago. And at those  time we ate here almost once a wk. were back for vacation and went to joe's shanghai for their specialty soup dumpling. They served us 5 pcs mini dumplings , warm not hot . Since we have not been here long time we thought that they made it smaller. We didn't complain. We ordered  take out 2 orders of dumplings. We reached home and my daughter opened the package to find  out that theyre bigger and same size as before. Apparently they served us a substandard food. Its a  shame . When i checked the pictures i've taken i found out that they served us collapsed dumplings the reason why it was small and dry.

The Good:

Obviously the soup dumplings are amazing, pork over crab. 

The beef with scallions was fantastic, very good quality scallions and the beef was cooked just right, slightly crispy and full of flavor. 

The Bad:

The pork lo-mein and it was probably the worst I've ever had. The amount of grease was hard to believe, and even with all that grease, it lacked any flavor whatsoever. The pork didn't even look like pork, we thought they messed up the order. It looked like chicken, but it was dark and full of fat. Inedible. 

The chicken fried rice was not much better, I wouldn't order either of these dishes again.

I went there with my friends to eat late lunch :) we didn't have to wait and could get in soon! That was the nicest point because usually we have wait !! There are two Â∞èÁ±†ÂåÖ but I recommend you to choose meat with crub ! That one is better! Make sure when you eat, use spoon ! Because there are a lot of soup in Â∞èÁ±†ÂåÖÔºÅand it's the most delicious part !!

I had high hopes for this place since it's so popular but I was slightly disappointed.

Went in just to order a simple pork soup dumpling to go. Waited a couple mins and two other people came in to order take out as well. As the first bag of take out comes out I expected it to be mine because I was the only one who ordered one item. But no the lady at the counter claims it's the other ladies first when I was standing right there as I heard her order and pay for the same item I did ONE PORK SOUP DUMPLING. It was not worth an argument but it's not hard to remember who came first when all you do is stand at the counter and place take out orders and collect money. Anyways my "order" came out a minute after and I just grabbed it and left because I know the first one should've been mine and the one I took was supposed to be the other lady's. 

Although disappointed from the poor service I still had high hopes for the soup dumplings I was about to devour. Open the container and all I see are sloppy flat looking dumplings with all the soup surrounding it NOT IN THE DUMPLING. (Maybe this wouldn't have bothered me as much if I actually got my order instead of the one that came out after). As I pick up the dumpling with my chopstick the top just splits open inviting more soup to spill out over the tiny spoon. The only reason I'm giving this place 3 stars is because the soup that I drank from the container, not the dumpling, was very flavorful. But the soup also left my lips really sticky which was very annoying. I didn't even finish all 8 dumplings because I just got annoyed with eating them. 

Maybe it would've been better to dine in but with those lines I would rather eat at other Shanghai places in Chinatown. But who knows maybe I'll be back to try some other dishes everyone raves about.

This place is a favorite, but lately the juice buns have been a little overcooked and burst before I get them. The ambience is cheap and cheerful, and you often get seated with other people, but it's part of the fun. I wish they would go back to making the juice buns better. Their handmade sauteed noodles are delicious. Staff is OK, not superfriendly, but they get the job done.
It's the crab meat that makes these soup dumplings good especially since the classic place to go in Shanghai also does the same.

Overrated, oily food, annoying strangers sit at the table with you. (But you might like that? :) 
Not a place to take a date. Been here 7 times at other people's request and can't really get into it.
Food was not bad but not good at all.  The service is terrible.  The servers are rude and rough.  I felt very offended and won't go back in my life.

i've been here a handful of times over the years, but this last trip was surprisingly disappointing. 

obviously, the thing to order here are the juicy soup dumplings. we've ordered a bunch of other things like noodle soups and apps, but they're not memorable.

and if you're doing the dumplings, you should do the pork dumplings. that's the OG. the crab dumplings are just too rich. and this, coming from a huge lover of crabs, is saying something. 

it's cash only and they add in the service fee already, so remember that when you're automatically adding in the tip.

Went with my friends. We ordered some soup dumplings, drunken chicken, rice cake with shrimps, and string beans.  Nothing was tasty!  The service was bad.  Waiters paid no attention to our table.  But put 18% tips on after tax.  That was so illegal!  It was the worst experience!  Over rated, over priced!  Don't even deserve one star.

Joe's Shanghai is a restaurant famed in New York for its xiao long bao. Having hearing excellent things about it, it had long been on my places to eat, and we finally made our way here on the same day as the Chinese New Year parade. When we got here, it was 11:30am on a Sunday, and there was a large crowd standing outside the restaurant already. Much of the crowd's attention was directed to an argument between a group of prospective diners, and the hostesses handling the line. 
The supposed disagreement was due to the party stating they had enough people for a reservation, and had confirmed this over the phone, but found that when they got to the restaurant, the staff said there were no reservations offered at all. At one point, one of the staff members was shouting at the potential customer, which really wasn't a good look for the restaurant. 
Anyway, we managed to put our name down, were told it would be about a 25 minute wait. The wait time ended up being exactly that, and when finally our number was called, we had another brief wait for a table, but this time, inside the bustling restaurant. 
The inside of Joe's Shanghai is one of the busiest New York restaurants I have ever seen. There is barely standing room, and you will inadvertently push, or be pushed, just being inside the restaurant and standing. After a couple of minutes standing, we were then seated at a large, round share table. We ordered the crab and pork xiao long bao, the pork xiao long bao, and the scallion pancake. 
The food was served quickly after ordering. The scallion pancake was equivalent to other restaurants I have had this at. It was fried without being excessively oily, and retained a crisp exterior. It was not terrible but not something I would rave about, nor order again if I came here. 
Both of the xiao long baos were quite good, though not the best I have had before. They were cooked well, with the right amount of broth in them, and had good flavor, though I had a strong preference for the crab xiao long baos, which I thought were more flavorsome. 
Service was satisfactory and friendly, despite the public disagreement we had witnessed prior. This is a place I am content to visit once, as I've tried Shanghainese food equivalent to this place in New York, and without the long wait.

Due to the high reviews i found on yelp, i decided to try this place in chinatown. Boy do i regret it! The wait was not bad for two but we were not informed we would end up sharing a large table with strangers. The first thing i noticed about this place was that 90% of the customers were well.. Not asian. Being asian myself, i have gone to hundreds of chinese restaurants. I found some of the items to be way overpriced. The 1/2 crispy duck was mostly small, boney, skin, fat and cost $18 dollars. Usually, this would cost much less in the surrounding restaurants or where im from. Although, my girlfriend did enjoy the crab and pork dumplings. i think it's truely overhyped and would never return. People should give surrounding restaurants a try as well. This restaurant is definitely capitalizing on it's yelp reviews and naive first time customers like me.

I am SO SAD (and angry). Joe's Shanghai is dead. I used to crave these specific soup dumplings on a regular basis, make it a point to take friends from out of town here, and even dine at their midtown location. My hubbie and I went tonight and ate what was hands down the worst Chinese food I've ever had in NYC. Actually scratch that - the takeout restaurant in my upstate NY hometown is better these days. The crab and soup dumplings were painfully bland and had shells in them (totally changed from the amazing savory pockets of tastiness they used to be); the noodles came out in a solid ball and the waiter tried to tease it out like a hair knot at our table looking ashamed of himself (the sauce too was again, flavorless); and the new place has lost all of its vibe and feels like a shabby healthcare clinic. I don't even care about the long lines, the shitty service, and the fact that they now charge tip (probably bc they know you wouldn't want to leave any) - it's the travesty of having no sense of pride and respect for what this place once was (which was even a bit overrated but at least tasted good), clearly not caring at all about the quality of the food, and taking advantage of poor tourists just to make a buck. People - please do yourself a favor and stay away.

Place is definitely over hyped.  Yes, they have extremely good soup dumplings, but let's also judge this place for other things.  The place is crowded and packed like a sardine can.  It's noisy.  The waiters rush the heck out of you.  Aren't you here paying for the whole experience?  So why is it I feel like the one that must bend over backwards to get some service?  Remember, you are the paying customer, not part of their, "they get rich, you get out asap," plan.  The decor started out nice, but is really in the need of a make over now.   As for the other food here, it's okay, nothing above the other area establishments.  The price is slightly higher than the area competition.
The soup dumplings are yummy. We had other dishes also it was alright. The fried shrimp with sweet and sour sauce wasn't good. Other than that it's alright. Not worth all the hype.
Just so so. Soup is too thickened with corn starch. The place is now a tourist spot, unlike it was 15 years ago. I am from Shanghai and was disappointed with the current quality.

Living in Los Angeles and San Francisco, I've eaten at a lot of chinese restaurants and have grown to appreciate the finest of chinese foods.  I was pretty excited hearing about Joes Shanghai Dumplings and all the rave .  However, when the food came out, I was bitterly disappointed.  The dumpling meat was overcooked, drenched and soggy from too much liquid.  But, I also ordered the meat noodles and that was decent.  

Price: good. fair price for chinese food
Presenation: its chinese food so whatever
taste: okay, but not the best
service: chinese waiters are notorious for continuous PMS attitudes

Overall, I've had better.

The steamed buns are the only thing worth here. Too bad. The service is horrible. Not only the waiters barely speak English,  they toss the plates at you. By the way, the gratuity is included in you check. Will never return to such a place. Do you want to enjoy Joe's Shanghai? Order steam buns to go. Everything else is overrated.

We got here around 3:30 and there was already a wait.  You get a number from the hostess and you wait until she calls your number.  We waited about 20 mins.  

Once seated you will be sitting at a table with other patrons. It's definitely a little awkward but after a while you don't even notice the people at the table because you're busy eating.

We ordered the pork dumplings and crab dumplings. Both were just ok.  The soup seeped out of the dumplings and the skin was a little thick on some.

We also ordered scallion pancakes which were very delish.

Tables are cramped in, service was absolutely disgraceful , signature dumplings were a 2/10 compared to Shanghai in melbourne. 

I recommend giving this place a miss

We came around 1pm on a Thursday for lunch. It was crowded and we had to get a ticket to get seated. We had 3 orders of soup dumplings which turned out to be too much for 3 averagely hungry women. The soup dumplings are larger than other dim sum restaurants and are very doughy. They taste like a hearty beef broth inside.

Pluses:
- Seems authentic
- Food is good

Minuses:
- Cash only, and they automatically tack on all the service fees
- Servers are kind of rude
- Very chaotic environment
- Little conversational privacy since you're seated with other random people

Not good. Came here because of all the good reviews but I don't see it. Really excited about the soup dumplings but was very disappointed. Chewy, over cooked, flavorless and greasy...The rest of the meal was mediocre at best...Oh, and let's not forget the rude service...also a great bonus...!
I'm sure there's a good soup dumpling somewhere in Chinatown, it's just not here...

I'd heard about this place from a few people and saw the reviews on Yelp. People seemed to like it and I'm not sure if that played a role into my experience here but I felt that it was really overrated. 

I love soup dumplings. They're so flavorful and delicious. And the ones at Joe's were incredibly delicious! but based on what we ordered, that was the only thing I can recommend here. We also ordered a whole fish and beef and broccoli. Neither were that great and the beef and broccoli was mostly broccoli. I'd say it was about 3/4 broccoli, not even kidding. So from that standpoint, it was a rip off. 

On top of that, we had an hour wait for just the two of us at 8:30pm. I know you have to expect to wait here, and I did know that was going to happen, but I was hoping the food would have at least been worth it. If I find myself back here in the future, I know to only get the soup dumplings and then leave. That's what the table next to us did and I think they already knew that everything else on the menu just wasn't worth it.

This place is overrated. However, I must confess that in addition to being a foodie, I've also spent a significant amount time in Asia. The xiao long bao are oversized and tasteless. The pork inside lacks the freshness and juiciness that a proper soup dumpling should possess.

We also ordered the string beans, Shanghai noodles and Yeung Chow fried rice. All were very greasy. The noodles were over cooked and the string beans hardly had any minced pork served with it.

First time I had their steamed buns was great, but after trying a few other places. Shanghai village on Elizabeth or Mott street is much better. Also joe shanghais food is over priced. More for tourists now rather good comfort food

First time visit. No waiting line cause today is raining. Quickly get seated, the staff forgot to give us water so we have to ask to remind them. Ordered their popular dishes. 

Spent over $100. 

XLB: it's not authentic XLB, the flavor is kinda off. I don't like it. 

Fried scallion pancake: I didn't finish the whole thing. Too greasy, and not crispy.

The dessert soup is way too sweet. 

I had a really high expectation before coming, and left with disappointment. Nothing special. Would not come back again.

NYCgo website raved about the soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai, so my friends and I decided to stop by while exploring Chinatown.  We went around 1:30pm.  The restaurant was still filled with customers, but we managed to get a table for 6 within 10 minutes.

We ordered the pork soup dumplings and the pork&crab dumplings.  Each order came with 8 dumplings.  The size of each dumpling was a little bit smaller than a golf ball.  The pieces that I ate were all filled with soup.  However, a couple of my friends said that their pieces were dry inside.

Overall, I thought the dumplings were average.  Not bad tasting, but I've had better.  Not tasty enough for my Asian taste buds.

Damn fellow Yelpers.. I'm quite shocked by all the great reviews for this place because I wasn't impressed by anything I had here. Also quick tip, cash only. 

For a table of 4 people on a Friday night, the wait was about an hour or so which isn't too bad. Prepare to sit with strangers at your table. We got 4 orders of soup dumplings, 2 crab meat and 2 pork, an order of fried rice, and a plate of vegetables. 

I have had my share of soup dumplings and was hoping these would be comparable to Shanghai Manor (right around the corner on Mott St.). However as soon as I went to pick one up, I knew it wasn't going to be any good. The skin was on the thicker side, yet each one broke at the bottom when we picked it up. There was no flavor to either of them, they could've both been pork for all I know. The vegetables... bland. Fried rice, bland. 

I really don't understand the hype of this place. If you really want good soup dumplings without all the tourists, do yourself a favor and go to Shanghai Manor. The prices there are better too.

This place always looks crowded. For me, it's overrated. I bought a seaweed fish. They gave me a tray of fish with a carton of white rice. No sauce. $20 something. The fish was so oily i couldnt finish it. I was tender. I really wanted to enjoy it esp bc of the reviews but I wont be going back.

3 months after my visit I'm finally writing this review.

So I visited Joe's Shanghai on my 2nd trip to NY (Feb). Came here Sunday for lunch and the wait was about 30 mins. I guess it's not bad compared to how many people was there. 

Xiao Long Bao (crab meat) - skin is too thick but the fillings were good and juicy.
Xiao Long Bao (regular) - skin is thick too and the fillings were not as good as compared to the crab meat ones and it was also juicy.
Shanghai Fried Rice Cake - It was good but I've had better.
Shanghai Fried Noodle - also pretty good

I would come back here again for their Xiao Long Bao but just wished their skin could be as thin as Din Tai Fung's. Price here is a lot cheaper than Din Tai Fung's tho.

We went there on a Monday night around 8:30pm.. was able to get a table super fast (yay), but we had to share the table with 4 other strangers :(.
I watching them fork n knife the soup dumplings away.. ( such a waste of soup )  :-o
Good thing the food came out really fast, hot and fresh. But  I was very disappointed after tasting it. Blah... greasy, and  flavorless.

on top of that, they did not use the right type of vinegar for the soup dumplings. There were barely gingers in the vinegar sauce... enough said.

When the bill came, I noticed they had already added 15% service charge. Is that standard in New York?? 

Overal, it could had been a 2 1/2 star, but do i even want to come back here again?? NO!!!

We had a hard time finding this place, which was recommended by friends of ours. People come here for the food and the famous dumplings. Otherwise, there's not much to appreciate. Service can be sporadic, prices are Disneyland-like, and seating is uncomfortable. If you're not in a large group, you will most likely be seated with other parties around a large circular table. It's not all that weird because many Chinese restaurants do this, but I don't like hearing other peoples' conversations.

The place told us it was a 25 min wait and we waited an hour. Tables are shared and the food was not all that for the wait and line outside. The dumplings were not even that good. We orders beef that was shavings and was not good at all. Don't believe the hype.

After a typical New York City weekend of shopping around SoHo, drinking PBRs until 4am, and eating frozen yogurt, all I wanted was Chinese delivery on my Sunday night.  My legs were tired from walking to the NBA store earlier in the afternoon, but I decided to make the 15 minute walk for the tasty food that I had heard about at this restaurant.  I was disappointed.  The food was one word: bad.  The dumplings were the only saving grace and that's honestly not saying much.  The noodle dish was bland at best.  The noodles were over salted and not cooked al dente.  I had to immediately throw the noodle dish away and take out the trash because it smelled up my house. The kung pao chicken made me want to punch someone.  I had two bites which is one more bite than I could handle of the noodle dish.  I would not suggest this restaurant...ever.  Walking through the extremely smelly and crowded streets of Chinatown to pick up this below par food ruined my Sunday night.

Pretty average dumplings. You'll find may places nearby are better. However they are the rudest of the lot. I swear the 3 waiters helping us were hovering so closely I could feel the heat off there junk!!! Pass.

No dim sum here!

Was in Manhattan the other day with a hankering for Dim Sum . Used yelp to find a dim sum place and was directed to Joe's.

Got there around 12:30, was seated immediately.  But I didn't see any carts.  I asked the server about dim sum, and she said no carts, dim sum through the menu.  Looked through the menu.  The options were either hidden, or on another menu.  I got up and left.

Giving the place 3 stars out of courtesy.
The dumplings were amazing! I got the Lo mein and it was okay, very large portion, probably wouldn't order it again. Lots of people waiting but moved quick!

:-0

Yikes.

I haven't been to the Chinatown location in a year, but I just went to the Flushing location, which my friends heard was better all around. More authentic, etc.

Hence, here are my 2 recommendation for your meal @ Joe's, if you are seeking authentic Chinese food.

     1) Get the Steamed Dumplings.
     2) Get nothing else.

That will save you more than half your bill, with which you can enjoy elsewhere.. -- Wu Chang Pork Chop house? Yea, that's what I'm talking about.. :)

Love me some xiaolongbao. Especially on a chilly fall night. A party of 3 of us went for dinner on a Saturday evening so we already knew that we should be expecting a wait to be seated. We saw the massive crowd of people outside the shop on the otherwise empty-looking street and knew we had reached our destination. We got a number and were told the wait would be 30 minutes. I'm really not sure what the system is for seating here, a lot of people waiting seemed confused. A few times the girl would come outside and basically roll call everyone's numbers to see who was still waiting. For this reason, it's probably not a good idea to take a walk around the block while waiting for your number- they are not called in order or anything close to that. After about an hour and a half we finally got seated at a round table with 2 other parties. We ordered the crab and pork soup dumplings with some beers right off the bat. Beers weren't super cheap, but dumpling price was on point. As others have noted, tip is included in your bill. Decided we would try another dish while we were there, so we also got the mapo tofu. The guy asked us if we also wanted to order rice with our mapo tofu, which was confusing since mapo tofu always comes with rice. It's not a dish you just eat straight by itself. OK, so we order some individual bowls of rice so we can eat the mapo tofu. Dumplings came first. They were very tasty and hit the spot. Slurp your heart out. No complaints with the side vinegar and ginger dipping sauce either. We finished these pretty quickly and then our mapo tofu and rice came out. The dish looked okay, but seriously lacked in any flavor (big flavor bang and numbing Szechuan peppercorn feeling is what defines mapo tofu). So this was a fail. We had to ask for the hot chili sauce and vinegar dipping sauce to mix with the tofu to even make it palatable enough to eat. We probably should have just stuck with what this restaurant specialized in- soup dumplings. We weren't a big fan of the host/waiter that kept hawking around the table, trying to pull dishes out from under you before you were even finished. It felt very uncomfortable, like he was just waiting to shove you out even though you were ordering multiple rounds of drinks and dishes and hadn't even been sitting down for a half hour yet. I understand there's a line outside, but come on, I just came from that line....after waiting for an hour and a half. Let me at least enjoy my meal in peace. Front of house staff was very friendly as we were leaving though.

The Skinny: Joe's Shanghai is the ninth circle of Chinese food hell; (1)service: barely existent, the worst ambience, definitely not kid friendly(1); value: do not come here...you have been warned.(1)

My husband has a xiao long bao obsession. Normally I have no problem with this except for today when he chose to bring me, my parents and our 7 month old here. If thoughts were daggers, my hubby would be deader than Jon Snow with no hope of resurrection because I'd kill the Red Woman too. (I do not leave things to chance -I'd even birth an assassin shadow baby too).

First of all, the ambience is terrible even by Chinese restaurant standards. By terrible I mean the hub's cheap vinyl chair had a massive rip in it with foam bits sticking out. Not to mention the fact you get seated at filthy crowded communal tables. I didn't go to the restroom but the hub's did and can verify how disgusting it is. 

This place is definitely not baby friendly by any means. The hostess made us store our stroller in the front so my baby was on my lap. This meant I couldn't sit comfortably the whole time. And I want to be frank... My child is breastfed. I am not ashamed of breastfeeding my baby in public but I do not want to be in people's face about it especially while they are eating. The communal table meant that the four young people sitting across from us had to watch me breastfeed and change my kid (which is out of necessity and because we had no stroller to do so). Totally awkward. This joint made me feel like an animal wanting to chew off its leg to escape.

We ordered some pan-fried noodles, some soup, soup dumplings (regular and crab filled - 3 orders), green onion pancake and a dish of duck and vegetarian goose.

The dumplings were mediocre. Too large, too thick skin and half of them burst when handled. The pork flavor was minimal and tasted a lot like filler. The crab dumplings didn't taste like crab. It was oddly stringy...kind of tasted like crab from a tin.

The duck tasted old like some bad leftover duck. The vegetarian goose was horrible too. The green onion pancake was greasy and too thick.  The soup was a terrible mess of thickened salt water with peas and carrots floating around.

The pan-fried noodles with seafood were stir-fried with a bunch of broccoli, snow peas and carrots (completely saturated with a goopy sauce). This is pretty much a sign that this place is not legit and caters to a largely Caucasian crowd.

All of this terrible MSG ladened food set us back $75 before tip.

Avoid this place. There has got to be better Chinese food in NYC than this.

waiter: "WHAT DUMPLINGS DO YOU WANT?".... wait what? i literally just sat down, i haven't even opened the menu yet!!! but people come here mainly for the soup dumplings & the abrupt waiters already know it (i guess it gets people in & out faster)

we ordered the 2 most yelp-recommended dishes:
-----the pork soup dumplings (xiao long bao): i've had better.. the soup inside was a bit game-y & SOUR.... BUT i liked the thin skin
-----scallion pancake: nice unique charred flavor!

FOODS CHEAP, but there are better xiao long baos & scallion pancakes elsewhere

NOTE: if you're a small party, you may be seated at a large table w/ strangers so that they can accommodate the large number of customers!
Waaaaay overrated.   Poor service, greasy food, and always a crowd of people.  One of the dishes we ordered looked like it was reheated in the microwave.  I prefer Asia Manor on Mott Street.

Not really worth the hype or the long wait in line. The only thing decent is the soup dumplings. Nothing really too special about these dumplings except for the size. Also, don't bother ordering anything else. Things I usually get at almost every Chinese restaurant does not look the same here and tastes pretty bad. If you want some soup dumplings, just go to any Chinese restaurant in Chinatown that offers dim sum and they should have it.
On the night of December 2nd, Joe's Shanghai got 105 violation points from the health department... and I got food poisoning. It's too bad because the food tasted great.

I love soup dumplings and joes got some decent dumplings. But to wait for a table and to deal with the staffs that thinks their better than their job, I'll pass. So many places in Chinatown to get decent dumplings, I'll have to pass.

Crowded with law fans and tourists. I think they soup dumplings got bigger and less tasty but still one of the best places for shanghainese food. Last time i was there we ordered crab soup dumplings, pretty good and crispy duck, it will not disappoint. The jelly fish was very bad. Tasteless, flawerless, waterly, not fresh. I don't think i had jelly fish so bad. I don't understand how they managed to get this one wrong.

Came in for xiaolongbao because the place is famous.  People are right : tourist trap!!  The service is poor.  My friend and I were seated at a large table with strangers.  We were not given the option to wait for a private table.  Before we had a chance to look at the menu, the waiter barked at us about "soup dumplings" (apparently, everyone comes for the xiaolongbao).  We ordered the standard pork/crab combination, as well as an order of mapo tofu (called something like "home style spicy Szechuan bean curd").  The xiaolongbao were decent, but just decent.  No need to write home.  Grand Sichuan's are clearly better, soupier, and tastier.  The mapo tofu was bland, not spicy at all, very little taste.  Had a generic feel to it.  Again, Grand Sichuan's mapo is much, much better--tastier, earthier, spicier.
Service was OK.Place is super busy. Food is Ok. Another place that is built on word of mouth rather than the quality of its food. It's like eating food cooked in 10-w30.

I have to say this restaurant is like a piece of shit. The only star is for onion pancake and fried rice. Three people spent 80 bucks on lunch but what we felt is eat 20 bucks food. The other food can be directly dropped in the rubbish bin.

Overrated! Joe's Shanghai used to be a great restaurant serving authentic Shanghainese dishes but since it became very popular, the quality of their food noticeably went down in quality. We ordered XLB, crispy noodle and Peking duck. The noodle was okay, my son liked it, the CLB was decent - it was juicy but the wrapper was a little too thick - pls skip the duck it was not worth the price, the portion was small and the meat was dry, the skin was not crispy ( definitely not recommended!)

This is a place to avoid n Chinatown.  It seems they stopped caring once they received their awards.  Maybe zaggot needs to give out Negative awards to places which clearly do no make the grade.
Let me be specific with some low lights.   pot stickers are greasy and have a
thick skin.  The soup dumpling shao lung pao were suppose to be delicate
with thin skin wanton wrapping, they were much larger in size.  and the
meat inside was very fatty and the soupy center was a bit of a goey mess.
Then the pan fried noodle consist of a  meat and vegetable topping over crunchy "ramen" like noodles.  Probably my mistake for ordering cantonese food in a shanghai restaurant.   
Then the pea pod greens saut√©ed with garlic was not very tender, chewy
and tough is not how this dish is suppose to be.
Oh i almost forgot to mention service.  I know in ny chinatown is not
known to to provide anything beyond good food at a good price.
we arrived early for a week day lunch and had five good size adults, and with the restaurant almost empty they want to sit us on table pinned to the wall, so we asked if we could sit at a table which had a little bit more 
room, the hostess rolled her eyes and threw the menus at the table 
we requested.  I wished i could have videoed this to a youtube on
how not to act in a service industry.   
Apparently they don't need any more new customers because they must have plenty of loyal followers who don't mind being treated like dirt.
They have a row of seats outside on the sidewalk for a waiting area.

Fuck this place. Yeah I get it the dumplings are good. I can't say they are the best I've ever had but I think the prices are reasonable, the food is good, and the portions are of good size. The service sucked. Rude ass wait staff who couldn't care less. Beware 15% gratuity is "built in" to every check. I didn't think the service warranted 15% and they didn't get a dime more than that. This place was a complete disappointment.  Also note this is a cash only location.

WARNING FOR PEANUT ALLERGIES!!!!

My cousin went here for dinner last night and ordered noodles with his dad. His dad took a bite and asked the waitress if there were nuts in them to which she said no. My cousin is extremely allergic to peanuts and didn't have his epi pen with him at this time. After his throat started swelling up they ask another waiter who confirms there are "no nuts but there is peanut" in the sauce (not sure why they didn't disclose this on the menu or confirm after the first time asking). This is a SERIOUS thing - restaurants need to a. Know what's in their food and b. Tell customers what's in the food before they eat it and almost die.

Best part is that they actually wanted payment for the food until the manager finally came out and realized how serious this was and didn't charge them. The free food didn't exactly cover the costs of an ambulance to the emergency room / medical costs that incurred so in summary would not be recommending this place for people with food allergies.

It was good but not the BEST of the BEST or so they say. Basically can have the same quality in any other chinese restaurant that makes soup based dumplings. Nothing special about it. Not worth the hype.

Came here to try the food as I had read so many reviews about the dumplings here - this place is located in China town and we got here around 6:30 and got seated around 7 pm. This place has a nice ambience for a Chinese restaurant and the seating was also quite comfy. The service is mediocre though as the food took forever to come out in between dishes. We ended up ordering:

* pork soup dumpling - large pieces lots of soup and flavor

*crab soup dumpling - unique flavor and yummy taste

* sesame chicken - crispy and crunchy on the sweeter side

* lo mein noodles with beef - terrible with no flavor I would definitely skip this

Overall, didn't meet the hype for me but nice Chinese spot with lots of options for food.

Super crowded. Sat with other people in a round table. Food came out pipping hot. Had to flag a waiter down for water. I ordered the soup dumplings w beef and shrimp, scallion pancake and spring rolls. The food appeared fresh. I had been shopping all day and I didn't take my food to go. I didn't get service while I was there so I couldn't look at pics on yelp when I was ordering.

Somewhat disappointed by dinner at Joe's. I've been there two or three times now and feel like it is totally overhyped. The actual food is nothing special in the least! It's standard Chinese food...everything is fine but nothing outstanding. Just some regular sesame chicken, lo mein, etc.

Really, the only noteworthy thing on the menu is the soup dumplings. You can go with pork or with crab/pork so we had one order of each (8 dumplings to an order). They are delicious. The dumpling dough itself is thin and the soup inside was tasty. Only disappointment was that some of ours had no soup inside!!!!!!!! Not good! For seafood lovers like myself the crab is the way to go. The broth itself really tastes of delicious crab. If you aren't such a shellfish fiend, go with the standard pork.

For the amount of time to wait on line and the annoying drunk frat boys who were playing loud drinking games a few tables over (I feel very sorry for the poor people who had to share a table with them), it just wasn't worth it. I've been to some much better restaurants in Chinatown.

We had dumplings and Kung Pao chicken here. Both were pretty ordinary. We have had much better dumplings and Kung Pao chicken elsewhere. The waiter had a very bored look on his face and it seemed that he was quite unwilling to be our waiter. The service was average. We have been to much better Chinese restaurants overall -  with respect to the quality of food as well as the service. Just because it is in Chinatown in Manhattan and it is highly rated on Yelp doesn't make it a good Chinese restaurant.
We waited for an hour to be told that they are not making the dumplings right now and they don't know how much longer it will be.  Very disappointed!

I don't get the hype.  We ordered both kinds of soup dumplings and they were decent but not outstanding.  My meter-stick for comparing this type of restaurants is how good their ja-jiang mien is, and this place is absolutely horrid.  It's literally just noodles with some runny goop heaped on that tastes like kungpao sauce.  I don't believe in a universal standard way of making all dishes but this is like rolling a stick of butter in instant coffee and calling it tiramisu.  I sincerely hope this isn't actually the best dumpling house that New York has to offer because it is far inferior to what I'm used to from the West Coast.

Shanghai 'soupy' dumplings as big as your face. Ok, bigger than I have ever seen and definitely struggling to fit on a spoon/inside you face hole.  The bonus of being seated at a communal table means making friends and getting some good china town tips for further dumpling enlightenment. (Big Wong's and Prosperity Dumplings next on the list.) Also highly entertaining bants.

I think Joe's Shanghai was definitely overhyped for me. Everyone would talk up their XLBs, so I was really excited to try them. I thought they were okay, but really not worth the hype or the long wait...or the hassle of getting cash. The XLBs felt clumsily made, and they didn't feel very fresh either, so that was pretty disappointing. We did try some other noodle dishes and those were decent, but also nothing to write home about. Prices are decent though, especially considering we're in NYC! As for the staff, much to their credit, they're very quick and efficient, so once you get seated, you can be assured you won't be waiting too long to get your food! I wouldn't necessarily recommend Joe's Shanghai, but if you were keen on trying it, I wouldn't try to discourage you from going.

Cash Only. 

Pork Meat Soup Dumpling was delicious when It was hot. But I thought it became too oily when I had the last two. I shared the dish with my friend and I had four dumplings total.

Fried Dumpling was a ok but nothing special woul

Crispy Shredded Beef was like beef version's orange chicken. Overpriced. 

I wouldn't come back again because I didn't like the fact that we had to eat with other groups of customers at a same table.

On my recent trip to NY, I was asked what I wanted to do while I was in town.  My only request was to a) eat "real" ramen (I live in FL and the ramen options are seriously lacking in this state) and b) eat soup dumplings....and soooo I checked out my trusty Yelp app and it pointed me in the direction of Joe's Shanghai.  Boy was I disappointed.  Probably out of all of the meals in the city, my dining experience at Joe's was the most lackluster.

I timed my visit perfectly.  There was absolutely no wait on the rainy Monday morning at 11am.  95% of the dining room was open...so why would they make my dining companion and myself sit at a table with 1 other diner.  I understood if it was busy or if we came in at lunch time....but really did they need to force us to sit with a stranger for no real reason besides laziness?

Moving onto the menu...well they have pork soup dumplings and crab.  Ordered both options and some additional menu items.  Don't get me wrong, the soup dumplings were good...just not great...and definitely not mind blowing.  Similar to the dumplings you can find at any standard dim sum restaurant but with some additional liquid inside.  The portions are fair and the prices are reasonable but not really worth making the trek all the way to Chinatown to experience these underwhelming bad boys.

They are cash only.  Also the dining room is small and they try to capitalize on dining space by making communal dining tables when it's busy.  Decoration is typical to a Chinese restaurant...not the cleanest or awe inspiring but standard Chinese restaurant vibe.

My real complaint was the service.  There really was none and the little we did made our dining experience less than enjoyable.  Interacting with our various servers was almost painful.  They forgot one of our orders...which to be honest wasn't a big deal but when it came time to pay the bill the server argued with me saying I never ordered the item...which come on kids who really forgets food they are looking forward to consuming.  Anyways I'd stay away...check out other options for soup dumplings on Yelp and/or restaurants in Chinatown.

Meh.

Crowded as fuh.. . Filled with tourists and zero space between tables. We had to share a table or else stand around awkwardly waiting for one by the entrance. 

The soup dumplings were very good but a lot of places have good soup dumplings these days. 

What set this place apart from other Shanghainese was some of the other dishes. The giant meatballs had a great taste - I think consisting of worchister sauce and cumin. They were very tender and delectable. 

Just don't make the mistake of ordering Cantonese dishes here - the salt and pepper ribs were pretty mediocre. 

Prices are not exactly cheap for a hole in the wall crowded Chinese eatery but I'm happy for them to have "made it" with the tourist crowd. 

What's up with the "C" health inspection grade though?

Please Bring Cash, and get ready to share a table with complete strangers and wait 45 mins ! 

The decor and the wait staff is below par but the soup dumplings are AWESOME! Its a bit expensive for NYC Chinatown but I guess if you are craving Soup Dumplings (Siu Long Bao) and Shanghai food this is the place to be.

My Picks:

Appetizers:
- Soup Dumplings (Siu Long Bao) Crab/Pork, I personally like Pork
- Scallion Pancake
- Cha Jang Mein (Noodles with Blackbean Sauce), this is a Big bowl

Main Course:
- SubGum Pan Fried Noodles
- Fried Rice Cakes

I've been going to this place for years. The food is incredible. 

Must order items: Soup Dumplings, Scallion Pancake and the Sesame Chicken. 

It's a shame the service is terrible, the wait is incredibly long and the "suggested tip" of 15% is already included with your bill.  Shouting waiters that slam plates on the table can really ruin a meal. 

This would get 5 stars if it was take-out only.
Long wait and always a crowd. Decent steam dumplings but I've had better. Cheap food but they force a 18% tip. Weird for Chinatown in my mind.

This place was good, but considering the fact that my dinner slots were limited to my trip to New York, I didn't think it was exceptionally great. 

To me, it just felt like any other decent Chinese restaurant that we can find in almost any well populated city. The Shanghai dumplings were in fact, pretty good, with lots of juiciness inside and a more of a salty flavor. In comparison to Din Tai Fung in Seattle, I would have been able to wait to eat at DTF and feel just as satisfied (or yet, more satisfied). This restaurant is your typical china town restaurant- busy, not much of an ambience, and the hustle and bustle of waiters. 

If you are compelled to try this place, I wouldn't say don't go, but there are SO many delicious foods in New York to try, I would probably go elsewhere and give this place a whirl if you are in the area.

After getting lost to find this place, I really wanted to be at least 4 or even 5 stars, but I can't lie and will not be fair to those read this review for advice. So I am giving this place 2 1/2 to 3 stars. The 197 persons place is cramp once you walk in and you may sit with strangers while you eat. We were a party of 3 and luckily when we walked in, we were seated right away at our own table.

We went here for a reason and that was for their siu long bao (steam dumplings); however, since we were there, we wanted to try other things as well so we ordered the pan fried seafood noodles, onion pancakes, and fried yellow fish.

I have to admit, the siu long bao was worth being lost for about 10 minutes in the rain to find this place. They were big and juicy inside. When I say juicy, I mean juicy. It was filled with the broth and the skin was nice and soft. We ordered the pork and the crab one and I have to say the pork tasted way better. The crab has like a crabby taste, I mean I don't think it was bad but it didn't seem fresh. Oh, it reminded me crab in a can type thing.

The green onion pancakes were thick, crispy and filled with onion flavor which I enjoyed very much.

I don't know how yellow fish usually taste but I didn't like it very much even though it was fried with some sweet chili sauce. I guess is a milder fish. The pan fried seafood noodle is one of the worse pan fried noodles I had. I guess I expected the Cantonese way of making it but the noodles in this dish was white thick noodles, normally would not be for frying. The crispy noodles had the texture of foam and the soft part tasted like mushy spaghetti. I think the best part of this dish, was the scallops and shrimps, everything else seemed like it was from a can.

If I had to, I will just come back to this place for their green onion pancakes and siu long bao but other than that...I will pass.
Xiao long bao is good but fried rice is bad. I think you can order more xiao long bao and noodle.
Seven fat fish swim in a tank near the entrance to the restaurant. I am convinced that the souls of the waitstaff live exclusively inside of these fish.

I read the reviews and saw the pictures but was not informed that I would be sharing a table with several complete strangers.  The food was fair and the service was very curt.  We ordered pork and crab dumplings that were fair honestly not as good as 101 Noodle Express in San Gabriel, CA.  Our second dish was the scallop pancake, which was good but rather small.  Pan fried rice cakes  with beef followed by black mushrooms with bamboo shoots rounded off our dining excursion.  The value was on point for the quality that was mediocre.  Please be mindful that they include tips on the bill so there is no need to provide gratuity.

The Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) are DELICIOUS!
I went to Joe's Shanghai with two other friends, we ordered two orders of dumplings and one noodle, and this was enough.

I liked their crab meat xiao long bao better than their pork, but that is personal preference. I do suggest that you go and try both :)

This place is semi hidden in an alley...small and smelly street. bummer!

I went on a Tuesday for late lunch, so I didn't have to wait, but we did have to share a table with a person. Be prepared to wait longer if you go around noon or the weekends. I can see how crowded this place can be.

The reason for the 3 stars: 
-I liked only their dumpling, the noodle dish that we ordered was alright - not bad, but super oily - had better at other places
-it can get crowded. I personally don't like to share the table with another party, but it gets crowded, you don't really get a choice (unless you show up with enough friends to occupy a big table!)
-CASH only! remember to bring cash people! 

I would go back, but i'd stick with the xiao long baos only. However, I would like to try other places that can offer good xiao long bao and other dishes too :)

Yes, the dumplings are good.  Yes, the food is Chinese.  But, what's up with the long waits and the overpriced food?  Is it because it's a tourist trap?  Yup.  Good for them.  Lucky for them!

I'd only go back if there was no wait, and if I weren't that hungry.  There are a multitude of other places where you can get as good food for half the price.

I am devastated to see how much Joe's Shanghai has  increased their menu prices and it's astounding that not everyone is mentioning this here. 

 We were regulars here for many years back when they were located on Pell.  By regulars, I mean we were often there weekly either at this location or at their (now closed but very greatly missed) Flushing location.  We have only done take out from the Bowery location so far.  We've always loved the pork soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, crispy beef and pan fried crispy noodle. Also could never get enough of their chili oil.

But these prices are now absolutely insane.  I understand, COVID, COVID, COVID and transportation increases, the increase in prices of chicken and beef, supplies, and on and on. But come on, guys.  

Your competitors have increased their prices by a couple of dollars or $0.50 in many cases, but you guys have literally more than doubled your menu prices within the past year or two.  

This is so devastating and depressing bc many of us, who once had good salaries (after spending so many years getting advanced degrees) no longer have that excellent salary and, as a result, we currently cannot afford to spend $16.95 for for fried rice(!?!!), $19.95 for pan fried crispy noodle (?!!?), $24.95 for crispy beef (!?!?!),  and $14.95 for soup dumplings (WHAT?!!?).  Goodness even bokchoy is $19.95.

Oh, and after paying $14.95 for soup dumplings, I see that they aren't even packaged nicely. They are jammed together with all the precious soup 
leaked out at the bottom of the container. THe dumplings get totally torn up.  We do not have this issue when we take out from your competitors who are also charging 1/2 the price you are charging for better food. 

We drove by on Saturday, April 16 hoping to place a takeout order  but we couldn't believe these prices.  We couldn't even  bring ourselves to place an order due to their outrageous prices, and here I am two weeks later still feeling devastated by this.  You were among our favorite restaurants in NYC.  We even gladly suffered through the brusk service and being forced to sit on top of strangers just to enjoy this food. 

This inflation is so beyond what it should be.  How could you do this to your loyal customers? I am just so sad because I really miss this food and i am extremely disappointed in these decisions that you have made.

For those of you eating here, just think carefully about your money situation as we are living in a time in which things can change without warning.  There are far, far less expensive places that are on the same level (or even better) as Joe's Shanghai.  Just search online and you will find them.   Save your money by making wise choices especially if the food quantity and quality are better, or at the very least equivalent, elsewhere.

This place is so overrated and not worth the hype. The only pro is the quick service and nice/clean interior. I'm not sure if there is just a decline in food quality since it's become so popular with tourists, but I didn't find any of the food we got enjoyable or flavorful at all. The scallion pancakes barely had any scallions in it and were really bland. The fried pork dumplings had no flavor, just grease, and the dough was way too thick and gummy. The pork soup dumplings were really big, making for a good portion size, but the skin was also way too thick, the soup was not clear or flavorful, and the filling was just okay. The dumpling skin to meat filling ratio was so off that we couldn't even eat most of the skin bc it was too much.

We end up at Joe's due to extremely high volume of positive reviews on Yelp. We arrive on a Saturday night around 7:00pm and waited an hour for an open table. The wait wasn't the reason why I rated this place with a 3 star, it was just the mediocre dishes that garner the middle of the road rating.

First on the plate, the xiao long bao was not up to the standard that I am used to in Taipei or Los Angeles's Din Tai Fung, the skin was too thick near the top of the bao, the soup was fairly well represented, but the filling not well mixed between the lean and fat pork. There also a lack of sweetness in the filling. The The fried pork chop was dry and uninspiring. The fried rice was perfect in this otherwise average meal. 

If this what Chinese food taste like in NYC, I'll have to stick to steaks and pizza.

I'm probably the only person that feels this way, but I was a little disappointed. Joe's Shanghai has such phenomenal reviews, and I was so excited to try their soup dumplings. They wrapper was a little too thick, and the filling was dry. Definitely not the best soup dumplings I've eaten. The saut√©ed green beans were absolutely amazing though. By far the best green beans I've eaten. Maybe I'll just need to return and try different dishes.

The staff did not pay attention or come to your table unless you called for them. They stood around until they were called for. Even if you were ready to order and you looked like you are ready to order, they did not go over to you unless you called them over.

I was okay with sharing a table since it's often done in Chinese restaurants. But usually, there is a seat in between you and the separate party. We were elbow to elbow on a Tuesday afternoon and each time the large group spun the rotating tray or turntable in the middle, it would bump something. I sat with a seat in between at first and they were very insisted on having me move over (told me 4 times lol) and I eventually did. Turns out, they planned on putting another group of 2 at the same table, which now consisted of 3 groups (2 groups of 2 and a group of 6). This was my first experience at a restaurant sitting elbow to elbow with strangers when there were more than enough EMPTY tables for us to have sat a seat apart, more than enough tables for each group to have had our own tables. Was not the communal seating I expected or have always experienced. 

The pork soup dumpling tasted homemade, but the same usual filling that other restaurants and stores sell. Still delicious soup dumplings. I order Szechuan food for the spicy kick, I could not taste the spice, but I saw a small amount of Szechuan sauce. Tasted like any other beef noodle soup. 

tl;dr - overhyped, most likely won't visit anymore and if I do, its a no to sharing a table. (They don't usually ask you to share if its a group that fits their open table sizes; they have tables for groups of 2,4, and 10)

The dishes we order were tasty. It always crowd and long waiting time. The restaurant is cozy. Bad customer service. I didn't enjoy the food since I felt I have to rush to eat and get out from the restaurant.

Hmmm. Coming from la, this is on par with din Thai fung. Shorter wait. 20 mins vs 90 minutes. Actual dumpling is larger but the actual wrapping is thicker. The meat could be cooked more thoroughly. 

Only disadvantage. They don't have as many dumpling selections when compared to the #1 spot in la

Stumbled upon Joe's while in China Town, only to find out it was an acclaimed restaurant with plenty of reviews and high praises, which came as a delight! The concept was hilarious to me - tons of people crowded outside, one woman screaming numbers and giving you nearly 5 seconds to get to the door before moving onto the next. Amazing. 

After about 20 minutes we finally entered the restaurant to find a packed house. The restaurant moves quick, you're shoulder to shoulder with the people next to you and your server is at the table before you have even sat down. All amazing. Unfortunately however, the food was lacking. My girlfriend is vegetarian so we asked what was on the menu for us. The vegetarian shanghai noodles were a must. Unfortunately, our vegetarian shanghai noodles came with beef and only after a few fork fulls did we notice. This kind of threw things off. I'd suggest laying off the vegetarian duck as well, as it was really just cold mushrooms. 

While this is a slightly unfair review, we had read plenty that said it was great for vegetarians. The dumplings, which they are famous for, only come with meat/fish, there are no vegetarian spring rolls and I mean aside from that, who wants a plate of steamed vegetables? Next time I will be returning and trying the chicken / beef dishes. I'm sure those are good.

I have been to this place before and yes they do have amazing soup dumplings. HOWEVER... I just had lunch there today and I have a fully backed COCKROACH stuck against one the dumplings!!!! It was the most disgusting scene and experience I have ever had at a restaurant.

We understand in CTOWN we take our chances but that crosses the line. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED

This place is usually packed with a diversity of people from all over. Their hottest item on the menu is the juicy pork buns. Today I got to try some of the items on their menu and were not very crazy about most of them. I guess the only dish, besides the pork buns, I would have again is the pan fry noodles.

Food: terrible. Extremely greasy and every single bite is coated in salty, greasy sauce. The sauce wasn't even mixed well, some piece of vegetables have so much sauce while some has no sauce. 

Service: terrible. The waiter seemed very rude and didn't even want to hear our questions. Condescending tone. 

Ambience: ok.

To be honest, I don't understand why everyone likes this place. I think it's just a Xiao long bao place that all the kids and tourists go to. I've been to many other places that have better soup dumplings.

The soup dumplings are always good. They are what put this restaurant on the  map after all. The rest are standard Chinese cuisine. The only problem with this place is that they add 18 percent service charge to the bill automatically. And when they bring the change they leave out the receipt so I'd imagine some customers would leave more tip thinking that the bill didn't include it. That's some shady as fuck move. I am not against tipping and I normally tip 20 percent. But I'd like to have that choice rather than have the 18 percent included without my say in it. Just be aware.

So my first on my NYC pigout.... came here bright and early on Tuesday for some XLBs. We had one order of the pork XLB, green onion pancake, and shanghai noodles....  Food came out quickly and service was medicore... thought the XLB's were juicy, large and of course fatty! Pretty good but for some reason wasn't all that impressed...due to jetlag? who knows... I'd probably go to Shanghai Cafe instead for some XLB grubbin..

Also they charge you a 15% "service charge" here for tip and its cash only.

This is supposed to be a Shanghainese restaurant, right?  Well, I came in and ordered two "longs" of Little Dragon soup dumplings and the wine chicken - both of which are Shanghai classics - and I was sorely disappointed by both.  The soup dumplings were hot, but the broth was almost sour.  The dumplings themselves were too large - when dumplings are too large the meat inside of them do not cook right.  The wine chicken was a complete disaster - the smell was about right for this aromatic dish - but the taste was bland and oily.  The chicken itself was white instead of the traditional yellow for wine chicken and my girlfriend and I didn't even finish the dish.

This place is swarming with tourists.  If you want a more authentic Shanghai cuisine experience, go a couple doors down to Shanghai Gourmet for a more authentic experience.  There, they actually speak Shanghainese, I saw a bunch of Shanghai tourists munching down, and their soup dumplings are way better (although I did not try their wine chicken)

It was all hype for us. 
Place was very crowded, outdated and the bathrooms were disgusting. The food was just okay, honestly the reviews on this place set my expectations a little too high which is probably why I was so disappointed. 
Cash only
Horrible service, dirty and rude workers. Waited for half hour in the cold just so the front door girl can tell me they skipped my number

Joe's Shanghai on Pell St. on Sunday night with six friends. Mobbed. We were told 20 minute wait for table--we waited 45 minutes and got seated with two strangers who hogged the table. Obnoxious servers who declined to offer any hints or suggestions from their multi-page menu. We each ordered different dishes with intrnt to share, but soup, appetizers and main dishes arrived all at the same time making it impossible to try to share anything. Waiters brought stacks of bowls and plates which we passed around the table. Empty dishes remained uncollected which made the table more of a garbage can than a place from which to eat food. Requests for tea refills went unanswered as did r√®quests for water. Food was serviceable but nothing memorable. The din and crowd noise was headache level. Of course no credit card service and our individual checks were written in pencil on scraps of note paper. None of the waiters was able to decipher the bill or tell us the cost for individual items. So our group of seven got ripped off to the tune of more than $350. Mediocre food, absolutely the worst service since the Soviet Union went out of business. With at least a dozen superior restarants within a five minute walk I am totally baffled by the rave reviews for this unremarkable at best second rate dive.
I ate dinner at Joe's Shanghai (crab/pork soup dumplings, vegetable lo mein and pepper shrimp) last night and by 4 a.m. was sick as a dog with food poisoning. Beware!

It's been 3 years since I've come to Joe's Shanghai, and I always had fond memories of its soup dumplings, however, today's experience was a two thumbs down! My soup dumplings were super mediocre, the skin was a little 'rough' and the meat and soup tasted like they put too much MSG.

 I also ordered the cold sesame noodles, which was flavorful, but I bit into what tasted like hardened old noodles! No, no, no!  I guess with a restaurant this popular, the quality of the food has gone down and it doesn't really matter to them anymore. Too bad!

This place clearly comes highly recommended.  I didn't love it.  Yes, there was a 30 min wait on a Thursday  at 6:30 but that was expected.  Ordered the pork soup dumplings, which were just average if not bland.  Tricky to eat, one exploded and shot out on my dress - you've been warned!  Also had Kung Pao chicken, again not great but to be fair, I don't eat peanuts so it may be better.  Also had double cooked pork, it was good but very garlicky.  Personally, I won't be back - too many great restaurants in NYC!

If you like to dine in cacaphony sitting next to a bunch of strangers, go here.

Also, their soup dumplings are decent, but Shanghai Cuisine is better.

If you're in the market for Soup Dumplings, go to Shanghai Cuisine. I can't sing their praises over Joe's more than this.

Joe's: Annoyingly loud, crowded, long waits, mediocre-good dumplings.

Shanghai Cuisine: quiet, not crowded, decent service, best dumplings in NYC.

First time back in years -- what a mistake. 

The XLBs were different sizes and shapes. Most were lopsided and thrown onto the bamboo basket with shreds of lettuce around the dumpling I couldn't peel off the skin. Three were torn with soup seeping out onto the lettuce. The worst part? The filling was greasy and the soup, an oily, scorching mess. 

Their XLBs are offensive, borderline criminal; simply hot messes.
(See photo for proof.)

It's like Joe's doesn't give a two sh*ts about quality anymore since they are so famous. I will never step foot in there again.

SCREW YOU, JOE'S.

Very good food but poor service and too many people for what you get.

Pro:
- Great soup dumplings
- Other menus are pretty good too

Con:
- unfriendly and unresponsive staff
- unreasonably long wait during peak hours
- place is too full of people (uncomfortable)
Too busy..overly crowded. I've had better Chinese food and soup dumplings. It's overrated for what you actually get.

This was my first time ever eating the "dumplings with soup" inside, so I didn't really know what to expect! We ended up waiting a mere 30 minutes, but I was impressed that the server said we'd be waiting 30 minutes. Not a minute more or less. There was a huge line outside so I could tell from the mixed crowd that Joe's Shanghai is pretty popular.

The funny thing about this place is that they seat you with random people in a huge round table. Forget about getting your own private table, you'll probably be rubbing elbows with some random person. But that's the fun part about being in New York!

All we got were pork dumplings and pork + crab dumplings. I honestly couldn't tell the difference in the two, but they were both really good! Just remember not to pop the entire thing in your mouth or you'll burn it (as it shows on a funny cartoon on the outside window)

The best part about this place was the bill. Including tip, it cost about $8 per person WITH DRINKS! Amazing!!! I was totally stuffed! 

I think I would have to visit one more time to see how consistent all of this is, but for now it's a 3 star place for me!!

The food is just ok
Service sucks and the soup dumplings are ok but nearby noodle village is better

This is not my first visit to Joe's Shanghai, but it's the first time I've been here in a while. Usually when I crave soup dumplings, I frequent two Shanghainese places on Mott Street. This time, I was with a friend who is new to soup dumplings, so I decided to take her to Joe's Shanghai since this place is more wellknown (so I assumed better). The last time I had been here was 3 years ago and I didn't remember much about the taste. 

Came as a party of 2 and didn't have to wait, but we were also right before the dinner rush. Wait service was good for chinatown, but I think that is because they cater to a large foreigner customer base. 

The food: we ordered a soup, pork soup dumplings, and beef pan fried noodles. The soup was okay, friend and I were both happy with it. The beef pan fried noodles were 3$ more expensive than the other places I go to, and did NOT taste as good. Greasy, oily, not authentic at all. 

However, my problem was with the soup dumplings. The middle dumpling was already leaking, and the ones on the side were all stuck to each other or stuck to the side. There was basically no way to eat them without having them all break. Maybe it was because I had ordered in English, and they thought I wouldn't know how soup dumplings should look?

Anyway, after some deliberation about whether we should just eat them or not, I called a waiter over and made the problem known in Chinese. The waiter seemed very surprised to hear me speaking his language fluently. He tried to be like "oh, it's only one that's broken. It's very hard for the entire batch to all be perfect." As he said this, he tried to move two of the dumplings that were stuck to each other on the side. As soon as he did, they both broke and started leaking soup. At this point, he gave up and just got us a new batch. The new batch was a little bit better but still had two/three that broke easily. 

All in all, I've never seen soup dumplings look that sad... at least the waiter was nice enough about getting us a new batch. These dumplings are definitely not the best in NYC; you get find better tasting ones for cheaper in many other places.
