Lesson learned -- more famous place does not mean better food. Everyone, go to Mott Street for your soup dumplings.

Can someone please explain to me the hype over Joe's??? Think I'm missing something but my two experiences here have not warranted anything above an A-Okay Dumpling house.  Typical Chinese pushy in & out service, check.  Not so good XLB, check. Typical Chinatown hole in the wall, check. 

Skin is too thick and rough, takes actual skill, time & technique to craft a thin skin soup dumpling that doesn't fall apart.

Definitely not worth the wait.

tl;dr:  AVOID THIS PLACE - food was subpar; service was almost non-existent; and they snuck in a 18% gratuity without informing us and then chased us down the road like raving lunatics to hustle another $10 out of us.  
----

The wife was craving some good chicken dumplings, so just like any other hapless tourist, I found this restaurant using our favorite search engine.  Read the glowing reviews there and on Yelp, so we took a subway down to Chinatown to get our hands on these dumplings everyone was talking about.  We arrived around 2:30 PM on Thursday (12/23/21) and had to wait about fifteen minutes to be seated.  The place was busy, but not overwhelmingly so.  

First thing I noticed was that the place only took cash, which I thought was a little strange considering how well it was rated by others and seemed to cater to a diverse, non-local only crowd.  Okay, no big deal.

We were seated and it took about 10 minutes until someone finally got around to coming by our table.  We were expecting them to have a full dumpling menu like most of the other Chinese restaurants in Manhattan, but no, they only had two types of dumplings - pork and vegetables.  Strike one for me, since my wife couldn't get the dumplings she was craving.  Since we were already there and were quite hungry, we decided to eat and we ordered a plate of veggie dumplings to start.  

Along with that, my wife ordered the sake and I ordered a Diet Coke, which took  another good while to arrive at our table.

Along with our dumplings, we ordered two dishes - I ordered the bean curd dish and my wife ordered the Singapore chow mein. 

The dumplings were okay at best and pretty much standard fare one would get at any random Chinese restaurant in the area - nothing special. 

The bean curd dish was just a plate of tofu with veggies, but with very little sauce or liquid.  It was also okay - nothing to write home about.  I ordered a side of rice to try to make more of a meal out of it.

My wife's chow mein was substandard with poorly cooked noodles.  She said the chicken was good and tasty, but the rest of the dish fairly bland and routine.

So we chalked it up to not reading the reviews closely and getting sucked into a tourist-trap type of restaurant and we finished up and asked for the bill.

This is what we ordered (with prices taken from their menu online):

Steam veg dumplings - $7.95
Sake - $8.95
Diet Coke - $2.25
Singapore Chow Mein - $11.95
Bean Curd Home Style - $12.95
Extra Rice - $3 (guessing, since it was not listed on the menu)

Total - $47.05 before tax

So we received a cash bill for something like $60 or so.  This means that they had already added 18% to the bill as a gratuity.  Being inattentive, I just put down $70, figured that a $10 tip should be sufficient for a $60 tab.  That's about a 15% tip I thought in my mind, which is generous considering how bad the service was.

For some reason, my wife had $3 more dollar bills in her pocket and she put those down too.  We normally tip 30% whenever we eat out, so I am guessing she felt bad that I had not tipped the usual percentage.

So we laid down $73 cash for a $60 bill, or about a 22% tip.

Now remember, this was an extra $13 tip on top of the 18% gratuity they had already added to our bill!

Without thinking much, we walked out of the restaurant and we were about half a block away when someone from the restaurants comes chasing after us yelling and carrying on.  I couldn't fully understand what he was saying, but it seemed that he was telling us that we had shorted them on the bill.  He was waving around the cash we had put on the table, but he was pointing at the bill and saying something that wasn't very intelligible.

My wife, not wanting to make a scene and wanting to make our next appointment and escape this raving lunatic just handed him an additional $10 bill and we walked away.  I guess we both looked like unsophisticated tourists to one of the restaurant staff, so thought they could hustle a bit more money out of us by startling us and by making a scene in the street.

So they essentially got $83 out of us for a $60 bill that itself was inflated with this hidden 18% gratuity.

We vowed to be more careful in reading online reviews and religiously avoiding hyped tourist-trap restaurants in the future.
Good soup dumplings and awesomely old school interior with neon lights. The place is bigger than it looks on the outside and service is quick and thorough!

Didn't see what was so special about this place that warranted the reviews it is getting. The service sucked and was rude ate that. The restaurant was a hot mess and the food was nothing special. We had gotten Crispy Pork Chop with Pepper Salt and pork dumplings. Which were good, but nothing to rave about. Not to mention the location, on Pell, a dumpy back alley street that stank. Will not be coming back.

To the girl who compared this to Din Tai Fung, no no.

4,000 reviews?! I had to come and try it. However, trouble from the start is that China Town parking is RIDICULOUS. Just try to park wherever you can, then walk! Walking will get you there faster, and you'll get to enjoy more scenery.

This is the first time that I've been seated WITH a random group. Alright, so it's 11:45am, and there's a good chunk of people waiting. The lady tells us 20minutes, which was a lot shorter than we were guessing. We planned on walking around, but we ended up staying and waiting. Good thing because we ended up getting seated in 10 minutes instead! What was NOT a good thing was the fact that my party of 3 was seated WITH another party of 3 that are already eating so that we fill up the 6 table perfectly. IT'S SO WEIRD. We just split the table, but you can't help but feel squished and uncomfortable.

Now, the comparison between DTF and here caught my eye. My top 2 dumpling houses are Din Tai Fung and Mama Lu's, and this place falls under these 2 in my opinion, for the debate was not very close. It costed $40 for 3 items, so it's pricing is between DTF and Mama Lu (with Mama Lu being the cheapest). The inside is small and kind of dirty, which drifts away from DTF and more towards Mama Lu's, but the dumpling is the most important factor. Although the dumplings are very big compared to regular ones, the juice inside is dull--nothing special. Mama Lu's is sweet, and DTF's is boldly spiked. The only one-up this place has is its size that makes it more filling.

Joe's is pretty well OK in my book.

You come here to get xiaolongbao (literally, and quite comically, "little juicy buns"), otherwise known as "soup dumplings" or "Shanghai juicy dumplings," a specialty of that particular Chinese city.

They're relatively large as far as dumplings go, and they're basically pork meatballs with a little bit of spiced aspic stuffed into elastic and chewy wheat-flour wrappers. The aspic melts during cooking, filling the dumpling with "soup," hence their name. Just don't chomp on them, as the scalding juice WILL squirt all over your face and leave you with painfully pink burns on your face for a few days! That goes for any xiaolongbao you ever eat, regardless of where.

Get 'em with the optional crab. My buddy, who's got a severe allergy to shellfish/iodine insisted on having them that way and he got sick (DUH!). Fortunately, both of us have been trained to deal with such emergencies!

They also made a really tasty salt-and-pepper fried quail.

Since I hail from the Chinese-food capital of the U.S. (the San Gabriel Valley, near Los Angeles), nothing in New York's Chinatown really appealed to me, but it served its purpose while I lived there. It's definitely worth a try!

I really believe that people who gave this place anything higher than 2 stars have never had the authentic shanghai style soup dumplings (Xiaolongbao) or their are not Chinese. This place is terrible. I won't come back to eat even if the food is free, unless u pay me $50. 
I've never had such an awful Xiaolongbao. The size is like a fist big and the wrap is so thick, and I thought it has not enough juice inside! Authentic Xiaolongbao should be tiny, a bite size with wrap so thin, u can see through it. And have a lot of juice in it.
I have coworkers who thought this place was awesome and that i'm super picky. One of them are Texan and one of them are Mexican. So I told them, why don't we go to Applebee's for steak and taco bell for tacos? Then they stopped teasing me and apologized.
I wish I could give this place zero stars

I haven't been to this famous soup dumpling landmark in a while.  Ever popular with both Chinese and non-Chinese patrons, it is perpetually packed and one reason I haven't visited for years.  Memorably, this was where I had soup dumplings for the first time over a decade ago.

It's a no frills, small-ish dining space primarily decorated by their numerous articles and media recognition pieces.  Cramped seating and tight spaces all around.  Service basic but adequate.  

Every table gets the soup dumplings and if you're not here for that, I don't know why you are.  Order one or two sets of 8 as soon as you arrive at your table, then take a seat and pick out the rest of your orders.  I prefer the crabmeat and pork over pork only.  The soft, tasty filling is encased in a thin, pliant skin, with a mouthful of soup inside.  After eating heavenly soup dumplings in Shanghai, I've had trouble finding satisfactory ones in NYC.  Joe's are good, not great.

Also had five spice beef (ok), fried cold tofu (better than expected, very tasty), scallion pancakes (lightly crisp, good balance of substance and thinness), tofu with crabmeat (delicious!), Shanghai fried rice cake (good but very oily), and the subgum casserole (HUGE portion, tons of items in the soup, good flavor).

Overall a decent meal, if not exceptional.

Heard about this place from several reviews and a coworker about how awesome it is and I'll say it lived up to the hype, but not necessarily the OVERhype. Came here with family and they were all impressed with the food - got the scallion pancake, soup dumplings, kung pao chicken, singapore noodles and the chicken fried rice. Food had simple flavors.. spicy dishes weren't very spicy (probably a 3 on a scale of 10)?

No reservations and we had a half hour wait around 6:30 on a Thursday! Food came out quickly though. Overall a decent place but there are many good eats in this city so if the wait's long I'd say go somewhere else. If you are going, go with no expectations and you'll be pleasantly surprised.

The complete finest Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao) outside of China (perhaps even better than Hong Kong). The crab ones are really so tasty they melt in your mouth. Do not expect excellent service or cozy atmosphere. It is a restaurant in Chinatown, which means you go there for the food, not the setting. as soon as I lived in Hong Kong, this place was a must once I visited NYC to get my xiao long bao repair!

The food looks better than some other Chinese restaurant I'm Chinatown. The beef Sichuan had medium amount of paper which was good for my taste. The pick probably not the best choice for a shanghai style restaurant. Usual folks try soup dumpling which is their signature dish,  but it does not have enough variety. Also 15 percent tip is already added to your bull.
 Downsides, small space,  decor is way old and rusty, only cash accepted. Servers do not attend regularly only when you ask them, basically looks like there is no assigned server for any table like some low key Asian restaurant.

The soup dumplings are pretty good. I went there ~1pm on a Sunday and waited less than 10 minutes. Service was fast. The place was packed and the guy at the next table kept on bumping into me. 

Overall the xai long bao (soup dumplings) were really yum, the scallions pancakes were greasy and crispy, and the fried long flat noodles (pork) were alright.

environment is poor. arrived at 3pm but still be request to share a table with others. some tables are empty but not to open for us. XLB is not traditional. Too big and hard skin. Ordered spicy fish and chicken bone. Totally not Chinese food.  Using same sauce in these different cuisine. The waiter said they serve for foreigners. Okay. Definitely will not come back.

Don't know what's the big deal with this place.  Had to wait 45 minutes to sit.  Their bathroom is an absolute war zone.  It's so disgusting.  One of my requirements for a restaurant is to have. Spotless bathroom.   This place was so dirty I felt like I had to go disinfect my whole body.  The soup dumplings everyone raves about were so whatever.  The Chinese food we ordered was a little on the pricier side of other establishments in Chinatown.  When it came to pay the bill, I didn't realize it was cash only and pulled out a cc.  They ran over like a swarm of bees and started yelling cSh only cash only.   Gottttttt it buddy.  Heard you the first time.  They were swarming around us like cockroaches.  Prolly cuz they have many cockroaches in the kitchen.  It is so dirty in there. When I was leaving.  The waiter started saying something directly to my face in passing.  Grrrrrr. I know what you said
Beijing duck disgustingIt's not Beijing duck! They even use Mexico wrap...Other food tastes so so.

Just so you know this is a family style restaurant so you're sitting at a large round table with a bunch of people you don't know. In my case 5 other people that did not speak English which made for an interesting dynamic. 

This place seems constantly busy so make sure you have plenty of time and plan on a wait.

The Pork Buns seem to be the appetizer/meal of choice here. I did not much care for them not that they were bad just a texture issue. However, the 5 other people at my table ate 4 orders (32) of them so take that for what you will.

The Kung Pao Chicken was bland and just tasted like bell pepper not much flavor at all.

Then since this was my first time in Chinatown I went with a true safe pick Sesame Pick. It was delicious something I would definitely eat again.

Not worth the wait and hype. Soup dumplings are fine but you get more of the same almost anywhere else (or better) with better environment, service attitude - waiting to eat here on a weekend night is like standing in line at Boba Guys on opening night for 3 hours: not worth.
They require cash only, but they charge us with tax. And the service is horrible!! I don't think the price matches my experience.

This place had a lot of hype. Maybe it was too hyped up for me. I wasn't impressed. 

What the reviews say is true. You get to sit next to strangers. They try to pack as much people as possible. I think that's cool. It's better than waiting in lines. Just ignore your table-mates like I did if you're anti-social.

Anyway, I tried their crab and pork soup dumplings, pork soup dumplings, and their seafood noodle soup. 

Their seafood noodle soup was bland and terrible. Honestly, with the excellent noodle soup places in NYC (eg. ramen and soba), there is no reason to get it here at Joe's Shanghai. The noodles tasted like it came straight out of a bag, and the broth was tasteless and tepid. 

Their soup dumplings tasted okay. The soup needed more flavor. It also tasted too fatty. The meat needed more umph to the flavor. It wasn't a bad soup dumpling, but I expected better.

This place is cash only, but it's cheap. Their service is lightning fast and efficient. They're not the friendliest of bunch, but they're polite and fast. I like that. 

I would advise you to ignore the hype and save yourself the trouble. I would avoid this place. 2.5 stars.

The old location was great, but at this new location the quality of the dumplings has gone down a bit. It feels much more catered towards tourists and they're just coasting on the reputation they built up 

There are much better dumpling places around

This place is way over-hyped than it needs to be. Gets very crowded and you have to share tables with strangers. Soup dumplings are cheap but not too flavorful. I got crab and pork but they didn't taste like crab at all. Scallion pancake is ok but nothing special.

Seriously? If you enjoy waiting forever to eat at a place that's packed with tourists because of a Zagat write-up, then you'll love this place. Never mind that their dumplings are not that much better than most other places in Chinatown or Flushing. I've eaten here twice because of friends, and the best thing about this place is seeing the tourists scramble back onto the sidewalk to avoid getting hit by cars on narrow Pell Street.

Too harsh?

I decided to check this place out because everyone I know totally RAVES about this place and claims it is the best soup dumplings they have ever had. I come from California..where there it is very easy to find legit (& cheap) chinese food on every block. I got to admit, this place did not live up to the hype. I believe Kung Fu Ramen (49th & 8th) makes better soup dumplings than this place.

Pros:
--You get seated really fast! We had a huge group of 7 ppl and only had to wait 5 minutes.

Cons:
--it has a B rating. uhh..what kind of sketchy stuff is going on in the back that prevents it from getting that A?!
--Sesame chicken tastes like large orange chicken panda express and the broccoli that comes with it was raw
--***ADD $2 TO EVERYTHING ON THE MENU LISTED BY YELP!!!** i was totally expecting a different price than what was actually listed there
--be prepared to meet new people because you WILL be seated next to other groups of 2-3! (Though it is a very efficient way of cramming so many ppl into such a small place)

Is it bad? No, not necessarily. Would I come again? Ehh....debatable. I believe there are better places in the area.

Their Soup dumplings are expensive and way overrated. They carry that zagat review as if they are the end all be all of Chinatown. It's fine by me. Tourists seem to LOVE this restaurant and I avoid is at all costs. Tourists have little experience with soup dumplings and likely chinese food that doesn't come in the fast food form and thus don't know any better. Like I said, very over rated for their price but I'm fine with it as long as tourists don't clog up the other restaurants!

Joes Shanghai is a great Asian restaurant if you like American- Chinese food. It's not very authentic and the flavors are not as strong as I am use to with the authentic Chinese take out. But overall it's a good place to start if your wanting to try Chinese cuisine!

I'll start off by saying this location looks a lot fancier than the other location. I love the pork dumplings and all of its soupy glory. I would say they are Joe's Shanghai's best dish and the only thing I will ever get from here. It's nice and hot which makes it perfect for a cold day but it still tastes delicious when the weather is warmer, it's worth overheating for in the hot restaurant. I tried the cold noodles and it was way too peanut buttery; it literally tasted like noodles mixed with just peanut butter you get from jars. The service is definitely not attentive and is barely even there (which is probably why all checks automatically have 15% gratuity added). Everything with the exception of the soup dumplings was not my cup of tea.

The soup dumplings here are okay. I was too hyped for this place. 
When you get there walk into the restaurant and get a ticket from up front. There is no space to wait inside, so you have to go outside until your number is called. They have a crazy disorganized way to get people seated. Workers come out and ask for your number. Then you have to shout it out in hopes she puts your number on her list. After all this chaos, you get seated in their packed restaurant. Don't expect to be seated at a table with just your party because you will share tables with strangers- I guess an interesting experience. 
Then the waiter comes and ask for your order. We ordered their soup dumpling and fried rice, but we ended up never getting our fried rice. Sigh... 
Soup dumplings are okay. They have a lot of flavor, but their wrappings were slightly too hard. They didn't taste as fresh as they could be. 
We asked for a cup of water multiple times, but never got them:( 
I was pretty happy to leave the hectic place after a while. 
Are the soup dumpling really worth the long cold wait outside? Are they really worth the chaos you have to endure for them?? Mmmmm... They weren't for me....

Soup dumplings are great here but it is not worth the hype.

My family and I decided to try this place out after it was all over social media but we were a little disappointed. 

Staff is not friendly at all.. and they tend to throw the dishes/food at you.

There are way better and nicer place in NYC for soup dumplings.

This is a very overrated place. The restaurant smells and the food is not fresh at all. If you come here, just order soup dumpling and nothing else. Even the soup dumplings here I had much better version of it somewhere else. The wrap of the soup dumplings here very thick and it was a bit salty.
I didn't enjoy the food.  It wasn't satisfying for me.  The food was bland and covered in heavy thick sauce.  The service was good so 3 stars otherwise it'd be 2 stars.

Average, expected so much more and everything had the potential to be so good! Ordered the general's chicken and it was pretty much breading. Scallion pancakes were so thick and douhghy. Pork dumplings and bok Choy were good. Complimentary oranges at the end were nice and sweet.

My friend and I were in the neighborhood and craving some Chinese food.  Yelp led me to this place.  We had an average experience, not bad but not great.  The first thing you notice is the organized chaos of the restaurant.  You are quickly ushered through a maze of waiters and tables until you are squeezed into the empty seats at a large circular table with strangers.  This is New York after all, so this seating arrangement was slightly awkward because nobody wanted to make conversation.  The waiters are on top of their game.  We had barely looked at the menu when we were asked for our order and our entr√©es arrived shortly after.  This is a positive and a negative.  I felt as if I was being rushed.

We ordered the pork dumplings which were a godsend.  Having been in Europe for six weeks where good Asian food is hard to come by, these juicy dumplings seemed like a tiny miracle.  It is apparent that dumplings are Joe's Shanghai's specialty.  I then ordered the chicken and shrimp in plum sauce.  It was mediocre.  My friend ordered the Singapore Noodles which were also mediocre.

If I come again I will probably only get an order of dumplings which only cost $4-5.  Be prepared for the chaos.  This is certainly not a place to bring a date or have an intimate conversation.
got the soup dumplings to take out - i do not recommend taking out soup dumplings

You come here bc you don't know pork dumpling soup from the waiter's elbow.
You come here bc you want to introduce your non Asian bf to Chinese food.
You come here bc you're Asian and want to be ironically surrounded by non Asians in Chinatown.
You come here bc it's dirt cheap.

Honestly I was pretty underwhelmed. Maybe it's because I've been spoiled living in SF and Seattle, but at the end of the day I wasn't that impressed. Also, the large communal tables with a ton of randos just wasn't my jam. Oh well!

3.5 stars. I finally visited Joe's after avoiding it for some time for fear of it being over-hyped. My verdict? They do serve some really solid soup dumplings, but not necessarily worth such a long wait. I've eaten similar soup dumplings in California in restaurants with absolutely no wait. 

Also, I'm not sure if it's just me or I'm going crazy, but for some reason I find the dumpling skin at all the XLB places in NYC to be a bit too thick. And Joe's was no exception.

They did have a great soup, and were generally quite good. However, the crab soup dumplings weren't very good - definitely just stick with pork.
Bad service. They know that 15% tip will be added automatically on the bill so they dont care about costumer service,never smile never say thank you.

I realize I may be Yelp crucified once the soup dumpling experts get ahold of this review...I've had better. They were good, but I've had better.....(luv u Nom Wah) Pork dumplings 8 for $9, good broth but a little more fatty than I would've liked. (Pork and the pork with crab combo are the only dumpling fillings available). My boyfriend had white fish in white wine sauce with fungi and a side of steamed white rice. (See pic) Simple but delicious. 

I really appreciate the ambiance here. Kinda feels like someone's dining room. Home-y, family style and you even sit with strangers if there aren't enough of you for a large table. My boyfriend and I sat with 4 men who were already well into their meal. To our surprise, not awkward. Everybody just rolls with it. Complimentary tea throughout your meal (loved it, next time I'll ask what kind it is) and orange slices at the end of your meal. It was pretty good. Not spectacular as it is painted but solid. Give them a try. I'll return for other stuff & report back! 

Oh! CASH ONLY

The food is okay, pretty oily. Not worth of the price. That's why I didn't see any Asian dining here. Also, the charge 15% of tips with check came in. I mean... They spilled water all over my pants... NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE. Sucks.
Extremely disrespectful waiters and staff. The food was average. Chinatown has several other better eateries so please take your business elsewhere.

We stopped in and had the crab meat with pork dumplings after our next door table's ecstatic recommendation. They were okay, but what we really enjoyed was their Scallion Pancake with dipping sauce. We also shared the Seafood Flat Noodle, which was tasty. The joint was packed, which is great for the owners, but we found ourselves too tightly stuffed in, so we got out as soon as we could.

noodles are GROSS. Only dumplings are ok.. I'd never come back here . :( Bad service. This place is all about the hype. Customers are all tourists (who only depend on Yelp reviews) .I'd not recommend this place to anyone.

The wait on a Sunday night was unusually short, roughly in line with others. I don't think it would've been worth it.
Interior: Bright and clean, not too crowded. Bathroom was nice except for a very dirty stall. Utensils were clean.
Food: Good overall. Some dishes had generous portions, others not so much.
Service: Slow and highly variable. Long waits between plates.
Prices: Pretty cheap, closer to $ than $$. 15% service charge and taxes are included. Cash only.
It was not a bad meal, but the experience did not justify the popularity of the restaurant. You can do better elsewhere.

This place is wayyy overhyped and definitely a "tourist trap". 

First of all, let me start by saying- I don't mind waiting in line for awhile for good food.... but! This place has a totally messed up system. The tables here are communal, so I understand that sometimes a 3 person spot may open and jump ahead of the two, but they completely skipped our group and then when we asked they basically just said "oops." 

Second. I know this place is busy, but the customer service is subpar. They rush you through your order and seem frustrated if you ask questions. 

They are known for their dumplings - they only have two kinds. They're just okay. We tried both (pork and a pork+crab) and I honestly couldn't tell you which was which. We also had the scallion pancake which was oily and lacked flavor unless you put a lot of sauce on it. 

Dumplings came out quick. There's the one positive. 

There are sooooo many other places to get good food in Chinatown that I wouldn't waste your time on this one.

Date number two.  This time it is dinner for Shanghainese pork xiao long bao.  This restaurant has a high table turnover rate and it is extremely loud flooded with the constant Chinese chatter conversations.  Unfortunately my constant sneezing and nose running all day throughout the night I was unable to fully enjoy my date or dinner.  We also ordered Shrimp Pan fried noodles Ëôæ ÁÇí Èù¢ which was swimming with MSG and too much oily sauce.  We shared a table with another party unable to have our individual table as it were Yum Cha style due to lack of space.  This restaurant is very popular for Lo Fans who are inexperienced with authentic Chinese food especially Shanghainese.  The xiao long bao are on point in true Shanghainese ethnic.  I can consume xiao long bao as if it were a full fledged meal.  We both enjoyed the soup dumplings as they are a Shanghainese staple and necessity.  Extremely loud restaurant as you cannot hear yourself think.  Dinner time is very crowded and it is extremely inaudible for couples or families to engage in intense physiological conversations with my date.  Waiter service is below average. My date is very dry monochromatic who exhibit signs of great selfishness and apathetic.

I know this place is famous and everyone and their half-brother's nanny's girlfriend is raving about how great their soup dumpling is, and if you ever go to New York you have to make this an obligatory stop if you even considers yourself a foodie.  So it was added to our long lists of places to dine at weeks before we even left to go to New York for our culinary adventure.

But after checking out the highly rated pizza and hot dog joints (I really like Gray's Papaya), and also the fantastic Katz's Delicatessenin the preious days of our visit, we finally made our way to Joe's.  Got lost briefly after coming out of the subway, and had to ask around, but eventually we arrived at a decidedly aged but still very famous restaurant.  

The wait for us wasn't long, and we quickly ordered our food.  We were there to only try their famous soup dumplings, so we didn't really have to debate what else to order like we usually do.  And this review is for the crab meat and pork meat soup dumplings only, since we didn't try anything else.

So after a brief wait, our steaming hot dumpling of legend arrived.  We all took several pictures, trying to capture the whispy steam along with the moist parcel of soupy pork dumpling before gingerly picking it up with our chopsticks and succeeded in not puncturing it and letting the broth run out.

My initial reaction to the crab meat soup dumpling was that it was really salty, and I can't really taste much of the crab flavor.  The original pork meat ones was better, but it did not knock my socks off.  Maybe it was the high expectations and all the hype leading up to the final tasting, but it was just okay.  In fact, I have had better in California at a "no-name" restaurant, and really superb ones at Din Tai Feng in Taipei, Taiwan.  To Joe's Shanghai's credit, when I picked up my dumpling from the top, I can see the sag on the bottom of my dumpling indicating a lot of juicy broth is encased inside (my mom taught me that trick).

The reviews from my friends were also about the same, the original soup dumpling is better than the crab meat soup dumpling.  The great thing about our visit was that we were all able to check off Joe's Shanghai from our foodie's bucket list.

Also, we never made it to Dumpling Man while it was still opened during our trip, so I can't say which of these two restaurants' dumplings is better.
The food was good but not excellent and very pricy. The service personel seemed uninspired to say the least. There must other restaurangs in that area of Chinatown where the money is more well spent.

Good soupy dumplings. I tried both pork and the mixed pork and crab. Dough part of the dumpling was thicker than what I had at Din Tai Fung in Seattle and LA. Prefer the thinner and denser shell at Din Tai Fung.

soup dumplings are fine, scratches the itch.





*auntieknowsbest

I moved away from New York City four years ago.  I am back for a visit and went to Joe's Shanghai for the used-to-be superb crab soup dumplings.  i was shocked.  instead of the rich crab soup the dumpling contained soup that didn't even taste like crab or maybe just barely.  Was the place sold and the new owner is cutting corners?  It is a mystery to me how they could take the goldmine of a deservedly world reknown signature dish and monkey with the recipe.  I had gone there for years and will never go back.

Overall: Not really worth the hype or the wait but if you aren't willing to go to flushing, probably your best bet

Found this place on social media - its pretty popular on YouTube, Tik Tok, and Instagram so there's always a very long wait (Saturday lunch time was about 1 hour). I would say all around was not the best and did not really live up to the hype. For the soup dumplings, the inside should be soupy and broth like - here it was so heavy and oily - it tasted almost like they put vegetable oil in it. The meat inside and the outer dough was very delicious though. We also got a few veggies and dim sum platters which were hit or miss. For the price, it was pretty cheap and the review may seem harsh but I had high expectations for the place with all of the hype and the history. I will say that in Chinatown, Joes Shanghai may be the best soup dumplings you can find but it doesn't really come close to the famous/classic soup dumpling places in Flushing. For me, instead of waiting 60 minutes in line, I would just take the train 40 min to flushing. But if you aren't willing to take the trek, Joes is probably your best bet and its really not that bad considering the price point - it just could be better. Also they are cash only so bring cash!

So, came to Joe's Shanghai after many years, remembering tasty soup dumplings and having a craving after work.  Of course there was a wait, and of course there were tourists lined up outside, but we nevertheless put our names on the list.  To pass the thirty minutes, we walked around the vicinity to find a place to have a beer--an exercise in futility.  

When we were finally seated, we made light conversation with our tablemates, who were enthusiastically scarfing down their meals.  We ordered pork soup dumplings and crab soup dumplings, crispy shredded beef, and seafood with rice cakes.  My friend said that for a Shanghainese place, they sure have a lot of Szechuan options.  The soup dumplings came out fresh and piping hot, but for some reason, the pork soup was bland to me.  The crab dumplings were pretty good, the soup was tastier than the pork, but all in all, the dumplings were a bit underwhelming.  And that is only because all the rave reviews set the bar a bit too high.  They were acceptable dumplings, but not stellar.  I have had more delicious soup dumplings at dim sum in the outer boroughs.

The other two dishes were what you would expect from a take out joint.  They were pretty greasy, salty and lacking in protein.  The beef was dredged or battered, and fried, and then covered in a sticky, sweet sauce, similar to General Tso's style, which I avoid.  It was definitely junk food.  The seafood dish had a bit of seafood and was mostly rice cake.  I found the squid and shrimp pretty chewy, not very appetizing.

I won't remark on the service as many before have noted that after you wait, you're rushed in, order right away and get the check as soon as you drop your chopsticks, but that's fine with me.  They also add their service charge to your bill so you won't have to do any math, although it's just the minimum for their "bare bones" service.

If I were to return, which I don't believe I would, unless it were to the Flushing location, I would stick to the dumplings and perhaps steamed items.  But really, there are so many authentic, outstanding, no-wait places waiting to be tried that it seems silly to return.

I love the xiao long bao here but the service really kills my mood. The servers are extremely rude at times. The Joe's Shanghai in Flushing is much better! The food tastes the same, and the atmosphere is more relaxed compared to the one in Chinatown.

I was so excited to try this place after friends have raved about it.  After trying the pork and crab dumplings, I was pretty disappointed.  Maybe I just had high expectations, but with as many reviews as this place got, I expected better.  Oh well, I guess I gotta go to Shanghai one day.

Joe's Shanghai is the first place I ate in New York, and I don't know what the attraction is.  It's similar to some place I ate at in Philadelphia - the blonde wood, the menu, the lay-out, the restrooms downstairs. It looked like everyone was enjoying their food, and the servers are busy and efficient.  But the food itself just isn't that impressive.  

I've only had soup dumplings one other time, at that place in Philly, so that's my comparison. Joe's pork soup dumplings are good, but not great.  They're big, so big that you can't eat them whole, and when you bite into them, broth squirts across the table. The dough is chewy; I seem to prefer the lighter doughs.  And the broth seems a bit congealed, with lumps of something or other. I also tried a scallion pancake.  Again, it was good, but there was barely the hint of onion. Nothing worth a special trip or anything.

It's worth noting that they don't take credit cards, so you have to make sure to add up everything on the menu before ordering if you normally don't carry large amounts of cash around with you. That's a little annoying, and if you only have a twenty it might preclude something like the crab and pork dumplings.  It's nice that they give you hot tea, but odd that they give it to you in a glass instead of a cup (some ice and sweetener would turn it into some decent iced tea).  

They also add a 15% service charge to the bill, so there's no need to tip.  I don't know if that's good or bad, because I usually tip 20% and it kind of cheats the servers out of that other 5%, but it's what they do.

This might well be the best restaurant in New York's Chinatown, and the best soup dumplings in New York - I would have no clue. But next time I'll try to try somewhere else.

I went to Joe's on a Holiday Monday right at opening. I did not have to wait. Service was quick. My husband and I ordered the pork soup dumplings, sesame chicken, and beef pan fried noodles. The pork dumpling was good but not great. It needed some salt and the texture of the pork was different than I've tried. The actual dumpling was good and there was enough soup inside. The sesame chicken was crispy and sweet. The beef pan fried noodles were very good as well. The beef was not overcooked. The noodles were soft and crunchy.  

The inside was big. Some of the tables were close to each other. 

Would I come back? Maybe for different entrees but not the soup dumplings.

CASH ONLY!
Horrible service, the dumplings are good the rice sucks. No duck sauce and no fortune cookies. Servers look like they hate life.

The soup dumpling is definitely a 4 star.  However, other dishes are 2 stars.  Stick to the famous dumplings, but skip other traditional Shanghai dishes like drunken chicken (it was dry and flavorless).  If you only want the dumplings, this is a good place.  If you want the various traditional Shanghai food, this is not the place to go.

What can I say about this place that hasn't been said already?

Not much. Might as well emphasize the important points.

Waiters here are quick and efficient... they're always busy but the only long wait is to get a table cuz there's always a million people ahead of you. Once you're seated, you get your food quick. Don't let those soup dumplings sit for long... they're terrible once they get cold.

Joe's Ginger is only a few steps away, less crowded... but I like this place better. Maybe for the same reason the original 53rd and 6th halal truck is crazy popular while the one across the street is only a fraction of the wait. I mean, it's only human nature to want what you can't have.

Note that it's cash only and tip is included.

Tried this place because of the reviews. It was okay. Nothing so would come back for again though. Expect that they will seat you on a table with other people no matter how small your party is and there are smaller tables open. We were told they always full the bigger tables... 

The food was okay. If I was to recommend anything it would the the crab and pork dumpling soup. Everything else was ‚Äç

What happened Joe Shanghai? This place was delicious in the past but right now I feel like it's greasy chinese food. My crab meat soup dumplings came out cold and it's not as flavorful as it used to be. I prefer my options in Flushing now. My chicken lo mein was VERY OILY and you might as well rename it and called it veggie noodles with extra oil as a topping. I was having trouble finding the chicken pieces.

I bumpped into an old friend and decided to have lunch here but now I know to steer clear from this place next time we have a reunion.

Soup dumplings were so delicious! Wish we ordered 2 orders. Also ordered crispy pork chops and beef fried rice, both were just okay.
The workers are not so nice, a lady at our table (you sit with strangers) ordered one thing, but the waitor said she ordered another, and he wouldn't budge. He was actually very rude to her, so unprofessional and makes me not like them much.

Food is not as good as I think. Sweet and sour beef barely have meat inside. Kitchen looks hella dirty. Worst customer service ever. My brother has to drop off my family and go find a parking since it was raining. They refuse to let my family to be seated and have to wait outside in the rain until everyone is present.

It's not that amazing . It's good but same as many other soupy dumplings I've had. Prices are reasonable but the place looks very dirty. They wee very crowded they make money they should renovate the place !

Expect communal tables and a long wait. There is another Joe Shanghai in midtown that has shorter wait times. The juicy buns are good, but there are other hidden gems in Chinatown that have comparable juicy buns. The other dishes here are OK - I wouldn't recommend them.

They were great, then they were good, now they are ok/good. The customer service isn't the best, its pretty much "you get what you get" and sometimes that's hit or miss. I've begun to go elsewhere for my soup dumplings these days...

Place is $ cash only. One round of pork dumplings,  one round of crab dumplings, and a fried pancake, total of $22.15 after tax, before tip. 

Pork dumplings are no better, or worse than other dumpling houses near by, same goes for the fried pancake. We went on a Friday before closing (didn't have to wait to be seated, but me and my wife shared a table w/ others). It was pretty busy even as we left at 11pm. Typical Chinatown service.

Came here because of the great YELP reviews. However, I was very disappointed. They do not take credit cards and the food was very bland. The service was not great, nor friendly. With all the other restaurants nearby, I would definitely NOT recommend this one.

i seriously don't get why this place gets the hype. the soup dumplings are pretty flavorless compared to others in the city- even grand sichuan on st marks has better ones, or shanghai asian manor around the corner completely kills it. the only thing you can taste is the salt.

scallion pancakes are a grease soaked, flaccid mess. not crispy, not particularly scallion flavored, and doughy. 

avoid this tourist trap.

I'll try it because the store's comments are very 
good But the truth is quite the opposite. I even think the store has made a fake comment! Not only are people super many, but each table also has to dine with different guests! Can you imagine a table with four groups of customers? I don't recommend going to the restaurant very much. I don't think I'll be able to go any more.

Joe's Shanghai is over hyped!! We order their special pork dumplings and was a little disappointed the fillings has curry.  The long string was was overpriced $15!  Scallion pancakes was good with a very centered!   This place was  just OK....   Yank Sing in San Francisco got Joe's Shanghai beats by 1000%.... the BEST and delicious dim sum of all!!!
This Joe's is not as good as the one in Flushing. This one is bit greasier and definitely more cramped. Still good food but not as good as the original. Very greasy rice cakes and scallion pancakes

Okay so over the years i have definitely experienced better soup dumplings. The chinatown location is mayhem! My friend and I ended up sharing a table with two other parties and it was definitely cramped. There was barely enough room to put the food down! I was afraid that the staff will spill dumplings, sauces and anything in between on me. I was super stressed out the whole time. If you're looking for a good atmosphere to eat and talk this will not be the place. You will be eating and hustled out!

The quality of the dumplings were also not up to their usual standards. It looked as if they didn't even try to place the dumplings apart so they won't stick. Some of the dumplings were open at the top so just imagine the disappointment when you pick one up only to realize all the soup is gone!

If you're in the area for soup dumplings there are better ones around chinatown with less of a crowd and a better experience! Don't just eat here for the name it's americanized and not as good as it use to be.

Sorry Joe, our date didn't go well. Maybe I expected too much from you since you are so popular for your soup dumplings. The displayed articles about you on the store window were quite impressive. You seem to be known in Japan and even somewhere in Europe. 

BUT, after waiting 30+ min with only god knows how you count your numbers with those tickets and quite unpleasant hostess who kept saying - I heard you and your number is not up yet - several times when trying to check if my number was called - I was already wanted to go home. 

Finally we sat in a round table with a bunch of strangers, I could not locate your famous soup dumpling order in your menu. We just guessed and ordered with some sauted seasonal vegetables.

Maybe our conversation during dinner was too intense to notice your dumplings but, it was all sloppy and broken even before we picked up from the steam tray. Heh? S**t. What's the point eating broken soup dumplings? And ones that are not broken, weren't even hot enough. 
The sauted chinese bokchoy was too soggy and lifeless.

Please Joe, maybe you became too comfortable with your fame since you got too popular. I won't call it conceit, tho. But, I am afraid to tell you that I won't return your call for our next date. I found better somewhere. Good luck!

Outstanding  dumplings that has the soup inside.  Caution, very hot!!!  If you eat it like a vampire (ie...suck out the juice) then you'll have a good experience.  We got two different orders, but the crab and pork were the best.  I think this is the tasting best dish and best value at this place.  The other dishes: Fried Pork Chop and noodle dish were just okay.

NOTE:  we saw a lot of young non-Asian types.  My guess is that most of the crowd just followed the Yelp reviews just like us.  Note to self:  when you don't see a lot of old Chinese folks in a restaurant in Chinatown, best to look elsewhere.

Compare to the average Chinese food in SoCal, this place is close enough if they lower about 50% percent of the price tag. The dumpling is about average, nothing special. No where near Ding-Tai Fong as other reviewer mentioned. We waited for about 30 mins for early dinner ( 5PM). I'm not sure why new yorker can't find a better Chinese place to go, maybe it's a tourist place after all.

Stick with dumpling( steam or fired), the other dishes is below average, crispy duck is bland and  tasteless, stir fry veggie dish are way over priced, try somewhere else if you can...

After a failed attempt at dim sum (more on that in another review), we ended up here because my friend wanted dumplings and I suggested she try xiao long bao. Searched across Yelp for places with soup dumplings in Chinatown and stumbled across this place...and the line. After about 30 to 40 minutes, we were seated at a large table with 4 other parties. (It's okay though. It's New York. You're lucky you have a place to sit in a restaurant at this price range.) 

Food was better than decent and the service was great. We ordered Shanghai fried noodles (they were okay), garlic eggplant (tasty but extremely sweet), a green onion pancake (good but greasy), and she, a basket of pork XLB. They were more than accommodating when I asked for no pork in the two normally pork-laden dishes--I'm vegetarian. My friend liked this place so much, we actually repeated the trip a week later and stood in an even longer line. That said, I'm sure you can probably get better XLB and Chinese food in NYC. But until I discover that place, this will do.

First things first, this is just average soup dumpling.
I don't understand why people hype it so much, because to me, this is just a little better than the frozen soup dumpling.

I got the scallion pancake, lo mein, and 2 stacks of soup dumplings. All tasted fine, but I guess I just have high expectations for the hyped restaurants where some places meet or exceed my expectation and some place just disappoints. And this would be one of the one that didn't meet my expectation.

The xiao long bao is really the only thing you should get here, and maybe the nian gao. Definitely one of the best xiao long bao I've had, dare I say as good as ones in Shanghai? As good as that was, I was so confused by the dumplings here. The skin was so thick and chewy, and the filling was not even that good. Those were so disappointing that we didn't even finish them. I would just stick to first two and you're set.

Meh.  Struck me as tourist-trappy.  Wife and I went because of the good reviews here on Yelp.  Waited about 30 minutes on  Friday evening around 7 pm.  Super crowded, you sit wherever they can cram you in, sitting with strangers (not at all a place to go if you want to enjoy a meal with the person you came with).  Pork soup dumplings were very good.  Crispy beef entree was decent, but not worth $18.  Fried pork dumplings were really bland - tasted no ginger, and even with the accompanying sauce, very bland.  Ive hosetly had better at a Panda Express.  Overall, struck me as an overhyped place, good if you're wanting the "hey, let's go meet strangers and share a communal meal with them at a famous restaurant" experience, but otherwise, not worth the travel and the wait.

You need to be psychologically prepared before coming here, otherwise you'll have a really shitty time.
1. Food is good, although as vegans we barely have any options. 
2. You will have to wait in line for about 20 minutes. Outside.
3. The place is small, you may share a table, and although it looks like it, you're luckily not sitting on each other's lab (or someone else's).
4. The service is the RUDEST you can possibly imagine. When we asked the hostess if we can switch table she yelled several times if we were ready to order. The waiter had the nicest attitude. No, not really, unless you consider throwing the plate in front of your face a nice way of serving people.
I get it, they want you to order quick, shovel the food into your mouth, pay and leave, but man, I'm still a human being and above all a paying customer. 
5. They have the audacity to include the tip already into your bill. I don't care why, but tip is given based on good service and this was worse than a German divey bar full of old, bitter, frustrated fisherman without a job.

If anyone thinks this place has good soup dumplings is a sucker and probably a tourist.  Absolutely the worst experience.  Our soup dumplings were sloppily made, had no soup inside them, and sat on a bed of shriveled up cabbage that was so disgusting.  We got up and left.  Pile on top of that the overpriceing, the line out the door, and you have yourself a classic tourist trap.  Don't go here.

actually 3.5 

- pros: good inexpensive meal, xiao long bao with pork and shrimp were great, 
sesame pancake was good.  

- cons: servers are hectic and not careful enough.. we ordered sesame pancake, waited for 30 minutes, and figured out that the server didn't even tell to the cook in the kitchen.. and lastly, CASH ONLY even if we had more than $20.. 

Came here for Friday lunch with my friend who had studied in China for a half year.
arrived here at around 12pm and we kinda worried about a long waiting, but we could get seated as we entered inside. most of the seats are big round tables for a party of 6~8ppl, so we had to share a table with a family of 5 ppl, and another mid-aged men.

Food was nice, compared to its cheap price. But do not expect nice and careful waiters/waitresses.. some of them can't even speak english very well.

When it comes to the taste, this place is the best place for Xiaolongbao (tiny juicy bun with crab meat) in New York. If you want the best tasting xiaolongbao, go to this place.

There are a few things that will turn you down though:

1) There is a long line (sometime more than an hour)
2) Be ready to share the table with others. This is not where you can expect a cozy dining experience. Find a seat, eat, and leave.
3) Don't expect good service. Again, sit down, order, eat, pay, then leave. Don't expect anything extra.
4) Plates and utensils aren't very clean. Inspect them carefully. If you see anything, wet your napkin with hot tea to clean them.

Well, food is great here though.

I went here with my bf expecting quick, cheap Chinese food (particularly dumplings).  I was a little bummed out, overall. The place felt touristy, although there were some non-tourist looking hipsters there.  Also, no Asian diners, a sign that Chinatown locals don't necessarily eat there.

The soup dumplings were really good, although they burned my mouth.  But they were hot and tasty and fun to eat.  The meat could have been a little more flavorful, but it passed.  We also had Shanghai noodles (meh) and a scallion pancake (pretty good, not too greasy).  We didn't touch the main entr√©es, because they were overpriced for Chinese food.

Overall, go for the dumplings.  They're like $5 for 8--great deal and delicious.

Wait longer than communicated
Garbage bins being carried near tables
No English communication
Food not really nice
Poor staff - not even making an effort for service

I know that when it comes to Chinese restaurants, you come for the food not the service but we got two waiters that were just nasty and rude. To make it all worse, the food was not that great. The soup dumplings looked sad and wilted, like a ball that's lost most of it's air and when it came time to sink my teeth into them there was barely anything there. Just a small amount of filling which left me wondering, where's the soup?!?!  The scallion pancakes, which should've been a no-brainer were thick and chewy and tasteless. 

I'd go back to Joe's but only if I had to, Shanghai Cafe on Mott St is so much better!
Not as good as the hype. There are much better places for soup dumplings, especially in the last 5 years. Only tourists and nostalgia buffs should eat here.
This place is always good for the soup-filled pork dumplings. The long wait for a table and then the community table is less desirable.

I was craving xiao long bao so figured we'd goto Joe's Shanghai after our haircut appointment (right across the street).

Joe's is an established name in NYC and is well-known for its soup dumplings.  What can go wrong, right?

Well, plenty, as it turns out.

First dish -- scallion pancakes -- put us off on a bad start immediately.  The pancakes were literally SWIMMING in oil.  Now I understand you need oil to fry things but... the excessive oil was scary and disgusting.   I used my paper napkin to pat it dry but in the end we could not make ourselves finish the dish.

We each ordered a basket of the soup dumplings.  This was the real test.  After all this was what Joe's was famous for!  

Sad to report, the xiao long bao here fails miserably on ALL fronts: 1) the skin was way too thick; 2) the taste was, well, not tasty at all; and 3) they over-cooked them so every bao turned out dry and shriveled up.

Oh the service sucked too.  I don't expect good service in Chinatown but this place takes the cake for having some of the rudest waiters.

Last but not least, not a big fan of sharing tables with strangers.  The 4 Caucasians sitting across from us kept staring while we ate.  Particularly annoying as they kept commenting on how good the food is when we know it's shit.  

I just don't understand WHY folks keep insisting this is the best xiao long bao place in NYC?!?

Lesson learned.  Craving soup dumplings?  Goto "The Bao".  So much better there.

GREASY GREASY GREASY GREASY 

The only reason this spot got two stars is because of the soup dumplings, they are indeed tasty.  Besides the dumplings, we ordered the scallion pancakes, chicken with rice cakes and pork with crispy noodles.  

We were greased out after the dumplings and scallion pancakes and a few bites of the crispy noodles.  The MSG was overwhelming & it literally took 3 beers to finish the meal.  

To top it off the female host/seater was extremely rude.  However, the wait staff was extremely attentive and fast.  

Decor was drab and "chinatown dirty", meaning its only acceptable in Chinatown.  Feels almost like a tourist trap

I would only return for the soup dumplings

Came to Joe's to see what all the hype was about and honestly it didn't amaze me. Food was great, ordered two varieties of soup dumplings which came out huge and extremely tasty. However, the staff at Joe's weren't the most welcoming. My friend and I sat near the register and constantly had people bumping into us since we shared a table with strangers. Yes I understand it's extremely busy and the waiters have to cater to everyone but the constant bumping into the chairs without apologies made this review go down to three stars. They also add a service fee charge that comes with the meal so it'll be good to read your receipt carefully. Overall, great food, horrible staff.

Not really sure what the big deal is. Ridiculously long line, the food was sub-par and covered in too much sauce and MSG. Go to any of the other hole in the wall Chinese restaurants in the area. You will get a lot more bang for your buck.

Absolutely disgusting!!!! The crab / porksoup dumplings was so greasy and the ground pork they used had such a foul smell on it and no taste of crab at all,On top of that They sat me near a garbage with a little curtain that covers it that the odor that came out of it was so horrendous .I complained so they end up putting me in a communal table where they were wiping and using a stinky rug while hurriedly taking out the other people's dishes beside me almost hitting my plates.It's not like they had no other tables there were plenty in the back.Sad to see such quality go down . Ate only 1 of eight soup dumplings I was served,  I simply got grossed out.

The waiter yelled at me for a bit but I'll forgive because the dumplings were really good 6stars !! Shrimp fried rice was amazing also !! But pan fried noddles were disappointing it was very chewy in the middle. costumer service was ok. Overall 3/5
The food took too long and was not worth the wait. They did not take credit cards, which was a major inconvenience. The tables were way too packed together.

The trouble started with the front door, when they were ready to seat our party and lead us inside, but then gave the table to another group.  At that point we should have walked out, it was an absolute cluster *uck in there.  The greeting staff were absolutely confused, like chickens with their heads cut off.  They really didn't know what they were doing.  I also noticed a sign stating that 15% gratuity would be added to ALL orders (not just large parties) "for your convenience", and we figured out why before we even sat down.  Before our jackets were off our waiter comes up to us and irately asks is if we want pork bun appetizers.  I know they want to turn their tables but this was just absurd.  They were breathing down our necks so they can get another group in.  

The service was as tek s. stated in an earlier review "horrifically abysmal" which I could forgive if the food was any good.

The Shanghai buns were mediocre at best.  They had a very mass produced taste and feel to them.  Most of the issues with the dumplings is textural I suspect because they have been previously frozen.  The wrapper was thick and gummy, the filling was a bit dry and tough, and the soup was pretty good but too fatty.  A good xiaolongbao should have a thin chewy wrapper,  tender pork and a velvety soup.  The other dish we got, chicken pan fried noodles was just bizzare.  Cellophane noodles which just acted like a sponge to the noodles.  The chicken was okay but that's all.  

All this seems par for the course for this place.  I would not recommend it to anyone.  I don't understand why they get rave reviews, the Joe's in flushing is much better.

Joe's Shanghai is a huge tourist trap. Their soup dumplings are fine, but nothing to write home about except for the over an hour wait only to be crammed into a table for 4 with 2 people already sitting there and the God awful service. They bark at you to order and then pray. No thanks. There are better soup dumplings in Manhattan.

I'm Chinese and eat Shanghai food every month and I don't understand how this restaurant even get 4 stars.
The soup dumplings was horrible the meat inside is marinated with too much soy sauce. It should not taste like this!!

overrated.  

the soup dumplings are way too greasy, heavy and meaty.  want the best soup dumplings?  din tai fung in arcadia, ca (near LA).   the 2 stars are for the green onion pancake.  they're thick and fluffy.  yummy!  everything else is just like any other of the 3245t43245643 chinese restaurants out there.

Cash only.

The "prawns" dish- their signature citrus prawns were standard U12 shrimp.  They obviously have no idea what a prawn is. I do appreciate the dish came with broccoli.

The noodles were ok, didn't blow my mind but had a nice wok flavor.

The dumplings were grease filled rice paper morsels that really tasted like nothing other than grease.

Spring roll was good. $2.25 for one.

Overall damage was $50 on food that probably cost $5 to make.

I went over here during the summer with some work colleagues. You know this place has been overated on yelp when more than 50% of the patrons in a restaurant in Chinatown are white. The line was huge. We waited around 30 minutes, only to share a table with a couple of girls. 

The soup dumplings weren't anything special or that much different from Shanghai Cafe's. So if you're looking for soup dumplings, head there. God knows the line should be much shorter, and it's probably cheaper too.

IIRC, I had no complaints with the service.

TL;DR: Not worth the hype. Less than average soup dumplings and food. Make sure you bring cash, and expect at least a little bit of a wait

I have had soup dumplings several times, but every time, I was just following my group of friends/meeting at a place that other people picked. I never had a strong opinion until I had really good soup dumplings last time I was in NYC. So decided to give Joe's Shanghai a try, since it's so well known for soup dumplings/dim sum. 

Husband and I came here around 2PM on a Friday, and there was a decent amount of people waiting outside. They will give you a ticket and put your name down and come out and call when your table is ready. 

FOOD:

~Scallion Pancake (3/5): Had decent flavor and texture, but was incredibly oily and doughy. Not enough scallion spread throughout the pancake

~Hong Kong Style Hot and Sour Soup (2.5/5): More sour than hot, and very sour. Couldn't really taste anything else other than acidic flavor

~Pork Soup Dumplings (2/5): They are a decent size. At first I thought the soup was flavorful, but realized it was just incredibly salty. There is a decent amount of meat filling in it. The dumpling dough had a stale quality to it. 

Overall, the entire experience was very disappointing.
It was meh. If the line is longer than a 10 minute wait- not worth it. There are other places in the city that are worth going to if you're not a tourist (or an advanced tourist).

Joe's Shanghai makes a pretty good soup dumpling. The last time I was there, we ordered the pork soup dumplings and the crab and pork soup dumplings. The dumplings came out perfectly, each a little delicious pocket of meat and soup. 

If you're set on coming here for soup dumplings, I would go early to avoid the crowds. If you're pretty flexible, there's plenty of other shanghai restaurants right on the same block.

The crab dumplings were very good but the beef soup noodles were a bit on the spicy side. The scallion pancakes were a bit bland but the crunch factor was great. The young chow fried rice was on the salty side but the rice cakes was decent

Why's this place so well-known? Their dumplings were just disgustingly greasy.  Literally, the soup was just... grease.The filling looked and tasted like MSG-covered chorizo. It's a dumpling made of burrito drippings!

If this is what good Chinese dumplings taste like, maybe I'll stick to my crappy, American-friendly dumpings. If only Panda Express had dumplings...

This place does not deserve 4 stars.  I will never understand why people are waiting outside of this place, although that's exactly why I wanted to try it on a weekday afternoon.  Complete waste of money and room in my stomach.  We ordered cold sesame noodles and black mushrooms with bamboo shoots.  The cold sesame noodles were so disgusting, we couldn't make ourselves eat them.  If the staff hadn't seemed so rude (except for the very friendly lady at the front who finds you a table) I would have tried to talk to them about not paying for the noodles.  It was like peanut butter on top of overcooked cheap spaghetti.  They didn't taste like sesame and they didn't taste like any noodles I had before anywhere - they dissolved into a thick glue substance in my mouth.  Maybe no one orders this dish and they found a pot of cooked noodles from last week laying around.  The mushroom dish was maybe a 2 or 3 star rating, but left a strong cornstarch taste in my mouth.  They didn't ask if we wanted rice (some places include it, some don't, but they usually suggest to order rice or ask you.  Our waiter said nothing to us the entire time).  The tea tasted weird.  And they charge you a tip automatically!  They also took our money before we were ready.  I would never ever go here again, when there are SO MANY restaurants in the area and even the so-so ones are 1 million times better than Joe's Shanghai.

Joe's Shanghai = Eh!

I haven't been here in a while, and my husband never has, so I figured we go and have some much needed soup dumplings. It's been a long winter and I figured the warmth of the dumplings would be nice.

Wrong.

I know chinatown, and I know chinatown servers, but this place was just overpopulated w/ tourists and too-busy-to-help-you servers. I was overwhelmed. I'm not chinese, but I somewhat look it, so the constant bombardment of "are you readys?" was overwhelming. After trying to remember what I used to get, I just picked some random things (along w/ the pork soup dumplings) that sounded like it and was sadly disappointed. I wasn't that crazy about the flavor from the soup dumplings. My green beans were definitely the "americanized version". And everything else was just blah.

After eating everything, I actually remembered that my shanghainese bff brought me to some other places a long time ago that I actually liked better. Dummy me didn't ask him prior to my visit. Won't be back.

I'd like to open by saying that this place is definitely overrated. The fact I waited on line pretty late on a Wednesday night when Shanghai Cafe is literally blocks away was a little ridiculous...that being said....

The scallion pancake is fantastic. Crunchy on the outside, delicate on the inside with a nice charred scallion flavor. As I've come to understand, the sauce to accompany is supposed to be a slightly sweet and salty ginger sauce. The sauce in general wasn't that tasty and didn't have any ginger. I could totally be wrong though. 

The soup dumplings...the dough is too thick, but magically, too tender at the same time. The only way to not loose the broth is to let them cool down quite a bit, but then the dough gets chewy. We all know how that goes. I would also venture to say that the entire filling and the broth is made from Pig's feet, which although is super delicious and unctuous, it's very funky and overpowering. You don't taste any of the other seasoning and it takes a ton of vinegar to balance the fattines, so you end up really overpowering any delicate flavors. 

Not bad, but there are better options in the area and definitely in Flushing. (Yes I know that's an hour away)

This is the only soup dumplings place in NY I have been to, so I have nothing to compare this place to. Nonetheless, Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings are truly amazing. They are so juicy, meaty and rich in flavor! The pan fried noodles is quite good as well. 

Yet there are some complaints I have against this place. Firstly, I don't understand their mandatory 15% tip policy. Maybe it's because they get a lot of large group customers, but it's still annoying. Another thing is that they didn't fill the bottom of the dumpling case with enough cabbages the most recent time I visited, so many of the dumplings got stuck to the bottom and exploded when I tried to pick them up. Lastly, the wait can be ludicrously long, especially during weekends. There is no doubt this is one of the better places to dine at in Chinatown, but I don't think it's worth an hour long wait. For these reasons, I am withholding from giving this place more stars.

I think this place is overrated. No credit card payment, cash only! 

It was overpriced for China town and the food was average for my taste.

The water spinach was $14??? Why, water spinach is super cheep at the Asian market and grow like weeds.

The shrimps and scallops $21 were OK, nothing special.

I'm sure there are plenty of good Chinese food and way more reasonable in China town than this.

Sorry Joe!

I had high expectations for this restaurant based other's experiences.  In particular,  my companion had wonderful past experiences here so I was excited. However, my experience was a disappointing.  The quality of the was food okay as it did not taste any different than dishes at other Chinese restaurants at which I have dined. Thus, other than family style seating that works well for the restaurant, nothing set it apart as great.

The quality of the service can improve; while taking our order the waiter began a conversation with a co-worker, which I thought was rude.  In general the wait-staff seemed disinterested in the customers. Whether it is a cultural dynamic that I do not comprehend or not, the adage of when in Rome has value for any business. Later in the evening I went to the bathroom preceded by an employee.  The person was in the bathroom for quite a while and I did not hear water running for hand-washing prior to exit.

This is just my experience and I certainly do not wish to dissuade anyone from trying as it may be a wonderful for you.

Service was great which is why they got the extra star but, their reign has been going on too long and the food was terrible. 

Too salty and over priced. We had 4 dishes and not a single one was good. Add two beer and final price was $86

This place was alright. Tried it for the first time, and it was not like what I expected. Got the Lion's head, which was too sweet for my taste. The salt and pepper calamari taste good but not very crunchy. The green beans is what expected of a Chinese restaurant. The xiao long Bao was better than ones in Houston but not great. Over all, I would not go back here. It is more of a one time experience kind of thing.

3 stars.

Service people were nice (at least if you spoke Chinese), food was okay, but not that great. Reminder: this place is cash only. 

We got the Â∞èÁ±†ÂåÖ (xiao long bao) which was okay. The skin is a little thicker than usual, but they are larger size than typical.

We also got ÂõõÂ≠£Ë±ÜÁâõËÇâÁµ≤ (shredded beef and bean sprouts) which I would maybe give a 4/5. Beef was tender, beans were good. We also got ÁÇíÂπ¥Á≥ï (stir fried rice cake with beef) which was not good at all (2/5).

So overall a 3/5.

We were there yesterday because seeing the high ratings on yelp. Got there. The food is way too much oil. Xlb is ok, not much special compared to the ding tai fung in Cali or Taiwan. Service is horrible and the restaurant look dirty.

Unless you want to clog your arteries, you don't want to eat here.

Recommendations
*Don't eat here, eat at Shanghai Cafe (only a few blocks away) where the soup dumplings don't taste like lard/fat.  I felt slightly sick after eating this, and I'm CHINESE! Yes, Chinese food is suppose to be greasy, but this restaurant is definitely Americanized Chinese:/ 
*The crab soup dumplings were disgusting.  I had to try to convince my friend and myself to eat it, because we didn't want to waste food :/
*If you spill your soup in your plate you will notice that it hardens after a while, soup is NOT SUPPOSE TO HARDEN. Gross
*Shanghai noodles was probably the only redeeming item today, unfortunately :/

I am completely shocked and perplexed as to how this place has a 4 star yelp status. I thought this place must be good as the first time I tried to get in there was a crowd of people outside (both Chinese and not). I say this because being Asian, we can nip out the good from the bad. There was also a 20 minute minimum waiting time. Homie don't play that...

So I got here another time where there was no wait. Weeeeee I was execited. 

Well, Joe's is the epitome of a tourist trap. I think 5 people must've said this place was really good, and the sheep of society followed because nothing about this place was extraordinary. 

Once inside, if you're not with a large party, expect to sit at a table with a bunch of strangers. Ok, that's fine but now I guess my party and I will order less to accommodate room for other people's food at our table. Service was rushed and they never came back to check if we were good, wanted water, or were still alive at the minimum.  Total dumpling sweatshop factory. 

While I agree the soup dumplings are exceptional, as they are super juicy and flavorful, anything outside of that was mediocre to not so good (fried quail, pan fried noodles with shrimp, scallion pancakes, etc.) 

I have zero desire to come back here and sit with strangers in a cramped space to eat dumplings.

3.5 / 5.0 - Note: This place is Cash Only and a 15% Service Charge is added to your bill.

We'd been to other locations and came here for the tasty soup dumplings.
While smaller shops and bakeries in Chinatown have always been cash only, we hadn't expected this restaurant to be cash only. Fortunately, we had enough cash for an order of soup dumplings. There is also an ATM inside, although we didn't check the fees.

- SOUP DUMPLINGS
We ordered the Crab Meat with Pork Meat Soup Dumplings ($10.45+). It comes with 8 soup dumplings, which are quite large for a soup dumpling--they didn't fit in the soup ladle. They were meaty, juicy and filling, but the broth was too salty for me.

Also, the sauce barely had any ginger, which they'd brought out with the menu before we'd even ordered anything. They only gave us one, though, and never brought out another after we ordered the soup dumplings.

- SERVICE
The restaurant was not busy, since we went before noon, but the servers never came around. We had to wait to catch a server's attention across the restaurant each time to order or to pay the check. Although we would have still left a tip, we were displeased to see a 15% service charge automatically added to the bill considering the poor service.

I love soup dumplings and will continue my search for the best soup dumplings in town.

The flavor was not there for their soup dumplings. I have had many dumplings in my lifetime. The MSG here is super strong and the soup dumpling skin was too thick. They lack flavor and essence in the dumplings. Pan fried dumplings were too greasy where there is remaining grease on the plate. The skin is too thick again. 

They have more big table than small tables. So if you have 2 - 4 people party, you might have a risk of sharing a table with another small group. This takes away the privacy you want. 

If i can give zero starts, i will definitely do that.

Really liked their crab meat xlb and scallion pancake. It lives up to the hype! 

However, the only slightly negative comment I have about this place is that upon entering, I was hit with this huge smell of "stinky socks", if you could describe it like that. It was extremely unpleasant (especially by the doorway) but you get used to it once you're inside (sadly). Food is good, but just this is maybe something that could be improved. 

Due to the number of people waiting to come here, you may be asked to sit at communal tables with another party. 

It's also cash only!

wonton filling is sour,
xiaolongbao with meat clip smell,
dishes are not delicious, service
attitude is poor, tip is mandatory good.

To comment purely about the food, this place was THE BIGGEST DISAPPOINTMENT of my entire trip to New York. Not only is there so much hype surrounding this place, paired with the impossible feat of getting a table, the food DID NOT measure up to expectations to say the very least. So tread with caution....

My boyfriend and I ordered their 'famous' Xiao long bao (soup dumplings), fried salt and pepper fish, and pan fried noodle with pork and mushrooms. Firstly, the Xiao long baos were steamed over shredded cabbage which yielded a very odd flavor to the dumplings, and in part made them so soggy/ fragile that some of our dumplings bursted before we even started eating them.
