There was also not enough soup in the pieces that did survive - the filling was so so but the only thing I can lend a positive review to was the size of the Xiao long bao and the amount per order, both very good! 

The fried salt and pepper fish was SOOOOO salty, like too salty and the fish was an odd mushy consistency within the fried exterior. I've had this dish before at countless other restaurants and this was the first time I had ever felt it was too salty. 

Lastly, the pan fried noodle with pork and mushrooms was good in presentation and theory, but the flavor was just so bland and blah that I couldn't get myself to eat it after the first few bites....the noodles had the texture of styrofoam and less like a fried noodle and the sauce altogether just lacked a lot of depth - oh and the mushrooms looked like they came straight from a can. 

We wanted to love this place after so many locals and so many of my friends RAVED about it, but as a restaurant with such a huge following on social media, I expected something outstanding! I've had better Xiao long baos and Chinese food in general back home in CA! Sadly a huge waste of time.

If you're looking for authentic, no nonsense Chinese, specifically Shanghainese food, Joe's Shanghai is it.  Located on a small narrow street in Chinatown, the bustling frenziness and authenticity of this restaurant is almost unmatchable anywhere else. 

Yes, the soup dumplings are their staple dish and highly recommended -- there are two options.. the ones with crab meat and pork and the ones with solely pork.  I've never been a pork lover so I personally prefer the crab meat ones.  Just remember to drink the soup since that's where all the flava is!  Other dishes that haven't failed are the: Shanghai noodles, string beans with minced pork and the red bean dessert (forgot the name but it's wrapped with thin dough and lightly fried)  It's really a Shanghainese dessert so hard to find in other Chinese restaurants.

As for the atmosphere, what can I say?!  There aren't too many authentic Chinese joints that come with all around good service and sparkling tables so don't expect that here either.  What you will get is an offer to share a table with another party if it will move the waiting queue along quicker and food dropped on your table as soon as it comes out unceremoniously.  Well, you don't come here expecting 5 star treatment.. 

Hopefully, the buns alone will make up for it.

The bill will be inexpensive at least!

Go up the street to Joe's Ginger. 25 Pell st. most definitely better soup dumplings,  no tourist and they don't treat you like shit. I mean it is Chinatown still,  but they're nice enough. And they have beautiful saut√© Chinese broccoli!

Obviously had to stop by Joe's Shanghai when my native Shanghai family came to town! I knew this place was infamous for its long wait time (last time I came on a Sunday night and waited nearly 1.5 hours) so I made sure we went at an unusual hour - 5:30pm on a Monday, and we were seated immediately. It was so empty we even had a table to ourselves! (Usually you end up sharing a table with at least 1 other party). Be warned though, I noticed that it got rapidly more crowded the closer it got to 6pm, and by the time that we left (around 6:45 maybe) it looked like there was definitely a wait to be seated. 

We ordered the hot and sour soup, pea shoots, a cold vegetable dish, and of course, the xiao long bao! The hot and sour soup was very thick but it tasted good, nice and spicy. The pea shoots were saut√©ed with garlic and the portion was generous. The cold dish was also fine; I don't really remember anymore because I was excited about the soup dumplings finally arriving at our table! They were actually not as good as I remembered them being when I last had them (like I mentioned above, I had been waiting for a while by that point, so maybe I was just really hungry??) but they were still pretty good. The skin was thin on the bottom, which made lifting the dumplings a bit treacherous as we tried not to break the skin, but that's the way the dumpling is supposed to be made so it's fine. The tops of the dumplings were on the thicker side compared to other dumplings in the city. As for the fillings, the crab and pork one was a little fishy, and the plain pork one was okay. I think I might like Shanghai Caf√©'s xiao long bao better now that I've tried Joe's twice - either Joe's is inconsistent and the xiao long bao really was better last time, or they rely on people's hunger to color their perceptions of the food.

I was so excited about this xiao long bao, because people are talking so highly about this restaurant and everybody I met asked me to try it here. In addition to that, it has 4 stars in yelp with over than 1400 reviews. So I think it must be amazing. I went here on the weekend and the waiting line was only less than 20 minutes. It was on the weekend and lunch hour. Nice! So I ordered 2 pork and 1 pork+crab xiao long bao. 

When the orders came, I was so excited and I took the first bite with excitement. It was sooooooo disappointing. The skin of the dumpling was soooo dry, chewy, and hard. I can see the flour on top of the dumpling. I barely wanna chew the skin of the dumpling. The soup was great, but the meat was just okay. Nothing special. I don't know why people love this place so much. I still think Los Angeles' Din Dai Fung is still the best xiao long bao I ever eat.

I got very sick from eating here today so be careful.  I had dim sum, noodles, and fried dumplings and felt fine until about 6 hours later and then just started vomiting profusely several times.  I had no other food today and no alcohol.  I will never eat there again.

Not to mention that the food is indistinguishable from any other Chinese restaurant, the "20 minute wait" is actually an hour, and the only way to describe the style of the wait stuff is "bum's rush."

Argh! I double tipped. What a shady business practice. This explains why the service was so good and streamlined; dealing with a capacity crowd is no small feat for NYC.

Place is packed with customers. They seat different parties together at the large round tables. Hurray! I got seated with the easily-impressed overexcited amateur group. No coat check, my trench got stepped on a few times. 

The food was edible. Nothing impressive. I can easily think of 3 other dumpling spots in the Los Angeles SGV I'd rather eat at. 

Apparently people love the dumpling juice. Well my crab dumpling juice was fishy tasting and oozed traces of the dirty yellow "crab mustard".

I'm revoking some folks' Asian cards. A NYC Din Tai Fung would put Joe's out of business. It's not even close.

Got here on a busy Friday night and was seated next to 2 other parties which I didn't mind since I grew up in Chinatown and it was pretty normal to be sitting next to strangers. We got each of the dumplings and they all tasted OK. They all tasted about the same and I wasn't really blown away with any of these. Was't the best soup dumplings I've ever had but it was OK for what it was.

This used to be my favorite place for soup dumplings until I found Nan Xiang in Flushing (so now every weekend I'm conflicted over making the trek out to Flushing, and my desire for delicious soup dumplings). Joe's soup dumplings are still really good, the skin is really thin, the soup is flavorful. However, everything else on the menu is a wash. This place has turned into a tourist destination and the waiters/menu now caters more to western taste (and prices). Every time I go, there's always a line out the door, and you're inevitably going to have to share a table with strangers.

Errrrr, as someone having Xiao long bao for over 20 yrs , I have to say this place makes something I would never consider as Xiao long .... It's sooo big and the cover is just too thick .... Can't understand y so many ppl praised it

Honestly, this place is overhyped. Definitely NOT even worth the 30+ minutes wait. 

I ordered the pork and the crab meat soup dumplings. The pork is not that good, pretty bland and the skin is too thick. The crabmeat has better flavor, but again, the dumpling skin is way too thick. My friend said this place doesn't live up to the praise and hype. If the line is shorter, I might come and grab some crabmeat soup dumplings when I'm really craving some.

I was so excited to come back here - my last trip was around 4 or 5 years ago. Since then it seems like they moved and must have changed the soup dumpling recipe. I used to rave about these dumplings- they used to be small, delicate, and the soup inside was perfect. Todays dumplings were huge, thick wrappers, and filled with so much fat it started to make my stomach turn. Disappointed.

for those that want below par food or can be classified under the category of tourists, this is your place to go.  they are experienced with non asian speakers. also, long waits for a table equal high quality food, right? i mean come on! everyone is going there!

almost everytime i pass by this place, i see a line out the door with people holding their zagat guides waiting to get a seat during dinner time. i use to come here when i was a kid, when chinatown was less crowded, when tourists didnt even know what a soup dumpling was....

but now with shanghai cuisines popping up all over the city, there are much better places to go if youre a local. a hole in the wall usually is best.... goodluck on your search!

This was loud and crowded, but we had to leave when several members of staff crowded around our table to make fun of someone in our party who was disabled. They actually pulled friends out of the kitchen to stand near us and laugh. We had to leave. This has never happened to us in such an open and mocking way. Shame on this staff.

Poor service, we asked them for water 4 different times and it took forever! The food wasn't even good either! And to top it off they only take cash, so we had to go to the ATM and take out cash with a $3 fee, so stupid!

SERVICE CHARGE IS INCLUDED.  Their food prices are already not cheap and they started adding tips on the check and don't even tell the guests.  When I tell fellow diners next to me at a communal table who were calculating the tip amount, they wouldn't believe me at first and asked the waiter to confirm.  The waiter pretended that he doesn't understand and wouldn't give a clear answer.  After asking several times if the tip was already added on the total, he reluctantly said yes.  This is also CASH ONLY place.  They give you the check, and you look at the total and leave a few bills and they will return change without a copy of the check.  I've seen many innocent people leaving tips without knowing it's already included.  If you don't have cash, there is an ATM machine at the entrance of the restaurant and the fee is $3.5!!!
Food is good but not great.  Table is disgusting and you have to sit with random strangers if you don't have enough people in your party.  As soon as you are seated, number of wait staff will rush you to order while you browse the menu.  Why add servie charge when there is no service?  This place has become an expensive tourist trap and I am appalled by their sneaky business practice.

Good food and good prices. Crispy beef tasty. Black mushrooms and bamboo shoots would have been nicer if sliced bite-sized. All-round acceptable. Would recommend esp for small groups watching their spending money.
Horrible service. Terribly crowed. The food doesn't live up to expectation. Honestly have no idea where they got their high ratings from. I would give zero star if there's such option.

So I never make bad reviews but don't expect all the  great things you hear about Joe's Shanghai. We came for the XLB which were good but overcooked. They were all  stuck together so when we tried to get them with the tongs they opened and half the  soup came out in the dish before  before getting to our plates. But the real problem here was that the service was beyond horrible and I know not to expect great service in Chinatown but this server was the rudest. He didn't even look at us while ordering, he knocked my tea over (which is complimentary but just tastes like hot water) when he brought the food and didn't apologize, and he snapped at me when I asked a question and then when I snapped back he acted like I was the rude one and told all the rest of the staff and they all circled my table like a bunch of vultures and he got someone else to give me my check. I have never seen something so ridiculous there are other places in Chinatown with food that is just as good without the shit service. Joe's Shanghai is super overrated.

Overrated. I might be a bit too harsh on this establishment but here's why I'm rating 2-star. For a place with thousands of reviews, I'm expecting some top notch food but Joe's just doesn't deliver. Arriving at 530pm, I was in a 30-40 minute wait. Once you're inside you'll get seated at a table with other people unless your party is big enough to fill one of those big round tables. Don't really mind it though, just something you should anticipate. It's as clean as you'd expect from a "real" Chinese restaurant. I had the Xiao long nap, scallion pancake, and general tso chicken. It's decent. I'm from socal and this place is just about as good as any 3-star place you'll find here but with a long wait and less spacious. If this is the best Chinese New York has to offer then I'll be avoiding it for the rest of my time here. Also cash only, but no tip since it's included in the price. If anyone knows a better place to get Chinese food, send me a PM!
I felt kinda nasty after leaving and found the soup dumplings here to be a little on the gelatinous side. They were ok, but I'm not going back since the wait is out of hand.

Of course we came for the soup dumplings. They were pretty good. And fun to eat. 

We also tried the shanghai noodle soup, which was hearty and comforting. The broth was a little too salty for me. I actually diluted the leftovers with water the next day and that helped. 

We also tried the chicken with rice cakes and the cabbage beef and mushroom dish served with tortillas. The flavors aren't complex. Generally everything is really salty. It tastes good (in a fast food way), but not exactly rich or interesting.

Great Chinese specialty restaurant... but time is money too.

Joe's Shanghai does indeed offer some of the best tasting soup dumplings in the area. There is no doubt about it. They have the traditional pork soup dumplings and also the less often seen seafood and pork soup dumplings.

However, the waits are sometimes ridiculous. I mentioned that time is money. But more than that, I really believe that you can get great soup dumplings all over Chinatown. It doesn't necessarily have to be at Joe's Shanghai. If you're not into soup dumplings or not hoping to try them, don't even waste your time. Aside from the soup dumplings, Joe's Shanghai's menu is just okay. You can definitely find those items elsewhere in the vicinity without the wait, and they are probably just as good or better tasting.

came here because of the yelp reviews, very disappointed. this might be a good place for people who've never had real xiaolongbao or chinese food in china, but if you grew up in china eating authentic chinese food, this will more than likely become a disappointment. their xiaolongbao is not authentic, okay?! first, it breaks/falls apart when you try to pick it up no matter how much care you take--a real xiaolongbao is not supposed to do this! think sushi, would it be real sushi if everything just comes apart when you try to pick it up?!! the magic of xiaolongbao lies in the fact that you're able to taste the dumpling and the soup inside the dumpling all at once in one single bite, when a xiaolongbao falls apart and the soup and meat leak out, it's just not xiaolongbao anymore!!!! what's more, their xiaolongbao is twice as big as a real xiaolongbao--as i said before, a real xiaolongbao is supposed to be eaten in one bite so the soup doesn't leak out--it's impossible to eat their xiaolongbao in one bite unless you have an ENORMOUS mouth!! we also ordered a typical/traditional shaghainese dessert, which turned out to be a disaster! and another dish--another disaster! 
din tai fung is the place to eat authentic xiaolongbao, too bad there's only a few in LA and none in NYC!

Drove all the way to the city to try the highly rated dumplings from upstate. They were okay. Not bad, just okay. The Shanghai noodles were bland but mixed with Lions Head was pretty good. The turnip short cakes were awesome and the only reason I rated this place a 3 star.

As for me I don't like this place-- it looks like a cheap not very clean diner. We came at 1pm and had to share a circular table. I ordered my favorite orange chicken and it was not very good but not bad. The only thing that I liked was the pork dumpings. Also the restroom looked very dirty and there was a sign near the sink that said some man peed there, I think staff must do the cleaning work better. 
P.S. be careful they put the tip in a bill.
Such a disappointment....waited 40 minutes. Had so much better food. Soup dumplings literally broke apart before it even got to my spoon. Seriously I could have just ordered regular dumplings

Went here on a weekday around 2pm and the wait was only 10 minutes. Not bad for a table of 8, right? Except they sat us with 3 strangers. Didn't really bother me, but odd. I guess you gotta do what you gotta do to keep maximum business.

As far as the food is concerned, I felt that their dishes were typical of any Chinese restaurant. The only one that stood out was, of course, their soup dumplings. I was a total newbie and didn't know how to eat these, so don't be like me and stab it with a fork. The name says it all, there's soup inside. They had 2 types: pork and crab. Surprisingly, I enjoyed the pork more and they were cheaper. 

This restaurant is deep in Chinatown, which was good because if you want Chinese food, this is the place to go to. The restaurant was typical with the aquarium at the entrance and questionable bathrooms in the back. Service was average for a typical Asian restaurant. Although, if they seem like they're rushing you when they order, they are, but they do make really good recommendations to expedite the ordering process. All of the dishes were yummy. No complaints with the food.

It's chinese food... so service was very chinese, haha. The famous dumplings were good... salty like I'd expect it to be, but I don't see what the big deal is... it's good- and it's modestly priced (it is chinese food though)... and the sweet and sour soup was decent too although they put a couple different kind of mushrooms in, some of which just didnt belong (not in the magic mushroom sort of way), but in the asian cuisine kind of way. Overall it was pretty good-- warmed us up in the rain, and didn't break the bank. So go if you can... don't if you can't.

This is where you go for the fun and the experience with people who make an outing fun. The food is pretty good, the soup dumplings ARE good, very good actually if you're into them but the rest is a bit weird. I love the green bean side but most main dishes are not the best.

The three stars is for the food only.

This is a fast-paced restaurant with very minimal service.  You will need to ask for every single thing you want (water, etc.).

I go somewhat regularly (at least once a month) and I've noticed that they are pressuring their customers for bigger tips.  This is corroborated by other reviews I've read here on Yelp.  If you tip less than 20% or so, they seem to get upset.

Since I live across the street, I ordered from Joe's Shanghai. It was odd that my order was ready for pickup (in 5 mins!), even though no one else was waiting for food. It was annoying that the total was $19.50 cash. The restaurant is still adding the mandatory 25% tip (even if you pick up the order personally)! They won't be serving anyone in the dining room at 45 Bowery (new location) until the COVID-19 pandemic is over. There's no temporary al-fresco patio with tables & chairs like other restaurants have constructed.

It was even more disappointing that the "pork meat soup dumplings" ($7.95) were lukewarm, not hot. The wrapper was much thicker (poorer quality) with a much smaller amount of pork mixture. Since there was almost no soup, a spoon was unnecessary for the bland soup which might've been reabsorbed into the wrapper. The dumplings were NOT traditional Shanghai soup dumplings that we Chinese have eaten most of our lives. (2) The "pork fried dumplings" ($7.95), with the tiniest amount of meat, were also prepared poorly & NOT hot. Both dishes were very bland & mediocre! We do not recommend this new Joe's Shanghai location.

This place is way overrated and someone of a tourist trap. Want good soup dumplings? Then try Shanghai Dimsum on Elizabeth Street. Joe's tends to have a lot of oil in the "soup", and a lot less broth. Also, it is kind of weird staring at people eating these things when you're at a giant roundtable. You almost lose your appetite watching people trying to shove these things in their mouth. They are good though, just not here.

if you're looking for authentic shanghai xiao long bao DO NOT COME HERE this place is an absolute joke. I'm from California but my parents grew up in shanghai and I spent many years of my childhood flying back and forth from Asia and California. I've eaten so many delicious xiao long baos I can't even count and I really take pride in my culture and heritage. 

AUTHENTIC SOUP DUMPLING: like the name suggests, they're supposed to be small and pack a light, flavorful punch. The soup is filled with flavor and dumpling skin is thin but strong enough to hold the meat and soup. The meat is also supposed to be tender and juicy as well. That's basically my description of an authentic xiao long bao. 

SOUP DUMPLINGS HERE: incredibly subpar. Skin was way too thick, the soup was overly greasy and heavy, and the meat was too fatty. The xiao long baos came out and were basically unrecognizable. These dumplings were massive and looked nothing like what they're supposed to be. We also ordered the beef noddles and, again, were given greasy, oily, heavy food that was bland and disgusting. 

Another thing about this place that left me completely unsatisfied was the horrible service. Waited almost 30 minutes just for a class of water and was not treated the way customers should be treated. I don't understand the hype of this place at all. They do NOT serve authentic xiao long baos, there's horrible customer service, and food is subpar to say the least.

Came here twice and honestly the quality decreased and it is a tourist trap for those who have not had good dumplings before. No locals ever go here which says a lot. Service isn't good because its so busy and every one just wants to you to hurry up and leave. If you want good dumplings ask a local. If you want to be a tourist who wants mushy oily hard chewy dumplings with bad service come here.

For a city NY's size, there MUST be better dumplings elsewhere...yet other Yelpers seem to love this place. I've lived in Asia and Vancouver BC, so I know a great dumpling. But let's start at the door and  the posted "B" rating from the health dept. I overlooked it as I figured do many happy Yelp reviews couldn't be wrong. In fact, my soup spoon wasn't completely clean...ack. * Now to the dim sum: people rave about their xiao long bao. I found the dumplings had an off-balance ratio of meat to dough, and the meat was a bit loose rather than a tight ball. The flavor was nothing special. I also tried an onion-oil pancake, which was served a bit overcooked for my liking. I would not return.

This was our very first meal on our trip to New York and after a short wait (because we were willing to share a table), we were treated to a feast of classic Shanghainese dishes. Although very popular and well known, we found that the food was too oily and other than their signature dishes, there was something left to be desired. 
The dishes we ordered included: 

Xiao Long Bao - their most famous dish and for good reason. Thin skin, filled with soup and meat that was not too fatty but flavourful.

Potstickers - very good as well, nice skin and tasty meat filling. 

House Special Glazed Crispy Chicken - thinking that it would be a half chicken cut up we were surprised to see golden glazed chicken chunks that were battered and fried similar to sweet and sour pork. Served with broccoli, we were so surprised to love this dish. With white meat chunks that were not over battered in a perfectly sweet and tangy sauce, we finished the whole dish! 

Shanghai Fried Noodles with Pork - This was a nice sized portion of noodles that were stir fried with some veggies and pork strips but there was way too much oil.

Bok Choy with Mushrooms - wanting a veggie dish, we went with this classic. Nothing wrong but the sauce was too gloopy for me.

Lions head Meatballs - the least favourite dish of the night, we couldn't even finish it because although the portion was very large, the meat itself was not very good either being overworked or mixed to flour and much too fatty. Similar to the above, sauce was too gloopy.

Overall, I had high expectations for Joes Shanghai and was quite disappointed with the dishes that were not their "classics". For somewhere so popular I would have expected to be blown away but left feeling uncomfortably stuffed.

if you don't like to share round tables with other folks - don't come here
if you don't like a loud room - don't come here
if you don't like waits - don't come here
if you don't like sloppy service - don't come here
if you don't like tourists - don't come here
if you don't like greasy typical chinese - don't come here

I am asian, but came here for my first time ever having soup dumplings yesterday night.

I wouldn't crave the food ever, but I would/ will probably return with out of towners.

The Wait List:
To begin, there will be a line and it will be long, whether you are a party of 2 or 10 and there will be groups of all sizes which goes to show the popularity of Joe's. Come as a date or with your entire group of friends, they will accommodate you. Like in the Chinese restaurant episode in Seinfeld, the person taking numbers for the waiting list will say "about 5 ..10 minutes", but it will be more like 40 minutes. You will feel like you are waiting and waiting and starving, and honestly the wait is half the fun and I felt it added to the crazy anticipation and excitement of trying the best dumplings that are quoted as "better than sex" by some other Yelper. So yes, expect to wait.

The Food:
I heard about Joe's from a friend and all the articles online fameing it as the best soup dumplings in nyc and a nyc must try before you die - so i went in fully expecting mind blowing food, but for me it didn't hit the spot. The dumplings were definitely tasty and fun to eat and watch my date eat while trying not to let the soup IN the dumpling explode OUT. The crab and pork dumpling wasn't anything unexpected and I preferred the bolder taste from the just pork dumpling (which is also $2 cheaper at $5.95, if money matters to you). The soup in the dumplings were flavorful and no complaints about the raved soup dumplings, just nothing new in flavor that I haven't tried before in asian cuisine. It just tasted as I would expect. 

*Some reviews mention the ginger dipping sauce for the dumplings as amazing, but its just soy sauce, vinegar, and some shredded ginger... It was delicious, yes, but nothing unexpected.

*The Scalion pancake is tasty and greasy and crispy and everything I had hoped for. The dipping sauce savory sweet and syrupy. That dipping sauce was our favorite part of the meal.

*We wrapped the meal together with the shredded beef noodle soup, my date's choice. She said it best, "nothing special, but the beef is really good". Again, the food tasted very good, but it didn't have bold flavor that sucker punches you unexpectedly and says "who's your daddy!?" It doesn't make you wonder what is that flavor!? What is that ingredient? How can I have this everyday!?  The broth was beefy and full of flavor. Better than most soups. The beef strips were the highlight of the soup - very soft and sweet. The noodles were disappointing. Its like water noodles with no flavor.

The End:
The experience was fun (waiting in line and eating those dumpling bombs) and now I can say I have tried Joe's Shanghai. I would come back with someone that has never been before and I would say it's a great place to try. The entire meal was less than $30 for 2 orders of dumplings (16 dumplings total which is filling), scallion pancakes, and beef soup.  

We were full, but were secretly thinking out loud to each other "Wow, yesterday was so much more delicious at Prosperity Dumplings (big fried dumplings and on the real cheap)".
I think this place is totally over-hyped. I normally swear by Yelp and the reviews. The service was terrible and the food didn't make up for it. It was over salted and average. Sorry.

This place has great soup dumplings.
The moment we were seated our server asked us how many plates we will be having..
they have a peculiar way of eating so that the soup doesnt flow everywhere- you need to keep it on your soup spoon while eating it!
There was about 45 min wait on a Saturday evening around 5:30.
We were seated on a round table with a random group of people, basically thats how their seating is..
Other food was ok , not worth mentioning.
But I would def go back for their soup dumplings.

I went here today with a friend. It was a busy Sunday and we waited 10 mins for a seat. Not bad.

We had crab and pork soup dumplings. The crab dumplings were just okay. The pork dumplings taste good though. Next we had the shredded pork and tofu with jalapenos. It taste good but it's a little too spicy for me. The dumplings came with a sauce that tastes like vinegar.

They included the 15% service charge in the bill, which I'm not really crazy about. In my opinion tip should be optional according to how one likes the service. Not saying I wouldn't tip the waiter. 

Would I go back? Maybe. If I do, I would order the pork dumplings again.
Crab soup dumplings! Shanghai noodles! Green beans! This place hit the spot after a 6am kinda night. Fresh, hot, & not too greasey.

You guys, this is NYC. There are SO many places where you can have an amazing  food, great service, AND not spend a million dollars. But this is not one of those places. You walk in and the patrons are 98% out of towners. This is what we call a tourist trap. You do not have to go here "just to experience it" because Betsy from book club said it was amazing. Break the cycle and make your own choices and actually enjoy yourself instead of suffering through "an experience." 

I went here with a couple out of town friends because they heard it was really good. *sigh* I should have know. But they brought up soup dumplings. I love soup. I love dumplings. I love soup dumplings! How could this be bad?

First of all, you will wait. And if it's cold and/or precipitating, you will hate it.

The service was horrendous! From the hostess to the server, everyone was SOO rude! It was one of the worst "restaurant" experiences I've ever had. I've been in NY for over 10 years and a server for most if that time, and I was shocked at how rude they were. I always tip 20% or over (I'm usually pretty understanding if a server forgets water or to put the sauce on the side - it happens) and I wanted to leave 0 tip here. But of course THEY ADD A 15% AUTOMATIC GRATUITY or else nobody would ever leave anything.

The dumplings were just ok. I tried the pork soup dumplings and they were pretty bland (although I do tend to prefer more savory, salty broths). When I broke one open, the "meat" was pretty unidentifiable. And all of the dishes my friends and I tried were no better than a cheap take out place. And it was pretty awkward with everyone trying to talk about how good the dumplings were, but you could tell no one really thought they were worth it.

Want some good food? Try the ramen place around the corner - Bossanova. Now THEY now how to whip up a good broth. Or go to Queens and get some REALLY good soup dumplings for much cheaper (although still some short waitstaff). Look around and you'll find SOO many options that are amazing. Act like a real New Yorker and "know better."

Really, this place is not worth it. Not the money. Not the wait. Not the "experience."

Been meaning to come to this place for a fee years now; found it today with no wait so, we tried it out. Went to try their soup dumpling which has been all the rave but quite honestly, it was ok. Underwhelming if you ask me. I had the pork soup dumpling while they are a decent size, the meat is not seasoned. Also ordered kung pow chicken which was good. Didnt go crazy ordering other items as this was to try out only. 

In my opinion, the wait lines are just hype, not sure who made this place as popular as it is but it didnt meet my expectations.  Couple of things that we noticed; the person who wiped the table used a smelly towel, like the ones that sit wet for days if you know what I mean. The mens bathroom was awful. At least make it look clean, it wasn't as busy as I usually see it. Not sure I'll be back to this location,  maybe will try flushing location or go elsewhere.

It was my first time visiting nyc & I was mad excited to try this place.  Heard all the hype a couple years ago & a bunch of my friends recommended me to try this place during my trip.  Soooo that being said, I decided to make this my 1st stop & get the anticipation over with.  I was also super hungry after having been on the plane for 7 hrs & in the car for another 2 hrs.  Me & my friend get there & are told there is a 25 min wait (as expected) & are given a ticket with the number 24 on it.  Me being the starving marvin I am, I'm watching the host like a hawk as she is calling out the numbers... "20...21..22...23...25" I'm like wait, hold up she skipped us!  And my friend says, no she's prolly just looking for bigger parties, they prolly don't have 2 seaters available.  By this time we've already waited 30 minutes.  I wanna say something but my friend keeps telling me not to, that our turn will come.  After 50 minutes I'm like fawk that, I go up to the host & ask her how much longer for #24, she says "oh I called it a long time ago, u missed it."  WHAAAAAT?!?!!!  by this time I wanna friggin strangle her cuz HAIL to the no we did not miss nothin, me and friend were watching her like a hawk the whole time!  Ughhhj!!!  So anyways, she seats us within 10 min & we order the crab soup dumplings & scallion pancake.  Luckily they came out pretty fast... Unluckily they both tasted fricken WUTEVAS!  I'm dead serious.. and the bullshit wait had nothing to do with it... The wait actually should've made it taste even better.  First off, scallion pancake is wayyyy overly greasy & not Enuff scallion... My mamas Korean scallion pancakes takes a huge shit on these.  And the soup dumplings were seriously NOTHING SPECIAL.  The flavors did not explode in my mouth... The soup did yes, which i understand can blow a persons mind away (-__-) but I'm talking about taste & flavor here!  Smh.. I agree with most of the people that rated 1 or 2 stars.. it's totally overrated & a tourist trap
The wait takes forever. We waited for over an hour and the only reason we stayed was we waited for that long already so might as well stay. I'll go back and rate the food but they starved us.
Used to be a fan, but no longer. Quality has gone way down, unfortunately. Better Xia Long Lao at Emerald Kitchen and Xia Kin To.

I don't understand all these raving reviews?!! I decided to give this place a try due to all the reviews and I happened to be in the area.  

First, I took off my jacket and before I got to sit down at the table, the waiter asked me if I was ready to order!  I told him that I just got here and he said "well, you better hurry, because take long time." Wth?!

I ordered the shrimp dumplings - horrible. It tasted like pork and imitation seafood crap! I also ordered the scallion pancakes - terrible!  I make much better scallion pancakes!  They were greasy and overcooked.

I get my change back for my bill and I literally had it for less than a minute and the waiter took it while I was figuring out the tip!  I told him I was not ready and asked for it back. HORRIBLE, horrible service and the food was terrible!  I've had 10X better Chinese food at a take out!  I will definitely not be coming back.                            
Also, if the majority of the patrons are not Asian in a crowded Asian restaurant, rule of thumb - it typically isn't good.

I have been waiting to come here. I am disappointed. It's just a hype. The dumplings were not great. The food were expensive and they only take cash. It was only my husband and I and they charged a 15% service fee.  There so many other place that is better and take credit.

This review is only for Joe's shanghai in Chinatown NY...the service was even worse than the one in Flushing...they asked us to share table with 7 other ppl. There was barely room for us...also given it was so busy, the crab soup dumpling wasn't that great..the soup inside all came out and it tasted tasteless..but I still love the soup dumplings at joe' shanghai in general...next time I will go to the one in Manhattan..
The only star I given because of the soup dumplings. Other food, services are so bad.

Dim sum is ok but the dishes were just terrible. The rest foods we ordered full out of expectation. The fish head pot we need should be dry and tasty while it was served with a fish meat felt like being in the refrigerator for ages, very fishy smell and lot of soup looks like pure soybean sauce!
Other dishes we dared not even call them Chinese food. 
Service is also disappointing but surprisingly so crowded there. 

 No reason to go there again unless for dim sum only.

Over rated, dumplings were good but not great compare to other dumplings places. Noodles had no taste other than heavy soy sauce.
15% tip with no smile from the servers , hurry up and get you out ASAP.
Because the place has high rating we expected high of it. But there is not a large variety of dumplings and we didn't really liked the idea of soup in the dumplings...

I'm Chinese and i love really authentic Chinese food, this place really disappointed me. We came back to this place after many many years to check if it's still good and turns out there was not a single Chinese customer when we were there (bad sign). And we had to wait in line for more than an hour.   Ambience was bad, we had to share a table and the food did not even meet our expectations. Many many more authentic Chinese food in the city.

We walked right in on a Saturday around 11:30.  Good thing we did because the crowds kept coming immediately afterwards.

The pork XLB were so delicious.  How did they make the skin so thin yet the soup stay in?   Both my husband and myself were not fans of the crap..oops I mean crab XLB.

The green onion pancake was good...a little greasy though.  The black bean noodles tasted how they should as well but nothing special.  

The price was great for the two of us and we were full. I give it 3 stars for great XLB but okay everything else.  

(FYI: Kinda gross that the server had to check every dish to make sure it was clean before giving it to us.  He went through several dirty dishes and put it back in the "clean pile" before bringing us out the clean ones)

I was very looking forward to it, cuz it was impressive couple of years ago when I first came to NYC. 
This time, the dumplings were just OK.

I heard such amazing things about this place and their soup dumplings that when my friend finally suggested it for a small get together of friends, I was pumped. I could not have been more disappointed. 

When we got there, we were supposed to be 10 people but one could not make it. They told us after waiting 15 minutes, that we lost our reservation because everyone was not coming and that we would have to wait over an hour. I basically told them if they wanted to turn away a table of 9 hungry girls, that's their loss, not ours. We waited another 5 minutes and were finally seated with two other women. 

The soup dumplings we got had no soup and smelled funky. Every other table was happily eating them though so we just assumed we got a bad batch but weren't willing to try more. 

We constantly got yelled at by the staff who could have cared less about our table. It was impossible to get a glass of water let alone anything else. They even yelled at us for improperly using the lazy susan. 

We ordered other typical dishes which were not so great or two weeks later as I write this, I would have remembered them. The price was cheap and it was good for the amount we ate, but nothing less expensive then any other place around those parts. I really dont know what the hype is all about.

BOOO! Totally just a tourist thing to try in Chinatown. I get the feeling tourists come here simply because Joe's Shanghai is known...or perhaps even because the name Joe evokes a feeling of a more Americanized restaurant than your other selections in Chinatown. 

The attitudes of the staff here and at their other locations leaves NOTHING to be desired. Hostess told us the wait would be 20 minutes, but that the whole group had to be there first. Everyone arrived within 5 minutes...and suddenly the wait became 40 minutes. After 40 minutes, another 20 minutes. All of this from a painted, eyeliner tattooed American Born Chinese with horrible Chinese and even worse English. Please don't talk to me like I'm not from NY and am an idiot to waiting for tables. 

Honestly, I've had better soup dumplings, these taste like the defrosted frozen sort to me. Perhaps just an off day, but I'll never come back because of the service.

Their service is worst I've experienced. Went here to try their dumplings as few friends recommended. Horrible experience began as we were placing our order. The server seemed irritated by any questions and special requests coming from our family member who could not eat certain things. Also, when I walked up to a group of servers to simply ask for some plastic forks, they commented, go back to your table and call your server... wow. Why should any customer put up to this type of shitty service and be forced to pay 15% tip that is automatically added to your bill? I could careless how good their dumplings are... never going back there.
Very very greasy Chinese food. Good if you're into that. Definitely hits the spot, but not a place I'd return to unless I had an exceptional craving for their noodles.

Ok. So I love Chinese food huge fan and don't expect much at all. I was told by friends to go to this place so I went! Food was good. But the problem was that the service that they provided to me was absolutely disgusting. Food was thrown at me, waiters bumped into my chair 5+ times, I had to ask for water 3 times before we all finally got waters and they yelled at us because grandma was slow getting out of the warm car. These people have no respect nor do they know how to run a business. The food was good too and it was all destroyed by people who run the place.

Horrible place, the food is overrated and the fact that they don't do reservation is plain rude. They make people wait in the cold outside and ask you to not wait inside. Do yourself a favor and don't go there.

To be transparent this place USE to be good but the place has GONE down the DRAIN with service, food on the other hand is either ok or just salty for tourist taste bud. 
VERY tourist oriented because of the new location next to the so call hotel that is also terrible.. 
The soup dumpling is like average no difference from Trader Joe's frozen dumplings the skin is too thick and there isn't must flavors that wows you anymore, the spicy dish is really meant for American (no offense) that can't handle the spice.. The noodle are either too chewy or too soggy what's the deal can you get it right.. The fried rice is like pebbles too hard and dry.. 
Oh on the other hand I have to say if the tunnel opens
You keep an eye out for cooks and assistance smoking or take a break out there Dude is nasty sneezed on his apron then wipes his had and back to work.. if ya get sick you know why... 
I would recommend Shanghai Asian Cuisine on the other end of the tunnel that is better even Shanghai 21 on mott st. 
I will recommend Shanghai Joe if they improve serve and revisit how their food use to be, but they need to be more attentive to their works with hygiene issues.

My 2nd trip to New York as an adult and I swear I thought I haven't been here. When I walked in I realized I had.

That just means it wasn't memorable the first time around. I prefer DTF (not down to fuck, Din Tai Fung) over Joe's. It's cleaner and tastes better! 

Yes I understand New York is cramped and it's just an overall dirtier city but the quality of food is just better at DTF.

But if you live in NY I guess you really don't have a choice.

The soup dumplings are what they are, probably can find similar ones at your local dim sum place. 

The beef noodle soup wasn't as flavorful and the vegetable was just as it would be anywhere else.

Just got done eating here and they are SHADY AS FUCK!!!!! Our total bill was less than $32.50. We gave them $40 and they kept the change. We told them we want change back and they said "u said no change".... Uh, no. If I said that then I wouldn't be expecting any change would I? Dumb ass. 

They brought our change back and I guess they didn't know I understand Chinese so they started talking shit about us. Also, the change they brought back was $3 less than what they owed us. They definitely didn't deserve the 25% tip they stole from us.

Food is ok. Service is so bad and waiters need to learn how to speak English. Any English. 

Shady ass people. Will not come back. My advice would be bring small cash ($1 or $5) if you decide to give it a try. Don't expect them to give you your change back.

Wow totally disappointed.  After Yelping the best Chinese in Chinatown, this place came highly rated. When we arrived at 4pm there was already an 45 minute wait.  We thought that was a good sign.  Found the dumplings bland.  Pork, flavor non-existant.   Crab, only taste crab no subtlety of flavor.  Ordered the braised pork shoulder, was hoping for Shanghai Pork Chops, did not see them on the menu.  Before me was placed an uncarved, non trimmed monstrosity on a bed of Spinach and brown sauce.  After trimming off the inch of fat there was maybe a serving and a half of eatable pork.  Spinach and brown Sauce were good.  Orange beef was decent.  Spicy green beans were bland no seasoning.  Should have known as the number of Ethnic Chinese eating there were vastly outnumbered by the Tourists (including myself).

Personally, I was a bit disappointed making the trek out here from upper east side.

We got the crab and the pork. I preferred the pork. The crab honestly left me feeling a bit sick. 

Scallions pancake wasn't bad though.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here.

I've  avoided this place for the past couple of years because I thought it was a tourist trap. Finally came here today and it wasn't that bad and no lines. The soup dumplings are pretty good. What I like best about them is that they have more meat compared to the other soup dumplings I've had in china town.

i can see how you might say this place is good. 

joe's serves its share of yummy food, from the xiao long bao (or i guess they like to call it soup dumplings) to the cong you bing (scallion pancake) to the chao nian gao (uhh.. shanghai-style fried rice cakes? i think that's what it translates into). these are three of the most classic shanghainese dishes to order, and they pull it off without a hitch here. i especially like how their xiao long bao places more emphasis on the soup rather than the dough wrapping. 

however, places like this are a dime a dozen, especially in densely-populated areas of asian restaurants. and paired with the ridiculous wait times, i just can't justify coming here twice. not when there's just as good nearby or out in flushing (where the original joe's is located). the only reason i would come back again is to try the shi zi tou (lion's head), which i didn't have the space to try last time.

prices are competitive here, and for the portion sizes, you probably won't find a better deal. although it's cheap, remember to bring cash because that's all they accept here.

you also have a CLEAR advantage here if you speak chinese. the hostess is nicer and more helpful, and the waiters are much more attentive. this is a plus for me, but i know it's rude to other people and service technically shouldn't be biased like this (except we all know that chinese restaurants have notoriously bad service).
Remember it's cash only guys! Definitely like their XLBs but it was a little different this time. hopefully it's just a one time thing.

I just wasn't that impressed. The soup dumplings are tasty and affordable (8 for $7), but they are too big for the spoon and ours stuck to the bottom of the steamer, half of them cracking open on the way to our mouths and losing soup. Not cool. The cold sesame noodles tasted like pasta and peanut butter (not in a great way) and lacked crispness. The chicken in the chicken noodle soup was very tender and tasty but the soup itself was funky (in a 'Am I going to get sick from this?' kind of way.  Everyone has a bad day in their restaurant, but for me I'm not going back.

Overrated.  Definitely NOT the best dumpling I've ever had. 

Located in Chinatown and was not surprised at all walking into a busy restaurant, but the waiter walked us all the way to the back and had us sit next to a couple...at the same table!  WTF? I mean, I guess I shouldn't be so surprised since this IS Chinatown.

Ordered the steamed pork dumplings right when we sat down, since we knew these were going to take awhile.  Everything else on the menu seemed regular and nothing in particular stood out to us, so we just ordered veggies and a plate of Shanghai noodles. 

Dumplings finally came out, and yes, they were big!  I noticed the soup inside looked a little brown, so when I took my first bite, all the soup came out and I got to see that they had marinated the meat with some soy sauce or something that made the soup look much darker than usual.  I must admit, these were the juiciest dumplings I've had so far because they had a LOT of soup.  However, it wasn't the taste I was looking for.  I usually like the simple soup, straight from the pork flavor. I wasn't impressed at all and only ate 2.   Noodles came out really bland and wasn't much tastier than the ones I usually have back home.  Disappointed.   

I don't think this was what I expected to eat when I flew all the way here from SF.  I wouldn't say I had a bad experience here, but definitely would not come back again if I was visiting.  This is the kind of restaurant where I would come once in awhile IF I was living in NY.

The food overall was very good. Especially the sesame chicken and Lo-Mein. However, they did not have a very descriptive menu. The hot sour soup had broiled shrimp in it and it did not say it on menu. Also the seating hostess was quite rude and snapped at us bc we did not move fast enough to our table.

Came here on our NYC trip because of glowing popularity and reviews (some claimed it is the best in NYC). However we were pretty meh :/ 

At least we came here early so that we don't need to wait, so it wasn't like we wasted time waiting. We ordered dumplings and scallion pancakes, as none other dishes interest us. Both were good, at least not too salty (which I was expecting), but didn't wow us. The dumplings were huge?!?!? The scallion pancakes were fried and crispy. 

I seriously had better, but what prompted me to visit was because I thought NYC doesn't lack good Chinese food, so it must be legit? However it really is just ok. If you are in the area, craving for dumplings, there is no line and you have cash, come. Otherwise, there's a million more things to eat in NYC. 

Not to mention the decor, wow so old school and 20 years ago? Maybe that's what attracts people and add to the "authenticity", but still very meh to me lol

Everyone comes for the soup dumplings and they were better than average, though I did find the dough too chewy.

Service was fast, the place is small. I actually much rather the Flushing or the Midtown location than here. Also, too many tourists.

Omg the worst Chinese we have had since the Pandemic!! Seriously inedible!  The only thing I ate was the lomein! The beef with scallions has 0 flavor and tasted like dishwater. The dumplings were so doughy we couldn't find the filling. The crispy chicken was dry and flavorless!! We threw it all out and had peanut butter and jelly sandwiches along with the boring but edible lomein

Was in Chinatown for a friends wedding and first thing in the morning we booked it down to Joe's shanghai because my bf, who is a fan of YouTube food channels, saw that this the the place to go for Xiao Long Bao or soup dumplings! 

We arrived right as they were opening and there was already a small gathering of people waiting outside. We quickly made it in though and secured 3 seats at a communal table which we would later share with another sweet couple and a man solo dining. It was a little awkward at first, but we quickly talked and became friends with our new dining buddies! Ofc, don't feel pressured to socialize with your table mates, I saw plenty of other communal tables just minding their own business and enjoying their food quietly! Within 5-10 minutes, the restaurant was PACKED and a line was quickly forming out the door. We got lucky! 

We ordered two baskets of the pork soup dumplings, and I got the pan fried crispy noodles with beef and mixed veggies. My bf and friend each got some kind of beef noodle soup. The soup dumplings came out steaming and fresh and looked so beautifully authentic in the bamboo baskets. Usually, people eat them by super carefully lifting them and placing them on a spoon. Then you nibble a small hole on the side and suck out some soup. Then you one shot that whole thing and let the rest of the delicious soup and pork explode in your mouth! The soup was soooo decadent and flavorful it was almost overwhelming. Definitely on the heavier side, but so delicious. The pork was seasoned well and complemented the soup perfectly. After my 4th dumpling, I was already feeling weighted down haha! They pack a punch! 

My fried noodle dish was pretty good as well! The sauce was my favorite part! So delicious with mostly savory flavors and a hint of sweetness! The beef was very tender and pretty good quality as well. As for my bf and friends noodle soups, they said it was just alright. It wasn't that great or anything. They ended up just killing those dumplings and getting full off of that. 

The other sad thing was that the dumpling skins would get stuck to each other or on the bottom of the basket and when you go to grab it, it would rip. All that beautiful soup would come spilling out in the basket *CRIES*. If it was one, I'd be ok with it, but this happened to like 5 or 6 of the dumplings and just shows that the careful artistry in constructing the skins and making sure they don't stick to the bottom wasn't there. A little sad all that soup was wasted:/

The service is kind of abrupt and curt, but they are fast and get the job done. Their English seems quite limited so I don't mind the one word responses. 

Overall, I think I would come back just for the dumplings. Their other dishes are great, but you can get those anywhere else. I saw stuff like Kung Pao and general tsos chicken. I liked how they had a wall with photos of all the celebs that came to eat there! Definitely give this place a try if you can beat those lines!

Definitely something we would try again.  If I were rating the Soup Dumplings on their own merit, 3535 stars!!!

However, I'm not.  I have to review this restaurant as a whole experience.  

Obviously it's a local favorite since the Chinese barber across the street told us to go there...or maybe he was just being lazy.

We were not overly impressed with the other dishes we had and although we did talk to everyone at our round table...I didn't really like the round table.  I felt very crammed in, elbowing people I didn't know...and feeling bad that my tea pot was invading there table space.

We had a sour cabbage and pork noodle soup that was good and a Jalepeno Pork and Squid stir fry that was not very good...too salty.
Not the best cleanoiness.  The only good thing on menu was king pao chicken. Over priced. Wouldn't return. Rude staff.
Nothing special, the soup dumplings were a bit soggy.

Might have been good once upon a time, but now it's just a tourist place. The xlb was freakishly huge. 

FYI I'm a xlb snob. I traveled to Shanghai just to eat xlb, and omg it's amazing there. I know there's no way joe can compare, it's Shanghai. But even San Francisco is WAY better.

There is a formula for this place. If you want to get soup dumplings, great! Just order tons and tons of soup dumplings.

Do not get distracted by the many other things on the menu because you will be disappointed. We came here and got - hot/sour soup, mapo tofu, pork shoulder and clams in black bean sauce.

He wandered away from the "plan" and proceeded to curse ourselves on the way home. Again, just get TONS and TONS of soup dumplings.

Imagine the soul-crushing disappointment when you bite into a delectable xiao long bao, only to discover that all the soup has leaked out. This happened to at least HALF of our soup dumplings, even before we touched them. The first one I picked up had a hole in the bottom and I quickly ate it to salvage what soup was left. We were not so fortunate with the others, which were also broken and had leaked all of the soup by the time we got to them. I guess we should just count ourselves lucky that we had three that were actually intact.

If we hadn't been so unfortunate, I would have rated Joe's Shanghai higher. However, the xiao long bao is the main draw here! You should at least get that right.

Very busy...we arrived around noon on a Sunday and were seated right away at a round table with two other parties. It appears to be all communal seating...not sure what the seating situation is during less busy times...if there are any!!!
Plenty of wait staff but there is a sense of rush the whole time! Unfortunately I hadn't studied the menu beforehand and was disappointed that none of the soup dumplings were vegetarian. I felt the need to make a fast decision so I chose vegetable lo-mein!!! There was nothing wrong with it. I was just hoping to try something more interesting but I felt the waiter had no interest in making suggestions or helping me find a meatless option. They are interested in serving you as quickly as possible and getting you out of there. My son did try the pork soup dumplings and said they were delicious. Cash only and they add the gratuity regardless of the size of the party! My personal experience was just ok!

I do love their soup dumplings, but the rest of the food, e.g. the scallion pancakes, is oily and about the quality you'd get at another decent Chinese place nearby. The food is cheap, the service is fast and efficient. The community seating can be a bit disorienting, the cash-only policy annoying, and the wait time ridiculous. All in all, there are better places to go - try Xi'an Famous Foods around the corner, followed by dessert at Chinatown Ice Cream Factory.

It doesn't  even deserve an one star. Worst place I ever been to. They charge you a 15% service for being mean and rude. I heard everyone said this is a must go place when you visit NY Chinatown for dumplings "Xiao long bao". The dumplings is just average. I had better. It's not worth it unless you want to be treated like dirt. Talked to the manager and she said oh cash only. WTH.

The food is really, really good. 
The pork soup dumplings are amazing.
You will have to wait a longggg time.

All that said: IF YOU TRY TO EAT HERE WITH YOUR SERVICE DOG, prepare for a battle. 

Nobody working here or managing this place knows anything about service dog laws. I know most people don't, but this is a super popular restaurant in New York City. A lot of people with service dogs live and visit here. They really could do better.

There is no such thing as licensing or registration for service dogs. There is no service dog registry. There are no such things as official service dog IDs. Any service dog ID anyone in the US has is a prop bought online. While some legit handlers do buy them for situations exactly like this, it's literally not a thing. Despite explaining this to a manager and 3 different hostesses, and literally pulling up the US Dept of Justice's ADA website FAQ on service dogs, they were attempting to refuse access. Meanwhile, my dog is sitting quietly at my side throughout this whole ordeal. It was only after putting up a great deal of an argument and being asked to show them documentation from my DOCTOR that they asked for (ILLEGAL) that they let my party in, after telling us they would seat us far away from other customers (not a problem for me, but also illegal to segregate SD handlers in public spaces). My SD laid down under my chair for the entire meal and I don't think a single patron nor our waiter noticed him till we left. Was super frustrating and I was just lucky I had it in me to put up a fight that day or I wouldn't have eaten there.

Apparently Joe's Shanghai has the best soup dumplings here. Maybe I'm a bit of a snob when it comes to soup dumplings, but these do not hold a candle to the soup dumplings I had out in San Francisco. The skins on the dumplings here are too thick, and the dumplings are too large. I like my dumplings smaller, closer to bite size, which is how they do them out west. Heck, I wouldn't even say these are the best soup dumplings in New York; the ones at Shanghai Cafe are better. The main reason I really am not a fan of the soup dumplings is that more than half of the ones I ordered with my girlfriend had little to no soup in them at all. If I wanted to order regular pork dumplings, I would've ordered it off the menu...but to say the least, it's a bit underwhelming. The dumplings that make it out intact are pretty good, but those are relatively few and far between.

The rest of the food is pretty good; the moo shu pork is delicious, along with the clams in black bean sauce. It's a bit hard to enjoy the food if you go at peak hours, though; as it's a tourist hot spot, the restaurant gets packed, and when you're crowded around a group table, it's not a terribly enjoyable culinary experience. The service is lackluster by Chinatown standards; it took us a good 15 minutes or so for them to serve up our round of soup dumplings...at 10 PM at night when there were quite a few empty spots in the restaurant. All in all, Joe's is a decent restaurant, but it's a bit overrated in my book. Don't forget to bring cash either - they don't accept credit cards.

I took my family here tonight. I'm a New Yorker and they were visiting from Florida. Worst experience at a restaurant in my life.
Let me first say we are fairly easy going group just looking for some good food. 

It began with the hostess being extremely aggressive and accusatory. 

I told her there were seven in my party and my grandmother was waiting in the car since it was 32 degrees outside. And there was no space to wait inside. She kept questioning if my entire party was there. After waiting an hour... our table was finally ready but the hostess refused to seat us because my grandmother was getting out of the car. After one minute she continued threatening to give our table away. 

It was so uncomfortable the sole reason I did not walk out was because we were starving and had already waiting so long...

The entire experience was a complete disaster. The food was good but the service was constantly scouting and knocking into us and over things the entire time. The food wasn't good enough to ever have to deal with all that again..

I literally just began saying hello hello and TWO waiters walked by me with no response.

With that sad, unless you are the most patient person in the world I would skip this hell whole and order seamless.
Not a traditional Chinese, the restaurant cooked more like American ways.  You can see not many chinese people in the restaurant.  Kinda disappointed and don't think I will return again.

I was so so excited to finally get to try this Michelin rated Shanghai dumpling spot that people have been raving about for years!  Sadly, it didn't blow my mind away. Luckily I came at an off about on a weekday around 3:30 pm so there was no crazy lines outside so I had no wait time.  The inside is nothing special, it's your typical Chinese restaurant atmosphere....loud and a lot going on.  

I only wanted to try their famous soup dumplings so I ordered one set.  They came out very quickly and were huge.  I've never seen these types of dumplings so big.  The filling and soup were just ok, what I didn't like was the outside skin.  It was so thick and doughy almost bread like....not delicate at all.  Sadly, it did NOT hit the mark for me.  Maybe it was an off day or this place is just overrated.

The place is CASH ONLY!   Unfortunately, these did NOT blow my mind away like I was hoping for after all these high reviews.
Go there for the steamed mini soup buns, but stay for nothing else.  For true, edible Shanghai fare, there are a couple other places in chinatown I would recommend over this place.

Not so much. 
Been here 3,4-5 times. WHY?
Not so much. 
Too many other FANTASTIC choices. 
You just can't rest on your laurels and depend on your previous success in this biz. Thumbs DOWN.

Am I missing something. How does this place have so many good reviews. I only came here to try their "famous" xiao long bao and ended up with giant hockey pucks. The XLB was soo big it didn't even fit in the soup spoons. And the dough was so thick we would only drink the soup and eat the meat inside.

This review is for the Chinatown location - a cramped, poorly maintained, over-hyped and over-priced restaurant serving, at best, average Shanghainese food.  It is a chaotic waiting experience (go inside to get a number!), and once seated, unless you are a party of 5-6 or more, you will likely be seated at a table with another party.  It was kind of cool, but unexpected. The service is just awful. There is no other way to fairly or accurately characterize it.  The waitstaff is all men, and our assigned waiter was dismissive, rude and unhelpful, to put it politely.  He forgot our daughter's food, and we had to ask TWO other waiters to bring us rice to accompany our dishes. 

We ordered the mixed pork/crab xiao long bao.  They were delicious and by far the highlight of a mediocre meal.  The eggplant in garlic sauce was greasy and had little flavor to it.  The pan-fried Shanghai noodles, despite having spinach mixed in, was bland and greasy.  The final dish was the General Tso's chicken (their spelling, not mine) and that was served hot, had decent flavor and was not overly sauced.  The broccoli that was supposed to be in the dish was served cold on the side.

The waitstaff has NO incentive to provide good service.  There is a mandatory 18% tip added to your bill.  So, whether they serve you well, or not, is irrelevant because they still get a nice tip.  In no other universe, would service this bad get anything close to 18%.  I suspect that may be why they instituted the mandatory service fee.

There are other places in NYC to get delicious xiao long bao served in a clean restaurant with good service. You would be wise to explore the alternatives. We will not be returning.

PS: We witnessed them "clean" the tables by dumping tea from either the kettle or used teacups onto the table and wiping them down.  Given that I had drank out of my teacup (my lipstick was visible on the side), it meant they cleaned the table with used tea!  Really?!

I've been coming to this Joe's for I can't believe it 18 years I was part of the brave crew that discovered this place and I have brought countless people here. Well today was my last visit. After dutifully waiting an hour longest wait ever I walked up to the door hostess and she the wait would be 45 more minutes unless I pay $20. Ugh!!! I would have been happy to pay for a table when I got there before waiting, but now I've got a kid and a couple of seniors waiting isn't an option any longer so we needed to sit so I paid ten dollars got a table and had a very late lunch. But as a result will never return. And I will now share this story with the Hundred people I shared this place with.

I was coming here with high expectations that I would be getting close to the best xiao long bao in the US.  I ended up very disappointed.   Their xia long bao may be very authentic, but if that is the case, I don't like authentic.  This place is worth trying out at least once, but I won't be back.

I thought the dumplings had plenty of soup inside.  However, I thought the soup and meat filling were greasy and had too much fat.   The meat in the dumpling was also fatty enough and/or finely ground enough that I found the filling mushy.  I would prefer a thinner broth with a leaner meat filling.

I came at 11AM which is right around opening time on a Saturday.   There was no wait at the time, but the place quickly filled up after and there is table sharing.

One of the worst food experiences I've ever had , not just in NYC, but in general.  We were one of the first tables to get seated and get our orders in.  We ordered the spicy Szechuan beef dish and an order of their popular crab meat and pork soup dumpling.  It is absolutely unacceptable that our food came to us an hour later, way long after other patrons who got seated 20 minutes after us and have received their orders!  I wouldn't have felt so mad if the food was actually good.  The beef dish was so oily and had no flavor.  I almost threw up instantly after the first bite.  Let's move onto the dumplings.  I cannot believe people rave about them.  They were crappy at best and I would consider that a compliment.  I've tasted frozen dumpling samples from Hmart that were better.  The service was just as good as their beef dish, nausea inducing.  If you are looking to be severely disappointed in food and wish to get diarrhea for the rest of your day than I invite you to go to Joe's Shanghai!  I should have known better than to come here once I saw their B rating for sanitation.  Bubble guts here I come!

I went to New York with some friends and they highly recommended the soup dumplings at this place.  

We waited for about an hour before we got seated which I didn't mind too much since...well...we were in New York...there was a lot to see around the restaurant that the time just went by.  The restaurant is really crowded though and there isn't a lot of room for the waiters to get around the table.  You also get seated with random strangers.  If this place is so popular why not invest in a bigger location?So far...not so great but tolerable.  

I'm used to getting served water and having it refilled periodically but the waiter never bothered after he served it to us the first time.  It was hard to get his attention because a) the restaurant is super busy and b) the restaurant is extremely crowded and there was probably no room for him to even serve water that often.  He wasn't very attentive (-1).  

I got the soup dumplings since I had never tried those before.  They come out in a wooden (bamboo?) steaming basket so your dumplings can stay fresh.  The dumplings were large and plentiful (great price too).  Tried it.  Ummm...where is the flavor?  It was so bland!  THIS is what people were crazy about?!  I'm sorry I guess it's the Indian in me and I appreciate savory foods.  The broth they used tasted like cheap canned broth (I'm sure it wasn't but that's exactly what it tasted like).  Further more, the meat inside was also very bland and very SMALL...in that entire large dumpling the amount of meat inside was the size of the tip of your thumb.  I realize there needs to be room for the soup inside the dumpling but I mean...come on.  I had to put a butt load of that red garlic chili sauce they had at the table just to kick up the flavor.  I was extremely disappointed (-1).  

One of my friends is a vegetarian and she got some sort of veggie pancake that was actually a lot more flavorful.  Another friend got the lo mein with steak and I have to say that was the best lo mein I have ever had.  

Other than that, I don't plan on coming back to this restaurant for the soup dumplings but would come back for something else.  However, the quality of their claim to fame (the soup dumplings) needs to justify the ridiculous wait time...but it didn't.  Lame.

This place is way too packed and way too popular. Most of their customers are white so I don't mean to be racist or prejudice in any way but the food was very "americanized." My group of friends and I stayed in Manhattan by time square so it was quite the distance to get to China town. We were expecting some authentic chinese food. 

 Right when we showed up the lady host said "our party was too big and told us to wait 30 minutes." Cool, it's chinatown so lets do some sight-seeing. We walked around and when we came back, 30 minutes later, she said I cannot seat you guys until you're whole party is here. Mind you that the dining area is about 1000 square feet and I have a party of 14. We aren't just going to come into the restaurant and stand around until you have a table ready for us. So the stand-off began. Half of my party was standing in the door way and the other half was standing outside. The host finally took our word for it and gave us 2 tables. The tables are really cramped and each one can fit only 6 comfortably; we had 14. 

 Onto the food: it was pretty decent. Just very americanized. If you are wearing a white shirt or an expensive shirt i advise you to eat the dumplings VERY CAREFULLY. Once you bite into one of their dumplings the juices will squirt everywhere. Their calamari could use some better battering(it was way too light and bland) and no honey walnut shrimp?!?! I substituted it with salty pepper shrimp and they actually clean the spines out for you here which is really impressive. And our flounder was cut up and deboned for us without asking. The tables aren't so big either so we got our courses 2 entrees at a time. Nevertheless we were stuffed and content with our food choice.

I only got the soup dumplings but I thought they were only okay. They definitely held up during delivery which is key. The dumplings are big, they give you 8, and the skin is nice and thing. However, the soup inside is kind of weird - it's super thick and sticky, almost as if they pulled the fat off the top of a broth and stuck it in the dumpling. The flavor also isn't that impressive. Overall, I've had better but these were a decent option for takeout soup dumplings.

We had 7 adults and 2 babies and were waiting for our turn. We waited an hr for the table when the host brought us inside to finally sit when she said I didn't realize you have 2 babies. We said we told you we did. We then waited another 30 min for her to find us a table and when she came out again she said oh another party was here and they have 9 people. They told us the other party didn't show when they were called so after 2 hrs we finally were brought inside. Now they said we have to wait another hr since the other party finally showed? Our babies were hungry and after 3 hrs of waiting all we got from the restaurant was a shssss ... very disappointed, staff is very unprofessional and disrespectful. We are never coming back.  It does not matter how good your food is, it is as bad a shit if your staff and service is the worse.

Yeah, not a big fan. Though I have nothing really against Joe's and their food or service, I just find them to be a commercial story more than an interesting place to dine where NYC offers real indie Asian restaurant that were the inspiration for this place. Two stars for boring and unoriginal. Go to Shun Lee or hit some China Town unique spots in Yelp

Joe's Shanghai isn't that special and their soup dumplings are good at best but normally OK only. I've tried a good portion of their menu, as my friend loves to take me here, and there's nothing special about it though you maybe surprise by a dish or two. For the most part we just stick with the soup dumpling and other items from the appetizer section and maybe the almond tofu dessert. It's quite crowded most of the time, especially at night, and if you come with a big group they won't seat you until everyone is here. If you come with a few people you may also get stuck being seated with other people on a big table. If you like waiting for a table, being seated in a crowded area and eating mediocre food then this place is for you.

The first thing that irked me about this restaurant is that they sit you with strangers at the same table.  At a 10 person round table, they sat 4 different parties.  I've seen this before at Asian restaurants, but it made me a little uncomfortable eating across from a total stranger who kept glancing over at me.

As for the food, it was a good bang for you buck.  The food is very unique, and I recommend people try it at least once.  I thought the food was decent, but not a place I would want to frequent often...

I'm really not sure what the hype is about. This place is mediocre, at best.

We went to the Chinatown location and were excited to try their famous xiao long bao (soup dumplings) only to be disappointed. The xlb's are a bit too big (making them unwieldy to eat), have too much skin, and the pork filling lacked flavor. We tried other dishes that were also nothing to write home about including the beef tendon noodle soup, scallion pancakes, yang chow fried rice, saut√©ed green beans, and general tso's chicken. 

Because we're talking about soup dumplings it has to be said... I'll take Din Tai Fung (the gold standard for XLBs, IMHO) any day over Joe's Shanghai. Period. (Unfortunately Din Tai Fung is not yet in NYC).

Probably one of the most over rated restaurants. Xiao long bao is ok - nothing spectacular. The rest of food is probably Panda Express grade. Ambience is pretty terrible and they don't take credit cards.

The soup dumplings here are overrated because they are not very good especially when compared to Nan Xiang Dumpling House's. The soup in the dumpling was thick and gooey and the skin was too thick.
