I ordered the ones with crab and they did not have the usual crab flavor that you would expect - very disappointing! The seafood pan fried noodles were even worse because they didn't even use the right kind of noodles - the thin yellow ones that are very crispy when fried. Instead, they used these thick whitish noodles that tasted so bad that we didn't even want to finish them. I don't understand why this restaurant is so popular. I went for lunch on a weekday but it was still very crowded.

Highly overrated in my opinion. I brought a friend here and talked it up so much based on the Yelp reviews and was pretty embarrassed afterwards.

The soup dumplings are not bad here, but I've tasted ding tai fung and it hands down has this place completely beat. In terms of other establishments in the vicinity, Shanghai Cafe had better soup dumplings in my opinion. 

Their dumplings here was a good bang for your dollar, but the meat didn't seem tightly packed together so had this sort of crumbly texture like it was shredding apart when I was eating it. Plus the soup had an odd sweet flavour note to it which I feel did not go well with the meat. I'm more of a salty and savoury kind of girl.

Not tragic but seriously overhyped, there's a better option so close by! Would never return here for that reason.

Everyone talks so highly of this place and I had to check it out for myself.  I kept an open mind and tried not to compare it to the dumplings I've tried back in LA (Ding Tai Fung). 

The dumplings is what you expect it to be, full of soup in each and everyone of them.  I found the soup inside the dumpling to be lacking, it doesn't have the intensity and richness that should compel you drink it up.

I found this place good to try once due to the high recommendations, but that's it.

This place is SUPER hyped up. So many features on different "must eat lists" but i was quite confused because I thought it was very average...

Overall, good soup dumplings. I'd just order a bunch of those and maybe a veggie dish (we got eggplant, which was very good). The other dishes are average, and you probably can skip. I'm sure you can find better noodle dishes in Chinatown.
Meh. The soup dumplings were fine, but the noodle soup was a bowl of flavorless grease, what I imagine dishwater tastes like after soaking a stewpot all night.

i dont know if most of the reviewers here have ever actually had an XLB from taiwan/china/HK before, but im guessing no because everyone rates this place so highly.  

the food here sucks.  the XLB is the only thing really worth ordering, assuming you can even stomach it.  is it better than not having XLB?  i guess some is better than none.  so go ahead and come here if you really desperate for XLB.

come to los angeles, and you;ll find better at over a dozen places.  but once youve tasted the stuff from the motherland, its just hard to stomach this place.  ive had it each time ive come to NY, and i keep walking out the door feeling like i wasted a meal opportunity.

We ordered the xiaolongbao (both regular pork and crab), a scallion pancake, the cold beef appetizer and the beef with scallion. 

The xiaolongbao have thin skins that are prone to tearing. Some didn't have very much soup in them. The flavor was reasonable, but they don't compare to Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao in Flushing. The cold beef dish was pretty good.

The other two dishes were even less exciting. The pancake is very thick, so the crispy outer layer gets lost in a mushy center. The beef with scallion is your typical Chinese family style meat dish; no reason to come here for it.

The atmosphere is certainly an experience. Probably something you only want to experience once though. Sharing a table is slightly awkward, especially when both parties have too many dishes to fit on the table.

It's overhyped, but it's an okay option if you're in the area and don't want to trek over to Flushing.

Came here today and it was just alright. Our waiter was speaking to us in multiple languages (english, mandarin and cantonese) a little bit of everything. Which got me confused on what language to respond with. We ordered the cold appetizer, squid which tasted bland as if it was bought from the supermarket in little pouches. We also ordered, 2 orders of crab and pork soup dumplings. In one of the dumplings, it still had pieces of shrimp/crab shell in it. The wrapping was a little thick for my taste. There were a lot of waiters but very unorganized on who takes care of which tables. Decor was nice, clean, bright and new. 

The BEST part yet, they automatically charge you "service fee" of 18% even if it was only for 2 people. Is this even appropriate to charge gratuity of 18% without the customer's consent? What if the restaurant didn't deserve that much? Would this consider robbing their customers?

It was a bit challenging finding this place because it was in the depths of China town. Let me go straight to the point! Very busy SMALL Chinese restaurant that's serves dumplings and several Chinese cuisine! Food taste good and price was reasonable! My only problem was the tables were so close to each other it makes you feel claustrophobic! Although the food taste good I only gave it 2 starts because I'm very very CRITICAL when it comes to CUSTOMER SERVICE!! Staff was rude in a way and when you're seated they rush to take your orders right away. The server we had knew little of the English language and he was very rude and aggressive. When the food was served not even 10 minutes you are given the check right away. It seems like they care more about your money than providing an extraordinary customer service experience. There are pictures of Celebrities around the restaurant who has been there before but don't be fooled because the service you will get will not be as close to those former VIP guest.

I feel this place is hyped up and overly talked about, which is why people line up over an hour just to eat it. If you go as a party of two, you're most likely going to be sharing a round table with other parties. 

Food-wise the only thing I thought was good is the pork dumpling (xiao long bao). However, its very inconsistently made. Some of them fall apart and the soup comes out before you even put it on the spoon. Some don't even have broth in the dumpling. The crabmeat one tasted cheap and not clean. So again, I'd recommend getting the pork dumpling if you must come here. Theres other places that I think are a lot better. When you compare this to places in Asia, this place is mediocre at most. Even bigger chains like Ding Tai Fung (which is hyped up as well)is much much better and feels a lot cleaner than this place. Wouldn't come here again even if there weren't a line.

Ok. So it WAS Christmas, but.... Seated is quickly at 930. Waited a while for waiter to take order.  Afterwords, our waiter went home at 10, presumably the end of the shift. Another waiter brought us some tea, and then I had asked him three times for water. The downstairs was not that busy in the upstairs had all the cleared out. We finally got our water, food was delivered. The food was not  Bad, but the same that you would find in many Chinese restaurants.  Our waiter brought us the bill which came to $20. We gave him $40 and ask for change of five dollar bills. Our waiter never returned and went about doing other things, another waiter had grabbed the tray of bills and change from the cashier and took  it in the back. When we came up to the cashier to acquire a better change they had no idea how much we gave or what are change was to be. We had to tell them as they had not expected to be giving us change. Would have been quite the tip on poor service.

Maybe I came on one of their off days. My experience here was HORRIBLE....the only good thing that happened was the waiting time for a seat. That's it. It was about 10 minutes. For 2 people.

I came here with my boyfriend because many people have recommended this place to him. Raving about their soup dumplings...it was small and not up to standard. I even found a strand of hair in the lettuce underneath the soup dumplings... I've seen and tasted better than what I have had here. Shanghai Deluxe makes better soup dumplings than this place...

This place is so crowded....they don't even have tables for 2. We had to dine with 2 other couples.....People kept hitting my chair trying to pass through. My chest was pretty much touching the table....one of their waiters even had to stand between me and my boyfriend to let others pass.....

Now the food. We had the "braised bean curd over spinach." They gave an extremely small amount of spinach...is it because spinach is expensive now and they're trying to save food? Whatever the reason, it was way too little to have been served. Now the braised bean curd....it was bland beyond belief....I like bean curd (tofu) a lot, but this? Impossible to like....

Last but not least, the service charge......seriously??? I understand for a group of 6 and greater, but for 2?? Since this was a horrible experience for me (and I'm not coming back here), I didn't give them a penny more. I wish I didn't need to pay the service charge either....

This place was highly recommended on Yelp...the food was good and potions were generous.  Dumplings plus two dishes were more than enough for three with plenty left over (general tso's chicken and Shanghai thick noodles).

Notice that there is a 15% service charge added to your bill already.  Also they brought a wrong rice dish to our table, we didn't notice and started eating it and then they came and took the dish away...who does that???

I honestly don't understand what is the big fuzz about this place. Food-wise average across the line, customer service -1 stars and cleanliness 2 (there was mold in the bathroom sink). It says 11pm but we arrived at 10:20 and the server rushed us to order since they were closing the kitchen . 40 MINUTES before "closing time." If you are closing the kitchen more than 30 mins before closing time, SAY you are closing 30 minutes before! Not only that but they put us to dine with 2 complete strangers having more than enough tables available, really? One of the worst customer service experiences, all would've been forgiven if food was good! But no...unless you favor egg shells in your shrimp fried rice because that's what we got...a lot. Mmmm...delicious calcium supplement. All of this for $48? Plus credit cards not accepted and they include the service fee of 15% on your bill for only 2 PEOPLE. No thank you, NEVER ever going back to this sorry excuse of a Chinese...sorry Shanghainese...restaurant. What a joke. Yelp failed us this time
The hype is not real. Soup dumplings are not mind blowing!! There are other places in New York that have cheaper and better ones. Nothing much to say, because they were not memorable at all.
Stopped in for lunch with wife and girls. Great broth dumplings , tasty slurping. Rice and noodles were also good. They server family style a few plates can be shared amongst a few. Enjoy

It's NOT all that great. Don't believe the hype.

Tip: Don't wait for more than 20min to be seated. It's not worth the wait. If you really want to eat the soup dumplings catch a train/cab to one of their other locations. It's the exact same dumplings but in a less hectic/crowded place.

The food was good. Soup dumplings were good. I'm just not convinced it's the greatest soup dumpling spot in NYC. I also don't think the hassle and the drama is worth it. 

Pro: Food is good. Prices are reasonable considering how popular this place is. 

Cons: Ridiculous wait times. Especially if you come during lunch/dinner hours. Trust me it's not worth the 40min to an hour wait time for a party of two. More people = longer wait.

 The seating system sucks. Chances are you'll be seated with a bunch of Tourists or the suckers that bought into the hype. If you are lucky they'll respect your privacy but so far that hasn't been the case with me. Maybe I'm just not that social.

Came here on monday afternoon where the restaurant wasnt packed at all.. the person who greeted us also greeted another party and ask all of us to follow her which makes us very confused, normally other restaurant would seat one party at the time. Not complained about this, but could be more organized.
Like i mentioned, the restaurant wasnt packed at all but yet the two of us were seated in a very small table next to the stairway. The service was really slow, they ignored us for so long before taking our orders. The food came pretty fast though. We ordered the lotus cake, soup dumplings, salt and pepper pork and plain scallion noodles. All of them were very very very salty, fyi, i normally preferably to eat salty food but this is already wayy to salty even for salty food fan like me.
When we were eating, i dropped the chopstick by accident and one of the staff who stood not far from our table had an eye contact with me and saw me dropping it, but instead of quickly approaching me with a new pair of chopsticks, he was just ignore me until i have to wait some time to stop another staff who passed by to give me a new set of chopsticks. The server never come back to our table to asked how was everything, he was only simply come when taking our order (after a long time) and dropping check. I mean this place better of self service rather than having such staffs. I would never recommend this place to friends and its a no no coming back here.

So, you can say I'm one of those fools who wait an hour in line to eat great food, and Joe's is one of those few places where I will give up my precious hour to satisfy my soup dumpling craving.  My wife and I have been coming here for 25+ years, and we have been trekking up from the WDC area a few times a year to drip our way to eat the famous soup dumplings. The dumplings have always been spot on and consistent, which is a primary key to a successful restaurant.   It has been over 3 years since our last visit due to the COVID pandemic, and we have final broke out of the shell to make it back to Joe's to devour the soup dumplings, and I must say, I am so heartbroken to find that the soup dumplings are NOT what it used to be.  The dumpling skins have become thicker, the soup taste profile is a bit off, bit into more crab shells than usual, the side dish sliced ginger is not thin, and the most noticeable is the size of the dumplings is larger.  Furthermore, the bamboo baskets are not lined with Napa cabbage, which makes the dumplings stick to the parchment paper.  Why am I complaining about the larger sized dumplings?  I did notice that there are considerable amounts of NEW restaurants that are serving the same style dumplings in the nearby blocks, and I can only assume that Joe's is feeling the competition.   With competition,  one will always try to do bigger and better.....  I have been in the restaurant business for over 40 years, and I can see that this is an initial sign of nervousness when they are met with fierce competition.  I've always preached that quantity will never prevail over quality in the restaurant business.  Quality will always create and increase repeat customers.  I am so so sad to see the negative changes at Joe's.  Unfortunately, last night at Joe's might have been the last.  It was great while it lasted.

This is definitely not Din Tai Fung. Nor was it even close or similar to the DTF in Taiwan. I will give them props for being better than the DTF in Bellevue (Seattle suburb) since that one was horrendous. 

We stumbled across this location while we were wandering around Chinatown and noticed a line out the door. Any place with a line = I will stop and see what it's about. Lucklily for some odd reason there was only a 10 minute wait at noon on a random Saturday. Lunch #1 for me (after 3 Breakfasts that same morning). We sat down and ended up sharing a table with a really nice touristy couple. We ordered the crab XLB and the standard XLB.

Good amount of soupy broth but the meat and soup wasn't as savory as DTF in Arcadia or Taipei. The skins weren't as thin as I liked them but they were done pretty well for XLB options stateside. Solid 3 stars!

I find it really hard to believe that the soup dumplings here are the best that you can find in New York.  I've been here twice now and would say that the soup dumplings are great, but not the best.  The pork dumplings are 3.5/5 and the crab dumplings are 2.5/5.  I'm not a fan of the crab dumplings because they smell a little fishy (yes, it's a shellfish, I know) and not as juicy as the pork dumplings.  

Pros: 
- Cheap juicy dumplings 
- The line goes really fast  
- Communal seating is a bit weird at first, but you quickly appreciate being able to see what other yummy things people are ordering. 
- Other dishes I've ordered here have been good and they seem to be willing to add/substitute stuff within the dishes per your request (e.g if you want chicken breast as opposed to sketchy, dark meat chicken). 

Cons: 
- Cash only ... although that's not really a major inconvenience 
- The downside of communal seating: Wait staff often confuse what you order vs. what other parties on the table order 
- Visibly dirty.  This place feels dirtier than the average Chinatown place.  I seriously feel like bringing my own utensils and water cup.  Bringing a germophobe here will not end well. 

Verdict: I'm a dumpling snob.  I like my dumplings looking all pristine when they come out, not all different sizes and different colors (hmmm... mystery meat?).  However, these dumplings are good, cheap and worth the wait.
Maybe it was all the hype.... The soup dumplings were good and I'm glad I tried it but nothing to die over.

Very lfew vegetarian options! However the wait staff was  attentive and our meat-eating friends seemed to think it was okay! Good serving sizes for sharing and a decent amount of seating - we got seated quickly even though there were 8 of us.

I grew up in Shanghai, and I think the dumplings were okay-- a bit overrated, in my opinion. 

We also ordered a Shanghai Wide Noodles, and it was alright as well... average in quality, and not exactly a Shanghai delicacy. More of a simple, stir-fried noodles thing. 

Our third dish was a Celery & Tofu & Pork dish -- a classic Shanghainese home-cooked staple. That was pretty delicious, and just the way I remembered it! 

Portion sizes were very generous, which is nice!

I went with huge expectations but was rather disappointed. The XLB was bland and had almost zero flavour. The Shanghai noodles and stir fried pork were okay but super salty, like a cheap Chinese fast food place. There are much better Chinese options in the area - Joe's is absolutely not worth the hype or the wait.

Consistently good XLB (soup dumplings). It's what they are famous for, after all. I wouldn't order anything else on the menu if you are looking for good/authentic Chinese food...the other dishes taste like an afterthought - oily, hastily prepared, and overly salted. 

But the XLB...pretty worth the wait. I usually stake out a day to go on an empty stomach with the intention of getting 2-3 orders of XLB. Both the pork and crab ones are amazing, and $7-9 for 8 dumplings is a pretty good deal. The skin on these soup dumplings is pretty thick though, and the broth inside rich, if not a bit greasy. I needed a couple glasses of water to cleanse my palate afterwards. Still good if you're alright with that.

Note that this place is cash only, and the wait can be quite long, especially on weekend afternoons. While the restaurant itself is bigger than most, it still gets incredibly cramped - you'll end up sharing seats at large tables. Due to its popularity, I think Joe's can be good for the novelty and introducing people to XLB. It's like XLB for the masses. But there are Chinatown restaurants that serve XLB at equal or better quality AND serve other really good, authentic dishes.

If you think the soup dumpling here is good, you should consider Xian house of dumplings in SF. Both are very delicious: the latter comes in a smaller/cuter size that you can eat it with one bite; the former comes with XL size and make you feel really satisfied with your dollar spent. The service is ok to terrible: the ok part comes with a 30-minute wait (which is fine if their food is actually good); the terrible part comes in when they serve me wonton with RAW/RED pork!!! Except for the food safety, everything else seems on the ok side.

It's been a while since I've dined here, but thing I do not understand is why this place is a "must-go-to" on city travel guides and food shows. This place isn't bad in terms of their food, but it's extremely overrated. I mean, there's always a crowded of customers waiting outside the restaurant. Any local would be sane enough not to eat here. There are places such as Shanghai Asian Manor and Shanghai Asian Cuisine located in Chinatown that offer just as good or even far better xiao long baos without the long wait. 

The service here is typically what you'd expect from any restaurant in Chinatown. You tell the servers what you'd like and they bring it to you. Then you'd never see them again until it time to pay. 

Aside from the famous soup dumplings offered here, Joe's Shanghai also offers more "traditional" dishes such as wood ear, different types of Shanghai noodle dishes and appetizers/ small eats including scallion pancakes. 

Overall, I've only been to this place once and I'd never go back again. The hype sure is real here.

I really like soupy dumplings but because of my allergies, there really wasn't any I could eat. It is in Chinatown so it pretty busy and crowded. Not sure if I will go back again. My friends enjoyed it though.

Unfortunately this is my first one star review and it's only because i had some of the worst service i've ever had in the city. We sat at our table for about 15 minutes before someone came to talk to us. Then our food took another 45 until it came out. Waaaaaay too long considering the kitchen was fully staffed and the restaurant was pretty empty. 

After when we tried to use the restroom they told us that there wasn't a bathroom. then it was dirty. and then we could use it. Weird. No matter how good those dumplings were, we will not be returning.  0/10

I was not impressed with the XLB here :( I wonder why it got such great reviews?! My husband enjoyed the Shanghai noodles though. Wish I had room to try the crab, which was recommended by my cousin. We order waaay too much XLB for two people. Get the pork + crab, tastes almost the same as the pork, and save room to try other things!

So, I didn't actually eat here, even though there are a ton of positive reviews here on Yelp.. 

Why, you ask?

Well, the stench that greeted me from more than 10 feet away was unbelievable.  

Look, I KNOW it's Chinatown, but this was unreal!

The whole look and feel to the outside of the restaurant was very unappealing. Dirty and rundown.

LOOK, I know it's Chinatown!

Hey. How come there is no letter grade rating in the window? Don't all restaurants have to display that?

OH! There it is, next to the inner door in the vestibule...

I'd never even seen a C rating before!

Yuck.

The food at this place tastes great. I've been going here for years, but it does have its flaws. It is crowded, dirty, and the ingredients are likely the polar opposite of certified organic. 

I've tried a lot of things here, but highly recommend the famous soup dumplings and the vegetable with bean curd.

Pros: soupy dumplings are great, as is the crispy beef

Cons: wait + sharing tables + slightly over-hyped

In enjoyed dinner, but wasn't overwhelmed.  It's solid for it's signature dishes, but lacks the finish to be great.

I guess I'm spoiled by my new found Chinese place in my hometown, The Bamboo House in Syracuse, NY. I thought this was good, but it wasn't as fresh and delicious. We had szechuan chicken and vegetable Lo Mein. Not super exciting I agree!  Not my choice either. I would try something else my next time through.

We heard about the soup dumplings so on a whim, we popped in on a Friday night. The place was packed but we got a seat within 5 minutes. We had to share a table with two other couples which was a little awkward. The waiter came over right away and asked if we wanted soup dumplings and we said yes but had no chance to look at the menu. He put in our order and when we asked what else he recommended or what else was popular, he just kept yelling at us "beef, pork or chicken!" It was so unnerving and we almost walked out. The soup dumplings are good, but we wouldn't go out of our way for them. I also would never want to deal with that rude waiter again.
Decent soup dumpling, not as good as it used to be. Packed with tourist. Cash only. Long lines. Plenty of waiters and waitress standing around.

Bottom line first: The hype is not worth the wait, price, nor abuse.  Food was only so so. Since they write in a standard 15% tip, no matter the party size, they have no problem treating customers like crap. And they do. Looking at the crowd, this place got it's high ratings from Band-Wagon Zombie high star Yelpers.

My coworker recommended this place for XLB, and I was intrigued by the amount of reviews this place had. My boyfriend and I came here for lunch on a weekday, and we were able to be seated right away. The service was quick and attentive. We ordered the pork meat soup dumplings, as well as the crab and pork meat soup dumplings. The crab and pork meat soup dumplings had a flavorful and delicious broth, though I wish that the wrapper was softer and thinner. The meat filling was also huge and overwhelming. My boyfriend and I were not a huge fan of the pork meat soup dumplings because the broth was too fatty for our liking. Kind of a let down because we were excited to try XLB in NYC Chinatown for the first time while visiting form California, but it doesn't compare to SF Chinatown's XLB.

The soup dumplings (pork or shrimp) were good. But I'm not necessarily head-over-heels going gypsy over them. 

The scallion pancakes were really good; tastey, warm, and crispy.

Let's start off with five stars and do the deductions from there.

-2 for cleanliness:  It's Chinatown yes, but let's face it, the space is not huge, it wouldn't take much to clean it.

-2 for the insanely rude, arrogant, and immature hostess:  Let's see....where to start?  Playing with hair in a restaurant - check.  Playing with your cellphone in front of customers -check.  Throwing menus at customers and saying nothing but "share table" - check. 

So we're at one star, right?

+2 for the soup dumplings, but, they are NOT the best.

Cheap meal, above-average food, but this is hype beast in full mode.

Did I mention the hostess sucks?

The famous soup filled dumplings. Tasty but super rich and salty. I couldn't help but think about the fat content. 
Ok for everything else we ate, but over hyped in my opinion.

So after reading all of the awesome reviews, I had to give these soup dumplings a try. When we walked up there were people waiting outside and we were worried about getting a table, but they got us in immediately. Sure we had to sit at a large round table with other small parties but I didn't mind at all. We started with the famous pork soup dumplings and I really didn't understand them. I thought I was going to get soup with dumplings in it, not dumplings with soup in them! Either way, I loved the ginger soy dipping sauce. Overall, I realized that I just am not a dumpling person.

I also had the orange beef which was delicious and my husband had the salt and pepper pork. The pork came with a special salt mixture that you put on it and it was really tasty. Overall, the food was good, but I have had better. It was a great night in Chinatown, but I bet there are better hidden little gems out there.

I really don't get what's the big deal about Joe's Shanghai. My friend took me there cause she heard it is "sooooooo good" but seriously, I didn't like any food that I had there. The soup dumplings were disgusting. The meat stunk of something unpleasant. The noodle soup wasn't that great either. It is overcrowded and I just cannot enjoy food with distraction like thousands of waiters staring at me. 
I know where to go for my dumplings... definitely not here.

**THE XLB REALNESS**

Joes Shanghai is to Din Tai Fung as Popeye's is to (insert $$ soul food restaurant fried chicken here).  I understand why someone might ENJOY Popeye's MORE but there's absolutely no way it's "better" or "higher quality".

FACTS:
- Joe's is much juicier than DTF
- Joe's skin is much thicker than DTF
- Joe's other dishes besides XLB are very mediocre (not terrible, but not great whatsoever)

Din Tai Fung is very refined and sophisticated compared to Joe's.  So it depends on your palette really.  But 95% of real Chinese foodies will take DTF over Joe's.

*** BUG ON THE WALL OF THE BACK TABLE *** so discomforting to see while eating after waiting over an hour to be seated at a table full of other strangers. Very loud and crowded restaurant with too many tourists and rushed service! The food was incredible but service, atmosphere, and seating is below average. Joes is a favorite but this was so disappointing as they brushed it off and pretended it didn't happen after nearly 5 minutes of us trying to get their attention to remove it.

I have been here more than a few dozen times over the last decade, and the quality has definitely gone downhill.  Here's what you can expect:

1. LONG lines/wait at almost any time of day/week.  I have gotten lucky during the day on a weekday, but even then can be a long wait.
2. You often will be seated at a shared table.  I have never had a problem with this, but it should be noted, since I have been seated next to people who are angry the whole time they are sitting with strangers. 
3. The service will be spotty.  You don't really have just one server.  At least a few different people will approach your table, depending on who it is, you will either be helped greatly, or you will be forgotten and you just need to tell someone else what you want.
4. You will usually be offered to start your meal with the dumplings.  DO THIS.  This is usually the only reason why people show up.  Place the soup dumpling on your spoon, poke it with your chopstick so that the soup drips into your spoon, drink the soup, then eat the dumpling.  Extra points for next spilling any on your plate.  This takes practice.
5. The food is generally served in large portions, which is fine with me!  I usually take home leftovers, and order to share with my group.
6. BRING CASH.  You cannot pay with a credit card.  Tip is actually included in the total, so watch out for that too, because you have to look at the receipt to notice this (no one tells you).

If you are looking for other good soup dumplings, I prefer Shanghai Cafe, where the service is better, it is less crowded, and an overall more enjoyable experience.

The food are bad so I only took picture of the soup dumpling, the only dish that I like lol Would have been a 1 star if not for the soup dumpling. 

~ Pork Meat Soup Dumpling Â∞èÁ±†ÊπØÂåÖ (3.5/5) ~
It's a good Chinese style soup dumpling, generous portion, a lot of yummy soup inside. The dumpling is on the thicker side (which is the way it is in China), it's not bad but I prefer Taiwanese style with the thin and smooth dumpling skin (like din tai fung). 

~ House Special Glazed Crispy Chicken ÁÇ∏Ê∫úÂ≠êÈõû (1/5) ~
We asked the server whether Crispy Chicken in Ginger Sauce (ËÑÜÁöÆÊ≤πÊ∑ãÈõû) is ÁÇ∏Â≠êÈõû (which is a crispy skin chicken) and he pointed us to House Special Glazed Crispy Chicken (ÁÇ∏Ê∫úÂ≠êÈõû), which turns out to be wrong. I mean he speak Cantonese how can he not know what is ÁÇ∏Â≠êÈõû ? Lol 
After the dish was served we were shocked, but accepted the dish nonetheless. It is SO WEIRD. It's sweet & sour pork but the chicken version. We have never had a chicken version before and it felt SO WRONG. We grew up with the pork version, which is like 99% of what are served in Hong Kong. Plus it's a bit too sweet, and the fried chicken is quite dry and not tender. Maybe a foreigner would love and devour this dish, but not us. 

~ Buffalo Carp Fish Belly in Brown Sauce Á¥ÖÁáíÈØáÈ≠öËÖ© (0/5) ~ 
Worst fish I have ever had in my entire life!!!!!!! It has a super strong stinky, smelly, fishy taste, it's revolting! For god sake did they not use ginger?!?!?! It's outright inedible. Did not touch the fish after few bites I just can't. 

~ Saut√©ed Seasonal Vegetables Ê∏ÖÁÇíÊôÇËèú (2/5) ~
Stir fry vegetables is a basic Chinese dish but this is not done well. Vegetables used were odd, not the typical ones you'd get. The sauce is very runny and oily. 

Will I be back? No
Did not enjoy any of the dishes we got (except for the soup dumpling). Perhaps there are other dish that are good, but I'm not paying my own money to find out by trial and error.

I'm not crazy about this place. 

Every non-Chinese/ non-Asian friend of mine who thinks they know something about Chinese or Asian food always suggests or brings me here for soup dumplings (xiao long bao). Then they try to show off their knowledge by explaining to ME what it is and how to eat it - Uh, sorry bud, I've been eating AND MAKING these by HAND since I was a kid- my dad was born in Shanghai. We take dumplings seriously. You get a "B-" for effort. ;-)

It was a much more decent haunt when I was a teenager in the 90's- from what I remember, that was when the press started blowing them up. Even an old friend and classmate of mine (who is now a curator in PS 1) swore by this spot, when we were teens. 

What can I say? I liked it after the first try in the 90's. Then after the second, I started to get bored. Then the third. Then the fourth. How often can you eat hyped up xiao long baos? Not that often. Better to go to #9 Chatham (http://www.yelp.com/biz/hop-shing-restaurant-new-york#hrid:SKgegYilESYPRg1u5u8eBw), and get some dim sum and get some xlb's in Flushing. I'm listing this spot as one of the many Americanized hyped up spots in Chinatown-. Even though the xiao long boas are still Chinese tasting, it's the same vibe as going to one of these guys: Wo Hop (http://www.yelp.com/biz/wo-hop-restaurant-new-york#hrid:F-sVFNFgkDCUC2bnCXDG7Q) and Hop Kee (http://www.yelp.com/biz/hop-kee-new-york#hrid:ctrmjxSMFCBVZW7bJ8WRGA). 

This place is a bore and a bit too American touristy for my taste.

I understand why people like this so much but for me the dumplings just don't live up to the hype. Or maybe it's that I'm not a huge fan of soup dumplings and prefer my dumplings stir fried. Either way, I still like this restaurant for its other food and have found my previous visits to still be quite good. I've been here a few times over the years and each time I find myself a little underwhelmed with the dumplings.

We're changing the review. Went over to check it out 10 months later and they now have an "A" sanitation rating. We tried to get in for lunch but it was very busy.  At 2:30 in the afternoon, the place was packed. My only complaint is the way they sit people, we had a group of five, and we couldn't get a table because they kept filling up the tables with groups of one or two as they walked in the door. After about 20 minutes of just waiting, it gets old watching all the people walk in and sit in front of you, but we understand it's New York and they need a quick turnaround.
We're looking forward to eating here again and giving them a better score when we can actually get in to try the food.

I've heard so much about this restaurant, so when we were in the area, we just had to visit. The wait for a table wasn't as bad as I expected. But then I understood why; Each table sits three groups of two, so you have to share your table with strangers.

We started with the Scallion Pancakes which were delicious. If you like Scallion Pancakes, I definitely recommend the ones from here. 

We then shared the Jumbo Prawn In Citrus Flavor from the chef's special menu. I thought it was very good. The portion was big enough for the two of us to share. We also ordered the Shanghai Fried Flat Noodles, but I wasn't a big fan. They were more like Udon noodles and I don't think that they went with the jumbo prawns.

Service was quick. Our waiter was nice and knowledgeable about the menu.

I'm glad that we got to try Joe's Shanghai, but I don't think it's a place that I'll be longing to come back. The restaurant was too crowded and rowdy and I felt like there was a lot going on around us (like workers bumping into us while taking out boxes, and staff talking loudly over our shoulders). The food was good, but nothing that I will HAVE to come back for.

mediocre. mediocre. mediocre. mediocre.  
 
Came to visit from the high volume of ratings. Sorely disappointed. Service was meh. Had way better Xiao-long bao. This was our first experience of having to share tables with other parties which we do not mind at all. This place is a joke. The other dishes that we ordered were the singapore chow mai fun and the prawn and scallop in garlic sauce were also so-so. I HOPE THE REST OF THE CHINATOWN RESTAURANTS ARE NOT THE SAME.  
 
Tourist, dont waste your time here. OVER-hyped.

Really sucked.  Was going to be 35 minutes for the Peking Duck so we ordered the crispy duck.  Not great.  Only came with a bowl of white rice which we had to ask for 5-10 minutes after the duck.  Seemed pork soup dumplings where doughey and somewhat flavorless.  Cash only was also a turn off.
As a Shanghainese this place is really just A-OK. Can get wayyyyy better stuff for a wayyyyy down price.

This place is definitely overrated. Order soup dumpling for my lunch base on good reviews, but very disappointed. The soup dumpling taste terrible, by no way it could be one of the best soup dumpling in NYC. The dumplings were too thick, the pork meat inside were not fresh at all. 
I was order based on the Yelp menu, I was very surprise when it came out to be $6.80 after tax for the pork meat soup dumpling, and they accept CASH ONLY.

Location: There are so many stores around Pell Street. Last time, I tried Hand pulled noodles. And now, I am here trying some real chinese food with my parent.s The store is unexpectedly tiny. They asked people to table together. So be prepared that someone violates your privacy during your time at Joe's
The wall has many pictures, trying to show off how great they are.

Food: we can xiao long bao. Celery with tofu, and one of their fish signiture food.
The food is very.. too oily for people who enjoy salad all day long to eat. 
But the taste is alright.

Service: is a mess.

THEY ONLY ACCEPT CASH.

BAD
3.5 stars

Joe's Shanghai full of crowds is misleading; there were barely locals eating there, mostly tourists who eat there biased from the good google or yelp ratings.

The xiao long bao is too big of a dumpling; normal dumpling size is much smaller and you can enjoy the juiciness. 

So this is a disappointing experience overall.

I spend my childhood in Shanghai, therefore, I have had my fair share of xlb.  I have been to them all, from the touristy place in Yu Yuan to the expensive Ding Tai Feng located in Xing Tian Di, and the numerous cheap no name mom and pop style shops dotted through out the city.  This and sheng jian bao are the two food items that I missed the most about Shanghai and they are also the hardest to recreate by outsiders.  Bourdain was right, you can't find anything more perfectly constructed than a good xlb.    

Joe's xlb was very juicy, even juicier than some of the ones I had in Shanghai.  The skin needed to be thinner, but it wasn't so thick that made me question whether I am eating a xlb or just a northern style dumpling.  The filling was also quite tasty with a good texture.  However, Joe's xlb had one fatal flaw.  The soup inside the bun was distinctively chicken rather than 100% pork.  Its not that chicken broth is not tasty on its own, but the flavor of Joe's xlb deviates so much from the authentic version that it didn't quite satisfy my craving after I ate it.  I suspect that its much easier to make a gelatin broth from chicken carcass and chicken feet rather than the labor intensive process involve cleaning and scraping pork skins.  The other stuffs in the restaurant are probably not worth ordering since I saw many tables had the gloppy American tourist type Chinese food.

Honestly, this place is a tourist trap. I think their soup dumplings are dry and not as flavourful as I had hoped. I do remember though when I was younger they use to make better ones and it was cheaper. Now it's expensive and overrated. Better off finding a hole in the wall for soup dumpling these days.

I have been to this place several times. While visiting NYC in Sep 2018, I brought my family here and I won't be going back. Their dumplings are ok and I would say maybe below average. Dumpling skin is too thin to hold anything so it breaks easily. I also had fried dumpling and it was too oily. There are definitely better options out there in NYC. 


Cash only.
This was the worst Chinese food I have ever eaten, except for the soup dumplings.

Are u serious to give 5 starts for this trash restaurant? Food is OK. Service is garbage. Cash only. Tip is already included for every single bill regardless u asked or not. Just backing fire on travelers for easy money rather than working on better service and food. Please try other chinese restaurant before u have all NYC restaurants, please.

I thought this restaurant was overrated... It's located in the center of Chinatown in Manhattan and attracts mostly tourists looking for what they assumed as "authentic Chinese food." The restaurant is overly crowded to fit as many tables as they can in the limited space. Service was not impressive.. Your typical Chinese waiters. 

Good wise, we had 2 different kinds of soup dumplings: crab and pork. They weren't spectacular but weren't bad. We also had fried pancake which was pretty bland. That's about as Chinese as you get. Rest of the menu are your typical Chinese American items like general tso chicken etc.

Went here with two other people for dinner last night. We shared all dishes, and agreed that this was one of the worst meals of our lives. Out of seven dishes, only the cold sesame noodles were good.

Boiled pork dumplings- Gummy, spongey dumpling wrapper like those on cheap frozen supermarket dumplings. The filling was spongy and tasted off, like the pork had been frozen and thawed many times. It also exuded a rancid tasting grease.

Soup dumplings - Soup filling tasted like hot garbage.

Seasonal Vegetable - Bok Choy was cold, wilted, and drenched in oil. Asked for dish to be prepared 'hot and spicy', but it was completely bland.

Singapore noodles - The shredded chicken was dry and gummy, tasted like cardboard, and stuck between your teeth. The noodles tasted like the inside of an old curry jar. The shrimp was completely inedible.

Sesame chicken - Edible, but barely. Completely shellacked with an overly sweet sauce. Felt like I was eating candied meat. 

The worst part of all of it was the price, which was exorbitant given the quality. I would never eat here again.

Come 'on folks.  Those jiggly little soup dumplings that this place made press for are available at any Chinese restaurant that serves this region.  I've been to many a Chinese restaurant in my lifetime and even the little hole-in-the-wall places can execute this dish correctly.  That said, this place is still yummy, but definitely not original.   Don't make yourself crazy waiting in line when you can have your appetite satisfied in many other places in the area.

FYI they are cash only!! There was also an 18% service charge.

We ordered the crab and pork soup dumplings, shrimp fried rice and pepper duck. The dumplings were good, but the shrimp fried rice and duck were only okay. We had to ask for sauce for the duck because even with the seasoning and lemon it had no flavor.

My 1st trip to the Big Apple to see the other half would not be complete without a trip to Chinatown.  We actually went to C'town for cupcakes but we though we'd get dinner too.

The 2 of us got there a little after 5pm but the restaurant was already quite busy.  We had to share a table with others even though there were still empty ones that did not get filled by the time we left.

The soup dumplings were very good with the wrappers being just the right thickness.  The filling was on the salty side but there was plenty of hot soup on the inside (caution!!).  The clams in black bean sauce was also a bit salty but it went well with rice.  The best thing about the dish was that the clam-meat-to-clam-shell ratio was close to 1:1.

The chief complaint - and the major reason for star deduction - was the poor quality of service.  We had ordered rice with our meal but it took 2 additional attempts to get them.  I was actually actively ignored by some of the waiters!!  They were quite snooty to us compared to the way they treated the Mandarin-speaking customers that were sitting across the table. I didn't know I had to "prove" that I am Chinese enough to get equal service.  If I had known, I would have spoken to the waiters in both Mandarin AND Cantonese.

The food was good (but I suspect better options can be found elsewhere in C'town) but the terrible service just overshadows it all.  We probably won't be returning to Joe's again unless we were really craving some soup dumplings.

Not the best option in the area. Decided to get take out from here this evening. For $20 I got the beef and broccoli. Words can not do the portion size justice. I got a 1/4 of a large container and like 3 spoonfuls of rice in the same container. So less than half of the container had food. I had really high expectations for this place. For $20 the food tasted average and the portion size made it completely a three time experience...... The first, the last and the never again. Hopefully someone will chose better than I did. McDonald's came in clutch tonight.

Service was awful!!! Waited for an hour but didn't get to try their food due to human needs. Yes, I understand we were a big party of 10 (which included 4 seniors) and to top it off was Friday night 8pm so we knew we had to wait. We come from Los Angeles and was looking  forward to Chinese. We were given number 32 on a raffle ticket  and estimated time 20min. We took advantage of the wait time and decided what we were going to eat. At 8:30pm I took this picture notice how I aim up to avoid all the heads of waiting people thinking soon we would be called. After the picture taken of the front entrance I go inside and ask how much longer since we have 4 seniors (in laws 71yrs, 68 yrs., and two friends  73 yrs and 65yrs) women says 4 numbers before you. Then after a min of me coming back out she says 30, 33,34,35. I was like what the heck?!?!! At this point I tell my husband to go ask how much longer. Maybe split tables? He comes back and they say 10-15min at 8:46pm. Two of the seniors decide they no longer want to wait so they opt to leave. At this point I decide to go find a place to go use the restroom  and and get something to drink since I didn't believe their estimated time. To my surprise the estimated time was a true and the women says all of you need to be here. My fiend explains that two left since the wait was too long and I was on my way back from toilet  and getting a drink (around the corner) little did I know I was shooting my self on the foot. The lady was MEAN, rude and had no compassion and simply called the next party on the wait list. My husband tried calling me and texted me but no luck my phone  had no more battery . My friend told her they knew what they wanted to order and that I was in my way back but restaurant host was rude and said "no"  not all here while stomping feet . Please have in mind the majority of us was there. So from thinking we were going to be seated and being inside the entrance restaurant. The RUDE host ignored my family and rest of friends. Now our 1hour wait time was down the drain. My family hungry, tired and restless walking away from the restaurant since that I didn't pick up my phone and met them hauling ass to get back but they said too late they turned us away. I felt HORRIBLE  since it was my fault.  Waited for an hour and got turned away since not all present. I had no idea ‚Äç what their policy was.

I'm sure many of you have already heard of this place, and it doesn't need too much introduction.  Joe's Shanghai is one of those places that I feel like defines Manhattan Chinatown.  This place is pretty packed at all times as well, and you should expect to wait if you're attempting to eat here.  Definitely come here an hour before you're actually trying to eat to put your name on the roster, and your wait time won't seem so bad because you can wander around the area and explore, making your otherwise boring wait in the middle of the alley not so bad.  While I hesitate to call this place a tourist trap, there will definitely be a lot of tourists there, as Joe's has made a name for itself and its famous soup dumplings.

Now, as far as the actual food goes, the traditional soup dumplings are definitely something you will want to try.  While I feel like your mileage actually varies based upon the day and how busy the restaurant is, they do do a solid soup dumpling.  I saw some of the food that other people had ordered, and it didn't really seem too remarkable.  I also had another order of crabmeat dumplings as well, which actually weren't as good in my opinion as the pork dumplings.

This place may not be the best place around, but it is established, and if you're not feeling particularly adventurous, Joe's Shanghai is an excellent standby location, and if you have never tried it, I think it's worth a visit if the line isn't too long so you can decide for yourself whether or not it lives up to all the hype.

Okay so I heard great things about this place and yelp raves about this place so I went out of my way to check this place out. Got there and there was about a 30min wait, no problem - there's definitely a lot of things to do around there. The seating is with a group of people in a round table, it was pretty cool I must say.
Food is not that good to be honest. I was with my wife and dad and none of us enjoyed our food. Food is plain and nothing special at all. To top it off!!! The tip is already included ! A nice 20% regardless of what you order or how much you order. It wasn't worth the $$$. Wouldn't go back

Overrated, touristy, terrible service, and not worth it.

I should have read the reviews more thoroughly here. I made the mistake of including tip on our meal.

Dumplings are interesting....but I wouldn't order again. Underwhelming. 
Having grown up with a mom that cooked with msg, I think there is a  lot of msg in their food. 

We didn't' have to wait in line, otherwise this would be a one star.

Waiters were like machines pushing a herd of people in-n-out for feeding.

Craving for some Shanghaiese foods? This place might do it for you if you don't know much about authentic Shanghaiese foods. I'm 100% Shanghaiese so I know what and how it should be. 

Their xiao long bao is way too big! It is juicy indeed, but the flavor is totally off. All the other dishes are mediocre. I'm not saying I've tried all of it but giving this restaurant 3 shots is more than enough to know this is not authentic at all. Is it good? Yes. Is it authentic? No. 

They get really busy here so try not to come during peak hours as you'll be waiting forever. Get ready to share tables with strangers as the restaurant itself isn't too big. It is totally about the hype. Come and try it so you'll be able to tell everyone you've tried it.

As a soup dumpling lover I've been to all three Joe's Shanghai locations- midtown, Chinatown and flushing. I will never return to this location, perhaps even all of them, due to poor customer service here. I walked up to the two hostesses and BOTH of them were preoccupied with playing with their nails. I had to greet them and asked them for a table for 2. Still playing with their nails and not making any eye contact, they told me there's a 60 minute wait. 

Their soup dumplings are mediocre, so is everything else on the menu. There are much better soup dumplings in close proximity with much better service. Don't let the high ratings fool you.

If this is NYC's best raved about dumpling place, it's a bit disappointing. The experience wasn't bad but it's nothing to rave about. Just basic soup dumplings. It is better then some of the places I've tried in the area but nothing in comparison to Din Tai Fung's clean presentation, texture, and taste. 

Customer service was ehhh bad. They're rude but they got my food to me in a decent time so I guess I can't complain while in china town. Also they only take cash and have a 15% service charge so don't bother adding gratuity.  

Now that I'm in this area I'm trying to find new favorites.

Very yummy soup dumplings, which is what I came here for. However, I discovered my favorite was actually their noodles (forgot the name, but there were vegetables in it). Absolutely delicious! Just wish I could've been seated at my own table instead of with strangers. The decor and service weren't good, but what can you expect from Chinatown?

It's like a Chinatown tourist trap gone wrong... or maybe right, depending on how you look at it. First look, you see the people standing outside... waiting, and it's typically a 30 minute wait.. once you get in, it's community seating.. yep, you sit where ever  with whomever. Slurping strangers with bad eating habits and loud chewing is all part of the "experience".. 

After living in NYC for almost 10 years, I was forced by some friends to experience this gem and well, let me tell you... there are better places to go. 

Ok, lets get to it. Soup dumplings are meh, but again... they are at other places with better commutes and service. 
We ordered Dumplings, string beans and a few other dishes... and well, the chinese place down the street on UES serves better food, as it was bland and lacked much flavor. 

The waitstaff or people working here are close to rude... rushed and well, they're trying to turn the tables..here is a tip people.. walk around the corner on a nice day and you can get a plate of authentic dumplings for a dollar or an entire platter for $5 and you'll be full, the service is better at the counter and you wouldn't have wasted your time here standing in line etc. 

Look for soup dumplings elsewhere.

I have no idea why this place has so many reviews and why people wait so long to get a table here. The good is super average and tbh white people bland. I took a group of my chinese friends with me and we all were shocked at how low the bar was. 
Typically when you sit down u get offered tea in any traditional chinese restaurant. Also it's almost inevitable you can order chow fun.. first time i don't see chow fun on a chinese menu?!  Then we had to beg to get rice with dishes that come with it. Horrible service and just not worth it. There are far better places I have been to in Chinatown

I've been here twice. During my first time a couple years ago, I thought these dumplings were the best of the best. However, during my second time (going for lunch this time), I wasn't very impressed. Yes, they were still soupy, but the soup wasn't that good. It's still a must try if you haven't yet.

JONASAPPROVED!

Came here for the xiao long bao like everyone else. They are pretty good. Definitely the juiciest XLB's I've ever had. There's so much soup in that dumpling, I don't even know how it doesn't pop! I also tried one of their noodle dishes, it was whatever. If you want some juicy, soupy, xlb's come here.

Came here in June with some friends. The food was okay -- there are a lot of better places in Chinatown. Not sure what all of the hype is about. 

On the particular night we went, the waiter kept rushing us to leave which was annoying and a bit rude. I understand you want to go home, but the place isn't even closed yet. I understand some people stay past closing and that's a hassle for the staff but it wasn't even closed yet.

Eh. I don't get the hype. This is definitely one of those places that are famous for being famous...the Kardashian of the food world. 

Nothing that stands out about this place. While it is a nicer Chinatown restaurant, the food isn't better than other Shanghai places and nothing really shines here. Everything is just eh. Save your money and head down the block to Shanghai Garden. You'll get more for your money and your tummy will thank you.

Having been a longtime customer of Joe's, I felt I've had enough meals there over the years to notice a downward trend. 

the chef who makes the soup dumplings must have left recently (within the past 2 years) because the flavor of the broth and the wrapper of the dumplings are significantly different. The wrapper texture is now thicker and puckers more out of the steamer. And the crab meat dumplings -- something is seriously wrong with it. Not even the vinegar and ginger could save it.

In our most recent meal, we got the subgum rice cakes. It was OK -- not much different from any of the other Shanghai places in Chinatown or Flushing.

I agree with other reviewers: The Joe's in Flushing is about 25% percent better. At least I don't have to share tables or get charged an automatic 15% tip there.

i'm not gonna lie, i did enjoy these soup dumplings (and may be a bit tardy on the hype with joe's). my friends and i have casually dropped by at least 3 times so far and i've tried their pork and crab dumplings. the soup is on point and precisely the way a taiwanese soup dumpling should taste. the only detail that bugs me out is that they took authenticity to the max. the servers are obnoxious, low key, and borderline rude. they didn't expect my friends and i to inhale four orders of crab soup dumplings..and then some. our server repeated three times that the serving size is 8 pieces per order. we savored our meal to the final piece and deliberately ordered another two, which sent two of the young turds sniggering. whatever, who cares. we laughed at ourselves too. but yeah, if the authentic "chinese dining experience" is what you're going for, then be my guest. situated in the back alleys of chinatown, it is decently priced albeit personally, i'd rather sit at home and make my own 8 batches of soup dumplings. it's the cheaper bet.
Tourist trap! There was nothing special about the food here. It tasted like a typical Asian buffet, there was nothing special about the food here. Long wait times as well

First off, two heads-up for any potential diners: (1) You will only be seated you if your whole party is present and will most likely be seated at a shared table with other diners and (2) They are CASH-ONLY so be sure you are bringing enough Benjamins with you if you plan on ordering lots. 

Joe's Shanghai has been on my NYC To-Do list for a while and I was excited two weekends ago when I finally got to cross it off. That excitement quickly simmered down once I started eating. This place should be really reviewed based on the merits of its food, since I can say the prices are reasonable, the service is solid, and the atmosphere and seating is expected - it's a popular Chinese restaurant in the heart of Chinatown so expect it to be noisy and crowded. 

So, the food...

To be honest, I may have set my expectations too high when coming here. All my friends told me this was the go-to place for soup dumplings and I have been dying to try it. For the meal, we ordered two steamers of soup dumplings (Xiao Long Bao), Kung Pao Chicken, Mapo Tofu, and noodle soup. The focus of this review is probably going to be on the soup dumplings; the other food was solid, fresh, and good but fairly average compared to this restaurant's peers in the area. 

Soup Dumpling Soliloquy:

So I am by no means a soup dumpling expert, but there are a few things I like to see when I eat one. There has to be a well-made casing to hold in all the soup, the broth should be flavorful, and the filling should really accentuate all three together into one very satisfying bite. 
Joe's Shanghai kind of delivered on all of this. Kinda. The casing was fine, the broth had some taste, and the filling...tasted like filling. So it was a decent dumpling, but I fail to see where all this hype is coming from. I guess the food was hot so that's a plus and the wait to get in wasn't too long, but for me this definitely ended up being just a checklist experience - something so that I can say I've been to Joe's Shanghai. There are lots of places to get quality dim sum around Chinatown, and not that this place was bad by any means, but I would probably wouldn't go out of my way to eat here. 

tl;dr 95% chance this place is overhyped, 5% chance I had just had an off experience. Food is fresh, but average

I haven't been here in years but it seems it has became popular through out the years. I am very disappointed in the awful service I received. My uncle from out of town was visiting the city for my brothers wedding. He hasn't been here in a few years and was craving Joe Shanghai's water dumplings. So we got here at 5 and got a number. We were a party of 9 and because we were a large group many of us were coming from different places and was not there yet. They refuse to seat us even though there were 2 people missing. When we finally all arrived, they told us there were no tables for us. We waited for another 45 mins and constantly asking asking the lady when will the table be ready. She would rudely ignore you and keep screaming numbers in our faces. They could never give us an approximate time on when they could seat us. My family and I ended up leaving and going to another restaurant. I will NEVER visit this place again and never will recommend this place. When they get their head out of their ass maybe I'll consider this place. Joe Shanghai, you're not that special. Get over yourself!

Last time I went to Joe's Shanghai (granted, quite a few years ago) They added a tip to our bill without notifying us, and then the manager got angry when we noticed and wanted it refunded as we had left one at the table. There are other better, more honest, and and less touristy places to get Shanghai dumplings in the city.

Nothing special order pan fried noodles chow mien (it wasn't what I expected, noodles were different) and pork dumplings they added 15% service charge ($20 is expensive for what you get) and provide minimal service I wouldn't go again

This place is completely a tourist trap. Food is nothing like the original Shanghai recipes. If I could give Zero star I would. The line for the table can only be described as like in a concentration camp. The only different between them is  in a concentration camp you will eventually get some decent food and be satisfied whereas in JS you would pay through your nose and be well pissed off (avg waiting time is 2 hrs). If you really like oriental food then do yourself a favour walk a few yards  towards the main china town there are plenty of decent restaurants and the prices are much reasonable and most of all the quality of food is MUCH better.  Only the restroom is the only thing I would come back for.   The restroom is spacious and relatively tidy and clean compared to average NYC restaurants and food establishments. 

:-(

Disappointment! We thought we were lucky to get a table bc it was a rainy day but the food was horrible. The only thing that was ok was the pork soup dumpling but even that was stretching, they all fell apart as we were picking them up...that still worth 2 stars but the rest of the food...Shanghainese wonton, chicken vermicelli were horrible.  The wontons were so salty we only ate a few n left.  Joe Shanghai...what happened to you?!  I'll not be back.

The best way to describe my situation would be that I had actually made a reservation for Joe's for 12 people for 7:00pm on a Saturday night, they were gracious enough to actually allow the reservation. She only said that we should all arrive on time or they will give it away. I asked for the grace period and she had informed me 10 minutes. 

Of course, not all my party shown up promptly, the last person to show up was 7:07pm but she had actually gave away the table not honoring the time slot and we had to wait 30 minutes to get the next big table. Originally I was going to give the place 2 stars but garnered the additional star was the waiter who served us that night. He made up for the lack of customer courtesy at the door with a good personality which is often not available at a Chinatown restaurant. 

The food is amazingly well prepared and fast served. The soup dumplings are amazing and addictive as well. The pan fried noodle dishes I enjoy every time and consistently good. The scallion pancakes come in a good size portion and the dipping sauce is a sweet soy sauce. Overall, we weren't rushed out and I think it was because we just kept ordering beers all night so the owner must have been OK with our straggling at the end. 

I'd return again, but understanding that it's best to go and wait. You will wait, because it is such a crowded restaurant. The food though is worth it and you know you'll be out in under an hour.
The food is great. Xiaolongbao is perfect. My main concern is tat the staff is extremely rude and disrespectful. If ur not anyone important you will be treated like trash.

Fresh soup dumplings.  Prices are very reasonable.  15% tip is built in so not much thinking to do on your end.  No credit cards taken. 
Service is pretty proforma.  They're attentive, but you'll notice it's to move you along, not cater to your needs.
I've been to three locations.  The midtown location is more upscale. 
On Friday evening in Chinatown the line was assembled in the street I assume to enjoy primarily their XLB...they definitely enjoy a following.
Long wait to sit... But fast food service. Dumplings are not that good... Especially compared to Din Tai Fung...

TLDR: Order the soup dumplings
Joe's Shanghai is a New York city staple and infamous for their soup dumplings and similar dim sum dishes. I ordered their pork soup dumplings as an appetizer (they are definitely big enough to share between two people). The are delicious, juicy and perfectly spicy. I highly recommend coming here if you're in the mood for a satisfying soup dumpling. However I give the restaurant experience a 3 star review because of the lack of attention to other dishes. Their noodles (pictured below) desperately needed to be cooked more thoroughly and flavored better.

This has been my third or fourth visit here. And every time I've come here, I always get some xiao long bao and pork fried dumplings and some chicken or vegetable dish. And each time I come, the more I think that this place is a bit overrated. Yes, the first time I tried their xiao long bao, I thought this place was the best place EVER. I had never tried xiao long bao before and I wanted more and more and more. But now that the excitement from my first experience died, I can truly see and taste the actual quality of the food... Take a bite of the dumpling and look into the soup.. there are chunks and chunks of fat floating around. Let drops of the soup sit on your plate for a couple minutes... it coagulates and looks disgusting. But maybe I'm thinking about it the wrong way. It's still delicious... But I just can't help but notice the gross things... Now I pour or half of the soup and pour in spoonfuls of the ginger/vinegar sauce [which is DELICIOUS]. 

The pork fried dumplings are GREAT. Yes, a bit greasy because it's fried, but I love the thick dumpling skin. And the vinegar/ginger sauce complements it quite well. I just love that sauce. But I just love vinegar in general. haha. 

This place is overall pretty decent. I would suggest going to the Joe's Shanghai in Flushing though. That one is MUCH better. I feel like the soup in the dumplings were less fatty. And the crab/pork xiao long bao are so good. They just melt in your mouth. So good.

Oh and don't be fooled... Tip is included in the bill. I almost missed that and double tipped... whoops.
This place had poor service a B rating and gave me diarrhea. The food taste and flavors was not anything out of the ordinary. I wonder if their likes were bought.

Terrible service!!! Went today and they weren't even very busy. Ordered before several tables around us ( they pack you in like sardines, even with so many other tables free) and the other tables were finished or at least eating and we didn't receive anything. Waited 35 min and not even a dumpling. I asked how long and the man said it was coming. Another 10 min and still nothing. How long does it take for steamed dumplings, especially when everyone around us ordered and received theirs. Too many places to go in NYC to be treated so unpleasantly.  Think again before choosing this place. The ambiance was expected... definitely a dive but their reviews brought me here and I can't say anything about their food since I didn't receive it.

The soup dumplings are the star of the show, but if you come on a night when Joe's Shanghai is so busy that the dumplings are not cooked properly, the place loses its main attraction. The supporting cast needs to perform better. Reviewers have commented on the service, which we also found lacking. It wasn't always bad, but the waiters and hostesses seemed more hurried, and come off as uninterested in the customer's experience. My wife and I visit Joe's three to four times a year. We tolerate the wait and the dining in close proximity to other patrons, because we really enjoy the crab and pork dumplings. We had dinner at Joe's last night and the first round of dumplings seemed over-steamed, with little or no juicy soup inside.And another thing, don't take my money, including a service charge then forget to bring me my change, as if this was a tip on top your service charge. Come on Joe, you can do better than this!

What is the mass hysteria about this place. It's just another Chinatown restaurant that caters a dumbed down menu to a public who doesn't know any better.

The soup dumplings lacked depth of flavor and juiciness. There is better to be had to Brooklyn from past experience. 

Not saying the food tasted bad, it was just a gimmick rather than anything overly authentic. Tired of this sort of BS across New York.

Next.

Waited to be seated for forever. Finally after being seated, we were stuck at a table with random people. Then people that were sat after us, were served first. What they don't mention while waiting 40 minutes outside is that they can't serve alcohol.
Over hyped in my opinion the food was very average. For hearing that it has the best dumplings in nyc i was pretty disappointed!

Definitely do not see the hype with this place. This place is filled with mostly non-Chinese tourist. Well that explains the hype.

The wait wasn't bad but expect to be seated like you're going to yumcha with strangers because the place is small so you will most likely sit with strangers.

Got both versions of soup dumplings, cold sesame noodles, and scallion pancake. The only good thing was the pancake. The soup dumplings barely had soup in them and they both tasted the same - really bad, like expired meat or something. The noodles was bland too.

If you want to feel like a tourist then this is the place for you.

I love me some soup dumplings!! Especially when California has a bunch of hole in the wall dumpling spots.

I heard all the hype around Joe's Shanghai so yes, I threw it on my itinerary and the boyf agreed. Came on a Thursday during lunch and was seated immediately. Cash only! 

We got the iconic Crab and Pork dumplings to share. 

I love the idea behind crab and pork, but the dumplings we had were legit the most doughiest dumplings I've had with lack of filling. I was shocked that THIS is what everyone was raving about. 

The dough was oddly dough-y. Way too much starch for my liking. Plus, they are pretty pricey dumplings and not that much filling to accompany it. 

Happy to have crossed it off my list, but nothing that made my toes tickle.

Came here because of the high ratings on Yelp which explains the truck loads of tourists including myself. It really was not worth the 40 mins wait tbh. This place was already far from our Airbnb in New York so what ended up to be mediocre dumplings in a shady and smelly hood made it worse. I'm no expert when it comes to XLB and I don't have it often but XLBs famous to this caliber I really expected more. I think the only thing that stood out was the abundance of soup in each package. But when I think of crab I think of fresh, sweet and savoury. The brown soup that poured out was none of that. There was not much flavour and I told my boyfriend. He responded "...but the vinegar compliments it so well." Ummmm, if it can't blow my socks off on its own without a sauce to help... then it's really not that great. 

I was also creeping other people's dishes at my table (they are so packed here you gotta sit with randoms) and it's definitely not quality Chinese food. Would not revisit...

We only had to wait about 10 min for our table. It was an experience... sharing your table with strangers. The food was great, particularly the soup wontons and scallion pancake. The service though was not... our waiter was kind of rude and when the bus boy was cleaning up the table he was leaning right over my husband where my husband had to move out of his way while he was eating. May be just a culture thing... but it was good food. Our next visit to NYC we will probably try another place though.

Great dumplings! Very bad service and rude servers, the hostess stare at you like a ticking clock to make you eat fast so they sit the waiting customes outside. Loved the squid with salt and jalapeno pepper, well marinated. Okay place if you like sharing a table with strangers. Our server yelled at us so I yelled back my order- that shut him down. Restroom leaves something to be desired- soild and dirty toilet paper on the floor and hand dryer is as old as the paleolithic age.
I peeled into the kitchen and am sure it is not the most sanitary one, has a smell (not from the food) but a musty unclean smell

Second time 9/17 to eat here since the soup dumplings are amazing.
The male servers are good and attentive to the diners but the HOSTESS- the one who shouts for customers to come in is the RUDEST i have seen. Literally she is screaming at people and throwing the menu on the table and barks at people. Thankfully we finished our dinner , i saw 5 people almost walked out because of her. 
Told the lady at counter but not sure if she even understood what i said. 

Great eats, dirty restroom, RUDE lady hostess but at least good male servers.

Skip all food except the soup dumplings. The soup dumplings are good. They are not the best quality but you are not paying much for them.

Ambiance: Well it's a Chinese restaurant that smells like Chinese Food, with large round tables covered with cloth tablecloths. Each table seats 8-10 people.

Service:  It's quick, and nothing fancy.  Know what you want when they come by or expect to wait.  They do seat you wherever there is space so expect to make some new friends by the end of your meal.

So I have to give them 3 stars for the value.  I definitely have had better soup dumplings in NYC (better meaning better taste and quality! try Liberty View in Battery Park for awesome soup dumplings).

Perfect for a COLD Day (not the 90 degree day we went)!

Soup Dumplings were great and cheap.  

We got both the Pork and the Crab soup dumplings.  Not the BEST I've had but they were good and we were happy.  I prefer the Pork. The order was perfect for two people (Meal came out to around 15 dollars and we were full).  

Tip: Tables are shared, CASH Only.
Dumplings were good but not amazing. Line becomes ridiculous in the evenings. Not sure what the hype is all about, but overall it was a cool experience.

We had dined here numerical times. Every time when I visited New York China Town, this was my must go place. This time I noticed the food was not taste the same and the quality of the ingredients were not good. The fried rice was liked just mixing the meat with the steam rice. The rice noodle dishes tasted disgusting. What a disappointment. It's a shame to see one of my favorite place going downhill. This is a cash only place, be aware of what you ordered !!!

Another must go to in my New York Trip.  I saw this in Facebook, and had to have it.

We went to Joe's right after walking from Downtown Manhattan to Brooklyn Bridge, and walked to China Town for brunch. So hubby and I worked on our appetite for sure.  We arrived around 11 am, we did not have to wait, but we shared a large table with a party of 7.  So that kind of cramped our style.

My husband and I ordered two Xiao Long Bao- Pork and Crab.  We also had the scallion pancake and an order of Mu Shu Chicken.  

I have to have a redo and maybe I would give more stars.  The party of 7 in our table ordered almost the same entrees as us, so the server was confusing our orders with them, and due to the cramp seating, I can't get comfortable with my eating. 

Over all it was good, but I must have a redo- next time.

Updated review: after our third trip here we noticed a C rating from the health inspector on the door. The crab dumplings really upset my stomach one night. So sad. We liked this place the first time we came here.
A lot of the food carts they bring around are cold and the food doesn't taste fresh. I wanted to like this place because it's was recommended but I don't think I'll be coming back
The chicken w/ steamed veggies was horrible.  The soup dumplings were just ok.

What a SOB place  to find!! Finding our way through the tourists and locals in Chinatown to come to this place was a real pain in the butt! The wait was not long but the inside of the restaurant was a MAD HOUSE! 

People flying around everyone shouting this and that. I guess that's a Chinese restaurant for you. We got seated with a bunch of other people, communal style since we were only 2.

Crab and pork dumplings - Meh. Pretty disappointed. Monterey Park here in LA has better dumplings than that! I didn't like the juice just flowing outta the dumpling, it was hard to eat. And I could barely taste the crab.

Beef Chowmein - So so. Just your average pan-fried noodles w/ brown sauce and beef.

Everyone left and right to us were raving about the dumplings....eh, not the best but worth an experience I guess.

Din Tai Fung in Arcadia, CA has the best dumplings. Joe's does not even compare. The soup in the dumplings is overly salted and the dumpling just too heavy and has a overwhelming taste of raw flour.
