Tried their noodle and rice dishes which were extrememly salty and have so much MSG in them my body started to react to it. 

Would rather go to Vanessa's Dumplings down the street than wait in line for Joe's.

Eh, I mean I like soup dumplings and the place is close. I find the place just 'too cool for school.' The staff doesn't seem to care- even for an Asian place because their wall of fame seems to make them think they're fireproof. The pork and crab dumplings are good, but I've definitely had better-just not in Manhattan, but it's worth the trek out to Flushing if you really want XLB.
The food was good. The service was rushed. Exactly as expected for a Landmark establishment of this caliber.

Joe's Shanghai is quite reputable. 

Food wise, the Juicy Buns are definitely above average: but you can find better in one spot in Flushing...although the wait might be even longer. 

Their steamed bread (plain buns?) are tiny but really fresh. Do not get the fried ones, as the oil used seemed a bit old...made the bread much darker than usual with a funky oily smell to it. Bottom line: these ultra fresh, delicate breads aren't made for frying. 

Scallion pancake at this place is definitely below average. Do not get it. 

A word about the crowd at this location: the waiters will pass everything over your food, your table, and you...even dirty plates from another party at your table. They are also in a rush to clear your table...when my wife finished her food, they cleared away her plate settings along with all the sauces, while I am still working on my food. A strange habit that bothers even their manager. 

The waiters can speak English well enough, but the busboys do not. But if you can speak Mandarin, that's a different story. 

Anther word of caution: NO NEED TO TIP! Unless you really want to. 

Alot of people miss the tiny postings (font size 12?) on the walls stating that 15% service charge is already included in the bill. We saw lots of people struggle to figure out what the tip should be, only to find out that service charge was already included in the bill. Since we went there few days after the Lunar New Year, we wanted to give a much bigger tip, something that borders 25-30%. But we got ticked off when the manager refused to remove the service charge from the total so we can leave our own tip...so it was their loss...sorry!

My family and I haven't come here in years. We decided to go today on a whim. Once our food came, we realized why we have not been back for so long.   We remembered the last time we came we said the same thing...food was so bad and it continues to be today. Unfortunately this restaurant only survives by reputation. The food had no taste and the Xiao Long Bao was not up to the usual standards. They were big and mushy and broke apart immediately to the touch spreading the soup all over. The seasonal vegetables were suppose to be cooked with garlic and oil. Instead they came with no garlic and no taste at all. Super bland. The beef noodle soup was horrible. Noodles were not cooked. They were doughy and raw.  We would not recommend this restaurant unfortunately. It is iconic to NY but unfortunately they have let there standards slip from 10/10 to 2/10 Very sad. We always just accepted the poor service for the good food but now there's no reason to go at all. Bad service and bad food. Try Pinch in soho for the best Xiao Long Bao (chef/owner from Ding Tai Fong) plus amazing side dishes and the best beef noodle soup!

I live in a nearby neighborhood so like I like to walk to Chinatown.  All,that is to say I am no stranger to Chinatown.  I have enjoyed Joe's Shanghai in the past so I was happy to go for an early dinner with the hubby.  Sadly, like many places that become popular JS  has taken a bad turn.  We ordered crab soup dumplings ( cause you always order soup dumplings here).  They were just okay.  We also,order cold noodles with sesame sauce, which was awful.  The noodles were over cooked and the sauce was too thick with unmixed globs of s

Oh hell no.

Went here on multiple recommendations about the soup dumplings. Stopped by this place on a Saturday night (located on sketchy side street) and found a line of people waiting for the lottery. I thought 'It must be really good if there's a line'. My party waited almost 45 mins. to be called. I'm no stranger to Chinatown's crowded eateries and lumped seating arrangements where you're often seated next to strangers. We were hoping for a small table but found we were about to be lumped with two other parties at a large round table. I was not about to endure unwanted awkwardness so I opted for takeout. We ordered pork soup dumplings and headed back to my place to enjoy them...or so I thought. On the way over, I kept thinking 'What is that nasty vinegar-like smell that keeps following us?' I was hit full on with that odor when I opened the container of dumplings. I gave them a try thinking it had to be good since people raved about them. No - they were terrible! They fell apart easily and ended up in the trash. Gross. Sticking to Flushing restaurants that do it way better.

Not too shabby for a touristy spot, but I was expecting more. The soup dumplings (xiao long bao) from Shanghai Dumpling King in SF are better. Joe's are bigger, the skin thicker, and the meat felt more processed. Their kung pao chicken, however, was decent. (I know what you're thinking.. minus credibility points for ordering this, but don't judge until you try it!)
Hmm...I'm not sure if I just had high hopes or if we came on an off night. I really was not wowed by their xlb or their other dishes.  Everything was ok but not impressive.

Maybe they had an off day, but my soup dumplings were breaking, they were filed with oil not soup.  They don't have just crab, and I am not docking stars for that but I could have sworn I read they had just crab, but they have either pork or pork and crab but not just crab.  I think that's another reason I did not enjoy it because I don't love pork.  We also ordered scallion pancakes that never showed up... we weren't charged for it though but that's great service!  Yeah I won't come back and give it another chance.... Just not my thing.

Overrated.  My friend lives 1 block away from here so we walked over and waited for about 10 minutes for a table for 8 people.  

It was a HOT day. The AC was not cool enough. A lot of Caucasian tourists. $6.65 for a steamer of 8 xiao lung bao.  The skin was thin but not as thin as Ding Tai Fung in Arcadia, California.  I love the broth but I realized it is so oily and the crab meat dumpling was oozing with yellow crab meat juice.  

I retasted this place after eating here 5 years ago, I have to say I won't be back.  The tables are tight. The service is fast.  I heard the other locations are a bit better.

It was good. Don't get me wrong. The soup dumplings were good. but they did not amaze me like I thought they would. The size was a lot bigger than the ones i've tried before. And soup inside was very flavorful. The dough for the wrap was just ....lacking. It seemed to doughy for me. I prefer the thin wrappers likes DTF. The meat filling was decent. I prefer Mama Lu's/. (yes i'm comparing to spots in 626/CA area)
Is the wait worth it? Maybe. It is a tourist spot.  I say gotta try it once I  your life.

Positive:
1. Food is excellent. I only tried crab/pork dumplings as most people reviewed about it on yelp. 
2. Pepper fried duck was good too. 
3. Service is quick. No bull shit. 

Negative:
1. They do not have any dumpling without pork. Even the crab dumpling comes with pork. So if you do not eat pork, forget the dumplings. 
2. Only cash accepted. 
3. Overcrowded(due to popularity) 
4. Tables are shared amongst strangers, so do not expect privacy

I've been going to Chinatown for Shanghai buns for many years, so I've had my fair share. Finally visited Joe's since there was no wait. Not a big deal but if you didn't know, you have to share big round tables with others. The buns were a bit bigger than usual but there was really nothing special. Save yourself the wait and go to the many other Shanghai restaurants around. Nothing against it, but doesn't deserve the hype.

Decided to pay this place a visit while in Chinatown. I tried the shrimp dumplings, Shanghai's fried rice and veggie dumplings. The portions were quite generous, we even took some food to go. A good option if you happen to be in the neighborhood.

Yes the soup dumplings are amazing but that is it! The attention seems to be on raising prices which makes it less attractive for a Chinatown location. Sorry last time as a local visiting this tourist trap!

If this place only served Xia Long Bao it would deserve a 5 hands down! 

Let me help you out, if you're reading all the reviews everyone and I mean everyone is going to give this place 5 stars solely on the Xia Long Bao and they're not wrong. I have never seen so much soup stuffed into a dumpling, and its packed full of flavor. These are literally THE best dumpling ever!

Sadly everything else this place serves is mediocre at best. After trying several other dishes we decided to actually save our appetite for another restaurant. Don't get me wrong the rest of the food wasn't bad it just wasn't anything special. Com'on it's New York why eat something mediocre when you can walk down the street and eat something orgasmic.

In the end this place is a must just for the dumpling. If I was rich I would fly back just to eat them! (Too bad I'm poor)

Great place to get soup dumplings but I've had better. There is always a long line no matter what time you go. The restaurant always seems to be a bit crowded and hectic, so if you want to go here for a first date I would reconsider it.

Dumplings:

I suspect there might be a dumpling vampire somewhere because the last 2 times I came, my dumplings had been bled dry of the precious soup that makes them *soup* dumplings.  I lived in Shanghai for a summer and all the dumplings I had there were small and delicate, "ping-pong ball-esque" if you will, with just a bit of filling of filling and a TON of soup.  These, on the other hand, are larger, thicker skinned and big on meat - more "golf ball-esque".  Not bad, just not what I expected from THE soup dumpling place in NY.  They're also a little stingy with the vinegar.  I need a lot of vinegar and that little dish they brought out will not do...tisk tisk tisk.

Other stuff:

- Lion's Head (Stewed Pork Balls): YUM!  I guess I'm a sucker for meatballs.  These were fantastic.  Big, soft, and fluffy.  Definitely hit the spot.  Also made the other 7 people we shared the table with very jealous. (Definitely worth ordering for the jealousy factor alone -- ball envy.)
- Some fried noodle dish: Yum. (no caps) 
- Veggies of the day: YUM (no exclamation mark) sauteed with garlic and magic.

Administrative stuff:

It looks like a high-end version of the standard hole-in-the-wall (HITW) Chinese joint but with a lot more tourists and the prices match the look.  Service is the standard sub-par service we have come to expect and love from said HITW restaurants.

Worth a visit, not worth the wait on the regular.

Honestly, the soup dumplings are good, but I know two other spots just as good for cheaper and better service. 

Highly rude and rush you out practically the moment you get your food. As much as I hate to admit,  but there is also an air of racism as everytime I go, I have noticed my party gets consistently better attention if there is an Asian person in my party (they do not even specifically have to be Chinese, or of Chinese descent). 

I will recommend only if you are into the idea of getting really quick food and don't mind the hustle. Otherwise, there are many better spots in Chinatown to spend your time and money.

Okay, Joe's has been renowned for its dumplings for years and I think Joe's been living off this for years .  Sorry, but I think even the dumplings are overrated.  Sure, it takes skills to make dumpling skin that is both thin and yet elastic enough to contain that much broth in addition to the filling.  But I'd take a little less broth if I could have broth that tasted better.   

And with all the great Chinese food you can find in Chinatown/Flushing, I don't think it's worth the trek down here just for the dumplings.

I remember when this place first open and it was the BOMB. Unfortunately, very unfortunately the quality of this place went downhill fast. They have so much business that they don't really care about how the food is made anymore. The soup dumpling's skin was thick and squirts oily soup. If you let the soup sit on your plate for a while, it starts to coagulate. Their food, however, is still one of the best Shanghainese restaurants in NYC.

THEIR SERVICE IS HORRENDOUS!!!!!!!!!!! I know us Chinese people's customer service is not that great compared to American restaurants however I have never experienced such RUDE, RUDE, RUDE servers. I asked for a table for 4 but my friend was late so I wanted to put us down on the list first (long line). It's okay to just tell us nicely that we have to wait until my friend comes BUT THAT LADY JUST YELLED AT ME. HOLY COW. Literally, just screamed at me with her high pitch voice and her gross attitude. The waiters were all snickering when we ask for normal things people ask for in restaurants. I really didn't understand what was so funny and what's with that attitude. 

I wonder why they put that 15% service charge on the bill though. Is it because their service is so shitty that people refuse to pay tip so they have to enforce it?

THEY ARE THIEVES. That said, the food is terrific. Never had a problem there. But the service downright sucks. They are rude, and inattentive. Even when the restaurant is slow. BE VERY CAREFUL WHEN YOU ARE PAYING WITH LARGE GROUPS. Tonight I went with a group of six and we all put $20 in, which was well over the amount of the bill but we needed change back. Instead, our waiter insisted we only gave him $100 instead of $120. Then the owner came out and accused us of lying... a group of six people lying over $20.

So yea. Just...be wary and confirm how much cash you give them since they don't take credit cards. Otherwise they'll conveniently miscalculate and it will never be in your favor.

i have no idea what everyone is raving about. I went here with my sister after reading these great reviews and was SO SO disappointed. The famous "crab" /pork "dumplings", firstly had no sign of any crab and secondly squirted out oily soup...or should i say dishwater. 

we also got the "flat shanghai noodle".. which was also gross and not flat but cylinder shaped.  i had to drench it in soy sauce to make it taste okay. 


We are  however comparing to Shanghai/CHinese cuisine in australia which is way less oily, far more flavorsome and has less MSG. 

p.s we both have stomach aches
Service was good and it seemed really popular. The food was just ok, not the worth the price at all.

I give this one star because you can't go any lower....let's get right to it....we came from another place that we had apps in....shanghai 21...very good...we came here for the duck!  We decided to order more soup dumplings....scallion pancake ..vole noodles sesame sauce....beef noodle soup.

Ok...the soup dumpling was dry....like the outside was dry...not moist or soupy...hard and doughy....the noodles in peanut sauce was hard noodles in melted peanut butter....the scallion pancake was a thick fritatta like greasy pancake....the beef noodle soup had this loooooong dark black hair intertwined in the noodles!

Ok the duck....im so excited about it....waited half hour for it but that's what you do for duck.  It comes out...they already cut it up!!!!  We wanted tableside cut up presentation....bummer....skin is not crispy....you bite into it and your mouth fills up with grease.  I'm done with this place!  Now I know why its cash only...you can't fight your credit card company about it then.  Save your hard earned cash!

If you are looking for a just OK Chinese food then this is an acceptable choice.  But apparently their flavor is not authentic enough even for my two US born and bred teenagers who are so used to high standard of Southern California Chinese restaurants. Bottom line - this is a bit too touristy for our taste.

Idk the line is long, you're sharing a table with random ppl, smells sort of like steamed banana rolls and it's cash only. 

But they give you sooo much food for your money. We ordered both the pork and crab soup dumplings, cold noodles and scallion pancakes. It was too much for 2 ppl. The dumplings here are hugeeee. It taste decent but the wrapping is really thick. I liked the pork one more than the crab one. You definitely taste the crab in the crab dumpling but it's very overpowering. They have hot oil and vinegar with ginger on the table. Scallion pancake was nice and buttery. Definiely would pass on the cold noodles. It's just sesame sauce, no other seasonings on overcooked noodles. Happy to have tried it but there are better soup dumplings elsewhere for cheap.

It's very greasy "Chinese food" that gives Chinese food a bad name. I've tried soup dumplings and scallion pancake at other places and the quality of the ingredients and technique of the cooking gives a better less-greasy product than Joe's. 

Other things I ordered were Shanghai style flat noodles and stewed pork with tofu skins. 

The noodles were oily and so was the food generally. The cost for 2 appetizers, 2 entrees,  1 coke, 2 bowls of rice came out to about $50. 

The price isn't high but not low either and sort of typical for a meal at many places (so no cost savings here). 

The place like the name is kinda greasy looking too.

This is a typical overrated restaurant. The only dish that was worth eating was the soup dumplings. Four other dishes that we tried were lame and salty. Also they obviously were evading tax for the waiter accepted the next table White customers' credit card payment, but demanded cash only from us. I hope IRS would pay attention to this restaurant for the discrepancy between the amount of business they are getting and the earnings they file. I would suspect they only report half of their earnings to the IRS. Remember the more tax they evade, the more tax everyone else has to pay and it is illegal. Next time, refuse to pay tips unless they take your CC.

The Kung Pao chicken had no heat at all, but it had good flavor.  The spring rolls were crispy, and decent flavor but they did not have duck sauce.  The pork dumplings are excellent, and the potions are plentiful.  That said, the wait is very long and they seat you out of order.  several numbers after mine were called out before I was seated.  The family style seating leaves them few options for seating, and they are often seating 2 or 3 separate groups at the same table.  $14 for kung pao, I expected a bit more.
Oily oily, cash only, and no XLB that's seafood based. It's the last one that really got me. Otherwise most people probably think this place is decent.

the famous XLB dumplings were quite good though the crab version was hotter than the pork one and the broth seemed to be richer. We also tried clams in black bean sauce, a family favorite that we haven't had in a few years. Plenty of clams (and generous salting) we (two) had no trouble finishing 2 orders of The  xlb and the clams with the rice. 

We arrived at about 5:00pm Saturday and had no wait. Of course the scene was very different when we left .  Note: this is the sort where everyone uses chopsticks so if you have self-conscious guests who don't like being the only ones in a packed, non private table using a fork find an uptown place!

What happened to Joe shanghai? This used to be my go-to place for soup dumplings in Chinatown but it recently moved to a new location nearby. The decor is much nicer and the space is bigger but everything else went downhill. 

Our soup dumplings came out first. We had a order of the pork soup dumplings and a order of the crab and pork soup dumplings. They were filled with plenty of soup inside and the flavor was good. However, the skin of the dumpling was a bit too thick and overpowered the filling. 

Throughout my whole dining experience here, the service was odd and unorganized. Before we even had a chance to look through the menu, a server was standing behind us waiting to take our order. After we ordered our food, we asked for a cup of tea but yet they came back with a plate of cold chicken instead that we didn't order. When we were almost done with our meal, we inquired about one of the missing items we ordered earlier and he told us he didn't put the order through. Why did he say okay when we placed the order then? They also put a vegetarian noodle dish on our table but another waiter rushed over to take it back since it didn't belong to us. We ordered the beef pan fried noodles. When it finally arrived, the noodles were nice and crispy and there was a good variety of ingredients inside. However, we thought the dish was way too salty!
Great ambiance, very clean and good service. The food portions are large and satisfying. Good food. There is better in the area but the food and the price and suitable and good.

I use to crave the dumplings from this place, until I went with my sister.  I was shocked when she poured out the soup from her dumpling onto her plate and only ate the dumpling.  She was practically missing out on the essence of this "delicacy".  My sister ended up doing this for all the dumplings she ate and after some time, her plate looked like a disgusting, jello-y, vat of fat and grease.  It was the first time I saw what the soup actually looked like and it grossed me out!  Now I understood why my stomach would always hurt after eating these dumplings, it was because I was drinking lard!

But if you decide that you want to fill your stomach with fat and grease, the pork dumplings are better than the crab, and the scallion cake compliments the dumplings as you get the same grease but deep-fried.

There are two ways to eat these dumplings.  First, you take a dumpling from the basket and place it on your spoon, and this in itself is an art as you don't want to tear your dumpling during the transfer or you'll lose all the soup.  Once you've successfully placed the dumpling on your spoon, you can go one of two ways.  I usually bite the top of the dumpling and then slurp the soup.  Others poke a hole at the bottom of their dumpling with a chopstick, let the soup pour out into the spoon, and slurp the soup before eating the dumpling.  In either case there's a good chance that you'll burn your mouth so be careful!

This place is definitely a tourist destination - and if you're a local like myself you know there are far more better dim sum / Shanghai places.

With that said, the highlights for me were the soup dumplings. Which again, were good, but I've had others that were great.

I LOVED their chicken fried rice. They gave so much, definitely enough to share for 2-4 people and be satisfied. I don't know if it's the seasoning, or what to put my finger on - but it's delicious and probably the best fried rice I've ever had.

Didn't really care for the pan fried noodles. I got the beef option - and the beef and broccoli in the brown sauce was delicious - but the pan fried noodles were thick and became soggy because of the sauce. And instead of absorbing it and being packed with flavor - they become chewy and less desirable. 

PS. this place is cash only! heads up.
Only okay. I feel like it is overrated and a bit of a tourist trap. I think there are definitely better Shanghainese restaurants around.

I've been coming here for over 10 yrs now. I'm not sure what happened but the quality has definitely changed and its disappointing. The ratio of wrapper to soup and meat is pretty significant. The wrapper is much larger and you no longer are able to enjoy the dumpling in one bite. I'm not sure if the owners changed but it's sad... I always look forward to visiting Joe's when I'm in NYC. Maybe, it was an off day fo

I had the Xiao Long Bao, their signature meat bun. It was mediocre, nothing I could NOT get here in Virginia.

I wish I had the CHANCE to eat here. It was so packed..

Used to be one of my favorite dumpling spot in Chinatown . Now I would say that there are 3 other places in Chinatown that have better prices and tastier dumplings and tip is your option (Joe adds the tip to your bill).  Service is bad and the waitstaff can be rude at times.  Yelpers who give them rave reviews need to venture into Chinatown and try some of the other dumpling places.  Joe Shanghai went from a great place to an average place.  Next time you want soup dumplings explore other options in Chinatown.  Walk down Bayard or Mott street even Elizabeth street you have so many options. Don't limit yourself.

Dumplings are okay. Cool location. A lot going on inside, it can be a little intimidating if you're not a regular I guess. Not my kind of spot. I sat at a random table with an older man and woman who were also there alone. A little weird, waiters all over trying to tend to everyone. The place was packed. I went for a quick bite at lunch hour. Might want to avoid the lunch hour here lol. (12-2) Dumpling+Noodle is my favorite spot in Bronxville.

I was so excited to eat at Joe's Shanghai tonight after work!!! The atmosphere was lively, cheery and bustling at 6pm and I was with good company :). Despite the crowd, we were seated promptly and with a smile. It was looking to be a promising first experience.

Now, I know my xiao long baos. My parents are from Shanghai and I had them every day while I was there in June. And let me tell you, the XLBs at JS did not disappoint...

...that is, until we found a MAGGOT latched onto a dumpling. I thought it was a loose piece of cabbage at first, but upon closer inspection, I saw its juicy segmented body and little leg bumps...mmm, insect appendages...

Needless to say, we all lost our appetites. When we pointed out the maggot to the waiter, he dismissed it as a "vegetable bug" -- what the heck is that? -- and said he'd put in another order for us. But we didn't want more -- who knows how many maggots there are hidden in those dumplings??!

We were refunded that one order of XLBs and decided to take our noodle dishes to go, barely touched. We left empty-stomached, spooked, and very disappointed. No way I'm coming back.

Very juicy xlb. I liked them a lot;  it was good . The restaurant filled up quick, we arrived before they open and had to line up outside the store . I didn't try anything else just one order of pork and one of crab to go since it was almost time for us to check out of the hotel.  After we walked back to the hotel, the xlb were still steamy hot.  I will come back for more next time I visit NYC.

Community tables, huge portions, food is ok. Not the best Chinese food out there if you ask me but decent food. Dumplings are good, fried rice is ok, duck very very dry. The service is terrible. I read the reviews before and most people said the service is great. Maybe I really didn't get lucky this time, but our waiter was a ******* ! Didn't give us any water, wouldn't respond when I'd talk to him and when I asked if I could get watermelon (I saw many plates with some so I made me want some too!) he straightly said: no. A dry ass no. And left without any explanation. The guy sitting next to me was just as shocked as I was and said he probably didn't hear me. So he asked him for me! The guy purely and simply looked at him and ignored him. WTH?
Also didn't care to ask if we wanted a doggy bag for our leftovers. They got thrown away immediately. Let's say communication isn't the speciality of the house. And I won't go back.

The food was ok. Standard Shanghai dishes and the taste was alright. Around half of the dumplings were stuck to the steaming basket and had no soup which was disappointing. 

The worst part of this restaurant was the service. We were a party of 2 placed on a table with two other parties. This was fine since the restaurant was mostly full. We asked the female server with glasses by the door if we could get some help to remove some empty plates from the table as the table became full. She answered in a very rude tone and said "No I can't". No wonder this place charges a mandatory 15% service fee.

Don't expect tablecloths or fine china - or even the waiters to pay attention to you without excessive flagging.

Joe's Shanghai is a pretty typical, run of the mill Chinatown restaurant - expect it to be busy, cheap, and loud, and don't expect to always get your own table. There's always a crowd waiting outside, and they seat as efficiently as possible - that includes filling up the bigger tables as fully as possible. 

The menu options have all the family favourites, but people really seem to come to Joe's Shanghai for the soup dumplings. 

The soup dumplings were pretty good - they definitely weren't the best I've ever had, and I honestly don't think they were the best in Chinatown either. None of them had popped or leaked, but the skin is pretty thick, and instead of being plump, some of them kind of shrivel up. The other food on the menu is pretty run of the mill.
Soup dumplings are really big and oily. 456 Shanghai in Chinatown is better.

The hot and sour soup was excellent. The rest - soup dumplings, pickled cabbage, cold sesame noodles - was WAY too oily. Too oily even for our 6 foot teenager who is a human food vacuum. I love Chinese but would have to say give this one a pass.

Very noisy & crowded.  Menu is not clear, start doesn't always understand English.

I thought the food was ok.  I could get better in my in neighborhood.  I wouldn't go out of my way for this place.

We got pork and crab xlb. They were really big and there was tons of soup inside but I feel like it is not as flavorful. It definitely needs soy sauce and vinegar to make it taste better. The onion pancakes was way too starchy n it didn't have enough onion. I would not order that again.

Be prepared to share your table with at least 2 other parties and be massively confused about whose xiao long bao is whose. 

I'm actually ok with the arrangement and the somewhat hurried pace, but I think that the food is overall pretty average.

Soup dumplings have good integrity, thin skin the way I like it, but the soup was too oily/salty for me. Reasonable price though ($6.75 for 8)

Also ordered the salt and pepper pork chops, which came out a bit soggy, didn't have enough spice, and sadly reminded me more of chicken nuggets :(

The shanghai noodles tasted pretty good, but more saucy/oily than I'd like.

Cash only!
The food is medicore but the service is extremely TERRIBLE.   They don't treat customers with any respect but yet they want to receive 20% TIPS.

Totally disappointed after flying 5,000 miles to try out this place.

First, three groups of customer -- 11 people -- needed to share a table.   We ordered the cold dishes:   Dry Bean Curd with Mixed Vegetables and Wine Chicken.  And then Peking Style Minced Pork Noodle and two orders of Xiaolongbao.

The dried bean curd is lousy in quality -- but I don't blame the chef since there ain't any good dried bean curd found anywhere in North America.  But the wine chicken is really so so -- most likely due to the kind of Shaoxing wine the chef uses.

The Xiaolongbao is the most disappointing -- we couldn't even finish it.  The top part of the dumpling is tough (most likely as a result of refrigeration) while the broth tastes like fatty pork mixed with MSG.

Did our fellow yelpers, who are impressed by their dumplings, ever try the Xiaolongbao from Ding Tai Fung?

But the food is incredibly cheap -- many items came under $5 -- so you get what you pay for.

For me customer service is really important in a restaurant. Waiters/Waitresses can easily ruin your appetite. To me, the food was a bit better than other shanghai restaurants you go to in chinatown. The waiter/waitresses do not respect customers.
Not authentic at all...and the do not have dim sum as it said in yelp.. Too salty and very American Chinese... First time yelp lets me down:(

I do NOT know what the hype is with this place. 
The Shanghai Dumplings were OK; definitely NOT the best. 
The 'skin' on the dumpling was too dry and thick. It was Not silky nor was it yummy. 
The filling in the dumpling (we got the Crab and Pork) was OK. 
The ONLY thing i liked was the soup IN the dumpling. that was flavorful and thicker than usual. 

The other dishes were really quite bland/ boring. 

Summary:
- Shanghai Fried Rice- Pretty yummy. 
- Yang Chow Fried Rice- that was OK. 
- 5 Spice Fried Chicken. SO BLAND. I don't know why they wouldn't just marinate the chicken and coat it with the 5 spice instead of bringing out the salt in a separate dish. 

We also ordered 2 different dishes which LOOKED and TASTED exactly the same except they were served on 2 separate plates and with 1 different ingredient. 
HELLO? 

I felt completely ripped off.
I also just found out that the Service charge/ TIP has already been added to the check- i paid an EXTRA 15% for so-so food and bad service? FAIL

No more Joe's Shanghai for me- I can get MUCH better dumplings from random dimsum places in SF or LA and definitely Way better ones in Asia. 

Fail

The hype this restaurant joys and the long wait outside are not reflective of the overall quality of the food. The dumplings were "good", not great. The duck was tasteless . Sesame noodles definitely had peanut butter added which is a no-no. Service was quite good. Best bet in Chinatown is to poke around and see where the locals are eating and avoid the touristy places such as this. We live in San Francisco and we follow our own advice!

Joe's has long been on my list to try, and unfortunately was a total miss for me. The food was decent, but it wasn't amazing. We did order take out online and eat once we got to Brooklyn. Which I do reccomend if you want food but don't want to wait in line, it was ready fast!
We enjoyed the plum chicken & shrimp (not v much shrimp) & the soup dumplings were pretty good too. The chicken fried rice was very dry which was strange because it was very dark like it had lots of sauce on it. The general tso was fried nice just wasn't quite as spicy as I expect it to be!
The food wasn't terrible by any means, I just think I'd rather try somewhere else next time

Came here during COVID so didn't have to wait in line for hours like it used to be. The soup dumplings are amazing as always, but the regular dishes are just so-so. TBH the dishes are on the pricey side given the quality and quantity.

Came here on a Thursday evening around 8:15 pm, waited for a good 45 minutes for a party of 4. Came in and saw that we were sharing a table with 3 other people, no worries, that's fine. At this point, we were already starving. Decided to order the Shanghai flat noodles, which was good BUT I must add...this dish was quite oily. Literally, each strand slithers into your mouth without any suction - kid you not. Next, we ordered the crab and pork dumplings...alright, I've been to a few XLB restaurants back in California so I know what good XLB taste like. As they set the order of the dumplings, I noticed half of them already had their juices popped!!!! No need to use the silver tong, use your chopsticks so you don't burst the soup, but no need for that since it was already spilled all over the lettuce -___- This place is hyped up, not a fan at all and will not be coming back. Let me go back home and fill this satisfying hunger. Bleh

Was here last year... Quality went down for sure.  Also it was noticeable more expensive this time.  And they added an automatic tip on a party of two! 

Last time I'm coming here

Oh, wow.  This place is so overrated.  Overrated in the same way Notre Dame football is overrated.  The dining room is crowded...which, for a Chinese restaurant, is actually a good thing.  Don't eat in a Chinese restaurant that doesn't have crowds.  Trust me.  But I digress.  The crowd makes for unfriendly service and you'll likely be rubbing elbows with strangers.  I don't mind this if the food is good.  But it's not worth it for average food.    

Their steamed pork dumplings (soupy dumpling house specialty) were pretty good.  Careful when taking a bite, as the juice squirts out all over the place.  Decent flat rice noodle dish.  Actually, all the dishes we had were decent to good.  

This place is a typical Chinese food dive, with dive-like service, cleanliness, and seating.  But not-so-dive-like prices.  Throw in the crowds and the poor service and you have a below average experience.  If you've convinced yourself that you want a "cultural" experience of really crowded dining rooms with people speaking loudly (code for semi-yelling) to go along with brusque service because it makes you think "China"...then you might check out this place.

Jesus christ , I have no idea how this place got so famous. The food here is quite bad, and they sure do use a lot of rubber bands in their food. Yes I know they're not rubber bands but they sure do look, feel, and taste like it. There are other ways to make that stuff without it being so... so rubber bandy. I would give this place one star as they are rather pricey as well, BUT they do have good soup dumplings and I am aware that's the main attraction. But that's my tip, only get the soup dumplings, just about everything else sucks.

Everyone always raves about this place, so I just had to try it out. It was pretty empty when I went there, perhaps it was too early to really be dinner time. I tried the regular soup dumplings and I wasn't that impressed. Perhaps I eat frozen ones too much? I didn't really like it all that much and I feel like this place is pretty much over-hyped.

It's been several years since I've been here but the experience has tanked. Ordered two xiao long baos and it took 40 min to come out. And only 1 order came out and they charged us for two. The dumpling is also not as good anymore.

Omg I was so excited to try Joe's Shanghai especially the crazy amount of reviews at this particular location, but it is really not worth the hype.


Being from the west coast here in Los Angeles, I have my regular dumpling house I go to called Mama Lu's. I of course had expectations Joes will surpass the Lu's, but it didn't. Their famous xiao long bao aka pork soup dumpling lacked flavor and the texture of the wrap is not authentic at all if you know what a true xiao long bao is suppose to taste like. Only thing that attracts customers is the huge size of these dumplings, but I'm more of a quality over quantity type of gal.


We also ordered szechuan beef with bean curd and shanghai noodle soup. Those weren't good either. So I honestly have nothing else to say about them.



Overall this is more of a tourist spot. The service is just like any typical fast pace Asian restaurant (meaning no service pretty much). Portions are huge though.

I don't get all the hype.  It's okay food.  I do not like that they add the 15% tip to the bill.My friend and I went on a Sunday at noon and there was no line.

The soup dumplings tasted like other places to me.  The Szechuan beef tendon noodle soup was good.  I liked how soft the noodles were.  The Singapore chow mai fun was yummy and had lots of fun.  I liked how fluffy the eggs were.  

I think sharing the table with an annoying couple took away from my experience.  The couple was annoying and the guy had to ask his wife every time he if he was allowed to eat something.  They wouldn't stop asking us what we ordered and how do we eat our soup dumplings.

Food is good as expected. But price is high. They also need to renovate. The furniture is old. But I think they believe in not changing anything because of the superstition that it will blow away all their good luck and blessings. They also need to get their city rating up from B. It's kinda gross to think that they're not clean back there handling food.

The worst service ever. The hostess skipped our group having us wait for over an hour. After confronting and asking, she continued to ignore our party until I spoke to the manager. We also sat at the table with random strangers already eating. The odor in the Restaurant smells atrocious. I would never recommend or return.

The food definitely wasnt bad but all the buzz about it is uncalled for. The xiao long bao was alright, and the same goes for the beef tendon and their house chilli. I'd head to shanghai asian manor over it any time.

So disappointing. We ordered crabmeat xiaolongbao, yuntun soup and fired rice cakes. All taste weird and bad. I would say not even as good as any other random restaurant in Chinatown. Don't know why it is so over-rated. Will never go there again.

I personally think this place is just overrated.  There are plenty of good Shanghai food in Chinatown besides Joe's Shanghai. One time I order my Xiao Long Bao and inside the dumpling it has a nose hair.  I almost ate it and good thing my friend caught it before I popped it in my month.  Yuck, never again I would go to this place.  Very disturbing!

Dude take card 
The food was O.K. The dumplings and the chicken are the only good things there. Forget about the seafood it was slimy and gross like it was cooked and then reheated.

This place is way too crowded and overrated.
If you see too many non chinese people at chinese restaurants you'll know it's overrated and all whitewashed.
the xiaolong bao wasn't that good, too much juice. When they brought the steamer out the buns look like they been mutilated. They need to have better presentation of their items. They should look the same everytime each time they bring it out. Being busy is no excuse to skimp on the presentation.
Do not get the spring rolls, do not get their pai gu noodles, the noodles are just regular noodles and the pork ribs are like fried. i was expecting them to be in soup form. you wanted me to mix a fried pork chopish item in a stewed noodle???!?!

I rather go the cheap dumpling places like Prosperity and others as they tasted way better and CHEAPER

For those that live in chinatown or the area and have eaten at different places around CT, they can attest to the fact that this place is nothing special at all. The high rating and fame comes from hype, nothing more. Their food is mediocre / OK; nothing spectacular that warrants the 4 and 5 star ratings.

People who fall for the supposed rating, be prepared to be some what disappointed. Their Xiao Long Bao's are supposedly their specialty, compare it to any other shanghai restaurant, there isn't much if at all any discern-able difference. Their other foods can be rated as a dime a dozen, nothing super tasty of fantastic.

Me and my friends always laugh at the ridiculous amount of people piled up waiting to get in, especially since there's better food and plenty of other restaurants in the vicinity. But to each their own.

Food was pretty decent. Not any better than my local Chinese food places. I'm shocked it has so many high reviews and maybe a lot of the yelpers are from parts of the country/world where food Chinese food doesn't exist. It's good but not great. The wait staff is rude and wouldn't refill our waters after our first glass. They seemed like they were rushing us out. Which isn't a great feeling when you're trying to eat and enjoy conversation. Go when it's dead and over it'll be a better experience.

This place is always crowded. Loaded with hipsters and some Chinese. If you're looking for XLB(Xiao long bao) in Manhattan this will most likely be your best option.

Is it the best XLB? No. It's not Din Tai Fung (when are you opening one in NY?) but it ain't bad. They have American Chinese food like General Tso chicken- I had it the first time here with friends while sharing a table with a lazy Susan with a bunch of teenage upper east side kids.. On a food culture trip... It ain't bad.

The service is horrible. Feed you. Check and pay! That's basically it. Beware of sour puss face waiters, they love their job so much that when they forgot your meal and you ask them about it- that 10 mins takes over an hour!

Food was ok. I have had way better Chinese food. Maybe we just did not order the right food but it was not that good. I had the salt and pepper squid (tasteless) and orange chicken ( this was good and very tender). We also got the crab and pork soup dumpling and it was not that great. . The service was ok. We were not offered water when we sat down and had to ask twice and finally got it half way through. The restaurant was less than half full but keep in mind that this is a small place.
Terrible food, terrible service, doesn't live up to he's name. There is no reason no come here with so many good restaurants around

I was looking for real chinese food so I did my research on yelp and found Joe's Shanghai. At first I was thinking, what kind of a name is Joe's Shanghai, is it a american chinese food that I got myself into too. The place was in back alley of ChinaTown so it took me some time to found it. The place itself was extremely pack and when I walk in, I saw all of their pic;s on all of the food magazine so I was happy that I want here. I order the crab and pork dumbling, soft shell crab and the minced pork noodle and 2 sing tao beer to drink. The dumbling was very good, it was so juicy that It was spilling all over the place. I have to admit, they make it better then the best place in California but it is only the 2nd best place. The first is has to be China.
The minced pork noodle was too sweet for my taste and the soft shell crab was a bit greasy for me. Next time I go here again, I am just going order more dumbling and more beer's to drink LOL

Typically love every dish from here but ordered the beef w scallions for dinner. I would think the dish would be as mentioned, beef with scallions. Instead it was filled with this tasteless vegetable that legit was 75% of the dish, which I assume they use as a filler to use less beef. Insane that I paid 23 bucks for this. Gross.

This restaurant is only about the money and not about the customer.  They sat many tables in front of us and could careless about the table order.  The experience was ruined due to the excessive unnecessary wait!

Health grade pending for the longest time, now a hidden "C" inside the front door. A C rating equates to some nasty stuff..sad because the food is fantastic. Sorry, can't go back until that grade improves.

Oh Joe, what has happened to you? I think the Joe of my youth may have passed to the other side without sharing his secrets. This was my favorite Chinese place for decades, but since COVID the food is no longer okay. So upset.

Three stars only due to their POOR CUSTOMER SERVICE (if you could even call it that)... They have so many staff working (if you consider standing around chatting to each other working), where you try to wave one over, they look at you, and seriously look away. WTH????  If it weren't for the yummy xiao lung bao's, i would really pass on this place. It's small, I feel like someone is ALWAYS walking into my chair, it's loud, and very uncomfortable when you're trying to indulge in ur xiao lung bao, but then there's this total stranger that's sitting at the same table....

This place is always packed, but our wait was pretty short on memorial day weekend. 

It was my 2nd time trying this place. I liked the amount of soup inside the dumplings but they were too bland (at least for this time). The ginger sauce helped only a bit. Hopefully it'll be better next time~

((I personally prefer Philly's soup dumplings @ Dim Sum Garden))

Love the food but hate the staff. My favorites are the soup dumplings. The staff however can be really mean. They will literally yell at you, roll there eyes and walk away shaking their heads if you ask them for anything.
Totally disappointed on our last visit -- now I think just a tourist trap.  Last time I was there a year ago sooooo much better quality.

Came here on a Tuesday afternoon for some Xiao Long Bao (one of shanghai's most famous dish). Joe's Shanghai is one of NYC's first restaurant known for the dish. Over the years I feel that their quality of their most famous dish has decrease. There are other places in Chinatown that have this dish and taste the same if not better.

The waiters and waitresses are not polite, and many times you have to share tables with other parties. It is literally as if you are eating in China (the lower class restaurants). 

It is still a good place to go if you want a quick fix, doesn't mind the bad service and on a low budget. Also want a true feel of what most places in China feels like, then take a chance, you have nothing to lose.

I had a great time regardless because I was with good company. Go with good friends, ones that you don't need to impress.

Also, there are 3 locations: queens, midtown, and chinatown. The place is chinatown is about $2 cheaper per dish than the one in midtown. Queens is too far to compare for its distance.

This restaurant is disgusting. The the silverware they gave us was so dirty it stuck to the plate. When we asked the waiter about it he shrugged. The food has the same names as the food at Joe's Shanghai but not any flavor. We also observed the waiter telling a German tourist that he owed $6 for a tip and pressure him to pay it.  I think that's called being mugged by your waiter.

The soup dumplings here are really good, along with the scallion pancakes.  When we arrived there it was cold out, and there was space to wait inside BUT! the girl who gave us a number told us we had to wait outside ... makes no sense to me but okay...anyways, to not get confused the soup/Shanghai dumplings are listed as "steamed buns" under the appetizer section. We ordered the crab & pork ones and the pork - the regular pork ones taste better than the one with crab meat.  The scallion pancakes were crispy and good, a little oily.  The two other dishes (Shanghai noodle and Eggplant with garlic sauce) we ordered were way too oily, which led me to believe that every other dish were would be pretty oily.  Overall, I would only come back here to eat the soup dumplings but probably nothing else.  We ended up bagging the two dishes up and giving them to a homeless man on the street.

This place is spacious and the service is alright, however being known for their soup dumplings, I was not impressed. 
Served in a wooden dish in 8, around half of their dumplings were either dried up, or had all the soup already drained due to poor quality. 
Could use improvement.

one word.  OILY!  everything OILY!! the din tai fung in LA is wayyyyy better.  the leaking soup in each dumpling was cool but the taste was OILY!  wasnt' satisfied at all so we went to the halal cart within the next hr and pigged out on a gyro & rice dish. and then, THAT hit the spot. we had to wait an hour for a table,which we shared with two other couples. suuuuper crowded and for what? some oil... i had to drink hot tea to oil it down.
Go for the soup dumplings, not the Peking duck! The duck they serve is literally $30 and you get scraps!

I came to this place with very high expectations since there was so much buzz around it. Sadly, was greeted with a giant C health rating at the door which I felt like they tried to hid in the corner. This kinda threw me off but I was already there so I decided why not. The food was decent but I would only recommend getting the soup dumplings since they is what they are known for. The egg plant in garlic was just the same as I could get any where else - nothing special. If you love soup dumplings then defiantly check this place out besides that thought, go somewhere with a better health rating.

I've been hearing about differences in west coast versus east coast Xio Long Bao and wanted to see for myself. I've been several times to that famous west coast location in LA and was excited to try Joe's Shanghai. We caught the metro on a rainy Sunday morning to Chinatown, it was a short walk from the Canal street station and passed several dumpling shops on the way. Fortunately for us, we arrive at around 11: 15 am and we were able to get seats for 3 right away, no wait! 

Food: Pretty big menu but we were here for the soup dumplings. We ordered the Crab Meat with Pork Soup Dumplings, Pork Meat Soup Dumpling, Pork Boiled Dumplings (for contrast), and Egg Drop Soup. First off, the soup dumplings are huge compared to their west coast cousins at that famous place (rhymes with Tin Dai Mung). Filled to with an amazing amount of rich, creamy, fatty broth that overflows the soup spoon, it was definitely not a one bite and done dumpling. Drain out the soup first and enjoy, top with some of soy and vinegar and it was delicious. We favored the crab dumpling slightly ahead of it's porky brother. The boiled dumplings were okay, definitely bringing up the rear of the three we ordered. Compared to people around us, we really didn't bring our dumpling A game. We were not able to finish the 24 dumplings between the three of us which was a bit surprising. The diners sitting around us were still packing it away as we sadly (but happily full) admitted defeat.

Service: Loud, hurried, chaotic, everything that a good Chinese restaurant should have! Since it's a shared table, they place the food order on the table sized lazy susan and gesture to the party that "owns" that dish. Each party then removed the dish off the center and placed it by their plates. It can get a little crowded if you don't keep up with the pace of the food. Food itself came out very quickly once ordered.

Atmosphere: Bustling, loud, lots of activity, large round tables that you share with total strangers, it was a great experience. Never having been here we did not know what to expect since we were seated right away. When we left Joe's after about 45 minutes there must have been 40+ people waiting outside the door. It was a cool experience but if that crowd had been there when we arrived we may have very well chosen one of the other dumpling spots in the area. 

Value: Soup dumplings were all under $10 with entree meals priced between $10 and $20 provides pretty good value. 

Overall: I wouldn't mind returning in the future to try some of Joe's other offerings. Some of the noodles dishes seemed quite popular as well, coming with a larger group probably is better as people can try a wider variety. I was a little torn as the boiled dumplings were okay, the soup dumplings were good and the price to size ratios were off the charts. They compared well to their west coast cousins especially in the value department but I've had better xio long bao in NY but at a much higher price point. I'd give them a 3.5 stars.

I still don't understand why people come here from all over the world, including Asian countries. I thought they would have better xiao long bao over there? Don't get me wrong, the food here is not bad but not the best and not worth the wait.

Not recommended. 
Went there on Chinese New Year Eve. The service was really bad. no reservation accepted, were asked to wait outside, and no seating before everybody arrives, even we told them that we could order right after seated. 
NO sense of customer service and lack flexibity at all. 
I will never come back again, and next time will try Shanghai Cafe instead, heard they have even better Xiao Long Bao!!!

This was one of the first restaurants we ate at when we first moved to Manhattan because I heard good things about it. Turns out, the food really is just average, and the services is sub-par. We had just moved from LA at that time and LA has such a great variety of authentic Chinese restaurants that we really were not impressed by Joe's Shanghai at all.

Omg, so much MSG my throat is dry the next two days.

Joe's Shanghai is known for their soup dumplings/xiaolongbaos. The meat is super soft and there is darn good piping hot soup residing inside the dumpling shell. BUT (yes there is a but), there's too much excess skin for my liking, thus creating an ultra saggy and unpleasant looking dumpling. I've had better but this is pretty solid for NY standards.

The jelly fish was overly chewy and unmemorable. #chewingfordays. I'd skip.

The crispy pepper duck was too dry and overcooked, definitely not what I'm accustomed to.

The pan fried noodles had too much noodle and not enough sauce to coat and soften the noodles.

The fried rice cakes were bomb and delicious on day 2 (leftovers).

The scallion pancake was crunchy and pretty darn savory when dipped in sauce.

Clams with scallion and ginger was light and refreshing. Very Ê∏Ö and the best pick of the night!

Overall, Joe's is pretty standard. It's your typical Chinatown restaurant with the addition of above average soup dumplings. Oh yeah, CASH ONLY!

Soooo it seems like this is where the locals go, but when you look around, there seems to not be any Asians insight except for the workers (the case when I went at least). So what does that say about the food? It was an interesting adventure, I would go with someone experienced if you dare to enter. They are a very fast paced restaurant and will give you a ticket for your place in line. Expect to be seated around a round table with multiple groups of people. This makes ordering a little interesting and conversations directed across the table.

The food was all okay for me, nothing super outstanding. They're popular for their soup dumplings of course. I do have to say the portions were decent at least. Their menus could use an update and some pictures. Also, CASH ONLY! I wouldn't come back when there's so many other places in Chinatown to try!

Very tasty, and renowned for their soup buns, which are well worth coming here for. But expect to wait in line, and sit at a crowded, noisy, shared table.

The reason why their soup buns are so good is because the super thin skin is tough enough to not break while picking it up with your chopsticks. When you bite into it, hot, oily (yes, a bit unhealthy, but tasty) soup comes gushing out. It's best to nibble at a little corner, and slowly suck out all the soup. I like mine with vinegar too, but thats a personal preference.

Their other food is more Americanized, and not spectacular. I would stick with the soup buns. Oh, and not all the waiters will understand you if you speak English to them.

Extremely bad food and bad service. It is not worth the wait. They gave us table for two next to a dust bin - this is not how you treat customers who wait for an hour. The food was not cooked well and priced high

I worked in Shanghai about one year. Joe's Shanghai has the similar food. I have to say it is real Shanghaine food. Kind of sweet. Some of my friends are fans of this. So I came here several times since the first try. Cons: Limited space. Not clean enough. Kind of noisy. Sometimes you need to wait.

Not impressed the second time around. Was there about 3 years ago and the soup dumplings were delicious. This time around the broth was salty as all hell and over reduced. Also most of them were stuck together making it a nightmare to get apart without breaking. 
And here's my main tip if you go here. Try the soup dumplings if you must but do not even dare ordering any dishes unless you like throwing your money away. It's clear they are hanging their hat on the mediocre dumplings and everything else is given absolutely no effort. There's much better places to spend your hard earned money.

I don't know what all the fuss is about.  We waited an hour and a half (for a party of 11) and honestly, I have had better XLB and better Chinese food.  That is not to say the XLB was bad, it was just OK.

The dumplings have a thicker skin than I'm used to and the soup is not as flavorful as I had expected.  The dumplings are however, huge.  The crab dumpling was slightly better and only because you can really taste the crab.  We also had green beans and Shanghai noodles which were meh.  The green beans were too soft and the noodles were dry.

Is a wait time of 30 minutes worth it for Joe's Shanghai? I've had my fair share of soup dumplings and to see an establishment that's as busy as them really boggles the mind. To answer my own question earlier; absolutely not. While the soup dumplings did succeed with soup/meat ratios and flavor, I couldn't get over the fact that the dumpling skin was extremely sticky towards my lips. I checked to see if my lips were chapped, they weren't, thank goodness. 

My wife and I had to share a table with a group of people which is understandable considering the volume of clientele going in and out. One idiot group member at our table asked the server "why do we have to share a table?" I simply looked at her and proceeded to take our seats... Don't want to digress further, but let's all be honest to ourselves and know that soup dumplings is a relatively simple comfort food. The fact that there's so many people going to eat the same, just doesn't make sense. I could get the same quality, possibly better price, and not have to wait.
One of the worst Chinese place I have ever been to in the states and yes I am a Chinese. If you want actual Chinese place food, this is not the place to go.

This place is ridiculously overrated.

The skin on the soup buns was too thick and tough. They tasted like they were sitting awhile between being made and being steamed. The jellyfish was blah. The noodles with peanut sauce were passable, but I could do better then that at 3AM after a night of partying in my own kitchen. Combine that with absurdly rude service - unforgivable!

Never again. Noodle House in Flushing - here I come!

Oh god! It was horrible experience. The round table has to be shared with bunch of other groups when it's crowded and they didn't let us know until we got inside. They only try to make money and don't consider its experience and the service  at all. I'll never go again

Be honest, I'm not sure why this place is so popular!

Since I'm in Chinatown, it will be unfair for me to judge the environment! You will know once you visit there! (Wink)

Food quality, the soup dumpling skin (white dough) is very thick. I'm from Asia, and soup dumpling is the thing for me!  But I'm totally disappointed with their soup dumpling!  However, their service is pretty nice!  Surprise surprise!!!!! Especially from Chinatown!

I've been here several times and the last time I went I realized this place isn't ALL THAT. The only decent things are the scallion pancakes and the dumplings. The people that work here are rude though, which makes me not enjoy it so much.

Came here with family to sample some of the "best soup dumplings in the city." I was a little scared of the wait, but our 25 minutes quickly turned to 10 and we were seated at a table with another couple. We were just looking for a quick snack, so we ordered both the pork and crab meat soup dumplings as well as a dish of saut√©ed pea shoots.

I had high standards for the soup dumplings because of its reputation and unfortunately, I was disappointed. To be honest, the dumplings didn't have too much flavor. The meat inside the dumplings was fairly plain tasting and didn't have as much spice as I expected. The soup was a little oily. Also, the crab dumplings had a more of a fishy flavor than a fresh seafood flavor. Other than the relatively cheap price, these soup dumplings weren't all the rage for me. The pea shoots were good, but honestly, it's hard to make them incorrectly. And for $13 for a dish, I thought it was insanely priced.

If you're looking for a relaxing dining experience, this is not the place for you. First, if you are a smaller party, you will most likely be sitting at a table with another couple, which was the case for us. It was a little squished and to be honest, I almost grabbed some food from one of their dishes, mistaking it for ours. The wait staff there is fairly attentive, but to the point that your meal feels rushed. The constant hovering made me feel uncomfortable and made me feel like they wanted me out as fast as possible. I understand that you must try and accomodate numbers as much as possible but not at the expense of the customer experience.

If you've never had soup dumplings before and want to say, "I've been to Joe's," then come. Otherwise, save your time and money and try another place.

I was in NYC for the weekend and heard that Joe's Shanghai was famous for the xiao long bao. I was super excited to eat here, but I guess I should have known that it wouldn't meet my expectations. 

We did end up sharing a table, but that wasn't a problem at all. The servers are very, very busy so it's hard to track them down at times. But we ordered a couple of orders of xiao long bao, shanghai fried noodle, and a fish dish. Unfortunately, I can't remember the name of the fish dish but it was just AWFUL and inedible. We didn't eat it and tried to explain to the staff that it was disgusting, and they ended up taking it off the bill. As for the famous soup dumplings, they really were average, or even a bit below that. The skin on it is a bit thicker than the average dumpling, so it really affected the overall taste of it. I think that the most delicious xiao long bao has to have the perfect combination of skin, soup, and meat that blend together and melt in your mouth. This definitely did NOT hit the spot. 

BUT besides the mediocre food at this restaurant, I really do like Chinatown in New York. It's a great neighborhood to buy souvenirs, bargain for T-shirts (especially if you're buying a bunch), and just walk around. In fact, while waiting for our table (there IS a long wait), my friend and I walked around the corner and got a 15 minute foot massage.

I come here to satisfy my soup dumpling craving. They consistently make good, reliable soup dumplings but the pork ones only. The crab/pork ones tend to be far too fishy. 

I can't really speak on most of the other food since I really only come here for the soup dumplings. The scallion pancakes and the salt and pepper calamari were just ok. There is always a line but with a handful of people like me just getting soup dumplings, it goes quick. We usually come here for dumplings then eat dinner or dessert elsewhere.

TLDR: Tables are cleaned with spit!!!

Came on a snowy day with a friend and had soup dumplings and beef pan-fried noodles which were both okay. The pan-fried noodles were served on a big plate which was very deceiving. The actual portion was very small. They only put a ring of noodles around the beef and vegetables in the middle of the plate and when you mix the noodles into the sauce, the portion is only enough for one person. The waiters were also a bit much. My friend and I had just put our coats down on the back of our chairs and didn't even have a menu open when the first waiter came to ask us our orders. I don't know what they expected, but we asked for more time. This was a constant theme during our experience here. Our order of soup dumplings came out first and we had wanted to keep the cover of the container it came in, on top to preserve their warm temperature. Immediately after taking out 2 dumplings, a waiter came by and opened the container to see if there were any dumplings left as he was trying to take it away from our table literally 1 minute after putting it down. I'd understand if it was a busy day but the restaurant was 70% filled and we had just gotten the dumplings. The waiters constantly came to our table to take miscellaneous objects away during our entire meal which was very uncomfortable to feel like we were always being watched. 

To top it all off, as we are about to leave the bill comes with a service charge of 18% already included. I've never seen a service charge for a table of 2. Confused, we looked around to see if a nearby table of 3 has left an additional tip after paying their bill. They haven't, so we now know that the 18% service charge is in fact the mandated tip baked in. However, as we watch the waiters "clean" the table that has just left, we saw them purposely spill the tea from the previous customers onto the table and proceeded to use a rag to spread and wipe it across the entire table surface. Once the SPIT, BACKWASH, you name it, was smeared everywhere on the table and dried, the waiters proceeded to place the new dishes onto the table for the next customers. Less than a minute later, a couple was seated at the table, with no clue that they were setting their belongings and hands on a table smeared with someone else's spit. This is absolutely DISGUSTING and incredibly IRRESPONSIBLE to do especially when we are in the middle of a pandemic. We almost gagged because we had put our masks and hands on the table when we were dining and the very likely possibility of someone else's germs and spit on us is atrocious! This calls into question the restaurant's other "cleaning" practices including their dishes, cups, and utensils that you'll be using when dining here.
If I were to rate the soup dumplings, I'd give four stars. They are reliably decent, especially if you come really hungry. Unfortunately, I find the other food really salty and greasy.

Every time we pass by Joe's Shanghai, we always see a long line of patrons so we never bother to eat here. But last week, surprisingly Chinatown was empty and we only saw a group of five or so people waiting to be seated. So my husband and I thought, "hey, let's see what's with the hype of this place!" 

Seconds after we got to our seats, a waiter asked whether we'd like some dumpling soup. I was irritated by that (we hadn't taken off our coats and touched the menu) and sort of regretted my decision of eating here. We declined the offer because of dietary restriction, but that didn't stop other waiters from asking the same question. Don't they assign tables to the waiters??!! :( 

We ordered Shanghai tofu (basically mushroom and tofu with dark sauce, sweet taste and served cold), calamari in black bean sauce (plain, nothing special), and sichuan beef stew (the beef was tender, not bad...). On the scale of 1-10, I'd give a 5 for taste and presentation. I think we might have ordered the wrong dishes, because most people around us ordered the dumplings; they must be good, but shouldn't there be more tasty food served in this so-called most sought out place in Chinatown? 

Not only we're disappointed by the food and the waitresses, we didn't appreciate being put at a table that's only inches away from another table. We could hear every word said by the patrons next to us. The noise level in that restaurant was unbearable. I've been to crowded restaurants, some are much smaller than Joe's Shanghai... I couldn't wait to get out of the place. 

The final verdict: not going back again, and will not recommend this place to anyone.

I grew up loving this place as THE place to get soup dumplings in NYC but I've back a few times in the past 6 months and was rather disappointed. Maybe the quality has gone down in the past few years? Or maybe I've just been spoiled rotten by the recent opening of other, better restaurants in Chinatown. 

When I go, I usually order the crab and pork soup dumpling and another dish of beef noodles. The beef noodles are an oily mess of flavorful thick noodles - so slimy yet satisfying. The soup dumplings come out piping hot but some of the soup dumplings didn't have SOUP which is strange for a place famous for its soup dumplings. For the 30min-1 hour wait, I expected better soup dumplings. 

Also note this place is cash only and it's mostly all communal seating, so you'll be sharing a table with other groups. This place also feels extremely touristy - there were few Asian people actually at the restaurant. 

I'm not sure if I'll be coming back because there are definitely better places for soup dumplings in Chinatown.

I truly don't understand all the hype. The soup dumplings were very average. We only tried the pork ones (5 out of the 16 didn't have soup in them) and they lacked flavor! The soup inside was average and the pork was not seasoned enough. The soup dumplings at Shanghai Cuisine are far superior! We had the Lo Mein that was tasty and General Tso's chicken was good as well.

Joe's Shanghai...the only reason why you guys even get 1 star is because I didn't have a choice because Yelp wouldn't let me continue your review without selecting stars.

I will just say, that this place is a major tourist trap. I am a tourist and I do not live in the NYC area, however, I do come around to visit family pretty often. And this, my friends, is how I fell victim to the hype of the glorious Yelp reviews. People, THE HYPE IS NOT REAL.

Let's start with the service. At your typical "Chinese" restaurant, there's not much service (I'm Chinese, I totally get it). It is what it is. However, this place has absolutely non-existent service. The server did not say one thing to me. When I was ready to order, he stood there and stared at me with his notepad and pen. So I'm thinking, I guess this is the part where I order. Once we ordered, he just walked away and didn't say anything. 

Our food starts to come...Xiao Long Baos and the Shanghai Noodle Soup, but our String Beans came when we finished our food. What the hell am I going to eat with my String Beans? Does this mean you want me to order a cup of your overpriced white rice? That, my friends, I did not do. Also the Xiao Long Baos appeared to have been sitting around for awhile because the skin was dried, and a few of them were popped, so all the soup was flowing out.

Also, we sat at a shared table with some French people visiting. When their meal ended, the server walks up to both parties, points at their check/tab and says "Are you done?" while they're trying to figure out our US Currency. Dude, they were trying to get you your money, but you had to be rude about it and say "Give it to me." Yeah...that leaves a good impression for us Americans. And with that, they pretty much rushed me out too.

By the way, they automatically charge you 15% tip (no matter how small your party is). They take the food total, plus the 15% tip, then tax that total. Can you say, "Scheming?"

When they were clearing out the table, one of the servers drops one of our spoons on the table and splashes some sauce on me. Dude picked up the spoon and walked away. Really? Nothing? Like nothing? You could have said sorry? Umm...guess not.

All in all, as I mentioned above, THE HYPE IS NOT REAL. If you ever make it out to SF, check out Kingdom of Dumpling. Joe's Shanghai has NOTHING on Kingdom of Dumpling. Put those two places in one city, and sorry, Joe, you're done and SOL.

On a final note, I've had better all around service in Hong Kong, seriously. TAKE YOUR MONEY ELSEWHERE!
Very disappointing. The food and the service have come way down over the years. Not worth the trip.

Got to say I was looking forward to eating here with my friend Michele from China who's choice it was to come here.  We bothwere not so impressed, I didn't lead on that I wasn't enjoying the food though, didn't want to ruin the date.  The dumplings kept falling apart before they got to our mouths, they then brought out the wrong steamed fish and the pork dish wasn't up to par as well.  We should have stuck with the wrong fish bc the white fish that they finally got right wasn't good at all.  Very disappointed, the saving grace of the night was walking around the block for ice cream at The Original Chinatown Ice Cream Factory...yummmmm...

Food was decent, service was atrocious. We were seated around 8:45pm, didn't get our food until almost 10pm after multiple reminders, and immediately were given To-go boxes and the check. We didn't even finish half the food by the time they were rushing us out. It also took them forever to take our order as I was trying to get there attention, despite there being a bunch of people working on the floor. Organization was just horrible and it didn't seem like a well-established restaurant. I actually rly enjoyed the crab XLB though. Noodles are extremely oily and not special. Green beans were soggy, no crunch, but at least not too oily. Really not impressed by this place.

This is just a spot to rip off tourist. Food does not live up to its hype. If you are craving for Shanghainese food/ soup dumplings...just go down a block or two down Mott and there are plenty of better Shanghainese food with fraction of its cost. This place has a different attitude/mood towards you depending on your race. Yes, you read that correctly...your RACE.I am not even going to mention it any further as I am sure you can picture how nasty waiters/cashiers can ruin your appetite. Depending on your race, if they treat you well once you step...that means they know they are about to rip you off. I DO NOT recommend this place and support restaurants like this because you are kind of supporting their behavior that it is ok to do what they are doing. Meanwhile there are so many other Shanghainese around the area not too far a block or two that has quality food with fraction of its cost and WAYY better customer service that actually treats you like human beings.
Perfectly adequate Chinese food but you could find comparable dishes nearby at a lower price. They seem to benefit from a yelp-driven tourist hype. Good meal but probably won't return

Waited over an hour! Safe to say the soup dumplings are delicious. I recommend going with a large party, faster to get seated and large portions for a good price. I think we ordered the wrong dishes. The pork shoulder was good but a bit bland in flavors and the noodles as well. I would Iike to try more. Authentic is always good!

It's very disappointing. This restaurant is definitely OVERRATED. The service is terribly bad. The foods are just like what you expect in an average Chinese restaurant. I won't call it authentic Shanghainese. Nope. 

The restaurant automatically adds 15% service fee on your check "for your convenience."  I guess that is the root cause for such poor service. The waiters do not care much about their customers. We split the table with another pair of customers. The other half of the table came later than us, but got to order earlier. Later the waiter totally messed up two different orders. Both parties ordered the signature dumplings. The other pair of customers got it right away, while we waited for maybe 30 minutes. 

We had to remind the waiter SEVERAL times to get our foods. By the time we got the complete order, the other pair of customers already finished their dinner and left...

I assure you will find tons of Shanghainese restaurants in NYC better than this one. Again, it shocks me that this restaurant gets 4-stars review. That's OVERRATED. You would be wasting your valuable time if you expect a 4-stars restaurant.
Horrible service and food is not good. So overrated never returning. Dumplings were not even fully cooked.

Apparently Joe's Shanghai is famous for their Xiao Long Bao's, AKA Shanghai Steamed Soup Dumplings.
