I by far preferred the pork meat soup dumplings to the crab meat soup dumplings, though the crab meat was a novelty to try. I wish the lettuce underneath the dumplings were more presentable and edible though, which they usually are at most Chinese and dim sum restaurants. This isn't quite the case with Joe's Shanghai. Overall, I would get the pork Xiao Long Bao for sure. 

The wait wasn't that long for us, though we did go on a random Thursday morning in September. The awkward thing was that the waiter insisted on seating us at a humongous table next to a man who was eating there by himself, even though the entire restaurant was pretty much open. I guess they do fill up by the afternoon, though it was kind of awkward and I would prefer a table for two rather than sitting with strangers.

Went there today to see what the hype was about. The famous pork dumplings are great but u def need another order of them. I also got vegetable fried rice and ginger chicken and they were fantastic. The only downside is that the service wasn't wonderful. The waiters were rude and treated customers with very poor hospitality. The restaurant also has a grade of B from the NYC health department.

Stay away from this place! Dumpling quality is not consistent.  I got stomachache after eating lunch at their restaurant.  We asked for two orders of crabmeat soup dumpling but one order came without any soup inside the dumpling.  Now I can tell those are leftovers!

Over the years, the quality of the food has diminished. The soup dumplings are no longer plumpy and juicy. Most of the time, it's dry, I feel like it's been sitting there for hours. For how busy the place is, I would think that they make new batches every few minutes - not sure why it's coming out like that. The shanghai flat noodles are also no longer good. It's extremely oily and bland. Its very disappointing. The wait is usually very long because of tourists and you may need to share a table with someone else. Hopefully, there will be a change soon!

This great New York Staple lives up to the hype. A super fun and chill restaurant down in the heart of china town. The reason you go is for the soup dumplings. They are awesome. Light pillows of dough stuffed with pork (or crab) and a a delicious porky broth. It is served with a side of what seems to me rice wine vinegar and soy sauce. Super tasty! Our table ordered dumplings, prawns in chili sauce (tasted like sweet and sour though) string beans( fresh and still had crunch) and a couple of soups to share. While the food was tasty wish it would have come with some rice and I probably could have ordered more food. A little pricey for Chinese food but definitely a fun trip

Bring cash, no credit cards accepted. I had gen tsio (sp?) was good, average. My daughter had shrimp fried rice, better than average. Everything else was average. I'm from Missouri, sorry but I've had as good, better, at home. Place can use some updating and a good cleaning. We got seated quickly, but line began to form afterwards. With I could give it better, but they get what it is. Oh, and service fee of 15% is added to bill.

I heard so much about Joe's Shanghai that I finally decided to check it out on my most recent visit to NY. My friends and I ordered a bunch of dishes that were very typical Chinese fare. My main reason for going though was to try the soup dumplings. They were definitely good and tasty, but I've had better... There are so many Chinese restaurants in Manhattan and Queens/Flushing that I feel like there has to be some other place that serves awesome soup dumplings. I think Joe's Shanghai just got really hyped up by word of mouth, but I left feeling a little disappointed.

Came by the other day for a mid-afternoon snack in an attempt to try NYC's finest XLBs. To my surprise, the line was out the door at 3 pm. The experience consisted of a ~10 minute wait along with sharing a table with ~10 other random tourists.

Ordered the crab XLB and it was merely okay. Couldn't really taste the Crab. The skin was pretty thin and the soup was plentiful. 

...all in all, the xlb was merely okay. The service was quick and prompt ...although they were more concerned with the speed of churning out a seat rather than dining experience.

...they did pull a sneaky trick and inserted a 15% service charge when they presented me the bill.

~$8.61 incl tax and tip for the crab xlb.

This place has great food, fast service and good prices. The only problem was our server couldn't answer any questions and told us to call him only when we knew what we wanted, I don't think many of the waiters spoke or understood English. Other than that Good Food.

Took an out of town visitor here based on a lot of great reviews I've read and was pretty disappointed.  It was fine... it just seemed kind of run-of-the-mill.  The pork dumplings were quite good I have to say.  But the chicken & shrimp in plum sauce and seafood noodles we ordered just seemed bland.  Also didn't love that our party of 3 was seated at a round table with 2 other people.  That was kind of weird.

My girlfriend is not going to like my review because she thinks this is four stars but you know what I didn't like it that much.  I didn't dislike it, I just thought it was okay.  The pork dumplings with crab soup were tasty but the veggies had some black stuff on there which made me question what was it.  The noodles I ordered weren't great, it was just okay, and that is why I am giving it three stars.  There isn't much more I can say.

Was decent, but a bit let down overall considering how many people gush over this place. The food is not bad, just very overhyped. The portions are quite large so keep that in mind if you decide to order multiple dishes. They're known for their soup dumplings, but honestly I think they were just average (and too big to eat in one bite). I know I've probably been spoiled by going to Din Tai Fung pretty regularly in LA, still haven't found anywhere that comes close to how great everything is there. 

The staff at this restaurant is on the cold side, not unfriendly - but not the most welcoming either. Our table was a little dirty and you could see oil and sauce splashed a little onto the walls. Also, they only accept cash, but there's an ATM out front.

Me likey soup dumprrings at Joes  ^__^

No seriously, their soup dumplings are really tasty, cheap and fast.  

Everything else, I could take or leave.  The scallion pancakes were also tasty, but completely drenched in oil.  My twice cooked pork was incredibly salty and greasy.  Even the vegetable dishes were completely drenched in oil.  

After consuming more fat and oil than Oprah on a twinkie bender, I gasped for air as my palpitating heart tried in vain to pump much needed blood through my constricted arteries.  I could have died right there on the spot.  An autopsy would reveal elevated cholesterol and sodium levels due to a nasty bout with fried noodles in a mysterious brown sauce.  

In the eternal battle of my metabolism vs food, mooshoo pork will win out in the end. 

The prices were a bit higher than Joe's more modest china town neighbors, though the atmosphere was just as hectic and unnerving as the rest.  

You certainly won't be maintaining a svelte New York waistline dining on this sort of food every day, which is why I probably won't be back any time soon.

3.5 stars

Probably would've given 4 stars if the food wasn't so damn oily. 

Was there on a Friday night and despite there being a line, my wife and I were seated immediately at a table which we shared with other ppl. We ordered:

Crab meat with pork meat steamed buns-extremely rich and flavorful broth but also fatty and heavy. 

Pork steamed buns-broth was still flavorful but thankfully not as heavy and oily as their crab version.

Fried rice cake with beef-sliced rice cake is one of my fave things to eat at Shanghainese restos. Their version was on point flavor wise but again extremely oily.

FYI: Come with a large group only if you don't mind waiting. All others, should come in groups of 2 or 3 to ensure little to no wait.
Tourist trap. Incredibly crowded and loud, community seating with other patrons. Atmosphere turned me off so we left before eating.

If you're just beginning your soup dumpling journey, fine, try Joe's. But there are far, far better quality Xiao long bao in Chinatown. I've tried around five different respected places' takes on soup dumplings, and Joe's lacks that rich broth flavor. I've also found several bits of crab shell in my soup dumplings here, and on one occasion, one arrived already burst.

If you want to really enjoy this delicacy, go to Shanghai Cafe or Shanghai Asian Manor.

Unfortunately, this place is overrated and watered down with tourism. 

Scallion Pancake 5/5 delicious!
Soup Dumplings 4/5 yum!
Kung Pao Chicken 0/5 Absolute trash! 

What knocked a few stars off was the disgusting rubber chicken they use with absolutely no flavor. They have a C rating from dept of health. Lastly, they sat me next to the "waiters station" literally 12 inches from hearing silverware and glassware clanking in my ear. Be prepared to wait 30-45min outside.

Oh yea, xiao long bao, soup dumplings.  Hen hao chi!

Joe's Shanghai is delicious for soup dumplings and the steamed buns good too, just like Shanghai.  I can't vouch for anything else on the menu, but I don't think anyone can...

Don't expect service, just expect great soup dumplings :)
The food delicious the problem only accept cash money ATM  to Spencer 3.50 the restaurant clean good  I love duck Pek√≠n

I am in town for work so I came alone. I was seated in 5 minutes. You get seated with random people at a table. I ordered the pork xiao long bao, a spring roll, scallion pancakes, and cold sake. The xlb was too doughy for me. You could also taste the fat in the broth. There was a ton of broth inside, but it wasn't was good as din tai fung. Also, the size is bigger than a mouthful. I ended up cutting away a lot of the dough. It was okay but nothing I would crave. They also didn't have any vegetable appetizer. The spring roll never came, but I was full from the xlb and pancake so I didn't complain.

I've been here several times and although the food has consistently been good, my last dining experience left me underwhelmed. The steamed dumplings tasted funny.  The broth inside tasted like dirty water.  The chicken and beef dishes were okay.  However, I was really turned off when I used their rest room which smelled awful and was filthy but even more so the esthetics of their kitchen. It was incredibly dirty and unhygienic! I had been a fan of JS for a few years but as a result of the last visit I highly doubt I'll ever return unless they thoroughly clean up and/or upgrade that filthy kitchen! Sadly enough and to no surprise my fianc√© got sick! He definitely will never go back.

This was the first places I've dined in NYC where i said to myself... i can cook better than this. I ordered the Shanghai stir fried noodles (with chicken). It was in much need of seasoning, and - can you believe - it cost $21.50 (tax and tip included). The noodles weren't bad but they weren't anything special either, and the lack of ingredients made it less palatable since it was eventually just noodles and chicken pieces. 

Given we were a group of 10, I appreciate that they allowed us to have separate checks. (we all got separate things so that must have also made it easier). But gosh I can't wait to go home and make my own stir fried/lo mein.

To top it all off, I took a look around the restaurant and there were very few Asian diners, if that tells you anything.

This place has our favorite soup dumplings and pork shoulder, but we are not a fan of sharing a big table with random strangers. The place is also crowded and the waiters can bump into your seats easily or reach over your head and may spill something.

Plus, this place is cash only! Be sure to stop by the bank to withdraw to avoid ATM fees!

We do prefer the other location by the Theater District of Manhattan, which is more grand in scale, decorated more nicely and has a bigger menu selection (plus hardly any wait). The soup dumplings here taste the same!

Dude, I hate to say this, but I think this spot is overrated.  After many rave reviews from friends, I went way out of my way to eat here during my last visit to NY.  Braved the weather and the wait for some very good but not spectacular soup dumplings.  Places like these are kind of a dime a dozen here in California.  Though the dumplings at Joe's are huge and soup-y, more so than I've encountered before which was cool, I don't know if I'd go out of my way again.

This place is always busy.  Yesterday was my second time here since we came here from VA and this was our first stop.  I think they been hyped up because of not many places offering soup dumplings but my husband and I have found several restaurants in DC/MD area where their dumplings are way more big and better.  It was still good but doesn't live up to all the raving about it anymore since we found some back home that tastes better. 

They are cash only so make sure you have some before going in or there's an ATM right down the street.
Nothing special. Soup dumplings were good for the price but the chicken is not good, tiny portion and super expensive. Chicken bones in the vegetable noodles... The waiters are kind and free rice

This place has very high reviews.  I had high hope.  I do realize people who live in different places, cities, or states do have differences preferences and tastes. For me who lived in California for 10s years, this place is not for me. 
Rather than saying delicious or not. I rather make a comparative so some readers can get a better idea.  
For me, My fav Dimsum is Elite restaurant in So Cal.

Meh.  Everything meh.  Those "soup" dumplings just have grease and soy sauce inside, and taste little different from suburban Chinese takeout.  Except for being a bit Americanized, Joe's is no better or different than virtually any other Chinatown restaurant.  Tourists with flyover state accents, however, make for good comedy, sitting shoulder-to-shoulder with strangers at group tables, feigning blinders on to avoid contact with the strangers, or trying stale conversation (with the receiving party being annoyed sometimes), etc.  It's kinda funny to watch (we had our own table because of a large group, but still were up against other tables and could view it all).  Other than the comedy, there's no reason to go to Joe's.  Enjoy authentic food elsewhere, and the dumplings you could get in Levittown.  But, all that said, if you want regular stuff, Joe's is fine.

One of the worst meals I've had in my life. Should have known when I walked in during lunch rush hour and there were like 3 parties and they were all white people. 

The soup dumplings were very bland. The broth was... didn't taste like anything. And they were too big and cumbersome to fit in your mouth or your spoon. 

The crispy beef was sliced too thin so all you tasted was the cornstarch and it was overly sweet. 

And servers don't have designated tables so 5 different servers were asking us the same questions over and over. Constantly interrupting our meal. No we don't need our plates changed every 5 minutes. My god.

My wife and I checked out Joe's because of all the reviews and it was close to our hotel.  We went around 9pm (they close at 10) and were quoted a 40 min wait time, so we just ordered there for take-out. 

Food came out pretty quick.  We got soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, General Tso chicken, eggplant in garlic sauce, and Szechuan beef - total was about $100.

The General Tso's was not fried and crispy, but instead mushy and lacked flavor.  The scallion pancakes were just okay.  The Szechuan beef was pretty spicy, which was nice.  Overall, not great.  There has to be better Chinese takeout in Chinatown.

TIP: They only accept cash. They do have an ATM on-site.

Excellent Pork Chop House was closed for Lunar New Year, so I decided to try Joe's Shanghai, which apparently a lot of dumb people like.  The place is a tourist spot, so keep that in mind.  I ordered one of my favorite dishes, xiao long bao, and was extremely disappointed after reading all the rave reviews.  The consistency of the pork was like mush and the soup inside was thick.  Most items on the menu are way over-priced, so I got the pork chop noodle soup.  While the pork chop was tender and quite good, the noodle soup was pretty plain.  It's pretty much noodles in a clear broth. 

Thank god this place doesn't deliver.  Don't believe the 3,4, or 5 star reviews.  Those people probably don't know what they're talking about.
I have seen so many recommendation about this place so i was expecting a lot... Abd was REALLY disapointed! Food wasn't good or either fresh...

OVERHYPED.
Way too crowded and food was mediocre. Half the menu was crossed out. There was only 2 types of soup dumplings. We decided to try the pork and crab meat and it tasted so weird. The flavors did not go well together. The only thing I liked was the pan fried pork dumplings. We also had an order of seafood pan fried noodles. The pan fried noodles look and taste nothing like the other places you would usually get it. It was thick, chewy and bland. 
Yes, it may be an original hot spot. But it probably tasted better back then than now. Now it's just a tourist site. If you take a look around you, what do you see or rather what do you NOT see? Asian customers. The local Asians know where the best Asian foods are and it's not here.

I used to drive to nyc from DC just for these soup dumplings. They're just not that good anymore. Not bad just not like they were. Over cooked and tough, the pork dumplings I'd have to think about ordering again. The ones with crab tasted good enough but again over cooked to the point where they were all sticking and impossible to pick up intact. They still have a line out the door, though, so maybe it was just a bad day.

Examine your bill carefully, I found out they over charged me after I left.  I order 2 dumplings 15.90,  1 Scallion pancake 2.95 & Shanghai noodle 8.95.   Total is 27.80,  but my bill shows 35.44 & I paid it without thinking.  Not sure what they add on to come up with extra $5 after tax unless they automatically add-on gratituity.  Feels ripped off so be sure to check your bill.

We had the soup dumplings and they were so so.  The dumping went from two thick to breaking and useless.   Din Tai Fung is the gold standard.  These were sadly more like tin.   I have three because i am sure some of their other dishes should be better.
Very good, but maybe not worth the wait and the hype. Crab soup dumplings are something to search for...these were very good. The rest is just a dirty old Chinese restaurant.

Just a ok. We ordered the regular suspects and everything was very average. Nothing stood out as being great or even really good. Our party of 7 had to share a big table with two other groups. Typical Chinese service. Soup dumplings were big and had a lot of soup in them but over the taste was underwhelming. Sorry but I was not impressed.

This was my second time here and unfortunately was not any better than how I remembered it. As a party of 3, we had to share a table and we were rushed (granted the place does get very busy). 

And I'm sorry...maybe it's one of those acquired things, but it just smells bad. I believe it's that vinegar sauce that has probably seeped into the carpet over many years...

I like soup dumplings but the soup just tasted greasy..the food overall felt heavy and oily. The turnip appetizer was good though!

So many better hole-in-the-walls to go to in Chinatown though...

How do u say OK in Chinese? you say Joe's Shanghai! 
         I took a 3 hour bus ride from boston to get to this joint! I woke up pretty early just to catch the "china bus" (coined by my japanese friends) and after some fast paced walking Joe and his kung fu waiters greeted us.  The place being super packed we sat next to these uber-geeky tech nerds from NYU! The hong kong cats raved about it as they ate! The white buy with them kinda just picked at his food! so what was i to think?
        And my thinking was OHNOMEDONOBOWDIS! And that day i was thinking in chinese. I have never tried shanghai style dumplings so i was super madonna like a virgin this whole she-bang! But besides that the dumplings were fat! they were juicy! and they made mouth's water! It just wasn't mine! i think we had two or three different kind of dumplings that day. People seemed to rave about it. but i wasn't really accustomed  to the taste. but i did feel like Bruce Lee was watching over me. He would have been proud...and he would have found them great!  So with that. I made like Cane in Kung Fu and left to wander the world...
XLB skin a bit thick, but the soup was flawless. We had pork and crab and plain pork. Cash only establishment, expect to wait at all times but the food comes out fast.

Over hyped in my opinion. The effort to get cash out of their ATM is a reason alone on why you should maybe not consider spending money here. The dumplings were nothing special, they hoenstly tasted like Trader Joe's.
I can get better chinese in any takeout place in the boroughs! Do yourself a favor and save the subway fare.

This was the only restaurant that had a line outside so I thought we were in for some great dim sum. You tell the hostess how many in your party and she gives you a number. However, the order in which she calls your number seems completely random (there were people with the same sized party as us, who had an earlier number but we were seated before them). The prices were low but I was not impressed with their food--especially the highly reviewed soup dumplings. Perhaps it's because we're from San Francisco and live on a street with much better dumplings, put stickers, noodles, etc. My boyfriend wanted to eat here so I'm happy to have gone once but it's not a place i would return too.

My friend and I came here for just soup dumplings. Since we were a party of two, we got seated with other random people. It's pretty hectic in there and servers aren't that attentive. As for the food, the soup dumplings were yummy. Good amount of soup. But the dumpling was a little doughy. Overall pretty good though! They only take cash.
Overrated!! Its a tourist trap. They pay the tour guides to bring people there. Service is rude. There are better tasting dumplings around town.

Very authentic place in the heart of Chinatown. They have shared tables so be prepared to share your table with some strangers. When my friends and I popped in on a Saturday around 4:30 there was no wait but the place was pretty busy. By the time we left an hour later, there was a wait list and groups of people waiting outside. 

After reading reviews about the dumplings at this place, we of course had to order some as our app. It was very different. I've never had steamed pork dumplings like these. They were pretty good but not amazing. It was more fun trying to figure out how to eat them. We also ordered the Kung pao chicken and seafood pan friend flat noodles and they were delicious!

The service was fast and staff were pretty friendly. I'd come back.
Overhyped. Food is not so great, it' alright. 15% service charge extra other than the tax?? I dunno if it's a New york thing but we Cali boys are not used to it

We went to the restaurant at 12.pm .they got a lot of table. We ask the host for a small table because we only have 2 people. But the host told us we must had a round table to share with someone.And she told
Us that is your only choice.so we choice to left.never come back again

Honestly I feel like this place is way too hyped. Don't get me wrong the soup dumplings are awesome but to wait an hour I need to SERIOUSLY be craving them. After waiting an hour (in the cold) we finally got in. We ordered scallion pancakes to start which were the BEST I've ever had. I would've ordered 2 orders of it it was delicious. Then we had the infamous soup dumplings which were delicious - the soup tasted so good, the dough was thin which is great because thick dough makes it hard to enjoy. Lastly we ordered the king pao chicken which was absolutely terrible. The chicken was so shady... it wasn't spicy... barely any flavor. Just not worth it. I gave this place 3 stars because of the longest wait I've ever experienced, where we sat (right next to the trash and dirty dishes and a couple that was as hardcore fighting), and the fact that I can find amazing dumplings at other spots. Enjoyed it but not moved.

xiao long bao! 

they're great here but definitely taste completely different from the traditional ones they make in shanghai. the ones here have a broth that tastes much more buttery but they're good in their own unique way. 

also, in order to make things move more quickly, you might get seated at a shared table with random strangers. just a heads up.

So my friends and I went here and we got two different tables. One table got better service and better tasting food than the other. Only difference was race, I can't say much more but this is nyc this shouldn't happen. Staff weren't happy when my minority friend picked up the checks for both tables.

Food was great as usual. The major issue was I saw one of the service staff leaving the bathroom immediately after flushing and there is no way he washed his hands. The sink and air dryer are very noisy and it would take at least 5 seconds to complete that process. Gross!
Standard pre-frozen chinese food; check out Shanghai Asian Manor instead. Joe's is expense for what it is, long wait. Residents will come here mid-week to avoid the wait.
The food is good. However, the dim sum menu is very limited. The other items are the typical American Chinese food items; they are well made with quality ingredients.. Also cash only FYI.

Decent experience, but nothing amazing.  Friendly staff, quick service.

Potato pancakes with scallions were amazing.  Pork "soupy" dumpling were very good, but mis-named as pork buns (and we really wanted pork buns).  Chicken and shrimp in plum sauce was good, but too much bamboo and bland flavor.  Beef and string beans was good, but also just bland.  We had requested the schezuan string beans and pork, but to replace the minced pork with beef.  Waiter said it would cost more, which we ok'd.  I think we just got the standard bon-schezuan green beans and beef.

Canned coke and iced tea, and bottle beers.  15% gratuity included on bill.

I would try another place next time, but if you've never been, it may be worth a visit.

I've been to many soup dumplings restaurants but this one, I have to say, is overrated. The crab dumplings are ok I mean but u can find them with better quality and cheaper at Nanxiang Restaurant in Flushing. Plus, this place charged u 15% service fee for basically no service.

Don't expect good customer service if you come here and they will seat you in a table with other people. Must try the dumplings they are as good as the reviews here mention.

Noodles were bland. Jellyfish delicious treat to try.
I got nightmare food poisoning after eating here! Stay away!

Was not blown away. I liked the potato pancake. I would get that again. There are no vegetarian options for the soup dumplings, just so you know. They are all about efficiency and getting the most customers in at a time instead of service. It's pretty comical the extent they will go to get the customers inside. I waited for 45 minutes with a number. It was crazy. Potato pancake, yum. Wish I could it to-go to avoid the wait and service drama.

Joe's Shanghai was a decent Shanghai restaurant. It's definitely a place for people who are new to Shanghai cuisine, since there are much better places in Chinatown for xialongbao's and Shanghai cuisine. 
The price was a little expensive for this type of restaurant, but the food was good at least. Highly recommend their Crab meat xiaolongbao (soup dumplings). We ordered the regular xiaolongbao, crab meat version, and braised pork shoulder.

Okay...maybe I was expecting more but honestly if I tell you PF Chang... Yes the chain restaurant... Has fresher spring rolls, you know where I am going with this! Spring rolls were greasy little things, not very fresh. Pass. I live in MKE and gotta say our local Stone Bowel makes a better dumpling and that isn't saying much. They were ok, not great. Pork soup with soft noodle. Seriously buy some ramen at your local grocery store throw some stringy meat in in and call it soup. I love ramen but can buy this for 59 cents at Pick n Save. 

Super crowed with locals and tourist mixed. Wasn't horrible but I wouldn't go again. 

Derive is pretty bad also. Couple at our table, maybe French were treated so poly and it wasn't a language barrier.

It's OK. I've had xiao long pao before. 

The beef tendon noodle was average as well. Not bad, but not special.

I was introduced to Xiao Long Bao probably 10 years ago by an ex. She was older and more travelled than I was at the time XLB and it changed my life. She told stories of thin dough, not weak, but still ever so slight chew. A broth so complex you'd think it was a reduction or a jous and pork frolicking with crab inside. The best of all dumplings and quite possibly the best pasta of any kind.

I'd been going to DTF (Din Tai Fung) for a while now driving from San Diego to Alhambra, yeah 100 miles away for a singular dish. I had high expectations coming here. After all NYC has the most Chinese American's and is like 5th by percentage. It's in Chinatown so I pretty much figured it would be good considering the # of reviews and how packed it was.

Service is typical Chinese restaurant (not fine dining). Flagging down for everything, but doesn't take away from the meal. You're a little grumpy having waited anywhere from 10 to and hour if you came early and more if you didn't.

Their XLB is larger than DTF, juicier than DTF, but the soup is fattier and not as complex and the skin is much thicker and chewy. The crimping is sloppy, but not functionally sloppy. Sesame seed noodles have good flavor and a slight aftertaste that doesn't linger. Good body and bounce. The hot and sour soup was thick, almost chunky, but not in a slurrie thickened sort of way and actually a little bland for the consistency, minimal depth. Scallion pancake was greasy and delicious in it's own way, soft, crunchy. I would murder that with some naan and hummus or bitchin sauce/majestic garlic spread. Drunk food for sure. I playfully called them gravy long bao's because the soup was so fatty. And I know your all thinking it now, what about real gravy, I've tried it and it doesn't work. I've got chef friends of mine playing with that flavor profile already, but if you beat me and them to the invention it's all yours. 

You marvel at the community around you since you use communal tables, everyone enjoying their dumplings lost in their own worlds. Price for most dishes is pretty good, and not just for NYC or Chinatown, but solid making all your expensive places just overpriced. I had 3 orders of XLB and with my soup, noodles and pancakes I was stuffed. That's a meal for 2 normal people apparently, but suggested portions are for ninnymuggins anyhow.

Cash only, can get stuffy and hot, very crowded as it's fame perpetuates itself and continues to disappoint anyone whose been to DTF. It's solid for the area and very popular, but mediocre xlb is better than no xlb.

XLB are the best in the city when they get them right, but every time I come, at least 2 in the basket have leaked out. 

Hostess gave us an attitude in the 3 minutes we had to deal with her. Servers were friendly (when I spoke Cantonese to them), but I also heard them giving other customers attitude, which is so not cool. 

There are much better XLB places, even in Manhattan, not worth dealing with the service and quality control issues.

While I was looking for this place, I accidentally almost stumbled into Joe's Ginger, which I'm pretty sure just has a similar name to trick you into going in there. Anyway, we arrived at around 11:30AM on a Saturday morning for lunch and was slightly afraid that there would be a long line. I think we beat the rush, because around 12 it started to fill up and a line went out the door. The restaurant itself is pretty grimy, though that's kind of the standard for a lot of the authentic Chinese restaurants I've been to. The waiters are brusque and don't really seem to care to take your order or bus the dishes. One of them was chewing/eating something while taking our orders and when we asked questions, he would just nod or shake is head because his mouth was full. That's some unacceptable professionalism and I'm sure if Gordon Ramsay was there, he would have ripped off that waiter's head.

They ask right away whether you are here for the soup dumplings, since that is what they are most famous for. We had one of each, a set of 8 normal soup dumplings and a set of 8 crab-flavored soup dumplings. I read somewhere that the thick, gummy shells of Joe's Xiao Long Bao is pretty bad, but I like the thicker shell because that prevents them from breaking. The insides were very hot and juicy, the soup being perfectly seasoned and the meat being just the right portion. My entire family loved it, including my brother who usually complains for ages whenever we get dim sum or anything like it.

The rest of the dishes were nothing to rave about, however. The Crispy Pork with Salt and Pepper wasn't too bad, though a bit soggier than I would have liked - I love them super crispy and crunchy. The General Tso's Chicken was accompanied by cold broccoli (why was it cold?) and the chicken was made from white meat, which made it dry and unflavorful. The Chili Prawns were covered in a wonderful tasting sauce that was kind of like a spicy sweet and sour sauce but milder and with garlic. The shells of the shrimp were too tough though so it was hard to eat it without taking off the shells. The Hot and Sour Soup was pretty bad and I didn't like that at all. It didn't have that signature bitter taste and instead just... meh... I don't really know how to describe it. 

The soup dumplings are great and I would suggest people to come just for those bad boys and skip the "authentic chinese food." It is not worth the wait if you are here for anything other than the Xiao Long Bao.

This place is good if you don't mind sharing  large round tables with complete strangers. 
The food is very good and it helps if you have some knowledge of what to order. I personally always go for 1-2 orders pork soup dumplings, rice and orange beef or tso chicken when in this cramped setting. The meal goes a little smoother if the surrounding strangers are friendly.
The location in Flushing is 10x better!

What is all the hype? Yes greasy broth can be tasty, but overall quality of the soup dumplings are edible, but forgettable.  The Lo Mien noodles were ok but I've definitely had better as well.  I'll stick with the oh so much healthier and tastier Korean style steamed dumplings or dumpling soup.  Oh and cash only if you didn't know.

I expected more from this place based on everyones ratings. I LOVE soup dumplings and although these were good I felt like they could have been much better. I was not a fan of the dumpling skin however the broth and meat inside were delicious. 

I also had the crispy fried beef and that was fantastic! The size of the entrees are quite large. I shared mine with my sister. I'll definitely try this place again because I'm hoping for a better experience.

I believe everyone mentioned all that is needed to say. 

So, I'll just add...DO GO HERE WHEN VISITING NYC! and when you do, ONLY order their soup dumplings!

Our wait wasn't too long.  Although it was uncomfortable b/c it was a cold evening.  We were also a bit intimidated by the B Grade given by the sanitation department. B isn't that bad, I guess. 

And it wasn't. 

We had:
-3 spring rolls
-2 orders of pork soup dumplings
-Szechuan Beef with Bean Curd
-Singapore Chow Mei Fun

However, I am only a fan of their famed soup dumplings.  They also had a crab filling, which we haven't tried, but I'm glad we ordered the pork instead b/c I can't imagine how the broth would be for the crab. And I am also glad that I watched a video on how to eat them.  Being a voyeur also helped, considering that everyone else on our table ordered soup dumplings as well.  The pork broth was amazing.  Actually, I think it was the broth that makes this dumpling famous. (The dumpling itself isn't too special).  That, and it's really fun to eat!  I think I'll attempt to make these at home.  

The spring rolls were mediocre. Nothing special about them at all.

The Szechuan Beef with Bean Curd was alright. Definitely second best of the four items that we ordered.  But I have had better. 

The Singapore Chow Mei Fun was marked as spicy on the menu. The waiter also cared to warn me that this noodle dish was spicy.  That's perfect, honestly. However, when our order arrived, it looked like rice noodles spiced with curry powder--and that is exactly what it tasted like, also.  Don't get me wrong; the dish was good. I just thought it funny that I was basically warned twice about it being "spicy."


All in all, we had a great experience.  I would go back when I return to NYC, except I would only order their soup dumplings.

Such slow service for an empty restaurant.
I asked for extra ginger in soysauce 3 times and they still don't remember.
Waited for 20mins for food, and the restaurant isnt even busy! 
They argued the xiao long bao takes 10mins, okayyy what about the noodles? 
All of a suddenly they can't argue anymoreeee.
Food was mediocre, i rather go to elsewhere.
Oh and tip is mandatory, included in the check! 15%
What kinda shitty establishment is this???

I give this place 3.5 stars.  The soup dumplings were good but not absolutely amazing. I have had better out in san franciso.  We also ordered a black peppered duck, which was pretty good. It was a deep fried duck which we dip into salt and white pepper on the side.  Honestly dont see whats all the hype is about.  Have not tried any other places in new york to compare so maybe the best there.  I can say it is better than din tai fung for comparison.

Their soup dumplings are pretty decent for NYC, but it pales in comparison to the soup dumplings at Din Tai Fung in LA.  This place is always packed, so there's usually a line for seating. I gave them only three stars because you get seater quicker if there is a white person in your party. If they know your party is all Chinese they make you wait longer. WTF????

I am so glad I went because of the hype and many recommendations. 

I think I overordered and had just way too much food. Nevertheless, the soup dumplings were good. I didn't love them though, but I don't think it's because they were not well made, but just my own preference of the type of food it is. 

The General Tso's chicken was nothing special. 

I like the service but sharing tables with randoms was a bit weird, but not bad. Everyone was friendly at my table. 

Would I go back? Probably not.

When I got there, I had high expectations because of the reviews. I grew up on Chinese food so my expectations are probably much higher than most. The wait was just a little over an hours which I did not mind waiting for good food. You must go inside to grab a ticket from one of the staff to be put on the list and receive a wait time! We had to share a table with other guests, which was a little uncomfortable but I completely understand due to their high volume. The staff weren't very attentive. I had to ask for water several times b efore he got it for me. I recommend getting what they are known for which is the soup dumplings. They were juicy and delicious but you much eat them right away! The stir fry noodle were good as well, had a chard flavor from the wok. But the beef noodle soup was terrible! There was literally no flavor. It just tasted like hot water tbh. Idk if that's a mistake or that's how they normally make it but I would never order that again. The sweet and sour fried fish was good. But the strong ketchup taste ruined it. I expected more from this place. Also, there is automatically 15% gratuity added on to the bill.

I have reached out to Bikeway to have mobile bike service performed on my bike at home. Over a month and no response.  Went into store to acquire why no response.  Store clerk told me he would tell Manager and I should hear from them. Going on 3 weeks and still no response. 845-297-5477

Service was slow and terrible. We ordered our food and waited 45 min for it. Everyone who came in at the same time and after us all received their food before us. Soup dumplings were bland and the spicy Szechuan beef dish we ordered was nothing but a dish of oil and string beans. Total disappointment. Not even worth one star.

Stick with the soup dumplings - it's delicious but do not do take out. Huge mistake - the dumplings did not hold up. No soup in the dumplings - bursted during transportation 

Otherwise if you plan on ordering Americanize Chinese dishes - you're better off with from cheaper take out places 

Shanghai noodles were bland - just mainly noodles and a few pieces of pork. Oh. And TONs of OIL. Won't ever order again 

General tso's chicken - bland!! Boring - barely had any sauce 

Hot and sour soup just god awful - tastes plain sour dumped with white pepper

This place is only good food soup dumplings - won't would save your money and go to another restaurant if you want other Chinese main dishes 

Oh and everything is cash OnLy

I was in the mood for something soupy and flavorful and wandered into Joes Shanghai anticipating some life changing shanghai dumplings. The dumplings were much larger than the ones I normally eat and they surprisingly asked me whether I wanted shrimp or pork? I got the pork and wasn't impressed. They were okay but I thought they were supposed to be amazing? Anywho, we also ordered a chow mein which was delicious! The noodles were fat with a different texture than what I'm used to. I wanted to pack up what was left and take it on the plane with me, but I thought - "better not". 

The food was alright and service okay. Be prepared to share table as they don't care whether you want to sit with your party alone.

I've only been here for the soup dumplings, so I will consider coming back and leaving a review for more of the options. The soup dumplings were definitely really good! I've tried xiaolongbao in MANY places and this is one of the best. The service is okay, and it is definitely crowded, but I didn't mind too much. The prices here are also great, very much worth it. FYI, this is also one of those family-style restaurants so, if you're coming with a small group, prepare to share a table with strangers.

Sunday late afternoon, my long exploration made a pit stop at Joe's Shanghai.  We walked from Union Square through Soho and ended up in Chinatown.  

My friend's had Joe's Shanghai on her food list venture.  She said that a lot of people told her the Joe's Shanghai has really good xiao long bao. Xiao long bao are soup dumplings with minced pork.   We ordered pork and crab pork.  As I took my first bite, I expected an explosion of flavor and excitement in my mouth.  No fireworks.  I was not impressed.  Not sure if it was all that hype from my friends and the long journey I had to get to Joe's Shanghai, my expectation standard was too high and it just didn't satisfy me.  The crab pork tasted almost the same as the pork.  I didn't taste any different.  Many it was an off day.  I'd give it another try if I make to the Eastcoast again.

Top notch service.  We were taken care.  Tea was brough to our table immediately after seating.  All the servers were attentive and not zoning off like some restaurants I've been to.  I asked for water and it came within 5 minutes.  Asked for the check, came in 5 minutes.
Average at best. Granted, I di NOT have any dumplings which did look good but the rank and file food is average at best.

I'm sorry people. It seems like this place is a hit for everyone. For me on the other hand... it was a bit of a dissapointment. (Please don't kill me =P)

My mother is shanghainese so I can be a bit of a shanghai food snob I admit it. It's ok. I work with it. One of the most popular dish in Shanghai is the Dragon Dumplings (xiao long bao). I'm sorry but it lacks flavor! MOST IMPORTANT PART!! MUST HAVE FLAVOR!! Sauce within the dumplings were ok. Skin around the dumpling too THICK! 
I heard so much about this so I expected to be able to enjoy some happiness and unfortunately.. I did not find it. Ai...

Everything else like the fat noodle (Chao nian gao), and other stirfry dishes was pretty good. So the place isn't bad. can't really go wrong with those right?

Gets super crowded though. Make sure all your party is there before they seat you. Until then.. I'm still looking for my yummy xiao long bao..
Ai.....
Food was good. You have to sit next to whatever seat is available meaning you can sit next to a stranger. Quick prompt service however bathroom and setting of the restaurant.

both the soup dumplings were okay. but I heard it's best in town so it's good I guess

the Hong Kong sweet and sour soup - tastes ok

pan fried seafood noodles - no good. do not get.  if you want noodles, get stir fried or something where the noodles are soft

peppered shrimp - pretty good!

sesame beef - kinda sweet. I liked it

they automatically add gratuity to very bill because their service is really bad; if they didnt do that, no one would tip them lol

I believe this place is a tourist trap.  The soup dumplings are fine and I think are middling in almost every way. I appreciate the effect that Joe's Shanghai has had on soup dumplings and New york Chinatown, but I think their quality does not stack up to other NYC dumplings spots

The workers there were so rude. I ordered take-out and when my food was ready, the lady continued to watch her TV on her phone. I ordered the pork soup dumplings because of the hype for them. They were mediocre, nothing to brag about.

the foods are good..but always pack with customers which create problem for getting seat! the waitress is extreamly easy to forget your ticket # and skip you! the worst part is THEY DON'T CARE! so...take it or leave it...

We had Joes Shanghai at their other location several years ago and it left us disappointed. After all the raves from our family and friends, we decided to stop by and give them ONE more chance. 

Parking is a bia in Chinatown so make sure you come with all your guests Bc they will NOT seat you if your whole party is not there. 

We had the crab soup dumplings, pork soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. The soup dumplings I believe were over cooked. It would break apart on you so you're left with just the dumplings Bc the soup had ether evaporated or it leaked out. Crab one tasted weird -- like gritty tasting. But the classic pork soup dumpling was good. The scallion pancakes were also delicious. It was crispy, just the way we liked it. 

My suggestion though is to change out the carpet because it smells really bad when you walk in there. 

I wouldn't mind coming back here but I hear there are several other soup dumpling shops in Chinatown that we wouldn't mind giving a try before coming back here.

I've heard a lot of good things about Joe's Shanghai, so I had to take the chance to eat here during my trip. I came here with three other people, and we waited about 40 minutes for a table during lunch on Labor Day. We were finally seated at a large table alongside another party of four, which was a little unexpected but ended up not being too awkward. 

We ordered both types of the xiao long bao (pork and crab meat pork), stir-fried veggies, squirrel fish and spicy chicken. The xiao long bao were flavored well, especially the crab meat one, but I wasn't a huge fan of the size and texture - I expected smaller sizes and thinner dough (like what they have at Din Tai Fung), and these seemed more like soup buns than soup dumplings. However, the squirrel fish was flavored well, and was probably my favorite part of the meal.

Bottom line - the soup dumplings here don't taste bad, they just aren't what I'm used to - 1) they were way too big for the spoon and 2) the skin was super thick.

Of my 15 years of living in NYC, I have never visited Joe's Shanghai until recently when one of my friend from California who is obsessed with them. So we agreed to go and I was also excited because it is very famous and it has tons of reviews on yelp. There was so many things that I was not happy with. 
1. the soup dumping was SO disappointing. the skin was thick but at the same time it would break when you pick up the dumpling. the soup it self inside the dumpling was meh, it tasted just like a regular dumpling flavor and that should not be the way it is. 
2. the wait staff is constantly eye balling you, kind of "rushing" you to finish up so they can clean up and get the next customers in. they literally stand right next to your table when you are almost close to finish and it just felt super uncomfortable. 
3. we also ordered some other Chinese dishes and those were so bland and being a Chinese myself I was just so disappointed.  

overall, i would probably never come back.

Joe Shanghai's was way over hyped. My group of 6 waited nearly 50 minutes, despite the hostess originally saying the wait time was going to be 20 minutes. It didn't surprise me that we waited a lot longer since Chinese restaurants often do not provide the right wait time. We wanted to try their soup dumplings since everyone was raving about them, but were completely underwhelmed. The meat filling was a little too fatty for my liking and the dough used was okay. I expected something to the similar caliber of Din Tai Fung, but Joe Shanghai fell completely short. The only thing that saved our meal were the green beans. They are heavy on the garlic, but we're crispy on the outside! They were pretty good. We also ordered the pork noodles which seemed to use fresh noodles. If you're coming for the soup dumplings, I'm sure you can go to somewhere else where the wait will not be as long and be just as satisfied.

Just stopped by Joe's and noticed that it has a "B" health department rating.  Thought you would want to know.  It still has a line waiting to get in.  I think I'll wait until it gets an "A".  Too bad, I was looking forward to trying the dumplings.

This was our very first meal on our trip to New York and after a short wait (because we were willing to share a table), we were treated to a feast of classic Shanghainese dishes. Although very popular and well known, we found that the food was too oily and other than their signature dishes, there was something left to be desired. 
The dishes we ordered included: 

Xiao Long Bao - their most famous dish and for good reason. Thin skin, filled with soup and meat that was not too fatty but flavourful.

Potstickers - very good as well, nice skin and tasty meat filling. 

House Special Glazed Crispy Chicken - thinking that it would be a half chicken cut up we were surprised to see golden glazed chicken chunks that were battered and fried similar to sweet and sour pork. Served with broccoli, we were so surprised to love this dish. With white meat chunks that were not over battered in a perfectly sweet and tangy sauce, we finished the whole dish! 

Shanghai Fried Noodles with Pork - This was a nice sized portion of noodles that were stir fried with some veggies and pork strips but there was way too much oil.

Bok Choy with Mushrooms - wanting a veggie dish, we went with this classic. Nothing wrong but the sauce was too gloopy for me.

Lions head Meatballs - the least favourite dish of the night, we couldn't even finish it because although the portion was very large, the meat itself was not very good either being overworked or mixed to flour and much too fatty. Similar to the above, sauce was too gloopy.

Overall, I had high expectations for Joes Shanghai and was quite disappointed with the dishes that were not their "classics". For somewhere so popular I would have expected to be blown away but left feeling uncomfortably stuffed.

Overrated, overrated, overrated, did I mention overrated?

I was super excited to try Joe's Shanghai after all the amazing reviews of how great there food is. I went there on a Saturday night and it was super packed. You go inside, give you're name to the lady and they give you a ticket....then you wait outside. 

Note: THERE IS A SIGN ON THE DOOR THAT THEY ARE CASH ONLY. BRING CASH.

When they sat us we were only two and I assume its "family dinning" so we sat with 6 other people on a large round table. At first it was very awkward, the two of us sitting with people we have never met but they were very kind and we enjoyed this "temporary large family."

We ordered scallion pancakes which were very good as well as the sesame chicken which I didn't see what was special about it. It was a standard sesame chicken. The rice they serve is really good, but the service was lacking. I felt myself needing to ask for everything from a cup of water, to a straw to napkins. 

The entire experience was overall okay. People rave about the dumplings but the only option was pork and we don't eat pork so that was a no go. 

Overall there was more hype surrounding the food than the actual taste. For the amount of men in the dinning room serving and walking around I would really expect service to be better. 
The oranges they bring at the end with you're check was nice. I believe there must be better Chinese food/dim sum in Chinatown.

Not sure why this one has high ratings.  The food is mediocre.  We had XLB, rice cakes, string beans, crab tofu, chicken.  XLB was good (hence the two stars), the remaining dishes were rather bland.  Service was mediocre at best.  

Tried to order some traditional Shanghai favorites like ÈäÄÁµ≤Âç∑ÔºåShanghai spare ribs, and many items found in traditional Shanghai cuisine, and they didn't even know what those are.  

If you are a tourist and not looking for authentic Shanghai cuisine, then this is ok.  Otherwise go elsewhere. 

Other notes:  the place is cash only, and tips are automatically added on at 18%.  The fact that tips are automatically added might have contributed to the fact that service was mediocre.

Food - 8/10
Service - 6/10
Atmosphere - 4/10

First, the low marks for atmosphere are primarily due to the long touristy lines, NOT the fact that you are seated with strangers if you have a small party. I don't mind that.

Came here often when I first moved to NYC, and the soup dumplings are some of the best I've had. 

Overall good food. But upon walking in and seeing a swarm of tourists squirt pork juice all over their faces, one cannot help but burst out laughing while realizing this place has deteriorated into a trap. 

It is NOT worth the long wait. There is a nice restaurant 4 doors away on Pell St. called Shanghai Gourmet that serves identical menu items without a wait time. Or go to Shanghai Cafe on Mott St. which also serves decent soup dumplings. Also, those two nearby places are filled with only local Chinese - a clear hint that they have decent food, at the very least.

You'll get standard Chinatown service here, quick and attentive but sometimes rude. 15% tip is automatically added to your bill, CASH ONLY. Prices are fairly cheap.

Recommend:
Soup Dumplings (classic, I prefer the regular pork, not the crab ones)
Scallion pancakes (not as greasy as some other places)
Shanghai Fried Noodles (Shanghai Chu Chao Mian)

We waited in line for some time before being seated. Which I thought was a good sign. I looked up the reviews prior to being seated and thought "This place is going to be great!"

We were finally seated, we were asked what kind of dumplings we wanted even before ordering drinks. They really get down to business here. For the 8 of us, we ordered two regular pork and two pork with crab meat. They literally came out in a flash.

Once I bit into my first dumpling, I knew this wasn't the place. The filling was extremely salty and not that flavorful. I was disappointed. 

We also ordered: 

Shrimp Pan Fried Noodles - Too much sauce. Overwhelming.
Twice Cooked Pork - I thought it was decent.
General Tso's Chicken - Devoured by my table.
Salt & Pepper Calamari - Decent.
Mushrooms & Bamboo Shoots - Good.

Super disappointed.

When I return to this fantastic city that never sleeps, I will be sure to check out more of Chinatown to find the real hidden gems. Because this place is super overrated and not worth it at all. One good thing, is they have reasonable prices on some of the dishes. Another bad thing, is they only accept cash.

service is not nice. got automatically charged 18$ for a group of 4
they even didn't notice the customer in advance 
never come back
The wait is insane for this kind of food.  I don't understand what the hype is about.  Service is rude and I can get better dumplings and noodles at East Dumpling.

Perfectly good Chinese food...pork soup dumplings were quite satisfying...the smoked fish was good too.  I've been here twice for lunch and would go back.  Cash only. Yes, it's crowded, with tourists...and the staff is not very pleasant.

Came here based on a friend's friend's suggestion. The soup dumplings is what we had to try according to most people. We ended up getting 2 orders, one of pork and the other crab. Both were tender and full of protein, but both lacked flavor. It was basically stuffed dumplings with lots of liquid in them and no salt or other ingredients. You had to use the soy sauce to bring in flavor. Maybe this was the intention but for me personally, I would've liked to taste more with just the dumpling and the sauce be an enhancer. The prices were reasonable for New York. Each order had about 7 dumplings each.

Overall, flavors weren't greatest so I wouldn't personally recommend this to anyone. But while we were there, it was packed and filled with a very diverse group of customers. It was somewhere in between clean and dirty. It was definitely authentic Chinese, with servers, menus, decor and overall vibe. It was very much a get them in and out as quickly as possible. Everyone was rushing including hostess and waiters. They could work on the customer service portion of their business.

Also, CASH ONLY!
Wait was forever and we were told we were next for twenty minutes straight and watched other people in front of us. Servers were rude and the food was really bland.

Every time when I am in NYC I must come to this restaurant for best dumplings and pancake, I never have problem to add 15% tips for even one person ,  downside the service is very bad and waiter staff is rude. if Anyone come for a best dumplings don't expect any good service !!

Was honestly disappointed :( 

My friends and I came here after a long day around the city and ready to eat, but it just didn't live up to my expectations. The food wasn't particularly bad or anything but it also wasn't particularly good to me. We waited about half an hour before we were seated around 6pm which was a lost faster than I expected; however, the seating is crammed and you have to share large tables with other parties. Not sure if I could come back here and wait again as the meal was pretty average to me... The food came out sporadically so we were eating vegetables by themselves for a good 15 minutes before receiving any of the dumplings that we got for our meal. The soup dumplings that we ordered came out to our table and weren't hot as well. I wouldn't say do not come here but I also wouldn't call it a must visit (contrary to other reviews)

Ordered the chef recommended Shanghai chicken broccoli was good chicken was ok . I eat out a lot probably wouldn't come back there's so many other places . Service was good ambiance is nice as well. Cash only spot.

Disappointing experience. First of all, they make you share seats at the table with other people, even though the restaurant is 25 percent full. Then we had to wait for a while, whereas the locals were approached the moment they sat down and had a visibly better service: were approached more often even though we were sharing the same table and served by the same waiter (!). 

The Xiao Long Bao, or soup dumplings are not done correctly. They are extremely oversized. So it was hard to eat it my way - placing whole dumpling in mouth. I don't do that traditional routine where you break the dumpling and let the broth escape and then drink it separately - might as well order regular dumpling and a soup! Another moment, some dumplings were broken - so the broth leaked out. Also, don't select the dumpling with crab meat/pork - not worth extra money! Stick to traditional pork.  My Xiao Long Bao experience gained from Shanghai, Beijing and Hong Kong, so I know dumplings.

The xiao long bao (soupy buns, if you prefer) at Joe's Shanghai are just a short stroll from Apotheke. If stiff cocktails stir up your appetite, as they often do mine, this proximity could come in handy for you.

We were seated immediately, at a table already occupied by six diners. No matter, that's how they do things here (gotta love efficiency!) I did no ordering and left it up to my proficient dining companions who knew what we'd be having before we ever left the bar.

Half the fun of eating these soupy buns was trying not to spill the soup. S(he) who spills soup pays the bill. But I must admit, I didn't find the xiao long bao crave-worthy. We also had the baby bok choy and the pork and fried bean curd with jalapenos. 

All in all, a solid meal but nothing so memorable as to convince me to rush back to Joe's Shanghai.

Maybe it's because I'm Chinese, but these xlbs are just alright to me. I liked them, but feel like it's a little bit overrated. I came here when it first opened in the morning and was able to get a table quickly. My friend and I ordered 2 orders of the crab and pork dumplings for $8.25 each (first on the menu). We liked them, but we agreed we weren't in love. Overall, good cheap meal, and worth trying!

I only came here for XLB. I got pork and crab XLB. It was good but there were things I would have liked to be done differently. First of all the dumpling skin is thick! If you've ever had DinTai Fung in Socal it is almost paper thin. Secondly it is HUGE! It did not fit on my soup spoon and the soup kept spilling out. Which leads me to the soup. I thought that was very good. The filling was good too, reminded of a bun rieu crab/pork/shrimp meatball. I also did take out, took them less than 15 mins which was impressive considering the line they had waiting.
Mediocre food really. I've had better xiao long bao. Don't know what the hype was about lol.
Food is not bad, very overrated , ok for tourists, I  eate crab Dumplings Shanghai Noodles and

The wait time the hostess originally told us was 5-7minutes max. That wasn't the issue, though, we waited about 10-15 minutes, in this time there were 3 other groups of 2-3 people that were waiting behind my fianc√© and I.. (let me mind you, we were all other ethnicities except Asian.) The 4th group that came barely got a number, and were seated before any of us within 2-3minutes and they were of Asian decent. The reason was because they "had a group of 3 people." But that didn't make any sense since the people behind us were a group of 3 and they were there long before them. Anyways long story short I walked out shortly after because thats just rude. I will not be returning to this place. I would not recommend to waste your time on this place when there are many more restaurants around who will treat you with more respect.

Meh. we came here around 7:30 PM one night (Saturday) and the place was packed! I think we waited half an hour before deciding to go down the street to another restaurant, where we ate gleefully.

We did come back Sunday night around 9 PM and were seated in 5 minutes. The place was still pretty busy, and we shared a table with other diners. We ordered two servings of pork soup dumplings, crab dumplings, the seasonal vegetables (pea sprouts), turnip turnovers, and a noodle soup.

My family thought the dumplings were pretty good, but not worth waiting for. Crab dumplings were not as good. I thoroughly enjoyed my pea sprouts (which I always do) and we also added an order of fried green beans. Those were also very good. I didn't find the food too greasy at all. The only other thing I tried was the turnip pastries/turnovers. the pastry itself was really good. The filling would have been better, but it needed some salt. I was surprised they were under seasoned.

Eh. Wouldn't waste my time coming back.

Being half Shanghainese, I have high expectations for XLB. Before going to Joe's Shanghai, a lot of people hyped it up for me but it did not meet my expectations.

There was a long wait and the restaurant was really cramped. I went with a friend and we were seated at a big table with strangers. The table was not big enough for the number of people that were seated at the table. 

I ordered XLB, the double cooked pork, and fried rice cake with chicken. The XLB wrapper was not thin enough. The XLB was too juicy. It was almost as if they purposely inject the broth in the XLB rather it being the natural broth that comes from the meat. The perfect XLB needs to have the perfect thickness of the wrapper and the perfect flavor of the meat filling. I prefer Din Tai Fung's XLB and some of the Shanghainese restaurants that I have tried in LA. Another dish that I ordered was the double cooked pork. It  was really flavorful and delicious. However, the portion was rather small and it was filled with mostly cabbage rather than meat. The fried rice cake with chicken is also good but my dad does a better job at making this dish. 

The service is also not that great. The servers try to rush you to order and through your meal. If I do come here next time, I would rather order to-go.

I only come here for the soup dumplings. They are a good deal and are one of the best things i've ever eaten. However, my family only orders takeout now. The restaurant is very busy with tourists and the wait can be up to over an hour. Other then my favorite dumplings, the rest of the food is okay. The restaurant seems kind of dirty and the chairs are the old metal kind last time i went inside. Also, i don't really like sharing a table with a group of tourists that are looking at me the entire time. Last, the bathrooms are something i do NOT want to venture to. I recommend ordering takeout to same time and cleanliness.

Both the pork and pork & crab soup dumplings were pretty good! They're not nearly as good as the ones I've had in Asia, but they will definitely suffice if you're craving some sizzling hot and cheap soup dumplings to fill your cravings. Please note that these are HUGE (quite ironic considering xiaolongbao literally translates to "small" in Chinese). I guess larger portions aren't really worth complaining about, but the size does make picking up the dumpling without ripping the skin or spilling the soup much harder...so be careful!

I also tried the Shanghainese fried flat noodles, fish and wood ear cooked in a Chinese wine broth (apparently very traditional Shanghainese dish!), and some simple stir fried veggies. Everything tasted fine but were a bit too greasy for my liking. 

Though the wait may look long, the line moves quickly as the restaurant is very fast at getting food out. You will unfortunately likely have to share a table. For some reason, the restaurant contains mainly large 8-12 people tables when the groups that come are usually between 2-4. If you're uncomfortable with eating so close to strangers, then you probably shouldn't come here.

I'd eat here again if out-of-town friends really want to have a no-frills dinner at a popular spot in NYC, but otherwise, I'll stick to the many other options in Chinatown for my dumplings.

I don't understand what the hype is about. The food was not authentic - the soup dumplings were good but the rest of the food was just American Chinese that you could get at Panda Express. We waited for over an hour on a Tuesday to be seated, and only at a shared table. The waiters were very busy and you had to shout to get your order taken. Ambiance was very chaotic.

Joe Shanghai, more like Schmo Shanghai.

This place is so overrated.  Upon arriving, the first I see is a 10 person line forming outside, what look to be about a 30 minute wait.  But my hot and steamy partner, hotter and steamier than any pork dumpling, got us a table in 30 second.

Sharing a table doesn't bother me much, neither does the rude wait staff.  I mean most Chinese restaurants have sub par wait service, but I think that's part of the charm.  But 15% gratuity regardless of service?  Ridiculous.  So be careful not to double tip, because even if you eat here by yourself, it's an automatic 15%.

The dumplings are average and inconsistent, and the casing seems to thicken as they cool.  The broth is salty in a not so good way and the meat is what it usually is at other places.  The seafood noodles ranges from bad to horrible, and is bland as can be.  

Regardless this place will be a fun time for you and your five best friends.  Come and have a rowdy time.

It's not great.  It's good.  But, meh, I've experienced better.

Read everyone else's opinion, but honestly, if you know Â∞èÁ¨ºÂåÖ you'll know this place shouldn't be as popular or well rated as it is.  Plus, if you know Din Tai Fung, or if you've eaten at other XLB places in Taiwan, Hong Kong or Shanghai, then you also know what the gold standard is.  And the gold standard, being 5 stars, means this place is 2, which maybe 5 stars for NYC, but is 2 stars in the global context.  Ya feel me?

Yay, its cheap.  So I guess you could say you get a good cost to quality ratio there.

And the wait?  What a joke.  The hot pot place across the street is more delicious and more authentic a culinary experience.  So laugh at everyone in line, cross the street, eat, drink, be merry, get your check, go back outside and watch the people that were 'just' in front of you in line STILL wait for a table.

I'll be honest, I should have googled "how to eat soup dumplings" before I entered this establishment.  These are really what they say:  Dumplings with soup in them.  With each bite I had it all over me, as well as on the table.  Unfortunately, the table looked like a crime scene when it was all said and done.  When we were leaving, I watched a local eat them, and went "OHHHHH".  Do yourself a favor and look it up :).  Also, we ordered crab ones, and they were super fishy.  Wasn't a huge fan.  This place is cash only, and didn't have a super great vibe.  To top it off, there was a lady in the corner staring at us.  Very strange.  There are too many great places in Chinatown, I should have gone elsewhere.

I came here because a friend really loved their soup dumplings.  And while I used to come here quite a bit, I've unfortunately found their quality to have gone down, especially in regards to their soup dumplings. 

PROS:
- good quantity, decent to share but I would definitely get other dishes if you are hungry
- came out hot, so hot the soup could still burn my tongue haha.
- flavor was still pretty good.
CONS:
- fairly thick dough: this to me will cause more of the soup to soak into the dough.  I came for SOUP dumplings.  
- slightly dry, closer to regular dumplings. 

It is much more tourist-oriented than for the locals.  I'm sure the locals go there too.  But the 7000+ reviews definitely have assisted in this. I know I use ratings a lot when I travel.  The one other thing is that I felt rushed and not at ease by the staff, like I was always watched.  Perhaps it was the space as this was right before COVID, but it just doesn't give a good feeling for eating.  

My friend loved it.  But she likes a thick-skin on her dumplings (including her soup dumplings).  I guess this is personal preference.  If you are more of a dough-fan, then these dumplings are for you!
i got food poisoning, and everything was super greasy.  pass.
The most I can give is three stars. Crowded and bad services. The xiaolongbao is okay but not super good. Don't go with a high expectation. Oh right. The dishes are more than disppointing.

I went here on the evening the day after my birthday. My father and I walked past here and decided it seemed to be worth a shot due to the critics reviews and Michelin approved status. 
We got the string beans and chicken, Peking duck and the soup dumplings. The Peking duck tastes good and the skin was crispy but it was lacking in flavor. The quantity was also sub par compared to other locations. The soup dumplings I had no complaints. The string beans were also very overpriced. We ended up spending over $80 on the three dishes. It made sense than none of the customers were Asians. This seems to be a place for tourists.

I heard so many good things about this place, and I have to say that I was very disappointed with the xiao long bao. The wrapper was extremely thick- it should be translucent and thin, and the broth was extremely overwhelming. It was too thick and it just had no flavour apart from tasting like animal fat. If you are looking for good xiao long bao, this may not be it. Even though the prices are extremely cheap, you're better off going to a more upscale joint like Din Tai Fung.

I'm a little disappointed by this high rated Chinese restaurant. The steamed bao and dumplings were just so so. The spicy fish filet wasn't cooked as the authentic way and tasted not that good. They sell Chinese beer more expensive than other Chinese restaurants in NYC. And the overall experience wasn't nice too - they don't take card and the ATM machine in front of their door charges you for taking cash with any bank. The restaurant looks old and not very clean and people (including their staff) were talking very loud and noisy.

2.5 hr wait time. Definitely not worth it for mediocre Chinese food. Super crowded, the waiter was anxious to get our orders in immediately when we sat down, not having yet looked over the menu. Visiting from the West coast, this place is not worthy of the high praise and long wait time.
The wait isn't too bad. Turn over was fast. The food wasn't as good as I expected it to be specially Xiong long bao; but the beef and scallion, fried rice, and kangkong was better.

My personal mission to try as many soup dumpling places as possible. Another one ticked off the list. A friend and I ordered pork soup dumplings, scallion pancake, baby bok choy and fried pork dumplings. Soup dumplings were good but actually not the best that I've had (and this place is pretty hyped up). Scallion pancake was a little bland and slightly too greasy, baby bok choy was cooked well but the flavors weren't my favorite, had a slightly different aftertaste, fried pork dumplings were again good but not the best I've had. Glad I was able to try this place and would def go back but not the first on my list.

I thought the food was alright. If your from California this Chinese food will not cut it. The fried potstickers were good but the shrimp and chicken in sweet sauce and Broccoli chicken were both oily. Like I said maybe this is considered good Chinese food in New York

It's an inexpensive eat and as the Yelp consensus displays below, there is almost always some degree of a wait.  Known for their soup dumplings, it's this combination of cheap eats and tasty hype that keeps the lines sustained to the degree that they are.

We came on a Friday night and waited only about 10 minutes. When you arrive, sidle through the crowd to get inside and look for someone holding a clipboard and a roll of Admit One tickets (really).  They'll give you a number and you can do the standard wait-time estimate request then.

If it's as crowded as it usually is and you have a small party of just a couple of people, you'll be seated at a large table with other couples and trios.  Before you can blink, one server will drop hot tea at your wedge of the table and immediately thereafter, before you can crack the spine on the menu,  the server will stop by for your order and assume that at a minimum, your culinary forecast for the evening includes an order of soup dumplings.

For two people, we had one order of the hyped soup dumplings (they come eight (8) per order), one order of the scallion pancakes, and and an order of turnip pastry buns.   Again, the wait on the food is a function of how busy the rest of the joint is, but not overly noticably long.

The dumplings were tasty, but as other Yelpers have found out, the soup contained therein is scalding hot within the first minute of your food arriving.  Other Yelpers have commented on soup dumpling eating methodology so I won't repeat here, but I"ll just summarize by saying "Sip and Nibble,  don't Wolf"  (or your throat will have hell to pay).

The scallion pancakes were overly greasy, but still tasty when we kept them paired with the tea to make it taste less oily.  The turnip rolls were tasty as well, but if there's ever a moment to exercise the "chew your food thoroughly" clause, this is the time.  You'll have to put your teeth to the resilient turnip shreds inside the rolls.

For this meal, with only the complimentary tea to drink, the meal was less than $15.00, which again harks at the inexpensive list prices which keep the crowds a comin'.  

Service is to-the-point and they can only financially compensate themselves for the cheap prices by turning tables like mad, so don't take offense to the abrupt service.  Eat, enjoy, be on your way and you'll be full and content (and still have a few bills in your wallet) when you leave.

(in my best Seinfeld voice) No soup for you! 

Review just for the soup dumplings. Missing my chance on my last NY trip, I made sure to save room for their famous xiao long bao (soup dumplings) or what they call "buns" on the appetizer menu. Xiao long bao are basically dumplings that have soup inside. 

An order of Xiao long bao: 8 big dumplings, comes in crab or pork 
3 locations: 2 in Manhattan and 1 in Queens
Service: super quick and attentive - great operation getting people in and out. 15% automatic gratuity added to your bill. I was seated immediately on a Thursday evening. 

Crab dumplings: the soup is more of a gravy consistency. I didn't feel like there was enough of the soup. The dumplings are very large compared to din tai fung (a famous international xiaolongbao chain). I managed to finish one order by myself but I was kind of pushing it. The filling was alright, nothing too amazing.

What I loved: the vinegar soy sauce that came with it
