Bottom line: compared to what I've had at din Tai fung (West Coast), it's kind of lacking and overhyped. But I will be back to try the pork dumplings.

This place is overhyped and overated by Yelpers! I was seriously disappointed by the quality of the Xiao Long Baos. To think that I daydreamed about the food on my 6 hour bus trip from Boston to NYC, I feel this was a let down. Honestly, yelpers, Ding Tai Fung in Asia is wayyy better (they have a branch in Arcadia, Los Angeles too).  

The Xiao long Bao dumplings had very thick skins at Joe's Shanghai, and I felt they were overcooked, so the skin was soggy and the soup broke through the skin very easily. The place was overcrowded at 6pm and we were forced to share a table with 3 other parties, but there was barely any space to place the dishes we ordered on the shared table. We had also waited 40 min for a seat, so the overall dining experience was mediocre.

We also tried the other dishes: braised fish (so oily and sauce was so thick one couldn't even taste the fish), stir fry dou miaos (greens) and red bean dessert (too sweet!) As for the Xiao Long Baos, the crab filling was only slightly tastier than the pork filling ones. 

We paid over $60 for all the dishes, and sadly, as much as we had tried to like the food and place, it just wasn't going to happen. I'll have to rejudge New York Chinese food standards if this is one of the best Xiao Long Bao places in town.
Worse service ever!!! "Famous" dumpling just ok. After finishing the last dumpling, they brought the check not even allowing me to decide what else to choose. I defiantly do not recommend.

Yelp published Joe's Shanghai as a dim sum place because someone was uninformed and assumed that this place served dim sum. To clarify, Joe's shanghai is a place for Americanized-shanghainese cuisine and definitely not dim sum. The idea of dim sum is carts with small plates of food being served fresh to the table and what you see is what you get along with tea service. Joe's Shanghai is not any form of dim sum. And my rating for the city location remains at a two-star for food that is always too greasy in comparison to its other locations, as well as, a stuffy environment with table settings and service that don't meet my expectations.

This place was just okay. I admit, the soup dumplings were really good here. But that's about it. Come here for only soup dumplings. Everything else was not worth a second visit.

We ordered the sesame chicken, wondering what made it a popular item on yelps list... Panda Express does it better!!! The sesame chicken seemed like it was fried last night. And then microwaved...

The Peking duck was a disappointment. I saw pictures of it being a Beijing style Peking duck experience. The duck was fine, but they served it with taco sized, mission tortillas!! For the value and wait, I was hoping for something better. I was hoping for thin "pancakes" of half the size to make bite sized wraps..

The other foods were okay, but not stuff we would order again.

I ordered the typical tray of the soup pork dumplings, and the crab soup dumplings. Rule of thumb, orders of these pork dumplings usually take 10-15 to come out in a mildly busy atmosphere. These items came up approximately 2-5 minutes in a busy Sunday night. I'm pretty sure these were prepped and waiting to be served 30 minutes to an hour in advance. The dumplings came out somewhere between cold and mildly warm ruining the experience of having it served with the soup hot in the dumpling and skin barely containing the hot pork and soup bursting out of a bite with vinegar. Also ordered a tofu and Chinese spinach soup and young chow fried rice. The soup was strongly flavored with msg and the young chow fried rice was bland using chicken to substitute the red roast pork which is a very important ingredient in this dish. 

There are  plenty of less popular Shanghai restaurants with better quality if you're looking for good Shanghai food in Manhattan Chinatown.

I love Xiao Long Bao. To preface my comments about Joe's, I want to establish my baseline comparison. The current standard for me is a restaurant called Din Tai Fung.  It arguably may not be the best, but it's very good. Now, to be fair, I looked it up, and the mom and pop that started Din Tai Fung aren't actually from Shanghai where XLBs originated from, so I'm not sure if they improved on the original formula, or if theirs is authentic or if Joe's Shanghai's is authentic, or what. But apparently they started off as one mom and pop shop, and now they're all over Asia and parts of the Western US, so I think my tastebuds weren't alone in thinking they were doing something right. I suppose I'll have to drag a Shanghainese friend to both and ask. 

Regardless of what the deal is, I simply find the ones at Joe's to be not very good. While the soup found in DTF's dumplings is delicate, balanced, and delicious, the soup in Joe's is punch-you-in-the face heavy and fatty. To me, it was almost like tonkotsu broth inside. They were also double the size of DTF's dumplings, giving you double-the-already-strong dosage. If you want to feel like a gross whale afterwards, these might be the ticket. 

We did order other dishes besides the dumplings, and those were actually pretty good. But not good enough to battle the crowds.

Came here on a Tuesday for lunch.

The good: Soup dumplings are super yummy and so are their scallions pancakes.

The so so:
Like many restaurants in the area, service is mediocre

The bad:
- Place is really old and not that clean.
- Cell reception is spotty
- They only do cash 
- Can get crowded quite fast.

Final Verdict: If you like dumplings, this is a place you should try at least once...and so I did.. so won't be rushing back.

I was disappointed from beginning to end.  We traveled all the way from Florida to get their famous soup dumplings.  It was my husband first time in NYC and would be his first time trying soup dumpling.  I wanted this experience to be a good one for him since I've had soup dumplings before and from Joe's Shanghai. And it's was great then.  

When we got to the restaurant, the hostess was plenty rude.  We understand there is a long wait and was ok with that.  We place our name on the list and we proceed to sit on the bench that was empty and available inside the restaurant.  I was told to get up and wasn't allow when asked why, the hostess said it's for the people that are ahead of us and they are waiting onside so we would have to wait outside too because it's unfair to those that are here before us.  I didn't understand the concept.  I asked if they knew that these seats were available, she said yes.  Because the people ahead of me chooses to wait outside, why do I have to wait outside especially I was 6 months pregnant and it's hard for me to be on my feet for a long time.  She basically told we had to wait outside while the bench is not being used.  It was plain stupid and unreasonable but did not want to argue any further so we waited outside standing in the hot summer heat.  

We finally got seated after 30 mins.  At this point I was tired, hot, hungry, thirsty and upset so I just want to get our drinks and food.  We ordered two ice waters and the water was warm, they didn't put enough ice so ice were melted by the time it reach our table.  The soup dumplings taste terrible and fishy.  We got the pork and crab dumplings.  Can't even taste the filling inside.  It's was mush and didn't taste right at all.  There were 6-8 dumplings in an order, we couldn't even finish it.  We probably had two each.  We didn't order anything else after that.  Just paid for our bills and left.  Never coming back here again.

Went here because of the great reviews. I ordered cold sesame noodles, they were so bland, no taste at all.
Ordered chicken with broccoli. It was so greasy, I couldn't believe how much grease was in the dish and no taste because all there was , was oil! I just ate the top part, not to ingest all that oil. My friend ordered beef with scallions, it was greasy as well, but not as bad as mine.
Also we had to share a table.
And be careful, the and the tax and tip on the bill, no matter if your one, two or ten people, so don't tip twice!!
No, I won't be going back!

Ambiance: 2
Food Quality: 3 
Service: 1
Value: 3

The Gist: I came to this place for one thing and one thing only, the soup dumplings. 

After waiting for about half an hour on Sunday afternoon I can honestly say that they did NOT live up to the hype!

One couple at the table I was randomly assigned to waited for their dumplings for about 45 minutes and had to order two other dishes to hold them over while they waited. 

While the pork dumplings were certainly better to than the pork/crab combination I can honestly say that this is a great concept with a par at best execution.

Joe's Shanghai is quite overrated.
I don't understand what all the hype with Joe's is about.  The wait here is really long, it's touristy, and the XLB's (xiaolong bao / xiulong bao / Shanghainese soup dumplings / shoulonpou) here are not amazing.  Sure, they come out piping hot, but I like the ones at Petite Soochow (Ridgefield Park, NJ) just across the river a lot better.  Yes, I understand that not everyone would want to travel that far.
 
I didn't particularly like the Joe's in Flushing either.

I think this place is seriously hyped. The soup dumpling isn't so bad. but the rest of the menu is atrocious! Really bad. I had bad taste in my mouth all day long.. I will not go back there again. I prefer the Taiwanese Chinese restaurants in Queens- cleaner more tasteful.

Joe's Shanghai is overrated and not worth your time. Yes, it is very famous and everyone hears about it, but really you can have better Chinese food elsewhere in Chinatown minus the wait. 
Like most people who ended up in Joe's Shanghai, I heard raving reviews from friends and family, so I decided to try it. 
Came at lunch time on Monday so almost no wait with just the two of us. We placed the order of soup dumplings and at the same time, two tables were also seated. We waited for 20 minutes for the dumplings to come while the people at the two tables were having their second servings of soup dumplings. Service leaves something else to be desired as we were neglected while they served other people.

Finally soup dumplings came and they were at best medicore/OK. There is soup that comes out of the dumpling when you bite it, but other than that, it tastes like plain dumplings. Not worth your time. Go somewhere else for better Chinese food WITHOUT the wait. I won't be coming back at all.

I had heard so many things about this place, but I went I was pretty disappointed.  Even without the hype, I don't think I would have been that impressed.  (I'm rating the  When it comes to siu lung baos IN the US, there are better places such as Din Tai Fung. (even though those have a Taiwanese spin)  There is even a better place in New York (I'll have to dig up the name of the restaurant).   

If you do go, stick with the pork dumplings.  The seafood one was not good.  In any case, this place does not live up to the hype.

Arguably the worst service and attitude of any place I've ever been. Visiting from out of town and this is usually one of our stops. But after eating there Saturday afternoon my wife and I both said WHY do we come back ? We'll never be back. The food is mediocre at best ! And the service is atrocious.  It's hurry up eat and get the FUCK out is there mentality. And it's cash only, can u say we're screwing the IRS ! Do yourself a favor and try some other place we definitely will on our next visit to NY.

Was expecting better since they put the word "Shanghai" onto their restaurant name. For a Shanghainese who had countless authentic soup dumplings in SH, the ones served in Joe's Shanghai is very very mediocre. Their pork and crab filling does taste more fresh than your other options in Chinatown. However, the size of the soup dumpling was what had me shook. One equals two of those in Shanghai! They are way too big. The pleating was not done nicely either. The worst part was the skin. Their skin were way too thick and unenjoyable to chew on. I tried their other auth Chinese food as well. Either was too oily or had loads of MSG added. The restaurant makes you sit with complete strangers. Ppl from my neighboring seats ordered Americanized Chinese food like "genera Tao chicken" and "mangolia beef". Maybe that's a better choice.

I had this place bookmarked since it had so many great reviews, but sad to report I feel it is a bit of a tourist trap.

XLB: 2/5. Massive in size, but the shell was thick and the soup was very fatty and got sickening quick. Maybe I'm just used to Din Tai Fung's lighter broth and smaller XLBs, but we were only able to finish a couple.

Szechuan beef noodle soup: 3/5. A light broth, chewy noodles. Taste was good but nothing special.

If you're just visiting, I would skip.

Famous place but other than that, I've had better or at least similar soup dumplings from other places for cheaper, and better environment and service! Most Chinese places (less modern ones) in Chinatown don't do  tips. And the food is cheaper too! But if you are looking to say you went to Joes then yes I totally understand. But if your in the mood for great soup dumplings and cheapest, then go somewhere else. If you do go here, pork soup dumplings is the best. Crab one was fishy.

I use to love this place because it was such a tourist destination. It's been years since I've been here and the service still sucks. For sure I'm not here for their service. I'm here for the famous xiao long bao...so good! Since my family came to visit we decided to go to Joe, the famous xiao long bao is not as good as it use to!! I'm sure in NYC there are plenty of awesome hole in the wall places. Definitely wouldn't recommend this place. But of course they have set their name as a tourist attraction place. "Must go!" There service is still awesomely suck!!! What restaurant have a service charge of 15% for just three people?!? If we didn't look carefully to that we would of double tip them a suck ass service. NOW THAT IS SOMETHING I DONT CARE FOR RESTAURANT TO DO! Service charge should be included if the party if greater than 6 people.

It's Christmas, and yes I know the expectation is a minimum of 45 minutes to an hour wait.

But we were the lucky ones that were able to get a table within 2 minutes of entering.  And while all the filled tables around us starting getting their food, I was still in the Christmas spirit and refused to believe that we were the only ones forgotten.

And as I started typing this and we finally received our food, I altered my initial one star review to a solid three stars:  the food here, while I have had better, was good.  The owner even came out to greet us personally.  This I like!!!!

We had the standard broccoli beef, combo pan fried noodles (fan of the thin crispy noodles so not a favorite for me), fried pork (very tasty and not greasy), and of course their famous soup dumplings, which were flavorful and tender.

All in all, a solid three New York experience.
Famous for their dumplings however only 2 kinds served. Bad service as well. Left without ordering.

Items Selected:
Pork Steam Buns
Fried Pork Dumplings
Kung Pao Chicken 
Pan Fried Noodles with Beef

Originally located in Flushing, the Soup Dumplings such a sensation that locations in Chinatown and Midtown soon followed, Joe's Shanghai is as close to an institution as anything in the Five Boroughs, accolades from the Times, Zagat and several international publications turning each walk-in-only Restaurant into the sort of place both locals and tourists are willing to line up for.

Originally founded in 1995, though the praise and d√©cor would make many assume the restaurant that has since expanded to Japan is far older, it was around 2pm on a Saturday that a party of three approached Joe's at 9 Pell Street, the low-ceilinged space completely full with persons of all ages, colors and ethnicities, one of the six-person communal rounds soon to partially open up after a mere ten minutes of standing at the door.

Owned by Mei Ping Matsumura and "Joe" Si, the somewhat Americanized Chinese menu taking its roots in the food of Hong Kong but spreading across hundreds of items including a few, like the sweet Congee, that servers will frankly tell patrons *not* to order, it is with Hot Tea (that is also used to wipe down tabletops) already present that diners are handed menus, Tap Water refilled intermittently on request with a few additional Sodas and softdrinks also available.

Mostly English friendly, a necessity thankfully recognized by ownership as no effort has been made to detail dishes on the menu - the famous xiaolongbao still listed as "Pork Steam Buns" even though almost everyone calls the Soup Dumplings either that or XLB, it is essentially as if servers already have "1" or "2" written down as they seat patrons, the former $8.25 and stuffed with Pork plus Crab while the $6.25 version eschews the Crustacean and comes across with a smooth, briny smack thanks to the cloudy Aspic with a surprising amount of shredded Meat mixed in it.

Flooding the table with condiments, chopsticks, small cups and eventually food, those ordering past the Dumplings are offered a bevy of options including whole Ducks, various Seafoods and Noodle dishes, the Fried Pork Dumplings taking a wrapper similar in thickness to those of the Soup Dumplings and placing it around ground Sausage with just a bit of spice and serving it with Ginger-infused Soy for dipping.

Hoping that a place of such regard would have mastered Kung Pao Chicken, though the Sichuan origin of that dish probably should have raised some second thoughts at a place with Shanghai above its door since the areas are over thirteen hundred miles apart, Joe's version comes with a lot of oil and not much spice, the Vegetables completely eschewed with extra Peanuts filling in alongside the generous plate of cubed slightly overcooked Breast Meat.

Doing better by the Pan Fried Noodles, a Shanghai standard that here sees thick, flour lengths first broken and then cooked springy in Dark and Light Soy Sauce plus a bit of Sugar, Joe's Beef is sliced thin and added to the pan late which makes for a unique taste with some bites briny and others meaty, the saut√©ed Spinach standing in for Bok Choy another odd choice leads to an earthy finish, rather than the more typical bitter.

This place is really hyped up, but honestly, I've had MUCH better "hood Chinese food" lol. Just saying. 

I had this place bookmarked for a few years. So when I found myself in chinatown one day and hungry, I decided why not finally try it? The crab/pork soup dumplings are good but it's not like "OMG I have to come back" good. They were just regular good lol. We should've stopped there. For the meal, we had general tso's shrimp and it had no flavor, no spice, vegetables barely cooked, shrimp overcooked, the rice wasn't even good. I could've gotten some bomb general tso's for $7 from the local Chinese food restaurant. Not to mention the really bad service and the place is filthy. Maybe the traditional Chinese food is good here? Idk, I tried to like this one but I will never go back.

Don't be fooled by all the reviews, the meal and the atmosphere was awful. When you go in they simply jam you into any seats that are available with other people. The staff is completely indifferent and only or in a hurry feeder order so you can get up and get out. Don't think that you're going to Chinatown for something special  or home flavor, this place is really bad.

Okay these are my first time trying soup dumplings... I think? But whats the hype about this place?  We waited about 20 mins and then got sat down with another family.  I guess thats pretty smart of the restaurant to turn around tables quick.  But the dumplings itself were not that amazing... Some parts of the dumpling seemed super dry while some were nice and tender... do order the pork meat dumplings over the crab meat ones.  the crab meat ones were even more greasy and had a funky after taste. I do admit though you can get two rounds of dumplings for less than 20 bucks if I remember correctly.

The archetypal Lonely Planet tourist trap. Prepare to share tables, deal with missed orders and dirty tables. To be fair, the service tries hard given the chaos.

"Kao Fu" -- the traditional Shanghainese beancurd appetizer (not sure what it is on the menu). Came in huge, crude chunks, overly chilled, which spoiled the entire dish. Zero marks for presentation, and I'm comparing it to plebeian street versions.

Crab/Pork dumplings -- Taste-wise was fair with a good amount of stock in each bun, but the skin was overly thick. Alternately saggy, soggy and tough in all the wrong places. Perhaps it's a lack of viable competitors that garner Joe's the accolades they have, but in comparison to the xiao long bao stalwarts worldwide (read: Nan Xiang Xiaolongbao and Din Tai Fung), this is a poor imitation of the real thing.

Shredded Turnip Shortcake -- Pretty tasty and fresh. No complaints except that some sections were bitter (hard to avoid with turnips)

String Bean Szechuan Style -- Hard to screw this one up, still far from noteworthy

Shanghai Fried Noodles (thick) -- this is called "udon" by the staff, and was a disgrace to this Shanghainese street classic. The noodles did resemble bland udon rather than the earthy handmade noodles typically used. Seasoning fell short, just a mix of oil and soy sauce without the right zing. Parts were burnt, not in a good way (i.e. not "wok hei"), making the entire dish taste charred.


I might be the contrarian here but Joe's Shanghai is nowhere near the authentic experience promised in tourist guidebooks. The restaurant really seems to excel at Western-friendly Chinese take-out style stuff like the double pan fried noodles with beef everyone seems to order. Never again, unless taking a tourist friend there "for the experience". Thank god for Chinatown Ice Cream Factory round the corner.

That says it all. Meh, I've experienced better, far better and the wait on Christmas day was ridiculous. Our party of 7 waited for over an hour and 40 minutes to get into this typical Chinatown restaurant. Certainly, Joe the owner was directing traffic and admitted to me that this day was the busiest of the year for him. However the food, service (which was good for the typical Chinatown restaurant but no better than just acceptable), ambiance (none), setting (same ol chairs, tables, abused carpeting, barely passable bathrooms, etc...) and however else you gauge a restaurant, but why should this restaurant have a line that stretched past 5pm into the night when a similarly sized Chinese food restaurant across the street was only 3/4 full (Famous Sichuan) with no waiting line? Sure the restaurant grade of "B" might have something to do with that, but just because Joe's has an "A" doesn't really mean squat in lettered cleanliness? I saw the kitchen, believe me, I could find 100 kitchen issues in 5 minutes. 

All that being said, I am not giving Joe's a poor grade because of the stupid line-up. We chose to wait because so many people said it was the best. One fellow was waiting for a single seat for the same amount of time. So do people just want to say they waited? Have fun with the people in the crush? Our group made the most of it, but by the time we did get in, they had no available Won Ton soup and a couple of other items. What we did order was indeed meh... Shanghai noodles (just ok, good noodles, too much oil, vegetables just fine, no flavor, just the typical overly Unctuous oil flavor. Beef and broccoli, same thing, limited flavor, just crunchy vegetables and too much oil. Genreal tso chicken, not too much heat, also too greasy, nothing special, Shanghai dumplings, some turmeric flavor, sticky bun and plenty of water inside. Not a great version of a steamed dumpling and oh, by the way, no dim sum really beyond that. 

We also had an udon noodle soup with chicken and spinach which was not better than average. I've had far better noodle soup at deli's on 8th ave and 35th in midtown for half the price. Additionally a sweet and sour soup to share for two, also loaded with thickening agent and limited in flavor as well as the egg drop soup. Thickening agent galore. 

Also, the rice, was just rice. Frankly, if I wait for over an hour and a half, I expect perfection or close to it. There are 100 restaurants in NY's China town that would do the same or better with similar cleanliness, kitchen, indifferent staff without the wait. Frankly, having cooked Chinese meals as well as having eaten hundreds or more over the years in different cities and countries, Joe's of Shanghai will not be visited by me or anyone I know simply because it isn't worth the wait, certainly not for the food. 

I will try the "B" rated restaurant "Famous Sichuan" across the street just to compare Joe's of Shanghai and it's one hour and 40 minute wait. I suspect it will be just as good or better, rat dropping, cockroaches or other contravention or not. I mean really, is Joe's of Shanghai so much cleaner, or higher quality? I doubt it. 

So come on people, don't follow the hoards. Make-up your own minds and know that most restaurants in China Town are similar, not one standing out for food quality, preparation, service (one plate was actually just dropped on the table in front of one of my guests), ambiance, etc... Especially Joe's. Nice fellow. He has a gold mine, but really, don't waste your time.

Beware. This is not the same beloved restaurant that was on Pell St.  Must have sold their name. Despite an attempt to keep things the same on the surface the food is quite different. Dumplings have completely different taste. Barely taste the crab. It's kind of bland. Food in general is is too sweet and over salted. Not bad -- just nothing special, passable NY Chinese food. Table set up changed (no tea pot, no jar of fresh chilli paste) Menu morphed. Vegetarian dumpling now available. Fried! Sacrilege. We were very disappointed. Felt like tourists. We had been eating at the original for 10 years.

Is this a scam? Is it dishonest? Whatever. The food is not the same.

Don't believe the hype. Native New Yorker here. The place used to be great until it got over hyped and they started generating for revenue. After that it's gone down hill. My most recent visit has lost me as a customer forever unless they can make some serious changes.

So here's what happened,
Three people gave us an estimated wait time of 20 minutes. That was fine since the place was full. Ten minutes later they tell us our table is ready. We go inside and then the maitre d' tells us another few minutes because the other maitre d' gave the table away to a group of three that came after us. We were a little annoyed but fine we'll wait the extra minutes. Long story short, half an hour later were still standing and waiting. People who've just came in and asked for a table were seated before us. When we asked about it they gave us attitude saying they were popular and people needed to wait. Needless to say, they were rude and arrogant.
The soup dumplings (Xiao Long bao) is still decent but quality has definitely lowered to just to keep up with demand. In my opinion they should be able to do both if really wanted.
The staff need a serious attitude adjustment though.
Meh. I don't really like the food. It's not one of the cleanest spots I have been either. Would recommend for someone wants a china town experience

the soup dumplings are really good here

but I wouldn't really recommend the noodle/rice dishes here... very bland

Dear Joes Shanghai,
You just lost a loyal customer today. You have been my favorite for over 10 years. I took my family, who's never been to NY, to visit and highly recommended you. However, today's experience-  I'm highly disappointed and will never come back. Your server, who brought out the wrong food, yelled at us. Your "Diced pork & Dry bean curd" dish was mainly made of chicken. When pointed out, you claimed a string of pork ear was "pork", and that was the only pork ingredient in your diced pork dish. Although the food was incorrect, the servers attitude was the most upsetting, being yelled loudly by your server. 
We won't be coming back, but as well-known as you are. I'd recommend you retrain your server so other guests won't have to experience that we went through.

Terrible digs, sub-par and overpriced XLB, and lackluster dishes. The fried flounder is the only seriously tasty thing I've had here. I'd rather get a foot massage across the street and then go Shanghai Cafe deluxe, 456, or flushing.
Don't understand the hype. West coast XLB, or dim sum palace in Manhattan is a lot better than this place. Broth tastes dirty and dumplings are too big.

Not sure how difficult it is to find soup dumplings in the city, but I felt that this place was a bit overhyped. The soup dumplings with crab meat were pretty good, but the plain pork ones were very average and didn't have enough soup in them. I tried a few other veggie/meat dishes as well, which all tasted just mediocre.

The restaurant itself just seemed too noisy and crowded, but service was still prompt. Fortunately, all the food came out within a reasonable span of time. I just wish the quality were better.
Overrated and not very delicious sadly. It's more for the tourists than the locals who want good food. Service is excellent as is the ambiance but the food has really gone downhill.

As Californians, we were spoiled with xiao long bao from Din Tai Fung. We had high expectations coming to Joe's Shanghai, but unfortunately, the soup dumplings didn't meet our expectations. The vinegar sauce also was not as flavorful. The green onion pancake was more appetizing. I would give the onion pancake an 11/10. The crispiness was on point and the sauce doe the pancake was savory - hint of sweet and salty.

Three stars.

Pretty good soup dumplings. Very fattening, but sometimes you need that, especially on a cold winter night.

Tip: If you go with a large party, you might end up waiting hours outside to get seated together. If your party don't mind splitting up in 2s or 3s, you get seated much quicker.

Last time I was here, this place was rated B for their sanitary inspection. Not sure if this is true, but the restaurant within the same block under a different name is under the same management, with the inspection grade of A and no waiting lines. I'll update this review when I visit next time and find out more info. Till then, happy slurping!

I was recently in NYC for a sporting event and visited Joe's Shanghai based off of the recommendations from a couple of friends.  Obviously I went with the XLB since that's what they're famous for.  I also ordered a peking duck.  The XLB was ok, not the best I've ever had but definitely hits the spot when you have a craving for soup dumpings.  The duck on the other hand was pretty magnificent.  The skin was perfectly crispy and the duck was tender and moist.  Only reason this review wasn't a 4 star is because the price of the food there was pretty inflated, but I guess that's what you would expect in NYC.  I do have to say though, there are plenty of great whole in the wall type of restaurants in the city that wont break the bank.

I am a XiaoLongBao - Soup Dumplings Connoisseur.
I've had XLB from Cali to China to NYC and this place is one of the worst I've had ever. 
Skin - was so thin it was falling apart and not only couldn't hold the soup but could barely hold the meat.
Soup - was loaded with so much pepper it make it taste almost spicy but not a good spicy.
Meat - is on the same boat as the soup. I don't see how they can disregard how much pepper they are loading in there. It's like eating something and pouring a bottle of pepper in your mouth between each bite.
Atmosphere - on top of that, they only take cash (which didn't affect me). They charge a gratuity on anyone regardless of how big is your party (which doesn't affect me if they would do their job and serve). Have you ever had. Group of guys joking and staring at you while you eat? It's pretty uncomfortable.
Most XLB places hire females or a mixture, but they only wanted guys and for that they probably have people that don't want to tip them and they resort to charging it.
Don't get me wrong, I have nothing against them charging a gratuity since it was stated. The problem I have is if you're going to charge one then actually do your job instead of standing there and messing around.
P.S. This is my personal opinion but look and compare the reviews for the places around NYC.
I will give any place a second chance but I just don't see myself ever liking this place. It lacks in every aspect of XLB with no positives at all. 
Also they leave their Black vinegar dip outside sitting on the table which is gross. I hope they change it between customers but regardless it's not sanitary to just leave it sitting there. At least have the decency to bring it from the back whether it's clean of not; at least I won't see it.
Do yourself a favor and go to any of the hundred ones around there.

If you are only ordering xiao long bao and don't care about your time or comfort, this place rates higher than my review. In all honesty the xiao long bao are 4 stars, almost as good as Ding Tai Fung in Hong Kong. However the rest of their menu is 3 stars at best. Avoid the duck and most cold cuts, nor is much of the seafood any good for a Shanghainese place. Expect to wait in a stench filled street filled with garbage if you go in the evening. Also expect very rude service, in fact this is the first restaurant I am rating down for their horrible wait staff. Thus this review would normally be 3 stars for their overall choices of food.

I've heard great things about this place until I experienced it for myself.  I went with friends for lunch and the service was HORRIBLE.  The pork buns on the menu were not what we expected, and once the was just dropped off at the table with not know what some of the entrees were.  We had to ask numerous times for refills on water. We were constantly ignored by the wait staff.  I will NEVER be returning here and I encourage others to do the same.

We showed up to this place pretty late on the night we arrived and the line was stretched out down the block. We found the hostess and got our name on the list before heading to the bar next door for drinks as we waited. Once inside we the place was truly raucous and loud, but everyone - from all walks - was clearly having the time of their lives. 

The environment was fantastic but we got approached by two different waiters for our orders and they ended up bringing us a dish we didn't actually ask for. Additionally, once we got all our food (which was way too much for the tiny top we were seated at) it was overall fine, but honestly a bit bland for what we were hoping for. In my personal opinion the place is fun as an environment but a bit overhyped so far as the actual food is concerned. 

Go here fam, but no rush to do so.

I came here and didn't have to wait at all. We were seated at the same table as another party (which was fine, I did this in China as well) and I was really excited to try the dumplings/dim sum.

This place was super packed and the waiters had a mentality "eat and get the hell outta here". So I felt like I was in an eating contest with my food. Literally the waiters were running around like they were in an olympic race. It gave me a bit of anxiety. 

We ordered a bunch of food: noodle dishes, dim sum, dumplings, etc. hoping that everything would be the best Chinese food we've ever had.

Sadly, I wasn't really impressed with any of the dishes. I thought the flavors were quite bland and nothing special. I'm not sure what all the hype is about but there are a lot better places for dim sum and Chinese dishes. It's mainly tourists here which is understandable but it's not worth the wait or hype.

Maybe I'll come back and try it again to see if I'm missing something, but for right now, not impressed!

A complete tourist trap in Chinatown.  Would definitely never go to again.  

To start off I found the staff to be rather pushy and not hospitable at all.  Instead of feeling welcome here, I felt like my group was being rushed in and out as soon as possible.  

Next, the food is completely lackluster and just doesn't taste that good.  

I had the tofu, shrimp, and diced pork.  It was supposed to be spicy --- it wasn't in any way, shape, or form.   Instead it was completely bland and boring.... and for some reason it had peas in it.   I really don't understand that.

The signature dish here is the soup filled dumplings ... these are ok ... but I can't imagine any reason to justify sitting outside in a line waiting to get inside to have some.  At the end of the day, I would rather just have a normal bowl of Chinese soup with dumplings on the side.  You can find soup and good dumplings at a million other restaurants in chinatown.  Having the broth inside the dumpling loses its allure rather quickly. 

Finally - they don't take credit cards and they automatically add the tip into your bill.  Neither scenario are ones that I appreciate.  Keep both in mind please when ordering.

If you want really good Chinese food, I would highly recommend walking around the corner from here and checking out the Hop Shing located at 9 Chatham Square.   There you will find real Chinese food --- the way the Chinese like it.  (For what its worth -- the majority of people at Joe's Shanghai were not Chinese -- the majority at Hop Shing always are -- that should tell you something)

Waiting to get into this Joe's Shanghai just makes no sense to me.  I will not be back.

I don't get it, this place was terrible. The chicken was old, dry, and undercooked (pink). The soup dumplings were way too soupy to even pick up. Half of the dumplings were already punctured when they reached he table.
The service was questionable even for Chinatown. In my option Joes Ginger is the better option for Shanghainese

Was in the mood for some dumplings and Yelp lead us here. 
We ordered the soup dumplings and the pan fried dumplings. Pork and seafood. Some of the dumpling wrappers were thinner than others. Because of that, the soup dumplings fell apart and some were leaking broth as we picked it up off the basket. The dumplings itself were bland to me. It needed some more seasoning. The seafood dumplings were fishy. We could definitely tell they were seafood from the after taste. The pan fried dumplings was nothing different from your regular Chinese take out. Not the worst dumplings but definitely not worth a second visit. Don't think we'll be back. Headed back to Yelp for another dumpling place.

This place is a way too expensive. One beef broccoli costs 17.00 + tax.  The rice is not free. In general the rice is free for restaurants.  This place is bullshit.  The only good dish is soup dumplings.  Not recommended!

Real authentic Chinese place, food is good and on point!
Quick service, had to ask for fork n knives! Long noodles, im guessing in house made...

I am not normally one to give soup dumplings anything but 5-Stars, but when we went, even though we devoured hundreds of dumplings (pork, crab) they seemed a bit overly mass produced.  Almost immediately after arriving at the table they got too sticky, thus spilling out everywhere when you tried to remove them from the baskets, and the soup tasted too gelatinous.  The flavors were good, and the rest of the food was good, but I just wasn't overwhelmed.

+1 Star for when they came to sing our friend Happy Birthday one of the waiters wishes he were an opera star and probably could be with the set of lungs he has.  It was quite memorable.

As soon as I walked in and saw that we were the only asians should've been a warning.  Ordered the pan fried shanghai thick noodles, onion pancakes, and their "infamous" shanghai dumplings.  Searched through their whole menu and sadly this place doesn't even have soybean drink.  The onion pancakes came, super greasy.  The noodles came, super greasy, and taste like burnt wok.  The dumplings came, and they were unruly in size.  The soup was absolutely disgusting!!! Can't even call it soup, it was ALL oil, and it tasted funny.  Not to mention, there's SOOO many waiters here that are just hawking at you.  Ugh so uncomfortable.
Worse part of my NY trip, can't believe I wasted my time and money coming here.  total FML.     

Conclusion: Tourist trap, over-hyped, frozen shanghai dumplings taste better than this, health hazard if you eat these 

FMLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLL

The definition of overrated. I knew something was off when I arrived at the location and the staff told me and my friend 20 minute wait. We walked away for four minutes than all of a sudden our table was ready when nobody left. Very fishy, almost like they said that to dissuade us to not dine here. The soup dumplings were at a inflated price because Joe makes a killing on tourists or people that never had Shanghai food. None of the dishes that were soup dumplings would stand a chance to be sold by themselves. Insider Food did an interview with Joe and he said that his soup dumplings have 30 pleats good and on average chefs have 26 pleats. Well it's clear Joe doesn't work in the Chinatown one because there was 22 pleats when I went. The best surprise of the whole experience is when they charged me for 2 whole orders of crab meat soup dumplings when I ordered one pork, and one order of half pork / crab meat. Pork was $12.95 and Crab is about 3 dollars more but do what you gotta do to keep the lights on I guess. There are local places all throughout Nyc that won't charge an arm for soup dumplings and have better quality.
Good dumplings but is the worst service ever... I would not come back... The food came late, forgot the order... the waiters are clueless

These infamous Xiao long bao (soup dumplings) are definitely one of the best, if not the best, in the city. Believe the raving loyalists, the newspaper reviews plastered all over the walls, and everything else. The dumplings are everything you want them to be- fresh, piping hot, and perfect inside and outside. Served with vinegar and fresh ginger. They deserve 4-5 stars alone. However, the rest of the food here is kind of abysmal. The only other thing I'd order besides the bao is maybe Chinese water spinach which is decent although really oily. Also, while I do love the crab and pork versions of the soup dumplings, there always seems to be crab shell fragments in at least a few pieces per steamer. If you're into crab shell Russian roulette then this is the perfect entree.

Came in for the crab and pork soup dumplings because we'd heard that they were the best in the world. I'm not sure you can call these xlbs but they were rather soupy and decent. Definitely not even close to top 10 best dumplings I've ever had.  I thought the skin was too thick and overall the way this entire establishment is run is pretty unappealing. Rude service, rushing people out, pushing past customers in the narrow walkways with plates of food... meh.
Came with my family and ordered a bunch of food. Things were good until I got a piece of metal in the first crab soup dumpling I bit into.

Eh, really wasn't that great.  Soup dumplings were great (also my first experience) but the other dishes were nothing to write home about.  It you want to gorge on Chinese food and spend about $10, this is your spot.

Really unimpressed. Dumplings were fine. Fried rice was tasted like smoke. Kung pao chicken wasn't the least bit spicy and had zero flavor. Would not come back. Definitely feel like we got sucked into a tourist attraction.

I'm sorry but Joe's Shanghai is completely overrated! Everytime I've tried to come here there has been such a long line that I decided to pass.  This time I was in Chinatown on a Saturday with friends and figured we'd give it a try and we got lucky - walked right in.....

Now one thing that I guess is cool about this place is that they sit you where there is an opening - so you will sit at a table with random people. One very important thing you will notice when you enter Joe's Shanghai is the lack of actual Chinese people eating here - I think that's a clear sign about the food here!! The decor was the same, it really felt like being in a cheap chinese american restaurant. 

For food we ordered Pork buns (Soup Dumplings), which are priced well - 8 for around $5, beef w/ Broccoli, sauteed bok choy, scallion pancake, and chicken and vermicelli. Really, the soup dumplings weren't anything special - there wasn't much soup in the dumplings and they weren't that flavorful - They were just ok, but since I've had really good soup dumplings in Shanghai and comparably good dumplings at Nan Xiang in Flushing (http://www.yelp.com/biz/nan-xiang-dumpling-house-flushing) i know what really good dumplings should be like.  The rest of the food isn't worth going into much detail - and really made for the American palette. I will add that the scallion pancake was super greasy!! Try the Scallion Pancakes at Nan Xiang if you want try to try a good one.

This place is a waste of time if you have to wait on that long line - the food isn't great, the ambience isn't the best - and really this place is so overrated - plus there are so many other good AUTHENTIC chinese food restaurants in the area.

Uhhh I dont know why people RAVE about this place. I have certainly have had better. Maybe I am a Cali snob and am missing the delicious chinese cuisine in the Bay Area. Maybe since I have been eating chinese food all my life, every chinese place is just meh to me. Maybe I am right and this place is a little overrated. *shrug

The dumplings are good, but not good enough for me to wait and share the table with 5 other parties of 2. 

If you absolutely have to have their soup dumplings and dont believe me that they are just OK.... go next door to Joe's Ginger (i think thats what its called). They are owned by the same people and you get to cut down on the wait time.
Soup dumplings are great, but the mandatory 15% tip + tax "for my convenience" is a little telling. I still like shanghai cafe better because they have bubble tea.

the xlb's at joe's are okay.  i am not really a fan of joe's because it's so americanized.   i usually judge a chinese restaurant by how many non-asian people frequent it.   i'm not saying the food isn't good at joe's and i am not saying it's bad that there are more non-asian people in line for it than asian people.   asian places with a lot of non-asian customers usually charge more for their food and usually charge tax.   a typical chinese place in chinatown does not charge tax and the prices are usually lower and i feel their food is inferior because they americanize it somehow.

joe's prices are more money and they charge tax.   i don't think the xlb's at joe's warrant such a long wait when there are better shanghainese places to get your xlb fix.   because the lines are so long at joe's, the waiters end up rushing you and it is so cramped inside.   if i am going to eat xlb, i want to be able to eat it without waiting forever for a table and without being kicked out shortly after sitting down.

on another note, i do order joe's via seamless when i order dinner at work, but i only order it because it's on the firm and i don't have to wait too long for it.

if you want good xlb, try the shanghai place across the street from the police precinct on elizabeth street. now that's a good mom & pop's shanghai place.   (avoid 456 shanghai - that's another tourist trap.  shanghai cafe/shanghai manor are good contenders).

The dishes were good, but their customer service was the worse I've even seen. Their staff were rude to us, and they were saying something in our back in Chinese. Overall, it was a not very good experience, a little bit disappointing because we were very excited about it. And the staff ruined everything.

i hate to go against the grain here, esp since majority of the 800+ reviews for Joe's Shanghai seem to be glowing.

moved near Chinatown, and found Joe's off yelp.

got the infamous #1 - pork/crab buns (aka: soup dumplings).

delicious, but wasn't BLOWN AWAY like everyone else seems to be.
maybe there is a slight bias there, since chinese cuisine isn't my #1.
also, this was my first Xiao Long Bao experience, so I also didn't have anything to compare it to.

all in all, i would recommend.

This place is completely overrated. Two of us had to wait over 15 minutes to be seated at a table for eight--with three other parties. 

Tried two types of soup dumplings, both of which were bland and terrible. The one that supposedly had crab in it was especially poor, as I apparently paid extra for little strings of seafood that didn't taste like anything. The skins didn't complement the dumplings at all and were simultaneously too thick yet broke when picked up with chopsticks.

We also had the cut noodles, which have long been a favorite dish of mine. The ones here were excessively doughy, and yep, flavorless. The accompanying meat was over-tenderized. Service and decor were typical Chinatown, which is fine with me. 

I'm probably spoiled from growing up in the SF Bay Area, but this place was terrible even by NY Chinese food standards, and I most certainly won't be back.

Tip: Try Amazing 66. It's not Shanghainese cuisine, but at least it's tasty.

Can't be comparable to real soup dumplings from
Din tai fung. Also really disliked their noodles. Furthermore, we went right when they closed and they seated us. But then said they only had soup dumplings and noodles. Which is quite limited, I wish they just turned us away

We were staying at the Hotel 50 Bowery next doors which had a partnership with Joe's and allowed us to order $50 worth of takeout each day we stayed there so we tried Joe's twice during our stay. I couldn't understand what the hype was about. The soup dumplings wrappers were much too thick and taste itself was below par. I've had much better elsewhere (Din Tai Fung for example). 

Other things we tried were just meh as well. The Szechuan Spicy Beef Noodle soup had a weird taste and the wonton soup felt really basic. I won't be dining in anytime soon.

I didn't like it here. I'm not a fan of communal seating and in a place where everyone orders quite a few different things it felt cramped and awkward. The soup dumplings were fantastic. The rest looked and tasted like very poor quality Chinese food. Hugely disappointed.

Well, I tried their small steamed bun in flushing before & it was awesome . However,the food here tasted more slaty & the price is little bit higher than flushing. I felt disappointed . Even though they are the same name of the restaurants, the chefs are different„ÄÇI don't recommend ppl come here but suggest to go to  the one in Flushing. It's better

Soup dumplings remain exceptional...but service has deteriorated from casual to downright sloppy and inattentive.  When we finally received the food we actually ordered, we found the quality poor.  Joe's is no longer the special destination we looked forward to.

Joe's Shanghai is my least favorite Shanghainese place. It's hype doesn't help either. It attracts a lot of tourists, and a lot of people who do not know what is GOOD Shanghainese cuisine. 

My father lived in Shanghai for many years for business purposes, and he is also not a fan. The soup dumplings are not soupy, and the dough are too thick. Why do the dumplings break even with such a thick dough btw? 

I highly suggest for people to spend a few more minutes on yelp, or tripadvisor and potentially look for a better restaurant to try minus the hype.

My friends and I got there right before the Friday night wave so we got seated within 5 minutes. It's cash only but they have an ATM right outside.

Ordered beef noodle soup, Shanghai stir-fry udon, original and crab-meat soup dumplings, and kungpao chicken. The beef in the noodle soup wasn't spectacular and I've had better Shanghai stir-fry udon elsewhere.

The only pro is their soup dumplings. I've never had soup dumplings this size in NYC and they were filled with yummy soup. If you go here, definitely try the soup dumplings to spend your money wisely

Food is good at the restaurant but we had an awful experience ordering food to be delivered today. They use postmates which was a complete disappointment and awful experience. The food was waiting to be picked up for delivery and postmates cancelled last minute leaving me stranded to pick up a large order for a group lunch. All they send is an email when it's too late to make other arrangements, it's horrible customer service and they cannot be trusted to deliver food.  The restaurant should provide a reliable delivery service  that works.

This new location has a nice interior but the food is overhyped. The crab meat soup dumplings are nothing to write home about (somewhat bland) and the shanghai stir fry noodles are too salty. I did like the scallion pancakes (good ratio of fluffiness to crispiness) and the red bean dessert pastry. 

The food was overall pretty decent but for me, not worth an insanely long wait for some very average soup dumplings. That's what we came for!

This place was just OK to me. The price point for the food is fine but I did not see the hype for it. Service was fine and they seemed like they were always in a rush, which was understandable given how busy it was. We would have to try to flag them down if we needed anything. We ordered soup dumplings, scallion pancake, and the Shanghai noodle soup. The soup dumplings were not that great to me. It was hard and doughy on the top while being dry. Other soup dumplings I had were with a clear broth on the inside but this was not. There was scum inside and it was a lot richer than others I have tried. The scallion pancake was okay but a little greasy. The Shanghai noodle soup had a lot of veggies, which I was craving for during my trip, however it was pretty bland. Not sure if I just ordered the wrong items or if I came on a bad day, but I was not impressed.

The soupy dumplings are definetely the thing to get, and they were really good and fun to try something different.  Otherwise, I wasn't overly impressed with the food.  We had the salt and pepper prawns--a little too fried for my likely.  They were good, but I wouldn't order them again.  
Also, I'm not sure how the line up works.  There were a few people waiting for tables when we got there, but we were still seated immediately, in front of the others who were waiting.  I can't complain, but not sure how that works.

I really, really wanted to try this place. We even waited in line, and got inside and a table! Unfortunately we had to leave because they only offer their famous foods in pork and we don't eat pork :(

The food was not bad in this china town restaurant. The waiters are rude, but in a really cool way. I tried ordering several different dumplings and they wouldn't allow it. He said it was too much. The only reason I gave it two stars, was for the cleanliness, it was pretty bad. I used the bathroom after I finished my meal and had I gone prior to ordering, I would have walked out.

I'm not quite sure what the big deal about this place is - I tried their famous pork and crab XLB, and while they were the juicest dumplings I've ever had, they just weren't that good. The crab tasted stale and fishy, and was probably canned, not fresh. There was an enormous amount of broth in the dumplings, so if you have a XLB juice fetish, then perhaps Joe's is for you. However, I didn't think that the broth was that flavorful - it was kind of fishy and soupy, but not very rich. 

Joe's is not in the same league as Din Tai Fung, and it would be considered mediocre in the Bay Area.  That being said, as a San Francisco native, I do think that NYC Chinese (and East Coast Chinese in general) is pretty weird, so YMMV.

We also had an order of seafood rice cake noodles, which wasn't that good, but was better than the XLB.  The service was actually entertaining, since they try to shove as many people as possible into their restaurant as possible. The two of us shared our large round table with 3 other parties. I have no problem with the service, since busy, crowded, and rude usually correlates to excellent food, however the food wasn't that great, and I don't know why people rave about this place. Perhaps this might be good for NY, it's pretty bad for LA or SF.

Joe's Shanghai has a been one of my favorite places for many years.  I just went this week and was surprised when my favorite, soupy dumplings tasted awful.  They were  filled half way with some oily brown broth not there usual delicious tasting yellowish broth.  The crab/pork filling well lets just say I would question whether it was crab/pork.  It was pretty bad.  The worst of it was that I took friends who also ordered it (because I bragged so much about them) and they couldn't even eat one. I tried to eat them anyway and after the 2nd one I through all of them out.  Very disappointing.  I'm hoping the Chef was just having a bad day.

What I like - The food, quick service, price, and the oranges after the meal. What I don't like - The stink of that whole area when you are waiting outside, the rushed service, no rating on the window. I am so torn about this place and only go here (my third time) because my wife and our friends really like it. Chinatown is just really nasty.
I love this place. The dumplings are great. Waiters can be a bit pushy & I don't enjoy sitting with strangers and hearing x-rated convos about exes as I eat but other than that I love it !

Horrible experience. 5:30 on a wednesday and it's packed. The servers work on an assembly line and treat you as if your chair's sitting on it.

Their focus is on getting you out. Asses on my shoulders as they place the plates down, arms reaching  across my head and face.

Had shredded pork with bean curd and jalopenos - flavorless, it was disgusting. 

My friend had the orange beef with broccoli that actually tasted ok while there but 2 hours later in turned into shrunken brown pieces of sweet dough-paste.

There's no need for me to ever go back. So many restaurants in the area have stepped their game up so bye Joe's Shanghai.

What a freaking illusion. 

Love,
Nicole from
GetUnstuckNYC.com

Not worth the wait and this place is the literal definition of a tourist trap. The soup dumplings were not it. The skin of the soup dumpling was thick which usually isn't supposed to be the case. Staff had an attitude and a 18% automatic gratuity was applied. Even more troublesome, this place is cash only. 

If you want good soup dumplings, just avoid this place and go to Flushing.

Eh.  I love Shanghainese dumplings, but I thought this place was just okay.  I was excited to try it too because I always hear about this place and how great it is.  We walked right in around 1PM and were seated right away.  They seat all small parties in a communal tables.  After about 10 minutes, it seemed like a tour bus unloaded into the restaurant because it was then super crowded.  We came just for the dumplings so we ordered one of each, the pork and the crab.  They were nice and juicy but the flavor and texture of the skin was just not as good as others we have tried.

Expected a lot from this place as it has tons of good reviews, and the long wait for a table. The food was good but a bit oily and not super flavorful. They don't serve any bottled water and service wasn't great. Good location and well priced.

Soup dumplings here weren't transcendent.  They were okay.
Not bad, but I've had better.  In the US.  On the East Coast.  Which suprised me immensely.

I've heard a lot things about Joe's! It's definitely an institution in NYC. I was excited to try them out and decided to order delivery on UberEats. Everything came packed well and hot. That was probably the only good part about the meal. 

What I tried-

Pork Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings): 
These were gigantic and came with 6 pieces which I thought was a great deal! However these had little to no flavor and were extremely greasy. For XLB/soup dumplings, I understand the fat helps with the juiciness and flavor of the dumpling/soup but this has literally no flavor. The vinegar it came with with also too sour. I ended up using vinegar that I had at home (the Lee Kum Kee brand) and that made it a bit easier to eat. Would not order these again. 

Shanghai Noodle Soup:
You get to pick what type of noodle you want for this dish but again, nothing helped since this was also flavorless. It was packed with veggies and shreds of pork but literally no salt, no spice, no seasoning. I honestly thought I caught COVID since I couldn't taste anything. The noodles were a nice texture and the pork had some flavor but that was it. I would not order this again. 

Again, this was a to go order so I didn't go to the restaurant or see the inside or anything so I can't comment on ambiance. I was very disappointed with my meal though and I hate leaving bad reviews but this was a waste of time and money. There are better options in Chinatown. 2 stars since the food is edible. Hopefully they change things up and improve their seasoning.

So after seeing various New York foodie YouTube vids/vlogs and reading the Yelp reviews, I finally had my opportunity to go and see what the hype was all about with regards to Joe's Shanghai and their soup dumplings (XLB). And here are my honest opinions...

Coming from Southern California, Asian food is already good here. There's no doubt about that. But I was curious as to see what made Joe's Shanghai's soup dumplings unique versus the soup dumplings here Mama Lu's at Monterey Park or Din Tai Fung (I have yet to try DTF because I personally think that DTF's XLB is overpriced af). Plus, my friends and I wanted to visit Chinatown in NYC so that was one of the perks of coming here during our NYC trip haha.

When we arrived to Joe's Shanghai, it was around 8:30PM and it was still packed. We waited for a good 15-20 minutes before we were seated. One thing that I immediately noticed about this place was how many tourists were dining at this place. And by tourists...I mean by how many Caucasians were at Joe's Shanghai. It was an interesting observation because I would assume mostly Asians would dine at Asians restaurants but like no joke, it was mostly white people dining in hahaha. Extremely touristy. When I noticed that, I kinda knew that this would be some sort of a tourist trap but hey, I wanted to give this place a chance. Interestingly, a passerby-er shouted out that Joe's was a tourist trap right in front of the restaurant and we should try somewhere else LOL.

The wait wasn't too bad. Though, it was extremely packed inside. And extremely loud and obnoxious...like your typical Asian restaurant.There are a bunch of large, family style tables but you're bound to share a table with fellow strangers. From what I remembered, we ordered the XLB, fried rice, and orange chicken. The fried rice and orange chicken were alright. The orange chicken literally tasted like oranges so it was a nice version of this common dish. Though, nothing too special but a little overpriced in my opinion.

As for the XLB, what I do like about Joe's XLB is that I do believe that their soup:dumpling ratio is on point. It was served hot when it arrived (as it should). In each XLB, there is a right amount of soup per each bite and it's extremely juicy. Prices here are fairly cheaper than DTF but Mama Lu's is still slightly cheaper, I believe. Though, my criticism of Joe's Shanghai's XLB is the flavor of the soup.The soup in the XLB at Mama Lu's is much richer and more flavorful than at Joe's Shanghai. Plus, I believe that at Mama Lu's, the soup dumplings contain more soup flavor than actual dumpling (so every bite turns out amazingly delicious and rich, which I actually like to be honest). The other food entrees at Mama Lu's are much more appetizing and affordable than at Joe's Shanghai. To be honest, I was missing and craving more of Mama Lu's XLB because I miss the complex, rich flavor of their soup dumplings.

Overall, it was pretty meh and I was sorta let down of Joe's Shanghai. Indeed, it is a tourist trap. Honestly, I wouldn't go out of my way to get XLB here since I know that there are some pretty bomb XLB here in Southern California. It was a good experience though!

Decent grub - I didn't really enjoy the flavors
I don't expect fine dining but the xiao long bao just wasn't sitting right with me.

Cheap prices comparatively to other joints but not so clear service . This may be a hot spot in NY but I just didn't like it so much :/

It's true the crab and pork soup dumplings are exceptional. We also had the Chinese cabbage with dried shrimp platter, the scallion pancakes, and mushroom and bamboo shoots. All were tasty though the two vegetable dishes could have eased up on the saucing - the ingredients shine all on their own! 

My beef had to do with the experience - waiting for a table is not unheard of, but once you sit down, I'd really like to not be further rushed. We ordered several dishes and they came nearly all at once. Our order for a party of 5 overwhelmed the surface area of the table we were sharing with another couple, and left little room for their dishes. Additionally, sitting on the aisle side of the restaurant meant I was hit no less than 5 times by passing servers, other patrons' bags, and the like, and these were no slight pats, but ones that sent my head or arm knocking forward to disrupt items on the table. Managing the crowds or staff is clearly not high on JS' priority list.   

I'm glad I came once for the famous dumplings but if the rest is part of the charm of JS, I'd rather opt out.

Definitely overrated.  There is always always ALWAYS a line to Joe's Shanghai and I always hear about the good reviews.  I finally gave in and went to try this place with my sister and her friends.  It was a disappointing visit for us.  The food was OK.  Maybe we were just unlucky but some of the dishes we ordered were just too salty and I don't know what happened to my dumplings.  It was dry; where did all the soup go??? 
Shanghai Cafe offers better dumplings for sure (although the service not so much).  

I personally wouldn't recommend the food.  However, if you want to go with the crowd, be my guest!  They do offer ok service, better than nothing!

Coming to new york, this was the first place my family visited. The service was okay, but our food came out in the weirdest orders. Once we finished ordering, scallion pancakes came out right away. We ordered two XLB, and it took 20 minutes after the scallion pancakes. However, only one reached the table and then it took another 10 minutes for the other XLB to hit the table. Flavor wise, everything tasted great, just wished both of them arrived at the table because it was sort of weird waiting for food once the dishes were done. Additionally, my family ordered noodles and soft shell crabs and they didn't reach the table for quite awhile. Everything tasted great, just wished it did not take so long for food to hit the table and was hoping they would the table all at once like a normal family dinner.

I ordered the pork dumplings, string beans, and stirred fried noodle. I think the pork dumpling tasted mediocre. It also didn't have a fixed shape but more of a saggy look to it. The string beans was probably my favorite but could have been cooked with less oil and same goes for the stirred fried noodle. It was just too oily and gave such an unpleasant taste to the mouth. 

Overall, I think the food tasted good for its price but I'm not sure if I would come back here a second time.

I have a soft spot for this place - the Xiao long bao are not ideal size, texture, or flavor balance, yet I still come back and will pound two trays solo... 

Joe's is the White Castle of Xiao long baos - tasty, cheap, greasy, and utilitarian.  I love them even if I know there's better :) 

Cash only and you may share a table with someone

Had high hopes for this place because of how popular it is, but not worth the hype in my opinion. Our party of 6 came around 7 on a rainy Tuesday evening, and we were seated within 10-15 min. It was super crowded, and we were sat at a table against the wall--a bit tight of a fit but cozy enough for our party. 

To be honest, only the pork soup dumplings (xiaolongbao) were good (nice meat to soup ratio!). Everything else was just okay (lacking flavor)--we ordered jellyfish (too much oil), two meat dishes (chicken and cucumbers and shredded meat that came with wraps), and one veggie dish (tofu skin/broccoli/carrots). It was only $16 per person with tip, which is such a steal for the amount of food we had, so you can't beat Chinatown dinner prices. I would maybe come back for the soup dumplings/give their Midtown location a try, but there are other restaurants in the area with tastier dishes.

Joe's Shanghai is really good. For most of my friends this is their first experience with soup dumplings-which are the must order items on the menu. Also, its important to note, unless you have a shellfish allergy, order the soup dumplings with crab in them. They are 1000x better than the pork ones. Joe's Shanghai is always a fun option because it is always busy and the food is always good. I think you can find better food in NY but for the cost and the experience, it is a must visit.

I've heard good things about this place but was a little underwhelmed. The soup dumplings were not my favorite-- they were really big but the soup was too fatty. I prefer a cleaner broth, and the skin was too thick for my liking.

cash only. no credit cards. be prepared to wait and share table with other. the dumplings are amazing. we can finish 2 orders of crab meat dumplings easily. that will set you back $25 bucks... or so.
Recommended if you are in nyc

Ok so many emotions about this place. If you go make sure you go early the lines get long very fast. Oh and don't forget cash, they only accept cash but do offer a ATM at a fee. 
 First the food was awesome we had the dim sum , fried crispy noodles, general tso chicken and lo mein. All was absolutely delicious. How I went this long without ever having pork and crab dumplings is beyond me.... 

 Service isn't very friendly, you get rushed around and once you place your order you never see your sever again. Until it's time to hunt him down for your bill. Also keep in
Overhyped! Horrible service, very dirty place, food wasn't even that good to be honest... Overall bad experience . Once again, horrible service

We were strolling by Chinatown this weekend so decided to check this place out as it came out right on top on Yelp.
We ordered the usual suspects - going by all the rave reviews here; soup dumplings, scallion pancakes and pan fried noodles.

Soup dumplings were delicious and worth all the hype, the scallion pancakes were even better taste wise, however, a tad oily. Same with the noodles too, tasted well except the oil again. Going only by the food, I would've given them 4 stars.
But - the service! How can I forget that - all the reviews below are quite accurate in describing the horrendous service. The waiter glares at you scornfully as if daring you to ask for anything  except the specific order. When I asked for a fork he mumbled something in Chinese which I couldn't understand.
Again, when we asked for the check and presented a card he shouted "NO CARD, ONLY CASH" as if we had committed a grave error. And while returning the change he conveniently retained the bill (perhaps to hide the auto deducted 15% service charge hoping we wouldn't see it and tip him again), and when we asked to be provided with the bill he AGAIN mumbled something in Chinese pretty scornfully and grudgingly got us our bill.

Phew, not sure I would want to return for this kind of service again!
Maybe get something to go if you really have to.
Mediocre at best. It's not good soup dumplings. Pinch's is better.

Supposed to be the mecca of shanghai dumplings in NY.  I just thought they were okay.  The service wasn't anything special.  Most dumplings broke when removing them from the steamer.  Had to share a table with another set of people, it wasn't a big issue, just something to note.

The food came out fast, I just wasn't wowed.  Apparently everyone else loves this place, so give it a try for yourself.

Too much hype! I was really excited to try their famous xiao long bao, but I will have to agree with a bunch of other Yelpers that this place is overrated. Maybe it is just because I found the dumplings to be too flavorful and fatty.  I must admit the dumplings had the most soup that I have ever seen inside a xiao long bao, but the soup got sickening.  After a few I would bite the skin, and pour the soup out into a bowl. Eventuall I started only eating the skin and tossing the meat as well.  The scallion pancake was good, but a little too doughy than what I am use to.  Joe's Shanghai was a cheap meal compared to other eats in NYC, but I still wouldn't choose to revisit this establishment. Oh and being Chinese, of course, they seated us at a table with three other pairs of people.  I like to be able to eat my food in the company of the people I came with, not strangers!
Not the best dumplings or noodles, but passable. Also had the green beans. Think that that was our favorite dish.

When I read about the long waits and the raves about the dumplings, I expected to be wowed.  That is the danger of high expectations.  This is no Din Tai Fung, my friends.  I thought the soup dumplings were too sour, and a couple fell apart in getting transferred to the spoon.  The crispy beef was pretty good, and the scallion pancakes were tasty, but nothing to write home about.

Food was all around very good, especially the pork soup dumplings.  The pork fried rice was great and a big portion, too.  Some of the dishes were a bit on the salty side but could be just me, since others in my group didn't seem to mind.

The service was good, if a bit rushed, but prompt and response for the most part.  

The decor is... nothing to write home about.  Your typical (?) Chinese restaurant that's been in business for years and years and have not renovated in years and years.  But all in all, clean "enough".

Only true negative is that 15% service charge is automatically added on the bill, so when you are paying, be sure to check and not double-tip.  And they only take cash.
I found a fly cooked on top of my dumpling. still got charged for meal. Disgusting!! Do not recommend

Came here with my gf for dinner around 8pm on a thursday. It's about 1/2 hour wait they said but I'm sure we waited for at least 45 mins. It is super packed and crowded.  We had to share a table with a party of four that was finishing their meal. Ordered the scallion pancake, shanghai flat noodle, pork soup dumplings and crab soup dumplings. The food was ok but the soup dumplings were warm at best when it came out. I kept on getting hit by the waiters when they walk by because I sat on the edge and it was so packed. When the party of 4 left, the waiters were cleaning/wiping down the table shaking the whole table while we were eating. I thought that was pretty inconsiderate. Then they seated 2 more parties of 2. Yes, that's 3 different parties of 2 in one table. Awkward. In conclusion, nothing spectacular and there are other shanghai places in CT that ain't as crowded.
So overrated!!! Absolutely not worth the wait. The soup dumplings were good but their Beef & Broccoli was so tasteless.  We will never go back

Had been this place 5 yrs ago, and really liked it. So I choose here to be my first stop this time. But the soup dumpling doesn't taste as good as before. Cash only but still charged tax. Really disappointed.
Came here with three other people and had an obscene number of xiao long bao. They were pretty juicy, but not as delicate as I'd like them to be.

So overrated, so full of tourists, so cramped. Asked for a table for 2. Saw 2 seats clearly available near the front and asked if those two pointing to the seats were ready. The hostess said we have to see... But then was told to go to the back. Ended up sharing a huge round table with 2 other families. Awkward and cramped. The soup dumplings were fine nothing special. The meat sauce noodles were fine but the noodles were too mushy. As we left I saw that the table that was available ended up being given to two white tourists. Interesting seeing as they don't take reservations those seats could not be reserved. I also asked for ice water 3 times because it was boiling hot in there but didnt get it until the end of our meal. Will not be returning to this restaurant.

The soup dumplings are very disappointing - skin is too thick, size is too big, and presentation is just awful (maybe I'm asking for too much for a 8.75 soup dumplings).

And the service was very bad - below average Chinatown level - so why includes the tip amount in the final bill?
This place is for tourists that don't know good Chinese food. Greasy, not friendly. I have no idea how they even got a rating. The place is filthy.

Stopped by here with the BFs parents and sister visiting from Japan; I knew this place was known for soup dumplings (even showed up in the Japanese New York guide..) so three stars doesn't really reflect the quality of their soup dumplings (I'm a vegetarian).

The rest of the guests seemed to really like it.  But as for the rest of the regular Chinese restaurant offerings, the food was pretty standard.  I had some clams with black bean sauce which were clearly pre-frozen clams.  Again, standard.  

Wait was about 45 minutes even around 2PM, and service was spotty as Chinese-restaurant usual.

Took my mom here when she was in town visiting.  She's a picky eater and doesn't usually eat a lot of different cuisines besides Chinese and Japanese.  We went here for dim sum and we both thought the food was mediocre.  My mom kept saying how she could get better dim sum in New Orleans.

the soup dumplings are certainly tasty, but their wrapper is a little too thick for my liking and the top is always a little tough. i wish din tai fung opened in nyc already.

we also had the hot and sour soup and that was below average. it tasted like third-rate takeout hot and sour, not what i expect from a place like joe's shanghai. 

service is attentive and fast. 

i would go back for the dumplings and nothing else. my experience at their midtown location was average as well.

First off, if you're looking for Joe's Shanghai, don't be confused by the nearby "Joe's Ginger" which is also nearby. I was walking here using Google Maps and it said "I had arrived" but all I saw was Joe's Ginger.
