Luckily, I kept walking just to be sure and found Joe's Shanghai, which I was expecting to be more of a stand-out place.

It was something like 8:30pm when I arrived and the place was still packed and there was a line outside. I stepped inside to put my name on the list. I told a woman I was there by myself and she directed me to follow the group ahead of me to be seated. I was concerned about the line of people waiting outside and wanted to clarify whether she really meant to seat me. She snapped at me and told me in a very rude tone to "go ahead" as if I was some idiot.

I was seated at a large round table with seating for 10, along with two other parties. It was weird as we didn't introduce ourselves. We ordered separately and were billed separately. 

Having heard so much about Joe's Shanghai, I assumed this place accepted credit cards. But it's cash only. So I walked in there with just $30 in my pocket and was scrambling to have an adequate meal for under $30. I knew I wanted the soup dumplings (xiao long bao) but I did not think that alone would fill me up, so I also ordered the Shanghai noodles. 

Together, the dishes did fill me up. I was disappointed in the dumplings. Not impressive at all, at least after having them from Din Tai Fung. I ate at Din Tai Fung in the LA area a few months ago and was so blown away that I've been on a soup dumpling kick ever since. People kept telling me to try Joe's Shanghai and so I made my way out to NYC for them. (Of course, I had other business here).

Compared to Din Tai Fung, the dumplings here are not even comparable. In fact, no better than some random Chinese food places I've tried in the interim. Objectively, without comparing them to Din Tai Fung, I would not be impressed with soup dumplings here, and if I tried them for the first time here, I would not even say I like soup dumplings in general. They were fine, but nothing to rave about. 

The Shanghai noodles were thicker than I thought they'd be, and really greasy. But they were tasty in the moment.

The service at Joe's Shanghai is non-existent. People come to pick up plates once you've cleared them, but you have to flag them down for more water or if you want anything else. 

There are pictures along the wall of celebrities who have eaten here, and that makes you feel like you're eating in a really happening spot. But the fame is self-perpetuating and the novelty of it all is really the only reason to seek this place out. The food here is okay, but it's not some sort of wonderful experience that you need to go out of your way for. 

Overall, I'm glad I got to try this place out because I would always wonder if I didn't. But I paid for eating here the next day, when I kept having to run out of meetings to go to the bathroom multiple times throughout the day. That has only ever happened to me when I'm overseas, typically in Asia. 

Be warned that the food here may mess up your digestive system for a day or two. Though on second thought, if you want a dining experience that approximates what eating in China would be like, then maybe Joe's Shanghai is worth a try after all.

I hate Joe's Shanghai. What Chinese person in their right mind likes to frequent this place? (I'll tell you. Mostly 2nd or 3rd gens bringing their mostly white or non-Chinese friends. Is this some sort of initiation?) I don't know a single Shanghai-nese person that would ever recommend this place to anyone. The soup dumplings are good, but the rest of their food is disgusting. You're already in Chinatown. go to a good Chinese restaurant! If you want a better Shanghainese restaurant, please continue walking down the street! 

Here is my one disclaimer though, both the Elmhurst (which is no longer) and Flushing restaurants have better food. And no tourists or poseur Chinese. If you feel you really have to go, please go to the one in Queens instead. Otherwise, why bother?

This is my usual dinner destination when ever i have friends visiting from out of town.  Come in groups of 4 and more for your own table otherwise, you are seated at a communal table with other diners.  I personally prefer having my own table to enjoy my meal.  The SOUP DUMPLINGS and SCALLION PANCAKES are my favorite.  Every time I'm in the neighborhood, there's always a line waiting to be seated.  Normally i bail out once the waiting period exceeds 30 minutes, but my craving of the soup dumplings just makes the wait worth-it.  They  have other dishes that are very good as well,  but i feel i can get those at  nearby restaurants with no lines.  Just a warning though, please check your bill before paying, seems like there's a hidden 15% gratuity already added to your bill written in Mandarin.

Don't expect service when you come here, do expect to sit at a large communal table, do expect to be ignored, do expect greasy delicious food. I felt horrible after leaving here. Had the crab and pork soup dumplings which I would have loved in another life but I felt like I was sucking down on lard this time- couldn't handle more than one. Had the corn and chicken soup which turned into gelatinous slop once it cooled, had the beef Lo mein- thick delicious noodles but coated in a layer of fat and grease. Have had much tastier food in other local spots with less guilt attached..Tasty Hand Pulled Noodles puts this place to shame.

I was visiting from LA and was passing by and decided to stop in and get one tray of soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. I wasn't that impressed. My NY friends to me this place was better than Din Tai Fung, but I didn't love it. The soup felt greasy. The pancakes were too "bready". We wished it were crispier. Overall service was good and there was no wait, always a good thing.

Probably one of my least favorite Chinese restaurant, came here for the hype of the soup dumpling. Which was okay in my opinion, it's to be expected to have a wait to be seated or be seated with another group at a table. Service was delayed but food was delivered. Not sure if I will go back, maybe in a few more months id think about giving it another try.

Losing stars because of the long wait and lack of communication as to how long.  The seaters can even be rude.  BUT... Once inside the food is like no other Chinese food.  Its soooo good!! And the soup dumplings are a must try and enjoy.  I dont think I would return to THIS location.  The other I hear is easier to get into.

Considering there's not a lot of good chinese restaurants in all of New York, this might very well be the best New York has to offer. Even so, I find it to be very pedestrian. Perhaps I've been spoiled by the generous restaurant selections available in Los Angeles or maybe I'm just a picky eater. Whatever the case may be, I found that the XLB (Xiao Long Bao) had no distinction. The dumplings were mostly filled with broth. There was very little meat inside. The wrappers were very thick and sticky, making it unpleasant to chew.

One thing that stood out at this restaurant is that you can expect to find yourselves sharing a large circular table with one or two other parties due to the small space and limited seating. This might be a fairly common practice in New York restaurants, but I have never encountered this before and it was something I took notice of.

The line was extremely long which made my anticipation grow! I had high expectations with all the reviews. I was looking forward to a nice Chinese dinner. The dumplings were definitely the highlight of my meal. The beef udon was okay. The eggplant was too sweet and the spicy Szechuan beef was not good. I wouldn't order those again nor recommend it. If your in the area and there isn't a wait get dumplings but I wouldn't go out of my way for it. It is not comparable to Din Tai Fung if your from the west coast.

OK Shanghainese food. Got better quality in Shanghai Cafe on Mott St. instead. This place has gotten too touristy. Most people that come here are not Chinese. We had to share a table, got so-so Shanghainese food, & got slapped with an automatic (not optional) 15% gratuity fee on the bill. There was only 3 of us!!! Like I said tourist rip-off!

It has moved to a new location. 46 Browerlu is the current address. I called the restaurant twice to ask for the direction, and the person who answered the phone just told me to keep walking. I had mentioned the old address, but she had never informed me the new address.

TERRIBLE VISIT! 
The servers are very disrespectful.. And the quality of the food is just not even presentable anymore. The noodles are burnt, and the soup dumplings are barely hot. The price that you pay for the amount of food is not even worth it. Let's come to conclusion, JOES SHANGHAI is one of the worst, and most over rated soup dumpling place. Everyone needs to realize that the amount you pay here isn't worth it anymore!

A M B I A N C E

Very busy. They rushed us in and rushed us out. 

C L E A N L I N E S S

Too busy to be clean. 

O V E R A L L   Q U A L I T Y

For a dumpling specialist they do not have many dumping choices at all. Maybe 3 options. The soup inside the dumpling was very tasty. The dumplings were too big and wide in my opinion. They didn't fit on the spoon and would explode before my mouth. Not the best dumplings at all. 

C O S T

$$ 20$ per person. Not worth it in my opinion. 

W A I T   T I M E S

We were 4 people, seated right away. 

P A R K I N G

It's New York, no parking. 

L O C A T I O N

In China Town.

Although previous visits of Joe's Shanghai have been ok and regardless of the fact that I think their dumplings (xiao long bao) are over-hyped*, I was unprepared for the disappointment their take-out dishes will bring. 

The shrimp fried rice had no shrimp.  I tell you, the corner Chinese restaurant where we live had better fried rice.  The Shanghai beef noodles was terribly bland and had about two tiny pieces of beef. It was very thoughtful of the husband to go out of his way to buy their food thinking it will make me happy and save me from making dinner, so I did not grumble about the food as we ate. 

Joe's Shanghai, I think I just love the memory of you.  It's time to move on.

*The dough is too thick and the size unwieldy unlike that of CB.

I was looking forward to some great Chinese food in NYC.  This was so disappointing.  The atmosphere is like an mcl cafeteria.  The waiter boys are lazy and not particularly friendly. My husbands dish came out a good 15 minutes before mine.  The sesame chicken was over cooked and dry.  They only take cash but there is an atm inside the front door.  They automatically put a surcharge on your tab which explained why the waiters had an attitude.

We went to this Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown based on high rating hype. The restaurant's on a side street was not exacting easy to find using the online navigation provided. It was busy around late lunch time but there was no wait. We could tell all customers were out of town tourists. Belatedly we found out they do not accept credit card so our menu selections were limited. We chose Xiao Long Bao soup dumplings, aka Pork Steamed Buns (the main motivation of our visit) and String Bean, a typical Szechuan style vegetable dish.  We found the steamed dumplings larger in size than the usual, dainty ones we had tasted elsewhere. After eating 2 orders of these, we concluded that they were excessively soupy (watch out for plenty hot liquid squirting out at first bite) and doughy. The string beans were average. Watch out: we noted they automatically added a 15% service charge on the bill (for a party of 2) which seemed unusual to us.

It's just OK. 

I used to hate XLB so much because my bad experience in the past. I remembered the thick flour and fatty ground pork that I used to eat. When I used to live in Shanghai, I tried to stay away from them.

Since I moved to NY, my friend convinced me to go to Nan Xiang in Flushing and that was the first time after 10 years that I stopped eating them. It's not like what I had in the past. I start liking it ......so much now... 

So last night I had a craving for it, then I picked this famous place in the city. I went with high expectation that it's gonna be just so good like the one in Flushing. We ordered 2 kinds of XLB and all I can say that I only like the soup. After I drank the soup in each one I almost wanted to leave the meat and the flour. We also ordered Shanghai fried noodles and strangely I like it better than the famous XLB. Fried Man Tou is good to order as dessert since it came with condensed milk.

Can't go wrong with the price. It's cheap and worth trying their XLB so that you know there're better places out there.
Not really sure how to say not the taste that I like the dumpling top little bit tough the price are ok

Usual NY crowd on a Friday night. We lucked out to get a big table since it was close to 10pm. Had the soup dumplings, green beans, scallops, beef, shrimp and tons of beer. 
Loud, inspires you to eat a lot, sweat a lot. 
I like it.

Don't come here if you like friendly service, the staff is extremely rude. Also don't come here if you would like to eat anything else than pork. You can only pay cash, but they tell you AFTER you ask for the check. You can use their ATM, but they charge you $3,50 for that on top of the gratuity. Seriously don't understand why this place gets 5 star reviews. Will never ever come back to this dirty place.

I looked up "Best soup dumplings in NYC" on google and this restaurant came up in a blog for top 10. 

Just to warn you, the shanghai dumplings here are NOT good. The meat is questionable. Pretty bummed! We left without finishing them. I do not believe this was an anomaly, I'm questioning whether any people with positive reviews of the dumplings on here know the difference between good and bad Chinese food.

If you're ever in SF, I recommend Mama Jis for dim sum and szechuan food, and Shanghai Dumpling King for dumplings.

Their crab soup dumplings are a solid 4 stars. The rest of their food? eh.

I had their pork dumplings, crab dumplings, scallion pancake, and their shredded turnip cake. The shredded turnip cake had a short black hair inside of it.... The waiter cut open the cake for me and right when I put my chopstick inside of it, the top of the flaky pastry turned over to reveal the nasty hair. If it weren't for this, I would have given the place 3 stars. I showed the waiter and he didn't seem to care or offer to even replace my turnip cake. Maybe there was a language barrier? I don't know but it was disgusting to see the hair on the dough since it had to have been pretty visible when the cake was being made. Its not as if it was mixed in the filling or anything. Just literally right on the inside surface of the pastry.

That really put a damper in the rest of the meal. Anyways, the scallion pancake was alright but nothing amazing as other people claimed it to be. The turnip cake (I still ate the other half. Was that gross of me? haha) was alright as well.

Since Joe's is famous for their soup dumplings, I ordered both types. The pork was a bit too salty for me but the crab was very delicious. If you're going, I would avoid the pork since they weren't really worth it. 

**TIP** Eat the soup dumplings RIGHT when you get them. Don't wait to finish your appetizers or anything because once they cool, the soup starts to separate and the flavors aren't blended anymore. Not only that, they start to leak from the top if you wait too long. 

I question their sanitary habits but the crab dumplings would make me come back!

Cheap Shanghai Dumplings that aren't that great...

I came here since people rave about their Shanghai Dumplings, but I thought it was a little too salty and I did not like the skin of the dumplings. It was too big and that it droops over. Texture was not great. 

I'm sure there's better else where.
Great food, but it went right through me (within 3 hours). Do not recommend if you're trying to get lucky.

Really wanted to be wowed by this place but alas my expectations were too high. 

They add an automatic 18% gratuity so there is less incentive for good service to be provided. Our waiter was so brusque and rude when taking our order.  We felt pressured and rushed.  He didn't understand English so I could not engage him at all. 

The food is brought out in fast assembly like dumping slaw in a trough to hurry you out and make room for the next group of pigs. 

The beef and broccoli was ok except the meat tasted a tad gamey. I did not finish it. 

The pork fried rice was ok but lacked the traditional bean sprouts and i had to spit out a nervy piece of pork.

The soup dumplings didn't WOW me, I've definitely had far better.  Service was also not very good, it took about 40 minutes to get our dumplings... meanwhile, several tables around us had gotten theirs' even though they showed up after us.  We had the standard pork, my friend says the crab & pork are simply not worth the extra expense.  Overall, it was a solid and cheap meal.  Would I go back?  Probably, but I'd like to try some other soup dumpling places in the area first ;)

I have been living in NYC for five years and this is the first time that I have tried this place.  
My first thought, is that its WAY overhyped.  I came here today not even really at a real meal time and it was still packed mid afternoon. I ordered the pork soup dumplings and even at first glance, they are smaller than others in the area, not as fluffy, and honestly kinda sad looking .  Upon trying them they were ok, a tiny portion of meat in each bun with hot soup around it.  
I ordered two portions of the soup dumplings, 16 in total and shared them.  I also ordered a scallion pancake which was pretty good.  

All in al, ive been to better places that have soup dumplings, this place has the fame in the name so I guess thats why it continues to be popular. Ill give it three stars because the prices were pretty decent and they waiters are english speaking and speed effecient.

Not the greatest, not the worst.  If you are with a large group it will take a while to get in.  If you're by yourself or someone else, it won't be a problem to get in.  

The food is your standard American Chinese variety.  Nothing special.  The dumplings are good though.  

Service is hectic and they try to bring people in and out ASAP, which makes the atmosphere a bit chaotic.  

Cash only and tip is included.  I suppose they kept getting stiffed by tourists, so can't blame them there.

I have to say I am very dissapointed in this restaurant, it opened not too long ago at the new location on Bowery and the wait was usually 40 minutes(tourist trap) today we walked by and it was no wait so we decided to give it a shot I been to the old joes over five years ago and was not a fan, gave it a second chance.. the appetizer arrived first and we were all excited and starving their soup dumplings is plump that's where they get one star.. that is one of the better soup dumplings in Chinatown it's comparable to shanghai cafe and 21 shanghai, shanghai cafe is better IMO. Their kao fu, sweet tofu with mushroom was also a hit... it's a cold appetizer dish. Everything else that came after was lacking in everything it was either way too sour for the sweet and sour fish, too salty and bland for the chicken, too breaded and salty for the pork chops and the pig feet even though drenched in sauce managed to be dry and salty and the only thing my coworkers thought was decent was the string beans cause it wasn't terrible(it was just bland).. if you do come I recommend sticking with the appetizers and their soup dumplings.

Was greeted in the beginning by a nice young lady. As soon as we hit the table the service was bad, poor customer service and the food was mediocre. For having so many celebrities here I was surprised.

So I've heard a lot of hype about this restaurant, but it was a pretty unimpressive experience for me. The soup dumplings were great, but the two other dishes my friend and I ordered were nothing special at all. One of the dishes we ended up barely touching, and neither of us were interested in bringing it home and eating later. I've had better Chinese food in plenty of other places. Also, the service was really mediocre. I never got the glass of water I asked for at the beginning, and I felt like the waiters were giving us attitude. I would give one star, but the soup dumplings were good, so two-stars.

Poor service. Rude workers. Went with my family. They gave a 4 seated table. We needed 2 more and they were refusing to accommodate. They left us standing in the middle of the restaurant until we decided to leave because it was awkward and unfair. Nasty people
The dumplings weren't bad, although the service was not great. We felt rushed to finish and leave. Bathroom was clean.

It's really not delicious, me and my friend are very disappointed. The wine chicken and the crab meat dumplings no any flavor, this is my first time to leave bad review on public. No good service you have to pick up the food and bring it to your table. Even during the Covid-19, other restaurants offer patio dining service but this one they want you to bring it food.

Ordered take out so avoided the wait

Had to try the legendary soup dumplings which were okay.

Server also suggested we try their Turnip Dumplings which she was a best seller. Husband tried it first and with a straight face warned me that it was the most disgusting thing he'd ever tasted.

I thought he was being dramatic so I tried it. I couldn't swallow (and I always swallow! ba da bing!!). It tasted like runners feet.
Tourist trap! Don't go, especially if you are vegetarian. They pre-added a service charge on our bill, even with 2 people. Food was mediocre at best.

My husband and I went here thinking third times a charm for Yelp restaurant recommendations in NYC. At least that's what I was expecting with Joe's, but we only had a good experience rather than amazing.

We took the subway in and knew we'd found the right place when we turned the corner on Pell Street and saw about twenty tourists standing outside. 

Things to remember:
1. Bring cash, but if you forget, there's a Bank of America around the corner. 

2. If you have a party of two or one, you'll be seated fifteen minutes faster than the crowds waiting outside, which was a pleasant surprise for us. 

3. Once inside, expect to share a table with total strangers and hold conversations with them.

4. Stick to the rolls. Everyone else has said it, but the reason to go here is for those perfect little inverted balls of soup. I didn't know what to expect, so when the server mumbled something to us I remembered a previous recommendation and said, "Yes, pork." In minutes we had two beers and a steaming pile of beautiful dumplings. Once I bit into them I realized why they're SOUP dumplings -- they seal the soup liquid inside of a little dumpling sack with the pork. This would typically be a fun treat, but my first unexpected bite resulted in a burnt tongue from hot soup and a mess all over my plate! After my third dumpling I'd mastered the art of drinking the soup and then eating the dumpling, but it's hysterical to watch the entire restaurant as they attempt to tackle such a delicious and silly food.

5. The rest of the food is hearty, but nothing out of the ordinary for a Chinese restaurant. I wish we'd stuck to the dumplings and tried the crab ones. One serving of eight dumplings per person and you don't need a mediocre entree.

6. Gratuity is included. There are signs on the wall to remind you that gratuity is included and the check comes out quickly once you're done along with a little plate of orange slices.

We had a fun experience and got to know the other people seated our table. I think families, friends, small groups and couples will get a kick out of the experience, too. Just keep in mind, the dumplings are great, but the rest of the food isn't four star quality. I wish they'd open a stand outside of the restaurant where you can order a big sack of dumplings to go!

Came here with a group and waited for well over an hour to be seated.  When we finally arrived at our table, we hadn't even taken off our coats before the waiter appeared and asked "How many dumplings do you want?".  We told him we hadn't even sat down yet and needed a minute.  30 seconds later he re-appears and asks the same question.  Again, we told him we needed a minute.  This time he gave us a full 3 minutes to decide what we wanted.  We ordered and the food arrived extremely quickly, which was great, but it took 5 tries and talking to 3 different waiters to get a glass of water.

As others have mentioned, the soup dumplings are awesome.  So are the scallion pancakes, soups and lo mein.  However, the employees are only focused on turning over tables and not customer service.  Amazingly delicious Chinese food, but don't expect a particularly pleasant dining experience.

This place is so much over rated. Food quality is just okay, even for the soup dumplings where they are famous for. There are better quality else where. They also added 18% tips to the bill automatically for a party of 4.

Everyone loves Joe's little soup dumplings.

But everytime I went there, I couldn't stop myself from geting so full loaded with dumplings that I sweared to myself I won't come back again until next  year... ^_^... 

Recommendation:
Crab Meat with Pork Meat Steamed Bun (8)  $6.65
Pork Steamed Buns (8)  $4.65
Eggplant with Garlic Sauce (with Pork)  $8.35 

To try:
Stewed Bean Curd with Crab Meat 12.95 
Chunks of Chicken in Hoisen Sauce (with Bone) 11.95 

Didn't like...
I really didn't feel comfortable to share tables with other guests...

I had an incredibly disappointing experience at Shanghai Joe. The service was absolutely horrible. The food was pretty good but not enough to make up for the poor service as the waiter was also extremely rude and unprofessional. He was dismissive and acted like our presence was an inconvenience to him. Save yourself the trouble and find somewhere else to eat as there are places like Chow House which have better food.

The servers are rude, mandatory 15% service charge is added, and the worst part was that the soup dumplings had no soup inside them. They were over cooked.. I saw another tray go to a different table and theirs looked fine. It would have been better if they apologized and cooked us a new batch.. But that didn't happen. Very disappointed!

Cheap, filling, greasy, tasty.   Was playing tour guide to some friends from out of town (Houston, Palm Springs and San Diego) and we needed a nosh after going on a wild goose chase to buy bootleg purses*.  

Anyway, we walked by and there wasn't a wait so we dashed in to grab some salty nourishment. I say this because everything here seems kind of salty.  We had the soup dumplings, scallion pancakes and fried dumplings.  The fried dumplings were nothing special.  Very generic and I wish we hadn't ordered them.

The scallion pancakes were great, however.  I liked getting the pieces that were a little well done.  Soup dumplings (or pork buns, whatever you want to call them) were great.  I really like them.

Service is bruque but efficient.  They really get people in and out and fit in as many people as possible, so make friends with the other people sitting at your table.

For my out of town friends, they thought it was cool.  I'd go back, but I'd never wait more than five minutes for a table.  We all left stuffed to the gills and it set us back $7 each.

_______________________________________
*Side note: I don't approve of that, but the girls didn't want to hear any of my objections, they just wanted the faux Tory Burch bags-

Vegetable dumplings were delicious as well as the noodles and that's about it.  

Orange beef was tough as nails and overall food is way overpriced for what you get.  $20 plus dollars for Kung Pow Chicken and even more for the Orange Beef.  Get very little and the side of rice was nearly non existent. 

Look for a hole in the the wall with lower prices.  This place is not worth it.

This is the standard of soup dumplings.  This is not necessarily a quick place.  You sit at tables with other strangers and order your food because it is cramped. *Cash only.

I don't ever look at the menu.  I just get the soup dumplings - some pork, some crab.  I think it was like 4.45/6.45 per batch.My brother and I each ate 2 containers (8 in each container) to start our day of New York eating.  

I wish there was a return policy on broken skin - where the soup has already come out.  Although there were only 3 broken ones, it's all about the juicy soup that your slurp up.

People talk about this place or other places being better/worse every now and then.  I have had better or worse, but this is the place that started it all.

Yes, this is the restaurant with the best soup dumplings. But if you want vegetarian fare, this probably isn't the best Chinatown has to offer.  Do not be fooled by the name Crab dumplings: that's a pork dumpling with crab included.

From what I can tell the few times I've been here, the Dim Sum makes Joe's a staple in Chinatown.  However, even meat eaters don't seem to get as much outside of the dumplings.  Unless you're looking for something in particular, I'd score your sesame chicken somewhere else and save the money.

I must admit this place is great for groups, espcially our families visiting from out of town.  Otherwise you have plenty of other places to choose in Chinatown.

The good: Went around 3pm on a Thursday, and there was no wait.  The filling was tasty and the soup inside was plentiful.  Service was fast and very efficient. 

The bad: The skin was WAY too thick and chewy, and the xiao long bao were too big to eat conveniently in a single bite.  They are easily 50% bigger than Din Tai Fung's, which are the perfect size.  The hot and sour soup was completely flavorless and tasted Americanized (just straight up sour).

Overall: It's worth a visit and will hit your soup dumpling craving.  In fact, if I had never had DTF before, I'd probably think these are great.  However, if you have been spoiled by better, than make sure you lower your expectations when you walk into JS.

We went because of the high number of reviews but failed to see whats so great about it. They will make you share the table with a random party to fit in more customers. Food was strictly ok. We had ordered crab dumplings and kung pao chicken. There are definitely better chinese food places out there.

If you ever find yourself at Joe's Shanghai, you MUST try the soup dumplings.  It's what they're known for, and by far, the best item on their menu.  Be careful when eating though, as the soup is hot and the dumplings puncture easily, which can spill soup everywhere if you're not careful.

That being said, the rest of their food is mediocre, like any average Chinese restaurant, which is the main reason why this review only got 3-stars.  

We sampled an array of other items on their menu, from pea shoots to noodle dishes, but its clear that we would only be coming back for the soup dumplings.

 Tips:  Don't leave tip - there's already 15% added to your bill, a little high for mediocre service.  Also, if its dinnertime, you should be prepared to wait half-an-hour or so.

Probably the worst Shanghainese food I've ever had.  I was never impressed back in its original location but I don't remember it ever tasting this bad. 

Oily, bland and tasteless. No name dumps without the recognition JS has tastes better.
Don't get the hype.  Neither I, nor my Chinese friend, enjoyed our meal.  Just OK food in a loud, busy place.

Scary - I ordered from here for lunch today. There was a sharp piece of metal coming out of a piece of general tso's chicken. Totally shocking and unbelievably unsafe.

I was enjoying the dumplings before finding the metal in my food, but as you'd imagine I threw the rest of the food out. Would never visit or order from here again.

I don't understand why there are so many raving reviews when you could get similar soup dumplings elsewhere or even at their own chain restaurants on 56th street or 37th avenue where there is probably better service. In all honesty, I come solely for their soup dumplings but, it can get boring. Unfortunately, whenever I decide to venture off into other foods on their menu, I am disappointed. 

If you want to try their soup dumplings, then come here. They offer either crab pork or pork dumplings in a stacked bamboo container straight from the stove. Always piping fresh. It is best eaten with some soy sauce, vinegar, and ginger. It gives the pork a fresher stronger flavor. Make sure to use your spoon to catch the soup when picking up the dumplings! 

Now if you want to try other foods, I recommend other restaurants. Their portions are small for the amount they charge and their service is atrocious. To be tightly seated with other strangers is honestly unappetizing and with all the cash they make under the table while evading taxes, they could use a renovation. At least their bathrooms. Even their waiters could use some etiquette lessons.

I would only come back to entertain friends who insist on trying out this infamous soup dumpling restaurant.

Finally departed their old world location on Pell but surviving on their reputation from 30 yrs ago.  Shanghai Deluxe & Green Bo offer more authentic Shanghai cuisine. Tops Nan Xiang in Flushing offers casual cuisine as up-to-date as in SHA & HK. 

Nan Xiang is expanding beyond Flushing.  There is now a location on 33rd St between K'town & Empire State Bldg - nice modern operation, serving many Shanghai casual cuisine items. 
Pinch in Soho, offers quality Shanghai menu at a higher price point.  
Din Tai Fung to open in Midtown.

They moved the original Joe's Shanghai to a new location so I wanted to give it a try. During dinner time, the wait was long so I decided to order take out. (wait is like 1.5 to 2 hours, I don't recommend the wait unless hour are a tourist.) I called the restaurant and it took them 40 minutes to prepare my food for takeout.

I order the the pork and crab soup dumplings. I do not recommend ordering those for takeout bechasw they stuff them in a takeout box, the dumplings get stuff together and when you go to eat it, the soup falls out. It ruins the soup dumplings. 

I also ordered the fried rice, beef rice cake and beef soup noodles. They were pretty good for takeout.

Overall, a good soup dumpling spot but not worth the wait because there are other soup dumping just as good around the corner. They need to have better soup dumpling takeout box to not ruin the soup dumplings takeout experience. Please also bring cash, the still do not accept cash.

I came to Joe's Shanghai when I was in New York on vacation, and one of my friends insisted we go here for the best soup dumplings ever.  Maybe I shouldn't have gotten my expectations up, but I did, and when I bit into it I was pretty disappointed.  I never thought the soup dumplings at Din Tai Fung were anything that special until I ate this one.  It didn't taste bad, but it didn't make me want to eat more of them.  The meat chunk inside was a bit too large, and the soup was a bit oily.  The flavor was a bit too pungent and pretty heavy.  Also our other dishes weren't that great.  We had the eggplant which was good, but I don't like when eggplant gets so soft it's unrecognizable as eggplant, and our pork/beef dishes (I don't even remember which one they were that unmemorable) were just so-so.  Overall I was pretty disappointed.  However, it was very cheap so that is a plus.

Joe Shanghai's used to be the reigning king of soup dumplings,  but not anymore.  This week I've tried two different soup dumplings from this restaurant and Nan Shian (Flushing).   I have to admit the soup dumpling was so much more superior at Nan Shian.  

I also tried their Shanghai noodles, good, but quite greasy.   Good stuff, but it's just A-OK.

I went with two friends and waited an hour sat afternoon to get a shared table. We ordered the pork dumplings which were the best dish. Crispy skin duck was not good at all,only tasted the game duck taste and salt. Fried pork chops were very heavy with oil soaked crust. Cold sesame noodles looked good but tasted only of peanut butter.

Is this a hyped restaurant or not? Do not waste your time or money there. Oh,btw most tourist and few Chinese were there, is this a sign or what?

 I am Chinese from San Francisco and have been to NYC many times and have yet to find a decent restaurant that serves good Chinese tasting food.  What is wrong with the Chinese food there? I have had great food all over NYC ,but never good or even passable food in Chinatown. You Chinese chefs and restaurants should be ashamed.  Come to San Francisco and taste what you should be cooking. 

Very disappointed customer

I came here with high hopes! I was slightly disappointed, but it was pretty tasty. Does not compare to Din Tai Fung in Los Angeles or abroad. The soup and pork was good, but I didn't like the texture of the dumpling. Also they are too big! A smaller dumpling that fits nicely in the spoon is much better. I'm glad I tried out this hotspot, but I won't be going back for seconds.

The xiao long bao are good. Not better or worse than Shanghai Cafe on 100 Mott st but twice the price. Portions are very small. Mostly for tourists. Would not come here again given how close Shanghai Cafe is. If I wanted the best soup dumplings in New York I would go to Nan Xiang Dumpling House in Flushing.

Joe's Shanghai used to be great many many years ago. However, the quality of the food just gone down way too much. Even a tourist would questioned and asked me if this is how it always tasted like. All I can say is this is not how it used to be. Don't waste your money next time to come into this tourist traps place! The carpet smell like bathroom in their dinning room. Everything is just old and dirty, the food taste either too salty or flavorless. Their service is horrible! Plus they would automatic added tip on your bill without telling you and ask for leaving tip. So we would leave cash tip on the table and without knowing the tip has already been included in the bill! This is so wrong!
Pretty good but not worth it if it is a long line. We went on a weekday and the wait was about 15mins. Service is mediocre, typical Asian restaurant.

I've been wanting to try this place for years and was able to get dinner with my family when we were all in NYC for the weekend. Even at 10 PM on Saturday night there very packed. We had to wait for a table for 6 of us. They have communal tables mostly so be prepared to sit and eat with strangers if you have a small group. 

Of course our waiter was rude. We were seated at 1015 PM and told us to hurry and order before the kitchen closes. So my family scrambles to order soup dumplings, shrimp fried rice, beef crispy noodles, and crispy duck. Soup dumplings are what they known for and it's good but not that good to put up with bad service. The beef crispy noodles were so salty. The crispy duck and fried rice were good though. It's nice that they give you oranges for dessert at the end. I was not a fan of their pricing either... charging almost $18 for sesame chicken. I'm glad I got to try it but I won't be back. 

Beware... cash only.

My experience here was comical at best. The service was so bad that it was funny haha.  Good thing was that we were seated right away (came at about 4 pm on a weekday), but the server also wanted to take our order right away (can I at least open the menu first?!!?) what had us cracking up was that ... I don't know If it's all menus or just ours .. Was that the most frequently ordered items (ie the soup dumplings) were already circled in the menu! So he kept pointing to those saying.. "Ok 2 order ok?" Haha.. I asked him if we could have a second to look at the menu.. And he basically used a scare tactic on us by telling us that they take 15 mins to make!! Needless to say it worked and we went ahead and ordered the pork soup dumplings (since he was right.. That is exactly what we came for ) Much to our surprise the dumplings came in about 5 minutes! (What happened to the 15 minutes ?!) hehe.  Dumplings were definitely tasty... Good thing we were laughing the whole time since we barely noticed the severs watching over us like Hawks so that they could take our plates as soon as we put our spoons down haha. This time to no ones surprise we got our bill instantaneously.. Ok ok you want us out!! 

Now I know why they already add tip ;) 

To make a long story short: 
Cash only 
Prepare to be rushed 
Gratuity included in the bill 
Come around 4 pm to avoid a wait!

Came here twice with friends for dinner and the food was good but i think it's a bit overrated. got the soup dumplings both times and both times they weren't very juicy, like the soup had dried up already or something. it was rather disappointing seeing as how this is what Joe's Shanghai seems to be known for. 

the atmosphere was boisterous and loud and good for a fun, casual dinner with a friend(s). 

the andwere both pretty good and both my friend and i were both rather pleased at how much meat was in the . 

the waiters here always seems to be too busy and it was hard to flag them down for water or our check even though there were several just standing around towards the end of the night when it wasn't even that busy. 

overall the food is decent but i think it's over-hyped because of how touristy it is. i would come here for the sake of bringing a friend to the famous Joe's Shanghai's, but would probably normally avoid it.

Recommend: AVOID THIS PLACE

MEHhhh...DON'T BELIEVE THE HYPE. I have been coming to joes for the past two years and this last experience is my last and final visit. After venturing NYC Chinatown scene and trying out a number of Chinese restaurants, specifically serving soup dumplings,  joes quality of dumplings are now near the bottom of my list. The pan fried noodles are also not what they used to be. 

The service has always been bad, even at Chinese food restaurant standards. Ok, I get it, you want to be "Authentic" by treating non-Chinese patrons rude. But seriously, this last visit was the worst. After we sat, we were rushed to place an order even though the place was half empty. The food came out and tossed onto the table with no mind to placement. Had to ask several times for utensils and napkins. Water boy came out with fingers "in the glass" as he was trying to hold too many glasses at once...Yuck! We were rushed to pay the bill and as they were closing asked to get up and leave. There were still several other people still eating so with the effin rush? Bye Joe's... your staff is RUDE AF and give Chinese restaurants a bad rap.

Joe's Shanghai is known for their xiaolongbao. That's really the only thing you should get here, the other food leaves something to be desired. Everything else we got seemed a bit too salty for my tastes, especially the string beans - and Chinese style string beans is something I love!

Xiaolongbao are decent but not the best I've had. They're more juicy here than other places so do yourself a favor and put the bao into your spoon before trying to eat it. Otherwise, you'll end up with a hot liquidy mess on the table and maybe on you as well. The crab ones are better than the pork ones.

In true Chinese style, you may have to share a crowded table with other people. That may be weird for some, but lots of places in Chinatown do it, especially really crowded, popular places like Joe's.

After hearing so much about this place, I've decided to give this place a try.

First off this place was PACKED with tourists, making the wait almost an hour just for 2 people. We also had to share a table with another group of 5, who seemed discontent with havinig to share a table with strangers. By the end of our meal it turned out that they were expecting another 2 people to join their party but didn't inform the server beforehand (could've just said so from the start instead of making us feel uncomfortable). This already irritated me and my friend from the start.

Onwards to the food. We ordered the pork soup dumplings cause DUH, that's what you do at Joe's Shanghai, along with some spring rolls, scallion pancakes, and the Singapore Chow Mei Fun. The noodles were awful, and had a weird taste compared to the usual singapore noodles. We barely ate any of it and defiinitely did not want it to go. The scallion pancakes were pretty good and spring rolls were okay. The soup dumplings were "meh." They were decent, super oily and the meat wasn't as good as other soup dumplings that i've had. It definitely did NOT live up to the hype. They were just o-kay. I was very disappointed.

I would say try it once just to go, but for the wait time and the crowdedness, not worth it.

Been wanting to eat here for a long time but everytime we came there was a long wait and so we'd go elsewhere. This time we hung in about 20 minutes. I should mention that we could've sat right away if we were wiling to sit at a round table with a bunch of strangers. But we looked at her like she was crazy and said, 'Absolutely not. We want our own table'. And so, we eventually got one and it was much better than sitting with ppl you don't know. That would've ruined the experience for me. I must say that the hostess had a bit of an attitude when we made it clear we would not be sitting with others. Anyway, on to the food. We ordered the soup dumplings because that's what they're famous for. Ehh. They were ok, nothing out of this world. Personally, I don't get it. We also ordered the Young Chow rice that comes with shrimp and were very disappointed to see the shrimp had not been cleaned. I'm sorry but that's a deal breaker. I don't like seeing that black vein in my shrimp. My friend ordered the melon soup. I thought that was crazy but he said he'd had it before. When it arrived I tasted some and it tasted like dirty sock broth, no lie. I said I told you not to order that. Some ppl never listen. We ordered the Beef with Bean Curd as an entree and it was spicy and good, just not great. It was also a little overpriced for such mediocre food. I would've given them a 3 if not for the lousy service. Our waiter was very condescending. Maybe some ppl get off on being treated like crap but when I'm already being fleeced for overhyped food, I don't appreciate mistreatment on top of it. I wouldn't go back. Once was more than enough. I'm sure Chinatown has much better places to eat.

O-V-E-R-R-A-T-E-D.

This was not a pleasant dining experience.  It wasn't worth the 1.5 hour wait outside, and wasn't worth getting jammed in.  

Nice of the waiter to sit me down, thrust a menu in my face a split second my ass hits the seat and demand to know "how many?"  No, I'm not some uppity foodie who doesn't get it - I happen to be Chinese and fully understand how ghetto Chinese restaurants can get.  

Their soup dumplings were indeed good, but I've had better.  If you're ever in Chicago try the xiao long bao at Moon Palace in Chinatown on Cermak next to the fire station.  Much, much better and none of the hassle.
Food is OK. Service rude and indifferent always. Is it really that hard? There are better choices. No return for me.

We enjoyed the pork dumplings, lo mien, and onion pancake. However, the half-hour wait in the street with the many cigarette smokers, and the cacophony inside at a communal table that was too big to engender conversation, makes this "must experience" into just another Chinese restaurant. Probably would be better during off hours, or after December when they change location.

I came here for dinner on a Saturday night.  Prepare for a long wait since it's super crowded here after work or weekends.  They will give you a number and call it out frequently just to make sure you're still around.  We waited almost 45 minutes for a table.  When you're seated, make sure to order xiaolongbao (soup dumplings) as soon as possible since it does take some time to make.  I do like their crab/pork and pork soup dumplings since they're big, have a lot of meat/soup in each one, and the soup is very tasty.  Everything else is not very memorable - ordered the flounder, braised string beans, pan fried noodles, pork chops, and scallion pancakes.  I feel like I could better Chinese food elsewhere but the soup dumplings are pretty good.  However, I don't know if they're worth the long wait though.

Still good, one year later.  However, I gotta say...after my XLB excursion in Shanghai...I found these to be a little bit too big (what??!) and not as delicate as the XLB I devoured in China.  Also, as much as I love the idea of communal dining...I don't like it forced upon me.   Wow, did that sound snobby... But in reality - the broth is fantastic, but the filing isn't.  We ate at 5pm and thanks goodness - by the time we left, there was a line out the door.

Food was "picked up" and "delivered" within 1 minute. Unless my driver is Nightcrawler from X-men, there's just no way this is possible. Restaurant blamed everything on Doordash and refused to send their own delivery man. What a joke. As long as you still have problematic door dash as one of your delivery options, expect to get horrible reviews.

I had always been told that Joe's Shanghai has the best soup dumplings in New York, so I guess I had pretty high expectations going in. I'm writing a belated review, so maybe this place has improved from the last time I was there, but honestly I was not super impressed. 

I got a portion of the pork soup dumplings, which were good, and the prices are fair, but the service was just so so. I felt like the server was in a hurry, and the place wasn't packed. Maybe it's just the way they are conditioned because it's generally crowded, but quite unnecessary.

I'd recommend you go so you can taste and see for yourself, but there are other places where you can have soup dumplings that are just as good as or better than they were here.

Do not come here if you want XLB 
Or if you already had XLB before & looking for a fix 

It's completely white washed with tourist 

They alter it to meet the westernized taste and texture 

I dont know how they got an award lol
Great food, but it's a really unpleasant experience... Way too many people, way too much noise.

We ordered a bunch of food but everything besides the soup dumplings were disappointing. ÁÉ§È∫∏ was okay. Soup dumplings were great. Shanghai stir fried noodles were so so. Braised pork with pickles was very disappointing - full of soy sauce and nothing else. Not flavorful and weirdly sweet. Service was bad the servers ignored us several times and when I asked about their specialties and recommendations the guy seemed very annoyed and impatient. Well they don't do tips maybe that's the cause but I would still expect any servers to be kind to customers.

I came here on a Thursday night for a family dinner - we had 8 people and were seated fairly quickly (which was basically the ONLY saving grace of the night.) 

1- Because the tables are set for 10, they forced us to share a table with an unfortunate duo AFTER we were seated (so we were not given the option to change our minds and go elsewhere because we were already seated.) It was unfortunate for the couple on a date, having to share with all of us. 
2- because the table was set up with a lazy susan, the duo was forced to crowd all their dishes in the little space on the table between them because otherwise their food would be mixed in with ours. 
3- the food came quickly but all the stirfried dishes looked and tasted the same - and were essentially thrown on the table rather than placed down and explained. 
4- the staff was brusque and rushed, shoving in between us to place dishes without warning. 
5- the space was so loud, it was impossible to hear across the table. this was not helped by the staff shouting loudly across the room. 
6- they skimped on the lettuce layer underneath the soup dumplings, meaning EVERY SINGLE DUMPLING busted open when picked up. 

we couldn't get out of there fast enough and we're definitely never coming back. There are better alternatives in the area - Joe's Ginger up the street and Shanghai Manor on Mott street.

alright, i don't know why there's such big hypes about this place. i was expect something authentic like in Asia.. but it was more Americanized... bigger in size and doesn't taste as delicate in flavors. the dumpling wrapper/skin tasted rough not as soft or smooth. The filling was okay. maybe all the hypes made me expect a lot. but to me it doesn't taste as good as the ones I had in Asia for sure. it was kind of disappointing. Good thing we didn't wait for too long. there were 3 of us, so we shared a big table with 2 other groups. my first time seeing that in NYC.

As average as it gets, what's with the hype?  The highlight was suppose to be the crab dumplings and even that was just average.  The rest of the food was greasy Chinese food, that had tons of MSG to it.  The seating is horrible, they sat us down in a large shared table, and we were blown to icecube with the horrible A/C vent above us.  The food got cold as soon as it hit the table.  Sorry not going back, there's gotta be better Chinese food that Joe's in New York right, very disappointing.

They treat their customers like crap.  The waiters are over-worked, cranky and often unresponsive to even a modest request.l (I had to ask 3 times before I could get a glass of water. ) When my food came, it was plopped down on the communal table three feet away from me.

The mandatory tip on ALL checks is smack in the face.
soup dumplings are good. and cheap. the other items like the scallion pancake... not bad. it is good, but i've had better! 3.5

Came here for the soup dumplings. Got mapo tofu, eggplant, and rice wine dumplings too.

The soup dumplings (we got pork and crab) were okay. I've had better (though I've also been to Shanghai, so maybe my standards are out of wack)

Mapo tofu, eggplant, meh. Rice wine dumplings were the worst I've ever had.

I was definitely underwhelmed. And they didn't even have good service to make up for it.

Xiao Long Bao, as described by many, will be the best in this place in NYC. Don't get all into the hype about being the BEST, it's just pretty good place in NYC. The food is judged by its soup, the stuffing, and the skin. How it's made is a whole different thing. 

The rest of the food is just there to please others who want to try other things.  Yes, it's definitely a tourist trap, but it's all good. 

Very hectic busy place. You'll be seated with other people, sharing the table 50% of the time. 

There's almost always a wait outside. 

Why 3 stars:
1) Xiao Long Bao is good..the rest is ehh. 
2) Sharing tables. Ehh, they do it in most asian restaurants, but I still don't like it. 
3) Waiters will serve you, but they're not over the top caring for you. Attitude's like "Eat well & happy, but get out when you're done. We have others. Please don't linger. I'm underpaid and over worked with stupid tourists". It's understandable. 
4) A charge of 15%?! Yes, it's the standard, it'll solve my math, and efficient, but I still don't like it being placed on there.

Interesting spot for some delicious food! Had the pork steam buns and they were very good. Nothing incredibly special but enjoyable nonetheless. Service was fast but be aware that they take cash only at this location. Overall good food for decent prices!

for the hype that was around this joint i was expecting punch in my face type of meal.  and explosion of flavor in my mouth.  but i was a bit disappointed.  the only thing memorable there was the soup dumplings and dont get me wrong, they were quite tasty.  outside of that, the food was so-so.  food was either salty or bland.  the meal didnt really seem to fit.  and for china town food this place is pretty expensive.  i definitely recommend you hitting up shanghai cafe.  much better spot.

I'm not usually a fan of Chinese food, but this was the best I've had. I probably wouldn't pick this place out of all the amazing restaurants in Manhattan, but if you are in the area and love Chinese food, definitely stop by! You'll love it if you don't mind the other things I'll mention.

4 stars for the food, knock one off for everything else. 

The wait was horrific. Some customers were served first for the same items even though they arrived later than us, one person in our group was served a half hour or so before the rest. 

Also, the waiters were very hard to understand, they really rush you to order, and aren't very attentive, but that's to be expected for such a busy place in China town. 

Beware! The portions are very big. 2-3 people could share each $15 dollar entree, but it's meant to be that way.

The food was much better than expected, especially for the price. The dumplings seemed to be very popular, almost every table had them! Worth a try. 

This would be a 4-5 star for Chinese food lovers, but if you are just looking for a place to eat in NYC, service makes it a 3.

I've been to the Midtown Joe's location dozens of times; it's more expensive and you get fewer dumplings per tray, but the service goes above and beyond what I experienced tonight. On top of that, I became violently ill no more than an hour after leaving the Chinatown location.

We ordered three trays of dumplings, half of which were broken open by the time we were served--dried out and sticky by the time we ate them. Plus one star for the shredded beef special, which was decent. 

Cash only and family-style seating.

Meh
- Soup Dumplings
- Singaporean style noodles

It was pretty cool coming to an institution like this. The skin is a little thick and I wasn't  a huge fan of the crab/pork ones. There wasn't too bad of a wait and it was cool sharing a table with random folks. Really good service but the food didn't hold up. Din Tai Fung is absolutely a beast compared to this.

So I feel the odd man out here, but Joe's is just okay.  Finally, came down for lunch to try the famous Joe's Shanghai.  Firstly, if you go for lunch for a party of 2- there is no wait.  Though, there was considerably a much longer wait when we left around 2 pm.   I'd say everything to be said about the service is true-- serious lack thereof.   I mean, I'd expected as much from Chinatown but surprisingly my boyfriend was pretty uppity about the lack of service.  The waiter didn't respond, took a long time, didn't bring up anything at the same time, etc.  Normally, I wouldn't care but Joe's Shanghai tries to portray itself as a much better, American friendly, cleaner, Chinese restaurant with its touristy lure (ugly polos are for sale).  The service was truly Chinatown and budget- as least to us. 


Onto the food.  The soup dumplings (in the appetizer section, called the Pork Buns)- good.  I went to a place in Flushing that was better.  Too bad I can't remember the name (next time, I will , I promise!)  The skin of the dumpling was a bit dough-y and thick for my taste but I guess you need that to hold on to the soup.  The meat- a good size, but too salty. I ended up passing it along to my boyfriend to eat.  The best part?  The broth.  The broth did have a lot of flavor, but it's too bad the rest of the dumpling mildly added up. There's a good quantity for the price though- I think it was like $6ish for 8 soup dumplings.

The rest of the food?  Good. I, again, ate with my eyes and over ordered.  The dishes are pretty big here.  We ordered the shredded turnip cake as another appetizer, and this I was a HUGE fan of. Liked the sourness of the shredded turnip mixed it with the fried batter, it was a little greasy but understandably so- not too greasy.  It went well with the dumpling sauce.  As a main, my boyfriend had the beef tenderloin pho type of soup- sadly I don't eat beef so I can't comment but he said the noodles were perfect, and broth flavorful. 

I had the diced chicken with cucumbers, which embarrassingly I thought was going to be kung pao chicken. It wasn't bad-- the chicken was good. It could have been spicier but I liked the texture- the worst is when chicken gets that soft bone texture; there was none of that here.  I also thought that the cucumbers were nice because they weren't overly cooked,  I'd like to think it was a healthy dish, which made me feel good.  Pile that on with a bowl of (stale) white rice, and you'll be STUFFED.  Be forewarned- don't eat with your eyes!

In the end, I think I left on only a lukewarm note mainly because this place is so expensive for Chinatown.  Turnip cake, soup dumpling, pho and diced chicken, came out to $35; which more than Chinatown's average price.  Thus, I wasn't down for that.  I'm glad I came down to try it but I don't think I feel propelled enough to go back.

Extremely rude service. The awful experience started when we requested a number in the waitlist. I asked about the estimated waiting time. The woman at the front desk shouted "I have told you the waiting time. Go back and look at your number!" Don't come to this awful place!

I am usually kind when i rate restaurants...but this place is just horrible...after hearing about this place on Zagat (when Yelp wasnt around then)..i had to come.....i am a #1 fan of Xiao Long Baos!!! 

Anyways.....because its "so famous"...you find 25% locals and 75% tourist who are here.....I ordered Pork and Crab dumplings..and the crab dumplings were ok...but the pork dumpling tasted terrible..the inside was still pinkish...--medium rare in dumplings?..0_0 so i waved one of the waiters over....there seems to be like millions of them there...i dun even know why.....

And it still took a while for one of them to come over.....I told him that the pork dumplings doesnt seem to be cooked..and instead of replacing my dumplings....they just took it away and re-steamed it....and it was still pinkish afteward. I hate to have the waiters over again...because the one before was rude ...

So i ended up leaving 4 pieces of dumplings there.....and i felt so bad because i dont usually waste food.....sniff sniff!!!!

SHAME ON THEM! 

Service sucks, food is ok...Plus its freaken overrated!

On another note.....the Joe's Shanghai on 5th Ave....is so much better!! Better in Service and Food....!!

BEWARE... Tourist Trap!!
Excited to try NYC's famous Xiaolongbao's, I went straight towards the place with the most reviews. Deep in Chinatown, I was confident this place would deliver. But when I looked around inside, there was not a single local. The xiaolongbaos were large, much bigger than the ones from Din Tai Fung. The wrapper was also noticeably thicker. The dumplings were decent but definitely not worth the hype. The leek pancakes on the hand were surprisingly good. They weren't particularly special, but they did taste better than the dumplings. Try another place for  xiaolongbaos!!!

Soup dumplings = XLB.

I don't know what all the hype is about.  Sure, lots of soup broth but the tip of each dumpling is chewy.  This place was on sis's bucket list of eats so we came.

# 9 is the pork dumplings and #10 the crab ones.  Skip the crab ones.  Too seafood smell.

We ordered three other dishes.  All were good but not great. 

I don't think I would come back.   We've got great XLB back home.

Let me save you the trouble. This is just a decent Chinese restaurant. If you're coming here to try the XLB's turn around and head to Kung Fu Kitchen instead. If you're just looking for a basic and slightly overpriced Chinese meal, you'll be fine. 

The XLB Analysis - 

Skin - The thing that stands out to me most on XLB's is the dough. I'm so confused by the endless DTF comparisons as the XLB's aren't even comparable. What makes DTF's XLB standout is the ability to get a really thin wrap. When your dough is thick, it makes the knot on top thick and chewy. If that's what you're looking for, then you'll be fine with Joe's XLBs. Personally, I think a thinner skin allows for the soup base to shine more.

Soup - Pretty flavorful, but unfortunately for Joe's I had Kung Fu Kitchen's one day before and the pork fat in Joe's just couldn't compare. Wasn't as juicy and rich. 

Meat - Solid, no complaints here. Pork is juicy and flavored well.

The rest of the food is fine. Pan fried noodles were delicious. Fried rice is seasoned well. Joe's is a reliable place for mid-tier Chinese food. Confused by the hype. Just because Manhattan doesn't have great Chinese food doesn't mean you should lower your standards.
Worse experience. Wait more than half an hour for the wonton soup. Can't freaking believe it

Well we came here just for soup dumplings. And it was good. We got the pork soup dumplings and it was good, but not great. In addition, the place was PACKED, we were crammed like sardines...but at least the waiting time was within 5 minutes. Like typical Asian establishments, we were shown a table with people already eating. Classic.

My husband and I stopped here for a quick snack because the reviews were so good, almost the best in the area. I'm not sure if it's because we had high hopes or just got a bad dish but we were not impressed. We ordered the chicken fried rice (to go, cash only) and couldn't believe the lack of flavor and scarcity of meat. The food was in desperate need of more seasoning and more salt. We came very hungry and left unsatisfied by the food we ordered. Also... cash only?? In New York?? Post Covid?? To be fair, there are ATMs in the restaurant.

The only thing I love here is the soup dumplings. The skin is thin with good amount of meat/crab filling. I love that inside the dumpling has a good amount of soup. The soup is really flavorful. From all the places I've been to, this place has the thinnest skin with lots of soup.

If there's a long wait, I don't think it's worth it. I've tried other dishes here but they weren't that great. I would come here ONLY for the soup dumplings.

Having lived in New York 15+ years, this place holds so many great memories. Fast forward to 2018 - it's steadily declined.  Now this isn't the place for an ambient dining experience but maintaining standards should count for something. 

Whether I carry out or dine in it shouldn't lack the minimal people skills that I've encountered more than usual and it's enough. My suggestion would be to brush up on your customer service skill set or find another purpose in the restaurant. The food saves you but it'll be while before I return. And I don't respond well to rudeness - so there's your forewarning.

Pros:
Quick take-out. 
Scallion pancakes. 

Cons:
Greasy, 'made too far in advanced' tasting food. 
Canned mushrooms and imitation crab.
Requested vegetable spring rolls. Actual rolls had pork and shrimp.
Cash only.
Run down /tired space.

Tossed the leftovers. Sad I wasted one of my precious NY meals here.
The worst service I have ever seen. Soup dumpling was the only one I ordered bz it is a specialty of the restaurant. Never come back!

My husband and I went to this restaurant because of all the reviews. We got the soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, General Tso chicken, eggplant in garlic sauce, and Szechuan beef for takeout since they were too busy for dine-in. Food was about $100.

TIP: They only accept cash. They do have an ATM in the vestibule of the restaurant if you need it. 

I personally thought that the food was just okay. My favorite of all the food we ordered was the eggplant in garlic sauce.

Food was definitely overrated.

The XLB were pretty good, but overall, it's not something to be impressed about. The chicken fried rice was okay, but the flat noodles were greasy. You can just taste the MSG. The service is bad too. (Cash only)

Place was packed.  Waited 45 minutes for a table for 4.  We came here for the Pork soup dumplings and they were just ok.  I've had better.  The rest of the dishes were just ok too.  Food came out one entree at a time and they forgot our Shrimp dish but Overall service was good.  Our server was nice and kept our drinks refilled.  Checked on us often.  Glad we tried it but will not return.

BAD SERVICE!!!
We had a party of 9 and asked if we can have 2 bills for the table. The waiter rudely told us that we will have to move to 2 separate tables if we want 2 bills. NOT ACCOMMODATING!!!
The food was not all that great. 
The only good dish they have there were the dumplings.
The bill came with 18% gratuity already included.
That should not give them the right to treat the customers badly.  Base on their service. The gratuity should have been 5%. 
Upon leaving the restaurant, I spoke to the manger about the poor service and the rudeness of his staff. He offered NO apology.
It is apparent why the staff is so unprofessional and rude. Leadership should start from the top down.
You will NEVER see me here again!

Outdoor seating widely available right outside the store. Indoor restroom available for use. No indoor seating. 
Food was good and decent price for chinatown. 
Soup dumplings were slightly salty, but nice and soupy! Chicken had bones in it, just FYI. Chicken did not taste special, just fried chicken with some scallions sprinkled on top. Scallion pancakes were pretty soggy in the to-go container, but basic flavor. 
Would go again to try different items on the menu. 
Also, cash only!

Decent food, not so great service. To start with the positives, the food was good. They are well known for their soup dumplings. There are two options to choose from the pork or crabmeat. We ordered the pork soup dumpling and was fairly impressed. We also ordered the crispy shredded beef and a duck dish. Both were good but not out of this world amazing. I'm pretty thrown off with the service. We went on a Monday night, it was somewhat busy and the server decided to seat us in a shared table even though there were clearly open tables available. It also seemed that our server's favorite response to every question we asked that night was a "no"! They managed to mess up our bill in which they combined our total with the other people we shared the table with. I'm not sure if this was an off night for them since I see a lot of the rave reviews but I wasn't impressed. Luckily there are other locations in NYC (Flushing and Midtown). I'm willing to give it another go, just not at this location.

Joe's Shanghai sucks.
I used to love it but it was so bad I was really embarrassed to have taken my cousins there last night.
Really, really, really rude waiters - kept trying to take our food before we were finished eating, insisted on keeping the check in the tray when I needed to hold it so my cousins wouldn't try to pay.
The only flavor in the food was salt.
  Seriously, in something called Crispy Pepper skin duck you should be able to expect a little pepper.

Only the soup buns were okay.

Sanitation was rated a C at the front door and it seems like its reflected on the food. I just shared one order of Pork XLB which comes with 8 pieces. It was not bad but it did have a "fishy" taste to it as my friends described it as. We didn't understand why as it should only have pork in it. I definitely wouldn't say this is the best place to get XLB, as there are better places like shanghai Asian manor, the Bao, etc. I wouldn't say this was a horrible place either. 

The only thing is that this place gives 8 pieces for ~$6. Normally you'll find places giving 4-6 for ~$6. Service was good and getting seated during the afternoon was quick. There's auto gratuity of 15%. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but maybe if I was nearby.
Not impressed. I guess that's why we are spoiled with good Chinese food on the west coast.   There are much better Chinese food options in New York Chinatown.

Everything was good but nothing to rave over. Apparently this place draws in a huge amount of foot traffic and we just happen to go through on a snowy weekday so seating was a cinch. Crispy duck was crispy, the soupy dumplings were strange but pretty good, and the green onion pancake was fluffy. Recommended by several frequent NYC visitors and I now know why but my next visit might only be if I happen to be by Chinatown.

Solid food but overrated and not particularly worth waiting for. I went with a group of 8 and we waited 20-30 minutes since it was on a weekday and snowing outside. I've tried to go a few times before and the wait would always be 1-1.5 hours. If I even tried to wait that long, I'd end up walking around Chinatown and eating my fill at other places for half the price.

Pros:
- Lots of soup in the pork dumplings! They were yummy but fell apart rather easily. 
- Scallion pancakes were delicious.
- Portions for other entrees are massive. We were way too ambitious when ordering and didn't finish 1/3rd of the food.
- Decently clean bathroom! A rare find in Chinatown.

Cons:
- Long wait. Your whole group has to be there when called otherwise they'll skip onto the next.

Tips:
- Cash only.
- Definitely get the pork dumplings over crab.

Have you guys been to Ninja NYC? It's an overpriced restaurant where real life ninjas serve and cook you food and demonstrate ninjutsu skills that put Naruto to shame.

I didn't know they had a training camp here at Joe's Shanghai, where waiters literally shuriken-tossed shit on your table. Plates were literally thrown down, almost knocking over our tea cups. The way my dad smacked my 64/100 math exam down on my desk was gentler than that shit.  Dishes were served and placed at our blind spot ("uh... so does that belong to us or the other party sitting at our table?") It was a race to see how fast they could service our table and masterfully withdraw to the sideline where they just stood and looked pretty (they weren't.) You can put Paris Hilton behind the counter in a McDonalds and she'd provide you with warmer service. As we stood up to leave, the host lady gave a very nonchalant "thank you bye" without even looking at me. No smiles whatsoever; it was as if Kim Jong Un himself would come conscript them if any friendliness was shown towards Western devils.

Food was standard and overpriced. The soup dumplings were in line with what Joe's Shanghai usually produces, which is pretty good. The double cooked pork looked nothing like double cooked pork and tasted salty like hell. I had to call a waiter and ask him to confirm if that's what we ordered.

Tea was lukewarm when we sat down.

Get your shit together Joe's. I've had better... say, your Flushing branch? 

15% gratuity is included. I am not sure whether that's because
a) They knew nobody would be sane to tip more than 15% for their shit service anyway or
b) They were afraid people would just not tip at all. 

Jando S is pretty spot on. I'd avoid.

"What the eff are soup dumplings?" was exactly what I thought when my friend said that we were going to spend the first meal of my 4th of July vacation at Joe's Shanghai. When we arrived we placed ourselves on a long list of patrons waiting to be seated. We then waited on the curb with all the other hungry patrons and when they finally called our number, they herded us into the crowded restaurant with everyone else waiting and proceeded to seat us at a table already occupied by a family of tourists. Wonderful.

The soup dumplings were delicious. The broth in the dumplings was not too salty, but full of flavor. The meat (we got beef) tasted just like the meat filling in siomai. DELICIOUS. Our entree was like any other dish in a chinese restaurant and quite frankly not worth writing about. The service just stinks at Joe Shanghai. I mean 1. why do they call everyone on the wait list at exactly the same time? 2. how the hell am i supposed to enjoy my meal with a family watching me stuff my face? 3. the waiter gave me the stink eye when I tried to order a beer 4. the waiter(s) tried to rush us out before we even got our entree.

If I could sit in front of my t.v. with a tub filled with soup dumplings, I would. Unfortunately the sad reality is I can't. And so with great regret, I give Joe's Shanghai 3 stars. Not because the soup dumplings weren't everything my stomach expected (and more!), but because the service sucked. If you can, get your dumplings to go ...

I had meals at this restaurant's Chinatown and Mid Town places.  Xiao Long Bao was average at Mid Town but was 1 star at Chinatown.  The ones at Chinatown were discolored and looked like the basket was waiting for order for over 30 minutes.

Shanghai Fried Noodle was sufficient taste but greasy.

Radish Pastry ËòøËîîÁµ≤ÈÖ• was completely tasteless.  Very bland with no taste of radish or much else.

I think this restaurant is overhyped by reviewers who are not knowledgeable of Shanghai cuisine.  Both restaurants had almost no locals dining.

Good food, scallion pancake, pork dumplings, orange beef, beef flat noodles But the service is Horrible! What a shame! The waiter was none attentive and rude. They literally throw the plate on the table and runway . Oh and 15% tip automatically included and they only take cash! If you're a foodie who likes good service, spend your money somewhere else.

I've been to the original location more than 10 years ago and that was the first time I've ever had Xioa Long Bao. I knew this place was famous and wanted to try it again. Luckily for me, I didn't have to wait too long for a table for 1. Normally, you do have to wait. Since it was just me I could only order 1 dish and that was their Xio Long Bao. The portion sizes are HUGE! This can feed a family of 4. Let's just say people that come to Joe's are usually a bigger group. Therefore, this dish is suited for a large group. 1 person was too much and because it was huge I couldn't try anything else in the menu. The dumplings are really soupy and they are generous with the meat. You are also paying for it too because a basket of the dumplings aren't cheap.

In general, 1 dumpling was already popped and the soup spilled on the basket. (hence the picture) Therefore, I am disappointed in the presentation. Also, heads up there is an automatic 18% gratuity.

came here for the famous soup dumplings which were okay. i've definitely had better but these weren't so bad. Got the pork and crab dumpling and just the pork dumpling. the crab dumpling is a little bit fishy for my taste.

the staff was friendly and we had really good service.

Wow!  

The service was absolutely atrocious...in a kinda "in your face" way. 

Waiters -

1. Rushed us to order
2. Rudely plopped food down on our table 
3. Only refilled teapot and water after we flagged them down
4. Kept reaching to take our plates away even though we weren't done, leaving us to reach for the remaining portions as the plates were hoisted in the air. 
5. Dropped check on table even though we didn't request yet. 

Things to know:
