1. Could have shared table seatings since mostly large tables. 
2. 15% tip added to check 
3. No reservations which means won't seat you until all present. 
4. Cash only. 

Frankly, I don't care how good the soup dumplings are.  When the service is this poor, respect yourself and go elsewhere. 

Where I'm coming from -  born in NY, Chinatown native...believe me when I say there are better alternatives. I've been here 3 times, and disliked every single time. Each time because out of towner friends wanted to try, and I aimed to accommodate. I'm stronger and tougher these days and will now point others in another direction when this restaurant is brought up.

Joe's is a classic Chinatown staple that is increasingly overrun by the tourist crowd. Lines are long - you can end up waiting over an hour on weekends - and while they have recently renovated the place, the seating is still not very comfortable.

The food is still uniformly good, there are no 'bad' dishes but also nothing that seems particularly outstanding or special. The soup dumplings are a must-try. I find the exterior of the dumplings are a little thicker than some of the more authentic Shanghainese restaurants. 

The servers are definitely overworked during peak times so it's hard to expect great service. Note for first timers, you may have to share a table with other patrons. The restaurant is cash only and an 18% tip is included in your bill.
Not a real Chinese food at all!! I can't believe there were so many people on waiting line!

We decided to go here based on the amount of reviews this place had on Yelp. It's in Chinatown in an alley so it does look sketchy if you don't know where you're going. We visited from Dallas and really wanted to have dim sum and what better place than Chinatown? It was much to my disappointment that this is more a traditional family style Chinese restaurant than a dim sum restaurant. That should definitely change on Yelp because it misled me to thinking there would be carts circling around me while I ate. 
We went on a Wednesday night and the wait for a big group of us was about 30 minutes. I would say expect a wait if you're going for lunch or dinner. It's a small restaurant and only one story. We walked around Chinatown during the wait since there isn't a wait area inside. You come in and it's what a Chinese restaurant should be like, a lot of hustling and bustling. The only thing on their menu that reminded me of dim sum was their famous soup dumplings. These take awhile to make so be sure to order as soon as you sit down if you want to try these. Like I said earlier, we didn't know it was family style so we each ordered a dish. We were a group of 9 girls. That being said, I wish they told it was family style because we were overwhelmed with food by the end of the night, which isn't a bad thing. We just felt bad because we were leaving the next day and our hotel didn't have a microwave so there was no point in bringing back the leftovers with us. 
My friends thoroughly enjoyed their foods but I didn't think it was too special. I got the braised beef noodle soup with bok choy. I only ate the beef because it was the only thing seasoned. But I did enjoy their soup dumplings! I wish I could have packed these things with me. It was super yummy and a decent size. The good thing was that everything was super cheap. The downside, if you're going in a big group, just split up the check on your own and have one person pay because accepted payment is only cash. 
Would I go again? Maybe, but only to gobble up the soup dumplings.

This review is not for the food - we never got that far!
The fiance and I got here, and saw a crowd of people in the street waiting to be seated. I put my name down and got us a ticket "#69" woohoo! the high point of the evening! The lady at the front door told us it would be approximately 30 minutes before we got a table. We were there 20 minutes, then 30, then 45, and then we passed the 1 hour mark, checking in with the lady regularly. The last time we went back and talked to the lady, a full 30+ minutes after her estimated seat time, she just shrugged said "I don't know" and went back to chatting with her friend. 

Anyway, I'll be sure to be back with a good book and cleared schedule next time, cus I really have to try their fabled soup dumplings just once!

It is an OK place.
The food, especially the xiao long bao are just average.
(There are so many other better places for xiao long bao couple of block away)

My non-Asian friends always do a big group dinner here during Christmas or New Years. So I do eat here occasionally.

What is all the buzz then? Crowds form outside in sub-zero degrees weather?
Their claim to fame is the old tourist guide and food guide books written by people who are not too kine to authentic food and only go with with the herd.

There use to be three Joe's Shanghai, Chinatown, Elmhurst Queens, and Flushing.
I think the Flushing location is the best of the three. 
The Elmhurst location have been closed for several years.

Go, enjoy yourselves at Joe's. It is good but not the best.

How fun are soup dumplings?  Pretty freakin' fun!  I ordered out from here today and I really didn't know what to expect.  I thought the dumplings came in soup...but they are FILLED with soup... soo cool.  

We had to wait ten minutes for our pork/crab meat filled buns, so while we waited, we read the Time Out, City Search, etc articles in the restaurant window.  I loved the cartoon that explained HOW to eat a soup dumpling.  THANK GOD.  If I hadn't read that, my mouth would be scorched and I would be soo out of Yelp commission for like a week, at LEAST!  I

 had my spoon and chopstick, took a little nibble, sucked out the soup (garlicky and oddly thick!) and casually ate the rest of the dumpling.  I was happy that I got take out because I feel the walk back to work sort of cooled the dumplings down. 

Overall, if you're looking for dumplings, enjoy the experience, don't expect some magical spell to be cast on your tastebuds.  They were good but not like amazing...just more fun.   I have no other soup dumplings to compare them with but judging from the crowd and line, I can at least attest to the fact that they are fresh!

Came with a friend and we were both hungry. We ordered the shredded beef, eggplant with garlic sauce with pork, crab meat soup dumplings, and turnip shortcakes. Overall I actually enjoyed the food, but was not very happy with my seating arrangement. We were asked if we would mind sharing a table with other people; I assumed that there would at least be some sort of divider between us and the other party. 
Instead, we got sat at a round table for 4. They tried to put another party of 4 at our table (so squeezing 6 people onto a 4 person table). But there was an empty 4 person table next to us so we just asked if they could be moved there. Eventually we got a pair of people sat at our table and there really was no separation between us. If you're willing to overlook this then definitely recommend going for the food.

I went last night and the place is more hype that quality.   First the good:
Me and my partner split Pork Dumplings and Hot n Sour Soup.  The dumplings were good (I would give them a 4 *), we disagreed on the Hot n Sour soup.  I thought it was also 4 Stars, but my partner hated it, so let's make it 3 *.  
The rest of the meal was not good.  I had Double Cooked Pork.  It was very bland and had lots of tofu in big chunks in it.  N
Food was good but way over priced!!!! Left hungry and still paid over $80 not including tip. Rice not included with the meal and was charged $2 for a tiny bowl of rice, got 5 small shrimp for $23.

I was expecting the best... but its was an ok for me.. 

I've never heard of this place but my friends told me it was pretty popular and that it was delicious, in my opinion I thought it was ok. I had better. I feel like this restaurant caters to Americans, and me being Asian I have higher expectations for a place that serves Asian food, not saying it was the worse but it was just ok for me.

ALSO.. I hate the service here, I mean I know asian people are rude, but for a place thats so popular they need to learn some manners. Our waiter kept coming to the table to take stuff away, for example Im eating and he wants to reach across my plate to pick up the chopstick wrapper... like seriously can I finish taking my bite first.. 

I dont want to sound mean and make this place sound terrible but I wont be going back.

I always love coming to this spot. The dumplings are definitely great but I am only giving a 3 stars because of the cleanliness. I alway thinks if the carpet is dirty and the tables are super clean that the kitchen maybe a little dirty too! Hmmm.. I only wonder. Anyways I do enjoy the fried beef with white rice. Even though it's not super healthy it's definitely delicious. Also, don't expect to sit by yourself as this is community seating. It's really fine for me but you can't really have a deep conversation bc I'm sure everyone else is listening at the table.

Their xiaolongbao is good and their American Chinese food is decent. 

I wouldn't go for any authentic or Szechuan food. The more "authentic" food turns out to be super home style, and the Szechuan food becomes Americanized. 

For the brand, I feel like they could do better with the more authentic dishes, or just remove them from the menu if they don't think it fits. Also could be useful to have an American and Chinese menu separation.

Let me preface that I am a pescatarian. That isn't the best fit for Chinese food. Especially a place that is authentic and specializes in soup which I doubt has a vegetarian base. (Never have visited China, I *think* this place is pretty authentic, but I can't say for 100% certainty.) 

Oh, and Joe's ONLY TAKES CASH. So come prepared.

Anyway, I get nervous eating at Chinese restaurants that aren't Americanized because I don't know what has pork or beef in it, even if its under the "Vegetables" section. So, my sis and I were in Chinatown and found Joe's Shanghai on Yelp and thought we'd give it a try. It was the middle of a weekday at lunch, so there was no wait to get in.

I ordered the Vegetable Pan Fried Noodles and she got the Pork Mu Shu. We sat at a round table with other guests and made good friends with the guy sitting next to us. My sis shared her Mu Shu with him, and she had some of his Kung Pao Chicken. They both loved their meals. Me? Not so much. 

The Noodles were sooooo greasy. When I bit into the noodles, I could feel the grease coating my mouth. The sauce was unbelievably greasy as well, and left this shimmering film all over the bottom of the plate.  The tofu in the dish was firm tofu but it wasn't cooked enough, so it had a crumbly texture rather than the soft insides that a well-cooked tofu should have.  

My sis went to use the restroom...I didn't dare. She came back and said I should stay away. I didn't ask for details, and didn't care to experience that horror show.   

I was not a fan of Joe's...but because my sis liked it and our new friend next to us liked it as well, I'm giving it 2 stars vs. just the 1 star I would have based on my meal.

Tourist trap alert!!!

Man this place is overrated to the n-th degree. Compare the overratedness of this place to House of Nanking in San Francisco. Both these places probably got some endorsement from some food critic years and years ago and rested on their laurels forever.

Only thing remotely good here was the Drunk Duck (basically duck soaked in alcohol and spices and served cold) - hence two stars instead of one. The XLBs were so mediocre it wasn't funny - and in the meantime, I'm witnessing these folks at our table announce to each other how good the XLBs were, like they had to confirm with one another that, in fact, their hourlong wait was not in vain! Was I in the Twilight Zone or something? Because that's how it felt like...

Guys, guys, guys, snap out of it! I, for one, was outraged for having to make the long trek down to Chinatown, wait 30 minutes, and get served these super-mediocre XLBs. And I certainly don't need someone to tell me that the long wait somehow miraculously changed these crappy XLBs into something special, because it didn't. Hello!

I mean, come on, seriously... I have a thick skin, but the skins on these XLB were thicker than mine.

Tourist trap.  Don't go here.

It's a tiny place that seems to always be packed.  We had approx 45 minute wait (new years day) for a party of 4.

First thing I noticed -- most of the people are white.  Shit.  My expectations immediately dropped.  I'm sorry if your'e white and reading this, but it's generally true -- an asian place with mostly white people does not tend to be very good.

But anyway, we are put into a tiny table and order the soup dumplings.  $5 for 8 pork and $7 for 8 crab/shrimp.

The pork dumplings were boring.  It definitely is a dish that depended on the fat from the pork for flavor -- not much else going on as far as flavors go.

The seafood dumplings were better.  You could really taste the crab in the dumplings.  It also has some weird metallic aftertaste.  I', not sure if it was coming from the dip or the dumplings themselves.

Anotehr issue I have with the place is the way the dumplings are served.  I'm ordering soup dumplings.  That means I want the taste of the soup.  So waht that means for the cook is to make sure the dumplings are not touching the steaming basket or stuck to each other.  Because the dumplings will rip and the juices will leak out.  Fail.  Some of the dupmlings seemed to be missing the soup altogether.  I'm a very good chopsticks user and I got blueballed a few times as I bit into the dumpling for the juices -- and it was already dry inside.

I also lol'd when i saw white people poking the dumplings with their chopsticks, letting the juices all leak out.  Don't do that guys.

The scallion pancakes -- crap.

Oh yeah, 15% gratuity added no matter what, even though the service sucks.

I'm going to make sure my friends avoid wasting a night out in NYC here.

No idea why this place gets such high ratings, the food is just plain okay but pretty bland. They're not very friendly and rush you in and out, the waiters never step aside while you're walking through but instead try to push their way in front of you.  If you are a small party of 1 or 2 they crowd you in at someone else's table which gets awkward fast.  Also they force a 15% tip and are cash only.

I'm not going to lie to you, I haven't been super impressed by Joe's Shanghai.  Everyone raves about the dumplings and while they're good they didn't really change my life.  Everything else I ordered was pretty forgettable.  And frankly the dumplings probably would have been too if it weren't for the extreme caution required to eat them.  With respect to that, by the way, I suggest picking one up in the spoon provided, breaking it open and sipping out the juice like hot tea first and then as it becomes suitably cooled eat the actual dumpling. Perhaps add a little sauce if you're into that sort of thing.  The Family style seating is kind of cool if you are sat next to interesting people but it can suck if your table mates are obnoxious (aka tourists).

Been here for like 3 times already because different people all want to check it out. The pork soup dumplings are definitely very soupy and hot but they are way too greasy for me and the flavor really isn't as good than alot of other soup dumplings i have had in Asia. 
The crab and pork dumplings are definitely better than the the regular pork ones. We also had other dishes there, which were just ok

Overall, i think it's way too hyped up. not worth the wait

This place is on everyone's go to soup dumplings list. I had the pleasure of coming here when visiting friends one time, and did not know anything about how popular this place was. They do not take reservations, so I waited for about 35-40 minutes outside, in the cold. When it was finally our turn to be seated, I was almost ready to call it quits, if it wasn't for the investment of time I had already sunk in. I went with a group of friends, about 10 of us in total. We ordered several orders of the pork soup dumplings, and 2 orders of the crab soup dumplings, along with some lo mein, fried rice, several other dishes. The experience was good, but I the crab soup dumplings were the most memorable. They were memorble because they were not good, compared to the rest of the dishes. I remember taking a bite, and thought to myself if I really had to finish the rest of it. The flavor was off, it did not taste like I was eating crab, but more of like something foul. The regular soup dumplings, were pretty good, but absolutely forgettable. If this is your favorite or only place you know to get soup dumplings then by all means keep going, it's not bad. However, if you want to know if there are other restaurants that serve also serve delicious soup dumplings, the answer is yes! Go do some research, you will definitely find better soup dumplings. 

Overall:
I later find out that it was not as popular with locals as it was with tourists. Apparently when tourists google soup dumplings, this place pops up from all the good reviews from other tourists, and being a competent restaurant, they were able to maintain a good image and good reviews from out of town-ers, which gives it its high score of 4 stars. However, it's not the same with locals here. There are other restaurants here that serve the same quality soup dumplings, and some maybe even better based on personal preference. The long lines from tourists are usually a turn off for most locals, and they prefer to go to less popular establishment but still serve delicious soup dumplings.
Cash only.  Share table.  Food was hot and fresh.  Service and price are much better than Midtown location.

Hype Hype Hype!

Soup dumplings were OK at best. The skin was kinda tough. Though, it looks like the dumplings were overcooked instead. FYI, if the skin sticks to the steamer or to each other, its likely the dumplings were overcooked. overcooked sink becomes sticky and tears really easily. Portion sizes were reasonably large. Each dumpling was bigger than the spoon. Mostly soup and skin, not too much filling. The dumplings were not made that well either. A couple of them opened up while steaming so the soup just all leaked out (probably cuz it was over cooked).  The crab filling still had bits of crab shell.

Other than that, all the other dishes were mediocre.  The sliced beef noodle soup was bland. The noodles were a tad too hard and chewy.  The sesame chicken had way too much batter. Some of the batter wasn't fully cooked.

I guess Joe's Shanghai is one of those NYC tourist locations milking as much of their own mythology as much as they can before it's gone.

Bottom line, this place is just another old school tired restaurant. If you care for soup dumplings, you can definitely find better places, cheaper places, more interesting places, more authentic places in NYC.

NOT WORTH IT. Definitely tourist trap. We went to a different place for xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and was so glad we did. We came back to Joe's afterwards just to try and it was underwhelming. The XLB was too fatty with not much flavor. The skin was also a little on the thick side - a bad sign. I really didn't even want to finish the rest of the XLB. Cheap? Yes. Get what you pay for? Yes. The wait here is too long and is overhyped.

2 stars. Maybe 3 if I'm feeling happy. 

Not sure what all the fuss is about. Seems to me like a classic case of a lack of options. 

You see,  I am taiwanese and come from southern California, so I've had my fair share of din tai fung and the like, both in the motherland and back in La. 
Joes does NOT compare. Here's why:

The food isn't that good. But I understand that there's not many options in the area for those looking for the authentic Chinese meal. 
I ordered the classic dumplings, mixed option, and it came out in a speedy 10 minutes despite the restaurant being packed (I ate alone and sat at a community table with 3 other parties). 
The dumplings themselves just looked unappealing. The texture wasn't great and would stick to your mouth,  and the flavor of the meat and juice was average. 

Now for the service. Usually I let Asian establishments off the hook for horrible service bc that is just the culture. Knowing that,  I expect some tlc if yelpers give this place a freaking 4 on 2k reviews. 

Don't be fooled by the wall of celebrities, they just don't know any better, so you shouldn't either. 
That being said,  if you've never had this kind of entree before,  then I'm sure you'll love it as something to set the bar low for the future. 

Note: just in case you consider me biased as preferring taiwanese over shanghainese, I don't have any,  and consider myself an American that just loves to eat the best of the best. 

And I will say their other dishes looked and smelled good. So take this review for the dumplings only.

Having lived off of soup dumplings (by choice) whenever I visit Shanghai and it's neighboring regions, I can honestly say the dumplings here did very little for me. In every other aspect, these had the hallmarks of an authentic soup dumpling. But when it comes to the flavor, it's like someone took a soup dumpling and turned down the volume by about a third. 

There is only one redeeming factor about these dumplings, and that is the fact that they exist at all. It can be remarkably hard to find these in other parts of the country, so it's definitely worth a trip to try these if you've never had them. 

Don't bother with the rest of the menu. You can get much better versions of everything on the menu elsewhere on Canal.

I went to Joe's Shanghai with eight of my friends, we were all starving so we ordered the crab and pork dumplings as a starter with the idea of ordering more dishes afterwords. 

It was early afternoon, not really a busy time, we were seated right away and the dumplings came very quickly as well. 

I picked up a dumpling, put it on my plate, sat the plate in front of myself, and then stared at it for a good minute because there was a COOKED COCKROACH stuck to my dumpling. 

Sorry Joe's, I won't be eating at your place any time ever.

Went to try the famous soup dumplings. Honestly they were just as good as any other soup dumplings but still great. I do think the place is overhyped and we had to wait in line and take a number to get in

The food was great but I got a food poisoning later.
Waiter was kinda rude.
He told us to leave right after we paid the bill because people were waiting.
But do I go back?
Yes!
The food was that great.

If you're coming here, only get the soup dumplings and the scallion "pie". The soups dumplings are huge and contain a lot of soup. The scallion "pie" is thick and crunchy. 

Everything else here is terrible. We got the eggplant dish and it tasted like someone knocked over the sugar into the dish. Does not taste authentic at all. We ordered four dishes aside from the soup dumplings and scallion "pie" and could not finish any of it because it was just disgusting. The meat in the soup was old and sour-- inedible.
I really liked the soup dumplings. It's just waaay too crowded though. I would definitely go back to try other things but I want me some soup dumplings again =)
Good food but relatively slow service and hurried at the beginning which made it hard. Good duck though and cheap wine!

Was decent, but was definitely not worth the hour and a half wait. Soup dumplings is a must try when at a Shanghai restaurant. However, I was not very fond of their soup dumplings. Considering that their dumplings keeps ripping and some are even leaking soup out before we even get them. Had their Shanghai noodles but was okay.

Horrible customer service! If there were minus 5 stars to give, I would definitely have chosen it. Didn't eat. I am not going to spend money for the bad service. I can have the same kind of food anywhere in Chinatown.

TOURIST TRAP!!! If you like going to Bubba Gump Shrimp and other tourist traps like that, this place is definitely for you. There's no locals there at all. I'm so pissed I even wasted two hours of my life eating here. The dumplings were not even good, if you have been to DTF, you know what I mean. The bathroom was a nightmare, beyond disgusting. 
The dumplings and every single dish we ordered had about a half a gallon of oil in it. 
This Joe guy is probably counting his cash and laughing at all you stupid Americans.

The worst soup dumplings I've ever had.  Overly fishy crab, limp wrappers, tasteless broth.  All served on unappetizing lettuce leaves. The vinegar/ginger sauce tasted rancid. I can't believe the positive Yelp reviews. 

The dining atmosphere is terrible.  Chaotic, noisy, ice cold a/c's blowing air directly on patrons.

People:  If you think Joe's has good bao, you owe it to yourself to check out  Grand Sichuan on 29th and 9th.  You'll thank me.

If you want to try authentic chinese food, please do not come here. Everything here is Americanized, i order spicy fish filet, a big no no. Probably they do better at shanghai food, but I'm not a big fan of "one restaurant, multiple cuisine" at all.

When you come here all you should get is the soup dumplings.  Everything else is just so so.  The place is definitely very dirty and crowded.  It's a place you order your food, eat as fast as you can and get out.  Not a place to sit around and just hang.  The waiters there are very very rude.  When given the check, 1 or 2 of the wait staff stands around to make sure there's enough tip.  There was one time, they embarrassed a customer by yelling out "you didn't give enough".  I think I would have been mortified if it happened to me.  I hate going there just for that reason.  It's one thing if they gave great service and should deserve the 15 or 20% tip.  But when food is thrown at you, and they have difficulty taking your order because they don't speak or understand english and they look like they are bothered when asking for a different fork because it's dirty one, I think 10% should be sufficient enough.  The wait staff is taking advantage of the fact that everyone goes there for the soup dumplings and no matter how bad the service is, customers will always go back because of their food. 

i've been back enough times and every time I leave that place I always say, no more.

OVERALL 3 stars. Been here two times. They're all about their dumplings so right off the bat they ask you how many dumplings you want and what type of meat. The servers speak fast so it can be hard to understand plus their accent. I'm Asian too and I have a hard time understanding them. Servers seem overwhelmed and stressed. Hard to get something from them.  

DUMPLINGS sure they're tasty and it's kind of annoying you bite into it and all the soup liquid comes gushing out so be sure to have a bowl right under it. But it's not where I'm back in California now craving them type of that tasty good if you know what I mean. But they're good sure. 

FOOD other food was ok good. Nothing absolutely mind blowing. 

INSIDE is not that big considering they PACK AS MANY tables and chairs. You end up sitting with people you don't know. It's hard to move around and get around. If you're claustrophobic you will not like eating here. If it wasn't so cramped I would probably like this place better. Photos on the wall of famous people who have eaten here are cool to look at. 

Bathrooms in the back are dirty and grungy one room toilet style, but if you gotta go you gotta go especially after drinking all the soup that comes out of those dumplings. Haha. 

WAIT yes you might have to wait a long time and either it's really hot when I came or really cold. Makes it annoying to wait around due to extreme weather conditions I'm not used to. Parking is street parking so expect to circle around and around looking and probably have to walk and keep track of the time to re feed a meter.

yes xiao long bao might seem like it's the same everywhere but it really isnt and this review is SOLELY on the XLB cause i didnt get anything else =P

pretty affordable for the size you get...i think it was like 5.65 for a tray and they're pretty hefty portions than most places

the XLB here are a little bit fattier than most and you can definitely taste it in the broth inside the dumpling and you can kinda see it too, a little rich but not super heavy.  
I liked it

The only thing was! my XLBs' skin was a little tough, like as if it has been cooked and sitting out for a bit and the dumpling's skin harden which made eating and enjoying it a little difficult.

Definitely a must try in NYC

on a side note! - beware of the waiters, i know for a fact i heard one of the waiters fart loudly and he was within proximity of where i was eating...lost of my appetite afterward AND when asked about the tip charge that was ALREADY added onto my bill, the waiter said yes and i can hear the other waiter speaking in mandarin giving him crap about why did he tell me that and he could have gotten more money from me (wow...luckily i understood him)

I came here because I saw a video on how amazing the soup dumplings were! I feel like when I came inside I wasn't expecting the place to look or serve what it did. I thought it would be a dim sum or authentic Chinese restaurant but it really wasn't. I don't know if I would come back

Thus far, this has to be the most disappointing meal I have had in NYC. For the number of positive reviews I have seen on this place and the number of news article written, I have to say I am not a fan. 

After waiting for over 1 hour in 35 degree weather, we were put together with another family and was forced to share a single table. 

Can't say I am accustomed to that but what really bothered me was the quality of the food.

We ordered some mapo tofu.... it did not taste like mapo tofu at all! It was blend, and was not a tad bit spicy. We also ordered a crispy duck.... and it was way too salty and the duck was dry.

Their xiao long bao "soup dumpling" was ok. I've had better. 

Long story short, I was not at all impressed.... and if asked if I would go back.... that would be a no.

There are plenty of people that will like this place because they have not had better food but unfortunately I have.

Decided to try this place out because of all the raving reviews. The entire place is super packed with 2-3 different parties sitting at your table. It was pretty awkward since it was a round table. 

Also the food wasn't phenomenal. The only dish that stood out to me was the soup dumplings which is the only reason for tourist visits. 

Please be aware that portions are big! Our eyes were bigger than our stomachs :/

Coming from San Francisco, which has a huge 1st generation Chinese and Asian American population, I had much higher expectations for NY Chinatown Chinese food. 

To me, overall the entrees were too Americanized and lacked flavor but the biggest disappointment was the Chow Fun! The noodles texture felt like they had been saturated in water for far too long and then microwaved. I mean, honestly, how can General Tso chicken lack flavor???My husband really enjoyed the soup dumplings, but I cannot attest to those because all of them (even the crab ones) had pork inside of them and I don't eat pork. In fact, the food, at this restaurant was so bad that our meal ended, when I asked, "are we just eating this food because we spent $60 and this doesn't seem like the type of restaurant that remove items off the bill"?

I'll try another restaurant in NY Chinatown, eventually, but it won't be this place!

the crab dumplings were good, but nothing to go crazy about, i order salt pepper duck was good too, my only complaint was that i ordered one Crab dumpling dish, and they brought me 2... wtf is that. people who work there are shady and always looking to tack on something to your bill.

I went here with a party of 5 on Saturday evening. The wait was about 40 minutes which was probably the longest time I waited for a Chinese restaurant.

The menu consisted of a mix of Chinese-American dishes and more traditional dishes. We ordered noodles, scallion pancakes, chinese vegetables, egg fried rice and of course, the soup dumplings. I don't really eat pork but I just had to try one and omg! It was so good. It tasted a little MSG-ey but it was still good. I also enjoyed the egg fried rice, but it was a little mushy. The rest were just okay.

The service was quite good as well. I found it funny that most of the diners here were NOT Chinese or any kind of Asian, which was strange considering that this place is super popular and is in Chinatown. Nonetheless, it was still good to me but I would not go out of my way and wait 40 minutes for this place. Plus, my native Shanghainese friend claims that this place is not authentic at all. Oh well!

I'm starting to get the feeling that Joe either employs my friends or puts some kind of crack in their food. Whenever I meet up with them at school and ask "where do you want to go for lunch?" the same thing always comes out of their mouth. Joe's Shanghai. Which is always followed by my sighing and asking "didn't we just go there last week?" Seriously they are Joe's Shanghai addicts. We usually make the short journey from City Hall and grab lunch then either rush back to class or go our separate ways. 

As soon as we're seated the waiter immediately asks how many of the XLB (haha props to the yelper who made that up) you want. We usually opt for about 3 or 4. Get the ones with the crab meat. It gives the XLB that slight hint of sweet seafood flavor. Once in a while we throw in a scallion pancake. I can't say they're great but I suppose they're not awful either. Let's just say I've definitely had better. I also came here once with my girlfriend and aside from ordering the XLB we also had the Cha Cherng Mein (not sure of the translation but I think it's noodles with shanghainese sauce). It's actually pretty tasty and they give you lots of noodles and lots of sauce. I like my noodles like I like my women, saucy. 

Be warned, none of the waiters or waitresses speak a word of English or any dialect of Chinese outside of Mandarin. Their extent of English consists roughly of everything on the menu. I once asked for a replacement plate and chopsticks because mine were dirty and it took three waiters and lots of hand motions on my part before I finally got what I asked for. I was this close to flailing my arms and possibly drawing stick figures or diagrams. It may or may not be due to the language barrier but I feel that the service here is sub par. They always try to stuff as many people as possible onto a table and then get you in and out as quickly as possible. I always feel like I'm being rushed. My friend has gotten into countless arguments with the waitresses. most recently because rather than give us our own table for a party of 6 in a half empty restaurant, they tried to squish us into a table with other patrons. But then again she is Taiwanese and from Flushing so you know what I'm saying. Haha, I kid I kid! Don't hate me!!

My opinion? The food is pretty good but the service could use some work. It's also a tourist trap and to be honest I'm quite impartial to tourist traps. I can think of other places in Chinatown to have XLB and with better service too. Prices here are also slightly higher then other Shanghainese places. If not for my friends I probably wouldn't come as often, if at all.

Haven't been to Joe's Shanghai in awhile but I was craving for some soup dumplings. My fave place would be Nan Xiang in Flushing for it but since I was in Ctown, I decided to come here. One thing I hate about this place is that it's filled with tourists usually, where tour buses would bring them here which I find pretty annoying. Next, they love to make you share tables which is what happened to me last night. Had to share with 3 other groups on a big table. For 2 people, we ordered 2 orders of soup dumplings. shanghai noodles and a pork chop noodle soup. I used to love this place back in the days but I feel like some things have gone down hill for sure. Soup dumplings have definitely gotten saltier and pork chop were so so. Shanghai Asian Cuisine on Mott Street might be better than them now. I won't be coming back here. Wished Din Tai Fung was in NYC.

Come here for soup dumpling, and just for dumpling soup....
I recommend to eat it there though, taste different if you take it out, even after you microwaved it. 
If you want to eat another dish, go somewhere else... Had beef broccoli, and squid with black bean before and it was a big disappointment, so not worth the price they put there. I found better taste, with better price around.

One thing that i really dont like it here is that mandatory service charge 15% that they put automatically in your bill. I found some restaurant charge it if we have large party, but Joe charges it even for 1 customer. Well we have to pay tips anyway but, i think its sneaky for the restaurant to add it without prior notice anywhere. I remember when I first eat there, and didn't know about  this, and we ended up double tip them, like 35% from total.. For just ok service that we got, I don't think they deserved it.. I'm very sure I'm not the only one who didn't know bout this, and paying more tips more than we thought. Maybe it's their way to get more tips, or tourist trap? but come on !!! You get more tips if you improve your service, right???

Very shortly after discovering this place--I'll admit, a real treasure--it became my favorite restaurant in Manhattan. This was a few years ago. I came here alone frequently. I came here with friends frequently. I wanted to be here constantly... I learned how to eat the soup dumplings: hold on spoon, take a small bite, let juices into spoon, let steam rise, take small bites, take small sips of broth, have multiple orgasms... In Shanghai, at least in some establishments, these are served with a straw. More fun, and much more accessible... I used to prefer the pork with crab, for a more tender center, but then I came to prefer the overall more delectable pork only... 

The real thing that won me over about this place was the jellyfish. Real quality, real simplicity, real cheap... I'd been places like Chin Chin and Shun Lee Palace, both of which I think entirely missed the idea (or were perhaps trying to camouflage the essence of this amazing acquired taste) but here I had, right in front of me, completely accessible in terms of price and location--and, as I soon learned, consistency--a wonderful dish... 

Delicious dishes: [cold] sliced kidneys with mixed vegetables, ducks web with celery, drunken crab. [soup] salted egg and sliced pork with mustard greens, ham and winter melon, hong kong style hot and sour (which is, still, every time I have this, a childhood favorite, the best I've had in ages). [seafood] spicy buffalo carp fish belly, braised sea cucumber with pork tendon. [pork] lima bean salad and pork with bean curd tripe, lion's head (SO GOOD). [noodles] shredded pork with pickled cabbage vermicelli soup, szechuan beef tendon vermicelli soup... Another favorite, which must have a rather small seasonal availability, is "salt and pepper silver fish with jalapeno" which I haven't seen or heard of in awhile... 

You pretty much always have to share a table. The service is friendly. The bathrooms are clean. The prices are good... It's touristy, but usually only populated by the very bravest tourists since the "average" American will run away as soon as they see Pell Street or the line outside or the communal tables or realize that most of their favorite dishes aren't available.

Had the crab and pork xlb which were disappointing because a few were not sealed properly and had no soup by the time they got to us.  The flavor was good though. The fried pork dumplings were delicious and the scallion pancakes were my favorite.

Find them a bit expensive for Chinatown.

Will be back to try other menu items and the scallion pancakes again!
The xltb's skin were not so thin and the flour were thick and dry! We ordered a steamed fish and it came out overdone and tasted bitter.

Soup dumplings are definitely amazing and some of the best you can find in New York City. However, considering the crowds of tourists, I don't know if it's particularly worth it. The rest of the food is good as well, but nothing you can't get at another solid Shanghainese restaurant in Chinatown.

Xiao long Bao was ok skin was a little thick and  not as good as the ones I've had elsewhere (Flushing Queens I'm not reviewing to promote another restaurant). Also ordered beef and veg on pan fried noodles ,beef had a weird flavorless texture so just ate the vegetables. The pan fried noodles were white puffy and tough and not pan fried ,we left that on the plate also. Had the vegetable and bean curd ,veggies were ok but bean curd was deep fried and held oil like a sponge ,left that on the plate also. Saw this restaurant on a you tube episode and went in  excited and came out disappointed.  Place was busy ,lines out the door, go figure the hype and no Asians eating there... hmmmm... 9/15/18.
This place is ok. The soup dumplings are okay, it was a bit too brothy for me. The lo mein was not that tasty and on your bland side. Green onion pancakes were really oily. Not a fan

Ordered:
1. Crab & Pork Soup Dumpling- Ground meat texture instead of what I'm used to in my dumpling which is more smooth and cohesive. Did not like it much compared to other soup dumplings I've had. It was not that "soupy". Only 2 choices of soup dumpling. The other was only pork. 
2. Mixed Vegetable Dish- It had tofu and probably 6 different vegetables. Good sauce. 

Ambiance- Typical Chinese restaurant. Crowded but we were lucky to not have to stand in line as we got there early around 6pm. Nice and attentive waiters.

The food was really nice we tried the buns or soup dumplings and we tried the eggplants which we love. On weekends the place is crowded and inside is also very busy, not a quiet relaxing place and you seat altogether with strangers  in these large tables which to me it was ok but if you have to share private or more intimate conversations that is not the right place. They have an extensive menu but I understand they are famous for their soup dumplings which were really good.

Why is this popular? Just because you make the shanghai dumplings huge, doesn't make them good. The soup and meat were bland. The green beans had a weird rubbery texture. The shanghai noodles were very oily. Honestly, this would be considered the worst Chinese food  in SF

I remember the days when Joe Shanghai was thee place to get your soup dumpling fix.  But somehow this place became more and more tailored to tourists and quality plummeted (probably to keep up with the demand). Plus I don't like waiting over an hour just to get seated.  

I prefer Kung Fu Xiao long bao or Nan Xian in Flushing for that soup dumpling fix now.

Horrible! The staff and servers are SO rude and dismissive that it truly is a problem. The food is greasy and unimpressive. Just skip it! Not to mention the bedraggled ambiance - ok i get it that it's what you get for that price- but with so many spectacular options in NYC- why suffer this?!
The servers were soooo rude and inattentive that we had to go and ask the hostess for our check and she also didn't seem to care one bit. Just pathetic!
Spare yourself the waste of time and subpar food- go around the corner to NY Noodletown instead!

This place is too overrated. Got to Chinatown, and into Joe's Shanghai for their "famous" soup dumplings. 
They were OK, but not worth any wait or any bragging. Half of our dumplings popped before we could even drink the soup. The pork dumpling tasted a bit like liverwurst, I don't know. 

Just to say, I won't be going back anytime soon.

Joes shanghai is as authentic as china town gets. Although it has an A sanitation rating, it does not look extremely clean. They do not take reservation and things can get a little wild / unorganized at the door. If you are looking for a date spot this is not the place. All the large tables are communal seating and you are pretty much sharing dishes with others at your table. We ordered the soup dumplings which did not disappoint. Joes is known for their soup dumplings and they were extremely juice. I also recommend getting the shanghai flat noodles. The noodles are very thick and delicious. Aside from the mess at the door and the communal seating the food was delicious.

This restaurant is highly overrated  but I may be biased since I just recently finished a six month stint in China. The food at Joe's Shanghai is nothing compared to its advertised equivalent that you can find on the streets of Shanghai or Hong Kong for a fourth of the price. 

The food was decent, but it was also not what I expected after seeing its stellar reviews. Chris and I ordered both types of xiao long bao (pork steamed buns, crab meat and pork steamed buns) and the crispy jumbo prawns with meat sauce. The prawns looked and tasted like a over-battered version of sweet and sour pork--with shrimp. There were no hints of meat sauce or spices (the menu item had a chili pepper icon next to it). It was a bit overcooked and too sweet, which would have been okay if sweet and sour shrimp was actually what I ordered.   

Now for the soup dumplings. The size of the dumplings is much larger than average. This means it takes much longer to eat, so by the time I got to my second dumpling the skin was already cold and hard. When it's cooled, the top of the dumpling is almost inedible because of the thick and doughy skin. These type of dumplings however are typically made with extremely thin skins that serve to bring attention to the meat and soup within. I needed to eat the skin separately just to make sure the dough doesn't overpower the taste of the filling. As for the filling itself, I honestly couldn't tell the difference between the two types I ordered. They tasted exactly the same: frozen, bland mystery meat. The soup compensated by being very rich and heavy. Put together, the dumplings were passable. 

Service was fine. The waiter was a bit overzealous at the beginning of our service. I had to tell him three times that I wasn't ready to order; but after that, he left us alone unless we needed him. 

There's no comparison to the real deal. If you've had authentic xiao long bao before, you'll be severely disappointed with Joe's Shanghai. However, I wouldn't be surprised if this is as good as New York's got. So if you're new to soup dumplings, by all means go here. 

- Tiffany

I like the food but the service merits a 2 star! I simply hate waiting on a line when the staff shows no urgency to get me seated. It's also just too crowded to sit. Definitely consider taking out instead

Let me start off by mentioning I am a huge dumpling fan. I had been dying to try Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings and literally waited in the rain to be seated. The line is long, expect that. 

The restaurant itself is pretty big and they do a good job of packing everyone in. It did take a while for us to be waited on however. 

The crab and pork soup dumplings were a nice size and the flavor was pretty good but the texture wasn't the best I've had. There was something missing from the broth so I can say I've had better dumplings. 

The scallion pancake was very greasy, and don't get me wrong I love a bit of grease, but the oil on these overpowered the doughy-ness I normally love.. Again I've had better. 

The crispy fried beef was a nice shareable serving but it was unexpectedly sweet and while the first few bites were good the sticky sweetness completely overpowered the dish. 

My main issue with Joe's is not the food, it was the lack of cleanliness. The menus were dirty the place itself felt a little run down and the major thing for me was the vinegar and chili oil  serving dishes were dirty and seemed to not be changed out. 

I had heard so much about this place and was a little disappointed that it wasn't what I expected but I might be back to give it another try.

I used to love Joe's Shanghai.  But this last experience was terrible.   Utensils were all dirty and the Lion's Head and Pork shoulder had no flavor.  Except a bit of over sweetness.   As if they forgot to flavor it with the savory part.  Had to ask for some soy sauce just to add some flavor.  

It's gone so far downhill as to be not worth visiting.   I would advise everyone to find another place for Shanghainese food.  Very disappointed.

Dine in this restaurant after COVID-19 reopen. The place seems ok and clean, my friend and I order a fish, and after 20 mins the waiter told us we didn't actually ordered that because he thought we're just asking for recommendations when we're ordering. Then it took them another 30 mins to cook that. And after we tried that fish, I have to say I am furious. The fish tastes like mud and must have been frozen for a long time. I understand the difficulties that restaurants were facing during COVID but they shouldn't do this. Very disappointed. By the way, the waiter just took 10 dollars off our bill while we barely eat the 20 dollar fish.

Ate at Joe's Shanghai this last Sunday the wait for our party of 8 was not too bad at all took about 20 minutes. Our group ordered the:

Crab Dumplings
Pork Dumplings
Fried Mini Buns
Cold Noodles with Sesame Sauce
Sauteed Seasonal Vegetables
Sliced Braised Beef Noodle Soup
Pan Fried Noodles
Singapore Chow Mei Fun

The price is okay for New York, expensive for china town there are a lot of better places to eat in china town. The food was oily and not very flavorful.
The pork dumplings are decent the soup is a bit salty but it seems like this is the only place around that one can get soup dumplings hence the rave reviews. The Braised beef Noodle Soup wasn't bad either.

It is china town so the restaurant is not the cleanest and the decor is typical.

I was disappointed at the Xiao Long Baos.. It wasn't what I expected. I've definitely had better. I also ordered the Shanghai noodle and I think that was even better than the dumplings. I had saw the reviews and since it was our first time in NY, we went all the way to Chinatown from Times Square to try it. Definitely was not worth it.

Overall an average experience for us in Joe. We had a few dishes and their soup bums. Reasonable prices and quick turnaround time. Perhaps our standard is a bit high given we have some very authentic Chinese in Sydney, so we didn't find the food particularly special. 

Plenty of non Chinese patrons so I guess they are doing something right. Not a place for native Chinese unless they are going for a quick bite and doesn't want to walk far for other options.

Came here for a quick bite recommended by a local friend. 

Soup dumplings and scallion pancakes were ordered. 

Soup dumplings were nice, hot, and steamy! Delicious as well. 

Scallion pancakes were amazing and crisp. It was good with the sauce given. Both are recommended. 

Service was fast and typical of an Asian place. Shared a table which is a nice way to meet people and have them take pictures. haha.

I like to come here on a weekday to avoid the rush. I don't eat meat, which pisses me off, because I've heard the soup dumplings are amazing. Plenty other yummy things for me to choose from though. Their scallion pancakes are the best I've ever had, and the Shanghai fried rice is delicious. Service is quintessential Chinatown style, quick and efficient, so go in with low expectations and realize that gratuity is included in the check. Really hard to find this place for the first time, as I don't think Pell has a street sign, but after one trip you'll remember forever!
sadly Joe's is not what it used to be. Most of my soup dumplings were broken. It seems to be flooded with tourists.

I should have gone with my gut when I saw that less than 1 of every 10 people dining here were Asian. This is one time I should not have listened to Yelp.

Guys, I don't care how many famous people eat here. The food was so generic, watered down, flavorless, and Americanized that I really would have been happier at Panda Express. REALLY. 

The scallion bread is greasy as hell here, and their dishes are covered in flavorless sauce. If this is what NY Chinatown is about, fuggedaboutit- I'm going back to Houston Chinatown. 

The one redeeming food we had? Their iconic, much-lauded Xiao Long Bao (translated into Chinese as "Little Dragon Soup Dumplings," just for your shits and grins). Those were served searing hot with a nice texture and 6.95 for 8, I believe. 

There are plenty of restaurants full of CHINESE people in Chinatown here. Try one of those. I should have. 

Enjoy your standard surly Chinese service (to be expected at any Chinese restaurant) at a flat rate of 15% tagged onto the bill already. Cash only.

We went to Chinatown to get some good Chinese food and this place was not it. The staff were not that friendly and the food didn't seem well seasoned, like they were missing salt in everything. We got the fried rice, soup dumplings and I got the hot beef soup. The soup was just hot and not flavorful at all. We will not be back unfortunately.

I discovered this tourist spot by accident. I thought it was gonna be Joe's rice rolls. 

Their specialty is pork/crab soup dumplings. The first few were good; the crab is with pork. The remainder weren't so good. I dunno why. 

On the other hand, the eggplant slaps! Usually the eggplant is shrimp but theirs comes with tender pork strips. Delish leftovers. 

The service was meh. Oh they only take cash

Went there yesterday on the hype of the Shanghai soup dumpling. While that is a ok, the rest of the menu items are not. I am a tourist so it's easy for me to say that I won't visit this place for my next NYC visit.

We had the XLB, subgum casserole, eel with chives, and stir-fried vegetables. The soup was quite delicious. Unfortunately the XLB wasn't quite as good as what I had in their Flushing location. Overall, the entrees were a bit too oily for our taste.

We also had to share a table with another customer.

I'm sad to say that Joes did not live up to the hype. We went on a soup dumpling crawl to six different restaurants and Joe's was tied for least favorite. We might have had a bad batch but our dumplings' skin were so thick, all of the dumplings were already broken so all that was left inside was oily pork :( 

21 Shanghai House around the corner had no wait and were so much better. Sorry Joe's :( 

Their scallion pancakes were amazing though!! Would go back just for them.

Came here on a Monday night- no wait but was seated next to the cleaning supplies. Gross.  I've had Joe's before, but this visit really made me realize that I do not want to come here again. I ordered the pork XLB with the delicious soup inside. The only downside to the dumplings is that they smell like feet. Don't get me wrong, they are definitely tasty....but just smell horrible. I notice the same smell from Joe's Ginger's dumplings (which has the same owner). 

FYI tip is included in your bill.

I hear about Joe's Shanghai from different crowds. Many in NY deem it the best Shanghai Dumplings they've ever had. Me? I pity them. 

Food: 
Pork Shanghai Dumplings - Lots of broth which means they use a lot of lard. Very good flavors but why the heck is the skin so thick? 
Crab Shanghai Dumplings - Almost no broth. Same thick skin. 
Vegetables - The bok choys were not the freshest. Even so most restaurants will just snap the ugly looking areas off....they didn't bother with that. 

Btw our vinegar saucer can use more ginger! 

Service: 
Very fast paced...wait staff gave us the hurry and eat mentality. Ordered two items then the waiter bounced off leaving us with blank reactions...like....is he coming back to take the rest of our order...? 

Environment: 
I love older Chinese restaurants. It adds to the flavors. 

Price: 
Not too pricey. 

Din Tai Fung in California and Asia is light years better than this. Heck the lesser known joints in those areas make better dumplings. Don't believe the hype. 

Food: 3
Service: 1
Environment: 3
Price: 4

The dumplings themselves were great. I had the pork and crab mixed with pork dumplings. A little bigger than I'm used too but tasty! The dumplings themselves are 4 stars but the atmosphere and restaurant facilities suck. Who wants to be crammed in a table with random other people. But its New York City chinatown so you can't really be expecting 5 star amenities and service. The standard that I compare all dumplings to though is Din Tai Fung in LA and in Taiwan. So compared to there the dumplings are just a notch below and they don't offer the dessert dumplings that Din Tai Fun does. Overall Joe's Shanghai is good but no reason to make a special outing there if you are there on vacation with precious time to spare.

Soup dumplings were just okay... Some had absolute no soup some had... The reason why I gave them 1 star is because the waiters were absolutely obnoxious. Can not believe how rude they were. Would not comeback here again.

I'm giving it 3 stars just because i feel that people hyped up the soup dumpling so much for me, and we waited about an hour to be seated, and I thought it was ok.  It was good, don't get me wrong, but I just don't think soup dumplings are my thing.  The  other dishes we got were good.  Glad I crossed it off my list of places to go, but i think i would only go back if I had friends who really want to try it out.

Let me start by saying that I love supporting my fellow Asian restaurants and would prefer to write 5-star reviews but this place is more hype than good or delicious. If NYC patrons really enjoy this restaurant, then they have not truly enjoyed delicious authentic Chinese food. 

Who is Joe? And has be been to Shanghai?
Joe's Shanghai caters to those that like so called soup dumplings that tasted good but aren't delicious.

Joe did get the authentic Chinese service unfortunately of the rude and apathetic servers.

How many times did I have to ask for hot tea for my invited guests? Three times before they got anything hot to drink after coming in from the pouring rain.

We ordered both their pork dumplings and crabmeat pork dumplings but just got the pork ones. UPDATE: Got charged for the crabmeat pork dumplings too and only noticed after I paid :(

We ordered the Shanghai fried rice, Chicken lo mein, Crispy pan-fried noodles with beef, scallion chicken, and string beans saut√©ed in garlic.

Funny thing, the string bean saut√©ed in garlic was the table favorite and it's not even on the menu.

They already know how bad their service is normally that they already included 15% service charge for a table of 4; no signage on their menus or anywhere displayed (Surprise!!)

Food was adequate: 3 stars
Service was sub-par for America: 1 star 
Total: 2 stars

I didn't even want to take any photos as I was utterly disappointed after glowing reviews from someone I should have questioned when it came to Asian cuisine.

Not sure my review will matter to most, but be careful fellow Asian authentic eaters.

Kudo's to Joe for his business acumen to get the NYC masses to dine/takeout there... he's definitely doing something right but didn't do it for me.

Long wait at 9 pm on a Saturday night approx. 35 min. Seating is family style (12 people) which was WEIRD to me, but fun.

Dumplings are 8 for $5, so get a bunch of them. They're pretty money. If I got a do-over, I'd just get a ton of dumplings and call it a night.

I wanted to get a beef and bean curd entree, but I was told it would be a while. Since I was starving, I ordered the beef and broccoli for $11. The generous portion was great, and the food was decent, but nothing more.

It was a good experience, but I won't be coming back. $20 can go way farther with Chinese food.

Eh. I don't get the hype. 

Interior: 3/5
The restaurant may be small but the ambiance sure was busy and loud! It has the family vibe of a dim sum place but for Shanghainese food. Nonetheless, they still had American pop playing near the front of the store. 

Service: 5/5
Surprisingly, we were quickly seated for a party of around 8 on a weekday during lunch hours. Despite the workers rushing around all the tables, they still gave us their undivided attention, taking our orders and picking up empty dishes. 

Food- 
Value: 2/5
They have a large assorted menu but the dishes are pretty expensive for the quality and size! Disappointed. 

Pork Soup Dumplings: 3/5
Compared to other places, the soup is flavorful! They sure pack a plentiful punch in one dumpling! However, that was the only thing that stood out the most to me. Otherwise, they're pretty mediocre. 

Scallion Pancake: 5/5
Soooo good and definitely recommend! Bless they were served super warm and chewy!

Shanghai (?) Pan Fried Noodles w/ Chicken: 2/5
The noodles were...interesting. Had that similar taste to that Chinese rice krispie snack, sachima. 

Pan Fried Noodles w/ Pork: 4/5
These are the noodles I was used to! Oily, but definitely had that fresh off the wok taste that I enjoy! I'd say this is a safe staple to order! 

Beef Rice Cake: 1/5
The rice cakes were such a disappointment! They fall flat, in that they were too soft and floury. I definitely had better elsewhere. 

Service was fast! But other than that, I would not be going back here for their Shanghainese food.

Unfortunately, this place is all hype. I guess I set my expectation level too high when I had heard about this place from friends. I can get better noodles and soup dumplings in Edison. Lots of foot traffic - the place gets very crowded. Cash only and gratuity is already included in the bill. Again, the food is decent; I've just had better. The soup dumplings barely had any soup in them. The ratio for noodles and sauce for the cold noodles was off.

It's  good Chinese . The soup dumplings are tasty. All of the usual Chinese dishes you expect. All of it is good. 
Very crowded but line moves quickly. Slurp up those soup dumplings, and move on. Not much on atmosphere or friendliness.  People still leave happy.

I had to come to one of the most popular soup dumpling restaurants in Chinatown. This place was super crowded on a Saturday evening. We had to wait over an hour to get seated even though the restaurant is pretty large. The service was pretty fast once we got seated.

We ordered the classic pork meat soup dumplings for $8. They were very good and hot. I still don't think they were worth the wait though. There are plenty of soup dumpling restaurants in Chinatown that are just as good. We also got spicy pepper salt calamari for $17 which was good but I wish it was crispier. We also got shanghai egg noodles stir-fried with beef for $17. There were so many noodles and beef.

Overall, the portion size of everything was large, but I don't think the food was amazing compared to other food available around it. There are so many good restaurants with no wait in Chinatown.

theres a lot of hype for this place but for some reason i thought it was just ok. the line to get in is totally ridiculous. we waited for about an hour wc is totally fine with me. the line of people waiting outside was crazy! and when they call out someones number people jump up and cheer like they just won the lottery. hahaha. it was funny. 
inside, its a typical chinese restaurant. lazy susans galore. the pork and crab soup dumplings were good but not like oh emm gee amazing. tasted like any other dumpling ive had. and the other dishes we had like gen tsaos chicken and i think sweet and sour chicken were also alright. same as any chinese place. so overall i thought it was a pretty average chinese restaurant. idk if its wortht he long line outside.

Heard about this place many time from friends and family so finally decided to try out during my trip to NYC.

Even though we were told that the wait would be about 15 min.  We ended up waiting for 45 min.  Later, I was told by others that this was actually not bad for a party of 6.
People with a party of 2 seemed to be getting their tables way before us.  

As soon as we sat down after 45 minute-wait, we were told to hurry up and order because food'll take long time to come out.  Well, food came out pretty fast.  We realized, they just wanted people to hurry up and order, eat and leave so they can sit the next customers.

Ordered the famous soup dumplings - 2 different kind.  It was okay.  It wasn't spectacular in any sense.  It was just so so.  Other food items were just okay too.  

Scallion Pancake and Eggplant with Garlic Sauce were actually pretty good.
Shanghai noodle soup was so salty.
Moo shu pork and kung pao chicken were mediocre.

Don't know why this place is so popular and packed.  It was just plain ol chinese restaurant.  Oh well, live and learn.  

I would probably not visit this place again because food was mediocre and service is pretty much non-existent.

Waited too long for a mostly average Chinese "tourist" menu. Soup dumplings, the house specialty, were hit or miss on this most recent visit (half our double order were dry inside). Fast & friendly service once you're finally seated, but count the change carefully when paying your cash-only bill. The restaurant's "ego wall" collage of reviews and kudos is sadly dated and out-of--touch with the present tense.
I didn't enjoy the food overall.  Maybe the Singapore Rice Noodle dish was the best of the items ordered.  Most lacked taste.
Completely average, nothing to rave about and certainly not worth the newly found long waits due to yelp overhype. The soups dumplings are good but not worth waiting for.

The crab and pork soup dumplings are great.  The skins are very thin and lots of delicious savory soup to slurp up.  However, the other dishes were mediocre and greasy. The shredded beef had 2/3 celery and carrots, and barely a 1/3 beef.  The seafood fried noodles had a gooey dark sauce instead the usual light white sauce.  It was disappointing. So, really the only thing I would order here are the soup dumplings.

We came here because of many recommendations from friends who live in the city. Coming from Toronto, I guess I'm pretty spoiled in terms of authentic chinese food. I found the dumplings are very delicious and well done. We felt rushed though. The waiter basically was hurrying us along to order then threw us the bill the moment we finished eating. It was a bit unpleasant. Not sure if I will ever come back here again when I visit NYC

If you lived in California and like Din Tai Fung then don't bother coming here !

Overall service is 2 stars with surprisingly good service as American standard place.

I used to come here during college and once in a while after college.  At the time, the soup dumplings here seemed to be unrivaled by competitors and had no equal.  I came here two weeks ago looking to redeem myself from what had to be the 'worst.xlb.ever.'in Chicago.  It had been three years since my last visit to Joe's Shanghai and the wait for a seat was still as long as ever, but would the food still be as good?

I have to tell you, the food wasn't as good as I remembered.  The xiao long baos weren't as steaming hot and soupy as they were in the past.  Even the dumpling skin seemed to be lacking.  I think we have a serious quality control problem here.  They weren't as bad as the ones I had in Chicago's Chinatown, but still, average at best.  Maybe since this place is so established with tourists, it no longer has to try as hard.  I am greatly disappointed.  Even the tong cai greens I ordered were disappointing.  Half of the greens were wilted.

If I ever visit NY's Chinatown again and want XLB, I know where not to go.  For you locals, it's not worth the wait, go somewhere else.  I now dub this place tourist trap!

I think I had much higher expectations given the reviews. The soup dumplings were good, but I had better dumplings elsewhere. As other reviewers stated, many of the dumplings leaked even before we tried to lift. The dumplings are bigger than other places, which actually makes it harder to eat and fit in the spoon. Having said that, all their portions are generous and prices are very reasonable, so no complaints there. The salt pepper pork is very salty; the scallion pancakes are very good though. All in all, a pretty decent meal at a reasonable price. Cash only, gratuities are included to the bill.

The queuing system is a complete mess. We were told that our wait would be an hour. When they called our number, they asked if everyone is here yet. We said not yet, and they told us that they would not give us the table until everyone is here. Once we have everyone, we asked again how much longer is the wait. The girl told us another hour. That was after we waited for an hour!  No apology or whatsoever. Staff are rude. We saw other parties coming in and checking on their waiting time, and many of them also complained that they have already waited for an hour or so, and were told to wait for another hour.

Go somewhere else unless you have the whole day standing in line, and make sure your whole party is here.

Food is average, you can get better dumpling somewhere else

Food was mediocre at best. Everything we ordered was greasy (crab and pork soup dumplings and the worst string beans I've ever had). Shanghai noodles were the only decent thing we had. Don't waste your time at this tourist trap.
Soup dumplings were good but not great - the skin was a bit too thick and dry. Don't order their fried dumplings or cong you bing; they're really greasy and ordinary.

The line is always super long for this place but that's okay. I waited about 10 minutes for a table for 2. Though the food was quickly served the only downside about this place is the waiters are super rude and they honestly don't give a damn.
Please change your business hours. It says 11pm but I arrived at 9:50pm and was turned away

Not sure what the hype is all about. People who raved about their XLB, probably never had DTF, which still holds the best XLB in my opinion.  We ordered the pork and crab dumplings. The dumpling's skin was too thick, and it was way too big. The soup inside of the crab dumpling was greasy. I was not impressed at all, I've had better, way better.

Came here before noon on Friday and expected to wait. But we were seated as right away. Not even gonna mention service because I'm in Chinatown so I don't expect any. Thank goodness we didn't have to wait. Otherwise, I felt I would be ripped off in taste and time!

Semi-authentic, Americanized Chinese food. I ordered Kung Pao Chicken and it was great. Wife and kids ordered General Tso and sesame chicken and there wasn't much chicken in it, mostly batter. The hot and sour soup was awesome! They only take cash. It was pretty expensive, especially for lunch. I would probably walk around and try a place with less than $9 lunch menus outside and try that.
This place is toristy trap, foods okay, service could be better. They seem to want to rush you out of there, definitely not a place for catching up with peeps.

I have been eating here for 20 years. Today the soup dumplings were off, they were cold and had little flavor. On top of that prices went up on dumplings and beer. They charge 15% tip and then tax you on 15% tip. Doesn't seem legal. 
Very disappointed today and very sick at stomach this evening.
Classic Americanized Chinese food. Decent soup dumplings but worth stopping in if you're looking for good Chinese in Manhattan!

I have mixed feelings about this place. Bear with me...


The wait wasn't long and they're quick to get you seated. You will be seated with other people, so fair warning. This doesn't bother me as I've dined in places like this before. When you're given the menu, you feel a bit rushed. I wasn't sure about some menu items, so as I questioned the waiter he seemed annoyed that I wasn't familiar with the dishes. He then brought me a menu with pictures so I was able to order. All the items come family style, so 2 people can easily share a meal. My husband had ordered the crispy duck, which the waiter forgot to enter. All the food came out little by little which was irritating because some people finished before others. What's worse, when the food came out I kindly asked the waiter which chicken this was and he ignored me. The reason I asked him was because he placed it in front of the wrong person. I asked another waiter and he was also irritated by my question. We ordered a fried rice to share which came out at the end. 

The food was delicious. I had the Shanghai beef noodles, my daughter had the sesame chicken which was also amazing, and my dad had the crispy beef. The pork fried rice was out of this world. The kung pao chicken wasn't all that great, it was our least favorite. Can't tell you how the crispy duck was. We also ordered the pork soup dumplings as an appetizer to share and they were delicious. 

So food = above average. Service = sucked. If it wasn't for the crappy service, I would rate this place 4 stars. They were extremely rude and I left dinner really irritated. Hope this helps.

Not to much I can add to what has already been said about this place.  Yes, the Soup Dumplings are outstanding and a must have.  I have had them twice...once to go (not the easiest thing to eat while walking but we managed) and once at a sit down.  Typical Chinatown communal dining.  The night we ate there, we shared a table with a couple from LA and their local hosts who were kind enough to offer us taste of their dishes when we admired them. The shanghai casserole was excellent and the salt and pepper shrimp were just about perfect.  But be forewarned, this place gets crowded  and there is often a wait.  Which only means..its worth it!

Went for Father's Day which probably contributed to a lower rating since I wanted to have a conversation with my Dad which did not involve a bunch of strangers - seating is "family style".  Waiters are quick (efficient) but do not adhere to convention when serving - had their arm in front of my face more than once.  Food itself is okay but nothing spectacular.  I had noodles with peanut sauce - too much peanut.  Beef and green beans - less meat, more beans (though they were good).  Steamed crab dumplings were supposed to be "amazing".  I was not amazed.
Soup dumplings are tasty, but the rest of the fare is nothing special.

Such a disappointment. Soup dumplings were too fatty and the meat wasn't good. Pan fried noodles were really gross and there was mold on some of the vegetables. They also pre-included the tip in the bill. Shanghai cafe is 100 times better!!! SHANGHAI CAFE for the win.
this is a worst restaurant . the food very very salty and the server so bad. I never come here again

Pork soup dumplings were flavorful and there was a decent amount of soup in the dumplings. I thought the skins were a little thick compared to what I'm used to in San Francisco. The soup was good though. I haven't had it at any other NY restaurants so I can't really compare it to anywhere else in NY. But, I can say that it was good. 

It makes me want to get some when I get back to SF after my trip! 

But overall, a decent experience. 

Tip: If you dont want to wait, order for pick-up and eat the order outside fresh! (what we did) Definitely was just as good as in a bustling restaurant. And if you want to eat at the restaurant, be prepared to wait. There were plenty of people waiting. So, start heading over before you're hungry to compensate the wait.

I wish I had done more research and realized that the dim sum (and all other plates for that matter) cannot be ordered in small portions here. So, we had the crab and pork soup dumplings because that seemed to be the must-have there. We would not have known how to eat them had we not been seated at an 8 top with a party of 6 Japanese tourists who seemed to know how to enjoy these pockets of fun. You use the soup spoon to take them out of the large bamboo steamer, pour the black vinegary sauce sitting on the table over them, then use your chopsticks to puncture them and let the rich broth drip onto your spoon. YUM! We also had some noodles that our waiter 9not the nicest guy on the planet) claimed to be the special (first ones on the menu) and they were good, not mindblowing. A couple of Shing Tao beers and that was enough food for the both of us. If you don't require super friendly service or refuse to sit with other people and not in the mood to sample lots of smaller plates and have CASH, then you might like this place. Next time we're in Chinatown, we'll look for cart service which I saw is actually a filter in Yelp!

I'm wavering between 2 and 3 stars but I'll stick with the 3 because I actually enjoyed the salt and pepper pork chops and green onion pancakes (not what they're known for).  This a just OK restaurant and I know there are better options in this same vicinity.  I think this is a perfect example of the downfalls of being a restaurant that's heavily listed in Trip Advisor, Travel books (Lonely Planet) and food blogs.  They are very advertised and the quality of the food is just not there, especially with their most famous XLBs.

We ordered their famous pork xiao long bao (shanghai soup dumplings) as well as the salt and pepper pork chops and green onion pancakes.  The XLBs are quite large but the skins were tough, the soup inside was thick and greasy and the meat was not as flavorful as I hoped.  We were sat with another couple at our table and without expressing our feelings, they let us know that they've had better dumplings in other places as well.  But, despite my disappointment, I do admit that I very much enjoyed their salt and pepper pork chops.  They were crunchy, hot and well flavored.  The green onion pancakes were also very well prepared and ate every single piece.  But, unfortunately people aren't looking for these items and would have to say you should look to other places for XLBs. 

Nearby I would recommend walking just a couple of blocks away to Shanghai Cafe (http://www.yelp.com/biz/shanghai-caf%C3%A9-new-york-2 although there are many other terrific options in Flushing.

Really deserves 3 out of 5. 
Don't go there expecting too much or you'll be sorely disappointed... 
Also do try the red bean dessert!

The soup dumplings are legit. There's a reason why there's always 30+ people standing outside waiting to eat. The rest of the food, however, is comparable to your local Chinese delivery joint. Gorge yourself on dumplings and skip everything else.
