Over hyped and over priced.  We ordered many dishes.  None of them were special. They were average to bad.  Noticed there were no Asian customers except us.

Tourist restaurant = long lines = long wait time

Pros:
-Come here for the the pork soup dumplings. All the other dishes are mediocre - you can get it at almost any authentic Chinese restaurant close to half the price.

Cons:
-Due to the long lines, they rush you out of the place. So if you're trying to have a group gathering and need to chat - this is NOT the place to go. 
-Weird seating arrangements
-Pricey compared to nearby restaurants

2 FOR FLAVOR! Minus 3 stars for cleanliness and service.

The place is carpeted and stinks like mildew and dirty feet, and the restaurant overall is FILTHY, as well as what you can see of the kitchen from the bathroom line. I know Chinatown doesn't have exactly the best reputation for cleanliness, but a touristy place like this really has no excuse.

Our server seemed completely annoyed with us, and we were very straight forward and were an easy group. You also will have to share a table w other people - something to be aware of.

The soup dumplings were good, and the shirmp on top of crispy noodle was also delicious!
I wouldn't say they are using the best quality of ingredients, but it's tasty.

I've been to Joe's Shanghai a few times years ago but stopped going because of the long wait.  (FYI - the Joe's Ginger down the street is operated by the same people/owner, and on par with Joe's SH in terms of food quality if not better.  I always go there since it's usually a much shorter wait and a LOT less tourists.)  Recently we took our visiting friend there, since her friends in california all recommended her to try Joe's SH.  As expected, there was a line and we waited about 45 min.  They placed the 5 of us on a big round table, which we had to share with another group of 4.  I'm not a big fan of sharing tables, but had to comply since we were all starving and didn't want to wait another half an hr for our own table.

We ordered both pork soup dumplings and crab flavored soup dumplings.  They came out decent - hot and steamy and definitely had a lot of soup inside the buns.  However the skin/peel isn't great, still a bit on the thick side.  We ordered a few other Shanghainese dishes (I grew up in Shanghai), including a fish head casserole, braised pork shoulder, and a few other veggie dishes, but none of them were amazing.  Especially the braised pork shoulder - it's supposed to be juicy and flavorful, but it came out to be extremely dry and hard to chew.  It was almost like eating pork jerky.  Not cool.  Don't think I'll be back again any time soon.

Longstanding Chinese restaurant doling out favorites in a cafeteria-like atmosphere. Saturday afternoon, was able to get a seat at a large communal table without any wait. 

Most of the main dishes are on the expensive side as they are family-style. Since I didn't have a family with me, I opted instead for the Spring Roll ($2.75) and the Pork Soup Dumplings ($8). While waiting, you are served green tea that's piping hot and good for the stomach. Spring roll is served with a side of soy sauce and stuffed with shrimp and pork. Found it to be overly greasy and not well balanced. The flavor of the shrimp was the saving grace. Soup dumplings come shortly after, several steamed pieces served with soy sauce and ginger. Again, flavor is a little dull - could have used some more spices for the added kick. Towards the last few the dumplings got much colder, so didn't finish the last two.

Servers come around often to make sure they get people in and out quickly. Not a fan of the automatic gratuity to go along with cash-only policies (especially since the main courses are more expensive).

Came here bc of number of reviews but was underwhelmed unfortunately....it was packed yet the quality of what we had was overrated.

I had Gen Tso chicken 
Fried rice
Pork soup dumplings 
Spicy shrimp 

All were just good, with number of reviews we expected to see Jesus walk on water. 

We had to share a table with two other parties, which was fine...

I've had better quality taste, texture, freshness from my local Chinese takeout place in Palm Beac

COUNT YOUR CHANGE!!!!  The cashier tried to stiff the person ahead of me.  He gave the cashier $20.00.  The bill was under $10.  She gave him $3 change.  He complained and thereafter she gave him the correct change.

I went to pay for my take out meal and handed a $20.00 bill.  My meal was about $6.80.  I was handed $3.20.  I told the cashier that I handed her a $20.00.  She chuckled and gave me back an additional $10.00.

Businesses like this can't last too long when they really couldn't care less who is behind the cash register.

2+ hr wait? No thank you.

GO NEXT DOOR TO JOE'S GINGER!!! Virtually no wait and, surprise, its owned by the same owner as Joe's Shanghai!

Besides, J Shanghai's dumplings are overrated: oily soups and thick, chewy skin. Be adventurous and check out more unknown places in the neighborhood; theyre guaranteed to be better.
Price gouging !! Price went up 30% within 2 years not going here anymore. They illegally add 18% tip for a party of 4 and try to mask it by calling it a service charge.

Having grown up in LA, I've had more than my fair share of Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings) and Shanghainese food. I was really disappointed and expected more from this place considering the crowd and the reviews! 

Came here on a Friday night around 8pm. Huge crowd outside the door with a 40 minute wait time. Luckily for a party of 2, it was a little faster so we got in within 20-30 minutes. Like the other reviews have mentioned, smaller parties get put into communal tables. 

We had an order of xiao long bao, scallion pancake and pan fried noodles with chicken. The dumplings were good but definitely not the best I've had (If you're ever in LA you need to go to Din Tai Fung). The scallion pancakes were probably the best thing. The pan fried noodles were not at all what I was expecting and it ended up taking 20 minutes AFTER we had finished the dumplings for them to come out. 

Not surprising the service wasn't great (based on other reviews we didn't expect it to be) and the place was dirty and cramped. I'm not picky on locale so long as the food is authentic. This place is decent BUT definitely overrated. I would consider going back but not until after I've tried a few other place to decide if it really is "the best in the city."

Don't forget: cash only!
The soup dumplings here are good, but not great. The other aspects of eating here (e.g. long line) make it not really worth it.
Definitely overrated. XLB's are thick skinned and the broth is just grease. Rest of the food's passable but can hardly be considered Shanghainese.

I know, this is on every NY list. Take the visitors. Show off the amazing Shanghainese cuisine. But honestly, I've had so many better soup dumpling that maybe I'm not doing this right.

It's fine, and challenging the conventional wisdom is risky, but I'm still waiting to see what's so incredible here. Perhaps I need to keep trying (I will). Maybe it peaked already and is coasting downhill for a bit?But my impression has been that you can do a lot better.
Great soup dumplings! Didn't really enjoy the fried rice and other entrees we ordered.

When I got into the restaurant, I knew there was something wrong. The restaurant was full but over 90% of customers were not Chinese. This kind of restaurant is usually over-rated by those non-Chinese customers who have never been to China. As a Chinese, I know only those restaurants with over 50% Chinese customers are worth the visit. 
But I still tried their best selling food - soup dumplings. It was good but not excellent. I would have given them 3 stars based on the soup dumplings. But the other foods we ordered were so disappointing. The turnip cake was bad and the fried noodle was very very very horrible.
I hope the post can give a warning to other Chinese customers. I know the non-Chinese customers enjoy the food. My comments might not be valid to them.

Had to try the Pork Xiao Long Bao and I must say...it was good!! I can't say it's THE BEST but definitely tasty. I'm actually not a big fan of dumplings like that but I decided to give it a try since everyone was talking about it. Definitely was a good and I'm coming back tommorw before I head home just for the XLB. Turnip cake was not good at all. Try the fried pork, it was actually good as well. It winter right now so good gets cold easily so I wish the pork stayed hot longer but the flavor was good. Had the Crab & Pork Bao too and it's very similar tasting to the pork. I would get both to try and taste the difference. Pricing is very affordable $5.95 for their XLB. "Service Charge" AKA tip is already added to the bill.  Service is crappy as in almost any Asian restaurant in Chinatown so I wasn't expecting much per usual but I thought it was funny. Kinda rushed us out so they can get the next crowd in. Again expected I guess.

I'm done with this place. It's been mediocre for quite a few years but today the best of the dishes (salt & pepper shrimp; pork soup dumplings) could most charitably be described as mediocre, while the rest of it (scallops & prawns with garlic sauce; kung pao chicken) was revolting. The scallops & prawns was particularly disgusting -- salty and fishy tasting to the point of being inedible and, at $31, a rip-off. What's nastier than foul-tasting, stanky seafood?  This place has gone from good (in the 1990s and 00s), to hit-or-miss, to consistently mediocre, to consistently bad.

I've probably eaten here over 100 times since it first opened in the 1990s. The wait staff used to be friendly and the food was pretty good. It's mostly gross now and I have no desire to eat there again.

The most expensive Shanghainese food in Chinatown, and yet not the best , I live in Chinatown and ate there once with my friends. Never again , at that time they even charge you for the tea, (the only Shanghainese restaurant in Chinatown that charge ) 
Most of their customers are tourist , you don't see locals eating there.
came for the soup dumplins. we did a take out order, so they suffered a little, not a lot of soup bu they come with the authentic black vinegar

Coming from the SF Bay Area with tons of yummy Asian food, I have to say Joe's Shanghai is definitely waaay over-rated. 

We ordered the Pork & Crab XLB - I took one bite and couldn't finish.  The flavor was meh.  The dumpling filling did not taste fresh, but instead was super fishy in my opinion.    

We also ordered some veggies (kong xin cai) and the cold sesame noodles.  The veggies were okay/standard.  The noodles were luke warm and texture wise were kind of mooshy.  

Considering this place had 4000 reviews, 4+ stars, I was expecting some damn good Chinese food or at least some yummy XLB.  Sad to say, Joe's Shanghai was way below expectations.

Living in Chinatown throughout all my life I'm pretty sure I can identify which restaurants are authentic and which restaurants aren't. Joes Shanghai has been one of the most overrated places ever. Im glad the restaurant is doing well and I hope they continue their success. Many of the local people in Chinatown usually don't eat here because it doesn't taste as good as other Shanghai restaurants and the line here is just long. I can name you 3 other shanghai restaurants in Chinatown that taste 10x better! Sorry Joes, I don't like the restaurant but I don't hate it as well.

I hope that you've been able to enjoy Joe's Shanghai in the past when their soup dumplings were amazing because sadly their popularity has gotten the better of them and they're simply not of the same quality.  You used to have to wait because the soup dumplings were made fresh but even if you sat and waited 20 minutes you waited eagerly knowing you were in a for a delight.  However, the soup dumplings are pre-made now so they really aren't the same.  

I used to go to Joe's and stuff myself with a dozen dumplings and walk around in a happy food coma as their soupy goodness filled my being.  Unfortunately, after having their dumplings recently I don't think I'd bother ever again.

To be honest, from all these reviews I thought this place was going to be AMAZING. It was just okay.. 

Got the shanghai dumplings, pork dumplings, greenbeans, and some noodle dish.. I don't remember the name because it was that bland.

It was nothing special for all the hype.

Being a soup dumpling fan, read Joe's Shanghai's positive reviews and decided to check it out with a friend, new to them. Ordered the Crab and Pork Soup Dumplings  (a.k.a. Xiao Long Baos) which were extremely big. That being said, their huge size, the inadequately sized spoon and lack of bowl to eat them over made them difficult and sloppy to get down. The flavor also did not match those of the recently closed former Grand Sichuan on W 24th & 9th - where their's was one of my favorites.

We also ordered half a Peking duck, which was served with half the boneless meat with skin on one plate, the boned meat on another, a small saucer of sauce, four pancakes to wrap, plus a plate of scallion and cucumbers. The slices on the boneless plate were more skin and fat than meat. The boned meat place required a lot of work. More importantly the sauce and pancakes were inadequate given the level of meat. It required about 6-8 pancakes for the half and a larger bowl with sauce. Paying for any extra pancakes, given the level of duck, seems not right given the price.

If you're longing for soup dumplings, there has to be better places out there in NYC.

ALERT! - Be aware of the automatic "Service Fee" they add to your bill - even for parties of 2 - if you don't want to double tip!

from a recommendation, we took our parents to joe's shanghai to eat the infamous dumplings. honestly, it was just ok. it wasn't a horrible experience and the food was okay--i just don't think the food was so amazing that it warranted the almost hour wait. the crispy beef however was quite delicious!

The place was too crowded. We knew the food was gonna be good but there isn't a really good energy because people are just constantly watching you eat, waiting for you to get out of your seat. It was pretty stressful eating here, especially with the tight spaces, and the waiter barely came to our table, which wasn't too great.

We went a second time and after 20 minutes, just ended up going to Shanghai Gourmet down the street. It was smaller but ten times better in experience and the food was priced at an awesome bargain for the value we got.

First time I came here: Soup dumplings were fantastic.

That was two years ago. Revisited this place with a relative who isn't from New York so I thought I'd take her here. The dumplings weren't fresh, the dumpling skin was overly floury and stale and the broth was not so great.

Annoying wait in smelly ass Chinatown. 

What happened to THIS PLACE

I love Xiao Long Bao (Shanghainese soup dumplings)... but Joe's was just ok - good/not bad for if you're craving, but nothing worth crazy fanfare. 

For a party of 2 who came around 1PM, we got seated almost instantly but at a communal 10-person round table. This is no high class dining establishment... here you sit, you eat, you pay, and you leave - its a well oiled machine with fast (and too focused to pay attention to service) servers to match.

We got an order of pan fried pork dumplings, cold noodles in sesame sauce, and pork soup dumplings. Fried dumplings were standard, the noodles were nothing special, and imo the xlb falls short of LA's Din Tai Fung... The broth was nice and hot, but the skin and meat didn't wow me... My fave US XLB still goes to SF's Shanghai Dumpling King, but when in NY, I suppose Joe's is worth a go if you're looking for xiao long bao.
Horrible service, food was great but the service just made the visit horrible. So if you want horrible service but great food then by all means food is great.

Look- I love a hype. I know it is usually overrated but I still love restaurants that are hyped up. I find them fun. 

I walked into Joe's solo and got seated right away (SHOCK) I have been to nyc many times and eaten many different kinds of soup dumplings but never at Joe's. FINALLY I GOT TO TRY JOE'S.

I went in, got the chicken on the special list and also the soup dumps. The dumps are big. They are not soupy inside but more gravy like. While hot it was not bad, when it got room temp. It was actually kind of gross. The chicken was actually really good. Everything was on the expensive side, but like I said- I like a hype and am use to the price. 

I am giving one star because I really didn't like the soup dumplings... Like I would avoid them to be honest. The chicken was good but the rice was burnt! How can a Chinese place have burnt rice??? I didn't love the place. I am totally fine with bad service if that is the vibe of the place, but for these prices it is sort of not okay. 

Okay what really ticked me is they added an 18% service charge. I don't mind. I usually tip higher then that regardless so no big deal. I left another few dollars because that was the change I had. 

The treated me awful after I left the tip and even yeah "hey!" super meanly when I tried to leave. I turned around and asked if something was wrong? He said "oh nothing." Then in Chinese I heard him bitch about my tip.... I am so confused. I googled and googled to see if there was an extremely high 18% service tax in nyc and if I was suppose to tip more? I asked my nyc friends. No one understands what happened....

Look- I would not skip this place because again I love a hype but the soup dumplings really aren't that good.

The food is outstanding. But the servers were so rude they killed all my mood both the times I was there. My friend tried to order a wonton soup once, and I think they misheard her somehow, the server told her to order something from the menu.
The second time we went there, we tried to order a spicy soup. In the bottom of every page of the menu says that we can modify the spiciness, so we said "make it not too spicy please". Though I showed them the words printed in the menu, they argued with us, told us to order something else that is not spicy at all because "they can't do that". 

This place is tourist-packed, too. I wish they were just a little nicer, because I do come back to places for the pleasant service they provide.
i think it's a lil over-rated. i like the other local joints and their xiao long bao. not big about sharing tables.

Considering the wait and hype around this spot, it barely lived up to its expectation. I came in here on a Monday afternoon with a party of 2 and we were seated in about 10 minutes (not bad but other parties had to wait about 20-35 minutes). Ofc we had already planned out what to order. Pork soup dumplings, crab and pork soup dumplings, and Shanghai thick noodles. For a place that specializes in XLB's I expected to get the food in a matter of a few minutes. Over 10 minutes later our soup dumplings came and I'm not sure if it's just me but I'm not a big fan of the bok choi under the soup dumplings (I think they're used to prevent the dumplings from sticking to the traditional paper that other places use so the dumplings won't break upon contact). They get stuck on the dumplings and taste bland. The dumplings itself were alright (definitely had better in flushing and even the neighboring 21 Shanghai). The crab soup dumplings were stuffed very densely and was definitely better IMO than the pork soup dumplings. The Shanghai noodles were nothing special (very greasy too). The bill came out about 29 for 2 people so it's definitely not too pricey but was it worth the hype and wait? Naaaaah

Allow me to tell you that I am never coming back here again. As much as I love xiao long biao, the fact that you actually came back and demanded I pay you the fucking 11 cents that I was short from the 15% TIP was WAYYYYYYYYY too much for me to handle. 

Not to mention the complete lack of real chinese food. Hunan/sesame chicken?  Overly salted string beans? Overpriced and NOT worth even 5 bucks in my book.

Good bye.

Good soup dumplings are hard to come by in The Netherlands, so I made sure to pay this place a visit on my US trip. We came here right before opening time on a Sunday and managed to snatch the only table for two (next to the entrance and a Halloween-decorated fish tank). The food was ordered quickly (waiters do speak English if necessary) and then the waiting game started. 

The first dish that came out were the Shanghai noodles (~12 min). Oily but yummy. Then the scallion pancakes. Also pretty good. And lastly, 20 min after we ordered, the pork soup dumplings. Don't they have some of these steaming before they open, knowing everyone will want them? 

The dumplings are big, they won't fit in your spoon without overspilling. The dough was thicker than I'm used to. And they sure are soupy. Verdict: meh, I've had better. 

All in all, okay place to get your soup dumpling fix but only if there's no line.

It's been my understanding this place has turned more into a tourist trap than a venerable food place. That's probably true since we shared a round table with two groups of Frenchies.

However, it's undeniable that their food is still cheap and good.  Their hearty soup dumplings are twice the size of Ding Tai Fong's but they win because 1) You can never get any at DTF due to limited availability and 2) You pay more for less there.  DTF definitely has a more refined product but if you want down and dirty, Joe's is the place to be.

We also had their green onion pancake - greasy but good - and their zasai and mustard green noodles.  The default noodles were mushy and had no bite but the broth was tasty, though not complex or rich like that which is used in Japanese ramen.

Service is brisk and the place COULD be cleaner.  But like the mom and kid who also shared a table with us, you can get out of there full spending less than $10.  SERVICE CHARGE OF 15% IS ALREADY INCLUDED IN EVERYONE'S TAB!!! (another sign of a tourist trap)

Soup dumplings were good. Shanghai noodles were way too greasy, but they always are. 

Ugh the low reviews are because they charge a mandatory gratuity, doesn't matter how big your party is and the waitstaff are not pleasant. It's like they know they are getting tipped no matter what so why try to be a nice server.

This is a well-known restaurant for Soup Dumplings, so there will always be a long line outside waiting for a table. If you come in a small group, most likely you will end up sharing a table with some people. I didn't think their soup dumplings were that great.  They were VERY greasy. Also, I don't like the seating arrangements. Another issue we encountered was that we found TWO HAIRS in our food (and in separate dishes)!. One thick greasy hair was in the center of our rice cake dish, and another one was actually WRAPPED INSIDE of a soup dumpling.  It was gross! We won't eat in here again.
Not so hot. Pricey and long wait. Servers are hard to understand. Soup dumpling--I had better on the west coast.

I've been here 2 times now- once a few years ago and once tonight.  I think the soup dumplings used to be bigger!! But- they seem a little more authentic now.  This place has the soup-iest dumplings I have ever had! And I've had a lot of them- in Shanghai, in CA, at Din Tai Fung in both China and the US.  The pork ones are better than the crab ones.  Save your money and don't splurge on crab. They're meh. 

I didn't think the rest of their food spectacular.  Their beef noodle soup is decent- I like the noodles!  I love ham and winter melon soup so when I saw it on the menu, of course I ordered it.  What came out was TOTALLY not what I expected.  The Shanghai-nese version of this soup is a clear broth with large chunks of winter melon and small slices of virginia ham.  What they served was some mixture of egg drop soup, with frozen peas and carrots, luncheon meat, and small cubes of winter melon.  I mean it wasn't terrible I suppose, but it definitely was not what I was craving.  The scallion pancakes were ok- a little too greasy and over fried but the sweet soy dipping sauce bit was a nice touch.  

Don't expect to have a private meal here, or even your own table.  Both times I've been, we've been seated at a communal table with others.  It's really not that bad though.  Sometimes it's fun to talk to other people.  Tonight, we were the only Chinese people at the table and someone we got all our food first and started chomping down.  It was a little awkward when the rest of the table was just staring at us eating while hungrily envying us but such is life.  Pays to be Chinese sometimes! 

I would go back but maybe just stick to eating soup dumplings and maybe the beef noodle soup (which is only about $5 for a good sized bowl!).

These three stars were for the food.
Good food but terrible service. Some wOne of the guy looks like to be the supervisor give me attitude when asked for help saying why would I ask him to collet the empty dish while there's another waiter was around? How would I know who's serving me especially he's the one place my orders for food, so I assumed I can ask for help from him.

Went here instead of my usual place Shanghai Asian Manor, and I was so disappointed with the food quality. The meat in the soup dumplings was full of gristle and made them hard to eat. Also ordered the General Tso's chicken and I honestly can't say with confidence that the meat was chicken. Go to Shanghai Asian Manor instead!

waited for way too long even though we put our names down (2h?)
food was good, got crispy veg noodles, dumplings, and green beans
did not get orange slices at the end :(
wouldn't get the crispy noodles again, beans were standard, and so were dumplings. 
would not wait again

Overrated.  
Tried their crab and pork dumplings with scallion pancake. Too salty and very greasy. 
:/

Place is very crowded. We had to ask people who were eating to get up from their seats to get to ours.
Waiters were behaving like they had a train to catch. He was in such a hurry to take our order that he had to come back two times to ask what exactly we ordered.
Talking about the food. It seems like they get a lot of oil and broccoli for free. Our food was full of it. At the end we felt like that's all we hate. 
All in all for the amount of reviews this place has and the stars it has for us it was below average. 
I would not visit this place again unless something dramatically changed.

For the money he food was ok. The portions were a good size and the God was very good quality. However the meals don't come with rice or fortune cookies but they do give you tea. The staff was really nice as well.

The food was good. We had the pork soup dumplings, pork fried rice and General Tso chicken.  I'm undecided about the soup dumplings. The rice and chicken tasted fresher than the local neighborhood spots but all in all it was a bit average.  The customer service was what you'll find I believe in most restaurants in the area. Typically no one is particularly friendly but not necessarily rude, they just get you in and get you out. I'd give the spot another try to sample other items on the menu. Oh and FYI seating is shared I suppose unless you have a large enough party to fill an entire table.

I can't really decide between 3 or four stars... so 3.5?

I bookmarked Joe's shanghai after hearing from numerous friends on the west coast that this is a must try.

I live in LA is surrounded by Ding Tai Fung devotees.. here and there i hear from people that Joe's Shanghai is better..so I had to give it a try.

On a monday night around 8pm the place was packed. No reservations walk ins only. My friend arrived early and was able to grab a number (although they won't seat you until you're entire party is there).

Given how popular this place is, it's likely you'll be sharing a table with another party..which is kind of odd.. not my favorite way of dining with strangers right across the table from you.

Anyhow, the staff was quick to serve us..but it took them forever to request for anything else. Boo.

For the three of us we ordered the following

2x of the pork XLB
-they were definitely bigger than what i'm use to.
-upon biting the xlb, be careful! This particular one has lots of stock (soup) inside and it can get quite messy
-for me the skin (wrapping) was a tad bit too thick to my liking
-the meat was good and had good flavor, but the texture was a tad bit too mushy for my liking

scallion (green onion) pancake
-too oily! but some people like it this way
-not crispy enough for my taste buds

garlic saut√©ed green beans
-this i liked..and probably enjoyed the most.

So.. was it better than the SoCal contenders? eh.. Although the price was comparable ( a bit cheaper actually) I think in terms of the XLB i enjoy those at DTF(which isn't amazing either and overhyped as well) a bit more. It's more delicate and the flavor and texture combos work better. 

For that alone, I would probably say that the XLB places in CA are a better option, but of course..this is just MY opinion. 

Test it out with your tastebuds..and see how you feel.

*cash only

Place is known for their soup dumplings but it's just another Chinatown locale.  Just tasty, greasy, Chinese food.  The place is fairly dirty, needs to clean up a bit but what do you expect for Chinatown!  I would still recommend going there over other Chinese restaurants.

this place is allllllll hypeeeee. totally a tourist spot. super disappointed. first of all, the dumplings didnt even look authentic. they were wayyyyy bigger than what they should look like. second, half of our dumplings broke when we picked up. they all stuck on the bottom. WTF!??@?@?!?!?!!!!!!!!! the taste was jus ok. we also order KAO FU, which is one of the most famous shanghai appetizer. ewwwwwwww, grooossss. ive experienced better even in boston. dun even compare to shanghai's soup dumplings. not even close. super long line, full of white ppl that dunno any better. if you see full of white ppl at any asian places, you should immediately know it's bad. avoid at all cost.

I don't get it. The service was bad. The food quality was horrendous. The wait was long. Everyone said my dish was the best and I thought it was gross.. can't imagine how bad their food must have tasted. 

The Emperor Has No Clothes!

This is where I feel in love with soup dumplings. And I must say they're dumplings areg ood, but I can't compare too many places though considering it was my first time having them. Got the crab and pork and another order of just pork. It was full of soup and flavor. And the dipping sauce was great.  Also got the turnip shortcake and it was crunchy and juicy.

The Singapore noodles wasn't exactly what I expected. I wasn't too fond of the flavor. I say stick to the dumplings.

It gets pretty packed and busy. They only have huge round tables so if you're not a big group you more likely share a table with a family or two. I think it's nice to talk and meet new people. Sat next to a woman who lead an interesting life. Traveled around the world and lives in the upper east side. You never know who you'll meet.

Came here with Boo Boo after work on a Friday night. We we're lucky to be seated right away because it was just two. Unfortunately, we got seated at the small table by the entrance. 

We shared an order of soup dumplings, sesame noodles and scallion pancake. The pancake was way too greasy and may be commercially made. The noodles was okay but needed something. The soup dumplings we're good but I wanna say I'm not a fan of them. 

Boo Boo entree was salt and pepper shrimp. She liked them a lot but was full from our shared plates.

I ordered the fish head casserole. The bowl was huge and everyone stared at me as I was eating. Someone gave their name and took a look at me and shook his as he walked out to wait. The large fish tank I order was really good. It was earthy and herbally. It was took big and hot to enjoy at the small table we sat at. I finished it the next day for breakfast with noodles. 

I don't get the long line of this place. I will have to read up on bon appetit to figure out why this place is so great.
My boss and I both got sick. Terrible atmosphere and service.

FIRST OFF CASH ONLY!! Listen if you want traditional and American style Chinese food that's super fresh then this is the place, but don't expect to come here and be blown away by the food. It's an upgraded version of your local hoods Chinese food because it's clean and fresh but overpriced for what it is. The restaurant is extremely over crowded. The ambiance is cool, but The tables are practically on top of each other. The service isn't great. The pan fried pork dumplings were ok, nothing crazy and dumplings is what they are known for. The General Tsos chicken was average but incredibly fresh. The sauce on it tasted off, but that's me I guess. The Shrimp lomein was also average. One appetizer and two meals was $100 which is crazy for regular Chinese food and they have auto gratuity.

Overhyped. Always a long line. Waited approximately 20 minutes which is not that bad considering previous visits I've waited over an hour. Service is meh. Very cramped inside. Of the few times I've been there I had to share a table with another party..which made the dinner awkward. It felt more like a fast food restaurant than a family-style restaurant. The moment we were seated, a waiter came by to ask what we wanted to eat while we were still settling down with no chance of even opening the menu. As we were still deciding what to eat, the waiter came a few times before that too. We felt rushed. I also noticed on the walls they have autographs and photos of some famous Chinese celebrities. We ordered: 

1. Shanghai stir-fried thick noodles w/ chicken - a bit too salty, noodles were nice and chewy
2. Preserved veggie w/ meat thick noodle soup - my all-time favorite I always order at Shanghai restaurants. They use the preserved (possibly canned?) veggies (snow cabbage) which is dark green. I know it's preserved and should be dark green but because I've tried this at other restaurants that served the fresh green snow cabbage, I prefer the latter more. Just a personal preference, the dish itself is fine.
3. Pork soup dumplings - the skin is a bit thicker than other places I've tried. Not as much soup as I expected - broth is kind of thick, but still tastes good.  

I've eaten here a few times and probably won't be coming back on my own will since I prefer another Shanghai restaurant in the Chinatown area (Shanghai Cafe Deluxe on Mott St.). But I would still probably come if friends decide on this place in the future.

This place is known for soup dumplings, and they're okay, but not stellar. I prefer Shanghai Asian Cuisine on Elizabeth Street, a couple of blocks away. As I'm from the neighborhood, I am fairly familiar with the restaurants, but out-of-town friends have heard rave reviews and must stop by, regardless of the wait and sharing of a table. Well, we came on a Monday afternoon and didn't have to wait for a table, but we waited 35 minutes for the soup dumplings. We kept asking the waiter where they were, and he told us it was crowded - no, it was not. Finally, we told them to cancel the second order of dumplings. After having noodles and scallion pancakes we were already stuffed. I had the Shanghai noodle soup - it was savory, if not a bit salty.

Queue was quite long on rainy days when we got there.
The waitlist system is super outdated, there is no enough room for people who wait to be called.
I was given ticket with number.
Restaurant was packed at the time I came as it was during lunch time.
Dumpling choice surprisingly only fews, mostly menus are a la carte with many options of different protein.
The pancake was tasty and Dumpling was delicious.
To note this restaurant only accepts CASH payment and the gratuity has already included in the bill.
The price, is slightly higher compared to restaurants in the area.

Our favorite Joes Shanghai was midtown and closed. Now they have new location on Bowery and the food is not as good. It was so oily all of it. Soup dumplings were still delicious as usual. The oil left in the bottom of the plate was bad!!!  From the Shanghai noodles to the beef and broccoli.

Overrated spot in Chinatown, if you're an out of towner there are better choices. I was disappointed from my eating experience. Be prepared to be packed like sardines because of the crowds. I don't think many in the "know" go here. I normally wouldn't choose a place like tis but I went with a friend. Never going back. I've been in NYC all my life, and have eaten in many of the area restaurants since a child.

Didn't wait too long to be seated as expected but the food wasn't as great as i thought it would be. One of the dumplings we had was also frozen on the inside. I had high expectation from seeing so many good reviews. Def disappointed

Skip. Take a flight to SF and have way better dumplings ANYWHERE!

Giving one star bc required.

Yuck.
Overpriced and not that good. You pay for the name these days not the food quality of a time past
Food was mediocre at best and the sitting arrangement was terrible. The soup dumplings there was nothing special, if not below average, imo.

My friends and I think Joe's Shanghai is OVERRATED for their xiao long bao. The food contained MSG. We left the restaurant very thirsty. We ordered:

*xiao long bao - when xiao long bao arrived at our table it was turning cold. the wrap/skin were thick and soup tasted salty. A couple of the dumplings were broken.I like xiao long bao from Nan Shian Dumpling House MUCH better.
*scallion pancakes - it was nice and hot and tasty. Hmmm, I wonder if they used MSG with their pancakes.
*shredded turnip shortcake - This was different and something we never tried. It was not bad. Didn't know what to expect.  

2 stars for cold xiao long bao, thick wrap/skin, and use of MSG.

Listen, there is a ton of hype around Joe's Shanghai especially around their soup dumplings. Let me be honest here, they were not that good. Their inner flavor lacked, there wasn't too much soup and it doesn't come close to the best soup dumpling in NYC. The other food was great - cold sesame noodles but if you're going for soup dumplings go here instead:

-Red Farm
-The Bao 
-Shanghai Heping

This place is a tourist trap. The Shanghai food from another block over with the same dishes cost half the price and tastes a lot better. Can't believe we spent over $100 only for four items. We order the pork soup dumplings of course. This was the only decent item on the menu. Then we ordered a cold dish (tofu appetizer), this was really small and can't believe it was $15, totally not worth it for the lack of tofu. Then we ordered a noodle soup with five spiced beef, the beef was r really fresh and tasty but the noodles and the soup was so bland and lack flavor. The amount of noodle was so little it wasn't even enough for a small child to be full. Finally we order the sesame chicken, this was so dry , heavy in sauce but very dry chicken on inside. This was $20 and probably Panda Express would've taste better than this. The only dish that was decent was the soup dumplings and the Rick cakes. But even rice cakes was very greasy like fast food. For the sesame chicken- They probably cooked it overnight and reheated the chicken in the morning. It was pretty disappointing experience because we waited over 30 mins because we saw so many people waiting outside thinking this would be good but boy was I wrong. Never again.

Joe's used to be my "go to" xiaolongbao spot, period. The first time I ate there in early 2000's, in my mind better than my experiences at DTF or even spots I had gone to in Shanghai. Times have changed. Service at Joe's was never great but now I find it completely rude. Our waiter hovered over us to order and snatched our menus when we were done. We never got waters refilled. Plates, utensils and cups were not clean. Food was still decent. We ordered squid with pickled vegetables, house special flat noodles, rice cake w/ pork, string beans, xiaolongbao(3 pork, 2 pork/crab) and green onion pancake. Best item was the green onion pancake which came hot and very crispy. Exactly how they should be served. Worst was the flat noodles which were like udon noodles cooked in soy with some additional toss ins. The xiaolongbao were still good, just not great. The soup was a little watered down, skins on some felt a bit thick and despite this, many were stuck together causing immediate tearing of the skin when picking up. All in all, good meal, just not special enough to battle a trip into Chinatown.

I was pretty disappointed with this place after all the hype, and the line at the door. Clearly Joe's reputation supersedes this place, seeing as it was packed with white folks and tourists on a Monday night. My 3 star rating is based mostly on the food, as I didn't really mind the typical rushed NYC wait service, the communal seating or the ambiance. What we ordered was the pork dumplings (which were juicy and excellent, though I have had better), the lion's head (which was a huge disappointment as I was expecting a soup perhaps with vermicelli or at least a few more bok choi and all we got was a plate of undercooked meatballs), and the bean curd home style (now this was the real disappointment as I feel I get better bchs at my local takeaway around the corner from me in the Jers. And what's with the saucy sauce!?). Anyway, probably not planning to come back here anytime soon. Still waiting for Chinatown to wow me with more than it's raw ingredients like cheap veg. Hope it happens soon...

I live in Chinatown , and have been in this place for a couple of times, a very busy Shanghainese restaurant , but not the best, and also more expensive than other ones in the area. I prefer to go to the one on Bayard Street, their dishes are much better. 
I always tell my friends , go and compare it yourself , you will agree with me

Two stars is generous. I threw out most of my delivery order. The mei fun was so soggy that the noodles fell apart. Tasteless. I didn't like the filling in the soup dumplings. The beef with string beans had a sharp unpleasant garlic taste. Overpriced compared to other Chinese restaurants. I thought it might be better quality. No.

Overrated. It's not that amazing as the newspaper or other media had promoted. Â∞èÁ±†ÂåÖ Xiao Long bao or the small pork dumplings that looks like mini steam buns are average and not so amazing that I would rave over it. I saw a line up a few times and thought what a waste of time. If you never had Chinese food except for ho-lee-chow or Manchu wok or Panda Express then yes this will be amazing. 

Otherwise - this is just average.

Joe's Shanghai is a very stressful place to eat. The process for sitting down seems more complicated than it really is, and that's probably because no one really explains it. Then, you get sat down, and it's kind of a place where you need to know what's happening and know what you want before you get there, or else they'll just pass you by. It's loud, and there's a lot of yelling happening because it's usually so crowded. 

That being said, the food is really quite good. The soup dumplings were great but wait for them to cool down before you give it a go! My favorite however was definitely the scallion pancake. One of the best I've ever had.

The food was good but I felt the staff treated us like livestock, herding us around the restaurant to suit their needs. Definitely not where you would want to go for a relaxing dining experience. The hosted was very rude. Take out is the way to go here.

Having actually had soup dumplings in Shanghai the last 3 years, I can most readily assure you these are not it. They look it, but the taste is far from it. It's a step down from Ding Tai Fung which is a Taiwanese attempt at soup dumplings, but far from the authentic article especially the  crab meat versions. I was happily willing to accept these before I took a 3 year assignment overseas to China, but having had the real thing for so long, it is hard to go back to a poor facsimile.

TL;DR: Shanghainese girl is not pleased with their pork XLB's. Also their twice-cooked pork "hui guo rou" (also not Shanghainese???) and the rest of their menu is not legit at all.

SERVICE: Well-staffed, but since it's always busy/crowded, I get that it won't be perfect.

FOOD: If you're looking for non-authentic Chinese food because you have a Western palette or don't really care to find real Shanghainese food, this is the spot for you.

The place is called Joe's SHANGHAI, but when I looked at the menu, I could barely find anything other than the XLB's that made me miss the motherland. I was pretty disappointed, but decided to try the XLB's because I wanted to give them a chance.

Going in, I knew their XLB's weren't supposed to be authentic, but it didn't even taste good. It was packed with heavy flavor, but lacked depth. The meat wasn't soft and juicy, it was like a hard meatball. The skin was okay, but not thin enough. I dropped my dumpling (rookie move) and it didn't break.

There was a Shanghainese family sitting across from us, I think visiting from out of town. They ordered twice-cooked pork, string beans, and kung pao chicken (all not Shanghainese dishes btw, these are the classic dishes my parents and I order when we realize we got duped). Their faces when the food came out though, it looked something like this~  :|

Also the people there, let's just say I saw mainly chicken & broccoli, sesame chicken, and orange chicken come out of the kitchen. Real adventurous bunch.

Overall, L O L.

The service was mediocre. They rushed us to choose quickly. The pancake was soggy and tasted terrible. The pork+ crab soup dumplings don't taste really good. I feel like I can find frozen Xiao long bao and make it taste the same as the ones they serve, this is probably full of msg.

Serving very tasty Dim sum, however, the service was gross. I brought one of my old Japanese friend, which was, I think, mistake. It appears famous for some Japanese because it was shown in a few Japanese guide books. The restaurant does know this and pasted some ads written in Japanese. The hospitality, however, is not reached to the level which deserves for real Asian foodies.

The xiao long bao (XLB) here is more like DA long bao, it's so huge. BIG basket dumplings, if you translate literally. They're wobbly, messy, doughy, and it's just a challenge just to get the entire thing onto your spoon without breaking the outer skin. Forget those mini sharp metal tongs that they provide, it's totally useless.

On more than one instance, I barely moved those clumsily-constructed suckers a millimeter and all of the precious broth spilled out and onto the bamboo plate. That's just not good. I even did the slow "rollover" method, taking my sweet time. That's the liquid gold that you're paying for. Otherwise, you just have a sad, empty, and pathetic dumpling staring right back at you. It's nothing special without its juice, it's mojo.

I guess it's a matter of personal preference, but I like the smaller, delicate, and more compact XLB's from Din Tai Fung, if you want to compare restaurants in the US. China, of course, is in a whole other league. Although the skin is thinner, it is so well-made and strong enough to hold all of the juices inside. I also love being able to pop an entire XLB into my mouth, instead of nibbling one bite at a time like at Joe's.

While the pork dumplings were good, the crab ones did taste a bit funky, with some fishy flavor aftertaste. The green scallion pancakes were of the thick and chewy variety, with a very nice crisp on the outside. We also tried the seafood pan fried noodles and the the yellow fish. As someone who grew up eating good Chinese food all his life, I found the dishes to be disappointing, especially at the prices they were charging. 

With all the people waiting outside for their turn in mangling big juicy dumplings with those wretched tongs, it's a definite tourist trap. I thought it would be different, with the location in such a small alley-way, hidden and tucked away from the main streets. Chinatown in NY is so vast, it just dwarfs SF Chinatown. But so goes the never-ending cliche--it's all about quality, not quantity.

Everyone goes crazy for the dumplings here, but I'm not sure why. 

I had the Sesame Chicken and it was good, but not any better than other decent chinese places. The place was packed while other restaurants seemed close to being empty. 

I can't compare it to other New York chinese restaurants, since this is the only one I attended...but I'd try something else before I came here again.
I have no idea why everyone goes here, the food was sub par, and the atmosphere was hectic and crowded. The dumplings were very unappealing as well. Would not recommend.

The soup dumplings are very very good, and I like the ambiance and staff--it is a well run and efficient establishment.  My problem is with the rest of the menu.  It is all very expensive and the dishes are quite large.  I understand tourists are willing to pay and that this set up works for a big group sharing multiple dishes, but it is impossible to eat the dumplings and an entree with 1 or 2 people.  I wish they had a lunch menu with smaller portions.

My friends were ranting and raving about soup dumplings before i came to new york.. i wasn't exactly sure what that was. so i get here to the infamous joe's shanghai and ordered 2  soup dumplings and 1 pancake for my friend and i to share. when they came out to my surprise its the same thing as xlb! (xiao long bao) here i thought i was in for a treat. I still thing Ding Tai Fung in California is better. :)

More like 3.5. The hot and sour soup was good. The shanghai noodles was also good. However the XLBs were ehhh. We ordered the pork and the crab. At first taste it was good but the thick skin over powers the meat and soup inside. When it sat on the table for a bit the skin got hard and certain parts became inedible. My heart still belongs to Din Tai Fung for XLBs.

This place is just okay.  Not worth the wait and not worthy of the hype.  Who the heck wants to sit at a table with other people?  Is the food that good that you have to disturb the social dynamics of your personal party by sitting with another group?  Might be interesting if you sit with another tourist group from Russia, France or Poland, but who gives a crap about that.  But, what if the other party is too overwhelming or creepy or just some loner?  

Indeed, the soup dumplings are delicious, but I wonder...isn't there some other place that has the same stuff? 

Not many local ethic Chinese at this place from what I saw...mainly lonely planet and fodors aficionados looking to experience a 'true piece' of NYC Chinatown.

Shanghai dumplings is what this place is all about. We had an order each per person. The first three was very good and then it went downhill. The dumplings were either broke when I picked it up (was very careful) or there was barely any juice inside. If all were made nicely, I would've given 4 stars.

Couldn't decide between a 3 and a 4. This place is known for their soup dumplings, like well known. We stayed in the hotel next door and there was a line every single day at most times of the day. The crab and pork soup dumplings were exceptional. The taste of the broth in the dumpling was just really delicious so I get it. The wait, however, and the unorthodox way they seat people just realllllly annoyed me. We waited over an hour for them to seat two people but saw parties of 3-8 come after and get seated before us while also asking those parties if they minded sharing a table so idk what was going on. 

Everything else we got besides those soup dumplings was meh, run of the mill Chinese takeout.

I might crave those dumplings but def not the experience so idk if I'll be back.

I've had some damn delicious Xiao long baos in my tiny life span and I was so excited to try these because everyone I know who has lived in NYC has raved about them. Except they really didn't live up to the expectation. My friend and I ordered 3 orders of Xiao long baos because that's all that I came for, haha! And while they were good, they were not amazing. The buns were definitely filled with soup and the meat tasted fresh but the flavor was only a little above average. 

We also ordered some veggies and rice. They served our buns intermittently through the meal and almost forgot our 3rd order of buns! It just felt like they wanted us to leave at that point. Regardless, I had a good meal, and would recommend this place to someone who is missing their soup dumplings while in Manhattan. Not a bad deal for a good meal!

The shrimp fried rice and the fried dumplings were nothing to brag home about. Didn't have much flavor. The soup dumplings were great! The General t chicken was also very good. Restaurant had a "B" rating when I went...I made the mistake of looking up why. Don't make my mistake.

Went there last night with my family. Don't really understand what the fuss is about the dumplings,  I found nothing good about them, couldn't taste the filling and really, to wait an hour and a half for these dumplings was not worth it.
Apart from the fact that the place is dirty and the rest of the food is just average.
We ordered fried rice and noodles and they were extremely greasy. 
Don't waste time and money in this place.

I'm going to be the black sheep here and say that although Joe's Shanghai is good, I believe Shanghai Manor is better.

You start by taking a number and wait outside among other eager eaters. A hostess will come out to call your number based on party size not based on the number she gave you. Oh and she may quote you 30 minutes but surely, it may be greater than that wait time.

They offer communal seating in round tables and for me, it makes it somewhat unbearable to eat as others watch me devour soup dumpling after soup dumpling. 

Soup dumplings are a solid 7.5/10. The dough is too thick and most of my soup dumplings were deflated with not enough soup!! BLEH. 

Moving on, their seasonal sauteed vegetable dish is literally broccoli, onions, a few wild mushrooms and bean sprouts. Meh. The sauce was just whatever as well. 

I surely don't think it's worth the 30+ minute wait but be my guest. I'll stick with Shanghai Manor.

This place is always occupied with Long line of wait and you can see many people waiting outside. Eating environment is not ideal because you are always sharing table with other strangers. You probably draw more attention to other people's food than your own. 

Their Xiao Long Bao is huge compared to other restaurants. The skin is ok thin so you feel the delicacy of Xiao Long Bao. But the folds of the skin are not as precise as ding tai Fung. 

The meat and soup inside the buns are flavourful and I think it's better than ding tai Fung. So overall Xiao Long Bao quality is good. 

The stir fried green bean dish was too oily. I wouldn't recommend to order.

The service is SUPER BAD. When we asked if the restaurant had wifi, the waiter just shook his head instead of politely responding us. The waiters here also seemed to keeping their eyes down so we had difficulty calling them. Very unpleasant experience !

Their soup dumplings are delicious and their food is good as well but the wait is just ridiculous! 

I honestly don't think that it is worth the wait. 

40 minutes for dumplings? No thank you!

Food was good. Service was just okay. The only thing I hate about this place is that they don't give you a receipt even after you have paid unless you ask for it. And they would make you wait a long time for your paper receipt. Also, they automatically include a tip for themselves so make sure you ask for your receipt to verify this yourself so that you don't leave another tip behind which I almost did, but didn't after I double checked the receipt.

For the hype, I think this place is ALRIGHT. There's always a ton of people lining up outside during the weekends. The Shanghai dumplings are good but not amazing. I've had better elsewhere in the neighborhood. The service isn't great. You tend to have to share tables with other people. They also rush you out when you're done. Tip is added automatically to the bill. It's cash only so be aware.

Mediocre food, really wasn't that impressed and am confused why it's rated so high. Most importantly, THERE IS NO DIM SUM, as it's mislabeled on here. Soup dumplings were okay, not the best in the neighborhood and the two dishes we ordered we not very good. 

T

The dumplings were excellent as we expect it.  Very juicy with crab meet inside.  I would order them again in the future.  Overall i like the foods but service is a different story.  The waiter was loud and rude. The restaurant takes cash only.  We had two people but they put 18% tip on the bill automatically.  I would give  a 4 stars but zero for service so 2 stars sound about right.

Two stars starts off with a two hour wait and follows this up with some subpar food.  The soup dumplings pale in comparison to mediocre wonton soup and were followed by overly greasy Chinese food.  The soup dumplings actually tasted like stinky feet on this trip to this institution.  The one saving grace was a semi-decent prawn dish but it did not make up for the 10 or so dishes that were worse than most delivery places in the city.  I would highly recommend avoiding this place unless with tourists that insist on trying this place.

Food sucked. It was gooey with fat and didn't taste very fresh. It was like a regular shitty chinese place, except you have to share a table with random people and there's a wait. Also, not cheap given it's bad quality. 

Their only good thing is the soup dumplings and they're not even that special: just salty hot water with a little bit of meat in them.

Bottom line: HIGHLY OVERRATED

Went here for my friend's birthday last year. 

The dumplings were very tasty, but since I'm from Hong Kong, I can't say they were entirely memorable. However, if you're looking for authenticity, this place is it.

The soup dumplings are perhaps the only food I remember eating that made an impression. The soup had a nice salty and savoury taste while the doughy texture was slighty tough, and not easy to break. That could be good or bad, depending on your perspective, but I like my skin thinner. 

There is an unfortunate long wait. You might have to share tables (I hate that), and the restaurant itself is hard to find.

YUCK

I have no idea how this place draws you all in by the thousands. Was it on the food network and I missed it? Simply stated this place is awful. 

Decor - what decor?
Noise level - concert
Tables - enjoy your large round banquet table with several others you don't know.
Cleanliness - ok I know this is chinatown but this place makes CASH hand over fist and the place is a junky pigsty. I was super happy I didn't get sick afterward.

Soup dumplings - eww - too thick dough and pork had very little flavor
Scallion pancakes - greeezy
Moo Shoo Pork - too slimy and gross with no flavor to even bother finishing.

People NY is full of restaurants. Why would you choose this one?

The first time I tried this place, it was the bomb! I ate the deep fried sea bass, soup dumplings, and fried rice (forget which one). However the second time there was a disappointment. I had the sesame oil noodles, Kung Pao chicken, and crab and pork soup dumplings. Overall, the soup dumplings is the best item there of those that I've tried. I've tasted better dumplings though. I felt like these dumplings were fatty and had a heaviness to it. Other places I've been to they had a clean light taste to it. The waiters are not friendly either. I think it was better the first time because of the nostalgia feeling of being in Chinatown in NY...I'm not from NY. I probably wouldn't go back again. Plus...the streets of Chinatown smells like hot garbage during the Summer...

Staff was rude. I ordered for takeout then decided to have a few small bites so I wanted to get a table. They were so adamant about me getting a table bc I already asked for takeout, they said. How is it different from me dining in and then asking for a box to takeout after? I just did the reverse and they weren't even busy but they just didn't want to serve me. Literally had to talk to 3 waiters, including the head staff before they gave us a table. Food was also not even that great, really disappointed with their xiao long bao. Will not come back

I came here with family around 4:30 and it was still pretty pack. We ordered 2 xiao long baos (soup dumplings), Shanghai cho chow mein(I forgot what's it's called in English), Pan fried noodles, scallion pancakes and some kind of sliced beef with sweet and sour sauce. The xiao long baos were yummy and fillingexpect that the second order, ALL of the soup dumpling were popped before reaching our table. The noodle dishes were pretty salty, everyone else agreed with me. The sweet and sour beef was decent along with the scallion pancake. However, they gave us probably like 5 drops of the soy sauce that came with the scallion pancakes so it was pretty disappointing not being able to dip the scallion pancake with the sauce :( 

There are better places for Shanghai food around Chinatown, save your money and go there. Although Joes is cheaper, it's not worth it. You'll be disappointed.  

ALSO, check your utensils. My spoon was covered with dried up soy sauce or something. They did not even apologize.
SOUP. DUMPLINGS. really really great...efficient service and a good late night meal, but as for the rest of the food, just decent. Not bad, just nothing to write home about.

Place is smack dab in the middle of china town. If it weren't for my handy iPhone I'd be lost in busy lil china town. 
Tried this place because of the reviews. Got the pork dumplings for ONLY $4.50 (6 dump-lings) and cha cha myun (black bean, tofu noodles). Meal came out to approximately $12! 

So when you walk in, it is mofo crowded. They basically seat you where a seat is not occupied....meaning 10 person table=2 person party times 5. Hey strangers!!! Let's be friends. The restaurant was also very LOUD. Screaming my order is never fun.

The dump-lings were OK. I was expecting something amazing from the reviews and what my friends have said. I swear it's just for the experience and not the flavor. The broth in the dumplings was bland. How disappointing. I had to douse my dumpings in vinegar sauce and eat it with the even more so bland cabbage from the basket in which the dumplings were steamed. 

What was good was the cha cha myun. Needs more meat but the flavor was intense and only bad part about it was that I had to gulp down 3 glasses of water to eat the flavorful sauce. chayyyyyyy! It was good but I'd probably eat it once in a blue moon. Don't want high cholesterol or diabetes from the sweet black bean sauce.

Anyways, hit it once for the experience, and honestly, once was enough.

Ok, yes, the soup dumplings are good.  But that's about it.

For an entree, my friend and I split General Tso's chicken and the Braised Duck.  The chicken was good, but it was around $15, which is very pricy for what you get and for being in Chinatown.  I really didn't think it was any better than the kind I get back home from Panda Express, which is a fraction of the cost.

The duck was good, but a little too fatty.  It also seemed to come out way too quickly to be cooked fresh.  And it did not agree with my stomach at all!  I was nauseous for the rest of the day.

Also, the service was pretty bad.  I really wasn't expecting much on that end, but I'm not complaining about the waitstaff.  I'm complaining about the hostesses.  There was a 40 minute wait but they were not calling people in order.  If you happened to be close to them when they asked if there were any parties of two you got the table, even if someone else had a lower number.  Inefficient way of doing business.

Skip this place.  There are plenty of places with great dumplings that also have great entrees.  And there are plenty of cheaper places in Chinatown with better food.

I know, I know, you must be wondering what the heck I'm doing in China Town when I'm flying all the way across from CA. But, honestly, I think there's something about China town that you just gotta visit and eat there no matter where you are in the world. 

Well, I came here because I heard they got good Xiao Long Bao. The thing is, I don't eat pork, so I wouldn't know what good Xiao Long Bao is and what bad is. However, I figure I can eat other food here and see how it tastes!  We ordered Chinese water crest with garlic, crispy beef, noodle soup, and a melon soup. The melon soup was a complete disaster, so not gonna even waste my time talking it. The veggie was nothing special; nonetheless, it wasn't overly salted, which is a +. Noodle soup.... it's just noodle soup...  The best dish was the crispy beef. It tasted almost like sweet and sour pork/chicken, except with beef. 

Bottom line, nothing special about this place~ if you're in NY and craving for Asian food, I would go to a Malaysian restaurant b.c. there's no Malaysian food in the West Coast.

Great food but way too much going on here.

We tried a few of their dumplings, steamed and soup. Also had the  scallion pancakes. These dishes were all delicious and worth the 30 minute wait. And that 30 mins is short compared to their usual wait. 

The problem is that you share tables with random people and are seated super close to them and the servers are working very fast to get you in and out. I love good and efficient service, but I'm not a fan of being rushed. 

Come for the food but be warned. I will probably be back.

Take it easy Joes Shanghai, don't rush me.  

I went here cause i've been craving soup dumplings a lot lately.  it was between coming here or shanghai cafe but my friend suggested this was the better bet.  WRONG.  i ordered the crab/pork meat and another just pork meat.  now the food itself is pretty good.  8 pieces of tasty hot soup dumplings.  yummmmmm.  3.5 stars for the food itself and I'd happily round that up to 4 if the service was decent.  WRONG AGAIN.

they sat us in a table of 10 with strangers, whatever, fine i'll make new friends.  upon looking around, they were all pretty old and grotesque.  taking their fake teeth out to eat and talking loudly like all chinese old timers.  apparently their hearing has gone but their voice box is as good as ever.  maybe i'll just ignore them afterall.  

we get our food quickly enuff and the waiter (an ugly troll of a man) stands next to me waiting for me to finish.  as soon as we finish our meal, he quickly asks "anything else?".  back up off me buddy, let me digest you nasty old man.  so i order some more tsing tao and nurse it just to annoy him as he hovers over me breathing down my neck with smelly hot breath.  *shivers*.  the people on our table had 2 empty seats as they wait for their friends to show up.  the waiter asks if they're showing up and they said probably not.  they get a scolding "YOU HAVE TO TELL ME THESE THINGS!!!" he yells in his most intimidating voice which was kinda funny.  

we finally leave with all the dirty stares upsetting my friend.  big shout out to lindsay and her company.  joes shanghai, decent food (i actually like shanghai asian manor's soup dumplings a little more and they have much better service and is not as crowded with a better decor).  very bad rude wait staff.  i understand u have other customers waiting but you just don't rush customers out like that.  as michelle on full house would say (god i hate that show)...HOW WWWUUUDE.

First time eating here and I've lived in NYC for decades. I've gone by many a time but I refuse to wait in line to get into a restaurant, especially a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown when there are dozens of alternatives within 2 minutes.  But late on a Sunday night I strolled right in to encounter the dry 'yeah so what' welcome of the staff.   I loved the energy in the room of lots of Asian families dining among the obvious tourists and obvious locals trying to assert themselves to no avail.  

I'd rate the place A-OK mainly since all the people at my large group table were so much fun to sit with for a guy dining solo:  strangers became friends very quickly.   To sit with so many strangers was a nice change of pace.  But I just realized (thanks to reading other Yelpers reviews) that these guys charged me service charge and I did not notice it and over generously tipped on top of that.  I'm an idiot and p.o'd about it.

One of the women at my table insisted I order the pork soup dumplings and kung pao chicken, so I did.  Both were good, but I wasn't bowled over by the soup dumplings, they were rather mild in taste and kept breaking before you could get them out of the steamer because they were sticking to the bottom, which was annoying.  The chicken dish was excellent, not greasy at all, clear flavors, and I never got bored eating it which happens with Chinese food a lot for me half way through the plate.

I wish the meal came with rice.  It's the first Chinese meal I've had in my life where rice was not offered. And even asking twice for rice, the four or five waiters were too busy kibitzing to bother remembering to bring some.  I'm not supposed to have a lot of carbs anyway, so no biggie.

Oh, and there was no fizzy water to be had either.  "No fizzy water, tap water only."  Ok.  But after saying that it would have been cool if they actually brought some.

I spent $30 on two dishes with service charge and my damn generous tip, so the value and bang for buck is not terribly great.

So the place was good but I'll probably keep trying other places in ChiTown before going back.  Unless I walk by and there's no line.

I'm so tired of my out-of-towner friends asking me to take them to eat here. How many times do I have to tell you that I don't want to come here? It's not good!

First off, I hate the name of this restaurant. What Chinese person names their kid, Joe? No offense to Chinese people named Joe, but the name of the restaurant is basically setting up the target market of those who'd be appealed by this name and come to eat here.

If you've had soup dumplings in Los Angeles (as one fellow Yelper mentioned, Din Tai Fung in Arcadia is amazing, and I'm not sure why they haven't opened a NYC branch) or the soup dumplings with the straw in Shanghai, then this place sucks. It's definitely not a place where people are supposed to expect authentic Shanghainese soup dumplings. Aside from their mediocre soup dumplings, the food on their menu is also pretty sub-par, that is, if you eat Chinese food on a daily basis. But if you enjoy Panda Express, then you probably think this place is the most authentic Chinese food you've ever tasted. I equate Mid-Western Americans eating here to a Chinese man from China coming to NYC to eat street cart hot dogs and saying that it's the most amazing hot dog he's ever had.  

So, I just don't understand what the hype is all about, and why there's always such a long line?

The soup dumplings are amazing here. They definitely remind me of Din Tai Fung (I've only had it in Southern California). It's hard to describe the experience of eating a good soup dumpling. In quick summary, you put some of the dark vinegar thing on your soup spoon, pick up a dumpling with chopsticks and place it on the spoon, nibble part of the soup dumpling, drink up the warm soup, eat the rest of the dumping, then repeat. One order of the dumplings can be enough for one person's meal. If sharing one order, then another dish should probably be ordered if you want to be satiated at this place. The wait staff knows this is what you want to order--it's even circled on the menu. I think number 9 is what you want.

If you're alone of in a party of 2-4, you will probably share a big circular table with other people. I want to give this place 4 stars, but they made it a little awkward that I was a single diner.

Overly priced with small portions. This place had some quality years ago but was really disappointed with the food recently.  Cash only and an automatic 18% tip for rude service.  The menu also is pretty limited for a Chinese restaurant.   Avoid the tourist trap, tons of better places in the area

I had high expectations for Joe's as it was top rated for Chinatown. I was extremely disappointed in the service. Our waiter took our order and never came back. After we noticed everyone around us who arrived after we did was already eating we asked about our food and it was delivered to us 10 mins later. The food was mediocre at best. After took the first bite we immediately regretted passing up other restaurants along the way. On top of that when we asked for our ticket we noticed the automatically charged 18% gratuity for a table of 2, who only saw their server one time. This place was a terrible experience. Will not come back and would not reccomend.

It seems that the only reason why most people go to Joe's Shanghai is just for soup dumplings.  I recently went a couple Saturdays ago, and as expected, you could hear the whole restaurant slurping up soup dumplings in sync.  Personally, I don't care for Joe's soup dumplings...  I think the ones at Shanghai Gourmet, a few doors down, are substantially better.  Yet, it doesn't matter as Joe's reputation seems to be entirely based on soup dumplings.  

The one thing that irks me about Joe's is that it is a tourist trap!  The line/wait can be crazy at times, and In my opinion, it's usually way too crowded for what it's worth.  Service can be slow at times as the kitchen does get backed-up, and be prepared to sit at a table with strangers in a community setting...  So don't be afraid to say Hi to the person sitting next to you.  However, in spite of my criticism of this place, there is one dish here that I think is fantastic and makes me contradict myself, and that is the braised pork shoulder, complimented with a traditional brown sauce.  It's the kind of dish that draws a lot of attention and stares when they bring it to the table. I highly recommend it if you like pork!

Folks, I have eaten here several times since 2011. Food quality has diminished significantly and prices have skyrocketed! Everthing is saturated in grease and has little flavor.  This place is outdated. Do try other places or only have the dumplings.

We ordered shrimp fried rice. It looked good but there was no tastes. It's like they used dried veggies and frozen shrimp and no seasoning or a dash of salt.

We ordered general zhu chicken and it tasted like candied chicken served with bearly cooked broccoli. 

We ordered eggplant with garlic sauce. It was drenched in oil and tasteless. 

The dumplings were fine. 

The service is so consistently bad.  They yell at you if you are unhappy or have a special request.  The servers were all male most couldnt speak english.  There meal also includes a 15% service fee so be sure not to tip unless you want to go above and beyond cause they certainly won't return the favor while you are ordering or eating.

Unfortunately this place was a huge disappointment. Way too much hype. We ordered the scallion pancake, XLB, crab and pork XLB, and stir fried noodles. The best dish was the scallion pancake. If you've ever had Din tai fung, you will also be let down! The XLB wrapper is way too thick leaving an unpleasant gooey texture to the XLB. Service is extremely friendly and quick. There's a 15% gratuity and is cash only.

Foreigners and Americans have clearly marked their territory in Chinatown. Joes Shanghai is decent but unfortunately not worth the wait or expense. The soup dumplings are delicious, but the equivalent of chicken soup - comfort food at its best. Also, for the clean freaks out there - be warned - clean walls are low on their priority list.

All time classic dumpling shop in Chinatown. I would say if it wasn't for the lines (tourists) I would give it a higher rating....I find it inconvenient because while it is good, it is not din tai fung good...and as such the line jockeying is not warranted.

This is a mixed bag review. I would never put this place in the 5 star category but it did have some really good food items.

The good - the food

Soup Dumplings - very good, not the best I ever had but very tasty.
String Beans - flash fried and delicious
Crispy Beef - tasty but not the best

The bad - Communal tables - my fellow yelpers, you left that small piece of info out of your reviews.....

The ugly - no surprise, the service. The staff couldn't be bothered with you. They gave you the impression that you were interrupting their time playing on their phones with your requests of water and food.

Don't know if this is worth the trek to Chinatown but I am glad I tried it.

Not terribly impressed with the soupy dumplings here at Joe's. First of all, I didn't know the right technique to eat their stuff and so my first bite into their famous soupy dumplings meant an instantly scalded and burnt tongue for me. Second, it gets very crowded very quickly, and unlike some other equally popular places in Chinatown - where the servers are still relatively nice to their customers - the guys at Joe's seemed to know that they were popular and for some reason thought that gave them the right to treat everyone like dirt. If you're going to treat us like dirt Joe's, I'll take my cold hard cash somewhere else, no matter how popular your dumplings are.

We were walking through China town on our way back to Times Square from Battery Park. There was this place that had best soup dumplings in New York written on the side and so we had to stop in and try these dumplings. We were seated at a corner table and handed menus. It was SO hot in the restaurant. To the point that we were actually sweating just sitting there.  The server came over and we ordered 2 beers and an order of soup dumplings. She asked what else and we said that is it. She immediately got upset and was pushing us to order more. We said we weren't really hungry and just stopped in to try these amazing dumplings. She was huffy and walked away. The dumplings came out and honestly they were pretty bad. No flavor. Super bland. The whole experience was just disappointing,

After waiting for one hour for a table, we were ushered into this small tiny place that they call restaurant. We were seated on two different tables...ordered dumplings and various other dishes.

We had: flied lice, fish in tomatoe sauce, flied noodles, beef something, another beef something dish and the dumplings.
