Tried the dishes and was utterly disappointed! For a second there...I thought I skipped to dessert already! YES...that sweet!! Umm, the food not the waiters. (please, don't get me started on them...) So there I was, sitting in a crowded chinese restaurant in china town (which does reek of garbage and urine...the streets not the restaurant) 

Then the dumpling came out. 'big deal' I thought to myself, but being the person that I am...I tried one anyway. WOW, I was in heaven! Never have I tasted such a exquisite thing. It had the texture of a dumpling and yet the flavor of a soup! Yum yum in my tum tum!! 

Well, too bad that, that was only the outstanding thing at the restaurant! I did not like any of the other dishes that we ordered. 

Definitely a hit and run restaurant. The waiters expect you to know what you wanna order before you sit down...and pay as soon as the dishes are empty or your stomach is full!

When the rest of the world has Din Tai Fung, New York has Joe's Shanghai.  Supposedly, this is the best place in Manhattan to get xiaolongbao (soup dumplings).  I'm so obsessed with xiaolongbao I can eat it for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.  Naturally, I had to check this place out when I was in town.  

The xiaolongbao was decent indeed.  Certainly better than anything I can get in Chicago.  But it was far from great.  First off, while the wrap was thin (a good thing), it didn't have enough integrity to give the xiaolongbao a perky shape - our xiaolongbao laid lazily on the steamer.  Second, the soup and meat ratio was a bit off - not enough meat.  While I hate to eat a xiaolongbao with too little soup, this one had too much at the expense of having enough meat.  Last, the flavor of the filling (soup and meat) was not strong enough (a bit watered down) - I expect burst of umami when I eat great xiaolongbao.  But it just didn't taste like they use top-quality pork and pork-stock gelee for the filling.  While Joe's Shanghai's xiaolongbai is by no means bad, it can't hold a candle against the real deal at Din Tai Fung.  Perhaps I'm being a bit too harsh - after all, this is New York, not Taipei or Shanghai.  But it's hard for me to drop my expectations for something I love so much and know so well.  So please take my criticism in its proper context.  

We also ordered the turnip cake, which was pretty good.  Zhajiang Mian (noodle with pork meat sauce) wasn't bad, but the noodle was not  hand-pulled la-mian (and therefore not al dente) and the sauce was too mild for my liking.  The beef with scallion was fine, tasted like any other Canto restaurant who can marinate their beef in soda water.  

Decor felt like a diner, and seats were cramped.  Service was efficient, if not a bit too brisk.  

Overall, like its name suggests, this place does well in Shanghai / jiangsu dishes - xiaolongbao and turnip cakes were 4-star level.  But dishes from other regions were rather average.  If I come back, I will only order the regional cuisine in which they specialize.
Overrated.  Rush service in order to get as many people in as possible.  Cash only is a negative.  Entirely too bright.  Nothing special about menu.  There are better shanghai places.
This place is gross.  Filthy and uncomfortable.  The food is merely marginal at best but at least it is cheap.  A tourist trap and the soup dumplings leave a lot to be desired.

I used to be a frequent flyer here, I would just stop in and have an order of the soup dumplings. Lately I've noticed the skin has become thicker and it's just not the same... I don't recommend that you get any other dish here, they're standard Chinese take out items.

This is the worst joes Shanghai location I have ever been to. The service was terrible. The waiter came to out table and didn't even ask what I want to order I had to call him back. The food is at best mediocre and inaccurate to its description. I got the szichuan style fish, which has a Chinese dish title that means spicy fish fillets in soup, "shui Zhu Yu pian". That's the way the dish is supposed to be according to the Chinese name. If you type the Chinese name into Internet the fish fillet with soup should be the only images that come up. However, my dish came and it was NOT a soup. It is a dish with fish fillets coated with some kind of sauce on a bed of cabbage! If that's the dish they are bringing, they should not use the Chinese name that refers to one specific dish! The total came up as very expensive for what I ordered. Never going to come back again.

As a tourist who has never been to Chinatown before I felt a little awkward being seated next to another couple at a four person table. 

The restaurant was busy, our waiter was a little slow, but our food came quickly.

The dumplings tasted authentic though to be honest Shanghai dumplings are not my favorite. 

Prices were reasonable but not cheap. Tip was included in the bill.

long wait always.  food's good, but it's way too packed, and you seem to be rushed from start to finish.  if all stars aligned, you'd get a good meal.  otherwise, 3-star for everything.

bonus: thought i saw russell wong getting take-out from here one time.  *drools*  xD
:)

Joe's Shanghai was nothing out of the ordinary Northern-style Chinese cuisine. To be frank, it was actually sub-par compared to the other restaurants of the same type of cuisine. The service was fast. If you have a small party then you'll most likely have to share the table with others. The food was greasy even compared to other Chinese restaurants. The dumplings aren't as hyped up to be. They don't make any dumplings without pork! You could definitely find the same exact food down the street for a lower price. Wasn't anything out of the ordinary. If you are really craving Northern-style Chinese food then you'll do much better at a Chinese-Islamic style restaurant. Where they have better quality meat, larger portions and cheaper prices. There are plenty of those sprinkled all over the 5 boroughs.

This review is based solely on the experience and service I did not receive.  I picked this place based on the good Yelp reviews.  We walked in and were seated right away.  After waiting for about 10 minutes and having not received a menu, I attempted to get the attention two of the older male employees, a couple of different times, they both looked my way and totally disregarded my attempts to ask for assistance.  Two other parties, who arrived after me, were seated, received service and starter food and I had yet to receive a menu or acknowledgment.  

I left this, cash only, restaurant very disappointed with the service and not being able to try the food I'd read about on Yelp.

Pretty good place, fast service! We came for dumplings/dim sum but they don't have a large menu of this type. They had a few on the menu but they were just ok.  It comes up in the search for dim sum but is a little misleading. The entree that we did order were very good, though!
Horrible experience!! Shared Tables, Rude Service and Disgusting rest rooms!! Food was okay and definitely not mind blowing!! Will not return back!!
Not a fan of their crabmeat pork soup dumplings here. The soup didn't have any seafood taste to it and it was really oily. Definitely a touristy restaurant.

Its all about experience. 

If your first Xiao Long bao (soup dumplings) happen to be while you are in NY you will probably hear about and choose Joe's Shanghai. And 2 things will happen. 

You will love it and your tongue will be burn as hell. But after a while you will realize that Xiao Long bao shouldn't be the reason for going there. 

For what I have experience at Joe's their soup dumplings are quite random  As when they get cold, and this can happen before to get into your table, it doesn't really taste good. The dough get too sticky and is thick and bland and the soup can't be qualify as soup anymore but a thick greasy sauce instead. If the temperature is still hot you will like it, but to me are not the best you can taste. The dough will always be too thick and the flavor, no other than dough, can overpass the tasty soup and filling inside. Which are not the best ones either. About the filling you can choose among crab with pork or just pork . But I wouldn't say it taste like crab or pork although you can notice the difference between them. And at this point I have definitely quit tasting the pork ones. Its suppose to be a meatball, you know, it should be a ball of meat rich in flavor and juicy .. mostly juicy. Well Joe's balls are not juicy at all (hey, for real laughing go to meatball shop reviews. Peter D. Read please http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-meatball-shop-new-york#hrid:gOpoFCHTm9MriahPhTl_nA).  But going back into Joe's balls.. not juicy, but sticky and the look is unappetizing and I wouldn't eat that unwrapped.  

Its all about experience; but even for someone as me that has not too much of it I have already taste much better Xiao Long Bao. 

Other that soup dumplings the food is good. Consistent at least. The fried rice is good, vegetables have been always tasty and fresh. Their crispy noodles and garlic beef are also things to try. I'd recommend their Sauteed Black Mushrooms with Bamboo Shoots. Its an interesting dish, flavorful and full of crunchy texture but you have to be into vegetables to totally enjoy it. One of the things I tried last time was their drunken chicken (wine chicken), a cold appetizer that besides is a temptation to try just because contains the word drunken, it actually taste quite good. Its served at room temperature The meat is firm but tender and its not seasoned at all but a mild flavor instead acquired after the marination in the alcoholic broth.

The service is good one you are seated because the ones that will gave you your number are not as nice. Before entering time just past very slow as the waiting time could be 1h, even by 530pm, a bizarre time for food intake. And probably more during the weekends and at regular hours. Tables will be shared with others, known or not,  and upon entrance the time just go so fast. Water, tea, ordering, receiving food, and eating. There is also an army of servers that looks your party very close checking if you need something else or just refilling water or just if you are ready to pay and release the space to the next customer. But any case,  they have been always friendly and funny. 

Its all about experience and Joe's is already a touristic destination that you have to try. The place where you will be asked to go because its suppose you have to. But there is more places at Chinatown where the food is as good as at Joe's . Or better. Probably. For sure. And where the waiting time could not even exist. Maybe they don't serve Xiao Long bao, but again Joe's shouldn't be the first destination to get that. 

Its funny that the best thing I experienced last time I went to Joe's was the spicy chicken pieces that we got next door at Quickly; a Taiwanese tea place known for their bubble tea and snack food... but wait.. you don't really need to go to Joe's for that.

Joe's Shanghai was overrated.  We tried them out and felt crowded and the wait staff isn't that pleasant and all this might've been tolerable if the xiao long bao were good...but they were just okay.  We compared it to Shanghai cafe the next day and there was a big difference in flavor and Shanghai cafe's bao didn't break as easily as Joe's.  

We had ordered the crab and the original xiao long bao at Joe's and honestly there was no difference in taste, which is just wrong.  Half of them broke and the soup escaped!  The pan fried noodles were delicious, light and airy!  The portion looked humongous but we ended up finishing it because the noodles are so light!  YUM! 

I recommend trying Shanghai Cafe instead for your Xiao Long Bao fix.  It's more spacious and the food is better!

The first thing I noticed when I walked in was that the majority of the customers are non-Asians (mostly white) which kinda made me suspicious. It sorta ruined the authenticity effect and expectations but I remained mainly optimistic. We got the famous noodle dumplings. About 8. They were good. Fun to try but didn't taste anything exceptional if you ask me. Reasonable price. Not really an authentic 'dim sum' restaurant with waiters going around with carts of food. Sesame chicken was mediocre. And please don't get the fried noodles! I'm so used to good Vietnamese fried noodles in Jersey City. The noodles here were a joke. Huge portion but absolutely terrible.

We were happy to finally try this Chinatown classic!  Definitely get your expectations in check before coming - this is not a quiet, intimate restaurant by any means.  We waited about 30-45 minutes on a weekday afternoon around 2 PM (it was a long holiday weekend).  Communal seating (if your party isn't big enough alone), loud noise levels, and service that is a tad scattered and rushed.  Soup dumplings were good, although we definitely preferred the pork over the crab.  Scallion Pancake was also a nice starter.  It's quite the experience.

The staff here can go fuck themselves.

We were a party of 6 (wife and inlaws -- we're all Asian and *locals*) but was told there was a short wait -- ok, fine, no problem, we can see they're pretty busy, it's cool.

Roughly about 10 minutes later--during which they told us we had to wait outside because we were "in the way"--we watched as a party of 8 tourists finish and leave. Did the staff at Joe Shanghai seat us--a party of 6?

NOPE.

Instead, they were waiting for a smaller table of 4 to finish and tried to seat us there, off in the corner. Their reasoning was that they wanted to "reserve" the larger table for a bigger party (of tourists, of course). And that's just fucked up on so many levels. Yeah, sure, you're going to make money off tourists anyway but fuck you if you think  a tourist's dollar is worth more than anyone else's.

THAT SAID:

Frankly, I'm not even sure why this place gets the kind of rep it does, as the siu long bao is okay but certainly not magical like pretty much all the reviews here state it is. I'd even go so far as to say that Shanghai Cafe over on Mott has better siu long bao.

And if you REALLY want their food, then just walk down a few stores to Joe Ginger. It's the same freaking place! The food is the same minus the crazy crowds and shitty staff! It's amazing that the reviews for Joe Ginger is worse than Joe Shanghai--is your life really that superficial that folks are going to laugh at you for checking in at one as opposed to the other?

The new place is not so great. Bad experience. Horrible. If it ain't broke don't fix it. I'm beyond upset. 

The line is not as fast or organized. Seating is slow but I was prepared  for that. 

Then we saw beer on the menu but when we went to order our usual Tsingtao they said they had no license for beer sales so I was stuck drinking Diet Coke which I don't care for. Water sucked with the dumplings. Not the same. What happened to the license? Maybe tell people! 

It took forever and a day to be seated but I didn't mind until we were basically told to hurry up and order almost immediately after being seated. So rude! 

Do not rush me. Ever. I took a subway from Times Square then walked seven blocks to get here. Wtf. 
Now let me mention this all was on Christmas Day. This was my Christmas meal! I'm am so upset to be treated this way. Unacceptable. 

I had to ask for water twice. Got weird looks from staff. Whatever. 

Had to ask for the customary ginger for the dumplings. It was exhausting. They brought the food out in stages. Bring it all out at once please. My complaints go on and on. 

The food is good but the new place sucks. Just sayin. Not sure I'll be returning.

Underwhelming. The skin of the pork soup buns is thick, almost gluey. Soup is oily and unflavorful. Everything we tried was tasteless and bland, and the dim sum menu wasn't impressive. I wasn't sure what the queue was for, or why it was so busy, since the experience was so subpar. There isn't anything to write home about their Chinese food -- Joe's Shanghai is plastered with awards won in the early 2000s. Spent time reading one on the walls, and the recommendation was for General Tso's, the shining beacon for inauthentic Chinese cuisine. So really, there was no difference between this store and the neighborhood Chinese place. Still searching for a reason for its popularity.
The soup dumplings was not good. Each dumpling I tried picking  up fell apart and the soup drained out before I could try it. Stay away from this place.

I was drawn in here because of the high rating and reviews. Was disappointed from the services to the foods. I ordered the pork Shanghai dumplings the skins were dried compared to other places. I asked for several times for water refills and additional dipping sauce.

I was Cold and Hungry.. The line was LONG.  So I decided to walk around and get a haircut..If you actually have time which most likely you will... you can explore around the block. 

The Bad:Do you feel rushed? Ofcourse you do! Forget about seating, if they can fit you in they will. The wait staff is there for one purpose and one purpose only to get you in and out ASAP. 

The Good: The Xiao Long Bao's are tasty, big, filling, but lack something. Maybe they made it like an assembly line fast and quick,  you can end up with a good batch or a bad batch. 
 
Bottom line I'll give them another try soon.
Food was excellent.  We had to share a table with another group as well which dinner a little awkward. My biggest complaint is the hostesses were rude and spoke very little English

The food was mediocre. The crab dumplings were not as juicy as I was expecting, and the noodles didn't have good texture to them. The worst part would be the service... The waiter wasn't attentive at all and the woman who seemed to be in charge didn't care to talk to any customer either. The overall experience was disappointing.

Here's my assessment:  I'd go again, if I could be seated without a wait.  Because frankly, we didn't find Joe's to be any better than other Chinatown restaurants.

Their claim-to-fame soup dumplings bring people in.  The challenge is to eat them without burning your gullet.  We tried a variety of things: salt n' pepper calamari (lackluster), Szechuan beef (spicy, in a bed of bean sprouts with a chili sauce that worked well with the calamari), pan fried noodles (boring), eggplant with pork in garlic sauce (our favorite dish, with a brown, slightly sweet sauce.)

Service is quick, d√©cor typical Chinatown -- really, nothing you haven't experienced.  Since I read 'cash only' on Yelp, that's how I paid.  You might want to call before assuming they take credit cards.

Great xiaolongbao. 

Could add some boiled/steamed options to the menu. Space could use some cleaning.

Can people stop hyping things please?! I came here with my family while on vacation because it was soooo overhyped by my sister's boyfriend. We had to share tables with other tourist which I don't mind as I'm use to doing that in Chinatown dim sum places back in SF. We ordered their oh so famous shanghai dumplings, green beans, Shanghai noodles and some other dishes. Their dumpling's skin is way too thick and the soup base is way too oily. It looks like I smeared Vaseline across my lips - not sexy. I can honestly say it was one of the worst dumpling's I've had. My grandma steams better ones from prepackaged store bought XLBS. I'm not even comparing these to din tai fung dumplings just the local dumpling places in sf and it still didn't pass the bar. Don't waste your time here!

My feelings about Joe's have cooled. Forgo the wait and the hype, give Shanghai Cafe (pretty close nearby) a try for their better soup dumplings.

Ps. Never go to the Joe's Shanghai in Midtown East. More expensive, worse tasting, even more of a tourist trap than this Chinatown location. But more details to follow in a future review...

There's definitely been a huge hype created around the soup dumplings (xiao long bao) and Joe's Shanghai - and I don't see what the fuss is all about. It's not even close to being the best soup dumplings that I have ever eaten (that honor goes to Ding Tai Fung in Taiwan; even the lesser one in Arcadia, CA is head and shoulders better than Joe's).

Basically, you enter Joe's and you order one thing and one thing only, their soup dumplings (either pork or crab). You share a table with another tourist family and you better hope that their well mannered. I once had a boy from another family sitting at the table start taking dumplings out of our steamer; definitely a weird moment. Anyways, the skin of the dumpling is definitely a little heavier, stickier, and some what unappetizing. The soup inside the dumplings is oily and heavy - and sometimes the actual meat itself was undercooked. 

Joe's, in my perspective, does not live up to its hype. But hey, you're talking to a guy that steamed his own dumplings hand made by a cute Chinese grandma; so maybe my expectations are a little high.

I would give this place a higher rating, but their noodles were not good. Only their baos were good, but not as good as the ones in Flushing, at this place called Nan Shian Dumpling House. If you can, go there instead!

The baos were okay at Joe's, but the soup seemed really thick. I like a thinner soup, and when I ate here a second, time, I was actually disappointed, because it was not as good as I remembered it. I went with my sister, and we ordered pork and crab baos, along with tendon noodle soup and a peking style minced pork noodle, just because it had the spicy sign next to it, and I love spicy! Boy, was I wrong in ordering that! When the dish came out, it looked nasty. It looked greasy and the noodles were drenched in this ketchup looking sauce, literally drenched. It was spicy, sweet, and salty, and that thick sauce was just all over the place. I didn't even finish it because it was that bad, and plus those two cartons of baos were enough. Nothing special about my sister's tendon noodle soup. None of us finished our noodles.There are better ones elsewhere, like Bo Ky, over at Bayard.  It would have been better for us to order only 1 noodle and shared it. 

I also went to the Joe's in Flushing. Pretty much the same. My friend and I ordered this pan fried noodle thing with pork. It was so greasy! I felt so greasy, and fat afterwards, and no matter how much I wipe my mouth, it still feels greasy, along with my whole face! I probably could use that leftover oil on the plate to cook me some veggies.

If you come here, just get the baos, and if you're still hungry, get something you've eaten before, or go elsewhere. Also, the last time I went, which was around last year, the tip was already included in with your bill.

It's basic Chinese , why is the line so long. Must be over 200 other restaurants in Chinatown serving the exact same menu.

I had the flounder and cold sesame noodles. I would recommend don't order this but I don't eat pork. Most other dishes here have pork including the dumplings. Can't they make a vegan dumpling? No not here. 

And it's cash only. What really annoyed me is that joes has a grade B for cleanliness. 
I will try other places in Chinatown. This one is for tourists only.

After getting off the bus from DC, my friend took me here for dinner.  I had no idea it was this popular, and although we waited a bit, it wasn't for too long.  However, since it was just the two of us, they seated us at a large table and we shared with a couple other people.  Could have been awkward, but we just talked to each other and ignored those around us.  We immediately ordered the crab and pork xiao-long bao while contemplating other food.  We eventually decided on a tofu with crab roe and a stir fried rice cake.

I'm not crazy about xlb, so while the crab and pork xlb were good, I didn't go gaga over them.  The tofu was really decent though as was the chao nian gao.  Several of us at the table ordered some form of chao nian gao.  We had plenty of food left over for her lunch the following day!

Extremely overrated and overpriced. Service was very fast, almost too fast as if they wanted us out of there asap. The food was not that great. No better than your corner take out place. For the prices they charge, I would expect far better.

Well Joe's congratulations on the new location! It's more accessible, bigger, brighter, and a huge upgrade looks wise than its original location. Although I'll surely miss the original spot because it had so much character! If you want to beat the crowds, try getting there around 11-11:30ish, which we did and our party of 8 waited less than 20 minutes.

New spot, same menu, same prices (surprising). Any trip to NYC meant a stop for XLBs at Joe's. At the new location, these are still really good! Definitely worth a try if you are a fan of XLBs.

What was disappointing was that the fried rice and the green beans don't have the same flavor. The fried rice used to be bright and moist. This visit  it was darker and dry.  Which is sad because I used to love their fried rice. The green beans also took a step back, leaving me wondering, where'd the flavor go?? 

Maybe the need time to break in the new kitchen, but until then, I can only remember the memories of what used to be remarkable

Food was mediocre at best. Service was authentically Asian which means pretty bad.  And mandatory 15% tip is absurd for this type of restaurant.  Where you can't even get your own table and is sharing with strangers to eat

Their scallion pancakes are the best ! I really dislike that so many people have overrated this place. I don't have a thing for their soup dumplings. I think the soup inside is a bit too thick. But otherwise, this shanghai restaurant is pretty good. Wouldn't come here with friends because the wait for a table is forever haha.

This place is hyped up with a bunch of lo fans, the soup dumplings taste like every other place in fact I had better ones. I went in for dinner on a Thursday night and it was packed with foreigners. I had one of the worst tables, it was near the dish and kitchen utensils, so the waiters keep brushing past me dropping my bag. If you do not like sharing tables, I suggest skipping this place, I had a waiter that kept brushing me because he needs that "open area" to take orders from people in the same table and its annoying. My soup spilled because he knocked my arms over. Not to mention the Lo fans took our tea by accident. The table was so cramped with food.

I ordered pork soup dumplings, chicken pan fried noodles, and salt and pepper pork chops. First off the soup dumplings taste like every other places. I like how the soup is flavorful and the skin was chewy. The noodles were okay, I was expecting the yellow version, the noodles in my opinion was very soggy and chewy which I like but it was too fried up. I wouldn't recommend the pork chop b/c it wasn't salt and pepper at all and most of them were fat.

Standards gone way down since I last visited 4 years ago.
Dumplings which is their Top Seller looks pretty messed up and the skin of the dumpling too thick and twisted really ugly . 
Soup inside was oily and dark colored.

Soft shell crabs were good but different way of ginger and onions.

Vegetarian duck was very tasty .

I dislike them trying to stick someone to sit next to a column !  We have to stand up when they have to put people on the next table , so it is really inconvenient to have a dumpling hanging on your mouth and then we're told loudly to stand up so others go in to the corner .  Told them they just need to do without one seat but they want every seat taken as it is $$ lost but we have to be inconvenienced to make it work for them.
With this kind of 1/10 service , I think I will skip
This restaurant on my next visit to NY .

Mehhh..... 

I have had really good XLB in Hong Kong and from Din Tai Fung in LA. I came here expecting XLB's similar to one's they serve at Din Tai Fung. If you are also expecting the same caliber let me lead you in the right direction and tell you to  look elsewhere because this place is not that. 

Get a ticket and wait until they call your number. The wait for two was closer to 45 minutes even though we were told 20 minutes at the door. If you don't like eating with strangers next to you then this place won't be for you either. There are only 4-5 large tables at this restaurant and everyone is jammed packed like sardines at each table. The service here takes Asian service to a whole new level; they are unbelievably bad. My girlfriend and I ordered 3 orders of XLB (two pork and 1 crab each coming with 8 soup dumplings). With communal dining it will be hard to fit your 3 orders of soup dumplings near you since the table is pretty cramped. Now the wait for the food was not bad, it took 10 ish minutes to come out. The soup dumplings were decently sized but extremely greasy. I wish I had taken a picture of my plate after I was finish eating. It got to the point where my lip was starting to get a shiny gloss from the grease. 

Now let's get back to the service. Service here is absolutely the worst. I was seated next to three white customers and the waiters pretty much ignored them. One of the ladies ordered a vegetable fried rice and another one ordered normal fried rice; when it came out both fried rices looked exactly similar there were no vegetables on it so she called over a water. The waiter just insisted it was vegetable fried rice which I find hard to believe. BTW the service charge (tip) is included in your bill already so make sure you don't overpay. Obviously they know their service is real crappy hence why they automatically charge you. Not only that the restaurant just feels grimy and disgusting. I would not recommend Joe's Shanghai to anyone. Let me be frank with you, soup dumplings are not supposed to be that greasy.
This place was really overrated. I've had soup dumplings all over and this place was highly recommended, don't know why. Service was good but food was very ordinary. Not worth the trip to Chinatown.

Having been convinced by yelp and a coworker to give it a try, i decided to finally try their Xiao Long Bao. I have tried  a TON of different places Xiao Long Bao in new york from Shanghai cafe to Shanghai Cuisine to Shanghai gabaghoul.

The Good: we did not have to wait long(like 2 mins) to get in. The waiters were responsive to us fast. The calamari in black bean sauce is quite good. Very spicy but good.

The bad: the Xiao Long Bao are only adequate. Not the best, not the worst. In addition the crab XLB tastes entirely too fishy. Also the service is not that great. I ordered a cup of water and he brings me a scalding hot glass of water. Umm wtf am i supposed to do with that?? Take a bath??Plus we got stuck next to some loud annoying idiots :|.

Summary: I felt like it was like going on a date with a REALLY popular person at school only to find out they have no personality. I kind of went expecting the XLB to give me some life altering experience and to redefine the Xiao Long Bao experience. Only to find out it wasn't even as good as some of the ones  I already had :|. Not gonna bother with this place again, the atmosphere is subpar with the xlb being average. There's better nearby :| and certainly not the second coming of Xiao Long Bao by any means necessary. If you're expecting angels to sing while you eat it, not gonna happen :|

Big lines, big bluster; not so hot.

Drawn to Joe's by virtue of it's renowned XLB, was willing to stand in line for an hour despite ample seating at nearby just-as-good Chinese joints.  Bad call.

XLB came piping hot, but dumpling skins were thicker here, and overall larger than their Din Tai Fung (and even Boston's Gourmet Dumpling House) counterparts.  Pork dumpling was certainly better than the pork/crab - as it is everywhere.  While okay hot, dumplings were nearly inedible when they cooled.

Other food is forgettable.  Crispy fried whole bass came with a sweet and sour spicy sauce.  Who puts sweet sauce on fish?  Fortunately, fish smelled fresh, and was otherwise a reasonable adventure.

There are better places for tourist food.  Go there instead.
Rude, curt staff.  Pell street is a shady dump.  Food is garbage, utter garb.  If you like shard, you'll like their dumplings.  Joe's on W 56th is much better.

I heard so many good things about Joe's shanghai dumplings, but it didn't live up to the hype. I had the crab and pork dumplings. The crab was definitely better than the pork. Their sesame pancakes were good, but a little too oily. I think din tai fung dumplings in LA are better.

Xiao long bao (soup dumplings) are kind of my thing. I was born in Shanghai, have eaten them all over Shanghai and in Nanxiang (the "original" home of XLB), and definitely eaten my fair share all over the US (including manhattan and flushing). 
It's all about calibrating expectations--are these as good as the ones you get in Shanghai? Not by a long shot--compared to the ideal, they are too big, the skins are too thick and sticky, and the soup is on the greasy side. But--the flight to NYC (or train ride to Chinatown) is MUCH shorter than the one to Shanghai. 
The regular ones here are not bad by Manhattan standards (yes, there are better ones in Flushing, but again, unless you already live out there, it's kind of a trek), the service is quick and efficient, and it is kind of fun to look around at the various celebrity photos dotting the walls. 
The crab ones are probably best avoided--the ones we got tasted "off" and had bits of grit and shell in them.

I laughed a bit to myself when I read some of the earlier reviews of Joe's with tales of food other than the dumplings... Who tries the food other than the dumplings at Joe's?!?! Well, I guess a bunch of people did, and that's what we have these reviews for! 

Joe's is actually a chain, and the Chinatown restaurant isn't the #1 store... I'm *told* the location in Flushing is the one where the reputation for soup dumplings came from. This one in Chinatown is obviously more accessible (and infested with tourists) and has great dumplings, and then there's the red-headed stepchild of Joe's, up in midtown... Maybe there are more, but I haven't been to them.

Go straight for the dumplings. They're fun and challenging and delicious all rolled into one, and it's enjoyable to go with a group of friends and pile up the steamer containers towards the ceiling as you gorge your senses and tummies with those little soupie dumplings!

Their location recently moved to this new location at Bowery. We have always loved soup dumplings and we visit joe Shanghai every single time we visit New York. we always felt joe Shanghai is much better than Din Tai Fung with their amount of soup actually in the dumpling. It has been in few years so we were excited to go back to joe. Good thing we checked on google because we did not realize they had moved from their old Chinatown location. We arrived at 1:45pm on Saturday and had to wait for 30 minutes which we did not mind considering how good these are. We finally made it in and had to share a table which is always the case. The dumplings were good as usual but the service was very very slow. We ordered 3 baskets and it took over 30 mins. Plus, by the time we finished our last basket the last dish still had not arrive yet. We were very disappointed. I am not sure if it's the new kitchen and them working out the kinks but service was less than desirable.

It's good if you don't have to wait long for a table.  We came when they first opened, and ended up having to share a table with 2 other parties.  Always find that awkward -- and not sure the food hype really justified the compromised experience of having to sit with a bunch of strangers.  Cash only (of course, it's Chinatown) so be prepared.

The soup dumplings were good and seafood panfried noodles were average. But, it is so Americanized, and I think they scam people a little bit. For example, adding a service charge on the receipt.  Plus, they make such a big deal about how amazing their dumplings are, but I can most likely walk down the block and get dumplings just as tasty. The service here is on your back the whole time and you feel really rushed.

PLEASE READ: Cash only, made for tourists, would not recommend. Pricey and not worth it.

This place is trash. I'm visiting NYC for the first time, coming from Los Angeles. I've had my fair share of authentic Chinese food in the San Gabriel Valley such as Dragon Noodle, Mama Lu's, and Din Tai Fung. I saw this place had 7k reviews with a 4 star rating. They were multiple reviews with 1 or 2 star rating saying it wasn't worth it, however with the amount of positive reviews I gave it a shot.

We ordered the crab soup dumplings, cold noodle with sesame sauce, pork fried dumplings, and shredded pork with pickled cabbage soup.

CRAB SOUP DUMPLINGS: Horrible, they were big and filled with lots of soup, however the soup was so FATTY AND OILY. I couldn't drink after I tried it. Ugh thinking about it makes me sick. The skin and meat tasted good at least.

COLD NOODLE W/ SESAME SAUCE: Tasted more like peanut butter. Generic taste. Was below average.

PORK FRIED DUMPLINGS: Filling was average at best and not enough. Could barely taste the meat and very bland. Would not recommend this. Soaking in the sauce made it taste better.

SHREDDED PORK W/ PICKLED CABBAGE SOUP: Meat was tender, broth did not look appetizing, it tasted good though so it was fine.

Coke: 12oz can, the best thing I had here.

Overall we paid $60 for all these items and I left disappointed. It wasn't even that good. Should have gone somewhere else.

So many of my NYC friends recommended this place so we were expecting delicious dumplings. We ordered 2 pork dumplings and 2 combo dumplings to share. We also ordered the scallion pancakes and pea leaves in garlic. The dumplings were good but NOT good enough if I had to wait to eat here. The pancake and pea leaves in garlic were good though. The food was really cheap though.

Except for being an anchor in the heart of New York City's Chinatown, Joe's Shanghai was just your average Joe.

Oh, the XLB are ok ... just far from amazing. Seriously, I've been to Shanghai several times. The XLB dumplings are so much better there (or in Taiwan) ... and even better in So Cal ... or Flushing. This can NOT be the best Xiao Long Bao that New York has to offer. Please tell me there are better XLB out there. Please.

Ok, don't trust me? How about my wife? She was born and raised in Shanghai China. Her take is the same as moi: any Xiao Long Bao is better than none, but Joe's Shanghai XLB were just a-ok. There's nothing wrong with being an average Joe either. 

After about a 15 minute wait we were seated at a round table ... with another 2 couples and a single diner. Yep, 4 different parties sharing the same table. Luckily, they were nice and everyone was there with one thing on their mind: Xiao Long Bao. My wife and I shared a double order of Joe's famous steamed Pork and Crab XLB (Xiao Long Bao) and an order of fried egg rolls listed as Shanghai Spring Rolls on the menu. 

Three stars for the average Joe's Xiao Long Bao. Two stars for the Shanghai Spring Rolls. Two stars for the communal loud dining experience and two stars for rushed chaotic service. Unfortunately for Joe's Shanghai, Yelp ratings aren't cumulative cause that would make it a 9-star restaurant. Actually, I'm not even sure why it's getting 3 from me except I'm a sucker for any Xiao Long Bao ... even those from just your average Joe.
Everything is so salty and they don't even taste good.  There are so many other place that are way better everywhere else.

Joe you're so close to being a 4 banger!  But the mandatory 15% gratuity, cash only, and you made me feel rushed when I was trying to enjoy the explosion of your extremely juicy dumplings in my mouth.

It's pretty amazing how much soup they put in their XLB.  I had XLB at other places and although some were tastier, maybe less expensive, and even let me take my time slurping their juice, Joe packs it in BIG.  It was also nice that Joe's green pancake was yummy and wasn't oily as most others I've had.

So here's three stars for you dumpling man.  See you next time when I'm in Chinatown picking up fake LV.

I had the turnip cakes, scallion pancake, and the soup dumplings.  Everything was ok - meh - edible.  Nothing was fantastic or well executed.  It is cheap though.  I suspect the high ratings are from tourists who don't know what good Chinese food is supposed to be.  

The soup dumplings were the biggest disappointment-- they're over-sized and poorly made.  The truly good and authentic xiao long bao establishments make them just big enough to barely fit int your mouth in one bite.  These are huge and the top knot of the dumpling is messy and will come unraveled.  

Meh. Don't need to come back here again.

I came here for lunch with hubby and his friend. Joe's Shanghai used to be packed during lunch but not so much anymore, likely because there are newer restaurants in Chinatown. We were seated right away on Sunday at 12:30pm. 

We ordered 2 orders of crab soup dumplings, a Peking style minced pork noodle and a pork pan fried noodle. Portions are big, hence we could barely finish. Dumplings used to be better, they were a bit dry today. Both noodles were a bit too salty for my taste, there was an overwhelming amount of sauce on top. Hubby's friend liked it though.

Service was the same, they have enough waiters standing around to take your order and clean your table the minute you are ready.

The bill was $40 including tips, well worth it!

What a rush! They want you in and out. Got the check without even asking for it. 

The food was mediocre. The best was the little soup buns.  They didn't even have the pan fry buns. What kinda Shanghainese restaurants don't have Shang Jian baos??

Service was a rush as I mentioned. What pissed me off the most was when the waiter placed the piping hot xiao long baos in front of my daughter. Like wtf. There are plenty of space in the middle of the table. This place is overrated and I won't be back.

Soup Dumpling's!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I went here yesterday for a meetup with my girlfriend's friends and I have to say is wow. First off you do have to go looking for this place a little bit cause it is off the beaten path a little bit. It doesn't seem to be to hard to find however since the place was packed and when we left I overheard more people down the street saying they were going there.

I never even heard of soup dumplings before last night and now Im just mad I haven't. The people I was with ordered 2 servings and we went to town. The service was fast and Im pretty sure they probably have a guy just making soup dumplings all day back in the kitchen. Anyway I digress, We also ordered beef with string beans, Shrimp Lo-Mein and General Tso's Chicken. The food was all delicious and spicy just how I ordered it. The Sake was perfect nice and "walm" and I only have two complaints about this place which brought its rating down to a three. 

The first one is I don't know if its an asian thing or what not but I cannot stand eating at a table with complete strangers, which I have only experienced one other time at Pho restaurant. I can't stand this practice especially with the spin thing on the table your food spins around this rando's and the same with there food in your face when your friend is grabbing a dumpling.

Number 2: The wait staff holy crap take a chill pill guys. I swear It felt like as soon as you sat down they were trying to push you right back out the door.

I Never wanted to try Joe's Shanghai based on a hunch it's american (white people) asian food. Well, the restaurant was just around where I was, so why not?

We ordered 2 dishes : fried dumplings and pork soup dumplings, solely because that's what they are "famous" for. Big disappointment. The dumpling skin is fine, not too thick, and the soup was just fine, but the meat was lacking of almost any real depth of flavour. Usually fried dumplings are hard to get wrong in any other restaurant because they are so basic, yet joe's Shanghai failed on both. Both dishes had almost no flavour. 

We had to ask for chili paste/hot sauce, and even their hot oil chili paste also had almost no taste LOL. Sorry, this one is all hype and there are better Shanghainese restaurants in NYC

Service just hit or miss. Its not bad but it's not great. It's asian restaurant in chinatown anyway. And they put 15% "service charge" automatically on the check. I just pitied them and add $1 extra tip on top of the service charge for $16 food ( before tax and tip ) so total I gave the mediocre service 25%. 

I live in NYC so I'm not a big fan when they put the tip automatically for party of 2. My assumption maybe is tourists' area and generally they don't tip. Oh well....

Not recommend this place. Unless u want to eat mediocre food. For Xiao long bao I suggest " Nang Xiang Xiao long bao" in flushing

I had such high hopes here... but I had kind of a shitty experience. The waiter was your typical rude chinese guy (whatever, used to it) but he kept rushing our table even though it was not very busy. The soup dumplings were not made with love. Half of them stuck and popped as I gently removed them - hell, I was operating like it was heart surgery and they just couldn't make it.

After reading the reviews I stopped into Joe's for a late lunch. It was a fun experience trying someone now and we had seen that there were a lot of reviews we stopped in. We had the pork dumplings chicken Kung poa and flat noodles.  The dumplings were okay but the flat noodles were out of this world. We ordered ours with seafood. If and when I go back I'll definitely try something similar if not the same exact thing. We shared a table which was fine and atmosphere was definitelyactive. I would definitely recommend stopping in if you've got some time on your hands. Fun experience and good food.

Not really good & delicious as people comment 
Eggplant too sweet
Crispy shredded beef very sweet
The soup dumplings only good with the meat. The wrapper super thick.
We were expected for the roasted bejinh duck but we super disappointed.

I had pork soup dumplings to go and they were really terrible. I really wanted to love it at least 10% but I cannot to any extent reconcile the other reviews with my experience. The dumplings smelled so awful I wanted to gag, like rotten tomatoes,and I was 90% certain the cabbages in the dumplings had gone bad. I was really questioning whether they had prepared a batch that they had been planning on throwing away for me,it was that bad,since I had informed them that I was in a hurry and had to catch a bus.1 portion has 8 dumplings, I was only able to stomach about 3. Taste aside, the texture of the dumplings wasn't phenomenal, it was about the same thickness as average Chinese fast food dumplings. I've had really good. dumplings in Hong Kong so I'm using that as my yardstick. The only reason I gave them two stars is because the extra star is for customer service.

This place is usually over crowded and I never got a chance to go there at normal hours. 

The only time I went was a week night about an hour before they close. 

The soup dumplings are highly overrated. If you have tried the authentic soup dumplings in Shanghai, you know exactly what I mean. Not impressed. Perhaps one of the reasons the dumplings were below par was because I went there late and they gave me crappy leftovers, well, I don't know. 

The cold-served appetizers are pretty decent. I also enjoyed their cheap Tsing Tao beer.

Might as well be inedible. The service included an inefficient hostess, a throw the menu on the table waiter and a money hungry waiter who yelled " time to collect the money" and then not give us change. I wouldn't have mind the change if he haven't make such a remark so loudly. In addition the place was super loud so I had trouble  hear myself the whole time. 
For starters we got the shredded pork and pickled cabbage soup. There were not cabbage in the soup -_-  and too much gross tasting pork. Tasted like pork and some weird pickle boiled in msg water. 
Now for the star of the show, their most prized dish, soup dumplings... We got both varieties the pork soup dumplings and the crab meat soup dumpling. First of all, the wrapping of the soup dumplings were tough, sticky and way to thick but even so they manage to have almost all of them leaking. The pork soup dumplings were almost flavorless with the remainder of the filling. And the crab meat soup dumpling tasted and smelled like rotten seafood being masked with pork... It stunk so bad I gagged and thought I was going to throw up. So thank god for the oranges they provide at the end of the meal since I couldnt get rid of the taste regardless of how much tea I've gulped down afterwards.

Not worth the wait. I've been going here for 15 years. The food is usually quite good. But I had a really bad experience Saturday night. It was about 20 degrees out. I was in a party of four. we waited well over an hour while the girl at the door kept taking in parties of 7 and 8 that arrived long after we did. I finally started harassing her and asking her why she was making us wait when they were seating large groups that had just shown up. I get that it's hard to find room for big groups but all they have there are big tables and they empty out constatnly. We finally insisted that they pair us with a group of 3 and seat us the next time they had room for 7, which was about 10 minutes later. To top it off, the food was mediocre and I notice they got a B from the health dept. Sigh. Really, really, really disappointed by the way we were treated. Especially awful due to the weather and the fact that we had friends from out of town. It was late - we arrived at 745 and were not seated until almost 9 pm and we were starved by the time we sat down. Any normal restaurant would have apologized and given us a free appetizer or something. But no, they acted like we were wrong to ask for a table after waiting patiently for 45 minutes and seeing people seated who'd just shown up again and again. If you MUST go here, and you are a group of 3 or 4, I advise you to connect with the next small group that arrives and put yourselves on the list twice - as individual parties of 3 and 4, and then as one larger group of 7 or 8. i guarantee the big group will get seated first.

Terrible service. They made us wait for a long time, and we got in line just like any civilized citizens not to block the street... We heard them calling out our number, walked to the door and they already gave our table to someone else. I can't imagine what kind of food would give them such attitude.

I've had many many xlb throughout my life, the best is still Din Tai Fong dumpling house from Taiwan.  Joe's weren't bad, but the skin on the dumplings were still too thick.  It was deliciously juicy nonetheless, and the crab dumplings were even tastier.  I recommend getting both the crab and the regular to compare!   We arrived before 7 on a Saturday, only waited 10 min.  It may look like alot of ppl but it moves very quickly.
I'm not really sure what the hype is. After getting XLB from Ding Tai Fung many many times this place can't even compare. I think I prefer Shanghai Cafe and other places instead.

The Â∞èÁ¨ºÂåÖ here is definitely good. I used to come a lot, but now it's become a tourist spot and the wait is too long. They also put parties together at one large table, which is uncomfortable sometimes. While the food is good, the experience isn't that great, so it loses some stars. Also their other dishes aren't that great. There are other comparable soup dumpling places nearby that offer a better overall experience.

I'd have to say my experience here was mediocre. I suppose I'm not used to a fast-paced environment like this. My party of six was seated at a table with a party of four. It was a little uncomfortable, but wasn't all so bad. As some other reviewers said, they tried to cram as much business in as they could. Even the service was very rushed.

I had originally had a mind-set for dim sum so I didn't really know what to order. Our waiter went ahead and suggested their golden item, the (what I know them as) soup buns. We ordered both the pork buns and pork and crab buns. I wasn't all too amazed as everyone seems to be. The pork buns itself didn't hold a lot of flavor, but the buns with the crab meat was all... seafood-y. I think I preferred the crab combo rather than pork by itself. We also tried to order some wonton soup (I don't quite remember) and they told us it would take about 45 minutes because it was frozen. Not very easing, but at least they were being honest. The scallion pancakes were just dough. I'm more familiar with the ones that are cooked into a bubble so I was kind of disappointed to see the plate in front of me presentation-wise.

Other than that, the buns came out fairly quick. Not bad for something you don't see at a normal Chinese take-out.

Single visit, August 2022: We only tried the soup dumplings. They were decent, but fall short in authenticity. They were almost double the size of soup dumplings in the actual city of Shanghai, and had much thicker skins.

To be fair, most soup dumplings in the USA follow a similar recipe, but when the restaurant has "Shanghai" in the name and is situated in NYC Chinatown, we'd expect better.

Not what's it's made out to be. It's somewhat traditional in its preparation but the portions are small and the food is not that great. There are many more tiny Chinese restaurants just down the block that offers equally if not better food at lower prices. Plus, you get to skip the ridiculous line that always builds up in front of the establishment. The decor is very old as are the menus and furniture. I wasn't very comfortable, especially because my menu was kind of soaking, but it's not so dirty id leave. It's to be expected of an old Chinese restaurant. From a Chinese native, I'd recommend you look elsewhere for authentic tasty food. However, if you're just looking for a quick bite and you're lucky enough to not be greeted by a 15 min wait, then go ahead. It's not entirely bad.

Communal tables, cash-only, and screwy line system - this place is, HANDS DOWN, not my favorite place to be in. 

You come in, get a number, and wait outside with the masses. The annoying part was that they don't call the numbers in order, or at least that's what happened when I was there. The disorganization has nothing to do with your party size either. When you're finally called, you're seated with a bunch of strangers. I'm thankful to have been seated with two others on the half-table by the wall, but even then, they kept staring at us because they didn't know how to eat soup dumplings.

The food here is pretty good and cheap considering the flavor and amount you get. I wouldn't say it's 4k+ 4-star reviews good, but still ok. Of course as everybody mentioned, the thing to get are the xiao long bao, or soup dumplings - but there are only two choices: pork or toilet. I mean, crabmeat. Obviously the crab one is my lesser favorite because of its fishy fishy broth, but it's ok! The pork one is cheaper so win-win!

Foods decent but the wait just makes it not worth it. Lots of people rave about this chinese food so maybe it just set my expectations too high. Price wasn't friendly either but understandable. I've been living in NYC for few years now so I know there are many better options out there.

Expectation for the Xiao long bao is that you'll pick it up gentle while it's form is still in tact, then putting it on a spoon. You then bite the top to let the soup cool off, and eat it. 

Reality is that the Xiao long baos were put over Napa cabbage. The Napa cabbage is suppose to become a barrier for the container and the dumpling so it won't stick. Parts of the dumpling stuck onto the container causing the dumpling to rip and the soup to spill out. Another is that these dumplings are suppose to fit on your spoon perfectly however these dumplings were so oversized! Even when I did have a perfect formed dumpling, when I bit the top, the soup would just fall off the spoon! That's not how you're suppose to eat the dumplings. The taste was great, but the whole point of xiao long baos was because of its soup, and for that reason I give this restaurant 3 stars. 

SERVICE: 
Service was on the other hand pretty great! The staff seems super attentive even when the restaurants packed with customers! All Asian employees but know and speak English well!

Do yourself a favor and DO NOT wait over 30 minutes MAX in line. There are similar restaurants in the area that do not come with the wait. This place is VERY average when it comes to Asian cuisine. The Lao Ming is edible. What really places this place on the map is the pork soup dumplings. They're tasty. Careful though, the soup inside is hot. You don't wanna pop one of these in your mouth. The soup dumplings are really the only reason to come here, but even they are not worth waiting over 30 mins in line for.

Soup dumplings/xiao long bao-5 stars
Any other dish-2 stars (barely)
Service-1 star

Their soup dumplings is excellent: chewy and elastic skin that holds all the delicious juice in while the filing is well balanced and seasoned.  And not to mention they are decently sized as well!

But that's pretty much where it ends; eat your soup dumplings and run!  We made the mistake or ordering Peking style minced meat noodles and st saut√©ed shredded beef and they were both horrible!  The noodles was gooey and had no bite, the sauce on top was bland and has no flavor and was basically one big starchy mess with no sight of any meat.  I actually took one bite, and sent it back and didn't even bother asking them to pack it up or for a refund, just wanted it out of my site.

As for service, I know that Chinatown is NOT known for it, but when your server who works at a place known for their soup dumplings tried to rush you but taking your last two delicious soup dumplings out of the steamer and onto your plate and BREAKS THE SKIN this releasing the purpose of the soup dumplings without any hesitation or apology, it is not acceptable.  Especially when 15% service charge is built in regardless of party size.

Bottom line, come for the xiao long bao/soup dumplings and nothing more.

The soup dumplings here are 5 stars. I prefer the pork one over the one with crab. They're delicious and hot and the soup is very flavorful. The other dishes here are 4 stars. We got noodles, calamari, and fried rice. The noodles were really good, but the calamari was very bland. I didn't taste the rice so I have nothing to say about that, but my friends all said the food was pretty good, except for the calamari. The service here is negative stars. So everything kind of averages out to the 3 stars I have to give them. Do not come here expecting any amazing or decent service. Their service here, as my friend would describe it, is exceptional... exceptionally horrible. 

We came here for dinner and knew this place was famous for their soup dumplings. Unless you're a party of 10, you will be sharing a table with another party. We didn't want that at first because we're never used to it in Boston, but eventually we didn't mind. We ordered the food, and when the food came, the server literally tossed the food on the table. When it was time for the bill, I reached out my hand so the server could hand it to me, but instead he threw it over to me even though my hand was on the bill. 15% tips is already included and I could understand why they would do that because if they don't, they wouldn't be getting a tip at all. Their service here is just horrible that you have to keep reminding yourself you're here for the food not for the service. Overall, I would definitely recommend coming here to try their soup dumplings, but after you're done with the food, just leave. Staying any longer would just make you feel very uncomfortable because they're just so rude.

$hady, terrible customer service and I got bed-ridden sick the next day.


They have no consideration for your time.  At firstw e were told it was a 45 minuate wait.  It ended up being a 3 hour wait even though they saw us with an 8-yr old child.  No matter how I beeged them if he could have simply a bowl of rice while we waited, they pretended they didnt hear.  Just the nastiest tbing you could do, but to these people asking for an ounce of humaity is asking too much.
Second, they are cash only and sneakily automatically place the tip on the bill, so tnhey end up getting a double tip if you dont take the time to read the bill.
The next day I was bed ridden with a fever cold-sweat and shivering with chiils, blood-red eyes.  I did not recover for another 72 hours regardless of how many medications I took.
be careful.

For the first time in my life I feel compelled to write a review about something I am completely upset about it.  I don't even want to give a 1 star rating because I don't believe it even deserves that!  I wanted to give a full explanations why I will never come here again! First I want to point out the 2 people who made this experience miserable - Jean and Clare (Jean is the one with glasses behind the counter and Clare is the tall one who seats people), I have to put that out there because they are the rudest hostesses I have ever encountered!  I made reservations in advance for 16 ppl (as we had family coming out of town and I thought taking them to Joe's Shanghai would be a nice treat, boy was I wrong).  Our reservations were for 7pm on a Friday night for 16 ppl.  I was told on the phone that all parties must be present to be seated and I asked you don't give a grace period and the person on the phone said 15 minutes late we give away table - which to me was fair.  Friday night 6:50pm I receive a call from the restaurant - and meanwhile I'm standing right outside waiting for the rest of my party to arrive, they were asking if I am still coming and I said I am right outside waiting for everyone to arrive and the person on the phone said ok.  6:59pm I receive another call from them asking when am I arriving and I said I'm right outside so I walk in and I speak to Clare and she asked if all our party was here and I said no, just 6 of us, then Jean screamed you gonna lose your table.  I informed her when I called the person said they wait 15 mins for all parties to arrive and she said who took your reservations?  Really, how the heck am I suppose to know that and Jean screams I give you 5 mins!  By this time it was 7:05 and some of my party arrived so there were 12 of us (missing 4 who were stuck in unbelievable traffic!).  My sister started to say to Jean, why cant you seat us, we can order for everyone right now (and it got to the point she had to convince Jean that we are ready and Jean or Clare started to count how many of us were there and says if there's 14 I will seat you!).   Luckily a guy (who I think may have been the manager) said ok we will seat you.  Mind you by this time I was ready to leave because before the time that the 6 ppl from party arrived I was already having a screaming match with Jean and Clare who kept insisting I'm going to lose my table. With a party of 16 we had 2 separate tables but the one that seated 6, they gave away and our party had to be split into 2 tables and 6 of us had to share a large table while 10 of us were at the table next to them. By 7:15pm all 16 of us were there!  If it wasn't for my family, I would've left and never came back. To make matters worse, 2 tables down from us there was a party of 7 with only 4 people there and 30 mins later the rest of their party of 3 arrived.  Now tell me why were they allowed to be seated when everyone from their party wasn't there and not us?  When I asked Clare she said they had reservations!!! WTH I had reservations too!! For 16!!!! They cater to tourists and being Asian (as I am), they treat you like crap!!  Well that's how Jean and Clare treated us! We spent close to $300 on our meal and it wasn't even an enjoyable one. The food was subpar and having 6 people in our party sit with strangers was just totally wrong!  If it wasn't for the rest of my party I would've left and been happy to spend my money elsewhere. I did speak to the manager (I think) and he apologized and said Fridays are usually busy and I said don't take reservations then if you can't accommodate your guests. To Jean and Clare, there is a special place for people like you because of your attitude, you do not know how to treat your customers. I will never, ever, ever be going back there and I'll be sure as heck to NEVER recommend Joe's Shanghai!

3.5 stars. 

Food: Pretty decent. Had the crab xiaolongbao to start, which were definitely good, but not excellent. The meat tasted fresh and there was a good soup to skin ratio, but the skin was a little bit too thick. The other two dishes we tried (kao fu-traditional Shanghainese bean curd dish and a pork noodle soup) were also pretty tasty but fairly standard fare. 

Environment: I recognize that there is limited space in Chinatown, but this type of overcrowding was just a bit too much for me. My friend and I shared a round table with another party and there was limited space between all of the tables. If you're not afraid to squeeze and are looking for cheap Shanghainese food, then this is not a bad choice! But personally the environment detracted too much from the food.

Joes Shanghai six years ago was much different and better than my most recent visit. Unfortunately, the crab soup dumplings and regular soup dumplings lacked the same light dumpling wrapper and filling we remembered. The soup inside also had more fat renderings than I'd like. The restaurant was renovated but unfortunately the meal lacked luster this time around. Service was fine. Cash only to avoid credit card charges, plus an automatic 18% gratuity is included.

Horrible customer service. They rushed us to order and eat so they can seat the tourist. This place caters to tourist because they think they can make more money off them. Food was subpar but there are other great soup dumpling restaurants out there. Please is ridiculously small and packed. I would never come back here and would never recommend this place to anyone.

Really really really bad service. And this is why Chinese restaurants get a bad wrap. You shouldn't yell at your customers. This "younger" server literally YELLED at us for asking about the status of our dumplings. When I say YELL, I mean't YELL. The "older" server handled the situation much better in a much more civil manner. 

We ordered crab dumplings and it took them close to 30 minutes to give us our order. Of course we're not happy. I understand most people ordered the pork dumplings so crab dumplings take longer. But the guys next to us who ordered the same time as us also ordered crab dumplings. They got theirs right away. Therefore, something must have gone wrong. 

Anyway, the food is good. But service is unacceptable. You shouldn't YELL at your customers and think it's okay because you're some famous Chinese restaurant in NY.

the dumplings are good. so are the pan fried noodles. for some reason though, they seem to have trouble making beef. always seems tough and leathery to me. stay away from the beef dishes and you should be fine...

The only thing that's god is the dumpling. Everything is bad. Seafood casserole was made from frozen seafood bag and it was dry. Didnt like it all all. I also ordered Chilean Sea bass. It was so oily and totally destroyed the fish. Also they didnt descaled the dish so i ate a mouthful of scales ! 
BAD

Not being familiar with the area, I found this place via Yelp. Walking to this place and based on the exterior I was a little hesitant to go inside. We decided to give it try. As we sat down we quickly realized how popular this place was with many locals and regulars. Pros: based on our experience, The food was great! Probably would've given them 4-5 stars based on the food however.. Cons: they do make you share tables with strangers even when there's half of the restaurant empty. They are cash only. And thank goodness for the yelp heads up, they do automatically add a 15% gratuity into the bill.

Pros - GREAT food in an authentic China-town restaurant!!  Service was very fast and prompt! Five stars for these aspects!

Cons (and what prompted me to give 3 stars) - it was SO cold! I understand cool temps are better than warm temps. But, almost every diner had her/his coat on while eating (so it wasn't just us) and almost every table has some or all seats right below vents blowing cool air. So, that was a big drawback. It's not a deal-breaker, though....it was our 3rd time there and we'll return for more delicious food :)

Xiao long bao is what this place is about.  Secret of beating the lines is to do lunch around 11:00 AM.  Still a light chance of a wait but its not long.

The waiter/host staff are as awful as it can get.  They do treat you like sh_t, like they are doing you a favor for letting you eat here.   I put up with it because I'm here visiting once a year from CA.  NYC is where I grew up.

Their cold apps are very good, the cold braised beef and jelly fish are some of the best I've tasted but I come here for their xiao long bao.  I get one tray of each, with and w/o crab.  This fills my appetite and I'm off to the next great meal in NYC.

5 stars for the food, 0 star for the staff.  I rounded UP because their food is really good.

The soup dumplings are good. Plenty of soup and flavorful meat. That's great if that's all you want to eat. If you plan on ordering something else, DON'T.

I think it would be hard to screw up beef noodle soup, but they did. Two orders of it. The noodles were extremely soggy, so it was probably already sitting out or they overcooked the nasty noodles and served it anyway. Or maybe it's b/c we're not Chinese they figured we wouldn't notice? Ugh.

If you want good dumplings and good food, go to Shanghai Cafe!

The soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai have a pretty thick skin. They're also not made very well, so the little twist you usually get on top of the dumpling forms a big, chewy knot of dough. Maybe you like that. I don't. The filling inside isn't spectacular either- I think they overfill the skins, so that by the time you get your dumplings, most of them have already burst and all the soup has leaked out. Joe's is pretty overrated, IMO. I'll stick with Shanghai Cafe- it's cleaner, brighter and cheaper.

Now it's really going downhill. Joe's in Chinatown is full on part of the tourist circle of life. It is on par with the out of towner ranks of the Carnegie Deli or even Serendipity in Midtown, where the waits are long and the food is overpriced. The kind of establishments where Zagat rates them as a "must visit."

Folks who have never experienced the wonder of a soup dumpling are sure to  marvel at Joe's. The explosion of pork and crab juices in one's mouth is already an amazing feat, but soup dumpling cherry popping experience is frequent here. And despite it's rather mediocre results over the last few years, most folks simply come here because they know no other alternative. Being famous helps, in addition to the fact most of the staff speaks fairly solid English here.

The prices are "generally"  considered inexpensive overall, but are definitely pricier than some of their competing neighbors. It's nothing absurd like the Midtown Joe's Shanghai (http://www.yelp.com/biz/joes-shanghai-new-york) and the food isn't nearly as tasty as its Flushing location (http://www.yelp.com/biz/joes-shanghai-flushing).

One would think that with more foreign customers the restaurant would somehow attempt to differentiate itself by offering better service. Nope. It's still just as shoddy and as rough around the edges as ever. How's being rushed out after waiting an hour plus for subpar dumplings feel now?

Other soup dumplings really can't compare to those found here. The broth of the soup dumplings is my favorite part---it's really intriguing and has an almost creamy mouth feel. The exterior pouch is a little too thick for me but I think it helps to retain the broth. The dumplings come out super hot in a steamer. Pierce the dumpling, sip out the broth, spoon some chili paste and soy sauce on top, and eat the rest of the dumpling. Eat them quickly or they will start sticking to the steamer and all the broth will ooze out. Though they offer pork and crab and pork dumplings-- I really can't taste the difference between them so I opt for the less expensive pork dumplings. The dumplings are cheap and an order of 8 pork dumplings is just $5. 

Their other dishes however were disappointing to me and there were so many other places in the area that offer better food. Everything I have tasted so far was really generic and bland. The dishes were also overpriced, ranging around $10-15 a plate. I recommend skipping out on their main dishes and going somewhere else for dim sum.

Service is never really stellar here [nor is it anywhere else in China Town]. So expect a sullen face and the feeling that they are trying to rush you out of there. 

I usually come here just for snack and I try to come during odd times so that I don't have to wait.  I don't think  the dumplings themselves warrant a long wait, but I think they are definitely a must try when visiting the area.  

Food: 3
Value: 3.5
Service: 2.5

Overall: 3

We were told by one of our friends that this was a very touristy place that there were xiao long bao's better elsewhere... Regardless, we went anyways just to see if it lived up to the hype. The restaurant inside was very authentic, there were full tables of different parties eating together and busy workers running about. My visit here was a while ago so I can't remember every detail about my visit here. I only remember how I was mildly disappointed in the hype. 

We ordered 1 crab and 1 pork xiao long bao. None of them amazed me. It was just okay? The skin of the little baos constantly broke. A few of them in our baskets were already broken when we got them. I'm not going to blame it on our chopstick use since even using the utmost care, we broke them. I preferred the pork ones much better than the crab, while my sister preferred the crab. It might be down to just your own personal taste. 

It was an alright meal to be had, but it didn't get rid of my hankering for really yummy xiao long baos... Perhaps I'll just have to go back to my boyfriend's place so his mom could finally put my cravings to an end.

Love love love the soup dumplings there. And the price is good. 

Their service is fast once you get the table (normally has a long waiting, they do not take reservation). 

Need to sit with strangers on the round tables, if you wanna get private table, the wait will be even longer.

This place is a tourist restaurant. This was probably the only restaurant that I had to share tables with strangers, besides dimsum. This place is just way too crowded. The tables and chairs are so close to one another, there is nowhere to move. Lost count of how many times either the staff or customers bumped me. Although the food does come outta quickly, it does make you feel rush.

We got xiaolongbao, scallion pankcake, hot and sour soup and crispy seafood noodle to share. The noodle portion was big since it was fried so that wasn't too bad. Xiaolongbao is good here.

Overall, the atmosphere of the restaurant, does not make me want to come back.

We came here around noon and boy, the place was packed.  But things ran pretty smoothly with the servers herding the customers like cattle.  Avoid bringing more than four people with you or they might have to seat you in separate groups.

Got two orders of the crab soup dumplings.  Pretty tasty but a bit salty.  Will have to try the pork next time!

Shanghai cafe is my go-to for xiao long bao but every so often I would visit Joe's for their hearty version of the soup dumplings. I hadn't been there for a while so I decided to pay a visit today and I was kind of disappointed. I thought the taste was really bland. The first round of the dumplings were undercooked so they tried again with another round and the second time it was over cooked. Still, I got my fix but I think I'll leave these dumplings for the tourists from now on.

We were craving good Chinese food, so we came here, based on "word of mouth." It was OK, but it needed to be better. Food was plentiful, yet bland. No particular difference between the dishes that were marked spicy and the ones that were not. I was looking for flavor, and I didn't get it.
Totally and completely overrated.  Skip it-service is totally rushed-dishes are marginal at best.  Not memorable....

Came here around 12ish on a Saturday no wait, if you go later you'll probably have a wait as I've come after 2 pm twice and both times there was a wait of over 30 mins. FYI CASH only and they already charge you 15% service charge on your bill. 

Ordered the regular pork Soup Dumplings, Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup and Chicken Pan Fried noodles. Before we get to the cons, let me preface this by saying the food was good and tasty. I'd recommend getting then andwould rate the food as 4 stars.

That being said there were a few things that I observed that bothered me. 1. Women's bathroom had no paper towels or air dryer. I went back to my seat with wet hands and used the napkin on the table to dry off. When I asked the waiter for another napkin he gave me a paper towel - the ones you'd find in the bathroom. I found this to be weird, why not just have regular napkins? 2. There was leftover food residue on the corner of the table from a previous customer. Like must have been a sauce because when I tried to wipe it, it was jelly like and somewhat hard. I couldn't remove it. 3. Upon seeing them clear several tables, I can see how that residue was not only left but caked onto the table. The waiters didn't spray anything on the tables. They just used those "napkins" aka bathroom paper towels to wipe the tables. And it wasn't like they wiped the whole table. They just wiped certain spots maybe where there was visible food particles?

You'll have to wait a while to sit down so you'll be starving. You take a look at the menu and think maybe you should get something in addition to the soup dumplings. Don't do it. Seriously. Stick to the dumplings and at least you'll enjoy your food. Everything else, you're better off at any of the thousand other restaurants nearby. 

The restaurant itself also leaves a lot to be desired. Perhaps the best strategy is to get the dumplings to go, and get some other dishes nearby.
Not sure why this place is so highly rated.  It seems that Joe's has become more of a tourist destination than anything else.  It's no better than the average mall food court fare.
