The kids liked the soup dumplings although not as good as the ones in California. My wife beef stewed spicy noodles soup was very spicy but tasty. The shredded crispy chicken was good according to my son and spicy beef was excellent by my daughter. My noodles were ok.
We will not come back here regardless of how ok it is.

I wish Asian restaurants had more etiquette and concern for their customers. I felt like this place wanted to cram as many people as possible so we were put right next to their trashcan, ugh. Unfortunately, we couldn't ask for another table because it would have been a long wait. 

The food wasn't particularly good either. I thought their xiao long bao was average. Din tai fung and Mama Lus make it better. The shrimp and chive dumpling in broth, turnip shortcake, Singapore chow fun were all average. 

Service was horrendous- and they automatically charge 15% tip to the bill! It made me so mad. 

Restaurant is also dirty and smelly. Chinatown in general is dirty and smelly. I don't know how they got an A grade but this place doesn't deserve it, it's more like a C. Never never come here.

Upon arrival,  there was a very long line.  Based on the reviews we decided that it must be worth the wait.   Were we wrong. ..  The fried dumplings,  scallion pancakes,  duck dish, and chicken dish were mediocre at best. We've had better at corner Chinese carryouts that also serve subs.  The soup dumplings were very good, but not worth the wait. 
My husband, son and I all agree "one and done. "  We will not go back.
Decent Americanized Chinese food. Different than other places in Chinatown. Quick service. Good place for getting your Chinese food coma.
I had lunch yesterday while on a break from jury duty. The dumplings were excellent. I would definitely like to come back for  dinner when I have ore time and can try more things.

The soup inside the pork dumpling is jam packed with oil/grease and MSG (which is why you are SO thirsty after you leave this place).

i mean, its good, you just leave feeling gross.  

yung chow fried rice is good here.

they do not have a good selection of seasonal chinese vegetables.

the restaurant feels DIRTY.  i saw a baby roach on the wall beside me once.

shanghai fried noodles are good here, as well as scallion pancakes.  and shanghai rice cakes.

Service was terrible and after that the food quality takes second place. The focus was on getting you in and out as soon as possible to maximize the turns on the tables - while the food is tasty it is not that much better than other restaurants - Vanessa's fried dumplings in Williamsburg are just as good and at less than half the price

I first heard of Joe's Shanghai from friends (who are not new yorkers or foodiea) and the yelp review convinced me to try it out. I normally go to Nang,x k Xiang in Flushing Queens. I waited in line for 45min and Joe's Shanghai was not worth it at all. The dough was tough and not delicate. The texture was all wrong. The dumpling inside was a bit mushy although the flavor was okay. People who think Joe's Shanghai is worth standing in line for have never had authentic dumpling soup or juicy bow. There were a lot of white people in line and hipsters which is the first hint that this was going to be bad. I will never go back. Please try Nang Xiang if you haven't.

Don't trust the 7000 reviews. Had way better dumplings elsewhere. The soup wasn't clear and felt like the meat wasn't cleaned. The service was good though and portion size was good. So if you care about quantity over quality, this is the place.

I haven't come here in a very long time because the line is always so long, but today there was no wait since I went early.  However, I must say I was very disappointed.  I had to sit in a table with 2 other groups and we barely had any rooms for our foods.  I ordered two orders of soup dumplings and 2 sides, vegetarian duck and kau fu.  The bean curd skins were over cooked on top and there was very little mushrooms.  The kau fu was too sweet.  

Most people probably come here for the soup dumplings so let's get there now.  First, the skin was so thick.  Second, the soup was also thick and my brother had some that wasn't fully cooked and he saw some red, blood juice come out.   Third of all, it was so salty I had to drink so much tea.  

Then to end it off when I was leaving I saw that they had a C for sanitation.  Getting a C is really difficult, that means they must really not clean at all then.  It was especially disappointing because I remember how it used to taste and it tasted a lot better.

Should we talk about the delicious soup dumplings or about the fact that the Health Department closed the kitchen last Friday night at 7:00 when they showed up unannounced and saw whatever they saw back there. We were seated promptly, ordered our food and then waited and waited. Normally the food comes out immediately but last Friday our waiter kept coming over to apologize. When he said that it would be twenty more minutes before our food would arrive, I noticed many people getting up and leaving. At that point, having eaten there many times before, I sensed something was terribly awry. I asked a woman who works there if something was wrong in the kitchen. She did not hesitate to express her annoyance that the Health Department had shown up at such a busy time unannounced. I guess the fact that they saw something serious enough to warrant closing the kitchen immediately didn't phase her. Well it phased me and my husband and I can't say we'll be rushing back any time soon!

Came here on the Sunday afternoon with my parents because they haven't gone in a while and was craving Shanghai food. The wait was of course really long and even when seated, everyone was bunched up. Ordered the soup buns, some noodles, and a few appetizers. The soup buns were pretty good and usual. However, we started eating the other food, things got saltier and saltier. My dad whose a usual picky eater and used to love this place dislikes his last visit and I know he won't be coming back for a while if he wanted to get Shanghai food.

The worst customer service ever. This place was way too packed and we were forced to share a table with other 2 groups "without asking". The waiter who served our table was awful. He spilled the clam soup all over his shoulder and pants and didn't try to take care of it. We regretted so bad that we picked this place. Actually the dumplings which this place is famous for are very good but the other food was overpriced and didn't taste good at all. Don't order "Double cooked pork". That was disgusting. There are lots of better Chinese place out there. We will never go back for sure.

I ordered their dumpling which is a MUST order for shanghai restaurant, pretty good food but the service is average. The place itself is kind of crowded and I don't like the fact that i have to share table with someone else.
It's fine. Nothing great, but not bad. The soup dumplings are well-made

Tried this place because all of the good reviews. It was just...ok. The soup dumplings arrived hot, so I just don't understand how they didn't impress me! We got soup dumplings, fried pork dumplings, scallion pancakes, and general Tso's chicken. China town in Honolulu has wayyy better soup dumplings!

Completely overrated. There seems to be a lot of hype around this restaurant, and so the wait is pretty long (~30 minutes). However, the service was pretty abysmal. I felt like I was being hurried into just leaving so there would be more space for other customers. Also, you may get seated with random strangers at a large table if there is no room. The soup dumplings were ok; I've have the same quality in other Chinatown restaurants. The crab soup dumplings were better than the normal pork ones, in my opinion.

We really wanted to try this! Went all the way down only to find it has a C rating? To get a B is hard to do, so to have a C it must be filthy. What a huge disappointment after coming all that way. Diners beware

I went to this place multiple times with family and friends. I never had a real bad experience. But the other night, I went with friends and the waiter was RUDE. We haven't done or said anything to warrant the RUDENESS. A friend had asked for napkins and he hid them under the teapot and plates. He asked again and instead of answering, he mumbles under his breathe in Chinese saying, I gave you the napkins. Next he gives us a pot of tea that has no flavor and color. It was just HOT WATER. I asked the guy for another pot and he was rude about it. Took the pot and gave us cold tea. My friend confronted him and said we haven't done anything to deserve such service and attitude. He walked away and hid in the kitchen. I would never go back! The food isn't even worth it. Prices is overpriced for the size offer. My friends like this place so we went but after this experience, I wouldn't even bother. Didn't even bother to tip the waiter well. Paid for our dinner and left

This place is pretty decent. Their XLB is pretty juicy. However, when comparing this to Ding Tai Fung it just doesn't compare. I'm not that big of a fan of DTF but I do like the skin of DTF's dumplings. Here it's kind of just big saggy and juicy. It's tasty but probably not worth waiting in line for. Luckily when I went it was pretty empty and got seated right away. 

I also got the rice cake noodle soup which was actually pretty good. The restaurant is small so we sat next to another couple really close. 

I wasn't too sure what the service charge was on the bill. I asked the waiter if that's tip and he said yes. Hopefully that's really what he means because I didn't leave anything else. lol
Probably had too high expectations based on the great reviews. Unfortunately the soup dumplings here didn't meet my standard.

Visited on a Thursday night for dinner and waited around 30 minutes to be seated, so it's a bit of a wait. This place is also cash only. 

The pork dumpling was definitely my favorite and is well-deserved as one of the most popular dishes. We also ordered the crab XLB, green beans and the flat noodles, which were nothing too special. 

While the pork dumpling is the star of the show, the overall experience was not worthy of the wait considering how every other entree left a lot to be desired.

I can see the charm. It is a classic Chinese joint in the city. The soup dumplings are great but not incredible. Nan Xiang has a +1 on these. But if you've never had them, then get here and try them. It's definitely a must try once spot but I'd leave it at that. 

The service was cumbersome. We were quoted 25 minutes and were seated an hour later. Cmon guys... 

As for the rest of the dishes, I hate to say that you should order the General Tso's or Sesame chicken but honestly, that's probably what you should do. There's nothing traditional about the menu options. I guess that's what they're all about; being the go to spot that caters to those who think that fried chicken nuggets covered in a spicy, sweet sauce is authentic. Whatever, who am I kidding, the Sesame chicken WAS delicious.
Extremely rude service! The food is not bad, but just ok, I've had better Shanghai food. I wish they would not take their customers for granted and that waiters would be more respectful.

I'd give this place 4 stars for the Xiao long bao, or soup dumplings (XLB) alone, but the rest of the food is suspect. Thickener in the Hong shao (brown sauce) dishes?! Nuh-uh.

The XLB are about as good as they get really. I've been to the touristy Nan Xiang in Shanghai and Ding Tai Feng in Taipei. Joe's didn't have the Japanese tourists coming by the busload, but the XLB themselves are just as good. The skins are thin, the soup is plentiful, and the whole thing is full of salty, meaty goodness. It's not my favorite food in the world; it can be a bit greasy due to the solid collagen that needs to be stuffed into the dumplings for the soup effect, but I crave it from time to time.

I've recently taken a liking to good Shanghai food, and unfortunately, this place really doesn't deliver on that front. I ordered the carp tail in brown sauce (Hong shao hua shui) and it came in this starch thickened brown sauce that was just off putting. The fish itself was cooked perfectly, but Shanghai style Hong Shao dishes should have a runny soy and sugar based sauce. The sauce here was just gunky. Joe's added the worst part of cantonese food, the starch thickener, to one of the tastiest shanghainese dishes. I seriously discourage ordering any of the shanghai tropes at this restaurant despite its name, but if it's XLB you want, this is a good spot.

The food is a bit pricey ($15+ for general tso's) but delicious. It was my first time trying their soup dumplings. They were good in my opinion, but personally I prefer fried which is why I wasn't too crazy about them. I also tried the scallion pancakes and they were amazing! 

The only thing I didn't like is that you have to share tables with strangers (must be a cultural thing)! It was the quietest dinner I've ever had with my boyfriend. It makes it really uncomfortable to have a private conversation, not to mention there's barely enough room for your food since table space is limited. If you decide to come here make sure to bring a bunch of friends so you get your own table. Also, cash only!

Coming from LA (aka the land of the dumplings/soup dumplings), I was expecting Chinatown in NYC to get it down to a science. Sad to say, I was not impressed with the food here. Was it good? Yes. Was it spectacular that it needs to be set apart from the rest of the soup dumplings and pork fried dumplings? Absolutely not. 
The waiters and waitresses working here are also not the nicest. 
I will say that whatever chicken dish they have on their menu is actually cooked perfectly.

The service was HORRIBLE and the food was mediocre. The waiters had absolutely no manners. They screwed up our order and then had the nerve to give US attitude when we corrected them. They also  automatically added their tip to the bill, which I found offensive. They didn't deserve a tip to begin with. This is one place I definitely would not revisit!!!!

The food was great, but service was horrible.  The fried rice was very good as was the General Tao's Chicken.  We also enjoyed the spring rolls and hot and sour soup. I won't visit again, based solely on the service.  There are plenty of other equally good Chinese restaurants in the area.

This is the problem of going to Taiwan and try the famous soup dumplings in taipei. 

now nothing compares.

The dumplings here are too big, skin is too thick, and the meat inside not juicy or flavor enough.

But they will do until I go back to taipei.

After years of wanting to check this place out, I finally did so and unfortunately found it pretty lacking. First, the soup dumplings, what they are known for. Not soupy and I'm guessing the top of the dumpling should not be dried out and hard. Disappointing. We also had some cold meat dishes and found them pretty mediocre and a little salty. The shredded turnip cake and pea shoots were quite good, however.

Lastly, the prices are a little high for china town and the place is very cramped. It seems they have gotten a little complacent and I hope they can get back to what earned them such a high rating in the first place.

I've had Joe's Shanghai bookmarked for quite some time and was looking forward to some delicious xiao long bao.  I feared that we would have to wait but to our surprise we were seated right away.  The tables are very close to each other and some parties share a table with others as well.  

We ordered 2 orders of xiao long bao (8 for $8 and change) and an order of Shanghai chow mein (however they called it something else, like stir fried flat noodle or something).  The xiao long baos were big and full of broth and served piping hot.  So much juice that I even squirted some on the table as I bit into it, however, the dumplings were bland and even the vinegar tasted diluted and the ginger wasn't fragrant at all.  The xiao long bao held up pretty well with only one served punctured.  The Shanghai chow mein was standard, plentiful and had a little more flavor.

Service was solid.  It's cash only and they automatically add gratuity on the bill.  If I recall correctly our bill was about $28.  Joe's Shanghai can't compare to my beloved Din Tai Fung in Arcadia, and I've even enjoyed xiao long bao more in San Francisco.  2.5ish rounded up.

Cash only but service was fine. We only waited about 20 minutes when there were couple parties in front of us. After we ordered, food came out really soon. Soup dumpling and noodle soup were lukewarm. I usually have no problem with meaty heavy food but I couldn't take more than 2 dumpling.

The dumplings were good. I tried the crab ones. There was an abundance of soup in them compared to other places I've eaten at! We also got some sort of stir fried noodle dish that was pretty tasty, as well. 

However, I felt uneasy at this place due to the aesthetics and scent it was giving off. We were seated next to their recycle containers and for the duration of my meal, I couldn't really enjoy my food because there was a strong sour odor I couldn't ignore coming from them. 

The employees also kept coming in & out of this closet behind them and had to remove the recycle bins back and forth to open the door to get into this closet. At one point, one moved the bin too far out and it brushed up on my arm and it really grossed me out!

Sorry I can't overlook this one and regardless how good the dumplings were, I can't shake this one off.

It has been a disappointment.  Its food is not what it used to be, the quality was degraded.  The waiter service was very poor, not polite and friendly at all.  I got better service from any noodle shop in China Town than I got from Joe's Shanghai.  

I would NOT recommend this place.

Easily the most overrated place I've ever eaten at. The 5 star reviews have to be fake. 
We ordered soup dumplings which were nasty, pork fried dumplings which were over cooked, Sichuan spicy beef which the meat had a weird slimy consistency and Sea-bass which was just weird the way it was cut and the sauce sucked.
Don't go to this place, the service is terrible also.
Way overpriced and overrated, there are way better ways of spending your money in this city.

Oh Yelp, you led me astray with this one. Best dim sum? Really?! I mean, the food wasn't horrible, but let's not get crazy. It was good enough (especially the scallion pancakes) but the waitstaff was completely indifferent bordering on rude. My friend and I were seated at a larger table ("You sit over here! And you sit there!") and had a stranger join later, which was kind of awkward. We were given menus, but never offered drinks beyond the standard tea. Food came fast but nobody really cared whether we liked it or not. Seems like staff was more preoccupied with getting us served and out the door as fast as possible. They also add service fee to all orders but then make it look like tipping is still needed. And CASH ONLY? What is this?! Anyways, this place definitely doesn't deserve all the rave it gets. Skip.

Two stars for the first time I ate at this place (when I was also tipsy from a prior engagement and probably didn't know any better, but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt). ZERO for the second. Overhyped, overrated, overdone. 

I took my dad who was visiting from Korea here based on Joe's reputation (and that inebriated first visit), despite the notoriously long waits. I'm used to hurried service in crowded Asia-town joints in general, but this was ridiculous. The server was practically shouting at us to order before our butts had even touched down in our chairs (no hyperbole). We requested a few more minutes, whereupon we were provided with 40 seconds of peace to skim the menu. We quickly ordered some requisite soup dumplings and saut√©ed black mushrooms with bamboo shoots. The black mushrooms were burnt, and the bamboo shoots (and this is coming from someone who is practically a panda, I love bamboo so much) were disgusting. The xiao long bao were obviously hurried, and quite honestly, I much prefer the frozen xiao long bao Boyfriend's mom defrosts for us at home on idle Sundays over this. On top of that, you know, 20% gratuity tacked on to the receipt for... what?

Conclusion? Joe's is nothing more a slap-in-the-face reminder of how easy it is to fall for name value in NYC and be bitterly, bitterly disappointed.

Joe's Shanghai lovers might hate me for this but, this place is alright, I have eaten more authentic food right here in Chinatown. Also, having grown up in South East Asia, I can be a asian food snob.

So, the wait is usually long to get - about 20-40 depending on the time of week you are there. Once you go in you sit at large communal tables which is really cool. As everyone knows, Joe's is really famous for their soup dumplings and they are pretty good, especially the crab ones. However, otherwise the food feels like Americanized chinese food. 

I would explore more places in Chinatown than go here again. Any restaurant that keeps me wanting more is where I return but, Joe's Shanghai..umm not so much!

Chinese.  Known for their soup dumplings.

Several years ago this place used to be good.  Venturing to this location and the Flushing location for their good dumplings.  However, as of late their dumpling quality is not as good.  The soup doesn't have too much flavor to it anymore and the quality has gone down.

However, if you are here not for the dumplings, but for the other food.  Their Shanghai noodles are still great, along with the Shanghai Mei Fun.  The rice cakes are a little oily, but still reasonably good.   Their hot and sour soup isn't so bad either.  If you want to try a hiddle gem.  You should get the fried chinese bread with condensed milk.  It's a nice little sweet treat.

If you want better dumplings, try Shanghai Cafe in Chinatown

The entrance is crowded and reeks.
Service is mediocre at best. You are seated at a round table with strangers, there not enough room on the table with all the dishes. When asked for forks they just "throw" it on the table. Food regular Chinese.
BTW they add 15% service charge and didn't provide receipt had to ask for it.

The food is good but service is very poor. I liked the pan fried noodles, the buns, dumplings, and vegetable dishes. The dishes were surprisingly fresh and tasty. There were six of us but we were still expected to share a table when the lunch rush was over. Go because of the chef, but anticipate rude service.

Like some other reviews on here, I too was told by my friend in NY that Joe's Shanghai was so much better than Ding Tai Fung in Arcadia. In fact she said she couldn't even eat DTF anymore because Joe's Shanghai was so good. 

The XLB at Joe's was decent, but no where near the best. I think they focus too much on the "soup" part of soup dumpling, making their wrapping too thick and their soup too much. The meat was almost like an afterthought. I prefer my rice paper wrapping thinner, and the meat more hearty. Joe's meat was kind of like a lame meatball patty. However, I did like that they provided little tongs so you can pinch the top of the XLB so they won't break. 

Their green onion pancake was atrocious. Soo bad. It was super greasy and falling apart. I know it's not the healthiest thing to begin with, but it was so greasy that the top layer and the bottom layer of one pancake was slipping and sliding with each other. 

If you are not too familiar with this place, don't be weirded out if you are seated at a big table with another group. That's how they get the line going. 

BTW, I suggest Dumpling House in Arcadia for really good dumpling if you are from socal.
Waited for 1.5 hrs on Christmas Day and was seated at a big round shared table.  This place was overhyped as I was letdown by the crab and pork xiao long bao but liked the steamed sea bass.
Trader Joe's has better Chinese food in its frozen food section. this place is so mid and so overpriced.

Is Joes Shanghai really the highest rated and most popular Chinese restaurant in all of Chinatown New York?  I really don't get it - especially after waiting for 2 hours to get a spot.  Still - I think I need to give it the benefit of the doubt because there is a good chance I might have ordered all the wrong things to satisfy a group of 7 extremely hungry but picky eaters who along with myself had been on a less-than-halfway point of a marathon journey muscling our way through Manhattan from Wall Street to Harlem all on foot.

I personally thought Joe's Shanghai was pretty average.  The whole fried sweet and sour fish was much more entertaining to look at than it was to eat - very bland and worst was not all of the flour was cooked.  That was a first for me...  The shrimp lomein tasted underwhelming and ridiculous but the scallion pancakes were a nice rebound as was some of the clear broth soup which might have had about three shrimps in it.  I know I am going to get a lot of heat for this (and this is more my problem) but I don't really don't get the craze about the dumplings as I was told these were " so like the best things ever" - they weren't.  And I realize this is all coming from people who are from like Flagstaff, AZ, and Frederick, MD.  I am told it's a "textural exercise" more so than a tasting experience.  Whatever.

I absolutely love Chinese cuisine and when I think of it - I expect an orgasmic explosion of flavor and no I don't mean in a General Tsao's Chicken way.  It pains me to say it but I thought this was a major disappointment.  But I am glad we tried it.

Went for dinner on a tuesday night around 6ish, there was no wait! (Probably bc it was really cold out). Pretty decent soup dumplings - a 3-star bc of the price (if only wage inflation mimicked food inflation....) we also got the shanghai noodles which are like stirfried thick noodles with pork - delicious, not too much veggies however.

I'll make it simple ---- nothing is edible here except the soup dumpling. 

Honestly I don't get the line that builds up everyday outside of this restaurant. The food simply fails as authentic Shanghainese food --- hell, it even fails as Chinese food period. 

Everything is really extremely overly unnecessarily greasy and the worst dish here has to be the fried tofu and vermicelli soup. Not only is it NOT authentic, the vermicelli wasn't even cooked through. 

There're so many Shanghainese places around and not too far from this location; save the wait.

Friends have recommended this place to me so much. Ended up getting the soup dumplings and they were okay. At first, I enjoyed them though they felt a bit one-note, but as I kept eating I started to feel sick. I don't think the pork fat they use in the broth in the soup dumplings is particularly good. Either it was sort of spoiled or it was just too much fat for my tummy (which is ironic because my belly has some fat storage heh), so I won't be coming back.

Came here and got the crab and pork soup dumplings, pork soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, szcechuan beef, eggplant. 

I think people have their own preferences, and I don't want my crab dumplings to have that much of a seafood flavor. As for the pork one, the soup seemed a bit lighter than I'm used to. However, overall the dumplings are pretty large and consequently there's more of everything. What wasn't to my liking was how the skin is thicker and the meat took multiple bites. When you are eating it, it's not bite sized and it doesn't quite fit in the spoon. I thought that took away from the experience and made you focus on the skin a bit more (which is obviously bland).

The scallion pancake was interesting as the outside was crispy, but the inside layer was very soft and almost a mushy layer. I prefer pancakes more chewy and crispy.

The beef was so heavily battered that you couldn't really taste the beef anymore. It's likely that they put a lot of cornstarch and baking soda. The sauce was good, but the beef just ruined the dish.

The eggplant was exactly what you would expect. Very oily and salty. The pork with it was really good though. Very nicely flavored with all the oil.

Overall this place I think is over hyped. It's not a pleasant experience there and don't think many Chinese people would consider it a place they have to go to....

1) Long wait-- at least 40 minutes on a good day
2) Overwhelmingly crowded even at 10 PM
3) Sub-par dumplings and noodles

Go somewhere else!

I loved this place. I did. The wait and sitting with strangers were so worth the soup dumplings. 
Then we went, ordered soup dumplings - only soup dumplings, which we reiterated twice - and received beef and broccoli or something. I told the waiter about our wrong dish, and instead of apologizing, he condescendingly told me I was wrong and had received what I ordered. I repeated that no, we had certainly ordered soup dumplings, and he (even more condescendingly, in a "silly, erratic woman" kind of way), told me I clearly didn't remember what I had ordered. 
2 stars, because if you get the soup dumplings they are quite good. 
Go to Shanghai Cafe. Just as good, less of a wait, you can sit alone, and the waiters aren't so horribly rude.

Just left this place..after bragging to our kids we received the absolute WORST SERVICE ever. We literally had to ask for everything we got, drinks included, multiple times as well as having to stop random workers for cutlery and even rice. I'm hoping it wasn't because we were 2 men with small 3 kids but I cant believe that's not the case.  Extremely disappointed and will never return.

Not really sure where to start here...obviously this place is extremely well rated, but I guess I had high hopes. I will say it was a 100% authentic Chinatown experience from start to finish, but I've definitely had better!

Came here on a Sunday around lunch time so there was obviously a wait - we put our name down and waited about an hour (although they only said 30 min). You wait outside and listen for your number to be called. They have some seating outside but barely and it's a pretty busy street, especially when cars go by (the sidewalk is extremely narrow).

Once we were seated, the service was pretty slow. It was communal seating and 8 of us (tables are for 10), but we actually had 2 parties of 1 sitting with us, which was surprising. They ended up chatting the entire time and when one didn't realize it was cash only, the other paid for his entire meal, which was so sweet and heartwarming to see. 

We ordered the soup dumplings which is what they're known for, which had a lot of flavor but were extremely messy to eat! The spoons that they had for them only fit about half the dumpling, so you ended up with soup all over your plate. It comes with 8 dumplings though, so that was definitely a deal. We also got the scallion pancakes, which, although not quite what they traditionally should be, were fantastic. 

The menu overall was pretty hard to navigate and didn't have many descriptions, so it was hard to know what you were getting. I ended up having better luck looking through the Yelp photos and asking what the pictures were and ordering based off of that. I ended up getting the fried Shanghai noodles, which were good but didn't have a ton of flavor. Ended up pouring sauce all over it to help! 

In general, nothing felt really clean and it was kind of a circus, but I guess that's part of the experience! Also, cash only, so be prepared) although you could easily have a full meal including tax and tip for under $10! I'd recommend coming with a group so that you can try a bunch of different things, but just note it's not super easy to get seated!

The one thing that REALLY grossed me out was the C rating. I know there is controversy over how those are earned, but at a place that already feels very grimy to begin with, definitely left feeling nauseous just knowing it had a C. Hopefully they'll work on fixing it, but it seems like they had a enough business and are so highly rated that it clearly isn't affecting business much so who knows how important it is to them!

Service was typical and the food came out extremely fast. 

Pork soup dumplings were rancid and sour I almost threw up. These were the worst soup dumpling I've ever had. 

Scallion pancake was decent and super crispy but they fry it in very old oil. 

Crispy noodles were good. Large portions and good flavor.

Joes is a decent place for fast American style Chinese food, but I would recommend going somewhere else for soup dumplings. Maybe my dumplings were old but there was definitely something very off by them.

Soup dumplings are good, not amazing or better than the streets of flushing. The food is really good, the decor is pretty bad. Old chairs and table, and waiters will watch your every move. It was a bit awkward. Food was delicious, if I'm in the area I will def go again! 

Food recommendations:

Braised pork shoulder
Soup dumplings 
Sea bass
Any fried rice 
Hunan pork w shrimp 

Can't go wrong with anything honestly. There is a wait and expect to sit with a random group of people, which makes the experience fun.
Sometimes disappointing, sometimes delicious. I would prefer consistency but I won't stop visiting this place.

TOURIST TRAP!

The minced chicken corn soup and clams in ginger sauce were both too salty while the pan fried noodles was so under seasoned. We tried both the soup dumplings and they were really subpar. Please do yourself a favor and go to Noodle Village they have the best soup dumplings in town. The server also applied an automatic 18% GRATUITY  on our PARTY OF TWO and when I was 69 cents short ( cash only and again the tips already included) he showed an attitude demanding for it and stood right by me watching as I was combing through my purse to make sure I do not any change on me. It's just horrible.

Save your money & appetite.  The ambiance was okay, the food was mediocre, but the service was awful.  These people were not only unpleasant, but "out of there way" rude.  At one point, our server (AKA: family member forced to work) literally tossed a bowl of rice on the table near our four-year-old daughter.  We practically had to beg for water during our meal, and then the bill at the end of our meal.  When we walked out of the restaurant two of the workers were passed out on a few chairs in broad daylight, which was slightly amusing.  However, to make matters worse we walked through Little Italy and absolutely regretted eating at Joe's Shanghai.

Being a native New Yorker I knew this place was basically a overhyped tourist trap yet I always still give it a chance once or twice a year especially moving to this new location. However, I must say this place is not worth the wait. We waited for 20 minutes to be seated then ordering our food we had to wait another 20-30 minutes trying to get our food. The tables that were next to us all had delayed dishes coming and you can sense how we all wanted to just cancel our dishes and leave but the waiter would say it's already made yet it still hasn't come. There is definitely something that management needs to work on in the kitchen because this tardiness is unacceptable. My suggestion for those who want something worth the quick wait, checkout my go to, Shanghai 21.

Edited review:
I had to change this from a two star to one star while sitting at the restaurant writing this review because after our dish came it took a bit for just white rice to come. Then there was a screaming match with the cook behind and the waiters. I'm thinking the cook must have been on a extended break while rows of tables were waiting forever. Horrible...

I just can't justify giving this place higher than 3 stars. Yes, it's good. But 5-star, crazy-hype, mob-out-the-door worthy? No.

CRAB & PORK SOUP DUMPLINGS/PORK SOUP DUMPLINGS (aka xiaolongbao aka xlb):
The skin on these is thicker than at Din Tai Fung, but the plus side is that it allows each dumpling to hold more soup. The xlb here are certainly juicy, filled with plenty of meat and soup. An order per person will nearly fill you up, surprisingly. 

SCALLION PANCAKE:
I was underwhelmed by these. They did the job of filling me up, but they weren't as crispy, savory, or flaky as so many other places offer.

All in all, our total was only $10 each for 3 dishes! It's a good deal, that's for sure. But the experience...that's where it's lacking. 

EXPERIENCE:
Plan to wait for at least half in hour in the mob that gathers outside. Once your name is called, you'll likely be seated at a communal table with other parties. Then, due to the large number of people and constant need to get customers in and out, you'll encounter some pretty unfriendly service. I've been to plenty of great Chinese restaurants with poor service, and I generally take it as a given. But here, it just seemed a step below. Water spilling on people, waiters bumping into your chair constantly, waiters ignoring you...This is largely due to the fact that they're so ridiculously busy, so I don't know how much I can really blame them. It's more likely the result of the overblown hype of the restaurant.

OVERALL: 
What really irked me about my experience here was the fact that there are SO many equally good or better xlb places in Manhattan. You're in Chinatown, for goodness' sakes! Explore a little! It's certainly tasty, but you're missing out on the myriad of other options available. 

It would be different if they were serving a highly unusual dish that no one else has, but this is not the case. It's not like Joe's is the only place in Chinatown or elsewhere that has xlb, and I think a lot of tourists and others forget that. My recommendation would be to go if there's no wait, but if there is, skip it and try somewhere different.
Have not gone back after my bad experience described in previous review. Try tipsy Shanghai or Che Li. There is no need to wait 45 minutes to an hour for this place. None whatsoever.

This place is best known for the soup dumplings. The waiters are shocked if you don't order them. If you do wish to have them get them immediately upon sitting down as they take a bit of time to cook. The soup dumplings here are quite good and I really liked them until I had the crab filled soup dumplings at Shanghai Gourmet. They are even better. The remainder of the food here isn't very memorable, but not bad and certainly well priced.
the soup dumpling is the best...others is ok and the service made me speechless...by the way 15ÔºÖ tips wtf!!!

Well, it's no Din Tai Fung when it comes to soup dumplings, but if you're already in NYC, then this Joe Shanghai's can't be beat at five dollars an order. 

Compared to DTF, the dough of the soup dumpling is much thicker and denser which results in a very different soup dumpling experience.  The broth is bit on the too fatty side without the flavor, but that may also be because the thicker dough off sets whatever flavor the soup has so it's not as pronounced. 

Service is prompt, and I would defer to the other numerous reviews talking about the wait times.
Cash only. No extra charge for the waiter bumping your head with his butt every two seconds. It was quite the squishy butt doe.

Came in for a quick bite since I was in the area.

Ended up getting the vegetable dumplings and F2 Seafood Saut√©ed flat noodles.

The dumplings were not that great IMHO and the noodles were just okay.  Maybe the location in Flushing is better?

The wait time for a table was non existent at around 630pm on a Wednesday, but quickly got busy as I was about to leave.

The free orange slices for dessert were nice.

The service was so-so, but didn't need too much I guess.

kinda got shanghai'ed on service and dumplings were fine but not dandy.

the quick:
if you've had quality dumplings, nothing here will surprise you...
except maybe the lack of service...
except maybe how popular they are...

Try new things where ever you go!  And I've had my west coast Din Tai Fung (http://www.yelp.com/biz/din-tai-fung-arcadia-3#hrid:e2jy9AqWBLo3UehuthFtUA) so it was time see how it's done in the east!  To sum it up, food was probably on par if just a smidge under DTF but the service kills the experience.

If you're an asian customer but don't speak the language you won't get the same service.  At least on my visit, we got pushed into ordering items we didn't want, rushed into finishing and never really enjoyed our meal because of the lack of elbow room.  Felt like we were in the bottom floor of the titanic, wall to wall of patrons.  The white customers got introductions, smiles, handshakes with the manager and a bit more breathing space than us.  Perhaps they were friends with someone but just by observation, they got the only handshakes.

None of the food here made this place a must have.  Same as any other dumpling place you might enjoy.  It was a fun experience, felt like real chinatown meal but I'd just as soon eat back at home, where the food, space, & service appear professional and even keeled.
The dumplings are definitely nothing to write home about. There aren't many GOOD soup dumpling places in the city, but the hype for this restaurant does NOT match up to the actual food provided.

Came here on a Saturday for dinner and was told the wait time was 45min. We walked around Chinatown and amazingly, it was 45min right on the nose! We were taken to the back of the restaurant and the 3 of us were seated at a table set for a dozen. It was super cramped. We ordered the pork and shrimp soup dumplings, which were huge and delish! We also got a stir fry seafood noodle dish, which was a bit on the greasy side. The flavors were excellent, but due to the how hectic it was, the cramped nature of the restaurant, and the craze of dishes being spun on the lazy susan to your party's location, I would give this place 3 stars. It's also cash-only!

Admitting upfront: I can't help but feel like this review is premature.

I went with my girlfriend and we got only two things: the soup filled dumplings and the sesame chicken. I wasn't in the mood for the chicken, but I have a problem with pretty girls, so...

Anyway, the soup dumplings were amazing.  All that juicy, umami, salty, greasy flavor is absolutely spectacular.  Eat 'em with a spoon though, they tend to squirt.

The sesame chicken (which, admittedly, I was not in the mood for) was just "aight".  Totally run-of-the-mill stuff, but at least one of the pieces didn't seem cooked all the way.  The rice (which should have come with it, but required us to ask for it--no big deal though, it was a total madhouse when we were eating) was really really good though, oddly enough.  Never have really been impressed with Chinese rice before.

So yeah, given the popularity of this place, I'll admit that my stars probably aren't the most authoritative, and that I'll have to come back to get the real skinny on this joint.

5 star for food, but the service can be rough. Is like I just sat down and already you are trying to rush us out. I get the turning over, but this is over the top. And then that they have a C rating from Sanitation. Thats worst then I ever seen from this place or any for that matter.

Ok another place that has a lot of hype. Yes the dumplings are pretty good but you're in Chinatown with many hole-in-the-wall places that serve soup dumplings for cheaper or the same price that are just as good or better (and you don't have to wait forever). Crab soup dumplings are $6.65 for 8 and pork soup dumplings are $4.65 for 8. Service-wise, they are fast and the food comes out fast too. If you have a small party, they will seat you at a big table with other guests since they are so busy. They do not take credit cards, cash only.

Food: 6
Decor: 3
Service: 5

*ratings out of 10
I think I went in thinking it was going to be like Din Tai Fung.  It was good, but I was over hyped up about this place.

My friends and I had time to kill and wanted to snack on something. So we walked over to Joe's. 

Crazy amount of people out front waiting to be seated. I can tell it's a tourist hot spot. Let's just say there weren't too many Chinese people standing around waiting for some soup dumplings. 

Here's my tip, and what we did. Order to go. 

Just walk right in and go to the cashier. Order the #1 (crab and pork xia long bao). It comes with 8 and it's hot when you get it. We waiting around maybe 15 minutes for it to come out. Then we trotted outside and ate it right next to everyone who were waiting on line.lol. Needless to say, we got some salivating glances as we devoured it. 

The soup dumplings were good! Is something I would wait in that ridiculous line for? Not sure. It had crazy hype so I had high expectations but I've had pretty yummy soup dumplings elsewhere too. I was pretty content with ordering it to go and going on our merry way to the bar around the corner after we ate.

18% tip already included in price, but the service doesn't  match the tip. The waiters were playing their phones or talked with each other at corner. I stayed on my seat and waited 3~4 minutes for service.

Good, not great. 

The soup dumplings are good and satisfying, but it really baffles me when people say it's the best. I mean, I guess I haven't had any that are better than Joe's, but at the same time, I'm still not blown away. Maybe that's just me. 

Everything else is mediocre chinese fare, so in comparison the soup dumplings are amazing. I will say though, that on a cold night, this is a meal that warms your insides and makes you feel good. 

The one in Flushing is about the same.

There have been many reviews for Joe's so I had to try it. I tried 3 different types of dumplings here and they were warranted enough to come here. Tried the Crab Meat with Pork, Pork Meat Soup, and fried dumplings. However, I'm not sure if it was all the hype or in general but it did not blow me away and my expectations were a bit let down. But don't distract from the fact that these soup dumplings are not bad. The service was lackluster though and wasn't really attentive too much besides when we needed the check and when they brought the food. 

I would give it a 3.5/5.
Food is pretty good, the sea bass is really fresh and shrimp dumpling was very good. but super crowded at lunch time and cramped space and noisy.

the soup dumplings were disappointing. The size is large compare to Ding Tai Feng but it is not as juicy as DTF. Also, I think the dumplings were overcooked. There were a couple of broken skin and the soup leaked out. Cash only!

This place came recommended for the soup dumplings. While the dumpling filling (pork and crab) was very flavorful, the dough of the dumpling was very thick. But that surely couldn't keep the soup inside the dumplings. The dumplings were stuck to the bottom of the steamer because there wasn't enough cabbage lining under it so when we tried to lift the dumplings, all the soup leakes out. All in all, just some regular dumplings you get in any other Chinese restaurant

We also had the scallion pancakes but they were quite greasy. I have had them in Beijing and those were more layered with more scallions in them.

We also had the fried octopus, shredded beef with pepper, beef and rice cake and mei fun. Again, nothing special with these food but they were well made. 

The food itself was very affordable. The ambiance barely gets 2/5. However, this place is considered one of the oldest and  authentic restaurants so ambiance surely reflects that! 

The place was packed with lots of people waiting at the door trying to get a seat on a Thursday night

We had to check out joe's Shanghai since it's one of the most reviewed restaurants. Pork soup dumplings is good!both the hostesses were sweet and nice! But the place is so cramp and so loud! They asked you if you're ok to share table with others, if not then you have to wait longer. We couldn't enjoy our dinner coz incoming customers are standing and waiting next to our table. I was afraid that they may accidentally knock out our food. Another customer who was waiting for a table reached over our table to take pics of the picture frames on the wall! Which was really annoying! They only accept cash! Thankfully we had enough cash on hand. Food is still good. If you don't mind this kind of environment or ambiance, then you'll be ok.

This place has depreciated since my last visit. I went in with an old friend living in New York with high hopes of impressing her, but the service was unresponsive and the cold noodles I was so enamored with came out soggy and bland. 

Guess this place got in over their heads with the high volumes of customers that its quality tanked. 
 
i'll just have to find a new spot next time i visit Chinatown in NY.

Listen up people, all 1700+ of you that reviewed this place:
Joe did not invent the soup dumpling and no matter what else you order it comes drenched in the same lame sauce. Go somewhere else and get back the 40 minutes you wasted in line here.  

Just around the corner at Great NY Noodletown you can get soup dumplings and items where there is some distinction in flavor. 

I don't know how things like this happen. One place gets on some tourist list and then, boom! I'm just happy that every tourist goes here and I not to my secret spots down the street that have great food.  But if you feel like getting on with your life, get out line and go down the street.

This place is always so busy and I feel like a chicken without a head. However, the soup dumplings are to die for. We did order a few other meat dishes which left me feeling quite thirsty. Although the atmosphere makes me want to run out, the soup dumplings bring me to a state of bliss that everything just doesn't matter anymore.

Joe's is old tired and indifferent. This is a place not to go to. The plates are thrown down on the table, one tiny plastic container of sauce for the dumplings. The dumplings were old, cold and tasteless. The staff is indifferent and we could to get out.

One of my sons wrote a Video Blog about this place, so it was high on my list of places to visit during my annual stop over in the NYC / NJ area. One of the days, 3 of us stopped by  for a late lunch (still it was a 15 minutes wait). The room was full,  it was mainly tourists and the seating's are 6 per table. I wanted to try soup dumplings - my son was talking about.

We ordered an order of crab meat with pork meat soup dumplings (8 is the count) and another order of just pork meat dumplings (8 is the count). Personally, I was not impressed, some how the dough was not cooked properly, my feelings is that the kitchen was  rushing the orders out.

My son also admitted that his first stop here was much different (talking about quality of the dumplings). Is it just a bad day for a cook, maybe?  In any case, the bills are paid in cash only, gratuity is already included and I don't plan to come back here any time soon. One thing is - this place located in the China town on the block with the most ready for Instagram pictures.

The only reason i come here is because it's famous enough for my non-ny friends to try. There are way better chinese restaurants all over the city. Joe's shanghai, especially the downtown one, is way too crowded, rushed, and basically no service. you wait awhile to inhale your food and get pushed out. if that's the kind of place you want to eat, go for it. the food is too mediocre to be famous.

Got chicken fried rice to-go. Not bad, needs soy sauce but wasn't given any. Beware, this business is cash only and they didn't tell us that when we placed the order. Ended up having to Venmo the guy working.

One of the worst experience I've had at a restaurant. The server was really rude. In the middle of taking our order, he stopped us to seat someone. Had to wait for a couple minutes before he finally came back. He tried for us to get something else on the menu that we did not want and was a much higher price than what we wanted to get. He slammed our food down right in front of us without a care and never came back to ask us if we needed anything else or more water. The guy that handed out change back from our payment stood around behind us probably to see how much tip we were giving. 

The food wasn't all the great. We just had dumplings and general tso. The general tso was overly cooked. The food was overpriced and poor quality. 

Would not recommend.
Seemed like a tourist trap. No locals, high prices (for chinatown), somewhat rushy service to free up space for the next guests.

What's all the rave about this place?? I don't get it. The dumplings spill out with some swine fluid like concoction an the other Chinese dishes are mediocre at best.  Everythig super greasy. Of course often that's the best part o Chinese but I had grease that didn't feel like was going straight to the arteries. Perhaps heat?

Anyhow. It did the job but with so many great places in Chinatown, why stop here? Shouldn't the masses of white people tell you to go elsewhere?

Wow, not exaggerating but seriously the worst soup dumpling I've ever had. My husband and I decided to give this place a try on a Saturday night, upon recommendations of a few of our friends. When we checked in, the hostess handed us a ticket with a number, letting us know that it would be a 30 minutes wait. But that turned into almost an hour and a half wait. We ordered both crab and pork, and pork soup dumplings. Honestly, I can deal with the wait usually if the food is really good. But it was inedible. The skin of the dumpling was thin, but it lacked elasticity, and once we picked it up with the tongs, it ripped immediately. The soup inside the dumpling had a starchy aftertaste, which was very unpleasant. If this is the best soup dumpling in New York, that's pretty pathetic. It's definitely a tourist trap, will never recommend this place to anyone.

I know, I know you all LOVE this place... you all ohhh and ahhh when you think of it and your mouths water and your eyes get big as they bring the dumplings towards your table. 

Well, unfortunately when I ate here I got food poisoning!! I did not even want to look at, smell or hear about Chinese food for years! Now, luckily that has passed... but I still cannot go back to Joe's. Sorry!
Too greasy and too salty. The dumplings Joe's is known for are way over hyped. Save yourself the wait and trek and just hop into any other chinatown eatery for better treats.

100% a tourist trap. 

These are not authentic soup dumplings. My family are natives from Shanghai, and I've eaten xiaolongbao my entire life in and around Shanghai, and I can tell you as a matter of fact that these soup dumplings taste worse than what you can buy from any Chinese grocery store. If you want better tasting soup dumplings, I suggest you buy a packet of frozen soup dumplings around the corner. I guarantee you they will taste 10X better than this place and will save you both money and time.

First of all, the dumplings' skin is all wrong. The wrapper is the thickness of regular gaozi dumpling wrappers rather than the thin wrappers on authentic soup dumplings. There was a lot of juice, but it was flavorless. You can't just substitute excess pork fat for flavoring. The dumplings are also really big which ruins the definition of a soup dumpling. They are supposed to be bite sized, and people are not supposed to use spoons to eat them. Not sure where that concept came from, but in Shanghai, the proper way to eat them is dip them in black vinegar and pop them in your mouth. None of this nonsense of cutting holes and sucking out the soup and using an actual soup spoon. Doing it all wrong. The scallion pancakes were also greasy and tasteless. There were a lot of tourists who don't know what the hell real Shanghainese food is supposed to taste like so they have nothing to compare it to.

Honestly I would give it zero stars if I could. We traveled out of our way to go to this restaurant based on all the rave reviews.

Service: The service was horrendous. As soon as we walked in we were rushed to a table and the seating style is where you are seated with other patrons which is totally fine. As we were looking through the menu the waiter came by and was rushing us to order. we told him we were not ready. I asked a question about an item on the menu and again he rushed me to order. He explained that the vegetable stirfry was a mixture of vegetables but he did this in a way where he was yelling the items. 

Food: The food was abysmal. When the veggie stirfry came out all it was was very very greasy pile of spinach and nothing else. It was not at all how he described in his yelling description. When I explained the waiter that the veggie stirfry was not like he described he told us too bad and he would not take it back. The soup dumplings were nothing to write home about at all.  They were mushy and did not taste good. I saw the other people seated at our table not finish their food either.

I would absolutely not recommend this place because the service and the food are very much below Chinese food standards. It was a waste of money and afterwards we were still hungry and had to go to another restaurant to eat lunch.

Actually went here by mistake, meaning to go to Shanghai Cuisine where I've had nice experiences a while ago.The soup dumplings were excellent but that was about it. An Orange Beef main course was in a strange batter with way too much egg in it. My friend's string bean dish was over-cooked. The piece de resistance was the waiter cleaning the table with tea that they poured from the pot and with a rag that looked a little too well-used. The seating was cramped and in a plain room with a bunch of tables thrown in. We did wait in line to get in so apparently people like this place, particularly many who are native to this cuisine.

The soup dumplings were excellent.  Everything else was good, but not great. I thought it would be weird sharing a table with strangers, but it  actually didn't matter at all.  Bring some cash because they don't take card. .

My best friend and I wanted to try this place because our friends suggested if we come to NY. As we walked in, we noticed that this was a CASH ONLY restaurant. Luckily I had $20 on me. Then we were seated on a same round table as other customers. i guess due to the crowd, this will eliminate the wait time, but I wished we were notified ahead of time because it was shocking. 
Food was good. We were expecting better because of all the recommendations. We ordered the Crab&Pork Buns and the Pork Buns.  We liked the Pork Buns a lot better. It did not take long for them to bring that out, but we wanted to order the dumplings that were in the soup and the waiter said "it will take 25 minutes."  Sheesh, do they need to go to China to pick it up or something? The portions we ordered were good enough for two girls. 
Food was good, but we will not be coming back because I'm sure there are better alternatives.

Stopped in to try the famous crab/pork xiaolongbao (steamed Shanghai soup dumplings). While they were good, some of our dumplings were stuck together and the precious soup leaked out. 

This location is authentic Chinatown, but a bit off the beaten path. I'm not a fan of the communal tables, so if you're going bring a big group and show up together. I agree with other posters that this can be a stressful dining experience for the uninitiated. You can't be afraid to flag down a waiter, or else you'll be overlooked.

Super Long wait.... There was 6 of us and we waited for 50 minutes for our table. By the time we finally got inside. Our table was shared by two other party.... Normally restaurant would let you know in advance that you might be sharing a table with other party. But not this one. 
As soon as you sit down, they keep asking you how many juicy pork bun even before you read the menu... 
Since I'm from FL... Can I take a look of the menu first???
Next time I might try the one on 56 St or the one in Flushing... Hopefully their service will be better.

Tips: Cash Only

Joe's Shanghai... give me a break.  Who the heck is Joe and why an American name?  I passed by this place several times just because of the name until one day someone forced me to go by gunpoint -- just joking.  I just wanted to check this place out because of all the hype.  

Was I disappointed?  The entree was aiiight.  But the soup dumplings were D-Licious.  I would come back just for the dumplings and I would get the entrees elsewhere.   

Once the last piece of food was gone, the check arrived  magically.  The waiter wanted us out because a line was forming.  What made my experience horrible was the fact that I was sitting across from a family who kept on yapping about rubbish to his daughter.  Can an Asian man enjoy his dinner with friends here... apparently not! 

Three stars Joe.  Here's a tip, you might want to add more tables!

This place is a total TOURIST TRAP... The food is average and the service is lacking. They automatically charge a 15% gratuity, no matter how many are in your party. They obviously don't work for it, and it is reflected in the service you get. I walked out of there missing my Din Tai Fung.

Joe's Shanghai has always been one of my favorite soup dumpling places. My husband and I has been going there for years. However, we witnessed the MOST HORRIBLE WAY they treat their customer from the most recently visit, 

My hubby and I were sitted at a round table shared with other ppl. There are 3 guys sitting next to us and it is obvious that they had never been to this restaurant before and don't know what to order. After they ordered their food, they were served an order of "scallion pancake". All of them looked really confused when it arrived as they have no idea what it is and also they don't really know if they had ordered it by accident. (You can really tell because we were sitting next to them and heard everything....not that I like to ear-drop)

They waited for a while and none of the waiters said anything so they decided to start eating the pancakes........And the moment when they put the pancakes onto their own plate, the waiter who took their order came running, literally pointing his finger on their face yelling -----"DID YOU ORDER THIS?" " YOU DIDN'T ORDER THIS RIGHT?" "UGH" "WHY ARE YOU EATING THIS. YOU DIDN'T ORDER THIS!!!"

The 3 guys looked so embarrassed and doesn't know what to do. ...... And you think that is all??? NO! He then grabbed another plate.. demanded them to put the pancakes ,which were on their own plates already, back to the plate and took it back to the kitchen!!!???

What? Really?? this is just unbelievable. Everyone is staring at them and honestly, they had no clue what that was!!!

The food there is great. If you can endure the horrible attitude, I guess it's worth a try. You might not get yelled at if you are lucky.

First experience eating Shanghai Dumplings!  Liked it, but don't understand the hype around the dumplings. Ordered ones with pork and others with crabs. The thing is that they are regular dumplings, but with soup inside! And soup is freaking hot lol! Burned my tongue! They should warn people like "caution hot" or something lol! Dangerous!Dumplings were OK! But whatever at the same time haha. The place itself is weird, cash only. Really!? Had to go to the ATM. Also we had to share a table with some weird people. Chinese beer tastes like ass, no offense lol. The most amazing thing about this place that they have tons of pictures of owner with celebrities eating his dumplings. Service sucked big time. My second time eating Chinese this week and from now one I don't have high expectations ...

I came here just for their soup dumpling and was truly disappointed! the broth of the soup is GOOD but the skin that wrap the meat is way too thick.. the service is far beyond good 
I might give another try next time when i go to NYC and we'll see what happen then.

Alright guys, let's break a lot of the "NYC = best Chinese food in the USA" groupthink that has plagued the minds of non-native NYers for as long as I can remember. There's some partial truth to that statement, but Joe's Shanghai trips and falls really REALLY short of expectations. Like, it probably can't even see the goal line from where it's fallen. Are the expectations high? Absolutely. But that doesn't forgive the piss-poor attitude, service, and lower standard of food than the rest of its competitors.

SERVICE: The servers here are rude, but in that subtle, passive-aggressive way that many Asian restaurants are guilty of. They made us feel like intruders, despite the fact that I AM Chinese. JUST LIKE YOU. They still delivered their services as expected, but did so completely void of hospitality and friendliness. Since the only way to get a server over at a Chinese restaurant is to make eye contact and the servers REFUSE to make any sort of eye contact with you, you'll be stuck waiting about 10-15 minutes just to get a refill on water.  So ration and plan accordingly.

FOOD: The only...and I mean, ONLY...saving grace of this restaurant is their dumplings--AKA xiao long bao. I've had better at higher-end restaurants (Din Tai Fung in Seattle/LA) and better at random restaurants (Szechuan Garden in AZ), but Joe's Shanghai does it pretty damn well. The bao's are loaded with soup broth though, so be careful! You may end up spilling some of that on yourself, as I did. MULTIPLE TIMES.

We also got their Pan Fried Crispy Noodles. It's not what you'd expect. If you're expecting Hong Kong Style Chow Mein, look elsewhere. The noodles are thicker, flatter in taste, and a hell of a lot less savory. Avoid this dish unless you know what you're getting.

Honestly, I can't remember what else we got. I was so frustrated I didn't even bother taking pictures. It was something simple like beef and broccoli. It was meh, I know plenty of people who could make it better--myself included.

Some may write off this review as being overly harsh, but you have to. It's NYC. If you aren't up to par, then the next restaurant will be. There are tons of framed images of the restaurant owner(s) with famous celebrities, but don't let that fool you. I'd look elsewhere regardless of the circumstance.

If I really wanted to consider the service here, I would have given them a lower rating but the dumplings are so good I let them slide on this one.  Anyone with any expectation of real customer service from any Asian restaurant in NY or any large city for that matter is delusional.  So just get over it and get used to it.  Eat the food and keep your whining to yourself.  Of course I wish this wasn't the case for the majority of the restaurants but it's reality so moving on to the food...

The dumplings are a hundred times better than anything I can get here in Dallas, I know I know, it's freaking Texas, but perhaps my standards have been lowered by years of consuming sub par Asian food at the hands of Americanized Asians forced to alter their menus to appease the timid and bland taste buds of those so called adventurous eaters here down south.  

We ordered the soup dumplings and a side of stir fried snow pea leaves both were excellent and left me feeling quite proud of myself as I can still manage to identify good Asian food.  The filling in the dumpling was delicious, I could sit there for hours and eat one after another.  That would not be a bad idea if it were not for the other strangers sitting at your table gazing at you while you dine.  If you can look past the long lines, the rude and impatient wait staff then expect to find some good eats in what are their famous soup dumplings.

over rated tbh.
full of tourists and long lines...why wait here for something that is way hyped up?
Try other local small businesses where they serve up better soup dumplings.
Its hard to eat there since staff rushes you to eat and get out for the next group of people.

I had an order of crab meat XLB ($8.25 for 8), which looked like pork XLBs ($6.25 for 8). They skimped on the crab and mixed in powdered crustacean shell to enhance the flavor. 

I had to ask if I were having the crab meat XLB and the staff said yes, with a peculiar look. 

For "the XLB experience" in general, go for pork XLBs instead - for $2 less. Just as flavorful and give you room for dessert (egg custards at an area bakery). Ask for extra sauce cups to catch the soup, as you delve into an XLB.

Look carefully at the receipt - 15% service charge is already there.

If you are into more "crab meat" and not mostly pork in your crab meat XLBs, go to Nan Xiang XLB in Queens. If they are still making XLBs like they did two years ago, it's worth the trip.

Have you ever heard that saying: "Americans created Chinese food" well that is EXACTLY what came to mind after eating at this establishment.

I'm part Chinese so of course I've had a lot of authentic Chinese food and have pretty high expectations but unfortunately Joe's Shanghai did not meet those expectations.

First of all, this restaurant has a B rating. Um...ew, why? I'm a nutrition/environmental science major and that just screams NOO to me right off the bat. So as soon as I saw that rating I already began to hold on to my fucking hat. 

I was so disappointed upon our food arriving to our table and was a little perplexed as to why this establishment has 4 stars from so many reviews. Perhaps my party and I just ordered the wrong dishes? 

The service was pretty average for a Chinese restaurant (meaning it was not that great & actually pretty forgettable) & there was a 45 minute wait but luckily we only waited 20 minutes. When we walked in we noticed the restaurant was PACKED. So crowded that they were even seating different parties at the same tables (sorry I'm from LA so that's not new nor is the hustle & bustle of a first world metropolitan to me but I found that even a little more annoying as I wasn't mentally prepared to share a conversation let alone let other people eavesdrop on mine lol) which is not cool in my book. Again, fortunately we were seated off to the side of the place at a table big enough for my party. We ordered immediately (having gone to these types of establishments many times before we already knew what cravings we wanted to satisfy) and the food came to us soon enough after. 
Boy were we disappointed..the seafood pan friend noodle dish was not what we had anticipated. The noodles they used were much different than the usual noodles that are usually used for that dish which made me feel like I had been eating the Viet styled pan fried noodle. Next, the spicy squid with salt (not sure that's what it reads on the menu) was not prepared to our liking..maybe that was our fault for not specifying? Lastly we also ordered the shrimp and noodle soup & when that arrived it honestly just looked & tasted like it was prepared by a man named Joe from Arkansas lol. It was NOT Chinese. Idk I guess we're just picky? The food was just so lackluster. 

Anyway, I'm glad this business is doing well but WE will definitely not be returning to this restaurant!

One of my stops during my NYC trip. Everyone raves about Joe's Shanghai so I had to give it a try. It's so busy here you have to share tables and it's cash only! As soon as you sit down they ask if you want to order dumplings. Well, i guess if you push one product I can see how you'd become known for it. Honestly, it was tasty but no different than the ones I've had here in San Francisco. I guess then it would make it average. I also ordered the shanghai noodles, also no different than SF. Sad to say, it wasn't a let down but probably not worth a stop when I visit NYC since I can get the equivalent back home, without having to share tables.

The low-down on Joes is that it's always packed. And the decor is awful. And most of the dishes are nothing to write home about.  And given the competition nearby, the prices aren't fantastic. 

BUT, then you taste the soup dumplings, and all is forgiven. They are heavenly. It's a strange process, chomping the top and drinking the soup; it feels so wrong, but tastes so right.

Go for the dumplings and stay for a second order.

do not recommend if your table is bigger than 4

They have a terrible system and will give any available seats away until there are less people.

They also have shady under-dealings. You need to pay them under the table cash to get a seat for big tables, if you do you can skip the line.

Cash only!!!

I was looking for a nice dimsum place where they go around with the carts and when I searched under dimsum, this place came up. That's the down side to yelp, it's not very specific. This place does not have dimsum. Onto the food: we had the shanghai soup dumplings, which were surprisingly delicious. The fried pork dumplings were ok, kind of peppery and inconsistently cooked. The scallion pancake tasted ok, but was too greasy. The beef and broccoli and mushoo pork were both good, but nothing special; I'm sure you could find them much cheaper and equally good elsewhere in Chinatown. I was surprised this place got so much hype.

It was ok. It is a bit overrated. The soup dumplings were alright, but I probably wouldn't eat here again to be honest. We also had the shanghai fried flat noodles; they were decent, not a ton of flavor. All in all.... I won't be back when there are so many other good places to eat in NYC.

A super popular spot for good reason. But also a bit of a tourist trap.  There are better places to get Chinese food in nyc but joes shanghai also has a deservedly decent reputation.  If you don't want to dig deeper it's a decent choice.

Took my niece here, who is like a soup dumpling maven, and she wasn't wowed.  Neither was I.  While tasty, the pork dumplings seemed a bit flat with not that much soup in them.  We really enjoyed the shrimp and chicken in plum sauce, and I liked the cold noodles - my niece not so much.  The communal dinning doesn't bother me at all - I like to be a little nosy and see what every one is ordering.  Given the wait time to get in, along with not being wowed by the dumplings, not rushing back.  Also not the biggest fan of the cash only policy.

Special trip from Midtown to Chinatown just for the infamous Joe's Shanghai's soup dumplings (XLB) was absolutely worthless. I was very disappointed and unhappy after trying their XLB. People who gave 4 or 5 stars to Joe's Shanghai's XLB really haven't tried good XLB, literally.

The wait time for us was 30 mins. Once we got seated and ordered, we were so excited and ready to try their famed XLB and expected it to be good. We were totally wrong. The skin of XLB was too thick - the filling was juicy but tasteless. The XLBs here are way overrated! My mom makes better XLB than JoeSchmoe, seriously.

The XLB at Joe's Shanghai is ONLY ordinary and acceptable, definitely not worth the wait!

We had to make a stop here for the famous soup dumplings. I ordered carry out because of the large crowd, but when I went to pick it up just a couple inured early, they were quite rude and wouldn't give me my order. We waited for a while and finally got the dumplings, but I wasn't very pleased with the service. The dumplings them self were not worth the hype, but still had a nice authentic place. I would recommend coming here for the popularity, but I'm sure you can find better soup dumplings elsewhere.
Fast service but super touristy, overcrowded, and food seems catered towards a more stereotypical American palate.

5 star doe soup dumplings. 1star for service.  We ordered eggplant besides the soup dumplings,  which never came.  We asked several times but the server never moved. Only after we said we would like to cancel it if the eggplant is still not ready,  the server went to check and immediately brought the eggplant.
Super disappointing. Flavor just wasn't there. I expected more because of the great reviews in Yelp. We didn't even finish our food.

This place was packed when we arrived, but we did go on a Sunday. The wait was not too bad, but it is helpful if you can speak Chinese. The xiao long bao's or  their soup dumplings were really good, however it does not as good as some of the other ones I have had in China. I had both pork and crab dumplings; the pork dumplings tasted better but in general I felt that there was almost TOO much soup in it (but that is just me being picky). 

The soup is hot, the service is fast...know what you want before you get seated. It's communal seating so if you are not looking for a romantic meal, think twice. Good prices and good food, I would go again!

Because their service (or lack thereof), I would never go back. 

I'm sure the 3500+ reviews says a lot about their soup dumplings, and I DO love their dumplings but can care less to go back because their staff (probably also their management) can care less if I go back.  After my third, and last visit, I've decided to take my business elsewhere, where tip is based on service (and NOT already included on your bill).     

Price: $-$$

Service: shameful

Groups: yes

Would I come back? No

I was disappointed to order here and only accept cash . 

I don't know where is it that they just impose rules on the public .

Going to a crowded spot like Joe's with just one other person (versus a group) is awesome because quick seating is almost guaranteed. 

Sat down and knew without looking at the menu what I wanted: soup dumplings. I'd had them at Shanghai Cafe but I wanted to know what they were like at Joe's. 

They were .. decent. I prefer Shanghai Cafe but it's just a personal preference; I'm sure there are plenty who like Joe's better. 

We also ordered pork fried rice cakes - I really liked this dish! 

I'll probably be back to try other things on the menu and share the soup dumplings with whatever friend(s) I might be with at that time.

Decent, but doesn't live up to hype. Ordered both types of soup dumplings, and half of them came broken. Large, but flimsy. The scallion pancakes we ordered were probably the best part! Beware it's cash only.
Only two things were great -- the steamed dumplings (xiao long bao) and the scallion pancake. Everything else was just Ok. The interior feels a bit gloomy.

Eh..... The xiaolongbao are not half as good as their reputation suggests. Really? 4 stars, Yelpers? Come on.....!

Tried both the shrimp one and the plain pork one. Super disappointed. The key to xiaolongbao is a really thin skin that can simultaneously hold the weight of the soup and pork without breaking, and also being light and chewy.  This is worse than most xiaolongbao I've eaten in my life - given, I did grow up in the land of delicious Chinese food (hong kong). Xiaolongbao skin was thick and overcooked. So if you're wanting to get authentic, great xiaolongbao, this is definitely not the place for you. (Although I'm not sure if there is a better place to go to in New York.)
