Their Singaporean fried noodles and homemade tofu dish is up to par, though! You know what, I might consider coming back for those dishes - but again, considering how overpriced and crowded they are (come on, its Chinatown,) I probably never will.

Came back for the soup dumplings here.  Dumplings were decent, not as good as I remembered before!  

Cash only.  They charged us 15-16% gratuity fee for two people less than a party of four or five included in the bill which I thought was odd...

I ordered:
- Original xiao long bao (sort of bland)
- Xiao long bao with crabmeat (best flavor)
- Scallion pancake
- Salt and pepper fried fish

Got here at 8pm and they seated us at a large round table with random people even when my friend and I asked to sit at an open 4-person table. 2 minutes after we sit down, 2 people walk in and are seated at that table we wanted. Not a huge deal though.

The xiao long bao came out very quickly and haphazardly. 1 of them was broken so all the soup came out. The presentation of the xiao long bao wasn't very appealing. They looked like they were melting. The taste was fine, but I still think Din Tai Fung (located only in Taiwan, Shanghai, and Los Angeles) has the best xiao long bao. The ones at Joe's were sloppy and huge, which would often cause them to fall off of my spoon.

Scallion pancake was quite depressing, since I barely tasted any scallion. The salt and pepper fried fish was decent, but the breading was too thick. I also found a small hair within the breading while I was eating. I didn't bring up the issue with the waiter because they looked really busy. 

The prices are fair here and I'm glad to get away from the outrageous prices I see elsewhere. 

I hear this one of the better places in NYC. I can see why, but it's so hard to say that it's the best when you've really had the best somewhere else.

Not the ideal location for a tourist to locate this restaurant. It's tucked away in a alley street where they usually film gangster fight in this quaint small street. Anyway, we had 3 ppl and had to share a large table with few others. With all the excitement and recommendations from friends, I expected goood soup dumpling.

Let's put it this way, it's good and it has the taste. I wouldn't say it's the best (which i had better ones in Canada), nor was it the worst, it was average good.  Being so reputable, I expected more and didnt expect them to serve soup dumpling that is already leaking soup... that was disappointing. Maybe the restaurant doesn't care for the presentation anymore?

The scallion pancake was tasty, but way too greasy.. Just average. 

I would probably go to the location in East Village in the future, i might probably feel safer.
Good XLB. Long Lines / crowded.

I have to say this is def. not a favorite. I've been to Joe's in flushing which is MUCH better than the Pell St location. Their dumplings tasted very different than those @ the Flushing loc. They weren't as juicy or tasteful. The dough was thick. The food itself was good but I have had better in smaller Chinatown restaurants. The wait was ridiculous. There is no waiting area so you have to stand outside and wait.  Unfortunately, the next day was garbage day and it was quite smelly of rotten garbage outside while we waited. Then you are seated with strangers @ large round tables. They cleaned the table with a dirty towel. The table was sticky. I had the pleasure of sitting next to a guy who just would not stop talking and saying the most rudest things to his girlfriend, her cousin and ate like a caveman. My hubs had the pleasure of sitting next to a guy who would cough all thru the meal and not cover his mouth. The dining room seating was so crowded that I got knocked in the head 3x by the waiters tray. The restroom.......YIKES. I've been in porter potties that I consider to be cleaner!  We thought experiencing Joe's on Pell would be a good experience but it ended up being gross and a huge tourist trap.....

Do the trip to Joe's in Flushing! It's worth it and you will have a much better experience - and awesome soup dumplings!

20% of our soup dumplings had no soup. Even the with-soup dumplings did not meet the hype. Items 9 and 10 are what most people order, #9 is the eight crab dumplings for about $6.65 and #10 is eight pork dumplings for about $4.65 (prices accurate as of Apr 2011). I would say one order of eight dumplings is good enough for a small meal.

All other menu items are WAY overpriced for Chinatown and completely skippable. No interesting flavors, just salty and really oily. We tried the braised pork shoulder and the eel with yellow chives (my mom is a eel expert and complained that they used frozen eel). 

Go here only if you're craving soup dumplings. Have fun with the wait and the automatic 15% tip.
It's true.  I only go here for the soup dumplings.  But they are so damn good.

I'm not sure why this place was so packed.  The food was so so.  We got the sticky rice, the edamame, crab soup dumplings for lunch.  The service was rushed.  They only had two waiters so I suppose that's why they were rushing people in and out.  There are so many other places to try in this area.  Provably won't be coming back.

The Crab XLB was amazing.  I think it was #1 on the menu.
The other dishes were ok.....
I have to agree with many of the reviewers.  
1. It is a tourist trap. 
2. Service is mediocre 
3. The wait (1 hour and a half for us) was not worth it.  

If you have time, head over to Flushing for some better Chinese food.

Joe's Shanghai is one of those places where you feel obligated to go simply because the amount of reviews it has on Yelp. It's like a right of passage to NY. As much as I hate giving it 3 stars and going against all of the highly rated reviews, I think this place is completely overrated and overhyped. The wait time usually varies between 30 minutes to 1.5 hours, and you're not allowed to sit until all of your members are there. They give you a line number system but even if one person is missing, it goes to the next group. Weekends are the worst and so is dinner time, although even during off hours I always see a massive line out the door. The interior is pretty small and is insanely packed. Basically it's a tourist trap. 

Joe's is renown for its soup dumplings. These especially hit the spot during a cold winter day, or simply after a night of shenanigans. I will say the dumplings are reasonably priced! I came with a group and we tried a couple of varieties. The xiao long bao was soft and freshly steamed. The inside soup was pretty good, but I found I needed to pour some sauces inside to really amp up the flavor. It leaned towards the sweeter side, whereas I'm more of a slightly saltier broth type of girl.

Overall the food is decent but the wait time is not worth it. There are much better places in Chinatown.

I'll admit I've not had xiao long bao anywhere else, but I've had my share of different types of bao/dumplings and while it was good, it wasn't out of this world, knock me off of my socks. I guess so much hype, I expected much more. The bun part seemed to a little too chewy. We had both the pork and the crab... both were okay, though I prefer the pork to the crab.

I was sadly quite disappointed with Joe's Shanghai.  After trying Nan Xiang a couple of weeks ago, someone whose food opinion I highly respect recommended this place, so I was very excited to try it, especially being that Flushing is a hike and a half away for me.

We went to Joe's on a Tuesday night.  The place was packed.  We were seated immediately at a communal table.  The service was a little spotty.  Although we personally had a pretty good experience, the people across from us would beg to differ.  Their server accidentally threw away their to-go food and then took ~10 minutes to admit it, while they were trying to leave. Awkward to watch - one of the drawbacks of the communal table situation. Part of the reason that it's annoying is that they automatically add gratuity onto the bill here.  

We ordered the crab & pork soup dumplings, the Shanghai noodles, and a side of bok choy.  

The dumplings came out first.  Even though all the flavors were there, EVERY SINGLE DUMPLING broke.  Not the best craftsmanship and made it very difficult to eat them.  

Next were the Shanghai noodles.  These were pretty standard and this was a large portion, so we were overall happy with the dish.  

Lastly, the bok choy came out.  While I love bok choy, it prompted both me and my dining partner to independently ask if bok choy was in season.  While there was nothing specifically wrong with the dish, it wasn't fantastic either.  

All in all, for $36, this was a large amount of food, but it certainly did not live up to the hype for me.

*2.5 Stars* After seeing people around me slurping up broth and biting into their steamy, plump, succulent soup dumplings, I couldn't wait to get my order. I guess it just wasn't what I expected after hearing so many great things about this place. My best friend and I got the pork and crab meat dumplings. The soup was greasy and the flavor was just so odd... it didn't taste anything like pork or crab meat. It kind of tasted 'old' and 'instant.' I liked the chewy texture of the dumpling skin but I couldn't get around the flavor of the meat or the thick oily broth.

I really liked the Crispy Shredded Beef. Despite the strips of beef being mostly crunchy breading, it was sweet and fried and 10x better than the dumplings.

We went around dinner time on a work night and thankfully didn't have to wait in line. We were seated immediately at a round table with some other folks, and although the place was pretty packed we were able to order, eat, and pay fairly quickly.

Food - 2 stars
Service - 2 stars
Value - 1.5 stars
Ambience - 1 star

I would not recommend this restaurant. I will definitely not be returning. The moment I walked in, my gut told me to walk out but the Yelp reviews reported 4 stars and so I decided to give it a chance. Staying was a mistake and a waste of stomach space.

18% tip automatically added or as they call it, a service charge which is not voluntary the way tip should be.  It's still cash only.  At this new location, the soup dumplings have changed with a thicker skin, less flavorful broth, and less tender filling.  I would rather go to Shanghai Cafe Deluxe, or whatever the new name is, on Mott St.
Meh. Soup dumplings were alright. A bit more fatty tasting than usual. (Which is what made it worse imo) The dumplings you can get in vancouver canada are definitely better.
If you and looking for American Chinese food, this is the place. A big NO if you are looking for real Chinese food

The dumplings are really good but the prices shot up a little since I last visited. Usually really crowded and you have to wait to get in but pretty much worth it when you have the munchies. The wait staff is a little rude and tend to rush you. I tried their place in Mid town but I didn't like it that much. It was even more expensive and the place smelled.

Really good xiao long bao has thinnish skin, a little bit of soup and is savory, i have had xiao long bao all over taiwan and at Din Tai fung the world famous xiao long bao restaurant that has locations all around the world. I think the best I have had have all been at random street stalls at night.. 

Joe's Xiao long bao has thick skin, a ton of soup and is weirdly sweet... in other words damn my cousin for being right this place has a weird take on one of my favorite chinese foods. Maybe in NY its considered good but if this thick skinned soupy ass thing they dare called xiao long bao opened up in the bay area it would close up real fast.

I gave this rating purely based on a possible rip-off situation committed by this restaurant.  It would be 3 without the situation I am about to warn the fellow yelpers.

I actually visited Joe's twice.  I went in there for the first time around 1:30 simply by seeing how busy the place was.  We were combined with 2 groups at a big table.  We enjoyed the lunch we had but did not recall the name of restaurant.

For my recent trip to NYC, I did some homework to google for "best Chinese Food in NYC."  This restaurant popped out and I yelped it for popular items fellow yelpers mention.  We went there before lunch rush hour and realized it is the same one we went to several months ago.  We were so glad that we made the right choice at that time.  We ordered two kinds of soup dumplings.  My wife and I have different opinions.  She thinks our San Francisco favorite is better but I think it is as good as yelpers recommend.  We tipped by our regular percentage on the receipt.

A few days after we got back to CA, my wife found the receipt while cleaning up all the receipts in her handbag.  She was so upset to find that Joe's actually charged 15% in their subtotal.  Normally we briefly check the restaurant receipts, but we just missed it.  I am sure there is a fine print to state that service charge would be levied for any number of guests on the menu.  We were burned by a dim-sum restaurant in Chinatown Oakland for years before we learned that it charges 10%.  We manage to warn our friends for this unusual practice to collect tips.  Therefore, when you visit this restaurant, don't be distracted by all the waiters standing around your table.  READ THE FINE PRINT, IF ANY, ON THE MENU, AND IT IS 15% IN YOUR RECEIPT ALREADY.

One star for the soup dumplings. They were ok. Definitely NOT spectacular, and definitely NOT worth the wait. 
Zero stars for everything else. 
Because of its popularity, you have to wait a while to get seated, and you have to wait outside. 
The restaurant itself is loud and kind of dirty. Not dirty in the way a "hole in the wall" place is dirty, because that's fine. This place was truly dirty.
Every table is a communal table, so unless you're a party of 10 that can take up an entire table, you're eating on a table with strangers. 
Several people on my table didn't realize it was cash only when time to pay, so clearly the restaurant should make that more clear. 
There is also an included gratuity of 15%. Included gratuity?!?! For what?!?! Half decent food, horrible ambiance, and a staff that just tries to rush you out of there so they can keep the wait line moving?
Perhaps this place was good at one point. Unfortunately, it's become a victim of its popularity. An increase in customers leads to increased pressure on the staff and the cooks. The staff just tries to rush you out. On my way out, none of the staff said thank you for coming. I've lived in NYC all my life. I know that most Chinese restaurants rush you and do not provide warm, attentive service. But even they say "thank you for coming." Not this place. This place was beyond rude. They just ignore you and they're probably happy you left so that they can keep the line moving. The increased popularity hurts the food quality as well, since cooks can't deliver the same quality of food because they're rushed. This then leads to customers, like myself, who, after waiting to get seated amongst strangers, eating "just ok" food, and being rushed out by staff, you actually regret spending money here.

I just moved to NY and was really excited to check out chinatown especially since I was living in Chicago for 6 years where the chinatown was almost nonexistent. I saw all the reviews of this place so I thought it would be a great meal. This place was really disappointing. I didn't like the communal seating method they used but more importantly, the food was mediocre at best. They seemed to emphasis rushing you in and out versus actually delivering on good food.

If you're looking for traditional soup dumplings, this probably isn't the spot for you. I had heard about Joe's Shanghai from many different spots that recommended NYC eats, so I figured I would give them a try. There was quite a lot of people waiting, but we got our number called in around 20 minutes. However, from there they still made us wait another 20 minutes or so which felt weird.

We decided to only get soup dumplings since that is what they're known for, and got an order of the pork and another of the crab and pork. They arrived pretty quickly, and we were all quite shocked when they opened the steamer basket because of how large they were. These are probably around double the size of your normal xiaolongbao, so a single order of 8 is actually quite a lot. The skin was also a lot thicker than normal, which my friends and I didn't really prefer. There was definitely plenty of soup inside, but the soup had some weird gelatinous bits within which was odd to eat. Between the two, we felt the classic pork was better but the crab wasn't too bad either. 

I don't think I'd return, but at least I got to try for myself the soup dumplings that people always talk about from here. Not traditional, but acceptable.

Disappointed with our experience at Joe's Shanghai.  We came here based on the reviews on yelp, and expected more.  When we arrived, there was a long line of people waiting outside so we assumed the place must be great!  The wait time quoted was 30 minutes, however it took about 50 minutes to be seated and that is only because two parties ahead of us left.  

The establishment is small and dark.  The wall next to our table was splattered with food, and during our meal a roach crawled out from behind one of the pictures and walked across the wall above our table.  GROSS!!  So much to say about the wait staff.  For starters, my husband accidentally walked in on one of them using the single-use restroom, and the man finished urinating, did NOT wash his hands, and then served food to a nearby table.  Totally unsanitary!  Also, they bring the food out one order at a time, so you are not eating your meal together.  The last dish was brought to the table 25 minutes after the first dish, so 2 of the people were finished eating before the other 2 even started!  Lastly, they are very unattentive - you have to ask for absolutely everything mutliple times (water, tea, napkin).  The restaurant automatically includes 15% tip and NY sales tax in your bill, so since the wait staff is guaranteed a 15% tip, there is no incentive for them to be attentive.  Also, be sure you bring cash!  There is no payment via credit or debit cards, cash only.

As for the food, the wontons and fried rice were outstanding!  They deserve 5 stars!!  The other food is nothing special.  Typical Chinese food you would get anywhere.

I would give a negative star if I could. We didn't even get a chance to eat here because the check in process was horrible... they told us the wait was  45 min and that was okay , however 15 min later they told us the wait was over an hour.... apparently they honor people who leave and come back even though they were called... this is unfair to those who wait... in that case why not make reservations.  The other downside was cash only.

Jury Duty for 4 months,  a dumpling is necessary. I heard this place was legendary.  We went there 3 times and only once did i taste a dumpling. I probably shouldn't have waited. It was pretty tasty. I'll venture back downtown, sans jury summons.

CASH ONLY
I've become a fan Xiao Long Baos, but the rest of the food is just ok.

The waiting line is long. They shouldn't let strangers sit at the table together. Uncomfortable to eat with anybody that you don't know. Not good service, the waitresses doesn't know how to do service, not friendly just stay in the front desk to clean the menu.

It is so famous in Yelp so we walked inside. We ordered four dishes. The pork soup dumpling is not bad but others are so so.Since the gratuity is counted into the total payment automaticallyÔºåthe staffs in this restaurant are not nice. They are impatient when we are orderingÔºàwe alrealy know what to orderÔºâand being rude while cleaning the tableÔºàone guy accidently hit me by trayÔºâ.
Good place for Shanghi food.
I had the dumplings everyone goes crazy over. They were tasty but otherwise this was just a busy Chinese food place - no dim sum, which was what I was searching for.

restaurant is to scam tourists - oily salty over priced food
poor service 
also be careful: cash only 
illegally silently charges 18 percent to your check

Yelp rarely leads me to a place I don't like! Sorry but  this place was way too greasy and not what I was expecting the shezuan chicken was drowning in grease and oil. They start you off with dumplings which were really good. My husband had the pork fried rice and we also thought it was way too greasy there's a line and a long wait and honestly it wasn't worth it to me.

This place has great prices and the food is above average. I did try the famous "soup balls" and was pleasantly surprised at how flavorful they were. The downside is that there is no private dinning whatsoever, you will sit with strangers guaranteed. And you will wait a minimum of 20 minutes until a rude hostess calls your number, because well... That's what you are at a place like this... A number.

During our trip to NYC, Joe's showed up repeatedly on our search for must-have restaurants.  Needless to say we made a point to make a trip to see what the hype was all about. 

Totally overrated, totally overhyped, and total disappointment. 

To start, the popular soup dumplings.  I don't think I've ever been so repulsed by a food item.  I've had soup dumplings before, and these were absolutely horrible.  Soup was bland.  Also, there was so much fat in the soup.  It looked disgusting and I couldn't eat them.  The amount of fat floating in the soup was repulsive. I cannot even begin to describe how bad it was.  It kind of set the tone for the rest of the visit as I was scared to try anything else. 

I ordered the Shanghai fried rice. The pics I saw showed a tastier looking version.  When we got ours, it was a very bland dish.  It was just white rice with eggs and onions in it. No sauce, no flavors.  Disappointed again. 

Then we had the crispy noodles with beef. Another popular item.  The crispy noodles were ok.  The beef wasn't horrible but something about the sauce was very off.  

Overall, I can't recommend this place.   Don't do it.

Their soup dumplings are amazing . However they had a C rating last time i went. My understanding of C means roaches rodents and food left out in improper temperatures. If they would just keep their place clean then maybe the food will be trust worthy enough to enjoy. I do like their pan fried noodles . But i will not go bAck until that letter is A

So, Joe's had a tough task in trying to impress, given I'd had my heart set on feasting at Shanghai Cuisine (which is, most regrettably, closed on Tuesdays).

Overall, a bit overpriced, I think, for the greasiness of the food. Shanghai's dumplings are more delicate and less oily-tasting. I'm also dropping my review a star for general ambiance and service; everything except getting the bill took eons.

For the SF-familiar: My dinner partner points out that the pork soup dumplings, drained of the soup, taste quite a bit like those of U-Lee on Hyde Street. Worth mentioning, not worth venturing out for.

I like Joe's Shanghai.. but what is up with the waiter?

I felt like the waiter was trying to rush us out? I know it was around closing time, but there were still 2 LARGE tables sitting there and EATING. Cleaning up a table with 3 people is not gonna make you go home that much earlier. We had one soup dumpling left and the waiter stood next to us with his hand on the chair waiting for us to eat it so he can take the steamer away. Then when we got the oranges, I didn't even get a chance to eat it yet and he comes up to us, grabs the plate, and says, you don't want it anymore, right? I immediately told him, yes, i want it.

I came because my friend recommended this place to me. I was hoping for a great experience, but I left feeling a bit disappointed. Service was horrible, our server was rude and didn't help us with anything. It was also strange to be seated with other parties too instead of having our own table even though there were open tables around us. 

SHRIMP FRIED RICE
The flavor was so simple and basic. It definitely wasn't worth the price. There was way too much soy sauce in the rice and it was very salty. It definitely was lacking the authentic fried rice I was looking for. 

SAUTEED STRING BEAN- with minced pork
This was one of the better dishes. I really liked the crispness. It definitely added some textures to some of the other dishes. 

CRISPY PEPPER SKIN DUCKLING
I really disliked this dish. The skin was crisp, but salty. I didn't like the flavor and it was just too fried for my liking. The flavor didn't stand out in anyway other than the salt. It was very disappointing. 

CRAB MEAT WITH PORK MEAT SOUP DUMPLINGS
If I ate this dish alone, I would give this restaurant 5 stars. The dumplings were my favorite part of the meal. It was so sweet and moist. I really like the sweet broth inside the dumplings. I've tried other places that have tried this, but have failed. If I ever come back, it will only be to order this and this alone.

I most likely won't be coming back. The service and food are disappointing. I did like their staple soup dumpling dish, but I don't know if it's worth the whole experience.

Rude and angry service on the phone. Placed an order and was told the total of the order. The amount seemed high based on website prices. So I enquired. Apparently they raised the prices but didn't update the website.  That is fine but there was no need to yell at me. The woman was so upset that I asked. She screamed that they will change it. The exchange was so unpleasant and should  have been handled with grace. This is a restaurant not a street fight. Do better!

My friend, who lives in New York, recommended this restaurant when I asked her good chinese restaurants.

I've been here a few times so far. My husband and I went to New York for the weekend and came here for lunch for the first time.
We arrived here around 11:30am and were seated immediately. People kept coming in, so I was excited for the food.
We ordered shrimp fried rice, xiao long bao,  and sesame chicken. Yep, we ordered so much food! I liked their xiao long bao a lot. Sesame chicken and shrimp fried rice were good too. 

I really liked their food, so we decided to come back here for lunch recently. We arrived here around 12:00pm and had to share the one big round table with two other 2-people groups.

We ordered xiao long bao, chicken fried rice, and dumplings this time. I was very disappointed that xiao long bao wasn't as good as the first time. Fried rice and dumplings were good though. Since all groups ordered so much food, we had to make room for the food.

The service was okay. It's a typical chinese restaurant. Nothing spectacular. The portions are large, and the prices are okay. 

I wouldn't come back voluntary but I may come back if my friends wants to come here.

Been coming here since I was a child and I have to say it's not what it used to be. The food have flavor all because of MSG, so it doesn't have the pure flavor on its own. And compare to other shanghainese restaurants, this is over priced, the food isn't what it used to be and it's not worth the wait. Overall, disappointing.

The food was ok. The atmosphere was terrible. There is usually a long wait to get in and when you do music is blaring, you sit down and the waiters are in you instantly asking you if your ready. They all seem very angry and they don't really care if they get your order right. Once we were done eating we were getting our money out and four waiters were circling around the table watching us. The food was not worth the wait nor the aggressive and unfriendly staff.

Like everyone said the soup dumplings here rule. But warning to the unaware... if you come here with a small group 1 to 4 people and its busy, then they will make you share tables. This place is small and tends to get crowded. So be prepared for the culture shock. For those of you use to this, it is just like Chinatown dimsum.

In addition to the soup dumplings, the next extraordinary item on the menu is the Shanghai Noodles. Order it, Eat it, and Savor it. Its a must order item. Everything else on the menu is good, as are the seasonal specials. But the noodles are the second best thing at this restaurant.

This is the best Joe's Shanghai location. The one in flushing sucks. I've eaten there 3 times and each time its proved incredibly disappointing. Its like the one in flushing is a franchise restaurant runned by white people or something. The food is just off. The one uptown is okay... good food, better service, but its a rip off. Down in Chinatown you can get 8 Xiao Lung Bao (soup dumpling) for $6. Up there its like 5 for $8. The pricing like that across the menu... 20%-30% more... just go down to Chinatown. You can get dessert at the Chinatown Ice Cream Factory after dinner.

We came first, then another group of people came in and the waitress ask us to share the round table. We didn't want to seat with a group of strangers, so we asked to seat just our group. Then the waitress spoke in Chinese with others and just asked another group to share the table. There was No "excuse me", No "sorry". What kind of customer service was that? 
I didn't try the food yet, but with the way they treat customers like that, I don't think we gonna enjoy the food and services
Sitting here thinking we went for dim sum. No dim sum.  And food is just ok.  Dirty glasses.  Very touristy.  There is much better just next store.

The soup dumplings are the worst I've had as a frequent visitor to Dim Tai Fong. It's clearly reheated vs freshly cooked. Everything else is poorly cooked too. I ordered a fish dish and the whole body is missing - how do I eat a fish head and tail?!

The ambience is just terrible, very loud and everything is greasy. If you are visiting NYC and Chinatown for the heck of it, please steer clear from this restaurant. Rest assured their waiters were not expecting you  to return the moment you walked in :)

NO. Just no. Am Chinese, visiting from California. Go to the west coast if you want good Chinese food. Like LA, or SF, or Vancouver (LA is #1. Speaking as someone who hates on LA lol). This place is not it; I feel bad for people who come here because of the reviews (like me).

The soup dumplings were huge and therefore awkward to eat. Too thick and starchy. The actual pork dumpling filling was fine. But the crab dumpling was so fishy and off-putting (this is coming from someone who doesn't mind fishy. Like fish sauce & shrimp paste fishy). Crab meat was the orangey fishy kind you buy from the can. Potent stuff.

THEN we ordered Sichuan beef. (Now I understand you don't come to NYC for Sichuan food. I just wanted to try it, since it was listed on the "favorites" menu). There was nothing Sichuan about it, no numbing, nothing. Needed seasoning (even just salt!). Barely spicy. Bad cut of beef, chewy. I sort of had to wrestle with it with my teeth and chopsticks. That very oily, starchy, almost gravy-like sauce that they do for Americanized Chinese food. Like they put cornstarch. When people stereotype and say 'Chinese food is too oily?' Yes, this was that, in a bad way.

Oh and FYI it's cash only with 18% service charge. The service was good, attentive.

Bottom line: If you want authentic food of different ethnic cultures... Follow the historical immigration trends. It's really that simple. For example, I'd come to NYC to try European/western cuisine. Or SoCAL if you want good Mexican food. The majority of Asians came through the Pacific. If you want good Asian food, you're better off looking on the west coast.

PS: This review may be a bit harsh, but I'm just trying to help people out.

I came here because of all of the hype behind this place, but I don't think it is worth it. We got the crab soup dumplings and the pork soup dumplings. Unfortunately, the soup dumplings lack a lot of flavor and they were a lukewarm when they were brought out. I had to smother them in vinegar to taste anything. I might come back here to try their other dishes, but I will be going to Shanghai Asian Manor down the street next time I am craving soup dumplings.

I came here. I ordered what people on yelp said to order. I couldn't even finish my dumplings. It was not good at all and I'm appalled that it has such high ratings on yelp. Seriously people.

I kind of like the fact that you share a table with people. It's a nice way to socialize.

So thoroughly overrated. So pissed that I ate here. Everything was bad- the waitstaff, the space, the food. Everything. There is 0 to redeem this place. How does it have this reputation. I've had soup dumplings in so many other places that are so much better. The only piece of food we had that was slightly tasty was the scallion pancake. My wife had noodles that were bland and tasted like they had been cooked in fat (Yuck) My father in laws dish of beef was tasteless and had been fried to a crisp. My dish of chicken was bland as well. Even their tableside hot condiment was bland (how can this be???) The service was rude, they forgot about us, our drinks were never filled, etc. The space is terribly loud and cramped, which we could all overlook if their food was stellar. But, it's not. There are so many places in this city, places in Manhattan, outside of Chinatown, in Queens, in Brooklyn, that have such better food. I would never, ever come back to this poor excuse for a restaurant.

I've had a good sampling of XLB (xiao long bao aka soup dumplings) in Chinatown and this place delivers tasty ones.  They have a good broth, don't break too easily (but aren't too doughy) and pack some porky flavor.  However, this place is a one trick pony.  Everything else on the menu doesn't wow--it's average at best and is very "Americanized" (greasy, food court type, overly sauced).  Don't think it's worth the long wait, but it is a fun experience.  

By the way, while you are waiting there is a great bar around the corner called Apotheke--check it out!
Dumplings! thats what people come here for they tasted alright... I think the best part of this was community seating and chatting it up with random people.

I wonder why Joe's Shanghai is considered as a tourist spot. The food seemed decent to me and there was nothing special about the restaurant itself. The day I went, it was lunchtime, and my Chinese lawyer friends who work in Chinatown decided to take me here since I was a tourist. They admitted it wasn't the best in NY, but I was game just to see what it was all about.

The walk to Joe's was right through Chinatown. As I was following my friends, I just kept getting distracted by all the shops. It looked like they all sell the same stuff just like they do in Asia. When we finally got to Joe's Shanghai it was around 3PM and there wasn't a wait. We got seated right away at a large round table later to be joined by other patrons whom we didn't know. Since this was just a late afternoon snack, we just got a couple orders of the soup dumplings.

Now, this wasn't my first time trying soup dumplings. Luckily for me, the first time I went my friend told me exactly how to eat them. Pick one up with your chopsticks and put it in your spoon. Poke a hole so the broth comes out. Blow, slurp, and chew. If it weren't for his step by step instruction, I'm sure I would've severely burned my mouth off because those suckers are scalding hot!

Joe's soup dumplings were nothing to brag about. They had good flavor, but I could tell the broth was extra fatty, and the health conscious freak inside me was freaking out about it. I think I preferred the soup dumplings at Din Tai Fung better, but theirs are just extremely overpriced.

Plus: Um ... the service was good and the wait wasn't as long as I thought it was going to be. The soup dumplings were aiite. It wasn't anything to go crazy over like everyone claims. (I'm from Rowland Heights where the Chinese food is hella on-point)

Delta: I actually don't know what everyone's raving about. I felt that the place was overpriced for what it was. I came here with my sister and her husband who I have not seen in so long and to be seated next to another family just made for a really awkward, unpleasant ,and loud-speaking conversation when I just wanted to catch up with them. I think if you're looking to enjoy some quality conversation, you really should not be going to Joe's Shanghai.

Maybe I need to go back to this place and assess it again. I haven't been here in well over a year due to my horrible experience.

Ratings
Service/Wait time - 0.5
Food/Drinks - 0.5
Environment/Music - 0
Price - 0
Experience - 0

Overall = 1
don't know why everyone loves the dumplings..thought they were gross. shanghai noodles were good, but nothing special

I've been here about 3 times already and was lucky enough to not have to wait for a table.

First of all, the sign says Joe's Ginger which made me unsure of whether this is the place everyone raves about. Secondly, I had the soup dumplings and while I think they were good. I didn't see the hype. I've never had a soup dumpling I didn't like and this didn't seem that much better than other places. We ordered spring rolls on a whim and they were cold in the middle. Service sucks like most places in Chinatown. But this trip was more of an in-and-out rather than a hangout.

I don't know how to give 0 star so I guess I need to give at least 1 star! Too bad!
I don't understand why people line up for this junk! To be honest, there is better xiao long bao (shanghai style small steamed pork buns) in Flushing and besides offering bad service, bad food, they also offer some rip off too!

Food:
Worst I have ever tried on earth! I ordered xiao long bao and sauteed baby shrimp; the pork is not fresh; buns are poorly shaped; the shrimps of course is not fresh and I could only taste corn flour of it.

Environment:
If you consider ....dirty and very unattractive; very crowded and who wants to share table with someone you don't know at all?

Service:
What? That's service? I don't really think that's any! The major thing I really want to make clear here: pal, you have right to decide how much you want to give your gratuity for the service you just enjoyed...BUT not to be forced giving a 15% "service charge" in your bill without being told/ mentioned anywhere in the menu. And I also believe most people didn't realized that they paid the tips already and they paid again after checking out. So, if you know you have to go, CHECK YOUR BILL AND DON'T DOUBLE PAID THEM!

Overall:
Garbage!
The service are pretty bad. There are other ppl order after us got dish before ask. And when I ask the waiter he actually shout at me.

SOUP DUMPLINGS. Love it.
I also tried the shrimp lo mein but it tastes like every other lo mein (nothing special). Just get the soup dumplings.

I would've given this place four..maybe five stars if it wasn't for the service. Poor service and they seat you in the most random places.. The second time I went, my friend and I were seated in one of those round tables that're usually used for groups. We sat almost leg-to-leg with other customers and had barely any space to move which got really awkward and uncomfortable. The third time I went, I was seated right next to the trash can and where they store dirty dishes which was really unpleasant since it started smelling like trash.. The waiters seem a bit rude as well. They just want you to eat then leave. I asked for hot sauce and they leaned over our food to get the hot sauce on the other table and said, "here. Use this." 

I've been to the one in Flushing as well and it's so much more worth it to go to that one. Only thing is that you have to wait for so long to be seated, but this one in Chinatown seats you fairly quickly.

Their waiting Service is very bad. The worst I have ever seen. You wait in a queue depends on how many people in your group. Which means if you have four people coming in instead of 2 ppl, even though you wait in queue earlier than four people group. They will let four ppl group go first. Because they have more four ppl tables than 2.

Everyone loves Joe's. This is a soup dumpling place, but I though the Gen CHWS was better. It may be me but soup dumplings smell like my grandmothers freezer. Not the one in the house the one in the garage. I'd say go or order In if you like soup dumplings.

I heard that Joe's Shanghai is famous for their xiaolongbao (soup dumplings), so I decided to drop by on Sunday to give them a try. There were no seats available so I asked for 2 orders of xiaolongbao (8 dumplings per order) to go. 

The dumplings looked very sad and deflated in the to go containers. The soup dumplings in the Yelp photos look very full and pillowy, so maybe the dumplings here are best eaten fresh. I did not enjoy the taste and texture of these xiaolongbao as much as the xiaolongbao from Nan Xiang Dumpling House in Flushing. The skin felt too doughy and the meat/broth did not taste as flavorful.

I'd like to come back and get a table next time so that I can try the fresh dumplings that they serve here.

Overhyped and not consistent. I've only been here once so maybe we were unlucky, but the state of our xiao long baos were unnacceptable. 

Food: My friend and I only got the pork xiao long bao and scallion pancakes to share-- the pancakes were great, but our dumplings were so soggy and floppy that they came ripped and stuck to each other/to the basket, causing all the soup to spill out.  The flavor of the soup wasn't that great either in my opinion. We showed the waiter and he offered us new dumplings (but 2 dumplings because we had 2 left), which was nice, but I couldn't believe the dumplings came out like that

Service: There's usually a wait to get in, it wasn't too bad for us (15-20 min) on a Sunday afternoon. Service is prompt; our waiter couldn't really understand my questions, but that's fine. 

Atmosphere: It was definitely packed in there and tables were places very close to each other.

Basically, overhyped. I've had better xiao long baos/shanghainese food elsewhere that didn't have a wait.

I sometimes go to the one in Flushing because my hubby loves their soup dumplings. I, on the other hand, not so crazy about their food. Perhaps because my home is northern China, the flavor of things are just not quite the same. Southern cuisine are often too sweet and too saucy, and their dishes are like the better Chinese take-out that I get from the neighborhood.  The decor of the restaurant is just like many of the older Chinese restaurants in the city, bright with fluorescent light and loud chatters. It would not be a good place to take your date to, forget about  intimate conversations. Their service is efficient and direct, like many of the Chinese places. "What's your order", followed by delivery of food, followed by delivery of the check. It's what I like to call "Eat and Get Out".

The prices are pretty reasonable. But if you're in Flushing, you could get so much more for your money by visiting the small hole-in-the-walls.

We wanted to go to their other famous Joe's restaurant but there were people waiting outside so we decided to come here instead. There was no waiting time and we were seated on the second floor.
We ordered pork and crab dumplings but I couldn't tell the difference at all... We also ordered fried rice, morning glory stirfry and a pork stir fry, all of these portions were super tiny (maybe my friend ordered the small size??)
But anyways it's not even a one-person portion so be aware of that.
Also once you are done with your meal, they immediately give you the bill, and if you don't pay ASAP they come and stand in front of you until you give them the money.
Not very pleasant service, but hey, it's Chinatown so what can you expect right...

Finally ate in Chinatown and picked a place based on Yelp reviews, (like usual) and was impressed by Shanghai Joe's having so many reviews and accolades from mainstream media. Cold sesame noodles, braised duck and Szechuan tofu were my favorites. Other dishes were not as flavorful. Next time I'll look for a top-rated option that has fewer reviews, less well known.

This place is a tourist trap. Very basic dumplings. It's not even good and nothing special. I don't know what's the hype is all about. Din Tai Fung makes way better dumplings than this place. Do not go there.

Food is decent. The soupy dumpling are good. Service is horrendous. Do not like the fact that they add tip to bill even if service was bad especially the people who seat you. The worst restaurant for groups as they will threaten to not seat you if a single member of your party has nota arrived yet. Overall the shanghai restaurants on mott st are better. The only thing good here are the dumplings.

This is the one time that Yelp has failed me. This place has seemingly positive reviews, but it just didn't do it for me.

The restaurant is not big by any stretch. We had a group of 6 people and yet they still sat us at this table that probably could fit 4 max. The food was alright. I've definitely had better XLB's. The XLB skin ripped easily, so before I can even put the damn thing in my mouth, all the juice (there wasn't much juice to begin with) was gone. As far as the the service, I felt like it was crap. I say that because this dude taking away our dirty dishes then proceeding to drop those dishes on the floor, which in turn dropped the leftover stuff from those dishes onto my jacket, which is hard to clean. No apology, no nothing. Imagine all the juice from the XLB that popped out and stayed on those dishes and then having it all on your jacket. That's what happened. 

If you like to buy into the hype of restaurants, then try it. But if you want good XLB's this is not your place.

Dined here while we visited NY since my husband loves soup dumplings and Joe's Shanghai is known for them. I was actually very disappointed this time around. 

We got the pork & crab dumplings, pork dumplings, chicken fried rice and general tso's chicken. Nothing tasted spectacular. The dumplings were not the best this time around. We both recall them being amazing! The fried rice just okay, looked and tasted too wet though, not very authentic. Lastly, the general Yao's chicken. Typically I wouldn't have ordered this but my daughter's friend wanted it so we did. Chicken was a bit dry, sauce was tasty though. 

Wish we left satisfied :/

After all the hype and looking at the pics which looks so good!!! We decided to stop here after visiting the 9/11 memorial!! Walking inside the was a weird smell which made me feel iffy about the place!!! We ordered food pics from photos seen on yelp that looks good!! But once our order came in, we tried the Shanghai flat noodles and it was not as good as what yelpers say!!! The dumpling to me was ok, nothing special!! After ordering so much food, my tummy was not satisfy!! Hate goin into a restaurant and it just didn't hit the spot!! Not only that but u have to share a table w other people so it kinda makes it akward waiting for their food and just stare at us eating!!!

I couldn't remember when was the last time I went there, this time was to treat a friend in town because of its name. All the food we ordered including the soup dumplings were subpar, too doughy thick and hard on top, I've had better. Good for their business though, it's just a tourist cult and trap to me.

I have been here twice 1st time I was here without the kids and thought food was ok and I would have rated it 3 stars. Noting over the top family style dining sharing  table with strangers. Service was also just ok. 2nd time we stopped by with my kids and let me tell u service was just horrible. This is my 1st bad review at Yelp. I don't like giving bad reviews but this deserves a bad review. 1st the waiter was not polite at all, he was not trying to hep with menu and really not accommodating. We needed plates, juices for kids he left for good 5 10 min we had to ask another waiter for help. Then the waiter kept taking to the people next to us the whole time in Chinese laughing and just chatting away. At one point he was kept passing my by my chair and rubbing against my back without saying anything.. I had to tell him to stop rubbing against my back every minute. He wasn't passes dishes or anything he  just kept talking to the people at the table not paying attention to us. We didn't feel comfortable at all. I told him straight up that he sucked and to stop rubbing against me, and then I spoke to the manager how horrible service was but nothing was done about it, just apologized. I will never go back no matter how good these saggy dumplings are!!
#1 dumplings on the appetizer menu were delicious. Everything else is blah! They also add msg which made my head hurt.
If you want to try the real things, I sincerely suggest you got to Philadelphia. The dumplings in Dim Sum Garden is million times better.

FOOD - 3/5
The portion sizes here are so generous, the xiao long baos were huge!! The food was okay, somewhat of a hit or miss because while the fried rice was super good, the taiwanese beef noodle soup was pretty bland.

SERVICE - 4/5
The restaurant had a ton of tables inside so we got seated immediately even if it was during lunch hour. The servers were super attentive and efficient. The only thing I would mention is that this place was cash only so make sure you bring enough!

AMBIANCE - 5/5
Thought the decor was veryyy nice for a casual Chinatown spot. Loved all the lighting inside and it felt so spacious even though many of the tables were filled. Surprisingly also had clean bathrooms which were much appreciated!

I decided to choose Joe's Shanghai solely because of high rated Yelp reviews. I've been to many restaurants in Chinatown and this has been my least favorite. The service wasn't attentive and was very rushed. The seating was tight and table very cramped. The food overall was average. It took a very long time for a Wonton soup, which I thought was a little weird. There wasn't anything special about it. At least it wasn't terrible, but definitely not the best I've had. I expected more coming from this restaurant.

Finally had the opportunity to try this place while visiting friends in Flushing. The food was delightful but I really cant give more than three stars..

The beef soup dumplings were delicious. Pretty big sized dumplings with lots of soup inside. As delicious as it was, I feel more partial to Petite Soo Chow's in Cliffside Park.

The service is terrible. Go with someone who can speak Chinese or you'll be ignored most of the night.

Not to be a downer, but maybe soup dumplings are just not my thing. Tried two varieties of XLB as well as the green onion pancake and thought it was pretty good but nothing special. Nice to say that I've tried it, but not crave-worthy.

Soup dumplings were good but not worth the terrible service we received. Didn't ask if we needed water or anything! They know the service sucks so they add a 15% tip to your bill regardless of your party size.

This place is just ok, not as good as I remember it. The crab dumplings were fine but I remember the Joe's Shanghai of old being a bit more delicious when it came to dumplings and such. Still good, but nothing to write home about.
The waiters are very unfriendly, they just want to done their job. We have to share table with others. The food was good but I was been unhappy by them. Won't go back

I have had Joes Shanghai in Midtown and Flushing. I hated one in Chinatown. Four out of eight the xiaolongbao came out already ripped and leaked. I regret that i didnt complain. So my ranking is from the best to the worst: Flushing, Midtown(although bit expensive), Chinatown(worst service and food).

We took our parents to dinner today. The front desk gave us a number and told us to wait. When our number was called, we were taken into the restaurant to share a table with other people. It turned out that we only had a seat for 2 people, and they drove us out and asked us to line up again.  , I went to the front desk and asked her what was going on, she replied that I meant 2 people, do you think it's a bit of a business and doesn't care about the number of guests, you can drive away guests at will, and drive away guests before they have eaten, what kind of service is this, dishes  nothing will happen,
This place was pretty good. First time trying dim sum and it was for sure different. I think I might of enjoyed my time more if the service was better.

NOT that great .... Service is horrible . Waited over an hour for a table which is fine but the hostess were very very rude and snappy . Shanghai buns were not good at all . Not sure why people rave about this place . Compared to the bao, these buns are not even close to how dumpling soup should taste like . The only good things about the place is the general Tso and the fried rice . Also be prepared to sit with other parties at a table. There are definitely other places better than this restaurant . It wasn't worth the wait and the food was mediocre . If your looking for tasty buns , go to the bao early in the morning !

We passed by the restaurant many times and finally got a chance to try it. 
We ordered the xiaolong bao, the scallion pancake, the lion head, the peppy fried pork chop, the pan fried noodles. 
The must-try are the bao and pancake. The bao is very juicy and good deal. The pancake is crispy and delicious    
The pork chop is too dry. The noodle is too salty. To us, they are not as good as the ones in other restaurant.
The lion head is disappointed  the first one is overcooked and it is all black. I have no  idea why the chef and waitress didn't notice.

Food came out hot, fresh, and fast. The XLB were a bit larger than I'm used to, and while I was excited to try the crab and pork soup dumpling, the crab had a strong fishy taste so I unfortunately didn't enjoy them.

The texture of the scallion pancakes were great and they tasted fresh. They were a bit disappointing though as they were super oily--didn't feel like I could stomach more than one piece. Very few scallions as well, and could have used some salt in my opinion!

Overrated. The soup dumplings taste like they've been sitting in the back for 10-min before they were brought out. The shanghai noodles were way too salty and Americanized. The dumpling wrappers were too thick. I mean... It wasn't "bad bad" it just wasn't good. Totally did not live up to the hype... Kinda bummed I wasted a meal in NYC on this place.

The two good things: service and the hot sauce.

Disclaimer!!!!!! You will sit at a table with strangers!!! You are lucky if you get a table with just your party. We were not aware of this and skipped all the reviews that said this. Worth the hype? I mean they were good but not worth the wait, poor service and sitting with strangers. Our table was full of lovely people but I felt like I was intruding in their space. The waiters kept reaching over and in between while we were eating. They also charge you an automatic a 15% tip for them giving you the menu and not refilling your water. Tip: Don't come hungry, came Saturday evening around 545, didn't sit till 7. Everyone came rolling in after that, it was crowded. Go inside to get a number, there is no line, claim your spot.

Food: it's good, not great.
Service: leaves much to be desired. Our waiter walked away from us irritated and rolling his eyes after we ordered 2 orders of soup dumplings. We had to call him back to tell him we wanted to order more food. He must have thought we were lowly tourists coming to try a trendy spot. 
Also, I hate communal tables. I had to sit sideways in my chair to keep from staring at another couple across the table. 

We tried both the crab and pork XLB. I liked them both but didn't find the broth to be as savory and rich as some of the places in Jersey that I like. I have no doubt you could find yummier XLB in Chinatown. 

We also shared a tofu dish that my boyfriend loved but I found slightly too sweet. It was #100 on the menu. It was quite oily too. Every bite I took of tofu, a hot stream of water and grease poured down my chin and I felt the ghost of future zits forming in it's wake. 

Glad I tried it but wouldn't run back anytime soon.

Joe's Shanghai was recommended to me by a coworker, who knows I love soup, when she found out I was taking a trip to NYC. I came here about 10 PM on a Friday after having dinner at a nearby noodle spot in Chinatown and the place was still going strong on a dinner rush. We were seated at a shared table and immediately asked if we wanted soup dumplings, their specialty. We ordered pork and another woman at the table ordered the crab.

I was actually really excited for this considering this is pretty much THE spot to get dumplings but when they came out most of them had already cracked and were losing broth. My favorite part of the dumpling is slurping out the broth before munching and this presentation made it near impossible. When trying to grab them with tongs the bun would stick and more times than not tear apart the buns.

The flavor was good but the experience was not there. If it wasn't for the company of some fun strangers who we all shared our dishes with, I probably would have left sooner. I will probably order an entree soup alongside my dumplings next time just in case.

"You ordered the Siamese Chicken!"

"No we didn't."

"Yes you did!"

"No we didn't"

"Yes you did!"

"No."

annnnnd scene.  For the sake of all that is holy with soup dumplings, being told what I ordered is like telling a fat man to eat a rice cake.  I order what I ordered and I don't enjoy being told otherwise.

There's 136 reviews for this place and they all focus on the food and they're right, the food is awesome.  The price is fantastic.  And the fact that they can serve large groups is fabulous.  But their service needs a lot of freakin' work.  I'll go to Green Bo instead.
Overrated. There are also better options for soup dumplings in Chinatown

Joe's Shanghai was once THE place for soup dumplings in NYC.  Unfortunately, that was 15 years ago.  Yes, their soup dumplings are good but it's not worth the wait.  Their shanghai noodles are too oily. I only go if visitors insist on trying it and the wait is minimal.

Yes this place is super touristy, but their XLB/soup dumpling is sure tasty! It says pork bun on menu but if you say soup dumpling, they know what you are talking about! 

I am truly indifferent to their sometimes rude service and lack of cleanliness, but Joe's always provides one heck of an experience!! Their soup dumplings just explode with soup and go so well with the low selection of sauces they have on the table for you to share with 4 or more people. Whether you be sharing a table with random strangers, slurping so much soup of your plate because you don't know how the hell to eat soup dumplings, or questioning why there is an automatic service charge, you got to love this place for what it is and you got to bring your friends and why not the whole freaking family to experience the Joe's Shanghai way!!

First off this place only accepts cash. Also a 15% service charge was added to the bill and I was dining by myself. 

I am shocked at the reviews for this place. I should have known what I was in for when I walk in and noticed that only 8% of the patrons were Asian. In a place like Chinatown, follow the Asians for the best authentic place to eat. 

Ordered the soup dumplings since so many people raved about it. I thought the outer dumpling skin was thick and you had to chew at it to break through. However the soup and meat inside did have a nice flavor. 

I also ordered the Shanghai Noodle Soup with flat noodles. I am sure this is a regional dish but it looked like beef Lo Mein. The soup looked like a gravy abut it was oily and it should have been more flavorful. The shredded cabbage and spinach was fine but I was disappointed. 

If in Chinatown for the day go somewhere else and enjoy a more authentic meal.

Come here for the soup dumplings, but nothing else! The soup dumplings are great but the other dishes are inauthentic and taste more like americanized asian food than Shanghai cuisine. Furthermore, this is a very touristy restaurant; expect to wait at least half an hour during peak times. That being said, the second time I came we got a fried bean curd dish that was a seasonal special at the time and actually very tasty!

THIS PLACE IS ALWAYS PACKED so don't be weirded out when youre seated and bumping elbows with complete strangers at your table. 

Jenny S. and I got Scallion pancake and XLBs.. There's not too much else that I can say bout this place.. looks like the 1500+ reviews have already said everything I wouldve said.

Both the XLBs and the scallion pancake were good, but nothing to rave about. The soup tasted a little off.. kinda like a slight sour, tap-waterish taste. Can't quite describe it.. maybe a bit gamey perhaps?

Scallion pancakes.. good, but even MORE greasy than most places I've had. It's almost like its deep fried and THEN pan fried.. had a little extra bite to it. Not something I'd necessarily crave, but hey, it was different.

I'm giving their soup dumplings 3 stars because the broth is too salty and it lacked sweetness. 

If you're willing to drive out to Flushing, I highly recommend going to Nanxiang. They make much better dumplings. 

But if you're starving and want something cheap and satisfying, Joe's Shanghai is not too shabby.

If you're coming here for the soup dumplings and other dim sum or appetizers this place is great. We ordered the crab and pork soup dumplings and scallion pancakes which were absolutely amazing. Based solely on these two items (the service and entrees not included) I would give this place 5 stars. 

However, our entrees were inedible. I ordered the Szechuan fish filet, which looked great but I could not eat more than two bites before getting grossed out. The sauce was super thin and about 50% grease and oil. It had good spiciness but  not much flavor. The texture of the fish itself was slimy. My boyfriend ordered the sesame chicken which was over cooked resulting in a chewy center and an almost burnt but somehow not crispy outside. 

Our waiter (probably the worst part) was rude from the start and obviously noticed that we were not happy with our food as we were sitting there not eating with full plates in front of us. I attempted to waive him down yet he would not even look in our direction. Finally a different waiter came over to check on us. He was very pleasant and told us he could refund one of the meals. I wish they had refunded both as we both couldn't get down more than 2 bites and both dishes were over $15 but at that point I was happy to get anything refunded. 

We were just really disappointed! Being in Chinatown, we were expecting to be wowed by the Chinese food however the take out near us was much better. I would say pick a different place to eat in Chinatown -- unless you only want soup dumplings and can deal with a rude staff.

Worst dumplings in New York. Soggy bok choy cooked in motor oil. Singapore noodles tasted like the inside of an old jar of curry. The chicken was dry. The shrimps looked like shriveled baby dicks with black veins. Overpriced!
So-so food... I am not coming back to crappy service and below-standard facilities for a bunch of xiaolongbao.

It is a raucously noisy place with a rather inattentive wait staff. But you're not going here for the ambiance or the service. You're going for the cheap, relatively well-cooked (as in, not overcooked or bland), American-style Chinese food. And for the soup dumplings as everyone else mentioned. They are delicious. Another great find is the rice cakes. We also had a vegetable that translated means "hole in the middle," and it was flavorful, well-cooked and a good addition to the starch and meat heavy meal. To top is off, this place is byob. Go with your group of 10 or more friends, bring some wine and slurp up your dumplings.

lord knows how many nights i have thought mournfully to myself that i should have kidnapped the woman who made xiaolongmantou (soup dumplings) down the street from our apt in shanghai, and brought her back here as my 'aunty'.

my craving for these little bursting morsels of joy can never be tamed.  nothing in any big us city that i've had comes close to 'old world', but when i needed a fix, this place did me well.  i ate an order to myself, and it wasn't expensive.  the other food here was pretty good as well, though not spectacular.  i'd say 4 STARS for FOOD.

however, it's very crowded and the staff is rather, shall we say, brusque.  i don't mind sharing tables with other parties, and i don't mind busy waitstaff not doting on me, but dude .. i do need to speak to you at least once.  without you scowling.
It would be better if the food could be more fresh!!! Really not as good as expected! Long queue waiting for disappointment!

It was not even super crowded like usual Friday or Saturday, almost claustrophobic.  I was there last Sunday. The service was the worst of any restaurant. They were giving us an attitude. Mumbling in front and behind our backs. Literally throw the food on our table. It was not just one waiter, all of them acted that way. Just because they have a lot of customers.  They should not treat their customers like that. They seem to want to push us or kick us out.  The been crepe dessert I've order was not edible.  I'm not going back anymore.

I've been going to Joe's for decades. It's become so touristy that it's lost it's appeal. We waited 1.5 hours (after being told 40 minutes).  The service was below par and the food was pretty average. Very disappointing since it used to be so good.

Went here with the old lady, got two different types of dumplings one was pork and one was pork and something else with the soups it was pretty good

There was no asians eating- all different ethnicities

I was the only asian

Super busy, i liked it

$30 bucks for two people
After a long wait for  a table.  I was so excited to try their famous pork soup dumplings.  AND I was not impressed !  As for other dishes I've ordered,  they were OK.

If you Asian or Asian tourist don't eat at this place,  it's not worth it. Nothing special with the pork dumpling and the fried rice. It's expensive too!.
They put us sitting together with 3 other parties! The waiters kept bumping to my chair. This is like eating in a market. I rather go to Din Dai Fung same price but you eat in peace and happier!

I was already pissed off that when I opened the door, two men walked straight in without saying thank you and they happened to be workers.
Then I got more pissed off that they put us in a combined table when there was like 6 other patrons in the restaurant.
Then I got more pissed off that one of the waiters tried to kick us out after our XLB even though we had another dish coming.
Then I was not happy that we had to pay 15% gratuity. Not that I wouldn't have, but it'd be nice to have a choice.
And, of course, I was not happy when the food made me nauseous on the way home and I puked it out at home.
However, the XLB was not as good as I thought it would be. The soup inside is very rich and the skin is pretty thick. It seems that the places that are hyped up on Yelp never seem to be that awesome. Then we ordered the shredded eel and yellow chives. Holy crap. That was the grossest thing I've ever seen - everything was just overdosed in sauce and we just left 3/4 of the dish untouched and did not pack it to go. Overall, no, never again.

This place is so over rated and full with tourist. It doesn't even taste good. I ordered their soup dumplings which they're known for and had to send it back twice because it tasted like the meat went bad. HORRIBLE! you could not pay me to eat here

CASH-ONLY! Push your way up to the waitress, get your name on the list, wait 5 minutes, and be seated at a table with others already with their mouths full, and say "YES!" to SOUP DUMPLINGS - one of each! Two layers will come out and they'll teach you how to slurp these surprising dim sum yummmmmmms. It's super cheap and super packed. Yum yum!

This place is okay. It's definitely not the best I ever had, and I would definitely not wait more than 10-15 minutes to eat here.

Thankfully, while the lines are usually pretty long, but we got in after about a 5 minute wait since we came in at 9pm on a rainy Monday. They seat everyone at a communal table (fine by me), and you sort of get your own little section to order and eat.

We got the normal xlb and a crab + pork xlb. We also got a Shanghai Noodle. Honestly, the Shanghai Noodle was the best, followed by Crab xlb, then Pork xlb. 

The xlb tasted sort of old and reheated; the skin was a little hard at the top and bloated at the bottom. It sort of felt mass produced, lacking any sort of care into actually doing it right. Perhaps on a less busy day or years ago before they got really popular, I could imagine it being way better, but I'd be astonished if they were really the best xlb in the city.

I mean, I didn't really expect it to be the best; but I still thought it would be good. It's pretty lackluster and if I had any more time in the city I'm sure I could find a better place. At least the prices haven't grown with the popularity, so there is a silver lining in all this!

This place is okay.  Its a tourist place and pretty crowded so you may have to share tables.  Their Xiao Lung Bao is okay, I like Crystal Jade Lai Mein Xiao Lung Bao in Hong Kong better.  

I went here a couple of times and the price is very reasonable but very crowded.  Both times I was here, I had to share tables.

TERRIBLE EXPERIENCE!!! We were told the line is estimated to be about 15 mins. Cool. It's our first time here, we wanted to wait inside cos it started raining. The girl at the front told us to wait around the corner and not inside. Okay we waited around the corner. After like 20 mins I was like why is it taking so long? But thought maybe they're just busy. Finally after 30 mins we decided to ask the girl when will it be our turn. Lol turns out she already called our number? I've been looking at her she doesn't even step a foot out of that restaurant, how can she expect us to hear her when she's the one that told us to wait around the corner? 

You would think they should put you back on top as a priority but no lol, she had the audacity to tell us we needed to wait longer aka putting us at the bottom of the list again?? I can't believe she was serious. Overall bad experience right from the start. There are so many other Shanghainese restaurants around here. We will not be coming back in the future.

Edit: manager and server were pretty good so an extra star for them.

I'm not super impressed with the xiao long bao's , and I miss ding tai fong! Joe's Shanghai is a super crowded chinese restaurant in Chinatown and you're usually seated at large round communal tables where you dine with 10 strangers. I don't mind doing that if I could at least get good XLB. The soup dumplings here are good but not great. The skin is very thick, and in Asian cuisine, getting thinner skin on the XLB is an art without breaking the shell. Joe's shanghai seems more crude to me because of that. There is a LOT of soup in the XLB which is fantastic, and the broth is rich and fatty. However, the soup dumplings still pale in comparison to other places in California and Asia. We also got the spicy fried whole fish, which was just OK in my opinion. It was doused in sweet and sour sauce, tasted like it was made more for an American palate than anything else. Overall the place felt like americanized chinese food (though with the slow/random service, you wouldn't think it).  I'd say if you're craving XLB in manhattan, come here for a temporary fix until you can go somewhere better for the same price. Also do not go to the one in midtown because that's a rip off.

We came here to get some soup dumplings. We ordered the crab and pork - I was expecting it to be bombtastic per the reviews, but it was subpar compared to din tai fung's soup dumplings. I wanted to like it, but it was just so-so.

On our rare weekend free, we decided to grab some Chinese food in the City after failing to find much good Chinese food in the Jersey area we were living in. After hearing the recommendations from natives in the area as well as seeing the awesome reviews on Yelp, we ventured out that Sunday afternoon to see what all the hype was about. Maybe it was the fact that my expectations were too high (after all, my family is from Shanghai and I was just there that summer eating the most authentic of xiao long baos), but the soup dumplings at Joe's didn't impress me all that much. The soup inside was overly oily and they were just so large that it was a bit overwhelming. However, I do have to say that it's impressive that there was a spoonful of soup in each dumpling. We tried the pork and the crab ones...definitely go for the pork ones if you do decide to go. The crab ones were too ... I'm not sure what the word is in English ... but almost too fishy/seafoody tasting? We also got wontons and an eggplant dish which were pretty average as well. The next time I'm in the city, I'll probably be trying something new...

2.5 stars. We ordered the crab soup dumplings and the pork dumplings. No complaints about the service, I asked for extra ginger to eat with the dumplings and the servers were quick to bring them out. I am not sure if it's fair to compare Joe's to Din Tai Fung because Joe's is a lot cheaper - for $5 you get 8 pork soup dumplings. However, the thickness of the dough and the greasiness of the soup made the whole eating experience seemed more like a chore instead of feeling like I am stuffing deliciousness into my mouth which is how I feel when I am eating at DinTai Fung. For a place so highly rated for its XLB, I was disappointed.

I LOVE the crabmeat dumpling!

But sadly that's the only high light. Other dishes are just ok. Or if you go to Joe in 5th ave, try the duck smt in the special menu. It's pretty delicious.

Grab a bubble tea nearby if you have to wait in line. But share it or do not finish it cause you'll be too full for the food.

Oh and Im also really impressed by an old waiter's table-setup skill in Joe Chinatown. A must see!

Meh... this place is so overrated. Perhaps it was really really good many years ago? I do not know. At least now that I know after having waited almost 40 mins for seats, the food was not worth the wait at all. 
The xia long bao was so so. While it was juicy, the meat inside was rather bland and the sauce has a greasy feel to it. The dough on the top of the dumpling is thick and boring. 
Garlic stir fried bak choi is stringy. 
The shanghai stir fried noodles, which is supposed to be one of the staples, is so bland and mushy. Very disappointing. 
Tea is watered down,no taste
Food going downhill. Skin of Soup dumplings are thick and not enough soup. Service is rushed and rude. Ambiance is noisy and crowded. This dining experience is not worth the wait
The food is great. The 18% service fee is not. I don't know how they get away with it, but it really left a bad taste on otherwise a nice meal.
Ordered delivery last night and all I can say is, no fortune cookies?! From what I ordered, I can comment that Orange beef was a bit tougher and small portion for the price.
quite frankly, this place has been overrated by many, and i don't know how it started but the dumplings are not bad at all.  although my favorite is still at a hole in a wall places nearby...

On a cold spring night in NY, three friends and I trekked over to Joe's Shanghai hoping to saturate our ever-hungry taste buds with delicious XLB juice. The experience? Meh.

The wait was an hour before we were seated at a huge table that we awkwardly shared with two other parties. Stuffing face in front of a stranger is an interesting dining experience, to say the least.

We ordered two orders of XLB, Shanghai noodles, green oinion pancake, and pea sprouts. The XLB broth was not flavorful enough and the skin was too thick. The meat was just ok. The Shanghai noodles were a disappointment, lukewarm and flavorless. The green onion pancake was very greasy. They did a fine job with the veggies (pea sprouts in garlic, can't really mess that up), although they didn't have gai lan. What kind of Chinese restaurant doesn't have gai lan? Maybe I'm just spoiled by all the fresh produce in SF? Another note: 15% tip is added automatically to all checks.

In any case, it was the cheapest meal I ate during my entire trip in NY, so I was satisfied (and giving it one extra star for the cheap factor). But it definitely did not live up to the Yelp reviews. Sorry, peeps!

Went the first time and thought it was great. However going the second time it was super bland. They messed up on one of my soups which is not a problem, however, they didn't take it to well when I told them about correcting their mistake. I personally don't take it personal and even liked the gritty ness of the 'unique' customer service. It gives it the fun NYC Chinatown experience haha. If I base it off the first time experience it's 4 to 5 stars but if it was the second time it would be a pure zero for lack of taste.

Worse service ever!!!!!!!!!!! I went there with my family and we waited in the cold for over an hour, they kept telling us we will be next and the table we were waiting for finally cleared! And!!!  They sat another  group of ppl on that table which they came wayyyyyy after us! Just because those ppl know the staff over there!!!  Speechless!!!!!!  And the food werent so  good anyway, not worth the wait and the hpassle! We ended up just left that stupid place! Never going back again! Worse place I've ever been to.......

We ordered 2 orders of shrimp fried rice and an order of kungpao chicken. 
The rice was tasteless. No flavor whatsoever, it literally tasted like nothing. The kungpao had zero hints of spice and the peanuts to chicken ratio was ridiculous. We were truly surprised at the lack of flavor cause it was so popular and packed when we went in, such a disappointment.

As long as I've been alive, I've been eating xiao long bao. They have been a mainstay of my childhood and a continued addiction into adulthood. Joe's Shanghai in Flushing was the one of the first restaurants that I remember eating XLBs at. Although I had heard rumors that the Joe's brand was rapidly declining, I never really thought about it too much since I had already dedicated myself to another XLB joint. When my friends and I decided to try the Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown I was a bit wary of the meal. I went in with no to low expectations. 

Unfortunately the rumors were true. Joe's Shanghai had become a typical tourist trap with an incredibly long wait time.
