The restaurant itself mirrored that of any other chinatown eatery, low ceilings and a bit grimy. I've never really had a problem with the ambiance, especially when the kitchen would put out good food. Unfortunately with nothing tasty to distract me I couldn't help but notice the other problems with the store. 

The food was incredibly subpar. I usually remember my meals very well but I can only think of negative things from Joe's. Normally soup dumplings should be served immediately after they had finished steaming. Unfortunately all the soup dumplings my group had received tasted as if they were sitting under a heat lamp. Instead of a delicate skin, the dumpling had a rough texture and would consistently with sticking to each other. When soup dumplings sit for a while, the skin starts to break down with the soup inside threatening to escape, making the entire experience worthless when the soup gets wasted on the plate. 

Although my group of five had spent a clear 70-80$ on dinner here, we all felt unsatisfied and went down the street to a noodle house to have an amazing 5$ noodle bowl. To this day, I still count the noodles as being my actual dinner, with Joe's being whatever it was. 

On top of the poor quality food, I felt as if the prices were a bit too high for the area. Joe's Shanghai felt as if they had inflated prices to take advantage of tourists. If it's your first time eating xiao long bao, Joe's Shanghai would be a good place to set your lowest bar.

Didn't like the service, got scoffed at when asking what a dish contained, which did end up containing something we didnt like.
Was hastily brought the bill. 15% service charge was included in the bill, not really appreciated.

In Joe's Shanghai, people eat on top of one another, in a noisy, ear-splitting maze of tables and customers. Joe's Shanghai really honed my understanding of the absurd, showing us that every dish could be cooked with the same sauce.

it was just ok.  friends have raved about this place so i had high expectations.  although i've never had the real mccoy in shanghai, these dumplings were avg - not super tasty, however they were really soupy.  the green onion pancake was good - served w/ a sweet vs. savory flavored sauce, and the rice cake w/ cabbage & pork was good - greasy.  the black bean noodles weren't to my liking - i'd pass on this.  overall, i was disappointed, at the same time i'm glad i finally tried this place.

I don't see how this place is any better than all the other chinese spots around Canal, but from what I was told the pork soup dumpling is their specialty and in my opinion it was ok.

The Shanghai noodles and scallion pancakes were nothing special. 

Maybe I need to order some other specialty dishes, but the 3 I ordered were ok.

I feel bad that I live in NYC and am not a huge Chinese fan, but Joe's Shanghai? Ok, by me. First thing's first - be prepared to wait at both the Chinatown and midtown locations. The soup dumplings are all the rave here and they should be. They are good and CHEAP. Just little pillows of heaven. I've gotten a few other dishes here, but nothing comes even close to the dumplings. I could make a meal out of those alone!

I've been hearing great things about the xiao long baos here for years but never had the opportunity to try them until recently. 

I'll start with the wait. We came on a Saturday evening hoping to get a table for two. As it turns out, so did everyone else. I disdain long lines, particularly when it comes to  restaurants because the food is almost never worth the wait but after years of rain-checking Joe's, I decided to man up. We took a seat ticket from one of the ladies working inside and asked her how long the wait would be, to which she informatively replied, "I don't know." Confused, we decided to stand aimlessly into the night not knowing whether we'd be called next or never (the number on the ticket does not correspond to the order of the wait list). All told, we waited about 1.5 hours before we got in. 

You're seated family style here so cozy up to the strangers next to you. (With everyone ordering the same things, this provides a great excuse to dip into thy neighbor's dumplings). We ordered an order each of the pork and the crab baos and decided to try the shanghai fried flat noodles and kung pao chicken as well. 

I've had soup dumplings many times in my life and these did not leave an impression on me. The best part about them was the dough. It was thin, but still chewy; really great texture. The filling was disappointing. The pork didn't have much flavor and there is very little meat. The crab was a bit better and I found it to be the more savory of the two. I guess you can't ask for much when one basket costs under $5 ($7 for the crab variety).

The noodles and chicken were mediocre. The noodles seemed to be stir fried in pure soy sauce with pork and cabbage. The chicken was decent but it needed to be spicier. 

Come for the above-average soup dumplings as it's cheap and will satiate your cravings. If there's a long line, go to one of the many other restaurants in Chinatown that serves soup dumplings. You won't be missing out on much.

This place is a little over hype and popular. The line to get a table can be ridiculous, if I'm going to wait 30 minutes, the food better be freakin amazing. Sometimes this is New York, where dumb people wait a ridiculous long line at places like Shake Shack or Trader Joe's Union Square. The food is good but not great after going through the 30 minute wait. 

Service here can be garbage. I called a waiter for a check and he intentionally ignored me and continued to walk his way. My water and tea aren't getting filled when they need to be and the food can take a little longer to come out because there's so many people inside.

I've had better, there's too much soup in the xiao long bao/soup dumpling. The crab meat soup dumpling isn't that good, just stick with the classic pork. The only thing I really like here is the singapore pan fried noodle. That's really about it.

You would think with all of the reviews this place would be better. It's just ok...you do sit at large table with other people and it's busy so you feel super rushed the whole time. In my opinion this place is overrete

If you want to have your dinner with a stranger at the same table, you can come here. Besides, there's one waiter's attitude is really poor. He seems wants to beat me when I asked him question coz the space is too loud. Furthermore, each dish here is a bit sweet except the xiao long bao.

Decent, but overrated. I came for the famed xialongboa (steamed pork buns), which were just OK. While they were juicy, the juice was more fatty than "brothy" - and in several bites, they tasted like nothing but fat! Service was friendly, though, and the Singapore mai fun was fine. I'd consider returning with out-of-town friends - the restaurant was packed with tourists! - but I can't imagine Joe's satisfying any of my (semi-frequent) xialongboa cravings.

OVERRATED. Having had XLB at several good places in Taiwan, including the original OG Ding Tai Fung location and other local places, it's hard to find anything worthy outside of the country. Even removing those from the discussion, either of the Din Tai Fung locations in Seattle, Dinesty in Vancouver, B.C., and other smaller places all do it better. Joe's Shanghai has been around forever, and have earned a reputation, but it's undeserved. The XLB here is pretty mediocre. Meat seems good quality and soup is a little bland but the skin is what really kills it. It's thick, they're ugly, and each basket arrive with at least 1 already broken and spilling out. Not much of a soup dumpling when there's no soup inside, is it? Bottomline, these are just so sloppy, and a real disappointment.

It's a pretty basic restaurant . We had the 1/2 duck, noodles, and dumplings. Duck was salty and they serve it with salt on the side! Noodles had some nice big spinach on top which was great. The dumplings interior was very dense and couldn't really enjoy it.

Decided to stop here mainly for their "infamous soup dumplings" and their house glazed crispy chicken. The soup dumplings were really BIG, flavorful and freshly made. On the other hand, their house crispy chicken was fair. Nothing spectacular at all. One thing we immediately noticed when the dish came out, was the pool of oil (canola) at the bottom of the dish. The sauce tasted very commercial and full of MSG! For the price of the meal ($40) we didn't think it was worth it and kept talking about how many delicious dishes we could have gotten had a e gone somewhere else. If you are looking to get great soup dumplings, and that's it I would recommend coming here, otherwise there are so many great mom and pop restaurants in the area where the food is BOMB.

Located in the heart of Chinatown in NYC, Joe's Shanghai is one busy little restaurant.  During my visit to NYC this past weekend I had to checkout Joe's and try their Xiao Long Bao (dumplings with soup and pork filling).  We were fortunate to get a seat right away but don't expect any private seating, they only have a bunch of these huge round tables and they seat everyone together (so if you don't have a party of 8+ then expect to be seating with a bunch of strangers).  The dumplings on the other hand were a bit overrated in my opinion (even though the taste was above average I think I was expecting something AMAZING).  Growing up in socal and living in Norcal I have the opportunity to sample a variety of dumplings and just because these dumplings have soup in them didn't make them that much more special then what I've already tried here in Cali.  I'm glad I got a chance to try it but it was definitely overhyped.  If you're in the Chinatown area then definitely check it out but don't go out of your way to come here...

Overrated dumplings. Less clean and more crowded even on low Chinatown-calibrated standards. Also on the lower tier of Chinatown bathrooms; the innards and surrounding area smelled bad (granted it was summertime).

My xia long bao review.

We only ordered the pork xia long bao.  I think that if you can't make the classic one right, then the other ones won't taste as good.

Way over hyped and the xia long bao didn't live up to its reputation.  It just didn't taste that great.

I normally would not voluntarily go there since there are so many better restaurants in Chinatown.  However, I had a friend from out of town visiting and he wanted to go so I agreed.
This place is so overhyped and full of tourists.  Every night the line is insane outside and the line is managed by the rudest staff ever.  You ask them a question about the line and the wait and they totally dismiss you like you're invisible or you're speaking Jibberish to them.
Once you do get a table the waiters inside are equally rude.  Before you're done eating they already want to clear your dishes and throw the bill at you.  It's definitely not a place you can take your time to chew your food.
As for the food, the soup dumplings are indeed good with  nice thin skins and plenty of tasty soup and meat inside.  However, the rest of the food is mediocre at best and much more expensive than other restaurants in Chinatown.  
Do yourself a favor and avoid this place.  Chinatown has lots of better eats and service even though Chinese restaurants are generally not known for their service.  Oh, and the nerve of the restaurant to automatically include a 15% tip on your final bill.  If it was up to me the service there deserves 1% tip.
Food was mediocre at best. The restaurant is small and dingy. They take tip from you and add it to the bill. Would not recommend this place at all.

Came here late on a Sunday night for dumplings and they were alright. Ordered the pan fried noodles and asked if they were crunchy (I honestly had no clue) and the server said no. Turns out they were definitely crunchy. Server wasn't really friendly but my friend got her dumplings so it was okay. Appreciated finding a table

Tonight's dinner at Joe's Shanghai was the worst meal I can recall ever having in a NYC restaurant.  I've eaten there a few times since moving to NY in 1995.  I've never been impressed, but their following has brought me back over the years to give it a second, third, etc try.  Sure enough, on this rainy Wednesday night, there was a line outside for tables, so whatever it has going for it hasn't eased up.  But it sure isn't the food?   No fresh or zingy flavors, just glop covering limp, aging vegetables, phlegmy sauce covering mealy sea food, and a pork dish that tasted like it came out of a tin can years past it's expiration date.  I can honestly say I've had better Chinese food in coach on Cathay Pacific.  And I suspect I would have had a better meal dumpster dodging on Pell Street tonight.  I am sooo disappointed!

Honestly, its a bit overrated. I mean the food is good, not going to lie. But the way everyone raves about the soup dumplings makes it seem as if its the greatest soup dumplings mankind has ever made.

The soup dumplings are good, a bit small, but good. Nothing too fancy. The sauce that came with it was a little strong for me, but everyone has their own preferences.

The restaurant was definitely cramped since its so popular. I was a bit disappointed that my friends and I had to situate ourselves in the same table as another couple. Kind of awkward and not too pleasant of an experience.

Their food in general is pretty good if you're looking for a more authentic Chinese food tasting experience. But don't be hyped up coming in about the soup dumplings or you may be disappointed.

Just to give anyone interested in Joe's Shanghai a forewarning. This place has a C rating, but surprisingly this restaurant was packed. Not a seat left open.

The service is that of what you would expect in Chinatown. It's rough around the edges in regards to manners, but you should be used to that given that you've made it this far downtown. 

The soup dumplings are the only thing to get here. My friend and I rounded out the menu with the Soup Dumplings, a vegetable dish, a seafood dish, and a pork Dish. 

They were all just OK, nothing great to rave about. The Soup dumplings were great, but severely lacking something. I can't put my finger on what it was. 

15% gratuity is included and this place is cash only.

Perhaps they're still working out the kinks, but my first experience left me with no craving to go back. Soup dumplings were very soggy. I also asked for no Pancake (which I was told was no problem) only to find, you know what,  in the dish. Also ordered Noodle, which was underwhelming. The Noodle was actually the best thing that came out of the kitchen (not what you'd expect from a place that has seafood bar in its title). The server was friendly but had no clue about the menu or the wine.

This restaurant is extremely popular. I wasn't expecting such a long line out the door, but it moved fairly quickly. They are best known for their soup dumplings. I'd never had them before. These steamed dumplings are filled with pork and broth. They serve large portions.  I also tried the chive pancakes, which were simple but delicious. I highly recommend the General Tso's Chicken - perfect combination of sweet and spicy.  Their menu selection is extensive, so I am certain you will find something you enjoy. 

Overall - high 3

Your'e coming here for the dumplings. That's it. You are not coming for ambience, service or your own table. You want to (carefully) shovel soup dumplings in your mouth and get out of there.

I am taking off two stars because they don't take reservations and the wait can be atrocious. Think 1h30 OUTSIDE during NYC winter. You have to be there to put your name down and then you wait. You stand in the cold as you watch other people, warm inside, sucking down these yummy soup filled dumplings and all you can do is hope you get called on next. But it takes a while.

If you want soup dumplings check it out. But be prepared to wait.

I'm going to say it, not the best I've had. I liked the ease of ordering. Paid cash and waited outside for take out. Got the crab and pork soup dumplings as well as the fried pork dumplings. They were okay. I was most surprised by the dipping sauce they served with the pork dumplings, it was sweet and salty and paired nicely. The crab and pork soup dumplings though, that was an absolute no. We didn't have more then one each because the texture on the inside was rough to eat. 
Go to SF for good dumplings.

Been going to Joe's for well over a year now for lunch. Always get the same thing, Chicken with peanuts in chili sauce. Today I ordered for the first time in a couple months and clearly they have a new cook or they are cheapening the dish. Instead of just chicken and peanuts, which is the way it has always been, now they are adding fillers like peppers to take up room and the sauce is very thin and lacks flavor. The dish is not appetizing anymore.
Worst Chinese food ever. Long wait, deplorable service. When I complained my food was cold, waiter did nothing. DON'T GO!

Food: 
I tried both just pork and crab n pork Xiao long bao. The skin is too thick, the broth was flavorful but oily. If I have to choose, I will order crab n pork one again, just because you can really taste the crab meat in it. Other dishes like stir fry rice cake or noodle was pretty good, but again, very oily. Cold dishes were inconsistently made. I mean, if you are lucky, you will get the tastier ones because they were marinated long enough; but if not, you will get the ones that weren't marinated long enough. I have gotten a cold chicken vermicelli that I can taste clogs of what i think is MSG. It was salt like texture but not salty, so must be MSG.  Yuk!!!!! But I do like their dessert. The red bean cookie taste great!!!!!

Service:
Not too bad but there are at least seven servers that just stand in a circle and chat right by my table. I guess I can't blame them, the restaurant is limited in space. But at least do not joke and laugh loudly when there's customers around!!!! BTW, they add in 15% tip to your bill, be aware of it!!!!!!!! And, this is a cash ONLY restaurant!!!!!!

this is a busy restaurant during lunch hours, do expect to wait if you have more than four people.

OVERRATED [last award received in '00, I think it's 9 years ago]

+ dumplings
- smell
- waiting time
- service
- price

= 3 stars. [more details found in 425 other reviews]
A disappointment. The soup dumplings weren't as good as ones I've had at other places for cheaper prices. Also had the kung pao chicken which was subpar at best.

Joe's Shanghai is one of those restaurants you'll have to try when in Chinatown. I don't necessarily recommend this place for the atmosphere, the service, overall food, etc., but I do recommend it because of their soupy dumplings. The few times I have come here, there has always been a line outside - It's a tolerable length of waiting time though, and they will try to usher you in as quickly as possible. Although, after a long day of walking through Chinatown, this would probably be the last place I would want to be. It also has communal tables because it is that crowded. You will need to sit next to strangers. This is not a bad thing though, but I personally prefer my own seating space and more privacy with my guest(s). Going back to their soupy dumplings, it's delicious and costs only $5 for 8 of them. It's sufficient enough for a meal, and you may not need to order anything else. If you never tried a soupy dumpling, then all the more reason to check out Joe's Shanghai.

I don't get what the deal is :) I couldn't eat the dumplings since there were no non-pork option. So I ordered seafood noodles which the waiter tried to explain to me to get the flat noodles vs. the pan fried noodles. And so I got convinced. Anyway the noodles were fine, nothing spectacular and also at a price point of $17.xx which honestly for the experience of the restaurant is super high. 
The place is old and dingy, crowded, you seat communally and the dinnerware is old too. So, why am I supposed to be excited about spending $21.37 on a plate of seafood noodles that aren't super amazing?

I think the food is overrated. It was not worth standing in the cold outside waiting for you to be called. The place crams customers in until you're elbow to elbow with them.

We waited an hour to be called and when they did, we sat at the back, with other people sitting side by side. Some people may like that, I however did not. 
The water came in a cup where the server touched the rim where your lips touch- who knows, they may very well put their finger in it too. The service was so slow. You literally have to keep flagging them and even then, they put their pointer up to tell you to wait. We weren't able to order after sitting until 30 minutes. We ordered the soup dumplings and crunchy noodle with seafood. It came after 10 minutes. The soup dumpling was okay. Just okay. I think we were better off to the other soup dumpling place, at least I know to never go to these disgusting Joe's Shanghai restaurants.

Going to the back where the bathroom takes the icing to the cake. It was awful, it reeked of death that day there for who knows how long. Then I looked at the floor and it's just disgusting as you renter the bathroom, it was a horror movie. It was so gross I literally wanted to cry because I DID NOT want to touch Anything but I really needed to pee. I got a scratch as this guy passed by me with a trash bag as he just finished cleaning the bathroom, I was scratched by something and I am praying I didn't catch anything.

Maybe it was because my friend and I went right before closing. Maybe the cooks were ready to go home and call it a night. I dunno. But I don't really have anything good to say about this place.

I agree with the other reviewers who say that better, or at least equally good, soup dumplings can be had at many other restaurants. I recommend Shanghai Cafe on Mott Street, just north of Canal. There, they serve the soup dumplings with a yummy ginger-soy dipping sauce. 

The soup dumplings here didn't live up to all the hype, and the other dishes were ordered were just so-so. I wouldn't go back.

On my way in I was reminded by my fianc√© that Yelp is not a good barometer for real Asian food... truer words were never spoken. This place would be palatable, I'm sure, for some reason who hasn't been to any of the infinitely better places within a stones throw of this joint. To make a long story short, Joe's is overpriced and not very good. Good luck finding an Asian person actually dining there.

Had the Xiao Long Bao with the crab meat filling which I didn't really like . I didn't like the fishy taste to it . The XLB had a good amount of soup in it though . Maybe we should have opted for the pork XLB instead ... oh wells , there's always next time . In addition to their XLB , we also had their  pork dumplings which didn't taste that great . The filling tasted alright but the wrapper of the dumpling didn't taste that good . Last but not the least , we had their Shanghai stir-fried noodles which were really good ... one of the best I've ever had . It was nice and flavorful ... seasoned and stir-fried perfectly .

I am only giving 2-stars because the food was decent, by the way this is not a full dim sum restaurant, they do not have cha siu bao- only a few dim sum items with the rest of the menu American Chinese.

We arrived at 1 PM and I put my name in for 6 people. After receiving a text 2 minutes later that there will be 2 more of us joining, I went up to the hostess and explained that we are now a party of 8 and she circled our reservation on her clipboard, which I figured was her way of noting this change.

After the 30+ minute wait for our table (which is fine) we are then brought to a table that only seated 6, and told we could not add chairs and would have to wait 10-15 more minutes for a larger table, and I was told I was wrong and told her 6. After mentioning she even circled our reservation she denied it and then walked away. I would say you get better service at a McDonalds's connected to a truck stop but I think that would be degrading to the McDonald's.

After being seated, the waiter barked "Appetizers and only took appetizer orders then disappeared and continued this with each course. I understand they are a very busy place but if you have to implement a mandatory 15% gratuity to every check, that shows how POOR your service is.

Very nasty hostess & rude staff.

Chinatown offers HUNDREDS of other places you can dine that are not TOURIST TRAPS. We got beers while we were waiting across the street and they had a very similar menu, sweet staff and took credit cards. In a city full of amazing restaurants, don't follow the crowds, you can find equally amazing places without all the overinflated reviews and write-ups.

This place was a huge disappointment. I've been several times before and I expected to sit with strangers and have rushed service, but the outdid themselves this time.

We started with the scallion pancakes and then followed with 2 orders of pork soup dumplings and 2 orders of crab-pork soup dumplings. We ordered long before our neighbors, but they just presented us with 1 order of pork soup dumplings while our neighbors got 2 orders of crab soup dumplings they did not order. I asked the waiter if it was ours, but he said our order was coming. We finished our order and the waiter came over and said that's all right? I said NO, we still have 3 orders left. His English was so poor, I wasted about 5 minutes trying to explain to him I only got 1 order of soup dumplings so far. He disagreed with me and tried to make me pay for 4 orders when we only got 1. My neighbor had an allergic reaction to the crab because he thought it was pork. And that's when the very intelligent server realized that he gave them the wrong order he just took it away half eaten and gave them a free serving of soup dumplings too trying to make it up to them.

I will be going elsewhere for soup dumplings from now on. I think it was a huge violation to serve my neighbor something is is allergic to.

Very very very overrated. 
1) The lines are incredibly long.
2) The food is really oily.
3) + bland.

Save your time and go elsewhere. There's plenty of other great restaurants for soup dumplings + Chinese food!

Over hyped. Average at best. The only good thing was the soup dumplings. Scallion pancakes were looking more like fried pancakes. 
Waiting staff was slow and extremely un courteous. I fail to understand the 4 star plus rating.

I have never written a review on Yelp before, but after eating at Joe's Shanghai last night, I felt compelled to set the record straight.  Bottom line:  The food here is horrible.  I had high expectations coming in after seeing a four star rating on Yelp with 1000+ reviews, but was utterly and completely underwhelmed.

Could not for the life of me understand the hype about the dumplings.  They are gross and horrible.  The whole fish is fishy and horrible.. the service, decor, everything - all horrible.  Best part of the meal:  the orange slices that come with the check.

Not even worthy of half a star.

Ever walked into an ethnic restaurant expecting to see a bunch of the same ethnicity dining there?  Lets just say i was surprised to see the absent asian folks at the joint.

The xiao long baos here were pretty good, the soup in the bun was piping hot and oh so savory! it's a great treat on any cold day.  

I didn't enjoy the crab meat one as much, the crab butter was a bit too strong for my liking.

I mean this place ain't bad, but i was expecting to see more of my fellow asian crowd.  You know what they say, good food brings in the crowd!

This is a "get in, get the f out" type of spot where you're seated amongst strangers.  The service is subpar, the food is pretty good and the hustle and bustle of chinatown and new york city in general become apparent in this very busy restaurant.  Expect a wait for 10-20 min to be seated during busy hours but its definitely worth the adventure.

You should know 3 things: 

First off -- Know that its "CASH ONLY" so don't forget to bring some fresh dollar bills.  They have an ATM right outside but it probably comes with a heavy cost. 

Secondly-- whatever you think it enough for 1 person is probably good for two people.  If you get what you perceive to be "2 entrees" you will not be able to finish all of the food --seriously, its a ton.

Thirdly -- its an authentic Chinese restaurant, get something different --try the duck, maybe get some soup dumplings amongst other things. Live a little and eat something other than orange chicken -_-  yes, I'm judging you. lol

Maybe the wait heightened my expectations too much, but every dish I had was just okay, including the soup dumplings.

If the line looks short and you have an intense craving for soup dumplings, why not stop by. But otherwise, don't waste your time, you can find much better Chinese food around the corner.

Avoid it at night or on weekends nights for you will be stuck in the streets waiting for a seat,  be crammed with strangers at a table, have to deal with cranky servers and wait forever for the food.
But,  it is one of the places with the better soup dumpling outside of Shanghai. How ever as one reviewer pointed once you know what the ingredients are you might not be raving about the dumplings and scallion pancakes (my old man makes them at home). It also doesn't help that I like to eat things fast, and no matter how many times I tell myself you will regret it, I'll bite into one of the bombs and burn the daylights out of my mouth.

The xiao long bao is hugeeeeeeeee so don't over order. It is not bad but if you are more used to the more refined taste, you are in the wrong place. Food in general is very oily and with huge portion. I still couldn't believe this place has the highest rating on Yelp for Chinese cuisine in NYC Chinatown.

Super crowded, massive lines, curt service staff are downsides. But, the food is good and pretty cheap. The portions are big for noodle bowls and other non-appetizer things, so I'm very satisfied with. However, plenty of other places can be found in chinatown that are smaller and equally yummy! That may have an equal lack of service, but are at least a bit less crowded and are in fact even cheaper. 

ALSO this isn't actually a dim sum place, I hate that I was tricked by yelp the first time I went here. They don't consider themselves a dim sum place either. There are appetizers but there aren't that many options - not great especially if you want to be adventurous.
Bed servers ever. The food not really good. My family when there with 4 people and that was our first time and we took time look at menu. The waiter was rushing us. I never go there again.

I have been sick from there food for 12 days and had to take antibiotics from such bad bacteria from eating this disgusting shit!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!DO NOT EAT HERE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Worth the hype? Definitely not. Overpriced food, little portions, soup dumplings not even warm. I've had better soup dumplings. 

There's so many more restaurants in Chinatown that taste delicious, worth the wait, and give decent portions. 

I will not be coming back.

Visiting a friend in the wonderful city of New York and had to make our way to Chinatown. Letting the power of yelp and hunger of our stomaches lead us here!  We waited what felt like forever (45+Mins) to finally be seated with our new family (strangers). What has me amazed is while reviewing my fellow yelpers I don't recall the system they use to sit you down at this place being mentioned... however all in all it was a fun experience and the food was good. The  (pork) soup dumplings are a must and (chicken) lo mein was authentic and so yummy! As for anything else I'm not won over...  the fried rice was ohhkayyy. I've had better and we tried one other dish that was not liked by ANY of the girls...

overrated soup buns. they weren't even plump. they looked like "saggy boobs" to quote my date. skimping out on soup in soup dumplings and bad presentation makes me hesitant on going back ! they would have gotten two stars, but the flavor of the pork/crab filling was really good. one more star for them.
Food is not clean bruh quality is bad after I eat i went home and have diarrhea for 2 days

*Still Cash Only*

I've been back to Joe's a few times in person and their XLB always hits the spot whenever I'm having a fix.

*WAIT*
We came early on a weekday and there was no wait.   Otherwise, you'll need to put your name with the hostess who will give you a number. 

*FOOD*
The pork meat soup dumplings are always plump and flavorful (11.95 for 8 pieces).   We also ordered the seafood pan fried crispy noodles which was very good, and felt the seafood portions were reasonable.  Also ordered the fried dumplings (8 pieces) but would skip these and save more room to try other dishes as the dumplings were pretty lackluster.  It was overly greasy and the skin was very thick.

*SERVICE*
Service was standard -- they do add an automatic 18% service charge no matter how large your party is.  

Still a good place to get soup dumplings, but everything else seems average.

Joe Shanghai are you really worth the wait? When you are really looking for somewhere for Shanghainese regardless of the wait or not. 

This is one of those places you can't bring your first day date to, extremely noisy and crowded here (worst than Shanghai Cafe). I personally came to eat and be able to chit chat with buddies but we just quickly ate and found another place.

I waited 45 minutes and the food was just okay. In Chinatown I would prefer to get the Xiao Long Bao from Shanghai cafe even though I think it is good but not great. Nothing is compare to Flushing's Xiao Long Baos or Shanghai of course. The fried noodles is average. I don't think this would be worth my time.

After hearing and reading such rave reviews about this place I went to check it out as I happened to be in the area.

What's up with the service? 0 stars. It was the middle of the afternoon and we sat down to get some xiao long bao as a snack. Pretty good deal for 8 dumplings at $4.65. However, this is all we (3 of us, only 2 ate) ordered and the waiter glared at us and shouted, "That's it?!?!" The rude treatment continued at the end of the meal when he took our plates, gave us our bill, and watched us leave with the same intense, angry glare. SO WHAT IF OUR BILL WAS $5.05 hahaha the service you provided was rubbish and we left feeling really weird. Watching the other waiters in the restaurant, most other tables were getting similar service from disgruntled, short tempered Chinese waiters.

Dishes and utensils all came crusted with old food. Yuck. This was before we ordered. RINSING DISHES UNDER RUNNING WATER IS NOT A PROPER CLEANING METHOD!

So, honestly, what is everyone's obsession with these xiao long bao? They are not that good! They are too large, the skin is too thick, the flavor is inconsistent, I could go on... Maybe the quality has gone down as this place as gotten much rave review and attention that is has become somewhat of a tourist trap?

I was considering ordering another dish, but I think their main draw is cheap xiao long bao, while all other Chinese courses are jacked up in price.

I haven't been down to Chinatown since I ate at Grand Harmony last August. 0 for 2, there is not much draw in making me come back to this neighborhood. I am Chinese and love Chinese food too! This just makes me miss San Francisco and Oakland Chinatown that much more...

I came here for trying out their pecking duck. It was decent in tasting. There is not much flavor and dry but the meat was cooked perfectly. I would rather try the soup dumplings next time. The Shanghai rice was very flavorful.
Average quality food, no lunch menu visible. $14 for lemon chicken and white steamed rice - not a one $ price by any means, more like $$. Try other $$ places instead that are nicer inside

don't bother coming here if you are a vegetarian.  

i imagine the soup dumplings are amazing.  my friends made deporable slurping noises as they ate them.  they said really charming things like, "mmmm, this is the best soup dumpling i've ever had.  oh wow, this is so good."

the tofu soup i ordered had tiny bits of chicken (or pork?) in it.  ugggh.

Chose this place as it was the only place in Chinatown with over 4,000 reviews and four starts.  Nothing special but nothing bad so it does not deserve four stars, just average Chinese-style fast food.  Very busy and you will wait (even if you get there early) and it's communcal seating.  The place is very busy so it's production style: order, get your food, eat it and that's it.  Servers are friendly but hurried.

What's super annoying is it's cash only BUT they add tip and tax to the bill. Otherwise would have given 3 stars. 

Soup dumplings were ok/average. The wrapper is too thick although they had plenty of liquid inside. Would like them more if we had never been to din tai fung (Still the best combo of size/wrapper/liquid).

Ate here today for lunch. Of course, the soup dumplings are delicious but not worth the total lack of customer service. We also, ordered the crispy beef and Shanghai thick noodles. The crispy beef was crispy flour bits with almost no beef. The Shanghai thick noodles came out only partially covered with the sauce as if it were too much trouble to give them another toss in the pan before putting them on the plate. 

The servers give you little or no attention. And seem to congregate in the back talking amongst themselves. 

Two stars for the soup dumplings only.

Our family of four just had dinner here on Saturday March 30, 2024.  We waited over half an hour for a table, then a mediocre dinner. About an hour after finishing, the stomach troubles began. My wife and I both had bad diarrhea upon returning to our hotel. One daughter vomited a little after that. The other daughter woke up at about midnight and vomited. Then the first daughter had another vomit/diarrhea combo about an hour after the first episode. My wife then repeated a diarrhea episode and I followed up with a violent vomit. I'm impressed that we were able to time our individual attacks while sharing one hotel bathroom. 

Going to guess that it was probably the beef/broccoli and/or the crispy noodles with beef, since those are the two we all shared. I'll be surprised if this is the only review of this type for that night. 

On the positive side, the service was good.
Good old school food. Cash Only is an issue for me anymore or would have rated higher
Bad service. Order dish for takeout after dinner, and packed leftovers. Back home checked only leftovers, missing dish. The bill did charge $20.80 for takeout dish.

It is quite an experience that I feel lucky to have been able to witness.  The place has such a unique aspect to it, from the no reservations, long wait times, carpeted floors, and communal seating, it is definitely not something you experience on a regular basis.

The service is extremely detached and unfriendly.  They serve one purpose, and that is to bring you food, nothing else.  You can easily sit and be finished with your meal in under an hour.  Living in NYC I already live a hectic lifestyle, so personally I enjoy the experience of dining out, almost as much as I enjoy the food itself.

The food itself was 4-stars.  That kitchen cranks out so many orders that it lacks that same personalized feeling as previously mentioned.  Overall it was good, but with all the other factors to consider here, I am not sure that it was so good it would be worth a return trip.  

I suggest you try it once to cross it off your NYC food list, but you will likely be tempted to make excuses to not go the next time someone suggests it.  Manhattan really has such great food establishments, you don't need to visit the same place twice unless you really wanted to, and this one hasn't made a comeback yet.

Of course we came to this place because everyone on Yelp raves about it and heard about it from people who heard about it from people.  

For the most part, I think a lot of "well-rated" places can be somewhat overhyped, but generally are worth a try. 

We were so looking forward to this place, but it was awful.  Service was fine. People were kind, place looked nice.  Overall, the food was just not flavorful. 

However, the food was sorry. The xiao long bao (soup dumplings) everyone talks about were not good.  You could tell they were from frozen. The skin was dry and didn't have the right chew or texture a good, authentic xiao should have. 

We also ordered a noodle soup, and the wide noodles (which was the best of everything, but still wasn't great). The noodle soup was SO bland we couldn't even finish it.  Everything was bland.  Even with the vinegar and hot spice the food itself wasn't flavorful. 

If I wasn't with a friend who said the food was bland first, I would have thought I was imagining the badness of this food. 

It was so bad my friend literally said "Do you think this is bland because we both caught Covid and don't know it?"  It was not of course. 

Anyway. Everything here lacked flavor. I really believe that people just hype other people up who write great reviews and it just keeps going farther. No way this food is actually great.

If you come here, you MUST try their soup dumplings. The fried beef isn't very good. It's dry and hard. We didn't end up finishing that dish. The other dishes were greasy too. We came here earlier at around 5:30 to avoid the wait but we still had to wait around 20-30 mins. I came with a party of 9 and they didn't have a table big enough so we had to split up.  The service was ok. We were rushed but that was only because so many people were waiting. But the waiters were friendly.
definitely not Din Tai Fung quality. go to Nan Xiang in Flushing!!

A good place for soup dumplings. You know it's authentic because of the curt service and grimy environment. It's good for a quick and dirty meal. I personally don't really care for soup dumplings because the soup tastes so fatty and gelatinous, but I think they're one of the better ones.

found this place on yelp. had to try their dumplings which i thought were pretty good. i wish they had more of a selection of dumplings. we ordered 8 and it was enough for two ppl. we also ordered a bowl of beef noodle soup. that wasn't so good. noodles were overcooked and soggy. meat was ok, but nothing special. good thing lunch came out to $11. ding ding. =)
Waited about 30 minutes. Once inside, service was pretty quick. They've got it down to get people out quickly. Food was good but nothing special. Definitely a place for tourists.

So many pros here. The service was great, the setting was delightful and the wait staff was on point. But how expensive.. would not mind paying this price if dumplings where fresh and tasty authentic dumplings but there Not.

Ugh the only good thing here was the chow fun fried rice. Hated how big the XLB were and how thick the dumpling wrapper was. The fried dumpling was so bland. The Peking duck was okay- had way too many fatty pieces , but where was the fluffy bao buns that come with it??? Instead it was a tortilla??? Not worth the hype.

Horrible General Tso's chicken dish. My portion was mostly greasy dough with miniscule pieces of meat. Small portion. The scallion pancake appetizer had very scant scallions, also mostly deep-fried dough. Kitchen help sneezes and wipe nose then handle your food. They call themselves Joe's Ginger now. I'm not going back.

Dumplings where ok and the noodles were pretty good. The place seems a little dirty and the service is not that great. Doubt that I'll ever come back. BTW, this is cash only but there is a Chase a block away.

I was expecting some quality Xiao long bao today but what I got was a platter full of SHIT.  Been dying to come here for the longest because everytime I walk by here, there is always a got damm line. 

Friend and I came here for a late lunch and even though we came at an off hour after the lunch rush, the quality of the food was beyond deplorable. Moreover, the wait staff's hospitality resembled a mental hospital ward in Uganda. BEYOND disgusted. 

Ordered the usual, crab meat with pork stuffed xiao long bao, a fried quail, and a rice cake dish with beef, along with some scallion pancakes. 

The xiao long bao even though came out in a timely matter, the presentation was beyond horrendous because the dumplings looked like they have been cooked 6 times and the soup inside of it looked like they were ready to burst. The scallion pancakes also were really bad because it was not even crispy nor flavorful. AKA i was eating fried cardboard. 

The fried quail looked pretty decent even though it was 3.25 but every thing was the pits. The rice cake dish tasted more like grease fried rice cake because it was overly greasy. It looked like they fried the rice cakes in lard and then they sauteed the beef in pork fat and then mixed it together to make it shanghai style beef rice cake. Despicable. 

The only highlight of this meal was actually the waitstaff. Every 2 minutes they would come over and ask you whether you were done with this dish or whether or not you want something. It's like eating in prison no offense because they were like the KGB and we ( patrons) were the prisoners. Furthermore, they were also laughing at the foreigners who were clueless on what to order, which is not a good idea when 94 percent of the clientele here is NON Chinese. To sum it up   they just have no fucking manners. Please Mr. Joe, tell your waitstaff to take Mannerisms 101. It's important for a successful restaurant. Thank you.

I have been to Joe's a couple of times. My first experience (non holiday period) was amazing. The dumplings were delicious and so were the Dan Dan Noodles and the Kung Pao chicken.

I recently visited it again ( during the holiday period ) and the food was not the only thing bad, the service was poor as well. Leave alone order arriving on time one had to wait for refilling water as well. The food quality did not help. The dumplings and Kung Pao were the only saving grace. The pork fired rice had uncooked onions and the chicken Hot-and Sour soup was a bowl of pepper.

This place has been on my Yelp list for Asian food in New York but definitely am not doing it again during the Holiday season

This new location of joes Shanghai is not good to be honestly. I have give it two chances and the the is not as same as the joes Shanghai for the old location. I believe the chef are new or the receipt are different. The food does not compare to the pervious location what so ever. I am so disappointed and annoyed. It's not flavorful. These ma fu tofu needs to be flavorful and spicy. It's sweet and not season.

Yuck Yuck Yuck- Maybe the dumplings are good but the food is nasty and they have a "C" rating. I wish i would have know that before i went but i had no idea because all the reviews on Yelp and when you get there and talk to the people are about the dumplings - Lastly the staff is rude!!!
Honestly this place is really overrated. The soup dumplings are decent but I'm pretty sure they made me shit my pants the following day. Skip it.

When it comes to cleanliness, well this place is not exactly clean.  I always judge a place by how clean the bathroom is and as you can imagine this place needs the bathroom police..Yes the food is good but the lack of cleanliness for their restrooms leads me to believe their staff is not following sanitation standards.  The waitstaff lacked engagement to guide me through the menu and yes I am sorry I am not Asian, but if its any consolation I love Asian food.  Perhaps next time I visit, i will bring Asian friends to see if the service is better. Long wait for a table so be prepared to wait.
I had the scallion pancake, rice noodles with vegetables with garlic sauce.  The food was very tasty..I did love the XLB fresh and tasty.  Probably the best  I had in queens.

Another restaurant still thriving on its fame from 20 years ago. 
Xlb thickest skin in town,  soup inside was so bland. 
Noodle soup so bland had to pour soy sauce and vinegar. 
Service was rude as usual.  
Never again.
Great dumplings and fast service.  Always  a short wait, but worth the wait.  A bit pricey for flushing, cash only  and kid friendly

The food here is pretty good, but it's definitely overrated.  

The soup dumplings aren't mind-blowing if you've already had legit soup dumplings.  I'm from Philly, and both Dim Sum Garden and Sakura's soup dumplings are on par with what Joe's had to offer.  The difference among them?  Joe's Shanghai crams as many tables as possible and you're forced to share tables with other people... Oh, and this is lunch on a Friday when most people should be working.  Weekend lines would not be worth the wait.
Delicious soup dumplings, average dishes. I found the pork soup dumplings to be more tasty than the crab-pork soup dumplings.

Wow.  Communal tables at its best.  Or worst?  Maybe you'll meet a friend from sitting here.

Packed, but we got seated quickly.  We ordered what was circled on the menu-the Shanghai noodles and dumplings-they were super greasy, so watch out for that.  But, they were tasty and cheap.  There's gotta be a balance somehow.

Our friend told us the soup dumpling was great, so we tried the crab meat one and it was alright, my friend said that the pork one would've been better, but my bf and I didn't know at that time. Other than that the Singapore rice noodles were yummy, and the roasted duck was good as well.

18% automatic service fee for a party of any size.

Food was mid, not bad but not good either. Overpriced for what it is. You can find better food elsewhere for cheaper.

Bathrooms are located a floor below. You have to walk down stairs.

I have the distinct impression that during the Covid crisis they are saving food longer than they should, and perhaps preparing in bulk and serving for a few days.   I had to throw out almost everything delivered to me.  It was just on the brink of inedible.

Let's start with the atmosphere, I know it's dim sum but I appreciate my own table. If you come here with less than 3 people odds are you're going to be seated with up to 2 other groups of people. Also good luck trying to have a conversation with the people seated next to you, it's far too loud to even hear yourself speak. Let me not forget the fact that I had to worry about poking the person next to me with my chopstick due the fact that so many of us were stuffed into 1 table and lacked spaced between us. Now to the food, I understand people come here for the soup dumplings but I don't believe one dish should make a restaurant, therefore we started our meal with the scallion pancake. As soon as the pancake hit our table the aroma of old oil filled our nostrils, and once we tasted it we could confirm it. Disappointed with the appetizer I decided to order General Tso, since any restaurant worth its weight in salt could cook a decent General Tso. Alas I was left disappointing, the sauce was mediocre while the chicken simply terrible and exceedingly dry, it resembled stale bread rolls with sauce poured over. I couldn't leave fast enough, the hype was over exaggerated.

We decided to wait the 45 mins for soup dumplings on a Saturday at 6:30pm. It was just two of us, but we were like this MUST be the best place ever because the crowd waiting spilled out in the street probably 30-40 people... SO here is my honest opinion:

1.) Dont come for the experience and service. The hostess is pretty loud and rude, but was probably tired and hot from yelling outside to the crowd waiting. She was quite irritable. Its so crowded inside, the waiter can just take orders but can't really hear your questions nor explain the food options. You just have to order and try it out.

2.) CASH ONLY. Yep, they should probably tell you that when you first start to wait for a table. The girls next to us skipped out on paying because they had no cash. They literally ran out the restaurant. Just terrible.

3.) Bathrooms are GROSS. Bring your own toliet tissue if you must and hand sanitizer.

4.) We ordered crab and pork dumplings, fried spring rolls, and shrimp fried rice- $35. All 5/10. Shanghai cafe is the bomb and it's unfortunately closed at the moment I believe. I would say its worth a 15-20min wait but if you're starving like I was, I would never wait that long there again. Sorry *shrugs

Hai okay-la. I grew up eating soup dumplings in Taipei and SoCal so I am never thoroughly impressed with Joe's. But when I have a craving, it is adequate. For me, it's not worth the wait. You should just go to Joe's Ginger a couple of doors down.

Good food horrible service. The staff wouldnt speak or acknowledge anyone that wasn't of Asian decent. And yes they speak English. Wasn't expecting that from such a popular restaurant that has tourist come in daily.

We arrived at 9 pm on a Saturday night and waited approximately 20 minutes before we were sat at a table where we had to split a table. 

We ordered quite a few items and everything arrived quickly. The servers are quick and quite in a rude type of fashion like they hate working there

The dumplings have a good skin thickness but on the thicker side i tried. The meat inside was overpowered by the saltiness of soy sauce. Dumplings should just be sweet and taste like the filling

We had the spicy beef tension noodle soup. The flavor was good but not spicy at all. Such a disappointment

The green onion pan cake was thick but flavorful

I've had much better shanghai food in California but only this in New York. The food was overall just ok and I don't think I will visit this place if I visit New York again

Ok Dumplings. I mean for juicy pork buns they are pretty good - not the best I've had, but not too shabby either. Lots of midwestern tourists not sure what to do (communal seating OMG! WTF!) this family of five we were sitting with kept trying to order General Tso's chicken and the waiter kept saying - NO! Dumpings! - but they didn't understand. They then ordered the dumplings (because my brother and I suggested them) and proceeded to melt their faces with them (we failed ot warn them that you have to drain the hot juice from them before eating). It was kind of a tragic comic experience.
Didn't try anything else but the dumplings. They definitely wanted us in and out of there.
Ugh not exellent we ate in the one in NYC and the waiters got takeout. I would not reccomend this resuraunt

Okay well I'm a little confused as to how many stars to give so I'm gonna go with 2, and here's why.
The food? OUTSTANDING!
The service? NONEXISTENT! 
And it's BOTH that make for a good restaurant.
I read the reviews and the pork soup dumplings didn't seem to ever disappoint. Oh wow were they good. I honestly could have eaten 20 of them by myself. I also ordered the Shanghai Flat noodles. They were probably the best I've ever had. The food, as I said, was excellent.
My mom and I were the first guests of the day. We walked in RIIIIGHT at 11 am when they open. Now I understand that when you walk into a restaurant right as it opens, you can sometimes catch a staff off-guard. I assure you this wasn't the case. After being quite rudely told where I could sit, we ordered our food. We received our food in a timely fashion but I guess so did the staff on duty, because the three employees on duty were sitting at a table across the way from us, enjoying their lunch. Apparently enjoying it enough to NOT provide service to their ONLY guests at the time. No refills, no check back, I had to ask for the check.... No service at all. 
The icing on the cake... After I cashed out, one of the  employees walked up to me as I was leaving to make sure I left a tip for "service". Yeah that actually happened. 
I'll probably never give these fools business again. No matter how amazing I thought the food was.

Amazing soup dumplings, terrible service. Was seated at a table with 7 other strangers (talk about awkward!) and the waiter was practically shouting at me. He also would clear our plates without asking or before we were even finished.

Oh my gosh when I came here I was really looking forward to having some of "the best soup dumplings in Chinatown" as deemed by multiple sources. I am currently reviewing and rating for 3 stars until I go again next time so I may update this in the future. My order consisted of the crabmeat & pork soup dumplings, regular pork soup dumplings, eggplant in garlic sauce, and a side of rice. My dumplings came out very hot and tasty but over cooked and they became dry when they got to my table. The eggplant and garlic sauce dish was also very hot and tasty, but lacked that Shanghainese spice and kick I am accustomed to. I suppose it's become a very Americanized establishment to better suit a wider range of patrons. It's great that the waiters all speak English, are very quick, easy to flag down, and check up on you often. The place is cash only, a little inconvenient but it keeps the prices low. The bathroom is also decent compared to some other bathrooms in Chinatown, but would appreciate it if they were better kept. Also there is no hook on the door for a coat and bag (I was heading out with my belongings and I had all my things with me so it's important to have a hook to use lol). I really enjoyed the service, temperature of the food, and the flavors of the food however I think it could do with some adjusting. So 3 stars will be my rating for this experience until next time!

Check your bill before you leave.

We got the XLB ($5.95), Scallion Pancake ($2.95), Shanghai Fried Flat Noodle ($8.95) and seasonal veggies (market price), and somehow the bill with tax and tip was $39.33.  

That means our seasonal veggies were $15 or somewhere there, or that these guys scammed us.  

And they rushed us out, standing and staring at us until we left.  It was very stressful, and that's why we saw a total and put down $40, and they had the audacity to ask if we wanted change.  HELL yes, if you already put 15% on my bill, I should get my change.  You pretty much are asking if I'd like to tip more than 15% for your bad service.  They should automatically give me the change

Btw - the Shanghai Fried Flat Noodles weren't flat - they were udon-like.

And some girls at our communal table put down short of 50 cents, and the waiter told them it wasn't enough.  Are you serious?  If you include tip, and tip is OPTIONAL, then they should be able to be short the 50 cents.

I'm just so unhappy with this experience.  But a learning experience it was.

I'll only be back for the XLB, lesson learned.

Soup dumplings are always a go to - big, delicious soup, and great temperature.

We also got the seafood pan fried noodles, that gets a 1-2 stars ( so this averages to 3). The noddles had a weird flowery aftertaste. Also the seafood that came with it was:
 - 1 squid part
- 2 shrimps
- 1 scallop
And some light vegetables. Do not get this here. It was bland and lacking in every area!

My review in one sentence:

Shanghai Cafe makes a better soupy dumpling. 

In the words of Forrest Gump, " ... and that's all I have to say about that."

Well like they all say, this place is known for their Xiao long bao. We came here during the winter storm Jonas and trecked the windy streets for dinner at this place. This also happened to be one of the only places open during the storm. We were seated promptly, but had to share the table with two other parties. They asked us three times within a span of 7 minutes if we were ready to order. No. I'm not ready to order 

We ended up ordering two pork and two pork and crab Xiao long bao. We also got chicken pan fried noodles. Everything was delicious, and this was definitely the best soup dumplings I've had. 

I asked for water three times. I didn't get water during my meal. They kept on pressuring us to see if we were done, even if there was no line waiting to eat.

I really wanted to like it more than I did. It is a solid American Chinese restaurant and the food is similar to any take out you'd get in many, if not most, American cities. Unfortunately, that's not quite what we were looking for. The overall rating was quite good and there was a huge line to get in, so we thought that would be a good sign. The ambiance was casual, which was what we wanted. And the food was good, it just wasn't great. And for about $120.00/couple (for food and one beer), I really wanted it to be better. The one real negative point was our waiter. The hostess seated us with menus and he literally followed her to our table and asked if we were ready to order. We asked for a minute to look at the menu and he appeared annoyed and came back every minute until we were ready to order. He was very unfriendly and not familiar with the menu. It was a shame because the other waiters seemed friendly. I think I would have found the price to be a little more justified if the service had been better. All in all it was a fine, but not memorable, experience.

Came in to no line (which I'm told is rare). The 2 of us were seated at a table of 8 but luckily friendly people. We ordered pork dumplings and fried noodle. Way too much food for 2. The price was decent but I felt you there were better options nearby from a pricing perspective. 

The dumplings were good. I had in my mind they would be excellent and maybe my expectations were too high. 

The fried noodle was average and there was plenty of it. It comes out hot and freshly cooked.   

Overall a good experience but I think I had the bar set too high.

If you've ever been to din tai fung, Joe's will disappoint. But I fear din tai fung is the industry standard and everyone else is fighting for second. I can't speak to any of the dishes here other than the xiao long bao which Joe's is known for and the only dish I ordered. Xiao long bao are soup dumplings, one of only a handful of items I can order in Chinese and one of my favorite foods in life that I openly seek when traveling. The line is long; as in 45 minutes to an hour in off hours like 330pm. The soup dumplings are good, but they skin is too thick and the meat filling is under seasoned and the broth while maintaining a tastiness that coats your lips, lacks depth and richness in flavor. Worth a trip for locals, soup dumpling first timers or frequent NYC travelers.

I was really craving some Chinese food last night. I tried calling WoHop but they close so early these days, 9:00pm. So I decided to try Joe's Shanghai. I remembered that they were good from their old days at their old location on Bayard street so I decided to try their new location on Bowery. 

I ordered a very basic dish of chicken fried rice and their soup dumplings for take out. As I started to unpack their food I realized that they did not included any soy sauce or sweet and sour sauce or mustard sauce. So what the heck I'll just eat the chicken fried rice plain without any sauces. Once I started eating it I noticed that it tasted pretty plain. Then I noticed that there were parts of the rice it that were really salty and crunchy. I had to pick these salty crunchy bits out of my mouth  because It was nasty, I was eating little clumps of dried salt. It was like the cook had done a half ass job and thrown in some MSG at the last moment but it hadn't dissolved into the rest of the dish. Everything thing was done half assed and so it ended up tasting that way. Also, no fortune cookies for desert. 

Sad to say that this place has really gone down the drain. I will not be going there again.

I felt like this place is overrated. I prefer nanxiang in flushing over this. The skin is thinner, which I liked but the soup was better over at nanxiang. The pics of famous people on the wall was cool though.

Went to this place near closing time. Ordered the crab and pork dumplings. They were average.  The scallion pancakes here were excellent especially with the spicy red sauce.

The place was buzzing with a lotta people. Would like to come back to try one of the entrees.

Personally I think there's too much hype about this place. There's always a line since they don't take reservations. We got there as soon as they opened and was able to get a table without any problem but noticed the restaurant was completely filled up 30 minutes later and the line outside was already long. The wrapping of the soup dumplings were a little thick I thought so not as delicate as XLB should be. For those of you who had XLBs at Ding Tai Fung on the West Coast or abroad, these XLBs are rather disappointing. The wait staff should be trained to be more personable. They walk and interact like robots so service was lacking. Overall it was a disappointing experience.
I've had soups dumplings all  over the world and these are not very good.

The good stuff, Pork soup dumplings (crab dumplings?  can anyone really tast it?), Shanghai Noodle Soup, and the Beef (or Chicken) Pan Fried Noodles, Chicken Rice Cakes.   the rest.. is M'eh... 

It's very Touristy.  It's a long wait sometimes, and you have to have EVERYONE in your party to get a table.

We went here thinking it would be the best Chinese we've had, and it was terrible. Absolutely terrible. The lo mein tasted completed charred, the chicken (#69) we had was bland, the service was crap, and all together, it was a waste of $60 cash, because they don't take credit cards. I'm thinking this place was great at one point but lost its Mojo over time. Don't come here if you honestly want good Chinese. But you all prob still will so whatevs. Hopefully it's better for you.

Still a tourist trap...  After a few months, I gave this place another try. A Sunday lunch with friends and family turned out to be a disappointing luncheon. The pork soup dumplings, fried stripe bass, shanghai noodles were tasty but nothing to rave about. The service provided by the hostess and waiters need a lot to be desired. They need courtesy lessons. if you need a waiter, keep waving your hands. If all the members in your party are not waiting with you, you will lose your table  asap and you'll be ignored and expect to wait another 15-20 minutes, OUTSIDE. As for the bill, there is a 15% mandatory taxable tip-ALL USD CASH ONLY. Just a note, you will share a table with other diners at the table. Go elsewhere. Try 456 Restaurant that's only a few blocks away.The atmosphere and waiters are more respectful and courteous.

Came here with my wife after reading all 480+ reviews to see what all the hype was about.

Here's the gist of it:

Dumplings are pretty good and the whole seating with a bunch of strangers adds to the atmosphere that you are in restaurant in the middle of Beijing. The waiters rush you yet they are not rude, just trying to get their job done in as fast and efficient way as possible.

The only downside is that the place did strike us as a bit on the dirty side when compared to many other Chinese restaurants we've been to. There is a lot of volume with people sitting down immediately after another party leaves and no one cleans the table thoroughly between customers. Considering you are sharing the table with approx. 8-10 other people, it gets pretty nasty after a while. Then again, the soup dumplings were really good and so was the duck we ordered.

Food quality is not as good as it was before. Dumplings are stuck to each other , so they break apart easily.  Wonton soup is too salty and the wrapper is too thick. It was a very good restaurant with the best dumplings in town, but too bad that it is not the same anymore.

I like this place, it's great to take friends that visit to experience a family style restaurant.

There's always a super long wait even on a week day during lunch. 

I've never had the dumplings, because I hate pork but my husband and friends do love them. I always order the scallion pancakes, they're so good!

The chicken and broccoli is decent, it's greasy though. If you take home left overs in hope of heating up later, the box is so disgusting from the grease that it's repulsive to eat.

The place isn't very sanitary, one time during family style eating, the woman next to me spilled her glass of water and the glass broke. The waiter rushed to clean it up, but as he was cleaning it up he nicked his finger on the glass and it started to bleed. Once he noticed the blood, he literally put his finger in his mouth and sucked it up. It was so disgusting!

Half star to this place! The service was lousy! They light up incense while we were seated right next to their worship alter! The food is no longer the same especially their well known soup dumplings! The flavor has gotten worse and they all tear apart when you try to nab then! We went there with a party of 3 people and they added tips to the bill without telling us and made us pay for additional tips unknowingly! Talk about losing customers fast! This place really have gone down the gutter! Good riddance! Will never go back!

Well I just don't get it. We showed up an hour before closing and they could not be more pissed. It was FILTHY (ehem, health board), dark and small. All of this I was willing to overlook for these amazing dumplings I heard SO much about. Eh. They were ok. I've had way better. The other dishes were ok too. Not good enough to put up with the attitude, gross interior, and the THICK fog of incense and cigarette smoke. PS. To top it off CASH ONLY. Sigh*

Sadly, I was not impressed. Came here on an extremely cold (15 degrees) night expecting to be warmed up by the yummy soup dumplings but instead, I left disappointed. We tried both the pork and crab dumplings and both was a let down. The skin was thick and ripped easily causing all the soup to spill out. Also, I felt like the dumplings were undercooked and being that it's pork, that's some serious food poisoning that can happen.

If you're looking for some Soup Dumplings, Joe's Shanghai will most likely be the restaurant to pop up at the top of the list. There are 3 locations, and I visited the one in Chinatown. Ambiance and friendly service are non-existent at this restaurant. Yet, you'll find the restaurant always full of customers looking for some good food. The tables are communal, so, be prepared to dine with others and have the opportunity to strike up some fun conversation.

While they're best known for their Soup Dumplings, there's an extensive menu of dishes to choose from. But never mind. Just order the soup dumplings (crab and pork) and a scallion pancake. For me, these are their two amazing dishes. Other dishes here can be hit or miss.

Very greasy and soup dumplings are better at Chinatown Brasserie (I don't even care that it's too white and overpriced. they taste better)

Expect to be underwhelmed and incredibly disgusted with yourself. But try it anyhow, this place is an institution.

I was introduced to soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai about 3 years ago, and man oh man is it good!!  

Everybody has their different methods of eating the soup dumplings.  The way I was taught was to place it on the spoon, bite the tip, then suck all the soup out.  Then, I put a spoonful of that vinegary concoction inside. And I eat the entire dumpling.  Mmmm, sooo goooood!!  I've tried both the pork and the pork/crab, my favorite is the pork/crab.

I've been here a number of times.  I've tried the cold noodles with sesame sauce, scallion pancakes, braised sliced beef, sesame chicken, gen tso's chicken, beef with broccoli, and orange beef - all just okay, not that greatest.  I've had better.

The service is just okay.  The servers are not attentive, and I've always felt a bit rushed.  The restaurant is like any other restaurant in chinatown; decor simple.

Just a warning... During the busy times, if you don't have a large enough group, you may sit with other people - like at dim sum spots.  You can try to beat the crowds by having a late lunch or early dinner.

The only thing about this place that I love is the soup dumplings and the decent prices for them, which I give it three stars. :-)

Overrated. Food was average, line was long, lack of space. Expect to share tables with strangers, they would not spare a single seat (this is not an exaggeration, I mean this word for word). Service is very rushed but food does come out fast. For service alone I would give it a 2 out of 5 stars. Place is not the cleanest, eating utensils  was not cleaned properly. There was some dry food on the side of one of my tea cups. Food is not cheap.
The entire time I was there they were trying to get you out fast, making me feel very unwelcome.

Not worth the hype. Very greasy and not memorable.
The only thing I would recommend is the scallion pancake but you can find those anywhere so don't make a special trip for them here.

I have been an Asian all my life, I know what is good dumplings and what's not.This place is a tourist trap, I had better soup dumpling from else where.

Honestly I think their soup dumbings tasted like the frozen ones I get from Chinese grocery store.  When we received the soup dumplings, they just looked very sad, very droopy, flat and not fresh. The soup flavor was average.
I also ordered the scallion pancake from there, it was moist in the center and not a lot of scallion flavor.

If you have never tried soup dumpling before I guess this place is OK because the price was cheap. But trust me there are better ones out there not worth the wait.

Over-hyped. Rude staff. Soup dumplings quite ordinary. I wish my friend who referred me had told me about the awkward community dining on circular tables. Unless you' have an inside scoop or can talk to the staff, don't bother. It was a wasted meal experience.

This is another highly overrated place but in China Town.
Went there last night to have dinner with my husband as we were in the neighborhood and this was pending one our list.
Waited for more than half and hour to be seated. It was ice cold outside so we kept on standing next to the cashier.
Positives:
Fresh food
Prompt Service
No wait time for food
Negatives
Food tastes only average
Does not accept cards
Does not give you time to breath.
15% service charge?!?!?!?
My husband however, liked the flavor of his pork dish. As for me, sour grapes as always 'cause, I am a vegetarian.  
After dinner the check came and my husband was a little taken aback. This was by far the most expensive Chinese food that we've eaten in the city $50 for 2 people! Thanks to the exorbitant 15% service charge. 
Sorry Joes Shanghai we are taking our business to Vanessa and Prosperity Dumplings.

The waiter ran after us for 2 blocks yelling that we didn't pay the bill. The bill was fully paid. We had to go back to the restaurant and speak to the manager to pull up cameras to prove we paid. It wasn't until he found the waiter who took our money that he believed that we paid. The waiter gave us the bill for the wrong table and we were told we shouldn't come to the waiter to ask for the check but wait for it at the table. We were paying the bill discreetly for a birthday. This was a terrible, mortifying experience.

3 stars for food only! This used to be a place I recommended to everyone. It's known for its soup dumplings and fresh food. It has changed so much over the years and I'm so dissapointed. Unfortunately it's definitely not know for its service or cleanliness. It was Chinese New year so I decided to go. I was always willing to take the bad service for good food. Now you will wait for 15-20 minutes to get a small cup of white rice that comes with your meal. If you need any question answered you can forget about it. The most disturbing thing of all is how terribly dirty the place is. Unbearably filthy. The walls right next to the table were filthy and the bathroom smelled like a sewer. Sorry guys I know how much everyone loves Joe's Shanghai.

We went to Chinatown to get some good Chinese food and this place was not it. The staff were not that friendly and the food didn't seem well seasoned, like they were missing salt in everything. We got the fried rice, soup dumplings and I got the hot beef soup. The soup was just hot and not flavorful at all. We will not be back unfortunately.

Invasion of the Dumpling Snatchers!
We've been among Joe's Shanghai's most loyal fans since shortly after it opened in Manhattan Chinatown in 1996. We've introduced generations of visitors and otherwise picky children to its iconic steamed buns (soup dumplings), and never had a dissatisfied customer, not once. So it pains us to report that the Joe's we knew and loved is no more. The new location is fancier and cleaner and a bit larger. The menu is essentially the same, though without the chalkboard specials. On the Monday after Christmas, despite a chill drizzle, the crowd outside seemed larger and more ravenous than ever. (The previous Friday, we'd given up after facing a two-hour wait.)
But to cut to the chase: This was our most disappointing meal of 2019. None of the waiters we'd gotten to know over the decades seem to have survived the move around the corner from Pell Street to the Bowery. The service at Joe's had never been refined, but it was always friendly and attentive. Now you are attended by unsmiling newbies toting iPads, and we had to ask three times for water.
The food wasn't awful. It was simply mediocre. All of our old favorites had been stripped of intensity and flavor. The scallion pancakes and turnip cakes, heretofore light and flaky, were now doughy. The fabled soup dumplings, once so delicate that it required craft and practice to move them to your spoon without bursting them, were so thickly wrapped that you could bounce them off your plate without incident. The soup and pork inside had lost all intensity. The result was perfectly edible and wholly forgettable.
The rest of our dishes were similarly bland. Kung Pao chicken, always reliable, was ruined by dried-out breast meat. The Peking duck--a new addition--was perfectly cooked and totally tasteless. Ditto for the string beans and pea shoots. At that point we gave up and filed out in mourning.
It seems clear that Joe's has a new set of chefs and prep people. We can only wonder if some malign corporate entity bought the Joe's name  and brought in their own talent-free staff. When our waiter wondered why we'd left so much food on our plates, we replied that everything had changed from the old place. He replied that they had just opened. We'd like to believe that with time, Joe's will return to the quality that made it a Chinatown legend. But we're not betting on it.

I came here for the Â∞èÁ¨ºÂåÖ and I was super disappointed. The price wasn't bad, 6.25 for the dumplings. However, the skin was so thin the soup came out the instant you picked it up. I won't be coming back here ever again.
