The service was also terrible. The servers were pressuring us to order food the instant we went in and then they were in a rush to get us out.

I think I've been spoiled by the Chinese food in the 626 that I thought these dumplings were just OK.

My friend and I didn't have to wait long for a table, but it was interesting that we were seated with other parties at a family table of 10.  I didn't mind this too much and it probably helped them move customers in and out faster.

We ordered the crab dumplings as well as the pork dumpling.  I preferred the pork over the crab dumplings.  We were pretty disappointed that more than half of our soup dumplings were already punctured in the tray.  I have no idea why they give you a metal tong to pick up the dumplings, when their skins are so fragile as is.  I think it's easier to use chopsticks to save any dumplings that still have soup left in them.

I've been here twice and I honestly don't understand why it has such high ratings. The xiao long bao soup dumplings are ok, but definitely not the best I've ever had, and the rest of the food is just ok. There's almost always a wait, and you have to share a table with other people, which can be really awkward. The wait staff isn't particularly accommodating and overall it's just not really a great experience. Will not be back.

Would have been rated lower if I had to wait longer.  I wouldn't want to roll up here in a large group.

I think the one in flushing is a bit better.  This place had plenty of tourists, and yes, it is funny to watch them stuff a whole scalding hot soup dumpling in their mouth, only to get burned.  The flushing location is bright and airy and this place feels a bit grungy and dumpy.

The dumplings taste the same, but everything seems a bit greasier.

Note:They add tip to your bill! so don't tip twice, unless you really loved it!

I came here with family and I was very disappointed with the service.although the duck we ate was really good, the crisped beef was horrible.we found easily a spot to eat at around 6pm but the waiters are very rude and seem to be doing you a favor for everything you ask.one of them spilled tea in my table and didn't even clean it and when I asked to clean he threw me a paper towel so I would clean it!!! Incredible! I didn't want to give tip but it was 15% included.food has some potential but really horrible service!

2.5 star. I'm rounding up because I haven't been to any other dumpling places in NYC so I don't have anything to compare them with (but I have been to several in Taiwan).

Arrived here at 4 on a Saturday afternoon and there was about a 20 minute wait for 2 people - when we left there was no wait, go figure. I came here just for the soup dumplings, so we ordered the pork dumplings and the pork dumplings with crab. 

What's good about them? Lots of of soup.
What's bad about them? The skin was too thick and chewy. The dumplings were too big and didn't fit properly in the spoon. Yes, in America, bigger is better, but making them bigger destroys the delicate nature of these dumplings. FYI, xiao in xiaolongbao means small. I would peg them at "medium." The soup also left a greasy aftertaste in my mouth, sorta like when greasy soup gets cold and solidifies. There was a putrid smell coming from the back of the restaurant. Restaurants in Asian might be dirty and greasy, but at least it's the kind of greasiness that makes you want to come back for more. This putridness... not so much.

Does it live up to its hype? Not really. Should you check it out if you've never had a dumpling filled with soup? Definitely.

Tip: Stop complaining about sitting with strangers, which can be quite enjoyable. It reminded me of wedding banquets back in Taiwan.
Also a 15% tip is included in your bill.

A better version of Joe's Ginger. It is an Americanized Chinese store that has solid soup dumplings, but not the best. There are other stores in NYC that have provided better quality soup dumplings. Joe's Shanghai however, is a solid place to go to that is very friendly to groups. The wait time can be rough during busy hours so watch out!
Super disappointed to find out they use pork Lard in all their dishes. Good thing i asked before they started making my order. Had to cancel the order. The young lady was nice enough to accommodate

I'd include a picture of this place in the dictionary under the definition of the word 'over-rated'. 

The original plan was to go to Nom Wah Tea parlor down the road. But it was closed for a private party. So we decided to go to this Chinatown "must-go". There is a ridiculous 1 hour wait time any time of the day and a chaotic number calling system. The streets are lined outside this establishment with tired, hungry tourists lining up for a slice of disappointment. 

When we did subsequently obtain security clearance to enter the premises we were seated in a loud family style dining place. We ordered the pork, and the crab and pork soup dumplings, and the seasonal soft shell crab. 

The soup dumplings - In most cases, bigger would be better. But with soup dumplings it is quite tricky. In comparison to other soup dumplings I have eaten these are mutant incredible hulk dumplings. They are huge. There is no way one is going to be able to eat them whole. The point of a soup dumpling is the incredible burst of flavour when you eat it whole and bite into it. The person next to me bit into his dumpling and sent soup splashing across the table. My friend just decided to give up and let the precious soup drip out of his dumpling. I had the worst time of them all. I believe there is such a thing as an ambient soup dumpling temperature. They should be served at a temperature that is safe to eat. I had my entire mouth burnt from the scalding soup and was unable to eat for days after that. While it is easy to blame me or the other diners for our "inexperience" at eating dumpling, I have eaten soup dumplings many times before (in NYC, I have eaten them at Nom Wah in Chinatown and the Bao in East Village). I have always escaped injury free. Also a quick glance across the room shows that this was the case with all diners (a lot of whom were Asian as well). Everyone's plates were a mess of spilled soup, every drop of which should be in your mouth. Bigger is not always better.

Soft-shell crab - This is hard to screw up. They are naturally delicious creatures. The breading was oily and not crisp. As much as I could taste with my burnt tongue they were all right. But soft shell crab is usually awesome, not just all right.

These soup dumplings were very very very okay. This place was hyped up to me for a while and so my expectations were to the moon and back. I adore soup dumplings more than life itself, so when I have soup dumplings from a place that people treat like a church, I feel like a sinner for never having gone. 
That...was not the case once I visited Joe's. We ordered soup dumplings. Lots of them. Each one was more okay than the last. They were very okay. SSOOOOO okay that I haven't gone back. Now - I don't want people to think they were bad. They are FAR from bad, but they are super mediocre. Have you ever had that one dish that was SOOO mediocre, it defined the word? That is how I felt leaving Joe's. 
It was a long wait, after a long day, for a very okay meal. 
If a friend wanted to return, would I? of course.
Would I decide to wander down into the bowls of Chinatown for the most okay soup dumplings I've ever had? when there are gold mines near by? Prob's not.

I was very exacted to try this restaurant since I am from Shanghai. Unfortunately, we ordered 4 stuffs and non of them are real Shanghai food. NOT EVEN CLOSE! Hi guys, if u r from china and looking for authentic Chinese food, trust me, do not go to this restaurant. This is basically an overpriced Panda Express.

If I were trying to find the largest concentration of white people in Chinatown, I'd beeline for Joe's Shanghai. There's always an unnecessarily long wait for this popular tourist attraction located in the southern half of Chinatown. I've been two times, and each time was "meh" at best. 

Guys, let's be honest, we've all had soup dumplings before, and while they're delicious, they definitely do not merit a 1-2 hour wait. PLENTY of other Chinatown restaurants offer the soup dumplings and they have much better service and much shorter wait time. If this is on your bucket list of "places to go in NYC" then fine, do whatever floats your boat. But if you ask me, the last place I'd go in Chinatown is a place with white people, because you just know that means it was recently or has been consistently featured in the NYTimes or some other newspaper. 

I'd much rather trust the locals than some food critic any day.

Joe's Shanghai is a must for New Yorkers and visitors alike. The soup dumplings are awesome and worth the price of admission. The food is great, such as a dish like beef with green beans. It's the good stuff.
I would give them a higher rating but after a few trips to Joe's Shanghai, I noticed some things that I found pretty suspect. Not with the food but with the service or business practices involved. 

1. Servers automatically bring you hot tea. I guess that's common for Chinese restaurants, right? However, I do like the option of being asked because you get charged an extra two dollars on your bill. I've noticed a lot of people who never wanted tea get jacked $2 for it. It's like, "Here's your tea." And you're like, "Thanks, dude!" And then your bill's like, "Two more bucks for tea, bro. Did you even want the tea?" Waste of tea. Waste of money.

2. Tips are included in your bill. They automatically tack on a "15% service charge" to your total. Sounds convenient and reasonable, right? But after that, they tax it with the rest of the bill. Wait...is that right? Are they allowed to do that? Doesn't matter because they do. I think that's kind of a dick move because what if the service was bad? How can you stick it to a restaurant with crap service? Your tips get taxed? What?!

Again, I like options when I go into a restaurant. I love Joe's Shanghai but not the shady tricks to up the bill. I would dispute it but I don't want to get jumped by the Triads over hot tea and pork soup dumplings. At least, now you know. And knowing is winning half the battle.

The reason I am giving Joe's Shanghai a 2 and not a 3 is this:
1.  The wait is too long ....and they call number's out then say "just checking" as a way to update their waiting list... but it is a big tease when you have been waiting for an hour and are hungry!
2.  The soup dumplings were good, but they the dough was very thin and therefore broke too easily...  it is no fun losing more than half of the soup of a soup dumpling!  I did like that they had the vinegar that goes onto it already on the table when you arrive though.

The famous dumplings that everyone raves about are not THAT amazing. I was so excited to try them during my annual trip to NY and I was deeply disappointed. I mean, they're good but I probably won't return to this restaurant. Beware, 15% gratuity is already added to your bill no matter the size of your party. Restaurant is small and you're probably going to sit next to random people. Also, I was misled by some reviews. This is NOT a dim sum place!!!!

Not bad, but I think overrated. I'm a big fan of soup dumplings; Din Tai Fung is a fave of mine. So given the high ratings for Joe's, I was hopeful. 

We got the scallion pancakes, pork xiao long bao, crab & pork xlb, and string beans 

The scallion pancakes were pretty good - nicely fried and good thickness and crispy. Green beans were tasteless and a waste; don't order it

Onto the dumplings... the pork ones were fine, but nothing special. The crab ones were ok; I actually just preferred the pork ones. A little too fishy for me.

Service was good.

We had a 10-15" wait, so it's fine, but i wouldn't wait 30 minutes for this. If the wait is short, you might as well try Joe's and see for yourself.
Tourist trap. Xiao Long Bao is humongous, sloppy, and overrated. Doesn't have the thin, fragile skin compared to other more authentic places.

Three stars for the soup dumplings. They were yummy! 

We were a party of seven. Portions are small and expensive considering it's China town. Food was mediocre at best. As a born and raised New York foodie I was not impressed. In fact China town in Queens Flushing blows this specific restaurant in Manhattan out the water. Better options for a better price.

Whoever heard of soup dumplings?  Well, probably not you if you don't live in NYC, 'cause Joe's "invented" them. 

Like the majority of China town restaurants the atmosphere is crap. Bright lights and quick, impersonal service is the status quo in chinese places.  The treck there takes you through the twisty, fish-stanky side streets in China town. When you arrive you usually have to wait, because this place is popular.  and CASH ONLY.

Armed with this information, I encourage you to check out Joes for four reasons. 
1) The community seating is a hoot.  You sit at a big round table and try not to talk too loud about the couple to your right.  
2) Its family style, which means your friends eat your food and you eat theirs.
3)The General Tao's is the best I ever had.  My friend ordered it and it came all white meat with a spicy, and not too sweet sauce.  Fried but not deep fried.  I was really impressed.
4) The infamous dumplings.  They're filled with soup.  So instead of ordering Wonton soup, you slurp it from your dumpling.

I am giving it three stars, because i don't like the dumplings and I think they should tell you that it is family style before you order - my friend didn't want to share her General Tao's and it was THAT good.

Great soup dumplings (crab is very tasty)! I have been coming here for years and anytime someone visits, I bring them here.  So why the 3 stars? Only because service has always sucked... But you kind of expect that for a place like this. Try it at least once and just ignore the service like they ignore you!
Overstated and underwhelming. Soup dumplings yummy, soup ok, service pathetic and rude.

Overrated. Sorry New Yorkers, but this place doesn't compare to the ones in CA. After reading all the reviews I was really exited to try this place. 
I was disappointed :( 

Dumplings were not very flavorful. The soup inside the dumplings tasted very greasy. Didn't like having to share a family style table with other customers.

Rude staff, cramped space and the foods not that great. It's a hype... maybe they were good at one time?! From a local.

We waited a good bit of time to get seated. They called our number and we we're walking to the server and she seats someone else. It was a wtf moment. She was completely rude and didn't speak much English.

We were seated at a large round table with other people (fine) and then server comes over to take the order right after. We told him we needed a minute to look over the menu. They guy gets an attitude and told us to hurry because they wanted to get other people in... I guess. 

It was so loud in the restaurant because everyone was so close together.

The food? Way below adverage. I've had better in little hole in the walls in georgia.

Possibly the worst restaurant service I've ever encountered. Food reviews should give a boost to the restaurant, however this restaurant deserves only one star because the food was good. About two weeks ago my friends and I were out in the city and we were looking for a good place to eat. As an iPhone user, I used my Yelp application to look for a good, yet affordable restaurant in Chinatown. Unfortunately, I happen to only look at the good reviews- the ones that praise this restaurant. Do not be fooled everyone. After hours of walking in the city in 90 degree weather, we had finally arrived at the destination following the GPS device. 

One hostess gave us a ticket to wait in line. We asked how long we would have to wait, and she replied 15 minutes. We thought to ourselves, oh, 15 minutes isn't so bad, right? Because we couldn't handle the heat, some of us went into the bubble tea shop next door. Luckily, the air condition was on blast in this place. We also found out that they do not accept credit card. Oh bummer.. 

30 minutes had passed by. Still no sign of the hostess telling us that it's our turn to be seated. Strangely, some people who came after us were getting seated before us. We were confused. We asked what's going on? She gave us the dirtiest look and told us that the people were done eating but were talking and not leaving the restaurant. 

Finally, we were seated. And what do we see? We were sitting with four strangers. First we thought it was four people who came in together, but later we found out that they were two separate couples. 

They also take the wrong order and expect you to just take the food and eat it. We ordered a pork dish but that did not come out, instead it was just general tso's dish. I must say the pork buns were good. 

All in all, I believe that this place is mainly known for tourists who do not know the city well. Here are some things to be wary of

1. Remember to have enough cash because 90% of restaurant in Chinatown do not accept credit cards. There are ATM's nearby the area. 

2. Don't expect to be treated like an actual customer. The waiters are very rude and hostile. They just want to order everything for you, by mistaking your orders.

3. Be open to eat at the same table with strangers!

Highkey overrated and can get better Xiao Long Bao elsewhere. The filling inside the XLB literally tasted like a dense meatball, nothing special and the fatty soup could not save it. The Water Spinach was extremely oily and I could barely eat more than a couple bites. Prices aren't cheap either, the Water Spinach was over $15...not worth.

This place was jam packed full of people.  I guess it was a chinatown hot spot.  

Coming all the way from San Francisco, we thought that we should try the crab meat with pork steamed buns.  It sounded really good.
I'm a little biased, because I've had better in San Francisco.  It was good for NY...but not worth the wait..

I also hated the long bathroom line

There is a major lack in the authenticity of their cuisine.  Many of the standard Shanghainese dishes aren't even offered. We ordered the snow cabbage and shredded pork noodle soup.  The broth was awful. The soup filled dumplings were mediocre.

Best in NY? Hardly. 2.5 stars but I'll bump up to 3 cause it wasn't all around horrible. My friend and I went here on a Saturday morning and were awkwardly sharing a large communal table. Just a warning for the odd sized parties - this could also be you.

Here's the breakdown:

1. CASH ONLY.
2. Turnip cake - not what I was expecting exactly. You need to drench it in soy sauce for it to really be good. It felt like was missing something.
3. Scallion pancake - emphasis on the pancake. It was overly thin and filled with grease.
4. Soup dumplings (crab and pork/pork) - more thick dumpling dough than soup and filling. It was overly bland. 

The service is standard for a crowded dim sum spot. They serve you when you ask for something and are trying to clean our room as quickly as possible. I wouldn't come back here for dim sum. It's all hype, not worth it,

Pork buns are one of my favorite foods ever and I like to think myself somewhat of a connoisseur. I've been to Shanghai and had soup dumplings there so my expectations for this place was high. The soup dumplings unfortunately did not live up to the hype in my opinion. The long wait times, apathetic wait staff and noisy, stifling dining room is not worth it for the sub-par food. 

Food: I had one order of the pork soup dumplings with crab and one order without crab. Although the dumplings themselves had great flavor, only about half had actual soup still inside. We had to send a batch back because all the dumplings were completely dry. The second batch came out better, but I still didn't get the hot outpour of soup from the dumpling that I expect. 

Service: As with most authentic Chinese restaurants, the service is abysmal. I am not deterred by this if the food is worth it. The restaurant is very efficient with its tiny dining area by having you order the dumplings right as you sit down. The dumplings come very fast and you munch on it while ordering other dishes if you like. 

Having to share a huge dining table with multiple other parties, the experience overall was hectic and unsatisfying. I hope this was just an off day for them and the next time I crave soup dumplings, I may try it again.

Absolutely love. However my last visit left me wondering if I was really eating beef b/c of the meat's texture so I didn't eat it I must say.) deducting 2 stars for that )The dumplings are awesome though!!

BACK TO QUEENS YOU GO, JOE..
when your OG status use to make your Xiao Long Baos gold.

cuz this joint,

is for the
tourist in you...
the strangers next to you..
the frozen premade dumplings steamed back to deceive you...
the oil blasting all over your mouth as your chew your dumpling,fool.
the intended sellingout to profit thanks to you. three Joe Shanghai's in NYC now. which means Kapoot!

no thanks.

so much other better joints nearby. Pshhhhhhh.

Service was good. Compared to the old flushing queens location, the soup dumplings taste so bad. The broth is so bland and the skin is way too thick. We also had the crispy beef that was recommended in a few other reviews but that too was not great. The strips were so thin you can barely taste any beef.

Joe's Shanghai is known for their soup dumplings. That's what I ordered and Spring rolls. First off, let's talk about the atmosphere. It feels so....Americanized. They have Ellie golden, Justin bieber, Coldplay etc on the back playing. It feels out of place. Like someone twerking to classical music. 
I'm not sure what's the hype about Joe's. Maybe cause there's a lot of reviews on Yelp. Their soup dumplings was 'meh' to me. I've had WAYYYY better ones down at Mott st and Bayard st. The meat inside the dumplings wasn't as juicy, and some of the dumplings were deflated so the juices was out. It lacks the sweet pork flavor. If it wasn't deflated it could've masked it. As for the spring rolls, forget it. There was a light brown hair on the plate. Clearly it's not mine, my hair is black. Y'all play too much and the bill came up to $50 that wasn't worth it. Go somewhere else to get soup dumplings. Overall, Joe's doesn't feel or taste authentic. You won't be seeing me back here.
I would give Joe's a 3 stars, but that hair on my plate.....Congratulations, you just played yourself.

Went there the day before Thanksgiving. The soup dumplings are interesting and good AND everything else was terrible including the service. When I returned the pork dish because it literally was slices of fat covered with sugary sauce the waiters were rude and almost insulting. When I refused to pay for the dish, they became very aggressive. The soup dumplings aren't that good!  I will never visit this restaurant again - EVER!

Received several recommendations but I have to say, I was disappointed . 
I don't mind waiting or sharing a table, as a matter of fact I met a lady with "local ties and we had a very nice chat. 
We ordered the crab and pork dumpling and the crispy noodles with beef and vegetables. The filling in the dumpling felt like a paste of pork, but no nice meaty texture of ground pork and I could not really find any evidence of crab meat. 
The noodles were very thick and no sense of fried crispy. I thought they were very leathery after being exposed to the gravy. Yes, I need to remember that I should not expect them like we have back home. 
The best dumplings I've ever had were in Beijing and I guess I keep hoping to find them in the US. 
Their seating is efficient and service efficient so remember that...they are efficient, not cordial or hospitable. They even had us move seats on the table so they could add another party of 7 delightful young girls. It is all about business, not in a bad way but don't expect it to be a nice family affair.

be prepared to knock some elbows while you eat because they seat you next to other parties on the same table. 

XLB is pretty good here but their kao fu is LEGIT! must try.

It is all about the soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai. This is where it began with soup dumplings and one friendly stranger.

The seating area puts strangers with other strangers at the large tables. It is fun being forced to make new friends.  We got to sit with a few strangers and one in particular had parents that preached sharing is caring. She ended up giving her last four soup dumplings to our group and that became our appetizer.

Onto to our little starlet, Soup Dumplings. They need to put a fragile sign on there because I am awful at handling these little delicacies. Between me being overzealous on the first couple and burning myself to me not properly opening them and juices ending up everywhere but my mouth, I think it is safe to say I am no soup dumpling expert. It did not stop me from enjoying every moment of the experience.

Sadly, Not all were created equally.

The Bok Choy tossed with Garlic had no garlic flavor at all. The garlic seemed to be just tossed in at the end, thus not allowing its flavors to come out. It is obvious when a cook does not use the garlic properly in a dish; it looks whiter than Casper the ghost.

The Fried Rice was nothing special and, to steal a line from my man Forrest Gump, that is all I have to say about that.

And the service.....

Well was what you expect a Chinese restaurant. It being to the point and very impersonal, but that is fine as long as they are quick with their service.

All in all, I will be back one day for my new friend, Soup Dumpling.

Joe's Shanghai is A-OK. 

Joe has been on my NYC to do for a while, and I got to experience it in all of it's glory on a Friday night.  I love that this place hasn't lost it's charm or been fully gentrified as it grew in popularity - the service isn't great, the menus are old and items are still spelled wrong but corrected with a few strokes of a Sharpie, and there is no ambiance.  I love it. 

We sat at a table of 6, and made friends with two Italian tourists who were visiting NYC for just a few days.  Love the communal seating arrangement.  Obviously the soup dumplings were ordered, and they were even more fantastic than I had imagined - $6.95 for 8? Sweet deal.  We also ordered some chicken dish, but it wasn't very memorable so I don't remember the name.  Our meal cost a total of $20 for two, and we could not find room in our bellies for anything else.  Except for the gratis orange slices that were presented to us with our check. 

Here's a good part of why I am subtracting two stars.  The Italian pair we made friends with had a bill of $78!!! That is an absurd cost for 2 at Joe's Shanghai - we paid $20.  They consulted with the waiter whether two entrees, and two orders of soup dumplings and two beers would be sufficient for the both of them - the waiter said yes, and had we of known we would have corrected him immediately.  I understand this can be a tourist trap and all, but the good person in me felt that was a bit unfair. 

Here is my CASH ONLY disclaimer.   

We hopped over to Apotheke for a quality cocktail afterward, and recommend you do the same pre or post Joe's. Note - you can't bring your Joe's leftovers to Apotheke, no food allowed.

Simply put, Joe's Shanghai is expensive for what it is in terms of quality and portion size. The portions are smaller than your average dish in most restaurants in Chinatown. We ordered the crab meat xiao long bao, lo mein, sauteed rice cake, the cold beef appetizer, and a plate of veggies. One dish that we simply inquired about but did not order was added to our orders as well, which is not appreciated - make sure you are very clear with what you are ordering and what you are simply asking about. Most of the dishes were simply bland. A freshly sauteed rice cake was already getting cold and stiff. The crab meat xiao long bao is the most flavorful menu item we ordered and too heavy for my liking. Nonetheless, it was pretty good when eaten immediately (before the dough gets cold and stiff). The crab meat is not imitation crab but rather actual meat from a crab. As mentioned, the food here is very expensive when you can easily get something cheaper and tastier in Chinatown - comparable Shanghai restaurants are a few dollars less PER dish which can easily add up. Lastly, more non-locals visit this restaurant than locals themselves. 

P.S. their vinegar dip for the xiao long baos is strong 

***Cash only!

Seating was limited and they wanted my party of 4 to seat with two other individuals I didn't know. I decided to wait for a table of 4. Food was awful had extremely salty scallion, with ginger chicken never again. The only thing that was edible was the fried dumplings. Spare yourself the headache go somewhere else.  The reviews and the wait to be served were both misleading since I will never ever go to the place. 0 stars

I first heard of Joe's Shanghai over 10 years ago on some Travel Channel show and the food looked so fantastic that I always wanted to try it.  Finally, I got my chance the other day and I was so let down.

#1 - I know this is a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown but we are NOT in China.  I don't appreciate the communal tables (unless you ask me first).  I had to sit next to 2 people who kept asking each other, "Wow, how did they get the soup in there?"

#2 - We ordered the second we sat down but the food took almost half an hour to come.  Really?  Steaming 1 order of soup dumplings takes that long?

#3 - The dumplings had plenty of soup but the meat filling had no flavor whatsoever.  I'm from China and I know that authentic XLB meat is not overseasoned but it shouldn't be bland either.

The positive is that the price was pretty good.  Trying Joe's was always a dream of mine so I guess my dream came true. Yay.

Why am I sucker for # of reviews on Yelp?  Let me breakdown the timeline:

11:40am - we sent a junior co-worker into a meeting on our behalf to take notes.

11:41am - I assemble 3 co-workers and we decide to walk to Chinatown for lunch.  

12:05pm - The original plan was to check out Prosperity Dumpling, but it seemed too far and we were unsure of the seating situation for 4 people.  We passed by Pell Street and I remembered that Joe's Shanghai was on 9 Pell St and had a ridiculous amount of reviews (that should be automatic right?).  I convince everyone to go, we get seated at our own table (there were a # of communal tables), and ordered:

- Crab and Pork Soup Dumplings: they were just OK (I kind of pushed everyone's expectations by saying that it's what they were famous for)
- Pork Buns: average mystery meat pork buns
- Shanghai Rice: the eggs and scallions were too plain  
- Pork Fried Rice: the better of the rices we received (nothing to write home about either).  
- Braised Pork Shoulder: wow, they weren't kidding (it looked like a charred pork shoulder).  It was good, but heavy.
- Orange Beef: good, but the beef pieces were chunks.
- General Tso's Chicken: pretty standard 
- Soft Shell Crab: it was good (I didn't get why it was served with different colored syrofoam)    

12:38pm - I invited our junior co-worker to join us because we ordered WAY TOO MUCH food (by sending him a picture of our table).

12:38pm - 12:50pm: I try to give turn by turn instructions to my directionally challenged co-worker via text (he quit).

1:05pm - we get the bill with 15% automatically added in (I didn't get that since we were only 4 people and I see 20% as automatic) and we had to roll each other down Pearl Street while in food comas.

By the way, they are cash only.

I just want to preface this with, this is not my mother's Chinese restaurant. This is my white friend, pulling her eyelids back, and making Chinese food. It's borderline offensive.

I'm sure Joe's was great at one point in time. 

I walk in, and there's a sour scent in the air. I've been here once last summer, and was pretty stunned with how mediocre this place is while ALL my non-Chinese (and a few Chinese) friends rave about this place. 

People always talk about soup dumplings so awesome that Olivia Wilde, Jonah Hill, and Jake Gyllenhaal's been here. I already have my own soup dumpling joint in Chinatown, so I might be slightly biased here. 

The first time I was here, I had only the soup dumpling. It was too salty, to gingery, and lacked any other flavor. I left, and vowed to never return. (There's always a long line for mediocre soup dumplings).

Last night, I went to dinner with a couple of our friends to get lobster, and needed a little booster afterwards. My friend raved about the soup dumplings, so we got that, along with stir-fried rice cakes. 

Stir-fried rice cakes is something my mom made for me since I was a child and it's one of my favorite dishes, ever. 

We got the soup dumplings, and I wish they were salty and ginger. They were so bland. The dumplings tasted frozen, and not even wrapped right. 

The rice cake finally came out, and THEY PUT SOY SAUCE ON RICE CAKES. The beef was too salty, the rice cake tasted weird, and it was pretty terrible. I paid for it, I ordered it, and I was hungry. Otherwise, I'd never eat it. 

The only redeeming factor is that the servers are really nice. They're really accommodating towards tourists and I KNOW they are overworked.

Yes the soup dumplings are good.  but the service and attitude and wait are not worth it now that there's shanghai cafe (is it a spinoff of the one in the tunnel?)...

careful with the bill, the gratuity is tacked on the bill.  i can't manage to remember this every time i go, so have double tipped like half the time.

Overrated spot. Dumplings were way too fatty and gross I couldn't even eat them. Noodles had barely any beef in them. The sesame chicken was good but nothing special. I ordered take out and they called me 3 times telling me to hurry up and pick up my order since they were closing. Totally understandable. I rushed to pick it up only to get there and see multiple parties still dining in. Not sure why they were blowing up my phone.... won't be coming back here.
Not sure why this place is so highly rated.  The food was good but not out of this world and the service was horrible.

Okk...I know,this is probably the most popular Chinese restaurant in Chinatown,NYC  (though I coudn't figure it out,why???)....and I had high expectations set,which were definitely not fulfilled!!!!...I will explain you,why!!!!...
Firstly,the place is so dirty,smelly,small for so many people,very poorly maintained...a perfect ghetto....
Secondly,the service!!!...It cannot be worse than this...you have to wait in a long line and also act as a gatekeeper and after that,when you sit,they will not give you enough time to think what to take...even if you try to take it,you will see their annoyed faces...and my friend ordered one dish,which was served to me,and I asked the waiter to serve it to my friend,instead...the waiter uttered something in Chinese with lots of annoyance (I know for sure,they are cusswords)!!!....so RUDE!!!!
Thirdly,after waiting for a long time,and it was a hot day (Memorial Day,2014)we were not even served with water...we had to drink from our own bottle,...
Fourthly,the waiter did not know,what type of wine was served as the House Wine on that day...he had to go inside and he took out the whole bottle to show us...it was so much ridiculous!!!
and Finally,the FOOD!!!!!....oh my god!...it was horrible!...the soup dumplings were better of the lot...but was OK type,not great,that you would die for it!...I have tasted many dumplings which are far better than this!...and the other dishes in the main course was not upto the mark!...one even tasted so bad,we thought it was rotten!!!...We didn't like the food,at all,though we were hungry like sharks!!!!....that's the main thing....
and for that horrendous service,you have to pay the 15% tips on the total bill amount....which we really thought,we would never give...but it was added to the bill!!...guess what,they know,they don't deserve it,so people are not gonna give it!...so they just forcefully take it from you!
I would never ever go back to this terrible place....it sucks....please don't ever go....don't recommend others!....I would not even give them one star,if I could!

We came here at around 3:30pm on the Saturday after Christmas. The wait for 6 people was about 35 minutes. The staff works their asses off here, and the crowds make it even harder. We got to our table, a big round meant for 8, we shared the table with 2, not a bad deal.
 
So obviously the soup dumplings (xiao long bao) are obligatory. We ordered the pork and the crab/pork. They were good, the shell was sturdy and the dumplings were big, but they were just good. The crispy shredded beef was tangy and had a great texture, the cold sesame noodle were also nice.

We've been going to John's Shangai for years and I think they're xiao long bao was better, and we never had to wait on line. I would try it at least once, it's cheap and delicious, but the wait is definitely a turn off.

The soup dumplings were pretty good but not amazing.  The "soup" in the XLBs were  based on fatty pork, not aspic, which is what is supposed to create the richness.

The vegetarian duck was quite unique and tasty.  

Overall, the price is quite reasonable.  I am glad I tried it once, but will not return to wait another 1.5 hours for the food.

We checked yelp prior to and found this place, very busy so we thought it would be good. Our sever was maybe 15 and could have cared less about us. Never returned to check on us and the tip is included with the bill otherwise he wouldn't have gotten anything. Food was ok, won't be returning customers.

The wait staff was the rudest I've ever encountered. We had never been before and they sat us after we waited outside (which was fine as there is no room inside) we sat down and the waiter immediately asked us for our order. He knew we had not looked at a menu. I had to tell him to come back three times. I felt so rushed and as if we were an unwelcome guest. We did order in a timely manner and he didn't listen. It was a rough experience and we will not be back. There were two of us and the 18% tip was already included.   That's all he got and I'm a generous tipper usually.

Food is always 5 stars but their service is always 2-3 stars. I order soup dumplings right away since they would take a while. Tables sat down after me received their tea and I told the waiter. He said it's coming and then went to take care of other customers instead of fetching me tea. The second waiter I asked was surprised and said I was with the two girls next to me.  I reminded him we had order food separately. 

He came back in a few minutes and asked if I wanted anything else. I told him i just need another minute.  He never came back to check on me.  I could have doubled the check but he was too lazy to come back. 

Then the bill came with 15% tip already added whether service was good or bad.   They also round UP your bill when going change.  My bill was $7.61.  I was going to give then $20.01 but can use the few pennies.  They gave me back  $11.35.  So my bill was up to $7.65. I know places that would round down their customer's bill.   Yeah it's only 4 cents.  But you know how many bills the process each day.  4 cents becomes 4 dollars then 40 dollars....
Service was ok. Soup dumplings were great. Definitely saw a little white mouse run through the kitchen...

typical bad service from a chinese establishment. i also thought it was weird that they seated us at a large sharing table with others (hostess didn't mention it to us prior to seating us - as we would have enjoyed having our own table). service was bad, they pretty much ignored us. the pork soup dumplings were nothing special, i've tasted better

Ugh, my 2 stars is being generous. I've been to this place many many times, and those were all 4 stars. Today's experience was so MEH, I had to write this review. I went in to pick up a pan fried noodle order in the afternoon. I think the chef must have been on his lunch break, because the dish I received, I had to throw out, it was that bad.  The sauce was overstarched. It was disgusting.  In my life I've only thrown out food less than 5 times.  What a waste. 

I'll go there for their soup dumplings, but that's it.

Food is good - slightly on the salty side.  The Xiao Lung Bao is very good.  I go there just because of that.  Otherwise, I would NOT eat over there:

Because ......

First, they add 15% service charge despite their less then professional service.  (Yes, there is a sign saying about adding the service charge - but it is printed on a regular white piece of paper with small letter font - may be a 10 pt. font? from 5ft away???)    Cash only and automatically add 15% service charge.  And make sure you ask for the change when you pay the bill or your might not get your change back. (That happened to me twice - accidental?)

Customer service and clearness is way way way below par.  I had to exchange my utensils and my vinegar for Xiao Lung Bao because they were not up to par.  And the fun part was that:  I particularly had to beg them to give me a new vinegar because they insisted that they were clean.  (And you call that a Customer service with automatically 15% tips?)

The soup dumplings are good.........but for AMAZING soup dumplings either go to flushing or to Williamsburg's M Shanghai bistro. Yeah, so I worked there for awhile but even if I didn't I'd say the same. Joe's is perpetually packed with tourists, which sucks, but there food is good.

I just noticed tonight that they put 15% service charge on the bill, add that with your bill, THEN tax you on that subtotal amount.

Why are you charging me tax on the service charge?????

Ridiculous!

We went around 8:45pm and were told a 30+ minute wait, which is a bit too much for New York restaurants, especially since there is no Yelp waitlist. When you are seated, you essentially share a large table with multiple parties, which can be fun or awkward depending on the group dynamics and your personality. It was ok for us.

The food failed to meet the expectations of the wait. We got the sesame noodles and the pork soup dumplings (xiao long bao). The sesame noodles were prepared poorly because of the flavor and the starchiness texture that accentuates the poor flavor. The xiao long bao was okay, as I have tried much better before. You carefully pick up the dumpling and place it in a spoon in case the soup leaks out. This was necessary because these dumplings are relatively large compared to the standard. The soup is pretty good but the pork inside needs improvement as it is not that flavorful. Overall, this place seems to be overhyped and definitely not worth the wait.

I brought my mom to this place to try their Shanghainese dumplings, boy was it a bad decision. Seeing that there was a wait outside the restaurant, you'd expect it to be a good restaurant. Once you walk in, all you see are tourists and "folks" that just want to "experience" the dumplings. With all the positive "expired" media and Zagat reviews, the restaurant is basking in it's former glory.

The specialties at this restaurant is traditional Shanghainese food. Stick with the basic or crab shao lung bao dumplings and you'll enjoy the food. The pot roast is pretty good too. Anything else is plain garbage, especially the rice and noodle plates.

The WORST part of eating here is the automatic 15% gratuity added to your food bill BEFORE taxes. Anyone want to explain to me why they tax you on tips? To MANY unsuspecting tourists or fools, they look past the 15% gratuity and put down more tips. Seeing how this is an Asian establishment, I won't be surprised if the owner let's the workers keep the post-bill tips, while he profits additionally from the pre-bill 15% gratuity.  

Also there is a HUGE pricing discrepancy of the dumplings on the menu. When we received the bill, I noticed that they charged TWICE the price that was stated on the menu. WTF is that all about? Instead of $6.65 for the crab meat dumplings it was $13.30 on the bill. The pork version was $4.65 on the menu, yet $9.30 on the tab. VERY VERY dishonest business practice.

+1 star for serving "ok" dumplings and pot roast.

- 100 stars for the super shady price discrepancy and the  pre-bill 15% gratuity.

-1 star for being forced to share tables with others. (isn't it entertaining for a Caucasian diner to be boasting to his friends that this restaurant serves the most "authentic" Shanghainese food in front of Shanghainese folks?)

AVOID at all cost! IF you must, and I say must try Shanghainese shao lung bao dumplings. Take the 7 train to the Flushing Chinatown and eat at Nan Shian dumplings. They serve the best HONEST Shanghainese dumplings in all the NY boroughs.

I used to think the XLB here was the best in the nation.  That was a few years ago.  I recently visited Joe's as I was in NY on a business trip.  There were plenty of open tables but they made me sit with other ppl.  That's fine, but just be prepared for it.  

I ordered the crab meat and pork XLB's.  They were hot and for the most part pretty good.  The downgrade is that some of the dumplings had already leaked prior to them delivering it to me.  Another minus is that the tables are really cramped.  This dude sitting next to me mixed up his XLB and ate one of mine!  I'm like you touched it,  I ain't gonna eat that one.  

I've heard from other locals that there are better places/less touristy than Joe's which I will have to check out.  It just didn't taste as good this time around.

Been coming here for years. Food is awesome and service is quick. 
Just one tip, no matter how long they say the wait is, add half an hour. That way your expectations are realistically set and you enjoy your meal rather than being annoyed at how the hostesses lied to you.

This place is so overrated! It's not worth the wait. I came here on a weekday at 6p-ish and it was crowded. I think we ended up waiting like 40 minutes.

Joe's Shanghai is known for their xiao long tong bao (shanghai soup dumplings). First of all, good xiao long tong bao is supposed to be light, thin skinned, and flavorful. Joe's Shanghai's dumplings are thin skinned, and flavorful, but it's not light and is actually a little greasy and salty. Chinese food is not greasy! American Chinese food is greasy! Nothing else we ordered here was that impressive. 

This place isn't Ding Tai Fung. In fact, it's not even close. If you've ever had good Xiao Long Bao, I wouldn't waste my time coming here. If this is your first time trying it though, then I guess it's not a bad start. This place is really for those who've never had soup dumplings.

Additionally, my boyfriend got sick from eating here. 

I personally prefer Shanghai Cafe for xiao long tong baos. The skin is not as thin but the flavor is better.

So this place is known for its pork soup dumplings. They are definitely yummy. I would go back for that but not for much else really. There is a line and they dont tell you they will sit you with strangers. So if you're expecting to be just seated with your party of four prepare to have guests. The noise level is high and the atmosphere is like that of a frat house with mostly young people from out of state. The people who are in the know take their stuff to go. I will do the same in the future.

I was really disappointed to walk in and find out that it wasn't a restaurant that has a variety of dim sum. Pictures of dim sum are the first items shown on the website, so I took an Uber there ready and excited to eat that. I got there, sat down, and found out there are only two types of dim sum, and they are only appetizers. They were ok enough but I wish I had looked at the menu before taking and Uber there.

Soup dumplings (xiao long bao) are a must-try when you're in Chinatown. Joe's Shanghai is a popular choice for authentic soup dumplings, but it's also a bit touristy. We were expecting a long line, but they seated us right away with other people like a communal seating. It's still better than waiting. 

Food came out really quick. Soup dumplings were hot and delicious, but some of the soup were already leaking from the bottom of dumplings before I even grabbed them with my chopsticks. They probably steamed our dumplings too long. Because of that, I didn't really get that "burst" or "pop" in my mouth. I also recommend getting a scallion pancake. They were crispy just the way I like it. Overall, soup dumplings were good, but I'm just disappointed about the leak. Also, this place is cash only!!!

This place has GREAT food. It was the first time I've ever had soup dumplings and had me return later that same week for more. I've since had more soup dumplings at several other places but this may still be the top but it could just be nostalgia. I've had other dishes and they were equally as good. You cannot go wrong with the food and going with big groups. 

Regardless of the party size, tip is included and I've got to say the environment is a bit chaotic and cramped but the worst is the service. It seems, to get people to order quickly, servers will standby waiting until you've been pressured enough to order. 

Despite that, I will visit again at some point.

I was really excited to try this NYC staple so the fact that the food didn't live up to the hype is a bit disappointing. I did take out rather than wait in line for dine-in, so this review is on the food only. I LOVE XLB and was expecting a lot from these famous ones. They were tasty, plenty of flavorful dumpling juice, but every single one of my dumplings was punctured - surprising because the dough was thick, which also wasn't that appealing. So I had dumpling soup...which wasn't bad, but didn't give me the joy of biting into a gushing xlb. I also ordered the cold noodles with sesame sauce and barely ate any of it. Noodle with thick, pretty tasteless sesame paste that I couldn't bring myself to finish.

When me and my friends walked in we were like on nice place got our seats. The dumplings was great but the service was so poorly organize. We didnt get our beers till like 20 mins later and we have been waitting for our other meals over 40mins. Sorry!! Maybe next time in a couple years.

Not worth the hype.

There are better places for soup dumplings like shanghai cuisine a few minutes walk away.

Soup dumplings:
-thick skin
-soup was very thick
+cheap
+quick to the table

Rice cakes were mediocre, too oily and not enough veggies/meat

Dine in:
~ a lot of people, on the loud side
-could be seated at a big table with strangers
+waiters take away empty dishes quickly
-feel rushed bc of the fast paced service

I usually don't write yelp reviews but my experience at Joe's Shanghai was EXCEPTIONALLY bad. I came with a friend on Sunday, and we were seated fairly quickly at a large round table with some other strangers which we didn't mind - we actually appreciated the efficiency. A waiter also attended to us pretty quickly, and all we put in an order for 1 order of pork soup dumplings. 

Then, we waited for OVER ONE HOUR to get our dumplings. All of the other groups at our table were getting SECOND, even THIRD orders of soup dumplings while we patiently waited for ours to come. We nicely asked the waiter how much longer the wait would be and he appeared to have forgotten what we ordered. When the dumplings finally came, they were pretty good, but not worth the one hour wait. While I recognize we were there on the Sunday after Chinese New Year and the restaurant was especially busy, it is pathetic that we had to wait more than an hour for just a 8 soup dumplings, especially because people that ordered after us were served first. 

We will not be returning to Joe's Shanghai.

So, so good.  Be prepared as Joe's Shanghai seems to have a perpetual 20-30 minute wait no matter what time you show up.  

Prices are good, servings are large and are served quickly.  I particularly enjoy their double cooked pork with rice.

So on my recent trip to NYC I decided to test the highly talked about Joe's Shanghai in Manhattan's Chinatown. I ate at 14 restaurants that weekend and this was the first restaurant with a C rating from the city 

So I started off with the Crab and pork Xiao Long Bao. Not sure why it's called steamed buns on the menu but yea they we're good but nothing to rave about. Strong crab flavor (roe) with lots of broth oozing out.Coming from the west coast we definitely have better XLB. 

Second dish was crispy beef strips. Which pretty much tasted like orange beef from panda express or one of those Western Chinese restaurants. 

Final dish I tried was the spicy bean curd and pork. Pretty much ma po tofu. The dish was lacking spice and they were kinda skimp on the pork. 

Having tried it now I probably wouldn't go back... There are so much better restaurants in that area to eat.

I personally thought this place was over-rated but a good value.  The soup dumplings were large but not as delicious as i've had in other places.  The fried noodles were pretty good. Sharing a table wasn't too fun, but not horrible.
Good dumplings, nice braised pork shoulder.  Service was fine.  Cash only.

Although this restaurant chain has been featured on cooking shows for their dumplings, this particular location is overrated. The minimum wait on a weekday is over half an hour, and the service is terrible.  What's worse, those waiting in line hover over your table and overtly drool over your meal. Tasty. Insult to injury after the wait was the fact that there are only two choices of dumplings. 

My suggestion is to find another dumpling place that actually has more variety. Chinatown has too many options, and one shouldn't feel compelled to go to this one.

Overhyped tourist trap I think.. The xiao long bao or soup dumpling was nothing spectacular. The only thing I will remember about the dumplings was that they were MSG filled and so were the rest of the food. I love dumplings and I just had 2 of these. Was not even tempted to eat more. 

The fries rice tastes so mediocre, and again overly greasy again. The eggplant's sauce was too thick as well. The pork chops were actually fried well but seasoning and flavor were a disappointment and tasted like the typical MSG-filled food they have. 

Good thing we did not have to wait very long to be seated because a wait will definitely not be worth it.

Gross food and dirty. Quintessential Chinatown: dirty & low quality food. Want some real proper Chinese food dedicated to those with actual tastebuds and standards? Don't come here... unless you are an uncultured foodie with low standards that enjoys oily fatty low quality Xiao long Bao.

It was windy, cold, and rainy (Hurricane Sandy was on her way), so what better way to spend our brunch then with some Shanghainese comfort food? 

We came here with a party of six and were seated at a round community table with two other parties. I admit, it was slightly awkward having strangers sit across from us, but it was whatever. We ordered several orders of their very popular soupy dumplings (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0CjK3esfpFcxIopebzjFxA?select=4iBG8FQNL37Q8mntLsGJyg#4iBG8FQNL37Q8mntLsGJyg), an order of their onion cake, and an order of their pork chops. I've been spoiled with great dumplings in Southern California, so I would say that I have pretty high standards and the dumplings from Joe's was at most average. I didn't like that the dumplings were so big and the skin was too thick for my liking. Albeit there was a lot of tasty soup inside, it just didn't quite hit the spot for me. I tried a little bit of the fried pork chop and it wasn't anything special. It was very lightly seasoned and came with a sweet and sour dipping sauce. The onion cake was good though. 

Customer service was lacking of course, but that didn't deter the crowds. At least Joe's is officially marked off my bucket list now!

This place typifies gross chinese food that is fit only for stupid midwestern tourists. It is really greasy and oily. None of the food tastes like anything, except for the pools of grease that it sits in. We ordered both pork and beef dishes, with scallion pancakes and springs rolls. Everything came fried, and left a waxy, greasy film on the inside of your mouth. Even the dumplings, which they are ostensibly famous for, tasted like a load of salt, msg, and fat. The worst part was the meat. If it could be classfied as 'fit for human consumption' I would be shocked. It was stringy, fatty chunks of mystery meat, that most closely resembled the overcooked gristle carved off poor quality steak.

If you like eating with lots of strangers (because you don't get your own table), very poor service (and the fact that a very fat tip is already included in your bill), and fat posing as meat, this is the place for you. However, you'll probably want to eat at McDonalds, because this food tastes about the same, just five times as expensive.
I like their steam crab meat bun and rice cake. It is always crowded with people. I wish it is less crowded or larger seating place. Not a good atmosphere for eating, it make me feel rushing.

(Disclaimer: this one isn't about the food since we didn't get to sit down, it's about how rude we were treated when trying get a table)
Me, my wife and three kids (10, 7, 4) were out in Chinatown for Doctor appointment. Decided to have lunch before going home. 
Pell Street was closed for the many restaurants. Tables are all over the street, and hard to distinguish which section belongs to which restaurant. We stood near the entrance of the restaurant hoping to talk to one of the server. One of the troubling sight I observed was customers has to help the server get the steaming hot little steam buns placed on their table. Then one of the server, said to us, "this is the entrance, don't stand here" we were on the side of the entrance, not in front of it. Then the 2nd one came out, and i asked "Hi, do u have a table of five?" (I spoke to him in Cantonese, which is what I heard him spoke to the other server) he said, "‰∫îÂÄã‰∫∫ÔºÅÈÇäÊúâ‰ΩçÊØî‰∫îÂÄã‰∫∫!" (Translation: Five people! Where can I get a table for five people!?" 
Granted, it's not easy to run in and out from the restaurant onto the street; but don't take your frustration on your customers 
Of cz we moved on to a different place.

This place is not as great as everybody is trying to say. I must admit the dumplings were great and probably better then at other places I've been to, but not that much. The food was very common, there are better restaurants.

What I really hate is the queue in front of the restaurant. Me and me friend we waited 50 mins to get in, because we thought it would be something really special. They seated us to a table with random people who were already eating. Man it was weird. The service was also not that good and slow, as there were too many people. They also brought my food first and my friend got his food after ten minutes after we asked them.

Came here with my friends a few days back, it was not packed like how everyone said it was (we came here at around 3-4). We ordered the Crab Meat Pork Soup Dumplings, the Shanghai Flat noodles and Scallion Pancakes. The pancakes were so frigging good, we had to order two. The soup dumplings were really fishy, and did not taste up to par as my friend had said so, she even agreed herself. The frozen ones I can buy from a supermarket, are much better than these. The flat noodles were pretty good, except it was very oily. That amount of food got 3 of us full, so I would say the serving size is generous. I would not come back here for their soup dumplings, maybe come back and try just the pork soup, but I will definitely come back for the scallion pancakes. Also, they do charge a mandatory 15% tip, it was listed on the back of the menu. To be honest, I think they treat the Asians better than they do other races just because....

Food: 6/10. The food is definetly not bad tasting but nothing too special also. 

Environment 5/10: The place is obviously small just by judging from the outside. Just hate that fact that they sit you with other strangers in this round table if u come in with 2 people or just yourself. So get read for awkward conversations. 

Service: 6/10: The servers are definetly very attentive and they check up on you every now and then. They should give the option where customer's should sit though. 

Tip: I know this place gets busy at certain times specially night and weekends. But if you are very hungry and see a long line outside the restaurant, just come up with a different plan. You are not missing anything.

This place amazes me - more because of its high ratings. 

The worst service ever - servers staring at when you'll finish your food (lol) - we got the menu and the server immediately asked so what do you want- it was a strange service!

Coming to the  food - the server cut the fried noodles so aggressively that it came flying on my face (of course no apology needed ;) his elbow hit us - again not bothered to apologize!

Ambiance : loud chaotic and yet was being managed - no complaints here

Payment : Those with credit cards beware this is CASH ONLY!

 Which brings me to another very interesting point - they actually have two ATMS inside the property so you can take cash out!! 

Is that even permitted?

Either ways - a v v bad experience and of course I'll never be back! Tons of places to eat in China town so don't fall for the one with most reviews and high ratings!!

The soupy dumplings are very nice and worth a trip to try, but the service and overall atmosphere leave much to be desired. The waiters are downright rude and chase customers for larger tips. Treatment of tourists is shameful.

Overhyped Shanghainese fair.

Don't get me wrong, the food was certainly edible. But after all we had heard and see with the piles of people outside, my friends and I thought we would have experienced more here.

Seating was fast and service was great, but the food was the star letdown. Everything we ordered was best described as mid. The scallion pancakes though, may have been the least "scallion"-filled I have ever had. Ever the pork soup dumplings had very little soup or unique flavor.

Strangely, despite our party of five, we were initially only given four duck skins for our roasted duck. We had to ask for a fifth since it would have been unreasonable to "split" a wrapper. We're thankful the staff were kind enough to offer an additional wrapper, but found it strange that it was standard to not include it. We would have been OK paying for extra if we had more people or if we had ordered more duck. But to expect us to wrap a WHOLE duck in just four skins is a bit too much.
I've never had such an awful service in my life. They literally tried to remove my plate from the table while I was still eating. Food is ok but there are better restaurants in the area.

I was brought here by a friend a couple years ago and wasn't that impressed. Decided to give the place another chance and apparently nothing's changed.

The XLB's were nothing special, think dough wrapping, average tasting meat. The yin su rolls were as expected, their hong sao fish had tonnnns of bones, and their shanghai rice cake dish tasted like something I could have made at home.

The place has a wait though I'm not sure why. Groups of 3-expect to share tables with another party. All in all I'm still disappointed and would rather try another restaurant in the area.

Don't buy into the hype. Just don't do it, especially if there is any sort of a wait.  

Good soup dumpling: thin skin but doesn't break when you pick it up with chopsticks.  Juicy, but not greasy or oily.  Flavorful, and the skin is not doughy.

Joe's Shanghai: opposite of everything I just listed above.

I been here several times with groups of friends and always thought the place was "meh" (but then I think that of the majority of Chinese restaurants on the in New York... ).

This time, I was nearby, missing Soup dumplings, and decided to give it a try myself - and realized I must've not paid much attention to the food as I did the conversation those previous visits because the food is as other reviews have mentioned... So oily, so greasy, and just overall not of a good quality (why are parts of my soup dumpling yellow?  From the grease?).  The overly aggressive service didn't help either, though I was one of only 4 tables filled at the place, they came by to make sure I still had my last two dumplings left four-five times so they could clear me out.

I flew back to LA this week and made it to a good soup dumpling place just to do a comparison and make up for this meal.  And wow...  Night and day difference.  

Hungry Kat does not approve.

2nd night in the Big Apple and after a disappointing 1st night dinner we wanted to try the best they can offer in Chinatown.  Check yelp and this place have an outstanding review.  When we got there the wait is an hour.  And bec there were about 50 people waiting in line to get in, we decided to wait and give this place a try.  Xiao long bao or soup dumpling was our main purpose and this is our favorite food and boy oh boy what a big disappointment.    The taste is   bland.  Most of the customer have to share table with strangers which I don't mind if the food is worth it.  Hing Kee in Chinatown Chicago has better Xiao long bao or soup dumpling.  Their other food are ok and nothing special.  What makes their food taste better is bec of the MSG.  You'll know because an hour after eating you will be very thirsty even though you had already drank a lot of water.  Beware you've been warned.
Food is okay but the line is always a minus point. Service are not very good and its a one time only place for me for the sake of the line.

Joe's is just one of those places that you go to so that you can say you've been, so if you've never been, go. However, it was my second time here and I will not be returning. Constantly crowded and the rude staff does not help very much either. I wouldn't mind waiting if the food was mindblowing-ly delicious, or if the service was impeccable, but Joe's falls short on both accounts. Their dumplings are good, but there are soup dumpling places lined up and down Chinatown, you can definitely find a better place to fulfill your xiao long bao cravings.

The line to get in was so long and it did not bring back the amazing memories of the last time we were in NYC 9 years ago. Nice dumplings and the okay Chinese food, but not what I remembered of the old venue.

i'm vegetarian so i didn't get to try their soup dumplings and maybe if i had then it would have been a better experience. as it were, i got a pan-fried noodle (liang mian huang) which was noooothing like wut a liangmian huang is...i don't know if they ran out of noodles that day or what but the type of noodle they used (a thick, white, fried thing) was nothing at all like the light thin crispy egg noodles that the dish is supposed to be. sauce, tasteless and bland. this was my first experience with "chinese" food in nyc in a long time..disappointing. go to flushing instead for proper food (and dumplings) the only thing i liked about it was that we all had to share tables because it was so crowded, which is something you have to do in hong kong all the time.

It's okay. I think this place is a bit overrated. I feel that the wait time to be seated could be long since it's well known and everyone comes. That aside, you might have to share tables (I don't mind but some might) and the space for all your food could be limited. Their food is like all other places I've been too.
Was very disappointed when visited.  They use to have the best dumpling in town, but I guess no more.  It was nasty when I ordered it last time.
Worst Chinese food I've had in a long time. Service was atrocious. Soup dumplings are just ok now. This place used to be great, but something happened when they moved locations. Stay away.

Crazy busy, tight inside, shared table seating, but that does mean you get seated reasonably quickly despite the crowds.

Green beans are a little too much dried beef-- not delicate in taste as a result. Not bad though, but disappointing.

Xiao long bao in pork form are pretty decent, the pork and crab are even better, but the end product is just average. They lack the delicacy or the presentation of the better places I've had, and while the taste was pretty acceptable, the taste again lacked the explosive bursts of flavor on your taste buds of the best places.

Eh.  I'm always glad when there is jellyfish as I guiltily love to eat it but overall it's pretty eh.  

Yay soup dumplings for pork eaters! They look finely crafted and bursting with flavor and juice.  
 
Not vegetarian friendly ( but that's to be expected at a dim sum place)

I guess I'm not eating the things everyone goes crazy for here- but I am a big fan of the genre/style/cuisine.

For what it costs, the food is great. However, I've had better Chinese food and steamed pork dumplings elsewhere. If you've had the dumplings at Din Tai Fung in Southern California, then Joe's Shangai doesn't even compare.

came here when i was 10 with my family and fell in love with the soup dumplings. fast forward 10 years later.. it wasnt the same. really hoped for the same taste but was definitely lost throughout those 10 years.

The place is sh*t. 
Waiters are rude and barely speak any English. 
There are some weird yells from the kitchen all the time. 
They don't accept credit cards.
The seating is cramped and you have to share table with 9 other people.
The place is quite dirty.
Food is average.
You'd be better off  by going to an other place.

On our trip to NYC, we tried this restaurant with 4 stars and 4k reviews, which is not common for a Chinese restaurant. But to my taste, food was too oily. Maybe it is more traditional style, really original from Shanghai. We tried soup dumplings, fried sea bass, shredded beef and a vegetable dish. Not bad but too oily.

Ok at best. 
The soup dumplings were good, but everything else was just meh. 
Atmosphere is like a cross between a diner and a Chinese restaurant.
Don't plan on a return visit that I do know.

I've been here a handful of times and no doubt, this place is always packed!  Service is fast, food comes quick, and prices are fair, definitely one of the more popular places in Chinatown.  However, it has become more of a tourist spot rather than a locals eatery so it has slightly lost some of it's luster.  

Don't get me wrong, their XLBs (xiao long bao) were good, but I cannot say they're great.  We had 2 orders of the pork + 1 order of the crab and without a doubt, the pork one was definitely tastier.  Each dumpling was juicy and filled with great pork flavor.  However, the crab ones were a bit disappointing.  We found them too salty and seafood tasting.  Overall, I still prefer the XLBs from DTF better (hands down, probably still my favorite dumpling house).   

Aside from their XLBs, I found their green onion pancakes + Shanghai fried flat noodle to be rather tasty.  Both definitely had some great "wok" flavors...very authentic indeed.  

Come early or be prepared to wait!

This place is a little out of the way from the subway. I took the 6 train to canal street but ending up having to walk all the way through chinatown for 10 or so minutes. And it is COLD (19 degrees and WIND). :(

But my friend and I were REALLY craving those soup dumplings. Just an FYI - for those who may be confused as I was - the soup dumplings are actually listed as Pork Steamed Buns on their menu. But everyone here refers to them as soup dumplings and so do the servers at the restaurant. I had to double check with him to make sure they were the same thing. 

Pretty much the first thing they ask you when you sit down is if you want the "soup dumplings." Which we got a tray of and they were ozzing with liquids... YUM! No matter how carefully I bit into the dumplings, the liquids squirted all over my shirt and pants. So probably not a FIRST DATE spot...

I also ordered the Beef Tendon Noodle soup and I was yearning for something HOT after the cold walk. The noodle soup was disappointing as it was not very favorable and the beef tendons were very tough and didn't taste fresh. But I guess I can't expect too much if the dish costs 5.95. 

They do add automatic 15% gratuity on the check and ONLY TAKE CASH so be prepared!!

My first visit to NYC and through my brother's research on Yelp, it made it on our list of "must eats" while there.  Before I start on the slightly above average food, I must warn the clean freaks and germaphobes.  This might not be the place for you.  It's on the uncleanly side, has a kind of bearable stench to it and bathroom was completely filthy with urine covered floor decor, dirty walls and the stench in there moves over to the unbearable side.    

And now to the food.  The famous soup dumplings were good.  I've had soup dumplings before and have had better.  We had both the crab and the pork.  I thought the pork was much better.  The crab had a slight fishy, unfresh smell and taste to it.  Not overwhelming by any means.  We had the Singapore Noodles, House Special fried rice (forgot the name), Shanghai flat noodles (fried) and they were all excellent.  We had some other protein dishes that were good.  My only complaint would be the steamed fish we had.  It tasted very fishy.  That usually tells me it's not fresh.  I couldn't tell if it would have been good because the fishiness (I think that's a word) was overpowering, especially in a steaming preparation where the flavors are mild.

Service was ok, but the hostess was rude and horrible.  We had a table of 12 and were told 10 minutes and it was well over an hour.  It was totally a scene out of the Seinfeld Chinese Restaurant episode.  They were seating people out of order and when we tried to get the hostess to ask her about our table, she would flat out ignore us as if she didn't speak a word of english (not racist because I'm asian too and so is my wife and friends that were waiting with me... plus she did speak perfect english).  But overall, food was good.

I think the 5 stars is a scam horrible food horrible service c on the cleanliness the ginger chicken was bland the dumplings were without flavor I have had much better dumplings in smaller lesser rated places

Meh.  Nothing special.  The soup dumplings were thick and chewy and very awkward to eat.  The ratio of meat to broth was off (too heavy on the meat in my opinion).  I like a smaller soup dumpling (like Yank Sing in SF).  Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings don't even come close to the deliciousness and perfection of their Yank Sing brethren.  Oh and to top it off the last dumpling that my husband bit into was garnished with a loooong black hair.  I'm a blonde.  Check please!

The only worthwhile thing to order here are the dumplings.  Everything else was disappointing:

[[ Peking Style Minced Pork Noodle ]] - According to the Chinese characters on the menu, this is "zha jiang mian", which is a Northern Chinese dish of ground pork with black bean paste.  Koreans even have a version of this black bean noodle.  It's so popular in Korean culture that they even have an 'instant' version of this: Chapagetti, which is pretty darn spot-on to the Chinese & Korean version of this.  Anyway, the point of all of this is that I love this dish when it's prepared right.  It was NOT prepared correctly here at all.  I don't even think there was pork in this dish.  There was a lot of finely diced firm tofu, but where was the pork...??

[[ Mapo tofu ]] - Also another unauthentic dish.  The flavor was not bad, but it was definitely lacking any spice at all.  It just was NOT mapo tofu.  The pork was also very minimal in this dish as well. 

[[ Xiao long bao ]] - The infamous Shanghai "soup" dumplings.  Yes.  They really are that good.  The skin is perfect: thin enough so that you don't feel overwhelmed by skin, but thick enough so that the broth doesn't spill out.  The broth was flavorful and plentiful, not too salty.  I would recommend getting the pork buns and NOT the crab ones.  It's not worth the extra $.  To me, the crab/pork mixture tasted kinda weird.  To my tablemates, they couldn't even tell that there was crab in them.  Additionally, it seemed that for whatever reason, the crab/pork dumplings seemed to have less broth in them.  

Overall the dumplings get 5/5 stars.  The other two dishes get 2/5 stars.  (I guess you get sub-par Chinese food when 90% of the customers are non-Asian.)  The service was alright, and our group of 4 got seated right away on a Monday night, so no complaints there.  You will get seated with strangers at a table, and they don't take credit cards at all (no matter how much you spend), which seems a little shady/antiquated to me, but hey, this is Chinatown, and they've got no shortage of business.

Food - Meh. 
Service - Eek!

Xiao Long Bao aka soup dumplings are huge and fatty. They tasted alright.  The pork fried noodles are okay.

We had really wanted another type of noodle but the waiter pretended not to understand us and really couldn't be bothered with us for longer than 20 seconds.  If he hadn't made us feel dumb we would have ordered more dishes and beer.

I will never take Din Tai Fung for granted.

I went here years ago --- when it was good. I don't think it's up to par anymore. The soup dumplings are os os (I had better). In my opinion, so don't rip on me, I believer there are other places that make it a bit better --- quality-wise. Joe Shanghai is officially a tourist spot --- in my book. Services are crap-tac-u-lar and a heads up --- the tips are included in the meal. Meh. Eh. Blah. Boo.

NOTICE TO ALL NEW people's who never been here : BEWARE DO NOT come here. I saw the review over 4K and 4+ or so Star figure it should be a good place .... NOT!!!!! Extremely disappointed and NOT happy. I Don't know why the life of me it even have customers only possible reason is cause the LIE Fake review they have for this place. 
Con: 
Rated C By the food and health department 
1: YOU have to share table with other people's 
2: RUDE disrespectful service you talk to them and they ignored you and rush you to eat and pay and get out. 
3: TIPS is NOT an option they charge you automatically on your bill don't matter your party and still expect to get more after you pay the bills with the tip that they already Added automatically on your bills and try to cheat you.
