4: RUDE , Disrespectful, Horrible Service, watch Your Bills or you will get cheated. 
Food wise it not worth it. Fried rice is plain tasteless fried pork chop is dry and plain no taste. Overall their food isn't anything worthwhile or good. Their dumplings which was all the hyped review is NOT worth the attitude and service YOU get from them. So Beware People's DO Not come here !!! Do not give them your business!!!

Had dinner at Joe's Shanghai on Saturday night. A shorter wait without our number being skipped, and a more refined order would have left me happier with the results.

Quality: They are known for their soup dumplings and they lived up to the hype. I thought the Crab Meat Soup Dumplings were superior to the Pork Meat Soup Dumplings, but both were delicious. The Pork Fried Dumplings were also great and should be ordered. I was not a fan for the thick and doughy Scallion Pancake. I also could have skipped the General Tso's Chicken, it was fine, but not one of the better iterations I have had. The Chicken Fried Rice was bad, bland, terrible rice, and the chicken was sad. The Crispy Shredded Beef was the only larger dish we ordered that I was excited about, the texture is unique and the flavor is wonderful.
Quantity: Large portions, order less than you need or expect lots of leftovers.
Value: $7 for a Scallion Pancake. $14 for Crab Meat Soup Dumplings. $12 for Pork Meat Soup Dumplings. $12 for Pork Fried Dumplings. $23 for General Tso's Chicken. $23 for Crispy Shredded Beef. $15 for Chicken Fried Rice.
Ambiance: Joe's Shanghai is located in Chinatown. The space is large, but very simple. There is little decor, a few paintings and pictures, however nothing that seems like it was purposely designed. The place is filled with tables, which are ready to be turned over quickly. Staff will hover when they realize you are done to get everything cleared and the next guests in. They kept the doors ajar, which meant a cold restaurant after a cold wait outside.
Crowd: No reservations and crowds will gather. Expect over an hour wait during primetime.
Service: The number system for a table is terrible, and we had to inquire after it became clear they skipped over us. Things move fast when you sit down.
Parking: Tough street parking, but lots of trains nearby.

For the best xiaolongbao (soup dumplings) in NYC, head over to Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown.  These tasty morsels will keep you coming back to this hole-in-the-wall where famous not-so regular Joe still takes your order.
$

Dumplings is 5 star delicious. But since I'm reviewing the restaurant as a whole I would say this is at best a 3 star. First of all, they make you share tables! You will not get your own table if you are in groups of 2 or 3. I find that kind of tacky but they have long lines all the time so they don't care if you leave. The food was very good. Had the kung pao chicken and also lots of dumplings and yu choy. I think the presentation of the restaurant and cleaniness can be improved. They only care about making money and the best way is to fill every seat in the restaurant!

Wow, I really don't understand the hype. Using shanghai cafe as a direct comparison, I left feeling sorry for the couple that were forced to sit at a large round table with us. They were told to come here from the recommendation of Lonely Planet. These tourists were from the UK. After trying some XLBs, they sheepishly asked us why for such a popular place the dumplings were so disappointing. In fact, their poor experience only validated the authenticity of the restaurants they frequent. 

We were equally disappointed. Our waiter had a weird habit of stopping by the table right as your seated to insist you order dumplings. It's a bit uncomfortable considering we hadn't even gotten our jackets off and barely had time to open the menu. Nevertheless we came here specifically to try the dumplings so we weren't phased. The dumplings are larger than others but that doesn't make up for the sad state of soup on the inside. It's thick and dark, as if the soup sat too long and started congealing. We were planning to order two but thankfully we stopped short. 

We also decided to try the salt and pepper pork chops. This is a simple enough dish but they couldn't even get that right.

Don't fall for this tourist trap.

Dec '12 Health Score - B

A typical Chinese eatery, that has become famous for its soup dumplings. There's lines of people out the door, and it's a cash only establishment.

While the soup dumplings are pretty good, the main thing is that they're cheap! $7 gets you 8 soupy dumps. Now I'm no mathematician, but i make that 0.87c a dumpling, which isn't half bad. 

The rest of the food is relatively standard for what you'd expect for a chinese restaurant - it includes all the staples such as general Tso's, black bean etc. 

The place doesn't take reservations, so if you come with a group, chances are you're in for a wait! As I say, the dumplings are good, but it's only 3 stars for me because I don't think the dumplings are so good that it's worth the wait. I'd much recommend going to Jing Fong (which again, has decent soup dumplings for the price, but probably no wait).

I'm a pretty big fan of shanghainese food and xiao long bao, but this place sucked big time. 

The beef pan fried noodles sucked. The sauce was overly salted, but yet there wasn't enough to spread onto the noodles.

The shanghai lo mein sucked really bad. It was bland... almost as bad as my moms cooking on a bad day. It was just bad... Nothing special.

The xiao long bao's were nothing special either.

Three calls to get water.

Originally I wanted to go to Shanghai Manor a few blocks away but I ended up eating here cause they close early. It definitely does not compare. Obviously you could tell most Asians would not eat here, their audience is mainly white people, some doing late night take out, others being tourist. Do yourself a favor and eat some actual good shanghainese food, seriously.
Dumping was amazing and really good.  I ordered fish dish too take a bit long. But ok.  I did not like service  waiter not care customer any more

Good XLB (soup dumplings) with lots of soup and flavors. Not overly sweet like most places but be ready for a long wait and share table with strangers. Packed and loud like most Chinese places. Good for the price but a little over rated in my opinion.

Cash only! Hope y'all don't mind sharing tables!

Joe's Shanghai was recommended to me by pretty much everyone when it came to visting Chinatown in NYC. Upon arrival, there was a short 15 minute wait, typical of lunch time in many Chinese restaurants, especially on the weekends. 

Apparently Joe's is known for their dumplings, as evidenced by dumpling cages (those bamboo baskets used to steam dumplings) on everyone's table. So following suit, we ordered the same. 8 good sized dumplings, the size of those noodle soup spoons for roughly $6 was a pretty good deal. In addition we ordered beef noodle soup and crispy pork chops with salt and pepper. 

For two we spent just about $30 for lunch. The restaurant's turnover was quick, so don't be afraid of the line. The food was good, but I was a little disappointed because nothing really popped out at me. I've had a lot of chinese food and unfortunately, Joe's Shanghai was just another chinese restaurant. The great thing however, was that we shared tables with other customers which gave us an opportunity to mingle with New Yorkers and other visitors. 

Overall Joe's Shanghai was a great deal for lunch (for 2) and provided the right ambiance and experience when visiting Chinatown in NYC.

The place here is pretty big. Took two stars off because the service was terrible, not that I was expecting amazing service in chinatown and all the plates, cups were really dirty. Make sure to watch your bill too because they will charge you more than what you got. The food itself was decent:

Singapore Mein Fun: was better than a lot of the places I have been too. I think I like this the most. The noodle was really flavor and not to spicy.

Pork & Crab Dumpling: I think shanghai manner's soup dumpling is way better. The skin is really thick, but the soup dumpling was big. There isn't a lot of soup in the dumpling either. I probably would not get this here

Spring Roll: Very oily and is not good. Taste frozen.

Hot & Sour Soup: The flavor was really good, but they add weird stuff to it. Like pork blood and intestines. 

Probably wouldn't come back because of how dirty the plates were. If you can't even wash your plates and cup, do you even clean anything in the kitchen?

So my boyfriend had been raving about this place for so long before actually coming here, and we finally had the chance to come here during a trip to New York with a buddy.. Although the food was okay, the customer service was absolutely horrible. We each ordered one order of dumplings each and after waiting about 30-45 for our food and seeing multiple people around us who came in after got their food before us we finally decided to ask them about our food. My boyfriend then asks our waiter about our order and our waiter is completely rude and just says wait, nothing else. We keep waiting and waiting then after five mins ask someone else and this person just flat us ignores us, then we finally ask this girl at the counter for a manager and eventually get our food and they still forget one of our orders. This place might be great to some but my first impression after hearing so many good things about their food and coming from California absolutely sucked. Maybe they think because they already have so many good reviews they don't need to keep up with their appearance, but they should also realize people from all over the country visit New York and "hot spots" in New York and they should treat every one of their customers with respect, especially if they can't even get an A (they had a B rating). They also include the tip in your tab, so more of a reason to give you really bad quality customer service because there's no way I would've tipped this waiter.

I do not understand the positive reviews. The food has no flavor, including the soup dumplings. Bland food, poor customer service (had to ask 3 times for water to go with our meal). They serve a pot of tea that is so hot it cannot be drank until long after the meal is over. The waiters could not care less about how they treat their customers because they add 15% gratuity to all orders.  The entire experience was a waste of time and money.

Extremely overrated. We're from San Francisco where excellent Chinese Restaurants are a plenty. The dishes were okay, but nothing stood out. Maybe we should have ordered the soup dumplings. We ordered the Fried Sea Bass, Fried Rice, Scallion Pancakes, and Sesame Chicken. Our teenager liked the Sesame Chicken. Everything was edible but nothing stood out. Service was curt, (which we don't mind as long as the food is good) The prices of the dishes don't pair with the overall flavor of the dishes. The ambiance was actually nice  due to the big family groups dining the same time as us. You can hear the subway rumbling by. (Which we liked. It gave the place an interesting vibe. Another group did not) AND they are cash only. There's a BofA close by and they have an ATM. Their bathrooms were clean.

Beware if you're coming here that you are okay with waiting because this place is PACKED.  They do have famous soup dumplings so there are a lot of tourist.  A lot of there tables are huge so be prepared to share tables with people. you will not really have much table space. I think for people who are not expecting this, the sharing table experience can be awful.  It is so fast paced there.  If you're looking for good service, this is not the place to come.  Only come here if you really really really want soup dumplings.  They are actually extremely delicious! If it's just chinese food you''re craving then go somewhere else and avoid the wait. It is definitely not my scene. It is too rowdy but if I'm craving dumplings I might have to stop in.

Hmmm ive been here a few times in the past, usually a long wait esp popular with non-Chinese,  would have given it 3 stars except my last experience was just not good...

We ordered 2 steamed pork soup dumplings (one w. crabmeat).. very dry
hot & sour soap.. too thick and barely warm
rice cake.. GREASY
service.. well first bowl was not clean.. second bowl was not clean...

Tourist trap! It's overpriced, with a terrible atmosphere and the food is mediocre. The soup dumplings were okay, but that could be because I don't have anything to compare them to. And to top off the whole experience, our waiter was picking his nose while taking our order! I really don't understand the hype. I get better food from my local Chinese take out.

We were tourists, just like anybody else in there, I'm sure. The best thing we got there was the "Pork Xiao Long Bao" otherwise known as dumplings in the basket. My boyfriend and I have been eating the dumplings wrong, because right when we saw other people eat theirs, they used a spoon and put the dumplings on to savour the soup and eat it with the dumplings.

This is how you're supposed to eat the Pork Xiao Long Bao for those who haven't ever tried it.
Step 1: Place the dumpling on your soup spoon.
2: Place it in your mouth or if you can't fit it entirely in your mouth, use your chopsticks and eat half of the dumpling and the juice will come spilling out on your spoon, but that is the good part, so you don't want to waste it!
3: Enjoy the deliciousness! 

The only cons there is the service and seating arrangements.
Service: When you first walk in and are seated, they automatically give you hot tea. I asked for water 4 times from 4 different servers and finally the last server gave me water. Service is terrible and tip is already included into your bill.

Seating arrangements: Luckily for me, I read from other Yelp reviewers that I may be seated with strangers at a table of 10. If I hadn't read that, I'd be freaking out like "why am i seated with strangers? I don't know these people!" We ended up sitting next to 2 other parties on the same table. Kinda awkward since you can't have a private conversation with the person you're with without being heard from others. Luckily I speak a 2nd language that nobody on my table speak. haha.

I'm not going to lie, I went in with very high expectations. I was wondering around Chinatown in NYC for the first time this past Sunday and passed by a huge line of people and I wanted to know what they were waiting for. 

Low and behold it was Joe's Shanghai. The place that everyone, including myself, have wanted to go for a long time. The line was too long so I went back on Monday when it opened. No one was in line and it was glorious. 

I walk in sit down and order the green onion pancake (a classic) and the crab meat filled dumpling. The service was pretty slow. It took me a while to get the attention of any waiter, it seemed like they were training a few of them. 

When the green onion pancake came, I was somewhat disappointed. It was a bit doughy in the middle but wasn't super crisp on the outside. I was even more disappointed with the soup dumpling. There was barely any soup in it. Even when one broke over the bamboo steamer it comes in, almost no soup came out. 

Maybe I came on an off day, but after talking to my local NYC friends, they said Joe's Shanghai is decent, but not great.
Good food. I can't wait to go back to NYC again as I will make sure this is on my itinerary. An added bonus we met great people at our communal table.

I was pretty disappointed during my experience. I'm here on vacation from Miami, & came here because all of the reviews and the 4 stars.

First things first....community seating. Myself and the company with me, waited 30 minutes to get our own table, which by the way, the staff made us wait outside in the rain until our table was ready. 

Let's talk about food. The dumplings were alright, nothing crazy. I had sesame chicken which was a bit pink AND, it was just the chicken...no rice, which I thought was odd. Food wasn't that great, the only thing we liked was the tea and the orange slices that they automatically serve.

Not returning.

Joe's is a Chinatown favorite and a go-to restaurant for a lot of New Yorkers and tourists alike. The soup dumplings are really good and perhaps the main reason why anyone should go here. Other entrees are good too, not great or standing out but not bad. My qualm is that all the soup dumplings contain pork. They don't have any with chicken beef or just seafood.

Joe's was SO disappointing!  I was surprised my foodie friends said that was their favorite and comparable to Din Tai Fung in Arcadia, CA.  I don't mind the location; I don't mind the lines; I don't mind sharing a table with strangers.  I DO mind flavorless, oily soup dumplings.

The skin was thicker than I'd have liked.  The soup inside was more fat than broth and the meat was forgettable.  Ok, I'm ragging on their dumplings, which was disappointing after all the hype, but the other food was pretty good.  The hot and sour soup wasn't bad.  The pan friend potstickers were meh.  The beef noodle soup was AWESOME as are the cold sesame noodles, which had the perfect "bouncy" texture when you chew it.

The prices are also something to rave about.  Between 5 of us, we ordered 5 baskets of XLB, 1 crab XLB, hot and sour soup, beef noodles, sesame noodles,  and pot stickers for a grand total of around $80 including tax.

Overall, I'm glad they weren't that good since NY is much farther than a simple 6 hr drive to Din Tai Fung in LA for me. ;)

I have now come to the decision that Joe's Shanghai is inedible. There's so much fat in the soup, it's disgusting. We also ordered green beans and they were really thick, almost as thick as asparagus. I can not come back here again. Not even for visiting friends.

I'm a sucker for hype...I need to know if it is true

The soup dumplings are good, at least four stars for the price...

However, two main issues: the server forgot my beer twice, and the place needs to be ventilated so it is not so sour smelling.

The pancake was excellent, but that's not hard to make 

The jelly fish was like bland fresh seaweed 

Wine chicken reminded me of good Hainan chicken(minus the garlic)...steamed, cold, juicy.

3.5 stars: their soup dumplings are okay, nothing spectacular. The first review I read was a huge turnoff - sanitation of the restaurant is a C. But what should we be expecting from a Chinese restaurant, right? 

Onto their soup dumplings... it's just regular soup dumplings. The skin is not as rigid or dry as other soup dumplings I've tried before which deserves a thumbs up. The crab soup dumplings were pretty fishy and the regular pork soup dumplings tasted mediocre. 

Along with their soup dumplings, we ordered eggplant and fried dumplings. I don't recommend the eggplant. The exterior was flavorful but when you chewed on it, the garlic flavor was gone and you're left with plain eggplant taste. Fried dumplings are also mediocre. 

Not sure why Joe's Shanghai has over 4k reviews. I'm guessing it was one of the few soup dumpling restaurant to open up back in the days. If you're really in the mood of soup dumplings and want the most of out your money then come here. Otherwise, there are better options.

We went to this place for a company holiday dinner. I my self love Chinese food and get even more excited it the peace is a pretty well know spot. This wasn't something for me to get excited for. The food is ok... not bad or anything just nothing that made me want to come back again and try. If you are in the area check it out but don't make a night of it.

I really liked it here and it was great food but nothing that i went crazy over and need to come back for. The service was also terrible

Steamed buns - these are the soup dumplings. They were really good and fill with a delicious broth (but hard to eat) 

Flat noodles - dont be deceived these are not actually flat, they are lo mein on steroids (really think lo mein). They were solid chinese noodles, but did have much flavor 

Crispy shredded beef - these were like all those little crispy pieces that get left at the bottom of the general tsos box. I loved them!! It was flavorful and crispy yum. We added these to the noodles and it was actually an awesome combination i recommend trying this. 

Kung pao chicken - really flavorful with a ton of peanuts. I added extra chili sauce and it was awesome that way

General tso chicken - it was good, but pretty standard

Crispy spicy prawns in meat sauce - dont be scared by the meat sauce im not really sure what that means but its basically crispy fried shrimp with a spicy thick general tso sauce on top- these were really good as well

Service - we called in advance and asked if it was byo and they said yes. As soon as we got there they said we are not allowed to byo - thats fine but they shouldnt have told us yes on the phone that made me annoyed. They then seemed annoyed at everything we were asking them and like we were a burden to them. At the end, they were staring at us and basically asked us to leave. There are a lot of good chinese places in the city so no need to come back here

My date was really excited to bring me here for the "best dumplings in NYC" and being a fat kid at heart I was excited to try them.  We arrive to a group of people waiting outside for their number to be called.  Turns out you have to get a number, DMV style.  We were told the wait would be about 30 minutes, so we got foot massages across the street.  Came back after half an hour and were told it would be about 35 minutes... seriously?  So no big deal, we walk around go into some shops and return.  Now it's our fault we left when they called our number.  So we stand for about 10 minutes extra and finally get seated at a family round table with a lazy Susan in the center. If only there were a device that would light up or buzz when your table was ready...  Anyhow, ok we are in, great! Except these amazing dumplings all contain pork and that is the one thing I do not eat.  Wtf, really?  So I get some of their non dumpling selections and they seem pretty good, 'not so bad' I think (shudder).The bill arrives and the place is cash-only.  To put the entire experience to bed, walking out the health inspection grade is a B hidden by inner entrance away from all the Zagat highly acclaimed reviews.  Sure enough on the walk to a late night drink my stomach was not happy.  Will NOT return.  NYC is too big to not have better dumplings, and there are definitely better Chinese dishes, plenty of options that will NOT make you sick even better if you hit the outer boroughs like Flushing in Queens.  If you don't have an iron stomach, just pass on this.  You're welcome.
The place was crowded and the food was okay. The only good thing we got were the crab dumplings.

-long lines at peak hours(naturally)
-great crab meat/pork dumplings that explodes with juice
-ate the shanghai noodles there as well which was really good
-be prepared to sit with strangers at a big table to expedite service
-don't expect a long drawn out meal...this place is all about customer turnover

This was my third time here. In the past the food has been phenomenal hence why I've came back. But this time, it wasn't great. The fried rice and scallion pancakes were just as good as I remember. 

However, the soup dumplings (ordered both crabmeat and pork combo and pork soup dumplings) had hard bits of chewy meat. The overall soup component was not very flavorful and required a lot of vinegar, spice, and soy sauce. 

The crispy shredded beef was good but not great- again, lacking flavor dimension. 

The staff is always so nice here & honest about their recommendations on what to order. Food always comes out in a timely manner. It's always really busy so make sure you come and expect a bit of a wait!

Total tourist trap. The signature crab and pork dumplings are ok but definitely not great. The worst part is the MANDATORY service charge on top of which they tried to get away with stealing some extra for themselves but not giving back our change! Don't waste your time unless you are too intimidated to go anywhere else in Chinatown.

A few friends and I went to Joe's this past weekend because we'd heard so much about it over the past year. We ordered up a bunch of dishes and decided to pass them around family style so that we could all share and taste each others' dishes. As expected, the soup dumplings were tasty... and interesting (because I had never had them before). However, most of the rest of what we tried was just okay. The only other stand out was the seafood noodles (not the crunchy ones but the soft ones). These were extra tasty!

As for atmosphere, the place is pretty much a dive. And, be prepared to wait if you wanna hit Joe's. The tourists know about the place, and the come in droves!

Well... a major let down. The place is a total hustle. Their only goal is to get you in and then for you to order as quickly as possible and get the hell out even quicker!! The food was less than tasty... service pretty scrappy... would never go back again.

All those stars on Yelp... have to be a bunch of hired hands dating them highly.

Overrated in everything.  We tried four dishes: the Shanghai noodle bowl, the spring roll, the General Tso's chicken, and Szechuan beef noodle bowl.  The dishes weren't good and were expensive.  The service was bad.  On top of that, they automatically charged 15% on top of our bill and DID NOT give the right change back....they overcharged me $10. BEWARE of this bad practice as they only take cash and there is no proof of deception.

I never had to wait in line because I got here at 11am sharp on a Sunday! We got a table for 4 immediately and already knew what we wanted to order Xiao Long Bao of course!  We tried every soup dumpling there was on the menu and my favorite one was the crab an pork dumplings. I like how these soup dumplings were super juicy and the broth was tasty. Price is VERY reasonable-$6.95! In CALI, they charge $8.95 so we indulged when we came to Joe's! 

Quick Tip: Cash only!

Please eat somewhere else!

We chose to eat here because of the reviews. They seat you at a table with strangers, so it is a very uncomfortable eating situation. Staff ignores you when you say, "Excuse me," when you are asking for help. I asked a hostess for a fork, and she said, "Ask a waiter." I told her they ignore me, and she said, "I'm not a waiter," instead of helping me get a fork! The air of the restaurant makes you feel like the staff is in a hurry to turn tables as quickly as possible without any Importance placed on customer service.

You can get equally as good food at any other place in Chinatown I've been to, and much better customer service and dining accommodations.

When deciding to go to Joe's Shanghai, I think part of the appeal is the dining experience and its reputation.  You enter a bustling restaurant where there's usually a lengthy line of people waiting to get seated, and there's something about being at a place that is in seeming high demand that can make your meal more exciting.  Joe's Shanghai is probably one of the better known restaurants in Chinatown, so be prepared for a wait!

Overall, my most recent meal was just average.  The soup dumplings were definitely the best parts of the meals.  I tried the crab and pork variety, and while I did not taste the crab in the filling, I thought it was a savory delight.  I also tried the pork fried rice and saut√©ed Chinese broccoli, and while I appreciated the freshness of the broccoli, I thought the fried rice was mediocre.  

Would Joe's Shanghai be my go-to destination for Chinese food in NYC? Probably not, but I think it's worth a visit to see what the hype is all about.

Always a long line of mostly tourists but the food is not what it used to be!
Service is hurried and too crazy.
Success has its negative sides.
Only the dumplings are OK.
Oh my god, seriously? Who said this is one of the best Chinese restaurant in NYC? He must never have real Chinese food. All dishes we got are awful. First time eating here, and last time too.

I love the juice buns that explode in your mouth.

But its not worth the wait (there are usually long lines just when I feel like having an explosion in my mouth!)....

Also, they are now way over-priced.  

When they first opened they were way above average.  Now, its an overrated tourist attraction.

Guess I'll be going on the mouth-exploding dumpling quest elsewhere.

Planning my trip to NYC, everyone's suggestion was to try Joe's Shanghai. My friend and I went on a Saturday and this place was packed. We got there around 12ish and didn't get seated till almost 1pm for two people. This place is small and cramped. When our number finally got called we had to wait another 8 minute to get sat. The way they seat people is also very interesting. A group can be sat together with other parties at a round table. Fortunately, my friend and I got our own table right next to the "drink bar". It was not the best location and very cramped. We were so close to the table next to us, that we felt we were eating with them. The worst part about our table, was that we could see how they handled the drinks and noticed they aren't very clean. Btw, they did have a letter "B" in their window. We ignored it due to the many recommendation. The staff worked like a machine. They just turned tables over and over. It was a typical Chinese restaurant where they did not communicate well and just in a rush. 
We ordered the typical Pork soup dumpling and I then learned why it was such a popular suggestion. They are pretty big and very soupy. The wrapper was was soft and the soup just the right amount of flavor. My favorite part of eating the soup dumpling was the dipping sauce. It brought the flavor to a new level with a little bit of tart and sourness. Along with the dumplings we order salt and pepper pork chops. For two people we were full after eating the dumplings and the portions for the pork chops was a lot. The pork chop was okay for me. I have better. It was a little on the saltier side and the breading wasn't crispy enough for me. The dipping sauce they provide is sweet and sour sauce. I preferred dipping it in the soy/vinegar sauce that they use for the dumpling. We ordered two portions of rice. If you are not a big rice eater, one portion is way more than enough for two people. 
After this experience, I don't really know if I will be back. If i do decide to come back, it will probably be for take out and only the soup dumplings. It is definitely an experience. The pricing were also reasonable since it is family style.

Soup dumplings are delicious! Not as good as Din Tai Fung but not too shabby. 
Green beans were really good, almost like finger food that we couldn't stop popping.  Green onion pancake was crispy,  thicker and breaded. Pretty delicious. 
The service is quick.
Overhyped IMO- got the soup dumplings and the sweet and sour soup. The sweet and sour soup had a strong vinegary taste while the soup dumplings were better tasting

I think this will be my last visit to Joes. The skin of the soup dumplings are thinner and theres a lot of soup... only plus. Do not try the pan fried noodles! The noodles look and taste like styrofoam and the sauce makes it worse.

The food really does live up to the fame. However, the service is always the downfall. They pack the restaurant where it is simply uncomfortable to sit. There is no room and I always fear things being spilled on me. The worst experience was when I was with a group of friends, and the waiter kept leaning on my friend's chair when he was waiting around. When we finished our meal and he was bringing out the oranges, he spilled juice down my friend's back. If you want good Shanghai food, this is the place to go, but be warned that it is extremely crowded, noisy, and the service may be lousy. For me, I prefer going down the block to Joe's Ginger. Relatively the same without the cramped space.

We were not fans of this place at all. It's a dank restaurant in Chinatown, except there's a lot of hype about the food, which I don't understand at all. 

We had the soup dumplings, the fried noodle dish, shrimp fried rice, and what was supposed to be this rice noodle stir fry dish (it turned out to be egg noodles). Everything tasted fine but was so overly greasy that I had a film of grease outside of my mouth. After biting into a soup dumpling, I had a mouthful of pork grease. Service was terrible, and we had to ask for water a couple of times. 

There prices weren't great, the food wasn't good, and the service was awful. Definitely not worth going out of your way for.

If Joe's Shanghai represents the quintessential East Coast xiao long bao restaurant, then I would definitely give the award to Din Tai Fung on the West Coast. 

Why, you ask?

Granted that Joe's xiao long baos are larger, however

- The dumpling skin was too thick
- Soup inside the dumpling tasted like it had MSG or was a bit salty
- After being uncovered for 5-10 mins, the dumpling skin became rubbery and the soup congealed...ewww

All of this makes for a bad dumpling. 

We also had the onion pancake which was OK and the lion's head meatballs were decent, although too large too finish.

Next time in New York, I'd like to travel to Brooklyn to try The Good Fork's dumplings as seen on "Throwdown with Bobby Flay".
The soup dumplings are great (but only the pork), and everything else is sub-par. Have been twice, and that's once too much.

Pretty decent soup dumplings! 

Pretty much always a wait and it's filled with tourists. You sit family style, round table with strangers unless you have a full party to fill a table. 

The rest of the food is OK. It's not expensive and there are a few good bars not too far away. (Apotheke - speakeasy)

FLIES IN THE FOOD. I used to frequent Joe's Shanghai over 4 years ago but this location suffers from quality and service. In the past, it was fine that the service was awful since the food was good but I waited over an hour and a half, like many others on Pell street, for soup dumplings with little to no soup in them. Go somewhere else, service is awful and they weren't apologetic at all when they moved the fly around and spread its wings in my bok choy. Yaso Tangbao in BK is much better with solid xiao long bao.

We stood in line for 45 minutes to be seated. We read the reviews and were very excited about this place but let's just say we've had much better food in Chinatown. Scallion pancakes were delicious, but pork dumpling soup was dry on the outside and bland on the inside. Pecking duck was our biggest disappointment. More than half of it was just fat. We didn't even eat a third of it. Unfortunately, I don't recommend this place.

The Great: 
- Great for big groups. We came here with a table of 14 and were able to order a ton of food and each ended up paying around $25. 
- The scallion pancakes are amazing
- Crispy chicken

The OK/good: 
- soup dumplings - a little too big, but generally good. Could have more of the meat flavor. I crave soup dumplings, but not necessarily Joe's. 

The bad:
- a little dirty. But..hey...it is New York.

Meh...that's my vote. It's def not 4-5 star worthy and more akin to a tourist trap. Famous soup dumplings had good soup, but meat wasn't the freshest I've ever had. The skin was more doughy than should be and not the lighter consistency it should be. Hot and sour soup came out cold, had to be reheated via microwave. So overall, very average and you might as well go to any other Shanghainese place in Chinatown without the long wait. My only consolation is that we didn't wait for seats cause we came midweek.

Food was mediocre and our waiters were not very nice. Don't order the shredded pork noodle-- that was bad. Crispy duck was too salty. I liked the dumplings and pan fried noodles though. Overall, I did not really enjoy it here even though I love Chinese food.

Overall, just had a pretty awful meal here. The soup dumplings are pretty good (by no means best in NYC, although certainly solid) but the rest of the food is BAD -- greasy, gloppy, americanized Chinese food. Everything we ordered had the same, one-note, brown-sauce flavor. In a city (and a neighborhood) filled with such amazing food, I'm shocked to see such an overwhelming amount of positive reviews for this incredibly mediocre restaurant. You're so much better going to a place like Tasty Hand-Pulled Noodles for this kind of food, or a dim sum hall like Jing Fong for spectacular Chinese. Finally, I'd like to note that this place is cash-only (which is bullshit) and overpriced, too.

Point being: Don't go here.

Soup dumplings were really good. Everything else was meh. Restaurant is small, but that's typical in new York.  We came on a day that was pouring raining and the place was still packed. Lucky for us, the wait for a table was only five minutes (probably bc there was only two of US). We shared a table with two other couples.
I was expecting more considering the reviews . It is a touristic place , food is not bad but the overall atmosfere is too noise
We ate here and it wasn't worth all the hype. We waited for over hour and the dumplings were alright. It was to bready and not enough flavor. I definitely think there are other better places in NY.

This place is so hyped up but I didn't really find it to be that great. 
There was a line of people before it opened and I'm trying to figure out why. 

The dumplings were not sturdy, some of them had holes when they were brought out. They stuck to the steamer despite the layer of lettuce underneath. They fell apart on contact with chopsticks. I saw many old Asian folks and none of them had dumplings on their table. 
The scallion pancakes were doughy and nothing special at all. 
The pork dumplings (or pork buns as written on the menu) were better than the pork and crab ones. 
Points for having water spinach because my friend tells me they don't usually even have it in restaurants because it's a hassle to prepare for cooking. 

Just a Note: 
The hostess's wear white,
The busser's wear yellow,
The waiters wear red, 
and the higher ups wear green.
No one is friendly and no one smiles.

It seems that majority of the time you have to share a table with complete strangers which depending on your personality is horrific or a cool opportunity. 

The music was all over the place jumping from authentic oriental sounds to mainstream Chinese music to the backstreet boys to Celine Dion to club music. 

Aim the words of another customer I met standing in line, you go in and they basically want you done and out right away. It's not a place to sit and eat and socialize, just consume the food and bounce.

If you have dumpling cravings this place will satisfy it but don't go in expecting something phenomenal because it will fall short.  It's a fine place to visit if you're in the area but certainly don't travel out of your way for it!

If you have never been to Shanghai, China then Joe's Shanghai is pretty alright. But for anyone that has traveled abroad and tasted the real deal, Joe's is a complete let down.

The "Xiao Long Bao" that Joe serves is what they actually call "Tan Bao" which translates to soup dumpling. Xiao Long Bao in essense is a fraction of the size of the soup dumplings that Joe serves to consumers.

With that out of the way. The actual taste of the 'soup dumplings" is mediocre at best. 1) the skin should be tender, almost the texture of soup wonton wraps, smooth. Joe does not deliver, the skin is tough and texture is rough. 2) the inside should not be overly flavored, the taste of the soup inside should be clean, clear, and resembles a good pork broth. Joe again does not deliver, the soup is a bit oily and overly flavored with other ingredients. Another negative is the color of the soup.

All in all, advertising the product as Xiao Long Bao's is a misrepresentation of what it actually is, soup dumplings (translated). 

Oh yea, I won't even speak about the rest of the menu, the crowded uncomfortable atmosphere, and rude wait staff.

P.S. Din Tai Fung might be an alternative to Joe's Shanghai, but even that place doesn't come close to the real deal.

Mmm... don't know what to say about Joe's Shanghai. I'm not sure why but Joe's Shanghai is one of the most popular Shanghainese restaurants in NYC. Perhaps the media attention (Zagat, food magazines, etc.), but I don't think it's all it's hyped up to be.

They're almost always busy and their service isn't great. 
Their xiao long baos (soup dumplings) aren't really crazy great either. They were actually quite dried out with little soup last time I had them. Prices are okay. 

To be honest I'd rather go around the corner and up the block where I won't have to wait an hour for a table and be served hot fresh soup dumplings, quick too!

Overrated, overpriced, overpacked, over-rude, and over a dirty and busy street!

Seriously, this place is considered one of the best in town?? For what??
Many starts ate there? Cool, they probably haven't be treated as we did, and maybe they received some special dishes form the kitchen.

I love Chinese food and Chinese culture, but the manners is this restaurants should be upgraded to a civilized American restaurant

This place is totally way too hyped and it is not worth the long inefficient wait. 
Their famous soup dumplings have thicker dough than usual soup dumplings and other dishes are just meh.
I know that NYC has so many overrated places because of the tourists who is not very experienced with different cuisines and this place is one of them.
I definitely had better soup dumplings and Chinese dishes at other places. 
You also get to sit with bunch of different strangers and you never get to leave the line for 2 hours because they will just pass you if you are not there. Not to mention, they just automatically charge you a service fee.
Not the best meat dumplings in chinatown. A little disappointed with the food. Service is just ok. I don't understand why there are always lots of people waiting for a seat.

Looked good and sounded good but got to tell you, only average.  
Dumplings were good when hot and huge. Order the appetizer and that is your entire meal... But not you have to like pork (the only option is yes pork)
Shrimp and scallop in garlic were excellent.  Truly the BEST item here 
Kung Pao Chicken. Terrible.  Over cooked and boring flavor. Very disappointing 
Cold Sesame Noodles ... Yes these were good and order again
Note.... Very loud restaurant. Do not come for a quite dinner and be prepared to share. Table and waiters climb all over you to set or clear the table. No personal room at all!
Overall. I would be back.  Came once. Been there, done that.  Moving on
Ps. Rice is not included

I actually love the area where this place is nestled in. it kinda has an old school china town back ally sketchy kinda feel to it. its one of those streets that if it was late at night and you saw no one on it.... and the fastest way to get to your house was through this street... you would much rather take the farther route of climbing a steep mountain barefoot with no rope and/or water 

Now to the food. the soup dumplings are quite small and the dumpling is just overly gummy not to mention by the time you get the dumplings... its pretty much dried out and the soup is left to basically droplets. what you say... "Youre Crazy!!!".... been here 3 times... not my choice to go but its been the same each time.

One of the more famous soup dumpling places in New York, not a bad choice if you don't have time to venture all the way out to Flushing. The xiaolongbao are slightly larger and has thicker skin than the ones I am used to from Din Tai Fung, but they are very popular. The clientele is mostly non-Chinese and there seems to be a lot of tourists (it is Manhattan after all). The food is average Chinese restaurant fare, not bad but not terrific in my standards. Would I eat it? yes. Would I stand in line for it again? no. If you want to eat at Joe's Shanghai I'd rather go to the midtown location which has more tables and is a bit nicer--the food is comparable.

3.5 stars. Visited for the first time this summer, mainly because of the soup dumplings (xiao long bao). There are 2 varieties to choose from, pork and crab meat. The XLB here are massive. Probably double in size in comparison to any of the others I have tried. The pork XLB were delicious and finished quickly. My group did not enjoy the crab meat XLB however. The crab meat itself was good but the soup inside these dumplings were a seafood broth which was not that enjoyable. The next time I'd definitely get multiple orders of the pork XLB. 

The other dishes we had were standard fare - chicken fried rice, stir fried beef with green peppers, all were tasty and came in large, filling portions. 

Came here on a Saturday for lunch and although there was a line, it took about 15-20 minutes to seat a group of 4. Will return for more XLB!

Have you ever walked into a restaurant already knowing that you're not going to like it? Yeah that was how I felt when I walked into Joe's Shanghai...But, because I'm a sucker for popular/trendy food places and this place is the most reviewed restaurant in Chinatown, I knew I would eventually make my way here. As soon as my group of 3 walked in, we were (not) greeted by an inattentive server and Justin Beiber being blasted on Z100. This is not, by any means, an authentic Shanghainese restaurant and you can tell because the majority of the clientele are not Asian. Because it was a rainy day, we had no problem getting seated but I have heard that there can be a line out the door on better days. Service, for the most part was meh but there was one server who was more attentive.

Scallion pancakes- Flavor was alright but it was too greasy and not crispy enough. For good scallion pancakes try the ones with beef at Nan Xiang in Flushing.
Pork soup dumplings- How is it even possible for people to say that these are the best soup dumplings in NYC?? The skins were so thick, the soup was bland AF, and the pork had impurities in it...
Chicken pan fried noodles- ALL WRONG. I honestly don't even know what they served us but they were definitely not pan fried noodles...The noodles were completely off and the sauce on top tasted like Chinese take out sauce...Skip this one and try the one at Shanghai Cafe instead.

There are a ton of Shanghainese restaurants in Chinatown that are better than this one. This one happens to be the most popular because it caters to a broader population of diners, not because the food is good. Well, I can finally mark Joe's Shanghai as "attended" in my books but I will definitely not be back.

First of all dont get spooked with my 3 stars, i still want yall to try this place. The food is good, real authentic as per taste. The szhewan spicy fish is really something you should not miss. It comes with white rice and the fish gravy can be enjoyed with either white rice or fried rice. Both shrimp and spicy fried rice are something worth the money plus the kung pao chicken should not be ignored at all. 
The prices are decent but this is a "Cash Only" spot which was a bummer, but they do have ATM in the premises, i guess extra revenue for the business. For me i am a creditCard guy and carry almost No cash at all, and during this COVID situation i don't even prefer cash exchange so this is something i felt somewhat should be considered by the business.
Now the main reason for 3 stars is their awful service. I bet places with free food would treat you better than this place. No smiles or friendly gesture at all. They will bring the food and as soon you done with the food, they will literally wait till you get out. I felt so pressurized to finish the food and GTFO as they were standing right there with new plates and employee ready to clean our table. So i am giving yall heads up if ya dont get a nice friendly customer service but hey the food is what we really appreciated. You can never change the people unless they want to change. Therefore get the cash, be prepared to race the food consumption and grab some candies on your way out, get both you handful so you feel better.

How can I start?
First of all... it is not expensive. Good prices. No Debit cards, or credit cards come with cash.
Be mentally prepared to sit in a round 10 sits table with other people. Food not that good. We went there because we saw the reviews and everyone was doing a big fuzz specially about the soup balls and the food in general. Not good flavors and the place was super unkempt. Restrooms; they will want to make you cry. Not a clean restaurant.

We came all the way from Texas and expecting to get some good soup dumplings and dumplings. The dough was definitely too thick and just a mediocre restaurant serving "hot & sour" soup and sweet n sour pork for tourists. Dumplings in Houston, TX taste better than this!

WATER IN DUMPLINGS = BAD

Maybe I'm not a connoisseur of Shanghainese cuisine, but where I come from we like to bite into our dumplings and not have a torrent of putrid pork water come gushing out.   I'm sure this is done on purpose, but I wasn't into it.  

I'll take Cantonese dim sum any day.
good food but poor service. Server (Partick) was rude to my friend. My friend asked him for some more rice but he was rude and he said Shit!!

We got here mid afternoon.  There were quite a few people waiting and we were quoted a 15 minute wait time.   We were seated in about 15 minutes so that was great. 

However, it was down hill from there.   While the service was fast it was annoying.   We weren't offered water and when we asked it seemed like it was a big deal to get it.  Ordering was rushed and not pleasant at all.   

Then the food came.   Terrible.   The dumplings were dry and seemed old like they were streamed 3 days ago.   The braised duck was flavorless and also seemed old.   The Singapore noodles were the worst I've ever had.   Dry no seasoning just gross.  I've had better at cheap Vegas buffets. 

I would NEVER come here again and I would NEVER recommend this place to anyone.   Prior accolades do not make a great current restaurant.
I only come here for the pork soup dumplings. Everyone should definitely start with that as an appetizer or even as your meal.
It's OK. It's not Din Tai Fung, in Arcadia

Not sure what the hype is all about....

If you had Ding Tai Fung then you know what I'm talking about. The skin on the dumplings here are TOO THICK. The meat was average. And the soup inside is not as flavorful as DTF's. This place provides a tong to help you remove the dumplings, but I just end up puncturing the darn thing. Better off using your chopsticks.

We also ordered some noodles (forget the name of the dish). It was like as if it was going through an identity crisis... it's semi stir fry noodles but as the same time it was sitting in soup.... Wouldn't recommend.

Honestly the entire meal was not very memorable. Pretty sure I won't be back.

I know this place is really famous for their soup dumplings but honestly they were a little bit disappointing. Maybe it's cuz they were waay overly hyped but it was just not as good as I thought they would be. The dumpling skin is definitely too thick for my taste.The wait to get in is also horrendous. The only thing that saved the meal was the beef noodle soup. That was so so sooo good! But it was also a little lukewarm. If it was hot, ommgg it would've been perfect! Still craving it now T.T Overall tho, the experience was ehh...

Good soup dumplings. Really tasty. The other items don't seem to be great though. 3 stars for the dumplings only. 

2 stars gone for the following reasons :
1. They don't accept cash
2. They are too cramped and forces you to sit with strangers. That's not an American style nor have I seen it anywhere except this place. What are you trying to do? 

I think the soup dumplings can only go so far. You have to keep up with the 'Quality and Ambience' game too. You can't be pulling the authentic card everytime.

We had a bad experience which is related to the trend of Chinese restaurants in New York Chinatown that only accept cash and adding tips amount in the bill. Although it is kind of noted in the restaurants, sometimes mistakes do happen when double tips were made at check out. The waiters knew yet they would not make a polite reminder to the customers. These practices need to improve before too many bad experiences scare away more and more customers.

Now the food at Joe's, they were just OK.

The dumplimg was good but everything else was just okay. It didn't deserve a 5 star especially when you enter the small restaurant the whole place smells like rotton food. That smell does not go away and its not pleasant at all while eating. Also I never like the concept of sharing a table with total strangers.

i only tried the dumplings, which were excellent.  i wouldn't think twice about recommending it to anyone.  it's not a soup.  try to remember that.  it's a dumpling that would normally go in the soup.  at least that's my take on it, but it really was good. i got the crab/pork meat dumpling.  and it was about $7.  about a dollar more than what i'm used to seeing.  but, hey, we all know it's a tourist trap with all those zagat awards.
what sucked was the service.  i went there at about 3p by myself to get my dumplings to go.  at first they gave me an attitude when they thought i was gonna eat in, since i'm not filling the table with more people.  once i told them it's to go, they told me just to wait in the front for my food, where i had the whole waitstaff give me looks like i was in their way every time i passed by.  there was no other place to wait.  the place looked pretty rundown, not unlike most chinese restaurants in the area.
i'd go back again for the dumplings, but i'd order in advance and eat it at home.  i wonder if they deliver?

I don't get the hype for this place. Went at 9:30-10pm and there was a long line, had to wait about 30 mins. The food wasn't good and def not worth waiting for. There's way better Shanghainese food elsewhere....

Pros (soup dumplings, relatively authentic Shanghainese food): Although this place is a well known tourist trap, the fact that Chinese people still go there says a lot about the quality of food they offer. The most popular dish here is the soup dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) by far, and with good reason. Having had authentic Shanghainese food from both Shanghai and Vic's Godfather, we've decided that the Soup Dumplings here are indeed very good. It's different from the ones in Shanghai of course, but you'll still love these burning buns even if you've had them back in motherland. The other dishes are good as well, and they provide quite a balance of both the traditional and americanized chinese food. For a tourist trap, it's not too bad. 

Cons (everything you can imagine to be negative about a tourist trap restaurant in chinatown new york): The lines are long, the tables crowded, and the service rushed. Sometimes the soup dumplings can be made a little too assembly-line like...

Bottom line: You can do a lot worse than to come to this place, but if you're only here for the Soup Dumplings, there are less crowded places that you can go to that will serve up ones just as good. New Yeah's for example. 

Recommendation: Sit down and immediately order the soup dumplings like a pro.

Comparable to: New Yeah's

Since moving to NY I knew I had to compare this to Din Tai Fung and I have to say, Din Tai Fung is still better.

WAIT: Came on a Saturday at 12:50 pm and there was only a 15-20 minute wait for 4 people.  She gives you a number and then calls it when it is your turn.  If your whole group isn't here, she'll skip over you so make sure everyone in your party is present.

ATMOSPHERE: Did anyone else notice the C health rating for this place? It's definitely your typical hole in the wall crowded, loud, Chinese restaurant with lots of round tables.  So if you come in a small group you may be sitting at a large round table with 2-3 other groups.  It's not that weird since the table is large enough.  The service is fast and pretty efficient so no worries there.

FOOD: Got the green onion pancake and 1 order of the XLBs.

GREEN ONION PANCAKE - pretty good, very flavorful.  Some of the green onions are almost saut√©ed giving it a grilled onion taste.  The crispy parts are really good but I did have one that was doughy.  They cut it into 8 or so slices.

PORK XLB - 8 in one basket.  Compared to din tai fung, these are much much bigger and they even give you tongs to pick up the pork dumplings. That signifies that the skin is much thicker and doesn't break easily.  As a result of that, the skin isn't as delicate and chewy or fresh tasting as din tai fung.  I will say however, that the soup inside (there's much more soup) is very flavorful and fatty.  So taste wise, I might have to say Joe's is a hair better than din tai fung.  The other thing that Joe's has going for it are the prices, it's about $7 for the entire basket, so cheap!

CASH ONLY so make sure you bring enough.  

Overall, it was definitely good but I still have to say that din tai fung is better.

For some reason, I'd never actually been to Joe's Shanghai before. Fully embracing the tourist experience, I stopped by for a quick lunch. Because I went at a slightly odd hour, I had absolutely no wait, but the restaurant wasn't exactly empty.

The servers really have this down to a science. After being seated, they come around asking "pork or crab?" since absolutely everyone orders xlb. I opted for crab, but next time, I'd just order the pork. I also got an order of the turnip cake, but honestly, the xlb is plenty filling.

This is definitely a tourist spot, as I looked around and noticed there were almost no Chinese customers. Ah well. A quick, cheap eat in the city is always a nice find.

Came in for dim sum. I should have looked a bit more before I came. It's not so much dim sum style. But really I just cared about soup dumplings!

We got here at 11:30 on a Sunday and they luckily had just enough spots for us at one communal table in the back. Our table was very friendly and everyone shared their main entrees with each other. We all ordered a bit too much. 

The pork soup dumplings were okay. They were nice and large, cooked well, and the dumpling was the perfect thickness. They suggest you pick it up, take a small bite and suck out the broth; then continue to eat the dumpling. This method actually worked pretty well. I was unfortunate enough to have one soup dumpling get stuck to the lettuce in the steamer and it broke before I could bite it, so beware! I had it in the spoon luckily though, so all was okay.  The broth was not as flavorful as I would have liked and have had before. That was what was missing for me. I really appreciated that they gave us a tweezer tool to pick them up though! Nice touch.

The spring rolls were the star here for me. I don't usually care for them and the flavor was spot on, they were huge, and the rolls crust was perfectly crunch and not too greasy. I was surprised how much I liked them. The sauce they gave us to dip them in was also fantastic. 

The pan fried dumplings were nothing special in my opinion. After I ate one I didn't need to have any more. 

Scallion pancake was good. It was a bit larger than ones I had been served elsewhere. Good flavor and not too greasy. 

Pork fried rice, again nothing special. Was missing some flavor. 

Our neighbor offered me a bite of her Chinese eggplant. This was really nice. Good flavor and I enjoyed the sauce it was cooked in. 

When we left there was a line out the door. Glad we made it in just in time. I'll try somewhere else next time for soup dumplings, and will likely go somewhere where they have more actual dim sum options than just large entrees.

I had my eye on Joe's Shanghai since I moved to NYC.  After spending a month in Shanghai before I came here, I missed xiaolongbao (dumplings with soup on the inside).  Someone had mentioned that this was the place in the city to get xiaolongbao.

Luckily, one of my friends planned brunch here this past Sunday.  We were planning on meeting at 12:30pm... but being me, I managed to get there by 1pm.  They wouldn't seat us until the entire party had arrived so I felt bad making my friends wait.  About 15 minutes later, we were seated at a table for 10 where there was another party on the other side of the table.  It wasn't a bad wait at all (at least for me).

We ordered pork xiaolongbao (dumplings are usually with pork meat so get pork!) and my friend ordered a few cold dishes (noodles, drunken chicken, cold beef) and some others (dumplings, scallion pancake, fried buns).  The meal was filling, we could have done without the last couple of dishes we ordered, and it was only $13!  Also, dishes came out surprisingly quickly.  

BUT--I will say that the xiaolongbao were okay.  The top of the dumplings were a bit stiff, but I guess this is the best you can get outside of Shanghai.  For a place that should be all about xiaolongbao (and other Shanghainese dishes), they did about a 3 star job.

Some tips: cash only and a 15% already included, go early to avoid the wait (by the time we left, there were about 4-5 tables of people waiting to get seated)

this place is for tourist.. 
i would not recommend coming here..
i tell you why...

once we got to the door..people already line up & wait..

once the door opens..people rush in to get their seats?

are u serious?

they give everyone table a cup of cold water..
they give us last?
even the menus they gave us last?

what the fk?

i dont like the host or waiter..the seat they give us?
i dont like the tattoo guy waiter with the stup!d hair cut.

i dont like this place..
the service is terrible..

i rather eat some where else.
mcds is 10 times better..

the 1 in flushing queens is better..

dont come here ever again..
0 star for food.
0 stars waiter bad service.

i left after few mins of eating here..
trash trash trash..
dont come here..

if you come here to eat you're a baka..

Not sure why people rave about this place. In short, save your time and money. We are big fans of XLB and Chinese food in general. The XLB "soup dumplings" in this place are absolutely gross. They filling is not tasty, especially the crab (they totally use canned or preserved products). They are greasy and not tasty at all. I saw a few postings saying they have better XLB than Din Tai Fung...Seriously people? Not comparable in anyway. 

Anyway, if you are looking for disgustingly tasting food and TERRIBLE service, be my guest.
Went downhill sometime around 2000 but the guidebooks never updated their reviews so it's possibly the most popular mediocre establishment in Manhattan.

I used to come here with my family for soup dumplings but I don't go anymore due to the long wait from tourists. The service is your traditional fast pace Asian restaurant, where you might find yourself sharing a large round table with strangers. Some might mistake the waiters brusque manners for rudeness but they're just being efficient. Food is still good although Americanized  (ie. A bit saltier and more sauce). As a local, this wouldn't be my first choice to come or bring visitors. I'll probably go to Shanghai cafe if I need to get my soup dumpling fix.

haha! the wait here is ridic!!!!!!!! This place is more for tourist and white people. It can be an hour wait at times. But their soup dumplings is the best. What I don't like is, that sometimes they try to force to leave as quickly as possible so they can sit another party down. I remember having to share a table with other strangers. I did not like that.

The food is mediocre. SERVICE IS HORRIBLE. When I arrived, there were about 30 people waiting outside so I thought I'd be in for a treat if that many people were willing to wait. After being finally seated an hour later, I was eager to taste their famous soup dumplings, given all the great reviews. The soup dumplings were good, but I've had better and I was expecting amazing. As for their wonton soup... My homemade version beats theirs by miles. Decent prices and ok food but definitely not worth the hype. I guess they have a big ego because they treat customers like numbers rather than people. People arriving after me, were seated before me. Even those people apologized to me. I will definitely not be returning. Despite poor service I might have returned if the food lived up to the hype of the plethora of newspaper clippings on their front windows. Obviously, it didn't.
Good soup dumplings. To be honest, not sure I think it's worth the wait because you can get other good soup dumplings elsewhere for no wait.
Busy restaurant we couldn't eat something. Menu was bad for strangers. It's not explanatory.

This place is always packed! People come here for the soup dumplings which are pretty good. I usually get 2 orders of soup dumplings, one order would be pork and the other is crabmeat. I'd recommend their fried rice, fried noodles, and if ure really hungry and not afraid of gettin stuffed--try their rice cakes! When theyre super busy w a long wait outside, i actually go next door to Joes Ginger becos theyre the same restaurant, have the same exact menu. Heard the owner owns both.. So jus incase u didnt kno now u do ;)

Two stars for the scallion pancakes and soup dumplings.

The service was horrible! The waiter literally yelled at my bf for asking a clarifying question. He also NEVER came back after placing our order. We had to track down random servers and even being acknowledged was a hassle. The other waiters were in a group showing each other their cellphone and laughing.

I'm never coming here again. I'll go down the street to Shanghai Manor for better service at a cheaper price !

Came here and we ordered a number of items but I only ate two dishes. Very busy but I find the food wasn't as good as the hype.  The dumplings were good but nothing extraordinary. The beef noodle soup was a major disappointment with tough beef that's chewy and the noodles were just inedible.   Overall, the food is just ok. Nothing to hype about.
Underwhelmed by this place.  There is much better Chinese available without the wait time and the take it or leave it staff.  This is a tourist trap.

Used to be great soup dumplings and I've been coming here for years.  Not so much now.  Lard pours out of the dumpling when opened and they just aren't as good any more.
On my last visit yesterday they're charging a "15% service fee" that's put in there before taxes.  I declined paying that on my LAST VISIT.

Wow, this place has a lot of reviews.  So anyway, I went here with a group of 14 from work for a farewell lunch for our interns.  We ordered food to eat family style and I will definitely say it is inexpensive.  I thought the dumplings (pork, since I don't love crab) were delicious.  The scallion pancakes were just okay.  The sesame chicken hit the spot.  I don't eat squid but my co-workers insisted on ordering that dish because they love it so much.  The eggplant was forgettable.  The mushroom dish was decent but a little too heavy on the soy for my taste.  So maybe I didn't absolutely love this place because of the dishes we ordered and I might like it more if I went with friends and just ordered what sounds good to me.  I probably won't go back though.

wait time was ridiculous and you still had to share a table with strangers. Price was good, cheaper than most places for the xiao long dumplings but the dumpling itself was just ok. Only had to options. Service staff was hard to get a hold of and wasn't so good.
I had to try this place since I had heard so much about the rave...more hype then it should be
I've been waiting for my food for 35 minutes. Terrible service.  They need to hire more people. I so mad I'm waisted my entire lunch break here.   I don't recommend this place

This place was a major disappointment for me. I had high hopes for their XLB because everyone raved about it. Located in the back of the alley in Chinatown. This place only takes cash, came here on a Monday noon and there was no wait at all. Ordered their crab meat xlb, pork xlb, and shredded pork soup noodle. All of the items didn't impress me at all. Wouldn't return, don't know what the hype is about. In my opinion din tai dung xlb is wayyyyyyyyyy better LOL. P.s 15% gratuity is already included in your bill no matter what's the party size. Also service was okay but not great. Don't expect anything because it's in Chinatown.

I've had better -- go to Shanghai Cafe -- for cheaper. 

Don't get what all the noise is about. :/

A bit too much hype, and perhaps I got my hopes up way too high.

Came in at about 1:30pm to an absolutely full house. Since it was just me, I was seated, family style, with two other groups. I ordered the pork soup dumplings and it arrived in a huge bamboo steamer. There really wasn't a lot meat inside of each dumpling, it was mostly soup. And the soup lacked the pizzaz in its flavor. Staff seemed really unhappy, I didn't feel as if I was served well. I wasn't ever offered a drink while I was there. More like cattle calling everyone in and out as fast as they could.
I live in San Francisco and the soup dumplings out there are far better. Our table couldn't even finish the pork soup dumplings. We did enjoy the Shanghai noodles, though.

Was a little disappointed when I went. I had heard a lot about this place and their famous soup dumplings. Honestly, they're just okay and I didn't understand the hype once I took my first bite. My boyfriend looked at me after his first bite and said, "Are you sure these are the ones everyone talks about?" Definitely don't make a trip to NYC just for these. I'm glad we ordered other dishes in addition to the dumpling disappointment or else this place would probably just get 2 stars. Their pan fried noodles were delicious!
Waited over an hour on a Tuesday around noon.  Wait staff was fast and efficient.  XLB were exceptional but the other dishes like rice cakes and eggplant were just average.

lthe food was overly salty and full of msg. it was also extremely oily. Tourist spot in chinatown, there are no asian people goign to the restaurant, that explains a lot! horrible service as well.

Do not go!
Joe's is loud, overcrowded with tourists, and the food is subpar in my opinion. There are far better places like New Green Bo to get "famous" soup dumplings. Joe's = yawn + eye roll.

Um... I like shanghai cafe better. Yes overall it was a little more expensive. I know joe's is more famous and it's really cool to see all the celebrity pics on the wall with joe but I thought the food quality was a little lower here too. Let me explain: the soup dumplings were very very fragile compared to shangcaf. The other dishes had barely any meats in it just all veggies... is that cheap or what. 
They also sat us with other groups of random people. I know space is a limited thing but c'mon man!

If you want bad customer service, come to this place!

My brother and I went to Joe's Shanghai for pork and crab meat dumpling.  After we had pork dumpling, the server tried to take away our plates and force us to leave.  We sat down for less than 15 minutes and the server already gave us a bill. 


People have the same tables with us, ordered the same dumpling after we ordered, but they got the dumpling first..


No matter how popular this place is and how good the dumplings are , I will not come to this place again!!!

Even the dumplings can't make up for the incompetent hostess's at the door, the extremely long wait times (50 minutes after being told 20 minutes multiple times), the cramped, loud quarters and the rushed service.  Don't waste your time!

Tourist Trap!!! 

I used to come here 10 years ago but some much has changed since last night. I understand that if a place is good, I can wait.

It was a Wednesday night and the place was packed. I don't even want to rate about their service because I expected none. 

However, the food is garbage and is way over priced. I can see the German tourists who sat in front of us were disappointed with the food since they had so much left over. 

First, we ordered their most famous crab meat soup dumplings. It has no crab meats and the old nice and juicy flavor is not there anymore. The skin is really hard. The order came out really quick. They had it done long before. They just kept the dumplings heated. I understand that they want more businesses so they make it in bulk but you can't downgrade the quality of food for the sake of speeding the process. Good dumplings take times to steam. 

The signature Shanghai saut√©ed noodles was drenched in oil and lots of salts and they are very cheap on the meats that a regular Chinese take out noodles tasted better than that crap. 

I couldn't understand why the American people who sat next to us kept saying that they are having the best dumplings. I really wanted to tell them that they are not eating good dumplings. Everyone has their own taste and they made it suitable for non Asian taste. 

It just bothers me that they are having such high ratings for that quality of food that they didn't put effort on it. I won't comment about the price but all I have to say that your money are more well spent on your local Chinese take out place than here, because they are serving you the same quality of food.

I'm sorry New York, I love your city but I tried the soup dumplings at Joe's in October and they can't touch those at House of Mandarin Noodle in Temple City CA. I know this isn't going to go down well but as consolation let me say that, contrary to other comments here,  the wait at Joe's wasn't bad at all.

Alright so let's see.

We arrive here 10 pm on a saturday night. As soon as we get seated, a server walks over and grunts,"Last order, crab or pork?" 

My friend and I look at each other, a little confused. We look back at him and ask, "Can we have a few minutes?" He rolls his eyes and spews, "We are about to close," before walking away. I can understand if a restaurant has their own last order policy at a specific time, but literally 30-45 mins after we order, another party is seated and that same server fiends over asking the same thing, "Last order, we're almost closed. Crab or pork?" Like that doesn't make any sense whatsoever, and that guy seems too angry to be serving people food.

Oh and the dumplings are mediocre at best. Admittedly, the scallion pancake was really good. The crab meat (with pork) dumplings and pork dumplings pretty much tasted the same (both had mostly pork, why even make two separate items? Oh I know, so you can put a little imitation crabmeat in one of them and charge an extra $2). Second time I've been here in 2 years and still consistently fraudulent. Hope that bum of a server learns how to live life happy.

Joe's Shanghai was very adequate. I'm giving it three stars because I didn't have incredibly high expectations, but I asked my friend what she thought and she said two because of it's reputation as some of the best dim sum in the city. 

HOWEVER, as long as your expectations aren't as inflated as Joe's Shanghai's reputation, it's really not bad.

The pros: 
1) The system for getting seated was actually better than I expected. They give you a ticket with a number on it (like the deli counter at the grocer) and you're seated in order that way. It's a good way of ensuring that you won't be forgotten if you come at a time when there's a long wait. Also, we came at 7:30 on a Friday and only waited 15 minutes. Maybe we were just lucky, but I was surprised it was such a short wait. 

2) Service was fast - if we hadn't taken some time to sit and chat after our meal, we could have been out of there in like 30 minutes.

3) CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP - total bill per person after more than enough food + a beer for each one of us was $20. They add on a service charge but it's only 15% - I only tip lower than that normally if something horrendous happens, so tip was actually cheaper than what I probably would have paid otherwise.

The cons:
1) The food was just mediocre. We ordered 2 orders of soup dumplings (note: for whatever reason on their menu the dumplings are listed as 'pork buns'. We tried to order both, thinking the dumplings were off-menu, and were told they were the same thing), the fried pork dumplings, the scallion pancake, shrimp lo mein, and mai fun - for four of us, it ended up being way more than enough food. The soup dumplings were some of the best I've had, but my boyfriend said that he's had better near his office in midtown. The fried dumplings were okay, although I thought they were too greasy/heavy. I didn't personally try the scallion pancake or the lo mein. The mai fun was okay, although the shrimp in it was pretty gnarly. I hate when places don't de-vein their shrimp.

2) I did NOT like the communal seating. Other reviewers had mentioned it and I assumed it was like a long table sort of thing - rather, we had a round table for 8 people and our party of 4 was sat with a family of 4. It was so so weird, and rather uncomfortable. Felt like an elementary school lunch table. 

Oranges were brought out with the check, which was nice. 

TL;DR: Maybe would come back if in the area, wouldn't go out of my way again. CASH ONLY.

Not sure about the reviews or the line to get in. The soup dumplings lacked flavor as did the Shanghai noodles. Perhaps the food is bland for the tourist clientele. The "sichuan" oil on the table tasted like it was made from regular red pepper. Better Shanghai style on Mott street. Cash only and the tip is added to every check.

The reason for 2 stars has nothing to do w/ the food-- in fact, the food was fabulous. Soup dumplings (xiao long bao) were amazing and definitely hit the spot the night I was there when it was 1000 degrees below freezing. However, thanks to the bitchy hostess who screamed at us for not being accurate about how many we had in our party, this place gets a meager 1-star rating from Clee. We could have easily squeezed in that extra chair, but nope-- apparently, saying you have 1 less person in your party than you actually do is a heinous crime.

i used to come here all the time w/ a friend before i found Shanghai Cafe. its ok tho i prefer my soup dumplings to be a little thicker so they dont break so easily and spill on my shirt, yes its happened here before. i forgot what else i've eaten here but it was nothing special since i dont remember it. also sharing a table here sucks
