I am Chinese and brought a few American friends to China Town and hoped to have some REAL genuine Chinese food.  I was totally disappointed because it is so westernized (like every dish has same heavy oily sauces), the menu is full of these typical fake Chinese dishes which do not exist in China but hugely popular here like Zuo Zong Tang Chicken and sesame chicken.   Almost all the guests are American and I was the only Chinese sitting there.   I will never go again.  There is soooo many good Chinese food in China Town like "Congee village" Á≤•‰πãÂÆ∂ and "August Gathering" ÂØåÁë∂ and many more ...

I by far have the craziest story about this place! First of all Ter, Esther and I decide to check out this ridiculously famous soup dumpling place. Apparently, Chinese people came up with this brilliant idea of making a dumpling soup all- in- one dumpling. The soup is actually inside the dumpling. Good way to cut out the middle man, China!

After much debacle of being lost in the financial district of NY, numerous map checking, gaggles of do- you- know- where- we- are- going, and lots of iphone google mapping we trudge our way into Chinatown. We finally make it to Pell Street! We walk up the steps only to have the hostess give us a ticket and estimated time of eating. And it's only 5pm... I thought New Yorkers ate dinner late at night! Eh.

Joe's Shanghai does something that I rarely see in California. They seat people Benihana style. As in, they have like 15 large round tables that seat 9 people each. If you party can't fit at a square table (like a table for 4), your party sits at a large round table. And if you have a few extra seats available because your party is small, you get to sit with a whole bunch of strangers that are next in line for seats.

* Names have been changed. And if you are any of the people that I mentioned in this review. Please feel free to send me a message. It would be crazy if we touch base via yelp. Because really, I don't have tourettes.

We finally get our number called and we get escorted to a table... It looks like a table of models? I see a lot of beer bottles. Oh no, they aren't models, they love their bottles, but they are ivy league UPenn banker- type yuppies? Eh? Sitting at the table is what appears to be the Friends cast. Three gorgeous girls with three gorgeous guys. It was like a J Crew catalog. Or a high road A&F shoot. Ridiculous. And I thought only Californians looked that good.

Ne hooz, during the meal Ross and Rachel (the couple that used to date and now they are just friends) start teasing each other. Not like you are funny... funny looking. har har. 

But more like...

Rachel: "Ross, remember that time when I was doing you with the strap on?"

Ross: "Oh, yeah baby. You rocked my world."

The kind where the 3 Asian girls would look at each other, cover their mouths and reveal a shy should- I- even- be laughing?- giggle... Inner battle between the two cultures... The submissive Asian side, where I think... I think it might be improper to laugh out loud, but since I am so accomodating I will release a shy giggle. And the Westernized side where I am like, "Damn that bitch was funny". Fall off my chair and roll on the floor laughing.

So, what do I do... I giggle like a lil school girl in pigtails. =X

After Joey picks up the tab he says, "Wow, I take three girls out and the bill is only 19 dollars. I have never picked up such a dinky tab. Damn, you girls are cheap."

And I say, "Don't forget the lube". 

Joey, "Wow, you said don't forget the lube. That is awesome!"

(distant clinking of beer and sake bottles and people doing the wave around the round table). 

And then the lil 25 year old Asian girl sporting her Abercrombie sweater is shamed. TOO BAD I said it in reference to Rachel using a strap on... on him. 

Note to self. Don't ever say "Don't forget the lube" in the middle of dinner.

But yes, the dumplings are good. And yes, you have to take a small bite from the top, let the soup leak on to your spoon and place cautiously in mouth. The dumplings are hot! Saying lube during dinner is not.

Given the hype around this place and their soup dumplings I was a bit let down. Came on a Thursday later afternoon for an early dinner and there was plenty of seating available. Me and a couple friends split the Crab Meat with Pork Meat Dumplings (A1) and Pork Meat Soup Dumplings (A2). I thought the soup wasn't all that great and the meat was just fine. Nothing necessarily bad about this place, just think it's rather overhyped.

Note: review based mostly on their bread and butter as the rest of the menu is mediocre at best.

First off I don't understand why people call it "soup dumpling" when it's suppose to be "Xiao Long Bao". Soup dumpling is a completely different dish we Shanghainese call "Tang Bao" - Tang = Soup, Bao = Dumpling (roughly). 

So right off the bat, if you hear people calling Xiao Long Bao's as "soup dumplings" then you already know they have no idea what they are talking about and they are just another product of mass consumption. =)

Anyways...

I've eaten here on several occasions and each time I try to justify why people line up for this....ahhhh, they have never tried the real Xiao Long baos to have an appropriate comparison.

Cons: 1. soup inside is too oily, too salty, too thick, too rich (it's almost like the top layer you sift away when making beef stew) 2. The texture of the skin is rough, not as smooth and delicate as it is suppose to be 3. the size is not what a Xiao Long Bao is suppose to be

Pros: I like their cold dishes (yep, no pros for the Xiao Long Baos)

Overall the majority of the dished ont he menu are throwaways but I'll eat the "soup dumplings" on occasion when I can't fly back to Shanghai or when I can't visit a Ding Tai Fung (even DTF is mediocre at best). 

I think the high ratings for this restaurant is almost as if I were to go to Peter Lugars and give them 5 stars because I absolutely don't know any better and think eating steak with no sauce is the best idea since sliced bread.

In the winter when there was no wait the soup dumplings are good. That is if you are craving soup dumplings only. We were told that we had a 30 minute wait. We ended up waiting for 1 hour 15 min -it was sweltering hot and the lady kept calling numbers before and after us of parties of various sizes. Finally we had to squish in a corner with strangers and ordered the soup dumplings- crab- which were really good. Not worth the wait. The number calling was totally unfair.

The food there is alright, famous in Chinatown for its "Shanghai Crackmeat Dumpling", but I've tasted better somewhere else before.  Most importantly, the service is pretty bad there.  The place relatively small, so whenever there's a line the door, the Chinese waiter or waitress there will try everything to get you finish up your meal, pay the bill and leave, so they can server the next table.   I figured that's probably why they automatically include 15% service charges of your bill (that's 15% of your bill+tax they charging automatically to your bill),  otherwise they would never going to get good tips with that kind of service they're providing. Despite the foold is not so bad, I will not go there again just because of bad services.

We Waited for 1 hour to get a seat, but what we ended up with having is a table shared with another two customers. It is a bit awkward and unpleasant after the long wait.  We ordered the fish on top of the recommendation list, but the fish is not fresh at all.  I don't really recommend this restaurant, and the only reason it is popular could be that nonChinese people like it, but it is not really good Chinese food.

I went to this restaurant after several recommendations about their soup dumplings, which even celebrities have raved about. Upon arrival, there was a line to get seated. After seats opened up, it was likely that you would be sitting at a huge table with strangers. 

Since it was so busy, you could tell that the waters were rushed. It took them a long time to get us water, and even longer for them to take our order. After the orders came out, they failed to answer any of our questions, or clarify which dish was for who. 

Even though the soup dumplings were good, I wouldn't say that they were worth the travel and wait. Honestly, there are several restaurants within the same vicinity that serve soup dumplings as well.

First time we've been back to Joe's since the pandemic, and the first time since they moved from Pell to Bowery in 2019. What a massive disappointment! After maybe 20 years of regularly heading to Joe's with friends and out of town guests we definitely won't be going back. I will bullet point this horror story to make it clearer:

1) Got seated and watched several waiters standing around doing nothing. They were literally standing still and staring off into space or at walls while we and other tables needed help. After five minutes I managed to get someone's attention to ask who our waiter was and that person offered to take our order, as if it was our responsibility to track someone down.

2) Unfortunately, our waiter barely spoke English and I couldn't understand what he was saying at several key points. One of the dishes we ordered was Joe's iconic soup dumplings and somehow he thought we wanted three orders for three people (which is waaay too much; there are 8 dumplings in each order). When three orders were delivered to our table and I explained  we only wanted one, the waiter became disgusted and acted like it was our fault. I watched as he brusquely snatched back two orders and stomped toward the kitchen where he gathered with other staff and gestured toward our table as if we were trouble. 

3) Speaking of soup dumplings, there is a lot of liquid involved in eating them, but they gave us small plates instead of bowls, which meant there was no way to lap up the juices with the spoon. We ended up tipping the plate into our spoons in order to taste the broth, which of course made a mess. What the heck is going on with that? They are called "SOUP dumplings," so bring some SOUP bowls! Also, the dumplings used to be so hot you could barely handle them and you had to be careful when eating them, and now they're only lukewarm.

4) Whenever we needed something (napkins, more water, tea) we had to look around for our waiter and it was virtually impossible to get his attention. So we started grabbing other staff whenever we could, but getting anyone's attention was challenging. The service is absolutely AWFUL!!! Service at the old Joe's on Pell was always a bit curt but very efficient. That is gone!

5) They don't bring black tea unless you ask. Most Chinese restaurants either bring tea automatically or at least ask whether you want tea. When they did bring the tea it was in plastic cups. Eww! Tea and plastic don't go together. Gross!

6) Most Chinese restaurants bring white rice with the meal or at least ask if you want white rice. Not at Joe's (anymore).

7) The food at Joe's used to be so good we would regularly pass 25 decent restaurants and schlep down to Chinatown. However, the food has officially turned to average. Not bad by any means, but no longer the feeling that we were eating food we couldn't get a block from our Midtown apartment. Why schelp all the way down there when we can walk half a block and get as good or better? Ollies is better than Joe's and we don't have to wait 45 minutes to get a table because they take reservations.

So we're officially done with Shanghai Joe's. It was delish while it lasted but Joe's has run its course now and the staff just don't care. We feel a little sad saying goodbye but all good things must come to an end.

the steam dumpling taste horrible ! I don't understand where all these good reviews come from. The skin of dumplings is thick, the meat is not good quality and salty . I came from Shanghai and know how the good stuff taste! This one is really horrible. The noddle is too wet and salty.
We coming for dinner she tell us wait for 20 minuets and we waiting for over hour and 15 mins and the lady with the ponytail have a bad attitude and never smile. So sad.

we definitely visit joes shanghai every time we are in nyc. but this was our first time visiting the new location since they moved. we remember we thought the place was good everytime we visited in the old location. but when we visited it at the new location, the quality of the food definitely went down and kind of limited. the noodles were very starchy. the pork soup dumplings were not hot. we were actually disappointed with the quality of the food.

This place was pretty underwhelming considering how much hype there is when you look at the yelp reviews. Far from being the best XLB. Dumplings are a little bit over sizes, the flour skin is also too thick. Definitely worth a try. It's cheap and I would definitely go back but it's nothing to rave about.

The famous Joe's Shanghai. Great xiao long baos (soup dumplings). Loved that they're served with the huge pieces of cabbages in the bamboo baskets to help retain even more moisture and flavor. The flavors are exquisite and you really should each order at least one serving for yourself because eff sharing.

Unfortunately, that's the only thing good about this place so I have mixed emotions and a review for this place. On the one hand, the XLBs are great and you got to try them if you can. On the other, the wait is always at least for 30 minutes and seriously, everything else on the menu is lacking in flavor and attention. So I will include this in both my must try and over hyped lists for NYC.

We tried their soup dumplings, crab and pork. We actually tried a few restaurants for Xiao long bao and I would give this place 2 stars. Just on their dumplings!!! The sauce they use for the dumpling is too salty, it ruined the dumplings for me. The sauce is just as important as the dumplings itself. But the dumplings wasn't good at all. We didn't even finish the dumplings, and I hate to waste food.

We waited two hours and the food was just ok.

I can't write too much about it, except I was mildly unamused. I don't know what the hype is. The xlb is huge and good, but is it worth the wait?! Not in my opinion. Everything else was good too, but nothing to write home about.

So crowded and we sat with another couple. We took so long to eat, we ate with another couple.

Not bad if you can get seated ASAP.

The dumplings were the main reason I was brought here. The experience wasn't all that good with the crab overpowering the soup. I was assured not every joes shanghai place isn't like this. Yet the price is increased compared to other ones. That's why two stars deducted. Otherwise wait nope there is more. Too much oil on the noodles. Chopsticks couldn't catch a grip....
Not a good first time experience.

The first time I tried Joe's Shanghai; I was in love.  Second time; the love is gone.  Maybe the cook was having a bad day?  The xia long bao skin was a bit hard and chewy.  The meat and soup juices was still consistantly yummy.  It just didn't have that "wow" factor anymore.  The cabbage leaves in the bamboo steam tray they put the dumplings on looked old with black spots on it.  Almost as if they reused them again.  Boo!

I've been told this is just another tourist trap in a NYC chinatown alley.  It does get rather crowded.  I'm sure there are better Shanghai soup dumplings places elsewhere in NYC.
Got soup dumplings. It was good but a bit salty. The salt and pepper short ribs are overwhelmingly salty. I can see the msg on it.

Pork soup dumplings were very good: much larger than expected, thicker dumpling skin, and lots of savory soup. The green beans were mediocre. Overall, if you've ever been to Din Tai Fung, you'll agree that this is no competition. 
They don't take reservations, and the process of getting seated is very hectic. Some people were given tickets, while I was not and had to ask. Service here is average at best: waiters are not attentive and as such, it is difficult to flag anyone down. I had to wait very long before ordering and asking for the check. An 18% gratuity is automatically added to the bill--interesting, considering the level of service. Also, they only accept cash!

Because of all the hype, I thought this place would be as good as everyone else said it would be. But..the food is average. Nothing special about them. Tried 3 different types of dumplings (pork, chicken, seafood). They all tasted the same. Their noodles were good but nothing to really rave about.

This place is overrated to me. They're famous for their soup dumplings, but honestly, their soup dumplings is only alright to me. Nothing that really blows me out of the water compared to other ones that I've had. The price pretty good though. They're cash only and gratuity is included in the check. The service is really bad though but that's typical for the OG Asian restaurants.

Service: 2/ 5 star 
Food: 4/5 stars 

Getting there on a Saturday night,  I expect it to be busy.  Was told it's a 30 minute wait for 3 people,  ok that's fine and they gave me my ticket number.  While waiting,  the guy with a mic kept yelling out ticket numbers ( that was going by quantity of people,  not ticket number order) we kept hearing him say all the 2 tops but none of the other 3 or more tables. There was a lot of people waiting for their number and delivery app drivers were getting angry as well. 
  The guy was having a meltdown on the amount of people waiting . 30 minutes went to over an hour wait. I'm sorry but don't give me a time frame where it isn't true, where the are other errands to finish. 
Some friends were in the japanese restaurant next door and finished within the waiting time of our restaurant. 
Some other people in line went to the japanese restaurant and were finishing their drinks, to wait out their time for joes shanghai ticket number to be called.
 The food was good and brought out at adequate timing,  since we had over an hour to look at the menu and ordered within sitting down.  Tried to order hot water multiple times,  I finally got it with the third server.  Is hot water that much of a rarity?? 
Pan fry noodles,  pork soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, fried fish,  all meats dish, and jellyfish were all tasty. 2 dishes came with jalape√±os and those definitely packed some heat, even without the jalape√±os on the dish . The bill came and automatically charged us 18% tip. That was laughable. The service wasn't that great. Their untrustworthy wait time, mainly their organization in the restaurant watered down their tip a lot, and tries to get hot water did not deserve an automatic 18%.

3 1/2 stars. 
There is a reason why there is always a string of lines waiting outside of the restaurant, despite the speedy service. Yes, it is a tourist trap. Yes, everything else besides the "xiao long bao," aka soup dumplings are worthless, but that's just it. When you come here, the only thing that is amazing on this menu are those crabmeat soup dumplngs, disregard everything else, and you will have one heck of a good time. 
Unlike Nanxiang, the king of soup dumplings, Joe's Shanghai does not make them on the spot, ours came out within three minutes, and were slightly undercooked. They were nevertheless amazing, full of juices and bits of crabs. Mhmm yummy!

This place was ok. The soup dumplings were good but just your average soup dumpling . (All Soup Dumplings are good) The Kung pao chicken was a bit of a let down because it didn't have much flavor. A little bit of a letdown because it wasn't that great despite the rave reviews.

All hype. Not good. Gross soup dumplings (unusually big), basic saut√©ed string beans, poor tasteless scallion pancakes, not great hot & sour soup. Only decent thing was their crispy shredded beef. Did I come on a bad day? Not sure why so many people rated it so high.

I really should be more understanding, but while the food here was good, I don't know if it was worth the hike in my blood pressure for the experience.  The energy that this place gives off is SO RUSHED.  

The way they rush you to your seat when a table opens.  
The way that you are sitting at a communal round table with 6 other parties of 2.
The way the wait staff is rushedly leaning inbetween you every 10 seconds to give something to that couple sitting at your table.
The way they rush you to order, and make you feel like you should know immediatley what you want, or what is good there.
The way they rush you to leave once the other parties at your table start finishing up.

Granted, I found this place on Yelp, so I realized it was going to be crowded.  The food was fantastic.  We ordered the pork dumplings (apparently not the SOUP dumplings though, as we got confused when ordering and the waiter seemed to just rush us) which were good, and the kung pao chicken and beef and broccoli.  All of the food that came out was delicious.   And I'll give credit where credit is due - these guys work their asses off!!

My drawback, like I said, is it is definitely not a relaxing meal.  However, I probably will go back to try these famed SOUP dumplings.

Rude tourist trap. Dont get your own table. You have to share it. Treated like cattle. Food fair at best. Reminded me of frozen chinese food So many better places around, trick you too with an extra service charge. Nasty staff too. Go to Wo Hop or others around. This is bad. Yelp steered me wrong. Must be tourists leaving reviews.          Only a B ratng...

We decided to go here because someone said it was better than Din Tai Fung. TOTALLY NOT TRUE. The waitress was very rude. We came in and asked how long the wait was and the waitress said it would be able 5 min. While we were waiting, we overheard her complaining (in Chinese) that a customer was staying too long and that they should hurry up and leave. When my mom asked 5 min later if we could get a seat (since there were some empty ones), she rudely replied, "I told you to wait 5 min. Please be patient." Normally, I would've already left at this point, but we stayed for the food.

Finally seated (we were grouped with random people at a table), we ordered the xiao long bao and a few other dishes. It was definitely very mediocre food. Maybe New York don't have authentic good Chinese food or something, but I have no idea why this place is rated so high. Our group of 4 people were all from the SF Bay Area in CA and agreed that we would never come here again.

Also, this place was not very clean. Our plates had dried food crusted on.

Soup Dumplings are great but their service leaves a lot to be desired. Been a fan for about 5 years however I was very disappointed on my last trip when I saw their C grading. For a place that stays constantly busy and makes money they should really have their health inspection as one of their priorities. Having worked in a restaurant I know that there can be a range of things that can get you from an A to a B, such as leaving an ice scoop in the ice maker or leaving boxes of products on the floor instead of on a shelf. However it looks like their offenses were much greater than that such as roaches and vermin prone environments. There are certain things I can look past however for now Joe's won't be getting my business until they think about practicing safe food handling as much as getting my money. A quick Google search will give you the information you need, Joe's Shanghai health inspection grade C report results.

A tourist or tik tok place at best !! If you're from NYC no reason to go at all food was ok .. great scallion pancakes.. soup dumplings fair at best .. TONs of places that are way better.. Dim Sum Palace much better .. service ok nothing special. bathroom dirty , where you dry yr hands tons of dust and grime.. walking up the steps from Bathroom not a good sight on the steps .. idk what the hype is .. will not ever return

Notice there's a lot of "Joe's" who own restaurants around NYC! There's Shanghai Joe, Joe's Ginger, Joe's Restaurant and even another Joe's Shanghai in midtown! And guess what? They all happen to be Chinese restaurants too! Oh, people are just oh-so-creative these days :)

I've been here countless times already and I used to be so thrilled about this place! However, lately I've been finding myself more and more disappointed with their xiao long baos. (FYI- my favorite place for soup dumplings is Din Tai Fung in Taipei-- the BEST XLBs in the world!!) Unfortunately, the last time I went to Joe's, I found their XLBs to be only so-so, with the meat inside the dumplings to be slightly pink and very very oily. Maybe there's a new chef in the kitchen? Or my trip back to Taiwan awakened my tastebuds..I have no idea. Their other chinese dishes are good but also americanized for the local taste.

Joe's Shanghai is ALWAYS busy on the weekends (being slightly better on the weekdays). I guess that's what you get for being one of the most popular restaurants in Chinatown! I must say though, the price is pretty good for what you get -- big portions! This place is cash only and the waiters are for the most part, helpful and friendly.

3.5 stars

Bf and I have tried many different dumpling spots and were excited to try Joe's as we've heard many great things. The restaurant is located in an alley of CT. The tables are communal, meaning you will share a table with strangers whether you like it or not (if your party is big enough, I suppose you may not have to deal with this). Inside is a little run-down and dingy, but expected (still seemed OK to me).

We tried the crab and pork XLB, pork XLB, potstickers, and the fried rice. Love the size, juiciness and soupiness of the XLB. However I was not too drawn to the taste of the dumplings. I probably liked the pork more than the crab + pork combo, but I still think I have had tastier ones. Skin was not too thin or thick imo. I was able to use my chopsticks to pick up the dumplings with ease, no leaking. I appreciate the sizable portions--the dumplings are probably twice the size of standard XLB. I was extremely full by the end of the meal. I don't remember anything too special about the potstickers, but I really liked the fried rice. The fried rice was well-seasoned and the rice was nice and firm with a ton of egg.

Overall a pretty OK experience. There are a ton of people dining in, so expect a wait. But still a good place to try at least once if you're visiting.

It's too touristy for me. I don't understand why every book is so in love with this place. The soup dumplings are not that great compared to some more authentic places in chinatown. I guess it's worth a visit for the hype but I wouldn't go back. The lines are always impossibly long? Why?
There's insect in the food!!!!!! And terrible handling services. Food taste great but just dirty as hell

Had my very first xiao loan bao at Joes in FLUSHING Queens over 20 yrs ago and the rest was history.  Nothing can come close to their taste and quality.  Have had them in many other places in china as well but nothing came close to the one in Flushing.  So when Joes went out of business in flushing during the pandemic i had to settle for other xiao loan bao places.  The only Joes left was the new shop in manhattan's ctown.  The cost of an order have since went up during the pandemic from 7.95 to 14 bucks an order.  Ok, fine since its the best, right?.  NO.  The old one from flushing was without a doubt 10/10.   Ctown was a 6 the most.  Don't taste the same.  Sigh.

My friend hyped this place up so much that I hauled a bunch of friends here through rain, traffic & a 20 minute wait.  Too much hype, too touristy and pretty average.  I would pop in this place if it was in my hood, less crowded or cheaper.  Otherwise this is not a destination resto.  Big ole Meh...

Let me just tell you 40 minutes, does not mean 40 minutes

My family party of 3 sat and waited for an hour and a half. A family of 3 came after us supposedly "knew" the owner by name, walked in, and was seated immediately. Fishy.
After confronting the hostess, she played dumb and said "I don't know what you're talking about" OK? Thanks?
A family of 16 (!!!) took a number and was seated immediately. 

Their dumplings probably are good, but it's sad that they don't value their customers enough to be honest with them. I don't mind waiting because I get it, it's a Saturday night, but don't lie.

Also, they automatically add 15% of your total to the bill, which I didn't know was even legal. 

All in all, the one star is for the integrity of this place...or the lack of. Won't be back.

I went to Joe's because of the high rating. I ordered a variety of foods including their famous soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, a spicy fried shrimp dish (I don't remember the actual name on the menu), shrimp fried rice to name a few. I personally thought the flavors were bland. The fried shrimp and scallion pancakes were delish! My 11yr old liked the dumplings. I would go back for the pancakes and shrimp though.

I'm probably spoiled by all the good eateries in LA, but Joe's Shanghai was pretty disappointing.  The hubs and I came for an early dinner but it was already busy.  We got seated with a family of eight strangers.  Kinda weird but this place is tiny.  So if you're not into dining with complete strangers, this might be an issue.  

Scallion pancakes were bomb.  I would get it again!  Got an order each of the pork and and crab XLB/soup dumplings.  The hubs thought the crab filling was a bit too fishy.  I though both dumplings were okay.  I felt like the meat wasn't fresh and the dumpling skin was too thick on top but too thin on the bottom.  This was an issue when we were picking them up to eat.  They line the bottom of the dumpling basket with napa cabbage but the dumplings kept sticking to it. What a waste of the delicious soup!  

Food was okay.  Staff was friendly and relatively attentive considering how busy it was.  Cheap prices!

Ever since I saw the No Reservations episode in China where Bourdain eats the largest soup dumpling I've ever seen with a straw, I was immediately smitten and knew that I had to find a place in New York that resembled it. After sharing my love of all things dumpling-esque to some friends, they had turned me towards Joe's Shanghai. Joe's is a NY staple that has catered to numerous celebrity patrons and chefs. That alone is enough of a reason to give it a shot.

I was a bit disappointed when I found out that they don't serve those massive dumplings I had seen on TV, but was pleased to know that they serve some of the tastiest lil treats this side of Chinatown! We ordered the crab meat and pork meat dumplings to see which one was best. Where to begin... the first lil bite of these lil guys is fantastic! Allowing the piping hot soup to billow out of the fragile moist shell and onto your palate. It's foodgasmic! Perfect to have on a cold night in the city .. or after a night of heavy drinking. I preferred the pork ones over the crab meat, but they were both delicious. 

The only reason I am not giving Joe's a 4 or 5 rating is because their other dishes lacked a bit. The general tso's was dry and overcooked. The chunks of chicken that were served were a bit fatty and didn't make me want more. Although, the scallion pancakes were excellent!!!! O yea... definitely craving some of those right about now!

The food is good here, but look at your bill carefully.  They put a tip on the tab before they even put the tax.

I think that's a really dirty trick, most people would miss it and end up tipping again.
Their soup dumpling is great. Food is great. But the guy taking our order stopped us from getting more saying we were ordering too much. It's not his call. That's just. Rude.

Recently came here a few mins before it opened and seated ourselves. We ordered the pork and crab one and this time I preferred the pork. The crab had a very strong "roe" taste to it. The skin on the dumplings was super thick too. So disappointed, at least it was very cheap.

Heard a lot of great things about this place and by the line that was at the door when we walked up it must be the best thing ever right? 

Eh... I was really expecting something so wonderfully delicious that I would be like a crack addict so addicted that I would just need more!  I think all the hype might have pushed my expectations above reality.  

Don't get me wrong it was good. Definately diffent than eating potstickers or shumai or hargow. Which I enjoyed the broth inside the dumplings.  But after that initial suprise from the first one you eat...you just don't get that from the 2nd or 3rd one.

Really crowded obviously a tourist attraction (myself included) but not a must have and a must go to every visit I make to NYC.

Oh and CASH only!

I don't seem to get why this place is crazy popular. I came here to get some crab meat soup dumplings and they were not what I expected. The soup dumplings came out slightly warm. I was expecting something pipping hot and enjoyable, but it really wasn't. 
The restaurant could use a tune up especially the tea cups and plates. They are all scratched up. Don't expect to get your own table. Most likely you will be sharing a table with other customers.
There are much better options in Chinatown to go to.

First the good part - the Dumplings are very good, no question. But, you will be better off just eating that. We ordered Lo mein chicken noodles and Salt and Pepper shrimp (shell-off). There was intense chlorine smell off the shrimps. There was barely any flour coating on the shrimp. At best, it was mediocre tasting. I could have had great salt and pepper shrimp at my local PF Changs which is far far better. Lo mein noodles didn't even have enough salt. My local Chinese restaurant makes it much better.

This place has become a tourist trap. Lines are long, it took us 20 minutes to get in. Service was fast, which is good. The nearby 456 restaurant has much better food and cleaner environment. 

Go for the dumplings, which are some of the best in Chinatown. Everything else, meh!!

First time at this new location. Food and service was good but we wished that they would tell us in advanced that there's a 15% service charge that's included in our bill. We didn't realize it until we got home and we gave tips on top of the total too. They should've had some kind of honor system.

for all the rave reviews - i have to say this place isnt anything wildly mind blowing.

the soup dumplings are good - i prefer the crab + pork to the pork.

we also ordered the sesame chicken and vegitable lomein. lomein was no good. but the sesame chicken was VERY GOOD!

im only giving three stars, cause the sesame chicken albeit delicious was overpriced. and the rest of the meal was just OK. also service leaves something to be desired...

Pretty mediocre food.  While I'm an ardent supporter of not-too-doughy xiao long bao, Joe's were flimsy out of the basket.  They tore much too quickly, spilling that ever-so-valuable soup out.  The one's that managed to stay together were a-ok, but nothing special.

Relatively expensive to boot.

The infamous 'soup dumpling' was just ok - not great.  Not sure why everyone thinks this place is 'to-die-for'...  I'd rather stab in the arm than return to this joint and get 'plates, cups, utensils, etc' thrown at me by those disgruntled workers!  They rush everything, from the moment you sit your butt down to when you finish your first bite, then it's 'boom' - the check is on your table, while the servers gwak at you to ensure you pay and leave a tip for them.  

Seriously, there are better soup dumpling places..  when visiting Cali, go hit up Ding Tai Fung, so freaking good.  Much better services and larger variety of selections to choose from.
overrated dumplings, overrated in general but Szechuan noodles are actually spicy and authentic so get that!

Best soup dumplings in town!  Crab with pork steamed bun is the number 1 item on the menu, not just literally. They have an extensive menu with a whole lot of items that can be overwhelming. Just focus on the soup dumplings and the kungpao chicken and you're good!

The noodle dishes are greasy. There's usually a long wait. Also, you are more often that not, expected to share a round table with strangers - like in many Chinatown dimsum restaurants. It doesn't really matter once the soup dumplings arrive!

Disappointed in the food. I ordered one of the specials, Szechuan fish and it was soggy and way over sauced. Big portion though. I was hoping for something more flavorful and savory, more authentic, and a smaller portion would have been fine.

Place is not clean. hardly anyone speaks English. They have good steamed dumplings Shanghai style but the rest of the food is below average. Fish ordered came out with a sweet sauce that was not edible. Seafood is below average. Sauces are not very good, but have no taste. Only thing that was above average were the steamed dumplings, very hot, so take your time in eating. Not good decoration, and restrooms are unclean like the flatware.
